title: JET WITH 82 ABOARD HIJACKED TO HAVANA
description: An Eastern Airlines DC8 jet with 82 persons aboard was hi jacked on its way to Puerto Rico yesterday and forced to fly to Cuba, an airline spokes man said.

title: Saints and Sinners Honor Frazier
description: Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight champion, was honored yesterday by the Circus Saints and Sinners at a luncheon at the Statler Hil ton Hotel.

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: New York (Sunnyside Gardens) Herschel Jacobs, 180 pounds, White Plains, knocked out Harold Johnson, 177, Philadelphia, rounds.

title: Greensboro Open Will Offer Casper Masters TuneUp
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31Billy Casper has chosen a royal road, with a stop here, to prepare for the de fense of his Masters golf title at Augusta, Ga., next week.

title: First Silver Dollars Since 1935 Are Struck at the San Francisco Mint
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 31  The first silver dollar to be minted by the United States since 1935 was struck here this morning at the United States Assay Office.

title: GALLEY SENTENCED TO LIFE FOR MURDERS AT MYLAI 4; LENGTHY REVIEW TO BEGIN
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 31First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. was sentenced to life imprisonment today for slaying at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians three years ago at the hamlet of Mylai 4.

title: U.S. Aides in Athens, Under. Fire, Defend Policy Favoring Regime
description: ATHENS, March 25  United States diplomats in Athens, under fire from both Senate investigators in Washington and opponents of the military Government here, are shifting their tactics slightly but hold ing firm to the policy that they, and the State Department have formulated.

title: Screen: A Battle Fought Strictly for the Camera:Bondarchuk Directs Craig's 'Waterloo' Rod Steiger Portrays Ill-Fated Napoleon
description: Sergei Bondarchuk's "Waterloo," which opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater, has at least to its credit that it means to be about the battle itself, essentially about the events of June 18, 1815, which resulted in Napoleon's defeat and the end of his second bid for power. As to the film's historical accuracy, I am not competent to say. In matters of record it seems to follow the encyclopedia accounts of the battle; in places it feels rather like an encyclopedia account. But the sense of the film itself is another matter, and the particular dullness of Bondarchuk's attempt to translate history into cinema makes "Waterloo" a very bad movie.In most non-essentials, "Waterloo" has all the look of qualitythe muted colors, the selection of realistic detail, the concern for a compositional control so obsessive that in each phase from the marshaling of troops to the joining of the battle, to the arrangement of corpses when the battle is over, any frame might be excerpted and labeled "handsome" or "effective." But in movies the look of quality is almost always a crushing bore. And Bondarchuck especially applies his delicate palette with the subdued refinement of a sledgehammer.Thus, when Blcher leads his troops to Wellington's aid ("Raise high the black flag, tzhildren!"I wish I could duplicate the accent), they are observed from a great distance by Napoleon and his generals. Napoleon wonders whether they are indeed the Prussians or perhaps much needed French reinforcements. But we don't wonder, because we have been hearing "Deutschland Uber Alles" in the cellos and basses on the soundtrack for quite some time. And not only in sound, but also in image, Bondarchuck orchestrates his filmmore or less the way Tchaikovsky orchestrated the Battle of 1812.Occasionally his methods work, as when by helicopter shot he spectacularly demonstrates the logic of the failure of Marshal Ney's cavalry charge against the allied infantry square at La Haye Sainte. But more often those methods amount only to ways of filling up the screen or parts of the screen with fleshed-out schema. The shadow of "Alexander Nevsky" hangs heavy over "Waterloo" (as, in fairness, it hangs heavy over almost every classy battle movie from "Henry V" down) and the drama it inspires has less to do with humanity or history than with a mechanical rhetoric of cinema.Against this background it it difficult to speak of performancewhich most often resembles a more or less detailed caricature worked out before a frieze of significant events. As in most movies of this type, in any 20 lines there is likely to be something laughable (I greatly admired Napoleon after Ney's debacle, running up to his command post screaming "What's he doing? Can't I leave the field for a minute . . . ?")which, given the frailties of historical epic, is not the point. Actually, much of the film's cast seemed to me pretty goodexcept for Rod Steiger.Steiger plays a peace-loving Napoleon, crafty, tired, much weighted with the destiny he seems never to get off his mind. Like a Willy Loman not wholly aware that he has lost his territory, he alternately schemes and complainsas if, in addition to all his other achievements, he had discovered at Waterloo the sources of theatrical naturalism. It is an awful performance, and every mannered point of it is emphasized by the elephantine selectivity of Bondarchuk's cameranarrowing upon the eyes, a weary fold of flesh, the carefully hunched back, the hat, the pudgy man's walk.During the first parts of "Waterloo," when Napoleon is much in view, I thought that no director, not even Bondarchuk, merited Steiger's performance. Later, in the heat of the battle, I felt that not even Steiger need have suffered through Bondarchuk's direction. But now critical calm has put all things in perspective, and I realize that they richly deserved each other.

title: Brazilian Indicates No. Political Changes
description: BRASILIA, March 31Presif dent Emilio G. Medici pro nounced himself satisfied today with the present form of militarydominated. Government in Brazil, which he called democratic order.

title: Cynthia Potter, Finneran Score In A.A.U. Diving
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 31  Tiny Cynthia Potter suc cessfully defended her title to night, but Jim Henry lost his to Mike Finneran, the Big Ten champion, as the Amateur Ath letic Union's national indoor diving championships began in the United States Military Academy's new pool.

title: Books of The Times
description: The gory turmoil, the puzzling upheavals, the murky events that constituted China's cultural revolution in the late nineteen sixties have been turned into a com prehensive and comprehensible narrative in Robert Elegant's book. The author, who was chief of The Los Angeles Times Hong Kong bureau during that time, has gathered an enormous amount of mate rial, sorted it out and woven it to gether into a weighty exposi tion. Some people may even be sur prised that so much information is available after all we have been hearing as to how unreliable reports from China are, how untrust worthy the sources, how Aesopian the lan guage. But the book makes that clear, too. For there was so much disloca tion, such a, loosening of controls that much information was smuggled, out with those refugees who left China for freer lands.

title: Advertising:
description: A turnout big enough to amaze even its sponsors crowded the Americana yes terday for the first. Direct Marketing Day in New York.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Opens Special Bicycle Ramps
description: Bicyclists were welcomed to the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday.

title: MILTON BROADMAN
description: Milton Broadman, a Manhat tan lawyer, died of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 57 years old and lived at 8801 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

title: Reports by Saigon on Toll Inflicted on Enemy in Laos Are Arousing Doubts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31  The campaign against Communist supply lines in Laos is over, but statistical warfare continues to rage, rem iniscent of the days when American commanders put the stress on the body count to demonstrate success in the Viet nam war.

title: JUSTICE IS SUSPENDED PENDING PANELSTUDY
description: A Long Island State Su preme Court justice was sus pended yesterday pending review of his record by a six judge Court on the Judiciary.

title: Ruckelshaus Acts on 2 Sections of Clean Air Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 William D. Ruckelshaus, ad ministrator of the Environ mental Protection Agency, took the first steps today toward implementing two key provisions of last year's Clean Air Actone dealing with hazardous substances, the other with emission control systems on new plants.

title: Chess: Popovych Shows the Value Of Timing in a Sicilian
description: First place. in the. 15man Manhattan Chess Club round robin has shifted as the tour nament progresses. At the end of the sixth round the leaders with 42 each were Jeffrey Kastner and Neal McKelvie. Dr. Orest Popo vych, a professor of chem istry at Brooklyn College, was third with 3.1.

title: MOHAWK MEDIATOR IMPOSES AN ACCORD
description: An arbitrator's decision on a backtowork agreement be tween Mohawk Airlines, Inc., and its striking 396 pilots was rendered yesterday. The air line said the agreement, effec tive today, assured the resump tion of service on April 14.

title: Clint Eastwood Is Star Of Siegel's 'The Beguiled'
description: Donald Siegel's "The Beguiled," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and the R.K.O. 59th Street Twin Theaters, sounds simple enough on paper: Clint Eastwood, as a wounded Yankee soldier, charms and then terrorizes the ladies who nurse him back to health at a very peculiar, more or less forgotten, Louisiana seminary during the closing days of the War Between the States. Nothing, however, is as straightforward as it seems in "The Beguiled," not even its perversities.Take, for example, the lovely opening sequence in which a little, 12-year-old girl comes upon the body of the soldier in the forest. She is, at first, frozen with fear. Through her mind we hear her wonder whether her father died the same way. Cut to the soldier, and through his eyes we see a curious, shapeless child swim into focus.They talk, exchange names, and just before the child helps him to stand, he draws her down beside him and gives her a long, not really friendly kiss on the mouth. She's confused, but immensely happy.The film thus begins as a quite odd Civil War romance, evolves into a battle of the sexes in which the man is more vanquished than victor, and then turns into the kind of grotesque character comedy that mightmistakenly, I thinkbe identified as gothic horror. There is certainly horror in "The Beguiled," but it is played for what amounts to an extended, completely silent laugh.Whether this is intentional or not, I've no way of knowing, but there's no other way to explain the amusingly overripe excesses in a film by a man who has, heretofore, managed to make films that were more complex in effect and a good deal more simple in design ("Invasion of the Body Snatchers," "Two Mules for Sister Sara")."The Beguiled" is Mr. Siegel's 26th film, as well as his most ambitious and elaborate. I'm not referring to the sets, costumes and Spanish moss-hung locations (the exteriors were filmed in Louisiana at a fine, photogenic, old plantation), but to the narrative style. The movie employs, in addition to straight exposition, interior thoughts spoken on the sound-track, flashbacks that contradict spoken dialogue and the kind of fantasies commonly enjoyedaccording to literary conventionby hashish smokers, sailors and sex-starved spinsters.In fact, every major character in the movie, with the exception of Eastwood, is a female suffering to a greater or lesser degree from the need for a man, including the little girl (Pamelyn Ferdin) who first finds the soldier, the precocious 17-year-old (Jo Ann Harris), who seduces Eastwood with the graces of Belle Watling, and the sweet virginal teacher (Elizabeth Hartman), who comes close to being an unequivocally decent person, the only one in the film.The most deprived (ergo, according to Hollywood Freud, the wildest and most dangerous) woman is the seminary's headmistress (Geraldine Page), whose initial flashback, as she stares at the bloody, maggoty soldier, is to the bed in which she and her brother made frenzied, slow-motion love. My favorite fantasy, however, is Miss Page's wine-induced dream in which she, Eastwood and Miss Hartman make love and then assume the positions of a piet, more exhausted, I suspect, than sorrowing.This is very fancy, outrageous fantasizing from the man who gave us "Riot in Cell Block 11" and" Baby Face Nelson," and must strike horror in the hearts of those Siegel fans who've made a cult of his objectivity. "The Beguiled" is not, indeed, successful as baroque melodrama, and, towards the end, there are so many twists and turns of plot and character that everything that's gone before is neutralized. People who consider themselves discriminating moviegoers, but who are uncommitted to Mr. Siegel will be hard put to accept it, other than as a sensational, misogynistic nightmare.I must say that I found it interesting (even when it approached the ludicrous) because of its place in relation to other Siegel films and because I have nothing but appreciation for the performers, especially Miss Page, Miss Hartman and Mr. Eastwood, who, by simply reacting well, has become an important actor of movies.One final note: The screen credits list John B. Sherry and Grimes Grice as authors of the screenplay, adapted from the novel by Thomas Cullinan. Those are the pseudonyms, respectively, of Albert Maltz, who did the initial screenplay, reported to have been a romantic comedy, and Irene Kamp, who did the rewrite with help, I'm told, from Claude Traverse, the associate producer. This may explain some of the peculiarities of the completed film.

title: Bruins Score as Esposito Gets 70th and 71st Goals
description: MONTREAL, March 31 (UPI) Phil Esposito scored his 70th and 71st goals of a record breaking season and Dallas Smith, a defenseman, chipped in with a pair tonight as the Boston Bruins pulled out of their fourgame losing streak with a 63 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: HIJACKEDPLANEBACK FROM CHINA WITH 24
description: MANILA, March 31 (Reuters) A Philippine Air Lines jetliner that was forced to fly to Com munist China by hijackers yesterday returned here today with its passengers. The pilot said the Chinese authorities had told him they disapproved of air piracy.

title: Parliament in India Condemns Pakistani Massacre in East
description: NEW DELHI, March 3The Indian Parliament accused Pakistan today of a massacre of defenseless people in East Pakistan that amounts to geno cide.

title: Big Soviet Industry Realignment Urged
description: MOSCOW, March 31A plan to reorganize Soviet industry into Governmentrun production associations similar to big United States corporations re ceived the support of promi nent regional leaders today at the Communist party's 24th Congress.

title: Newark Steps Up Drive To Recruit Policemen
description: NEWARK, March 31The city of Newark, which has had chronic difficulty recruit ing policemen, particularly from its majority black and Spanish speaking communi ties, is launching a major po lice recruitment drive.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Support for Nixon At 50%, Lowest Yet
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Only 50 per cent of American adults approve of President Nixon's performance in the White House, according to the latest Gallup Poll, released to day.

title: PENNSY'S TRUSTEES SEEK CERTIFICATES
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (AP)  Trustees of the Penn Central Railroad petitioned a Federal court today for per mission to issue $17.4million in trustees certificates to en able the railroad to enter the Railpax network.

title: Soviet Expels an American Exchange Scientist
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Soviet Union has accused an American exchange scientist of collecting slanderous infor mation from Zionists and other groups in Russia and expelled him from the country, the State Department said today.

title: Cessna Shows an Executive Jet
description: Bucking the severe bear market for corporate jets, the Cessna Aircraft Company kicked off a sales campaign here yesterday for a new plane that it said would give executive access to hundreds of American airports that are too small for present jets.

title: Shop Talk
description: Behind an unprepossessing storefront at 9332 43d Ave nue in Elmhurst, Queens, is a man turning out fine inlaid furniture that looks as if it belonged in a room at Ver sailles. Norberto Paganini, a recently naturalized citizen who came here six years ago from Argentina, learned his craft from his Italian father, who had learned from his. Before going into busi ness for himself. Mr. Paganini did repair work on the valuable old furniture handled by Dalva Brothers, antiques dealers on East 57th Street.

title: ROCKETS TRIUMPH OVER NETS, 132121
description: DENVER, March 31 (AP) The Denver Rockets opened up an 11point margin by halftime tonight and maintained it throughout the remainder of the game to defeat the New York Nets, 132121, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: MINE CHIEF OUSTS DISASTER EXPERT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Bureau of Mines has or dered the retirement of James C. Westfield, the nation's lead ing authority on the causes and prevention of coal mine disas ters, officials disclosed today.

title: Bridge: Seeking to Head Off a Ruff Can Sometimes Prove Costly
description: If the opponents are threatening to score a trick with a ruff, it makes sense to remove their trumps as quickly as possible. But there are exceptional cases in which this policy is a mis take, as. South found to his cost in the diagramed deal from the recent Vanderbilt Knockout Team Champion ship in Atlanta.

title: GENEVIEVE LOWRY
description: Genevieve Lowry, who head ed the United Service Organiza tions division of the National Young Women's Christian As sociation throughout World War II, died yesterday at her home, 549 West 123d Street, after a short illness. She was 178 years old.

title: Gibson Supports Suspension of Striking Teachers
description: NEWARK, March 31Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson supported the suspension of 347 striking Newark teachers today, as indi cations mounted that the nine weekold strike was further polarizing this racially divided city.

title: Egyptians Fired Over Canal, Israel and U.N. Report
description: TEL AVIV, March 31 (AP The Israeli military command said today that Egyptian troops fired machine guns acorss the Suez Canal on Monday night. It was the first shooting inci dent reported at the waterway since the Middle East cease fire ended March 7. The inci dent was also reported by Unit ed Nations observers.

title: Quiet, Please
description: Americans live in an increasingly noisy world. The blare of horns, the screeching of brakes, the rumble of trucks and the jet engine's whine and roar assault not only the traveler but countless others trapped in the car pet of sound. The pneumatic drill can make a simple street repair job worse than a visit to an oldfashioned dentist, and a major construction project can disrupt city block for months. Perhaps the worst hit are indus trial workers who earn their living in noisy factories. But even whitecollar workers are often subjected to the unending hum of inefficient heating and air con ditioning equipment.

title: McCarthy Looks Ahead
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  It was the morning after his 55th birthday. Sitting last Tuesday in the study of his small, pleasant Georgetown house where he writes his speeches and oc casionally works out a poem, Gene McCarthy was his usual relaxed and amiably sardonic self. He was wearing dark slacks, a faded blue, opennecked shirt and an old brown sweater. His face unlined and his gray hair tousled, he looked unchanged from three years ago when his primary campaign helped topple Lyndon Johnson from power.

title: Teachers Ordered Held
description: NEWARK, March 31 (AP) Superior Court Judge Ward J. Herbert today ordered the ar rest of an undisclosed number of Newark's striking public school teachers for picketing the schools in violation of an antistrike injunction.

title: Children Love Turtles, but Grownups? Indeed
description: You know how it is in New York, said Joan Murach, who has been working toward a Ph.D. in Russian literature at Columbia University. You're living in an apart ment and you want something live around you. So you get a turtle in a bowl. Then you realize he needs a tank. Then you realize he's lonesome, so you get another turtle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Verdict Protested Anew; 3 Try to Jail Themselves
description: The outcome of the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. stirred renewed and mount ing protests yesterday, with many Americans expressing their feelings through tele grams, petitions and resolu tions, and a fewboth public figures and private citizens  taking more dramatic action.

title: Development Commissioner Resigns
description: Robert G. Hazen, the city's Commissioner of Development, resigned yesterday to take a position with the State Urban Development Corporation.

title: Sabres Win on Shack's Goals
description: PITTSBURGH, March 31 (AP) Eddie Shack scored three goals tonight to lead Buffalo Sabres to a 64 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a National Hockey League game.

title: Earnings at Data Processing Reported Higher for 9 Months
description: The Data Processing Financial and General Corporation in creased its net income to $4, 222,803, or $1.05 a share, in the nine months ended Feb. 28 from $2,193,954, or 60 cents a share, in the yearearlier pe riod, it was reported yesterday. Revenues were little changed at $37,413,831 against $37,203,653.

title: White House Reaction
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31 (AP)  At the West ern White House, the press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said the regulation seems to be directed towards support of the President and his Vietnam policy. Asked by reporters if Mr. Nixon agreed that United States involvement in the war should be ended by January, 1973, Mr. Ziegler said. It's our objective to accomplish these objectives as soon as possible.

title: 76ers Need Victory Over Bullets To Remain in N.B. A Playoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 31 April Fool's Day for the Phila delphia 76ers will be an oc casion of seriousness as they attempt to escape elimination from the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: CAIRO ATTRIBUTES DEADLOCK TO U.S.
description: PARIS, March 31  Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad or the United Arab Republic declared today that the refusal of the Nixon Administration to bring effective pressure on Israel was to blame for the complete and very serious deadlock in the search for a Middle East peace settlement.

title: LINDSAY SOFTENS CRITICISM OF NIXON
description: Mayor Lindsay retreated yes terday from a planned attack on the Nixon Administration's effort to curb inflation with re straints on construction wages and prices.

title: PUBLIC TV LISTS MAJOR FALL FARE
description: The basic fall schedule for noncommercial network tele vision broadcasting was an nounced yesterday by Hartford E. Gunn Jr., president of the Public Broadcasting Service, which allocates time on the educational hookup of 202 stations.

title: EAST PAKISTANIS SAID TO FIGHT ON
description: KRISHNAGAR, India, March 31  Pakistani troops have ap parently failed to consolidate their positions in rural areas of East Pakistan, and small groups of about 100 are be lieved to be retreating to ma jor towns.

title: No Austerity in City Pay
description: After months of groaning about the high costs mandated on the city by Washington and Albany, Mayor Lindsay has the unpleasant duty now of demonstrating how effective he can be in holding the municipal budget within reasonable limits in the areas of his direct responsibility.

title: Reunify Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: ILLEGAL COACHING ON TESTS CHARGED
description: The Board of Education has asked local school authorities to investigate charges by some teachers that pupils at two Brooklyn elementary schools were recently coached for the citywide reading tests by being drilled on sections of the actual examinations.

title: Doc Blanchard Retires
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 (AP)  Col. Felix (Doc) Blanchard, allAmerica fullback at Army in 194446, retired from the Air Force yesterday. Blanchard flew 113 jet fighter missions in the Vietnam War.

title: Ties With Cairo Strained
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 30 King Hussein's relations with Cairo have grown frosty lately as the Egyptian authorities have made friendly gestures toward the fedayeen.

title: CORPORATE BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Corporate bond prices de clined quite sharply early yes terday and then they recovered part way in a performance that seemed to lack much conviction about how interest rates should move over the next few days.

title: Thieu Terms Laos Drive Saigon's Biggest Victory
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31President Nguyen Van Thieu declared today that his troops' recent thrust into Laos had attained the biggest victory ever for the armedforces of South Vietnam.

title: 3 Army Reservists Sue to Drill in Wigs Covering Long Hair
description: Three Army reservists yes terday challenged the constitu tionality of military regulations barring the wearing of short hair wigs to cover their forbid den long hair at weekend drills.

title: Merger News
description: The HarrisIntertype Corpo ration of Cleveland and the Datacraft Corportition of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., announced jointly yesterday an agreement under which Harris would ac quire a 60 per cent interest in Datacraft. Harris manufactures printing equipment and elec tronics products. Datacraft produces digital com puters and core memory systems. The principal de tails of the agree ment are these:

title: Hard Labor Defined
description: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 31 (UPI)Maj. Cleve Cunningham, public informa tion officer at Fort Leaven worth, said tonight that the hard labor Lieutenant Calley was sentenced to happens to be only a term.

title: J. Rankin O'Rourke, Aide Of Wall Street Firm, 71
description: PELHAM, N. Y., March 31 J. Rankin O'Rourke, a vice president of Walston & Co., member firm of the New York Stock Exchanges died yester day of a heart attack at his home. He was 71 years old and lived at 66 Clifford Avenue.

title: New Effort Against Trail
description: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31  A new phase in the South Vietnamese effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was announced here today by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Raise We Must
description: Consolidated Edison seems to have decided that the only way it can guard against more disastrous blackouts is to make electricity so costly that people will have conserve it. In petitioning the Public Servite Commis sion for an average increase of 14.2 per cent in electric rates, the troublebeset utility has cited inflationary pressures and the urgency of expanding generating facilities to meet the city's power requirements.

title: Firemen Begin Slowdown To Prod City on Demands
description: City firemen said last night that they were beginning a rule book slowdown as a pressure tactic aimed at getting further movement in their contract ne gotiations.

title: At Carnegie Hall, That Other Boheme
description: Leoncavallo's La Bohme? A misprint, surely. But no; as opera students know from books and even from records, Puccini's version of Parisian garret life, circa 1837, is not the only one. Still, who knows the Leoncavallo first hand, as a staged work? Until the Metropolitan Opera Studio and the National Orchestral Association collaborated on a concert presentation on Tues day night at Carnegie Hall, there seemed to be no record of even a concert perform ance here with orchestra.

title: Kuwait Holds 5 in Slaying
description: KUWAIT, March 31 (Reuters) Security forces have arrested five men believed to have been involved in yesterday's assas sination of the former Iraqi Vice President, Hardan Takriti, welinformed sources said to day. Four of the arrested men are Iraqis and the fifth carried a passport of an unamed state, although hei s of Iraqi origin, the sources added.

title: Westport Enjoined On Vote to Recall School Board Head
description: WESTPORT, Conn., March 31 The Westport Board of Se lectmen was permanently en joined today from conducting a special recall election aimed at ousting the chairman of the school board, Mrs. Joan G. Schine, a leading figure in controversy that began over the busing of children from Bridgeport.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoffa's Parole Bid Is Denied Until '72
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 James It Hoffa, the imprisoned president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was denied parole today.

title: U.S. and Soviet Discuss Modernizing Hot Line
description: VIENNA, March 31Talks to improve and modernize, the WashingtonMoscow hot line opened here today be tween American and Soviet experts under the supervision of the two delegations to the talks on limiting strategic arms.

title: Michael Cardinal Browne Dies; Tradition's Voice at Vatican II
description: ROME, March 31Michael Cardinal Browne, an Irish scholar who served as the Vati can's chief theologian and as Master General, or Superior, of the Dominican Order, died in a clinic here today. He was 83 years old and had been ill for several Months.

title: Market Place: Broker Scores Negotiated Fees
description: Muriel F. Siebert, the Big Board's only woman member, is totally opposed to the plan to allow negotiated broker age commissions on big trades. She says that in part her fears are for the little guy in this fight.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS CAMPAIGN CEILING
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The Nixon Administration, in a major reversal of position, en dorsed today most of the key provisions of Democraticspon sored legislation designed to re duce spending in election cam paigns.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, March 31Every body loves a puzzle, or should. To brighten the day, therefore, we offer the following brain twisters. For quit ters, the solutions appear at the bot tom of this space. Ready?

title: $2.2Billion of Strip Bills Sold By Treasury at Average 3.811%
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Treasury reported late this afternoon the sale of $2.2bil lion of strip bills. The amount of accepted tenders on these bills will be equally divided among 11 issues of outstanding Treasury bills ma turing on consecutive dates be ginning July 18, 1971.

title: An XRay Scanning Satellite May Have Discovered a Black Hole in Space
description: Observations with an earth satellite named Uhuru, the first vehicle, placed in orbit pri marily to scan the heavens at Xray wave lengths, have rel vealed what, it is suspected, sere one or more of the long postulated black holes.

title: Colombo Sr. Wins 3d Stay From Jail As Convicted Liar
description: A dapper Joseph A. Colom bo Sr. walked into and out of court yesterday  the day of Ills scheduled surrender to be gin serving a prison term. He received yet another stay in ex ecution of the sentence.

title: Nuclear Plant Used as Target in Simulated Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The Air Force has used a nu clear power plant on the shore of Lake Michigan as a practice target in simulated lowlevel bombing runs, according to Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Nixon Transfers 6 Miles of U.S. Beach to California
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31  President Nixon today asked the Senate and House Armed Services Com mittees to approve the first in a series of nationwide moves to transfer billions of dollars worth of federally owned land to state and local gov ernments for recreational and other public uses. He an nounced he had directed Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird to offer six miles of California's most valuable bechfront, now part of the Marine base at Camp Pendle ton, to the state of California. In the planned series of na tionwide moves, state and local governments will be given the first chance to ac quire such lands free. Those lands not taken will then be offered for sale to commercial or industrial bidders. The proceeds from such sales would be earmarked for the land and water conservation fund of the Interior Department for use in developing new state or nation al parks.

title: Navy Awards Rickover 2Year Extension of Duty
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee announced today that Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the Navy's top nuclear power expert, would stay on active duty for two more years.

title: Thruway Use and Income Up
description: ALBANY, March 31 (AP) The State Thruway Authority reported today that income and mileage reached record levels in 1970, with vehicle operators driving more than four billion miles on the 559milelong Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway,

title: Fairleigh Trackmen Win
description: TEANECK, N. J., March 31 Karl Harz won five events end led Fairleigh Dickinson's track team to victory in a tri angular meet today. Fairleigh had 86 points, Adelphi was second with 82 and Rider third with 11.

title: Greece Rebukes Rogers For Stand on Vote Delay
description: ATHENS, March 31The militarybacked Government rebuked Secretary of State William P. Rogers today for criticizing its delay in restor ing democracy in Greece.

title: Patrolman Says He'll Seek Presidency of P.B.A. Here
description: Frank Hughes, a patrolman In the Upper East Side's 19th Precinct, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in its June election.

title: TAPE IS PLAYED AT PANTHER TRIAL
description: A tape recording of an over seas telephone call in which death threats were made by voices identified as those of Eldridge Cleaver and Michael Tabor against Assistant District Attorney Joseph A. Phillips was played yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, March 31 Like the month of Marcy, Mayor Lindsay came here like a lion yesterday and left like a lamb after he had seen firsthand a rebellion against high spending and high taxes that has already resulted in the chopping of more than $700million from the proposed state budget for the fiscal year starting at mid night tonight. The Mayor and his col leagues from the state's Big Six cities were warned by Governor Rockefeller and friendly legisla tors that this was no time for the political posturing and grandstanding.

title: Communist China and Japan Reach Table Tennis Finals
description: NAGOYA, Japan, March 31 (Reuters)  Communist China, competing in the world table tennis championships for the first time since 1965, reached the men's and women's team finals today against Japan.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Arwood Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of William O. Sweeny as president for personal reasons and that Rawson L. Wood, chairman and founder of the company, will assume the additional position of president.

title: FIRE CAPTAIN GETS A HERO'S FUNERAL
description: Two thousand uniformed firemen, their whitegloved hands raised in salute, lined a quiet street in Queens yester day to pay tribute to Capt. John F. Dunne, who died Sunday in a futile rescue attempt in a blazing buiding.

title: HIGH COURT NO HELP TO XFILM EXHIBITOR
description: BOSTON, March 31 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Francis J. Good, criticizing recent United States Supreme Court rulings, has refused to black the Stone ham Board of Selectmen from revoking the license of a theater showing adultonly movies.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RETAIN FIRMNESS
description: The overall tone of prices on the London Stock Exchange remained firm yesterday even though leading issues failed to hold Tuesday's large after hours gains.

title: Democrat Aide Here To Head Health Group
description: The Tuberculosis and Re spiratory Disease Association of New York announced yes terday that Mrs. Edward N. Costikyan has been chosen as the association's first lay president, succeeding Cynthia R. Kinsella, director of nurs ing at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: O'Leary of U.S. Trust Co. Is Nominated at Fanny May
description: James J. O'Leary, vice chair man of the United States Trust Company, has been nominated to succeed Walter W. Heller as a member of the board of direc tors, of the Federal National Mortgage Association. Mr. Hel ler is a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and Regents Professor of Eco nomics at the University of Minnesota.

title: BOARD VOTE REJECTS QUEENS PRINCIPAL
description: The District 28 School Board in Jamaica, Queens, voted last night to reject the trial ex aminer's report recommending that Mrs. Desiree Greenidge be be reinstated as acting principal of Intermediate School 142.

title: RUSTIN ADVOCATES JEWISHNEGRO TIE
description: DETROIT, March 31Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, asserted today that no progres sive social or political move ment could develop in America without the continued close co operation of the black and Jew ish communities.

title: Theater: Vanderkellans
description: The reaction of the Negro bourgeoisie to the black rev olution is the matter under discussion in William Welling ton Mackey's Behold!, Here Cometh the Vanderkellans, which opened last night at the Theater de Lys. The Van derkellans are a patrician black family who live on cam pus in Holden University, a black school in the South. The time is Easter, 1960.

title: Body Identified in Tate Case
description: VENTURA, Calif., March 31 (AP)  A body found in a rugged wilderness area was identified today as that of Ronald Hughes, a defense at torney at the Sharon Tate murder trial who vanished mysteriously four months ago.

title: Schary to Quit Culture Post
description: Dore Schary, the play wright and former Hollywood producer, will withdraw from his $35,000ayear post as the city's Commissioner of Cul tural Affairs next summer to get back to my work.

title: Diplomat Weds Mrs. de. Ferranti
description: Frederick A. Warner, Brit ain's deputy permanent rep resentative to the United Nations since 1969, and Mrs. Simone G. de Ferranti were married here privately Mon day morning. Criminal Court Judge Frederick L. Strong performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Finds Selective Rail Strike Legal
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled today that a railroad operating union could conduct strikes against a few railroads to bring pres sure on all the nation's rail companies.

title: Peking Quits Federations In 2 Sports as a Protest
description: TOKYO, March 31 (AP) Communist China withdrew from two international sports federations todaytennis and archery. The moves were a protest against what It called a United States plot to create two Chinas.

title: CASUALTIES HEAVY AS ENEMY BURNS TOWN IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 1  Enemy troops have attacked and burned most of a district capital in the northern part of South Vietnam, reportedly inflicting heavy casualties on civilians and their militia.

title: DRUGS WILL CARRY LABELS ON WORTH
description: DENVER, March 31  The Food and Drug Administration plans soon to require printed ratings on drug labels and ad vertising to tell the doctor whether there is good evidence that the drug he wants to use is effective.

title: Fuel Policy Study Backed
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)  The Senate Interior Committee approved today a bill calling for a study of a na tional policy on fuels and en ergy. The bill would authorize the committee to look into the nation's present and future fuel and energy resources and needs. The twoyear study would cost about $200,000.

title: SIX JOIN DISSIDENTS IN CHALLENGING FOX
description: Six men have joined a group seeking to take control of the Twentieth Century  Fox Film Corporation, including an exec utive of one of the motion picture company's subsidiaries.

title: Alan Shesiach to Head The Yale Art Gallery
description: Alan Shestack has been ap pointed director of the Yale University art gallery, effec tive July 1. He will succeed Andrew C. Ritchie in a post Mr. Ritchie has held since 1957.

title: Burch Tells N. A. B. He Expects Conflicts Over Public Interests
description: CHICAGO, March 31Dean Burch, chairman of the Feder al Communications Commission, told broadcasters today that they were colliding headon with the concerns of consum ers and a more active partici patory democracy.

title: Jobless Rate Rose by 41% In New York Area in 1970
description: The unemployment rate in the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan area increased 41 per cent in 1970, while the increase for the city alone was 33 per cent. The increases, reported yesterday by the United States Labor Depart ment, necessitated sharp rises in unemployment payments in the city and in four suburban counties in New York and eight in northern New Jersey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I was recently chosen as one of the few winners of a National Science Foundation graduate fellowship. I say few not as a boast, but rather as cry of despair. I wish I were a mem ber of a group not quite so select.

title: College Forms New School
description: BOSTON, March 31 (AP) Northeastern University has formed a new school, the Col lege of Pharmacy and Allied Health Professions, by merging its College of Pharmacy with its Division of Health Sciences. The university said yesterday that about 3,000 students would be in the new school, which will be headed by Dr. Leroy C. Keagle as dean.

title: Canucks Tie Kings, 22
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 31 (UPI)Wayne Mali's second goal with 6 minutes 13 seconds remaining tonight earned the Vancouver Canucks a 22 tie with the Los Angeles Kings in a National Hockey League game.

title: CLINIC HERE PLANS ABORTIONS FOR $80
description: A clinic able to perform more than 10,000 abortions a year for an average fee of $80 will be opened here this summer by Planned Parenthood of New York City.

title: Thieu Comments He Was Confident Guilty Would Pay
description: DONG HA, South Vietnam, March 31  President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he had been confident that justice would punish those guilty of the killings at Mylai.

title: Trouble for the Dollar
description: A new crisis for the dollar may be in the making. Last year the United States ran a $10billion balanceof payments deficit in its settlements with foreign govern mentsthe biggest such deficit in American history. This year another big deficit is likely, though probably not as large. These deficits have meant a transfer far more dollars abroad than foreigners want to hold, but they have not been able to do much about because the dollar is an official reserve currency used by this country to settle its foreign accounts.

title: NEW DRIVE BEGINS IN AREA OF MYLAI
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31South Vietnamese troops have begun a sweeping operation in the general region where the Mylai massacre oc curred three years ago that may force as many as 16,000 people from their homes.

title: Mets Trade Swoboda, Then Lose, 122
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31Ron Swoboda, the leading homerun hitter and leading rebel in New York Met history, was traded to the Montreal Expos tonight for Don Hahn a 22yearold utility outfielder who has never hit a major league home run.

title: Liberals Seek War Crimes Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  With the aid of some Vietnam veterans, a group of liberal Democrats sought today to pre vail upon the House Armed Services Committee to conduct a public inquiry into alleged American war crimes in Viet nam.

title: At State Hospital, Quiet and Gloom
description: The dozen mental patients, some of them old, were in a narrow room. They did not talk. They showed no aware ness of one another. Obliv ious to the raucous sound of the television set, they stared at bare walls and un curtained windows.

title: Hoist the Flag Fractures Leg in Workout
description: Hoist the Flag, the favorite to win the Kentucky Derby, broke a leg during a workout at Belmont Park yesterday, ending the colt's racing ca reer.

title: Economic Analysis
description: There have been many occa sions, during the twomonth old negotiations to save the RollsRoyce RB211 engine for Lockheed's L1011 airbus, when aviation officials in this coun try have asked exasperatedly: Who needs RollsRoyce?

title: INSTITUTIONS PACE MARKET ADVANCE
description: Steppedup institutional pur chases paced the stock market yesterday as the list made modest advance in more active trading.

title: German Bank Rate Cut From 6% to 5%
description: BONN, March 31 Deter mined to stem the inflow of for eign currency, West Germany's central bank again eased its tight credit policy today, lower ing its bank rate by one per centage point to 5 per cent, effective tomorrow.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASK PULLOUT BY '73
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  House Democrats called today for an end to United States involvement in Indochina by the start of 1973.

title: TOP AIDE IN ALABAMA WILL DEFEND BLACK
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 31  Alabama's new Attorney General, William J. Baxley, an nounced today that he would defend the state's first black sheriff, Lucius Amerson, who is facing Federal prosecu tion on an indictment for violating the civil rights of a Negro prisoner.

title: JUILLIARD STUDENTS PLAY VOICES WELL
description: Oily Wilson, who teaches at Oberlin Conservatory and will become a faculty member at the University of California at Berkeley next fall, is a compos er with jazz in his background. In two places in his Voices, which was given its New York premiere on Tuesday night by the Juilliard Repertory Orches tra, the several percussionists take over in quasijam sessions that give the work both focal and climactic points.

title: Unwilling Witnesses Recalled in LoanShark Inquiry
description: Federal Judge George Ros ling ordered two recalcitrant witnesses yesterday to re appear before a special Brook lyn grand jury investigating a list of possible shylocking records seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last December from from an asso ciate of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., an alleged underworld leader.

title: Israelis Begin a Controversial Project
description: NEBI SAMWIL, Israeli Occupied Jordan, March 31 Israeli bulldozers have demol ished more than 30 old stone houses around the mosque In this ancient Arab village, to start a controversial housing development for Jewish immi grants in the Judean Hills out side Jerusalem.

title: MRS. JAMES L. JOHNSTON
description: Mrs. Agnes Byrnes Johnston, the widow of James L. John ston, the former Madison Square Garden boxing pro moter, died yesterday in Roose velt Hospital after a long Illness. She was 82 years old.

title: HusbandandWife Team Heads Union Camp Unit
description: The Union Camp Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had appointed a hus bandandwife team to head a newly established depart ment of environmental pro tection.

title: Beame Says Lindsay Has Less Control Over Spending Than Past Mayors
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said this week that he believed Mayor Lindsay had less control over city spending than pre vious Mayors because of the creation of 10 new superagen cles and new procedures in the Bureau of the Budget.

title: CON EDISON SEEKS A 142% INCREASE IN ELECTRIC RATE
description: Consolidated Edison asked the state yesterday for elec tricity rate increases of 11.4 to 15.3 per cent from all three million of its residential and commercial customers in the city and Westchester County.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The list includes the following:

title: Easing of Fee Rule By S.E.C. Queried
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Representative John E. Moss of California has asked the Securi ties and Exchange Commission for an explanation of why it diluted its original proposal to end pricefixed sales commis sions on large stock transac tions.

title: Navy Opens a Recruiting Drive To Increase Black Enlistiments
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The Navy has begun a five year program to bring the num ber of blacks in the Navy up to the level of their 12 per cent representation in the nation's population.

title: Assembly Gets Legislation to Tighten Fiscal Accountability of the City's Schools
description: ALBANY, March 31  As semblyman Constance E. Cook, chairman of the Education Com mittee, introduced legislation today to tighten fiscal and ac counting controls in the New York City school system.

title: News Man in the
description: ALBANY, March 31This was the final day of the old fiscal year for the state, and the lean man with the white crew cut most responsible for its cliffhanging quality ap peared to treat it anticli matically, chatting casually with his fellow lawmakers and popping hard candy into his mouth. John Henry Hughes was behaving in his 25th year in the Senate just as he did in his first, like a fiscal conservative with a manner as cool as his blue eyes.

title: Chinese Fishing Boat Sunk In Collision With Soviet Ship
description: MOSCOW, March 31  The Soviet Union announced tonight that a Soviet freighter had col lided with and sunk a Commun ist Chinese fishing schooner in the Gulf of Tonkin off the North Vietnam coast last night.

title: Aetna Life Scores Connecticut's Plan For Insurance Tax
description: HARTFORD, March 31  A controversial plan to raise new taxes in Connecticut by impos ing a 7 per cent sales levy on all policyholder insurance pre miums came under strong at tack here today by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest allline in surer, with assets of nearly $10billion.

title: JOHN RUTHERFURD OF NAVY RESERVE
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31Comdr. John M. L. Ruther turd, U.S.N.R., retired, of Palm Beach and Sands Point, L. I., died yesterday in Good Samari tan Hospital here after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Phone Rate Hearings End Here Without Testimony From City
description: Two days of State Public Service Commission hearings here on a proposed $391mil lion annual telephone rate in crease closed yesterday with out any testimony from the city administration.

title: SHORTAGE OF JURORS DELAYS SEALE TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, March 31 With one juror in bed with the flu and another in YaleNew Haven Hospital's intensivecare unit, the judge in the Seale Huggins murder trial recessed proceedings today rather than use up the only two alternate jurors on the panel.

title: Peru Seizes U.S. Boat
description: LIMA, Peru, March 31 (AP) The United States tuna boat Puritan paid $18;154 in fines and fees after she was seizure yesterday for illegal fishing in side Peru's 200mile territorial limit, the Peruvian Navy said today

title: United Nations Expected to Get Biological Arms Ban in Fall
description: GENEVA, March 31  The draft of an international con vention banning bacteriological weapons will probably be sub mitted to the United Nations General Assembly for approval this fall, delegates at the dis armament conference here said today.

title: COLOR TV SYSTEM DISPLAYED BY SONY;
description: The Sony Corporation inter rupted a press demonstration yesterday afternoon for half an hour because of smoke from a subway fire pouring into the basement floor of the Ameri cana Hotel and then showed what amounted to a working videotape recording factory.

title: Life for Lieutenant Calley
description: The military court that ruled against unnecessary barbarism in war in convicting Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of murder in Vietnam was wisely consistent in rejecting the barbarism of capital punishment when it sentenced the young officer to life imprisonment.

title: Dr. Herbert I. Horowitz Dead; Hematologist at Bronx Lebanon
description: Dr. Herbert I. Horowitz, chief of hematology at Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center and an assistant professor at Cor nell University Medical College, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 42 years old.

title: A Military Faction in Ecuador Revolts
description: QUITO, Ecuador, March 31 (AP)  An ousted general led a military revolt today against President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra and claimed support of most military garrisons in this capital city.

title: Leafs Tie Wings, 22
description: TORONTO, March 31 (UPI) Thirdperiod goals by Jim Dorey and Dave Keon helped the To ronto Maple Leafs tie the De trod Red Wings, 22, tonight.

title: Nebraska Passes Emergency Bill to Avert U.S. Welfare Aid Cutoff
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Nebraska appeared today to have averted an April 1 cutoff of Federal welfare aid by pass ing emergency legislation de signed to bring the state welfare system into compliance with Federal laws.

title: HAROLD B. BELCHER, MISSION OFFICIAL, 79
description: MELROSE, Mass., March 31  Harold B. Belcher, former treasurer of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches, died today at MelroseWakefield Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: U.S. Discusses Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 The United States has begun negotiations with the Pakisani Government for the evacuation of private American citizens and the dependents of American officials from East Pakistan.

title: Advertising:
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has split with the J. Walter Thompson Company, the world's largest agency, and will now do its own advertising with the help of outside independent services.

title: YANKEES BEATEN BY ASTROS, 9 TO 3
description: HOUSTON, March 31The Yankees moved to the Astro dome tonight to continue spring training, but the new environ ment didn't help. Houston won the night exhibition, 93. It was the Yankees' 19th loss in 27 games.

title: Hey Kids, It's Howdy Doody Time Again
description: Lets take a moment, kids, to relive one of the golden moments of early television.

title: Personal Finance
description: At a time when banks and thrift institutions have been cutting the interest rates payable on deposits, insur ance companies are apparent ly moving to increase the rates they pay to persuade more policyholders to leave their cash with the company.

title: KNICKS CAN TAKE PLAYOFF TONIGHT
description: An opportunity to wind up their firstround assignment in the National Basketball Asso ciation playoffs beckons the New York Knicks tonight at Madison Square Garden as they face the Atlanta Hawks with a 31 lead in the four of seven series.

title: Beame Says City Is Way Behind In Collecting for Extermination
description: Auditors from the City Con troller's Office have turned up nearly $1million worth of un paid bills in Health Department accounts owed to the city by landlords whose buildings re ceived extermination treatments to eliminate rats.

title: Clarence Britten, 89, Officer With Monroe Calculating Co.
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., March 31  Clarence R. Britten re tired secretarytreasurer of the Monroe Calculating Machine Company in Orange, died today in his home at 24 Salter Place, after a short illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Dr. Anthony Adinolfi, 40, Dies; State University Building Chief
description: As chief of construction for the state university system,Dr. Adinolfi managed the would$apos;s largest program for the devel opment of educational facilities, which by 1974 will have erected $4billion worth of facilities on more than 30 campuses through out the state.

title: Look, This System Is Not Working
description: Five years ago, when many of us began to write and speak about the problems of the public schools in cities such as Boston and New York, it seams to me that we were more than innocent in one regard. We would point out that schools in the United States were not encouraging children to think freely and to question bravely, to tight for justice and to cry for those in pain. We would point out that schools contained and silenced, muted and anesthetized our children. We would point out that this was not the way to turn out honest souls like Thoreau or good men like Gandhi or brave men like Malcolm X or Martin Luther King. We would complain like children standing by a huge and slightly obsolete machine. Look, we would say, this system is not working.

title: Chinese Were Courteous
description: MANILA, March 31 (AP) One of four Americans on the hijacked aircraft said at a news conference here today that the Chinese had treated them cour teously and had made the hi jackers apologize to them.

title: British Are Cautious
description: LONDON, March 31British officials took a cautious view today of the prospects for sal vaging the RollsRoyce jet engine contract with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, despite Lockheed's announce ment yesterday of a conditional agreement.

title: Cairo and Amman Call Separately for an Arab Meeting on Clashes in Jordan
description: CAIRO, March 31  The United Arab Republic and King Hussein of Jordan issued sepa rate calls yesterday for an ur gent meeting of Arab heads of state to end the new flareup of fighting between Palestinian commandos and Jordanian troops.

title: MRS. ROBERT F. LYNN
description: MANHASSET, L.I., March 31 Mrs. Marie Madeo Lynn, who helped establish the family services unit of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, died yester day in Nassau. Hospital after a long illness. She was 58 years old and lived at 12 Buckminster Lane with her husband, Robert P. Lynn, vice president and general counsel of Burlington Industries, Inc.

title: THE KINKS DRAW AN UNRULY CROWD
description: The British rock group, the Kinks, played Tuesday night at Philharmonic Hall before an en thusiastic and somewhat ag gressive audience.

title: TRISHA BROWN GROUP IN FUN AND GAMES
description: The fun and games depart ment of the Whitney Museum presented quite a few games and even some fun on its prem ises Tuesday night with An other Fearless Dance Concert by Trisha Brown.

title: KAHN LEAVES POST AT TELEPROMPTER
description: Directors of the Teleprompter Corporation yesterday reached a unanimous agreement in prin ciple with Irving B. Kahn for the termination of his employ ment as chairman and president.

title: Coco and Howard to CoStar
description: James Coco and Ken Howard have been engaged to costar with Dyan Cannon in Such Good Friends, adapted from the novel by Lois Gould, which Otto Preminger will produce and direct here this summer for Paramount.

title: Squires Snap Floridian String
description: MIAMI BEACH, March 31 (AP)The Virginia Squires fin ished their regular American Basketball Association season tonight with a 131123 victory over the Floridians, snapping the Floridian team's sevengame winning streak.

title: Crimmins Autopsy Testimony Conflicts With Mother's Story
description: The city's Chief Medical Ex aminer testified yesterday that Alice Marie Crimmins could have died any time between the afternoon of July 13, 1965, and 1:45 P.M. the next day, when her body was found, but that no more than two hours could have elapsed between her last meal and her death.

title: TWINS RELEASE TIANT, BOSWELL
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 (UPI)The Minnesota Twins re leased two pitchers, Dave Bos well and Luis Tiant, both former 20game winners, and recalled Sal Campisi, a righthanded re liever, from their minor league camp today.

title: News of Dogs
description: Every 10 days a truck rolls up to Bill and Betty Rob erts's St. Bernard kennel in Tolland, Conn., and drops off two tons of dry dog food. Once a month, 30 cases of beef, each holding 50 pounds, are added. We also use 50 gallons of cod liver oil during the year, said Mrs. Roberts.

title: Reserve Opposes a CreditLaw Change
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The Federal Reserve Board unanimously opposes a change in the law to give it power to influence the alloca tion of credit for social prior ity purposes. Arthur F. Burns, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress today.

title: Mrs. Harrison Tweed: Emphasis on Service
description: To find your work and to do it is the highest form of prayer is a favorite say ing of Mrs. Harrison Tweed, chairman of the annual lunch eon meeting of the Federa tion of Protestant Welfare Agencies on April 26. It sums up her viewpoint on life.

title: Coast Guard Gets Appeal on Oil Spills
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 To reduce the risk of oil spills from ship collisions, two en vironmental groups petitioned the Coast Guard today to estab lish sea lanes and shore based radar surveillance sys tems to control traffic in the nation's major ports.

title: Astrodata President Resigns
description: Astrodata, Inc., announced yesterday the resignation of R. B. Baker as president and treasurer, effective March 26. The board of directors has not yet met to select a replace ment.

title: Agnew Describes Fulbright As Arrogant and Frustrated
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)Vice President Agnew today described Senator J. Wil liam Fulbright as an arrogant, frustrated presidential candi date who was currying favor with the news media and feed ing Hanoi's hope for a divided United States.

title: Sports of The Times
description: An article in a British sports weekly earlier this year suggested that Marty Liguori, the Villanova distancerun ner, was overrated.

title: Moscow vs. Peking
description: BELGRADE  The victory of the Chinese revolution has neither elimi nated traditional differences between the Chinese and Russian empires nor opened the way for the world victory of Communism.

title: PRIVATE PENSIONS SCORED BY STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 Only a small fraction of Ameri can workers belonging to pri vate pension plans ever receive a penny in pension benefits, according to a Senate sub committee study released to day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Police Drag Away Man at U.S. Embassy Gate
description: MOSCOW, March 31 (AP) Soviet policemen dragged an elderly Soviet man away from the United States Embassy's gate today after the man appar ently tried to slip past them into the embassy compound.

title: COUNCILMAN LINES TRUANCY AND CRIME
description: The Board of Education was accused yesterday by a City Councilman of abandoning the truant to the streets and a life of unsupervised mayhem and crime.

title: Pope, in a Stern Lenten Speech, Deplores Permissive Morality
description: ROME, March 31Pope Paul VI, in a stern address, today de plored what he termed all per vading sensuality and contended that chastity was not utopian.

title: Rangers' 3 Goals in 3d Top Hawks, 42
description: Rangers firepower caught up with Tony Esposito, the Black Hawks' fluweakened goalie, in the third period last night as the New Yorkers scored three times and continued to look im pressive in a 42 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Both Parties May Hold Miami Beach Conventions
description: WASHINGTON, March 31  The decisions are still weeks or months away, but many Repub lican and Democratic politicians are betting that both parties' 1972 conventions will be held in Miami Beach.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PARIS TO GET TOUGH ON STREET DISORDER
description: PARIS TO GET TOUGH ON STREET DISORDERPARIS, March 31The Gov ernment shook up the Paris police today and announced a tougher attitude toward street disorders and those who pro voke them.

title: Trespassing Trial of Kahane Ends in a Hung Jury Here
description: The trial of Rabbi Meir Kahane, chairman of the mili tant Jewish Defense League, and two followers on 1989 charges of criminal trespass at the offices here of the Soviet press agency Tass ended in a hung jury yesterday.

title: THE SEASONS GIVEN BY M.I.T. VISITORS
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology opened a series of three spring concerts in New York Tuesday night with a presentation of Haydn's The Seasons at Tully Hall. Klaus Liepmann conducted the M.I.T. Glee Club (male), the Voorhees Chapel Choir (female) of Doug lass College, the Haydn Society Orchestra and three soloists Helen Boatwright, soprano; Martin Lies, tenor, and John Powell, baritone  in the per formance.

title: Pravda Scores Pentagon
description: MOSCOW, March 31  The Communist party newspaper, Pravda, charged today that Lieutenant Calley was a scape goat and that his trial had been part of a whole series of ma chinations by the Pentagon to save from justice most of those involved in the crime.

title: Welfare Is a Cancer
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.Welfare is a national moral and administrative die aster a cancer that is destroying those it should succor and threatening society.

title: POLICE IN BOSTON GET A REPRIMAND
description: BOSTON, March 31  The State Attorney General said to day that some Boston police men were guilty of indiscrimi nate assault and destruction of private property when they broke up a noisy street party on Hemenway Street in the heart of the city last May 10.

title: Seals Upset Stars, 41
description: OAKLAND, March 31 (UPI) The lastplace California Golden Seals handed Minnesota a 41 defeat tonight to delay the North Stars' clinching of third place in the National Hockey League's West Division.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Contrary to the impression created by your March 22 story [Wisconsin Democrats Would Like to See Lindsay in 1972 Primary}, there has yet to appear any discernible public interest among Wisconsin Democrats in select ing Mayor Lindsay as the Presidential nominee. The statement by William Gerrard, state Democratic chairman, that there would be some listeners if Mr. Lindsay entered the Wisconsin primary is a far, cry from, the state ment that many Democrats would like to see the Mayor enter the Democratic primary.

title: 2 U.S. Copters Downed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia March 31 (Reuters)Two Amer ican helicopters were shot down today while flying cover fgor an ammunition and gaso line convoy trying to reach Pnompenh up the Mekong River, military sources here said.

title: West German Six Upsets Sweden, 2.1
description: GENEVA, March 31 (AP)  West Germany pulled the big gest upset of the 1971 world ice hockey championships today when it beat Sweden, 21. The defeat removed all chances for the Swedes to challenge the Soviet Union for the title.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Bobby Knight was a be liever in discipline when he coached Army's basketball teams for the last six sea sons. The cadets did his bid ding, and his system pro duced some of the finest de tenses in the nation. Knight's six teams gave up an aver age of 57 points a game, won the national de fensive title three times in a row and played in the National Invita tion Tournament four times.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES MIXED AT CHICAGO
description: Prices of soybean futures closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade with the nearby options gaining af ter having dropped sharply early in the session. The new crop, or the deferred months were little changed after open ing lower and closed Slightly lower.

title: REBELS IN URUGUAY KIDNAP AIDE AGAIN
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 31 (AP)A confidant of President Jorge Pacheco Areco was kidnapped by Tupamaro guerrillas for the second time within three years as he sat in a dentist's chair yesterday.

title: Wojciehowicz Cleared
description: MIAMI, March 31 (UPI)  Municipal Court Judge Gerald Tobin dismissed charges of ticket scalping yesterday against the former Fordham football star Alex Wojcieho wicz. Wojciehowicz, a real es tate broker in South River, N.J., was charged with trying to sell a $15 ticket for $25 outside the Orange Bowl on. Jan. 17, the day of the Super Bowl game.

title: BIG BOARD ENDS M'DONNELL ROLE
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it was completing its role in the liquidation of McDonnell & Co., the first major broker age house to fail in the 1969 70 stockmarket decline.

title: FULL CLARITY URGED ON ANNUAL REPORTS
description: The Financial Executives In stitute, the national organiza tion of corporate financial of ficers, called on its members yesterday to include in their companies' annual reports to stockholders full disclosure of the accounting policies fol lowed in preparing the finan cial statements.

title: Bills on Unit Prices, Cafes and Job Bias Signed by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday bills that estab lish unit pricing to assist con sumers, ease cabaret licensing controls and prohibit sex dis crimination by employment agencies.

title: May to Miss 2 Weeks
description: CINCINNATI, March 31 (AP) The Cincinnati first baseman, Lee May, who suffered a knee injury in an exhibition game last night, will miss the first two weeks of the regular sea son, the Reds said today.

title: Union Carbide Lifts Prices
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion announced yesterday that it would raise prices for several industrial grade polyox water soluble resins by a range of 5 to 15 cents a pound, effec tive April 1. Grades W5R 205, 301 and 1,105, for example, will be raised from 60 to 70 cents a pound on quantities of 20,000 pounds or more.

title: F.T.C. Aide Assails Abuses in Consumer Collections
description: Abuses in collection prac tices concentrated among the poor, ethnic minorities and in nercity residents are creating the greatest irritants of any issue in the current consumer ism movement, the attorneyin charge of the New York office of the Federal Trade Commis sion said here yesterday.

title: Kremlin Rules Out Easing Of Bars to Western Ideas
description: MOSCOW, March 31Rank ing Soviet Communist party, leaders lashed out at Moscow's ideological adversaries today and told the party's 24th Con gress that there should be no letup in resistance to ideas not approved by the Kremlin.

title: Screen: 'B.S. I Love You':Peter Kastner Shines in Bright Comedy
description: "It's easy to like "B.S. I Love You," even with that wise-guy title. Yes, they elaborate in the credits. Some gifted people are involved in what turns out to be a neatly organized morality comedy with bright contemporary trimmings. The Faustian young hero is a bouncy but sensitive boy caught up in some Madison Avenue advertising and sexual coils and some hang-ups of his own.The best thing about the picture is the funny, blithely warm performance of Peter Kastner, the young Canadian actor who came on solidly in "Nobody Waved Goodbye" then marked time in "You're a Big Boy Now." He's dandy here as a hip but wistful operator who succumbs to office intrigue and an influential female octopus before seeing the light.With young Mr. Kastner appealingly front and center, the movie skips along jauntily, wisely and amusingly, reined in by a snug cluster of key performances and the pointed, tart dialogue. The excellent cast includes Joanna Barnes as the steely octopus, JoAnna Cameron as a sex-hungry kook, Louise Sorel as Mr. Kastner's patient fianc, Gary Burghoff as his pal and Richard B. Shull as a wily executive. Add a funny cameo by Mary Lou Mellace as a car rental agent, and a well-utilized rock score by Jimmy Dale and Mark Shekter.This marks the first feature written and directed by Steven H. Stern, produced by Arthur M. Broidy and photographed in color by David Dans. Nice going, men. Let's have another. Soon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Even for a Great Chef, Poularde Chevalire is a Pain
description: It is not male chauvinist propaganda to observe that, with few exceptions, all of the famous French chefs since the beginning of French cookery have been men. On the other hand, I have never known a French chef who did not at some point in his formative years have the influence, inspiration if you will, of a woman cook. It might have been a mother or a stepmother, or an aunt or some other, but the influence was there.

title: HOUSE BLOCKS BID TO CURTAIL DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 By a margin of only two votes, the House rejected today a bi partisan effort to limit the con tinuation of the military draft to one year.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS TRADING RISES
description: Volume improved and prices edged ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Handy & Harman Gets Loan
description: Handy & Harman, the New Yorkbased processor and fabri cator of precious metals, an nounced yesterday that it had arranged through Goldman, Sachs & Co. for a $10million, 20year loan from the New York Life Insurance Company.

title: City's Human Resources Chief Scores Proposal to Cut Relief
description: Human Resources Adminis trator Jule M. Sugarman charged yesterday that the plan by the Republican state legislative leadership for wel fare cuts was biased in favor of upstate communities and penalized New York City and its poor.

title: G.O.P. DEFERS VOTE ON STATE BUDGET; SHY OF SUPPORT
description: ALBANY, March 31  The Republican majority leaders recessed the Legislature late to night, the eve of the start of the 1972 state fiscal year, after an anxious but fruitless day of searching the G.O.P. ranks for the votes to pass a $7.7 billion budget.

title: Army Denies Judge's Plea For Inquiry Into Race Bias
description: WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)The Army has denied a military judge's petition for an official court of inquiry into al leged racial discrimination by West German landlords against American servicemen.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Putnam County streams may have a surplus of ang lers today as the trout fish ing season opens in New York State.

title: Monte Carlo Gets Title Bout
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 31 (UPI)  Carlos Monzon agreed today to defend his middle weight title against Nino Ben venuti May 8 in Monte Carlo.

title: Saigon Bans Weeklies Again
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)Saigon authori ties have banned the April 4 issues of Time and Newsweek from sale in South Vietnam for articles considered hostile to national security. It marked the second week in a row that the magazines have been banned here. The action does not affect sales to American military personnel in post ex changes.

title: FREDERICK BAXTER
description: NEW SUFFOLK, L. I., April 1 Frederick H. Baxter, retired vice president and controller of the New Jersey Zinc Company, died yesterday at Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport, after a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived on Old Harbor Road here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE IS ACCUSED BY ANGELA DAVIS
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 1 Angela Davis charged today that the latest judge appointed to hear her pretrial motions was prejudiced against her in terest and asked that he be disqualified.

title: That City Opera Repertory
description: On Tuesday the New York City Opera held a news con ference to announce its sea son for next fall. Julius Rudel, the musical director of the company, got up to say a few words. Veteran Rudelogists among the critics looked ex pectantly at each other. They knew what was coming. Mr. Rudel did riot disappoint.

title: State Facing Its First Deficit in 20 Years
description: ALBANY, April 1The state left the old fiscal year today with its first official deficit in 20 years, plus $195million in deferred obligations still to be paid.

title: TWO RED PARTIES STRESS AUTONOMY
description: MOSCOW, April 1  Presi dent Nicolae Ceausescu of Ru mania told the Soviet Commu nist party's 24th Congress to day that his country would continue to follow an indepen dent course even if this brought it into conflict with Soviet pol icies.

title: STATES MAY GAIN IN WELFARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Chairman Wilbur D. Mills was reported today to be will ing, to increase the cost of the welfare reform bill before the House Ways and Means Com mittee if a majority of the other members could be per suaded.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BUFFALO, April 1 (UPI) Steve Atkinson scored from just outside the crease with 14 minutes 53 seconds gone in the second period tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 3.3 tie with the Pittsburgh Pen guins.

title: MISS CRESPIN ADDED To WERTHER CAST
description: Opera roles are frequently passed around from one kind of voice and artistic personality to another, and sometimes an unexpected casting works out to the advantage of both the role and the performer. But the casting of Rgine Crespin as Charlotte in the Metropolitan Opera production of Massenet's Werther did not lead to the happiest of results for either the French soprano or the opera.

title: Braves Acquire Staehle
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 (AP)The Montreal Expos sold an infielder, Mary Staehle, to the Atlanta Braves today.

title: Witness Says Mrs. Crimmins Confessed to Slaying Daughter
description: Joseph Rorech, a Long Island contractor, testified yesterday that Mrs. Alice Crimmins had told him she murdered her daughter and that she agreed to the death of her son.

title: DeBusschere Steal Was Key Knick Play
description: If a poll was taken of the 19,500 fans who saw the Knicks rally to oust the Atlanta Hawks from the playoffs, four games to one, last night, the majority would probably agree that the key play of the game was made by Dave DeBusschere with 1 minute 38 seconds to play.

title: 14 Hell's Angels Indicted In Death of 4 Rival Cyclists
description: CLEVELAND, April 1 (UPI) Fourteen members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were indicted today on first degree murder charges in the fatal stabbings of four rival cyclists at a motorcycle show here.

title: Alioto Pleads Not Guilty To Bribery and Mail Fraud
description: SEATTLE, April 1 (UPI) Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco and three former Washington state officials pleaded not guilty today to Fed eral charges of bribery and mail fraud.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Don't look now, but the baseball season is almost upon us. It comes tiptoeing in, seemingly earlier than usual, while attention is still distracted by the dunking of baskets, the icing of pucks and the brokenfieldrunning of the football Giants in their bewildering version of the Jersey Bounce. But it has been ages since baseball commanded a solitary spotlightan opening day no longer has the power to mesmerize an entire nation into suspenseful anticipation.

title: Hunch Bet on State Raider Brings Lindsay Na Aid
description: Mayor Lindsay wagered two playdollars yesterday in a dem onstration of how the city's off track betting system will work when it starts operating Thurs day.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation has elected Shelton Fisher, president and chief executive officer of McGrawHill, Inc., as a director.

title: Taiwan's Envoy to the U.S. Is Named Foreign Minister
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 1  President Chiang Kaishek to day appointed Chow Shukai, the Chinese Nationalist Am bassador to the United States since 1965, as Foreign Minister.

title: Britain May Also Act
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 United States military planes will begin evacuating depend ents of American officials and private United States citizens from East Pakistan tomorrow, the State Department an nounced today.

title: U.S. Held Ready to Help
