description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Nixon Administration is pre pared to support and help negotiate an agreement between the United Arab Republic and Israel to reopen the Suez Canal, according to knowledgeable sources here.

title: Connecticut Residents Help Panther to Get Bail
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1  A dozen residents of nearby suburban communities have put up their homes and other prop erty as security to cover a $100,000 bail bond for a for mer leader of the Black Panther party here.

title: U.S. Veterans of Vietnam War Rally on Wall Street for Peace
description: A veteran of the war in Vietnam who has three Purple Hearts, a Bronze Star and a Silver Star told a noontime Wall Street rally yesterday, We are all of us in this country guilty for having allowed the war to go on.

title: UnitPricing Rules On Grocery Items Issued by the City
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner Bess Myerson issued regulations yesterday requiring all selfservice food stores and chains grossing more than $2 million a year to post prices by units, such as pounds or pints, on a wide range of products.

title: H. Alexander MacLennan Dies; Retired Hilton Official Was 73
description: H. Alexander MacLennan, who retired in 1964 as a vice president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, where he had set up its Carte Blanche credit sysH tern, died Tuesday in Naples, Fla., at the age of 73. He also lived in Burlington, Ontario.

title: Mrs. Marion E. Glover, 80, Of National Symphony Board
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Mrs. Marion Everett Glover, a longtime board member and honorary vice president of the National Symphony orchestra, died at her home today after an illness of several months. She was 80 years old and the wife of Charles C. Glover.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DETROIT, Friday, April (UPI)The United Auto Work ers today early canceled a 6:45 A.M. strike deadline against American Motors and agreed to work without a contract while talks continued on a new pact.

title: 2 Regulatory Officials Differ On Reorganizing of Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Members of two of the Gov ernment's major regulatory agencies took opposing views today on the proposals for reorganization of those agen cies that were made by a pres idential task force headed by Roy L. Ash, president of Litton Industries, Inc.

title: ASTROS' 4HITTER BEATS YANKS, 50
description: HOUSTON, April 1 Larry Dierker and Denny Lemaster of the Houston Astros combined tonight to shut out the New York Yankees, 50, on four hits. It was the 20th loss of the spring for the Yankees, who have, won only eight times.

title: G.O.P. Budget Turmoil a Laugh To Democrats Who Recall 1965
description: ALBANY, April 1  Demo cratic legislators, who were se verely criticized by the Repub licans in 1965 for not passing a budget by the deadline of midnight March 31, could hard ly conceal their glee today at the discomfiture of the Repub licans for failing to meet the deadline this year.

title: Advertising:
description: At 37, Sherwood Ross has already been a Chicago news paper reporter, a star of a Washington radio show, a news director of the National Urban League and a press aide to political candidates.

title: March Auto Output Climbed at 3 of Big 4
description: Gains in automobile pro duction for March were re ported yesterday by three of the nation's Big Four car makers.

title: Nice Opening Day, And Trout Enjoy It
description: CARMEL, N. Y., April 1 It was a lovely day to visit the streams of the Croton River watershed in Putnam County. The temperature was well above freezing by 9 A.M. and the sun shone brightly most of the time, but fewer anglers were pres ent for the opening day of the trout season than were observed the last two years.

title: RIVALRY IS URGED ON ANTIPOLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  Richard W. McLaren, the head of die Justice Department's An titrust Division, indicated today that he did not believe that it would be either necessary or desirable, in most cases, to per mit companies in the same in dustry to work together on antipollution methods and de vices.

title: Prague's Political Trials
description: Two political trials in Czechoslovakia last month must arouse grave misgivings. They raise the possibility that the most ruthless proMoscow elements in Czecho slovakiathose who have been calling for the trial and punishment of all involved in the late, lamented Prague spring of 1968have come out on top in the political infighting surrounding Gustav Husak.

title: MARCH.PERIOD SALES OF WOOLWORTH OFF
description: In one of the first reports by a major retail chain on March sales, the F. W. Woolworth Company announced yesterday a decline of 8.4 per cent in its sales in the fourweek period ended March 27. Volume to taled $172,249,843 against $188,073,530 the year before.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS SECOND MISTRIAL
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn declared a second mistrial yes terday in the case of Rocco Mi raglia, charging that newspa per reports had made it impos sible to grant him a fair trial.

title: G.M. AIDE HOLDS POLLUTION DROPS
description: Dr. William G. Agnew, head of the emission research depart ment of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that pollution from automobiles was decreasing.

title: FIVE CZECH MOVIES TO BE SHOWN HERE
description: A series of five Czechoslo vak films, two of which will have their premiere showings in this country, will be pre sented at the New York Cul tural Center in Columbus Cir cle starting Wednesday. The screenings, which will be held Wednesdays through Sundays at 4 and 6 P.M., will extend through May 2.

title: Towaway Fee Held Illegal Overcharge
description: A State Supreme Court Jus tice ruled illegal yesterday the $50 fee that the city im poses for towing away cars it deems to be illegally parked.

title: EASTERN CONFIDENT ABOUT TRISTAR JET
description: MIAMI, April 1  Eastern Air Lines, one of the biggest customers for the much troubled Lockheed Tristar jet liner, stressed today its con tinued confidence in the three jet airbus.

title: Prosecution Rests in Trial of 13 Panthers
description: The prosecution rested yes terday in the trial here of 13 Black Panthers accused of con spiring to bomb public places and murder policemen and of possessing dangerous weapons and explosives.

title: Cambodian Ships Get Through
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1 (Reuters)  A Cambo dian convoy sailed into port here today with important sup plies of petroleum and ammu nition after having been de layed for two days by Vietcong gunners.

title: Submarine Bearing Multiple Warheads Begins Sea Patrol
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)  The Navy has started de ploying submarine  launched Poseidon missiles armed with multiple nuclear warheads that can be aimed at many separate targets, it was reported today.

title: 400 College Leaders Condemn War Policy in Letter to Nixon
description: More than 400 student presi dents and college editors have signed an open letter to Presi dent Nixon condemning his policies in Vietnam and charg ing that the Administration seriously misinterprets the mood of both the campus and the countryside.

title: C. & O. PUTS NEW CAR FOR CABLE IN SERVICE
description: The Chesapeake & OhioBal timore & Ohio railroads an nounced yesterday they had placed in service a fleet of 35 custombuilt flatcars for haul ing communication and power cable.

title: Lee May on Disabled List
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 1 (UPI) The Cincinnati Reds placed their injured first baseman, Lee May, on the supplemental disabled list today for a 15day period. May strained a ligament in his left knee during a game with the New York Mets last night.

title: SpaceAge First Graders Learn Fast
description: YONKERSPut a group of 6yearolds in a planetarium, give them an astronomy lec ture and a celestial show and out will come a tumble of sometimes sophisticated, sometimes naive questions.

title: Navy to Yield Culebra Targets; 13Year Island Struggle at End
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The islanders of Culebra have won 13yearlong struggle to pre vent the United States Navy from using parts of their island as training targets. But it will take a few years for the Navy to leave the small Puerto Rican island.

title: WARRIOR BASKET CONQUERS BUCKS
description: OAKLAND, Calif. April 1 (AP)Joe Ellis threw in a 40 foot jump shot with one sec ond to play tonight to give San Francisco a 106104 vic tory over the Milwaukee Bucks and keep the Warriors alive in the National Basketball Associ tion Western Division playoffs.

title: MRS. HAROLD STANLEY
description: Mrs. Louise Todd Stanley, the widow of Harold Stanley, a founding partner of Morgan Stanley & Co., investment banking house, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. She was 69 years old and lived at 1 Eatt 66th Street.

title: Bert C. Goss, Publicist, Dead; Chairman of Hill and Knowlton
description: Bert C. Goss, board chairman of Hill and Knowlton, Inc., leading public relations firm, died yesterday in the Neuro logical Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 64.

title: Agnew Denounces HomeFront Snipers
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Vice President Agnew called critics of the war in Indochina homefront snipers! today and accused them of having fos tered a negative attitude to ward American combat vet erans.

title: Rocky Road to Pay Stability
description: Despite the vehemence of the initial protests froth building union leaders, there remains basis for optimism that labor will not boycott the joint unionmanagement machinery to be established under president Nixon, splan for putting restraints on the uprush of the wage price spiral in construction.

title: GENERAL'S REVOLT FAILS IN ECUADOR
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 1 (AP) A disgruntled general's one day revolt against the Govern ment of President Jos Maria Velasco Ibarra ended today the way it beganwith a commu niqu. Not a shot was fired in the interim.

title: Inmates at Federal Jail Here Take Over Cell Blocks for 3 Hours
description: Led by a small group of in mates, about 270 prisoners gained control of their cell blocks at the Federal House of Detention in Manhattan for thrice hours last night but re turned peaceably to their cells after a show of force by cor rection officers.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.2 From Week Ago Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrials materials slipped to 109.5 Tuesday from 109.7 last week.

title: The Forgotten G.I.'s Near Khesanh
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 30The American in fantrymen who have been patrolling the junglecovered mountains west of Khesanh fighting and sometimes dy ing in obscure smallunit clashes while supporting the South Vietnamese invasion of Laosfeel that they are for gotten men.

title: TV: Sammy Davis Discusses Racism
description: Sammy Davis Jr. once ap peared as the only guest on the David Frost Show, and after 90 minutes the viewer was reassured that the black entertainer could sing, dance and tell funny stories. Sammy Davis Jr. appeared earlier this week on Black Journal, and after a halfhour interview on the hourlong show, the view er discovered what it means to be a black entertainer, however superstar, in an in dustry controlled by whites.

title: Jersey Asks Fast Review
description: TRENTON, April 1 (UPI) The New Jersey Senate passed a resolution today asking Presi dent Nixon to speed up the re view of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s case.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. CHECKED GROUP RELAYING P.O.W. MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation confirmed today that it had questioned relatives of prisoners of war about the peace group that relays mail to and from American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: MISS HOGAN SCORES UPSET AT DURBAN NET
description: DURBAN, South Africa, April 1 (AP)Upsets marked the quarterfinals today of the women's open tennis tourna ment.

title: Shimada Leads With 63
description: HONG KONG, April 1 (AP) Kosaku Shimada of Japan shot a sevenunderpar 63 today and took the firstround lead in the Hong Kong Open golf tourna ment. Tied for second with 65's were Graham Marsh of Australia, Seiichi Kanai and Haruo Yasuda of Japan and Eleuterio Nival of the Philip pines.

title: Withering of Port Linked To Cheating on Dock Pay
description: The Port of New York, long the hub of maritime commerce, is steadily losing business to other North Atlantic ports mainly because of higher labor costs here attributed partly to cheating by longshoremen.

title: Mrs. Dorothy Breitenfeld, Statistician for Foundation
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 1Mrs. Dorothy Falk Breitenfeld, statistician and widow of Frederick Breiten feld, a New York patent law yer for whom she was office administrator, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home, 72 Stony, Run. She was 70 years old.

title: Bronx Drug Suspect Dies
description: A Bronx woman who had been arrested on a narcotics charge on Wednesday became ill in a Bronx detention cell and died en route to Morrisania Hospital, authorities disclosed yesterday. They identified her as 22yearold Janet Hooksof 1250 Morrison Avenue. Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said his office was in vestigating. Dr. Milton Halpern, Chief Medical Examiner, said the exact cause of death hid not been determined.

title: Ohba Keeps Flyweight Title; Gonzales: I Was Betrayed
description: TOKYO, April 1 (AP) Masao Ohba of Japan survived a battering in the final round and won a unanimous decision over Betulio Gonzales of Vene zuela tonight, thus retaining the World Boxing Association flyweight title.

title: Lakers Take 32 Edge
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP)  Gail Goodrich scored 33 points and had 11 assists to night as the Los Angeles Lakers trounced the Chicago Bulls, 11589 to take a 32 lead in their playoff series.

title: Florida Power & Light Co. Reports Gain in Earnings
description: The Florida Power and Light Company reported yesterday gains in 1970 operating reve nues and net income.

title: Screen: 'The Emperor and General':Japanese Film Shows Last Hours of War Young Officers' Group Weighs Surrender
description: Kihachi Okamoto's "The Emperor and the General" is a very long, very careful dramatized account of the events surrounding the Japanese surrender at the end of World War II. A Japanese movie, it deals almost wholly with the shaping of internal policy from just before word of the Potsdam Declaration of July 26, 1945, until the Emperor's broadcast of the acceptance of unconditional surrender on Aug. 15. However, the film is mostly concerned with the 24 hours preceding the broadcast  the drafting and recording of the speech, the suicide of War Minister Anami, the futile attempt of some young officers to destroy the recording and continue the war to destruction.As historical document, I suspect that the film is meticulously accurate, with everyone saying or doing what, on record, he did say or door, at the very least, saying and doing what, under the circumstances he would have said or done. To an almost stultifying degree, the action is confined to meetings of the cabinet, press conferences, audiences with the Emperoruntil the brief rebellion is joined and suddenly all hell breaks loose: blood gushes, bodies fall and heads, literally, roll.The aim of the young officers, under a Major Hatanaka, is not to win material advantage so much as to assure that Japan's behavior at the last should hinge not on the matter of victory or defeat but on the continuance of an honorable mode of action. This is a theme, and a real one, worth making a movie about, and it has been rather badly slighted in "The Emperor and the General" in favor of a suspense plotwill Japan surrender successfully or won't it?that in a film made more than 20 years after the fact seems a little silly.In curious ways the movie (and not just the characters in the movie) seems involved in Emperor worship. On the one hand it hides Emperor Hirohito from the camerabehind screens, doorways, people's backsallowing only the slightest symbolic identification, the way a cigarette holder or a black scotty used to signify President Roosevelt in the more reverent old American movies. And on the other hand it devotes very nearly obsessive attention to the outward signs of the Emperor's willto drafting, recording and even correctly copying out the proclamation. About half way through, "The Emperor and the General" begins to seem like a Kafka subject that has somehow been misread as semi-documentary.Some distinguished actors appear in the filmMifune, of course, and the wonderful Chishu Ryo, a regular in the Ozu stock company. But the rebellious officers (I am able to identify only Toshio Kurosawa) play broadly for mad rage, and in its treatment of the military "The Emperor and the General" looks distressingly like the rape of the Pacific, the way grade-C American movies showed it during World War II.Most of the rebels tremble with anger. But one of them, the commander of a naval air unit that mounts a kamikaze attack (not the film's finest moment) trembles both with anger and from pesky bouts of malaria  and his performance is perhaps the chief absurd glory of the movie."The Emperor and the General" opened yesterday at the Bijou Cinema.

title: BREAK APPEARS IN NEWARK STRIKE
description: NEWARK, Friday, April 2 The nineweekold teachers' strike here took a major step toward settlement last night when the Board of Education voted to accept a mediator's recommendations on key issues in the dispute.

title: C. & O.B. & O. Gains
description: The Chesapeake & OhioBal timore & Ohio Railroad sys tem reported yesterday con solidated earnings for the first quarter this year of $8.8mil lion, or $1.02 a share. This was up from $3.5million, or 41 cents a share, in the same quarter last year.

title: Quiet Rules in Charleston As Bridge Plan Is Stayed
description: CHARLESTON, S. C. There is a truce in this city thin week that is almost as welcome as the end of the cm War. The threat of a controversial bridge from suburban James Island to the heart of downtown Charles ton that would have turned the historic city into an au tomobile commuter route to commercial sections farther north has been temporarily stayed.

title: Efforts to Hamper Army
description: NEW DELHI, April 1With the Pakistani Army apparently establishing control of the main towns and cities of East Paki stan, the resistance fighters were reported turning to guer rilla tactics in the countryside, where travel is difficult.

title: Some at Mohawk Are Recalled With End of 20Week Walkout
description: Mohawk Airlines recalled nine pilotinstructors and 250 aircraft mechanics yesterday when a 20week strike by its 396 pilots ended.

title: Health Board Faces Cut in Authority
description: State health authorities are pressing the Legislature to strip the City Board of Health of its power to set public health standards here.

title: $916,185 REALIZED ON WALSKA JEWELS
description: Fine diamonds and emeralds belonging to Ganna Walska, the onetime opera star, brought $916,185 at auction yesterday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: Railroad's Profit Falls
description: The Western Maryland Rail way, controlled by the Chesa peake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio railroads, reported yesterday firstquarter profit of $457,346, or 22 cents a share, down from the yearearlier $920,877, or 48 cents a share.

title: Movers in Metropolitan Area Strike After Rejecting a Pact
description: The 4,500 union men who move household and office fur niture in the meropolitan area overwhelmingly rejected a con tract offer yesterday and went on strike.

title: Store Sales Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $6$7 million, down 4 per cent from the yearearlier $715million. Last week's total retail store sales were about 7.31billion, up 4 per cent from $7billion.

title: The Ordeal of the Army
description: PITTSBURGHNot before in my lifetimeand I was, born into the Army in the nineteenth centuryhas the Army's public image suffered so many grievous blows end fallen to such low esteem in such wide areas of our society.

title: The Child Is at the Center of Informal British Schools
description: LONDONCaren Cockrane, a shy 5yearold, leaned over a scale and patiently weighed stones, corks, dog biscuits and pine cones as she struggled, with the help of her teacher, to understand why a single large stone can be heavier than four smaller ones.

title: Baeza Rides 3 Winners
description: A crowd of 24,537 attended the Aqueduct program yester day. In the feature contest, James Drymon's Double Delta, under a ride by Braulio Baeza, scored by threequarters of a length over I'm For Mama. Time for the six furlongs was 1:10 4/5.

title: DRAFT UNTIL 1973 IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The House voted overwhelming ly tonight to continue the mili tary draft until the middle of 1973 and sharply increase pay and allowances for servicemen.

title: Arlo Guthrie Gives A Concert Marked By Country Songs
description: Arlo Guthrie played a con cert Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall and made a sig nificant move toward coun try music.

title: Prague's Political Trials
description: Two political trials in Czechoslovakia last month must arouse grave misgivings. They raise the possibility that the most ruthless proMoscow elements in Czecho slovakiathose who have been calling for the trial and punishment of all involved in the late, lamented Prague spring of 1968have come out on top in the political infighting surrounding Gustav Husak.

title: Bolivian ExConsul Is Slain By a Woman in Hamburg
description: BONN, April 1A Bolivian diplomat was shot and killed in his office in Hamburg this morning by a woman who gained entry by pretending to seek some visas, the West Ger man police said. They added that the killing bore the signs of a political assassination.

title: STUDENT KIDNAPPING LAID TO 6 IN JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 1Six young men, includ ing three former students at the Rutgers University Livingston College campus were indicted today on charges of armed kid napping, assault with intent to kill and possesion of illegal weapons.

title: March 6 Arrival Sues City for Welfare
description: A Sanford, N. C. woman with four children is suing the city in an effort to get on the wel fare rolls. The city maintains that the family is already get ting assistance from its home state.

title: Woman Gives Up Dream For Atlantic City Hotel
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 1 (AP)  A Philadelphia woman who bid $2million last No vember to fulfill her dream of owning the Ambassador Hotel here abandoned her dream yes terday when she failed to make a $200,000 payment.

title: FRANK D. LEMMON
description: Frank Davidson Lemmon, who rose from office boy to vice president, secretary and director of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, died Wednesday in Atlanta. His age was 80.

title: Scientist Is Picked as Aide to Morton
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Dr. William T. Pecora, director of the United States Geological Survey, has been picked to be come Under Secretary of the Interior.

title: Fate of Hoist the Flag In Doubt After Surgery
description: Hoist the Flag was resting comfortably and eating his hay in his barn at Belmont Park yesterday, his right hind leg enclosed in a fiberglass cast.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE UP 0.5% FROM '70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended March 27 was above the cor responding 1970 week. Inter city Truck Tonnage in the same period registered a de crease.

title: LONDON STOCKS UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: The British bankrate cut from 7 per cent to 6 per cent was largely responsible for higher prices and active trad ing on the London Stock Ex change yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Cut Bank Rate;
description: LONDON, April 1The Brit ish bank rate was cut by one percentage point today, from 7 per cent to 6 per cent, the lowest level since the prede valuation days of 1967.

title: PARAMOUNT CHIEF IS SET TO RESIGN
description: Stanley R. Jaffe, the 30year old president of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, an nounced yesterday that be will resign on Aug. 1 to form his own production company, which will supply films to be distributed by Paramount.

title: RALPH L. BAGGS
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1Ralph L. Baggs, a re tired businessman, author and former member of the Connecti cut Legislature, died on Mon day. He was 83 years old and lived in Danbury, Conn., spend ing his winters here.

title: Sputtering Mideast Fuse
description: Egyptian troops fired a few bursts from their machine guns across the Suez Canal the other day, the first shooting incident reported from the Canal zone since the Middle East ceasefire expired March 7.

title: Computer Sale Frustrates Ranger Fans
description: The Rangers' plan to make 1,500 playoff tickets available only through a special tele phone operation or through Ticketron outlets left in its wake thousands of frustrated fans, many of whom spent the night in vain at Ticketron loca tions.

title: Space Fund Rise Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A $3.4million spending ceil ing for the nation's space pro gram, increased $162.2million over President Nixon's budget, was approved today by the House Science and Astronautics Committee.

title: Chase Opens Rome Office
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the open ing of a Rome banking office in the Palazzo Italia, 25 Piazza Marconi. The branch, managed by Robert K. Lindell, is Chase's 13th in Europe.

title: FEDERAL COURT BARS LEGAL STRIKE RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A threejudge Federal court ruled today that there was no constitutional right to strike and that Government workers could be barred from striking.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BLOGRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Blographical Edition. Profiles of today's newsmakers In a loose lest edition. Write: The New York Times. Library Services, Box FP450, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.Advt.

title: EGYPT PROPOSES TRUCE IF ISRAELIS PLEDGE PULLBACK
description: CAIRO, April 1The United Arab Republic offered tonight to reinstate a formal ceasefire along the Suez Canal for a limited period if Israel would agree to a proposal of President Anwar elSadat for a partial withdrawal of troops to be fol lowed by a reopening of the waterway to international shipping.

title: Chinese Capture Title in Men's Table Tennis
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 1 (Reuters)Communist China reestablished its supremacy in men's table tennis today after a sixyear absence from international competition. It defeated Japan, the defending champion, 5.2, to take the men's team title and the Swaythling Cup.

title: JOHNSON, GUITARIST, MAKES DEBUT HERE
description: Playing a program that lasted less than an hour, Richard John son made his debut as a guitar ist at the New York Cultural Center on Wednesday night. A native of Kansas City, where he studied with Walter Fritschy before working with Oscar Ghiglia in Paris, Mr. Johnson performed some halfdozen standard works correctly. Ac curacy of pitch and firm basic rhythms were constantly in evi dence.

title: Hiram Walker Lists Slight 6Month Profit Gain
description: Hiram WalkerGooderham & Worts, Ltd., second largest Canadian distiller and one of the four principal producers of whisky and gin in the United States, showed substantially larger sales in the fiscal quarter and six months ended Feb. 28, but earnings were virtually un changed, according to the semi annual results reported yester day.

title: A Hearty Fish Stew, an Apple Dessert
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As the South Vietnamese stream back across the border, the official dispatches7and President Nixon him selfdescribe the military action in Laos as successful.

title: BRANCALEONE PLAYS DEBUSSY SMOOTHLY
description: As in his previous recitals here, Francis Brancaleone, who played at Tully Hall Wednes day night, showed formidable control of color and nimble technique.

title: Opposition to Galley's Conviction and Sentence Grows in Nation
description: With telegrams, offers of money and demonstrations, Americans in both the public and private sectors expressed growing opposition yesterday to the conviction and sentenc ing of FirstLieut. William L Calley Jr.

title: S.E.C. Rebuffs Big Board; Fee Deadline Stands
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission has received yet another appeal from the New York Stock Exchangeand has responded with yet another re jectionthat it postpone the effective date of its order end ing pricefixing sales commis sions on large stock transac tions.

title: Disputed TV Show on Jews Is Canceled
description: Station WORTV disclosed yesterday that it had can celed plans to broadcast a controversial and widely ad vertised television program depicting the Jewish Passover as a forerunner of Holy Com munion and other Christian practices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RESERVE TWISTS INTEREST RATES
description: Operation Twist was the watchword in the Federal Re serve System's dealings in the money market during the last week, banking figures indicate.

title: MAGAZINE PLANNING STOCKOPTION BONUS
description: New York magazine an nounced yesterday that it will offer options to buy stock in its parent company, Aeneid Equities, to writers, illustrators and photographers who con tribute to the magazine. The stock options will be in addi tion to fees.

title: Three Are Indicted In Union Shortage On Welfare Funds
description: Three executive's of the pub lic loading company that has the exclusive city license to unload freight cars at the Hunts Point Market in the East Bronx pleaded not guilty yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court to a grand larceny indictment.

title: Recapture of Base. Overrun by Enemy Reported by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 2A twoday battle in the Central Highlands in which a North Vietnamese regi ment stormed into a South, Vietnamese fire base and then was pushed out again was re ported today by the Saigon command.

title: NEW TRIMS MADE IN STATE BUDGET TO END DEADLOCK
description: ALBANY, Friday, April 2 A Republican impasse on a new state budget was ended last night with Governor Rockefeller and G.O.P. leaders agreeing to additional econo mies of $43million, for a total of $760million in reductions from the Governor's original $8.45billion proposal.

title: DEMOCRACY PERILED IN CHILE, SAYS EREI
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1 The former President, Eduardo Frei Montelva, tonight accused influential groups in Chile's leftwing Government of trying to install a regime that will make democracy impossible.

title: Like the Price of Cows, the Cost of a Bride Goes Up in Turkey
description: ANKARAWhen Ali Ihsan married here five years ago, he paid his father inlaw 6,000 Turkish lira (the equivalent then of $500) in baslik, or bride price. Now Ali's 18yearold sister is being courted by a fellow student whose fam ily has hinted that it considers 12,000 ($800 since last summer's devaluation) as a fair price.

title: Puerto Rican TV Plant Set
description: TOKYO, April 1 (Reuters)  The Matsushita Electric. Indus trial Company announced to day that it would shortly start assembling largesized color television sets, using American made components, in Puerto Rico for sale in the United States. The Puerto Rican sub sidiary will produce 25inch sets at a monthly rate of 2,000 units starting in July, Matsu shita added.

title: Joan Cadden Bride in West
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 1 Miss Joan Cadden, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Cadden of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married here this afternoon to Curt R. Zimansky, son of Prof. and Mrs. Curt A. Zi mansky of Iowa City. Judge William W. Gardner of the Boulder. County Court per formed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Opera's Season To Be 11 Weeks
description: The New York City Opera, now in the final weeks of its spring season, will return to the State Theater on Sept. for an, 11week fall season, the longest in its history.

title: Soviet Union Upset in World Hockey Tourney
description: GENEVA, April 1 (UP)  Czechoslovakia scored three goals in the third period tonight to beat the Soviet Union, 52, and delay the outcome of the world ice hockey champion ships until the tournament's final session Saturday.

title: Futures in Silver Coins Traded
description: Trading in silver coin futures began yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with mixed reactions from thoses participating in the market.

title: Penny's Trustees Tell Court of Loss
description: The trustees of the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company informed the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yester day that the bankrupt railroad operated at a loss of $66,344, 876 in the first two months of this year.

title: DIRECTORS BACK HEUBLEIN MERGER
description: Merger News

title: Mitchell Visits Seymour
description: Attorney General John N. Mitchell delivered a brief pri vate talk to Federal prosecu tors here yesterday during a visit to the office of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. It was Mr. Mitch ell's first visit to Mr. Sey mour's since he became At torney General.

title: Mild High Blood Pressure May Aid Aging
description: DENVER, April 1  Mild to moderate high blood pressure may be good for the aging mind, a scientist who has been studying the elderly for more than a decade said here today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The recent disclosures about extensive Govern ment spying on private citizens raises a practical question: Why not a domes tic intelligence advisory board to help the President maintain a balance be tween the security of the nation and the rights of its citizens? In short, counterpart in the domestic intelli gence field to the excellent committee of distinguished citizens now serving as President Nixon's Foreign Intelli gence Advisory Board.

title: Market Place: Details Cloudy In I.T.T. Report
description: A Canadian retail shoe company that recently was ordered by authorities north of the border to begin report ing sales to its shareholders was sheltered to a farethee well.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that the follow ing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Pound Circulation Decreases 11.42Million in the Week
description: LONDON, April 1 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: CostSharing Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Provisions to charge both aged and lowincome persons part of the cost of health serv ices they now receive free have been tentatively written into I new welfare bill, It was re ported today. new welfare bill, It was re ported today.

title: Knicks Oust Hawks, 111 to 107
description: In the most furious struggle of a furious series, the New York Knicks again won the gameend battle from the At lanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night, and with a 111107 decision ended their firstround assignment in the National Basketball Association playoffs, 4 games to 1.

title: LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI DEFECTION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 A man who said he was an Israeli Army officer defected to Lebanon yesterday. This brought to four the number of reported Israeli defections to this country in the last three months.

title: Utility Sells Stock
description: The Southern California Edi son Company raised about $98.1million yesterday with the offering of 3 million shares of common stock priced by a First Boston CorporationDean Witter & Co., Inc., underwriting group at $33.50, The utility will use the proceeds to retire short term loans and to help finance construction.

title: At Soviet Congress, a Personal Touch
description: MOSCOW, April 1The personal touch that ordinary workers give their speeches at the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party makes for a refreshing change from weighty affairs of state.

title: Lincoln and Micki King Win in Diving
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 1 Craig Lincoln of the University of Minnesota was the winner of the men's event, the one meter springboard, and Capt. Micki King of the United States Air Force, took the women's threemeter springboard title to night at the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor diving championships.

title: OneTerm President Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI)  Senators Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, and George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, introduced a consti tutional amendment today that would limit the President and Vice President to one sikyear term.

title: City Council to Open Inquiry on H. R. A.'s Performance
description: Criticizing the city's job training and addiction services program, a City Council chair man set the date yesterday for longdelayed hearings on offi cial creation of Mayor Lind say's ninth and last super agency.

title: Private Colleges Report a Decrease In Gifts Last Year
description: Small private colleges and universities suffered a de crease in voluntary financial support last year, while public institutions had a substantial in crease, according to a national survey by the Council for Fi nancial Aid to Education.

title: Stan Kenton's Stopover: No Mere Echo of Past
description: The real truth about New York todaythe awful truth is that it's a onenight stand between Hackensack and Pittsburgh.

title: ALBERT E. WINGER, EXCOLLIER CHIEF
description: Albert E. Winger, an honor ary director of Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., and former president and chairman of the board of the CrowellCollier Publishing Company, died here yesterday after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 1035 Park Avenue.

title: Gibson's Father Is Injured In Assault by 5 Youths
description: NEWARK, Friday, April 2 (UPI)Mayor Kenneth A. Gib son's 60yearold father, Willie Gibson, has been temporarily hospitalized for observation, after he was assaulted by five youths on a Newark street late last night.

title: Arab Guerrillas Marking Time; Their Impact in Jordan Weaker
description: BEKAA, Jordan, March 28 Goats romp. Old men doze in the sun. Children race on rented bicycles. But the armed Pal estinian commandos who once swarmed through Bekaa's dirt alleys are nowhere to be seen.

title: Rockefeller Appeals To Budget Holdouts
description: ALBANY, April 1  State Senator Thomas F. McGowan, Republican of Buffalo, rarely has had such royal treatment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurant Food Is Not Sole Criterion
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: KATHLEEN LONSDALE, BRITISH SCIENTIST, 68
description: LONDON, April 1Dame Kathleen Lonsdale, a leading orystallographer and professor of chemistry, died early today, at University College Hospital in London. She was 68 years old.

title: Montana Backs Voting at 18
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) Montana's ratification of the proposed 18yearold voting amendment yesterday has raised to 12 the number of states that have agreed to the provision.

title: Dollar Comes Under Pressure
description: PARIS, April 1 The dollar came under renewed pressure in Europe's money centers to day despite the action taken by West Germany and Britain to lower interest rates.

title: Cosmos No. 402 Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (AP)The Soviet Union launched the 402d of its unmanned Cosmos satel lites today. The Tess press agency said the satellite wash in n nearly circular orbit, from 160 to 1,70 miles above the earth.

title: Bomb Threat Halts Plane
description: AMARILLO, Tex., April 1 (UPI)A Trans World Airlines 72 jetliner on the last leg of a New YorkChicagoPhoenix flight made an unscheduled stop in Amarillo, Tex., early today to be searched for a bomb.

title: Making Justice More Equal
description: The riot at the Federal House of Detention here last night affords fresh warning of the explosive tensions that plague all penal institutions in this city. At the Tombs, most troublebeset of local prisons, these ten sions should be eased when the Department of Cor rection complies with a Federal judge's order to let prisoners in that dismal jail know exactly what rules govern the conduct of inmates and guards. The order was the outgrowth of a class action brought by the Legal Aid Society to force speedier official action toward ending the intolerable conditions in the city's over crowded penal institutions.

title: Knicks List Ticket Plan For Next Playoff Series
description: The Knicks have announced the following playoff ticket arrangements:

title: Welcome AboutFace
description: The Nixon Administration's proposals for reducing election campaign spending are as gratifying as they are surprising. They greatly improve the prospect that in the 1972 campaign, money will not be a prime requisite, as has been over the past two decades. And they represent a welcome change on the part of a President who has up to now given reformers little reason to regard him an ally in the effort to reduce the political power of the dollar.

title: THOMAS HURLEY, 62, A PACE COLLEGE AIDE
description: Thomas B. Hurley, supervisor of building and construction at Pace College Westchester, Pleasantville, N. Y., died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 205 St. Mark's Place, St. George, S. I.

title: Campaign Measure Hits Snag On Spending by Noncandidates
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Senate Commerce Committee has run into a serious constitu tional snag in drafting a bill aimed at limiting campaign spending by outsiders in behalf of political candidates.

title: Toots Shor's Closes Its Doors And It May Be for Last Time
description: Toots Shor's Restaurant, for years a nationally known wa tering spot of sports figures and theatrical personalities, closed its doors at 33 West 52d Street early this morning for what may be the last time.

title: Mutiny Trials of 60 In Trinidad Become Big Election Issue
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 1 (AP)Mutiny courts martial of 60 soldiers in this nation's tiny army have be come a major issue in elections to be held this year.

title: Ball Glitters, April Fool or Not
description: For the 1,100 guests who assembled in the Grand Ball room of the WaldorfAstoria, the evening seemed to have all the glitter of a diamond tiara. On April Fools' Day, however, things are not al ways what they seem.

title: The Screen: Five Shorts at Whitney
description: Film on Film, the Whit ney Museum's film program that opened yesterday, is a collection of five shorts, four of which might be described  very loosely  as love letters to movies. They are sophisticated, affectionate, and Just a bit arid, as an art tends to be when a pre occupation with its own forms becomes the substance of the art itself.

title: Competitive Rates Ready
description: Leading brokerage houses be gan announcing competitive commisssion schedules yester day in anticipation of Monday's deadline for the implementation of negotiated rates on certain large stock transactions.

title: Shop Talk
description: While it has become com monplace for fashion design ers to turn their talents to towels and bed linens, not many interior designers have. But David Hicks of London has, and his new line for J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., will be in Blooniingdale's seventh floor linens department early this month. Famed for his geometrics  he likes to think that he started the use of them in the United StatesMr. Hicks has created a number of them for sheet, pillow case and towel ensembles. But what will probably catch most eyes, especially at this time of year when everyone is sick of winter, is a floral that looks like an English garden in full bloom.

title: New Phase of Indochina Debate
description: News Analysis

title: RATES UP SHARPLY IN CREDIT MARKET,
description: Interest rates on corporate bonds took a goodsized step upward yesterday.

title: Wholesale Prices in March Continued Moderate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The rise in wholesale prices con tinued at a moderate rate in Marcha rise slower than in most of 1970the Labor De partment reported today.

title: STOCKS REGISTER A SLIGHT DECLINE
description: A sharp runup in the price of Canadian Pacific and firm ness in bank issues featured the stock market yesterday. The general market, mean while, continued to pick its way with great care in the opening session of the second quarter.

title: East Pakistanis Said to Adopt Guerrilla Tactics
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 1 Workers dig tunnels under main roads at night so they will collapse when soldiers in trucks move down them. Chil dren in trees and women hid den along roadways serve as lookouts and spies. Girls whit tle pointed sticks for pits where soldiers might walk. Young men practice ambushes, in many cases with clubs, stones and bows and arrows.

title: LOUIS CHRISTMAN
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 1 Louis Christman, founder of Christman, Inc., a leading furni ture store of this area, died Tuesday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he was Visiting. He was 83 years old and lived at 110 Leroy Avenue hers.

title: Jewish Women's Group Selects New President
description: DETROIT, April 1Mrs. Earl Marvin of Woodmere, L. I., was elected president of the National Council of Jew ish Women today as, the 100, 000member organization con cluded its biennial conven tion at the Detroit Hilton Hotel. Mrs. Marvin succeeds Mrs. Leonard Weiner of De troit.

title: 2 More Bodies Are Found; Canandaigua Fire Toll Is 7
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., April 1 (UPI)Workmen have recov ered two more bodies from the ruins of the Canandaigua Inn, bringing to seven the number of deaths attributed to a fire there last Monday. bringing to seven the number of deaths attributed to a fire there last Monday.

title: Chaparrals Gain Playoffs, Beating Rockets, 115109
description: DENVER, April 1 (AP)Don nie Freeman hit for 17 of his 33 points in the final quarter tonight, leading the Texas Chaparrals to a 115109 victory over the Denver Rockets in a game that determined the final playoff berth in the American Basketball Association's West Division.

title: Sharm el Sheik: A Focal Point of the Egyptian Israeli Dispute
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Israeli Occupied United Arab Republic The Red Sea waters at the point of Ras Nusrani, 15 miles north of here, are clear and deep. The far shoreline is the barren Saudi Arabian island of Tiran; on this side, two spiked old Britishmade cannon placed by the Egyptian Army point out across the strait.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yester day on moderate trading.

title: 2 Students to Attend Screening for Post Of Principal Here
description: The Board of Education has decided to permit two students to attend the screening of can didates for the job of principal of the Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn.

title: CITY AGENCY'S PAY UP BY $2.5MILLION
description: The city's Health and Hospi tals Corporation, which has a possible budget deficiency of $40million, has increased the total salaries for executives by $2.5million in the last nine months, Controller Abraham D. Beame reported yesterday.

title: Foe Recaptures Laos Post
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 (Reuters)  North Vietnamese forces launched a heavy coun terattack around the royal cap ital of Luang Prabang in north ern Laos and recaptured a stra tegic hilltop position, a De fense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 1, 1971

title: W. R. Grace & Co. Fills Top Management Posts
description: Directors of W. R. Grace & Co. yesterday elected J. Peter Grace, 57 years old, as chair man and chief executive officer end Felix E. Larkin, 61, as pres ident and to the new post of chief operating officer, effec tive May 10. Allen S. Rupley, 70, is retiring as board chair man but remains a director.

title: Charles, Trevino, Barber Lead Golf on 67's
description: GREENSBORO, N.C. April 1  Bob Charles, golf's No. 1 southpaw Lee Trevino, No. 1 on the 1970 moneywinning list and Miller Barber, golf's Mr. X, shared the lead at 67 today in the $190,000 Greater Greensboro open.

title: Advertising:
description: The V.F. Corporation has named Bozell & Jacobs to do the advertising for Itself and its member companies, which include Vanity Fair Mills, Berkshire International and H. D. Lee, all apparel makers.

title: Sunken UBoat Off Tampa May Carry Deadly Mercury
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 1Re ports that a German submarine, sunk near New Orleans during World War II, has drifted to within 30 miles of this port city have whetted the interest of ambitious fortune hunters, caused concern among some Government officials and raised questions of international law.

title: Rails for the Future
description: The abandonment of the SST could provide an opportunity to inaugurate a longterm transportation policy of great benefit to all Americans. The key clearly is neither faster air travel nor increased reliance on the automobile; the answer for efficient travel, particularly over short and mediumrange distances, is rapid mass transportation by rail.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 2, 1971

title: National Airlines Modifies Order for DC10 Transports
description: National Airlines, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had changed its order for 11 Mc Donnell Douglas DC10 trijet transport to include two Series 30 intercontinental versions for previously ordered domestic models.

title: PUBLIC JOBS BILL VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 Democrats pushed a public service jobs bill through the Senate today and proposed minimum wage increase in the House. Both actions represented the Democrats' efforts to write their own economic program.

title: U.N. SETS UP FUND FOR FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, April 1Secretary Gen eral Thant officially established a United Nations fund for drug abuse control here today and the United States promptly donated $1million.

title: Legal Steps Ordered in Athens On an Arrest Called Arbitrary
description: ATHENS, April 1Athens's chief prosecutor ordered crim inal proceedings today against the civilian or military offi cials who made an arrest that was branded arbitrary by an opponent of the militarydomi nated government.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: With oldcrop contracts dropping sharply, soybean fu tures came under heavy liquida tion on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The loss in the newcrop months was not as great.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS GALLEY RELEASED FROM STOCKADE
description: President Nixon yesterday ordered First Lieutenant Wil liam L. Calley Jr. released from the stockade at Fort Benning, Ga., and returned to his guar ters on the base while his mur der conviction is being re viewed.

title: Dissidence Unit Has Dossier on 14,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  A Department of Justice intel ligence unit that has replaced an Army Intelligence detach ment as the Government's main watchman of political dis sidence has compiled computer ized dossiers on nearly 14,000 Americans.

title: Schock's First N.H.L. Goal Ties Blues for Flyers, 11
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1 (UPI) Danny Schock scored his first goal in the National Hockey League to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 11 tie tonight with the St. Louis Blues.

title: Bridge: TrumpSupport Requirements Set Unrealistic Limitations
description: In the early years of con tract bridge, textbooks were in the habit of Iaying down requirements for trump sup port. This was unrealistic, be cause the number of trumps needed for a raise Varies inversely according to the probable length of the suit that is being supported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Sends Legislature 3 More WelfareReform Bills
description: ALBANY, April 1A reorgan ization of the state's welfare program moved closer to real ity today when Governor Rock efeller sent the Legislature three additional bills on the subject.

title: Advertising:
description: The Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Companies, which has four companies that have been served by three ad agen cies, has decided as a cost saving measure to centralize its advertising functions. The beneficiary of this move (and of some $2million in billings) is Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, which has a Washing ton office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I was glad to see Richard Shramko's proposal (letter Feb. 22) that a quality of life index (Q.L.I.) should be devel oped, in spite of a disparaging refer ence in Time as an engaging, if wist ful suggestion. While the day for a single quality index, comparable to the gross national product economic index is quite distant in the future, several public and private groups have been in the process of attempting to develop social indicators.

title: Mets Quit Sunny Florida, Carrying a Few Clouds
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1Gil Hodges left Flor ida today with his New York Mets healthy, Jerry Roos man's form questionable, a rookie named Charlie Wil liams on his pitching staff, 14 victories and 10 defeats end three exhibition games left against the Baltimore Orioles.

title: G.M. CUTS ELIGIBLES FOR ANNUAL BONUS
description: DETROIT, April 1 (AP)The eneral Motors Corporation has cut the number of its sal aried employes who will be eligible for bonuses this year by raising the annual earnings eligibility figure to $24,000, compared with $15,000 in 1969.

title: All Over Gets Reprieve Through $12,500 Gilt
description: It could have been the end for All Over, Edward Albee's latest play, after tomorrow night's performance, but an outright gift of $12,500 for operating expenses has saved it from extinction.

title: Spiraling Welfare Costs: No End Is in Sight Here
description: Twice each month, after welfare checks are mailed out, the welfare centers in the city are often so crowded with worried recipients who did not receive their checks that the doors to reception rooms have to be locked to keep others from getting in to complain.

title: New Giselle Turns To Original Music For Fresh Effects
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 1Peter Darrell's production of Giselle for Scottish The ater Ballet proves that original thought can still pay dividends, even with such an old classic. This is the company's first ven ture into the standard reper tory, and Mr. Darrell has ap plied the same dramatic logic and consistent characterization as in his own new works.

title: Colleges, High Schools Put Limit on Dribbling
description: The National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada yesterday established a playing rule for colleges and high schools that is intended to cut down on stalling tactics.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Rise
description: OTTAWA, April 1 (Canadian PressThe Government today auctioned $165million of new 91day Treasury bills at an av erage price of 99.219 and aver age yield of 3.16 per cent, com pared, with last week's 99.251 and 3.02 per cent. Today's $45 million of 182day bills brought 98.406 and 3.25 per cent.

title: TREASURY PLANS A NEW FINANCING
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The Treasury announced a new type of borrowing today  a $1.5million offering of three month certificates to overseas branches of United States banks.

title: 2 Georgians in House Shift To Opposition to the War
description: WASHINGTON, April 1A break appeared today in the once solid Southern flank in the House supporting the Viet nam war as two conservative Democrats from Georgia ani flounced their opposition to continuation of the fighting.

title: Books of The Times
description: Richard Harris has made a silk purse out of a banana peel. The nomination of a dim Florida jurist, G. Harrold Carswell, to the Supreme Court in January, 1970, and his rejection by the Senate 79 days later was the most ignominious fiasco, on the domes tic front, of President Nixon's first two years in office. As political slapstick, the story would almost write itself. Highlights: the initial puzzled hush at announcement of the nominee's name (Who?) is fol lowed by revelation of his 1948 statement that segregation of the races is proper and the only practical and correct way of life in our states and his flickering mem ory of his role as incorporator of a golf club seeking to avoid desegregation in 1956. Next, muddle and peevishness at the White House, with hasty consultation of The Federalist and the Constitution, bear fruit in a document known as the Saxbe letter, in which the President advises the Senate that advice and consent means it has the right of consent, only, to his nomination.

title: MRS. JAMES J. JOHNSTON
description: Mrs. Agnes Byrnes Johnston, the widow of James Joy John ston, the former Madison Square Garden boxing pro moter, died Wednesday in RooseveltHospital after a long illness. She was 82 years old. Her husband died in 1946.

title: Books of The Times
description: I nurse this odd sentimental hope that one of these days some school of writers Is going to come along and make great fic tional art out of some old fiveanddime form like the privateeye thriller, or the whodunit, or science fiction. The way Shakespeare elevated the traditional re venge tragedy when he wrote Hamlet. Something like that.

title: Army Reported Gaining
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 1 Troops from West Pakistan were reported on the of fensive today against pockets of resistance in at least nine East Pakistani cities and towns Thousands of civilians were re ported fleeing into the country side.

title: Colorado Forest Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A bill offered in the Senate today would add 142,230 acres of Colorado forest bland to the national forest preservation system. Senators Gordon Allott and Peter H. Dominick, Colorado Republicans, cosponsored the bill covering the Flat Tops area, composed of portions of the Routt and White River National forests.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 1 (AP)The White House announced today a $42million effort to promote jobs and help retrain unemployed scientists and technicians who are vic tims of defenseaerospace cut backs.

title: House Panel Backs Repeal Of Concentration Camp Act
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) A House Judiciary subcom mittee approved, 90, today a bill to repeal a 1950 law that allows the President, under cer tain circumstances, to place in concentration camps anyone suspected or subversion.

title: Week's U.S. War Toll: 58 Dead, 542 Wounded
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)The United States command reported to day that 58 Americans were killed in combat last week and 542 were wounded. It was the highest American death toll in a month and the Iargest number of wounded in six months.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SANTIAGO, ChileIn formulating foreign policy Washington must al ways separate two considerations: what is good for the inhabitants of the country in question and what is good for the United States. This duality lies at the heart of the approach to Chile's new Marxist Government.

title: Myth and Reality: Problems of Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Social issues are often shrouded in myth and miscon ??. As an example, for too long it was popularly believed that fathers of welfare families irresponsibly aban doned their wives and children to live carefree, devilmaycare lives financed by the public's largesse. But careful analyses by social scientists revealed that, in fact, ablebodied men on wel fare were often forced by the system to leave their families.

Shaffer of the Community Church of East Williston.

title: Flight of Doves':Dublin Background for Tale of 2 Orphans
description: "Flight of the Doves," which opened yesterday at the Loew's State 2, is a movie for kids. It is also a movie that parents are supposed to want to take kids to and this, I think, results in a genuine conflict of interest. On the one hand the film promotes an adventure-escape story that is adequately both terrifying and funny. But on the other hand it indulges in picturesque scenery for charm's sake, suffers adult sentimentality about little children gladly and, as if unsure about its fiction, interrupts it for various pointless entertainments.The worst of these is an ecumenical St. Patrick's Day production number, like something out of a 1940's B-musical, set in a park in Dublin. A lot of local talent appearsalong with Orientals, black Africans, tan Africans, continental European nationals and an Orthodox rabbi  and everybody dances a jig and shakes his arms and sings a song that goes, I swear, "You don't have to be Irish to be Irish." If you can value this, or even stomach it, then your soul is with the Horn & Hardart Less Work for Mother Children's Hour, and you are all by yourself a one-person generation gap.St. Patrick's Day, like the scenery, is mostly eyewash. But Dublin is in Ireland, and Ireland is where Finn and Derval Dove, young orphans with an inheritance that becomes a price upon their heads, have fled to escape a wicked stepfather and to find a kindly grandmother and a place they can call home.The stepfather gives chase, as do assorted cops. But the real danger is from a pursuing uncle, failed actor and half-master of disguise named Hawk Dove, a man of mixed impulses.The flight and chase are well-managed, except when we pause to sing and dance, the characters are generally complicated enough for interest and the balance between comedy and terror is sharp enough to establish a real and rather exciting tension. I could have done with less of Dorothy McGuire's Granny O'Flaherty and Helen Raye's Derval Dove (neither indomitable advanced maturity nor sweet little girlhood being my favorite ages of women), but the men are good, sometimes quite elaborately good.Jack Wild succeeds for me as Finn Dove because despite his determined professionalism he seems humanly to hate his part and to suggest a reservoir of surliness that redeems his casting as cute kid. I thinkat least I hopethat he is going to be a good actor.Ron Moody plays Hawk Dove, a virtuoso role, like a virtuoso, and so often does the film depend upon his ability to transform caricature into character that I cannot imagine its (relative) success without him. Ralph Nelson ("Charly," "Lilies of the Field") has never been one of my pantheon directors. But enough good things have happened in his movies, such as Candice Bergen's performance in last year's "Soldier Blue," and now, in quite different ways, Ron Moody's in "Flight of the Doves," that I should like this review to be a notice in his favor.
