description: Louis Armstrong, the jazz trumpeter and singer, was re ported in weakened condition yesterday at Beth Israel Hospi tal, where he has been under intensive care since March 15 for heart trouble. A hospital spokesman said the 70yearold performer spent a restless night Thursday, with increased re spiratory difficulty. Mr. Arm strong entered the hospital a few days after completing a comeback appearance at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel's Empire Room, his first engagement in more than a year.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended March 30:

title: Report on Japanese Steel Quota
description: TOKYO, April 2 (UPI)Jap anese steel makers have de cided to extend their voluntary quotas on steel exports to the United States for another two years, it was reported today.

title: Order in the Court
description: Spurred by the Chicago Seven trial and the current trial of the Black Panthers in New York, the Appellate Divisions for the First and Second Departments of the State Supreme Courtcovering twelve counties in and around the cityhave formulated a fair and reasonable series of special rules to assure order and decorum in the courts. The rules in themselves cannot prevent unruly behavior in present and future criminal or civil cases; but the specific standards can be effective and enforced because they serve as an early warning system.

title: DECISION BY NIXON ON CALLEY HAILED
description: President Nixon's order re leasing First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. from the stockade pending a review of his case continued to receive widespread public and private support yes terday.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs Running True to Form
description: The first round of the Na tonal Basketball Association playoffs are running true to form, All four divisional cham pions have either won or are leading their respective four ofsevengame series.

title: Italy Cites Other Reductions
description: ROME, April 2The Bank of Italy announced tonight that it would reduce its normal dis count rate from 5 to 5 per cent on Monday.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES FRAUD TO PLANT INDUSTRIES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Plant In dustries Inc., and its chief of ficer yesterday with violating antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Hint of Summer Stirs Fears in Hell's Angels' Neighbors
description: While the warm weather seeps into the grimy stones of East Third Street, neigh bors of the Hell's Angels wait with no joy behind drawn shades for the begin ning of another summer of roaring motorcycle engines and random violence.

title: Banning Germ Warfare
description: The Soviet Union's decision to accept a ban on biological weapons separate from a prohibition against chemical weapons has cleared the way for another agreement at the Geneva disarmament conference. The United States had previously taken a similar position.

title: Thant Authorizes Evacuation
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 (Reuters)  Secretary General Thant has authorized the evacuation of all United Nations personnel and their dependents from East Pakistan, a spokesman said today.

title: Shippers Call Pay Abuse A Peril to Their Survival
description: The head of the New York Shipping Association said yes terday that forthcoming con tract negotiations with the In ternational Longshoremen's As sociation would be an Opera tion Survival for the employ ers because of soaring labor costs connected with an earlier agreement to pay the dockers a guaranteed annual income.

title: MALAMOOD IS HEARD IN ROLE OF RODOLFO
description: Assuming the voice is pleas ing, it's an excellent prognosis when a singer new to a pro duction fits into it like a glove.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS EASIER IN LONDON
description: The striking British Ford workers' rejection of the latest pay offer and the British Steel Corporation's announcement of higher prices were reflected in a softening of prices on the London Stock Exchange yester day.

title: Gov. Wallace Sees Galley;
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 2  First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., now confined to a tiny apartment while his conviction for murder is appealed, spent his first day out of the Fort Benning stockade greeting a parade of visitors that included Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: PRICES INCREASE IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change finished slightly higher, yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Lawyer for Colombo Says a Tap On U.S. Phone Warned of Arrest
description: A lawyer for Joseph A. Co lombo Sr. told a United States magistrate yesterday that a tap on the Justice Department's telephone had warned his client of his impending arrest.

title: Noncommercial Radio Network to Open on May 3
description: A live, noncommercial radio network will begin operation May 3 with the hookup of 90 stations, including New York City's two outlets, WNYC and WNYCFM.

title: Margin Exemption Aids duPont Firm
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  The Federal Reserve Board granted a special exemption from its margin rules today to facilitate the rescue of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co.

title: KNAPP BODY WINS COURT'S SUPPORT
description: Subpoenas requiring 13 po lice officers to appear before the commission that is investi gating allegations of corruption in the Police Department were upheld yesterday by the Ap pellate Division of State Su preme Court.

title: BUSH UNIVERSAL LISTS A 1970 LOSS
description: The Bush Universal Corpora tion announced yesterday a net loss of $15,154,000 for 1970. In 1969, the company earned $1,646,000, equal to 66 cents share.

title: NEVADA TO CANCEL WELFARE SLASHES
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 2 (UMstate officials and at torneys for welfare recipients have signed an agreement all but ending Nevada's welfare conflict, which At times car lied into the streets of this gambling resort.

title: HEINZ R. GRAETZ, 67, WROTE ON VAN GOGH
description: Heinz R. Graetz, author and former Israeli shipping execu tive, died Thursday in Florence, Italy, at the age of 67.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: I remember their faces cleanly, from twelve years ago. Two kids, maybe ten or eleven years old, zipping by me, ascending a ramp inside Yankee Sta dium. One more ramp to go, winding up to the mezzanine, and the first exquisite glimpses of a patch of green field would be theirs.

title: Bridge: Declarer Holds Powerhouse But Winds Up With a Minus
description: To hold the hand of a lifetime and wind up with a minus score was the fate of almost all the South players on the diagramed deal. It was played at the Savoy Bridge Club in Los Angeles recently, and was reported by Edwin Kantar in the April issue of Popular Bridge.

title: Football Knee Injuries Laid to Cleats
description: JERICHO, L. I., April 2A change in the shoe worn by varsity high school football players as a means of curtail ing knee injuries was recom mended today in a report on a fouryear study of 61,000 youths throughout the state.

title: Antiques Regal House of Caramoor
description: Now is the time to make a tour of the house at Cara moor, the Northern West chester estate wellknown for its annual summer musical festivals.

title: SQUIRES TOP NETS IN OPENER, 113105
description: HAMPTON, Va., April 2  The Virginia Squires surged in the last four minutes tonight in the opener of their East Division semifinal round of the American Basketball Associa tion playoffs with the New York Nets and won, 113105.

title: Governor, in Interview, Hints New Budget Fight
description: ALBANY, April 2  Gov ernor Rockefeller conceded today that conservative Re publicans got their pound of flesh but he said that the battle over his budget was not ended.

title: Man In the News
description: TEL AVIV, April 2The Nixon Administration's move ment toward assuming the role of middleman in negotia tions between Egypt and Israel on reopening the Suez Canal has kept Walworth Barbour, the United States Ambassador here, even more busy than usual. But for the quiet, 62year old diplomat such occasions have become al most routine. He has headed the smoothworking United States embassy for nine and a half years. Neither in Israel nor in the United States is he a prominent public figure, and that is the way he wants it. In both countries, among the influential group ofolicy makers who claim his full at tention, he is a respected figure.

title: Man of Independence
description: It would be trite to call you a conservative; the word is far too bland and weak for your combination of total independ ence and complete firmness of decision. These words were employed by Duke University in 1965 in conferring a doctor ate of laws on Charles Albert Cannon, one of the nation's most powerful, most wealthy and most inconspicuous men.

title: U. S. Officials Hopeful
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 United States officials said to day they believed there was a high degree of probability that indirect negotiations would begin in the near future be tween Israel and the United Arab Republic on a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO. BAR NEGOTIATED. RATES
description: Howe, Barnes & Johnson, Inc., filed suit yesterday In Federal District Court in Chi cago to enjoin the, New York Stock Exchange from imple menting the Securities and Ex change Commission order to albolish fixed commission rates on stock transactions of more than $500,000.

title: Ocean Dumping, Limited
description: In the last seven years commercial fishing off the New YorkNew Jersey coast has dropped from 673 million pounds to 133 million, a decline of 80 per cent. Oyster production for the same period is off by 43 per cent. A major factor in these staggering losses is the sludge dumped offshore daily, as though the Atlantic were an infinite catchbasin for the wastes of man.

title: A New Science Studies Man in Life's Labyrinth
description: Is it significant that a man gets up in Brooklyn, gets on a train, stands up for 40 minutes, is crowded all the way and does this for 40 years?

title: 44 Horses Drop in Out of the Blue
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 2 Fortythree standardbreds from Australia and New Zealand landed at Kennedy Internation al Airport this morning, con cluding a world record airlift of horses. Actually, the flight, which began at Sydney, carried 44. One, a thoroughbred, was left at Oakland, Calif.dicate, headed by Alan Leavitt of New York and Hanover, Pa., was ready to spend $1.25mil lion for Albatross. I hear that 10 men will pay $125,000 each, one horseman whis pered. Another nooded in agreement. Yes, he said, I've heard the same figure. What's more, I've heard that Stanley Dander will be a member of the syndicate and that he will replace Harry Harvey [of Washington, Pa.] as the trainer driver of the great young horse.

title: Art: Callot, Great Stylist of All Time
description: Jacques Callot, who died In 1635 at the age of 43, was one of the greatest stylists who ever lived, and the col lection of his etchings  in cluding virtually the com plete list  at Associated American Artists, 663 Fifth Avenue at 52d Street, is a pure delight.

title: A Resistance Fighter Tells His Story
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 2 Santi Kamal was dressed in civilian clothes on Friday, March 26, when he saw several hundred West Pakistani soldiers arriving in trucks at Khulna, town of about 20,000 in the south of East Pakistan.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In this watereddown National Hockey League cam paign, which some observers have claimed is the most dreary they have had to cheer through, virtually every recordbreaker has had his critics contend, It's an expan sionleague record. But no one is taking credit away from Keith Magnuson. Not that they'd dare to, anyway.

title: Actual Tests Used To Prepare Pupils For Reading Exam
description: Pupils in at least two Brook lyn elementary schools were coached for the citywide read ing tests given here on Thurs day by being drilled on mate rial taken directly from the tests or based on them.

title: Orioles' Homers Rout Mets, 122
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 2  The Baltimore Orioles defeated the New York Mets, 122, to night in the first meeting of the two teams since Oct. 16, 1969, when the Mets won the fifth and final game of the World Series.

title: ANTHONY MACRO, 43, BRONX PROSECUTOR
description: Anthony V. Magro, Chief As sistant District Attorney of Bronx County since 1968, died Thursday of leukemia at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 43 years old and lived at 780 Grand Con course, the Bronx.

title: Canadian Reserves Down
description: OTTAWA, April 2 (Canadian Press)  Canada's foreignex change reserves edged down $5.6million in March to stand at $4,850,300,000 at the end of the month, the Finance Depart ment reported today.

title: Jan E. Van Horson Bride of Teacher
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., April 2Miss Jan Elizabeth Van Horson, who is with the adoption department of Cath olic Charities in New York, was married here this after noon to Edward Robert Tem ple, a mathematics teacher at New Hyde Park Memorial High School. The Rev. Paul A. Schweitzer performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church.

title: Washington Festival Lily White No More
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Linda Smythe, black and beautiful, and Belinda Carey, also black and beautiful, represent a new look for the capital's traditional rite of spring: the annual Cherry Blossom Festival, which opened Tuesday.

title: The Theater
description: Surprising as it seems, 1776 strikes as one of the most happily dramatic musi cals I have ever seen. To be sure, it can be objected that it suggests, for example, that Thomas Jefferson is overly concerned with sex, and that it is distressing to imply that the Declaration of Independ ence was in any way con nected with Jefferson's con nubial relationship.

title: Merger News
description: AMF, Inc., and the Head Ski Company, Inc., announced yes terday a plan of reorganization under which Head Ski would be merged into AMF.

title: Wicks Signs Contract With the Trail Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 2 (AP)Sidney Wicks, the all America forward from the University of California, Los Angeles, signed a fiveyear contract with the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association, the Blazers announced today.

title: BUDGET PACKAGE VOTED IN ALBANY; RELIEF CUT 10%
description: ALBANY, April 2After a night of exhausting and quar relsome debate, the Republican controlled Legislature today passed a $7.7billion budget that contains an increase in business and sales taxes and 10 per cent reductions in aid for many of the state's 1.6million welfare recipients.

title: Bach, Bartok, Xenakis
description: Stanislaw Skrowaczewsld's Ideas about Bach's D major Suite, which he conducted with the New York Philhar monic at the Thursday even ing concert, were an uneasy compromise between 19th century romanticism and 20thcentury musicology.

title: ANNE DONOGHUE
description: LOWELL, Mass., April 2 (AP) Anne K. Donoghue, woman's editor emeritus of The Lowell Sun, died today at Tewksbury Hospital in Tewksbury. She was 56 years old.

title: Woman's Peace Walk Is Over After 45 Days and 450 Miles
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Looking weary but smiling broadly, Mrs. Louise Bruyn walked up the white marble steps of the Capitol at noon today, ending a 450mile peace walk that she began 45 days ago in her home town of New ton, Mass.

title: OLIVARES DEFEATS CASTILLO FOR TITLE
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 2 (UPI)Ruben Olivares of Mexico regained the bantam weight championship tonight by pending out a unanimous 15 round decision over Chucho Castillo in their third meeting despite suffering a sixthround knockdown.

title: CITY SPURNS PLAN FOR LABOR PACTS
description: Blaming state budget cuts, Mayor. Lindsay rejected yester day the recommendations of a special impasse panel for set tlement of the contract disputes with the city's policemen, fire men and sanitation men.

title: ConsumerInstallment Credit Rose at Slow Pace in February
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Consumer installment credit expanded at the slow pace of $102million in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: ABDELKADER CHABOU OF ALGERIAN ARMY
description: ALGIERS, April 2Col. Ab delkader Chabou, general sec retary of the Algerian Defense Ministry, and considered Al geria's second most powerful personality, was killed yester day afternoon in a helicopter crash near Algiers as he re turned from an inspection tour to Eastern Algeria. He was 46 years old.

title: MICHIGAN PRINCIPAL TARRED, FEATHERED
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., April 2 (UPI)A white high school principal who has been active in promoting racial harmony has been tarred and feathered by a group of men who wore Ku Klux Klantype hoods and threatened him with shotguns.

title: Marijuana Is Dangerous
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.My discussion proceeds from a particular, point of view (or bias, if you wish)namely, that of, a psychopharmacologist over 30 years of age, who has learned trent experience that subjective effects of drugschanges in feelings and per ceptions reported verbally by the subjectdo not always correspond to the observable behavior manifested by the subject.

title: Publishers Battle F.C.C. on Owning RadioTV Outlets
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)The American Newspa per Publishers Association asked the Federal Communica tions Commission today to drop a plan to prohibit newspapers from owning television and ra dio stations and community an tenna television systems.

title: STOCKS MANAGE TOEDGEHIGHER
description: The snoozing bull market be stirred itself yesterday as sev oral stock groups moved higher in rather dynamic fashion. This followed six straight sessions of what one Wall Street analyst described as an almost mo tionless market.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Having read your March 13 editorial March We Must Not and having watched on television again this year the St. Patrick's Day Parade on Fifth Avenue, I wish to register my strong support of this and other peaceful, wellregulated, ethnic parades.

title: Downtown Art Scene: Celebrities and Horses
description: Within the last few years artists such as Malcolm Morley, Richard Estes, Chuck Close and others have am bitiously employed the photo graph as a prominent source of their painting. Their meth od is simple enough. They usually project the photo graphic image onto the can vas, trace the outstanding contours and details and then paint over the duplica tion. The exceptionally sharp focus of their resultant pic torial image has led some to define, if erroneously, these paintings as super real.

title: Campo's Entry Favored In Gotham Stakes Today
description: The Gotham Stakes has at tracted eight contestants for its 19th running today at Aque duct. Good Behaving, owned by Neil Hellman, and Charles Peti grew's Johnny West, an entry trained by Johnny Campo, is expected to be favored in the field, which is relatively large because of the withdrawal of the injured Hoist the Flag.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTMORELAND SAYS HE HARBORS NO GUILT
description: HOUSTON, April 2 (AP) The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who was the commander of Ameri can troops In Vietnam at the time of the Mylai slayings, said here today that he was sur prised at the outcry following the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley.

title: Boston Edison Is Struck
description: BOSTON, April 2 (AP)About 2,250 production and mainte nance workers of the Boston Edison Company, serving the metropolitan area, went on strike today, but the company said management personnel maintained normal service. Lo cal 360 of the Utility Workers of America struck after the membership voted down the company's latest contract pro posal.

title: WILLIAM H. SPILGER
description: HOPATCONG, N.J., April 2 William H. Spilger, a retired member of the New York Cot ton Exchange, who in his youth was a lightweight prizefighter, died yesterday in a Dover nurs ing home. He was 83 years old and lived at 66 West River Styx Road.

title: DEFENSE ASSAILS CRIMMINS WITNESS
description: The prosecution witness who testified Thursday that Mrs. Alice Crimmins had once told him that she killed her daugh ter and agreed to the death of her son was pictured by the defense yesterday as a jealous, disreputable man who planned and schemed for years to convict her in the court room.

title: Texas Oil Allowable Is Up
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 (AP) Texas's average calendar day oil allowable is 3,796,623 bar rels, an increase of 32,975 from March 15, the Railroad Commission reported today.

title: British Ford Workers Vote 21 to End Strike
description: LONDON, April 2A ballot of the Ford Motor Company's 50,000 workers produced a majority tonight of more than 2 to 1 to end the nineweek strike and to accept the com pany's offer of a twoyear contract. The company hopes that work can be resumed Monday at most of the 22 Ford plants.

title: Nixon Stays California Welfare Cutoff
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 2  Following a long meeting with Gov. Ronald Reagan, Pres ident Nixon agreed today to grant California another tem porary reprieve from Federal threats to cut off some $684 million in Government welfare contributions.

title: Large Rings at Chicago Show Give Big Dogs Room to Gait
description: CHICAGO, April 2  The largest indoor dog show to be held in America will get under way tomorrow in the Inter national Amphitheatre at the Union Stockyards. There are 3,649 dogs listed to compete in the twoday International Ken nel Club of Chicago fixture. Mrs. W. P. Wear of Cecilton, Md., is expected to name her best in show about 7 P.M., New York Time, on Sunday.

title: Auto Show Opening Amid Optimism and Dissent
description: The International Automo bile Show will open today at the Coliseum for a nineday run ending April 11.

title: Screen:
description: CHANGES, written, directed and pro duced by Gerard Damlano; distributed by Cinex International Film Distribu tors, Inc. At the World Theater, 49th Street east of Seventh Avenue. Run ning time: 81 minutes. (This picture has been given the selfapplied rating of X'no one under 21 admitted.

title: Additional Gains Shown For NewIssues Market
description: The newissue marketthat corner of the overthecounter market where shares of com panies selling their stock pub licly for the first time are traded  tacked on additional gains this week in heavy deal ings.

title: LELAND HAYWARD EULOGIZED HERE
description: More than 600 people, in cluding some of the country's bestknown theatrical personal ities, attended a memorial serv ice yesterday for Leland Hay ward, the talent agent and producer who died March 18 at the age of 68.

title: Johnny Johnson Author To Assist in Its Revival
description: Paul Green, the 77yearold author of Johnny Johnson, has been called in from his home in North Carolina to help prepare the show for its re vival at the Edison Theater on April 27. The propeace play with music has a score by Kurt Weill. Lotte Lenya, the com poser's widow, is assisting in mounting the production.

title: Pakistan Warns India
description: KARACHI, April 2Pakistan today warned India that seri ous consequences could result from Indian actions that Pakis tan regarded as grave interfer ence in her internal affairs.

title: Bauhaus Constructives on View Here
description: The Bauhaus, which Wal ter Gropius founded in Wei mar, Germany, in 1919, is wellknown for its radical contributions to virtually all of the applied arts as well as to painting, sculpture and graphic art.

title: Antiwar Editor Plans Trip To Vietnam on Mail Seizure
description: The editor of an antiwar newspaper for servicemen said yesterday that, he would go to Vietnam to investigate the ef fect of an Army directive con fiscating antiwar literature ad dressed to soldiers in Vietnam.

title: KIRK AND HIS GROUP GIVE PROGRAMS HERE
description: Rahsaan Roland Kirk this weekend joined the small but growing group of jazzmen who have brought their music to the rockoriented audiences of Fill more East. Mr. Kirk and his sixman Vibration Society are, appearing here through tonight, sandwiched between Tower of Power, a jazzrock group, and Santana, a Latinrock group.

title: PETRAGLIA LEADING IN AKRON BOWLING
description: AKRON, Ohio. April 2 (UPI) Johnny Petraglia of Brooklyn averaged more than 213 throughout the 48 qualifying games in the $100,000 Tourna ment of Champions and held the lead tonight going into to morrow's finals.

title: Mrs. Barbara Morgan, 83, Dies; A Specialist in Mental Testing
description: NORFOLK, Conn., April 2 Mrs. Barbara Spofford Morgan, an author and educator, died yesterday in Canaan. The widow of Shepard Morgan, a former vice president of the Chase National Bank, she was 83 years old and lived at Mountain Road.

title: F.D.R. Drive Detours Set
description: Traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be diverted to the service roads in the area between 20th and 34th Streets from 3 A.M. to 12 noon tomor row, the Traffic Department said yesterday. The area will be closed because of work by the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Soviet Lists Plans to Expand Iron and Steel Industry
description: MOSCOW, April 2The So viet Union today unveiled de tails of its program of iron end steel expansion over the next five years, indicating continued heavy investment in the na tion's basic industries.

title: Red Cross Aid Barred
description: GENEVA, April 2The Inter national Committee of the Red Cross has been refused authori zation by the Pakistani Gov ernment to send a relief team with eight tons of medical and other supplies to East Pakistan, a spokesman said today.

title: Ford Tie in Japan
description: Merger News

title: Despite the Hurdles, Schools Are Attracting More Organ Students
description: When you're 10 and you first start on the pipe organ you get a feeling of fun and power, that hooks you for life, said Philip, R. Maue, a lean, intense 23yearold from Shamokin, Pa.

title: School Integration Is Termed Harmful To Blacks in South
description: A leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence told a rally at City Hall Park yesterday that black peo ple in the South would be better off with school segre gation.

title: Classes That Meet A Desperate Need
description: It's like any other nursery school, only quieter. Most of the children have trouble speaking. Few of them can walk easily. Their mothers, some burdened with younger children, bring them every morning, so they can be with one another, so they can learn.

title: Ingenuity Was Ingredient in Adapting Cookies for Passover
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J.  When the David Brous family and 16 or so relatives gather at the Seder table for the first night of Passover on Fri day evening, they will wel come the holiday with a din ner that makes no departure from timehonored tradition until dessert.

title: Paul Abbott, an Executive With McGrawHill, Dead
description: NAPLES, Fla., April 2Paul Abbott of Southampton, L. a retired vice president of Mc GrawHill, Inc., the publishing concern, died here yesterday after a short illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Clash Near Kompong Cham
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 2 (AP)The high command said today that Cambodian troops killed seven enemy sol diers in a fivehour clash about 49 miles northeast of the capital. Two Cambodians were reported killed and 26 wounded in the action, across the Mekong River from the city of Kompong Cham.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, April 2 (Reuters)The Dutch bank rate was cut today from 6 to 5 per cent effec tive Monday, the Dutch central bank said today.

title: ALBERT N. JACKSON, DALLAS NEWS AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) Albert N. Jackson, vice chair man of the Times Herald Print ing Company, publisher of The Dallas Times Herald, died yes terday in his hotel room appar ently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ROUSE UNIT SPLIT ON MEDICARE CUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 major fight loomed today with in the House Ways and Means Committee over planned cut backs in Medicare benefits.

title: NASA and Apollo 11 Crew Get Explorers Club Honors
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Apollo 11 astronauts were among those honored by the Explorers Club last night at a dinner attended by 1,200 per sons at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Personality Choice in $119,600 Campbell Today
description: Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Per sonality, last year's 3yearold champion who is shooting for handicap honors this season, will face 13 rivals at Bowie Race Course in the $119,600 John B. Campbell today, one of the top races offered on the national program.

title: Ensemble Playing Of Zelenka Quintet Earns Admiration
description: The Zelenka Quintet, a group of young woodwind players, gave an admirable display of ensemble musicianship on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Tax Lien Forced Toots Shor's to Close
description: Toots Shor, the restaurateur, closed the doors of his West 52d Street establishment early yesterday when he learned that the Internal Revenue Service had obtained a tax lien for $49,000 in unpaid income taxes.

title: British Reserves Rise to Approach Records, but Pound Shows Drop
description: LONDON, April 2  A huge $800million inflow of foreign exchange in March provided Britain, with funds to repay overseas debts and add $122 million to her foreignexchange reserves besides.

title: INSURERS TO MEET DIESEL MONDAY
description: HARTFORD, April 2  Eight insurance industry leaders will meet with the new Republican Governor of Connecticut, Thomas J. Meskill, on Monday to voice a collective protest to the Governor's plan to impose a 7 per cent sales tax on all insurance sold in the state, it was disclosed today.

title: Nixon Rejects Proposal to Ease Tariffs on East European Goods
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 President Nixon has considered and rejected a proposal for lower United States tariffs aimed at expanding trade with the countries of Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union.

title: EGG TOSSERS MAR TOUR BY LINDSAY
description: For Mayor Lindsay, yester day was something like the best of days and something like the worst. On West 44th Street, seven young men were announcing the opening of Lindsay for President head quarters in seven cities; on East 114th Street, two young men were throwing eggs and a bottle at him.

title: Knicks Resting in a Maze Of Playoff Ifs and Puts
description: Amid schedule confusion reminiscent of the National Basketball Association's young er, bush league days, the New York Knicks rested on their laurels yesterday and re ceived an encouraging report on their wounded captain, Wil lis Reed.

title: ARMY WRESTLERS GAIN IN EASTERNS
description: A strong United States Army team, hoping to end the New York Athletic Club's 13year reign, as champion, started im pressively in the Eastern Ama teur Athletic Union wrestling, championships at the N.Y.A.C. last night.

title: Burroughs and Honeywell Plan to Lay Off Workers
description: The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday plans to lay off 700 workers at its Plymouth, Mich., plant. The lay offs will take place over the next two months as the plant switches from the assembly of electromechanical products to the assembly of purely electri cal products. Last December the company reduced the work force by 500.

title: TIME INC. TO PERMIT PACT CANCELLATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) Time Inc. and a subsidiary have agreed to give magazine subscription purchasers three days in which to cancel con tracts sold by doortodoor salesmen.

title: Jobless Rate Rises Again; March Level Reaches 6%
description: WASHINGTON, April 2The unemployment rate rose in March, after two months of de cline, and again reached the level of 6 per cent, the Labor Department said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: The hoard of the King Resources Company yes terday elected C. Harrison Cooper as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Cooper has been vice president of the King Resources Western division in Denver since 1968. The board also announced further steps in its attempts to reduce operating expenses through additional personnel reductions and reorganization of the top management group.

title: William A. Vanstory, Aide With Bell Telephone Co.
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., April 2 William A. Vanstory, a re tired vice president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Com pany, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 66 years old and lived at 8 Worth ington Avenue.

title: Repertory Runs Extended
description: The Lincoln Center Repertory Theater Company, under the direction of Jules Irving, has extended the runs of its cur rent offerings. Arthur Miller's An Enemy of the People, which had been originally scheduled to end its limited run at the Vivian Beaumont Thea ter April 18, will now play through April 24. Scenes From American Life, by A, R. Gur ney Jr., will close at the Forum on April 18 instead of April 10.

title: Talk With Robert Lowell

title: Young Lawyer Who Leads Franco Opposition in Seville Is Jailed
description: MADRID, April 3I have to go on denouncing the re gime. They can put me in jail. If the day comes that they have to put 200 members of the bourgeoisie in jail the regime will fall,

description: A little over three months ago, Massachusetts inaugu rated the nation's first no fault automobile insurance program in an effort to solve the problems that plague the present system  soaring rates, long court delays, in equitable settlements and the small return motorists get from their premium dollar in the form of claims payments.

title: A MAN AND HIS HOMES
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  Every red blooded Southern boy dreams of grow ing up and owning a house with big columns out front, Richard H. Jenrette said in his soft North Carolina accent as he stood in the shadows of the mas sive columns of his estate, Edgewater.

description: ATLANTA, April 3 (UPI) Hank Aaron and Orlando Ce peda hit homers today to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 62 vic tory over the Washington Sen ators.

title: LIMITS ON R.O.T.C. VOTED IN PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON. N.J., April 3 Princeton University under graduates voted in favor of re taining the three Reserve Of ficer Training Corps programs at the school as a noncredit activity, but it recommended conditions that the military services may find unacceptable.

title: Bernard P. Lampert Dead; Lawyer, Labor Arbitrator
description: Bernard P. Lampert, a lawyer and labor arbitrator, died yes terday of a heart attack at his home, 20911 Whitehall Ter race, Queens Village, Queens. His age was 57.

title: Letter to the Editor 20  No Title
description: The Iris Love controversy fasci nates me. I have often been tempted to take a lesserknown painting by Jackson Pollock or some wellknown artist and replace the name with Fred X. How many experts would still call the work brilliant, extraordinary, showing a dynamic plasticity of..."? Do.critics give their ayes of artistic approval in response to a name?

title: Mrs. Cummin Is Wed
description: RYE, N. Y., April 3Mrs. Leila Reeve Bright Cummin and Bruce K. Bernann were married here this morning in the chapel of the Rye Presby terian Church. The Rev. Don ald W. Poole performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Rosemont, Pa., and Little Cranberry Is land, Me. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bernann of Fort Lau derdale, Fla., are the bride. groom's parents. Mr. Bernann, a graduate of Colgate Uni versity, is with the brokerage firm of Dean Witter & Co. in New York. Previous mar riages of the couple ended in divorce.

title: Halina Tappin Plans Marriage In Winter to Peter Hapworth
description: BOSTON, April 3  Miss Halina Huntington Tappin and Peter Hapworth plan to be married next December in Washington.

title: Miss VostersSpahr Gain Squash Racquets Semifinal
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 3 Gretchen Vosters of the Uni versity of Delaware and Kit Spahr of Haverford, Pa., reached the semifinal round in defense of their United States mixed doubles squash racquets championship by defeating Anne Clement of Haverford, and William Davison of Phila delphia, 1511, 157, 15.5 today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Burch Is Trainer of Year
description: Elliott Burch was named win ner of the Walter Haight memo rial award yesterday by the National Turf Writers Associa tion as the trainer of the year. Burch, who handled Fort Marcy last season, will receive his trophy at the association's an nual dinner at Louisville, Ky., on April 29.

description: BOSTON, April 3Yale and Boston University, opened their crew seasons on the Charles River today, and the Ells cap tured the varsity heavyweight race by eighttenths of a second.

Boshell of Birmingham, Ala., decided it was time to retire the blackandrust eightpounder and the minpin became strictly a house pet.

The police said the Mayor knew before the raid started that his 17yearold son, John, was among It group of young people suspected of pos sessing drugs.

description: WASHINGTON, April 3As Clyde McPherson took the lead on the second leg of a relay race in the American Univer sity Relays today, a voice piped over the public address system, Who's that team in brown?

description: Three players have been named cowinners of the Pro fessional Bowlers Associa tion's Steve Nagy Sportsman ship Award for 1970. They are Johnny Guenther of Seat tle, Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Calif., and Dick Ritger of Hartford, Wis., who shared the votes of the touring pros.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONThe Loyal Order of Moose is not ex actly an exclusive organiza tion, but it does limit mem bership in its 2,000 lodges to white adult Caucasian males who, if married, are married to white Caucasians, and are of good moral character, mentally normal and ex press a belief in a supreme being.

title: Nuns at Denver Parley Prepare For Active Role on Social Issues
description: DENVER, April 3 A fast growing national organization of Roman Catholic nuns has made it clear that sisters will no longer accept a passive role in their church.

title: Israel: The Fight Is Onfor Hotel Rooms
description: JERUSALEMThey did not want to admit it, but the members of the tour group felt apprehensive as they stepped into the aircondi tioned bus in Tel Avlv early one recent morning, setting off on a oneday ex cursion to the Golan Heightsthe far outpost of Israeli jurisdiction 120 miles to the northeast. They were, after all, about to venture into a territory that is often shaded on newspaper maps to show that it was seized from Syria dur ing the SixDay War, a plot of earth sometimes also marked with symbolic explosions to indicate a flashpoint (as the politicians say) where World War III might erupt.

title: RollsRoyce (the Car) Will Endure
description: LONDON  Though tar nished by bankruptcy, the name of Rolls  Royce will probably endure, as it has for decades, as a stock su perlative for excellence in the world's automotive vo cabulary.

title: Lindsay's Long Shot
description: A fiveman board of directors, appointed by Mayor Lindsay and headed by Howard J. Samuels, holds the reins of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation. None of the members receives a salary for being a director, but Samuels gets $45,000 a year as president of the corporation.

title: 2 Bet Outlets Set to Open; 17 to Follow
YALE PARLEY HELD ON ANTIWAR ADS
description: NEW HAVEN, April 3Two hundred advertising people from New York gathered at Yale University today to dis cuss strategy on unselling the war in Indochina to the American people.

description: CHARLESTON, S. C., April (UPI)The Citadel has named George Hill, coach at the United States Coast Guard Academy, as basketball coach.

description: PITTSBURGH, April 3A collie, Ch. Impromptu Burnt Norton, owned by Jean Cullen, was chosen best today at the Western Pennsylvania Kennel Association show.

title: Daley Confident of a 5thTerm Victory Tuesday
description: CHICAGO, April 3The pot holes in the cramped streets of the 25th Ward were filled with fresh asphalt today and the al leys back of them were clear of trash. From the windows of far more than half of the aging bungalows and narrow two story twoflats jammed to gether along the streets, the solemn visage of Mayor Richard J. Daley was framed.

title: Double Amputee Regains License to Pilot a Plane
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., April 3 (AP)  Archer Crittenden swung out from behind the controls of his blue and white plane at the Chesapeake Portsmouth Airport with a smile.

title: Reader's Report
description: College humor may not yet be dead (as was recently al leged in the press), but it's pretty sick. One of these nine stories received the 1969 Paris Review Humor Award, and two were first published in a college literary magazine. Mr. Spike's modus operandi is to juxtapose the trite and the grotesque, leading sometimes to a hollow laugh, and sometimes nowhere at all. Bits of sciencefiction, cinema stencils, erotic reveries are rolled up into one nihilistic ball of wax. Some of the inter ludes are vivid enough to make one hope that the author will someday come forth with just enough structure to hold his impressions together.

title: The Spaniards came, saw, conquered and were conquered
description: Those Americans who date our his tory from the founding of the English speaking Jamestown colony I would put the figure at roughly 200 million are largely unaware of the equally commanding, parallel history of the Spanish in the nation.

title: Texas Wins Parade Contest
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) Texas won first place today in the annual Cherry Blossom parade contest for state floats. Georgia was the runnerup and Guam was third. In the judging for high school bands of 75 or more members, Altoona, Pa., won top honors. First place in the contest for smaller high school bands went to Abbe ville S. C.

title: Who Could Conceive of This? Asks Army Doctor at Khesanh
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 20  The 29yearold Army doctor, who has been treating wounded Americans here for 49 days, recalled with dread the time when a G.I. asked him a question.

title: HAWAII EXPECTED TO EASE SEX LAWS
description: HONOLULU, April 3  The missionaries who once put the lithesome brown girls into muu muus would be scandalized, but one day soon all forms of sex performed privately between consenting adults are expected to be legal in this state, except for prostitution.

title: Althea Hunt, 80, Taught Arts at William and Mary
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 3Althea Hunt, professor em eritus of fine arts of the Col lege of Wiliam and Mary, who founded the undergraduate theater and directed it from 1926 to 1957 died Thursday. She was 80 years old.

title: Why the High Cost of Auto
description: Frank Cunningham is beautiful guy, the Insurance Company of North America says in its new, widely dis cussed advertising campaign. But insuring him isn't our cup of tea,

title: MORE REFUGEES FLEEING PAKISTAN Hundreds of Families Cross From East Into India
description: NEW DELHI, April 3  Per the first time since serious fighting broke out in East Pak istan late last week, substantial numbers of refugees were re ported today to be crossing the border into Indian territory.

title: Thomas Block, Miss Fielding Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Fielding of New York, East Hampton, L. I. and Deauville, France, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Francoise E. Fielding to Thomas Roger Block, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Block of New York and Deal, N. J.

title: Teacher to Wed Mary Lee Block
description: CINCINNATI, April 3  Miss Mary Lee Block, a grad uate of the University of Cincinnati, and John L. Landsman, an assistant pro fessor at Colby College in Waterville, Me., plan to be married here Oct. 2.

title: Brazilians Battle Guerrillas
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Apr, 3 (UPI)Brazilian troops battled leftwing guerrillas in the Rio de Janeiro area today. One army officer and a guerrilla were killed, reliable military sources said.

title: Movies
description: I NEVER SANG FOR MY FATHER was no sad song for Gilbert Cates and Columbia Pictures. So now the producerdirector has signed with the company to do two more films: The Killing Zone, based on the novel by William Crawford Woods, and Jimmy Shine, an adaptation of the Murray Schisgal play that brought Dustin Hoffman to Broadway a couple of seasons ago.

title: Margaret Murchison Married Here to Thomas Ryder Rudel
description: Miss Margaret Murchison and Thomas Ryder Rudel, both of. New York, were mar ried yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presby terian Church by the Rev. Dr. Adam Weir Craig.

title: Corporations, Soviet Style
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev's warm endorsement of production associations at the current Soviet Communist party con gress suggests that a long Moscow debate may finally have been resolved. A production association in the Soviet Union is comparable to a large or mediumsize corporation in this country. It may embrace a group of geographically separate plantsfor example, an automo bile assembly factory and various parts suppliersas well as specialized marketing, purchasing, research and other personnel, all under one central direction. Another such association may put under one command a number of factories, all producing the same commodity, say, shoes or dishes.

title: CLASH AT TEACHIN UPSETS HARVARD
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 3 Since the disruption of a pro war teachin on March 26, Har vard University administrators have been meeting almost con tinuously with students to ex press their concern over the need to protect free speech.

title: Senior at Yeshiva College Wins Lehman Fellowship
description: Aaron M. Siegel, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Norman Siegel of 1839 Ocean Parkway, Brook lyn, has been awarded a Her bert H. Lehman Graduate Fel lowship in Social Sciences and Public and International Af fairs.

title: Salmaggi Is Trying a Comeback
description: Alfredo Salmaggi, the Brooklyn apostle of dollar opera, the man who put opera into Ebbets Field, the Polo Grounds and Yankee Sta dium, the first impresario in the United States to intro duce elephants and camels into operaAlfredo Salmaggi wants to make a comeback.

title: Japan Makes Her Mark
description: There is no doubt in the minds of importers of Jap anese automobiles that 1971 will be another record year.

title: What every parent needs to know a out movies (and isn't told)
description: WE'RE a family of movie nuts. Like many Ameri cans who grew up in the forties, our fantasy life is popu lated by Humphrey Bogart and Ava Gardner. When we read his tory we see Errol Flynn and Bette Davis. And when we want to take our children out for a treat the first thing we think of is a movie.

title: Smokers Segregated On United Jet Flight
description: CLEVELAND, April 3 (UPI) A United Air Lines jet took off for Miami today with smoking passengers segre gated from nonsmokers.

title: Cambodia Reports Attack
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 3 (Agence FrancePresse) Enemy forces attacked a Cam bodian Army fuel depot 9 miles north of Pnompenh last night the high command announced today.

title: Twin Sons for Schulmans
description: Twin sons were born March 25 at Lenox Hill Hos pital to Mr. and Mrs. Steven G. Schulman of Flushing, Queens. Mrs. Schulman is the former Miss Carol Ruth Blitzer of Bayside, Queens. Her husband is a partner with his father, Jacob S. Schul man, in the New York law firm of Schulman & Schul man. The children have been named Jeremy Leon and Jonathan Seth.

title: Rep. Hamilton Fish Jr. Remarries
description: Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of Millbrook, N.Y., and Mrs. Billy Laster Cline, also of Millbrook, were mar ried yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Broader Medicare Urged By U.S. Advisory Council
description: WASHINGTON, April 3A Federal advisory council pro posed today that Medicare be expanded to cover partial pay ment of prescription drugs for the nonhospitalized elderly.

title: Jersey Approves 6.3% Rise In Rates for Auto Insurance
description: TRENTON, April 3  The State Insurance Department has approved increases in auto mobile insurance rate's averag ing 6.3 per cent for half of New Jersey's drivers.

title: Swiss Teetotalers Protest Ald to Malagasy for Wine
description: GENEVA, April 3The Pres idents of Switzerland's national and local antialcohol societies have protested against a Swiss technical assistance grant of $175,000 to aid the Malagasy Republic's developing wine in dustry.

title: Bill Aids 27,000 Indians
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) About 27,000 Indians on state reservations in Maine, Connecticut, Rhode Island New York, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia would be eligible for Federal aid under a bill entered in the Senate Thursday. These Indians have been denied the bene fits of many Federal programs because, as a result of an his toric accident, they do not inhabit federally recognized tribes within the definition of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, said Senator Edmund S. Mus kie, Democrat of Maine, co sponsor of the bill.

title: The Black Mafia Moves Into the Numbers Racket
description: THE numbers racket is Harlem's most flourishing enterprise. Estimates which at first shock, but which seem valid on closer ex amination, hold that some 60 per cent of the area's economic life de pends on the cash flow from num bers. Harlem businesses for genera tions have been bankrolled by the cash of numbers operators. Bars, res taurants, corner groceries, apartment housesname the business and in Harlem those who know will tell you that they have been started, or in bad times saved from bankruptcy, by the money of the numbers man.

title: 115,000 Jobs for Students Are Federal Summer Goal
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3 (UPI)The Western White House has announced that 115,000 students, at least 62,000 classified as needy, will be hired by the Federal Govern ment for summer jobs.

title: MENEFEEPHILLIPS, FLUTIST, IN RECITAL
description: Katherine MenefeePhillips, whose flute playing is as at tractively distinctive as her name, made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night. The artist is no novice, however; she arrived with substantial list of performance credentials, and carried off a challenging program with con fident aplomb.

title: National Notes
description: The Navy has long had a spe cial reputation within the black community: A Negro could See the World, all right, but chances were it would be a steward's eyeview. Last week the Navy denied the specifics of that charge but granted the underly ing premiseand promised to change its ways.

title: Officials at Fort Benning Silent On New Calley Move by Nixon
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 3 While First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. settled into the clois tered routine of his semiseques tered life, United States Army officials here at Fort Benning remained silent today on Presi dent Nixon's decision to make a final review of the Lieuten ant's courtmartial conviction for murder.

title: Movies
description: THERE'S a brand new movie house in town. It stands on Madison Avenue between 74th and 75th Streets, and looks exactly like the Whitney Mu seum of American Art. As a matter of fact, it is the Whit ney Museum of American Art, except that these days, in stead of the museum pack ing them in with its art ex hibitions (something that, alas, very seldom happens), the public is pouring in and making a beeline for the mu seum's second floor where the New American Filmmak ers Series is presenting avantgarde films of extra ordinary impact and origi nathy. Clearly, the $1 mu seum entrance fee, which also includes admission to the film showings, has be come the hottest (and cheap movie ticket in town.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITER:

title: Arthur Levines Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Levine of Woodmere, L. I., last Friday, at Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Levine is the former Hiss Marilynn Marshall of Law rence, L. I. Her husband is president of Weis, Voisin Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock exchange. The child, the couple's third, has been named Alex Marshall.

title: Maria Franco Plans June 19 Bridal
description: WASHINGTON April 3  Mr. and Mrs. Ernesto Franco Holguin have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Maria Victoria Wal bridge Franco, to Charles Lee Granquist Jr., son of Mr.and Mrs. Granquist of North Had ley, Mass.

title: MOUND STRENGTH HOUK'S TOP ASSET
description: As the Yankees prepared to leave Florida last week, a club Secretary watching from, the motel lobby asked a friend Should get on the bus and say, I want a pennant this year?

title: Who Put Rhythm In Logarhythms?
description: THE Massachusetts Insti tute of Technology wants to have the best of both worlds, mean ing science and the humani ties. One of its moves in this direction has been the devel opment of its music depart ment, an unexpected emphasis at a school renowned for its training of engineers and sci entists. To show how far it has succeeded, it is giving three concerts in New York this spring. Last Tuesday its glee club was scheduled to pre sent Haydn's The Seasons in Tully Hall. On April 19, David Epstein will conduct the M.I.T. Symphony in Car negie Hall, and on May 11 there will be chamber music in Carnegie Recital Hall. The last two programs will in clude compositions by mem bers of the faculty, Epstein, John Harbison and Gregory Tucker.

title: 2 Policemen Slain In Coast Ambush After False Alarm
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April (UPI)  Two policemen were ambushed and killed by shot gun blasts last night when they responded to a report of a burglary that turned out to be false.

title: Miss Barbara Wile Prospective Bride
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 3Mr. and Mrs. Julius Wile have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Barbara M. Wile, to Paul K. Schwarz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schwarz. Both fami lies are of Scarsdale. A June wedding is planned.

title: Art Mailbag
description: Hilton Kramer's review was not only a condemnation of those lesser known artists in the Whistler circle of friends but also of the research which brought them to light. I can not argue with Kramer's opin ion; I question his ideas on the researching of uncommon subject matter. He stated that this exhibition was an exam ple of research divorced from esthetic intuition and tests of sensibilitya demonstra tion of academic folly. If we, as students of arta group which I assume in volves Kramershould be lieve without questioning, without researching, that one style of art or one painter is, in fact, tenthrate, then we must accept the old no tion that we should con centrate our studies only on masters.

title: India to Get U.S. Wheat
description: NEW DELHI, April 3 (Reu ters)The United States will supply to India 1,570,000 metric tons of wheat, 250,000 bales of cotton and 75,000 metric tons of vegetable oil under a new agreement concluded here this week.

title: Rehitch, $9.80, Triumphs As Suffolk Downs Opens
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)Re hitch raced to a 1 vic tory in the $10,000 Homecom ing Handicap today as Suffolk Downs opened its, 90day meet ing. The winner, ridden by Darrell Madden, paid $9.80, $5.20 and $4 after covering the: six furlongs in 1:11 15 under 115 pounds.

title: The Counter Revolution
description: The hottest item in the stock market these days is not a security but an auto mated quotations system called NASDAQ that is speedily revolutionizing the overthecounter market.

title: Angela Davis Is Nominated
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 3 (AP)Angela Davis has been nominated as a candidate for president of the alumni associ ation at Brandeis University, a spokesman reported. He said petition bearing more than 200 signatures supporting Miss Da vis had been filed by the dead line this week. At least 100 signatures are required. Miss Davis, class of 1965, is being bold in the slaying of an Oak tend, Calif., judge.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWThe time has now, come, Leonid I, Brezhnev told the world last Week, for the Soviet Union to meet the needs not only, of its marshals but also of its mothers, to produce not only enough nuclear missiles but also enough beefdteaks, midi skirts and automobiles to put and end to shortages and shoddy goods.

title: MEDICAID TO HALT PAY FOR ABORTION
description: Governor Rockefeller's office said yesterday that the state this week would temporarily suspend Medicaid payments for abortions unless a woman's health was in danger, while the Legislature considers whether to prohibit such payments per manently.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  When Depu ty Attorney. General Richard G. Kleindienst solemnly declared be fore a Senate committee last week that curbing campaign spending was a matter that transcends political partisanship he was repeating one of the most common and widely disbelieved maxims of American public life.

title: Soviet, Pinching Kopecks, Complains on Party Dues
description: MOSCOW, April 3The powerful Soviet Communist party, which administers vast sums in running this nation's multibillion  ruble economy, turns out to be a kopeckpinch ing organization when it comes to Internal party business.

title: Laver Fights Off 2 Match Points to Overcome Emerson in Tennis Semifinals
description: MIAMI, April 3 (UPI)Rod Laver fought back from double match point to defeat Roy Emerson, 26, 6.3, 75, and ad vance to the final of the $50, 000 Aventura tennis tourna ment today.

title: Science/Medicine
description: Last year some 750,000 Amer icans found freedom from pills, diaphragms, condoms, jellies and other contraceptive gadgetry and, not so incidentally, from unwanted childrenby undergo ing a simple operation that left them sterile.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Class actions, which have been hailed repeatedly in re cent months as a panacea for all sorts of consumer grievances, are rapidly be coming a ubiquitous feature on the legal landscape.

title: BRUINS WIN, 83, SET MORE MARKS
description: TORONTO, April 3 (UPI) Phil Esposito set another Na tional Hockey League record by scoring his 23d amd 24th powerplay goals of the season and Wayne Carleton registered three goads against his former Toronto teammates as the Bos ton Bruins routed the Leafs, 83, tonight.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: It was with shocked aston ishment that I read that Oli ver Hailey's Father's Day had opened and closed in one night. I can imagine Mr. Hail ey's rage at this, his finest work to date, being so brutal ly dismissed by producers Kipness and Kasha in spite of two glowing reviews.

title: Chess
description: THE Northeast High School team championship was won by Brook line High of Massachusetts in fiveround series of matches versus a dozen opponents in which two fourman teams, arranged in order of strength, squared off in headon com petition. Peter Koretsky, James Sultan, Alan Trefler and Golbert Hoy comprised the winning team on boards one to four respectively.

title: State Unit Calls Enforcement Of Drug Laws Ineffective Here
description: ALBANY, April 3The State Commission of Investigation charged today that enforcement of the narcotics laws in New York City was ineffective.

title: New Latin Investment Code
description: United states businessmen are fearful that a new in vestment code that has been prepared for Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru will deter or even choke off the flow of foreign capital.

title: Jakarta Curbs Diplomats
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 3 (Reuters)The Government has barred all foreign diplomats from travel in Indonesia until after the general election in July.

title: Homeowners Fight Housing Proposed For the Rockaways
description: The City Planning Commis sion heard a vehement, protest last week from homeowners in the Rockaiways objecting to (proposed moderateincome de velopment on a vacant 13 acre site in their Queens area.

title: A Big Chunk of Chicago
description: A SIXDAY booking at Carnegie Hall is enough to raise tremors of fear in the pulse rates of most major concert artists, but it hasn't fazed Chicago at all. No, not the Chicago Symphony but Chicago, the rock/jazz band whose surg ing rhythms and extraor dinary blend of firstclass musicianship and pop eclect icism have made them one of the country's leading groups.

title: Agnew at Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., (AP) Vice President Agnew arrived today for a brief stay at the Augusta National golf course, where the nation's top golfers will begin the annual Masters Tournament next Thursday. The Vice Presi dent said he would be here two days.

title: Richard Howard, 1971 National Book Award poetry judges, explain themselves
description: Dear Allen,

title: U.S. Ships to Visit Black Sea
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (Reu ters)Four United States de stroyers will enter the Black Sea April 16 for routine opera tions lasting six days, the Navy announced today. American ships have operated in the Black Sea since 1959.

title: Fund Established to Honor Memory of Whitney Young
description: The National Urban League has announced the formation of a Whitney M. Young Jr. Me morial Fund to receive gifts honoring Mr. Young's memory and work. Mr. Young, who was executive director of the league, died on march 11.

title: Nothing revealed the character of Nixon like the character of Carswell
description: After more than two years, Rich ard Nixon's Presidency still seems thin and unconvincing. He holds the formal powers of the office but not the implicit, authority which normal ly accompanies them. He was elect ed by a minority of the voters and inherited a damaged Presidency, but he has failed to extend and strength en this unsatisfactory base.

title: Eastertide tradition
description: There is no accounting for certain associations of holidays and foods. One family of German extraction that lives in St. Louis has a tradition of serving red snapper creole on Good Friday. Whether or not one associates it with the season, it is an excellent dish. Other firmfleshed fish such as cod may be substituted for the red snapper.

title: The Nation
description: They marched First Lieut. Wil liam Laws Calley Jr. to the stock ade at Fort Benning, Ga., last week. The longest courtmartial in military history had ended, and Calley stood convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the premeditated murder of not fewer than 22 unarmed, un resisting Vietnamese men, wo men and children at Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968.

title: Et Al.
description: An overly ambitious, sprawl ing survey of the animal food cycle, past and present, from tiniest mite through man and back again. Carr tries to digest the whole question of human food production and distribu tion; then, as if this wasn't enough, starts again with pois ons and pollution. The style is earnestreportorial salted with wisecracks.

title: CLENDENON SEES VICTORY ASSURED
description: The New York Mets will be gin their labors Tuesday with essentially the same team that finished third last year in the National League East. But the same players, the Mets insist, are better players and they can eliminate the sixgame gap that separated them from the Pitts burgh Pirates.

title: The Nation
description: We have witnessed a tragic political spectacle in Albany this past week, said John V. Lind say of City Hall 66 years later. Partisan lines were drawn and the needs of our cities were ignored.

title: Black Hawks Score, 41
description: DETROIT, April 3 (UPI) Dennis Hull scored his 39th and 40th goals of the season tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 41 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.The pressures of politics and war seem remote on this lovely stretch of California coastline, but last week there was no earthly way to avoid them. Mr. Nixon had come here 10 days ago to rest and sort out his thoughts before his television ad dress on Vietnam this Wednes day night. Yet, the world would not let him alone and he seemed, suddenly, a President under siege.

title: Letters:
description: There is a vocal, influential minority in the United States that lumps outdoor advertis ing with pollution of our rivers and atmosphere. This Is grossly unfair! Americans enjoy entertaining advertis ing. According to a poll con ducted by the University of South Dakota, less than 2 per cent of the travelers mov ing through our state found outdoor advertising offensive. Signs should be controlled, removed from beauty areas and properly spaced. Our Leg islature has passed legislation to accomplish this.

title: L.I. Hunt Season Ends And the Fox Gets Rest
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., April 3 The huntsman cast his hounds. They gave tongue, spoke to the line and bound ed across the rolling pasture. About 70 riders gave chase and the hunt began.

title: BUILDUP AT DMZ BY FOE REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  Intelligence reports reaching Washington indicate a continu ing North Vietnamese buildup north of the demilitarized zone and new enemy troop move ments in Laos, Cambodia and the northern part of South Vietnam.

title: Miss Strait and T. K. Petersen, Both. Lawyers, Have Nuptials
description: WADDINGTON, N. Y., April 3Miss Loraine Hall Strait arid Thomas Keene Petersen, both lawyers, were married here this evening by the Rev. Phillip Blips Gausby, an Epis copal minister, who per formed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Wendell Rip pon Strait, mother of the bride.

title: Iraq Mounting Propaganda Campaign to Build Arab Front Aimed at Forestalling Middle East Settlement
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3 The passionately antiIsraeli rulers of Iraq have been work ing lately to build what they call an Arab progressive front to forestall any peaceful Middle East settlement.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: Ron Goulart is a science fiction writer with a bleak but bracing sense of humor. All of these 13 short stories get a grim chuckle out of the coming technological apocalypse. Peo ple fall prey to computers; robots develop human frailties, and life is treated with all the reverence of a dataprocessing operation.

title: 450th Birthday For San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, which was founded in 1521, is celebrating its 450th anniversary this year. A United States stamp is to be issued on Sept. 12 to commemorate the birth of this, the oldest, complete, still livedin city under the Amer ican flag, The issuance will coincide with the opening of the 1971 National Governors' Conference in San Juan, Sept. 12 through 15, which will be attended by the heads of the 50 American states.

title: WASHINGTON
description: FIERY RUN, Va., April 3For a while it almost looked as if somebody were going to propose giving Lieuten ant Calley the Congressional Medal of Honor. Not since the firing of Gen. Dougias MacArthur during the Korean war has there been such an outburst of sympathy for an American soldier. So at last Vietnam has produced an officer everybody recognizesan anti hero for a war without glory or no bility and a symbol for a time of moral confusion.

title: Cecilia Agnes Larkin Wed to John J. Reilly
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., April 3 Miss Cecilia Agnes Larkin was married here this morn ing to John Joseph Reilly. The Rev. John P. Vitsas per formed the ceremony in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Cath olic Church.

title: 30 Dead on Madagascar In PoliceLeftist Clashes
description: TANANARIVE Malagasy Re public, April 3 (Reuters) Thirty persons were killed and six injured in clashes in south ern Madagascar between the police and members of an ex treme leftwing movement armed with guns, slings and spears, the Government said today.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THIS EDITOR: Some time early in the 60's, we got tired of putting on our white sportcoats, don ning our pink carnations and writing love letters in the sand, all as preparation for going out into the world, get ting jobs and becoming cor porate chattels, all for the benefit of young women who had grown up at their (and our) mothers knees expect ing just such emasculating rot.

title: Fordham Names Captains For Eight Spring Sports
description: Nine captains have been elected in, eight spring sports at Fordham.

title: MADISON AVE.

description: Physicians who believe that Americans can do more to lessen motoring deaths and injuries will be among the exhibitors at this years International Auto mobile Show.

description: Charles Lehman, a 6foot8 inch forward from Hickory, N.C., and Harold Snow, a 511 guard from Louisville, Ky., have been elected honorary cocap tains of the 197071 Columbia freshman basketball team.

title: NIXON DECLARES HE WILL REVIEW THE CALLEY CASE
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3The White House announced today that President Nixon would personally review and decide the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. before any final sentence is carried out.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 3 (UPI)Ross Grimsley, Don Gul lett and Clay Carroll combined to pitch a twohit shutout to day as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Detroit Tigers, 2.0, in the nexttolast exhibition game for both clubs.

description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 3 Miss Cynthia Eve Crider and Daniel Merwin Doolittle were married here this noon in the chapel of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church by the Rev. James S. Stewart.

title: Turbine Will Be Tested
description: WALLED LAKE, Mich.  Zometime next autumn, very conventional looking car with a very unconventional engine is scheduled to begin bucking Now York City's stopandgo traffic.

title: SCHAULER TO RETURN IN CITY OPERA ROLE
description: Eileen Schauler will return to the New York City Opera after an absence of several sea sons to appear as Florinda in Ginastera's Don Rodrigo. The soprano's first performance in the role will be on April 6 in the eighth week of the corn pany's current season at the New York State Theater.

title: Television
description: THE electronic medium as well as the theater continue to quarry riches in the vast literary reposi tory of Henry James. After Berkeley Square, The Heiress, The Innocents, The Aspern Papers, The Wings of the Dove and other  and lesseradaptations to the stage, screen, opera, television, we come to The Spoils of Poynton. It is a minor but brilliant work of the Master (for so his peers called him at the end) written in 1896 almost as if it were a play, just after he had had a terrible and fright ening flop in the theatera London audience had hooted him as he got up to take a bow. That is the great irony in James's extraordinary career. In the theater he was a helpless novelist. In the novel he was a powerful dramatist. Craftsmen coming after him continue to haunt the James quarry, as if to show him what he might have done had he been more at home backstage.

title: METS SCORE, 43 END LOSS STREAK
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 3 The New York Mets, backed by five double plays, defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 43, today be fore heading for Norfolk, Va. and tomorrow's final exhibition game.

title: Letters
description: Concerning the article about me in the March 7 Magazine (An Archae ological Find Named Iris Love, by Elisabeth Stevens), it was my under standing that it was to deal with the Archaeological Expedition to Knidos, its discoveries and related subjects. Therefore, I was most sur prised to read that a substantial part of the article is devoted to my per sonal relationship with my parents. I fail to understand why the writer would feel entitled to discuss matters of this sort and doubt whether they were of legitimate interest to your readers or, indeed, to anyone. It strikes me as a rather dubious pro cedure and in very poor taste.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wounded G.L.'s Bitter Over Calley Conviction
description: At the Memphis Veterans Hospital, where many Viet nam veterans are being cared for, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. last week was greeted with expressions of deep bitter ness.

title: Mills Paces Cougar Golfers To GAC Collegiate Title
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)John Mills posted a 71 for a tourna ment record 279 individual total today as his Houston teammates captured four of the first 10 spots to win the eighth annual GAC intercollegiate golf tournament. It was the Cou gars' 17th straight golf victory.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE giant economy of the United States was still making halting headway last week as it entered the normally morep lacid waters of the second quarter, but its progress continued to be disappointingly slowed by the dragging anchor of apathetic consumer spending.

description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aprli 3 Miss Susan Marie Foley and Ens. Daniel Lewis Larson Jr. U.S.N.R., were married here this afternoon in the Butler Memorial Chapel at the Mary mount School, of which the bride Is a graduate. Msgr. John J. Wallace performed the ceremony. A reception was held in Armonk at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Foley, the bride's parents.

title: Canada Names Border Aide
description: OTTAWA, April 3Louis J. Robichaud, former Premier of New Brunswick, has been ap pointed to the International Joint Commission that deals with United StatesCanadian boundary waters. He fills vacancy created by the death of Arnold Heaney, who was chairman of the Canadian sec tion of the commission.

title: M'ALISTER OF U.C.L.A. SETS LONG JUMP MARK
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (AP) James McAlister of the Uni versity of Los Angeles made a 26foot, 6inch long jump on his first attempt today.

title: Democratic Bay State Aide
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP)State Treasurer Robert Q. Crane was elected today chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

title: Jelly Roll, Bunk, Fats and Ella: Collector's Items
description: JELLY ROLL MORTON (Jazz Trip 1). JIMMIE NOONE, BUNK JOHN SON: Kings of New Or leans (Jazz Trip 2). EARL HINES: All Star Session (Jazz Trip 3). FATS WALLER: Waller on the Air (Jazz Trip 4). ELLA FITZGERALD AND ORCHESTRA: Webb on the Air (Jazz Trip 5). These five LPs represent the beginning of a new and relatively pro vocative series of jazz re issues which may, in some cases, involve initial issues. Their provocativeness rests partly on the fact that, al though they deal with major jazz names, the sources are so obscure that the record ings are likely to be unknown to even the more thorough Collectors.

title: The Spartan conditions of yesteryear no longer prevail at U.S. campgrounds
description: Sleeping cars used to run on railroad tracks, and steadily dwindling number of them still do. But these days, most sleeping cars move along interstate highways, and their numbers grow awe somely every year.Canyon. Every summer, the crowds of campers and trail ers at these sites, and other national and state parks, grow more and more dense.

description: George Dochat, soccer coach at Rutgers University since 1940, has announced his retire ment from coaching.

title: Photography
description: ANEW Super 8 cartridge type movie projeotor recently introduced by Bolex, is also the first one of this type that changes cartridges automatically and can be loaded with as many as six 50foot Bolex car tridges at one time. Called the Multimatic, and distributed by Paillard, Inc., 1900 Low er Road, Linden, N.J. 07036, this new projector is designed so that it threads itself au tomatically after the car tridge is inserted and the cartridge compartment door opened.

title: The Deliberate Season
description: The worst that can be said of April is that it is not May. There are many good things to be said for it, in cluding the fact that it Is not March. Even at its worst, April weather hasn't the bite of a March storm. It can rain in April without ending up as sleet, and when April has a snowstorm, as it occasionally does, the snow doesn't lock itself in for weeks.

title: For Young Readers
description: He's only a toyshop teddy, just a stuffed bear with an unpalpitating heart of excelsior. His kind is bought and sold a hundred times a day. Eventually eyes get pulled off, seams split, the stuffing leaks out and the end comes as a soggy lump after a rain. What happens to one bear in a book is of no matter nothing's real and it's all pretend. Only a lucky few survive between covers; one went bump, bump, bump down the stairs to fame. So will you care about Charles? Very much, I think. Why? Maybe it's the way Martha Alexander has drawn him in his joys and sor rows  a small, charming helpless ness, a simple fuzziness to his body, an expressive arch to his mouth and eyebrows. Or maybe it's in Liesel Skorpen's story itself, an account of the mistreatment Charles endures from a little girl who gets him as a birthday present and later trades him to a little boy for a kitten.

Most are in shades of yellow, though some are red or raspberrycolored.

title: John H. Ward, Writer, Dies; Investment Consultant, 90
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 3 John H. Ward, a longtime waterfront investment consult ant for many years in New York, died last night at the Meadow Lakes Nursing Home in Hightstown. He was 90 years old and lived at 30 Russel Road.

title: Drama Mailbag
