title: Et Al.
description: Concentrating on the age of steam, Mr. Hoehling gives us a readable rundown on the sink ings, epic and otherwise, that always fascinate the buffs. There's room in this modest volume for both the Titanic and the Vestris, the Andrea Doris sinking of 1956 and the fiery end of the sidewheeler General Slocum in 1904, for the Lusi tania of W. W. I. and the Athena of W. W. II. The author, a sea soned journalist and a gunnery officer in the Caine Mutiny era (he survived at least one tor pedoing), is thoroughly at home among his grisly statistics.

title: Funseth Cards 65 for 204 And Leads by 2 Strokes
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April Rod Funseth celebrated his 38th birthday today by scoring a 65, his best round of the year, and taking the lead in the $190,000 Greensboro open golf tourney by two strokes with 204 total.

title: Drug Education Panel Decries Abuse Films
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)A national drug edu cation council has condemned most of the drug abuse films shown to school children and military audiences as being inaccurate, misused and mis leading.

title: PLAN TO JAIL CZECHS REPORTED BY PAPER
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 3 (AP)The Swiss news paper Gazette de Lausanne re ported today that Czechoclovak Communist leaders were plan ning to intern up to 1,000 fol lowers of Alexander Dubcek, the former party chief, as a security measure In prepara tion for next month's 14th party congress.

title: Airport Role for Waterfront Unit Fought
description: Representatives of airlines and the New YorkNew Jersey Waterfront Commission are at odds over plans to extend the commission's jurisdiction to air ports.

title: Storm Jameson
description: To the Editor:

title: New York
description: At last someone has de cided to do something about the state's welfare costs. At least, that's what Governor Rockefeller said he was about last week as he set forth a package of legisla tion aimed at meeting the the dllemma head on. His program had a broad popu lar appeal, and It helped break the legislative impasse over the new state budget.

title: Mrs. Peck Has Son
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 3A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Robert Gray Peck 3d on March 18 at the New York LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Peck is the former Miss Anne Elliott Roberts of Scarsdale.

title: Those Tahitians Know How to Live
description: PAPEETE, Tahiti  Tahiti blossoms in the imagination like a great trcpical flower. There come to mind visions of green mountains with clouds towering above them, bounteous sea and tall, smiling, richly handsome people.

title: Thtre de l'Absurde  l'Academie
description: A very strange event took place in Paris on the afternoon of Feb. 25, 1971: Eugne Ionesco, the world famous avantgarde playwright, was received into the bosom of the Acadmie Francaise. This celebrated institution is normally looked upon as a bastion of cultural conserva tism; since its formal organization in the 17th century by Cardinal Riche lieu, it has almost always set its face against new ideas, except for one brief period during the 18th century when it was taken over by support ers of the Enlightenment. It has, in the course of its existence, commit ted some resounding blunders, not the least of which was its failure to recognize Baudelaire as a poet of outstanding genius.

title: Movies
description: SAN FRANCISCO.

title: WALTER W. YOUNG
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J. April 3  Walter W. Young of 1454 Deer Path, assistant vice presi dent of the National State Bank of Elizabeth, died yes terday in Overlook Hospital.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: Greta Walker's article on summering in Vermont, Time to Befriend a Woodchuck (Travel section, March 14), might have been called Keep ing Up the Frantic Pace in a New Setting. One wonders if the family really under stood or appreciated Ver mont's qualities. Restau rants, glider rides, afternoons around the pool, tennis, wor ries about mercury pollution, viewing celebrities homes, polo matches, entertaining and all, in one month! Could not all these activities have been pursued nearer home? Why travel 320 miles to have what appears to be every moment of the day crammed with the frantic schedule that most New Yorkers claim to be fleeing? The beauty of Vermont is in having noth ing to do but watch the snow fall in winter and the birds in summer.

title: Suns Enroll Moore
description: PHOENIX, Aug., April 3 (UPI)  The Phoenix Suns signed Otto Moore, a 6foot11 inch center, last night to threeyear contract.

title: Et Al.
description: A history of the Peace Corps' first 10 years, by a former dep uty director. The writing is lively and inside but not par ticularly analytical or critical. Ashabranner feels the P.C. should continue, even though American youth seems more in terested in domestic problems. P.C.'s mission, as he sees it, is instilling backward nations with a sense of dignity, as well as bettering their material lot, also making Americans more aware of foreign cultures. He is particularly good on the P.C.'s inception and the bureaucratic infighting that accompanied it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Theodore Gordon Flyfishers, Inc., a Manhattanbased con servation organization, has joined the state in an effort to combat water pollution.

title: WIDER LEADERSHIP AT HARV ARD URGED
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April  The Harvard University Committee on Governance has recommended a dramatic in crease in the size of the uni versity's toplevel administra tion.

title: Television
description: RIOT BOX or de fuser? Television has been called both, among a num ber of other things. It de pends on who is doing the analyzing, what program he is watching, how he is watch ing it and even where he is watching it.

title: Israelis Dismiss Report
description: JERUSALEM, April 3Israeli officials said tonight, that Egyp tian leaders were only making things more difficult for them selves by laying down condi tions in public for an eventual arrangement wth Israel to open the Suez Canal.

description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)Cam bridge University's crew pro duced a lastgasp surge on the choppy waters of Biscayne Bay today to overtake Brown and win the 2,000meter intercol legiate regatta by a 2.3second margin.

title: Western Gain Is Seen on Berlin Issue
description: BONN, April 3The decision of the East German Government to withdraw its offer to allow Easter visits by West Berlin citizens was evaluated here by senior Western officials as a tactical victory for the allied negotiating position in the four power Berlin talks.

title: U.S. Officials Are Concerned Over Discontent in Micronesia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 3 Severe political discontent in Micronesia has disturbed the United States administration in those strategic central Pacific islands and atolls, according to authoritative reports here and in Canberra.

title: Speculation Grows on a U.N. Session in Geneva
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, April 3A move of the General Assembly to Geneva for its 1972 session has become a popular topic for speculations here, although no official ges ture has been made, in that direction.

description: DETROIT  Six months after starting her first job as a secretary, and armed with enough money for a downpayment, she was mak in.p the rounds of dealer ships, shopping for her first raised car.

Home Improvement
description: UNDOUBTEDLY one of the easiest of all radiocontrolled elec tric garage door op erators to install, a new model recently introduced is designed so that an average doityourselfer can convert his manually operated over head garage door to safe, convenient electric operation in about one hour (assuming he starts, with a door that is properly balanced and in smooth working order).

title: Foyt Favored in Atlanta 500 Today
description: HAMPTON, Ga., April 3A. J. Foyt, the Texas millionaire who is picking up a few dol lars on the Southern stockcar racing circuit while waiting for his regular season to begin, is the favorite to win tomorrow's running of the Atlanta 500 on the 1.5mile oval of Atlanta In ternational Raceway. Forty late model cars, called Grand Na tionals, will compete for a $106,265 purse.

description: Sol Yurick, the Park Slope novelist whose writings teem with the sights and sounds of urban frustration, has become  between chapters of an in theworks Marxist detective novel  a volunteer editor and judge of new talent.

title: NAVY IS HOST TEAM IN KENNEDY REGATTA
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 3 (AP)College sailing teams from throughout the country will compete in the United States Naval Academy's sev enth annual John F. Kennedy Memorial Regatta April 17 to 19.

title: Bonn Raises Phone Charges
description: BONN, April 3West Ger man telephone users will have to pay 3 pfennigsfivesixths of a centmore for local calls under a general increase in Postal Ministry charges ap proved this week. Longdistance calls will also become more ex pensive, arid some mail rates will be increased.

description: Detroit, like it or not is watching Washington extend an increasingly stronger hand into its design rooms in the flame of safety as evidence grows that relatively small changes in an automobile can save many lives.

title: Dance
description: THE National Ballet Is a pretty risky title for any dance company to assume, and when the company is based in Washing ton of all places, the risks must seem compounded.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  For many Americans, given the seemingly widespread antimilitarism among today's youth, the idea that an allvolunteer army could ever be attained seems preposterous.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 3A man's face is the most carefully selected part of his wardrobe. It is also the one piece of clothing he will never be caught removing in public, or even In private, no matter how liberated he may be.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Assemblyman Gottfried frets about forcing landlords to maintain their buildings. Remember the situation in 1965 when landlords of new buildings gave furniture and months rent free in order to attract tenants? Compare the effectiveness of that compe tition for tenants with the system of using building in spectors to force landlords to maintain buildings.

title: PEREZ GROUP GIVES A DANCE PREMIERE
description: Rudy Perez, a choreographer whose trademark has been compression of both motion and emotion, seemed to loosen up n both counts in his latest piece, Monumental Exchange. The group work was given its premiere by the Rudy Perez Dance Theater Friday night in the Video Exchange series at the Merce Cunningham studio, Westbeth, 55 Bethune Street, in Greenwich Village.

description: The city office of the Na tion Weather Service was al most rhapsodic yesterday in discussing prospects for to day's Palm Sunday observ ances.

title: First Tory Budget
description: The reality is that, in making his basic budget deci sions, the Prime Minister faced an extremely difficult choicecall it a quadrilemma: Unemployment is indeed high and rising; investment is weak and the growth rate stagnant, threatening to drop the British standard of living behind most of Western Europe's within a decade; labor Is demanding ever higher wages, and prices are shooting up; and, though the British balance of payments looks strong at the moment, continuing cost and price inflation could swiftly erode it.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONOne objective of the 45day allied operation against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was to prevent a Com munist offensive in the northern regions of South Vietnam. But last week, only a few days after the operation ended, North. Viet namese and Vietcong forces struck in a series of attacks that were more costly in Amer ican and South Vietnamese lives than any in the area since last summer.

title: Leffler of Toledo Named Coach of Junior Mat Team
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 4 (UPI) Richard Leffler of St. Francis DeSales High School here, has been named coach for the United States freestyle team in the world junior wrestling championships in Tokyo May 16.

title: Cambodia to Remove Boys And Women From Combat
description: NPENH, Cambodia, April 3 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported today that the nation's armed forces num bered 200,000 troops, and it an nounced plans to take women and young boys out of combat.

title: Leftists in Singapore Form a Party to Challenge Lee
description: SINGAPORE, April 3  A leftist opposition party, the Peo ple's Front, has been formed here to challenge the domina tion of Singapore by the Peo ple's Action party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

title: Rested Knicks Drill for Next Playoff Round, Starting Tuesday at Garden
description: The Knicks, with a fourday rest after their bruising victory in five games over the Atlanta Hawks, will open the semifinal round of the National Basket ball Association playoffs Tues day night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kerr on House of Blue Leaves and How the Other Half Loves The Most Striking New American Play
description: WHILE I am so busy belaboring you with the lapses of cur rent playwrights, I wish to record a sin of omis gion of my own. I happened to miss John Guare's The House of Blue Leaves when it opened and have only now got down to the Off Broad way Truck and Warehouse Theater to check it out. That was not only remiss of me, It was masochistic of me. Here I was, sitting through dozens of plays that seem to have taken tedium as brides, and there was this enchantingly zany, desper ately sad, thoroughly origi nal little farce waiting for the all the time.

title: Air in Mexico City Is Termed Potentially Severe Health Peril
description: MEXICO CITY, April 3A member of President Nixon's Council on Environmental Qual ity has warned that air pollu tion problems in Mexico City are as serious as in many large United States cities.

title: Coed Crew Shapes Up at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 When Princeton University undergraduates overwhelm ingly applauded the advent of coeducation two years ago, few of them Imagined that coeds would eventually in fringe on one of the most traditional of masculine ac tivities and organize an un official crew team.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The temptation is almost Irresistible each spring to pick the winners from the provi ons year as the ones most likely to succeed in the new season Sometimes, though, it is an exercise in wisdom to resist that temptatien. The one I remember most was just before the opening of the 1064 season.

title: Anthony Burgess's Oedipus Rex
description: Unlike those empty commodities regularly passed off as examples of prose fiction nowadays, Anthony Burgess's new novel is really some thing: a book which represents a gen uine achievement for author and publisher alike, as elegantly printed and bound as it is fully realized. Intricate and imaginatively daring as it is, the novel is never given to disintegration and it affords all the pleasures of language at work and play.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: LOS ANGELES By the time he was 31 years old in 1966, Robert S. Fogarty Jr. headed a large subsidiary of Schlumberger, Ltd., the big international conglomer ate, and was building a repu tation as an administrative troubleshooter.

title: Who's Cooking With Gas?
description: STANLEY, my movie in dustry friend, was look ing extremely fit when, last week, he stopped by my office enveloped in an aura of spring. Actually, it was the scent of a new spray that prevents his nowshoul derlength hair from becom ing hopelessly tangled, as it used to do when he was caught in postluncheon con versation on the sidewalk in front of 21.

title: To err is papal, to protect divine
description: The Pope lied. Having made that accusation, Charles Davis, England's most notable younger theologian, left the Roman Catholic Church four years ago. Pope Paul VI had said that Catholic teaching on birth control was not in doubt when manifestly it was; the Pontiff himself had ap pointed a commission to make a study dealing with those doubts, charged Davis.

title: Letter Entries to Make Betting as Easy as ABC
description: When New York horse players start making legal offtrack bets, they'll be doing it by the letters rather than the numbers.

title: Music Mallbag

title: Bridge
description: EVERY bridge player on the road to tournament success has an accident occasionally. Those who are careless and lack concentration have a high accident rate and are likely to lose, if not their licenses, at least their partners. Even the greatest are not immunein a threeday period last month Giorgio Belladonna, 12 times a world champion, twice bid hand without realizing that he had only 12 cards.

title: Drop in '70 Recalls Could Be a Fluke
description: WASHINGTON  The number of motor vehicles re called for correction of safe ty defects dropped sharply in 1970. But the significance of the decrease  84 per cent from 1969  is in doubt.

title: Bored Youths on L.I. Looking for an Outlet
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I., April Their life seems to be an endless round of the leisure time loitering known as hanging out, in shopping malls, hamburger stands, openair parks, and notvery lively streetcorners.

title: EAST'S 7FOOTERS OVERCOME WEST
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 3 (AP)  Jim McDaniels of Western Kentucky and Artis Gilmore of Jacksonville, both 7footers, led the East to a 106104 overtime victory over the West today in the Coaches' AllStar basketball game.

title: For Young Readers
description: There are some anthropo orphic animal stories that, because they re semble the work of Beatrix Potter, are almost synonymous with the world of an English nursery. (Their colors are gentle, their characters limited to the smaller creatures of field and forest.) And there dwells in many of us the belief that there is inherent goodness in that world no wrong can come of anything that hints of Nannies and prams, crumpets and casement windows.

title: Stamps
description: THE maple leaf, long as sociated with Canada, is the subject of the dominion's national flag, and will be the subject of four Canadian stamps this year. The first is due April 14, one of a series depicting the Maple Leaf in Four Sea sons. As can be imagined, the April 14 stamp will be for the maple leaf in Spring.

title: Beware of Bouillabaisse
description: PARIS  France remains the best country in the world for automobile touring, com bining leisurely sightseeing with the pleasures of gas tronomic indulgence.

title: Television
description: HOW Do Your Chil dren Grow? Chan nel 13's new week ly halfhour series on childrearing, is conven iently scheduled at 10 on Wednesday nights, an hour when the kiddies should be safely tucked away and you have the peace and quiet to consider what in the name of Dear Doctor Spock to do about them anyway.

description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, April 3 (UPI)Minsky, a 3 yearold full brother to the great Nijinsky, won the Glad ness Stakes today, but his margin in the sevenfurlong event was only a short head in a photo finish.

description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)President Nixon will appoint John A. Scali, diplo matic correspondent for the American Broadcasting Com pany, to a White House post soon to help tell the public about the Administration's foreign policy, informed sources said today.

title: BUSHIDO, $25, CAPTURES$115,600 CAMPBELL AT BOWIE

title: Jersey Afghan Is Best In 5 Successive Shows

Hud son Kalloch, superintendent for the shows, told me no dog ever had taken more than three on the Sportsmen's Dog Show circuit, said Playfair.

title: Marine Out of Prison For Vietnam Slayings
description: WEIRTON, W. Va., April 3 (AP)  Michael Schwarz, home after a 10month prison term for the murder of 12 South Vietnamese civilians, celebrated a belated Christ mas with his family today while telling of hopes to re turn to Vietnam.

title: In the Air,Circuitous Bargains
description: Businessmen who want to obtain approval for their trips at a time when many corporations are sharply cur tailing travel expenses find that they can come up with bargains if they shop around.

title: Toronto Prelate Resigns
description: ROME, April 3 (AP)Pope Paul VI has accepted the resig nation of 77yearold James Cardinal McGuigan as Arch bishop of Toronto, the Vatican has announced He will be suc ceeded by Archbishop Philip Francis Pocock, his apostolic administrator and coadjutor.

title: A house for children and dog and adults
description: You'd never guess that this rather elegantly formal house in Connecticut was designed with children in mind. But it was. The owners insisted that no area should be off limits to their four childrenor their shaggy dog. De signer David Whitcomb used colorful patterned rugs conceal scuffs and footprints. Sofas and large seating pieces are covered in sturdy, but luxuriousappearing fabrics. More fragile colors and materials were reserved for windows and occasional chairs. Though the house isn't totally childproof, children are as welcome as adults.

title: Film Man Fiance Of Susan Hubbell
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 3 Miss Susan Hubbell and Nicholas Peter Serras of New York plan to be mar ried. Mr. and Mrs. James E. Hubbell of Stamford and Moretown, Vt., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Serras of Chephalonia, Greece, and New York.

title: RAILROAD STRIKE LOOMS IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 3 Railroad services were sharply curtailed across Canada today in antici pation of a strike scheduled by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers for noon Monday.

description: CAIRO, April 3 (Reuters) A rich new oil field has been discovered, about 50 miles south of Alamein, in the west ern desert, Industry Minister Aziz Sidky announced here to day.

description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., April 3  The Jewish Institute for Geriatric Care, a new facil ity designed to provide treat ment for aged patients and re search into the diseases of old age, is nearing completion next to the Long Island Jewsh Medi cal Center here.

description: Like vintage wines, vintage cars seem to increase in value each year, and the old Buicks can go the old Bor deaux one better: They pro vide transportation as their worth increases.

title: The SecondLongest Name in the English Language
description: WEBSTER, Mass.  It has the second longest name in the English language. It is Lake Chargoggagoggmanchauggago ggchaubunagungamaugg. (The longest is Lianfairpwilgwyngullgogerychwyrndrob williantysiliogogogoch, the name of a village in Wales, which means St. Mary's Church in a hollow by the white hazel close to the rapid whirlpool by the red cave of St. Tysilio.)

description: Mike Kekich remembers Maritza.

title: My Experiments With Truth, or  The Search for The Perfect Guru
description: I TURNED my back on Manhattan and set out for India to find guru. I was ripe for the trip, I felt. Two years as a caseworker for the New York City Department of Social Services had left me feeling full of other people's problems but pretty emp ty myself. Still, I was 24 and physically fit, so my case wasn't hopeless. All I needed, I figured, was to get back to myself (wherever that was) and away from it all. And India seemed the logical place for doing both. Halfway around the world, India wasor so I imagined full of gurus, or holy men, who might help me along on the road to en lightenment.

title: Morris Kellogg Becomes Fiance Of Miss Toppin
description: WEST HARTFORD, April 3 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Martin Toppin have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Elizabeth Livingston Toppin, to Morris Woodruff Kellogg, youngest of the four sons of James Crane Kellogg 3d, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, and Mrs. Kellogg of Elizabeth, N. J.

title: Between The Thunder And the Sun By Alfred Coppel. 257 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $6.95.
description: Mr. Coppel's supersonic thriller is calculated to con firm one's nostalgia for the iron horse. A berserk hijacker at large on a Miamibound airliner laboring through a hurricane this is the stuff that can ruin the inflight movie; when the communications system is zapped by lightning, it would seem that the hands of pilot Chris Aymar couldn't be fuller. This, of course, is only to get the story airborne: the author also piles Pelion upon Ossa by including in his passenger list a few unstable types capable of making things even worse. As Hurricane Serena blows just a whiff of good through the fuselage. Captain Chris flies a taut ship through some too credible misadventures.

title: For Young Readers
description: The thousands of Germans who made the hazardous 18thcentury oceancrossing and settled in Penn sylvania before the Revolution were remarkable for their industry, self reliance religious piety and close knit family life. Those who belonged to the Mennonite, Amish and related sects were also distinguished by cus toms and styles of dress that have been preserved to our own time in Pennsylvania and in other states where the descendants of these pio neers now live. George Kraus, a Viennaborn artist who has lived in the Pennsylvania Amish country, has captured the spirit and charm of the region and its agrarian society in two delightful little books, The Lord'Prayer and 'Me Lord Is My Shepherd.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Recordings
description: ANDRES SEGOVIA married the guitar at a preco cious ago and has car ried on a romance with the instrument, for more than 60 years that is a match for the longestrunning love af fairs of history. None of your fastflaming, overanddone infatuations, his; at 78 he still, talks about the guitar with the rapture of a newly smitten teenager. Anyone in terested in him or his in strument will want Decca's The Guitar and I, a disk con taining the first, one hopes, of many autobiographical recollections, written and nar rated by Segovia in Castil hamflavored prose that is constantly on the verge of taking off into Symbolist poe try. He was, it seems, always a man with appeal to the ladies, and My Early Yearn in Granada and Cordoba documents a romarstic crisis from his preteen years, as well as his awakenings to other, purely musical, de lights. One side of the disk is devoted to memoirs, the other to the maestro's per formance of some elementary exercises and studies by Coste, Sor and Giuliani.

title: Art
description: THE sources and opera tions of creativity, like those of character, are complex, often contra dictory and really appreci able only in individual cases. Nearly all artat least nearly all Western art since the Renaissancemight in fact be defined as the exercise of ec centricity, though of course it is not as such that we are accustomed to regard and value it. Rather, we speak of originality, thereby re ferring more to formal quali ties in the work than to per sonal idiosyncrasies in its creator and imagining that the work exists in a more or less orderly historical con tinuum. But now and then artists happen along who are so totally and flamboyantly eccentricreal cranksthat it is virtually impossible to account for them except in terms of the creative process itself. Such a one isor, alas, perhaps used to beOyvind Fahlstrom, currently showing at the Sidney Janis Gallery.

The baritone had had to cancel one concert at the school earlier this season. title: Medieval Brixen: Step Right Up For the Elephant Platter
description: BRIXEN, officially known in Italy as Bressanone, gets two stars in my stillunwritten book, The Trav eler's Guide of Missed Opportu nities"a list of the fascinating places I overlooked while I was nearby because I didn't know about them. Day after day, thousands of motorists zoom right past Brixen in South Tyrol on their way between Munich or Innsbruck in the north and Verona or Venice in the south. If they knew what they were missing, they would wheel around and head for BrixenBressanone almost with out regard to the speed limit, for here is an authentically medieval town that wonder of wondershas not yet been spoiled. It is a town with venerable inns where wine has been flowing for fully a millennium, and at one of which (named for an elephant) guests may or der an eyepoppingly elephantine meal which, alas, I dare no longer eat myself but will to describe.

title: Maine's Gorgeous Gorge A Mini Grand Canyon
description: TOWNSHIP 7, RANGE 10, Me. There aren't any com munities in this area of central Maine between Greenville and Brownsville and about 30 miles southwest of Mount Katandin, but it does have the Gulf, a threeandonehalfmilelong canyon where a sparkling stream races through the gorge over a succession of falls.

title: A truly bad book just doesn't happen
description: Here's a book so transcen dently bad it makes us fear not only for the condition of the novel in this country, but for the country itself. Such heroic wrongness cannot be the au thor's alone. Like a great book, a truly bad one needs a culture behind it. Its force  what raises it above the ordinary failurecomes from its seizing upon certain absurdities of the culture and celebrating them as both essence and revelation.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SANTIAGO, ChileHarry Hopkins once reputedly said: We will spend and spend, tax and tax, elect and elect, and whether he actually coined that phrase or not, it represented the formula by which the New Deal was consolidated in successive Roosevelt mandates. It is also the formula adopted by Salvador Allende to try to make irreversible the Marxist regime he is now establishing in Chile.

title: MEHL, DEFENDER, PAGES 420 SAILING
description: RYE, N. Y., April 3Steve Mehl, the 20yearold defending champion from the Scituate, Mass., fleet, held a 20point lead today after the first five races in the American Yacht Club's anual 420 Class spring invitation regatta were sailed in a shifty westerly breeze.

title: Ellen Meyer, Editor, Wed to Edward Joseph
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 3  Miss Ellen Gail Meyer, daughter, of Mrs. Nathan Meyer and the late Mr. Meyer, was married here this evening to Edward Leopold Joseph, son of Mrs. Robert Joseph of New York and the late Mr. Joseph. Rabbi Aaron Mauskopf, assisted by Cantor Paul Grob, performed the ceremony at the Gomley Chesed Synagogue.

title: Lyons Gray of Tobacco Family Will Marry Constance Fraser
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 3 Miss Constance Louise Fraser, daughter of the Right Rev. Thomas Augustus Fraser, Episcopal Bishop of North Carolina, and Mrs. Fraser, plans to be married on May 29 to Lyons Gray. He is a son of Mrs. Richard Edward Thomas Hunter of Winston Salem and Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Bowman Gray Jr., who was president and board chairman of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

title: CANADIENS ROUT RANGERS, 72;
description: MONTREAL, April 3The New York Rangers not only lost their National Hockey League contest to the Canadiens in the Forum today, 72, but they also lost a decisive edge In the race for the Vezina trophy.

title: Maoist Guerrillas in Italy Wage Fight Against Communist Party
description: ROME, April 3  Wellorga nized, tough Maoists have been harassing the Communist party this week in a poor suburb of Rome that has been regarded as one of its bulwarks. The party seems determined to fight back.

title: News of the Matto
description: THERE'S A New Life in Murray Schisgal's future. Which is almost as literal as it sounds. A New Life is the title of a play which once, as A Way of Life, was aborted during its previews, That was in January, 1969, the season when Schisgal expe rienced the nightmare of trying to get two plays on the boards at the same time. The other was Jimmy Shine, which, with Dustin Hoffman, managed to survive.

title: ELECTRONIC SOUND IS EXPLORED HERE
description: Among composers devoted to electronic sound and the ex ploration of multimedia possi bilities, Morton Subotnick is one of the more interesting. His written explanations of how he arrives at his results may be totally discouraging to the electronically uninstructed, of which this reporter is one, but the sounds he produces and the sights he creates to look at can be quite absorbing.

title: Books:
description: Anyone who has noticed and who hasn't?how many markets Japanese products have begun to penetrate will be interested in this book.

title: QUEENS RESIDENTS JOIN TO SAVE COVE
description: It is not much of a cove, hut as the tide begins to swing out to the East River, the marshes become more apparent along the shore and, intermit tently, the sound of birds Inter rupts the stillness of a gray afternoon.

title: Calley Verdict Brings Home the Anguish of War to Public

William L. Calley Jr. of the United States Army seems clearly to have brought home a sense of the anguish of war.

title: Rouge Chanteur, at $4.80, 6Length Victor in Florida
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 3 (AP)Leonard Prussky's Rouge Chanteur led from start to fin ish in capturing the $20,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap by six lengths today.

title: DANA PARKINSON
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  Dana Parkinson, chief of the information education depart ment of the United States Forest Service from 1936 to 1955, died today in Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md. He was 85 years old and lived here.

description: WASHINGTON, April 3The National Railroad and Passenger Corporation, which will drop half of the nation's intercity trains when it begins operation next month, is also planning a major revival of service in the Boston  New York Washington corridor that could largely sup plant air shuttles before the middle of the decade.

title: C. W. Post Is Considering a Weekend College
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 3  A weekend college is un der consideration by the Office of Adult Education and Special Programs at C. W. Post College to extend the current academic schedule to include Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Sadat Reported to Regard April As Decisive for Peace or War
description: CAIRO, April 3President Anwar elSadat was reported today to regard April as the decisive month for either a political settlement or war with Israel.

title: In Japan, Parking Tickets That Lock
description: TOKYO  Lockon tickets, which the national police agency devised to combat parking violators, have dras tically reduced the growing number of scofflaw cases in the major cities of Japan.

title: Albee's All Over The Living Are Dead, Too
description: EDWARD ALBEE, who used to bring us a new play or an adaptation every year, has been three years finding his voice since the experimental, enig matic BoxMaoBox, a ven ture that deserved rather bet ter than it got. It was to be hoped that, after this period of withdrawal, a renewed Ed ward Albee would return with his angry energies once more on the march. Instead his new play, All Over, seems simply to continue the withdrawal, this time in pub lic view.

Nix, Democrat of Pennsylvania, has announced that 96 members of Congress have joined him in sponsoring a bill to force the United Staes Postal Service to issue a commemorative stamp honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was as sassinated three years ago.

title: How to Shop for a New Car
description: DETROIT  The first as sumption you should make in buying a new car is that you are unlikely to beat the dealer in bargaining. He is a pro fessional, selling hundreds of cars, and you are an amateur, buying one every few years. The pro has all the advan tages.

description: If we up a skyscraper the way the White House put to gether its plan for controlling construction wages and prices, we'd all be indicted for at tempted manslaughter.

Finding an apartment, dealing with landlords, jobhunting, fighting the local bureaucracies, bargains, legal rights, abortions, beaches, bus routes, where to dance, the draft, family plan ning, cheap restaurants, etc. For the young swinger. For the old swinger, too.

title: Coins
description: THERE are few coins in history with the re ligious significance of Great Britain's Maundy pieces, which reigning mon archs have distributed among the poor and infirm for al most 15 centuries. The money is given away during a cere mony which is held on the Thursday before Easter and gifts often include clothing and food, as well as coins.

title: Medical Corpsmen Program
description: BOSTON, April 3 (AP) Northeastern University has announced that it will begin a federally sponsored program June 14 to train former medi cal corpsmen to be physicians assistants.

title: British Shops: A Growing Chain
description: LONDON, April 3A decade of offtrack betting has created a new growth industry in Britain and changed the gambling hab its of the nation.

title: Matson Invited to Compete In Kansas Relays April 14
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 3 (AP)A shotput event featur ing Randy. Matson, the world recordholder and Olympic champion, was announced to day for the 46th Kansas Relays April 14 through 17.

title: Daughter to the Meltzers
description: GREAT NECK, LI., April 3 A daughter was born March 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Bruce G. Meltzer at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset. Mrs. Meltzer is the former Miss Marylin K. Friedman. The child has been named Jennifer Joy.

title: Search for Seamen Ends
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 3 (AP)The Coast Guard sus pended search operations to day for 31 missing crewmen of the lost tanker Texaco Okla homa, which broke in two and sank a week ago off the North Carolina coast. Thirteen of the ship's 44man crew were rescued last Sunday and Mon day by merchant vessels.

title: Blues Beat Penguins, 43
description: ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP) Curt Bennett, a rookie, scored his first two N.H.L. goals to night to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 43 victory over the Pitts burgh Penguins.

title: Tepperbergs Have Son
description: A son was born March 8 to Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Tep perberg at Maimonides Hospi tal in Brooklyn. Mrs. Tepper berg is the former Miss Susann Pozefsky of Albany. Her husband is physician in charge of pediatric neurology at the Maimonides Medical Center. The child has been named Joshua Alan.

title: Frantic Motors Launches the Sloth
description: The appalling truth, of course, is that almost no one has really been exerting him self to give the driver what he really wants. Oh, there has been the usual talk about safety and pollution but only Frantic Motors has actually gone about putting things right. At least, it has em bodied some of the motorist's most cherished ideals in the design of its latest model, the Sloth.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR: A pleasant postscript to your article First Lady of the Passport Office (Travel section, March 14): On Wednesday, March 10, we applied for a passport at the Wilmington Passport Office (in the Post Office building). On Monday, March 15, we re ceived our passports, mailed from the Philadelphia office. This included a Sunday in the delivery time.

title: Pattberg of First Boston
description: March was a significant, busy month for the First Boston Corporationfor years the only major publicly owned securities firm in the nation.

title: Lectures, Tours and Classes

The program will begin at 10 A.M. and advance registration is required. The fee is $4. The center is located at Bible Street, Cos Cob, Conn.

title: NASSAU UNIT ASKS DRUG LAW REFORM
description: MINEOLA, L. I. April 3 Community organizations in Nassau County dealing with the problems of drug abuse said unanimously this week that a drastic overhaul of our laws on drug abuse is long overdue.

title: The President and Mylai
description: No development in the whole tragic history of the Vietnam war has produced a more spontaneous outcry than, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. The protests have brought into unaccustomed unity such divergent national figures as Gov. George C. Wallace Alabama and Dr. Benjamin Speck, to say nothing millions of Americans not normally given to public expressions of outrage.

title: Reader's Report
description: It isn't the man who disap pears as much as the novel. Tantalizing flashes of crotchety humor and clever aphorizing tempt the reader into one cul desac after another, until the book finally dissolves into a puff of confetti. If you don't mind the barren fictional stretches that mark his journey, a wan derer through life named Aris totle Harisiades has some orig inal observations to contribute. About immortality, for ex ample. (If souls are immortal, what a waste of time. If you've seen one you've seen them all.)

title: Connell Downs Davis, 54
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 3 (AP)  Truman Connell of Boynton Beach,, Fla., scored a 5and4 victory over J. Bishop Davis of Melvin Vil lage N. H. in the American seniors match play golf chain pionship today. It was the first time Connell had played in the event and was Davis's second unsuccessful attempt at the crown.

title: No Comment, Says C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had no corn. ment to make concerning Mr. Marasco's statement.

title: Et Al.
description: Recollections of a Louisiana childhood during the early I900's. Potbellied stoves, grand pa's wisdom, loyal nigras, hi y'all. The pastoral strings in some Dixie hearts will be set twanging by this superficial selfindulgent memoir.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Before the Air Line Pilots Association began contract negotiations with a large United States airline last year, it hired a consultant, at $12,000, to take a look at the line's economic health.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Well over half a century ago, George Bernard Shaw delivered the incisive comment on the Calley case.

title: Music
description: THE Mendelssohn symphony that Stanislaw Skrowaczewski and the New York Philharmonic conducted last week was listed as No. 1 in C mi nor. It was written in 1824, when Mendelssohn was 14 years old. But this Symphony No. 1 in C minor is really No. 13. It was the first that Mendelssohn al lowed to be published; hence the official number. Thir teen symphonies at the age of 14. Has there been anything like that in the history of music?

title: President Opposes Unlimited Abortion
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3President Nixon de clared today that he regarded abortion as an unacceptable form of population control and asserted that he could not reconcile unrestricted abortion policies, or abortion on de mand with his personal belief in the sanctity of human life.

title: Amalrik, a Soviet Dissident, Reported Ailing in Captivity
description: MOSCOW, April 3 (Reuters) Friends of Andrei A. Amalrik, author of Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984, said today that he became seriously ill with tubercular meningitis while in transit to a labor camp last month.

title: THE ATLANTA SCENE
description: TO THE EDITOR: James T. Wooten's article, The Life and Death of Atlanta's Hip Strip (March 14), was one of the most accurate that I have ever read. Mr. Wooten catches all of the sorrow and horror that enveloped the hip community in Atlanta.

title: Three Sign Bills' Pacts
description: BUFFALO, April 3 (AP)The National Football League Buf falo Bills today signed Bill Hun ter, a draft choice from Utah, and free agents Romus Jeffries and Bill Murphy. Hunter, a running back, will be tried at safety, Coach John Rauch said. Jeffries is a wide receiver and Murphy plays cornerback.

title: Art;FromOpenForm to the Monolithic Cube
description: THE changes that have overtaken the art of sculpture in this country over the past two dec ades are many, but one change has been more conspicuous, perhaps, than any other  the shift from open form, directmetal construction to sculptural forms deploying closed, weighty, monolithic masses. Sculpture of the former persuasion is generally airy, linear, and very personal in its imagery, whereas the latter tends to be bulky, volumetric and highly impersonal in its appeal. The one looks to drafts manshipto socalled drawing in space for its basic rationale, whereas the other looks to architecture, especially prefabricated modular architecture. And while openform sculpture tends to draw its imagery from the realm of gesture and sometimes even myth and anecdote, offering us the sub jective arabesques of the unconscious, the socalled primary sculpture of recent vintage is based on a more de tached and obective ratiocination.

title: NOTRE DAME PRIZE GOES TO KUNSTLER
description: NOTRE DAME, Ind., April 3 William M. Kunstler accepted last night the 1971 Senior Fel low Award of the University lof Notre Dame with a call to end the war nowby what ever means necessary, short of violence to human beings.

title: Small Populations of Plants Exist Tenuonsly
description: WHOOPING crane, bald eagle, snow leopard and peregrine falcon are rallying causes for conservationists who know that these members of the wild kingdom are threatened with extinction.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: TWO UNION CHIEFS MEET WITH MAYOR ON WAGE DISPUTE
description: Mayor Lindsay met yesterday with the heads of the fire and sanitation unions, but failed to case the city's stalemated con tract disputes with its uni formed services.

title: Joseph M. Valachi, Informer, Dies at 67
description: EL PASO, April 3 (AP)  Joseph M, Valachi, who broke a blood oath to disclose the inner workings of the crime organization he identified as the Cosa Nostra, died today of a heart attack at La Tuna Fed eral Correctional Institution, the prison announced. He was 67 years old.

title: N.Y.U. SURGE BEATS COLUMBIA IN TRACK
description: New York University's track team outscored Columbia, 257, in the final four events to break a 6060 tie and defeat the Lions 8567, in an outdoor meet at Baker Field yesterday.

title: A JESUIT RECALLS 45 BID TO JAPAN
description: ROME, April 3A Jesuit his torian reports that a secret United States agency ap proached the Japanese Govern meat by way of the Vatican in 1945 with a view to an honorable peace settlement two months before the first atomic bomb was dropped on Hiro shima, but that nothing came of the approach.

title: A Black Man's Dream of Personal Freedom
description: WELL, all right. The Negro Ensemble Company has chosen to devote its en tire 197071 season to a pro gram of plays centered around a single subject: Themes of Black Struggle. A program note The commit ment is substantially realized with NEC's third production of the season, Derek Wal cott's brooding allegorical drama, The Dream On Mon key Mountain.

title: Same mix: black labor, white capital
description: Few regions of the world can boast of the changes undergone by the Caribbean in recent years. In 1945, all of the countries were either colo nies of Europeans or clients of the United States. Today, only the small est have not won their independence and, although Cuba alone has found new allies, the nations of the Carib bean, as editor Tad Szulc writes in the preface to this collection of es says, represent a force that United States foreign policy cannot ignore. Yet, as Frank McDonald, a fellow of the Institute of World Affairs, co gently recognizes in the most power ful and sensitive section in the book, the changes, more often than not.

title: Renting a Car? Beware
description: There are two viable meth ods of escaping from New York City on any given weekend. One is owning a car. But unless you are a car dealer, a parking garage op erator or J. Paul Getty, that is the costlier way.

title: Congress Is Expected to Pass Boat Safety Act Soon
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 Congress is expected to pass before summer a comprehen sive new boating safety law that would set tough safety standards for manufacturers and operators of noncommercial pleasure boats.

title: KILLING BY DOCTOR STIRS THE FRENCH
description: PARIS, April 3If you can't trust a doctor, whom can you trust?

title: Battle Over Highway, Policy Intensifies
description: WASHINGTONThe high way lobby ham lost some battles and some momentum since its heyday, but the reports of its death are great ly exaggerated.

title: ItalianAmerican League's Power Spreads
description: The ItalianAmerican Rights Leaguean energetic,, wellorganized and militant pressure groupreports that since its formation here nine months ago it has spread from its New York base to 19 states and that its membership and funds are rising steadily.

title: The politics of the sixties
description: OR the whole political season from the New Frontier through the Great Society and on to the New Revolutioncould be called The Age of Outrageous Paradox. The more elaborate insult probably would be more welcome to most makers and movers of the politics of the nineteensixties. They relished the taste of ornate verbiage. They sadly lacked any nose for the smell of cant.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ONCE, the makers of automobiles and their public got together each year to indulge in mutual admira tion without the intrusion of critics or the raising of discordant issues.

title: Nixon Plan to Tax Sulphur Content of Coal and Oil Meets Unexpected Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 President Nixon's proposal to tax the sulphur content of coal and oil as an incentive for re ducing sulphur oxide emissions has run into heavy opposition even before a bill goes to Congress.

title: Royals Win on Error in 11th
description: MEMPHIS, April 3 (AP)An error by Ted Simmons in the 11th inning today enabled the Kansas City Royals to gain a 65 exhibition baseball victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Planning Commission Approves Coney Island Housing Project
description: The City Planning Commis sion approved a moderate income housing project for Co ney Island last week despite Community Planning Board 13's refusal to endorse part of the plan.

description: Miss Elizabeth Ann Murphy and Stephen Thomas Whelan Jr. were married here yester day morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the.Rev. Robert Moher.

description: A new, eightlane West Side Highway, with trains in its median strip, possibly double decked under parks and hous ing projects, and open to trucks as well as cars was outlined yesterday by the city's Trans portation Administrator, Con stantine SidamonEristoff.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

description: To the Editor:

title: Was Kurt Gerstein a saint in Nazi clothing?
description: Remember Kurt Gerstein? Rolph Hochhuth, Pius XII, the ambiguous ties maintained by the Vatican with the Third Reich, do you remember? Kurt Gerstein was the one who, be fore anyone else, attempted to shake the socalled free world into action by revealing not only the existence but also the inner mechanics of the kingdom of night where the massacre of innocent people came to be con sidered a scientific accomplishment and the fulfillment of a moral goal.

title: Graebner Advances
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 3 (UPI)Topseeded Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., easily beat Mexico's Joaquin LoyoMayo, 63, 61, and Clark Graebner of New York downed Gerald Bat trick of Britain 63, 6.2, in the quarterfinals of the Caribe Hil ton tennis tournament today.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The accounting profession, currently engaged in an as siduous effort to recruit more Negroes into its ranks, issued a progress report of sorts last week.

title: Hadl Home From Hospital
description: SAN DIEGO, April 3 (AP) John Hadl, a quarterback of the San Diego Chargers, was dis charged from the hospital yes terday after being treated for multiple injuries suffered a week ago in a horseback riding accident. He suffered a frac tured skull, a bruised knee and a fracture of the floor orbit of the left eye. He underwent surgery for the eye injury.

title: DRUG CASE PUSHED AGAINST LAWYER
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 3 Narcotics charges against former deputy New York dis trict attorney will be pressed despite a dismissal of the case in a county court, officials said today.

title: Academy of Music Seeks More Brooklyn Bookings
description: The Academy of Music is trying to lure the Royal Shakespeare Company of Great Britain back to Brook lyn next year for an extended season of repertory, possibly for a minimum run of a month.

title: The More Detroit Changes....
description: DETROIT New is the most tired word in Automo hilese. It is a relative term: What is new to the ad agency may be quite familiar to the consumer, like steel guardrails in doors, new at one factory and two years old at another; or sun roofs, new here and long avail able in imported cars.

title: The Turners Shift To a New Category. Called Porno Soul
description: Ike and Tina Turner have moved from being a soul band with sensual overtones to being the chief figures in a now cate gory of pop music that can only be called porno soul. They still aren't any easier to describe.

title: Mothers Tour Bronx in Campaign Bus to Spread Appeal for Lost Sons
description: A private bus, formerly used in political campaigns was used yesterday to help two mothers search part of the Bronx for their 7year old sons, who disappeared from home 12 days ago.

title: L. I. Radio Stations Keep Listeners by Catering to Matters of Local Interest
description: Is the Long Island Railroad running today? How jammed is the Long Island Expressway? Has snow closed the schools in Amityville? Are the fish biting in Great South Bay? Is it a good clay for Jones Beach? Has anybody found a fat basset hound who answers to the name of Nell?

title: YELLOW FEVER CASES INCREASE IN ANGOLA
description: LISBON, April 3 An epi demic of yellow fever was re ported this week to be spread ing In the area of Luanda, cap ital of Portugal's West African territory of Angola.

title: Madison Avenue Unloads the '71's
description: It's hard to figure what those darned consumerists are hollering about. More in formative advertising, indeed.

title: Cuban Bus Plunge Kills 6
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)Six persons were killed and more than 20 injured when a bus rammed a bridge abutment and fell off a cliff in eastern Cuba, the Havana radio said today.

title: Art Notes
description: DOUGLAS COOPER, the British art historian, critic, collector and Cubiphile, bounced into town the other day to install his show, The Cubist Epoch, which opens Friday at the Metropolitan Museum. Full of a visit to his friend, Picasso, he reported that be fore the artist made the re cent gift of his rare, classic Cubist sculpture, Guitar, to the Museum of Modern Art, the museum had offered to swap him a Cezanne land scape in its collection. But Picasso declined the swap, and made the gift anyway.

title: Leafy Lettuces For Summer Salads
description: HOME planted lettuce is ready to eat in just a few weeks. To thrive it needs five or six hours of sunshine, fertile soil and constant moisture. Being small, lettuce plants may be tucked into flower and shrub borders or planted as edgings along driveways and in strips of land against the garage. Even city lots where the sun lingers can yield good har vests, especially loose leaf varieties.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was one of the greatest of all composers and probably the most brilliant allaround mu sician who ever lived. He was also a rather strange, bitter little man. There still are mys teries about his life, and there are even some about his death in 1791, about two months be fore his 36th birthday. His last days, working feverishly on a Requiem (commissioned under mysterious clrounristances) that he believed was going to be his own; his, penniless circum stances; his miserable death; the rainstorm that kept friends from going to the cemetery; his lost graveit is a story of pity and terror.

title: Kenyan Teaches Culture Course As a Student at Brooklyn Poly
description: Otieno Ooro, an instructor at the Brooklyn PolytechniC Insti tute, enjoys an unusual rapport with his students: He is also a freshman Student there himself.

title: Businessmen on L.I. Are Seeking Community Support to Combat Rising Incursion of Organized Crime
description: JERICHO, LI., April 3  (businessmen's committee is seeking to enlist community support in a new effort to combat an increase in crime in Long. Island's commerce and industry.

title: the traveler's world by Paul J. C. Friedlander
description: MIAMI BEACHThe stirrings of dust from the rising Disney World have made the past year a period of serious introspection and some worry 230 miles to the south in the established resort world of Miami, Miami Beach and all the other resort communities In southern Florida and on both the peninsula's east and west coasts. The question: What will this vast Disneypromoted amusement park resorttourist center do to Florida's major industry, tourism, and especially to that part of it situated south of Orlando?

title: School Heads in U.S. Beset by Disruptions
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 3For Dr. Wayne M. Carle, this city's 41yearold school superinten dent, the week began with an urgent call Monday at 6:30 A.M. that a broken pipe had flooded Colonel White High School.

title: Red Sox Triumph Over Yankees, 51, As Siebert Excels
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 3 (AP) Sonny Siebert checked the New York Yankees on four hits and Duane Josephson hit a home run and started a three run rally in the sixth inning as he Boston Red Sox posted a 51 exhibition victory today.

title: Curfew Changed in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)Curfew hours for American servicemen in Saigon have been readjusted to conform with the existing Vietnamese curfew. The new hours of curfew are from 1 A.M. to 5:30 A.M. local time in stead of from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Adrienne Anderson Is Married On Cape Cod to Michael Dawson
description: ORLEANS, Mass., April 3 Miss Adrienne Elizabeth Anderson, a reporter for Life magazine, was married in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit here today to Thomas Michael Dawson, a second year student at the New York Theological Seminary.

title: The Scarlatti Inheritance
description: What is the Scarlatti inheri tance? Well, if you must know, youll have to find your way through petrified forests of flashbacks to a Swiss hotel on the German border. Here, in a suite of exclamation points, we come finally face to face with Ulster Stewart Scarlett, turncoat, Nazi, gangster, inter national ratter, as he prepares to turn over his cached hoard to his heir: (Theycontain mil lions! Millions! But there are certain conditions . . you will learn to understand! When you grow older you'll know those conditions have to be met! And you'll meet them! . . Because this power is the power to change the world!)

title: Miss King, Rydze Win A.A.U. Diving
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 3 They came somersaulting gracefully off the ceiling of the United States Military Acade my's swimming auditorium to day in the 10meter platform finals of the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor diving championships. They knifed into the water with a neat splash followed by circles of ripples. Then came the scores of the judges.

title: MANY FINES PAID IN INSTALLMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 3  Judges in many of the nation's criminal courts appear to be granting poor defendants a chance to raise the money for fines that, if finally paid, will keep them out of jail.

title: For Young Readers
description: A mixup in the names brought a crate destined for the Happleton Zoo to the front yard of Farmer Appleton Hoo and he was not amused.  Can't a body have a cage of ba boons in the front yard without everyone wants to stop work? cried Farmer Hoo, smacking the hired man with the hoe again.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Cosmetic Step

title: York College Due to Move in the Fall
description: York College, the city's new est senior college, will move in September into temporary quarters in a renovated depart ment store in Jamaica, Queens, only a few blocks from the site of its eventual permanent campus.

title: HAROLD F. ROBERTSON
description: MERIDEN, Conn., April 3 (AP)  Harold F. Robertson, who held 44 domestic and foreign patents on vinyl resins, died Thursday night at a hospital here. He was 73 years old.

title: Britons Tell of Killings
description: SINGAPORE, April 3 (UPI) Some of the 102 Britons who were evacuated here by air yesterday from East Pakistan told today of the fighting and carnage they had seen.

title: A Job for Congress?
description: Pressures are building for fullscale Congressional deci sion on what the legal status of professional sports ought to be. Right now there are no clear cut, uniform regulations on what the relation should be be tween the antitrust laws and traditional sports Arange ments.

title: How to Compete With the Imports: Think Small
description: DETROIT  John Z. De Lorean, a General Motors vice president who is gen eral manager of the Chev rolet Division, was only kid ding when he recently told newsmen:

title: California Banks on Steam Power
description: LOS ANGELESBy Octo ber, three buses equipped with steampowered engines are expected to be operating in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Oakland. They will begin a test to determine emission levels, system efficiency, re liability and operating costs.

title: Hoad Reported Well
description: TORREMOLINOS, Spain, April 3, (Reuters)Lea Hoad, the tennis player, has been seriously ill with pneumonia, but he has completly recovered, close friends reported tonight Hoad runs an international ten nis training center at Fuen girola on the Costa del Sol re sort and coached the Spanish Davis Cup team.

title: MercedesBenz Truck
description: WASHINGTON  Buying tires for the family car is somewhat less perplexing than it was a few years ago despite the bewildering array of brands, lines and grades on the market.

title: Spring's High Water Beckons Canoeists
description: CLINTON, N. J.The swift current is carrying us along the river at what seems to be a breakneck pace and we are no sooner around the first bend than we are facing what all of the novices in the group and that is nearly everybodyhad dreaded the most: rapids.

title: 3 Indicted in Wildlife Importing
description: The Government filed crimi nal charges here last week against two companies alleged to have smuggled in of baby crocodiles of a rapidly dying Nile River species and plum mage of the gray jungle fowl an Indian bird on the verge of extinction.

title: LEEDS TRIUMPHS OVER BURNLEY, 40 Clarke Scores Four Goals for British Soccer Leader
Brazil Takes 2 Singles
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, April 3 (UPI)Brazil won both opening singles matches today in the South American Zone Davis Cup series with Bolivia.

title: Et Al.
description: How defense contractors mulct the Government of mil lions, by an assistant to Sena tor Proxmire who has special ized in the subject. Waste, he concludes, is not the exception but the rule. Good clean muck raking.

title: POLL FINDS NIXON AHEAD OF 3 RIVALS Has Him Leading Muskie, Kennedy and Humphrey
description: President Nixon holds an edge in public opinion over three possible contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Wanted: Queens Citizen Born March 19, 1896
description: The Queens Borough Public Library is searching for some one to help celebrate its 75th birthday during Nation al.Library Week, April 18 to 24.

title: Books:
description: Where to tax next? For many communities this is a desperate question, and Al fred Balk offers a long, de tailed, footnoted answer. He suggests new thinking about taxing the tax exempts  the churches, foundations, charitable organizations and clubs, colleges, publicly owned property belonging to states; cities, etc., that are exempt from property taxes.

title: Temple Takes 8Oared Race at Orchard Beach
description: Using a beat of 30 strokes a minute most of the way, Tem ple's varsity crew won the 2,000meter eightoared race of the College Club Regatta at Orchard Beach Lagoon, the Bronx, yesterday.

title: The Knicks By Red Holzman with Leonard Lewin. Illustrated. 246 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $6.95.
description: The New York Knickerbock ers won their first National Basketball Association cham pionship last year with some outstanding athletes and a bril liant coach. Dave DeBusschere was one of the very best of those athletes; William Red Holzman was the coach.

title: Photography
description: OLD quarrels fade away; the works that pro voked them sometimes survive to a new life in a new time. Such has been the fate of Frederick H. Evans's platinum prints, which will be on view at the Witkin Gallery, 237 East 60th Street, from April 7 through May 2.

title: Lett ers
description: Barnard Law Collier's article about Ralph Nader's teenage raiders (The Story of a TeenAge Nader Raider, March 14) is a warm and sympathetic story of the courageous undertaking of seven intelligent, dedicated and very wonderful young women. Per haps I should say thank you to Mr. Collier and The New York Times for the credit which the girls' accom plishments reflect upon their school. We are all proud of these girls and hope that their example will be fol lowed by a succession of graduates of Miss Porter's School.

title: The Nixon Revolution
description: WASHINGTON, April 3For a re porter who remembers the days of Robert A. Taft, the Nixon New Ameri can Revolution of 1971 sounds re markably like orthodox Republican doctrine of 1952.

title: QUEENS GROUPS FIGHT POLLUTION
description: The four children, in heavy sweaters and mufflers, trudged down the sloped pathway to ward the basement at 19605 65th Crescent Avenue in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens. Each was carrying a box filled with empty bottles and cans and it was obvious the load was heavy.

title: Letter to the Editor 21  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: S.O.S. for Casa Guidi
description: To the Editor:

title: More Labor Trouble in N.F.L.: Owners' Tactics Called Unfair
description: The National Football League Players Association charged yesterday that club owners had reneged on several provisions of their contract settlement and had used the threat of with holding pension payments in an attempt to force agreement.

title: Futility on Ice?
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs, exercises In frustration for Ranger teams since they last captured them in 1940, begin their run on Wednesday and could last, until May 20.

title: Stamps
description: A NEW magnifying glass from American Opti cal Corporation, South bridge, Mass., could be of interest to stamp col lectors.

title: Fulbright Warns of U. S. Decline Unless Foreign Policy Changes
description: NEW HAVEN, April 3Sena tor J. W. Fuibright foresaw tonight the decline and possible fall of constitutional democracy in the United States unless there was a reversal of a foreign policy based on what he de scribed as greatpower mili tarism and everincreasing powers in the hands of the President.

title: Bronx BusTheft Suspect Sent to Bellevue for Tests
description: A 60yearold Babylon, L. I., man was sent to Bellevue Hos pital's psychiatric ward for ob servation yesterday after he allegedly stole and drove a city bus from Harlem to the Bronx.

title: Christian Children Are Guests at a Model Seder
description: One hundred black and white Roman Catholic and Protestant children sat quietly yesterday morning with 400 Jewish chil dren at tables covered with sparkling white linen and laden with matzoh and other tradi tional Passover food.

title: 35,000 Attend Dedication of $45.Million Hitter's Park in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (UPI)  The city's $45mil lion Veterans Stadium was dedicated today and 35,000 persons turned out to watch the baseball Phillies and the football Eagles work out on the AstroTurf field for the first time.

title: JAMES F. M'GROARTY
description: James F. McGroarty, a pur chase inspector in the office of the City Controller, died yesterday at his home, 1157 East 29th Street in the Flat bush section of Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

title: TREASURY IS CALM IN DOLLAR SQUALL
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The United States Treasury is tak ing a calm view of the latest international monetary flurry, plans no special measures and expects no changes in the ex change rate of any foreign cur rency.

title: UNION LEADER URGES LABOR AIDE'S OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)  A union leader demanded today that President Nixon dis miss Arthur.B. Fletcher, Assist ant Secretary of Labor, on the ground that Mr. Fletcher hinted that White House action to curb wage increases was really designed to weaken unions.

title: O.T.B. Gives Aqueduct A TwoWeek Deadline
description: Howard J. Samuels, head of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday he would do business with outofstate tracks if no agreement is reached with Aqueduct in the next two weeks.

title: ISRAEL OUTLINES ATOUGHPOSITION; BERATES CRITICS
description: JERUSALEM, April 4Pre mier Golda Meir outlined a tough Israeli bargaining posi tion tonight, assailing her for eign critics, but promising serious negotiations as soon as the Arab governments, as she put it, show a readiness to talk rather than deliver ultimatums and threats.

title: Michelle Milikowsky Wed to Broker
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4 Miss Michelle Milikowsky, daughter of Mrs. Matthew Milikowsky and the late Mr. Milikowsky, was married here today to Richard S. Harman, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a vice president of Cohen, Simonson & Rea, Inc., invest ment bankers in New York. Rabbi Maurice Hecht per formed the ceremony, at the Milikowsky home.

title: COOPER AND CHURCH PLAN NEW MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) A new CooperChurch amend ment is planned and it will ask President Nixon to set a date for total withdrawal of all United States forces from South Vietnam, its authors said today.

title: Antitrust Study Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Davits, Re publican of New York, said to day that he would introduce a bill to set up a commission to make a twoyear study of Federal antitrust laws and sug gest ways of revising them. The commission, which would have 18 members from the ex ecutive branch, Congress and private business, would be asked to analyze the effects of antitrust laws on a wide range of business and economic fac tors.

title: Advertising:
description: Redbook magazine believes it has discovered a gap in the specialinterest women's field and is leaping in to fill it.

title: A Negro Teacher's Plight
description: BRUCE, Miss., April 4  Casie Bonner's dream got lost somewhere along the dusty back roads of Yalobusha County in Northern Missis sippi, and he doesn't know where to begin looking for it.

title: Keino Runs 3 : 58.3 Mile In Games at Trinidad
description: PORTOFSPAIN, Trinidad, April 4 (A)Kipchoge Keino of Kenya ran the first sub fourminute mile in Trinidad and Tobago today. He was clocked in 3:58.3 during the second stage of the Southern Games.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Killed in Snowmobiles
description: WILMINGTON, Vt., April 4 (AP)Two men were killed yesterday when the snowmo biles they were riding plunged into an empty cellar hole near Lake Whitingham. The police said the bodies of Raymond E. Penson, 44 years old, of Wil mington and Alfred W. St. Laurence, 42, of Northhampton, Mass., were fotind by a search party around midnight.

title: City Opera Sings Turn of the Screw
description: At a particularly poignant moment in yesterday after noon's New York City Opera performance of The Turn of the Screw, Maralin Niska turned to Robert Puleo, who portrayed the boy Miles in Brit tens musical ghost story, and sang: Youre growing up. And indeed Mr. Puleo is. The 15 yearold artist, who made a nonsinging debut at the Metro politan Opera at age 7 and thus has an 8year stage career be hind him, croaked his way bravely through the difficult part of Miles, showing all the signs of having undergone a voice change. At his age, of course, he was long overdue.

title: Lord & Taylor Planning a Capsule Store Near Boston
description: On Tuesday, 10 miles from Boston on Route 128, Lord & Taylor will begin a diversifica tion move of an experimental nature.

title: Squires Down Nets by 114108 And Take 20 Lead in Playoffs
description: HAMPTON, Va., April 4  Charlie Scott scored 8 points in the last 2 minutes to help the Virginia Squires defeat the New York Nets, 114108, to night and gain a 20 lead in the American Basketball Asso ciation's Eastern Division semi final playoffs.

title: TV: Henry James in a Fine Series on Channel 13
description: The heroine's name is nothing less than Fleda Vetch. The story revolves about the long overexposed peculiari ties of the rich, the merely wealthy and the indefatigable climbers. The author was a notable underachiever as a playwright. Yet his The Spoils of Poynton being pre sented in four weekly install ments on Channel 13, is quite simply delicious. The first in stallment was shown last night, it will be repeated to morrow.

title: Expos Cut Two Players
description: BRADENTON, Fla., April 4 (UPI)The Montreal Expos got down to the 25player limit to day by placing Jim Gosger, an outfielder on the 15day sup plemental disabled list and op tioning Dan McGinn, a left handed pitcher, to Winnipeg in the International League.

title: Tully Recital Given By Eileen Dickinson
description: If Eileen Dickinson had played her entire Tully Hall recital with the dash, vitality and rhythmic assurance she brought to the closing Sonata by Alberto Ginastera, Satur day would have been a highly satisfying evening.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On March 2, the day the Board of Education said it was dropping 6,500 teachers for lack of money, Mayor Lindsay announced the city would spend $24million to buy and improve Yankee Stadium. That seemed lavish, even inde cent, to some people because the city already had a modern stadium inhabited by the Mets and Jets, and needed money desperately for other things. It seems even stranger now, on the eve of the new baseball season, because it turns out that the Yankees never expected such generosity in the first place.

title: Swarthmore Critical of F.B.I.
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., April 4 (AP)The board of trustees of Swarthmore College, a liberal arts institution outside Philadel phia, has adopted a resolution criticizing the F.B.I.'s alleged surveillance of a philosophy professor, Daniel Dennett. The check came to light when newspapers received copies of documents stolen March 8 from the Federal Bureau of Investi gation office in Media, Pa.

title: Karyn Gullen Is Bride
description: Miss Karyn Helen Gullen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Gullen of Middle Village, Queens, and Joseph T. Browne were married yes terday afternoon by the Rev. Joseph Dougherty at St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Middle Village. The bride, an associate editor at Chelsea House Publishers, is editor of Billy Sunday Speaks, which was published recently. Her husband, a graduate of St Francis Col lege, is on the public relations staff of the National Football League in New York. He is the son of Mrs. John Browne of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Mr. Browne.

title: Knifton Wins A.A.U. Walk
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 4 John Knifton of the New York Athletic Club captured the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 50kilometer walk (about 31 miles) championship today in 4 hours 10 minutes 42 seconds.

title: Miss Ullmann Bride of Dan Miller
description: LOS ALTOS HILLS, Calif., April 4Miss Margaret Ull mann and Dan Eric Miller, project managers at the Hewlett Packard Corporation, were married here this after noon. Rabbi Benjamin Segal performed the ceremony on the lawn of the Adobe Creek Lodge of the Los Altos Hills Country Club.

title: Fulbright Assails Israel For Communist Baiting
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4Sena tor J. W. Fulbright, the Chair man of the Senate Foreign Re lations Committee, criticized Is rael tonight for resorting to Communistbaiting humbug gery in an attempt to manip ulate American policy in the Middle East.

title: ABORTION AGENCY DEFENDS BUSINESS
description: A state attempt to dissolve a commercial abortionreferral agency brought countercharges of political motivation yes terday from the agency.

title: To Outlaw Biological Arsenals
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom Flag Raised Here At Protest for Soviet Jews
description: More than 1,000 persons gathered at Dag Hammarskjold Plazaz yesterday afternoon and cheered the raising of a free dom flag for Soviet Jews.

title: Bullets Qualify to Meet Knicks
description: BALTIMORE, April 4The Baltimore Bullets, playing what Coach Gene Shue called a super second quarter, outscored the Philadelphia 76ers, 4322, then coasted to a 128.120 triumph in the de ciding game of their National Basketball Association first round playoff series today at Civic Center.

title: SALT Can Be Saved
description: The strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) in Vienna increasingly take on the aspect of men in futile chase of a moving train. Development and deployment of new strategic systems in the United States and the Soviet Union are going ahead more rapidly than the diplomats can negotiate agreements to control them.

title: Brakes on Mass Transit
description: President Nixon's proposed revenuesharing plan to promote mass transportation would be extremely en couraging if there were even a faint chance that the highway lobby would let it slip through Congress.

title: Dale Katz Is Wed
description: Miss Dale Andrea Katz, who expects to be graduated next month from Queens Col lege, was married last eve ning to Eric Lawrence Schatz, a Queens College graduate now with the Social Security Administration in New York. Rabbi David Gordon per formed the ceremony at the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Katz of Forest Hills, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schatz of Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Rock Makes the Academic Scene
description: Rock music, once just a throbbing sound that filled the voracious ears of the young, now has a history, a culture and an encyclopedia.

title: Baroque Dances Stir Interest Anew
description: Amid the turmoil of 20th century living in New York City, a group of musicians, dancers and just plain ama teurs is taking time out to dance the minuet and learn the sedate manner of 18th century court dance.

title: REST PERIOD SEEN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The money and capital mar kets will mark time for a while. Bond prices are not likely to move dramatically, either up or down.

title: L.I.A.C. Wins in Lacrosse
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 4 The Long Island Athletic Club defeated the Philadelphia La crosse Club, 186, today at The Hill School, for its fourth straight victory. Tommy Pos tell led the scoring with four goals.

title: DAMONE DROPS ROLE IN GODFATHER FILM
description: Vic Damone has rejected the feature role of Johnny Fontaine in the controversial screen ver sion of Mario Puzo's bestsell ing novel, The Godfather, ac cording to a spokesman for the singeractor.

title: Heath in Bonn for Talks
description: BONN, April 4Prime Min ister Heath arrive in Bonn to night to seek a stronger com mitment from Chancellor Willy Brandt for Britain's efforts to join the Common Market. The British Prime Minister had spent the day in West Berlin before arriving here for talks tomorrow and Tuesday.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: SAN JUAN, P.
