R., April 4 (AP)Cliff Richey of San An gelo, Tex., and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., gained the final of the annual Caribe Hil ton invitation tennis tourna ment today, while Mrs. Ann Jones of England and Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., advanced to the women's final. Nancy Richey Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., advanced to the women's final.

title: Books of The Times
description: A mood of autumnal stillness hovers over this work, one of regret for vanished beauties, for glorious moments that have disappeared forever. It is almost as if Harold Acton were writing not his memoirs but those of another whose life he knew he could never duplicate. Everything lies in the past: the art, the literature, the build ings, the experiences, the values, even the people. For Acton admits that those who have meant more to him belonged to an older generation: Bernard Berenson, Max Beerbohm, Norman Douglas, Osbert Sitwell among others. And even his nearer con temporaries, like Evelyn Waugh, were those who shared his feeling for a vanished time. Although Acton is partly American, it is interesting how he was turned off by an extended visit to this country after World War II. He could appreciate the dy namism of America, but he was not at tracted by it and certainly did not want to be swept up by its energy. There was more life for him in the museums, libraries and private collections of good friends than in the streets and alleyways of Chicago, for example.

title: RABBI BENMEIR OF KNESSET DIES
description: JERUSALEM, April 4 (Reu ters)Rabbi Israel S. BenMeir, a leader of the National Re gious party died of a heart at tack while attending the con vention a the United Israel Labor, party here tonight. He was 60 years old.

title: Calley Lawyer Wants Fast Action by Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 4George W. Latimer, chief counsel for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., said today that he was greatly encouraged by the announcement here yes terday that President Nixon would personally review and make the final decision on the findings and sentencing in the Calley case.

title: Short Shorts? Maybe Later, but First Leotards
description: A 14yearold girl attends with her mother, and there are plump grandmothers in their 70's. The women are nurses, secretaries, teachers, Seventh Avenue models, air line stewardesses and switch board operators. Along with a smattering of housewives, the current group includes psychologist.

title: Telford Taylor's View
description: An authority on internation al and criminal law who served as a prosecutor at the. Nurem berg war trials said yesterday that while the acquittal of Lieu tenant Calley would have been a disaster, the verdict of premeditated murder was opa que as well as harsh.

title: Une de Mai's Trot Victory Enriches Lottery Player
description: NAPLES, Italy, April 4 (AP) Une de Mai of France cap tured the 1971 Agnano Grand Prix trotting race today for the third time.

title: Esposito Sets Record of 76 Goals
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP)Phil Esposito scored three times to day and broke the 75goal bar rier as the Boston Bruins con cluded their recordshattering National Hockey League regu lar season. The East Division champions routed the Montreal Canadiens, 72.

title: MRS. W. T. DONOHO CIVIC LEADER, 50
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 4 Mrs. Laura Barney Donoho, first vice president and chair man of the executive commit tee of the Women's City Club of New York, died last night at her home, 912 North Salem Road. She was 50 years old and also lived at 262 Central Park West, New York.

title: Aubrey Burch. Weds Miss Dale L. Sinram
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 4 Miss Dale Leslie Sinram and Aubrey Edward Burch, gradu ates of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, were married this afternoon in the Brookville Reformed Church by the Rev. Robert Charles Harrah.

title: Alta Romeo Wins BOAC 1,000 With Ferrari Next, Porsche 3d
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, April 4 (UPI)  Alfa Romeo broke Porsche's domination of this year's world manufac turers' championship competi tion today in the BOAC 1,000 kilometer event. The race was won by Andrea de Adamich of Italy and Henri Pescarolo of France. They completed the 235 laps in 6 hours, 24 minutes 32.2 seconds at an average of 97.17 miles an hour.

title: Perkins Plays Piano Works by Takacs
description: An interesting program of 20thcentury piano music was performed at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon by Jerry Perkins. He built it around three works by Jeno Takacs, one of his former teachers, and one of the works, Four Epi taphs, gave the key to the program.

title: Rookie Wins Greensboro Golf Playoff
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4Brian (Bud) Allin, a 26year old redhaired rookie, crashed through to success in big league golf today when he won the Greater Greensboro open at the first extra hole of a suddendeath playoff. Sinking a 32foot birdie putt, the former Army lieutenant, who served 18 months in Vietnam, beat Dave Eichelberger and Rod Funseth after all three had tied with 72hole totals of 275 at the Sedgefield Country Club.

title: BORROWING COSTS ON DIVERSE PATHS
description: The cost of shortterm bor rowing has hit bottom and has started to climb once again, but longterm interest rates are still headed lower, the invest ment counsel concern of Lionel D. Edie & Co., Inc., predicted over the weekend.

title: Biblical City in Jordan Sought
description: HESBAN, Jordan, March 29  American archeologists will soon be digging here for the remains of the Biblical city of Heshbon, the Israel ites' first great military con quest on their way from Si nai to the Promised Land.

title: Miss Horowitz Jersey Bride
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April Miss Michel Ann Horowitz and Adoniram Van Bowen of Seminole, Okla., were mar ried here this afternoon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am sure that in the present civil war in East Pakistan the sympathies of all freedomloving peoples of the world lie with the Bengalis in that region.

title: HOUK'S MEN LOSE TO RED SOX, 148
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 4The Red Sox routed the Yankees, 148, today in a game that saw each team bang out 16 hits. The loss was the sixth in a row for the Yanks, who concluded a training schedule of 31 games with only eight victories.

title: China Breaks Silence
description: PEKING, April 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  China broke its silence on the Pakistan crisis today by citing, and apparently approving, President Agha Mo hammad Yahya Khan's protests against alleged Indian interfer ence in Pakistan's affairs.

title: WESTERN OILMEN FACING NEW TALKS
description: LONDON, April 4Inter national oilmen, relieved that the Libyan negotiations on higher oil prices have finally been concluded without na tionalization or interruption of supply, are turning next to Iraq and Saudi Arabia.

title: Senate Panel Says Federal Programs Fail to Meet Needs of Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, April 4A Senate committee report re leased today contends that Federal programs have failed to meet the needs of olden Americans.

title: Zukerman, at Last, Makes Local Debut
description: Since Pinchas Zukerman will not reach the age of 23 until July 16, it might be said that he simply had not found time to make his New York recital debut until Saturday night when he did it at Hunt er College Assembly Hall. He has, of course, appeared enough here and elsewhere in the world to establish him self as one of the great violin ists, and his total success on this occasion could hardly have surprised anyone.

title: 16 Seized as Youths Battle Police Near U. of Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis., April 4 (UPI) A block party held by more than 2,000 young people despite a city ban in a studenthippie area near the University of Wisconsin campus here erupted tonight into rock throwing and teargas battles with the police.

title: 270.5 Million TV Sets Are Tallied in 131 Countries
description: The latest figures on the in ternational growth of television show that the home screen now exists in 131 countries with a total of 270,502,500 receivers in use.

title: Arab Commandos to Order Their Men Out of Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 4 (Reuters)The Palestinian com mando movement today an nounced it had decided to order its commandos out of Amman to ease a crisis with the Jor danian Government.

title: SECURITY NATIONAL INCREASES EARNINGS
description: The Security National Bank reported yesterday that its firstquarter net income was up 30 per cent to $3,458,000 or $1.13 a share, from the year earlier $2,660,000 or 87 cents a share.

title: Sports and Goodby to All That
description: Once upon a time, the legend had it, there was a world that remained separate and apart from all others, a privileged sanctuary from real life. It was the wonderful world of sport, where every competition was endowed with an inherent purity, every athlete was a shining example of noble young manhood, and every owner was moti vated by his love of the game and his concern for the public interest.

title: Stars Set Back Chaparrals, 113101 for 30 Playoff Lead
description: DALLAS, April 4 (AP)The Utah Stars went three games up in their fourofsevengame American Basketball Associa tion West Division semifinal playoffs tonight by rolling to a 113101 victory over the Texas Chaparrals.

title: Man In the News
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 Today was not the first time that John Alfred Scali, a journalist for the last 29 of his 52 years, had made the news instead of simply re porting it.

title: Bucks Trounce Warriors, 13686, to Take Series, 4 to 1
description: MADISON, Wis., April 4 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks coasted to a 13686 victory over the San Francisco Warriors today, to capture their National Bas ketball Association's Western Conference semifinal playoff, four games to one.

title: Cambodians Withdraw
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Mon day, April 5 (Reuters)A mili tary spokesman said today that North Vietnamese regulars be gan a series of attacks last night and forced Cambodian troops to withdraw from posi tions on the eastern bank of the Mekong River.

title: Richard Rosenbaum Weds Lois Omenn
description: MILLBURN, N. J., April 4  Lois Peretz Omenn, who will study law at Stan ford University, was married here this noon to Richard Barry Rosenbaum, who will serve his interneship at the hospital of Stanford's Medi cal School. He expects to graduate in June from the Harvard University Medical School. Rabbi Ell Pilchik performed the ceremony at the Chanticler.

title: Janis Ian Returns To Rock at Bitter End
description: Four years after Janis Ian won a fleeting moment of fame with her song Society's Child, in which, as a knowing 16yearold, she sadly com mented on parental hypocrisy, she came back to town this weekend, singing a new batch of songs at the Bitter End. Society's Child is behind her now, so far behind that, as she told some listeners who requested it the other evening, she no longer remembers the words.

title: Mets and Yankees Beaten in Preseason Finales
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 4The New York Mets wound up the 1971 exhibition season with 15.12 wonlost record by losing to the Baltimore Orioled, 51, today and made the final ros ter cut before heading to New York for Tuesday's Shea Sta dium opener against the Mont real Expos.

title: Center of Venice Is Flooded
description: VENICE, Italy, April 4 (Reu ters)The old center of Venice unexpected flooded tonight when an unexpected rush of water raised the level of the Venice lagoon three and a half feet above its normal level. Water seeped into luxury hotels along the Grand Canal, bubbled up through the paving stones in St. Mark's Square and forced some Vene tians to take refuge on upper floors of their houses.

title: Sunday in Saigon: A Lazy Festivity
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4This Sunday in Sai gon started for some today with antiwar songs and a party in a dimly lit cafe and ended for others with Gabriel Faure's Requiem in the Ro man Catholic Cathedral and a Chinese opera on television. In between, most people passed the day trying with varying degrees of success to forget the Laotian operation, the rest of the war, politics and high prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gen. Maxwell Taylor writes [OpEd March 10]: Since our involvement in Vietnam there have been only three strategic alternatives from which to chooseito advance, to retreat or to stand fast.

title: A Pacification Adviser Charges Corruption
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4  United States offi cials are disturbed by a lack of information from American ad visers in the field concerning the real status of pacification in South Vietnam.

title: SOVIET SAID TO GAIN IN CONSUMER GOODS
description: GENEVA, April 4The pro duction of consumer goods ex panded faster in 1970 in the Soviet Union than that of pro ducer items for a third suc cessive year, according to a United Nations report pub lished today. It was the first time in the country's history of economic planning that ex pansion of consumer goods ex ceeded that of producer items for three years.

title: David Austern, A Lawyer, Weds Marilyn B. Bell
description: Miss Marilyn Barbara Bell and David Thomas Austern, were married here yesterday at the Pierre by Rabbi Ro bart Ciordis.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today.
description: April 5, 1971

title: One Dead, 3 Hurt in Clash Of West Coast Motorcyclists
description: WINTERHAVEN, Calif., April 4 (UPI)Rival motorcycle gangs in this small town on the Mekican border engaged In a downtown street shootout last night that left one man dead and three others wounded.

title: Advertising:
description: Ecology advertising ap parently has two phases. The first phase came from industries that have sinned, were sorry and are doing something about it. That was a rather negative phase.

title: School Board Seeks Inquiry Into Reading Tests
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scrib ner, acting at the request of the Board of Education, will inves tigate the conduct of the city wide reading tests given last week to 600,000 elementary and junior high school pupils.

title: FRANK REICHENTHAL, AN ABSTRACT ARTIST
description: Frank Reichenthal, an artist, died Saturday at his home, 197 20 89th Road, Hollis, Queens. His age was 75.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international tending agencies here:

title: Delusive Pension Protection
description: Not even the catastrophic effect on New York City's fiscal future of the meatax budget cuts just ordered by the State Legislature appears to have awakened union leaders in the uniformed forces to the necessity for some element of realism in their contract expectations.

title: Navy Bachelor, 19, Adopts 2
description: VANCOUVER, Wash., April 4 (AP)A 19yearold bachelor who has four years of service remaining in the Navy Subma rine Corps has adopted two children. Robert Sturdevant Jr. of Vancouver received court ap proval to adopt Stephen Donald, 3 years old, and Betty Ann, 5. They are the young man's nephew and niece. Their par ents' marriage broke up. The Navy man's own parents will take care of the children while he completes his four years with the Navy.

title: Fashions to Wear Winning an Oscar
description: LOS ANGELES  Despite the efforts of Edith Head, one of Hollywood's leading de signers, to help actresses pick in advance gowns they will wear to the movie in dustry's annual Academy Award ceremonies, a year rarely goes by that there isn't some sort of fashion disaster.

title: Bar Group Opposes Abolition of F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The antitrust section of the Ameri can Bar Association believes that the Federal Trade Commis sion had made great strides recently toward revitalization and should not be abolished or split into two agencies.

title: Abortion Law Protest in Paris
description: PARIS, April 4Many of France's most prominent women declare in a statement to be published tomorrow that they have broken the law by undergoing abortion. Among the 343 signers are the writers Simone de Beauvoir, Francoise Sagan, Violette Leduc and Marguerite Duras; the actresses Jeanne Moreau Catherine Deneuve Marina Vlady and Micheline Presle, the television director Fran coise Fabian and many others of outstanding career or family.

title: $750,000 GRANTED FOR AID TO ARTS
description: Grants of nearly $750,000 have been awarded by the Na tional Endowment for the Arts and the United States Office of Education for teaching pro grams by professional artists, writers, moviemakers and per forming artists in elementary and high schools in 44 states.

title: Honduras Back on Course
description: Honduras has successfully carried out the first phase of its National Unity Plan, a sixyear program designed to reinforce the country's social fabric while rebuilding a democratic constitutional system. In a remarkably free and peaceful electionthe first direct election of a Presi dent since 1932the voters have chosen the distinguished lawyer and National party leader, Ramon Ernesto Cruz, for a sixyear term.

title: A Famous Paris College Closed After TakeOver by New Left
description: PARIS, April 4  One of France's most famous colleges, the Ecole Normale Superieure, was temporarily closed today after its director had resigned in protest against its trans formation into a Red base.

title: Knick Wife a Bullet Fan, But Only Against 76ers
description: Geri DeBusschere has never met Gus Johnson, but in the last three seasons she has become an ardent rooter for the bruising 6foot6inch, 235pound Baltimore Bullet forward.

title: Liberty Ships Studied For Use as Factories
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)The United States' obsolete and idle fleet of old Liberty ships should be con verted into floating factories to, mass produce urgently needed prefabricated houses, a study carried out for the Government urged today.

title: U.S. Investors Find Gloom in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 4 The Argentine military has an nounced plans to beat a hasty retreat and once again return a badly mauled economy to civilian control.

title: Robert Livingston Johnson 3d Marries Miss. Sheryl Z. Bolton
description: HOUSTON, April 4Miss Sheryl Zoe Bolton and Robert Livingston Johnson 3d, grad uates of the University of Texas School of Law, were married here last night. The Rev. Richard Wheatcroft per formed the ceremony in St. Francis Episcopal Church.

title: City Aide Says Prepaying Won't Close Fiscal Gap
description: The city's budget director said yesterday that New York City would still lose about $100million already budgeted for the current fiscal year de spite lastminute legislative compromises intended to ease slashes in state aid.

title: Enemy Raids Cast Doubt on Claims of Success in Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 Professional American and South Vietnamese soldiers who have assessed favorably the re cent operations in Laos have been unpleasantly surprised by the last week's heavy enemy at tacks in South Vietnam.

title: Train Kills Postal Worker
description: A 52yearold post office em ploye was killed yesterday when he was struk by a sub way train after ho either jumped or fell to the tracks at the Wall Street and Broadway station, the police reported. He was identified as Richard Hill of 2979 Eighth Avenue. The in cident caused a half hour delay in service.

title: Screen: 2 British Girls:' And Soon the Darkness' Opens at 2 Theaters
description: When art goes wrong there is nothing to do but lament the loss. The failure, say, of "Zabriskie Point" is a failure in personal vision and it is not subject to correction. But when an entertainment goes wrong, all sorts of ideas spring to mind, for everything is subject to correction.It was therefore in a fever of vicarious creativity that I sat through Robert Fuest's "And Soon the Darkness," which opened yesterday at the Forum and Murray Hill Theaters, and which should have been a good movie.Two British girls alone on a bicycle holiday in France, deserted stretches of country road, a few small towns with roadside cafes, flat reaches of open field interrupted only by an occasional overgrown wood unpleasantly dark in the glaring light of the dayelements that the film puts to purposes of atmosphere and terror with considerable economyuntil it loses its purpose and squanders everything it has earned in a mad effort to preserve suspense.Ultimately "And Soon the Darkness" tries to keep you guessing by the expedients of disguising good as evil and of providing so many false clues that not even the fruitiest denouement (in fact there is no denouement) would justify them.Everything hinges on the disappearance of one of the girls, the suspicion of sexual assault, the inability of the other girl to make herself understood or to learn what the local people think and fear themselves. Until the disappearance and for a while afterward everything goes very well toward building tension with understated effects. But eventually, by mere repetition, the understated effects begin to look like poverty of the imagination. Then terror becomes a function of gratuitous camera technique, and danger the product of dishonest characterization.The minor characters seem unusually well detailed in "And Soon the Darkness," and because none of them speak English, the details merge into interesting patterns of frustrated hostility. The secondary people who do speak English (Sandor Eles and Clare Kelly) fare less well, at least partly because they must contend with some of the larger idiocies of the plot.I liked both Pamela Franklin and Michele Dotrice as, respectively, the prudent and the imprudent of the two girls. Pretty and a little plump, by no means glamorous, they are, if only for the matter-of-factness of their portrayals, exactly right for their parts. And Miss Franklin, who does the principal work in the film, keeps her mounting fear well the proper side of hysteria.

title: Spahr and Miss Vosters Win U.S. Squash Racquets Crown
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 Gretchen Vosters of Wilming ton, Del., and Kit Spahr of Haverford, Pa., retained the United States mixed doubles squash racquets championship by defeating Mrs. Terry Thesi eres of Cynwyd, Pa., and Ron Prickitt of Philadelphia, 1613, 158, 1512, in a 45minute final today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Nine Injured in Derailment On L.I.R. in Penn Station
description: Nine persons were injured, none seriously, according to the police, when one car of a Long Island Railroad train was de railed in Penn Station shortly before 10 o'clock last night.

title: Memphis Names Section Of Freeway for Dr. King
description: MEMPHIS, April 4 (AP) Memphis, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed three years ago, dedi cated a section of Interstate 255 that bisects the city to the slain civil rights leader today.

title: Yale Students Shower Fulbright, A Weekend Guest, With Queries
description: NEW HAVEN, April 4Sen ator Fulbright, should America try its leaders for war crimes? . . . Do you feel, Senator, that you can really legislate an end to the war?

title: Allende' s Coalition Victor In. Local Elections in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Monday, April 5The lefbwing coalition of President Salvador Allende Gossens scored a victory in Chile's municipal elections yes terday as, it won 49.5 per cent of the vote.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 404
description: MOSCOW, April 4 (AP) Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that the Soviet Union launched another Cos mos satellite, No. 404 in the topsecret series. Tass did not give the date of the launching, but apparently it was launched today. If so, it was the third Cosmos launching in the last four days.

title: Palm Sunday in City: Solemnity and Gaiety
description: New Yorkers knelt in hushed churches and gamboled in sun lit parks yesterday as Chris tians here and around the world began observance of Holy Week with Palm Sunday services.

title: Bengall Sailors Desert
description: PARIS, April 14  Thirteen Bengali sailors deserted a Paki stani submarine in Toulon after a near mutiny last week, it be icathe known today.

title: Baseball Season Opens Today in 3 Cities
description: The baseball season swings into action today with a Viet nam veteran substituting for President Nixon at Washington, several key players missing at Cincinnati and Richie Allen, the vagabond slugger, in the spot light at Houston.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: Miss Schwalm to Wed
description: HEWLETT BAY PARK, L. I., April 4Miss Catherine Stacy Schwalm, who teaches Spanish at Hewlett Elemen tary School, and Jakob Jenny, who is in the executive train ing program of the interna tional division of the Marine Midland Bank in New York, plan to be married next au tumn.

title: CANTORS ARE HEARD IN JEWISH LITURGY
description: There Is a varied and vital body of music for the Jewish liturgy; this was clearly shown at the concert of the American Conference of Cantors yester day afternoon at Tully Hall.

title: EDWIN LA CROSSE, 86, LAWYER AIDED DEAF
description: CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., April 4Edwin L. La Crosse, retired New York lawyer and for many years a teacher of the deaf, died yesterday. He was 86 years old and a former resident of Westfield, N. J.

title: Hewitt Beats Santana
description: DURBAN, South Africa, April 4 (AP)Bob Hewitt of South Afrida won the men's final of the Natal open tennis cham pionships today, defeating Spain's topseeded Manuel San tana, 76, 61, 61.

title: MONEY AILMENT IS HARD TO CURE Lands With Surplus Dollars Avoid a Run on Fort Knox
description: PARIS, April 4  After movement of billions of dollars into the strong currency na tions of Europe last week, Western monetary authorities faced the unenviable task of trying to head off a new finan cial crisis without being able to tackle the basic cause of the disturbances.

title: Carla A. Ammerman Wed to Mark Kutsher
description: Miss Carla Ann Ammerman was married here yesterday at noon to Mark Saul Kut sher, whose father, Milton Kutscher, owns Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N. Y. Rabbi William Berko witz performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Retrogression on Abortions
description: President Nixon, in ordering limits on the freedom military physicians to perform abortions, has pronounced abortion an unacceptable form of population control. He says he cannot square abortion on demand with my personal belief in the sanctity of human life, including the life of the yet unborn.

title: Ann Dubov Married
description: BAYONNE, N. J., April 4 Miss. Ann Dubov and Eric Merrill Shapiro, who are with WCBSTV News, were mar ried here this afternoon. Rabbi Morris Tosk performed the ceremony in Temple Beth Am. The bride, a secretary in the science and arts depart ments, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Earl Dubov of Austin, Tex. Her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Shapiro of Bayonne, is a di rector of news broadcasts.

title: STEEL OUTPUT HITS BOOM PROPORTIONS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 4Steel mills were producing and ship ping at boom levels last week.

title: Drysdale Tops Laver at Net
description: MIAMI, April 4 (AP)Sixth seeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa upset Rod Laver, Aus tralia, in the $50,000 Aventura tennis tourney final today, 6.2, 64, 36, 64, to win $10,000.

title: RANGER GOALIES CAPTURE TROPHY
description: The one honor that had eluded Ed Giacomin during his brilliant career with the Rang ers was finally his to share last night as the New Yorkers ended the regular National Hockey campaign by downing the De troit Red Wings, 60, and taking the Vezina Trophy for goalies.

title: Big 3d Quarter Helps
description: CHICAGO, April 4 (AP)The Chicago Bulls scored 28 points in the third period today to take control of the game and went on to a convincing victory over the Los Angeles Lakers, 11399, tying their National Basketball Association semifinal playoff at three decisions each.

title: Embattled Marines Yield a Beach in California to Sunbathers and Surfers
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 4  On orders from President Nixon, the Marine Corps began a retreat this weekend from a sixmile Pacific beachhead that it has been defending stub bornly for years against almost constant civilian attack.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ELMORE R. TORN DIES; AGRICULTURIST, 64
description: TAYLOR. Tex., April 4 (AP) Elmore R. Torn, an interna tionally known agriculturalist and the father of the actor Rip Torn, died Friday night of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Tank Bombed in Bay State
description: HAMILTON, Mass., April (AP)A tank, reported to have been used by Gen. George S. Patton Jr., was firebombed in the town square here last night. The police said the explosion had lifted off the welded turret cover. No other damage was reported.

title: New York's No. 2...
description: State legislatures, the old brown atones among our governmental struc tures, are being renovated, strength ened, spruced up and lived in again. After years of quiet deterioration and purposeful neglect, almost all of them are in constant use now.

title: Family of 270 Forsakes Coast for a Tennessee Hollow
description: PEGRAM, Tenn., April 2 his quiet hollow in middle ??ennessee is a long way from he windy hills of San Fran cisco, both in mileage and in style. But a family of 270 ??ersons has traveled here ??rom San Francisco with the ??ope of slowing things down, getting back to the land, according to its leader. More than 60 brightly painted buses and campers are parked on a farm here, with longhaired men and their women scurrying about, building bridges, planting seeds, removing debris.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: HOCKENHEIM, Germany, April 4 (UPI)Francois Cevert of France, driving a Tecno, sped to a 4.9second victory today over Graham Hill of Eng land in the Jim Clark Memorial race for Formula II cars.

title: Hughes to Propose Panel To Fix War Crimes Blame
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) Senator Harold E. Hughes said today that he would pro pose the creation of an interna tional commission of leading jurists to set standards for as sessing blame when innocent civilians are killed in a war.

title: Panel Battles Inattention to Inner Cities
description: WASHINGTON, April 4One day recently, Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma and a small team of investigators were visiting the black slums of At lanta, as many other teams have visited slums across the country since the mid60's.

title: The Male Menopause: For Some, There's a Sense of Panic
description: A 47yearold Madison Avenue ac count executive was talking:

title: The Cry of America
description: WASHINGTON  The, trial of William Calley is over; now is the trial of the nation. The camera swings from the impassive face of the man who pre sided over the death of some 22 civil ians. Now the glaring light rests upon the people in whose name and by whose power many thousand times that number have died in distant Asia. If at the courtmartial the agony pierced the Army, and one of its young lieutenants, now it is ours.

title: C.P.A.'s Plan Two Studies
description: The American, Institute of Certified Public Accountants have announced two groups to study ways at improving cor porate financial reporting. Fran cis M. Wheat, a lawyer for merly on the Securities and Exchange Commission, will head a group to study opera tions of the Accounting Prin ciples Board. Robert M. True blook, a C.P.A., will head a group to study aims of cor porate financial statements.

title: San Quentin Inmates Brawl
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 4 (UPI)About half of San Quen tin Prison's 3,000 inmates were locked in their cells today fol lowing a brawl in which two prisoners were injured. The brawl began when two inmates were attacked as the Saturday night movie was ending.

title: ENGLISH SPRINGER GETS 25TH AWARD
description: CHICAGO, April 4The top Winning dog of the year, a flashy liverandwhite English Springer spaniel, Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, keeps right on the victorious trail.

title: KELLY IS WINNER IN DINGHY SAILING
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 4 William E. Kelly of the host Club fleet won the Interclub Class championship of Larch mont Yacht Club's 31st annual spring regatta for Frostbite dinghies today after trailing by 30 points when the first eight races were completed yester day.

title: SKI INDUSTRY SEES NOVEL EQUIPMENT
description: A waterproof stretch fabric that breathes, afterski shoes in red, white and blue and snoopy sunglasses with ear muffs were among the items that drew the attention of dealers on opening day at the Ski Industries America show yesterday at the Statler Hilton.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: In the Johnson Administration, peo ple used to talk about the nun gap as a necessity in getting the United States out of Vietnam. By that they meant that there had to be a reason able period of time between the American exit and the first Communist attack on a nunin other words, the collapse of the antiCommunist Gov ernment in Saigon.

title: Miss Pilou Is New Mimi at the Met
description: Jeannette Pilou was the Met ropolitan's new Mimi in Satur day night's performance of La Boheme. Miss Pilu gave a neatly sung, affecting account of the role that left a generally pleasing if rather neutral im pression.

title: STOKOWSKI DIRECTS THE MAHLER SECOND
description: The performance of Mahler's Resurrection Symphony No. 2 in C minor led by Leopold Stokowski at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon had a strong ceremonial quality about it. It was as if the conductor was taking special care to em phasize the programatic impli cations of the work as it might be said to relate to the Christian Holy Week, which began yesterday with Palm Sunday and will end Sunday with Easter.

title: It's Howdy Doody Time Again at Fillmore East
description: Buffalo Bob Smith, the Howdy Doody man, worked his old magic last night to his old audi encenow grown up to beards, jeans and protest buttonsand they loved him at 20 as they had at 6.

title: Walid Akel Makes Local Piano Debut
description: Walid Akel is a pianist who clearly enjoys digging into music of rich sonority and fiery character. The three pieces on his New York debut program Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall gave him ample opportunities and the young Lebanese pianist made the most of them. opportunities and the young Lebanese pianist made the most of them.

title: STOCK FEES BEGIN PLIABILITY TODAY
description: Today marks the uncertain start on the New York Stock Exchange, as well as on most regional stock exchanges around the country, of the controversial Securities and Exchange Com missionordered negotiated com mission rates on large securities transactions.

title: Brown First in A.A.U. Run
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y. April 4 Barry Brown of the New York Athletic Club won the Metro politan Amateur Athletic Union 15kilometer championship run today at Scarsdale High. Brown was clocked in 45 minutes 47 seconds. Howie Ryan of the N.Y.A.C. was second in 47:34 and Tom Donohue of Manhat tan College third in 48.51. The N.Y.A.C. won the team title with 50 points.

title: Indians Charge Broken Colorado Pact
description: DENVER, April 4  Indian students, some from the Pueblos of the American Southwest and others from Alaskan Eskimo tribes, have mounted a protest in Colorado, charging that the white man's government has broken another treaty.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a result of personal ambition and a Classic sense of shortsightedness Senator Proxmire of Wisconsin and his allies have taken a definite step to ward making America a secondrate nation.

title: Vienna Runs 54 Municipal Ventures, Cradle to Grave, Many at a Profit
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 4 (AP)Cliff Richey of San An gelo, Tex., and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., gained the final of the annual Caribe Hil ton invitation tennis tourna ment today, while Mrs. Ann Jones of England and Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., advanced to the women's final. Nancy Richey Gunter of San Angelo, Tex., advanced to the women's final.

title: Flyers and Sabres Tie
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 4 (AP) Andre La Croix's two goals 2 minutes 15 seconds apart late in the third period lifted the Philadelphia Flyers to a 33 tie with the Buffalo Sabres to night.

title: Chess: Tal's Imaginative Strategy Shown in Estonia Tourney
description: Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union, a 35yearold grand master who was world cham pion during 1960 and 1961, recently tied for first in the 16man roundrobin interna tional tournament at Tallinn, Estonia, with Paul Keres, the famous player, at 114

title: Candidate Proposes People Vote on Bills by Computer
description: BOSTON, April 4 (AP) Charles C. McCarthy, 30 years old, of Newton announced his candidacy for the United States Senate as an independent to day. He said that if he were elected he would conduct a telephone straw vote by com puter on all bills before he voted on them. He will run for the seat now held by Edward W. Brooke, a Republican.

title: Lisbon Is Troubled by Growing Militancy of Workers
description: LISBON, April 4  Strikes, slowdowns and protest demon strations, still banned by law in Portugal, happen anyway.

title: Dr. King Is Memorialized Outside St. Patrick's
description: Members of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence held a halfhour vigil out side St. Patrick's Cathedral yes terday to commemorate the assassination three years ago of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the founder of their civilrights organization.

title: Six Major Auto Groups Are Shaping Up in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 4The Japa nese automobile industry, which was partially opened to for eign capital investment as of April 1, is expected to be re organized into six major groups three of which will continue to be fully Japaneseowned, while the other three will be partly owned by the American Big Three: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler.

title: U.A.W.'s Office Workers Bitter As They End 3Week Walkout
description: DETROIT, April 4The sec retaries and office employes of the United Automobile Workers go back on the job tomorrow after a threeweek strike against the big union, but Solidarity House may never be the same.

title: FOYT BEATS PETTY IN 500MILE DUEL
description: HAMPTON, Ga., April 4A. J. Foyt, the visiting fireman from the United States Auto Club, defeated Richard Petty by 1.8 seconds in the Atlanta 500 today. It was his second 500mile victory of the season on the Grand National circuit of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

title: Leftists and Rightists Clash After Lull in Reggio Calabria
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, April 4 (AP)Leftists and rightists fought one another with stones and firebombs to day in the first major clash in this city since the police crushed an insurrection in February.

title: Pakistan Radio Reports Seizure Of Nine Indian Arms Vehicles
description: NEW DELHI, April 4The Pakistan radio has charged that nine Indian vehicles loaded with arms and ammunition crossed the border into East Pakistan and were stopped by West Pakistani troops.

title: Army Unit Surrounded
description: JESSORE, East Pakistan, April 3An army division is holed up in barracks near here, surrounded by 2,000 East Pak istani fighters and about 500 members of the East Pakistan Rifles, a paramilitary unit.

title: MRS. DANIEL TENNEY SR.
description: Mrs. Marguerite Sedgwick Smith Tenney, widow of Daniel G. Tenney Sr., a formermer chant and trustee of the Bow ery Savings Bank, and mother of Federal Judge Charles H. Tenney, died Saturday at her home, 19 East 72d Street. Her age was 88.

title: NEWARK TEACHERS REBUFF PEACE PLEA
description: NEWARK, April 4 (UPI) Leaders of the Newark Teach ers Union today rejected pleas to end a nineweek strike to morrow, saying union members would not return to work until 347 suspended strikers were as sured of reinstatement.

title: U.S. Finds Soviet Speeches Cautious
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Sen ior officials of the Nixon admin istration regard United States Soviet relations as in an in determinate state in which minor irritants often tend to overshadow major political issues.

title: Norris and Pulford Standouts as Kings Defeat Canucks, 42
description: VANCOUVER, April 4 (UPI) Jack Norris played an out standing game in goal and Bob Pulford scored the deciding goal today as the Los Angeles Kings beat the Vancouver Canucks, 42, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Chicago Soprano Wins Met Opera First Prize
description: Barbara Pearson, a 24year old soprano from Chicago, won the first prize, the Mrs. Frederick K. Weyerhaeuser Award of $2,000, yesterday afternoon in the Metropoli tan Opera National Councils final audition. Second prize, the Gramma Fisher Founda tion Award of $2,000, went to Thomas McKinney, a 24year old baritone and the only male in the finalist group of 10 singers.

title: FIREMEN WARNED AGAINST STAGING A SICKOUT TODAY
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery warned New York's 11,300 firemen yesterday that he would suspend any who went through with a reported plan to stage mass sickouts to day in their contract dispute with the city.

title: DURYEA APPLAUDS DEEP BUDGET CUTS
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea declared yesterday that the deep cuts made in Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget had served notice that the Legislature has become a co equal branch of government.

title: Penguins Tie Blues
description: PITTSBURGH, April 4 (UPI) Christian Bordeleau's goal midway through the final peri od gave the St. Louis Blues a 11 tie with the Pittsburgh Pen guins tonight in one of the roughest hockey games ever played in the Civic Arena.

title: Neighborhoods: Between the Duyvil and the Bronx
description: For nearly a century, Mar ble Hill, poised on a rocky promontory overlooking the Harlem River, has straddled two counties. Its heart has been in Manhattan, but its 52 acres have been in the Bronx.

title: Australia Clinches Cup Tennis; Japan, Brazil, India Advance
description: Australia, seeking to regain the form that made the coun try a Davis Cup power for years, took an insurmountable 30 lead yesterday over Indo nesia in the Eastern Zone semi finals, The Associated Press re ported.

title: Egypt Says New Oil Discovery May Make Her a Big Producer
description: CAIRO, April 4The United Arab Republic said today that the important oil discovery made last Thursday in the desert west of Cairo might put the country into the ranks of major petroleum producers in the Middle East.

title: David Davis Weds Miss Thorndike
description: ARDSLEY, N. Y., April 4 The marriage of Miss Carolyn Thorndike to David L. Davis took place here today at the home of Mrs. Ashley Thorn dike, mother of the bride. The ceremony, written by the bridegroom, was performed by Judge John H. Norris of the Municipal Court of Irvington.

title: Appellate Court Backs N.Y.U. On Closing in 1970 Disorders
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that New York University need not refund tui tion for 19 days of classes can celed last May during student disorders over the invasion of Cambodia.

title: Ripon Society Chooses Hickel as Man of the Year
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., (AP) Former Interior Secretary Wal ter J. Hickel was chosen today by the Ripon Society as its Man of the Year.

title: Bridge : Only One Team Still Unbeaten In Double Knockout Tourney
description: Only one team remains undefeated in the Greater New York Bridge Associa tion's Double Knockout Team Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy.

title: COLONELS INCREASE SERIES LEAD TO 20
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 4 (AP)Louis Dampier hit four 3point goals and collected 28 points today as the Kentucky Colonels posted a 120110 vic tory over the Floridians and took a 2.0 edge in their Ameri can Basketball Association East Division semifinal playoffs.

title: Stage: Follies Couples, Years Later
description: The musical Follies, which opened last night at the Win ter Garden, is the kind of musical that should have its original cast album out on 78's. It carries nostalgia to where sentiment finally en gulfs it in its sickly maw. And yetin partit is styl ish, innovative, it has some of the best lyrics I have ever encountered, and above all it is a serious attempt to deal with the musical form.

title: Policemen Seize 17 Before J.D.L. Holds Hightstown Protest
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., April 4 Thirteen persons were ar rested today in nearby East Windsor and four others were arrested hereall on charges of possession of dangerous weapons  shortly before 100 members and supporters of the Jewish Defense League marched in protest against re cent cross burnings.

title: Personal Finance
description: Are your bills beginning to worry you a bit more than usual? It's no secret that the economy is still a bit sluggish, that unemployment is relatively high, overtime pay is falling off sharply while at the same time consumer installment credit is continuing to ad vancealthough by not very much.

title: Soviet Aide Suggests Leaders Should Hold News Conferences
description: MOSCOW, April 4A Soviet Communist leader has suggest ed to the 24th Party Congress that regular, highlevel news conferences might provide an effective way of getting im portant news and propaganda messages across to the public.

title: NIXON TAX ACTION CALLED ILLEGAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 4One of the nation's leading tax authoritles charged today that the Nixon Administration acted illegally when it ordered into effect, without any new legisla tive authority, a tax reduction of some $3billion annually for business.

title: LEAFS TOP HAWKS IN SEASON SERIES
description: CHICAGO, April 4 (UPI) Jim Dorey and Guy Trottier scored secondperiod goals to night to give the Toronto Maple Leafs an uphill 32 vic tory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Ryan Sees Something of Himself in O'Neill's People
description: The corrosive passions of Eugene O'Neill's autobio graphical Tyrone family hung over the nearly bare stage of the Promenade Theater like one of the playwright's por tentous harbor fogs. The four principals, Robert Ryan, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Stacy Reach and James Naughton, were seated around a table decorated with a halfempty liquor bottle, some glasses and a deck of cards, and were obsessively picking away at the psychological scabs that scrimmed them from healing insight.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, April 4 (AP) Seventy Soviet Jews have sent letters to the Soviet leadership protesting the arrests of 38 Jewish petitioners last Friday in the office of the chief Gov ernment prosecutor, informed sources said today. The peti tioners sought information on the fate of 20 Jewish prisoners held in an airline hijacking at tempt last summer in Lenin grad.

title: Tribal King Is Buried in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 4, (AP)Sir Edward Mutesa II, the. Kabaka of the East African Kingdom of Buganda, was buried in a lacelined coffin in the royal tomb here today to the pounding of sacred drums and wailing of women mourners.

title: Navy Spends More to Combat Submarines
description: The United States Navy spends $3billion a year on antisubmarine warfare, learning mostly, one captain said, how fast we have to run to stay even with the Rus sians.

title: 608 Copters Reported Damaged
description: SAIGON, April 4 (UPI) Enemy gunners damaged 608 United States helicopters dur ing the sixweek Laos offen sive, shooting down 104 of them, Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam told South Vietnam's Sen ate Defense Committee in a report made available today.

title: HitRun Driver Kills 2 Boys
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 4 Two 14yearold boys were killed here about 7:30 last night by a hitandrun vehicle as they walked along Bayview Road. The police identified the victims as Edward Scott, of 19 Bayview Road, and Robert Seelig of 4 South Bay Road, Amitville.

title: Beat Mass Is Conducted in Suburb of Warsaw
description: WARSAW, April 4The yard of St. Christopher's Church in the drab Warsaw suburb of Podkowa Lesna was jammed this morning. Like visitors to other Roman Catholic churches here on Palm Sunday, the hun dreds of worshipers held sheaves of pussy willows and dried asters, colorful floral con trasts to their sober clothes.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices turned mixed in mod erate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

title: The Endangered Mason Act
description: On the statute books of this state is a law to protect endangered animal species by forbidding the sale of their hides. Prominent among the creatures protected up to now are the crocodile, the caiman and the alligator. But if a sly attempt to modify the law, known as the Mason Act, is allowed to slip through the Legislature in its closing days, these reptiles will once more be in serious jeopardy.

title: YIELDS RISE AGAIN ON UTILITY BONDS
description: Yields on highgrade utility bonds moved up another notch yesterday, but institutional investors continued to remain aloof and the key new issue sold slowly.

title: Carnegie Commission Urges the States to Spur Aid to Colleges.
description: If American higher education is to survive the nineteenseventies and retain its present quality, the states must provide their fair share of resources and leadership for support and, development, the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education said in a report released yesterday.

title: Government of Uruguay To Purchase Private Bank
description: MONTEVIDEO, April 5, (Reuters)  The Uruguayan Government announced today that it was purchasing the Banco Mercantile del Rio de la Plata. President Jorge Pachero Areco ordered the Governmentowned Bank of the Republic to purchase the private bank. Until recently, it was considered one of the most solid banking institutions in the country.

title: Bert Gilden, Novelist, Is Dead; CoAuthor of Hurry Sundown
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 5Bert Gilden, who with his wife, Katya, formed the writing team of K. B. Giklen, which produced the bestselling novel, Hurry Sundown, in 1965, died yesterday of a heart attAck in Bridgeport General Hospital. His age was 56.

title: POINDEXTER TRIAL UNDER WAY HERE U.S. Alleges He Harbored Angela Davis for Weeks
description: A Federal prosecutor told a jury here yesterday that it would hear evidence showing that David Poindexter had harbored and concealed Angela Davis while she was being sought as a fugitive from murder and kidnapping charges in California.

title: LONDON MARKET DROPS SLIGHTLY
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly easier yesterday when institutional buyers failed to follow through on last week's climb.

title: More Americans Getting That Horne Away From Horne
description: BOSTON, April 5The early spring sun has opened winterlocked roads in upper New England, and a movement that seems to be developing into an annual event has begunthe search for a second home.

title: BENEDICT F. DOLBIN, A SKETCH ARTIST, 87
description: Benedict F. Dolbin, whose quick drawings of public faces won him fame in preHitler Vienna and Berlin, died last Wednesday at his home, 3746 85th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 87 years old.

title: 3 Die as Truck Hits Train
description: TULSA, Okla., April 5 (UPI) A trailer truck traveling at 50 miles an hour hit a locomotive and derailed a Santa Fe train carrying 15 Campfire Girls from Tulsa and 21 other passengers today, killing two girls and the truck driver.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Unregistered Weapon Ban Upheld by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of the Federal law that makes it a crime to possess unregistered sawedoff shotguns and automatic weapons and such destructive devices as grenades, bombs and rockets.

title: Railway Slowdown in Britain
description: LONDON, April 5 (AP)Commuters were affected today by a nationwide slowdown by Britain's 30,000 train operators, who are seeking more pay. Many scheduled were canceled and most of London's 556 morning rushhour suburban trains arrived late.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON MOST FUTURES
description: Heavy liquidation of commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday followed a decision by Canadian farmers to increase the acreage of some agricultural products this year. Prices of virtually all futures dropped.

title: Tara Suspension Lifted
description: TORONTO, April 5 (Canadian Press)The Ontario Securities Commission lifted today its ban on trading in shares of the Tara Exploration and Development Company an Ontarioregistered company. The commission said it had been satisfied the company would receive a mining lease on its property in Ireland. Trading was suspended Thursday.

title: ARGENTINE PESO DEVALUED TO 4.04
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 5The Argentine central bank devalued the peso from 4 to 4.04 pesos to the dollar this evening. The new rate, which becomes effective tomorrow morning, is the start of a new policy of minidevaluation by which the Government hopes to counter speculation against its weakening currency.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHITE NIGGERS OF AMERICA. The Precocious Autobiography of a Quebec Terrorist. By Pierre Val!Wes. Translated From the French by Joan Plethora. Monthly Review Press. 288 pages. $7.50.

title: Lockheed Meeting Put Off To July 6 From May 4
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it was postponing its annual meeting from May 4 to July 6. Daniel J. Haughton, chairman, said the company and its auditors had been unable to complete an accounting for 1970.

title: NIXON IS CAUTIOUS ON AID TO MOVIES
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 5 (UPI)A sympathetic President Nixon met with leaders of the economically depressed film industry today, but he gave them little hope of concrete help.

title: TREATMENT CLUE IN CANCER HINTED
description: CAREFREE, Ariz., April 5A husbandwife research team believe they have discovered the reason why cancer patients do not reject their cancers, even though the canerlike a transplanted heart or kidney  is foreign to the patient's body.

title: Indians Accuse Utility
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (UPI)The Pit River Indians accused the Pacific Gas & Electric Company today of turning the tribe's sacred river in Northern California into a series of stagnant, polluted artificial reservoirs.

title: Vietnam Peasants Return to a Hamlet, Hungry and Bitter Toward Regime
description: PHUQUI, South VietnamThe peasants of this hamlet have returned home two years after having been forced from their huts during an American military sweep, but their lives are, disrupted and many are bitter and hostile toward the Government.

title: City's Welfare Case Rise Less Than Predicted
description: The city's welfare caseload had a slowerthanpredicted rise in reports for February that were disclosed by the Department of Social Services yesterday, but officials were loath to interpret any slackening trend as yet under way.

title: Panthers Dismissal Move Is Turned Down by Murtagh
description: Lawyers for 13 Black Panthers on trial in an alleged bomb conspiracy moved yesterday for dismissal of all 30 counts of the indictment, but Supreme Court Justice John Ivl. Murtagh denied the motion.

title: ASTROS TOP DODGERS FOR DIERKER, 5 TO 2
description: HOUSTON, April 5 (AP) Larry Dierker scattered 10 hits and Denis Menke drove in three runs as they led the Houston Astros to a 52 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers in a National League opening tonight.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Hi, sports fans. This is Bill Bellclapper talking at you here today at the start of another baseball season. My guest on this edition of Dugout Gasbaggery is none other than W. J. Bryan 4th, the 22yearold sensation from Cal Tech who has been kicking this league in the shins ever since he signed in for a bonus said to be in excess of $3.5 million. They call you one of the new breed, W. J. Would you be good enough to tell our audience what that means?

title: Publication Director Named
description: Philip W. Quigg, former managing editor of the quarterly journal Foreign Affairs, has been appointed director of publications of the International Institute for Environmental Affairs, a private nonprofit organization. The institute, founded Jan. 1, plans to publish ae journal, a newsletter, reference work papers and studies.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: GERTRUDE KAPPEL, ONCE A MET STAR
description: BONN, April 5  Gertrude Kappel, a Wagnerian soprano acclaimed in Europe and America before her retirement from the Metropolitan Opera 35 years ago, died Saturday at her villa by the Isar River on the edge of Munich. She was 86 years old.

title: SELECTIVE ISSUES LIFT STOCK PRICES
description: Some sizable gains scored by specialsituation issues helped the stock market yesterday to scare a modest advance in moderately active trading.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert J. Poulin has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Glamorene Products Corporation, a subsidiary of the Lever Brothers Company.

title: A POLICE OFFICER WINS TRIAL DELAY
description: A State Supreme Court Justice granted a sixday stay yesterday of the Police Department trial of Lieut. Francis X. Ward, one of the central figures in a grand jury investigation of alleged police corruption.

title: A.C.C. to Allow Members To Play South Carolina
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 5 (UPI)Atlantic Coast Conferonce officials eliminated today la rule that would have prevented member schools from competing against South Carolina after it withdraws from the conference in August.

title: City Taxes May Rise, But Don't Count on It
description: Despite the possibility that the city's income tax rate will rise this year, residents should compute their 1971 estimated taxes on the basis of the 1970 rate, the City Finance Administration said yesterday.

title: Coast Petition Seeks 6Story Building Limit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April Alvin Duskin, a selfstyled pacifistanarchist, filed today a petition with the City Registrar's Office for a special election to prohibit construction of buildings more than six stories high.

title: 981 High School Students Win R.O.T.C. Scholarships
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)  The Army has selected 981 high school seniors to receive fouryear Reserve Officer Training Corps scholarships for the 197172 school year, Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor announced today.

title: When You Build Your Own House, It Helps to Have Friends
description: RYE, N. Y.,The rocky, wooded 2acre site on Mead Pond here could hardly be called wilderness. But it's the closest thing to it that Allan and Barbara Anderson figured they would find within commuting distance of New York and at a price ($10,000) they could afford.

title: Record Makers Score F.C.C. on Drug Lyrics
description: WASMNGTON, April 5 (UPI).An association representing the record industry condemned today as sunconstitutional a Government warning that radio stations were responsible for knowing whether or not records they played contained drugrelated lyrics.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert Kleiman's March 22 column brilliantly summarizes the pattern of mismanagement at the Pentagon which has characterized the last two decades. The emphasis on unreliable prestige gadgetry at the expense of unglamorous support items has indeed created a hollow shell of military capability, and at a cost to the country of hundreds of billions of dellars. Enthusiastic support for deployment of the ABM, the silliest gadget of all, by Nixon, Laird and Packard shows that the present Administration has no inkling of the incompetence of the military establishment.

title: New German Jet Displayed
description: BREMEN, Germany, April 5 (UFOThe first commercial jet plane produced in West Germany since World War II was shown to the public at Bremen airfield today. It was the VFW614, produced by Vereinigten Flugzeugwerke Fokker, a joint German  Dutch company. The jet, powered by, Rolls RoyceSnecma engines, seats 40 pas/ sengers, has a top speed of 450 miles an hour and a flying radius of 360 miles. It cost $158,479,448 to develop and will sell for $2.4million.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: City Will Get $65Million Model Cities Grant
description: The city will receive the second grant of $65million it had requested for its Model Cities program, it was announced yesterday in Washington by Senators Jacob K. Javits and James L. Buckley of New York and in this city by Representative Charles Rangel.

title: Foe Bolsters Force In Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5 Reuters)A Laotian Defense Ministry spokesman said today that the North Vietnamese were reinforcing their position around the royal Laotian capital of Luang Prabang and bringing in antiaircraft guns.

title: Steel Production In Week Increases To a Record Level
description: Steel mills in the United States achieved the highest production in history tlast week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES CUTS IN WELFARE Most Recipients Lose 10% Medicaid Also Reduced
description: ALBANY, April 5The Assembly gave final approval today to a series of bills restricting welfare and Medicaid programsincluding one to cut welfare payments to most of the state's caseload of 1.6 million people by 10 per cent.

title: Economic Lift Urged
description: DETROIT, April 5  Walter W. Heller, the economist, said today that the Federal Reserve Board had done its share in providing a base for economic recovery and that it was now up to President Nixon to act.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Theater Benefit Parties: A HowTo Session
description: WOODBURY, L. I., April 5There's a good deal more to running a benefit theater party than corralling a few friends. About 50 women who are tact, acquainted with that fact, but missing some of the details, attended a seminar here today and learned some of the tricksof running a successful theater party without losing money.

title: Who Pays the Bills?
description: The tentative settlement of the city's wage dispute with the Uniformed Firefighters Association would be no occasion for civic rejoicing, even if all danger had passed of its possible upset by the union rank and file.

title: Bridge:  Ralph Cohen of Montreal Joins Managerial Staff of the League
description: A managerial gap at the American Contract Bridge League, created when Richard Goldberg stepped up to executive secretary on the retirement of Easley Blackwood, was filled last month by the recruitment of Ralph Cohen of Montreal as assistant to Goldberg.

title: Nun Appeals Court Decision
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP) Sister Jogues Egan asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit today to set aside her citation for contempt of court for refusing to testify in connection with an alleged plot against the Government. Three judges of the Circuit Court upheld the contempt citation on March 2; it was on an appeal from that decision that today's rehearing before the full court was granted.

title: Advertising:
description: The ITT Levitt Development Corporation sells lots through advertising and with lots of advertising hopes to sell lots more lots.

title: Morodi Outpoints Vitale
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, April 5 (AP)Anthony Morodi of South Africa outpointed Michele Vitale of Italy in a 10round bout tonight. Morodi weighed 133, pounds, Vitale 135.

title: High Court Refuses To Hear Jersey Plea On School Prayers
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The United States Supreme Court refused today to hear a New Jersey school board's plea for the resumption of prayer reading in the high schools.

title: Horlen Is Sidelined
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (UPI)Joe Horlen, a righthanded pitcher for the Chicago White So; underwent surgery today to remove torn cartilage from his left knee, which was injured in a game against the Chicago Cubs yesterday. Horien will be out of action six to eight weeks, physicians said.

title: FIREMEN AND CITY IN TENTATIVE PACT ON PAY OF $14,150
description: A tentative contract agreement reached yesterday by the city and the Uniformed Firefighters Association would give firemen a pension at full pay after 40 years of service and raise the salary of a firstgrade fireman to $14,150 a year in the final stage of a 28month contract.

title: MAGNUS MAGNUSSON
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Magnus V. Magnusson, Iceland's Ambassador to the United States, died yesterday apparently after a heart attack while showing a friend the gravesite of President Kennedy in Arlington National Cemetery. He was 60 years old.

title: McGill Optimistic on Open Enrollment
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 5Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, said at a meeting here tonight that minoritygroup demands for increased college admissions did not foretell a conflict between equality and excellence.

title: Jersey Assembly Votes Welfare Cuts
description: TRENTON, April 5After nearly four hours of debate, the State Assembly gave initial legislative approval this evening to a $15million cutback of New Jersey's welfare payments program.

title: Telegrams by Mail To Arrive in a Day Under New Service
description: A service by which New Yorkers can send written messages to any place in the continental United States for delivery the next business day by mailman was begun here on a trial basis yesterday.

title: College and School Results
description: College and School Results

title: Knicks and Bullets Evenly Matched
description: Anyone who remembers Wit year's sevengame, firstround series between the Knicks and the Bullets, which started with a double overtime Knick victory and, ended with a onesided Knick decision, can expect another spectacular battle.

title: TV: Worthwhile Sunday
description: Sometimes the magic works, shrugged the movie Indian chief after his ritual dance fizzled, sometimes it doesn't. It is much the same with the rituals of television.

title: JULIUS PAIDER JR.
description: Julius G. Paider Jr., a law secretary to State Supreme Court justices here since 1945, was pronounced dead in BeekmanDowntown Hospital yesterday after collapsing in the New York County Courthouse. He was 68 years old and lived at 405 East 72d Street.

title: Trail Raided Again
description: QVANGTRI, Thursday, April 6 (Reuters)South Vietnamese commandos staged another raid today against the Ho Chi Minh trail in southern Laos.

title: Pacers Beat Pros, 9190, For 30 Lead in Playoffs
description: MEMPHIS, April 5 (AP)  A fourthquarter rally by the Indiana Pacers gave them a third straight victory, 9190, over the Memphis Pros in their American Basketball Association West Division semifinal playoffs tonight.

title: Brandt Promises to Help Bring Britain Into Common Market
description: BONN, April 5 (UPI)Chancellor Willy Brandt promised Prime Minister Heath of Britain today to do everything in West Germany's power to bring Britain into the European Economic Community.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Shop Talk
description: More and more designers of classic jewelry are turning their talents to the costume or fun look. Van Cleef & Arpels, that bastion of classic jewelry at 744 Fifth Avenue (between 57th and 58th Streets) is enlarging its collection of fun and decorative jewelry. The collection won't be in the main salon, but in the boutique, which is next door, at Bergdorf Good. man. Even the hippies have adopted jewelry, Claude Arpals, the store's president, said recently. It's been invigorating for jewelry in generalall the beads and necklaces they've been wearing:

title: VIETNAMESE POST FIGHTS OFF WAVES OF ENEMY TROOPS
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 6  A South Vietnamese artillery base near the Laotian border was reported under heavy shelling yesterday after having withstood waves of North Vietnamese ground attacks the day before.

title: No Substitute for Peace
description: The United States is again playing with fire in its unilateral effort to promote an EgyptianIsraeli agreement to reopen the Suez Canalan effort outside the United Nations negotiating framework for an overall Middle East peace settlement.

title: 97,881 ABORTIONS REPORTED IN CITY
description: City health officials reported yesterday that nearly 100,000 abortions had been performed here under the new state law and that the trend toward earlier, safer abortions was continuing.

title: Aid to Democratic India
description: The revival of hope for peaceful development in India under a democratic system offers a challenge to the United States and to President Nixon's pledge to support freedom around the world.

title: Colombo Lawyer Says He Was Sarcastic in Claim of Tap on U.S. Phone
description: A lawyer for Joseph Colombo Sr. and a Justice Department official were in basic agreement yesterday that the department's telephone had not been tapped.

title: Levin Official Resigns
description: Howard S. Levin, a co founder of the LevinTownsend Computer Corporation, re signed yesterday as director of the company and as chairman of the finance committee.

title: Solitron Devices Is Sued
description: MIAMI, April 5 (UPI)The United States Philips Corporation has sued Solitron Devices, Inc., in Federal District Court here, charging infringment of a patent covering alloy germanium power transistors with higheffieiency emitter electrodes.

title: Two More Drivers Added to Series
description: WESTBURY, L.I, April 5Peter Wolfenden of New Zealand and Gordon Rothacker of Australia were named today to represent their countries in the second annual world championship harness racing drivers series. They join Herve Filion, last year's winner, of Canada and Billy Houghton, who will be the only American driver in the series.

title: Spain Lowers Bank Rate
description: MADRID, April 5 (Reuters)The Spanish bank rate was reduced today to 6 from 6 per cent. The announcement said the adjustment was made to bring Spain into line with the reduction of other interest rates in the international finance markets.

title: 13 Accused Here of Torturing Girls To Force Them Into Prostitution Ring
description: Four runaway girls who came to New York seeking adventure were subjected last month to several days and nights of rape and torture in a Bronx apartment building in an effort to force them to become prostitutes, it was charged In Bronx Supreme Court yesterday.

title: ALBATROSS SOLD FOR $1MILLION
description: Albatross, a pacing champion of 1970, was sold yesterday for a record sum foi a 3yearold harness horse  $1,250,000. The announcement was made by Alan J. Leavitt of New York, who formed the syndicate to purchase the greatest money winning 2yearold pacer with 1970 earnings of $183,540.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Once upon a time the elephants, the lions, the tigers, the acrobats, the freaks, the clowns and the other appurtenances of the Greatest Show on Earth moved into Madison Square Garden and other activity there ceased. The circus muscled the Knicks, the Rangers and all their angry fans out of the arena, forcing the holding of playoffs elsewhere, sometimes even in foreign cities.

title: City May Use Private Refuse Haulers
description: The city, in an effort to offset the financial squeeze of sharply rising wage costs and meager productivity gains, is considering farming out part of the Sanitation Department's workload to private industry.

title: Pianist Talks  But the Subject Isn't Music
description: Lili Kraus is well aware that some of the things she says are at cross purposes with some of the things she's done. At 64 she has managed to combine a career with marriage, children and grandchildren, but she doesn't suggest it for others.

title: New Injury Hits Canadians
description: MONTREAL, April 5 (Canadian Press)  The Montreal Canadiens, already hampered by a groin injury to Jacques Laperriere and an ankle injury to Phil Roberto, wound up today's workout with Yvan Cournoyer limping from a charley horse following a collision with John Ferguson. The Canadiens open their playoff series with Boston Wednesday night.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Elder Beats Agosto In Felt Forum Bout; Verdict Unanimous
description: Jim Elder, a flatfooted fighter with deceptively fast hands, gave Pedro Agosto of the Bronx a sound lesson in heavy hitting last night in their 10round heavyweight bout in the Felt Forum.

title: CONGRESS DIVIDED OVER CALLEY CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI)  Members of Congress, crossing party lines, split sharply today over the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and President Nixon's plan to make the final decision on his punishment.

title: Nixon Back at White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) President Nixon arrived back at the White House today at 7:31 P.M., ending a 10day stay at the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Hernandez Bout April 22
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 5 (UPI)The 10 round middleweight bout between Tom Bogs and Art Hernandez of Omaha has been rescheduled for April 22. Hernandez asked a postponement last week because of an, ankle injury.

title: NEW RECESS IS TAKEN IN BOBBY SEALE CASE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 5  The judge in the trial of Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins today recessed proceedings for another week in the hope that at least one of the two ailing jurors would recover by then.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Article 12  No Title

title: Taxi Revenues Reported Higher Since Fare Rise
description: A spokesman for the fleettaxi industry here said yesterday that gross revenues for the city's 6,800 fleet cabs were up an average of 12 per cent for the month since the new fares were instituted, compared with the same period in 1970.

title: City Hall Once Madhouse Site; Some People Ask: What's New?
description: An archeological team verified yesterday that City Hall was built on the site of an 18thcentury madhouse, a fact long suspected by historians, some politicians and not a few city residents.

title: A Plan To Curb Inflation
description: WATERLOO, OntarioBoth Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers Union, and O. A. Lundin, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, have expressed objections to the WallichWeintraub incomes policy proposal to tax corporations which acquiesce in excessive wage settlements.

title: Pentagon Reports Chinese Sent More Troops to Laos
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today that China had reinforced its troops guarding a road project in northern Laos by about 3,00 soldiers over the last several months and further additions were expected.

title: Bold and Able Wins, Lifts Derby Hopes
description: Bold and Able of the Calumet Farm, a pelt who was rated high among the 3yearolds at the start of the year, reaffirmed himself as a Kentucky Derby contender yesterday by winning a sixfurlong dash at Aqueduct.

title: Drought Imperils Florida Everglades
description: MIAMI, April 5South Florida's worst drought in 15 years has parched the Everglades and sent scientists skyward in search of clouds to seed with rainmaking chemicals.

title: Charles Philbrick 2d, 48, Dies; Poet Was Professor at Brown
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 5 Charles H. Philbrick 2d, poet, author and professor of English at Brown University, died yesterday in Rhode Island Hospital after a long illness. His age was 48.

title: Yahya Appeals to Soviet
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 5 (AP) In a message made public here today, President Yahya asked the Soviet Union to use its influence to prevent what he described as Indian interference with Pakistani affairs. He asserted that India had deployed nearly six army divisions not far from the borders of East Pakistan.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special, Committee on Colonialism  Subcommittee on Petitions 10:30 A.M.

title: 12 ARE APPOINTED TO BUILDING PANEL
description: Members of Unit to Stabilize Construction Wages Picked

title: Stage: Olathe Response
description: There is one thing that can be said for The Olathe Response, which opened last night at the Actors Playhouse. It is the worst play have seen this season, and doubt anyone's ability to have seen a worse one.

title: March Net Inflow Rose For U.S. Savings Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters)Sales of Series E and H Savings Bonds were $135million greater than redemptions in March, the largest net inflow in 15 years, the Treasury reported today.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Ronald Davis, rankandfile delegate of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, states his case persuasively [letter March 25]. But his premise that patrolmen are abused holds no water. Patrolmen, when accepted for duty in the New York City Police Department, are asked to swear  to uphold the law and defend it. They are employed to patrol, protect, defend, arbitrate, soothe, coolas part of their duty. Surely Mr. Davis knew this when he took that oath of office.

title: College Sports Notes
description: A few runs don't mean a thing in college baseball in view of the typical pitching that is produced. Take the case of Syracuse when it played at Navy last Saturday. The game was called after 6 innings because of darkness. The way things were going the teams were lucky to get in an official game. Four Syracuse pitchers walked a total of 24 batters as the middies trotted to a 241 victory. But there is some good college pitching around, such as Coach Jack Kaiser's staff at St. John's. The Redmen hurlers, led by Mike Proley and Bob Hummel, tossed 34 consecutive scoreless innings over the weekend, enabling St. John's to extend its winning streak to seven games.

title: Gulf Pressed on Angola By Presbyterian Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 5A group within the United Presbyterian Church has asked shareholders of the Gulf Oil Corporation to prohibit operations by the company in all areas of the world that are under colonial control.

title: The Consequences of Laos
description: President Nixon undoubtedly is tempted to accent the positive as he draws up a new balance sheet on the Laotian invasion for his report to the nation tomorrow on further American troop withdrawals. Public optimism about the outlook in Vietnam has always been felt necessary by the Administration to justify the troop rundown, which Mr. Nixon has committed himself to continue at the current rate of 12,500 a month or faster.

title: Crowded Democratic Primary Seen for Manhattan Surrogacy
