description: Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, New York County Democratic leader, declared last night that, judging by the rate of party candidacies for Surrogate in Manhattan, all I can see developing is a helluva primary fight.

title: BIG BOARD IS COOL TO NASDAQ PLAN
description: The New York Stock Exchange told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that the concept of including listed securities in the new automated  quotations system for the overthecounter market called NASDAQ is inimical to the interests of investors and the concept of a central market place.

title: Senators Tale Opener;
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Washington Senators won their openingday game today for the first time in nine yearsan event of no small importance in this somewhat dispirited town.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Mother Marie A. Callahan, ExHead of Georgian Court
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 5Mother Marie Anna Callahan of the Sisters of Mercy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Trenton, who was president of Georgian Court College in Lakewood from 1948 to 1962, died yesterday at. McCauley Hall. Her age was 84.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 300,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)The United States Command announced today a reduction of 4,600 American troops in South Vietnam, dropping the total number to 301,900, as of last Thursday, the lowest since late summer, 1966.

title: Talk of Lakefiavasu City
description: LAKE HAVASU CITY, Ariz.When people move here they're like newlyweds. They're here to make a fresh start and they leave everything behind them, said Charlie Madden, who runs hardware store. They need everything. I sell more garbage cans here in a month than I sold in Kansas City in two years. It isn't hard to see why people who move to Lake Havasu City leave their old life behind, garbage cans and all. In 1963, this was 26 square miles of empty desert. As one early visitor said, You couldn't find two rocks piled on top of each other. The nearest town of any size, Kingman, was 60 miles away; the closest major city, Las Vegas, Nev., was threehour drive. The moon might have seemed more hospitable.

title: Goodyear Expects Dip in Quarter Net
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's firstquarter earnings will be very little less than the $32,296,000, or 45 cents a share, earned in the strong first quarter last year, but results for the full year are expected to exceed those of 1970, Russell DeYoung, chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Akron.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS CITIZENSHIP CURB
description: WASHINGTON April 5The Supreme Court ruled today that when Congress extends the right of citizenship to persons who are not granted that right by the Constitution, Congress can revoke that citizenship through residency requirements.

title: KNICKS, BULLETS TO MEET TONIGHT
description: Obstacle No. 2 in the New York Knicks quest of a second straight National Basketball Association championship will confront them at Madison Square Garden tonight when they oppose the Baltimore Bullets in the opening contest of a fourofsevengame series.

title: T.W.A. and United Seek Talks on Cutting Flights
description: Trans World Airlines and United Air Lines have asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to discuss ways of reducing flights on nine major air routes on which they assert that excess capacity was costing millions of dollars annually.

title: Convicted Marine Waits
description: QUANTICO, Va., April 5 (UPI)Marine Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz, convicted a year ago of murdering 12 Vietnamese women and children, reported for duty at Marine Corps schools here today to await some kind of discharge or a review of his appeal. Private Schwarz was sentenced to life imprisonment by a courtmartial in Vietnam, but the sentence was later reduced to one year, a dishonorable discharge and loss of payment and allowances. He was released last Friday from naval prison.

title: Chinese Now Represented  On Human Rights Board
description: Irving Shen Kee Chin, a highly scrutable Oriental, yesterday becaine the first person of Chinese descent to become a commissioner in the Lindsay Administration. The Mayor's researchers said he was the first in the city's history.

title: Bill Rates Continue Sharp Rise At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 5 Treasury bill rates continued their sharp advance at today's auction from previous week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: MRS. SALO BOCHNER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 5 Mrs. Naomi Weinberg Bochner, the wife of Salo Bochner, professor emeritus of theoretical mathematics at Princeton University, and now a professor of the same discipline at Rice University in Houston, died yesterday after a brief illness at Santa Monica, Calif. She was 60 years old.

title: Carl Mays, Yankee Whose Pitch Killed Batter in 1920, Is Dead
description: SAN DIEGO, April 5 (AP)Carl Mays, the New York Yankees pitcher who threw the fastball that hit and killed Cleveland batter Ray Chapman in 1920, died yesterday in El Cajon Valley Hospital. He was 179 years old.

title: QUEENS DISTRICT SEEKS BOOK BAN
description: Members of a community school board in Queens are seeking to ban the Piri Thomas autobiography, Town These Mean Streets, from school libraries in the district because, they say, it contains obscene words.

title: Argentine Leader Sees End Of Military Rule in 3 Years
description: BUENOS AIRES, April: 5, (AP)  The new Argentine military Goiiernment of President Alejandro Augustin Lanusse said today that power would be handed over to a constitutional government in no more than three years.

title: MARK BERNSTEIN OF WILIMARK, 82
description: Mark Bernstein, president of Willmark Service System, Inc., 443 Park Avenue South, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital at the age of 82 fle lived at 945 Fifth Avenue.

title: Two Flee to West Berlin.
description: BERLIN, April 5 (AP)Two East German youths climbed the Berlin wall yesterday and fled to the West, police in West Berlin reported today.

description: To the Editor: Robert Kleiman's column continues tq, perpetuate certain myths about Pentagon management of recent years. Is it possible that another version is more plausible?

description: OPELIKA, Ala., Aprii 5 (UPI) Lucius Amerson, the ??? black man to become a ??? in Alabama since ??? tion, pleaded not ??? ??? to a charge of ??? the civil rights of a black ??? who allegedly was ??? in jail.

title: Fund Type of Accounts Run by. Banks Is Barred
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The United States Supreme Court ruled today that banks might not legally create and manage what amounted to mutual funds.

description: MOSCOW, April 5As speakers drone on at the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party, foreign delegations have been fanning out to meet the workers.

description: LONDON, April 5 (AP)Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the world lightweight boxing champion, will meet Sugar Ramos of Cuba, the former champion, in a 10round nontitle bout at Wembley on May 11, promoters announced today.

description: Professional ski racing, which for the last decade has been unsuccessfully trying to get into the high income bracket, took a giant step upward last night when it was announced that purses worth more than $350,000 would be offered to Alpine stars next winter.

title: Merger News
description: Wells Fargo & Co., the parent company of the $6.2billion Wells Fargo Bank and Trust Company, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the $1.1billion First Western Bank and Trust Company from World Airways, Inc., for $95milion in cash and notes. World Airways bought more than 99 per cent of First Western's shares from the Greatamerica Corporation for $63million in June, 1968. The bulk of Wells Fargo's 275 branch offices are concentrated in northern California, and the bank's headquarters are in San Francisco, The Los Angelesbased First Western, by contrast, has most of its 95 offices in the southern part of the state.

title: Stock Trading Is Started Under Negotiated Rates
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which has survived wars, panics and emergency closings since its founding in 1792, weathered yosteltay its first session without the umbrella of fixed commissions.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5Repression, a fact of life in Brazil for the seven years of military government, has been justified as a tool needed to rebuild the economy and the democratic system.

Starr, director of the Oral History Research Office of Columbia University, yesterday appointed Alden Whitman, obituary writer of The New York Times, as consultant to his program. In the unpaid position Mr. Whitman will advise with Dr. Starr on notable Americans whose memoirs might be worthy of inclusion in the university's Oral History Collection. Mr. Whitman will also interview some of these prominent men and women for Dr. Starr's archive.

description: BOSTON, April 5  The fortunes of two Yankee pitchers born four days apart 26 years ago, took, markedly different roads today.

description: In The Book of Imaginary Beings by Jorge Luis Borges there are many strange creatures such as the Unicorn, the Hippogriff, the Wulfnik and the Basilisk. But there is no Jorge Luis Borges. What shall he be?

title: MISS CRAIG PLEASES IN CITY OPERA DEBUT
description: A few hours after the Metropolitan Opera National Council had announced the winners of its 1971 national competition, an alumna of the 1968 audition finals made her debut with the New York City Opera. Appearing as Mimi in Puccini's La Boheme Sunday night, Patricia Craig fit right in with the company's roster of fine young singeractors, looking the part as well as singing it with sensitivity and compassion.

title: Bank Bombed in California
description: BEN LOMOND, Calif., April 5 (UPI)A bomb exploded early today at a Bank of America branch in this western California village. Some business machines were reported damaged. Investigators said the blast had been caused by two sixinch lengths of pipe taped together and filled with black powder. The bank is a redwood structure.

title: TOKYO CANDIDATES CAMPAIGN IN COLOR
description: TOKYO, April 5Tokyo, the largest city in the world, is awash in election colorsblue and white for Gov. Ryokichi Minobe and orange, green and white for his challenger, Akira Hatano.

title: SMITH BEATS RICHEY IN FINAL BY 63, 63
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 5 (UPI)Stan Smith, on leave from the Army, played almost flawless tennis today and beat Cliff Richey in the final of the Caribe Hilton international tournament, 63, 63.

title: Maureen Forrester: Artistry in Song
description: Ideally, any solo musical performance should tell the listener a good deal about the performer, even when he or she is trying conscientiously to do nothing but convey the composer's intentions. Maureen Forrester's recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, part of the Art of the Lied series, proved the point. The Canadian contralto, supported by John Newmark's expert though rather sketchy and smallscaled pianism, drew her own artistic profile while doing nothing but justice to songs of Mahler and Wagner. She emerged as an artist of great honesty, directness and warmth, not unexpectedly in view of her past recitals. But Maureen Forrester as a ??? tamorist? Yes, that too. Among the six songs she chose from Mauler's Des Knaben Wunderhorn, two of the most successful were the broadly funny Des Antonius von Padua Fischpredigt (St. Anthony Preaches to the Fish) and Wer hat dies Liedlein erdacht? (Who Thought Up This Song?). In the latter, Miss Forrester's ease in sustaining the longheld notes was both literally breathtaking and charming. In the darkerhued songs such as Urlicht, Wo die schnen Trompeten blasen and Das irdische Leben, the recitalist's seriousness and cellotoned contralto captured the mood more predictably, of course.

title: PAKISTAN AIRLIFT ON FOR AMERICANS
description: NEW DELHI, April 5Scores of foreigners, including more than 100 Americans, arrived in West Pakistan today by emergency airlift from East Pakistan, where fighting was reported continuing.

title: McCloskey's Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, April 5Representative Paul Pete McCloskey Jr., the California Republican who has raised the flag of rebellion within the G.O.P. against President Nixon's war policy, leaves today for Vietnam. Asked why he is going, he replies, with quiet intensity, to get the facts.

title: Fordham Gets Crotty, School Basketball Star
description: Peter Crotty said yesterday he would attend Fordham in September.

title: Screen: Inscrutable 'Snow Country'
description: For two long hours, "Snow Country" unreels with three Occidental strikes against it The import is playing a two-day engagement, ending today, in the Japanese series at the Bijou.In any case, the film should only confuse many American viewers who believe geishas to be traditional prostitutes and also those who know them to be highly trained companions. The picture is a highly indigenous drama, based on a novel by Yasunari Kawabata (a Nobel Prize-winner, no less), that throws little light on its background, much of it being a geisha house, not to say the characters.Most of the time the rather petulant geisha heroine, played by Keiko Kishi, and her painter-lover, Ryo Ikebe, stare at each other fondly, quarrel or pad around in the snow bewailing the hopelessness of it all.Indeed it is hopeless, with skimpy English titles that are occasionally downright baffling. That's hitch No. 2, at least on this side of the Pacific.Finally, the static, fragmentary and clipped-off facade of the picture suggests that the esteemed director, Shiro Toyoda, has deliberately siphoned out the whole thing to suit himself or home audiences, which is admirably chauvinistic but hardly enlightening here. The picture is never moving consequently, as it sketches the tender affair of the principals. For that matter, it's hard to tell if the two key performances are low-keyed or simply listless. Personally, we were more intrigued by the fresh-faced vivacity of the supporting Kaoru Yachigusa.The picture is different, granted. If only more substance and simple clarity had somehow managed to seep through.

title: No Comnient on Fulbright
description: TEL AVIV, April 5 (AP)The Foreign Ministry declined comment today on Senator J. W. Fulbright's charge that Israel was using Communistbaiting humbuggery to pull America into a war with the Soviet Union. One official said privately that there was no point in commenting because it will only give Senator Fulbright more publicity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In connection with your March 21 article about gypsy moths and the concern over lack of means to control the impending infestation, I think my experience could be of importance.

title: 15 of 75 Black Artists Leave As Whitney Exhibition Opens
description: Fifteen black artists out of a scheduled 75 have withdrawn from the Whitney Museum exhibition, Contemporary Black Artists in America, opening today. Their action is in sympathy with a boycott called by the Black Emergency Cultural Coalition, a group of black artists that initiated the show nearly two years ago.

The group, led by Keno Duke, a drummer, includes two tenor saxophonists, George Coleman and Clifford Jordan, and a French horn, Julius Watkins, who Is returning to the jazz scene after three years of teaching.

description: Isaac Stern, who is of course not an unknown quantity, played a program of music that was far from unknown at his Philharmonic Hall recital Sunday.

Its broad didactic approach seems illsuited to contemporary audiences desires for psychological complexity of motivation. Choreographer George Faison, with considerable daring and success, decided to ignore the un written ban and create a dance melodrama, Poppy, for his program of works presented Sunday evening at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is probably correct to conclude that the prosecution and conviction of Lieutenant Calley are consistent with the broad principles laid down at the Nuremberg Trials. But it does seem to me very important to bear in mind that the accused persons at Nuremberg were not the Lieutenant. Calleys. They were rather among the most responsible policy makers in Hitler's Germany.

The latest twist in the Washington cause celebre is not merely the program itself but the matter of editing procedures in the print and electronic media.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Cannot something be done to keep bicyclists off walks and dogs on leashes? If not, add the leisurely Sun day stroll in the park to the growing list of simple pleasures no longer pos sible in our city.

description: PARIS, April 5Bonami, the favorite to win the French Derby, has suffered virtually the same fate as his American counterpart, Hoist the Flag, the Kentucky Derby choice.

title: Dayan Suggests Israel Keep West Bank
description: TELAVIV, April 5Defense Minister Moshe Darin indicated tonight that he favored the territorial proposals of the Na tional Religious party, which calls for the retention a the oecupled area on the west bank of the Jordan River, rather than the Policy of the ruling Labor party.

title: STRIKE BY TEACHERS GOES ON AT NEWARK
description: NEWARK, April 5 (AP)The Newark teachers strike entered Its 10th week today, but the union said it would be able to call a formal end to the walkout within minutes if the Board of Education ratified new contract.

title: Mills Backed for President
description: WASHINGTON; April 5 (UPI)  Automobile bumper stickers promoting Representative Wilbur D. Mills for President appeared here today, although the Arkansas Democrat denied that he would be a candidate. The source of the stickers could not be determined, although Representative James A. Burke, Democrat of Massachusetts, said they originated in Massachusetts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Narch 26 editorial oversimplifies a complicated subject. The pressure for no fault automobile insurance stems from the hope that the cost would be reduced via some mysterious words called no fault. Logic says that reducing amounts recovered via our present net economic loss system would result in the same drastic reduction as is promised by the no fault fetish.

title: ALLENDE IS GIVEN MANDATE BY VOTE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 5The municipal elections yesterday gave President Salvador Allende Gossens a popular mandate to push ahead with his revolutionary Socialist program, but he still must contend with an alert and vocal Opposition.

title: Man in the News
description: When a witness takes the stand in the large, walnutpaneled hearing room of the State Commission of Investigation here, he is customarily confronted by a lowkeyed man with a quietly serious demeanor, unflinching eyes and decisive questions. The interrogator, Joseph Fisch, is the 38yearold chief counsel for the commission, and for 12 years on its behalf he has been asking questions to expose wrongdoing and official misconduct.

title: Brazil Sweeps Cup Tennis Against Bolivians, 5 to 0
description: Brazil completed a 50 sweep In the American Zone Davis Cup tennis series with Bolivia yesterday by winnning the final two singles at Porto Alegre.

title: Advertising:
description: Are you the president of a company? Are you also young and decisive? Want to meet a couple of nice girls?

title: Ammunition Abandoned
description: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)South Vietnamese forces pulling back after their retreat from Laos were leaving thousands of unused artillery shells and other ammunition at bases in the northwest corner of South Vietnam until United States officers complained, informed sources said today.

title: Pirates Face Picketing Threat at Opener Today
description: PITTSBURGH, April 5. (AP)The Pittsburgh Pirates obtained a temporary injunction today against picketing by brewery workers that threatened the season baseball opener tomorrow at Three Rivers Stadiuni.

title: HAROLD FELBER
description: Harold Felber of 7915 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, a commercial artist and lithographer, died in Elmhurst General Hospital yesterday after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: State Investigator Links Corrupt Police to Heroin
description: The chief counsel of the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that police corruptien was one reason the New York Police Department's, war against heroin was a failure, monumental waste of manpower and money.

title: Three Seamen Given Haven
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., April 5 (AP)The Coast Guard said today it had granted temporary protective haven to three Greek merchant seamen who feared for their lives because they had informed the authorities that narcotics were aboard their ship, the Hellenic Spirit. The men, who wil be returned to Greece by commercial airlines, were identified as Kouzoupis Theodorus, Kazontzas Dimitrous and Tsmoulakis An ton ios.

title: OWEN AND MODELL IN N.F.L. DEFENSE
description: CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP) George Owen, former director of player relations for the New Orleans Saints, was the first witness today before Federal grand jury investigating the National Football League.

title: Princeton to Race Navy at 9Event Rowing Regatta
description: The intercollegiate rowing season began last Saturday. Brown lost to Cambridge University in rough water at Miami, with Columbia sixth;1 Princeton beat Rutgers for the sixth time in a row, and Yale bested Boston University.

title: Barezhnev Is Given Ovation As Congress Votes Report
description: MOSCOW, April 5The 5,000 delegates to the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party formally endorsed the foreign and domestic policies of Leonid I. Brezhnev's leadership today and gave the General Secretary of the party a thunderous ovation.

title: ClearCutting Defended by Timber Men
description: WASHINGTON, April 6In a second clay of crowded Senate hearings on forest management, representatives of the timber industry vigorously defended today the practice of clearcutting, both in the national forests and in privately owned stands.

title: INCENTIVE IS URGED FOR STEEL INDUSTRY
description: HOUSTON, April 6 (UPI) The American steel industry, which has lost the top 15 to 20 per cent of its domestic market to imports, will lose the incentive to expand unless the trend is reversed, an Armco Steel Corporation executive said today.

title: U.S. PULLOUT BY 72 SOUGHT BY HARTKE
description: PARIS, April 6  Senator Vance Hartke, a strong opponent of the Vietnam war, said here today that the United States could end its involvement in the war by setting date for withdrawal by the end of the year.

title: Nations Muting Comment on Pakistan To Avoid Inflaming the Trouble There
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Nations around the world appeared today to be deliberately withholding comment on the Pakistani Government's military actions in East Pakistan for fear of inflaming the situation.

title: BUSINESS TAX CUTS GET MORE PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Senator Edmund S. Muskie, and the National Welfare Rights Organization, in separate statements, joined today the growing protest against the Administration's recent order reducing the taxes that will be paid by businesses by some $3billion a year.

title: District Attorney Investigating Sanitation Union
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is investigating a charge that John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, has misused his union's funds.

title: Red Sox Top Yanks 34
description: BOSTON, April 6Throughout the Yankees miserable exhibition grind, Manager Ralph IIouk maintained an optimistic attitude by insisting, If we win the opener, no one will remember spring training.

title: Women Players Invited to Join $250,000 Grand Prix of Tennis
description: Women tennis players, who bolted the U.S.L.T.A. last year and were suspended for a short time for forming their own pro tour, found the welcome mat out yesterday when they were invited to join the $250,000 Pepsi Grand Prix.

title: Students Question Candidates for Post as principal
description: You wouldn't bar any kind of student activism then? asked the Puerto Rican student leader at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn.

title: W. R. Grace Expects Drop Of 10c a Share for Quarter
description: J. Peter Grace, chairman and chief executive of W. R. Grace & Co. estimated yesterday that firstquarter earnings would be about 10 cents less than the 35 cents a share reported for the 1970 period.

title: DETERGENT MAKER SUES ON LABELING
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 6The Lever Brothers Company, the huge soap manufacturing concern, has asked the United States District Court here to stop Federal Trade Commission proceedings on a proposed rule requiring detergent makers to list ingredients on packages and to display pollution warnings in advertisements.

title: Health Care Bill Held Up Over Fear of Loss of Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Health care planners said today that the Nixon Administration's plan to introduce new medicalcare financing bill that would Affect almost every 41pdrican has run into a major snag.

title: EUGENE F. MORAN JR. OF TOWING COMPANY
description: BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., April 6Eugene F. Moran Jr., a vice president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company established by his grandfather, died yesterday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 235 Lake View Avenue West.

title: Music Figures in Tribute
description: Tributes to Igor Stravinsky were expressed yesterday by prominent figures in music, ballet and other arts. Among them were:

title: TV: An EarlyMorning Appraisal of Galley Trial
description: It's all a matter of priorities. Yesterday the news department of the National Broadcasting Company offered a twohour program examining the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and a twohour priogram featuring harmless little studies of such subjects as quintuplets and fox hunting in England. One was on evening prime time; the other started at the blurred hour of 7 A.M. You have one second to guess which was on at which time.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The Soaring Sixties came to an end with the bear market of 196970, the failing stockbrokers, the Penn Central fiasco, the empty feeling of the airlines, the sinking spell in the (aerospace and electronics industries, the evisceration of advertising budgets, the climb in unemployment and the emergence of the uptight consumer. Was this the end of an era? Prof. Hyman P. Minsky of Washington University in St. Louis says it wasand that the Soaring Sixties have given way to the Sluggish Seventies. His thesis is that the longest economic expansion in our history, stretching from early 1961 until the autumn of 1969, has fundamentally changed the structure of the financial system, decreasing its stability and dampening its vibrancy.

title: GOVERNOR IS FIRM ON ABORTION LAW
description: ALBANY, April 6Governor Rockefeller said today through a spokesman that he would veto any bill repealing the state's liberalized abortion law.

title: MOST CITY FIREMEN WILL EARN $15,000
description: The average firstgrade fireman will make at least $15,000 a year as the result of fringe benefits negotiated along with the tentative contract agreement reached by the city and the Uniformed Firefighters Association.

title: Woman Dies in Jersey Fire
description: JERSEY CITY, April 6 (UPI) A woman was killed early today in her firstfloor apartment when a fire damaged half of an attached threestory frame building at 186 South Street here. The police tentatively identified the victim as Mrs. Jessica Bogoision, about 65 years old. One side of the 12family building suffered smoke and water damage, and its occupants were moved out.

title: G.E. Plans StadiumLike. Tower
description: If the General Electric Company has its way, the coming years will see hundreds of Shea Stadiumlike structures springing up all over the country. These would be cooling towers of a radical design that closely resemble the home of the Jets and the Mets but would be only onethird the ballpark's height.

title: POINDEXTER JURY HEARS 18 TESTIFY
description: Several witnesses testified yesterday that David Poindexter and Angela Davis traveled together as man and wife in Detroit, Miami, New York and Pennsylvania for almost two months before they were arrested here last Oct. 13.

title: CURFEW IMPOSED IN CEYLON UNREST
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 6A nationwide curfew was imposed on Ceylon today in what was described as an effort to stamp out terrorist activity on the island.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL RAILPAX SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)Some Senators threatened today to take away the Federal subsidy from the new National Railroad Passenger Corporation unless rail service through their states was restored.

title: Drought in Kenya Results in Famine
description: BARAGOI, KenyaThe skeletons of cattle littered the roadside near this remote village and cloud of vultures swarmed restlessly over the remains of a starved zebra.

title: RANGERS TO START PLAYOFFS TONIGHT
description: Having Tailed 12 times since they last captured the playoffs 31 years ago, the Rangers begin their 13th attempt to win the Stanley Cup tonight as they meet the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden in firstround competition for the National Hockey League's most valued prize.

title: 3YEAR B.A. ASKED BY STATE U. HEAD
description: ALBANY, April 6  The newly installed Chancellor of the State University, Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, proposed today the establishment of a threeyear program leading to a bachelor's degree and called for greater cooperation between public and private educational institutions in the state.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 7, 1971

title: BULLS DEFEATED BY LAKERS, 10918
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6 (UPI)  Gail Goodrich scored 29 points and Wilt Chamberlain hit 25 and picked off 19 rebounds tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 10998 victory over the Chicago Bulls and into the National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff final against Milwaukee.

title: A Look at Women's Lib in Suburbia: The Emphasis Is Different
description: WESTPORT, Conn., April 6Women's liberation in suburbia It's there, it's growing and it's different from its counterpart in the cities.

title: Bloodbath in Bengal
description: Washington's persistent silence on recent events in Pakistan becomes increasingly incomprehensible the light of mounting eyewitness evidence that the Pakistani Army has engaged in indiscriminate, slaughter civilians and the selective elimination of leadership groups in the separatist state of East Bengal.

title: DR. DAVID B. MONHEIT
description: Dr. David B. Monheit, a gastroenterologist in Brooklyn for many years, died Monday in Maimonides Hospital, where he was an assistant attending physician. He was 64 years old and lived at 860 United Nations Plaza.

title: Tiny Crack in Ohio River Bridge Blamed in Collapse Fatal to 46
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) A crack so tiny it could not be seen  and so inaccessible that it might have defied Xday detection  triggered the Dec. 15 1967, collapse of Silver Bridge over the Ohio River at Point Pleasant, W. Va., the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: U.S. Is Said to Plan To Replace Korry As Envoy in Chile
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Edward M. Korry, the United States Ambassador to Chile, will be replaced in the next few weeks by Nathaniel Davis, now the Ambassador to Guatemala, State Department sources said today.

title: Woman Shot in Struggle With Her Alleged Victim
description: A 23yearold woman, accused of attempting to hold up a guest at the Statler Hilton Hotel, was reported in fair condition yesterday after she was shot in the stomach during struggle with her alleged victim, the police reported.

title: Smoking Foe Sees AntiCigarette Trend
description: CAREFREE, Ariz., April 6 The director of the National Clearing House for Smoking and Health predicted here today that by 1975 only a quarter of the adult population would be cigarette smokers, compared with the present level of 36 per cent.

title: PACIFICATION PUSH BERIN IN VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The, most ambitious and costly pacification prograni yet planned for South Vietnam has been put into effect by Saigon and Washington.

title: The Nostalgia Backlash
description: The aim of art, wrote Aristotle, is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance

title: A Lake of Blood
description: I have recently returned from Laos, where I spent the last four years. During the last year we interviewed over 1,000 refugees from northeastern Laos and the four provinces in southern Laos through which the Ho Chi Minh Trail runs. They had left these P'athet Laocontrolled areas, which are today inhabited by an Americanestimated halfmillion civilians.

title: KING HUSSEIN GIVES FEDAYEEN DEADLINE
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April (UPI)King Hussein said tonight that Palestinian guerrillas must move their weapons out of Amman within two days or the result will be cruel.

title: Nixon Offers Bill to Settle Claims of Alaskan Natives
description: WASHINGTON, April 6President Nikon sent to Congress today a bill designed to settle the land claims of Alaska's aborigines, but native leaders said they would continue their fight in Congress for more land and other benefits.

title: Woman Oklahoma Victor
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 6 (UPI)  Mrs. Patience Latting, a wife and mother, was elected Mayor today, making Oklahoma City, the largest city in the United States with a woman Mayor.

title: HENDERSON SAYS CASE IS TAINTED
description: FORT MEADE, Md., April 6 (UPI)Charging the Army's case was tainted by improper procedures, lawyers for Col. Oran K. Henderson petitioned a military court today for records of the inquiry that led to charges he had lied to investigators about the Mylai killings.

title: 20 in House Seek Welfare Plan Giving $6,500 to a Family of 4
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  A welfare program that would guarantee a family of four an annual income of $6,500 was proposed today by 20 members of the House, including a dozen blacks and one Republican.

title: No Complaints to Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Senate leaders of both parties said today that they, had received no complaints from their colleagues about suspected F.B.I. telephone taps on their lines.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: War Crimes Testimony
description: ALBANY, April 6A small group of legislators sat impassively today as, one by one, a half dozen young veterans of the Vietnam war quietly told of their war crimes.

title: CONSUMER BUYING CONTINUES SURGE
description: Results of the latest consumer survey by the Conference Board indicate that the surge in car and home buying evident in the first quarter will continue well into 1971.

title: Suppressing Urban Realities
description: The efficially suppressed report on savings the City of New York could realize by gradually discarding its own Sanitation Department and turning the work over to private, competitive cartage firms exposes the cruel sham that surrounds current municipal wage negotiations. Prepared by Deputy MayorCity Administrator Timothy W. Costello, the report provides unintended evidence of the weakness with which the city protects its treasury at the bargaining table.

title: Black Artists on View in 2 Exhibitions
description: The Whitney Museum's new exhibition, Contemporary Black Artists in America, which opened yesterday, is not very black and not very good, but it has a couple of black spots that are very good indeed. A secone show, somewhat blacker and much spottier, called Rebuttal to the Whitney Museum Exhibition, opened simultaneously at the Acts of Art Galleries, 15 Charles Street.

title: House Panel Ties Pensions to Prices
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today a provision for automatic increased in Social Security benefits geared to rises in, the Consumer Price Index.

title: Suffolk Gunman Kills Policeman, Hurts Another
description: WYANDANCH, L. I., April 6 One policeman was killed and another seriously wounded tonight when they investigated a child's complaint that her father had shot her mother. The house at which the incident occurred burned to the ground after a gun battle between the police and an occupant of the house.

title: The Spoken Word Links New and Newer Music
description: One overriding factor linked all the music on the Monday night New and Newer Music concert at Tully Hall. That was The Word. All the music on the program was concerned with speech and speech patterns. That is very much in the air these days, and its stronghold is at the Juilliard School, where Luciano Berio teaches, and where he is training composers in this technique, and training musicians and singers to perform it.

title: Cambodian Troops in Clash
description: KOMPONG CRAM, Cambodia, April 6 (Reuters)Cambodian troops reportedly killed more than 130 Vietcong soldiers in a fierce battle today across the Mekong River from this provincial capital in eastern Cambodia.

title: U.S. TIES POLLUTION TO FOUR CONCERNS
description: PITTSBURGH, April 6 (UPI) The Justice Department charged three steel companies and a chemical concern today with polluting the Ohio and Monongahela Rivers in the Pittsburgh area.

title: BigCity Help for Rural Doctor
description: SALEM, Mo.  A Federal medical experiment under way here in this remote Ozarks town could mean better health one day for rural Americans everywhere and an easier life for their overworked family physicians.

title: EDMUND G. HADRA, A RETIRED DOCTOR
description: Dr. Edmund G. Hadra of 215 West 92d Street, a retired physician, died yesterday in a Manhattan nursing home at the age of 93 after suffering a broken hip.

title: Italy's Unions Confirm Plan For General Strike Today
description: ROME, April 6A daylong nationwide general strike, scheduled for tomorrow, was anticipated today by printers who walked out to prevent the publication of Wednesday morning newspapers throughout the country.

title: FLORIDIANS DEFEAT COLONELS, 120 TO 102
description: MIAMI, April 6 (AP)The Floridians used a withering fast break to wear down Kentucky, 120102, tonight and score their first victory against two losses on the road in the American Basketball Association Eastern Division playoffs.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Merger News
description: The family of J. Irwin Miller, chairman of the Cummins Engine Company, and the IrwinSweenyMiller Foundation said yesterday that they plan to still about 12 per cent of the stock in the company from their personal holdings. Speaking to stockholders at the annual meeting in Columbus, Ind., Mr. Miller said that the funds to be raised would be used for philanthropib activities and also to per mit the foundation to meet requirements of the Tax Reform Act of 1969.

title: Exchanges Seeking to Fill Saul and Lasker Positions
description: While stocks went up and the rains came down on Wall Street yesterday, a quiet search was taking place to fill key posts at the nation's two largest stock exchanges.

title: 3 Radicals Appear Victors In Berkeley City Election
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 6Three out of the four members of the radicalleaning slate appeared to be on the way to victory tonight in their bids for election to the eightman City Council.

title: Communal Group. Quits Its Farm in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, April 6 (AP) A group that traveled from California to Tennessee in the hope of establishing an agricu tural commune in unpolluted environment has abandoned its farm north of here because there was not enough tillable land.

title: Australia Beats Indonesia In Davis Cup Tennis, 3 to 2
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 6 (AP)  Indonesia's Gondo Widjojo beat Colin Dibley of Australia, 61, 46, 7.5, 6.1, in the final thatch of the Davis Cup Eastern Zone tennis series today.

title: F. B. I. Under Fire
description: For decades, under a halfdozen Presidential administrations, J. Edgar Hoover has enjoyed a carefully nurtured immunity from attack and even from criticism that only the most sacred cow in the entire structure of the Federal Government could ever hope to achieve; But as the Federal Bureau of Investigation under his leadership encounters increasingly heavy going on sev7 eral different fronts, his; durable public relations triumph seems to be falling apart.

title: Market Place: Taking a Look At Fanny May
description: Fanny May  or the Federal National Mortgage Association, if you spell it out reached a high yesterday and closed at that peak, showing a 2point gain at 72.

title: 2 Councilmen Call City Shortsighted on Law
description: The wearing of hot pants or miniskirts, or, for that matter, any garment that does not fall at least halfway between hips and knees is illegal in New York City, two City Councilmen discovered.

title: STOCKS STEADY ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed steady yesterday after fluctuating narrowly. British Government bonds declined partly on taxloss selling and also on the continuing sharp increase in the United States Treasury bill rates.

title: KOSYGIN PROPOSES ALLEUROPE GRID
description: MOSCOW, April 6Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin proposed today the construction of an electric,. power grid endompassing Europe.

title: She Takes Her Own Breakfasts Along
description: When it comes to food, Laura Archera Huxley makes shopping very difficult for her friends.

title: Freed Marine on Leave
description: QUANTICO, Va., April 6 (AP) pvt. Michael A. Schwarz of the Marine Corps, who was released from a naval prison last Friday after serving a year for the murder of 12 Vietnamese civilians, was granted appellate leave today and departed for his home in Weirton, W. Va. Appellate, leave Is a statua under which no duty is imposed and no pays is granted.

title: Executive Changes
description: A shifting of directors at the Rheingold Corporation was disclosed yesterday. Edgar M. Bronfman, president of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc., has resigned and William J. Green, chairman of the Clevepak Corporation has announced he will not run for reelection. They will be replaced if the nominations go through by Sheldon R. Coons, an independent business consultant, and Fred R. Sullivan, chairman and chief executive officer of Walter Kidde & Co. Both of the resigning directors at Rheingold said that other business interests kept them from devoting the time they believed they should to the diversified brewery. Mr. Bronfman He said he was thinking of reducing his holdings said he owns about 169,000 shares of Rheingold but has not in sold any. He pointed out that the company is in a good financial position. Mr. Green has held about 22,000 shares but sold the bulk them in 1969 and last year.

title: Igor Stravinsky: An Inirentor of Music Whose Works Created a Revolution
description: During World War 1, Igor Stravinsky was asked by a guard at the French border to declare his profession. An inventor of music, he said.

title: PAKISTANI LEADER PLANS NEW TALKS WITH EAST'S AIDES
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 6  President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan has told the Soviet Union that he intends to start talks with rational representative elements in East Pakistan at the earliest opportunity.

title: Nixon Abortion Stand Assailed By Planned Parenthood Doctors
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., April 6 President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller of New York were sharply criticized today for their stands on abortion by the Arnerican Association of Planned Parenthood Physicians.

title: The Making of the Annual City Expense Budget
description: Mayor Lindsay and a handful of his most powerful commissioners are now in the midst of an annually recurring clash of interests that  in a thousand ways goes to the root of prosperity of individuals, and relation of classes and the strength of kingdoms.

title: KILLEN PRESENTS ENGLISH BALLADS
description: Lou Killen, who has been touring for several weeks as one of the Clancy Brothers (replacing Bobby Clancy), paused on his way back to England Monday night to give a memorable recital at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: Foe Seizes Posts in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6 (AP) North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces have overrun seven Government positions in northern Laos, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS TRADING RISES
description: The pace of trading picked up and prices gained yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The market opened stronger and improved during the day. The Amex index closed up 0.08 at 26.30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: City administrations periodically eye the commuter as a new source, of funds, claiming they are not paying for the services they receive. Poppycock. They do not work in a vacuum, but in commercial or industrial buildings upon which enormous taxes are paid, far greater than the few expenses that can be allocated to the commuters there, or to the building itself. These taxes do not educate their children, protect their homes or remove their sewage and trash; for these services they pay ample taxes in their home communities.

title: U.S. TOBACCO SEES PROFIT RISE OF 15%
description: Firstquarter sales and earnings of the United States Tobacco Company will be reported up at least 15 per cent, based on results of the first two months, Louis A. Bantle, president, estimated in a statement read to shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Flemington, N.J. Mr. Bantle, who is recovering from a minor operation, was not present.

title: 4 IN HOUSE PLAN HEARINGS ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 6A group of liberal House Democrats announced plans today to conduct public, informal nearings into the command responsibility for United States war atrocities in Vietnam.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Council, in Angry Session, Adds 6 Members to Elections Board
description: Despite charges of patronage and blatant porkbarrel legislation, the City Council yesterday approved, With only one vote to spare, expanding the bard of Elections by six members.

title: About Motor Sports
description: ATLANTA, April 6  The rich get richer in this sport, while the paying customer continues to function as a doormat. In Sunday's Atlanta 500 for latemodel stock cars the race start was stalled 20 minutes and the scoreboard was as accurate as a stopped clock. The race was scheduled to start at 1:30 P.M.so that the fans could be on their way home shortly af ter 5 o'clock. But at 1:30 P.M.the race drivers had not even started their engines. At first the track announcer spoke vaguely of a delay; next he said the fire trucks needed on the track were fighting a grass fire on the grounds. By a strange coincidence the trucks appeared at their stations at 1:50 P.M.

title: MexicanAmericans Win
description: CRYSTAL CITY, Tex., April 6La Raza Unida, a militant MexicanAmerican party, gained unanimous control of Crystal City's city hall in municipal elections today.

title: ENSEMBLE IS HEARD IN RUYNEMAN WORK
description: The New Amsterdam Ensemble, which always gives at least one new work by a Dutch composer on its programs, offered Daniel Ruyneman's Reflextions No. 2 at its Carnegie Recital Hall concert Monday night.

title: Union Pacific, Eastern Gas Form CoalMining Venture
description: The Union, Pacific Corporation and Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates have formed a joint concern, the Rocky Mountain Associated Coal Corporation, to develop the Union Pacific's Rocky Mountain lowsulphur coal reserves.

title: Divided Pakistan Was Born From Shaky Abstraction
description: The idea of Pakistan, of nation built on a shared faith in Islam and fear of India's vast Hindu majority, was an abstraction from the beginning.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Students to Protest Wad
description: The organizations were the Student Mobilization Committee, the National Student Association and the Association of Student Governments.

title: The Guggenheim Cancels Haacke's Show
description: Because of policies that exclude active engagement toward social and political ends, the Guggenhean Museum has canceled an exhibition by Hans Haacke, the artist, scheduled to open April 30.

title: 3 HELD IN NASSAU ON DRUG CHARGES
description: FREEPORT, L. I., April 6Detectives from the Nassau County District Attorney's office and Federal narcotics agent's arrested three West Coast men here today and charged them with the sale and possession of 270 pounds of highgrade marijuana valued at $270,600.

title: 25.5% Profit Rise for Quarter Reported by First National City
description: The First National City Corporation, parent company New York's largest bank, the First National City Bank, yesterday reported income before securities transactions in the first quarter of $43.1million, or 79 cents a share, up 25.5 per cent from the $34.3million, or 63 cents a share earned in the same period last year.

title: $500,000 Jury Award Cut In Half in LionBite Case
description: A $500,000 jury award to a Manhattan model for injuries suffered when she was bitten by a lion at the 1966 International Auto Show was reduced yesterday to $250,000.

title: COLLEAGUES OFFER TRIBUTES TO BURNS
description: A warm, vivid portrait of the late David Burns, who died after a heart attack suffered onstage at the Forrest Theater in Philadelphia on March 12 during the second act of the musical, 70, Girls, 70 was drawn yesterday afternoon by the men and women who had worked with him and those who knew him.

title: Former Broker Is Indicted On StolenSecurity Charge
description: Alfred Peter Avasso of Howard Beach, Queens, a former( floor broker at the American Stock Exchange, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of transporting stolen Government Securities.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Moriarty; Taught Physical Education
description: NAPLES, Me., April 6Mrs. Elizabeth Richards Moriarty, who taught physical education at Smith College and was assistant director of Camp Accomac in Bridgton from 1914 to 1952, died yesterday in Northetn Cumberland Memorial Hospital, Bridgton, after a heart attack, She was 82 years old old.

title: Inco Tries to Cut Turnover in Mining Town
description: THOMPSON, ManitobaThe breakfast customers in Ken's Restaurant are nearly all young men in work clothes. In the supermarket, they outnumber women shoppers.

title: Defense Opens in Trial of 13 Panthers
description: The defense in the trial of 13 Black Panthers accused of a bomb conspiracy opened its case yesterday with witnesses called on behalf of 33yearold Robert Collier, former staff director of the Tompkins Square Community Center on the Lower East Side.

title: Knicks Turn Back Bullets In Opener Here, 112111
description: By the narrowest of margins in a magnificent game, the New York Knicks won the opener of their fourofseven; game Series with the Baltimore Bullets last night at Madison Square Garden, 112111.

title: South Vietnamese Commandos Attack Enemy Base in Laos in a 10Hour Raid
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 7 (AP)Two hundred South Vietnamese commandos were landed in Laos behind a smoke screen yesterday for a 10hour attack on base area on the enemy's supplytrail network.

title: March Parking Fines a Record
description: The city's ninemonthold Parking Violations Bureau collected almost $3.9million in parking fines last month, a record for the bureau and for the city, Transportation Adrninistrator Constantine SidamonEristoff said in an interview yesterday.

title: DOLLAR PRESSURE APPEARS EASING
description: PARIS, April 6 Monetary authorities, denying the need for parity changes while acting to promote a better balance in international interest rates, appeared so far this week to have contained some of the pressures against the dollar.

title: Kansas Votes for 18's
description: TOPEKA, Kan., April 6 (AP) Kansas residents decided today to lower the voting age in their state to 18. With 1,454 of the state's 2,890 precincts reporting, a state constitutional amendment giving the vote in state and local elections to persons between 18 and 21 was leading, 127,315 to 75,260 opposed.

title: An Appraisal
description: When the history of 20thcentury music comes to be written, Igor Stravinsky will occupy the most prominent position in the period from about 1910 to the beginning of World War II. More than any other composer, he put his mark on an entire generation. He was a shaper, a seminal force, a creator who was the symbol of the musical avantgarde not only in the public eye but alsomuch more importantin the estimation of his fellow musicians.

title: New Lighting Will Be Installed To Brighten Central Park South
description: New lighting is to be installed beginning today on the park side of Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The day was sullen from the start and it grew increasingly disagreeable as the rawness and the dampness penetrated deeper and deeper. It hardly was a perfect day for the opening game of a new baseball season at Shea Stadium between the Mets and the Expos. It was at total variance with the traditional ideal of glorious sunshine and the gentle breath of spring. It was more like a last baleful display of jealous temper by departing winter.

title: School Boards Association Elects National President
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (AP)  Kenneth E. Buhrmaster, president of the Scotia, N. Y., school board, was elected president of the National School Boards Association today.

title: G.E. Division Sets Layoff
description: BURLINGTON Vt. April (AP)The General Electric Company's Airmaments division here has announced another layoff, this one affecting 172 employes by June 30. That will bring total employment at the plant to about 2,200.

title: Total of 38 Convicted Of Murder in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, April 6In response to queries, a spokesman for the Army said today that 81 men had been charged with crimes in Vietnam similar to that for which First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was convicted.

title: LEWIS GRUBER, 75, OF TOBACCO FIRM
description: Lewis Gruber, honorary chairman of the Lorillard Company, manufacturer of cigarettes and other tobacco products, died Monday at. Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 176 East 71st Street.

title: JESSICA LEWIS DIES; EXOPERATIC SINGER
description: Jessica Lewis, an opera singer of half a century ago who retired to bring up a family, died yesterday in Cellars of Lebanon Hospital, Los Angeles. She was 80 years Old and was the widow of Leon Lewis, who died about 10 years ago.

title: 5 Professional Men Accused of Evading $640,000 in Taxes
description: Five professional men an accountants, two lawyers, a physician and a motionpicture producer  were charged in separate case yesterday with incometax violations involving a total of more than $640,000 in unreported income.

title: Offtrack Dress Rehearsal Sets the Stage for Tomorrow
description: Employes of the city's offtrack Betting Corporation made 15,000 makebelieve bets yesterday in a dress rehearsal, for tomorrow's official opening of the venture.

title: WIRTZ NAMED HEAD OF MANPOWER UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Manpower Institute, a private organization for dealing with national manpower problems, today named W. Willard Wirtz, former Secretary of Labor, as its president.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Education. President Nixon announced the appointment of four members of the National Advisory Council on Supplementary Centers and Services for terms expiring Jan. 30, 1974. The council evaluates the Federal grant programs supporting development of educational projects. The appointees are Kay CurleyChief of Tulsa, Okla.; Walter G. Davis of Silver Spring, Md.; Myron B. Kuropas of Chicago, and Mrs. MarechalNeil E. Young of Philadelphia.

title: Paul Scott Mowrer Dies of 83; Won Pulitzer as Correspondent
description: CHICAGO, April 6Paul Scott Mowrer, a leading foreign correspondent for The Chimp Daily News and its editor in World War II, died on Sunday in Beaufort, S. C., while returning from a Florida vacation to his home in Chocorua, N. H., He was 83 years old.

title: CARLO deBIASI
description: Carlo deBiasi, coeditor for 38 years of the Brooklyn Catholic Italianlanguage weekly II Crociato (The Crusader), died yesterday at his home, 6015 19th Avenue in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: State Senate Passes Welfare Changes
description: ALBANY, April 6The Senate tonight passed a series of bills proposed by Governor Rockefeller to change the state's welfare system.

title: Advertising:
description: National Football League Properties has dreamed up still another way of making money, for its team owners. It is Pro! Official NFL Television Guide, a newspaper supplement that will run three times during the coming season in newspapers in 26 markets with a total circulation of 15.1 million.

title: Candide Due April 14
description: Candide, an adaptation of Voltaire's satire as performed by the Organic Theater Company of Chicago, will be the seventh production of Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival. It will be presented at the festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, for a limited run beginning next Wednesday.

title: WINTER'S NEW BAND PLAYS AT FILLMORE
description: Edgar Winter's White Trash, the new band led by the Texas pianist saxophonist, gave a solidly exciting premiere concert Monday and last night at the Fillmore East.

title: TV and Radio Schedule
description: The following New York television stations will carry the President's address live tonight at 9 P.M.: WCBSTV (Channel 2), WNBCTV (Channel 4), WNEWTV (Channel 5), WABCTV (Channel 7), WNETTV (Channel 13), WNYCTV (Channel 31). WPIXTV (Channel 11) will rebroadcast the address at 11 P.M.; WORTV (Channel 9) will rebroadcast it at 12:45 A.M.

title: College Aid Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) Eight Democrats on the House Education and Labor Committee introduced today an alternative to the President's plan to aid higher education.

title: Aniversaries
description: SIMOWITZRhoda and Sylvain, congratulations on your 25th Anniversary. Continue to stay as charming & happy as you are and win many morn Suvretta Cups.

title: BOND. PRICES END A 2WEEK DECLINE
description: The credit markets stabilized Yesterday, endingtemporarily at leastthe decline in bond prices that set in two weeks ago.

title: Aiken Says Nixon Will. Set 72 Pullout In Address Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont predicted today that President Nixon would announce in his televised speech tomorrow a schedule that would lead to the removal of all American forces from Vietnam by sometime next year.

title: MANITOBA PLANS TO SHIFT TAX LOAD
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba In hope of shifting some of the tax load from the Inner city to the wealthier suburbs, Manitoba's government plans to consolidate greater Winnipeg's 11 urban and suburban municipalities into a single government.

title: 130,000 TENANTS FACE A RENT RISE
description: Rents will rise April 21 by up to 4 per cent in 130,000 rent controlled apartments, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, Benjamin Altman, announced yesterday.

title: EDWARD J. SCHENK
description: BERGENFIELD, N. J., April 6Edward J. Schenk, who retired in 1961 as business manager of the Times Facsimile Corporation, died on Sunday in the Manor Nursing Home, Tenafly. He was 78 years old and lived at 114 Baker Avenue.

title: NELSON S. HURLBUTT
description: WILTON, Conn., April 6Nelson S. Hurlbutt, former treasurer of Fairfield County and former chairman of the Wilton Republican Town Committee, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital after a long illness. His age was 81 and he lived at 8 Cannon Road.

title: BOGGS SEES PERIL TO U.S. FROM F.B.I. Suggests Actions of Hoover Violate Bill of Rights
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 Hale Boggs of Louisiana, the House Democratic leader, reiterated his charges against J. Edgar Hoover today and stated categorically that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had had him under surveillance.

title: NEW CASES CITED IN READING TESTS
description: Six Principals have notified Board of Education headquarters that they suspect or uncovered irregularities by some teacher in the conduct of the citywide reading tests given on Thursday.

title: Trot Fans Go Home Early As. Snow Cancels 7 Races
description: WESTBURY, Li., April 6 A blinding snowstorm prompted the cancellation of the last seven harness races on the card of nine at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Bullets Coach a Most Unhappy Fella
description: Gene Shue, the coach of the Bullets, who was monumentally unhappy just being in Madison Square Garden last night, auk, to an even lower state of frtistration and despondency while watching his team lose a onepoint decision to the Knicks.

title: Police Aid Bill Reoffered
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) Representative Clarence E. Miller Republican of Ohio, reintroduced today legislation to extend Federal benefits to policemen and firemen not employed by the Federal government who are killed or totally disabled in the line of duty.

title: Moon Dust Is Being Given To Scientists Around World
description: WASHINGTON. April 6 (AP) The space agency today started distributing to scientists around the world moon dust collected by Apollo 14 last February.

title: Fausto Cleva Honored by Met Opera
description: Lowell Wadmond called it the golden anniversary of a marriage to the Metropolitan Opera, Rudolf Bing wondered how such a marriage could endure so long, and Fausto Cleve merely smiled modestly and said, It has been one of the finest associations of my life.

title: Seats for Werriwell Will Sell for $5 Each
description: The Broadway producers of a new musical, Frank Merriwell, announced yesterday that all orchestra seats will sell for $5 each about the level they were some 30 years ago.

title: Man in the News
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 6  A persistent fly buzzed around Wasfi Mustafa Tal, Jordan's Premier, during a televised news conference in Amman some months ago.

title: U.S. Table Tennis Team Gets Peking Invitation
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Wednesday, April 7 (AP)Communist China has invited the United States team at the world table tennis championships here to visit China for friendly matches, Rufford Harrison, leader of the American team, said today.

title: Dust Commander Retired
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 6 (UPI)  Dust Cofmnander, the winner of the 1970 Kentucky Derby, has been retired to stud at Golden Chance Farm in Paris, Ky., his owner, Robert E. Lehmann, announced today. Lehmann purchased the Bold Commander offspring for $6,500 at Keeneland's 1968 fall year ling sales and the colt went on to win $215,012, including $127,800 for his Derby victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To, the Editor: Your March 22 editorial; discussed the Permit Program arinounced by President Nixon on Dec. 23 as a major new effort to control pollution of the nations waterways. This program will implement, provisions of the Refuse Act of 109, whose application to water pollution has only recently been recognized, by requiring permits for alt discharges, except from sewers, into navigable waters and their tributaries.

title: Foreign Evacuees From East Pakistan Tell of Grim Fight
description: CALCUTTA, April 6More than 100 foreign evacuees arrived here today after, a.34hour voyage from Chittagong, East Pakistan's major port, bringing the latest eyewitness reports about the Pakistani army's attempt to suppress the independence movement.

title: Mets Beat Expos in Rain, 42;
description: On a day not fit for man or beast or baseball player, the New York Mets opened the season yesterday by defeating the Montreal Expos, 42, in a game that was delayed, tortured and finally ended in the fifth inning, by rain and gales.

title: Andrew Puther Weds Miss Getwin
description: Miss Gloria M. Gerwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Lawrence Gerwin of Memphis, was married here yesterday to AndreW Pucher, son of Baroness Erwin Roszner de Roseneck of New York and the late Joseph Pucher de Bagos of Budapest. The ceremony in the chapel, at the Church Center for the United Nations was performed by the Rev. Dr. Carl D. Soule, a Methodist minister.

title: Kosygin Emphasizes Consumer Goods
description: MOSCOW, April 6Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin said today that a greater share of governinept investment Would be channeled into consumer goods and agriculture over the next five years to carry through promises of a better deal for the average citizen.

title: Allende's Stronger Mandate
description: President Allende can take solid satisfaction from the results of Chile's municipal elections. His Popular Unity coalition fell narrowly short of the absolute, majority of the vote for which he had hoped, but its showing represented a spectacular gain on his own poll of 36.3 per cent in the Presidential election last September. His Socialist party, well to the left of its Communist partner, exceeded its, previous best by 50 per cent.

title: PRESIDENT URGES REVENUE SHARING IN AID TO SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 President Nixon invited Congress today to join him in redesigning the Federal role in aid to elementary and secondary schools. But his proposal faced certain controversy and an uncertain fate.

title: LEGISLATION SOUGHT BY PENNSY TRUSTEES
description: The trustees or the Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday presented to a House subcommittee proposed legislation to enable bankrupt railroads to readily abandon moneylosing branch lines and to increase freight rate on traffic for which revenues do not cover the cost of providing the service.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BUENOS AIRESThe most important thing about Argentina's new chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Alejandro Lanusse, is that he apparently is prepared to make peace with Juan Pettit, the aged dictator who fled abroad after being overthrown in 1955.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Memorex Is Suing I.B.M. For $1Billion in Damages
description: The Memorex Corporation filed yesterday a crosscomplaint in a California state court against the international Business Machines Corporation asking $1billion in punitive damages.

title: Poster to Push Federal Food Stamp Program Here
description: The smiling faces of two young girls soon will be seed on a new poster by riders of the city's subways and buses.

title: Abernathy Is Arrested in A. & P. Demonstration
description: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy was arrested here last night, Just six hours after announcing a national boycott of the A. & P. supermarket chain, when he and 44 others refused to leave the ground floor of the building housing A. & P.'s national headquarters.

title: GERMANS TO BACK BATTERYRUN CAR
description: BONN, April 6West Germany's largest electricpower company disclosed plans today to promote batterydriven automobiles for largescale use in this country's metropolitan areas by 1980.

title: Nets Trim Squires Lead To21 on 135131 Victory
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 6In what is becoming a grudge series, the New York Nets beat the Virginia Squires, 135131, tonight in a fightfilled third game of their American Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Bill Would Save Wild River
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) A bill to preserve the Big Fork River in north central Minnesota in a wild and scenic state has been introduced by Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota.

title: Text of Calley Prosecutor's Letter to the President
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Following is the text of the letter sent to the President by Capt, Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the prosecutor in the Calley case:

title: CLOTHING UNION OFFERS DEMANDS
description: The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America presented proposals for substantial wages increases and numerous other contract improvements as negotiations opened here yesterday for a new national contract covering 125,000 workers do the clothing industry.

title: G.I.'s in Vietnam Await Nixon Speech on Withdrawals
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 6When President Nixon makes his announcement on troop withdrawals, some of the most attentive listeners will be the 300,000 G.I.'s at positions from the demilitarized zone to the Mekong River delta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Arnold A. Hutschnecker's Road to Peace [OpEd March 29, 30] certainly provides a useful approach to making this a more peaceful world. However, it seems to overlook other roads. Since the pacification process is a learning process, great responsibility must be placed on schools and colleges.

title: SHARP DROP FOUND IN PARISH SCHOOLS Study Predicts 1,800 Fewer in 1975 if Rate Continues
description: A national survey of the nation's Roman Catholic elementary and secondary schools ordered by the United States Office of Education shows that, if the current decline in numbers continues, there will be 1,800 fewer schools in 1975.

title: India Denies Deployment
description: NEW DELHI, April 6A spokesman for the Indian Government today denied that Indian troops had been moved to the border of East Pakistan.

title: FUTURES OF COCOA ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Cocoa futures prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange here in fairly active trading.

title: 65,000 Vehicles Recalled In 4 Chrysler Campaigns
description: DETROIT, April 6 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation is conducting four recall campaigns involving more than 65,000 vehicles  39,842 passenger cars and 25,542 trucks  for inspection and possible replacement of defective parts, the company announced today.

title: ISRAELI BLOC ASKS SHIFT IN BORDERS
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, April 7 (AP)Israel's governing Labor party approved early today a demand for substantial changes in the borders between Israel and her Arab neighbors that existed before the sixday war of 1967.

title: Henry W. Johnstone, ExAide With Merck & co., Dead at 78
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md., April 6 Henry W. Johnstone, retired senior vice president and director of Merck & Co., manufacturing chemists in Rahway, N. J., died yesterday in Kent and Queen Anne Hospital, of which he was former chairman, after a sudden illness. He was 78 years old.

title: EXTENT OF JOB CUT ARGUED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 6The number of state employes who will lose their jobs as a result of budget cuts was a matter of dispute today as rankandfile employes who got the first pink slips wondered whether their bosses would, too.

title: 2dRace Tony Rides Again
description: Just before yesterday's first race at Aqueduct, a portly follower of form was on the escalator that leads to the clubhouse mezzanine section.

title: Books of The Times
description: RAT RACE. By Dials Francis. 214 pages. Harper. $5.95.

title: WASHINGTON
description: In the ten years since John F. Kennedy became the first Roman Catholic to be elected to the Presidency, religious issues have almost ceased to be a major source of political controversy in the United States, but the two front runners in the 1972 Presidential election campaign are acting early to avoid trouble over the question of legalized abortion.

title: Tape of Phone Talk With Key Witness Heard at Crimmins Trial
description: The state rested its case yesterday in the murder and manplaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins after playing police recordings of telephone Conversations between the defendant and Joseph Rorech, the key prosecution, witness.

title: Roundup: Lolich at World Series Pitch in Tiger Opener
description: Major league baseball, which has attempted to embellish its image with everything from national anthems to free pantyhose, is now courting divine intervention. Billy Martin, the new manager of the Detroit Tigers, opened his team's 1971 season yesterday by throwing open his clubhouse to the clergy of the Detroit area. Several Roman Catholic priests responded to the invitation, visiting the players before and after the game.

title: Consuls Attend Still Another DinnerTheir Own.
description: Consuls general come and go, and last night was no exception. It was back to the Plaza for another of those blacktie functions complete with French menu, wide smiles and discreet conversation.

title: NEWARK NEGROES FIGHT SCHOOL PACT
description: NEWARK, April 6A meeting of the Board of Education to discuss ratification of a settlement in the 10weekold teachers strike was continually interrupted tonight by a noisy, predominantly black crowd.

title: 3 Choreographers Show Their WorkIn Bill at Cubiculo
description: Works drawing upon coolly architectonic and warmly expressionistic moods were offered Monday evening at the Cubiculo as Suzette Martinez, Jan Van Dyke and Lillo Way shared a program. Of special interest were Miss Martinez's dully titled but rigorously structured and cleanly beautiful pieces Study in Repetitious Time Phrases and Dance for Two Dancers.

title: Bomb Explodes in School
description: A fire bomb was hurled into the teachers lounge of a Brooklyn junior high school yesterday morning, but caused no injuries and only slight damage. The police reported that the device was thrown at about 3:45 A.M. from the street through a secondfloor window of Brooklyn Junior High School 57, at Lafayette and Stuyvesant Avenues, in the BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Pakistanis Get Asylum
description: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, April 7 (Reuters)  Two men from the Pakistani diplomatic mission here sought and were granted political asylum by India last night, Indian sources said today.

title: Policemen Advised Of Reporters Right To Cover the News
description: Chief Inspector Michael J. Codd has told all police commands that representatives of the press with workingpress cards should be permitted through police and fire lines and into police stations, except where there are serious deterrents of danger or security.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Newman Shows Amazing Speed at Harpsichord
description: The first temptation is to dismiss Anthony Newman's harpsichord playing as a young man's romance with speed. During his Town Hall recital of baroque works on Monday night there were many moments when one felt he must have a plane to catch. Notes sprayed out of his instrument at bewildering rates, not only in such a temptingly flashy piece as John Bull's Walsingbarn Variations (No. 1 in your Fitzwilliam Virginal Book), but also in Bach's Passacaglia and Fugue in C minor, known to most music listeners as a noble edifice for organ.

title: FLORIDIANS DEFEAT COLONELS, 120 TO 102
description: DALLAS, April 6 (AP)The Utah Stars held the highscoring Texas guard, Donnie Freeman, to 4 points tonight and swept their fourofsevengame West Division semifinal playoff with a 128107 victory over the Chaparrals.

title: Editor Ordered Deported
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (AP) The Immigration and Naturalization Service ordered today that an editor of a Philadelphia underground paper be deported to his native Canada on the ground that his student visa had expired. William P. Biggin, 31yearold editor of The Philadelphia Prep Press, which started at Temple University, was termed deportable on the ground that he was no longer a student at Temple. His visa expired last June 30.

title: 6 Coast Guardsmen Kilted
description: BALTIMORE, April 6 (AP)Six Coast Guardsmen were killed today in a car accident. The men had been stationed aboard the cutter Chase, which is based in Boston. They were identified as David P. Zalewski of West Warren, Mass.; John R. Long of Marion, Mass.; Thomas J. Madey of Pittsburgh; Nicholas L. Stokes of Mt. Pleasant, S.C.; David A. Coffin of Milwaukee, and David J. Bratsch of Nazareth, Pa.

title: Pentagon Halts Army Ad Drive Alter Other Services Complain
description: WASHINGTON April 6The Pentagon has ordered the Army to stop spending money on ra dio and television advertising until it has evaluated the servIce's current $10.6million 13week campaign to sell an all volunteer Army to this year's high school seniors.

title: Football Transactions
description: WINNIPEGSlgned Don Burrell, San Angelo State wide receiver, and Mike Green, Nebraska fullback.

title: Shop Talk
description: Cacharel, a name that is likely to conjure up soft, often sheer wool, printed fabrics with small allover designs made into fitted shirts from Paris, started out eight years ago as a women's wear concern. Then three years ago its founder, Jean Cacharel, began making clothes for men in the French capital, The women's shirts, skirts, pants suits and dresses have been offered by some New York stores, including Bloomingdale's, since last spring. And now Bloomingdale's is offering Cacharel shirts and ties for men.

title: Negro Wins in E. St Louis
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., April 6(UPI)  James E. Williams Sr. was elected today as the first Negro Mayor of East St. Louis.

title: Two Accused of Tax Fraud
description: A former advertising executive and his sisterinlaw were Indicted yesterday on 13 charges of consporacy and tax evasion. The two, Bernard Kliman, 65 years old, of 400 East 56th Street, and Mrs. Evelyn Kreiger, of Hollywood, Fla., were accused by a grand jury of arranging to receive kickbacks from companies doing business with Mr. Kliraan's former employer, the Norman Morris Corporation, distributor of Omega watches. Mr. Kliman was also accused of understating his income by $150,000 from 1964 to 1966.

title: 50Mile Winds Sweep Area; Air and Ground Traffic Slowed
description: Rain, sleet and snow and wind gusts of more than 50 miles an hour knocked down power lines and caused some flooding in the city and suburbs yesterday.

title: 3 ExPolicemen Tell State Inquiry of Their Involvement in Heroin Traffic
description: Three former New York policemen told the State Commission of Investigation yesterday about their corrupt involvement in heroin traffic.

title: COSTELLO REPORT ENRAGES DELURY
description: John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Associationflushed with anger and the heat from television lightscharged yesterday that the idiot Costello was Interfering in the union's contract negotiations with the city.

title: SCRIBNER BACKED ON SCHOOL EDITORS Board Upholds Prior Review of Official Publications
description: The Board of Education has upheld a decision by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner that school principals or their faculty advisers have the right of prior review over official school publications so that student editors do not overstep the boundaries of responsible journalism by printing libelous, defamatory or obscene material.

title: MARKET FINISHES SHARPLY HIGHER
