description: The stock market snapped out of its recent lethargy yesterday and finished sharply higher in the heaviest trading in three weeks.

title: Colley Prosecutor Asserts Nixon Undermines Justice
description: WASHINGTON, April. 6Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d, the prosecutor in the Army courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., has protested to President Nixon in a letter that the President's intervention m the case has weakened respect for the legal process.

title: Daley Wins Fifth Term in Chicago by a Big Majority
description: CHICAGO, April 6Mayor. Richard J. Daley, one of the last of the bigcity political bosses, again proved the effectiveness of his Deinocratic machine tonight by easily winning an unprecedented fifth term. Any doubts about the hold Mr. Daley has on Chicago's voters were quickly dispelled as he overwhelmed Richard E. Friedman, a 41yearold independent Democrat running as the Republican nominee. With all 3,412 precincts reported, Mr. Daley had 735,787 votes to Mr. Friedman's 318,059. Mr. Daley won in all but two of the city's 50 Wards and *.Jok 69.82 per cent of the vote. The only areas carried by Mr. Friedman were Hyde Park, near the University of Chicago, and Armitage Street, on the Near North Lakefront. This year's total was only 11.,000 votes lower than the total four years ago, when the Mayor got 74.4 per cent of the ballots cast.

title: CITY DEPRIVATIONS SEEN IN STATECUTS
description: The reduced state budget threatens to deprive the city of at least $512million in major services, the Lindsay administration declared yesterday.

title: Bridge: Par Contests, Almost Extinct, Presented Many Challenges
description: An interesting form of bridge that has unfortunately become almost extinct is the par contest. Deals are specially prepared to present challenging problems in dummyplay and defense. Players score points for solving these problems, and also for accurate bidding.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Ta the Editor: Messrs. Perlmutter and Guberman were repeating the current line of the present Israeli Government and probably neglecting their own better judgment when they claimed in their March 28 letter that international peacekeeping forces pose a danger to the Middle East where the only hope for peace and stability is an ironclad commitment (by the United States) to provide Israel with matriel.

title: Igor Stravinsky, the Composer, Dead at 88
description: Igor Stravinsky, the composer whose Le Sacre du Printemps exploded in the face of the music world in 1913 and blew it into the 20th century, died of heart failure yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In Buckminster Fuller's poem [OpEd March 27], he states that Physics shows that universal energy is undiminishable. Later on he states that the universe is an eternally inexhaustible, energy system of Omniselfregenerative celestial mechanics.

title: CEILING CUT TO 7% ON JERSEY INTEREST
description: TRENTON, April 6 (AP).State Banking Commissioner James C. Brady issued a regulation today reducing the interest rate ceiling from 8 to 7 per cent in New Jersey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A little nuance that tells a lot is worth noticing in Mr. Brezhnev's sixhour speech at the opening session of the 24th Soviet Communist party Congress in Moscow.

title: 1970 LOSS POSTED BY UNITED BRANDS
description: The United Brands Company  formed last June through the merger of the AMK Corporation, a major meat packer through its John Morrell & Co. subsidiary, and the United Fruit Company, a banana grower and marketer  had net loss of $2,091,000 last year after extraordinary charges of $6,408,000, it reported yesterday. In 1969 a consolidated profit was reported of $28,660,000, or $2.48 a share, after an extraordinary credit of $4,000,000.

title: STUDENTS BATTLE POLICE IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea; April 6  More than 2,000 students of three universities here clashed with policemen today during separate street demonstrations against a program of compulsory military training in the universities.

title: Greatest of Composers
description: By common consent, Igor Stravinsky was the greatest living composer. He was the last of the heroic group that flourished, in the early part of the centurya group that included such composers as Bela Bartok, Sergei Prokofiev; Arnold Schoenberg, Anton Webern, Ralph Vaughan Williams. All of them helped shape the course of music. But of them all there was, in the period from about 1910 to 1940, no shaper like Stravinsky. After his Petrushka of 1911 and his Le Sacre dti Printemps 1913, music could no longer be the same.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: James Reston's March 26 column Divided Command in Saigon demonstrates that the electoral interests of Thieu and Nixon are irreconcilable.

title: Advertising:
description: The ad that linked Ballantine's Scotch with the women's lib movement caused considerable concern 21 Brands, the importer. At first they weren't going run it, but then the agency insisted. It ran. Now everyone seems to be happy about it.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: 18YEAROLD VOTE SPEEDED OVER U.S. 13 States Have RatifiedApproval Is Near in 19
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) State legislatures are moving swiftly to ratify the constitutional amendment to give 18yearolds the right to vote in all elections. Final action in time for the 1972 elections appears certain.

title: 2 Coast Banks Are Bombed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 6 (UPI) TWo Bank of America branches, one here and another in San Jose, were damaged early today in the 22d and 23d California bombings of the world's largest bank since February, 1970. Both banks were slightly damaged but no one was injured in either of the attacks.

title: Chagall Gets 2d Rank In the Legion of Honor
description: PARIS, April 6Marc Chagall was made a grand officer of the Legion of Honor last night, the second highest rank in the order.

title: Columbia Votes 197172 Budget With Deficit Cut by $5Million
description: The trustees of Columbia University have voted to adopt a budget for the forthcoming year that provides for a deficit of $10.8million, a reduction of more than $5million from the deficit in the current year.

title: Teacher Uses Rewards
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I. (AP) Vor getting A's on tests, for turning in extra work or for keeping quiet, 4thgraders hit Mrs. Shirley Reiter's class get white and purple slips known as Reiter Dollars. They can cash them in at Mrs. Reitees Redemption Center at the back of the room. It features Min purses, toys and model kits.

title: ONA TRUTH EXPANDS JAZZ CENTER'S WEEK
description: The series of Friday noon jazz sessions that have been conducted by Jazz Adventures for several months was expanded yesterday to include sessions on Wednesday at noon at La Martinique, the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street.

title: Advertising:
description: Dear Mr. President:

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: J. P. MORGAN'S NET UP 34% IN QUARTER
description: J. P. Morgan & Co., Inc., parent company of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's largest wholesale bank, catering almost exclusively to the corporate carriage trade, reported yesterday a 34 per cent gain in profits for the first quarter.

title: Berkeley and Chicago
description: The results of two elections last Tuesday might prompt an overquick conclusion that the American people are schizophrenic, polarized or both. In Berkeley, Calif., selfstyled radicals won three out of four contested seats on the City Council and the mayoralty went to a candidate who, for the most part, supports these practitioners of the new politics. On the same day Chicago, voted Mayor. Richard J. Daley an unprecedented fifth termnot narrowly but by a smashing 70 per cent margin, giving him 48 of the city's 50 wards.

title: $8,500 Taken in 2 Holdups At Queens Bank Branches
description: Two Queens branches of the National Bank of North America were held up within half an hour yesterday afternoon, apparently by the same two men. They escaped with a total of $8,500.

title: ROYAL CITY IN LAOS NOW ARMED CAMP
description: LUANG PRABANG, Laos; April 7 (UPI)Tbe royal capital, Luang Prabang, awakes to the sound of a different drum these days.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11  No Title

title: Remember When Crib Was Place To Sleep?
description: Kimberly Collins, a 13monthold toddler, didn't know she was standing in what's called one of the first new crib designs in 100 years.

title: Markert to Retire May 31 as Director of Rockettes
description: Russell E. Marked, founder and director of the Radio City Music Hall's acclaimed precision dancing Rockettes since the opening of the theater in December, 1932, will retire on May 31.

title: LETTER FROM SEALE CRITICIZES CLEAVER
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 7 (UPI)Bobby Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party, today accused Eldridge Cleaver of helping the pig power structure send him to the gas chamber.

title: Detergent Hearing Slated
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 7 Federal District Judge Edward T. Gignoux today set April 19 as the date for hearing the Lever Brothers Company request for an injunction against the Federal Trade Commission. The manufacturer wants to stop Commission proceedings on a proposed rule requiring detergent makers to list ingredients on packages and to display pollution warnings in advertisements.

title: Doctors Report Hodgkin's Disease. Yielding 10
description: CAREFREE, Ariz., April 7Hodgkin's disease, a form of cancer that was considered incurable 10 years ago, is now being successfully treated in 75 per cent of cases at some large medical centers, a panel of physicians reported here today.

title: Flood Loses an Appeal
description: A threejudge Federal appeals court upheld yesterday a lower court decision denying Curt Flood's antitrust claims against baseball, setting the stage for Flood's ultimate appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

title: Man in the News
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 7 When First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.'s courtmartial began here five months ago, his prosecutor believed American military involvement in Southeast Asia to be both necessary and proper. Now, after winning a conviction for premeditated murder and witnessing the storm of public protest it has prompted, Capt. Aubrey Marshall Daniel 3d is hay ing some second thoughts.

title: SILURIANS ANNOUNCE JOURNALISM AWARDS
description: Eleven awards for excellence in journalism in 1970 were announced yesterday by the Society of Silurians, a New York organization of past and present newspapermen who were working as journalists 25 years ago.

title: Washington Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The State Department today described the Chinese invitation to an American table tennis team to visit Communist China as an encouraging development and said it would welcome reciprocal visits by Chinese athletic teams to this country.

title: Ecuadorian Guilty of Aiding Illegal Immigration
description: An Ecuadorian woman pleaded guilty yesterday to helping aliens enter the United States illegally by coaching them to lie to American consular officials in Ecuador and immigration officials here.

title: Merger News
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the color picture tube manufacturing equipment of the Admiral Corporation.

title: Developers of Delaware Basin Concerned as Opposition Grows
description: DOVER. Del., April 7 The current national concern over matters of ecology and environment underscores the wisdom and foresight of those who inspired the creation of this compact 10 years ago, Gov. Russell W. Peterson of Delaware said today at the 10th annual meeting of the Delaware River Basin Commission.

title: The President's Vietnam Pledge
description: The President's Vietnam Pledge

title: MetsExpos Postponed; Yankees Unscheduled
description: The Mets, who opened the season Tuesday in sleet and gales, postponed a game yesterday in bright sunshine. But they hope to get together with the elements and the Montreal Expos in Shea Stadium this afternoon, with Gary Gentry pitching against Steve Renko.

title: DISSIDENTS FILE SUIT AGAINST OZARK LINE
description: ST. LOUIS, April 7 (AP)A group of stockholders has filed suit in United States District Court in its attempt to take over management of Ozark Air Lines, Inc.

title: SUE ATWOOD WINS 200 BACKSTROKE
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 7 (AP)Sue Atwood of Lakewood, Calif., successfully defendedlier 200yard backstroke title tonight in the finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union shortcourse championship.

title: Screen:
description: Judging by Ginger, the Astor Theater must have taken on this stultifying pancake of a sex teaser because the smaller sex showcases in the Times Square area turned it down. It's that dull. The picture isn't even as honest as most of these outright scorchers smelling up midtown.

title: SOUTH VIETNAMESE WILL REPLACE G.I.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 8 (AP)The South Vietnamese Government said today that the 100,000 American soldiers who will be phased out of Vietnam from May 1 to Dec. 1 will be gradually replaced by our own troops.

title: Special Study Group Named To Plan Volunteer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Joseph H. Blatchford, director of the Peace Corps, named a special study group today to plan the structure of the new volunteer agency proposed by President Nixon.

title: Abortion Reform Defeated
description: HARTFORD, April 7The State House of Representatives rejected today, 132 to 28, a bill that would liberalize the abortion law in Connecticut. At present abortions are permitted in hospitals only if the life of the mother is in danger. The proposal defeated would have left the decision to the mother and her doctor.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE T0 21MONTH HIGH
description: The stock market closed at its best level in 21 months yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Advertising:
description: Gaynor & Ducas, which will he losing the Scandinavian Airlines System business, has just been named by Northeast Airlines.

title: 9Week Ford Strike In Britain Is Ended As Last Unit Votes
description: LONDON, April 7  The strike that has hit the Ford Motor Company's British operations for more than nine weeks ended tonight.

title: COLUMBIA DENIED USE OF REACTOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Atomic Safety and Licensing Board announced today that it had denied Columbia University permission to operate a small nuclear reactor on Morningside Heights.

title: Report of Leader's Willingness To Meet Peron Stirs Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 7A report that President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, who has pledged to return his nation to elective democracy, is ready to meet with Argentina's exiled former dictator, Juan D. Per6n, created something of an uproar here today.

title: Large Black Opal Is Found
description: ADELAIDE, Australia  A large ovalshaped black opal, valued at $150,000 (U.S. $169, 000) has been discovered at Glengarry, 40 miles from Lightning Ridge in South Australia, the Australian News Service reports. The opal has been named the Orient Queen. Its discovery, and that of other valuable opals, has caused a new opal rush at Glengarry.

title: Amex Prices Show Rise
description: Advances edged out declines In moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: President's Galley Move Arouses Political Debate
description: WASHINGTON. April 7The increasingly political debate over the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. took a new tack today as Democrats and Republicans clashed over whether President Nixon had improperly intervened in the case.

title: Easter Bowl Tennis Today
description: The Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis tournament, with many nationally ranked players, opens today at 8 A.M. at three sites Bill Brown's Courts in the armory at 143d Street and Fifth Avenue; Boulevard Gardens in Jackson Heights, Queens, and the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx. The tournament runs through Sunday.

title: Universal City Will Dominate TV Schedulesin Fall
description: A master of popular television entertainment is a legend in show business but often nonperson to the set owner. One is Lew R. Wasserman, president and chief executive of the Universal City Studios in Universal City, Calif.

title: Lefkowitz Scores Proposal To Expand City Voting Unit
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday there was no justification for a bill, now awaiting Governor Rockefeller's signature, increasing the number of commissionersfrom four to 10on the New York City Board of Elections.

title: Market Place:
description: There has been a great deal of weeping and gnashing of teeth over the new Securities and Exchange Commission rule that forces corporations to report divisional sales to the S.E.C. annually.

title: Hanoi Agrees to Resume Paris Peace Negotiations
description: PARIS, April 7 (Reuters)North Vietnam agreed today to resume the peace talks here tomorrow after a threeweek interruption; a spokesman for the Hanoi delegation said.

title: Daley's Followers Take Victory Seriously
description: CHICAGO, April 7It was almost quiet in Suite 220 of the Sherman House Hotel, the headquarters of the Cook County Democratic organization.

title: Downtown Scene: Lyrical Abstraction
description: It is not difficult to like lyrical abstract painting. Its colors are appealing and even seductive, its vague forms wax pleasantly poetic and its relative freedom of technique and frequent noncommitalness of statement allow for all sorts of imaginative association and metaphor. If lyrical abstraction tends to be more accessible than difficult, more sensual than cerebral, it is still no less, worthwhile as an art form. Yet its sensuality can easily deteriorate into sensationalism, its color into sheer tawdriness and its noncommitalness into dizzying chaos.

title: Upstate G.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that Specialist 4 Clifford R. Osterhoudt of Homer, N. Y., of the Army, had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Personal Finance
description: A taxpayer fortunate enough to have some personal property that has increased in value, such as a painting, a stamp collection, a few acres of land or a summer home, can get a tax break if he arranges to sell to someone who will pay him in installments.

title: School Award for Hal Davis
description: Hal Davis, international president of the American Federation of Musicians, has been selected as the recipient of the 1971 Third  Street Music School Settlement Award for Distinguished Service, to American Music. The award will be presented at a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel on May 12 sponsored by members of the recording industries for the benefit of the school's scholarship fund.

title: SALUTE RETURNED TO A BOY BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 7When President Nixon's image came on the television screen in the living room of the James Platt home tonight in Avella, Pa., fouryearold Kevin Taylor looked up and said, There's President Nixon, Mommy.

title: Chile Confirms U.S. Will Replace Ambassador Korry
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7The Chilean Foreign Ministry confirmed today that the United States had requested agreement for the appointment of a new ambassador here.

title: House Rejects Increases In Funding for Education
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Faced with the threat of an other Presidential veto, the House rejected today a move that would have increased education appropriations $728.6million Above the Nixon Administration's requests.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: State Weighs Auto Insurance Changes
description: Youthful drivers may pay substantially more for automobile insurance than they do at present under a new rate reclassification plan under consideration by the New York State Insurance Department, it was disclosed here yesterday.

title: Russians Building a Siberian Pipeline
description: MOSCOW, April 7  The Soviet Union has announced the start of construction on a major oil pipeline from the great Samotlor field of West Siberia, the largest petroleum pool ever discovered in this country.

title: FINE FLORINDA SUNG BY EILEEN SCHAULER
description: It was probably to be expected that sooner or later Elleen Schauler would appear as Florinda in Ginastera's Don Rodrigo, and, on Tuesday night in the performance given, by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater, she did it for the first time.

title: Gambles, Inc., W. T. Grant Up in March From 70 Level
description: Gambles, Inc., and W. T. Grant Company reported yesterday increased sales for March over the comparable yearago month.

title: 15 Invited by Peking
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 7The first sizable group of Americans to visit Communist China since the middle nineteenfifties will be a table tennis team.

title: Penn Central Cuts Its Fares On Weekend Upstate Trips
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company announced yesterday a 40 per cent cut in weekend fares on trains between Utica, ColonieSchnectady, AlbanyRensselaer, Hudson and New York City.

title: The Speaker's Plans
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Speaker Carl Albert is a man with his own timetable. Albert, who will be 63 next month, told an interviewer when he was elected Speaker in January that he would not servo beyond the age of 70. A dedicated Democrat, lie does not intend to spend six of his eight years as Speaker tilting with Richard Nixon. He wants his party to win the 1972 election.

title: The Threat to Newark
description: The Newark Board of Education meeting Tuesday night had been billed as a public hearing on the ratification the agreement to end the tenweekold teachers strike. It was instead an orgy of intimidation and coercion an audience packed with ultramilitant blackpower advocates tried to engineer a takeover of the schools.

title: 23 in Chicago Street Gang Accused of Stealing Funds
description: CHICAGO, April 7Twentythree members of the Black P Stone Nation, a syndicate of black street gangs operating on Chicago's South Side; were indicted today on charges of defrauding the Office of Economic Opportunity of funds given the organization for jobtraining programs.

title: REV. RALPH S. THORN, LED CHURCH IN BRONX
description: The Rev. Ralph S. Thorn, retired minister of the Willis Avenue Methodist Church in the Bronx, died Monday night in Presbyterian Hospital after short illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 3090 Heath Avenue in the Bronx.

title: The Diary of One Who Vanished Is Highlight of Janacek Program
description: Leos Janacek, the Charles Ives of Czechoslovak music, composed in so original a manner and in an idiom so tightly bound up with his folk heritage that his works have been slow to find an international audience. To a great extent, it still is his operas that keep his name alive outside Central Europe.

title: Rifle Group Elects Leader
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) Fred H. Hakenjos, 63 years ea, of Wilmington, Del., was elected president of the National Rife Association today by the group's board of directors. Mr. Hakenjos succeeds Woodson D. Scott of New York.

title: 2 South Vietnamese Bases Are Reported Under Heavy Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 8 (AP)Heavy fighting was reported around two besieged South Vietnamese fire bases in the rugged Central Highlands yesterday. Headquarters in Saigon said that nearly 400 North Vietnamese troops were killed in daylong fighting, most of them by air strikes.

title: 2 Seized in Attack on Newsman At Newark School Unit Session
description: NEWARK, April 7Two men, including Dr. E. Wyman Garrett, a former member of the school board, were arrested here tonight on charges stemming from the assault on a New York Times reporter during a school beard meeting last night.

title: HOWARD J. DODSON
description: Howard T. Dodson, choirmaster and organist of the Abyssinian Baptist Church since 1946, died Monday in Harlem Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage during services on Sunday. He was 61 lyears old and lived at 2171 Madison Avenue.

title: Chile Ratifies O.A.S. Charter Special to The Nev York Times
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7The Chilean Senate ratified today the new Charter of the Organization of American States, assuring the full participation of Foreign Minister Clodomiro Almeyda Medina in the annual I meeting of the orgahization's General Assembly next week.

title: Roundup: Pepitone of Cubs Errs at Home and on Road
description: With the flamboyance of a blinking midway, Joe Pepitone of the Chicago Cubs has announced to the world that he is ready to play another season of baseball. An admitted Bacharach in a Sousa world, Pepitone confronted the legal arm of Mayor Daley and the best left arm of the St. Louis Cardinals in a matter of hours. He had his moments against each.

title: ABERNATHY REPORTS LINDSAY AID ON A. & P.
description: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, chairman of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had agreed to offer his good offices to arrange a meeting between the civil rights organization and officers of the A. & P.

title: State Hearing Told Heroin Dealer Was Willing to Testify Against Policemen
description: A lawyer for a convicted heroin dealer told the State Commission of Investigation yesterday that his client had agreed to testify in open court against a former New York detective who was his admitted partner in a drugtrafficking business.

title: McCormick Resigns Post at WORTV
description: Michael. McCormick has resigned as general manager of WORTV. He will be replaced, effective Monday, by Robert Glaser, who has been the station's general sales manager for the last two years.

title: BETS TURN BACK SQUIRES, 130127
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 7No fists flew in the New Yofk Nets 130127 victory over the Virginia Squires tonight, but the right punch still came at the right time.

title: American Art Sale Sets Auction Mark In First of 2 Days
description: Auction records were posted last night for American artists from the 19th century to the 1930's. The sale was held at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, and grossed nearly $1million in the first half of a sale of native works that will continue today.

title: CEYLON REPORTS POUNDING REBELS
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April (AP)The Government sent armored forces and warplanes into battle against Marxist insurgents today and said they had inflicted heavy casualties on the rebels in countryside skirmishes.

title: G.E. Sets Earnings Mark
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday its best first quarter ever. Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer, placed sales at a record total of $2,099,157,000 and net income at a high of $91,466,000, equal to $1.01 a share.

title: Unitas Undergoes Surgery on Right Foot
description: John Unitas, the Baltimore Colts quarterback, underwent surgery last night to repair a ruptured Achilles tendon on his right foot. The 37yearold star incurred the injury while playing paddle tennis at the YMCA in Towson, a Baltimore suburb.

title: Cadet Is Granted Discharge
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, April 7 (AP)Leonard Slazinski, 22 years old, of Dearborn Heights, Mich, who would have graduated in Juno with the cadet class of 1971 at the Air Force Academy here, has been discharged at his own request as a conscientious objector, an academy spokesman said today. It was the first such discharge at the academy.

title: Tigers Sign Boswell, Martin's ExSparmate
description: DETROIT, April 7 (UPI)Dave Boswell, a 20game winner for the Detroit Tigers manager, Billy Martin, when Martin was manager of the Minnesota Twins in 1969, signed a contract with Detroit today.

title: News of Dogs
description: The bullmastiff, bred to guard the large British estates and game preserves from preachers in the late nineteenth century, is in increasing demand today to guard suburban homes and city apartments in the United States. The breed, a cross of the bulldog and mastiff, has a long way to go before it challenges for a top spot on the American Kennel Club hit parade. Last year, only 429 clogs were registered, making it No. 72 of the 116 breeds in the stud book.

title: OneDay Strike Across Italy Causes Little Distress
description: ROME, April 7A nationwide general strike, called for one day by Italy's three major labor organizations, disrupted industry today but caused little hardship for the public and tourists.

title: Chess:
description: Sparks, Nev., was the scene of the recent 1971 United States National Open Chess Championship, an eightround Swisssystem event, which attracted 134 contenders. It was held in John Ascuaga's Nugget.

title: Stars Rally Tops Blues
description: ST. LOUIS, April 7 (UPI)JeanPaul Parise and Danny Grant scored on Minnesota power plays in the third period tonight, to give the North Stars a 32 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in the first game of the Stanley. Cup quarterfinals.

title: Black Hawks Scarp, 52
description: CHICAGO, April 7 (UPI)Bobby Hull, in the Stanley Cup playoffs for the 12th year, scored two goals tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5.2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in the opening game of their fourofseven series.

title: City's Personnel Policies Called Biased
description: Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton and Councilman Carol Greitzer charged yesterday that the city discriminates against women and members of minority groups in hiring and promotion.

title: Stolen Files Show F.B.I. Seeks Plack Informers
description: BOSTON, April 7The Federal Bureau of Investigationchas been recruiting informers, ranging from bill collectors to apartmerit house janitors, in an effort to develop constant surveillance in black communities and New Left organizations.

title: Poindexter Trial Hears Testimony On News Reports
description: The prosecution strove to show yesterday that David Poindexter was harboring Angela Davis when he knew that Federal warrants had been issued for her arrest.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: I.T.T. CHIEF EARNED $766,755 LAST YEAR
description: Harold S. Geneen, the 60yearold chairman and president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation who earned $766,755 last year, generally is considered to be the highest paid corporate executive in the land.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemical Plans Zurich Unit
description: BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 (Reuters) The Chemical Bank has been givenpermission to open a branch in Zurich, a Government spokesman said today.

title: State High Court Backs Mother In Baby Lenore Adoption Case
description: ALBANY, April 7The State Court of Appeals today upheld a lowercourt decision requiring that the baby girl adopted by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino of Brooklyn be returned to her natural mother, an unmarried woman who had surrendered the child to an adoption agency.

title: Ray's Brother Convicted
description: ST. LOUIS, April 7 (UPI)John Larry Ray, brother of James Earl Ray, was convicted late last night of armed robbery. James Earl Ray pleaded guilty to the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Bruins Top Canadierzs, 31, for 11th Playoff Victory in Row
description: BOSTON, April 7 (UPI) 2,6bby Orr scored one goal and set up another before being penalized out of the Stanley Cup opener tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 31, to run their playoff victory streak to 11 games.

title: HELEN HARDEN
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 7 Mrs. Helen Mulford Washburn Harden, author of the popular book, So You're Going to Have a Baby, died yesterday in Holy Ghost Hospital. She was 67 years old and in recerk years had lived in St. Lucia in the West Indies.

title: Bridge:
description: In a national knockout team championship, past experience has indicated that only teams of nationally known experts have any real chance to reach the closing stages.

title: SCHOOL CONTRACT UPSET IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, April 7 The Board of Education in a surprise move tonight rejected contract that would have ended ia 10weekold strike by the Newark Teachers Union.

title: Executive Changes
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday the election of James D. }little, former assistant Secretary of the Navy, to the post of senior vice presidentgovernment affairs, in charge of the airline's executive office in Washington, D.C. The company's present capital staff will report to Mr. 1little, and he will report to Najeeb E. Halaby, chairman. Mr. Hittle, who retired in 1960 from the United States Marine Corps with the rank of brigadier general resigned as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for manpower and reserve affairs on March 31. Prior to taking up his Assistant Secretary post, he completed several assignments concerning Congressional affairs, including serving as special counsel of the Senate Armed Services Committee and consultant to the House Armed Services Committee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Group to Ask Tax Bar
description: BRUSSELS, April 7The Common Market commission will make proposals within the next few weeks that would ban tax allowances by governments attempting to attract industry to developing regions, it was learned today.

title: MORNING RISE OUT IN PRICE OF BONDS
description: Bond prices climbed swiftly yesterday morning in a burst of enthusiasm that disappeared during the afternoon.

title: 9 in the Bronx, Including 2 Policemen, Indicted in a Usury Case
description: A largescale loansharking operation with diversified interests in arson, gambling, narcotics and the selling of counterfeit money was smashed yesterday, according to the Bronx District Attorney.

title: At Masters: Willie Mays Would Help
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 The sooner a black plays in the Masters, the happier we'll be, said Clifford Roberts, tournament chairman, when asked today to discuss the Augusta National Golf Club's policy toward black competitors.

title: ONASSIS IS SEEKING ARBITRATION PANEL
description: ATHENS, April 7Aristotle S. Onassis called today for international arbitration on his dispute with the. Greek Government over the revision of his $600million Greek investment contract.

title: Pennsy Lost $431 Million;
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company's net loss for 1970 was $431.2million, according to a preliminary report filed by the bankruptcy trustees with the Federal district court in Philadelphia.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Guerrillas Reported Killed By Israelis in Gaza Strip
description: TEL AVIV, April 7 (Reuters) Five Arab guerrillas were killed today in two incidents in the Israeliheld Gaza Strip, a military spokesman said here.

title: American Illusion
description: There are many reasons why a tragic sense of life does not come easy to Americans, and why a tragic sense of life is required if we are not to destroy ourselves. Until recently it was so easy not to believe evil of ourselves. Even when we saw the photographs used as evidence in the Caney trial, it was easy to be detached from them. They could not have connection to us.

title: SWISS MOVE TO AID THE POORER NATIONS.
description: GENEVA, April 7Switzerland is planning to help the world's poorer nations to increase their foreign earnings by facilitating the access of their products onto the Swiss home market.

title: Pacers Oust Pros, 102101
description: MEMPHIS, April 17 (AP)The Indiana Pacers won their Western Division semifinal series by taking a fourth straight game from the Memphis Pros, 102101, in overtime tonight in an A.B.A. playoff game.

title: A Stronghold for Beards No Longer
description: MEDINAT ISA, BahreinIn Abdullah Mousse's courtly baritone there was a touch of melancholy, a faint note of the wouldbe artist foiled.

title: White House Asks U. S. Aid to Bolster The Capital's Status
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) President Nikon called on Congress today to help lift the national capital to the status of a great American city and open the way for what he calls the New American Revolution.

title: Policemen Disperse Farmers
description: FOGGIA, Italy, April 7 (Reuters)The police used tear gas and clubs today to disperse several thousand farmers blocking a railroad line and the main highway here to support their demands for the payment of oliveoil subsidies that were due.

title: Cemetery Theft Indictment
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., April 7Leon I. Sinagra, 29 years old of 32 River Road, Chatham was indicted today by a Union County grand jury here on charges of stealing bronze flower urns valued at more than $21,500 from the Graceland Memorial Park in Kenilworth. The indictment charges the larceny occurred last Sept. 27.

title: City Record to Drop Listing of Vouchers For Less Than $500
description: The City Record, the official municipalgovernment newspaper, will no longer publish listings of expense vouchers or bills submitted by city officials for less than $500, Milton Musicus, Municipal Service Administrator, announced yesterday.

title: Bank Group Nominates
description: Francis B. Nimick Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Dollar Savings Bank of Pittsburgh, has been nominated as vice president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. The Dollar Savings Bank of Pittsburgh has no connection with the bank of the same name in New York City.

title: Model Bitten by Lion Were Takes $250,000 Settlement
description: A 26yearold Manhattan model who was bitten on the left thigh by a lion while posing at the 1966 International Auto Show has reluctantly agreed to accept damages of $250,000, her lawyers said yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and. Stream
description: There is an excellent store of basic information in Field & Stream's Justpublished International Fishing Guide for those who would like to angle in some distant part of the world.

title: Screen:
description: Vera Chytilova is a Czechoslovak director, born in 1929, who has been making movies since the early 1960's. One of her features, Daisies, played here in 1967, and I remember the episode as being the best thing in an omnibus film called Pearls on the ground, which was shown at the 1966 New York Film Festival. Something Different, made in 1963 and her first feature, had its local premiere yesterday at the New York Cultural Center, where it is the opening presentation in a program of early films of the recent Czech cinema. Something Different is playing through April 11 and, although a very much less than perfect movie, it is worth seeing.

title: Abortion Reform Rejected
description: BOSTON, April 7 (UPI)Bills to liberalize or repeal Massachusetts abortion laws were defeated today in the state Senate and House by overwhelming majorities.

title: An Admiral Speaks His Mind
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.One too often remains silent on issues which gnaw the vitals of his being. Along with a multitude of others I have long deplored the continuing decline of our country's prestige. Now, the disgraceful trial and conviction of Lieutenant Calley removes any reticence to offer constructive criticism of our government.

title: DONALDSON REPORTS INCREASE IN PROFITS

My wife, Gail, makes a very fine borscht, and we even feed it to Russian guests. But for the past year we've cooked Georgian in depth.

For one of the most demanding works in the repertoryfor the audience, too, with the opera's fivehour durationthe Met could call on replacements of a superior order.

description: MOSCOW, April 7The Soviet Union disclosed today that its military establishment was absorbing as much as a fourth of all the funds available for the growth of the nation's economy.

description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) Passengers boarding trains would be informed of emergency procedures to take in case of danger, As are air passengers, under a proposal made today by the National Transpertation Safety Board.

title: ' Shinbone Alley' Recalls Lives of archy and mehitabel:Marquis Theme Opens at Guild Theater
description: it s one day up and the next day downi led a romantic lifeit was being abducted so many timesas spoiled me for a wifedance mehitabel dancetill your old bones fly aparti aint got any regretsfor i gave my life to my artfrom "mehitabel dances with boreas" by Don Marquis"Shinbone Alley," which opened yesterday at the Guild Theater, is a musical cartoon feature about the late Don Marquis's philosophical cockroach named archy and archy's best friend, mehitabel, the down-at-the-heel alley cat to whom archy was a sometimes stern, sometimes astonished, but always fond Boswell. The movie, based on the 1957 Broadway show, has its ups and downs but, unlike the generous, ever optimistic mehitabel, I got my regrets.Except for one flaw, I might have forgiven the movie almost everything, including its rather ordinary, Tom & Jerry animation style, which occasionally peaks into designs in the now boring fashion of Max, and its musical score, which is, at best, reminiscent of Kurt Weill, not at his peak. "Shinbone Alley," after all, should send one back for a re-read of the original vers libre pieces that archy, more than 50 years ago, began to plunk out on the boss's typewriter (whose capital letters and punctuation marks were beyond his cockroach capacities).However, one thing about the movie must be unforgivable, at least to Marquis fans: the physical transformation of its heroine into a sleek, apparently sexy, cartoon pussycat, an unhappy feline sort of mix-up between Auntie Mame and Dolly Levi, with a voice provided by Carol Channing. Gone, lost in an earlier transmigration, is the indomitable old mehitabel who, as first drawn by George Herriman, looked like a refugee from Mr. Herriman's Krazy Kat world, a beat-up, emaciated lady with a gimpy hind leg and patchy, perpetually frozen fur that she tries to warm by dancing and singing the night away on the cobbles.Paradoxically, this cleaned-up, chic mehitabel, accountable to the animation designs of John D. Wilson, the film's director, is at odds most of the time with Joe Darion's screenplay. If you simply listen to the film, without watching it, you can actually hear the ferocious spirit of mehitabel behind all the pretty make-up. She is most definitely there, for example, when she staggers home to Shinbone Alley after a very short affair with a torn named big bill. Mehitabel says she has left big bill, but archy, somewhat petulant, points out that she never left a tom in her life. "I left ralph," says she. "ralph! ralph!," screams archy, "mehitabel, ralph was dead!"There is another bitter, pure Marquis sequence when mehitabel returns to Shinbone Alley with a litter of very tiresome, very unwanted kittens. With amazing, matter-of-fact cool, she discusses ways of disposing of them, in the river or maybe just by leaving them in a garbage can during a heavy rain. (They are not on hand at the end of the movie.)I thus am somewhat torn by this conflict between sound and image, resenting the rehabilitation job effected on the mehitabel, and yet cherishing those apparent reminders of what she once was, a toupours gal old dame with the soul of Cleopatra, the airs of Emma Bovary, the artistic longings of Isadora Duncan, the hangovers of Dorothy Parker's Big Blonde, and the sexual resolve of "Trash's" Holly Woodlawn.I suppose it would have been impossible to make an easily appreciated cartoon feature in the bleak visual style of Mr. Herriman's black-and-white drawings. The film's producers at least pay homage to the cartoonist in two short sequences. These are nice enough in themselves but have the effect of making the rest of the movie look as hard and idiosyncratic as a fresh marshmallow.Eddie Bracken provides the voice of archy and John Carridine is tyrone t tattersall, who has the best song in the show, a lament to the theater's good old days titled "They Don't Have It Here." I suspect that if it weren't for the attractively jazzy orchestrations, it would be impossible to remember the movie even has a score."Shinbone Alley" is a little like the old mehitabel. It suffers from split personality being based, as it is, on works that must go over the heads of 8-year-olds (at least those who won't know what's happening when archy gets rolled in a bordello staffed by ladybugs), but it's executed in a mostly juvenile style that's not too far removed from what the children see on television. It's a very mixed bag and this, in case you hadn't guessed, is a very mixed review.

title: OFFICIALS IN TOKYO COOL TO G.M.'s DEAL
description: TOKYO, April 7The Ministry of International Trade and Industry expressed reluctance today to approve General Motor's 35 per cent ownership of Isuzu motor stocks in their capital tieup plan.

title: US. IS PLANNING STEPUP IN ARMS FOR JORDANIANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The United States intends to increase substantially its military aid to Jordan, including additional modern tanks and possibly fourengine transport planes, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON WEAKEN AT CLOSE

title: Grumman Says It Faces Cost Problems on F14
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Grumman Corporation has written to the Navy, pleading that it is running into financial trouble in its attempt to meet its contract for the production of the F14 fighter plane, successor to the F4 Phantom.

description: WASHINGTON, April 7The Securities and Exchange Commission has indicated, in a letter to a member of Congress, that it still believes that pricefixing of sales commissions on stock transactions probably should end at the $100,000 mark, rather than at the $500,000 level that went into effect this week.

title: Laird Tightening Pentagon Control of Army Criminal Investigators

title: Helen Brooks, 60, Played Broadway Roles in 40's
description: Helen Brooks, the actress and the wife of James Waterman Wise, died on Tuesday in Nice, France. She was 60 years old and had lived with her husband in Europe, chiefly in Geneva, for the last 20 years.

title: Lindsay Urges Total Overhaul of Health Care System
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Mayor Lindsay of New York told a Senate subcommittee today that the American system of health care had failed to take care of the poor and urged a total overhaul of the national system.

title: U. of New Hampshire Head
description: DURHAM, N. H., April 7 (AP)  Thomas Benner 47yearold vice president and provost at the University of Cincinnati, was announced today as the new president of the University of New Hampshire. The announcement by the Chairman of the university trustees, Fred Hall Jr., culminates a year's search for replacement for John McConnell, 63, who will retire June 30.

title: Agnew Calls News Media Doubts Over Laos a Sign of Wide U.S. Masochism
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 Vice President Agnew said today that most knowledgeable people believed that it was too soon to judge the effectiveness of the South Vietnamese military thrust Into Laos. Yet, he said, the news media are pronouncing it a failure.

title: Gunmen in Teheran Wound Head of Military Tribunal
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 7Gen. Ziaddin Farsiou, the head of the military tribunal responsible for political trials in Iran, was severelywounded by gunmen this morning as he was leaving his house in north Teheran. His condition was said to be critical. His 16yearold son Farsad, who was with him, was also wounded, but not seriously.

title: U.S. Urges Pakistan Seek Peaceful Accommodation
description: WASHINGTON, April 7The United States called on Pakistan today to take every feasible step to end the conflict there and to achieve a peaceful accommodation in the civil disturbances that have racked the eastern half of the country since March 25.

title: 13 INDICTED BY U.S, IN JERSEY INQUIRY
description: NEWARK, April 7A Federal grand jury indicted 13 present and former public officials in southern NeW Jersey today In what was officially, described here as one of the biggest bribery conspiracy investigations ever conducted by the Federal Government in that part of the state.

title: 2 to Sue on F.B.I. Dismissal Because of Peace Activity
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) Two young women charging that they were forced to resign from the Federal Bureau of Investigation because of offduty involvement with antiwar activities said today that they would sue J. Edgar Hoover to get their jobs back.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Down
description: OTTAWA, April 7 (Reuters)The average yield on $165million 92day Canadian Treasury bills declined to 3.03 per cent from last week's 3.16 per cent, while the average price rose to $99.242 from $99.219. On the weekly issue of $45million in 183day bills the average yield fell to 3.22 per cent from 3.25 per cent while the average price rose to $98.413 from $98.406.

Ditson Conductor's Award for encouraging contemporary American music. A check for $1,000 will be presented to the conductor in Salt Lake City on Saturday, during the Utah Symphony's final concert of the season. Mr. Abravanel was born in Salonika, Greece, in 1903.

description: Attempts to combine a basic rock group (electric organ, electric guitar, electric bass and drums) with jazz horns (saxophone, trumpet, trombone) to create what is hopefully called jazzrock will apparently be exercises in futility as long as the rock element insists on playing its electrified instruments at die customary (for rock) earstopping level of amplification. Chicago, which is widely considered to be one of the better jazzrock groups, is demonstrating this conflict vividly at Cariegie Hall, which the group has taken over for the entire week, giving performances every evening through Saturday with additional midnight performances, on Friday and Saturday.

description: WASHINGTON, April 7Secretary of Defense Melvin It Laird said today that he had taken steps to guarantee there would be no more false alarms on the national civil defense broadcast system such as the One that confused the nation last Feb. 20.

The IBM 360 on the right, its associate, blinked 20 glass eyes and a man swallowed unnecessarily, and then it was 11:42:45 and the IBM 360 on the left wrote: Job 20 is purged.

Richardson Award, named for Werden's predecessor on The Times, was presented to Werden at a special reception by Roberto de Vicenzo, the Argentine professional.

description: The community school board of District 25 in Queens decided early today to put off action on a proposal to remove the Piri Thomas book Down These Mean Streets from school libraries until another meeting on April 19.

description: WASHINGTON, April 7President Nixon scheduled tonight a withdrawal of 100,000 more American soldiers from South Vietnam by Dec. 1.

description: GIANGHIA, South Vietnam, April 2  Quangduc has the fewest people of any of the 44 provinces of South Vietnam, and if those who live there had their way it would be smaller by nearly half.

Murphy had amended departmental rules to allow 18:yearolds to train as auxiliary policemen, assigned to performing clerical duties in police stations and, possibly, to auxiliarypolice rescue crews. The rules had required that trainees be 21 years of age or over to enroll in the voluntary citizens program.

title: Colonel Shepherd, an Architect, And Wife Killed in Auto Crash
description: Col. and Mrs. William Edgar Shepherd, who were active in civic, diplomatic and social affairs in Washington, were killed in an automobile accident near Columbia, S. C., on Tuesday. Colonel Shepherd was 80 years old and Mrs. Shepherd was 74. They had moved to Tryon, N. C., in 1967.

title: Court Denies Hazeltine Bid For Zenith Suit Rehearing
description: The Hazeltine Corporation has advised its stockholders that the Supreme Court has denied a petition for a rehearing of a Feb. 24 decision handed down by the Court against a subsidiary, Hazeltine Research. Inc, The Court previously ruled unanimously in favor of the Zenith Radio Corporation in its $19 million antitrust action against Hazeltine Research.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, April 7For the last 18 months, the economy, the war in Indochina and several associated issues have tended to dominate the American political dialogue. But this year's municipal elections, the first of which took place yesterday, are likely to thrust back into the foreground the questions of racial relations and social policy that loomed large in the voting for Mayors in 1967 and 1969 in such cities as Minneapolis, Detroit, Cleveland, Gary and Los Angeles.

title: Abortions Increase in Britain
description: LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) Legal abortions in Britain and Wales increased last year by more than 50 per cent to a total of 83,850, according to figures issued today. Of these, 16,000about 20 per centinvolved single women 19 years old or younger.

title: First MiddleIncome Units In City Aided by U.S. Begun
description: The city's first federally aided moderateincome housing projects, in the South Bronx Model Cities area, were started yesterday.

title: Council Unit Demands End To Subway Death Gamble
description: A City Council committee sparked hot controversy 3resterday In calling for the first real attempt in decades to reverse the subway system's collision course with disaster.

title: Puerto Rico: After Operation Bootstrap
description: So, what are you going to do for an encore?

title: No Test of Ideology
description: As for Chicago, no political observer in his right mind expected the defeat of Mayor Daley, in spite of the spirited campaign put on by a young, independent Democrat running on the Republican line. For all his culpability the brutal behavior of the Chicago police in August of 1968, Mr. Daley is not a reactionary ideologue in the fashion of a Reagan or a Thurmond. Neither is he a racist in a city with a great black population.

title: REACTION TO TALK MIXED IN CAPITOL
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 President Nixon's speech on Indochina was greeted tonight with praise by Republicans and with criticism by Democratic doves. Underlying the initial Congressional reaction was disappointment that the President had not gone further in defining a goal of total withdrawal from South Vietnam.

title: Westinghouse Chairman Optimistic on 71 Outlook
description: HOUSTON, April 7 (AP)The chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that the nation's economy has public buying power but is lacking public confidence. Once that is regained, the economy will move forward, Donald C. Burnham of Pittsburgh said at the annual stockholders meeting of Westinghouse.

title: Kleindienst Assails Boggs; Invites Inquiry Into F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Richard G. Hleindienst, Deputy Attorney General, asserted today that Representative Hale Boggs of Louisiana was either sick or not in possession of his faculties when he charged that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had tapped Congressmen's telephones and called for the resignation of J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Army Engineers to Issue Water Discharge Permits
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 7 (AP)The United Stats Army Corps of Engineers will begin this month to implement a permit program for all discharges into the nation's navigable waters.

title: So. Carolina Legislature Hears Frazier
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., April 7As the first black man to address the South Carolina Legislature since the Reconstruction Era a century ago, Joe Frazier changed roles today from world heavyweight boxing champion to civilrights champion.

title: Paris Collections Honor Max Ernst
description: PARIS, April 7The Max Ernst exhibition that opened at the Orangerie here over the weekend could be compared to a meal composed of beer, spaghetti, goulash, pineapple and cold tea, a menu of which everybody will like one course or another but hardly all. The show, ranging from 1920 to 1969, is a shrewd assembly of the almost schizophrenically dissimilar styles the artist has practiced over his long career.

title: New Drive Reported
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 7 (UPI)A Government spokesman said today that Palestinian guerillas had opened a new offensive in northern Jordan and the Jordan River valley, striking military installations, villages and an irrigation canal.

title: Mrs. Florence Latz, Aided The Blind for Many Years

description: Today is Good Friday. Following is a list of services that are or are not affected:

title: Effort Viewed as Way to Assure British Backing for Lockheed Project
description: The head of Trans World Airlines said yesterday that his company had been seeking a firm British European Airways order for the Lockheed airbus as part of an agreement for producing the plane with its original RollsRoyce engine.

title: Taubkin Retiring From Times; Blair to Head Public Relations
description: The retirement of Irvin S. Taubkin, director of public relations of The New York Times, snd the appointment of William G. Blair as his successor were announced yesterday by Sydney Gruson, vice president and assistant to the publisher.

title: Telephone Action Brisk, With First Pick a Winner
description: The first telephone bet for the nation's first legalized offtrack gambling system was made by a woman with the code name of Goldfinch here yesterday at 10:44 A.M. She bet $10 on Title Song to show in last night's first race at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: DOLLARS HOLDINGS INCREASE ABROAD
description: The turmoil in world financial markets during the last week led to a massive increase in the dollar holdings of foreign central banks, banking figures published yesterday showed.

title: A BRAZILIAN SINGER AND GUITARIST BOW
description: Vanja Orico, a Brazilian singer with many international films and Continental cafe appearances to her credit, made her New York debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. In a variety of folk and popstyle pieces, including some fascinating chants in Indian dialect, Miss Orico proved to be a fine entertainer. Her sultry voice, expressive gestures, charming introductions and infectious vitality all swirled the songs along with a bright lilt.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: 2,500Year Prison Term
description: DALLAS, April 8 (UPI)A jury sentenced a convicted murderer yesterday to 2,500 years in prison  the longest sentence handed down in Texas. But Robert Floyd Angle. 28 years old, will be eligible for parole in 20 years. He had been convicted of killing Jack Katz, 64, during a holdup of an auto supply store in Dallas in 1969.

title: A War Distorted
description: Whatever was to happen to William Calley, one result of the first Mylai trial was certain in advance: the United States Army was going to be found Guilty. The Army couldn't win. If Calley had been let off: a whitewash. If he had been (as he has been) condemned: a scapegoat for the higher brass. That's the way the media set it up and, in the courtrooms of our global village, the media, as we all know, are prosecutor, judge and jury.

title: 6 of 9 Retail Chains Report Increases In Easter Business
description: Despite a later Easter this year, consumer buying increased sharply last month in the stores of six of nine major retail chains that reported March results yesterday.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Pentagon generals and admirals, expert at feint and flank attack, have demonstrated in a series of bureaucratic skirmishes that they do not intend to be dominated by President Nixon's fledgling Office of Management and Budget Not all the details have emerged, but in the most Portentous clash the Joint Chiefs of Staff executed a successful maneuver around the office's director, George P. Shultz, and the Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird, to prevent a cut of $1.5billion to $2billion in the final defense request for the fiscal year 1972.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Nixon Move Denounced at Paris Talks
description: PARIS, April 8 PresidentI Nixon's announcement of continuing troop withdrawals was described today by the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong as a maneuver aimed at disguising the prolongation and widening of the war.

title: Emerson Beauchamp Bead; Active in Kentucky Politics
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 8 (AP)Emerson Beauchamp, a former Kentucky Lieutenant Governor and a central figure in the state's Democratic organization for nearly half a century, died last night of cancer. He was 71 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A healthy respect for history should make all who are concerned with the fate of Jerusalem take into account the fact that the Holy City is eminently and equally sacred to the three great religions, Judaism, Christianity and Islamciting them in the order of their appearance on the world scene.

title: POST OFFICE PLAITS A. SECURITY FORGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Post Office Department announced today that it would immediately begin organizing a new security force to protect major postal facilities.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
description: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: India, Backing Bengalis, Wary of Meddling Charge
description: NEW DELHI, April 8This house records its profound conviction that the historic upsurge of the 75 million people of East Bengal will triumph. The house wishes to assure them that their struggle and sacrifices will receive the wholehearted sympathy and support of the people of India.

title: Now Is the Time Revived
description: A revised version of Now Is the Time for All Good Men, the musical by. Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford, will be presented as the final production of the season by the Equity Library Theater. It will open April 29 and run through May 16 at the Master Theater,

title: Section of Road Seized
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 8 (AP)North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops were reported today to have seized a twomile section of Route 4, which links the capital city of Pnompenh with the port of Kompong Som, on the Gulf of Siam.

title: WHITE HOUSE VIEW OF WIRETAP RIGHT DENIED ON APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 5A Federal Court of Appeals rejected today the Nixon Administration's assertion that FedH eral agents may legally wiretap radical groups without, court approval.

title: GEN. HUMFREY GALE, EISENHOWER DEPUTY
description: GENEVA, April 8 (UPI)Lieut. Gen. Sir Humfrey M. Gale, Britain's deputy chief of staff to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the World War II Supreme Command, died today at his home above Lake Geneva. Ho was 80 years old.

title: Carter Goodrich, Taught at Pittsburgh
description: Dr. Carter Goodrich, Mellon professor of history and professor of economics at the University of Pittsburgh, who formerly served on the governing body of the International Labor Organization, died Wednesday in Mexico City. He was 73 years old.

title: G.I. TOLL IN WEEK AT 9MONTH HIGH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 9  The United States command reported today that 88 American soldiers, were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the highest toll for a week in nearly 10 months.

title: Fire Damages College Data
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., April 8 (UPI) Fire caused up to $500,000 damage today at the administration building of the University of California's new Santa Cruz campus. The police said they suspected arson. Student records concerning academic achievement, housing, loans and other data were destroyed.

title: Bridge: Optimism and Intuition Carry The Day for Potential Experts
description: Those who fail to survive the qualifying stage of a championship normally have the Oppertunity to compete in a consolation event. Experts who have had the misfortune not to qualify usually spurn this golden opportunity and seek other forms of consolation.

title: Mayor Leaves for Skiing
description: Mayor Lindsay left New York yesterday for an Easter weekend in Vail, Colo. Before departing for the skiing trip, the Mayor taped his Sunday night television program. City Hall aides said they expected him to return late Sunday night, although he has no public appearances scheduled through Monday.

title: Screen: Confrontations in 'Branches':Ed Emshwiller's Work Comes to Film Forum Portrays Fantasy Role of College Students
description: Ed Emshwiller began making movies in 1959, and ever since he has in one connection or another figured as among the best of those filmmakers who used to be, and maybe still are, known as the New American Cinema. Emshwiller is a cinematographer of considerable accomplishment, and even those who have not much cared for his films ("Thanotopsis," 1962; "Relativity," 1966; etc.) have admired their camera work. In his collaborations with others, for example as photographer of "Hallelujah the Hills" (1962), it is difficult to say much about Emshwiller's contribution that isn't praise."Branches," which opened last night at the Film Forum, where it will play on Thursday through Sunday evenings for the next two weekends, represents something of a collaboration. During the summer of 1970, Emshwiller was in residence at Cornell University where, together with a good many students, he made this filmwhich I trust was as much fun to put together as it now is to see.As the film's hero (Bill Weidnerlong-haired, bearded, and always wearing an undershirt marked with No. 1) sits in the student union listening to a friend (Christian Larson) tell a tale of improbable sexual success, he notices a pretty girl (Connie Brady) at the next table and fantasizes an affair with her. There may also actually be an affair. "Branches" is at no pains to clarify this, and I doubt that it matters much.What does matter is the succession of comic confrontations, somewhere between blackout skit and dramatic agon, that are the film's substance and the better part of its style.Actually there is rather too much style in the serious-cinema sense  superimposed images, repetitions of actions with minor variations, a chorus that alternately praises and blames the hero for obvious reasons. At its most pretentious worst, "Branches" looks a lot like a college arts festival, with much expressive formalism, a collection of modern dancers, and a ballerina who occasionally wanders through in the background.But at its least pretentious best it looks more like some of the nicer parts of college itselfintelligent, clever, at ease with its own discomforts. Bill is the kind of seducer who gets rejected even in his own fantasies, so I find him easy to identify with. And in the course of the little sketches, the returns to the battlefield of the daybed, that identification becomes an increasingly more rewarding pleasure.There are several other confrontations (all the talk is improvised, I understand)between Bill and an art-as-politics freak, between Bill and a Black Power theoretician, between both Bill and Connie and a women's liberationist and, best of all, a girl (Erica Saxe) forthrightly on the make for Bill. I loved the last and her rage at the beautiful Connie ("You are an evil person. Your hair is evil!"). But I loved Connie moreher reserve, her coldness, her appetites, her complexities, her arrogant good looks.Near the end, Emshwiller, who is old enough to appreciate a bit of sexual metamorphosis, dances her into a tree. He is very good at this sort of thing, and in "Branches," by grace of the life he fosters around himself, he earns his ecstasy.

title: Art by 22 Children From East Harlem Shown by Museum
description: Nearly 40 paintings, wood carvings, drawings and papiermache masks inspired by Central and West African motifsthe work of 22 children of Intermediate School 201 in East Harlemwent on display this week in the American Museum bf Natural History.

title: Hamburger With Good, Lean MeatWhat Next!
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: ERENNSY AIDES SUED BY TRUSTEES
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP) The Penn Central Transportation Company charged today that two former top financial officers and a principal investment adviser organized and Ranipulated an unlawful conspiracy that caused America's biggest railroad to suffer heavy losses and forced it into reorganization.

title: Brooklyn Boy Arrested In Shooting of 3 Persons
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn boy was arrested yesterday after he allegedly shot three persons in a dispute between two families.

title: Decision on Shoe Imports Is Deferred by President
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Nixon disclosed today that he had decided to defer a decision on general import relief for the shoe industry, though he opened the way to adjustment assistance for 11 groups of workers in the industry.

title: RentzelPleads Guilty, le Put On Probation for 5 Years
description: DALLAS, April 8 (UPI)Lance Rentzel, Cowboy flanker, received a fiveyegt probated sentence today on a charge of indecent exposure. He said he did itot intend to let the incident end his athletic career.

title: Blues Even Series
description: ST. LOUIS, April 8 (UPI)Jim Roberts scored two goals and Wayne Connelly one in the third period tonight as the St. Louis glues posted a 42 victory over the Minnesota North Stars an the second game of their playoff series. The triumphed evened the series at one game each.

title: Roundup: Indians Rookie Borrowing Clothes, Time
description: Harold Morris Hodge of Rutherfordion. N. C., arrived at Municipal Stadium in Cleveland yesterday with $5 in his pocket and wearing a sportcoat and shirt borrowed from two teammates. He said that He was uncertain about moving his belongings to Cleveland because, well, his future was hardly as stable as A.T.&T.'s.

title: Canadiens Rally to Beat Bruins 75
description: BOSTON, April 8 (UPI)Jean Beliveau rallied his Montreal Canadiens from a fourgoal deficit to a 75 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight to deadlock their Stanley Cup fourofseven playoff series at one game apiece.

title: Easterners Claim Control
description: KUSHTIA, Pakistan, April 8 (AP)  Two weeks after the fighting began, East Pakistanis appear to be controlling almost half of the eastern wing of the country, according to resistance leaders here.

title: Pulitzer Publishing Buys The Arizona Daily Star
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 8 (AP) The Pulitzer Publishing Company, publisher of The St. Louis PostDispatch, purchased The Arizona Daily Star today for an estimated total of $10million.

title: Merger News
description: ROCHESTER, April 8 CAP)The Gannett Company, Inc., a newspaper chain headquartered here, and Federated Publications, Inc., of Battle Creek, Mich., have reached a tentative agreement to merge, it was announced today. The agreement is valued at more than $69million. Federated publishes seven daily newspapers in four states: Battle Creek and Lansing, Mich., Lafayette and Marion, hid Olympia and Bellingham, Wash., and Boise, Idaho. Gannett has 36 daily newspapers in seven states. The merger agreement has been approved by the directors of both companies and is subject to the approval of stockholders of both.

title: Air Strikes Announced
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 8 The Pakistani Government announced today that it had mounted air strikes on hostile pockets of armed infiltrators in East Pakistan and had also raided roadblocks erected by miscreants.

title: Purpose of Invitation
description: TOKYO, April 8 (AP)A report from Peking today said that the Chinese invitation to an American table tennis team was aimed more at building friendship between the two peoples than at improving relations between their governments.

title: Soviet Congress Nearing End; Politboro to Be Named Today
description: MOSCOW, April 8  The 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party neared its conclusion today with a final round of praise for the Kremlin's policies and a secret afternoon session for the formal selection of the party's Central Committee.

title: World's Quietest Helicopter Announced by Hughes Tool
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Hughes Tool Company announced today that it had developed the world's quietest helicopter.

title: TIGER CAGE PRISON ATTACKED BY REID
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Representative Ogden R. Reid, the ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Opertions subcommittee, charged today in letters to two Administration officials that the treatpent of Communist prisoners in South Vietnam represented a continuing violation of the Geneva Convention.

title: Plan for Domed Stadium Stirs New Orleans Resistance
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 6 Louisiana officials are going ahead with plans to build a $150  million air  conditioned sports arena in downtown New Orleans amid allegations of boondoggle, swindle and kickbacks.

title: HOWARD DEVILBISS, A TOLEDO EXECUTIVE
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 8Howard Parker DeVilbiss, president from 1944 to 1967 of the DeVilbiss Corporation, manufacturers of spray painting equipment, died yesterday at his home. His age was 62.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Military conscription has been part of the American scene for more than thirty years. Many of our lawmakers appear to have become so habituated to the permanence of the draft that a great deal of the current debate over its extension does not focus on the heart of the question.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, April 8There was general agreement here today that President Nixon gave a little ground last night to all the factions that have been tugging at his Vietnam policy.

title: Electoral Board Boondoggle
description: The New York City Board of Elections is an anachronistic collection of patronage posts that fails to serve the citizenry and burdens the public treasury. To expand the board's membership from the present four members to a proposed ten, without making more fundamental changes, would be to move in exactly the wrong direction. Rather than fulltime posts at $17,500 annually, membership on the board could be made parttime and salary put on a perdiem basis. A single administrator could assume prime responsibility for registering voters.

description: CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)With Bobby Hull and Stan Mikita scoring twice each, the Chicago Black. Hawks stampeded the Philadelphia Flyers, 62, tonight to take a 2.0 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: Harry E. Maule, Editor, Dead at 84
description: Harry E. Maule, a book publishing executive and editor for more than half a century, died yesterday at the Montclair Nursing Home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 84 years old and formerly lived in Garden City.

title: 3Pronged Attack Reported
description: NEW DELHI. April 8 (Reuters)The Press Trust of India said Pakistan military forces launched a threepronged attack today to establish control in the western region of East Pakistan.

title: A.A.U. Invites Japanese
description: TOKYO, April 8 (AP) The Amateur Athletic Union has invited Japanese athletes to compete in the A.A.U. track and field meet in Berkeley, Calif, July 2 and 3, the Japanese Amateur Athletic Federation said today.

title: Elizabethan Drama At London Theater Keeps Its Secrets
description: LONDON, April 8Because some Elizabethan plays deal with the common life of the times, it is easy to read more realism into them than they actually contain. This temptation is stoutly resisted by John Dexter, whose production of Thomas Heywood's A Woman Killed With Kindness at the National Theater dwells more on recreating a vanished society than on relating it to the world we know.

title: India Accused in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8Pakistan charged here today that India was interfering directly in East Pakistan by using armed infiltrators in plain clothes, by sending in truckloads of army and by massing six divisions on the border.

description: To the Editor: The Appalachian mountains are being destroyed by strip mining while conservationists in and out of government agitate for new laws to stop it. Ironically, effective legislation to save the hills may be available, though wholly unenforced.

description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: State Will Ask U.S. To Give Long Island Priority for Work
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 8 State Labor Commissioner Louis L. Levine said today that he would ask the Federal Government to declare Nassau And Suffolk Counties high unemployment areas.

title: Little Stir in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8President Nixon's announcement of the withdrawal of 100,000 troops by December created little stiy, in Saigon today.

title: DISMISSAL ASKED IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: Six pretrial motions have been filed by defense lawyers in the Berrigan conspiracy case, including a motion to dismiss the charges because of publicity before indictment and a challenge to the constitutionality of a Federal statute under which the six defendants were charged.

title: American Paintings Make Record Gains As Auction Closes
description: An audience at an auction of American paintings yesterday  the last part of a sale begun on Wednesday evening bid enthusiastically on works that just a few years ago commanded a fraction of the $1million spent in the twoday evert.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is something very special about these northern voyages, Samuel Eliot Morison casually remarks at the start of his account of the earliest explorations of the treacherous North Atlantic, where anything might happen to you. And he's made a very special book about them. We're moved, to begin with, by its existence: a 700page narrative from an 83yearold historian who announces that it is the first, God willing, of a three  volume study. If it were feeble, who would say so? We could just compose valentines about his distinguished career instead of reviewing the look at hand. But no such polite sidestepping gavottes will be needed. The European Discovery of America is splendid: It is wittily, vigorously written, shrewd and decisive in judgment, unfailingly enjoyable.

title: 8 CHARGED IN LAOS WITH PLANNING COUP
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 8 (Reuters)  Eight persons, including several former highranking military officers, were reportedly under arrest today for their part in a proposed coup against the Laotian Government that was apparently called off at the last minute.
