title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to a. Defense Department announcement, the doctor draft has been resumed. Over 1,500 physicians will be drafted this year. Many of this group have already received their draft notices. Many are receiving them at this moment.

title: Mali Said to Foil Plot
description: BAMAKO, Mall, April 8 (Reuters)President Moussa Traord said last night that plot to overthrow his ruling Military Committee for National Liberation had been foiled. In a radio speech, President Traore said two members of the committee, Capt. Yoro Dialdto and Capt. Malik Diallo, had been behind the plot and had been discharged from the committee and the army.

title: Prince Recalls the Evolution of Follies
description: Once there was a little murder mystery musical called The Girls Upstairs fermenting in the minds of playwright James Goldman and composer Stephen Sondheim. Now there is the smash hit musical spectacular Follies thriving at the Winter Garden. The metamorphosis took six years, at least 19 rewrites, and, finally, nine months of intensive creative collaboration.

title: Mount Etna Is Erupting
description: CATANIA, Sicily, April 8 (AP)  Mount Etna thundered today in a growing eruption, and two 200yardwide rivers of molten rock poured almost a mile down the mountainside.

title: War and Proportionality
description: To the Editor: While agreeing with A. Frank Reel (OpEd March 31) that the Yamashita decision 25 years later appears to have been essentially an exercise in vengeance and to have violated historic principles by punishing a man for the position he held rather than for the acts he had committed or had omitted, I believe that Mr. Reel falls into grave error in concluding from this that the laws of war serve only to glorify war and to hide its true import.

title: MEDICAID'S ROLE IN ABORTIONS CUT
description: ALBANY, April 8 (UPI)The state's Commissioner of Social Services, George K. Wyman, issued an order today banning the use of Medicaid fees for abortions on demand.

description: SAIGON, Friday, April 9 (Reuters) North Vietnamese gunners shelled an American helicopter base here today in South Vietnam's Central Highlands. About eight rockets and mortar shells hit Camp Holloway but no casualties or damage was reported.

description: Over hoots and hollers from an angry audience that drowned out their voice votes, members of Community School Board 23 in Brooklyn ratified the suspension of the district superintendent, Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan, at a public meeting that ended early yesterday.

title: Families Flee Town
description: SATKHIRA, Pakistan, April 8 (Reuters)Scores of terrorstricken families tonight fled this town in the Khulna district of East Pakistan amid reports that a Pakistani Army column was moving on the area.

title: News Analysis
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 8 (AP) A New Zealandborn correspondent and a Japanese cameraman were listed as missing today, 24 hours after they disappeared during a battle.

title: A King's Songs Evoke the Medieval Era
description: The 13thcentury king of Castile and Leon, Alfonso X, was known as el Sabio. This has been variously translated as the sage, the wise and the learned. The epithet was coined for his cultural interests, not for his disastrous political rule. In a book called Las Cantigas de Santa Marfa he compiled songs and verses about the Virgin Mary, for whom he said ho foreswore all other women that he might regain through her what he had lost through them. He perhaps wrote some of the works himself.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the Boston Celtics were slashing their imperious way along the glory road during the reign of King Auerbach the Red, they were never merciful to the opposition. When the Chicago Bears were the most feared team in pro football, they showed their true character in the classic 730 rout of the Washington Redskins. There was no pity. Nor did the Yankees of Murderers Row and of succeeding Yankee dynasties hold down the score in kindly fashion. No fighter ever could match Jack Dempsey for killer instinct.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a draft law is prepared, it is important to study the consequences of some provisions which might be included in it. One of these possible changes is the elimination of the 2S Classification, the deferment for college students. At this very time many private colleges and universities are undergoing serious financial crises. These institutions depend on tuition as a major source of income and they likewise depend on a relatively constant number of their students continuing their studies in a normal sequence.

title: NOOSE PANEL BIDS C.B.S. YIELD FILMS
description: The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee served a subpoena yesterday on the Columbia Broadcasting System to obtain all televised and untelevised materials pertaining to the network's controversial documentary The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: Susan. Goldberger Wed to I. J. Jacoby
description: Miss Susan Goldberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goldberger of New York, was married Wednesday to James J. Jacoby, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Jacoby of New York.

description: Two newcomers joined the cast of the City Opera production of Roberto Devereux, Wednesday night, Sergio Di Amorim in the title role and Kay Creed as Sara.

description: Commemorative Chanel group by David includes easy coat and a sweater suit with a wrapped skirt.

title: Oakley Posts 71 in Taiwan
description: LINKOU, Taiwan, April 8 (AP)  Eleuterio Nival of the Philippines and Cho Amkill of South Korea shot fourunderpar 68's to tie for the firstround lead in the China open golf tournament today. Tomoo Ishii, who posted a 69, had a, holeinone. David Oakley of Vienna, Va., carded a 71 at the Linkou International Golf and. Country Club.

title: Californian Backs Boggs
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Representative Phillip Burton said in a speech at the Wornan's National Democratic Club today that he agrees with Mr. Boggs that Mr. Hoover should retire.

title: Offtrack Bet Shops Swamped on First Day
description: A $2 bet made by Mayor Lindsay on a pacer named Money Wise helped get the country's first system of legal offtrack wagering onto the track here yesterday.

title: TESTS ON READING DENIED TO BOARD
description: A Manhattan district superintendent has refused to turn over last week's reading test papers of his pupils to Board of Education headquarters for scoring because, he said, the citywide tests were unfair to many children.

title: HEGKL REGISTERS 20 SWIM VICTORY
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 8 (AP)Frank Heckl of Southern California registered his second upset in as many nights by winning the 200yard freestyle event tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union short course swimming championships.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
description: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: At Grand Central: Long Wait, as Usual
description: With a pot of gold hopefully at the end of the line, the openingday customers of offtrack betting at Grand Central Terminal waited as long as two hours yesterday to place their wagers.

title: Davis Case Judge Denies Bias, Refuses to Disqualify Himself
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 8  The judge whom Angela Davis sought to have removed from her pretrial hearings rpled today that there was no reason why he should be disqualified from the case.

title: IT WAS BIG NIGHT ON TRACK AND OFF
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 8Legalized offtrack betting got off to what Howard. S. Samuels, its most, enthusiastic proponent, described as a fantastic start, with $62,306 from two outside parlors wagered on the rapes at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Samuels, the president of New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, had predicted that the handle from Grand Central and Forest Hills would reach merely $10,000.

title: Beauty Stands Out In Cubist Exhibition
description: Having liked everything about The Cubist Epoch, which opens to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum, I was surprised to learn that it came under critical attack during its run at the cosponsoring institution, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It seems to have disappointed people who expected it to update Alfred H. Barr's 1936 landmark exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, Cubism and Abstract Art, and its nowclassic catalogue.

title: DEMARTINOS SEEKING REVERSAL ON CHILD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nick DeMartino of Brooklyn, whose 10monthold adopted daughter Lenore the State Court of Appeals ordered on Wednesday to be returned to her natural mother filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to reverse the decision.

title: Chief of S.C.I. Assails Police on Heroin
description: The chairman of the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that the Police Department's conscious policy of concentrating on arresting lowlevel street addicts has had no impact on the heroin acivities of organized crime.

title: Chemical, Bankers Trust Gain;
description: Two more of New York's principal banking organizations reported higher first quarter profits yesterday as declines in revenue were more than offset by lower costs for borrowed funds.

title: SALMONELLA FOUND IN CHOCOLATE CANDY
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI)Suspected contamination of a large batch of chocolate candy and cake frosting was announced by the Food and Drug Administration today, a month after the hazard was discovered. The manufacterer said most of it had been eaten by now.

title: Harvard Names a Curator
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 (AP)  Harvard University announced today the appointment of Harley P. Holden as curator of the University Achives. Mr. Holden, now assistant curator, is to succeed Kimball Elkins, who will retire July 1.

title: Pope Paul Compares Defecting Priests to Judas
description: ROME, April 8In an unusually bitter homily during Maundy Thursday rites today, Pope Paul VI likened defecting priests to Judas.

title: MADRIGAL SINGERS AND CHOIR AT TULLY
description: The Madrigal Singers and University Choir of Washington University, St. Louis, sang al Tully Hall Wednesday night under the direction of Orland Johnson.

title: Ceylon Army Reports Capture of Rebel Bands
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 8 (Reuters)  Army authorities reported today that troops had rounded up bands of armed insurgents who, they said, had mounted a nationwide terrorist, movement. They said the situation was under control.

title: Bridge Reported Destroyed
description: NEW DELHI, India, April 8 (AP)East Pakistani independence forces said today that they had blown up a rail bridge linking the armyheld cities of Dacca and Chittagong, had destroyed an airfield near Comilla and had captured an army depot holding nine tons of arms and ammunition.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: News Analysis
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 8Haven't you heard? Mrs. Ilona Hancock asked yesterday, Berkeley is at least five years ahead of the rest of the country.

title: COPPER REFORM BILL IS APPROVED IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile April 8The constitutional reform that President Salvador Allende Gossens has proposed to nationalize the copper industry, was passed by the Chamber of Deputies with small but significant modifications.

title: KNICKS, BULLETS IN GAME TWO HERE
description: With the competition down to four teams, the National Basketball Association playoffs resume today with the New York Knicks facing the Baltimore Bullets at Madison Square Garden in the afternoon and the Los Angeles Lakers taking on the Milwaukee Bucks at Milwaukee in the evening.

title: FRAUD PLOT CHARGED ON PARTS FOR PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)  A Federal grand jury indicted five former officials of an Indiana manufacturing concern today for conspiracy to defraud the Government by making unauthorized welds on parts they were supplying for the F111 military airplane.

title: U.S. to Be Asked to Reconsider Visit by a Red Chinese Athlete
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8Encouraged by what they consider a philosophical shift, a group sponsoring a track and field meet here May 16 said today that it would recontact State Department sources about Inviting a leading high jumper from Communist China.

title: OTB Losers Will Eat Better in Some Places
description: A restaurant chain jumped onto the OTB promotional bandwagon yesterday with an offer designed to appeal to losers.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Citizenship in Peril
description: Citizenship is an inviolable right. A naturalized citizen, unless he obtained his citizenship by fraud, is fully the equal of a nativeborn citizen and entitled to the same protection. But a 5to4 majority of the Supreme Court in an extraordinarily niggling, not to say tortured, construction of the Constitution, has ruled that the Government can do to a person naturalized abroad what it cannot do to a person naturalized in this country: deprive him of his citizenship against his will.

title: Blanton Backs Mills for 721
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) Representative Ray Blanton, Democrat of Tennessee, became the first Congressman today to announce formally his support of Wilbur D, Mills for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972,

title: Colley and Writer Get $100,000 Book Advance
description: First Lieut. William J. Galley Jr. and John Sack, a writer, received a $100,000 advance for publication of Lieutenant Calley's memoirs, Thomas Guinzberg, the president of Viking Press, Inc., said today.

title: HANNUM WILL HEAD A.B.A. DENVER CLUB
description: SAN DIEGO, April 8 (UPI)Alex Hannum quit as coach of the National Basketball Association San Diego Rockets today to become head coach, president and general manager of the Denver Rockets of the American Basketball Association.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The naive editorial Congress and the Middle East (March 26) appears in the company of such lucid articles as The Bean and the Pill and Divided Command in Saigon. All is not lost.

title: Nixon Planning to Clarify Caney Case Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, April 8President Nixon intends to issue a clarification of his intervention in the Calley case, White House sources said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: BAD NEWS. By Paul Spike. 152 pages. Holt, Rinehart and Winston. M.O.

title: Man in the News
description: When Howard J. Samuels tried for the second time in 1966 to become New York's Democratic candidate for Governor, his promotional brochure carried the title: The Man With the Plan. An editorial reproduced, in the brochure began as follows: Samuels is a 46yearold polaical package who seems to have everything it would take to run. He has brains, savvy, charm, obvious sex appeal, money, a handsome wife, eight children and a Horatio Alger background in industry.

title: Washington Post Criticized By Its Own TV Station
description: The Washington Post, which was critical of the Columbia Broadcasting System's methods of editing The Selling of Pentagon, has come under the editorial fire of its won televisien station, WTOPTV.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There have been some hopeful developments recently on the problems of transportation and air pollution in the New York metropolitan area. Governor Cahill of New Jersey deserves congratulations for putting the Port of New York Authority on notice that it must aid the mass transit situation; the extension of express bus service for commuters is good news, too.

title: Auto Talks to Resume
description: DETROIT, April 8 (AP)American Motors Corporation announced today that it would resume contract negotiations in Milwaukee Monday with the United Automobile Workers union. The contract at the plant expired last Oct. 14.

title: China Quietly Renewing An Active Role in Africa
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 8A Chinese Communist diplomat, Chang Li, came to this sultry capital the other day to open an embassy, establishing diplomatic relations with Nigeria and marking what many regard as a turning point in the Peking Government's relations with Africa.

title: Filion Joins Houghton With 3,000 Victories
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (UPI)Herve Filion scored the 3.000th victory of his career last night with Allegiance Son in the fifth race at Liberty Bell Park and became the second man in harness racing history, to aceompliih the feast.

title: 3 SENATORS AVER NIXON SAID HE HAD PULLOUT DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 Three Senate leaders said today that President Nixon indicated at a private briefing yesterday that he intended to withdraw all United States troops from Indochina by a specific date, but the White House vehemently denied it.

title: Children's Voices of Hope and Despair
description: The following quotations from Puerto Rican children at Public School 15 on the Lower East Side have been taken from compositions compiled into a paperback called Can't You Hear Me Talking to You?

description: Article 2  No Title

title: SAMUEL'S DREAM IS NO NIGHTMARE
description: When Howard S. Samuels woke up Yesterday in his apartment on East 52d Street, he had a terrifying thought about the plunger who had waited All night at Grand Central Terminal to be the first legal offtrack bettor.

title: Screen:
description: RIGHT ON!, directed by Herbert Danska; written by The Original Last Pouts; Photography by Amin Chaudri, Joe Zysman and Herbert Danska; produced by Woodle King Jr. and Mr. Denska; Presented by Concept East Ltd. At the New Yorker Theater, Broadway and 88th Street, the Evergreen Theater, 11th Street at University Place, end the Roosevelt Theater, Seventh Avenue and 145th Street. Running time: 80 minutes. (Not submitted at this time to the Motion Pictura Association of America's Production Code and Riding Administration for rating as to audience suitability.) With The Original Last Poets Wan Rain, David Nelson and Folios Lump.

title: A Black Director Of G.M. Will Vote Against the Board
description: DETROIT, April 8The new black director of the General Motors Corporation has told his fellow directors he will vote against them and in favor of an Episcopal Church resolution calling on G. M. to close its plants in South Africa.

description: Article 7  No Title

title: IRVING WERSTEIN, WROTE 40 BOOKS
description: Irving Werstein, an author of some 40 books, chiefly for young persons, died of a heart attack on Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 511 East 20th Street.

title: Revolution on Wall Street
description: The earth did not give way this week when the New York Stock Exchange abandoned the system of fixed commissions under which it had operated since its founding in 1992. To be sure, many brokers are extremely unhappy over the forced switch to negotiated commissions on the portion of orders over $500,000. They contend that this will slice deeply into their revenues and may drive some out of business.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Hope for Native Alaskans
description: Unlike most numbers games, the one now being played with the land claims of Alaska's native population promises more good than harm. As the figures rise, so do the possibilities that this country may treat the Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts of its northern reaches with the justice it denied to the Indians of its older states.

title: Goody's 66 Leads Masters Golf
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8Ever Rime the afternoon in April, 1969, when he tossed away the lead and a chance to win the Masters by taking bogeys at the last three holes, Charlie Coolly has been wondering if he would ever have an opportunity like that again.

title: Rock Singers Help Ease the Shortage of Cantors
description: For generations, most of the cantors who lead the musical part of Jewish services came from an lite group consisting of sons of cantors and devout youths who, from their earliest years, spent long hours singing in synagogue choirs.

description: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: SteppedUp Draft of Doctors Called Peril to Hospitals in City
description: The Defense Department's steppedup conscription of young physicians has placed thousands of sick people in New York City in serious danger, an organization of interns and residents declared yesterday.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
description: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: U. S. Envoy Sees Mrs. Meir
description: TEL AVIV, April 8 (Reuters) The United States Ambassador, Walworth Barbour, asked Israel to clarify her conditions for a possible reopening of the Suez Canal when he met Premier Golda Meir here today at his request, informed Israeli sources said.

title: Fire Chief Bars Flag Decals
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP) Fire Commissioner James J. McCarey has ordered city firemen to remove American flag decals from their helmets and flag patches from their uniform shoulders. He said yesterday that department regulations permitted firemen to display only the Hero Award and certain service pins.

title: 9 TOPPED MILLION IN FARM SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department said today that 23 big farm operators got Federal farm subsidies of $500,000 or more in 1970  the last year the law will allow most of them to get such large payments.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BUENOS AIRESIn France of the Third Republic it was often said that the best profession from which to launch a political career was that of veterinary because it enables a candidate to insure the farmer's vote in his district. In most countries the law is considered the likeliest springboard but any aspirant for high office in the Argentine Republic might do well to start in an officers academy.

title: The Foibles and Rigidities of the Spanish Add Up to a Best Seller in Spain
description: MADRID, April 8A recruit from a village in Aragon was given leave to go home for his aunt's funeral. When he reported back his khaki uniformcap, straps, insignia and allwas black. He had dyed it for the occasion.

title: Lunekhod Resumes Work
description: MOSCOW, April 8 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union's Lunokhod moon buggy has begun its sixth lunar working day on the moon's Sea of Rains, the official press agency Tass reported today. The lunar day lasts the equivalent of two weeks on earth. The Lunokhod, an eight  wheeled automatic vehicle controlled by scientists in the Soviet Union, now is exploring a lunar crater 220 yards in diameter.

title: Britain Widens Fight on Oil Pollution
description: LONDON, April 8The Government today asserted legal authority to seize or sink any oil tanker threatening to pollute Britain's shores, whether inside or outside her territorial waters.

title: NIXON ASSURANCES TO U.A.R, REPORTED
description: CAIRO, April 8Reliable sources reported today that the recent letter from President Nixon to President Anwar elSadat assured United States support for Cairo's proposal for an Israeli pullback from the Suez Canal and a reopening of the waterway. Mr. Nixon was also reported to have urged the Egyptians to be patient.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN NARROW GAINS
description: The stock market showed little reaction to President Nixon's televised Wednesday night address on Vietnam as prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: Grumman Expects Profit Only on First 38 Navy F44 Planes It Makes
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that it expected to make a profit on its present contract to produce 38 F14 Navy fighters, but diCknowledged that it faced losses on subsequent production contracts without a price increase from the Pentagon.

title: Chris Everett, 16, Upsets Miss Burr in Pro Tennis
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 8 (UPI) Thirdseeded Francoise Durr of France was upset, 6.0, 75, by 16yearold Chris Everett of Fort Lauderdale today in the $15,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament.

title: FLORMIANS VICTORS; EVEN SERIES AT 22
description: MIAMI, April 8, (AP)Mack Calvin's 35 points acid Ira Harge'd Play under the beards tonight led the Floridians, to a 129117 victor over the Kentucky Colonels, The victory squared their semifinal playoff series in the Eastern Division of the Amarican Basketball ASsociation at two games apiece.

title: POLICEMAN SAVES 3 BUT 2 DIE IN S.I. FIRE
description: A policeman on his way to work yesterday rescued three persons from a blazing threestory frame building on Staten Island. However, he was prerented by intense flames from, saving two small children, who died in the blaze.

title: Armed Suspect Shot Trying to Flee Court
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 8  An alleged terrorist bomber and bank robber was shot down in the Federal Courthouse here today while brandishing a sawedoff automatic rifle reportedly smuggled to him by his wife in their second escape attempt in a year.

title: TEACHERS DIG IN IN NEWARK STRIKE
description: NEWARK, April 8  The Newark Teachers Union announced today that it would make no further, proposals to end its 10weekold strike until the Board of Education made a contract offer.

title: Webcor Sets Comeback in Audio Products
description: In the fifties, during the development of the longplaying phonograph record, the Webcor name became one of the best known in the highfidelity field. But time, events, and the increasing flow of Japanese electronics imports took their toll on Webcor.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Nixon's Vietnam pullout speech of Wednesday night, on the surface, failed to stir any big waves in the stock market yesterday. But leading Wall Street analysts noted in private conversations that what stock prices failed to donamely, take a spilloffered proof of the market's internal strength. And this means, or so these Wall Streeters reason, that over the rest of 1971 and into 1972 the out look is for pronounced gains in equity prices.

title: Kleindienst Modifies Suggestion Congress Investigate the F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April S (UPI) Richard G. Kleindienst, the Deputy Attorney General, said today that he never intended to suggest that Congress undertake a fullscale investigation into the operations of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Brooklyn Museum Gets Year's Millionth Visitor
description: Yesterday morning at 10 o'clock Mrs. Anna Tannenberg, a 69yearold Brooklyn housewife, became the one millionth visitor to the Brooklyn Museum this fiscal year, which ends June 30. It was the first time that the museum reached the million mark in attendance within one year since 1933, when, as one museum spokesman said, people went to museums to forget about the Depression and get in out of the cold.

title: Screen:
description: 42d STREET MOVIE and SETUP: Two documentaries by Monoles Nob. At tho Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue and 75th Street. Respective running times: 18 and 60 minutes.

title: DR. LOUIS GOLDSTBN OF U. OF CONNECTICUT
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 8Dr. Louis H. Goldstein, professor of social research at the University of Connecticut School of Social Work, died, of a heart, attack Tuesday. His age was 51.

title: Let's Hear From Hanoi
description: One American dying in combat is one too many. But our goal is no American fighting man dying in any place the world. Every decision I have made in the past, and every decision I make in the future, will have the purpose of achieving that goal. President Nixon in his Wednesday night address on Vietnam.

title: Football Star Breaks Leg
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 8 (UPI)A Florida star linebacker, Eric Taggart, suffered a broken right leg in a motor bike accident yesterday that, may have ended his college football career. Taggart was injured when the accelerator on his bike stuck and he was flipped onto the hood of a parked car. His leg was broken just above the knee. Doctors said the break was so close to the knee a pin could not be inserted.

title: FAVORITE SCORES IN AQUEDUCT RACE
description: In contrast to the milling throngs telehrating the arrival of offtrack betting at Grand Cential and Forest Hills, a gathering of 24,043 anjoyed the expansive Comfort of Aqueduct racing yesterday.

title: Recording Rights Obtained
description: Worldwide rights to recordings by The Rolling Stones, the British rock group, have been obtained by Kinney Services, Inc., which includes the Atlantic, Elektra and Warner Brothers/Reprise labels. Ahmet Ertegun, president of Atlantic Records, announced that albums will be released on a new label called Rolling Stones Records, with distribution by Atco Records in the United States. The first release, a single called Brown Sugar, is scheduled for April 16, and an album, Sticky Fingers, for April 30.

title: You Used to Just Turn On the Tap If You Wanted Water
description: When a photographer was taking pictures of Maria Callas not too long ago in her suite at the Regency Hotel, she asked for time out for a drink of water. The photographer's assistant rushed to the serving pantry and brought back glassful.

description: WASHINGTON, April 8The Defense and Justice Departments said today that they had given up attempts to prosecute 15 former servicemen linked to the Mylai killings by Army investigators.

title: TOUR CHORUS HEARD IN A JOYFUL CONCERT
description: Concerts can be exciting, beautiful, stirring, stimulating and all sorts of other things. But they are not often joyful in the way that the one given by the New England Conservatory at Town Hall Wednesday night was.

title: PREPARED PIANO HEARD IN RECITAL
description: John Cage's Sonatas and Interludes, 20 pieces he wrote in the late nineteenforties for A piano whose sonorities he had altered by affixing a Variety of hardware and software to the strings, do not often get a hearing. Perhaps one reason is that the prepared piano, as Mr. Cage's invention Came to be called, requires for success ful performance an entirely prepared pianist. Mare Ajemian, who played the pieces on Wednesday night at the New York Cultural Center, is such pianist, and she ought to be; they were composed for her.

title: John F. Mc'Vevey Marries Mrs. Jost
description: RAMAPO, N.Y., April 8 Mrs. Helen Jost of Bardonia was married this morning to John F. McAlevey a widower, of Sloatsburg, who is Supervisor of Ramapo in Rockland County.

title: Billy Graham: On Calley
description: MONTREAT, N. C.The first tams I became suspicious that the United States might become involved in Indochina was in January, 1961. I had just played golf with Presidentelect John Kennedy, the then Senator George Smathers of Florida, and Billy Reynolds, president of Reynolds Aluminum.

title: Mr. Nixon's Vietnam Politics
description: President Nixon's latest restatement of his Vietnam policy is essentially a political document, taking into account the present state of American politics, the impending peace demonstrations in Washington, rising antiwar sentiment in the Congress, the Calley outcry and the approaching Presidential campaign. These factors were undoubtedly a prime consideration in leading him now to a commitment to end totally the American military involvement in Vietnam by a date that, though unstated, can hardly be much later than Election Day in November 1972.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Article 14  No Title

title: Passover Festival Marking Exodus Begins at Sunset
description: When the sun sets today, Jews the world over will begin observance of the weeklong festival of Passover, commemorating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage.

title: Albert Bids Democrats Lead a Drive to End Slump
description: WASHINGTON, April 8House Speaker Carl Albert said today that there was no evidence that the recession was ending, and that the House Democratic leadership, there fore, must initiate legislation to deal with it.

title: Poindexter Defense Ends Case Without Calling Any Witnesses
description: The defense rested without calling any witnesses yesterday after the prosecution completed its case against David Poindexter on a Federal charge that he harbored and concealed Angela Davis while she was a fugitive.

title: Madison Ave. Auto Ban Will Mark Earth Week
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the closing of a 15block portion of Madison Avenue in midtown Manhattan to traffic for two hours on each of five successive weekdays, as part of the city's observance of Earth Week'.

title: PENN DEDICATES CENTER FOR ARTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 8A new cultural center, the $5.7million Annenberg Center for Condinunication Arts and Sciences, was dedicated at the University of Pennsylvania today.

title: Theater: Still Flowering
description: Paul Zindel's tortuously titled play. The Effect of Gamma Rays on ManintheMoon Marigolds, is Just entering its second year of life. Now at the New Theater and with en entirely new cast, the production still stands as a glowing endorsement of the wellmade play that is in fact wellmade.

title: U.S. Bars LT17 On Sale of Okonite To Ling Company
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (Reuters)The Justice Department announced today that it had rejected a plan by LingTemcoVought, Inc., to divest itself of the Okonite Company.

title: Pope Pleads for Worldwide Aid To Church Groups in Holy Land
description: ROME, April 9Pope Paul VI called on the world's Christians today to give spiritual, moral and material support to Christian communities in Jerusalem and the Holy Land.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: THE KING (in disguise): lifethinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the King's company, his cause being just.

title: Easterners Flee Towns
description: GOALUNDO, Pakistan, April 9 (AP)  East Pakistanis were reported fleeing towns along the Padma River today, fearing an advance by West Pakistan Army units trying to crush the twoweekold autonomy movement in the East.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Basketball fans revel in matchups, a peculiar form of organic chemistry that involves not only the effect two opposing players have on each other, but how that synthesis affects their respective teams and the flow of the game. Knick fans particularly enjoy playoff series against the Baltimore Bullets because the teams are just enough alike as groups but different individually to make the matchups especially interesting. Will Jack Marin and Bill Bradley neutralize each other? Will the titanic rebounding battles between Gus Johnson and Dave DeBusschere tip the delicate balance of power between Wes Unseld and Willis Reed? And how will Coach Red Holzman respond when Coach Gene Shue employs his three little men backcourt?

title: Fringe Benefit for Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) President Nixon received season's pass to American League baseball games today.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Panthers Fear Growing Intraparty Strife
description: A growing fear among some members of the national Black Panther party and their supporters is that the transoceanic battles between the organization's bestknown officials might do more toward destroying the organization than three years of police actions in several cities have done.

title: Flag Patch Draws Charge
description: NILES, Mich., April 9 (AP)A 34yearold South Bend, Ind., man was charged with flag desecration today when he appeared at the Niles police station with an upside down American flag sewn on his trouser leg. The police said that James Million had told them that the flag was being used to cover a hole in his pants. He was released on bond pending a court appearance.

title: CANADIAN DOLLAR NEAR U.S. PARITY
description: TORONTO, April 9The wife of an American who works in Canada went to the bank not long ago to cash a fortnightly check drawn on a New York bank. She asked for the proceeds in Canadian money, which she would use to pay for groceries and other household items.

title: Bridge: Doubleton Honor's Position Demands Strategic Decision
description: A declarer with a suit combination such as the hearts in the diagramed deal must guide his play according to circumstances. To make three tricks, he must hope for a particular opponentwhichever he pleasesto hold a doubleton honor.

title: Montagnards Who Fled Cambodia Get Little Aid
description: SAIGON, South Vietnarn, April 9About 8,000 Cambodian mountain tribesmen who sought refuge in South Vietnam after the Vietnamese Communists captured their native regions last year are suffering from hunger and neglect although ample American funds have been allocated for them.

title: Maine Ratifies Amendment Giving Vote to 18YearOlds
description: AUGUSTA, Me., April 9 (UPI).The Maine Legislature ratified today the proposed constitutional amendment lowering the voting age in all elections to 18.

title: Protest by Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 9Dr. Wei Yusun, spokesman for the Chinese Nationalist Foreign Ministry, today called the invitation to the American table tennis team to visit mainland China a political plot.

title: The Draft Debate
description: Reversing the usual practice in Washington, the House has rejected the Gates Commission's recommendation for replacing the draft with an allvolunteer armed force but has voted the increases in military pay and allowances that the commission said would achieve its goals.

title: Paik Shows Ease at Keyboard In Varied Recital at Tully Hall
description: Facility is necessary to any pianist worth his salt, but KunWoo Paik seems to have it to an unusual degree. It worked both for and somewhat against the 24yearold Korean, who gave a recital in Tully Hall on Thursday night, a reward for being cowinner of the 1971 Naumburg Piano Competitions.

title: Yanks Get Felipe Along; Trade Pair to Oakland
description: Felipe Alou will become a member of the Yankees this weekend. Acquired in a trade with the Oakland Athletics yesterday that sent Ron Klimkowski and Rob Garth ner, pitchers, to the West Coast, Alou will join the Yanks in Washington, where they are playing a weekend series.

title: Holiday Purchases Help Stores
description: In many major cities and suburbs yesterday, consumers crowded into stores in a Good Friday buying spree that provided a strong climax to the Easter shopping season. Although today's business will be closely watched for its contribution to the nineday shopping period, most retailers yesterday were already hailing the season as a good one.

title: Will Harridge, an Ex President 01 American League, Dies at 86
description: EVANSTON, Ill., April 9 (AP) Will Harridge, president of baseball's American League for 27 years, died today in a nursing home. He was 86 years old.

title: Behind the Protests
description: The United States is fighting a war in Vietnam. It has come to pass that in modern warfare deliberately inflicted civilian casualties are taken for granted. Nonetheless, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Chief of Staff, assures us, It was clearly known to our troops that they were to avoid civilian casualties at all costs. Atrocities were to be reported and punished accorded to the rules of the Geneva Convention. General Westmoreland admits that many civilians have been killers in Vietnam; but to allege that any responsibility or guilt rests in the high command is, according to him, absurd. He places the responsibility on troops led by inexperienced lieutenants and sergeants, who are being tried.

title: Senator Horner in 10th Beats Yanks, 54
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The New York Yankees hammered 11 hits off Denny McLain tonight in R.F.H. Memorial Stadium, but the heavy hitting went for naught.

title: Curb on Joint Ownership Opposed by Broadcasters
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)  Broadcasters have joined publishers in opposing a Federal Communications Commission proposal to eliminate joint ownership of radiotelevision stations and newspapers.

title: Newark Teachers Back Gibson In Criticism of Racial Militants
description: NEWARK, April 9The Newark Teachers Union expressed support today for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's criticism of racial militants who have been creating tension in the 10weekold teachers strike.

title: BRITISH FORCE BACK SLICK, FEAR ANOTHER
description: DOVER, England, April 9 (Reuters)Two British Navy ships sprayed enough detergent into the English Channel today to beat back an oil slick that had threatened to pollute beaches at southeast coastal resorts.

title: OIL HUNT OFF CHINA STIRS U.S. WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The United States has advised several American oil concerns that they risk seizure of their ships if they continue to explore for oil deposits in a disputed area off the Chinese mainland.

title: A Kosygin Decline Is Seen in Listings
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 The new listing of the Soviet leadership was viewed by specialists here as reflecting a major rise in the power of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party General Secretary, and a blow to the prestige of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Guidelines by Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Last August Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced guidelines designed to reduce the voltune of subpoenas that had been issued from Federal grand Juries to obtain tapes and notes of reporters and film takeouts of television newsmen.

title: Roosevelt Harness Racing
description: Roosevelt Harness Racing

title: Laos and the Infection
description: Why was the protest so great at the invasion of Cambodia, and so small when the almost klentioal thing happened in Laos? Why the veritable scream of objection, closing down some 700 campuses last May, and an almost complete silence at the time of Laos?

title: Mira Signs With Dolphins.
description: MIAMI, April 9 (UPI)George Mira, a University of Miami quarterback who has never won a starting job in the pros, signed a oneyear contract today with the Miami Dolphins. The 29yearold Mira was given permission by the National Football League commissioner, Pete Rozelle, to sign as a free agent after being released from the taxi squad of the Baltimore Colts last season.

title: MRS. JAMES P. KEOGH
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 9Mrs. Pearl O'Mara Keogh, the widow of James P. Keogh, died this evening in Bergen Pines Hospital, Paramus. She was 95 years old and lived at 536 Palisade Avenue.

title: HANCOCK MAY ADD AUTO INSURANCE
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, long known to be interested in selling fire and casualty insurance, is expected to announce early next week that it would soon expand its operations into the coverage of automobiles and homes, it was disclosed yesterday.reputation. Its present venture contemplates the formation of a special Hancock subsidiary that would move into the field at least initiallyon a limited basis.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Premier of the Ukraine, which thus becomes the only republic outside the Russian Republic to have two top officials in full membership of the Politburo  53 years old  a World War II veteran, he served in Red Army for five years after having been graduated from chemical engineering college in 1941  after war he went to work in coke  chemical plant at Dneprodzerzhinsk, industrial city in Ukraine's Dnepropetrovsk Province  province was then headed by Mr. Brezhnev as party leader, and Mr. Shcherbitsky's career is believed to have been influenced by this early association with Mr. Brezhnev  under Brezhnev's aegis, Mr. Scherbitsky became second secretary of Dneprodzerzhinsk city party in 1948.  over following decade he rose through provincial party hierachy to become province's first secretary from 1955 to 1957  under Mr. Khrushchev's national leadership, he was made a party secretary of the Ukraine, then headed by Nikolai V. Podgorny as first secretary  became Premier of the Ukraine in 1961 and has held post since then except during period of differences with Mr. Khruschev, who sent him back to Dnepropetrovsk Province from 196364.

title: Nixon, Leaving Church, Encounters Protesters
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)President Nixon drove a block away from the White. House today to attend afternoon services at historic St. John's Episcopal Church and, on emerging, encountered a sprinkling of noisy antiwar demonstrators.

title: General in Service Club Inquiry Pleads Guilty to Gun Charges
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 9 Maj. Gen. Carl C. Turner, a retired Army officer, pleaded guilty today in United States District Court to unlawfully soliciting 136 firearms from the Chicago police and keeping them for his own use.

title: BUTTERFLY MARK CRACKED BY HALL
description: PULLMAN, Wash., April 9 (AP)Gary Hall of Indiana University broke the American record of 1 minute 49.6 seconds in the 200yard butterfly event with a 1:48.4 clocking tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union short course swimming chamiponships.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 9 (AP)Maryland yesterday ratified the proposed amendment.

title: Avalanche Kills 5 in France
description: BRIANCON, France, April (Reuters)  Five French skiers were killed in an avalanche today near Ceillac in the Frencl Alps. The avalanche plunged down the Col de Gerardin slope, sweeping away the skiers.

title: Calley Judge Backs Nixon on Review of the Trial
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI)  President Nixon's intention to review the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. is his right as commander in chief, according to the military judge at Lieutenant Calley's trial.

title: Leonhard Erharter Marries Sarah Jane Coleman in Idaho
description: Miss Sarah Jane Coleman, daughter of the Duchess of Manchester and George L. Coleman of Palm Beach, Fla., was married in Sun Valley, Idaho, on March 23 to Leonhard Erharter, a ski instructor at the resort.

title: Car Output Curtailed
description: DETROIT, April 9 (UPI) United States automobile production was curtailed this week because all auto plants were closed in observance of Good Friday. Next week's production also will be down as two companies extend the Easter holiday through Monday.

title: Albert 6G. Boesel Sr. Dies at 85; Retired Merrill Lynch Partner
description: ORLANDO, Fla., April 9 Albert G. Boesel Sr., a retired partner and stockholder in the brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, died today in a nursing home here. He was 85 years old and lived here since 1950.

description: Obsessed by one vision, many artists dedicate their lives and artistic energies to the development and fulfillment of that vision through a constant reworking of it and its attendant corollaries.

description: To the Editor: Why would it not be possible to convert that section of Boeing that was assigned to the development of the SST to making the parts and machines needed all over the country for antipollution systems?

title: Roundup: White Sox Top Twins for Third in Row
description: Leading the major leagues in triples is comparable, perhaps, to being the bantamweight champion of the world or the valedictorian of a graduating class of one. The triple, like the coffincorner kick in football and the twohanded set shot in basketball, seems to be going the way of the duckbill platypus.

title: A Diversionary Program
description: The effort by a Congressional committee to subpoena the film and records of C.B.S. News has the effect turning The Selling of the Pentagon into a new show that could be called The Unmaking of a Documentary. This counterattack, which continues the pressure brought against the network by the Vice President and Secretary of Defense, is a, diversionary move that overlooks the substance of the program and instead investigates the bearer of bad news.

title: India Protests in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9India protested today against a denial by Pakistan that her Government had failed to take action in the hijacking of an Indian airliner on Feb. 1. A letter from Ambassador Samar Sen of India to the President of the Security Council asserted that despite a Pakistani Government report on Feb. 13, Pakistan had never in fact deplored the hijacking, had delayed the return of the passengers to Indian territory by 50 hours and had made no effort to disarm and arrest the hijackers before they burned the aircraft.

title: Foe Breaks Up Rally
description: VITHANH, South Vietnam, April 9 (UPI)An enemy mortar battery broke up a rally and awards ceremony today for Vietcong defectors in this provincial capital in the Mekong delta. Seven civilians were wounded, military sources said.

title: 15Man U.S. Table Tennis Team Crosses Into China From Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, April 10  Members of the United States table tennis team crossed from Hong Kong into Communist China this morning, walking over a railway bridge that marks the border between this British Crown Colony and Chinese Communist territory.

title: F.P.C. Denies Ignoring Iowa Official on Merger
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The Federal Power Commission denied today that it failed to consider a request from the Iowa Attorney General that he be allowed to intervene in the proposed merger of two utilities.

title: Fairchild Hiller to Study Private Financing of SST
description: The Fairchild Hiller Corporation, whose Republic Aviation Division was a major subcontractor for the supersonic transport plane, announced last night that it would begin a study to see if private financing was feasible to resume work on the project.

description: Verse between 4 and 5:45 P.M., with uptown stops at York Avenue at 72d Street, 79th Street, 86th Street and 90th Street.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (UPI)The University of San Francisco announced today that C. Delos Putz Jr., a New York lawyer, would head its School of Law, effective July 1.

description: Two large offerings  those of the A. T. Cross Company and Multimedia, Inc.attracted strong demand in the new issue market this week and jumped quickly to substantial premiums.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: First representative of Moslem Central Asia among full Politburo members since an Uzbek served on Mr. Khruschev's Politburo (then called Presidium) from 1957 to 1961  son of an office worker  59 years old  trained as a mining engineer, he worked before World War II in big coppermining complex of Balkhash and in leadzinc center of Leninogorsk, both in mineralrich Kazakhstan  moved into republic leadership in 1942 as a deputy premier in charge of mining industry, serving for a decade  interest in metals research led to his appointment as president of Kazakhstan Academy of Sciences  resumed rise in political hierarchy in 1955 when he was made Premier of Kazakhstan while Leonid I. Brezhnev was republic's party chief  was himself appointed head of Kazakhstan party in 1960, but lost post two years later when Mr. Khrushchev sought scapegoat for poor performance of virgin lands program  after two years as Premier was returned to head of Republic's party upon removal of Mr. Khrushchev from leadership of Soviet Union  candidate member of Politburo since 1966 visited United States in 1960 as part of delegation of regional government leaders.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS $64MILLION MORE FOR SUMMER JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 9In the face of high unemployment and warnings of unrest in the cities, President Nixon announced today he would seek $64.3million in a supplementary appropriation for employing disadvantaged youths next summer.

title: Army Officers Disturbed By Caney Case Outcome
description: FORT BELVOIR, Va., April 9 The trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and its aftermath have left many members of the professional officer corps of the United States Army in a state of anguish and alarm.

title: Brooklyn Soldier Killed
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that Pfc. Wilbert S. Dupree Jr. of Brooklyn had been killed in action in Indochina.

title: OILPRICE POLICY CALLED A FAILURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Machinery established by President Nixon to stabilize oil prices and insure adequate fuel. oil supplies has failed to work, a high Administration official charged today.

title: JUDICIARY REVISION OUT AT DARTMOUTH
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 9Students at Dartmouth College defeated yesterday a proposed revision of the student judiciary that would have given minority students a larger vote in judicial decisions involving blacks or American Indians.

title: Black Nation Vexes Mississippi
description: BOLTON, Miss., April 9 A bizarre claim of territorial and political independence by a band of black separatists in Mississippi has led state officials to ask Washington to quell the insurrection.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry, stipulated they were being allowed in only to cover the tour of the United States table tennis team. The correspondents are John Roderick of The Associated Press and John Rich and Jack Reynolds of the National Broadcasting Co.

title: PRAGUE BARS TROUPE FROM A LONDON TRIP

description: MOBILE, Ala., April 9 (AP)  Alabama's antiriot law was declared unconstitutional by threejudge Federal court today.

title: College Sports Notes
description: The University of South Carolina decided last week to drop out of the Atlantic Coast Conference to recruit football players and other athletes who have a lower academic achievement mark than the already low minimum required by the A.C.C. The conference requires that a studentathlete make 800 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test before he receives an athletic scholar ship. This is too high for South Carolina football requirements, according to the Gamecocks coach, Paul Dietzel. He has long contended that he cannot compete with other state schools unless he can give scholarships to high school graduates who have about 750.

title: GAETANO D. MAIORANO
description: Gaetano D. Maiorano, an electrician with the EJ Electric Installation Company, 39 East 21st Street, died yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 8022 250th Street, Bellerose, Queens.

title: PingPong Diplomacy
description: The virtues of table tennis as both a form of exercise and spectator sport are well known. Now Mao Tsetung is demonstrating that table tennis can be used as subtle and effective instrument of diplomacy. This precisely what has happened with the announcement that the Chinese team at the world table tennis championship has invited the American team to visit the Chinese Peoples Republic for friendly matches, an invitation most of the Americans have been quick to accept.

title: At Philharmonic, a Rarity Among Choral Works
description: The Easter weekend of the New York Philharmonic opened on Thursday evening with two, choral works of a devotional nature. Choral music is, by and large, avoided by the big orchestras; it entails too much preparation and expense. Thus the two fine pieces, Karol Szymanowski's Stabat Mater and Haydn's D minor Mass, were all the more welcome. Especially the former. The Haydn Mass can at least be heard on records, but the Szymanowski work is a rarity.

title: Firehouse Is No Place to Cook a Souffl
description: Just as the chef on the 6 P.M. to 9 A.M. shift was completing a batch of veal rollatine, smothered In mushrooms and wine sauce, the firehouse alarm rang. It was 8:45 P.M., and 15 firemen were waiting for dinner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As West Pakistanis, we are shocked and shamed by the recent developments in our country. We decry the denial by West Pakistani leaders of East Pakistan's right to selfdetermination. We condemn the current policy of brutally suppressing the homerule movement in Bengal.

title: VENEZUELA GETS $70MILLION LOAN

description: The Johns  Manville Corporation, manufacturer of building materials, yesterday announced the appointment of J. E. Hesse to the new post of vice president for production and engineering. Mr. Hesse joined the company in 1942 and since then has held managerial posts among its various Idylsions. In his new post, he will hT responsible for staff production functions, plant engineering, general industrial engineerind and maintenance control.

title: Vietnamize At Home
description: Now that the Vietnamization of the war is under way in Vietnam, it's time to end the Vietnamization of our political system at home. This domestic Vietnamizationthe draft, the attitude toward dissent, the ubiquitous secret agentshas driven an entire generation into despair about their country. Now that the national purpose has changed abroad, our domestic actions must seek to bring the young back into the political process.

[OpEd April 2.3 Western European financing rnechanisims do display great variety. But they have one characteristic in commoneveryone is entitled to care as a matter of right. The Nixon Administration proposals fall far short of this goal.

description: The nation's major stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday as were many businesses because of the Good Friday holiday. Most foreign markets were closed also.

description: President Nixon's Council on Environmental Quality has called for a broad environmental study that could delay or even prevent the construction of the controversial Tocks Island Dam.

description: Jews the world over sat at the traditional Seder ceremonial feast at sundown yesterday and read from the Haggadah  the story of the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage and oppression.

title: RETAILERS SALES UP IS IN MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 Retail sales showed distinct signs of strength in March on the basis of preliminary figures, the Census Bureau disclosed today.

title: January Leads by Shot On 138 in Masters Golf
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9One Texan replaced another today as the leader in the Masters golf tourney as Don January, a slim 41yearold professional from Dallas, moved to the front. His total for 36 holes was 138 after he carded his second straight 69.

title: Suburbs Resist New Demands for Subsidized Housing
description: STOUGHTON, Mass. Because of pressure by the Federal Government in 1969, this white suburb of 23;000 has a new, subsidized housing development for lowtomoderate inconie families. But two neighboring towns recently blocked similar projects; and the Nixon Administration's stance against forced integration was said to have figured inthe opposition.

title: REV. PAUL E. SHELDON
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., April 9The Rev. Paul E. Sheldon, minister of the Pawtucket Congregational Church, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

description: The police arrested 69 persons during detnonstrations against the A. & P. supermarket chain here yesterday.

title: RANGERS, LEAFS FACE HEAVY FINES
description: As the Rangers and Maple] Leafs awaited tonight's third game in Toronto of their deadlocked Stanley Cup playoff series, a total of $14,600 in National Hockey League fines hung over them for the two brawls that interrupted Thursday night, game in Madison Square Garden.

title: STUDENTS ALLEGE CAMPUSF.B.I, LINK
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 9The deputy chief of theocampus patrol at Rutgers University and Livingston College was described as an established and reliable source of information for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in docurnent allegedly stolen from the F.B.I. office at Media, Pa., last month.

title: Film: 'Valdez Is Coming':Burt Lancaster Stars in Vengeful Western
description: "Valdez Is Coming" is a revenge Western, set in post-Civil War Arizona, about a man whose principles are somewhat loftier than those of the movie that contains them. It stars blue-eyed Burt Lancaster, wearing a lot of dark brown make-up, as a discriminated-against Mexican constable, and it was directed by Edwin Sherin, the man who directed the prizewinning stage version of "The Great White Hope." It opened yesterday at the Victoria Theater on Broadway and at other theaters throughout the city.Within the first half-hour of the movie, Bob Valdez (Lancaster) is humiliated, called a greaser, shot at and mock-crucified, all because he wants to raise $200 from the white men responsible (along with himself) for the killing of a black freed-man, a murder-suspect later known to have been innocent. The money is to go to the black man's pregnant Apache woman.This bare description of the plot will give you some idea of the film's very contemporary racial sensibilities, which though honorable, are simply the dcor of a harmless Western. On second thought, perhaps, it's not quite that harmless. The humiliations suffered by Valdez early on, as well as the ruthlessness of the villains, are of such unequivocal nastiness that the film's ultimate satisfactions come not from the triumph of honor, but from the scope of the revenge.As in almost every Burt Lancaster movie, I'm not sure how much of "Valdez Is Coming" was directed by the star, and how much by the director. A lot of fancy flourishes, which I associate with Mr. Sherin's stage work, are apparent in the film, as in its picturesque groupings of picturesque characters, and in a musical score that's much given to comment on the action. Mr. Sherin, I suspect, is also responsible for the film debut of the several New York actors in the cast, only one of whom, Jon Cypher, shows up to advantage.Mr. Lancaster himself is simply beyond criticism, an enduring star whose screen personalitydecent, liberal, tough, well-intentionedprovides the shape of the movies that are constructed around him.

title: 2 WOMEN LINKED TO COLOMBO HELD
description: Two Brooklyn women socused of conspiracy in a multimilliondollar gambling Syndicate allegedly controlled by Joseph A. Colombo Sr. were released on $15,000 bail each yesterday following their arrests by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Within 380 Hours, He Built a House
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.To most people, they are doll's houses. But to Robert A. Fernsler, a master craftsman who likes to think little in a big way, they are scale reproductions of buildings worth remembering.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon met with Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Ambassador at Large David M. Kennedy, and Nancy Hanks, head of the National Council of the Arts. He presented the American Cancer Society's Courageous Persons Award to Marguerite Piazza, the singer and presented the Boys Club National Boy of the Year Awards. The President received his 1971 Major League baseball pass from Bowie Kuhn, Baseball Commissioner; Joseph E. Cronin, American League president; Charles S. Feeney, National League president; Robert E. Short, president of the Washington Senators, and Ted Williams, manager of the Washington Senators. The President and his family then flew to Camp David for the weekend. He was expected to attend Easter Sunday services, in Gettysburg, Pa., with Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: Meminger Shows Way
description: HONOLULU, April 9 (AP)Dean IVIeminger of Marquette scored 35 points last night to lead the Midwest team to a 9795 basketball victory over the south in the second game of the opening round of the Aloha Classic. West won the opener, 11489, from the East.

title: Pentagon Says C. B. S. Program Led to Public Relations Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (UPI) The Defense Department acknowledged today that the Columbia Broadcasting Systera's documentary The Selling of the Pentagon, which the department has criticized as distorted and unfair, has resulted in some beneficial reforms in the military's public ihformation program.

title: Chile Leads Argentina, 20, In Davis Cup Zone Match
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 9 (UPI)Chile gained a 2.0 advantage over Argentina today in the second round of South American zone Davis Cup tennis competition. Patricio Cornejo defeated Julian Ganzabal, Argentina's No. 1 ace, 6.4, 64, 6.4, and Jaime Fillol defeated Tomas Lynch, 62, 6.4, 62.

title: Besieged Fire Base Fights Off Attack by Hanoi Commandos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 10 (AP)North Vietnamese commandos reportedly defied a hail of bombs and napalm early today and tried to penetrate beseiged Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands but were repulsed.

title: CITY PLANS CURBS ON RENOVATIONS
description: The Lindsay administration plans to issue new regulations that would prohibit landlords from evicting tenants to renovate rentcontrolled buildings that are already in sound condition.

title: Nixons Fly to Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon flew by helicopter tonight to Camp David in Maryland for an Easter weekend with their family.

title: Government Claims Gains
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 9 The Pakistani Government said today that antinational elements in the East Pakistani port of Chittagong had been destroyed and that many of them had surrendered to Paldstani troops.

title: Cairo Editor Says Impasse May Force U. A. R. to War
description: CAIRO, April 9Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the authoritative Egyptian editor, hinted today that the Egyptian leadership would be impelled to renounce its commitment to a political accommodation with Israel if a breakthrough could not be achieved soon on bringing about an Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territories.

title: Bush Says the U.N. Faces A Fight on Enlarging Site
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 9George Bush, United States representative to the United Nations, has advised Secretary General Thant that plans for an $80million improvement and expansion of the United Nations enclave are in jeopardy.

title: Hundreds of Music Lovers Jam Chapel for. Stravinsky Services
description: Amid the pungent aroma of incense, flickering candles and vibrant Russian chants, funeral services were held here yesterday for Igor Stravinsky, whose ballets, operas, symphonies, chamber music and other works made him one of the most famous composers of the century.

title: Experimental Class in Newark School. Is Indoctrinated in Black Subjects
description: NEWARK, April 9For the 30 students in Room 318 of the Robert Treat School, the day begins with a salute to the flagthe red, black, and green flag of black nationalism.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: U.S. CONTINUES AID TO PAKISTAN ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The United States is continuing to ship to Pakistan ammunition and spare parts for weapons under a program begun in 1967.

title: Market Place Some Optimism About Airlines
description: Listen to Arthur D. Lewis and he'll tell you that over the years the Civil Aeronautics Board has had an alarming tendency to live in the past.

title: The Talk of Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 1Belfast lies awake at night listening for explosions. The city waits for the morning to learn what further bomb attacksor murdershave occurred.

title: New Claims Lift Tax Debt Of Shor to Over $200,000
description: Toots Shor, whose restaurant was seized by the Federal Government for nonpayment of taxes, faced new claims yesterday, bringing his total alleged tax indebtedness to more than $200,000.

title: Squeaky Wheel, No Grease
description: The New York City Council's special committee on public transportation has called for an effort to reverse the subway system's collision course with disastera laudable purpose which it proposes to support with the insignificant appropriation of $15 million.

title: Jordan and Guerrillas Reach A New Pact With Syrian Help
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 9An agreement was reached today to end the current crisis between King Hussein and Palestinian guerrillas in Jordan. The accord is at least the 10th since the first confrontation between the Jordanian Army and the commandos in November, 1968. None of them succeeded in insuring durable peace between the Jordanian authorities and the guerrillas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As one of its remaining English contingent, I have enjoyed reading the March 21 news story about Chester Square. I hope and believe that we do get on pretty well with our American neighbors in a lowkey British sort of way, but there is perhaps just one small area where I feel your letters columns could strike a blow for even better AmericanEnglish relations. This has to do with children and their management (or lack of it).

title: Man in the News
description: NAGOYA, Japan, April 9 When Jack Howard was a high school student in Brooklyn, N. Y., 20 years ago, his 6foot, 175pound frame seemed ideal for outdoor games, such as football and baseball, In which he excelled.

title: Hoffa Furloughed From U.S Prison To See Ailing Wife
description: WASHINGTON, April 9James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned president of the Teamsters International Union, was released Wednesday from the United States penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., on temporary furlough to visit his seriously ill wife in San Francisco.

title: Army Makes Apology For Memo on TV Man
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)The United States command has apologized to the Columbia Broadcasting System for a memorandum to information officers stating that Morley Safer, a C.B.S. newsman, was visiting Vietnam with an ulterior motive.

description: Special police units here and in Jersey City seized what 20 pounds of what was decribed as undiluted cocaine and and arrested three persons last night. They were called members of one of the largest cocaine smuggling rings in the country.

description: American Basketball Association attendance for the 197071 regular season was 2,247,568, a 28.2 per cent increase over the previous season, Commissioner Jack Dolph announced yesterday.

description: NEW HAVENEveryone who believes, as I have, in the rule of law as an expanding, organizing force in national and international governance, has now to face the implications of the Calley trial and verdict. I have tried to do so, and have found that I almost cannot.

title: Three Religions Observe Holy Days in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 9Members of three, great religions converged on their holy city today in a traditional outpouring of faith.

description: Article 13  No Title

title: Durrett Signs With Royals
description: CINCINNATI, April 9 (AP)Ken Durrett of La Salle, who averaged 27 points and 12 rebounds, a game this season, signed a fiveyear contract today with the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Association. The 6foot7inch forward was Cincinnati's firstround draft selection.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 9The Instanet communications system, which was patented this week, enables institutional investors to trade in securities without going through brokers or exchanges. The Institutional Networks Corporation, New York to which Patent No. 3,573,747 was assigned, has maintained the automated service for about 15 months and already has more than 30 clients, including large banks and insurance companies.

title: Seoul Students in Melee
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 9 University students in Seoul continued to demonstrate today, for the fourth day, against a recently intensified collegiate military training program. About 2,500 students from two major universities fought with stones against policemen. Some 100 demonstrators were arrested, but they were all released later.

title: BLASDALE EXCELS IN BRAHMS PIECES
description: Justin Blasdale's performances of Brahms's Seven Fantasies (Op. 116) at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night were so beautiful in every way that, if he had played nothing else, he might have been described as a pianist of remarkable artistic maturity.

title: No Blank Check for Government
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati has upheld a lower court's opinion that the Justice Department is violating the Constitution by using wiretaps without court authorization. The ruling challenges Attorney General Mitchell's view that the eavesdropping powers of the executive branch in defense against dangerous groups are virtually unlimited.

title: Firemen to Vote Wednesday
description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association announced yesterday that a membership meeting would be held Wednesday to vote on a tentative contract reached with the city. Michael J. Maye, president of the 11,300member organization, said that the meeting, restricted to U.F.A. members, would start at 10:30 A.M. in Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street.

title: Antiques: Old Russian Easter Eggs
description: It is worth a detour to see the Russian Easter eggs displayed in the window of A La Vieille Russie, the antique shop at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Shop Talk
description: For the woman who wants to revamp her wardrobe and wants some help in doing it, Emily Cho's New Image service may be the place to call. Providing fashion consultation and a shopping service, Miss Cho will visit the client's home for an hour, look at her present wardrobe and make suggestions. The fee in New York is $25. I get a quick, clear picture of what she already has, Miss Cho explained. I learn about her life style and her clothes budget. Then I send her a wardrobe plan, suggesting what she should keep and what new things she needs. The client can stop at the consultation and do her own shopping, if she chooses. Or, at a later date, and for an additional $50, go on a threehour shopping session along with Miss Cho.

title: Double Delta, Takes Distaff Distaff at Aqueduct Before 47,146
description: Double Delta, to whom one race track is as good as, another, won the $33,300 Distaff Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against seven rivals in the sevenfurlong sprint for fillies and Mares, James Drymon's 5.yearold campaigner prevailed by a neck over Alfret! G. Vanderbilt's Cold Comfort, who enjoyed the margin of 33A, lengths over I'm For Mama, owned by Caoiar P. Kimmel.

title: DISPUTE DELAYS BUILDING BY CITY
description: City officials reported yesterday that more than $55million in construction contracts were being held up because of the failure of four building trades unions and contractors dealing with them to comply with onthejob training programs for members of minority groups.serious and noted that labor and material costs were rising each month, so that the city's construction costs will be higher than originally anticipated on projects that are delayed.

title: C.B.S. Gains Support for Defiance of Subpoena
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and Elie Abel, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, supported yesterday the Columbia Broadcasting System's refusel to respond to portions of It Congressional subpoena that demanded details on matters not broadcast.
