description: Article 15  No Title

title: Art Vivin Evokes the Paris That Was
description: The Perls Galleries, at 1016 Madison Avenue at 79th Street, are celebrating the arrival of spring with a show of paintings by Louis Vivin that could be called April in Paris and will stir the susceptible to frenzies of that currently popular emotion, nostalgia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Despite the moral indignation of our militant peace groups and dovish Congressmen urging precipitate, total or specifically timed withdrawal of our armed forces from Indochina, not one of these allegedly moral or humanitarian groups has suggested, mentioned or adopted a resolution to change our amoral, restrictive and anachronistic immigration laws so that, subsequent to our total withdrawal, the tens, possibly hundreds of thousands of innocents, scheduled to be victims in Communist bloodbath, may be saved.

title: News Analysis
description: The announcement this week from 20th CenturyFox seemed simple: Darryl F. Zanuck had resigned as chief executive officer of the corporation, but had retained his office as chairman of the company. In that capacity he would continue to concentrate on film production. But the reasons for the move were not clear, and no one at the source, or close to the source, was talking. This week, this season, every one is gunshy at 20th CenturyFoxfor good reason. In 1970 most studios lost money, although one film, Love Story, appears to have rescued an entire company, Paramount. Perhaps none was as besieged as Fox, which reported a loss of $77,355,000 during 1970. This was in spite of the resounding success the studio had that year with two pictures, M.A.S.H and Patton.

title: Editor Killed by Robbers
description: LOS ANGELES, April 9 (UPI) James Bradley Little, 38 years old, editor of the Architectural Digest, was pistol whipped and fatally shot in the back early today by three robbers as he was getting into his car with a friend after leaving a downtown nightclub.

title: Wagering at OTB Shops Increases on Second Day
description: Swamped by the public response to its New Game in I Town, the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation plans to open four additional windows today in Grand Central Terminal.

title: RAYMOND D. M'GRATH OF LAZARD FRERES
description: Raymond D. McGrath, a former member of the banking firm of Lazard Freres and onetime executive vice president of General American Investors Company, died yesterday at his home in Warrenton, Va. His age was 80.

title: Familiar Songs:' Celebration at Big Sur' Depicts Pop Festival
description: "Celebration at Big Sur," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is an account of certain features of the Big Sur Festival of 1969 after Woodstock and some time before the end. The music  by Joan Baez, Joni Mitchell, Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, Dorothy Morrison, John Sebastian, and others  is mostly folk and rather gentle rock. The movie making  by Baird Bryant and Johanna Demetrakas  ranges from the obligatory coy to the needlessly reverent.The film purports to give the feel of Big Sur, but, public relations to the contrary, I doubt that the feel of any event is really available to anybody not directly involved. At least in this case, the various zooms into, and stop shots of, the audience reveal little except that good-looking kids look good. And the freak shows and interviews around the edges seem mainly to exist for the camera.The camera, in a movie like "Celebration at Big Sur," can be an instrument of oppressiontaking more than it gives, making meaningless demands at the wrong times. For example, as Joan Baez sings "David's Song," we are offered not only Joan Baez singing, but also a butterfly on a branch, a sunflower, a baby in its mother's arms, and an ocean of surf pounding the craggy coast of California. This is not an extension of the music so much as a reduction of the musiccomparable to pictures in a non-picture book, or what happens to Bach in "Fantasia."Whether you care to see "Celebration at Big Sur" will depend mostly on whether you care to see a number of familiar people performing music you probably know already. Carol Ann Cisneros, a Texas folk singer who is new to me, sang one classical-sounding Spanish ballad, and she seemed very good.John Sebastian's lax sweetness is not to my taste, and I am afraid I admire Joni Mitchell as much for the ravishing planes of her face as for her music. Her performance of "Woodstock" received the most offensive movie treatment, with a kind of fiery-edged negative montage of her hair to accompany the refrain "We are stardust, We are golden . . ." Joan Baez sings songs by Dylan ("I Shall Be Released") and herself, and I guess she is the spirit of Big Sur, and overwhelming as she is, I am am not at all sure that the nobility of her presence ultimately compensates for the fortuitousness of her lyrics.

title: TV Station in Jackson Presents News in Sign Language for Deaf
description: JACKSON, Miss.In the broadcast studio of television station WJTV, Jerry St. John stood glancing over the 5 o'clock news budget while Frank Jennings, the news program anchor man, was slipping on a fresh jacket and taking his seat, and Glenn Dear, director, was shepherding his cameramen into place.

title: ELIE H, BINZEN, REALTY OFFICIAL
description: Elliot H. Binzen, a real estate consultant who was one of the ranking tennis tournament players of the nineteentwenties, died Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 74 years old and lived at Fox Meadow Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: We Accuse
description: These are excerpts from an editorial published jointly during Holy Week by four publications: Christian Century, Christianity and Crisis, National Catholic Reporter and Commonweal. The editors say that the joint declaration is unique in religious journalism in this country and this fact indicates the deep concern of these publications about the continuing involvement of the United States in Vietnam.

description: MOSCOW, April 9Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, today announced a shuffle in the Kremlin hierarchy that left the same men in power and seemed to enhance his preeminence in the leadership.

description: WESTBURY, L. L, April 9A breakdown today of racebyrace figures for last night's introduction of legalized offtrack betting at Roosevelt Raceway, indicated that the majority of bettors at Grand Central, Forest Hills and by telephone had followed the morning line and wound up regretting it.

description: City Hall argued in State Supreme Court yesterday that a suit charging conflictofinterest by the City Corporation Counsel was invalid because the plaintiff was not a qualified or aggrieved taxpayer.

title: Table Tennis, in China, Is Not Just a Sport
description: Table tennis is to China what the Dodgers were to Brooklyn, what college football is to the Southern hamlets of the United Statesa way of life. More than 100 million of Communist China's 760 million people, including Chairman Mao Tsetung, play table tennis, and they play it well.

title: JAPAN APPROVES COMPUTER DEAL
description: TOKYO, April 9The Government's Foreign Capital Council approved today a joint venture by a United States computer concern and a Japanese trading company with new condition designed to prevent a takeover by the American partner.

title: MARCH DEPOSITS UP FOR SAVINGS BANKS
description: The massive flow of funds into thrift institutions apparently continued unabated during March. The Savings Banks Association of New York State reported a record net gain in deposits at its member banks of $524million, against a net deposit outflow of about $220million in the same month last year and $27million in March, 1969. New York savings banks account for about twothirds of savingsbank assets nationally.

title: Ceylon, Combating Rebels, Imposes 24Hour Curlew
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 9 The Ceylonese people were ordered today to stay indoors for 24 hours as security forces battled insurgents led by militantly leftist youths.

title: Canal's Importance Questioned
description: TEL AVIV, April 9 (Reuters)  Premier Golda Meir of Israel said in an interview published today that the reopening of the Suez Canal for navigation was not so great a boon for Israel that Israeli interests should be exchanged for it.

title: Mrs. Lindsay Hospitalized
description: Mrs. Mary Lindsay, the Mayor's wife, who suffered a broken left collarbone while skiing in Colorado two weeks ago, entered a hospital here last Wednesday for observation and further treatment of the injury. The Mayor's office declined to name the hospital. Mr. Lindsay left Thursday for Vail, Colo., for a weekend skiing holiday.

title: GOODY LOSES LEAD BUT NOT HIS COOL
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 the round that Charles Coody played over the Augusta National Golf Club course today had more ups and downs than the course itself, Coody, who went into the second day of the Masters with a threestroke lead, scrambled today for a 73, which he said he Was fortunate to get.

title: Orange and Rockland
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., April 9Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., expects its annual sales of electricity to rise by 11 per cent and its gas sales by 6 per cent, Charles H. Tenney 2d, chairman, told some 275 stockholders at the annual meeting here today. He also reported that the company has several natural gas purchase contracts that extend to 1990 and, coupled with planned additions to liquefied petroleum gas production capacity, should provide adequate gas supplies at least through 1972.

title: HOW FUNK JR., U.S. AIDE IN KENYA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 9Howard V. Funk Jr., first secretary of the United States Embassy in Kenya, was killed today in an automobile accident near Lake Victoria. He was 41 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is argued that Hanoi would be left free to decide its course of action should there be an announcement of a specific date by which all U. S. forces would be withdrawn from Vietnam and that whatever leverage now exists to press negotiations by Hanoi would be vitiated to our disadvantage, particularly with respect to our prisoners.

title: G.O.P. War Critic Arrives In Vietnam for 4Day Visit
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 9 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr.arrived here today for a fourday visit to South Vietnam and charged that President Nixon had stepped up the air war over Laos while trying to gain votes by reducing United States casualties among ground forces.

title: The Mephisto Waltz'
description: Shift "Rosemary's Baby" to California, with the nice young couple abruptly exposed to some chic, jet-set zombies, including the world's greatest pianist. When this old demon dies, the husband acquires both his soul and pianistic genius, pounding out Liszt to prove it.The sensible wife, who squares off early with the old musician's horrible dog, expects and gets the worst, with a couple of murders. Add some angular photography and a spooky, haunted-house score pelting us in a miserably infantile botch of occult suspense titled "The Mephisto Waltz." The picture, opening yesterday, is terrible.Style and subtlety might have done the trick this time, whatever the merits of Fred Mustard Stewart's novel. But this shrill, heavy-handed exercise only makes us appreciate "Rosemary's Baby" all over again.Are there good things here? Several. One is the candid, clear-eyed performance of Jacqueline Bisset as the anguished wife. (Hello again, Mia.) Some of the color interiors are handsome. The casting of Curt Jurgens as the nasty old genius is interesting. It's intriguing, too, to hear Liszt's "Mephisto" hand-breaker pinched out thematically and surfacing the clanky swirl of spook music added by Jerry Goldsmith.However, Alan Alda, as the supposedly satanic hero, seems nothing more than a genial, naive climber. As his witchy seducer, Barbara Parkins purrs acceptably. Bradford Dillman is lost as a sideline doctor.At one point, before the goblins close in, Miss Bisset casually says, "The laundry didn't come back." Oh yes, it did  from "Rosemary's Baby."

title: TENNECO EXPECTS 71 EARNINGS GAIN
description: N. W. Freeman, president and chief executive officer of Tenneco, Inc., told the company's annual meeting in Houston yesterday that we are shooting at a target that would result in an earnings increase of about 10 per cent this year.

title: Bomb Set to Explode Found in Ulster Factory
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 9 (AP)The largest bomb uncovered in Northern Ireland this year was found planted in a cement factory today ready to explode.

title: Penn Central Asks Aid
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 9 (UPI)Trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad asked today for a Federal Government guaranty of $15million of trustee certificates to enable the railroad to participate in Railpax, the new national intercity passenger train service to start May 1.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Former head of Soviet Union's trade unions, was raised to prestigious post of Moscow city party leader in 1967  served 10 years as candidate member of Politburo before present promotion to full member  a wellgroomed man, he began his career as a land surveyor in 1932 at age of 18  five years later he followed in his father's footsteps as a railroad engineer, in locomotive roundhouse at Seppukhove, south of Moscow  rising in the local party hierarchy, he was picked to head the party's machinery industry department of Moscow Province in 1950  two years later he was appointed second secretary of Moscow Province under Mr. Khrushchev, then first secretary  as chairman of trade unions from 1956 to 1967, he traveled widely abroad to international congresses, visiting Finland and Italy  he was appointed Moscow city party leader by Mr. Brezhnev, succeeding Nikolai G. Yegorychev, who was dismissed over differences with the leadership on Middle East policy.

title: JACK CURIUM 59, PHYSICIST, DEAD
description: UPTON, L. L, April 9Jack Chernick, senior Physicist and head of the reactor physics division at Brookhaven National Laboratory, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 59 years old and lived in East Patchogue.

title: Pause in Memory Of War Prisoners Gets Slight Notice
description: Except for the Fire Department, most New Yorkers seemed unaware of Mayor Lindsay's proclamation calling for a moment of silence and concern at 3:15 P.M. yesterday for American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

title: CLATWORTHY PLAYS CITY OPERA RENATO
description: David Clatworthy stepped into the pivotal role of Renato in the season's fifth New York City Opera performance of Un Ballo in Maschera on Thursday night. The tall baritone did not let down the side. Renato, or Count Anckarstrom if you prefer Verdi's Swedish version, is any baritone's opportunity: king's counselor and best friend, cuckold, Conspirator, regicide and sole occupant of one of opera's grandest vehicles, the vengeance aria Eri tu.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Agricultural specialist of the Soviet leadership, was brought into the ruling elite upon the ouster of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964  promotion directly to full Politburo member without going through intermediate rank of candidate member is viewed as sign of priority now being given to improvement of agriculture, historically the weakest link of Soviet economy  born in 1918 into Russian peasant family in sugarbeet producing region of Central Russia  worked in sugar refinery before World War II  rose through ranks of agricultural officialdom in Central Russian farming province of Penza  Governor of province from 1950 to 1955  while Deputy Agriculture Minister of the Russian Republic, he was graduated, in 1957, from agricultural correspondence college  in 1960 he was appointed party chief of Stavropol 0Province, a key farming region of northern Caucasus  unon ouster of Mr. Khrushchev, was moved to Central Committee apparatus as head of Agricultural Department and raised to national party secretary for agriculture in 1965.

title: Longevity Note
description: BUSINESS LETTER

title: N.Y. Lacrosse Club Hands Jersey Rivals 1811 Setback
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 10The undefeated New York Lacrosse Club beat the New Jersey Club, 1811, today for its fourth victory.

title: Central Committee Newcomers Reflect Prestige of Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, April 10  While the 25man Soviet leadership remains a virtually closed club, new faces have appeared in the Communist party's Central Committee, the traditional jumpoff point to the top.

title: The New Individualism
description: WASHINGTON, April 10. The Easter Parade this year in America was riot of modern individualism, a costume party, a masquerade ball, and the clowns never looked more gay, or carefree or felt worse.

title: Anyone Dig the Art of Building?
Doctor Jailed for Fraud
description: MEMPHIS, April 10 (AP) Dr. Odis Strong, a Memphis physician, has been sentenced to three twoyear prison terms and fined more than $16,000 on charges of falsifying Federal Medicare claim forms in 1968 and 1969. He was sentenced yesterday by United States District Judge Bailey Brown.

title: The Triumph
description: Whoever first sang those verses we know as The Song of Solomon was celebrating a springtime of faith and a rebirth of all things when he said, For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone; the flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land. And it was not by chance that the singer of the Psalms chanted, The mountains skipped like rams, and the little hills like lambs.

title: Mafioso's Memoirs Support Valachi's Testimony About Crime Syndicate
Stravinsky: One Of the Originals Of History
description: IGOR STRAVINSKY was, like some composers before him, notably Berlioz and Wagner, late in developing. Professionally he came to music rather late, and his early E flat Symphony, composed under the tutelage of RimskyKorsakov In 1907, was undistinguishable from any other lateromantic Russian symphony. It had absolutely nothing in it that would suggest that one the most original composers in history was on the way. Yet three years later he wrote the Firebird ballet for Serge Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes, and overnight he became famous. Diaghilev, at the rehearsals of Firebird, realized the genius of Stravinsky. He predicted that the score would turn Europe upside down, and he was right.

title: Brabham Jumps 267
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., April 10 (AP)Danny Brabham of Baylor longjumped 26 feet 7 inches, best in the nation this year. in a quadrangular track meet at Texas Tech today. The jump was windaided.

title: PODELL ADVANCES HOUSE INFLUENCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Representative Bertram L. Podell lit a cigar after lunch the other day and announced with a broad smile:

title: Sally Kellogg Is Wed
description: WESTPORT, Conn., April 10In Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church here today Miss Sally Thorp Kellogg, daughter of Mrs. William Foster Deegan and the late Donald Bradley Kellogg, was married to Robert Dante Russo Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Russo of Bridgeport. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy, assisted by Msgr. David F. Bannon of St. Peter Roman Catholic Church, Bridgeport.

title: Under The Colors
description: As an important Communist critic of Communism, Yugoslavia's Milovan Djilas is famous for the incisive, foresighted books (The New Class, Conversations With Stalin) that got him thrown into Tito's prisons. When his political works get him incarcerated, the now 60yearold Djilas has also understandably turned to historical and autobiographical novels about his homeland. This long, diffuse and relentlessly epic novel about his native Montenegro (the southernmost Yugoslav republic, on the Albanian border) was written while he was jailed following publication abroad of Conversations in 1961. Focusing on the proud Radak clan of Serbs, it chronicles the SerbMontenegrin union and struggle for independence from the Turkswho, as feudal landlords, continued to dominate regions ceded to the new state by the Ottoman Empire at the 1878 Berlin Conference.

title: Guns and Dynamite Are Seized in Raid on L.I. Motorcycle Gang
COLONELS SCORE OVER FLORIDIANS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 10 (AP) Louie Dampier scored 26 points and established a league record of 18 assists tonight as the Kentucky Colonels whipped the Floridians, 118101, and took a 32 edge in their American Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff series.

title: John Romaine to Marry Kathleen Turyn
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., April 10  Miss Kathleen Ann Turyn and John Eugene Romaine will be married May 22 in Ellicott City.

title: Schools:
description: As the American melting pot, the schools are in trouble. The ethnic and racial ingredients of the pot, instead of mixing or integrating, are increasingly either refusing to mix or exploding. .racial power groups have joined the oldline segregationists in advocating separatism, thus dashing hopes for an integrated society emerging from integrated schools.

title: Miss Timothy, F. H. Connor Jr. Plan Marriage
description: LITTLETON Colo., April 10Miss Kristen Timothy, an associate officer in the Economic and Social Affairs Department of the United Nations in New York, plans to be married here in early sum mer to F. Hayden Connor Jr., general manager of Carl Fischer, Inc., music publishers, of which his father is president.

title: Claudia Dean Plans Bridal
description: ARLINGTON, Va., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. Alan Loren Dean have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claudia Vera Dean, who is a staff member of Senator William B. Spong Jr. of Virginia, to Daniel Martin Lewis, chief legislative assistant to Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Lewis of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York.

title: Child to Mrs. Francke
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Albert Francke 3d of New York on April 1 in the LyingIn Hospital. Mrs. Francke is the former Miss Linda Tapp Bird of New York. The child, whose father is a lawyer, is named Tapp FitzGerald.

title: Byron B. Ralston, Lawyer, Dies; Navy Officer in the World Wars
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 10Comdr. Byron Brown Ralston, U.S.N., retired, a veteran of both World Wars and a lawyer, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 159 Conies Avenue, Pelham Heights.

title: Yes, Yes, Alexis! No, No, Follies!
description: FOLLIES is intermissionless amd exhausting, an extravaganza that becomes tedious for two simple reasons: Its extravagances have nothing to do with its pebble of a plot; and the plot, which could be wrapped up in approximately two songs, dawdles through 22 before it declares itself done.

title: 24th Congress
description: In retrospect it is plain that the puppet show known as the 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party had one major objective: to demonstrate stability, unity and continuity in the Soviet leadership and its policies. There were neither dramatic changes in the party line nor sensational alterations in the Kremlin leadership. Those who wrote the script and prepared the stage directions aimed at the dullest possible meeting. They succeeded completely. In the process, of course, they again exposed as illusion any notion that a Soviet party congress is actually a democratic forum for the expression of the popular will.

title: Native American Holly
description: NATIVE American Holly (Ilex opaca), in its wild state, was once not far from extinction on the Northeast coast. Today, through vigilant protection and conservation measures, a number of the older stands have been saved, and are thriving in various parts of Long Island and New Jersey. In some cases isolation and inaccessibility have been their salvation, while others have been protected by Federal, state or municipal surveillance. The largest stand of holly in the North is within the Sandy Hook State Park in northern New Jersey.

title: Judge in Curt Flood Case Finds Baseball's Feudal Barony Is Kind to Its Serfs
Program of Dance By Nancy Meehan Evokes the Seasons
description: One of the most interesting and to ward off those looking for less demanding fare, this does not mean entertainingdance programs this year was presented Friday night by the Nancy Meehan Dance Company at New York University's Education Auditorium, 35 West Fourth Street.

title: Trinity's Yard Blooms Amid Canyons
description: TRINITY Churchyard on lower Broadway at the head of Wall Street is best known for the illustrious Americans whose remains are buried hemAlexander Hamilton, Albert Gallatin, William Bradford, Robert Fulton, and others. To take a leisurely stroll through the churchyard and read the weathered inscriptions on the stones is to reach back to the morning time of our country's history.

title: Margaret E. Myers Wed to Stephen Towl
description: RIDGEBURY, N. Y., April 10Miss Margaret Elizabeth Myers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Daniel Myers of Slate Hill, was married here this afternoon to Stephen Ackley Towl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Theodore Towl Jr. of Rhinebeck. The Rev. William Wildeman performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Revision Urged in City System of Picking Local School Boards
description: A complete revision in the way members of the city's local school boards are chosen, including abolition of the proportional representation method for their election, is being urged by the Institute for Community Studies of Queens College.

title: 35 Craft Will Start in186Mile Race
description: A newly built oceanracing version of the exotic pickleforknose tunnel hull designed by Ron Jones will campaign for national championship honors beginning next Saturday in the Long. teach, Cald.,toEnsenada, Mexico, offshore race.

title: In Limbo
description: Headliners

title: Bonita Shulock Plans Nuptials To R. T. Siverd
description: JEANNETTE, Pa., April 10 Miss Bonita M. Shulock, senior at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, and Robert J. Siverd, a student at Georgetown Law School, plan to be married in January.

title: Townsend Wins Italian Golf By 2 Strokes With a 277
description: ROME, April 10 (UPI)Peter Townsend carried his thirdround lead through the final 18 holes today and won the Walworth golf tournament with a total of 277, and the top prize money was 4,800.

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: Backstage Memories of the Library
description: To THE EDITOR: IFOUND Ada Louise Huxtable's article concerning the New York Public Library Building most interesting, not only because I love the building also, but because I worked there for a good part of the 1950's. There are parts of the building not open to the public that I got to know well. The stacks are particularly wonderful. They are under the main reading room all along the Bryant Park side, and they really consist of book shelves seven stories high (there are seven levels). The floors of the levels are, of course, solidly anchored, but the reach of the shelving is continuous, and there is a twoinch gap between the corridor floors and the shelves  which tended to be disastrous if you dropped a book: many's the time I had to straggle down two or more flights of stairs to fetch a book that had dropped through.

title: Quartet
description: The reappearance of this first novel by Jean Rhys, originally published in 1928 (with, in England, the title Postures), is the latest dividend from revival of interest in Miss Rhys that has recently produced new editions of her other novels. This early work opens the themedeveloped in Voyage in the Dark and reaching its full power in the beautiful Wide Sargasso Seaof an imaginative, susceptible nature destroyed by the assertive, unyielding world.

title: 3 U.S. NEWSMEN ENTER RED CHINA FOR WEEK'S VISIT
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, April 11Three American newsmen entered Communist China from Hong Kong this morning as part of a group of seven men who will be allowed to cover the current visit of an American table tennis team.

title: Westchester Bus Information Center to Help Riders
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 10 We've got the blises, we've got the routes, now all we need is the people, said Steve Goldmann, his optimism receding for the moment before the magnitiude of what ails the bus industry in Westchester County.

title: ELEANOR M. GREENWOOD
description: Special to The New York Times

title: FOR CONSTRUCTIVE CRITICISM
description: To THE EDITOR: Reading Julius Duscha's article about Nader's Raiders (Stop! In the  Public Interest, March 21) brought to mind President Pompidou's sad comment on the French riots of 1968: But, what trees do they plant?

title: STEAM CAR ENGINE HELD NEAR SUCCESS
description: RENO, Nev., April 10 (AP) In a letter to President Nixon, the millionaire inventor William Lear accused the Federal Government yesterday of ignoring his project to develop a pollutionfree automobile engine.

title: COAST DRIVE SLATED BY ANTIWAR GROUP
description: BOSTON, April 10 (AP)  A nonprofit corporation to generate public pressure against the Vietnam war and war in general will begin a broadcast campaign next week on the West Coast, according to Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska.

title: Gibson Warns of Racial Confrontation
description: NEWARK, April 10Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson warned today that this city was headed for a destructive racial and political confrontation over the 10weekold teachers' strike and appealed for a restoration of calm and reason.

title: New Center for Blind Opening on L.I.
When You Get to Paris, Skip the Louvre, Versailles, Invalides and the Eiffel Tower
description: PARISStrange to relate, I know people who don't like Paris. Most of them are Parisians, displaced countryfolk who miss the good earth and resent the traffic, the competitive pace and the bigcity rudeness. Often, they ask me why I cherish the place, and since it's a personal question, I must begin the answer with myself.

title: City Island Display to Show 100 Boats
description: The first annual City Island Sailboat Show will be held next Thursday through Sunday at Thwaites,Marina on City Island, the Bronx, with about 100 boats on display in the water and numerous exhibits ashore.

title: Mapping:
description: Everyoneor almost everyoneagrees today that the earth is round. Some 22 centuries ago, however, when most who thought about it believed the earth was anything but round, an ingenious librarian in Alexandria not only recognized the rotundity of our planet but devised a way to measure its girth.

title: If Hair Were Revived in 2016
description: WHAT a brilliant idea it was to revive Hair! And how clever to duplicate the ambience of the original production: the low building devoted solely to dramatic presentations (our elders called them theaters), the quaint, oldfashioned 7:30 curtain, instead of our 5 P.M. monstrosity, which seems designed solely to get Australian commuters home to Melbourne in time for tea.

title: Program Widening Its Effort to Awake. Suburbia on Poor
description: The Revitalization Corps, a private group that promotes contact between suburban and slum families, announced plans last week for a wide expansion of its program.

title: Going, Going, GONE...
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.Vacation bargainhunters will descend upon the nearby Smith Haven shopping mall next Sunday afternoon to bid on some 70 vacation packages to destinations ranging from Hawall to Africaand all in the cause of the Maryhaven School for the Educable Retarded here.

title: HIGH SCHOOL SETS FULLYEAR PLAN
description: HINESBURG, Vt., April 10 One of the nation's first allyear high school schedules begins here this summer as a school board's response to the public's refusal to finance enlargement of a crowded building.

title: Jeffrey Huvelle Becomes Fiance Of Ellen Segal
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your editorial of March 28 you correctly state that no real victory can be won in the war against inflation without a curb on the breakneck pace of the wageprice spiral. Your suggested remedy mirrors the Administration's principal proposal of putting on the brakes in the construction industry.

title: Don't Forget Jersey
description: To the Editor: The article extolling Pancho Segura's new tennis discovery, Frank Nunez, which appeared in Sunday's New York Times [April 4], ignored a significant and interesting fact relating to this young man's background.

title: How to Survive in Your Native Land
description: A large number of very good books dealing with public education in America and its mounting difficulties have been published in the past five years. Two of them are comparatively little known, and are superior in their concreteness and insight, and in the depth and significance of what they report. One, Miriam Wasserman's The School Fix: NYC; USA (Outerbridge & Dienstfrey, $10), is notable for its effectiveness in linking concrete examples of school practice to general inferences about the social functions of public education. It is Miss Wasserman's thesis that the public schools are not malfunctioning but rather that they are being destructive by designating society's losers quite effectively. This, she argues, is really what they are supposed to do. She demonstrates this with impressive, if depressing, evidence drawn primarily from the New York City schools.

title: YANKS TOP SENATORS, 60
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  The New York Yankees finally got into the victory column of the American League standings on this cool but sunny afternoon in the nation's capital. And it was wholly appropriate that the club's first triumph of 1971 was engineered by Mel Stottlemyre.

title: A Report On the Abortion Capital Of the Country
description: AFTER nine months experience under New York State's new abortion law, only one definitive conclusion is possible: What this country needs is a perfect contraceptive.

title: Wiretaps:
description: Electronic surveillers had a mixed week.  On Monday, the United States Supreme Court, which doesn't permit visitors to take notes and bans microphones and television cameras from its press section, announced that it saw nothing wrong with a warrantless informer, secretly wired for sound, broadcasting ostensibly private conversations to collaborating police agents who recorded them for posterity and subsequently introduced the tapes as evidence in a narcotics violation trial.

title: Ceylon: If We Don't Die Here
description: The world's first woman Prime Minister, Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike of Ceylon, returned to power last Mayafter five years in opposition as head of a coalition of her own leftist Freedom party and Trotskyite and Cominunist parties. The coalition's twothirds majority in Parliament seemed to indicate a quick conversion to farleft socialism for the Indian Ocean island's 13 million people.

title: LUDICROUS
description: Movie Mailbag.

title: FREE TAX SERVICE GIVEN IN BROOKLYN
BACON IS ELECTED BY SPORTS GROUP
description: James E. Bacon of the Harvard Club has been elected president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

title: Psychiatrist to Wed Frances Rosen
description: WORCESTER, Mass., April 10  Miss Frances Erica Rosen and Dr. Howard S. Berger will be married next month.

title: Ramapo Scored
description: To the Editor: It should be said loudly and clearly that Ramapo Supervisor John F. McAlevey's socalled controlled growth program [Innovator in Suburbs Under Fire, March 28] is in fact a cruel and cynical confiscation of property rights rather than a constructive innovation.

title: Wendy Fisher Wed To Jeffrey Bruner
description: MADISON, Conn., April 10  Miss Wendy Partridge Fisher was married this afternoon to Jeffrey Joseph Bruner. The Rev. Franklin A. Bower performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church of Madison.

title: Economic Survey Shows Opposition To Any Fiscal Prod
description: ALTHOUGH there have been some strong recommendations in economic circles recently for a more stimulative fiscal policy to prod the economy, the prevailing sentiment seems to be against any aggressive moves in that direction by Washington at this time.

title: W. J. HAWTHORNE
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 10William Joseph Hawthorne, retired chairman of the biological science department of the Christopher Columbus High School in the Bronx, died here yesterday.

title: BIRTHCURB MOVES FOUGHT IN IRELAND
description: DUBLIN, April 10 Moves to liberalize the Irish laws on contraception and to remove the constitutional ban on divorce legislation are running into both political and ecclesiastical opposition here, and few people now rule out the possibility of a major clash between church and state on these issues.

title: A Few Hours Of Sunlight
description: A fellow named Gilles is the focus of the latest petit four Sagan to reach American gourmetsand it must be said at once that the trouble with Gilles is his big mouth. Talk, talk, talk with his best boy friend Jean, over at the newspaper office, about how he doesn't want to exist, about his glandular pressures, about his melancholia. So  when Gilles meets Junoesque Nathalie, a smashing matron from Limoges who solves his problems does he know enough to shut up? Not Gilles. After Nathalie has chucked her husband and run off with him, there is Gilles blabbing away to Jean all over again. This time, about how he'd like to split and be back on his own.

title: Lonely Pitcairn Island To Get Regular Mail
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10 Regular mail service begins this month for Pitcairn Island in the South Pacific, where the most recent mail calls include lone ships in July and February.

title: Mimi Maddock Is Bride Of William Kemble Jr.
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 10Miss Paula Mimi Maddock, whose ancestors were developers of Palm Beach, was married here this afternoon to William Tyson Kemble Jr. of New York. The Rev. Hunsdon Cary Jr. performed the ceremony at the BethesdabytheSea Episcopal Church.

title: FIRSTHAND LOOK
description: To THE EDITOR: I do not feel Mr. Villas has the right to say that travel agents are simply not that knowledgeable on the spedfications of the various liners. . .  Perhaps he is not aware that many of the steamship companies in New York have frequent inspections of their ships so that travel agents can be apprised of the accommodations, cuisine, service, etc. These inspections are well attended by agents (on their own time) and they make it their business to be there so that they can advise their clients on what to expect. Seventylive per cent of the bookings received by the steamship companies come through travel agents.

title: CEYLON STIFFENS STAND ON REBELS
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 10 (Reuters)The Ceylonese Government, as part of its battle against guerrilla attacks, has decreed the death penalty for anyone aiding insurgents, it was reported today.

title: DERBY HEAD SCORES OTB ON WAGER PLAN
description: LOUISVILLE, April 10 (UPI)  Lynn Stone, president of Churchill Downs race track, the home of the Kentucky Derby, demanded today that the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation abandon plans for accepting wagers on the Derby May 1.

title: E.M. Haring Weds Janet K. Marshall
description: WOODBURY, Conn., April 10Miss Janet Kay Marshall and Eugene Miller Haring were married here this afternoon in the North Congregational Church by the Rev. Webb E. Wright.

title: No Gold Lam For Phil Ochs
description: Music

title: Ne Win Hospitalized in India
description: NEW DELHI, April 10 (UPI) Gen. Ne Win, chairman of the Burmese Revolutionary Council, entered the All India Medical Institute here today for treatment of a severe ulcer condition. He had been scheduled to leavve New Delhi for Rangoon today, but physicians said he would be in the hospital for at least five days.

title: Hotel in Tokyo
description: Letters to the Editor

title: MINE SAFETY ACT IS CALLED A PERIL
description: LOUISVILLE, Key., April 10 A spokesman for 400 smallscale coal operators in eastern Kentucky and Virginia charged today that the Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act of 1969 was killing miners and forcing operators to close their mines.

title: LAW RUNS 0:47.3 IN SCHOOL RELAYS Snyder Sophomore Anchors Mile Team to Victory
Donnkenny Projects. Increases This Year
description: Things are looking up for sportswear manufacturers in at least one respect. Knitted fabrics are in more plentiful supply, and production next summer and fall will not be held up by the shortages that delayed deliveries last year.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: N.B.A. Playoffs

title: Eban Denies That Talks On Mideast Are Deadlocked
description: TEL AVIV, April 10 (Reuters) The Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, denied today that the Middle East peace talks were deadlocked, as has been reported.

title: Osteen Beats Padres
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) Bill Sudakis belted two home runs tonight to back the threehit pitching of Claude Osteen as the Los Angeles Dodgers routed San Diego Padres, 92.

title: Well, It's a Heck of a Long Way From Marcus Welby
description: TLEVISION, the most potent medium of mass communication since movable type, has languished throughout its history in the thrall of big money and small imaginations, advancing steadily in its technical resources while remaining, in the content and especially the form of its uses, practically static. So goes the thinking of what might be called the video visionariesartistic and intellectual types inside and (mostly) outside the industry who have been frustrated down through the years by the persistent gap between their vision of television's potential as a formal and expressive medium and the deadhead level of its actual performance, a gap they have been powerless to affect. That is, until recently.

title: The Court: Justices Are Losing Their Cool
description: WASHINGTON  Since the Court this term has already downgraded citizens receiving public welfare, and citizens having the misfortune to be illegitimate, I suppose today's decision downgrading citizens born outside the United States should have been expected.

title: Penn State Quintet to Play In Next Holiday Festival Here
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 10 (UPI)Penn State has announced a 25game 197172 basketball schedule featuring appearances in the Volunteer Classic at Knoxville, Tenn., and the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival in New York.

title: WOMAN DESIGNS SUBURB IN POLAND
description: NOWE TYCHY, Poland, April 10 (AP) I got where I am today without being either a man or a party member.

title: Green Grass That's Not So Green
description: MANY persons are seriously considering an artificial turf backyard, and although the lover of living things may shudder at the thought of plastic flowers, perhaps plastic grass is not so displeasing to him. We do not intend to evaluate the esthetic or the economic value of artificial turf, but we have investigated some properties of the turf and find that it may be undesirable in some specific instances.

title: North Vietnam to Elect A New Legislature Today
description: SAIGON, April 10 (UPI) North Vietnamese voters will elect a new National Assembly tomorrow from a list of 522 candidates nominated by the Communist party and seven independents.

title: Yost Article Stirs U.N. Dispute On U.S. Attitude Toward Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 10  A bluntly critical appraisal of Israeli Government policies by Charles W. Yost, the former United States Representative to the United Nations, has stirred wide interest here.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: Senator. Fullbright's mendacious attack on Israel in his speech before the Yale Political Union is a blatant play on the fears of the American people of becoming involved in another Vietnam.

title: Princeton and Yale Varsity Crews Register Triumphs on Lake Carnegie
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 Who won? asked Pete Sparhawk, the Princeton crew coach, as he shouted to the shore from the coaching launch. The varsity crew race between Princeton and Navy was so close today that neither the coaches nor the competing oarsmen had any idea which boat finished the 2,000meter course first.

title: Nixon and Reagan Accused In Welfare Conspiracy Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (UPI)The California Welfare Rights Organization has filed a Federal court suit charging President Nixon and Gov. Ronald Reagan with conspiring to violate Federal welfare laws.

title: Palmer Award to Shoemaker
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)  Bill Shoemaker, the jockey with the most victories, has been voted the Joe Palmer Award for 1970, the National Turf Writers Association announced today. Shoemaker was honored for meritorious service to racing.

title: Harvard Captain Is Elected
description: Harvard's varsity fencing team has elected Geza Tatrallyay of Don Mills, Ontario, as 197172 captain. Tatrallyay is an pe fencer.

title: Andretti and Foyt Will Drive In Trentonian 200 on April 25
description: Now that spring is here, the area tracks are beginning to perk up. Trenton Speedway will open its season on April 25, with the running of the Trentonian 200 for Indianapolistype cars.

title: Michigan Newspaper Sold
description: NILES, Mich., April 10 (AP) The Niles Daily Star has been purchased by Ridder Publications, Inc. The sale of the Star Publishing Company and the Niles Printing Company was announced Monday by J. Eric Plym, publisher of The Star, and Walter T. Ridder, vice president of Ridder.

title: National Notes
description: The Big Bet What will happen to Harry the Horse and all his fellow bookmakers now that New York City's legal offtrack betting systemthe first in the countryis off and running? Right now, said one, I'm not worried. The welldressed, middleaged bookie believed he will at least be able to stay in business because:

title: Kentucky Will Review Effects of Cigarettes
description: GLASGOW, Ky., April 10 (AP)  Lieut. Gov. Wendell Ford said this week that the state was hiring top scientific personnel to determine if cigarette smoking damages health.

title: You All Scores an Upset Over Deceit at Keeneland
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 (AP)C. V. Whitney's You All, closing from next to last place, pulled an upset today in the $32,150 Ashland Stakes at Keeneland.

title: Long Island Railroad Helicopter Patrols Tracks
Any Number Can Play Scenario
description: IT is still a year and seven months until Nov. 7, 1972, and only admirers of Wilbur Glenn Voliva, small children, fools and people who love politics would try to predict what will happen on that day.

title: Elinor T. Upton And John Owen To Wed June 26
description: GREENS FARMS, Conn., April 10Miss Elinor Tidden Upton and John Russell Owen will be married here June 26.

title: Blow From the Draft
description: To the Editor: Last week the House Armed Services Committee tentatively voted to give President Nixon the authority to abolish deferments for undergraduate college students. This is a serious blow to intercollegiate athletics.

title: LABEL ISSUE STIRS THE GOAT RAISERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  Will an American eat a hot dog if he knows it contains goat meat?

title: Colon Has to Pause in Track Career
description: Slipping into virtual obscurity at the age of 19 after a sensational senior year in high school is not exactly Tony Colon's idea of how to succeed in running.

title: The Press and The Cold War
description: To the Editor: Professor Allen Weinstein of Smith  and you  wrote a strange review of my book, The Press and the Cold War.

title: WHERE DE SOTO LANDED
description: Letters:

title: An American Girl
description: Patricia Dizenzo's deadpan memoir of a Hackensack highschool girl shows us the dark side of Biondie and Dagwood. The time is the 1950's. The nameless narrator is as ingenuously involved as any of her teenage peers in girls basketball, cheerleader tryouts, prom dates and the best way to hold up her bobby socks. But Mom is not only domineering, she is a candidate for A.A. And dad, a whitecollar slave in corporate law, breaks down and cries when he can't get a decent enough raise from his Mr. Dithers.

title: CITY OPERA REPEATS ROBERTO DEVEREUX
description: Within a period of nine days, the New York City Opera is giving Roberto Devereux four times. The success of the Donizetti opera warrants it. Beverly Sills's remarkable portrayal of Elizabeth I is a constant in these performances, but the title role and that of Sara, Duchess of Nottingham, have been undergoing changes.

title: U.S. Team Awakens In Peking to a Meal Of Bacon and Eggs
description: PEKING, Sunday, April 11 (UPI)Fifteen members of the United States table tennis team arrived in the capital of China last night and arose this morning to a breakfast of pancakes and bacon and eggs.

title: Susan Tinsworth Married to S. A. Weiss
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., April 10 In the Manhattanville College Chapel here this afternoon, Miss Susan Barbara Tinsworth, a graduate of the college, was married to Stephen Arnold Weiss, who is president of the Sage Corporation, an engineering and building concern with offices in New York and Florida. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Martin, a Jesuit priest and cousin of the bride.

title: Anne d'Harnoncourt Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Ren d'Harnoncourt has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne d'Harnoncourt, to Joseph H. Rishel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rishel of Phelps, N. Y.

title: Canadiens Top Bruins, 31, for 21 Series Lead as Frank Mahovlich Stars
HOT STUFF AT SEA
description: To THE EDITOR: I share with James Villas a great enthusiasm for transAtlantic crossings by ship, but I must take exception to his commentsin A Connoisseur's Guide to Superliners (Travel section, March 14)about the food aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2. Havingtraveled on all the ships that he mentioned except the France (an omission I shall correct on July 1), I can say that in one important respect the food aboard the Q.E.2 is superior to all the others. My main gripe about shipboard fooduntil the Queenhas been that hot food is never hot when It reaches the table. The most superb dish loses something in the translation when it is served lukewarm or downright cold. The Q.E.2 handles this problem nicely by giving every hot dish an extra shot of heat at a centeraisle console in the dining room. The liner's room service was gracious and warm at all times.

title: Hewitt Advances
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 10 (AP)Secondseeded Bob Hewitt of San Francisco beat Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia, 63, 36, 36, 61, 61, in a thirdround singles match of the South African open tennis tournament today.

title: Henry A. Wallace of Iowa
description: The American left often seems like the mirror image of the Bourbons, learning nothing because it forgets everything. Yet radicals are not entirely to blame for their lack of memory. Social change and mobility make forgetfulness almost necessary, while historians habitually caricature radical leaders and ideas. The radical tradition, like that of so many minorities in America, tends to become invisible. At any time, like De Tocqueville's democratic man, the left is cut off from its ancestors and descendants alike, shut in the prison of itself.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Whether or not Erie Stanley Gardner was the world's bestselling mystery author (he probably was), his case is a phenomenon. For years he continued to turn out much the same kind of book, whether under his own name or that of A. A. Fair, and the public could not get enough of it. Perry Mason entered American folkways. Yet, judged dispassionately, Gardner was an awful writer. At best, he could tell a story in a fastpaced manner, with the inevitable courtroom climax. But his writing was impossibly trite and, frequently, sloppy. He had few real ideas; his books show little contact with the world around him; his characters had as much life as the inhabitants of Potemkin Village.

title: P.O.W. Treatment Protested
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)  The American National Red Cross said yesterday that it had received more than 72,500 letters protesting treatment of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam. The letters are in response to an article appearing in the April issue of the Reader's Digest, which describe conditions under which many prisoners of war are being held.

title: He's So Happy He Feels Like an Idiot
House Plant Clinic
description: AN Open House for House Plants will be held Saturday at The Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. During these four hours a panel of experts will be available to diagnose plantgrowing problems, recommend care of plants and tell visitors how to avoid pests and diseases.

title: Name of School Challenged
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 10 (AP)The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed suit in Federal District Court this week to change the name of Robert E. Lee High School. History records this individual, the suit said, as being one of America's greatest traitors, a man whose cunning and guile almost destroyed this country in his zeal to keep blacks enslaved.

title: U.S. PANEL APPROVES IRON WORKERS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)Presider Nixon's Construction Industry Stabilization Committee, acting for the first time under its authority to hold down wage increases, has approved a pay and benefit increase of nearly 6 per cent won this month by structural iron workers in 36 Texas counties.

title: DISSERVICE
description: To THE EDITOR: Recently I handed over the bargain  basement price of $12 to the Imperial cashier because I thought it would be fun to see a musical conceived in the classic Broadway tradition, Two By Two. The curtain had not been up five minutes, however, before it was quite obvious that I, along with a sizable audience, had paid our money to attend an entertainment that might be called The Danny Kaye Show, or perhaps One By One.

title: PENN CENTRAL FIRE DELAYS 30 TRAINS
description: An electrical fire on an Albanybound Penn Central train caused a delay of at least two hours to its passengers yesterday and reportedly resulted in delays of up to 45 minutes for passengers of 30 other trains.

title: Shoring Up King Hussein
description: Washington's reported promise of additional arms aid for Jordan may temporarily bolster King Hussein in his renewed confrontation with Palestinian guerrillas. But this risky expedient cannot keep the lid on simmering Jordan for long if the political situation in the Middle East is allowed to deteriorate once more. King Hussein's more urgent need is for peace, not a sword.

title: WILD PITCH IS KEY
description: New York got its first look at the Big Red Machine of 1971 yesterday and saw what the rumblings from the South were all about.

title: JERSEY GIRL RIDES TO JUMPER HONORS
Future Social Events
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Journalism Awards For 70 Announced By Sigma Delta Chi
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI) Winners of the 39th annual Sigma Delta Chi awards for distinguished service in journalism have been announced by the professional journalistic society.

title: Medieval Remnants Are Encased by A New Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT  What I find most striking about this city is the juxtaposition of the new and the old, brought about when the postwar authorities fitted contemporary architecture around the precious surviving vestiges of its antiquity.

title: 84 Million Live Fish Imported Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)The Government said today that 84 million live fish and 14 million other animals were imported Into the United States last year. Some became pets and most of the others were used in scientific experiments.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Selective Trout by Doug Swisher and Carl Richards (Crown Publishers, 184 pages, illustrated, $6.95) would be worth its cost if the fly fishermen who reed it learned of nothing more than the nohackle dry fly, a concept that Joe Brooks, in his introduction to the book, calls one of the, great dry, fly discoveries of North American fly fishing history.

title: CAMPAIGN IN KOREA MOVES TO BIG CITIES
To THE EDITOR:
description: Dr. Homan's article is truly a marvelous, funny and so helpful treatise! Our Cub Scout's hands are almost always, quarry gray in colorhe has colds all the time, too! And the 14yearold boy has no wellimprinted bathing habit!

title: BROWN OARSMEN SWEEP BOSTON U.
description: BOSTON, April 10Brown University's heavyweight crew hung on this morning to nip an improving Boston University eight by less than two seconds in nearperfect conditions on the Charles River.

title: Garelik Proposes Yanks and Football Giants join Mets and Jets at Shea Stadium
description: Instead of buying Yankee Stadium, the city should have all four of its major league teamsthe baseball Yankees and Mets and the Football Giants and Jetsplay in Shea Stadium, City Council President Sanford D. Garelik suggested yesterday.

title: UPSTATE AGENCY BUDGET CASUALTY
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 10 The Hudson River Valley commission, one of the quieter cesulaties of the budgettrimming in Albany, is about to be absorbed into a new statewide planning office and to lose its professional staff.

title: Orioles Edge Tigers, 21, on Johnson's Single With Two Out in Ninth Inning
description: BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) Dave Johnson singled home Frank Robinson with the winning run in the last of the ninth inning as the Baltimore Orioles edged the Detroit Tigers, 2.1, today.

title: Drowned Man's Body Found
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., April 10 Suffolk County police marine units ti.ls morning recovered the body of Donald Wiles, 20 years old, of North Massapequa, who disappeared late yesterday when his canoe capsized in the Nissequogue River. The police said Mr. Wiles and two friends were in the canoe when it capsized at about 5:15 P.M. yesterday. Peter Zimmerman, 22, of Central Islip, and William Lather, 29, of Huntington Station, were able to swim to shore, but Mr. Wiles disappeared.

title: Hospitals Expanding Hours of Clinics
description: In the waiting rooms of hospital outpatient departments the complaint has been hoard for years: I had to take a day off from work to be here.

title: Book Sales Off, Spock Says
description: PUEBLO, Colo., April 10 (UPI) Dr. Benjamin Spock says his antiwar efforts have caused a decline In sales of his longtime best seller, Baby and Child Care. I'm afraid that people like Spiro Agnew did persuade a certain number of people that if they used my book to make a formula or change a diaper, it would change their children into brats, the pediatrician said. Other people got the idea that their children might turn into traitors if they read my book.

title: DR. MILO B. SAMPSON, NUCLEAR. PHYSICIST
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., April 10Dr. Milo B. Sampson, nuclear physicist and professor of physics at Indiana University, died today at the age of 62.

title: Queens Benefit Concert Set
description: The Music Students Association Orchestra or Queens College will present a benefit concert at Public School 203, Springfield Boulevard and 53d Avenue, in Bayside, on April 24 at 8:30 P.M. The proceeds will go to the Bayside auxiliary of the Cystic Fibrosis National Research Foundation.

title: Camera World
description: CLAIMED to be the largest photographic exposition ever held this side of the Atlantic Ocean, Photo Expo 71 opens this Saturday in Chicago at the newly rebuilt McCormick Place exposition hall. Sponsored by the National Association of Photographic Manufacturers, and supported by 19 other professional and trade associations, Photo Expo 71 will open at 10 A.M. this Saturday and will close at 10 P.M. on Sunday, April 25. However, on the 17th and 18th, members of the trade only will be admitted from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M.the public will be admitted from 2 to 10 P.M. On April 1923, the public will be admitted from 5 to 10 P.M.; and on April 2425 the public will be admitted from noon to 10 P.M.

title: Israel:
description: JERUSALEMOur people wept by the waters of Babylon, said Me Dayan. Today, they weep by the waters of the Volga. I know there Is the Security Council resolution, the Rogers plan, the Dayan plan and the Allon plan, and there will be more plans. But there is something bigger and stronger than all of these. The Jewish people have returned to their homeland. The Army of Israel now stands by the waters of the Jordan.

title: Eliza Lansing Conze Is Engaged To Anthony Henry Billington
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Conze have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eliza Lansing Conze, to Anthony Henry Billington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Billington of Newbury, Berkshire, England.

title: Presidential Availability
description: To the Editor: Since Richard Nixon was sworn as President, the Washington press corps has been callingand more recently, shoutingfor more frequent access to him and more candid responses from him. At least partly in answer to these demands, the President in the past months has been much more available, and in many more revealing formats. Reporters have been given more meetings, in smaller groups, scheduled and spontaneous, televised and private. There has been time for probing and followup questions.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To the Financial Editor: Another aspect of the dangers in the death of our bees ought to be stressed in the most urgent and shrill terms. The disappearance of the bees, should that come about as your article (April 4) seems to indicate, would be as great a calamity to the world as possibly an international atomic war.

title: The Pamplona Bibles
description: In the year 1194, Sancho el Fuerte (11531234), King of Navarra, decided to have a pictorial Bible made for his own use. His father's chancellor, Archdeacon Petrus Ferrandus, was put to work on the project. Soon the Archdeacon had brought together four artists and set up a shop in Pamplona. He busied himself with laying out themes and cycles of events, and working up an entire plan for the Bible. One of the artists, designated by Francois Bucher as Master A, was put in charge of the painting of the pictures. Soon a massive pattern of 871 illustrations had been evolved, themes had been set and passages to be illustrated agreed upon. The four artists went to work and out of their activity came the wonderful Pamplona Bible of King Sancho el Fuerte, completed in 1197 and now housed in Amiens.

title: A Tough Act to Follow
description: On the face of it, Milton F. Rosenthal would appear to be in the classic showbusiness dilemmahaving a tough act to follow.

title: Jute Exports From East Pakistan Said to Be Resumed
description: KARACHI, April 10Shipments of jute, the tough fiber that is Pakistan's main export, have been resumed in East Pakistan, according to reports reaching this West Pakistani port.

title: Poisonous Chemical Dumped in Hudson; Water Called Safe
description: The GAF Corporation said, yesterday that it accidentally dumped more than 7,000 gallons of a poisonous chemical into the Hudson River last week. But state officials said there was no danger to drinking water or fish.

title: KOREAN FARMERS LEAVE THE LAND
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 10For thousands of years Korean farmers regarded their way of life as a noble one, for, as an old saying in this country goes, agriculture is the foundation of the world.

title: Call Me Manneschewitz By Thomas McMenamin. 239 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $5.95.
description: If you were born too late for Abie's Irish Rose, you're in time for this emotional equivalent. James Parnell O'Shanahan and Sarah Riecher meet cute in Iowa City, where Jim is studying advanced pottery and Sarah is studying photography or something. It's love at first night, and cohabitation leads eventually to a big semiJewish wedding in Akron, Ohio, the bride's hometown. Mr. McMenamin has not invested his novel with anything approach, ing narrative suspense, but he's full of schmaltz and sunshine, and  to paraphrase Barry Golden  he is not what is wrong with the world.

title: U. C. L. A. Star, 19, Living Up to Notices
description: LOS ANGELES, April 10  A 200pound freshman named James Edward McAlister seems like a sure thing to provide happy days for two coaches at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Children Sing Requiem in Land of Unrest
55,352 See Phils Beat Expos in New Stadium;
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP)Don Money's first hit of the season, a home run, keyed a threerun sixthinning rally that carried the Philadelphia Phillies to a 41 victory over the Montreal Expos today before 55,352 fans in the first game ever played at the new $45million Veterans Stadium.

title: PARENT IN GOAL WITH NEW MASK
Photo Display at Hewlett Is a Study of TeenAgers
description: The Fabulous Faces of Fourteen is the title of a photographic study of the upper middleclass teenager now on exhibit until the end of the month at the Hewlett Woodmere Library in Hewlett, L.I.

title: Rockefeller Forms Group of 300 To Aid RevenueSharing Drive
description: ALBANY, April 10Governor Rockefeller today announced the formation of a 300member bipartisan committee in the state to press for Federal revenue sharing.

title: NEWARK REGENCY DENIED BY JONES
description: NEWARK, April 10  LeRoi Jones, who helped Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson win election last year, sat opening his mail in his small, neat office as he scoffed at reports characterizing him as the power behind the city administration.

title: Final Opener Listed In Royals Stadium; Keefe, 74, to Attend
description: KANSAS CITY, April 10 (UPI) The last openingday game in Municipal Stadium will be played Monday night. The man who pitched and won the first one will be there.

title: SixthGraders in queens Leading Their Classmates Away From the Hazards of Drug Abuse
description: Out of the mouths of babes the words came: Pot, tea, grass, hemp. Red birds, red devils, pink ladies, yellow jacks, blue velvets. Bennies, beans, buttons, browns. Cartwheels, copilots, ups, downs. . . .

title: Ski Resorts in U.S. Report a Growing Number of Blacks Are Testing the Slopes
description: Skiing, a sport which has been enjoyed mostly by whites, is being taken up by a growing number of blacks across the country.

title: CRUISER'S PROTEST
description: To THE EDITOR: Three loud, long cheers for James Villas's charming analysis of transAtlantic steamship travel. But along with the cheers, two small corrections and one violent protest. The protest: Mr. Villas swung me around 180 degrees with his offhanded slap at pleasure cruising. While conceding that the diversion of transAtlantic liners to the cruise trade is essential for the economic survival of the species, he adds disdainfully, But there always seems to be something lacking on a Caribbean cruise, something incomplete and falling short of the experience of being on a majestic superliner headed for Europe at 32 knots in the middle of the Atlantic.

title: Computers:
description: Science fiction writers long ago decided that the medical care of the future will be wholly automated and computerized: Patients will be examined, diagnosed, treated and even operated upon by machines with no more human intervention than is now involved in a local telephone call.

title: Minority Loans
description: DETROITWilliam H. Pinkard, a 41yearold black man, quit the security of a $15,000ayear plumbing job with the Chrysler Corporation last April and plunged into one of the riskiest of propositions his own small business.

title: Alexander T Liebowitz Weds Denise F. Harvey in Belgium
description: Miss Denise French Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sherman Harvey of Medfield, Mass., was married in Mons, Belgium, yesterday to Alexander Thomas Liebowitz, a foreign Service officer serving as assistant to the political adviser to the Supreme Allied Commander Europe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Liebowitz of Sunnyside, Queens.

title: MANHATTAN SCORES IN TRIANGULAR MEET
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 10 Bob Brady, a Manhattan College freshman, won the shotput and the discus throw today to help the Jaspers defeat Fairleigh Dickinson and the United States Coast Guard Academy in a triangular trackandfield meet.

title: Dear Mr. Manager, OrAn Overdue Letter From an Overwrought Englishman
description: Dear Mr. ElHainid*, While in Tunisia, my wife and I were so impressed with the beauty of your hotel, and indeed of all the other apparently identical hotels dotted round Hammamet's delicious gulfyou'll have noticed that the Hammamet Sheraton, at present not much more than a swimming pool full of workmen's bicycles, is promised by a billboard just along the beach  that we might even come again sometime when it's neither raining nor Christmas. Meanwhile, we seem to remember, among a wealth of bedroom literature including cableforms (please write text of mesage [sic] on your backside [sic]), your courteous request to let you know what we think of your hotel.

title: Boy of the Year Award
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)  President Nixon presented the Boys Club of America Boy of the Year award yesterday to Pelton H. Stewart of Sari Francisco. Besides a plaque, the winner, who is 18 years old, received a $4,000 college scholarship as part of the Juvenile Decency in Action program of the organization, which has 900 clubs in 47 states.

title: Patriots Ticket Selling Fast
description: BOSTON, April 10 (AP) Ticket sales are soaring for the home games of the New England Patriots in their 62,000seat stadium under construcLion in Foxboro, about 20 miles south of Boston.. The club reported that 39,513 season tickets had been sold.

title: What's in Store for Us?
description: SINCE we now have a twoweek respite in New York's dance activity, it might be worth having a look at what is in store for us during the spring and summer. In the first place, it will not be quite such an interesting dance spring as we were hoping for, because of the cancellation of the Bolshoi Ballet, which was to have brought us New York's first sight of Yuri Grigorovich's Spartacus, his new Swan Lake, and Maya Plisetskaya in Alberto Alonso's Carmen.

title: Brezhnev Officially Listed Ahead of Soviet Politburo
description: MOSCOW, April 10The Soviet Union indicated today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, whose preeminence in the Kremlin leadership was underscored at the justcompleted 24th Communist party Congress, has now risen officially above his fellow Politburo membersapparently as the undisputed leader of the country.

description: Movie Mailbag:

title: For the Faithful, There Will Never Be a Coda to the SymPhony of the Brooklyn Dodgers
description: O Tempore, O Mores, O'Malley.

title: When Pumpkins Blossomed
description: Tuberculars die In the summer, explains a patient in a Yugoslav sanitarium, when the pumpkins blossom. By the time you appreciate the significance of this elegiac statement, you will be reaching the denouement of a Serbian epic that has not allowed your eye to wander for an instant. Mr. Mihailovic is a storyteller of hypnotic caliber. In depicting the rise and fall of Ljuban Stretenovich, champion middleweight and apolitical proletarian, he measures the quality of life in his country, maintaining all the while a pace as fast as Willie Pep's footwork.

title: Pakistan Stresses Islamic Unity In Messages Directed to East
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 10 The Pakistani Government has been stressing Islamic solidarity in an information campaign it is directing at the people of East Pakistan.

title: OLE FOR PROFILES
description: To THE EDITOR: Timothy Mahin's piece was one of the most concise and important articles on bullfighting I have seen in years. Ernest Hemingway arranged for me to travel with Antonio Ordez in 1961, and I spent several seasons, including 1970, with him as he fought all over Spain and France. Mr. Mahin's descriptions of Ord6fiez, as a man, as a torero, and of his latest season, were perfect. This is true of his summaries of the other significant toreros, especially of the charismatic El Cordobes, so different in style from the classicist Ordez.

title: How to Look Silly and Insult Your Host
description: IF everything went according to schedule (as almost nothing ever does in India), the Second TriennaleIndia closed on March 31 after a run of two months during which, so far as I was able to ascertain on the spot, it pleased only two peopleneither of them me. This international show, modeled after those of Venice and San Paulo, was a sorry affair, and the sorriest part of it, as well as the most pretentious and most expensive, was the American section, which was devoted to examples of the currently moribund minimalconceptual esthetic debacle. During a year when the Museum of Modern Art incurred its record deficit, its International Program, which was responsible for the American section, found notonly to transport the kinds of works of nonart that have been making people ask for their money back at the Guggenheim International, but also to transport artists and supervisors to work on the spot in New Delhi. I've no figure's on the cost, but a dollar ninetyeight would have been excessive expenditure for a show that managed to make more enemies for this country than any other single art event within my knowledge.

title: Gun Controls: The Gun Lobby Is Feeling No Pain
Espaliers Are Especially Decorative
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, the training of espaliers is easy. There's no reason why even the busiest gardener can't grow one, if he has a suitable spot.

title: Indiana Is First State to Enact Curb on Phosphate Detergents
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 10 (AP)Indiana has become the first state to ban nearly all phosphate detergents, which have been blamed by conservationists for the ecological death of some lakes and streams.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10Officials of the Bureau of Prisons in Washington professed today no knowledge of any activity by Hoffa other than his stated purpose of visiting his ailing wife.

title: Chile: Copper Is the Color of Allende's Mandate
description: SANTIAGO  If President Salvador Allende Gossens has his way. Chile's transition to socialism will be financed by the nationalization of copper, the country's principal economic asset. And the mines, smelters and sales organizations That translate copper reserves into export earnings for South America's first Mandstgoverned nation are owned, wholly or in part, by United States companies.

title: OutofState Student Quotas Being Set at Colleges
description: DETROIT, April 10  Some states, particularly in the Midwest, are making it tougher for outofstate students to enter their state university systems, which have traditionally served as a safety valve for the overcrowded colleges in the East.

title: Mrs. Percy Salisbury, 94; Mother of a Times Editor
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 {AP) Mrs. Percy Pritchard Salisbury, 94 years old, the mother of Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor at The New York Times, died today at a Minneapolis nursing home. She had lived In Minneapolis since the age of 3.

title: Test Finds 57c a Day Inadequate for Eating
description: LAS VEGAS, April 10 (UPI) They say poor people are fat. It's partly right because you have to eat so much starchy food, said the Rev. Herbert E. Osman today after eating 57 cents worth of food each day for a week.

title: For Women, a Decade Of Widening Horizons
description: WASHINGTON, April 10  After a decade of striking change, the American woman is now considerably more likely to attend college, work, live alone, marry late, be divorced or separated, and outlive her husband than she was at the start of the nineteensixties.

title: Books: Caveat Emptor
description: This can be described as a reachable book, physically and mentally. It's the kind of volume that a manufacturer or an advertising man could profitably keep near his desk for quick reference. Furthermore, legal tome though it is, the author makes the book perfectly understandable for the average reader.

title: 3 Homers by Stargell
description: ATLANTA, April 10 (UPI) Hal King singled up the middle with the bases loaded and no out in the bottom of the 12th inning to give the Atlanta Braves a 54 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, despite Willie Stargell's three home runs.

title: Matched sets
description: The cleancut sportswear that Americans have always worn so well  belted jackets, shirts, pullovers, slacks, knickers  is making a comeback. Both gals and guys are dropping the fringes and feathers and taking to a tailored look. Young couples still like to dress alike, but not in the old unisex way that was part male, part female. They've discovered that the classics are intrinsically asexual.

description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 10 (AP)  Penn State, Michigan State and Colorado State have accepted invitations to Tennessee's sixth annual Volunteer basketball classic next Dec.

description: LANSING, Mich., April 10 UPI)The Michigan Supreme Court has ruled that the city of Dearborn acted legally when it purchased an apartment building in Florida to house the city's elderly who could no longer tolerate Michigan winters.

title: BUCKS WILL RUN ON LAKERS TODAY
description: MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 10 (UPI)The Milwaukee Bucks go after victory No. 2 against the Los Angeles Lakers today and the key for the Bucks is to make sure they can run.

description: Raymond S. Harris, a screenwriter for four decades, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at the Mary Manning Walsh Home.

description: Charles R. Peters, owner of Plaza Photo Print, Inc., photostats, 8 West 56th Street, died yesterday in his home at 424 East 52d Street. His age was 70. Mr. Peters was a member of the New York Athletic Club.

description: Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, announced yesterday that he had introduced legislation in the House aimed at eliminating de facto segregation in educationr and housing.

title: HARVARD DEFEATS COLUMBIA IN ROWING
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10  Harvard's varsity lightweight crew gained the advantage in the first ten strokes and kept pulling away down the 2,000 meter course in an impressive sevenlength victory over Columbia today on the Charles River.
