description: Television

title: U.S. REPORTS RAID IN NORTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 11 (AP)  Two Air Force F4 fighterbombers attacked radarcontrolled antiaircraft guns inside North Vietnam and destroyed two of them in the 21st protective reaction strike over the north this year, the United States command announced today.

title: HARLEM ORCHESTRA PLAYS AT COLUMBIA
description: The Harlem Philharmonic Orchestra offered a nicely balanced program at Columbia's McMillin Theater Friday night. There was nothing shy or tentative about the performances, which were played with spirited vigor and commendable ensemble precision.

title: CLEAN HANDS AREN'T EVERYTHING (CONT.)
description: To THE EDITOR: Dr. William E. Roman, in his angry article, Wash Your Hands, Damn It! (March 7), invokes Pasteur, Koch and Lister, but they said little or nothing about hands carrying disease. Ignaz Semmelweiss and the senior Oliver Wendell Holmes did indeed tell us that hands carry disease, but they were the hands of doctors, not of children. Doctors are still incriminated in the spread of disease, especially staph infections in hospitals. The hands of children spread pinworm and polio, but the former cannot be controlled by handwashing, and the effect of modern hygienic practices on polio was only to delay the illness and generally to make it worse; control came via vaccination.

title: Musicals That Were Playful, Irresponsible and Blissfully Irrelevant
description: ITHINK somebody asked me the question. I was busy lighting Ruby Keeler's 37th cigarette (Miss Keeler smokes too much, winding herself not at all) and trying to hear, through the crosschatter of voices, Helen Gallagher's impassioned defense of everything from oldfashioned melody to the social principles of her mother, and I couldn't be sure. But since I was the only reviewer present, and in theory the theorist, the question was probably mine to answer. Leo Lerman, the grand panjandrum of Playbill, had gathered together a tableful of New York business executives to cross compliments and challenges with some of those responsible for No, No, Nanette, and one executive wanted to know if the astonishing new success of that 1925 musical wasn't merely a matter of nostalgia.

title: Hull Scores 2 Goals
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UPI)Bobby Hull scored two powerplay goals in the third period tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers and a 30 lead in their fourofsevengame Stanley Cup series.

title: RAISING THE DIFFICULT BABY
description: To THE EDITOR: I wish to express my appreciation to you and to Barbara W. Wyden for her article, The Difficult Baby Is Born That Way (March 21). Having worked for years with families with emotionally disturbed children, I have seen over and over again the heartbreak that parents, and especially mothers, experience when their children do not respond to them in a fairly normal, that is, affectionate and predictable fashion; and the guilt they feel for not loving their children as they believe they should.

title: Rolls of Nonpublic Schools Down 31,000 Pupils in Year
description: ALBANY, April 10 (UPI)Nonpublic school enrollment declined by 31,000 pupils last year, the State Education Department reported this week.

title: Laughing While We Face Our Prejudices
description: TACK GOULD'S recent Sunday review of All in the Family. was a most thoughtful piece and sufficiently positive to serve as an antidote to the negative opinion expressed by Stephanie Harrington. Well, almost.

title: Sacristan Gains Decision
description: MANILA, April 10 (AP)San Sacristan, a Philippine flyweight, scoring with one  two combinations to the head, gained a split decision over Harry Hayes of Australia in a 12round fight tonight. Sacristan weighed 113 pounds, Hayes, 115.

title: Good Guys and Bad Guys
description: WASHINGTON  The resolution that two lawyers here have submitted to the Fidelity Trend Fund, asking the fund to consider the social policies of corporations before it invests in their stocks, represents the first such effort  but clearly only the first  to be directed at institutional investors.

title: Miss Corrigan Wins 2 Finals In Collegiate Gymnastics
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 10 (UPI)Patti Corrigan Of Springfield (Mass.), Kathy Gleason of Buffalo State and Barbara Fleming of Fresno (Calif.) dominated the finals of the women's national intercollegiate gymnastics championships today.

title: TV USED TO FIGHT MT. VERNON CRIME
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 10Two remotecontrol television cameras that can photograph license plates two blocks away on a dark street were placed into operation here this week with all the ceremony usually reserved for political, inaugurations.

title: Out of the Blue
description: Support for an increase in airline fares came from an unusual quarter last week: the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company.

title: West Quintet Triumphs
description: HONOLULU, April 10 (UPI) A fastbreaking West basketball team beat the South, 12499, last night in the third annual Aloha Classic. The Midwest downed the East, 98.86, in the first game of the roundrobin tournament.

title: Green Tea Ice cream, Solid State Abacuses And Other Wonders Under the Rising Sun
Leland Hayward 190271
description: To THE EDITOR: THE fact that a superbly sophisticated Establishment producer like Leland Hayward presented Father Daniel Berrigan's play, The Trial of the Catonsville Nine, seems strange to most theater people, but not to those of us who knew that what both these men had in common was their desire and ability to celebrate life.

title: Dorothy Lodge Fiancee Of Charles Peabody Jr.
description: BEVERLY, Mass., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. George Cabot Lodge have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Meserve Lodge to Charles Augustus Peabody Jr., son of Mr. Peabody, of Hancock, N. H., and Mrs. Henry W. Reed of New York.

title: HOWARD A. CLARK
description: NORWALK, Conn., April 10 Howard Arthur Clark, retired executive of Standard Brands, Inc., New York, died Thursday at Stamford Hospital. His age was 75. He lived at 4 Bittersweet Trail, Rowayton.

title: Who's Inside the Dream Machine?
description: THE Great American Dream Machine has been called an electronic magazine. That label is a bit inadequate. It has been called a hodgepodge of the brilliant and the trite. That depends on the individual viewer. It has been called one of the most exciting and imaginative segments of television to come along this season. That's true.

title: BEYOND JAKARTA
description: To THE EDITOR: Jean Ogden Freseman's Central Java: Where Indonesia's Ancient Arts and Crafts Survive .. . (Travel section, March 21) is in my judgment one of the best and most comprehensive articles on travel in Java. I was born there and I have been to most of the places she mentioned. Java really begins just beyond Jakarta. How true! Though the island of Java is considered crowded by western standards, it is lush, dynamic, exciting, even sensuous. Tourists should keep uppermost in mind that Indonesia is much, much more than Jakarta. I also wish they could sample authentic Indonesian food and eclectic ChineseIndonesian dishes besides Chinese cooking. It is my sincere hope that Medan and the Minangkabau and Lake Toba areas in Sumatra will be opened up for tourism in the future.

title: Alcoholism: Challenge To the Theory That It's A Disease
description: Once again, city health officials propose to solve a huge health problem with a large, expensive program of medical treatment for those already sick. This time the problem is alcoholism and Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, wants to spend $10million a year in hospitals and clinics to try to wean 9,000 alcoholics off alcohol.

title: OVERPAYMENTS LAID TO ARMY ON LEAVES
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The General Accounting Office has said that the Army is overpaying servicemen almost $23million a year through errors in computing leave pay.

title: Art and Life In Bloomsbury
description: THE name of Dora Carrington  or simply Carrington, as she preferred to be knownis not one that looms very large in the history of modern British painting. The recently published Oxford Companion to Art, which in general gives the benefit of every doubt to British artists, does not even list her, and I cannot recall ever having read a single serious critical account of her painting. This last point is more noteworthy than it may sound, for Carrington was a member of the celebrated Bloomsbury circle of writers, artists andby no means leastart critics, who were not always averse to overestimating the accomplishments of their friends. But for this circle of literary intellectuals, whose principal luminaries were Virginia Woolf, Lytton Strachey, Roger Fry, Maynard Keynes, Clive Bell and E. M. Forster, the reigning genius painter was. Duncan Grant (who, of course, does make it into the Oxford Companion with a most

title: 1,700 GO TO FUNERAL OF SLAIN POLICEMAN
description: BLUE POINT, L.I., April 10 More than 1,700 uniformed policemen from Long Island, New York City, New Jersey and as far away as Buffalo attended a funeral service here this morning for Patrolman George Frees of the Suffolk County police, who was shot and killed last Tuesday while investigating a shooting in Wyandanch.

title: Four Photographs That Drove A Man to Crime

description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 10 (AP)Jack Lewis Jr. managed to take a threestroke lead in the $35,000 Magnolia Classic today despite a double bogey on the 18th hole.

title: OneYear Draft Law Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)Two Democratic Senators, Birch Bayh of Indiana and Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey, announced today that they would seek to have the Senate vote to extend the draft for only one year. The House has approved a twoyear extenson.

title: Armand Massard, 86, Dies; Olympic Committee Official
description: PARIS, April 10 (Reuters)Armand Massard, former first vice president of the International Olympic Committee and a 1920 fencing gold medalist, died yesterday. He was 86 years old.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Club Rugby

title: On Falling Roofs
description: To THE EDITOR: I have read It Happens, But Rarely [Feb. 28] about the collapse of buildings. This does happen more often than you know! Unfortunately, the news is not always published.

title: FANCIERS TO HEAR NUTRITION EXPERT
description: Dr. Ben E. Sheffy, Caspary Professor of Nutrition and assistant director of the Veterinary Virus Research Institute at Cornell, will be the speaker at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon at the McAlpin Hotel on Wednesday.

title: Keep It From Aging
description: A PROPERLY built house need never get really old or prematurely agedthat is, if it is reasonably well taken care of by its owner. A sensible program of preventive maintenance, coupled with prompt attention to minor breakdowns before they can cause Major problems, can keep any house young indefinitelyespecially if the homeowner also adds sensible improvements that update the house periodically.

title: Television:
description: If our freedom as a nation is to continue, then the guarantee of journalistic freedom must be maintained. That was the reaction of Vincent T. Wasilewski, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, to the latest salvo last week in the war between the Federal Government and the news media.

title: Christian Jerusalem Seems Resigned to Impotence and Uncertainty on Role in City
description: JERUSALEM, April 10  Outside the high wall along Saladin Street in East Jerusalem are the busy traffic and commerce of an Arab city. Within Is the air of an Oxford college as Anglican clerics in their black cassocks wander through the cloisters when the tower bells summon worshipers to matins.

title: Josh Gibson Was The Equal of Babe Ruth, But...
New Strain of Gonorrhea Aggravates Venereal Disease Epidemic on Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, April 10 The appearance of a new type of gonorrhea that is stubbornly resistant to conventional treatment has aggravated an already rampant epidemic of venereal disease in California, public health officials reported this week.

title: Mays Hits No.4 as Giants Win
description: ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP)Thirtynineyearold Willie Mays hammered his fourth home run in four games, sending the San Francisco Giants to a 64 triumph today and spoiling the St. Louis Cardinals National League home opener.

title: Paisley Leads Militants In Ulster Easter Parade
description: ARMAGH, Northern Ireland, April 10 (Reuters) More than 500 British soldiers were on hand as the Rev. Ian Paisley led 600 militant Protestants through Armagh tonight in the first of Northern Ireland's big Easter parades.

title: Nixon and War: End Is in Sight, He Says, but Critics Are Skeptical
Franconia, N. H.:
description: In New Hampshire, visitors, who arrived in a record 1,760,000 automobiles last year at Franconia Notch State Park spent an average of 10 minutes viewing, often through range finders, an unsculptured, natural outcropping known as The Old Man of the Mountain.

title: M.I.T. Outrows Yale, Trinity In ThreeRace Regatta
description: DERBY, Conn., April 10 Smoothstroking Massachusetts Institute of Technology, behind early, came on strongly in the last 150 meters to defeat Yale's host crew by 8 feet today in the varsity encounter of a threerace lightweight regatta on a frigid Housatonic River.

title: Elaine Mortola Will Be Bride
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 10Dr. Edward J. Mortola, president of Pace College, New York and Westchester, and Mrs. Mortola of New Rochelle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Hayes Mortola, to Edward J. Rabidoux 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rabidoux Jr. of Goshen and Brewster, Me.

title: Cougar II Wins $125,000 Coast Race Marred by Spill and Disqualification
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 10 (UPI) Chileanbred Cougar II posted a threelength victory today in the $125,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap on the turf course. The race was marred by a horse falling and the favored Fort Marcy being disqualified from second and placed last.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The least happy of the Knicks this season undoubtedly was Cazzie Russell. He broke a bone in his hand last November and spent two miserable months waiting for it to heal. For a man of his boundless energy and eagerness it was an agonizing vigil. Cazzie had been the sixth man of the Knicks, the supersub who led the turnaround assaults of a team deep in manpower.

title: Salminen Finishes First In Wellesley Road Race
description: WELLESLEY, April 10 Mass., (AP)Markku Salminen of Finland, tuning up for the Boston A.A. Marathon April 19, triumphed today in the second annual Wellesley road race.

title: Farmboy Comes Home
description: Joe Frazier, natty in a gray suit with soft blue stripes, modestly acknowledged the 30second ovation that greeted him in the packed hall. A heavyweight boxing champion of the world was used to ovations. But this one, last Wednesday, was different. For the 27yearold former farmboy from Beaufort, S.C., was addressing a joint session of the South Carolina Legislaturethe first black man since Reconstruction days to do so. With the American and Confederate flags as a backdrop, Mr. Frazier told the legislators: We must save our people, and when I say our people, I mean white and back. We need to quit thinking who's living next door, who's driving a big car, who's my little daughter going to play with, who is she going to sit next to in school. We don't have time for that.

title: Israel's Generation Gap
description: NO one in this town needs to be educated to the gold potential in a show related to the state of Israel. Years ago, Joshua Logan was beaten to the wirehe'd planned a musical, Blue Star"when Milk and Honey made it to the Martin Beck in 1961 and, following a lucrative stand there, toured happily for two years. A recent enterprise that set forth with banners high was the illfated musical, Ari, which Leon Uris based on his wildly successful novel Exodus. It failed only because of its deficiencies. Now comes word of a new musical venture loaded with hope. It is called To Live Another SummerTo PassAnother Winter and if that title seems tinged with a touch of poignance, it Is not inappropriate.

title: Bridge Hide a freak hand and enemy is ambushed
description: MOST bridge is played to some extent under time presure. Although the players are not strictly timed, as they are in chess, they have to be aware of the clock. In a rubber bridge game, prolonged thought will make the opponents restive if not rude. And slow player in a tournament will quickly get into trouble with the director for holding up the progress of other players.

title: The Bell Jar By Sylvia Math. 296 pp. New York: Harper &
description: The Bell Jar is a novel about the events of Sylvia Plath's 20th year: about how she tried to die, and how they stuck her together with glue. It is a fine novel, as bitter and remorseless, as her last poemsthe kind of book Salinger's Franny might have written about herself 10 years later, if she had spent those 10 years in Hell. It is very much a story of the fifties, but written in the early sixties, and now, after being effectively suppressed in this country for eight years, published in the seventies.

title: Wiggins Is Retiring June 30 As Harvard Vice President
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 (AP)L. Gard Wiggins, administrative vice president of Harvard University since 1960, will retire June 30, coincident with the retirement of Nathan M. Pusey, the university's president.

title: Margaret Adams Wed To David D. Fleming
description: WOOSTER, Ohio, April 10 Miss Margaret Ellen Adams and David Daniel Fleming, graduates of the College of Wooster, were married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Oliver R. Slang.

title: SLASH AIR FARES
description: To THE EDITOR: I agree wholeheartedly with the letter about lowcost flights from Bruce Ellison and headed Plea for Bargains (Travel section, March 21). The airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Board and the International Air Transport Association should realize once and for all that it is better to sell 1,000 tickets for $125 each for a round trip to London than 30 tickets at $400 each and fly the planes half empty.

title: After the Unspeakable, What?
description: WASHINGTON, April 10As the news spread through Washington that Representative Hale Boggs, Democratic leader of the House, had accused the F.B.I. of tapping Congressmen's telephones and proposed the retirement of J. Edgar Hoover as director of the F.B.I., strange things began to happen.

title: YOUTHS COUNSEL TROUBLED PEERS
description: NEW HAVEN, April 10  For the last 19 months an organization called Number Nine  which took its name from the Beatles song Revolution Number Nine  has been serving as a friend and big brother to young people here.

title: Mrs. King Forced to Default To Miss Evert in Semifinals
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 10 (AP)Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King, battled to a 67, 63 standoff by 16yearold Chris Evert, developed leg cramps and defaulted in the semifinals of the $15,000 women's professional Masters tennis tournament today.

title: Brewers Top Angels, 43
description: MILWAUKEE, April 10 (AP) Mel Queen walked Roberto Pena with the bases loaded and two out in the eighth inning today, forcing in the run that gave the Milwaukee Brewers a 43 victory over the California Angels.

title: TWINS TURN BACK WHITE SOX BY 53 Oliva and Powell, a Rookie, Hit Homers for Victors
description: CHICAGO, April 10 (UPI)  Tony Oliva and Paul Powell slammed home runs today that led the Minnesota Twins to a 53 victory over the Chicago White Sox, who took their. first loss after three victories.

title: Railpax Plans Innovations To Win Back Passengers
description: WASHINGTON, April 9  The National Railroad Passenger Corporation plans to offer jazz, movies and bargain youth fares, and perhaps beauty salons, barber shops and boutiques in hopes of persuading America to ride the train again.

title: Marine Gets 20Year Term In Death in Racial Brawl
description: NAHA, Okinawa, April 10 (UPI) A United States private was found guilty of unpremeditated murder today in the death of another marine in a racial dispute last fall at a firing range near Mount Fuji in Japan.

title: OKKER, NASTASE GAIN TENNIS FINAL
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 10 (UPI)Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Ilie Nastase of Rumania reached the final of the men's singles in the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today.

title: 3 SENATORS PRESS GIRLPAGE DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 Three Senators who have been thwarted in their efforts to appoint the Senate's first girl pages have started a new maneuver to win approval of the appointments.

title: Long Island Club Defeats Cornell in Lacrosse, 134
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 10 The undefeated Long Island Athletic Club's lacrosse team beat Cornell here today, 134, for its sixth victory in a row.

title: J. L. Ellenberg to Marry Joan Hellenbein
description: HARRISON, N. Y., April 10The engagement of Miss Joan Frances Helfenbein to James Louis Ellenberg, son of Mrs. Louis Ellenberg of New York and the late Mr. Ellenberg, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Helfenbein of Harrison.

title: U.S. Pilots Find Enemy Traffic Moving Freely on Trail in Laos
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, April 7American fighter and observation pilots who fly regularly over the Ho Chi Minh Trail report that traffic is moving freely along the enemy supply network now that the South Vietnamese have wound up their operation in Laos.

title: Better with bread
description: A fresh fruit salad arranged on crisp, curlyleaf lettuce, a salad Nicoise with its anchovies, black olives and egg slices, or any main dish salad, as a matter of fact, seems to taste better when accompanied by homemade bread. The quick breads given on these pages are more than salad accompaniments. The masa harina shells are great with chili and soups, and the sweet walnut bread makes a good breakfast coffeecake.

title: Miss Lovelock Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Miss Janet Evelyn Lovelock, senior at Cornell University, to Donald Ray Baer, who is studying for a doctorate in physics there, has been announced by Mrs. Lucien R. Tharaud of New York, mother of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Baer of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: Saints Sign 2 Free Agents
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (AP)The New Orleans Saints of the National Football League today signed a tackle, Bill Trout of Miami of Florida, and a cornerback, Reynaud Moore of the University of California, Los Angeles, to 1971 contracts Both are free agents.

title: SENATE PANEL ASKS DOCUMENTS ON F.B.I.
Colts WellStocked at Quarterback
description: John Unitas, who tore the Achilles tendon in his right foot while playing paddle ball with Tom Matte, expects to be in a cast for six weeks. Seven weeks after that training camp will open and the availability of Unitas, the 38yearold star quarterback of the Baltimore Colts, can be determined for the coming season. Surgery was performed Wednesday to repair the separatwo in the tendon two inches above the right heel. The surgery was said to be successful but the definitive proof must wait until training camp opens. Generally this is a slow healing injury.

title: An Egg At Easter
description: Book titles that claim too much are all too familiar. Those that claim too little are rare, and of these Venetia Newell's An Egg at Easter is perhaps rarest of all. The Easter egg is here, all right, in its many forms and legends; but Easter eggs are only a fraction of what Mrs. Newall gives us. A better title would have been The Egg Through the Ages or, simply, Egg Power.

title: The Couple
description: To the Editor: As a constant reader, I deplore your coverage of The Couple, a report by Mr. and Mrs. K. on their sex education. Valid points can be raised for and against this report. Your reviewers (Nora Ephron and Dan Greenburg, another husband  wife writing team) chose to ignore the book entirely. Instead, they reviewed its authors  in my opinion, most unflatteringly and most unfairly. So unfairly, in fact, I can't help wondering if you're about to change to a 1971 version of Joe Miller's Joke Book.

title: Burkes Have Daughter
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 10 A daughter was born April 2 at Holy Name Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. Philip John Burke. Mrs. Burke is the former Miss Laura Ganteaume, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ganteaume of Paramus. The child, who has been named Carolyn Elaine, is the granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Burke of Teaneck. The child's father works In the public relations field.

title: The Almost Year
description: What can a wellintentioned upper middle class white family do to calm the frustrations, cool the anger, assuage the rage of a black ghetto child who comes to live with them? Commit suicide, late Sixties militants might suggest. From a black point of view there are indeed few options. The author of The Almost Year, in a book that is remarkably free of cant, stereotypes, dj. vu and white liberal guiltridden sermonizing, seeks to find a way in which black abused and poor and elite privileged and rich can meet and exchange some warmth of themselves. For warmth, perhaps, is all that either side has to give.

title: Marion P. Jones Fiancee Of Kingsland A. Percival
description: NEW LEBANON, N.Y., April 10  Miss Marion Phelps Jones of New York plans to be married in early August to Kingsland A. Percival, who is descended from Ambrose C. Kingsland, Mayor of New York from 1851 to 1853.

title: The People and the Priests
description: RIO DE JANEIROPossibly the most significant movement in South. America today is the development of a Roman Catholic Church opposition to dictatorial governments and human suffering, a development in which priests, bishops and members of religious orders are playing an active role.

title: PHIL WILSON PLAYS JAZZ RECITAL HERE
description: Phil Wilson, a trombonist who was a bright star In Woody Herman's orchestra in the early 1960's, made a rare appearance in New York Friday afternoon at La Martinique, the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street. Mr. Wilson, who has been on the faculty of the Berklee College of Music in Boston since 1965, was teamed with Clark Terry, the trumpeter and flugelhornist, at the weekly jazz session presented by Jazz Adventures.

title: Protest by Peking
description: TOKYO, Sunday, April 11 (AP)Communist China, backing the Pakistani Government's efforts in East Pakistan, accused India, the United States and the Soviet Union today of interfering in the internal affairs of Pakistan.

title: Even El Cordobes Has
description: To THE EDITOR: I take exception to Timothy Mahin's remarks on El Cordobds in There Are Roughly Two Kinds of Bullfighters (Travel section, March 21). I am an aficionada. Therefore, on my honeymoon to Spain and Portugal, I dragged my nonaficionado husband to several corridas. We were unfortunate one sunny Sunday afternoon in Palma to see the great El Cordobds. After making one or two perfunctory passes he proceeded to butcher the poor beast. The crowd stamped their feet, clapped their hands, hooted, booed. El Cordobes's colleagues came into the ring, pulled him out and put the bull mercifully (as possible at that point) out of his suffering. El Cordobs was prohibited from reappearing that afternoon. How many more corridas he has ruined for the tourists I don't know. I do know that this was not the first (and I am positive, not the last) in which he has upheld my husband's views on bullfightingthat it can be brutal, bloody and far from ceremonious or brave. But I am still an aficionada.

title: F.C.C.Warning on Drug Lyrics Brings Sharp Reaction in Broadcast Industry
description: When Steve Leon, a disk jockey at station WDASFM in Philadelphia, heard that the Federal Communications Commission had issued a warning about broadcasting song lyrics that might promote drug use, he promptly pulled several drugoriented records from the station files and started playing them.

title: Unwed Mother's Key Decision: To Give Up or Keep Her Child
description: Should I keep the baby or put it up for adoption? That is the fundamental  and often agonizing  question that confronts unmarried women who have decided against abortion and are about to become mothers.

title: Fighting the System in the MaleDominated Field of Architecture
description: How much is tradition and how much Is biology, I don't know, but so far we just don't have great women architects, said Marcel Breuer, the last of the pioneers who helped shape 20thcentury architecture into an international style.

title: Chapel Street Sets Record In Middleburg Hunt Race
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 10) (AP)Rokeby Stables unbeaten Chapel Street made it four victories today with a recordbreaking effort in the Middleburg Hunt Cup race.

title: Unfixed Rates
description: The name of the game at the New York Stock Exchange remained the sameMaking Moneybut the rules changed drastically last Monday.

title: Student Trustee at College
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 10 (AP)Trustees of Springfield College have approved a proposal permitting a student to sit as a member of the board. They will select one of three nominees next month.

title: Mrs. Trimble Is Remarried
description: STRATTON MOUNTAIN, Vt., April 10  Mrs. Diana Neill Trimble was married here this afternoon to Henry W. Beardsley, senior vice presidentmarketing for the InterContinental Hotels Corporation. The Rev. John Bryden performed the Presbyterian ceremony in the Chapel of the Snows at this ski resort, where the bride and bridegroom both own property.

title: Army's Eleven Seeks an A for Attitude
description: John Roth Is Army's football captain for this year and a man with a mission. It isn't impossible, either, according to the senior or first classman, who is one of the East's best defensive ends.

title: Bay of Pigs Unites Cuban Exile Group
description: MIAMI, April 10 (AP)Juan Jose Peruyero sat in his dusty, cluttered office in the rundown section of Miami where he operates an auto body shop. He reminisced and he looked ahead.

title: A Day in the Life of One Husbandless Working Mother  It's No Picnic
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP)Shannon? Shannon? Come on, now, honey. It's time to get up.

title: L.I.R. TO EVALUATE CARS FOR SMOKING
description: The Long Island Railroad is considering experimentally reducing the number of smoking cars on sonic of its trains.

title: Fish to Lead Harvard Team
description: Dave Fish of Waban, Mass., has been elected captain of the 197172 Harvard varsity racquets team.

title: U. S. Officials View Chinese Action as a Move to Ease Isolation
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 United States officials tended today to regard Communist China's approval for the entry of three American newsmen into its territory as a further sign that China is moving cautiously to discard its mantle of selfisolation.

title: Raja Baba Triumphs by Length in $23,600 Francis Scott Key Stakes at Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., April 10 (AP) Raja Baba, a son of Bold Ruler, outraced five other 3yearolds today and won the $23,600 Francis Scott Key Stakes at Bowie Race Course.

title: Louise D. Talmage to Wed June 5
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 10Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen Talmage of New Canaan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Ditmas Talmage, to Thomas William Balderston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Eastburn Balderston of Philadelphia.

title: Mm, Mm, Goodand Conservative
description: CAMDEN, N. J.The Campbell Soup Company discovered 74 years ago that housewives, if given a choice, would flock to the local general store and pay 10 cents for a can of condensed soup, rather than spend hours peeling vegetables and bending over a steaming soup kettle.

title: 5 POLITICAL FUNDS DON'T REPORT AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Four major defense contractors and an oil company have executive political funds that pass out campaign donations to Senators and Representatives but fail to report them.

title: Enemy Airs Voices of Saigon P.O.W.'s
FASCINATING
description: It is a shame that the recent Roger Corman film festival at the Kips Bay Theater did not receive more than a fleeting reference in The Times. Though Corman is not a great director, he has consistently risen above his material and low budgets to create highly competent

title: Small Delights in a Queens Park
We Are All Bengalis
description: CALCUTTA  Crossing the border into Bangla DeshBengal Nation, as most LastPakistanis now call their region you feel you're seeing something filmed a long time ago by some newsreel pioneer. The ancient Enfield and Garand rifles in the hands of the overnight revolutionaries, the refugeeladen carts, the bodies lying unnoticed by the roadsideall this could be out of the Spanish Civil War or the Chinese revolution.

title: The Beach at Coney: Still a Fun Place to Go
description: For many visitors and local businessmen the principal asset and attraction of Coney Island in Brooklyn is not the carnival atmosphere of the amusement area but the sandy strip of beach that stretches along the edge of the Atlantic Ocean from Eighth Street to 37th Street.

title: Soccer and Stability
description: For a short period four years ago, there was a professional soccer franchise in virtually every major city in the United States, and New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston had two each.

title: Jane F. Seward to Marry May 30
description: MEMPHIS, April 10Miss Jane Fleming Seward and David Abbott Schneiderman plan to be married here on May 30 at the Schaffer Memorial Chapel.

title: Inflation Battle: Which Strategy?
description: The capitalist System is in deep trouble if inflation becomes an everpresent feature of the economy, topped by unacceptable levels of employment.

title: A Fire Didn't Stop It
description: THERE will be several unusual features about Filene Center, which opens at Wolf Trap Farm Park, Vienna, Va., on July 1. It will give the Washington, D. C., area its first stage in many years able to accommodate fullscale operatic productions. (The capital will get a second with the inauguration of Kennedy Center on Sept. 9.) It may also be the first American summer music festival with such facilities. The Santa Fe Opera built a beautiful theater for its own purposes, but the big sheds where the major symphonies operate in the summer can present nothing more complicated than ballet.

title: Massachusetts Schools Get $1.4Million in Health Funds
description: BOSTON, April 10 (AP)  Grants totaling $1.4million to eight health education schools in Massachusetts to help expand enrollments have been announced by the National Institute of Health.

title: 20 Hurt and 72 Homeless After Fire on Staten Island
description: A fivealarm fire spread through a complex of sixstory apartment houses at 80 St. Marks Place in the New Brighton section of Staten Island yesterday afternoon, injuring 20 firemen and leaving 72 persons homeless.

title: Church DrugTreatment Center In Manhasset Upheld by Court
description: MINEOLA L. I., April 10 The State Supreme Court ruled here this week that the operation of a drugtreatment center in the Christ Episcopal Church parish house in Manhasset was a proper religious use.

title: Soviet Reported Sending Advanced Jets to U.A.R.
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 The Soviet Union has airlifted into the United Arab Republic a small number of advanced jet fighter planes capable of outperforming any other fighter in the world, including the Americanmade F4 Phantom jets flown by Israel, according to Administration officials.

title: WALTER J. HOLLANDS
description: HORNELL, N. Y., April 10Walter J. Hollands, president of the Tuttle and Rockwell department store, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: A U.S. Irony
description: America is the envy and the aspiration of the world, but there are those who maintain our economic system is not the best, and ask is there not a better way. Sonic who question our society and its achivements are young. Some are wellintentioned. Some are sincere.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
description: Law

title: 10 GIRLS QUALIFY FOR TRACK TRIALS
description: NASHVILLE, AprII 10 (AP) Ten women track standouts, including a fourtime Olympic participant, Willye White, qualified today for the Pan American trials in the PanAmerican development meet here.

title: A Dollar Surfeit Abroad
description: PARIS  The big dollar holders of the world are getting restless, but they seem prepared to play along with the United States for a while longer. They really don't have much choice.

title: Pope Opens Easter Vigil At St. Peter's Basilica
description: ROME, April 10  Pope Paul VI presided at Easter vigil rites in St. Peter's Basilica tonight.

title: Rhode Island Crew Wins
description: SOUTH KINGSTON, R. I., April 10 (AP)The University of Rhode Island crew defeated Assumption by more than three lengths today in a 2,000meter race on the Narrow River. The victors were timed in 6 minutes 45 seconds and Assumpetion in 7:05.

title: ROCK GROUP RACKS MANN, JAZZ FLUTIST
description: Herbie Mann, the jazz flutist, has at times been backed by a jazz sextet, a Latin group, a 23piece orchestra, a bagpipe, and an audience full of whistles. Now he is appearing with a rock band.

title: Eisenhower's Widow Joins The Nixons at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., April 10 (UPI)Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower joined President Nixon and his family for a rare family reunion today, and the group made tentative plans to attend church together on Easter Sunday.

title: $36Billion Tax Break
description: Changed depreciation rules proposed by the Administration would represent a huge tax gift to business. By the Treasury's own estimate, the liberalized writeoff of capital assets, coupled with special allowances for repair, maintenance, rehabilitation, and improvement of eligible property, would result in a revenue loss of $3 billion in fiscal 1972 alone. Between now and fiscal 1980, the total tax break to business would amount to an estimated $36 billion.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Thanks, fellas, for telling us that some babies are just born that way. Fifteen yearsago we mothers were blamed for everything from schizophrenia to diaper rash. I remember one case of a baby with cancer of the hip who screamed every time she was diapered. Until it was diagnosed, the mother was told it was her insecure attitude which upset the baby. Who wouldn't be insecure with a baby who screamed every time you went near her!

title: Metropolitan Chess League Games
description: STAMPING grounds for competitive chess in metropolitan chess circles is the 48yearold Commercial Chess of New York, boasting 39 fourman teams of five divisions, based on strength.

title: BARBARISM ON TV
description: To THE EDITOR: Having spoken so plainly and forcibly in an editorial for an end to prizefighting exhibitions, The Times surely would not favor opening our gates to that other barbarous sport, the bullfight. Indeed, for various reasons, the bullfight is the more savage and brutalizing. Therefore, was disturbed to find the Travel section affording publicity in a caption with its article on bullfighters to the closedcircuit television show through which the promoters of the recent Fight of the Century are to introduce bullfighting into the United States.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: It was unfair to our previous landlord to list our address in Judy Klemesrud's article as 122 East 42d Street, from which we moved two and a half years ago. We are at 135 West 41st Street, but the picketing was at the entrance to the same building on 42d Street, obviously to attract more attention.

title: What Kind of Lieder Singing Do You Like?
Correct Care and Feeding Of Woody Ornamentals
description: TREES and shrubs constitute a vital part of our total environment. They contribute more than beauty to our world; life itself depends on them. The proper care of trees and shrubs  especially correct fertilizer useis an investment in a better landscape and a better environment.

title: MEDICAID CUT HITS AT CITY HOSPITALS
description: City officials estimated yesterday that the 18 municipal hospitals, already up against a deficit, face $15million to $35million of extra annual costs by having to take over poor patients eliminated from Medicaid benefits by new state legislation.

title: Green Light Weighed For Women at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, April 10 (UPI)For the first time in 20 years, women may again be allowed to drive in the Le Mans 24hour race, motor racing sources said today.

title: Squires Win, 118114, and Eliminate Nets From A.B.A. Playoffs, 4 Games to 2
description: The Nets' best season in the fouryearold American Basketball Association came to an end at the Felt Forum last night when the Virginia Squires staged a strong comeback to beat New York, 118114, and win their Eastern Division semifinal playoff.

title: TENNIS STAR TO SEEK FUNDS FOR THE POOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)  Arthur Ashe has volunteered to use his contacts in the tennis world to try help raise the $500,000 needed for a student project to give medical care to the poor in Mississippi's Quitman County.

title: Hempstead Official Seeks to Stimulate Recycling of Paper
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 10,  In an attempt to stimulate the market for recycled paper, Francis T. Purcell, Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor, announced a plan this week that would create a demand for recycled paper and paper products on the state, county and local level.

title: Diana
description: Four days after the townhouse explosion on West 11th Street last March, the torn, decapitated torso of Diana Oughton was pulled from the wreckage. Hers was, in fact, the second of three bodies found in the debris, in the rubble of what had been, we were to learn, a Weatherman bomb factory. Identification of the body remained a mystery for a full week while other aspects of the bizarre story unfolded. Two women who staggered away from the blast promptly disappeared, into an underground of apparently real dimensions. One of them was the daughter of the townhouse owner who had been vacationing in the Caribbean.

title: Hans Hirschfeld, 76, Dead; ExWest Berlin Press Chief

True, the savings offered are attractive; the sideeffects, however, are not worth it.

In viewing it as the strongest statement of the case for women's liberation and an uncovering of the male need for women's liberation, Miss Friedan failed to see the masculine point of view in what was obviously a man's world for directoractor John Cassavetes.

title: All together now.
description: Environmental design is the hot news. In simplest terms, it means total designarchitecture, furnishings, lighting, art and even plants are part of an overall look (An older generation might ask, What's so new about that? And the answer is that the concept is new in that individual lamps and pieces of furniture have been discarded. Everything is builtin and thus influences the shape of the interior space. It's a little like living in a hollow sculpture.) In remodeling this large cooperative for a young couple and their two children, architects Mayers and Schiff transformed a 70yearold apartment into a truly 20thcentury environment. To make the most of a view across Central Park, they took out the walls of three small rooms to make one impressive room with an expanse of windows. Because the new space needed furnishings of similar scale, the architects designed a 40footlong table that is not just for dining (above). It serves a variety of functions, from solitary lounging to largescale entertaining. The lighting was designed to dim, highlight or alter the individual or collective mood. Streaks of neon tubing in hot pink and chrome yellow curve and angle their way across the ceiling to add drama.

description: Movie Mailbag

title: The Beekeeper

title: Foreign Notes
description: A woman is France who undergoes an abortion, or even makes the attempt, is liable to six months to two years in prison. Despite the heavy penalty, it is estimated that from 250,000 to perhaps a million abortions are performed in France each year. In addition, welltodo women can go to Britain or Switzerland for legal abortions, thereby avoiding the dangers of illicit operations that kill several hundred women a year in France.

description: CHICAGOTen years ago, a colorful, rotund and openly venal North Side saloon keeper, ward healer and alderman named Paddy Bauler made what has become the most frequently quoted remark in local politics: Chicago ain't ready for reform.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE glaring paradoxes with which the international travel industry has saddled itself while becoming the world's largest single industry shone more glaringly than usual a few days ago as two European groups with seemingly similar but often divergent purposes met here in America.

title: L. B. J. Library Near Completion
Joseph Conrad Never Jumped
description: Nearly always at the end of his tether, Conrad brought to the art of novel writing a gloomy dedication for which it would be hard to find a parallel even in Flaubert, who had his amusements. Now and again a book came easily  The Secret Agent, for example; and writing Chance, in the flush of longdelayed popular success, he described himself as pelting along. But the writing of Nostromo gives a better picture of his working style: he finished it in a 36hour stint interrupted only by the necessity of having a tooth extracted (It broke!), and experienced only exhaustion, no elation, no relief, even. The book cost him nearly two years, punctuated by his own illnesses, the crippling of his wife, the failure of his bank, and the constant professional attentions of Ford Madox Ford, then called Hueffer, who actually seems to have written parts of it. When he emerged from his study he observed that his children had grown considerably in the interval. Man is a worker, or he is nothing: this was his belief, pronounced in an England that was already forgetting Carlyle.

title: Text of Gibson's Letter Asking End to Newark School Strike
description: NEWARK, April 10Following is the text of a letter sent by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to the Board of Education and the striking Newark Teachers Union:

title: The Conformist: Freud vs. Marx?
description: MOVIES may be the universal language, but they often lose more than Verbal nuances in translation. How can Americans make sense of the crazy, convoluted new political movies from Italy? It's easy to recognize the same contradictions and confusions in Pasolini's Teorema, Visconti's The Damned, Petri's Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion, and now Bernardo Bertolucci's The Conformist without understanding exactly why they're so confused or what they think they're saying.

description: Queens, the city's largest borough in terms of area, is also the city's most nondescript.

title: Is Women's Lib Coming to the Philharmonic?
description: AFEW months ago, Zubin Mehta made some remarks in these pages that might qualify him, in the eyes of Women Libbers, as the Male Chauvinist Musician Pig of the Year. I just dont think women should be in an orchestra, said the handsome Mehta, whose Los Angeles Philharmonic has 16 women members. They become men. Men treat them as equals; they even change their pants in front of them. I think it's terrible!

title: Clare Boothe Luce
description: You are a young, beautiful woman, Pearl Harbor was only yesterday, you have spent several months poking about disconsolate Allied fronts in Asia and the midEast, you have written a long analysis, cruelly objective, infinitely embarrassing to the Allies, and correspondingly useful to the Axis powers, and then, on the last leg of your journey, a British customs officer at Trinidad insists on examining your papers. He discovers the dynamite, calls in British security which packs you off under house arrest. What do you do?

title: Coast Desert a Vast, Littered Playground for Millions
Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: As a mother and a psychologist, and as someone deeply concerned over the plight of infants, I was appalled by the suggestions made in handling the difficult baby. Dr. Alexander Thomas is quoted as saying, . . . They [the parents] must learn to grit their teeth and sweat it out. They must learn it is wrong to do something, anything, to stop the crying. What sort of an inhumane attitude is being advised here? After all, crying is the only language the baby knows, and it has long been known that if he cries in vain or is not responded to, he will surely learn not to cry, but it will also be detrimental to his emotional development.

title: A Tribute to SaintGaudens

The Irish  born artist is best known to numismatists for his beautiful designs on United States coinage, especially the $20 and $10 gold pieces, minted from 1907 through 1933.

He won $5,102 today at the Louisville Downs harness racing track on the Big L, a form of multiple wagering where he picked the winplace combination in two consecutive races. He did the same thing March 30, winning $4,125.90 for a $9,227.90 total.

John Leonard, for example, commented that There hasn't been another American writer of Joan Didion's quality since Nathanael West. Movie people were quick to appreciate the merits of Miss Didion's writing, too. Perhaps nobody was more appreciative than Frank Perry, who will direct and coproduce a film of the hook with Dominick Dunne, starting this summer in Hollywood. Dunne's brother, John Gregory Dunne, is now at work on the screenplay with his wife, who Just happens to be young lady by the name of Joan Didion.

title: Today's Series LineUp: Babes and Baer . . .
description: SERIAL art or serial imagery is not a new development on the contemporary art scene; It has been prominent since at least the early sixties. It is a form of art based on series production  sets of works in which identical or nearly identical forms and formats are used from one painting or sculpture to the next. Generally speaking, the series concept replaces the notion of the single, selfcontained work of art. In its place, it substitutes a system of works, comprised of anywhere from two or three units to a dozen, intended to be viewed as an extended whole with the sum greater than any of its parts.

title: PRO ARTE MORALE OFFERS PASSION

In the last few years, it has offered some of the finest performances of major choral works we have had, and Its presentation of Bach's St. Matthew Passion at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night may well have been its most extraordinary achievement to date.

The opera was immediately labelled relevant, blasphemous, brilliant, worthless, incoherent, mature, and witless by dozens of clergymen and critics all talking at once. description: BUENOS AIRESWhen the police raided Salvador Batista's travel agency in a busy downtown street here last week, they found him photographing dollar checks he had cashed illegally and was planning to mail to a New York bank.

title: NEW POLICE ROLE IS URGED IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, April 10 A major reorganization of Miami's Police Department, with an emphasis on the social functions of the police force, has been proposed by Police Chief Bernard L. Garmire.

title: ARE LESBIANS SICK?
description: To THE EDITOR: Despite her fairness, Judy Klemesrud still manages to imply that lesbians are sick (The Disciples of Sappho, Updated. March 28). She tells her readers that the medical profession still largely maintains the sick theory regarding homosexuality but that, of course, depends on what members of the medical profession one talks to.

title: Godfrey Shares Golf Lead
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 10 (UPI)Walter Godfrey of New Zealand set a course record with a fiveunderpar 67 today to share the thirdround lead with Chang Chung Fa of Nationalist China at 214 in the China open golf tournament. Chang shot a 70.

title: Isaac Overtakes Pearson And Wins Greenville 200
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., April 10 (AP)  Bobby Isaac roared past David Pearson, the pole winner, on the 20th lap of the Greenville 200 stock car race today and left the field behind him for the remaining 180 laps.

title: South Africa
description: To the Financial Editor: The credentials used by Ulric Haynes Jr. (Point of View, March 28) are not the ones I or any other black person in America today would use to attack a sincere and true effort to relieve the suffering of black and nonwhite people in South Africa.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: Drama Mailbag:

title: MAXIMILIAN A. ROSE
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 10Maximilian A. Rose, an artist and concert violinist, died yesterday at his home, 3 Windermere Road at the age of 70. His studio was at 19 West 73d Street in New York.

title: HOUSING BUILDERS TELL CITY TO PAY
description: Construction subcontractors warned last week that unless the city began paying the $10million they contend it owes them for completed housing projects they would refrain from bidding on future con. struction.

title: North Vietnamese Elect A New 420Seat Assembly
description: HONG KONG, Monday, April 12 (Reuters)  North Vietnamese citizens voted yesterday in their first general elections since 1964.

title: A Greeting From Mao
description: PEKING, April 11 (AP)Entering China from Hong Kong this morning, we left a world of purple morning glories for one of lichee trees, banana groves and rice terraces.

title: Richey Captures Final
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 11 (AP)Cliff Richey, the nation's No. 1ranked player, defeated Vladimir Zednik of Czechoslovakia, 61, 63, in the final of an international tennis tournament yesterday.

title: BRAZIL ACCEPTS JOINT FINANCING
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The United States will participate in the financing of a huge steel mill expansion project in a fashion that preserves Brazil's strong desire for competitive international bidding.

title: Auto Racing Foundation Honors Hulman, Radosta
description: Anton (Tony) Hillman, president of Indianapolis Motor Speedway, has been designated Auto Racing's Man of the Year by the Auto Racing Fraternity Foundation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY STRATEGY OF CANADA DRAWN
description: TORONTO, April 11  Jack Austin, the Canadian Government's chief adviser on energy matters, has outlined a development strategy that ties Canada's enormous untapped oil and gas reserves to America's growing appetite for these basic industrial and household fuels.

title: Drought and Dust Storms Ravaging Much of Texas
description: ABILENE, Tex., April 11 The worst drought and dust conditions in 15 years have struck Texas, stirring memories of the early nineteenthirties, when dust storms drove many Texans and Oklahomans from the Southwest.

title: Producers Say Steel Output Is Nearing Capacity
description: PITTSBURGH, April 11Schedules of steel mills were full last week but not overloaded. With raw steel output at the record rate of more than 153 million tons annually, supply was still on a fairly comfortable basis.

title: Baby Dies in Fire in Harlem
description: An eightmonthold boy, Oswaldo Cueves Jr., died yesterday in an earlymorning twoalarm fire in a topfloor apartment of a building at 211 West 108th, Street in Harlem. The baby was being cared for by an aunt, Mrs. Magly Cueves, who was able to lead two older children to safety, the police said.

title: Faculty on Shakespeare
description: Scholars from England, Poland, Germany and Canada have joined the faculty of the Shakespeare Institute to teach at the sixth annual summer program at the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut, sponsored by the American Shakespeare Festival Theater and the university. They are an Kott, Polish drama critic; Clifford Leach, professor of English, University of Toronto; Terence Hawkes of the University of Cardiff, and Ernest Srhanzer, professor of English literature at the University of Munich.

title: Brezhnev's Future Priorities
description: MOSCOW, April 11.  The 24th Congress of the Soviet Communist party has ended with Leonid I. Brezhnev apparently more secure than ever as head of the country's political machinery, and his middleoftheroad program affirmed as the law of the land. Mr. Brezhnev's essentially consen

title: TV: The Renaissance Life of Bernard Berenson
description: Television viewers already have had the pleasure of Sir Kenneth Clark's Civilisation: A Personal View, and will have it again next fall when the 13part series is repeated by the Public Broadcasting Service. Tonight, meanwhile, they can have the added pleasure of A Renaissance Life: A Personal View of Bernard Berenson by Kenneth Clark, which will be transmitted nationally by P.B.S. and willbe shown on New York's Channel 13 at 9 P.M.

title: Progress in Argentina
description: In less than two weeks as President, Gen. Alejandro Agustin Lanusse has given impressive evidence that he determined to return Argentina to democratic constitutional government. He has now promised that the armed forces will hand over power to an elected government within three years. If he keeps that pledge the consequences will be felt well beyond Argentina's borders.

title: Dole Sees Peril for Nixon If War Does Not Slacken
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)Robert J. Dole, the Republican National Chairman, said today that if the Vietnam war was still going on at the present level next year, President Nixon would have trouble winning reelection.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 11 (AP)  An army spokesman said that Palestinian guerrillas attacked today from Syria sand tried to overrun the village of Turra, in the north, but were driven back.

title: 10 British Soldiers Hurt in Riot After Ulster Parades Mark 16 Uprising
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 11Ten British soldiers were injured in Londonderry today in rioting after two republican parades commemorating the 1916 Easter rebellion against the British in Dublin.

title: Powell Resigns as Pastor Of Church After 34 Years
description: The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, pastor of the Absyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem since 1937, when he succeeded his father, announced his resignation yesterday during an 11 A.M. Easter service.

title: RICHARD FREDRICKS IS RENATO IN BALLO
description: Richard Fredricks, one of the New York City Opera's superior baritones, came into a new role Saturday night when he appeared as Renato in the company's performance of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera at the New York State Theater.

title: F.B.I. SAID TO CHECK WAR FOE'S DAUGHTER
description: BOSTON, April 11 (UPI)A document stolen from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's office in Media, Pa., disclosed that the agency looked into the background of the daughter of a member of Congress, according to The BoSton Globe.

title: SOVIET DROPS PUN FOR 2 LARGE DAMS
description: MOSCOW, April 11  The Soviet Union disclosed today that it was dropping some costly projects,. including two big power dams, from its new fiveyear plan while adding other undertakings benefiting the consumer.

title: MANZIE I. JOHNSON
description: Manzie T. Johnson, a jazz, drummer with many of the great figures of his epoch, died Friday in Veterans Hospital, the he Bronx. after a short illness. He was 64 years old and lived, at 977 Anderson Avenue in the Bronx.

title: GEN. HUBERT HOOVER OF ARMY COURTS, 83
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Maj Gen. Hubert D. Hoover, who retired in 1948 as Assistant Judge Advocate General of the Army, died Friday in Walter Reed Hospital. He was 83 years old andlived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Masked Gunmen Wound Bronx Man and Take $150
description: Three gunmen, two of them masked, held up two patrons of a Bronx pool hall at 11:15 last night taking $150 from one of the men and shooting the other in the side for no apparent reason.

title: Youths Damage Nightclubs Over a Bogus Entertainer
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 11 (UPI)Young people did damage estimated at $50,000 to two nightclubs early today after learning that the drummersinger they had gone to hear was being impersonated.

title: Roundup: Indians'
description: Alan Foster spent much of his spring training telling anybody who would listen, I must be the luckiest guy in the world.

title: Small Share for Education
description: President Nixon's education message, though labeled as a revenue sharing measure, is in reality merely $3billion consolidation of more than 108 specific aid programs into five broad categories. The popular understanding of revenuesharing is that it gives,new Federal funds to the states. The President's plan does nothing of the sort. Even the $200 million above the appropriations for current programs are substantially less than would be provided through normal budgeting for growth and inflation.

title: NEW SAFETY RULES ON GAS LINES ISSUED
description: ALBANY, April 11 (UPI)New safety rules have been imposed on all gas utilities in the state as a result of a preChristmas explosion and fire that killed 11 persons in New York City.

title: On the Supreme Court:I
description: To me, the major accomplishments of the Supreme Court during the fifteen years in. which Earl Warren was Chief Justice were the revolution in criminal justice, both state and Federal; a translation of our society's proclaimed belief in equality into some measure of legal reality, and the beginning of a profound change in the mechanics of our political democracy.

title: Actors Fund Benefit Set
description: A special performance of The School for Wives for the benefit of the Actors Fund of America will be given at the Lyceum Theater Sunday night, April 25. Brian Bedford, who recently won a Tony as the season's best actor for his performance as Arnolphe in the classic Moliere comedy, heads the cast.

title: New Jazz Ensemble Brings Excitement To Brooklyn's Muse
description: A new 16piece orchestra with an impressive mixture of finesse and drive yesterday played the first of two Sunday afternoon jazz concerts scheduled during April at Muse, Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn.

title: Sports of The Times
description: .... Enough of the light stuff, now sports. Senator Howard Samuels, who 10 years. ago sired offtrack betting, came back to place a $2 wager on an 11yearold backstroker named Emily Reinhardt today to open New York's latest Cash Action facility, a twowindow substation in the cafeteria of Manhattan's Public School A.G. The recently completed school was named after the largest daily double payoff in OTB history, a whopping $346,789. As you sports fans remember, the only winning ticket held on the letters A.G. was by I.B.M.

title: 8 Gold Medals Won by Heal, Miss Atwood in A.A.U. Swim
Donahue First in Run
description: Tom Donahue of the Manhattan College Athletic Association won a threemile run yesterday, sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club at Clove Lake Park in Staten Island. Donahue, a 21yearold senior, was timed in 13 minutes 36.2 seconds, finishing 70 yards ahead of Tom Robinson of the New York Athletic Club, who was clocked in 13:46.

title: Mayan Terms Egypt's MIG23,s Burdensome
description: TEL AVIV, April 11  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight that the delivery to the United Arab Republic of more advanced Soviet aircraft was burdensome.

title: Boris LauerLeonarcli Is Dead; Editor and Sailing Enthusiast
description: Boris LauerLeonardi, who fled from Russia during the 1917 Revolution and became an editor and publisher, died at Memorial Hospital Saturday night. He was 65 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Frog Lives Up to Its Name
description: SPRINGFIELD, S. C., April 11 (UPI)A South Carolina bullfrog named Grasshopper jumped 13 feet 8 inches yesterday to win the fifth annual Governor's Frog Jumping Contest. The jump set a state rec, ord and enabled the frog to compete in the National Frog Jumping Contest at Angel's Camp, Calif., a contest inspired by Mark Twain's story, The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County.

title: WashingtonPeking Thaw
description: This year's spring has brought a most welcome thaw to the longfrozen relations between the United States and the Chinese Peoples Republic. President Nixon began the process by lifting visa restrictions for Americans wishing to visit China. Peking responded by inviting not only the American table tennis team but also representatives of two major American newsgathering organizations. Washington then moved swiftly to show its appreciation by warning American oil companies to heed Peking's objections to the exploration of possible petroleum deposits in the waters off China's coast. There has been no such display of goodwill between these two nations for more than twenty years.

title: Nikolais Dancers Begin 16Week Festival Tour
description: The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater has departed for a 16week State Departmentsponsored tour of 20 cities in Europe, Tunisia and Iran.

title: Puerto Rican Priest Gets Post in Annual Fiesta Here
description: For the first time in its 18yearhistory, the San Juan Fiesta, which is celebrated in New York by Puerto Rican Catholics, will be coordinated by a priest of Puerto Rican ancestry.

title: HARLEM MINISTER SLASHED BY YOUTH
description: A Harlem minister who has crusaded for two decades against narcotics pushers reported yesterday that he had been assaulted in his home by two youths who tried to rob him.

title: E. VINCENT SCHNEIER
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., April 11 (UPI)  E. Vincent Schneier, Luxembourg's consul to South Florida, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home here. He was 65 years old.

title: MISS HELDMAN BOWS TO CHRIS EVERT, 16
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 11 (AP)Sixteenyearold Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale upset Julie Heldman of New York, 6.1, 62, to win the Masters professional tennis tournament today the 12th event on the women's pro tour. Miss Evert previously ousted Mrs. Billie Jean King and Francoise Durr.

title: Quake Peril Spurs Protest Against Coast Atom Plants
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Ap?? 11  A littleknown earthtiake fault two miles from the Western White House has become one of the focal points of a crusade to halt the building of nuclear power stations along California's 1,100mile coastline.

title: Paris: Art Nouveau in Architecture
description: PARISToward the turn of the century, the worst insult one Bruxeller could sling at another was architect. The expropriations required to make room for the Palais de Justice, the largest and ugliest Victorian building in Europe, were the cause of this semantic quirk, unexpectedly immortalizedby Samuel Beckett in Waiting for Godot.

title: SCHOLAR ACTIVISM URGED ON BLACKS
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 11 Black scholars and students African affairs have asserted at a conference here that many of them must become scholaractivists, making use of history and developing new value systems for black people, to put fragmented people together again.

title: Here Are Some Helpful Hints as IncomeMx DayLooms
description: The time is nigh. You'll have to get down to that disagreeable chore, filing your tax returns, some time this week. Thursday,, midnight, as you know, is the deadline.

title: Columbia's Nuclear Dilemma
description: There is an Alice in Wonderland quality to the dilemma that Columbia University and the Atomic Energy Commission face as the result of an A.E.C. hearingboard decision to deny an operating license to the university's research reactor. Well over a halfmillion dollars Government funds has been spent to build and equip this minireactor, but the entire investment may be lost if an operating license cannot be obtained. It is difficult to understand why the issues were not threshed out before construction took place and before the money was spent.

title: Marcia R Rubine, Teacher, Wed
description: CRANFORD, N. J., April 11 Miss Marcia Ruth Rubine was married here this afternoon to Eugene Z. Du Bose Jr. The nondenominational ceremony, which was written by the couple, took place at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Rubine. Mayor Malcolm Pringle officiated.

title: Gucci Gets More ClothesConscious
description: It used to be suede skirt here and a silk blouse there, and lucky you if they had it in your size. After all, Gucci means shoes, luggage or handbags to the people who can afford them. The few clothes carried by the Gucci shops have been merely icing to tempt the customer who'd come in for the horsebit moccasins or a grosgrainstriped suitcase. Now there's a Gucci fashion collection planned to appear semiannually, just like those of any readytowear house. The spring and summer one shown the other day involved 42 outfits, which could take woman (and some men) from a morning yacht cruise to an evening party.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Redistricting Gain May Be Below Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, April 11The redistribution of scats in the House of Representatives necessitated by the 1970 census has begun, and it appears likely to cost the Democrats some of their strength.

title: Advertising:
description: How would you like to be in a television commercial?

title: HAWKS ON TOP, 62, AND OUST FLYERS
Bucks Rout Lakers, 9173; Wilt Outplays Alcindor
Rochester Church Burned
description: ROCHESTER, April 11 (AP) The sanctuary of St. Mary's Church in downtown Rochester was damaged extensively by fire shortly after an Easter Sunday mass. No one was reported injured.

title: A MAJOR BATTLE SEEN DEVELOPING NEAR LAOS BORDER
description: TANCANH, South Vietnam, April 11The defenders of a South Vietnamese artillery position called Fire Base 6 in the mountains eight miles southwest of here, besieged since the beginning of this month, are now said to expect a battle equal in intensity to the fighting in Laos in February and March.

title: Changes Held Possible The Washington Star
description: HONG KONG, April 11The new North Vietnamese National Assembly, which is constitutionally required to meet within two months, will elect a Cabinet as well as a President. This could provide the occasion for changes in the Government leadership in Hanoi.

title: Italian Communist Party Bidding for More Power
description: ROME, April 11The Italian Communist party, by far the most powerful Marxist machine in the West, is making a bid for even more power.

title: Sunrise Rites in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 11 (UPI)  Christendom emerged from its deepest days of mourning today with sunrise services here.

title: Pittsburgh Drivers Return
description: PITTSBURGH, April 11 (UPI) About 2,300 bus and trolley drivers began returning to work today ending a threeday wildcat strike. And 175,000 daily commuters braced for a nickel increase in fares tomorrow. Both the strike and the increase involved a 55contanhour wage increase the drivers received last week in an arbitration award. The drivers said it was not enough arid walked Out A court injunction ordered them back.

title: 747 Lands in Bomb Scare
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)An Eastern Airlines 747 jet flying from New York to Miami with 283 passengers landed today at Dulles Airport for an emergency check because of a bomb threat. No explosives were found, a spokesman said, and the flight was continued.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.,

title: Head of Blue Cross Urges Federal Health Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)The president of the Blue Cross Association said today that increased leadership from the Federal Government was essential to any plan aimed at improving the nation's health care system.

title: U.S. CHINESE ASK BACKING ON ISLES
description: A dispute over a group of uninhabited islands in the East China Sea brought thousands of Chinese and ChineseAmericans into the streets in Washington and other cities this weekend.

title: Books of The Times
description: Is it history that shapes men? Or do men shape history? The answer, it seems to me, lies somewhere in between. Both history and human nature have their immutable laws. But somewhere they must intersect, and somehowwhether it be through the further refinement of psychohistory, or through the development of valuefree sociology, or I don't know whatwe must eventually locate their interface. Both of these books about young Americans today are excellent in terms of achieving their objectives, but both fall somewhat short of offering a satisfying view of men and history.

title: U.S. to Spray Controversial Chemical on Fire Ants
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Agriculture Department experts are planning another incursion into fire ant country with an aerial weapon called mirex, an attack that environmentalists say is like using nuclear bombs on pickpockets.

title: Michigan Fugitive Case Raises NorthSouth Conflict on Justice
description: LANSING, Mich., April 11The case of a 21yearold black fugitive from Arkansas has again raised here a question of whether public officials in the North can reconcile their own feelings about Southern justice with the extradition laws.

title: ECOLOGICAL DRIVE AIDS STORE SALES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 The sales of Atexanders, a 10store chain in the San Fernando Valley, have increased nearly 5 per cent since an in:tensive ecological advertising program was begun in midJanuary. The chain has annual sales totaling $25million.

title: OTB to Break Even in 6 Weeks, Samuels Predicts
description: Howard J. Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, predicted yesterday on a television panel show, that OTB would break even within six weeks by selling $200,000 worth of tickets a day, Originally, On officials had estimated they would break even after three months of operation.

title: RAILROAD AIR RIGHTS SOUGHT FOR BUILDING
description: Private developers are exploring the feasibility of erecting a highrise apartment complex over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad tracks at 11th Avenue and 24th Street.

title: Consumer Products Believed Relegated to Lesser Level
description: There is more rhetoric than reality to the much advertised proconsumer bias of the Ninth Soviet FiveYear Plan for 19711975, Western analysts believe. Heavy industry is still No. 1 in the Soviet economy.

title: Buckley as St. George
description: That elegant crusader against liberalism's insidious erosion of American institutions, William F. Buckley Jr., has gone to court in an effort to chip a corner off the union shop, most resolutely protected of labor citadels.

title: Two Congressional Panels Plan Studies of U.S. Role in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 New hearings on Indochina directed to the moral and humanitarian questions raised by the United States role in the war  are to be held concurrently in the Senate and the House of Representatives later this month.

title: 23,300 Vegas Are Recalled For Product Improvements
description: DETROIT, April 11 (AP)The 23,300 Vega minicars made before the United Auto Workers strike against General Motors Corporation last Sept. 15 have been recalled in a product improvement campaign to remedy five possible faults.

title: ELIZABETH VICTOR ON CHARDIN GOAL
description: Elizabeth of New Jersey, the United States soccer champion, downed Blue Star, 10, to take over first place in the South Group of the GermanAmerican Soccer League, while New York Hota, the leader in the North Group, routed the Philadelphia Nationals, 5.0, at Philadelphia yesterday.

title: 33Cent Wager Brings Payoff of $81,258.60
description: SAN JUAN, April 11 (AP) One lucky bettor won $81,258.60 for a 33cent wager at the El Comandante race track today.

title: Bridge: A Ridiculous Contract Proves Embarrassing When It Fails
description: There arc few things more embarrassing in bridge than to reach a ridiculous contract and go down. And few things more irritating than to be told in the postmortem by the doubledummy analysts that you could have made the hand.

title: Two Killed in Arizona Crash
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., April 11 (AP) Michel J. Koziow, 20 years old, of Thornwood, N. Y., and Randall Deghetto, 24, of Clifton, N. J., were killed about 20 miles east of Flagstaff today when a pickup truck hit the rear of their car. The driver of the truck was hospitalized with head and internal injuries.

title: Survey Finds More Policemen and Social Services Help Cut Crime
description: WASINGTON, April 11 A survey of cities where serious crimes declined last year shows that the reduction generally was achieved through a substantial increase in the police force and through new social and anticrime efforts, ranging from community relations programs to sophisticated alarm systems.

title: NADER UNIT FINDS WATER PLANS LAG
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 A panel assembled by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, has concluded that after 15 years and 53.5billion in expenditures the Federal water pollution control program is a miserable failure. The panel's findings were released today in a 700page report.

title: Army to Test New TripleThreat Division Regarded as a Breakthrough in Land Warfare
description: FORT BELVOIR, Va., April 9  United States Army has scheduled tests for anew triplethreat division that Lieut. Gen. John Naughton describes as the first revolutionary breakthrough in the art of land warfare since World War II.

title: Coody's 279 Takes Masters by 2 Strokes
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11Charles Coody came back to beat the golf course that thwarted him two years ago and won the Masters title by two strokes today.

title: DIVISIONS PLAGUE YUGOSLAV LEADERS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 11Prices, tempers and suspicions are all on the rise in Yugoslavia. The Communist leadership that would normally be attempting to hold them down is itself paralyzed by bitter divisions over unresolved economic and political questions.

title: Agnew Sees Pullout Peril
description: SAN DIEGO, April 11 (AP)If all United States troops were immediately withdrawn from. Vietnam, the action would be followed by a potentially harmful rightwing protest, Vice President Agnew is quoted as saying.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 11Bumper sticker seen in California: Remember when air was clean and sex was dirty?

title: AN ECONOMIC LAG FACES EUROPEANS
description: PARIS, April 11The European economic community is facing a period of economic stagnation, higher unemployment and increased inflation.

title: Rebels in Ceylon Continue Raids Despite Crackdown
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 11 Strong Government measures appeared today to, have partly checked the activity of radical leftist insurgents in Ceylon.but they continued harassing raids in many parts of the country.

title: Youth Panel Holds U.S. Policy Is Rigid on Communism
