description: WASHINGTON, April 11A study group of the White House Conference on Youth has charged that those who shape United States foreign policy have become frozen in a reflexive antiCommunism leading to the ugly embroilment, in Vietnam, a distorted sense of the national interest and division and ferment at home.

title: Boy, 2, Falls 9 Stories in Bronx And Suffers Only Minor Injuries
description: A 2yearold boy fell from a ninthfloor window in his grandmother's Bronx apartment yesterday, but apparently landed on his back in some bushes at street level and was not injured seriously.

title: ExMarine, Republican, War Critic Paul Norton McCloskey Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, April 11When he arrived in South Vietnam on Friday, Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. stopped only long enough at Saigon's Tansonnhut Airport for pictures, then headed for Danang, far to the north near the demilitarized zone. It was a typical gesture in several ways: It showed his disdain for the official briefings that visitors usually begin with. It showed his willingness to get down to the hard work of research immediately and it showed his flair for publicity.

title: Sicilian Police Stop Tourists Climbing Etna to View Lava
description: CATANIA, Sicily, April 11 (Reuters)  The police today stopped hundreds of foreign tourists from climbing the slopes of Mount Etna to get close view of rivers of lava and boiling rock flowing slowly down the side.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JAY W. RYSKIND
description: Jay W. Ryskind, owner of the Rockland Distributing Company of Spring Valley, N. Y., magazine distributors, died Saturday of a heart ailment in) South Miami (Fla.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 2100 Lynwood Avenue, Fort Lee, N. J.

title: Ecumenism In Greece
description: ATHENS, April 11Most of Greece's 45,000 Roman Catholics, combining ecumenical spirit with practicality will celebrate Easter not today but on April IS, this year's date for the Greek Orthodox Easter.

title: FRITZ VON OPEL, INDUSTRIALIST, 71
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, April 11 (UPI)Fritz von Opel, an engineer and a grandson of the founder of West Germany's Opel automobile company, died in the Samedan District Hospital at St. Moritz Thursday. He would have been 72 years old May 4.

title: RawSilk Stocks Estimated
description: Stocks on hand of raw silk in March totaled 1,243 pounds, according to the International Silk Association (U.S.A.) Inc. This compared with 1,285 bales on hand on Feb. 28, 1971.

title: A Renaissance Man
description: FLORENCEOn New Year's Day, 1900, Bernard Berenson made his home at the Villa I Tatti, near Florence, and continued to live here for the next 58 years. There are many more spectacular villas in Italy but none that have played a greater part in the cultural life of Europeand the United Statesfor over half a century.

title: GAF FirstQuarter Income Shows an Increase of 34%
description: GAF Corporation, whose management is facing a proxy fight for control at the company's upcoming annual meeting, announced yesterday that its net income in the first quarter came to $3.3million, or 17 cents a share, up 34 per cent from the $2.4million or 11 cents a share earned in the first three months last year.

title: ForeignLanguage Critics To Reward Movie Winners
description: Scrolls for top movie achievements in 1970 will be awarded for the 13th year today by the AllAmerican Press Associates, a group of writers and critics representing 37 foreign language publications printed here and abroad.

title: Governor of Tokyo, a Sato Foe, Is Winning Reelection Easily
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 12 (AP)Ryokichi Minobe, who campaigned against air pollution and the proUnited States policies of Premier Eisaku Sato, headed for a landslide reelection victory today as Governor of Tokyo.

title: Laird of New York A.C. Wins A.A.U.Senior OneHour Walk
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 11 (AP)Ron Laird of the New York Athletic Club, covering seven miles and 1,510 yards, won the national Amateur Athletic Union senior onehour walk today. Last year he placed second.

title: Green Slacks and Old Coin Part of Goody's Magic
KIN TAKES FINAL AT EASTER BOWL
description: Grey King of Peoria, Ill., and Donna Ganz of Miami Beach emerged as the top winners in the finals of the Easter Bowl junior indoor tennis tournament yesterday.

title: LOBBY TO PROTEST BUSINESS TAX CUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 11Common Cause, the peoples' lobby organized by John W. Gardner, former Secretary of Healths Education and Welfare, joined today the mounting protest against the $3billion annual tax reduction for business that was ordered by the Nixon Administration last January.

title: Pastor's Easter Day: Joy and Fatigue
description: GEORGETOWN, Conn., April 11By 12:30 this afternoon, the Rev. Stuart Thody was ready for a nap. He had shaken the last hand and had patted the head of the penultimate child and, for him, Easter Sunday was over.

title: EscapeProof Prison Hunts Missing Convict
description: ATTICA, N.Y., April 11Authorities at the Attica Correctional Facility, where no inmate has ever escaped over the 34foot walls, were unsure today whether to list John Joseph Sullivan as the first escapee in the prison's 40year history.

title: Further OysterCadmium Study Urged
description: Toxic cadmium metal in concentrations some Federal health officials feel is well above safe levels has been found in oysters taken along the Atlantic coast from Maine to North Carolina.

title: U.S. Plane Fires Missile
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12, Monday (Reuters)A United States Navy A7 bomber struck at radar positions near the Bankarai pass in North Vietnam, the American command reported today.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS A ROUT OF INDIANS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April, 11  The Pakistani Government said tonight that its army had wiped out two companies of Indian troops in an engagement in East Pakistan, near Jessore yesterday.

title: DR. GEORGE S. KLEIN, N.Y.U. PSYCHOLOGIST
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., April 11Dr. George S. Klein, professor of psychology at New York University and director of its Research Center for Mental Health, died today, apparently of a heart attack, while driving near his home here. He was 52 years old.

title: Russian Delegation Views Licensing of Patents in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 11In one of a series of cultural exchanges arranged by the State Department with the Soviet Union, three Moscow officials have completed a study of how the American Government and American industry handle the protection and licensing of inventions.

title: Queens School Zone Plan Stirs Racial Controversy
description: A special appeals committee of the Board of Education will begin meetings this week to decide whether to ratify a controversial plan that would rezone nearly every high school in Queens.

title: HARTKE RUE GOT CORPORATE ASSIST
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The presidents of nine railroads and leaders of the trucking Industry chipped in toward an $80,000 sendoff for the reelection campaign of the Senator who heads the subcommittee handling rail and truck laws.

title: Chinese Greet Americans With Smiles and Curiosity
description: PEKING, April 1The members of the United States table tennis team visiting Peking took their first stroll in the Chinese capital today. They were followed by hundreds of smiling people.

title: Barada Token Captures Title For Hunters at Jersey Show
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 11Mrs. A. T. (Wissie) Brede of Ortfield, Pa., piloted Barada Token to the amateurowner working hunter championship with 14 points today at the Short Hills Farm horse show.

title: CATHOLICS TO GIVE ANTIABORTION AID
description: A counseling service offering an alternative to abortion will be opened today by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: VOICE ON PLANT SITES REQUESTED FOR P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, April 11  Governor Rockefeller submitted legislation yesterday to give the Public Service Commission the authority to resolve questions concerning the sites of electric power plants.

title: BONDS SEEN NEAR A CRITICAL PHASE
AIDES DENY HOFFA DOES UNION WORK
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 James R. Hoffa, the president of the teamsters union. visited his ailing wife again today, as persons close to him continued to deny that he was conducting any union businesi.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: MONTE CARLO, April 11 (UPI)  The Rumanian pair of Ilie Nastase and Ion Tiriac won the Monte Carlo open men's doubles final today, beating Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Roger Taylor of Britain, 16, 63, 63, 86.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) The executive branch's communications director, Herbert G. Klein, said today that President Nixon had not decided what to do with Lieutenant Calley, who was convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for killings at Mylai.

title: ANDRE BILLY 88; CRITIC IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, April 11Andre Billy, French literary critic, novelist and biographer, died last night in a clinic in Fontainbleau where he had been'treated following a leg fracture a week ago. He was the dean of the jury that annually designates the winner of the Prix Goncourt, the foremost French literary award. He was 88 years old.

title: Proposed Law Aimed at Dissidents Brings Protests in Madrid
description: MADRID, April 11A proposed law giving the Government increased powers to punish dissent is causing concern in legal and political circles here.

title: Six Arrested in Syracuse In Disruption at Cathedral,
description: SYRACUSE, April 11 (UPI)Six person, including a Lutheran minister, were arrested today at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception after walking down the aisle during an Easter mass carrying a wooden cross, with a Vietnamese peasant's hat attached.

title: Lorna Matheson, A Student, Is Bride
description: LEXINGTON, Mass. April 11Miss Lorna Marie Matheson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hugh Matheson Jr., was married here this afternoon to Robert Garth Kirkwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Brooke Kirkwood of Towson, Md.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 JORDANIAN. TRUCKS BURNED IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11  Five trucks carrying phosphate from Jordan were hijacked yesterday by masked men who forced the drivers to take the vehicles to a Beirut suburb. The drivers were freed and the trucks set ablaze With incendiary bombs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Cuts Fusion Research
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 The Nixon Administration has decided for financial and technical reasons to postpone development of clean fusion re??.

title: Advertising:
description: The National Railroad Passenger Corporationwidely known by the name it hates, Railpaxhas appointed Ted Bates & Co. as its advertising agency.

title: Labeling Plan for the Alert Consumer
description: WASHINGTON  Once you went to the supermarket and bought meat, green vegetables and fruit for dinner and you knew there was a good nutritional balance among the basic food groups.

title: ORDERS IN MARCH UP FOR 3D MONTH
description: New orders for March were up again for the third straight month but the rate was slightly slower than the previous month, according to a survey by the National Assocration of Purchasing Management, Inc.

title: Rajshahi a Ghost Town
description: RAJSHAHI, Pakistan, April 11 (UPI)  East Pakistani forces holding this city are strong on determination but weak on organization, weapons, communications and just about everything else it takes to fight war.

title: State Senate Panel Urges Curb on Liquor Discounts
description: The Ride Senate Excise Committee has recommended that liquor stores be required to make a minimum 12 per cent retail markup over wholesale prices.

title: Family in Plane Crash; Children Hike for Help
description: ORINDA, Calif., April 11 (UPI)  Two young sisters walked away from an Easter weekend plane crash and hiked four hours through dark, rainsoaked wooded terrain to get help for their parents and two brothers who were pinned in the wreckage.

title: A Sunny Easter Brings Out Crowds Around the World
description: Easter and lovely weather brought joy to the city yesterday, brightening Fifth Avenue and Coney Island and even the battered streets of the South Bronx.

title: William Baris, 56, Headed City Personnel Test Unit
description: William Baris, who retired in February as chief of the test development and research division of the city's Department of Personnel, died today in Coney Island Hospital after short illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 601 Brightwater Court, Brooklyn.

title: Toast of Friendship
description: HONG KONG, Monday. April 12A Chinese official said in (Peking last night that he hoped the visit of the American table tennis team would promote bederstanding and friendship between the sportsmen and people of the two countries.

title: Pakistan Attacks Reported
description: NEW DELHI, April 11Indian Government sources say West Pakistani soldiers, aided by artillery and air strikes, launched a series of attacks over the weekend against outlying towns and villages occupied by East Pakistani resistance forces.

title: Man and Wife Are Killed In Crash on F.D.R. Drive
description: A couple listed in the New York Social Register died early yesterday after their car hit concrete abutment just off the F.D.R. Drive at South and Jackson Streets, in lower Manhattan.

title: U.S. Juniors Lose 2 of 3 In Overseas Table Tennis
description: CANTERBURY, England, April 11 (AP)American youngsters took their first plunge into European table tennis today and turned in creditable performances against more experienced players in the British junior open championships.

title: Vote of the Week In the House
Holland America Cruises Replaces Line as Name
description: The HollandAmerica Line, headquartered in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, for almost 100 years, has changed its name to Holland America Cruises and moved its headquarters to New York.

title: Former Penn Central Officer Replies to Trustee Criticism
description: David C. Bevan, the embattled former chief financial officer of the Penn Central Company, who last week was accused of unlawful conspiracy by the bankruptcy trustees of its principal subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company, struck back at his critics yesterday.

title: Chief of Iran Military Court Dies of Assassins'
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 11 (AP)Gen Ziaddin Farsiou, chief of the military court, died at Gendarmerie Hospital early today of six bullet wounds inflicted by terrorist gunmen.

title: Issel and Charlie Scott Tie For A.B.A. Rookie Award
description: Dan Issel of Kentucky and Charlie Scott of Virginia finished in a tie for American Basketball Association rookie of the year honors, the league announced yesterday.

title: Princeton to Seek Head
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 11 Princeton University announced today that a committee of seven trustees has been formed to search for a president to succeed Dr. Robert F. Goheen, who said last month that he would resign no later than June of 1972. The search committee will consult with representatives of faculty, students, alumni and nonacademic staff.

title: Chess:Federation Expert Sweeps FiveGame Blindfold Match
The StepmotherCoping With a New Family and a Bad image
description: Almost since the beginning of time, stepmothers have gotten bad press. Just the mere mention of the word stepmother to many people is enough to cause visions of an ugly woman with warts who is evil to the children she has inherited by her marriage to a previously married man.

title: Two Shot as Rock Festival On Coast Turns Into Melee
description: LOS ANGELES, April 11 (AP)  The police said they wounded two persons with gunshots and arrested 129 others here today when an Easter rock music festival of 5,000, mostly young people, turned into a rock and bottlethrowing melee.

title: Soviet Ships Pass Bosporus
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 11 (AP)Three escort vessels of the Soviet Black Sea fleet sailed through the Bosporus en route to the Mediterranean today.

title: Lon Nol, on Mend, Back In Cambodia's Capital
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday, April 12 (UPI)Premier Lon Nol returned to Pnompenh aboard a United States Navy plane today after almost two months of medical treatment in Honolulu for a stroke he suffered on Feb. 8.

title: Chase Bank Rejects a Theory That the U.S. Dollar Is Weak
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank rejected yesterday the contention that the value of the dollar has weakened in the international money markets this year. In the latest issue of its biweekly publication, International Finance, the big New York City bank asserted that in the last few days the possibility of a major international monetary crisis appears to have waned.

title: CALLEY EXONERATION URGED BY THURMOND
description: WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) Describing the victims at Mylai as casualties to the brutality of war, Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, today urged the exoneration of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

title: Metropolitan Museum to Hold Open House Jubilee Tomorrow
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will hold an allday open house tomorrow as it concludes its centennial year of celebrations and marks its 101st anniversary with free admission to the museum and a variety of special events. Among the attractions will be two performances of John Bernard Myers's Off Broadpieces of Fifty Centuries, First Reader, at 4:15 and 8 P.M.

title: Halifax Wins in Rugby
description: BLACKPOOL, England, April 11 (Reuters)  Halifax beat Blackpool Borough, 4110, in in the only English Rugby League game played today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Market Crunch
description: The British negotiations for entry into the European Common Market have taken a worrisome turn with France's call for informal discussion of the future role of sterling as a reserve currency. This is a legitimate question, but one outside the negotiations as such and so complex that it has stirred speculation about French motives.

title: Coast Teachers Vote Return
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 11; (AP)Striking public school tenchers voted tonight to accept a settlement to end their walkout and schools were to return to normal operations tomorrow morning.

title: Neighborhoods: The Stadium Is Anchor to South Bronx
description: In sturdy apartment houses that form windowed palisades in the southwest Bronx live thousands of people who, when asked for directions to their home, will reply, with some pride, somewhat as follows:

title: POPE SOUNDS NOTE OF HOPE AT EASTER
description: ROME, April 11Pope Paul VI in a hopeful Easter message said today, The great ideas which are the guiding lights of the modern world shall not be put out.

title: PAKISTAN FACING CRITICAL STRAINS
description: BOMBAY, India, April 10The move by the military Government of Pakistan to suppress East Pakistani secessionism by force has introduced critical new strains and grave uncertainties into the affairs of a nation already afflicted by economic malaise and political instability.

title: Orr Scores 3 Goals as Bruins Win, 52, and Tie Canadiens in Playoffs, 22
ALLENDE FACING LABOR PROBLEMS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 10The manager of the lunch counter at the international airport here shrugged apologetically over the lack of hot coffee.

title: State Legislature Seeks to Bring Total Support Close to $15Million
description: In this year of budgetary crisis at Albany, the arts are not going to be as well nourished on state funds as they were last year. The cuts in support, however, are not so deep as some had feared.

title: State Judges Ordered to Make Quarterly Inspections of Prisons
description: The state's presiding justices were ordered yesterday to begin quarterly visits and inspections of prisons as soon as possible in a move to improve correctional facilities.

title: A Mixed Band of Monks Shares The Life of the Poor in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 11Only a dusty nameplate distinguishes the aging building from others on its North Side Chicago block. Inside a modernday band of monks has been putting into practice for the last five years its vision for an international, ecumenical church.

title: CocaCola Pact in Boston
description: BOSTON, April 11 (AP) Some 400 Bostonarea employes of the CocaCola Company ratified a new contract today, ending a sevenweek strike. The threeyear accord with the Beverage Workers Union calls for total increases of $1 an hour for mechanics and drivers and of 95 cents an hour for other employes.

title: Masada's Heroes Theme of 3d Seder
description: The historic heroism of the defenders of the ancient Dead Sea fortress of Masada and its relevance to modern Judaism was extolled last night in a specially written Passover Haggadah.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWARK SCHOOLS FACE STATE RULE, GIBBON CAUTIONS
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said yesterday he would have to ask the state to take over the Newark school system if the 10weekold teachers strike showed no sign of ending soon.

title: The Play and the Meals Are Tough on U.S. Team
description: PEKING, April 11Portraits of Chairman Mao everywhere. Martial musicThe East Is Red and On the Road to Socialism. Sumptuous Chinese banquets. A 12yearold boy, playing table tennis on a concrete table with bricks for a net, with the assurance of grown man.

title: HUBERT L. LONGUA
description: Hubert L. Longua, a financial manager, died here Saturday of a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 250 East 65th Street.

title: Directory Predicts Rise in Aid for 72
description: In the last five years, state and territorial funding of 55 arts councils has grown from $2.66million to $26.67million a year.

title: John Guggenheim Fund Gives $3.7Million in Grants to 354
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has announced fellowship awards totaling $3,787,000 to 354 scholars, scientists and artists,

title: Newark Held an Angry and Anguished City
description: NEWARK, April 11 Nowark has become an angry and anguished city as its black community gradually takes over the city's politics, schools and cultural life from an everdecreasing white minority.

title: 7 New Methadone Clinics Are Approved by the State
description: Facilities for seven new methadone maintenance clinics to serve about 100 narcotics addicts each have been approved by the state Health Department after being recommended by review agencies here.

title: Class 44: Books Battle The Tube in Uphill Fight
description: On the final day of school before the start of the spring vacation last week, Dorothy Boroughs, the teacher of Class 4.4, waged a brief campaign on behalf of books, libraries, museums and the great outdoors, in the hope of weakening slightly the immobilizing magnetism of television.

title: Churches Under Attack
description: Easter is the season of hope for Christians. It is also the time when church statistics for the previous year are finally assembled, and this year the news is not particularly hopeful.

title: Musicus Moving to Cut Building Costs
description: Milton Musicus, the city's Municipal Service Administrator, said yesterday that he had taken steps to accelerate the city's $8billion construction program with the hope of saving $10million a month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ESPADA CAPTURES 10ROUND DECISION
description: Angel Espada, the welter weight champion of Puerto Rico, made his New York debut last night in the Felt Forum ring and scored a majority decision over Edmundo Leite, Brazil's welterweight titleholder. Leite weighed 147 pounds while his rival scaled 144.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL DECLINED IN WEEK
Truth in Reading
description: The disclosure that some teachers and supervisors cheated in the administration of the citywide reading tests points up a recurring educational abuse. The bootlegging of test questions, currently at issue, is only a more flagrant version of the longstanding practice of teaching to the testa practice that sacrifices good instruction to a teacher's or administrator's quest for a better professional image.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (Reuters)The State Department said today that North Korean proposals contained old demands that were unacceptable to South Korea and the United States. Among them, he said, are the withdrawal of American troops and abrogation of the United StatesSouth Korean defense treaty and of the treaty establishing diplomatic relations between South Korea and Japan.

title: Flyweight Title Bout Set
description: MANILA, April 12 (Reuters)The World Boxing Council has sanctioned a flyweight title fight between Erbito Salavarria of the Philippines, the champion, and Susumu Hanagata of Japan on April 30.

title: Bronx Rapist Gets 25 Years
description: Thomas Gibbons, 28 years old, of 390 Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in state prison on charges of rape and robbery. Gibbons originally was charged with committing 14 robberies and rapes in the Riverdale area of the Bronx. He was tried on only one count of rape and one of robbery in a threeweek trial before State Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman.

title: Rolla Back in Prison After Visiting Ill Wife
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., April 12 (AP)James R. Hoffa, president of the teamsters union, returned tonight to the Federal prison where he is Serving a 13year term for jury tampering and mail fraud. He had had a fiveday leave of absence to visit his ill wife.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uses of a Forest
description: A muchneeded examination of Forest Service practices may at long last be at hand. Testifying last week before a Senate subcommittee, Senator Gale McGee of Wyoming not only proposed a review of timber management the national forests but sought a Congressionally imposed moratorium on clearcutting by logging companies until such a study can be made.

title: MARY KENNELLY, 72, EXOFFICIAL OF POST
description: Mrs. Mary McClung Kennelly, who was general manager of The New York Post from 1947 to 1949, died Sunday at her home in Campbell, Calif., after a heart attack. She was 72 years old.

title: REV. FIDELIS O'ROURKE
description: OLEAN, N.Y., April 12 (UN) The Rev. Fidelis O'Rourke, O.F.M., former law professor and dean of the school of business administration at St. Bonaventure University, died today at the university. He was 69 years old.

title: BASIE GROUP DRAWS 2 SELLOUT CROWDS
description: The The enduring popularity of Count Basie and his orchestra and of Ella Fitzgerald was made evident on Sunday when they gave two concerts to sellout houses at Philharmonic Hall. They were received with cheering enthusiasm despite the fact that the performances of both Mr. Basie and Miss Fitzgerald have long since been boiled down to bland, unadventurous routines. Or is it because of this?

title: News Analysis; Conservatism in Albany?; BudgetCutting Victory Seen Pointing To a Swing to Right in State G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, April 12  Governor Rockefeller has been mopping up after the fierce battle of the budget by signing a series of costcutting, education and welfarerestriction bills.

title: A Citizens Commission Writes to Seven Persons Who, It Says, Served as Informers for the F.B.I.
description: BOSTON, April 12A group calling itself the Citizens Commission to Investigate the F.B.I. says it has the names of persons who functioned as informers for the Federal Bureau of Investigation over the last few years.

title: Coast Awaits Poindexter
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 12Mr. Poindexter is expected to take on a key role in the campaign to get Angela Davis out of jail.

title: On the Supreme Court: II
description: Our system has now been operating with a Supreme Court exercising the great power of judicial review of the constitutionality, of Federal and state legislation for almost two centuries, Yet during all that time the Court has never overruled precedent to any significant degree in order to facilitate a significant contraction of human liberties.

title: Samuels Defends OTB Plan for Derby
description: Howard J. Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, urged Churchill Downs Race Track yesterday to withdraw its threat of legal action if OTB takes bets on the Kentucky Derby, which will be held May 1.

title: Hesburgh Bids Catholic Schools Learn From Youth
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 12 The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, told Roman Catholic educators here today that today's students had demonstrated closer concern for the church's traditions of human dignity and human rights than had the Catholic schools.

title: Marist Crew Irked by Regatta Mixup
description: The Marist College crew from Poughkeepsie, N. Y., still maintains it won the Grimaldi Cup race at Orchard Beach, the Bronx, last Saturday although the official winner remains Drexel of Philadelphia. The occasion was a bizarre one not unlike the Kentucky Derby of 1968, which had two winners, Dancer's Image and Forward Pass. Marist will protest the outcome to the National Assocition of Amateur Oarsmen.

title: Rosenberg Associates Nearing Its 25th Year
description: Anna M. Rosenberg Associates, headed by a woman who made it to the top long before women's lib, celebrates its silver anniversary this month as a publicrelations firmwhich is worth a small hip, hip hooray.

title: NOEL D. MAXCY
description: Noel D. Maxcy, for 40 years an agent with the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 239 East 79th Street.

title: South African Office Here Bombed
description: An explosion the police believe was caused by a pipe bomb tore a hole in the wall of the 14thfloor Madison Avenue office of the South African consul general yesterday.

title: Kosygin Meets Ambassadors
description: MOSCOW, April 12Premier Kosygin met separately today with the Pakistan and Indian ambassadors as part of an apparently growing Soviet effort to seek a solution to the crisis caused by the civil strife in East Pakistan.

title: Life Photograph, Drama By Michaels, Due Next Fall
description: Life Photograph, a drama by Sidney Michaels on a 1954 Vietnamese theme, will be presented on Broadway next fall by the team of Jack Milstein, Stanley Gould and Leonard Feldman. Arthur Penn is being sought to direct.

title: Poindexter Cleared In Davis Case Here
description: David Poindexter won acquittal yesterday on a charge that he helped Angela Davis evade arrest for almost two months last year while she was a fugitive.

title: 7 Get Suspended Sentences In Attack on School Buses
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., April 12 (AP)Seven white men pleaded guilty today to charges growing out of a riot last spring in which a mob attacked school buses containing Negro pupils at a newly integrated school. The seven men got suspended sentences.

title: A Cooking Timer Replaces the Iron Hand on Key House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 12On his desk in the Armed Services Committee hearing room, the new committee chairman, Representative F. Edward Hbert, keeps a small, $1.50 cooking timerthe kind, he says, his wife uses to time her gumbo.

title: KEUTER'S DANCES RECALL TAYLOR'S
description: Genuine admiration is only one step removed from benign obsession, but one that divides normal artistic growth from a parodistic inbreeding. It is the latter bind in which Cliff Keuter currently finds himself visavis the choreographic work of Paul Taylor. Last night at the Theatre of the Riverside Church, Mr. Keuter offered four works, only one of which formally acknowledged Mr. Taylor but all of which recalled him in the strongest terms.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CAIRO, April 12  Moves for another conference of leaders of the Arab world on the Jordanian Palestinian crisis gained ground today, with Libya reportedly joining five other countries already favoring such a session.

title: Parsons Bank in, Michigan Bought by Local Investors
description: MONROE, Mich., April 12 (AP)The Monroe Bank and Trust Company, once a part of the banking empire of Donald H. Parsons, has been repurchased by 108 local investors, including bank employes.

title: FIRST 4 OTB DAYS BRING IN $309,654
description: WESTBURY, L. 1., April 12A review of OTB action tonight disclosed that the first four days of legalized offtrack bet ting resulted in the funneling of $309,654 into the mutuel machines at Roosevelt Raceway. Onthescene betting over the same span reached an aggregate. of $9,156,845.

title: Cavaliers Sign Patterson
description: CLEVELAND, April 12 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers today signed Steve Patterson, University of California, Los Angeles, center,

title: Nun Killed, 28 Others Hurt In Bus Crash on Turnpike
description: SECAUCUS, N. J., April 12 (AP)A Roman Catholic nun was killed and 28 persons inured today when a New YorktoBaltimore bus slammed into the rear of a tractortrailer on the New Jersey Turnpike, the state police said.

title: Son Arrives in Havana
description: MIAMI, April 12 (AP)The son of Prime Minister. Bandaranaike has arrived in Havana in response to an invitation by the Cuban Communist Youth Union, the radio reported today.

title: Fostoria Glass Unit to Close
description: MOUNDSVILLE, W. Va., April 12 (AP)  The Morgantown Glassware Guild, Inc., one of northern West Virginia's steadiest industrial employers since 1901, will be closed by the end of April, officials of the Fostoria Glass Company said today. More than 125 hourly workers are affected by the decision.

title: Wedding Is Held For Gay Chanler And J. A. Gunther
description: GENESEO, N. Y., April 12 Miss Margaret Gay Chanler, daughter of Rear Adm. Hubert W. Chanler, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Chattier, was married at noon here today to John Andrew Gunther, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Gunther of Albany. The Rev. Walter Carron performed the ceremony in St. Felicity's Roman Catholic Chapel at Sweet Briar Farm, the Chanler home. The chapel was built in 1913 by the bride's grandmother, the late Mrs. Winthrop Astor Chanler, and has been the scene of many family weddings and christenings.

title: ROSEWALE VICTOR IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 12 (AP)The topseeded Australians, Ken Rosewall and Mrs. Margaret Court, reached the quarterfinals of the $51,000 South African open tennis !championships today.

title: Europe's LongHarassed Gypsies, Ending Parley, Seek World Recognition of Separate Way of Life
description: LONDON, April 12Gypsies, plagued for years by hostile flaws and harassipent ere pressing for international recognition and a new consciousness of their plight across Europe.

title: India Lists 547 Million In Early Census Report
description: NEW DELHI, April 12India now has 547 million people and 7 out of 10 cannot read or write, according to a preliminary report on the country's first census in a decade.

title: Coiley Defeats Colavita.
description: BOSTON, April 12 (AP)Unbeaten Johnny Coiley, 160 pounds, of Somerville, Mass., floored Luigi (Rocky) Colavita, 162, of New York three times in the seventh round tonight in gaining a technical knockout in a scheduled 10round bout at the Arena.

title: Drive to Nominate Lindsay As a Democrat Is Opened
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP)  A nationwide campaign to promote Mayor Lindsay for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination was announced today by a former campaign aide of Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California.

title: Navy Auditing Grumman Unit
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (Reuters) The Navy disclosed today that an auditing team was checking the financial condition of the Gruman Aerospace Corp oration. which has run into cost prolems on its contract to build the F14 fighter. A spokesman stated that the team was sent several weeks ago after the company said that inflation andthe worsening United States business climate was adversely affecting its financial position.

title: DR. MAX TRUMPER, 79, BIOCHEMIST, AUTHOR
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12Dr. Max Trumper, a biochemist and writer of medical textbooks, died yesterday. He was 79 years old and lived in BalaCynwyd.

title: HANCOCK CONFIRMS ADDING OF NEW LINES
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company confirmed yesterday reports that its agents would soon have a new product to sell  insurance on cars, homes and boats.

title: Ford Adds Service Unit
description: DEARBORN, Mich., April 12 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company has created a 1,700man customers service organization for the Ford and LincolnMercury divisions. The new division will have offices or representatives in 34 cities.

title: Marcel Gromaire, Painter, Dies at 78
description: PARIS, April 12  Marcel Gromaire, internationally known painter, engraver and designer of tapestries, died here last night in a hospital after a long illness. He was, 78 years old.

title: Firemen Fight Brush Fires In DroughtStricken Florida
description: MIAMI, April 12 (UPI)Firemen fought several small brush fires in dry, windwhipped southern Florida today, while forecasters said it may be June before rain relieves one of the worst droughts in the state's history.

title: DENUNZIO NAMED BIG BOARD CHIEF
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Ralph D. DeNunzio, vice chairman of the exchange's board of governors, had been nominated to succeed Bernard J. Lasker as chairman when his term expires next month.At the same time, the ex change disclosed that Stephen M. Peck, senior partner of Weiss, Peck & Greer, a member firm, had been nominated to succeed Mr. DeNunzio as vice chairman, Such nominations are tantamount to election, since there is only one nominee for each position.

title: S.E.C. CITES RISKS OF NEW SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Securities and Exchange Commission warned the public today of risks it believes investors will be taking if they buy a new type of interestbearing security that will soon come on the market.

title: Du Pont Predicts 21% Fall in Quarter Profit
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 12Shareholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. were told at the annual meeting here today that estimated earnings for the first quarter would be in the neighborhood of $1.50 a share, down 21 per cent from the $1.93 a share earned a year ago.

title: Chilean Paper Asserts Castro Plans a Visit
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 (UPI)The opposition newspaper, La Tarde, said today that Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba was expected to arrive in Chile April 27 for a fiveday visit.

title: Trenton Paper Raises Price
description: TRENTON, April 12 (AP)The cost of The Evening Times of Trenton was increased to 15 cents a copy today to offset mounting production costs. The price of the Sunday newspaper will remain at 35 cents. The daily newspaper cost 10 cents before the increase.

title: Gladwin Hill Given Award for Reports On the Environment
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 Gladwin Hill of The New York Times received today the Thomas L. Stokes Award for his reporting of environmental news in 1970.

title: 3 Go on Trial in Crash Fatal to 7 L.I. Children
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 12  Three New Jersey men went on trial here today on involuntary manslaughter charges arising from the bus accident last July 15 in which seven Long Island children were killed.

title: METROLINER RUNS TO INOREASE MAY 1
description: Officials of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation said yesterday that service on the route of the Metroliners, the aluminumskinned trains that run between New York and Washington at up to 120 miles an hour, would be increased on May 1 from seven to nine roundtrips a day.

title: Ernest Nell Is Dead at 72; Connecticut Manufacturer
description: CHESHIRE, Conn., April 12Ernest Iseli, founder and former president of the Iseli Company of Terryville, manufacturers of Swiss screw machinery, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Easing of Money Policy Tied to Supply Shortfall
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in January to ease monetary policy further, partly in order to make up for a shortfall in ithe growth of the money supply in the final quarter of 1970, it was disclosed today.

title: CARTER PUTS BITE IN BULLETS'
description: They call Fred Carter Mad Dog, and the 6foot3inch Baltimore Bullet backcourt man doesn't mind it. He enjoys it. His teeth gleam through a wide smile when one of his teammates shouts, Go get him, doggie.

title: ROBERT LEWIS, 50, EDITOR FOR TIMES
description: Robert C. Lewis, an assistant editor of The New YorkTitnes Magazine, fell or jumped to his death'yesterday from his apartment at 55 East 76th Street. Ills age was50.

title: City Lawyer Defends Outside Practice
description: A lawyer with the city's Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance said yesterday that he did not allow his private law practicewhich includes landlords as clientsto cause any conflict of interest with his city position.

title: A BangUp Party Ends Era of Town House Musicales
description: It was the end of an era, full of nostalgia and carefully devoid of regrets. The Sunday evening musicale held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Barlow was the final one of several hundred such gatherings held over the last halfcentury.

title: Bridge: Wei to Head Touring Players After World Title Test in May
Bond Interest Rate Levels Register Sharp Increase
Draft, Call for 536 Dentists Canceled by the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Pentagon has canceled its draft call for 536 dentists, Curtis W. Tarr, director of Selective Service, announced today. The call was issued last February.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 13, 1971 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Colonialism3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: U.S. Team Member Wants to Extend Stay in China
description: PEKING, April 12  John Tannehill, a member of the United States table tennis team visiting here, says he has asked his Chinese hosts if he can extend his stay for a few weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans Sue Mets for Opening in Rain
U.S. Jail Here Trying to Cut Crowding and SpeedTrials
description: There were 176 men in the cages on the third floor of the Federal House of Detention on West Street yesterday. A weak sun filtered through the dusty skylight and the men, packed in a space designed for a third of their numbers, were sleeping , or talking or wandering the squalid corridors.

title: Rocket Hits Marcos Home
description: MANILA, April 12 (UPI)Radical Filipino youths fired a skyrocket at the palace residence of President Ferdinand E. Marcos during a rally today to protest the disappearance of a leftist militant. The skyrocket hit the study room

title: COMMUNIST CHINA BACKS PAKISTAN AND WARNS INDIA
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12  The Pakistani Government announced today that it had received a note from Premier Chou Enlai of Communist China strongly supporting its efforts to put down a movement for autonomy in East Pakistan.

title: Gas Kills 6 Miners In Southern Illinois; 7th Is Overcome
description: GOLCONDA, III., April 12 (UPI)Six miners were killed today when they were trapped in a surge of hydrogen sulphide gas unleashed as they worked 800 feet underground in a southern Illinois fluorspar mine.

title: CEYLON'S FORCES TAKE OFFENSIVE
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 12 Official sources said today that Ceylonese security forces had gone on the offensive in efforts to suppress guerrillas, who are seeking to replace the Socialist Government of Ceylon with a more radical regime.

title: Man in the News
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 12 centuries the farnorthern reaches of what is now West Pakistan have echoed to the tramp of soldiers feet.

title: NEWARK WARNED BY HEAD OF POLICE
description: NEWARK, April 12Police Director John L. Redden warned today that the guns are being loaded again by those who would plunge this city into the same type of apocalyptic convulsions it experienced in 1967.

title: SURPRISE WITNESS IN CRIMMINS TRIAL
description: The murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins took an unusual turn yesterday when the prosecution reopened its case to call a surprise witness.

title: Deducting Your Cattle Ranch
description: Last week at a very sophisticated cocktail party, I ran into Monroe. Monroe is a very sharp guy with the latest word on how to avoid paying taxes. You can tell he doesn't pay any because he was wearing an expensive customtailored suit, with his initials embroidered on his shirt cuffs. He nudged me into a corner and sakk What are you doing about your taxes this year?

title: Transit Authority Gets Its First Tower Women
description: Two women railroad clerks were promoted yesterday, be coming the first tower women in the city's subway system.

title: A Fan in Court Helps Zale Gain the Verdict
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (UPI)Tony Zale won another bout today.

title: Books of The Times
description: CARRINGTON. Letters and Extracts From liar Diaries. Edited by David Garnett. Illustrated. 514 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $12.50.

title: Six Are Indicted in Bomb Plot Against Bronx Recruiting Office
description: Six persons have been in dicted in an alleged plot to blow up a NavyMarine Corps recruiting office in the Bronx last June.

title: Soviet Said to Have Let 1,000 Jews Leave in March
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (AP)An informed source reported today that more than 1,000 Jews were given permission in March to leave the Soviet Union for Israel.

title: Joint Oil Venture Is Set
description: CHICAGO, April 12 (AP)The Peoples Gas Company announced today that it had agreed to join the Eason Oil Company of Oklahoma City in an exploration program to find and develop new supplies of gas and oil. The program will be administered by the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, transmission subsidiary of Peoples.

title: Men's Stores Closing
description: The three Bruce Hunt men's stores in the Washington, D.C., area are being closed because of unsatisfactory performance, Lawrence Phillips, president of the PhillipsVan Heusen Corporation, yesterday told security analysts here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Ambition Is to Become a Rabbi
description: CINCINNATIA rabbi is a scholar, a teacher, a preacher, a counselor, a comforter, a leader and a preserver of Judaism, said the young rabbinical student. And most important, rabbi is a human being.

title: NASSAU IS SEEKING REALTY SALES TAX
description: MINEOLA, L.L., April 12A homerule message asking the State Legislature for permission to impose a real estate transfer tax in Nassau County was voted 3 to 1 today by the Republicancontrolled Board of Supervisors.

title: ROOKIPELLER SIGNS BILLS GUTTING AID
description: ALBANY, April 12Goirernor Rockefeller signed a series of austerity bills today that cut state aid to New York City lly $9.5million and to the City University by at least $3million.

title: Newton Trial Delayed
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 12 (UPI)Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, appeared in court today on manslaughter charges and had his trial postponed to May 10. Newton is free on $50,000 bail.

title: Case Says It's Quite Likely His Phone Is Being Tapped
description: NEWARK, April 12 (AP)Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, says that it is quite likely his telephone is being tapped, but there is no way of knowing for certain.

title: CHICAGO ED'S NET UP IN QUARTER AND YEAR
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first quarter. The Chicagobased utility placed operating revenues for the three months ended March 31 at $247,247,984, or 15 per cent higher than the $215,015,557 reported a year earlier. Net income rose to $35,786,040, or 76 cents a share, from $32,122,899. or 73 cents a share, in the like 1970 period.

title: NORTH KOREANS ASK PARLEY WITH SOUTH
description: HONG KONG, April 12 (Reuters)  North Korea proposed today that representatives of political parties and public organizations in North and South Korea meet to discuss issues dividing them, the North Korean press agency reported.

title: West Point Graduate, Foe of War, Wins Discharge
description: FORT MEADE, Md., April 12 (AP)First Lieut Louis P. Font, a West Point graduate who has been seeking a discharge as a conscientious objector because of the Vietnam war, was honorably processed out of the Army today, a Fort Meade official reported.

title: CANADIAN STOCKS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: The Toronto stock market was sharply higher yesterday in moderately, active trading. The industrial index advanced 1.27 to 187.41, its highest level since Dec. 1, 1969,

title: FRANK A. COSTANGY
description: ATLANTA, April 12Frank A. Costangy, who was chairman of the labor relations section of the American Bar Association in 196768, died today at his home here. He was 60 years old.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (Reuters)  The State Department today expressed serious concern at the cancellation by the Irish airline. It said the abrupt cancellation would result in a serious loss of revenue to United States airlines and seriously inconvenience thousands of Americans planning to visit Ireland.

title: Executive Changes
description: First National City Bank announced yesterday the appointment of George C. Scott as vice chairman. Chairman of the bank's credit policy committee for the past four years, Mr. Scott will continue to serve as senior credit officer. Mr. Scott who joined the bank in 1929 was named a vice president in 1948 anti became a senior vice president in 1958. Before being appointed chairman of the credit policy committee in January, 1967, he was senior credit officer in the bank's overseas division. He is a director of Dresser Industries, Inc.; Siemens Overseas Investments Ltd., Canada and of various affiliates and subsidiaries of the hank.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Commander Shifted In a Police Scandal
description: The commanding officer of the police precinct covering Greenwich Village was removed from his command yesterday after eight of his patrolmen were suspended on departmental charges of stealing cartons of meat from a packing plant.

title: Market Place: Asarco's proxy Irks Stockholder
description: Alfred R. Rose is disgusted with the whole thing.

title: Bruins Recall Defenseman
description: BOSTON, April 12 (AP)Bob Stewart, a 20yearold defenseman, has been called up by the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League for the team's Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoff with the Montreal Canadiens. Stewart played with Oklahoma City of the Central League this season.

title: JUDGE STAYS RETURN OF BABY TO MOTHER
description: A Federal judge here issued a preliminary stay yesterday to bar the return of a baby girl adopted by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino of Brooklyn to the child's natural mother.

title: Iraq Says 16 Jews Who Tried to Flee Are Free on Bail
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12An Iraqi Government spokesman said today that 16 Jews who had been arrested on charges of attempting to leave Iraq illegally had been released on bail.

title: Carnegie Hall Ushers Get Chance to Perform
description: The ushers at Carnegie Hall, many of them music students wanting to add to their income and hear concerts for nothing, probably dream of the day when they might be up on the platform as performers.

title: POVERTY AGENCY TO AID VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The White House announced today a pilot project aimed at informing lowincome veterans of the Vietnam era of benefits available under the G.I. Bill.

title: Selling of Pentagon Wins Special Peabody Prize
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, The Selling of the Pentagon, has won a special Peabody Prize award to be announced formally on April 21.

title: YorkvilleWall St. Bus Express Makes Debut, and It's on Time
description: It was scenic, quiet, comfortable. It was clean. It was cheaper than a cab.

title: AIM PRICES END ON A MIXED NOTE
Pakistan Claims Victory at Key Railhead
description: KARACHI, April 12  The administration in Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan, announced today that Government troops had destroyed all subversive elements around a key railhead and it promised that the lives and property of minorities and other people in the eastern wing of the country would be protected.

title: Mobile Homes Gain
description: Mobile home shipments in February advanced 18 per cent from those of the yearearlier month, to 28,440 units, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

title: CITIES TO RECEIVE ONEDAY AIRMAIL WITHIN 600 MILES
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Postmaster General Winton M. Blount announced today that nextday airmail delivery would be provided by July between principal cities no more than 600 miles apart.

title: New York Communities In New Airmail Service
LING WILL SEVER TIES WITH LTV
description: Paul Thayer, chairman of LingTemooVought, Inc., announced yesterday that James J. Ling had resigned as vice chairman and a director of the company, and would register immediately for public sale all of his stock ownership in LTV.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Back in the old days Eddie Brannick of the New York Giants would stand on his Polo Grounds parapet and gaze enviously across the Harlem River to the Yankee Stadium where the Bronx Bombers did their cannonading with considerable thunder and frequency.

title: Etna Observatory Destroyed
description: CATANIA, Sicily, April 12 (Reuters)An observatory high on the slopes of Mount Etna was almost entirely destroyed by molten lava tonight as the volcano continued its biggest eruptions in 10 years. One river of lava has crept more than 2,000 yards down the mountain, but so far no danger to life or other property has been reported.

title: BANKERS TRUST PUTS FREEZE ON '71 STAFF
description: The Bankers Trust Company, one of the largest financial institutions in New York, has clamped a freeze on its total employment in 1971, according to senior officials.

title: BOY HELD IN FIRE FATAL TO CAPTAIN
description: A 13yearold Brooklyn boy was arrested on charges of arson and homicide last night in connection with a Bushwick tenement fire on March 28 in which a 40yearold Fire Department captain, John Dunne, was killed when he entered the building to look for children who already had been rescued.

title: Fifth Escaper Recaptured
description: HONOLULU, April 12 (AP)The police arrested last night a fifth member of the sixman group that broke out of Halawa jail at gunpoint on Friday. Wendall Kealoha, 18 years old, was recaptured as he walked along a highway. Still at large is Edward Hose 3d.

title: Congratulations From U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (Reuters)United States space officials and America's first man on the moon, Neil A. Armstrong, sent congratulatory messages today to Soviet astronauts and scientists.

title: Roundup: Pitchers GetOff To heir Usual Fine Starts
description: Bert Blyleven of the Minnesota Twins pitched a threehitter against the Kansas City Royals. Gaylord Perry of the San Francisco Giants pitched a threehitter against the San Diego Padres. Rollie Fingers of the Oakland Athletics pitched a fourhitter against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: U.S. Yachtsmen Freed By Chinese After 4 Days
description: HONG KONG, April 12Four Americans, held in a Chinese coastal village after their yacht had been seized, were released Saturday and permitted to sail back to Hong Kong, it was disclosed today. They had been two days out of Hong Kong on a trip to Okinawa when the vessel was seized.

title: MORE COMMANDOS EVACUATE AMMAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 12, (Reuters)Ten truckloads of Palestinian commandos, firing shots into the air, left Amman today as Jordanian security forces continued a housetohouse search for hidden weapons.

title: San Jeronimo Hilton Sold
description: SAN JUAN, P., R., April 12 (UPI)  A Puerto Rican company, Antilles Mortgage Brokers, bought the San Jeronimo Hilton Hotel here at a public auction today for $8million. The winning bid was made for the brokers by Enrique Campos del Toro, president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Bank. A bid from Chase Manhattan Bank of New York of $7.6million was rejected.

title: Philip Bookbinder Dead at 67; Was Languages Typographer
description: Philip R. Bookbinder, president of King Typographic Service Corporation, 550 West 43d Street, died here Wednesday. He was 67 years old and lived at 209 St. John's Avenue, Yonkers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Decade After Man's First Space Flight, Soviet Sets New Goals
description: MOSCOW, April 12The Soviet Union marked today the 10th anniversary of man's first space flight by Col. Yuri A. Gagarin on the Russian craft Vostok 1, and forecast that the next decade would be an era of manned space stations in earth orbit, and exploration of the moon and the planets by automatic stations.

title: DR. WILLIAM W. COX, MONTCLAIR SURGEON
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 12 Dr. William Wheeler Cox, physician and surgeon here since 1919, died today in the East Orange Veterans Administration Hospital of complications following a fall last November. He was 83 years old.

title: STOCK OFFER SET BY MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, announced plans yesterday to make a public offering of its own stock in late May or early June.

title: Egypt Bars Dayan Proposal
description: CAIRO, April 12 (AP)Egyptian officials today turned down a suggestion by the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, that Israel withdraw her troops from the eastern bank of the Suez Canal under a permanent ceasefire and an agreement that no Soviet or Egyptian forces would cross the canal.The Egyptians insisted that their forces must occupy positions on the Israeliheld side of the 100mile waterway.Egypt will accept nothing less, officials in Cairo said. We have nothing new to add. Our position has been clarified by President Anwar elSadat's restatement of April 3.

title: Hungarian Bid to I.M.F. Raises Remote Chance of Membership
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A feeler from Hungary has raised once again the possibilityclearly still remoteof membership in the International Monetary Fund by one or more of the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Comment by Reuss
description: TOKYO, April 12 (AP)Representative Reuss said today that an F.B.I representative visited him in midMarch in his office in Washington and told him that three documents concerning his daughter had been stolen from the F.B.I. office in Media, Pa., and might be made public.

title: Victim of Prank Dies
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 12 (UPI)William Horn, 17 years old, who suffered a broken back in a high school prank Jan. 20, died yesterday of heart failure just after he was anesthetized for surgery. He and four other youths had been barricaded into a washroom at Arlington Heights High 1School by pranksters. When they tried to batter their way out through the door, the wall and part of the ceiling collapsed on them, injurying three.

title: DECEIT BY SENSITRON IS CHARGED IN SUIT
description: A class action on behalf of all stockholders was brought against Sensitron, Inc., yesterday, charging the company with acts, practices and courses of business, which operated as a fraud and deceit upon plaintiff and the class of plaintiffs in connection with purchases and sales of common stock and other securities of Sensitron.

title: Shop Talk
description: Almost everyone would like to take off for Tahiti but Stuart and Leni Goodman have turned their dream into reality in less than a year's time. Together, they are Gooleni, Inc., designers of shell jewelry that has caught on like a flash fire. Five years ago the couple, who are enthusiastic divers, started a shell collection; adding to it with each vacation to such places as Martinique, Aruba, Guadeloupe and Saint Croix. Mr. Goodman started doing shell paintings and a sculpture or two. And he made necklace of a heavy chain with a shell suspended from it.

title: U.S. to Send Copter Parts
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) A State Department spokesman said today that the United States was considering a Ceylonese request for six small helicopters and was sending spare parts for Bell Ranger helicopters. He said that the parts would be delivered to Colombo by tomorrow.

title: N.E.A. SCORES NIXON ON SCHOOL AID PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The National Education Association today criticized President Nixon's plan to broaden Federal aid to private school students. It said the proposal would provide Federal money for allwhite private schools in the South.

title: RISE IN PRIME RATE SEEN A POSSIBILITY
description: The sharp upward move in shortterm interest rates led bankers to speculate yesterday that the prime ratethe minimum interest rate on bank loans to businesscould move up a notch, despite a generally soft economy and weak loan demand.

title: Hamlet Wins 13. Nominations In 23d Annual Emmy Awards
description: Hamlet, which was televised Nov. 17 as a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation with Richard Chamberlain in the lead, walked off with 13 nominations in the 23d National Television Academy of Arts and Sciences Awards, which will be presented on the National Broadcasting Company on May 9.

title: Textile Failures Increase
description: Textile and apparel industry failures in February increased 26 per cent compared with the year before, it was reported yesterday by Credit Clearing House, a division of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. Liabilities in these failures increased 65 per cent over the comparable period in February 1970. The number of failures, including wholesalers and retailers selling textiles and apparel, increased from 82 last February to 103 in February of this year.

title: TAX AGENCY STUDIES WALLACE'S BACKERS
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 12A Federal grand jury began today hearing data gathered by the Internal Revenue Service on the tax records of persons who gave contributions to the campaigns or Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Peking Involvement Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, April. 12United States officials took the view today that Premier Chou's message of support for Pakistan was primarily political and did not presage any direct Peking involvement.

title: Drowning Given as Cause Of Whitney Young's Death
description: The National Urban League yesterday released the report of an autopsy performed here on the body of Whitney M. Young Jr., the league's executive director. It attributed Mr. Young's death in Nigeria last month to drowning.

title: Decibel Tests Aim to Pinpoint Why It's So Noisy Around Town
description: In a green station wagon with a microphone jutting four feet above its roof, noisecontrol specialists studied dials and jotted down figures yesterday in an attempt to set acceptable levels of noise in the city.

title: Colombo's Freedom Continued, But Bail Is Raised to $25,000
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., a reputed leader of organized crime in the metropolitan area, won another reprieve from imprisonment yesterday when a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled he could remain free on bail pending further appeal on a perjury conviction.

title: DR. J. S. KRESIIOVER, RETIRED INTERNIST
description: Dr. S. Siegfried Kreshover, retired New York general practitioner and internist, died yesterday in Bethesda, Md., where he lived. His age was 89.

title: JUDGE, RETIRING, SCORES FACILITIES
description: Judge J. Howard Rossbach disclosed his early retirement from Criminal Court here yesterday when he made public a letter criticizing the court's horrible caseloads and wretched facilities.

title: Sato Party Retains Most Key Offices In Local Elections
description: TOKYO, April 12Incumbent conservative governors defeated opponents supported by Socialists and Communists in local elections yesterday, except in Osaka.

title: ALFRED A. LOHNE, 53, ADMIRALTY LAWYER
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 12Alfred A. Lohne, senior partner in the law firm Hof Mendes & Mount, 27 William Street; New York; and a specialist in admiralty law, died here today apparently of a heart attack. He. was 53 years old and lived at 275 Maple Street.

title: HOTEL MAN HELD ON BRIBE CHARGE
description: The manager and partowner of a small hotel that housed 13 welfare families at a cost of $4,000 a month to the city was arrested yesterday on bribery charges.

title: Thousands of Children Gather at the White House for Easter Egg Roll
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)Thousands of children and a halfdozen clowns roamed the south lawn of the White House today in warm, sunny weather at the annual Easter egg roll.

title: United Air Chief Sees Earnings Heading Up
description: UAL, Inc., the holding company that owns United Air Lines, replaced its top management at the end of last year after the consolidated company suffered a $40.9million loss. Edward E. Carlson, the new president and chief executive officer, has instituted a deep costcutting program. Robert E. Bedingfield of The New York Times interviewed Mr. Carlson last week about the outlook for United Air Lines. Excerpts follow:

title: C.A.B APPROVES 9% AIR FARE RISE FOR U.S. TRAVEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Civil Aeronautics Board told the nation's financially troubled airlines today that they could raise their domestic passenger fares by 6 per cent next month and could count on approval of an additional 3 per cent increase this summer.

title: Bluegrass Is Growing As Music for City Ears
description: Bluegrass music, the lively country instrumentalists blend of mountain fiddling, ragtime, blues and gospel music that has been slowly working its way into New York's cultural bloodstream, will reach a new level of bigcity acceptance on Sunday when it will be heard as the focal point of two concerts at the New School, 66 West 12th Street.

title: NASTASE TRIUMPHS OVER OKKER IN FINAL
description: MONTE CARLO, April 12 (UPI)Ille Nastase of Rumania defeated Tom Okker of the Netherlands in the final of the Monte Carlo open tennis tournament today, 36, 86, 61, 61.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESSURE BY FOE RISES IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12Enemy forces in Cambodia are increasing their pressure on the 22,000 South Vietnamese troops there, while the Government forces still search for the momentum they lost seven weeks ago when their commander, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, was killed.

title: Sentences Eased for 27 Guilty in Vietnam Killings
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The 22 American servicemen, including First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., who have been, convicted of the premeditated murder of Vietnamese citizens were all sentenced to life in prison.

title: Rev. James Donnellon, 64, Former Head of Villanova
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12 (AP)The Very Rev. James A. Donnellon, president of Villanova University from 1954 to 1959, died yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: Two Seals Leave Hospital
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 12 (AP)Bill Hicke and Earl IngarfieId of the Oakland Seals of the National Hockey League were released today from Merritt Hospital after surgery. Doctors removed bone chips in Hicke's right elbow, and the Seals front office said Ingarfield's operation repaired a broken kneecap.

title: Smoke Opens Air Exhibit
description: PITTSBURGH, April 12 (UPI) A thick haze of smoke covered this city today, the opening day of a clean air exhibit at City Hall. Officials at the air pollution control center blamed a nocturnal inversion for the heavy concentration of carbon monoxide, accompanied by a strong sulphur odor from the city's steel mills.

title: Stuttgart Group in Scholarly St. Matthew Passion
Merger News
description: Shareholders of Kansas City Southern Industries, Inc., yesterday approved a plan for the company to reacquire the 21 per cent of its shares held by the Lee National Corporation. The approval clears all but one barrier in the fight for control of the diversified holding company. A Federal District Court on April 19 still must rule on the settlement between Kansas City Southern and Lee National to dis miss several damage suits between the two concerns.

title: Backers Say Plan of White House to Cut Business Taxes Is Needed for Economic Health of the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Supporters of the Administration's plan to cut business taxes by about $3billion annually struck back at critics today, contending that the basic economic health of the nation depended on the plan's being allowed to go Into effect.

title: LERNER STORE SALES FELL 17.2% IN MARCH
description: The Lerner Stores Corporation, the largest chain of readytowear apparel for women and children, reported yesterday a 17.2 per cent decline in sales for March. The month's volume totaled $25,459,719 compared with $30,751,361 in March, 1970.

title: Funds for Philanthropy Rose to $18.3Billion in 1970
description: Despite a declining stock market, inflation and high unemployment in many areas of the country, living individuals contributed $700million more to philanthropy last year than in 1969, a 5.2 per cent rise.

title: Bill Rates Show a Sharp Gain At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Treasury bill rates rose sharply again at today's auction from a previous week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Peacekeeping for the Mideast
description: The chances for successful international intervention to prevent renewed conflict in the Middle East may be decided by the deliberations of a 33member United Nations committee that reconvened last week. Based on the past record of that committee, the Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations, the prospects for success are not encouraging.

title: Huard Traded to Saints
description: DENVER, April 12 (AP)The Denver Broncos traded John Huard, a linebacker who missed the 1970 football season, to the New Orleans Saints today for an undisclosed 1973 draft choice.

title: State Lottery Sales Climb 50% in Year To $70.5Million
description: ALBANY, April 12  State Tax Commissioner Norman Gallman reported today that sales of lottery tickets had increased almost 50 per cent in the fiscal year that ended March 31.

title: Departing Aide Sees Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Chinese Nationalist Ambassador ended a sixyear tour here today by sounding a note of concern about the Nixon Administration's policy of improving relations with Communist China.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 12A vacation In Which scant attention was paid to the news may provide a poor perspective, but what offers a good one these days? And in the instant case, two strong impressions did work their way tmsolentifically through more personal concerns.

title: Indians Report Perils
description: NEW DELHI, April 12An Indian Government spokesman said today that the Pakistani Army continued to hold onto major towns and garrisons in East Pakistan, but that it had been forced by frequent ambushes to move down main roads in units of battalion size or larger. The spokesman also said that the Pakistani forces had had to reroute supply links from Chittagong to a Ganges. River town nearer to Dacca.

title: PROXMIRE URGES CUTS IN DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Senator William Proxmire challenged today a wide range of military spending policies.

title: Extra Flights Offered
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The 3,661 pilots of Eastern Airlines have offered to fly extra flights for their company this year with pay at straight rates rather than at overtime rates.

title: DISCLOSURE SUIT WON BY INVESTOR
description: A Federal judge, critical of a Youngstown, Ohio, company, said yesterday that entrenched management should not deny information to shareholders by grasping at flimsy excuses.

title: Frenchman Says True Radicals Must Be ProAmerican
description: PARIS, April 12  JeanFrancois Revel has made rather a splash in the European politicoliterary world this season with a shocking thesis: that one can be leftist and proAmerican too.

title: Frozen Orange Juice Drops In Brisk Trading of Futures
description: Disappointed holders of frozen orange juice futures rushed to sell yesterday, after taking a look at a Department of Agriculture crop report. The Government forecast a crop about the same size as its March estimate.

title: 30 U.S. Scholars Appeal To Yahya for Truce in East
description: A group of 30 scholars all experts on East Pakistanhave addressed an appeal to Pakistan's President for a truce and restoration of legitimate and responsive government, in the East.

title: Hawaii's Meat Certified
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that state meat inspection in Hawaii had been certified as satisfactory under Federal standards. Hawaii was the 39th state to meet Federal requirements.

title: Peter Verdicchio, ExHead Of Hoboken Savings Bank
description: ORANGE, N. J., April 12Peter G. Verdicchio, who retired in 1969 as president of the Hoboken Bank for Savings, where he had started as a bookkeeper in 1911, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 292 Winthrop Terrace, South Orange.

title: Crisis of Confidence
description: When President Nixon addressed the nation last week he appeared painfully aware how tenuous had become the confidence of the American people in their leadership. Repeating his promise to end the war, he recalled the many earlier occasions of similar assurances and asked, almost wistfully, Butcan you believe this?

title: Advertising:
description: The latest advertising push on the ecology front gets under way this week with a big blast out of Richmond from the Reynolds Metals Company.

title: End of Property Tax as School Fund Source Is Urged in Michigan
description: DETROIT, April 12Michigan's Governor proposed today a virtual end of the local property tax as the revenue source for public schools in the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Byzantine Scholar Named
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 12 (AP)William Carl Loerke, art historian, has been elected director of studies and professor of Byzantine art at the Center for Byzantine Studies, Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection in Washington. Professor Loerke, who is now at the University of Pittsburgh, will succeed the late Prof. Romilly Jenkins July 1, it was announced here yesterday. Professor Jenkins died in 1969.

title: Substandard Performance Cited
description: FORT MEADE, Md., April 12 (UPI)A spokesman at the Pentagon said the 24yearold lieutenant had been released because an Army selection board recommended his discharge for substandard per formance of duty. The lieutenant's tour of service was to have run until 1973.

title: Senator Jordan Recovers
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) Senator B. Everett Jordan, Democrat of North Carolina, said today his doctors had assured him that he had recovered completely from an operation Feb. 15 in which a malignant tumor of the colon was removed. He said he would return to his Senate duties Wednesday.

title: Americans Visit Great Wall
description: PEKING, Tuesday, April 13The United States table tennis team visiting Communist China saw the Great Wall yesterday. Their hosts seemed bent on making a success of this venture into personal diplomacy.

title: New Patriarch of Ethiopia Is Approved by Emperor
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 12 (Religious News Service)  Emperor Haile Selassie has confirmed the appointment of Archbishop Theophilos as the new Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church.

title: Theater: Of Adam and Eve and Songs
description: Charles Strouse did everything for Six, which opened at the Cricket Playhouse last night. He wrote the music, the book, the lyrics. It was not enough. Previously he had written the music for Bye, Bye, Birdie and Applause. Six might well have been subtitled Bye, Bye, Applause. It is calculated to make even Harold Prince's Follies look unpretentious.

title: EDWARD BRIDGMAN SR.
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., April 12  Edward Charles Bridgman Sr., a retired publish.. er and former president of the Allied Greeting Card Company, died yesterday in Riverhead. He was 75 years old and lived here.

title: TIMES TO PUBLISH BOOKS OF REVIEWS
description: Eight volumes containing reviews of the performing arts that were printed in The New York Times between 1920 and 1970 will be published in November by the New York Times Company and Arno Press, a Times subsidiary.

title: Arts in Capital: Crisis and Promise
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The National Symphony Orchestra is in the midst of another crisis. If this one seems more urgent to its beleaguered board and supporters than last year's, when President Nixon threw his personal influence behind the drive to raise emergency funds, it is because the formal opening of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is only five months away and the orchestra is to be one of its prime performing constituents.

title: DATSUNS ARE 1, 2, 7 IN E. AFRICA SAFARI
OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 12American spy satellites have detected a lot of big holes in the ground in Russia. Twenty of these holes are large enough to accommodate the biggest war rockets in the world, and naturally our intelligence people suspect the worst.

title: ' Buraikan,' Japanese Movie, Evokes Village Life
description: Chalk up "The Scandalous Adventures of Buraikan" as another Japanese import worth seeing at the Bijou Playhouse in its current series. The film opened yesterday and runs through tomorrow.We haven't the foggiest notion whose scandalous adventures the title indicates. What do come across, minutes after the opening, are the boldly mercurial direction, an arresting use of color and a pulsating flow of vignettes depicting a village in mid-19th-ccntury Japan.Masahiro Shinoda, one of his country's prominent young directors, sets the story in motion vividly, briskly weaving terse fragments that create a teeming rogue's gallery of kimonoed players. This picaresque stirring of characters and incidents is even enhanced by some snappy English titles, as when one young buck approaches a stately geisha and professes his love. "No kidding?," she retorts loftily. Good for you, baby.The story, looping together the vignette strands, gets even better and more meaningful as it pinpoints the village's feudal subjugation and simmering rebellion. Unfortunately, instead of coming down to earth hard for an explosive climax, the film coats an ageless themerevolt against oppressionwith artful but obvious theatricality.
