Thus the picture sheds its juice and impact.Most of the performances have a good cutting edge, especially those of Tatsuya Nakadai, Suisen Ichikawa and Shoichi Ozawa. Mr. Shinoda's interesting movie is derived from a well-known Kabuki play. It remains far more engrossing when concerned with mischief, mockery and intrigue rather than with history  the old, old story.

title: Offshore Oil Blaze Blasted Out After Burning Since Last Dec. 1
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 12The last flames of Shell Oil Company's drilling rig fire, probably the most expensive offshore blaze in history, were blasted out today afternoon by highpressure hoses.

title: PARIS FAILS TO END RIFT WITH ALGIERS
description: PARIS, April 12A twoweek effort by France's topranking diplomat to settle a critical dispute with Algeria has apparently failed.

title: TEACHERS RETURN IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (UPI)School days returned to normal for 89,000 children today as public school teachers returned to the classrooms after a 19day strike.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass. Freeman Willoughby of the Edgartown post office recently reminded me that the early run of small striped bass should be off the south shore of Martha's Vineyard before the end of April.

title: Procaccino Appointed To Battery Park Panel
description: ALBANY, April 12Governor Rockefeller appointed Mario A. Procaccino, former New York Controller to the Battery Park City Authority today. Authority members received $100 a day when they work, with a maximum of $5,000 a year.

title: UltraLeftism in Ceylon
description: Ever since the French Revolution, and probably earlier than that, there has been a law of escalating extremism which guarantees that no matter how radical a group may be, it will soon run into a more radical opposition once it assumes power. Lenin encountered the phenomenon more than half a century ago, and his pamphlet response to the challengeLeftWing Communism: An Infantile Diseasehas become a Soviet classic, now particularly useful for apt quotations directed against Mao Tsetung.

title: Pacification Wrecked in a Highlands Area
description: PHUNFION, South Vietnam, April 10  Three weeks of heavy fighting in the highlands south of Pleiku has left the pacification program and a score of hamlets in this district of refugee settlements in ruins, according to American advisers who endured a 12hour siege of the district headquarters compound. They say that another attack could come at any time.

title: Top Leaders at Memorial
description: MOSCOW, April 12 (Reuters)  The Communist party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and other top members of the Soviet leadership today attended the memorial rally.

title: IRISH AIRLINE TO END SHANNONDUBLINLINK
description: DUBLIN, April 12Irish International Airlines announced today that it was canceling the service linking Dublin with the International Airport at Shannon, effective April 19.

title: Army's Eyeglasses To Get a New Look With Black Frames
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)  In another concession to modern styles, the Army in January will stop issuing gray spectacle frames in favor of black plastic ones.

title: City Sues State Over Order That Limits Abortion Payments
description: New York City sued yesterday to invalidate a state order that limits Medicaid payments for abortions for poor women to medically indicated cases.

title: Goldman Band to Play Prospect Park Series
description: The Goldman Band will play its regular series of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Prospect Park this summer, Saturdays from June 26 through Aug. 14.

title: Strike Halts Philadelphia Buses, Trolleys and Trains
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 12The 13th transit strike in the history of this city halted service today on all bus, trolley, subway and elevated lines, forcing about 925,000 daily commuters to seek other means of transportation.

title: The Kind of Day That Girl Watchers Wait For
description: Call them what you like: hot pants, cool pants or just plain short shorts. Unlike the midiskirt, it hasn't taken a hardsell campaign to put over those tiny garments that offer the best leg show of the century.

title: U.S. KEEPS CHECK ON EGYPT'S ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) The United States said today that it was keeping a careful check on increased Soviet arms shipments to the United Arab Republic to determine their effect on the military balance with Israel.

title: Text of Newark Official's Statement
description: Following is the text of statement issued by Newark police director John L. Redden:

title: Miss Nixon's Wedding Set June 12
description: WASHINGTON. April 12 (UPI)Patricia Nixon said today that she and Edward Finch Cox had settled on Saturday, June 12. as the date for their White House wedding. The ceremony will take place at 4 P.M., and the President's dauhgter hinted it might be held outdoors.

title: Wheat Shipments Stopped
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (Reuters)  The United States announced today that it is suspending aid shipments of wheat to East Pakistan because of congestion in East Pakistani ports caused by civil strife there.

title: POLICE DISPUTED IN PANTHER CASE
description: Mrs. Clarice Bird, mother of Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers on trial here for an alleged bomb conspiracy, testified yesterday that previous police witnesses had lied about circumstances surrounding her daughter's arrest in January, 1969.

title: India Denies Charge
description: NEW DELHI, April 12 (AP)The Indian Foreign Ministry today denied a Pakistani charge that two companies of Indian border security forces had crossed into East Pakistan and the Pakistani army had wiped them out

title: Rites for Parsons Couple Set for New Canaan Today
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.. April 13A funeral service will be held tomorrow at 2 P.M. in St. Mark's Episcopal Church for Samuel A. Parsons and his wife, the former Ann Bowen, of 188 Chichester Road and 376 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. Both were killed early Sunday in an automobile accident in Manhattan.

title: General Fireproofing Co. Will Appeal Court Ruling
description: The General Fireproofing Company announced yesterday it would appeal the decision of Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt dismissing the company's suit against Thomas G. Wyman and the American Seating Company.

title: Fire Sweeps Jersey Woods
description: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP, N. J., April 13More than 6,000 acres of woodland were blackened by a forest fire here today that raged not far from the Lakehurst Naval Air Station. The police said no homes or commercial properties were endangered.

title: Corning Glass Elects President And Makes Other Appointments
description: Major management changes were announced yesterday by the Corning Glass Works following a meeting of the board of directors, which convened after the company's annual meeting in Corning, N. Y.

title: ADMINISTRATION OPPOSES BIG RAISE IN STEEL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 The Nixon Administration warned steel management and labor today that a big wage increase, such as the one the union recently won from the can industry, would only increase the steel industry's troubles and would probably mean higher unemployment.

title: Casey to Be Sworn Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)New York lawyer William J. Casey will be sworn in as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission tomorrow at a private ceremony in President Nixon's oval office. The White House said it did not expect to have press coverage of the 11 A.M. oathtaking, which will be administered by Chief Judge John J. Sirica of the United States District Court. Mr. Casey, 57, will be designated S. E. C. chairman.

title: Books of The Times
description: A few years ago, at a reunion of the surviving Lemay brothers and sisters (there had been 13 originally, but some were dead now and others had disappeared), one wife, a taciturn border malcontent whose marriage had been consumed in adamant opposition to her quickfisted husband, rose from her seat on the stairway as we settled down, cradled an imaginary machine gun in her arms, and riddled us, with humorless eyes, from one end of the sofa to the other with imaginary bullets. We roared as she joined the other wives in the kitchen, but her husband, staring after her with proud male possessiveness, said You think she's kidding, don't you?  Well, of course she was. And yet, at the point late in Harding Lemay's memoirs that the anecdote occurs, it would not have seemed incredible if the machinegun bullets had been real. The Lemays were that kind of family. The wonder is that anyone survived at all, let alone came through to write this spellbinding, painfully honest comingtoterms with the fractured past.

title: Jawboning the Steelworkers
description: In its third Inflation Alert, President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers has warned the steelworkers that they will undermine their industry's competitive position and create unemployment if they insist on a big pay increase this year.

title: Rangers Win, Lead Series by 32
description: Again refusing to yield to thirdperiod pressure, Ed Giacomin, with another rugged team effort in front of him, preserved a 31 victory for the Rangers over the Toronto Maple Leafs last night. New York took 32 lead in the fourofsevengame Stanley Cup series.

title: Union Asks Sizable Wage Rise As Aluminum Talks Begin Here
description: The United Steelworkers of America began yesterday to present proposals for a substantial wage increase and other major contract improvements as bargaining talks opened in the aluminum industry.

title: Ceremony Precedes Matches
description: PEKING, April 13  The United States table tennis team learned today that for the Chinese table tennis is part of an elaborate, colorful ritual that blends with traditional Chinese life.

title: B'nai B'rith Unit Elects
description: Mrs. John L. Goldwater of New York has been named general chairman of the newly formed national women's division of the B'nai B'rith AntiDefamation League Appeal. The appeal is campaigning for $7,505,000 to support research and education in community relations and civil rights.

title: Editors Urge U.S. Law to Shield Newsmen Against Court Action
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The American Society of Newspaper Editors was urged today to press for a national law to protect reporters from court orders, fines and jailing, to force them to disclose news, sources.

title: Evidence Mounts That Road Grooving Can Reduce Accidents on Wet Curves
Dr. de Bary Appointed New Columbia Provost
description: Dr. William Theodore de Bary, a professor of oriental studies, has been appointed executive vice president for academic affairs and provost of Columbia University, the institution's secondhighest administrative post.

title: Manhattan Life's President Returning to Law Practice
description: John J. von der Lieth, 49yearold president of the Manhattan Life Insurance Cornsince 1968, has resigned his post to return to private law practice, it was disclosed yesterday. He will continue to act as special counsel for the company. He described his departure as very amicable.

title: Canada Airs More Local Music, Brahms for Instance
description: OTTAWA, April 13New rules to protect Canadian radio and television from a United States cultural invasion are producing surprising footnotes to livingroom entertainment north of the border.

title: From P.T.A. to Mayor Mrs Patience Sewell, Latting
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 13Mrs. Patience Sewell Letting became Mayor of Oklahoma City this afternoon. She is the first wontan ever to head the government of an American city of more than 200,000 population. Scores of friends waited impatiently through almost four hours of zoning hearings to watch the 52year old woman take office. The crowd, which included a number of Negroes who had helped to elect her applauded vigorously as Mrs. Latting was sworn in.

title: COMPROMISE NEAR ON CAMPAIGN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Democratic and Republican Senators are nearing agreement on a campaign spending bill that would limit the 1972 Presidential candidates to about $20million each for all cornmunications expenses during the general election race.

title: Laird Says Air and Navy Units Will Stay After Pullout of G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the United States would maintain a naval and air presence in Southeast Asia after American ground troops had been withdrawn from Indochina.

title: F. B. I. MAY CLOSE SMALLER OFFICES
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Federal Bureau of Investigation is considering shutting down some of its small offices manned by a few resident agents, according to informed sources.

title: SADAT AND ALLIES FOLD 2 MEETINGS
description: CAIRO, April 13President Anwar elSadat conferred twice today in closeddoor meetings with the leaders of Libya, the Sudan and Syria.

title: The Postwar Economy
description: What will be the economic impact of the windup of the Vietnam war? The question has acquired urgency with the announcement by President Nixon that he will reduce American troop strength in Vietnam from 284,000 now to 184,000 by Dec. 1, 1971.

title: Two Chinas = No Chinas
description: MONTREALTrue, It is spring in Peking. But the glad spectacle of American, Japanese and other youthful foreigners playing Ping Pang in Peking and strolling among amiable Chinese crowds hardly represents a departure in policy for the Chinese. It does, however, draw spectacular attention to the sharp distinction the Chinese have always drawn between the friendly. American and Japanese people on the one hand and their hostile governments on the other.

title: Boston Pops to Receive Peabody for Public TV
description: The Henry W. Grady School of Journalism of the University of Georgia said yesterday that Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops Orchestra would receive a Peabody prize based on their television appearances over the network of the Corporation of Public Broadcasting. In yesterday's New York Times it was erroneously said that WQXR would receive an award for carrying the radio version of the concerts.

title: New Yorker Dies in Crash
description: WICHITA, Kan., April 13 (AP) Two airmen who were killed late last night in a onecar accident here last night in a onecar accident here were identified today as Sgt. Edward J. Shannon, 23 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., and S. Sgt. Ronald E. Reynolds, 23, Kansas City, Mo. A third airman, Sgt. Ronald R. Hurley, 21, of Claremore, Okla., was reported in critical condition at a hospital.

title: 162 Meat Plants on U.S. List
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The Agriculture Department announced today that 162 meat plants in Minnesota would be placed under Federal inspection on May 16 because the state had failed to develop a program equal to Federal standards.

title: John Scali of A.B.C. Is Appointed to Post At the White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The White House, in what was described as a move to broaden public understanding of President Nixon's policies formally announced today the appointment of John A. Scali as a special consultant to the President.

title: ROLLO MASSELINK, NEUROLOGIST, 66
description: Dr. Rollo J. Masselink, a neurologist, died at his home in Bronxville, N. Y. on Monday. He was 66 years old and lived at 150 Midland Avenue.

title: Total Inventories Of U.S. Businesses Rose in February
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Total business inventories showed a small rise in February and revised figures also showed a small increase in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: At Least 6 Reported Dead In Hotel Fire in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, April 13 (UPI) Firemen said at least six per sons were killed tonight in a blaze at the 52yearold PickCarter Hotel downtown. The victims were two men two women and two children, the firemen said.

title: G.O.P. GROUP PLANS ANTINIXON MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Republican figures critical of President Nixon's policies plan to meet early next month to discuss their future insurgency activities, former Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York disclosed today.

title: Jewish Youths Here Visit Plague on Soviet Aides
description: A small group of militant Jewish youths released frogs and mice in the offices of two Soviet agencies here yesterday as the start of what they said would be the harassment of the Russians with 10 symbolic plagues during this Passover week.

title: A Busy Guest: Young de Gaulle
description: New York's elegant upper echelons, as nameconscious as smalltown movie fans, have swamped a tall, blond, 22yearold Frenchman with invitations. Predictably, his name isn't John Smith but Charles de Gaulle, and he's on the town something like five nights a week.

title: Newark's Education Board: A Coalition of 5 Rules
description: The Newark Board of Education is essentially a body of middle and uppermiddleclass whites and blacks who represent a rough crosscut of the city's population of 380,000.

title: Roberts Gets Chief Aide
description: Seymour Rotker was sworn in yesterday, as chief assistant to Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts. Mr. Rotker, who had been executive assistant to Mr. Roberts, succeeds Anthony V. Magro, who died April 1. Mr. Roberts said that Mr. Rotker would continue to serve also as head of the Rackets Bureau in his office.

title: TRADING IS HEAVY AS STOCKS EDGE UP
OTB Plans Win and Triple Pools on Derby, Says It Can Handle $500,000
description: New Yorkers will be able to start betting legally on this year's Kentucky Derby six days before the race, it was indicated yesterday.

title: NIXON AIDES SCORE TAXI SETUP HERE
description: The limited number of New York taxi medallions was singled out by the Nixon Administration yesterday as an extreme example of how inflation is fed by artificial barriers to competition.

title: Brigade Is Decommissioned
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., April 13 (AP)  The Fifth Marine Amphibious Brigade Was decommissioned today, with its 10,000 men being absorbed by the First Marine Division, now moving out of Vietnam. A ceremony marking the return of the First Division to Camp Pendleton is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: ChinaIndiaPakistan
description: It was almost inevitable that the major nations. of Asia would sooner or later involve themselves in the tragedy now being enacted in East Pakistan. The process began two weeks ago when both houses of India's Parliament unanimously adopted a resolution expressing wholehearted sympathy for the East Pakistanis. Now the Chinese Government, whose hostility toward India is of long duration, has moved to take advantage of the crisis with a declaration of support for Pakistan should the Indian expansionists dare to launch aggression.

title: Chevrolet Recalls 1,700 Cars
description: DETROIT, April 13 (UPI)The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation is notifying the owners of 1,700 fullsize 1971 models to return them to their dealers for inspection of a possible defect that could lead to a loss of braking action. The company said today that the cars may have been assembled with an incorrect pivot bolt that could cause disengagement of the pedal from the bracket, leading ito a loss in braking.

title: Embryos of Mice Are Developed To HeartBeating Stage in Lab
description: In what Is regarded as an Important step toward the gestation of mammalspossibly including human beingsoutside the body, fertilized mouse eggs have been grown in the laboratory to the heartbeating stage.

title: Bruins Top Canadiens, 73, For 32 Lead in Playoffs
Nassau Bus Line May Cut Service In Lack of Funds
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 13 The Hempstead Bus Corporation, which serves 12,000 daily riders, said today that it might have to curtail its services severely because of its financial condition.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Foreign. The President announced the appointment of John A. Scali as his special consultant on communications in foreign affairs. Mr. Scali, 52 years old, former chief diplomatic correspondent for the American Broadcasting Company, will work closely with Herbert G. Klein, director of White House communications.

title: Port Authority Reports 5.2% Gross Income Rise
description: The Port of New York Authority collected a record $255.3million last year at its 24 bridges, tunnels, airports and other transportation facilities in New York and New Jersey, the agency reported yesterday.

title: Igor Tamm, Soviet Physicist, Is Dead
description: MOSCOW, April 13  Igor Y. Tamm, Nobel Prizewinning physicist and one of most independentminded of Soviet scientists, died here yesterday at the age of 75.

title: BIG ATEST PLAN IN ALEUTIANS SET
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Atomic Energy Commission said today that it planned an underground nuclear blast of less than five megatons this fall at Amchitka Island in the Aleutians.

title: Bill Would Almost Triple Speno's Death Benefits
description: ALBANY, April 13  The death benefit of the late Senator Edward J. Speno would be nearly tripled, from $79,515 to $214,800, under the provisions of a bill that has been introduced in the Legislature, informants in the State Controller's office reported today.

title: DARIN EXPRESS 31 IN WESTBURY PAGE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 13  Larry Mailer, the racing secretary at Roosevelt Raceway, is not opposed to women's lib. But the starters named for tomorrow night's eighth event might be evidence to the contrary.

title: Westinghouse Profit Up by 13% in 3 Months
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a gain of 13 per cent in firstquarter net income on a 4.8 per cent rise in sales.

title: PENN CENTRAL GIVES TERMS FOR RAILPAX
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP)The Penn Central Railroad says it is willing to pay $52,382,110 to have the National Rail Passenger Corporation take over the railroad's unprofitable intercity rail passenger service.

title: SHEPHARD S. MILLER, WON $SMILLION SUIT
description: Shephard S. Miller, a member of the law firm of Kaufman, Taylor, Kimmel & Miller, died Monday night in Miami Beach, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing. He was 39 years old and lived at 37251, Henry Hudson Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Chattanooga Negro Wins
description: CHATTANOOGA, April 13 (AP)John Franklin, an educator and businessman, was elected today to be the first black Commissioner in the city's history.

title: Vanden Heuvel Plans Hearings on Jail
description: William J. vanden Heuvel, the chairman of the city's Board of Correction, said yesterday that he planned to hold public hearings on the conditions for youthful offenders at the Bikers Island Reformatory.

title: Commuters in Philadelphia Manage Despite 2 Strikes
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (UPI)More than a million commuters overcame two transit strikes today to get to work in traffic that police said was moving better on the average than it had on the first day of the walkout.

title: Europeans Display A Revived Interest In U.S. Investing
description: PARIS, April 13Europe's financial institutions are accelerating their purchases of WallStreet shares, banks and brokerage houses in several key centers reported today.

title: 2 GUARDS CHARGED WITH USING FORCE
description: The City Department of Correction disclosed yesterday the suspension of two correction officers for allegedly using unnecessary force against an inmate at the Bellevue prison ward.

title: Sports of The Times
description: I have one request to make, said Thurman Munson Ron Hansen, his teammate. Just don't get nervous.

title: Suit on Knitting Machines is Filed by Jonathan Logan
description: Jonathan Logan, Inc., has filed a suit for $7.5million damages against four Spartanburg, S. C., companies and six individuals on changes that they diverted knitting inachines ordered by Logan to be sold to their concerns. Several of the individual defendants are former officers of Butte Knitting Mills, a Logan division.

title: Outlook Is Guarded At United Aircraft
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 13It will be another few weeks before the United Aircraft Corporation issues its firstquarter results, but business could be better, William P. Gwinn, the company's chairman, replied tersely here today when he was asked, How's your business?

title: Gulf Oil and United Nuclear Sign Pact for Reactor Tie
description: A preliminary agreement was signed yesterday by the United Nuclear Corporation and the Gulf Oil Corporation for the formation of a jointly owned company to design, manufacture and sell nuclear fuel for lightwater nuclear power re actors. A final agreement is contingent upon approval by boards of both companies.

title: Vermont Backs Voting at 18
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 13 (AP)A proposed amendment to the state Constitution granting 18yearolds the right to vote passed the Vermont House today on a rollcall vote, of 142 to 4. The measure passed the Senate last week. The amendment requires ratification by a succeeding biennial legislative session and must be submitted to a referendum.

title: Amsterdam News Will Be Sold
description: The New York Amsterdam Newsone of the country's largest black newspapersis about to be sold by its surviving partner, Dr. Clilian B. Powell, its 75yearold president and editor.

title: Cosmetics: A Proposal For Safety
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)President Nixon's consumer adviser disclosed today that cosmetics makers have offered to let the Government know what the industry puts in its productsso long as the Government keeps the list of ingredients secret.

title: Advertising:
description: It was a big day yesterday on the magazine front, with a couple of announcements about two new hooks emanating from news conferences held in Manhattan.

title: Philadelphia Arbitration Set
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (UPI)A Common Pleas Court judge has ordered binding arbitration in a public schools dispute that stemmed from the forced transfer of a fifthgrade teacher. During the arbitration, which will be at least 15 days but not more than 30, the schools will stay open for some 290,000 pupils. Judge D. Donald Jamieson signed the order yesterday bringing together the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers and the school board.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It probably is too much to hope that Governor Rockefeller and William Ronan read the two excellent OpEd articles on transportation by Lewis Mumford in The Times a couple of weeks ago.

title: ALGERIA RAISING 0IL PRICE IN RIFT
description: ALGIERS, April 13President Houari Boumediene today announced a substantial increase in the posted price of Algerian oil and called for a large reduction in Algeria's wine production. Both moves were related to the stalled negotiations with France, Algeria's major trading partner,

title: India Studies Statement
description: NEW DELHI, April 13The Indian Government reacted with silence today to an indirect warning last night from Communist China that the Chinese would stand firmly behind Pakistan against any aggression by India.

title: CELANESE COATINGS TO LIFT PRICES MAY 1
description: The Celanese Coatings Company, a subsidiary of the Celanese Corporation, announced yesterday that it would increase prices on selected product lines in its automotive and industrial divisions, effective May 1.

title: New Jersey Finds Its TV Voice With Channel 52
description: The Voice of New Jersey is being heard this week on television. On April 5 WNJT in Trenton began operation, the First of four stations designed to blanket the state with personalities, discussion of problems, regular evening news, a program for aspiring artists and a special presentation for black viewers.

title: English Says the City May Have to Close 8 Hospitals if State Budget Cuts Are Not Modified
description: A warning that eight of the 18 municipal hospitals may close unless Albany rescinds state budget cutbacks and the city gets new taxing powers was made public yesterday by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Apparent Escape at Attica Stirs Rumors and Disbelief
description: ATTICA, N. Y., April 13Fewer of the Attica Correctional Facility's guards have been coming into Glor's Soda Bar for morning coffee before work these last five days.

title: G.E. in Tokyo Silicone Tie
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with the Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company, Ltd., to manufacture silicone products in Japan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Because of the widespread popular assumption of the legality (not, of course, the propriety) of President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case, a word might be in order on the law of the matter.

title: JOHNSMANVILLE SEEKS HOLOPHANE
description: The JohnsManville Corporation announced yesterday it has submitted a proposal to directors of the Holophane Company, Inc., manufacturer of lighting fixtures, to acquire the company for about $58,475,000 in lighting field and its largest acquisition since it acquired the LOF Glass Fibers Company for $56.8 Amillion in 1958. In commenting on the offer by the manufacturer of constructtion materials and supplier of asbestos, Clarence C. Keller, president of Holophane, said he was surprised and flattered by the offer but Holophane directors won't consider the offer un

title: G.O.P. Foe of Nixon Sums Up Views He Found in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 (UPI)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the California Republican, who has said that he will challenge President Nixon in ?? 1972 primaries if he not ended the war by then, said today that most Americans he had met in South Vietnam felt that we can leave by the end of the year.

title: Gurfein Is Named to Post As U.S District Judge Here
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) Senators Jacob K. Javits and James L. Buckley announced today that President Nixon had nominated Murray I. Gurfein of New York City as a judge for the Southern District of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Times has not anything in print less fair:

title: U.S. Downgrades 2 More Vietnam Commands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13The United States command soon will downgrade its command system in South Vietnam's two middle military regions to reflect the United States Army's transition from a combat role to a support and advisory function, military sources disclosed today.

title: Lummus Will Build Plant
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., said yesterday that its Lummus Company subsidiary had obtained a contract to design and build a $10million pharmaceutical plant in Omaha for the Upjohn Company to make Lincomycin, a mediumspectrum antibiotic.

title: Gibson Set to Offer School Compromise
description: NEWARK, April 13Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson is preparing a new public proposal to try to end the bitter 11weekold teachers strike here, including a list of compromises already made by the union.

title: Kennedy Visits 3 Hospitals Here On Trip for Senate Health Unit
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy toured three of the city's hospital emergency rooms last night to find out, he said, how patients feel about medical. care in this city.

title: Daily Double Pays $3,168,  Highest at Big A Since 67
description: A dailydouble payoff of $3,168.20 for a $2 ticket provided the big news at Aqueduct yesterday as Cragwood Stable's 39to1 Upward Bound and Joseph A. Gilosa's 45toAurora Nymph won the program's first two races in that order.

title: Mr. Aurelio's Image
description: It is indisputable that image is an important political ingredient. What has always been true throughout political history is even more true in this era of electronic communications when a candidate's image appears every voter's living room.

title: Nisel Is in Lead
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 13 (AP)Norman Y. Mineta, who spent two boyhood years in World War 11 relocation camps, complied a strong lead tonight in early returns in a 15way race that could make him the first JapaneseAmerican elected Mayor of a major American city.

title: PROTESTERS HALT RELIEF BRIEFING
description: A briefing session exploded into a shouting match yesterday when Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman tried to explain the new state budget cuts that affect the poor to about 500 community representatives.

title: A.U.C. EXCHAIRMAN SELLS 48,500 SHARES
description: DETROIT, April 13 (AP)The sale of 48,500 shares of American Motors Corporation stock by Robert Eyans, former chairman of the company, has left Roy D. Chapin, the current board chairman, as A.M.C.'s largest single stockholder.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your March 2 editorial A Poet's Wilderness states, Conservationists contend that the proposed highway can be kept entirely out of the Joyce KilmerSlick Rock area by constructing it south of the wilderness where a secondary road already exists.

title: Ne Win Returns to London
description: LONDON, April 13Gen Ne Win, chairman of the Burmese Revolutionary Council, returned to London from New Delhi today for medical treatment.

title: $258Million City Bonds Sold at Lowered Interest
description: The city sold a record $258.1million worth of public improve ment bonds yesterday and then sought to give the lie to criticism that it was financially shaky.

title: Profits in Heroin Equipment Are Cited at Heaing
description: The State Commission of Investigation estimated yesterday that the owner of a small Harlem variety store and his partner made a gross profit of at least $135,650 selling heroin paraphernalia such as glassine envelopes during a recent fourmonth period.

title: Gang Holds 14, Then Gets $250,000 at an Army Post
description: Three masked robbersdescribed as friendly, polite and helpfulkidnapped a bank executive, held him overnight in a relative's home on Staten Island along with 13 of his relatives and friends, then forced him at gunpoint yesterday to help them steal about $250,000 from his bank at a military base in Brooklyn.

title: On the Island of Ceylon, Now Swept by Guerrilla Fighting, Insurgency Is Considered Out of Character
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Officials here view the insurgency of young rebels against the government in Ceylon as out of character for the island nation.

title: Bengalis Form a Cabinet As the Bloodshed Goes On
description: AGARTALA, India, April 13Although large numbers of East Pakistani secessionist leaders have been reported killed, and with wholesale bloodshed continuing, several members of the movement's high command are alive and have formed a cabinet.

title: On the Town, Hit in '44, Is Being Revived
description: A Broadway revival of On the Town, the Betty Cornden, Adolph Green, Leonard Bernstein and Jerome Robbins musical hit of 1944, is in the making for next season.

title: Secessionists Claim Sovereignty
description: NEW DELHI, April 12 (UPI) The secessionists who have declared the creation of Bangla Desh  Bengal Nation  proclaimed sovereignty over East Pakistan today and appealed to all democratic countries for recognition and assistance in the civil war with West Pakistan.

title: SEALE IS LINKED TO SLAIN PANTHER
description: NEW HAVEN, April 13For the first time since the prosecution opened its case against Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins nearly four weeks ago, the jury heard testimony today linking Mr. Seale with Alex Rackley, the man he is alleged to have helped kidnap and murder.

title: BESIEGED OUTPOST GETS SOME RELIEF
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 14Lead elements of a big South Vietnamese relief force reached Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands last night and more reinforcements poured in today, easing the pressure on the frontier outpost, which has been under siege for two weeks.

title: Lewis Rites Tomorrow
description: A memorial service for Robert C. Lewis, an assistant editor of The New York Times Magazine who died on Monday, will be held at 10 A.M. tomorrow at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Metropolitan Museum, 101, Celebrates With a Party
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art was feeling festive yesterday. It was simultaneously bringing to a close its highly publicized centennial year and celebrating its 101st birthday. So it threw an openhouse party and everyone was invited.

title: New Series of Nine Races Set In Small Sports Car Category
description: Big things have been planned for the little cars by the Sports Car Club of America. A ninerace program has been drawn up for the TwoFive Challenge series, which Is the competition for cars with engine displacements of 2.5 liters or less. In announcing the schedule, Hank Loudenback, the S.C.C.A. director of professional racing, said that it was possible two more dates would be added.

title: Arts Club to Give Medal To Ada Louise Huxtable
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, architecture and urban development writer and critic for The New York Times, will receive the gold medal for literature awarded annually by the National Arts Club. Presentation of the medal will be made tonight at a dinner at the club, 15 Gramercy Park.

title: French Withhold Comment
description: PARIS, April 13French officials withheld comment today on the oil measures announced in Algiers by President Boumediene, but uncertainty arose as a result of the Algerian move as to whether Herve Alphand, Secretary General of the Foreign Ministry, would return Thursday to Algiers for another attempt at a settlement.

title: Antiwar Women Chain Themselves to Fence
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Thirtyesven members of a group calling itself Women for Peace and Justice chained themselves this morning to a fence around the Old Executive Office Building, adjacent to the White House.

title: William Esty Is Picked To Handle S.A.S. Ads
description: Scandinavian Airlines System, with billings of about $2.7million in the United States, picked the William Esty Company yesterday to handle its NorthAmerican advertising.

title: $51MILLION MORE FOR MALL BACKED
description: ALBANY, April 13State Controller Arthur Levitt today approved an additional payment of. $51.9million to South Mall contractors but recommended legislation giving the state power to cancel construction contracts.

title: Peking Grants Visa to New York Times Reporter
description: HONG KONG, April 13Tillman Durdin, the chief of the Hong Kong bureau of The New, York Times and a longtime reporter on Asian affairs, was authorized a visa today to enter Communist China.

title: Impact of Inflation Stressed by Laird; F14 Inquiry Is On
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird explained today that inflation constantly overtakes weapons systems because they take so longfive to nine years to develop.

title: The Ultimate Pleasure
description: Every morning at the Institute of Psychiatry in London my rabbits excitedly push their heads forward as I fit small plugs to them. The plugs come in contact with thin platinum wires that sit permanently in their brains. When I let go, the animals rush to a lever and start pressing it down with their noses, some 500 times in 15 minutes. Each time they press the lever a miniscule amount of electricity flows to the platinum wires and causes activity in the brain cells there. The wires are in the socalled pleasure areas and the rabbits press the lever because the electricity gives them pleasure.

title: PRICES DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING Index Down 0.02 to 26.42 Volume Shows a Rise
Soviet Stressing Big Equipment
description: MOSCOW, April 13Soviet designers and manufacturers appear to be entering an era of gigantism in the production of equipment for the nation's industry.

title: I.R.S. Cites Private School
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had told a private schoolFayette Academy in Somerville, Tenn. that contributions for its operations were no longer tax deductible because it failed to adopt nondiscriminatory admissions policies. It is the first time that the I.R.S. has applied its new policy of holding back taxexempt status for such private academies outstide the state of Mississippi.

title: What Hath Man Wrought?
description: The first of the Post Office Department's many improvements, as it slowly converts itself into the new United States Postal Service, is somewhat more explosive than a new commemorative stamp issue and somewhat less than a damp firecracker.

title: SUSPECT CONVICTED OF POLICE MURDER
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn last night found a 21yearold man guilty of the holdup murder last year of an offduty policeman.

title: McCarthy to Teach Poetry at the U.of Maryland
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy has, agreed to teach poetry this fall at the University of Maryland in nearby College Park.

title: G.M. Explains Record
description: DETROIT, April 13  The General Motors Corporation is sending a 49page book describing G.M.'s work in air pollution, safety, abandoned car cleanup and minority hiring to its 1.3 million stockholders.

title: In Israeli Manner, Caftans and Shorts
description: You don't have to be Jewish to model Israeli fashions.

title: Ellender Suggests Congress Could Free Impounded Funds by Halting Outlays for Nixon Programs
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Senator Allen J. Ellender, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, raised the threat today that Congress would withhold funds for Administration programs unless the White House frees some $13billion in impounded funds already appropriated by Congress.

title: Impossible School Crisis
description: TRENTON, April 13While Newark's Police Director, John L. Redden, was warning that guns were being loaded and that the city seemed on the verge of new racial violence, Gov. William T. Cahill was vacationing yesterday in the Virgin Islands and both houses of the New Jersey Legislature were taking their annual Easter recess. Although officials of New Jersey's largest city were saying that the teachers strike now in its 11th week, had precipitated a crisis, the major concern of the Governor's office during the last 48 hours has been, not of Newark, but a proposal for a mammoth sports complex in the Hackensack meadowlands. The measure underwent a public hearing here yesterday, and the Governor, who is spending a long week at St. Croix, left word to be informed of any important developments regarding it.

title: MRS. R. R. BELKNAP, WIDOW OF ADMIRAL
description: Mrs. Julia Averill Belknap, widow of Rear Adm. Reginald R. Belknap and for many years active in the parish affairs of Trinity Church (Episcopal) here, died yesterday in Van Dyk Manor, Montclair, N.J., following a short illness. She was 95 years old.

title: Motta Voted N.B.A Coach of Year
description: Dick Motta's accomplishment of leading the Chicago Bulls to their first winning season was rewarded yesterday with his selection as the National Basketball Association coach of the year.

title: RCA's Off
description: The RCA Corporation's firstquarter earnings declined despite higher sales, Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: Environmental Chief sacks Nader on Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that he agreed with Ralph Nader's criticism of Federal programs to combat water pollution, and added that he was working to clean up the nation's waterways.

title: Belfast Boy Is Shot in Leg During a Protestant Parade
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 13A 12yearold boy was injured by a burst of automatic gunfire that broke the uneasy peace today after four days of Easter marches.

title: PRISONERS'PROTEST IS QUELLED IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 13Inmates of the turbulent penitentiary in Turin ran wild all night in rebellion that started with protest against Italy's archaic system of criminal justice.

title: G.M. SEEKS TOEHOLD IN FAR EAST MARKET
description: TOKYO, April 13 (UPI)James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corpora. tion said today G.M. had no intention of taking over Isuzu Motor, a leading Japanese automobile maker, through a capital tieup between the two companies. Mr. Roche, who arrived for a series of talks with Japanese Government and Isuzu officials to complete the proposed capital tieup with Isuzu, said G.M. hoped to buy 35 per cent of Isuzu's stock. The Government has been reluctant to approve it for fear of a takeover.

title: Solzhenitsyn Said to Seek Publisher for New Novel
description: MOSCOW, April 13 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was reported today to have offered his latest novel, August 1914, to several Soviet publishing houses in the hope that the authorities would end the ban on the printing of his works in this country.

title: A SPRING CLEANUP PLANNED BY CITY
description: Treat the city with carewith loving affection, Mayor Lindsay pleaded yesterday in urging New Yorkers to join in a spring cleanup of the city's streets.

title: LEVINE WILL ROW AS MET CONDUCTOR
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present a twoweek June Festival of 14 performances beginning May 31 and continuing through June 12. Two performances of Verdi's Aida, Rigoletto, and 11 Trovatore, Puccinis Madame Butterfly, La Boheme and Tosca and Mozart's Don Giovanni will be presented.

title: Taiwan Asks Gulf Oil Ship To Resume Work Off Islands
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 13 (AP)The Chinese Nationalist Government asked the Gulf Oil Corporation today to resume exploration for undersea oil around the disputed Senkaku Islands.

title: G. &
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., yesterday predicted that the conglomerate's earnings for the fiscal year ending July 31 would be 15 per cent higher than the year earlier. He had previously forecast a 5 to 15 per cent increase.

title: Public Appeal for Help Made by Mrs. Crimmins
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins appealed to the public yesterday to help her prove that she did not kill her two children six years ago.

title: Knicks, Despite Letdown, Are Favored Tonight
description: BALTIMORE, April 13 With the odds still overwhelmingly in their favor, but last Sunday's lesson fresh in their mind, the Knicks will resume their National Basketball Association playoff series with the Baltimore Bullets tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. The game will be televised in New York over Channel 9.

title: Changing U.S. Attitude on China
description: WASHINGTON, April 13When President Nixon asked Henry Cabot Lodge at the White House today whether he had learned to play PingPong yet, he was betraying the obvious fascination of this Government with the prospect of further dealings with Peking. And as the President's lighthearted tone suggested, he is confident that he could have a new relationship and escape the political restraints that he, among others, helped to create for previous Presidents.

title: O. A. S. ASSEMBLY TO HEAR ROGERS
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 13Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived today for the General Assembly of the Organization of American States, which will review hemispheric relations under the Nixon Administration.

title: After a 2Year Lapse, China Accepts U.S. Call
description: Mainland China accepted telephone call from the United States yesterday for the first time in nearly two and a half years, the American Telephone & Telegraph Company's long lines department said.

title: BAR UNIT SCORES CONVICT JOB CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13A special commission formed by the American Bar Association to upgrade correctional methods announced today that it would attempt to eliminate state and Federal laws that prohibit many former convicts from holding good jobs.

title: Businessman in San Diego Imprisoned for Tax Fraud
description: SAN DIEGO, April 13 (UPI) John Alessio, 60 years old, millionaire San Diego businessman who heads the Caliente race track in Mexico, was sentenced to Federal prison today for income tax cheating.

title: Murtagh Upheld in Contempt Ruling at Panther Pretrial Hearing
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh's contemptofcourt citation of a disruptive spectator has been unanimously upheld by a State Court of Appeals decision that declared that the court is not a public hall for the expression of views, nor is it a political arena or a street.

title: CEYLON GETS AID TO FIGHT REBELS
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 13 The Government of Ceylon is receiving military aid from Britain, India and Pakistan in its efforts to combat radical insurgents trying to take over the island nation.

title: Blakeley Resigns as Coach
description: DALLAS, April 13 (AP)Bill Blakeley bowed out today as coach of the Texas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association.

title: COALITION SEEKING NEW YOUTH VOTERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Representatives of labor, youth and civil rights organizations discussed here today possibilities for cooperation in mobilizing the new youth vote for the national election in 1972.

title: Romaine Brooks: Revelation in Art
description: The American expatriate painter Romaine Brooks died in Nice last December at the ago of 96. Although her name frequently turns up in memoirs and biographies of the European cultural scene in the earlier decades of the 20th centuryespecially that part of the scene where the literary and artistic intelligentsia and the upperclass homosexual world met in the salons of the haut mondeshe is virtually unknown as an artist, in this country. The small exhibition of her work that has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, is, therefore, a revelation.

title: Bridge: American Association Opens Spring National Play Today
description: A contingent of more than 100 players from the New York metropolitan area begin play today in Cleveland at the spring national championships of the American Bridge Association, the organization for Negro enthusiasts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The letter written by Capt. Aubrey M. Daniel 3d to President Nixon should be read and studied by everyone in America who is interested in the administering of justice. When the President long ago spoke about the need for lowering voices, Captain Daniel was one of those who took him seriously.

title: Chinese Tact Lets Us Lose Gracefully
description: PEKING, April 13Visiting United States table tennis players met a Chinese team today before 18,000 cheering enthusiasts in a match that could be described as an exquisite display of Chinese tact and politeness to guests.

title: CHINA'S AMBASSADOR ACCEPTED BY CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 13Ralph E. Collins, an Assistant UnderSecretary in the Department of External Affairs, today was formally named Canada's first Ambassador to Communist China. It was reported last month that Peking had accepted his nomination.

title: South Vietnam's Police Force Gaining In Size and Status as U. S. Increases Aid
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13  The South Vietnamese national police force is quickly expanding in size and influence here, largely because of increased American financial support and an organizational change that moved the police command to the highest levels of the Government.

title: MICHAEL ROSENAUER, ARCHITECT, WAS 86
description: LONDON, April 13  Michael Rosenauer. an Austrianborn American architect with offices in London and a studio in Manhattan, died Sunday of pneumonia at his home here in Grosvenor square. He was 86 years old.

title: ExMorton Aide Wins House Primary in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Apil 13 (UPI)William O. Mills, Republican, and State Senator Elroy Boyer, Democrats won nominations in special primary elections today to the Congressional seat vacated by Rogers C. B. Morton when he became Secretary of the Interior.

title: Jets and Giants Face Rugged Schedules
description: The Giants and Jets face rugged group of opponents next season in the National Football League schedule, which Was issued yesterday. Seven of the Jets 14 games will be against foes who were in the playoffs last season.

title: Mistrial in Census Case
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 13 (AP)A mistrial has been declared in the case of state Representative Thomas L. Little, who is under indictment for refusing to answer all the questions on his 1970 Census form. The jury stayed out one hour and 40 minutes before coming back without a verdict yesterday in the Federal court trial.

title: U.S. Team Sends Bid to China
description: WASHINGTON, April 13, (Reuters)The Washington. Darts of the North American Soccer League announced tonight that it had sent Premier Chow Enlai of China an invitation to send a team here to play.

title: 62d U.S.Soviet Session On Arms Held in Vienna
description: VIENNA, April 13 (Reuters) American and Soviet delegates met for 90 minutes at the Soviet Embassy here today for the 62d session of the talks on the limitation of strategic arms.

title: WILLIAM H. CAMERON JR.
description: MIDDLETOWN, Del., April 13 William H. Cameron Jr., headmaster of St. Andrew's School, died yesterday in Wilmington Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Looking for an Offbeat Gift?
description: Over the shop door, a fake stainedglass panel shows an oldfashioned girl arminarm with a mustached man in a top hat. When it first arrived, Brian Hall and Kurt Schuster thought it looked either like a nasty old man with designs on young girls or a rich uncle taking his niece on a shopping spree. They preferred the latter interpretation, and so the store at 1452 Second Avenue (76th Street) was dubbed My Rich Uncle Henry, as befits the East Side area where thinking up a provocative store name is half the game. (The boutique next door is called Eddie Fatootsie.) Besides, the proprietors are fond of cute names, perhaps because Mr. Hall is an advertising copywriter. Before they started the shop, they'd collaborated in a greeting card company called Grandma Pickle and Her Boys.

title: Martin Fennelly, Officer Of W. R. Grace Division, 56
description: Martin J. Fennelly, director of financial services for the chemical group of W. R. Grace & Co., Inc., died yesterday in Rosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 668 West Short trial, Sparta, N. J.

title: PAPER COMPANY LISTS DROP IN NET
description: Sharply lower earnings on slight improvement in sales in the first quarter were reported yesterday by the International Paper Company.

title: Pakistan Reports Seizing Indian Arms in Victory
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 13 The Pakistan radio said tonight that Pakistani troops had destroyed all miscreants in the area of Dinajpur in East Pakistan and had captured large amounts of Indian arms and ammunition.

title: MAN IS ACQUITTED IN TORTURE KILLING
description: BALTIMORE, April 13Charles Wyche was acquitted yesterday on charges that he had been the gunman in the murder of a Black Panther sympathizer suspected of being police informer.

title: G.M. CRITICS WOO FUNDS'
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Campaign G.M., the organization that is trying to force the General Motors Corporation to change some of its policies, is moving to enlist the nation's six million mutualfund shareholders in its battle.

title: The Unfairness Doctrine
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The American Society of Newspaper Editors is in Washington again for its annual skull practice, and this year it has some serious questions to discuss, for all news reporters and editorsradio and television even more than newspaperare under mounting pressure from all branches of the Government and from the public as well.

title: 3 BANK TRUSTEES RESIGN POSITIONS
description: The Federal Reserve Board's drive against interlocking directorates between competing financial institutions has led three top officers of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to resign as trustees of mutual savings banks here.

title: U.S. Acknowledges Sales of Ammunition to Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON April 13The State Department conceded today that the United States had been selling approximately $2.5million worth of ammunition yearly to Pakistan since 1967 as nonlethal equipment.

title: TV: WellareAn Agonizing Problem
description: The subject is welfare and few subjects can generate more misinformed and misguided emotion all the way from the corner barroom to the elegant cocktail party. Tonight at 10 P.M. the question of public assistance will be considered for an hour on The Anatomy of Welfare, a presentation of the American Broadcasting Company's news department.

title: Symbol of Urban Disaster
description: The cleavages highlighted by the Newark school strike go far beyond education to the basic issue of civic survival. Unless Mayor Gibson and the moderates still standing with him in the black and white communities can reintroduce sanity into the handling of Newark's catastrophic problems, racial extremists are likely turn that tormented city into an allblack compound under militant rule.

title: The Dance: Rock Opera a Ballet
Arson Barred in Coast Fire
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., April 13 (AP)The fire that destroyed part of the administration building at the University of California's Santa Cruz campus last Thursday was accidental in Origin and not arson, as had been suspected, the authorities have reported.

title: Mugging Victim Dies
description: RAHWAY, N. J., April 13A 63yearold victim of a mugging last night died today in the Rahway Memorial Hospital of head injuries. The police said the victim, Talmadge P. Bragg of Raleigh, N. C., was found in the rear of the Rahway Tavern, 212 St. George Avenue. The police said Mr. Bragg was visiting relatives here.

title: Nerine Barrett Winner Of Young Artists Award
description: Nerine Barrett, a 27yearold Jamaican pianist who lives in London, has been named winner of the first Michaels Award to be administered by Young Concert Artists, a nonprofit management organization.

title: Deportation Is Upheld for Draft Evader
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 13In a split decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled yesterday that a Georgia student may be deported to Canada because he renounced his citizenship in order to escape the draft.

title: Circus on Friday Canceled For Knicks Playoff Game
description: Both performances of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus scheduled for Friday have been preempted by the fifth game of the New York Knickerbockers playoff series against the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that the facts of Mylai have been proved before a court of law, wonder whether any thought has been given to honoring those who were present and refused to obey the reprehensible order to kill unarmed captives. To refuse to obey any direct orders in the field bespeaks high courage as well as moral sense, and the honorable questioning of orders should not pass unnoticed.

title: Permit on Dumping Waste In Sound Issued by Army
description: NEW HAVEN, April 13 While one arm of the Federal Government has been trying to stop waste discharges that have polluted Long Island Sound, another armwithout the knowledge of the firsthas routinely approved the use of the Sound as the dump for industrial waste.

title: KOJI TOYODA MAKES VIOLIN DEBUT IN U.S.
description: A noble tone, technical clat and a useful range of nuance are among the violinistic virtues possessed by Koji Toyoda, who made his United States debut at Tully Hall on Monday night.

title: EDWARD F. EVANS
description: ALBERTSON, L. I., April 13Edward F. Evans, an account executive with A. C. Nielsen & Co., marketing research organization, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 55 Argyle Road here.

title: Troops Will Leave, but Many Britons Won't Forsake the Charms of Bahrain
description: RIFAA AL GHARBI, Bahrain, April 2Joyous shrieks pierced the regal calm of the weekly horse and camel races staged here by Bahrain's ruling sheik. They came from a group of blond British children who were tormenting a big black beetle they had just found lumbering over the sand near the Ruler's seat.

title: Aline Saarinen to Head Paris Bureau for N.B.C.
description: Aline Saarinen, news correspondent and art critic, has been named chief of the Paris bureau of the National Broadcasting Company, the first woman to head an overseas bureau in television. She will replace Garrick Utley, who is returning to New York in May to become permanent host on the magazine program First Tuesday.

title: BIG BOARD APPROVES DEAL FOR SASSOWER
description: Arcs Industries, Inc. a small diversified concern, announced yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange had approved a plan for Arcs to acquire 20 per cent of the equity of Sassower, Jacobs & Schneider, Inc., a member house of the exchange.

title: YIELDS UNCHANGED IN FANNY MAY SALE
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) Interest rates were virtually unchanged today in the Federal National Mortgage Association's auction of $54.6million in mortgagepurchase commitments.

title: Parents Save Moneyand Children Have Fun
description: I've looked at so many bunk beds in department stores  and those Tinker Toylike environments, tooand either they're too expensive or they just aren't safe, said Mm. Waiter J. Jamieson Jr.

title: Bonn Links Improved Ties With East Bloc to Berlin
description: BONN, April 13West Germany is willing to pursue all means of improving its relations with the Soviet Union and other countries of the Communist bloc, but only if some satisfaction is achieved on the status of Berlin, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Berkeley Election Results Are Certified by Council
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 13 The Berkeley City Council officially certified today the results of the April 6 municipal elections.

title: Israeli Canal Plan Reported
description: JERUSALEM, April 13 (UPI) Israeli proposals for a limited withdrawal from the Suez Canal may be submitted to Washington next week, diplomatic sources reported here today.

title: JAMES M'GURRIN, EXCOUNTY CLERK
description: James McGurrin, former County Clerk of New York County, former head of the Division of Jurors, an author and a leading participant in IrishAmerican affairs, died yesterday in his sleep at his home, 60 Gramercy Park, apparently of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Tuesday Weld Festival Set
description: Ten films featuring Tuesday Weld will be revived during the week startling April 21 at the Eighth Street Playhouse. The opening double bill includes The Cincinnati Kid and Rally Round the Flag Boys. Subsequent dual offerings will be: Sex Kitten Goes to College and Private Lives of Adam and Eve"; Pretty Poison and Lord Love a Duck"; Wild in the Country and I Walk the Line"; and Bachelor Flat and Soldier in the Rain.

title: Roundup: No One Pirate Good Enough for Award
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates. devilish rogues that they are, will be remembered in the annals of baseball gimmickry as the inventors of such awards as the Black Max and the Green Weanie. Both have walked planks into nostalgia, but the Pirates, undaunted, have invented a successorThe Horse's Tail.

title: KAHANE SENTENCED TO PAY FINE OF $500
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane was sentenced yesterday to pay $500 or serve 90 days in jail on a conviction arising from a demonstration two years ago near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Market Place: New Prospects For Micro Scan
description: What happens when a man leaves his job, sets up shop in a holeinthewall to design and sell a product?

title: Executive Changes
description: Revlon, Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of Victor Barnett to the newly created position of executive vice president administration. Mr. Barnett has also been nominated to the board of directors and will be named a member of the executive committee. Mr. Barnett was previously vice president and assistant to the chairman since 1966. Before joining Revlon in 1961, Mr. Barnett was president of Burberrys (USA) and director of Burberrys Ltd. of England. In his new post he will have responsibility for an financial, legal, administrative and organizational planning areas within the company.

title: Transkei Chief's Demand Rejected by South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14The South African Government indicated today that it had no intention of conceding to a demand by the chief minister of the Transkei tribal homeland, Kaiser Matanzima, that administrative and executive powers be handed over to the territory, including the key departments.

title: Dream of Kings Takes Aqueduct Dash
description: Moving his mount into the lead at the start and keeping him there all the way, Angel Cordero Jr. rode Bobby Dotter's Dream of Kings to a ninelength triumph in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. There were only four competitors in the test for older horses, yet Dream of Kings returned $6 for $2 in taking the sevenfurlong race.

title: MUSKIE SAYS FE SPIED AT RALLIES ON 70 EARTH DAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Senator Edmund S. Muskie charged today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted widespread surveillance of last year's antipollution rallies on Earth Day, including his own appearance before a Washington meeting.

title: Henry Roth: No Longer at Home
description: Continuity was destroyed when his family moved from snug, orthodox 9th Street, from the homogeneous East Side to rowdy, heterogeneous Harlem, normal continuity was destroyed. The tenets, the ways, the faith were discarded too drastically, too rapidly. That may have been what he sensed when he wrote his novel, that may have been a kind of subliminal theme, dominating him without his knowing it. And once continuity was destroyed, there would always be a sense of loss afterward, an insecurityeven though he might ultimately say good riddance to all that was so abruptly terminated. Therein perhaps lay the explanation for the failure, not only his own, but or so many gifted literary people, his contemporaries, who in one way or another, for one reason or another ceased to develop creatively. The whole question needed exploration and study....

title: LowIncome Project Started
description: The New York City Housing Authority, which runs lowincome public housing here, announced the beginning of construction yesterday of 233apartment project in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. The 19story proiect, which will cost $7.9million, will occupy a 2.2acre site at Bailey Avenue and West 193d Street. It is expected by authority officials to be completed by the end of 1972.

title: Yankees Top Tigers, 84, as Alou Clouts in Debut
N. F. Gyurkey Weds Mrs. Morgan
description: MIDDLEBURY, Conn., April 14Mrs. Tania Goss Morgan of Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married in the Middlebury Congregational Church this morning to Nicholas Ferdinand Gyurkey of Hackensack, N. J., and Bondville, Vt. The Rev. Charles Luckey performed the ceremony.

title: ROSEWALL GAINS SO, AFRICA FINAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 14 (UPI)Ken Rosewall and Fred Stolle scored victories today to set up an allAustralian men's singles final at the $51,000 South African open tennis championships.

title: Faulkner Jeered in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 14 (UPI) Several hundred Protestants jeered Prime Minister Brian Faulkner today and threw stones and bottles at his car when he toured an area in Belfast where rioters were protesting the shooting of a 12yearold boy.

title: OSCARS TO MARK 43D YEAR TONIGHT
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 14The annual Motion Picture Academy Awards will be presented tomorrow night for the 43d time and this year interest centers on a man who insists he does not want one.

title: GEORGE Z. WHITEHEAD
description: George Z. Whitehead, a textile importer and distributor, died on Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 17 Greenway, Road, Lido Beach, L. I.

title: IMPERIAL TO BUY ATLAS CHEMICAL
description: LONDON, April 14Britain's largest industrial concern, Imperial Chemical Industries, announced here today that it would buy out Atlas, Chemical Industries, Inc. of Wilmington, Del.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In this time of economic crisis at the New York City Board of Education I am very much surprised that nothing is being said about the money being received from the New York State Lottery which is supposed to be used for education.

title: Queens Man Dies as Result Of Beating by Three Youths
description: A 60yearold man injured in an assault by three youths while out walking his dog in Queens Tuesday night died early yesterday morning in Jamaica Hospital, the police reported.

title: Philippine C47 Crashes
description: MANILA, Thursday, April 15 (AP)A Philipine Air Force C47 transport plane crashed today shortly after it had taken off on a flight from central Luzon to Manila. First reports said that 21 of 27 persons aboard had been killed.

title: Excerpts From Studies of Priesthood
description: Sociological Study

title: DANIEL J. KENNY
description: MALVERNE, L. I., April 14Daniel S. Kenny, retired clerk of Special Term, Part I, of State Supreme Court, New York County, died Monday after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 146 Malverne Avenue.

title: Common Stock Is Offered By Northern Illinois Gas
description: The Northern Illinois Gas Company is offering 900,000 shares of its common stock to the public at 32 a share, it was announced yesterday by an underwriting group that had won the award of the shares on its bid of $32.095 a share.

title: U.S. Team Reaches. Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, Thursday, April 15 (UP)  The American table tennis team arrived in Shanghai today. It will go to Canton tomorrow and return to Hong Kong on Saturday,

title: Books of The Times
description: Both of these books sound like throwbacks to another and unhappy time, for they deal with hunger in Americaa situation too many people still need to be persuaded exists. They deal with other matters, too: loss of pride and dignity; the blighting of children's lives, the narrowing of horizons, the resentment that builds up in a man's mind under unending economic pressure until it takes heaven knows what form. But these are dividends of the basic need. The problem of the people studied in these books, who live in the Mississippi Delta and in Appalachia, in the eastern part of Kentucky, is how to get through the month fed and warm. Both books are forthright and uncluttered. They are free of jargon and sociological rhetoric. And they cover roughly the same ground, except that half of Tony Dunbar's volume is devoted to the blacks in the Delta, Louise, whereas Bill Surface restricts himself to Appalachia. Their methods resemble each other a trifle, too. Both took down verbatim the talk of the people they interviewed. Mr. Dunbar, a young and earnest Southerner who has worked on various community programs, quotes from them in formal question and answer paragraphs when they suit his need. Mr. Surface, magazine writer and native Kentuckian, has used the talk to give an almost fictional finish to his chapters as he shares the life of one family for five days in the heart of winter. But there is a very visible difference between the two that is going to provoke passionate, fingerpointing disagreement.

title: Greene County Eager to Open Its Betting Shops
description: While OTB spurred itself through a sixth day of operation yesterday, a new offtrack entry named CompuBet whinnied impatiently behind the starting gate.

title: BritishChinese Phone Link to Open After 22 Years
description: LONDON, April 14  A direct telephone connection between, Britain and Communist China will reopen tomorrow after a break of 22 years.

title: Ceylon Thanks Nations for Aid In Her Fight to Quell Insurgents
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 14 (AP)Prime Minister Sirimavo. Bandaranaike has thanked friendly countries for supplying urgently needed equip, ment for her troops and policemen fighting youthful insurgents.

title: ELIZABETH B. SPRAGUE
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., April 14  Mrs. Elizabeth Bennett Sprague, former assistant fiction editor of The New York Herald Tribune and This Week magazine, died yesterday after a short illness. She was 71 years old.

title: QUEENS SCHOOL AIDE RESIGNS IN PROTEST
description: Mrs. Katherine James announced her resignation yesterday as acting president and vice president of the District 28 community school board in Queens.

title: POTATO FUTURES SHOW INCREASE
description: Activity in the Maine potato futures market increased yesterday and at the end of the trading session on the New York, Mercantile EXchange, 2,741 sales had been consummated. Much of the activity was said to have resulted from an increase in the cash market price.

title: His Mission Is Facts Richard McGarrah Helms
description: WASHINGTON, April 14In early 1969, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the Soviet Union was going for a firststrike capability in building new intercontinental missiles. At about the same time, the committee heard Richard McGarrah Helms, Director of Central Intelligence, give a professional estimate that the Soviet Union was concentrating on defensive missiles. Later, on June 23, shortly before the Senate began a debate on an antiballisticmissile system, both men appeared at the same closed session of the committee to resolve the apparent difference.

title: Rangers Out to Wrap Up Series Tonight
FIGHTING IS HEAVY NEAR FIRE BASE 6
description: SAIGON, Small Vietnam, Thursday, April 15North Vietnamese troops used flamethrowers against South Vietnamese forces in heavy fighting on two sides of Fire Base 6 in the Central Highlands yesterday.

title: Meeting of Taxi Union Here Breaks Up Violently
description: A membership meeting of the New York City Taxi Drivers Unionwhich still has not ratified its new contract with fleet ownersbroke up last night when hundreds, of drivers, angered over the new fare structure as well as the contract, hurled chairs at the union leaders and stormed the stage at Manhattan Center.

title: Economic Havoc Worsens Impact of Pakistan's War
description: AGARTALA, India, April 13 Peasants in many areas of East Pakistan are not planting their rice because the daily shooting between the Pakistani Army and the Bengali independence forces has made them afraid to come out in the open.

title: CHINA ASSETS IN U.S. STILL STAY FROZEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 14President Nixon's order today relaxing the previous ban on dollar transactions with Cornmunist China will not free nearly $100million of Chinese I dollar assets frozen in 1950, officials said today.

title: Agnew Says No to Suggestion He Take On Peking in Table Tennis
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Vice President Agnew, who has won national renown as a sprayshooting golfer, turned down today a suggestion that he demonstrate his prowess as a table tennis player in mainland China. The suggestion came from one of the Vice President's closest friends

title: Newark School Board Makes a New Offer to the Striking Teachers
description: NEWARK, April 14  The Board of Education presented new proposal tonight to the Newark Teachers Union designed to end the bitter, 11week teachers strike.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Philip C. Clarke deplores the illogic of pundits who demand total, unilateral United States withdrawal from Vietnam. [Letter, March 31.]

title: San Jose Mayor Is a JapaneseAmerican
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., April 14Norman Y. Mineta was elected Mayor of San Jose yesterday, becoming the first JapaneseAmerican to head a major city on the United States mainland.

title: Growth Over a Decade After Slow Start Seen
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Trade between the United States and China could grow gradually over the next decade to as much as several hundred million dollars a year, in the view of trade specialists here.

title: Quartet at Top of Gate Brings Unusual Teamwork to Its Jazz
description: Mel Lewis has brought to the Top of the Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets, a jazz quartet that has been proving itself regularly for the last five years under slightly different circumstances. Three members of the follyman groupRoland Hanna, piano, Richard Davis, bass, Mr: Lewis, drumsmade up the rhythm section of the Thad JonesMel Lewis big band, which has been playing on Monday nights at the Village Vanguard since 1966. They work as quartet from time to time, sometimes as the Thad Jones Quartet, sometimes under Mr. Lewis leadership.

title: EGYPT FEARS U.S. MAY BOLSTER FOE
description: CAIRO, April 14A remark yesterday by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that Washington was determined to maintain a military balance between Israel and the Arabs has stirred concern here that more United States fighterbombers and electronic warfare equipment will be sent to Israel.

title: Chou Relaxed and Jovial
description: PEKING, April 14  Premier Chou was relaxed and jovial as he received the visiting table tennis teams in a salon n the Great Hall of the People. He shook hands with all, was photographed VRth each delegation, chatted, asked and invited questions, laughed and joked.

title: SETTING OF GOALS FOR NATION URGED
description: A National Goals Institute, supported by both Congress and the White House as well as the private sector, was proposed here yesterday as a step toward resolving conflicting [national] priorities by a former businessman recently turned education administrator.

title: Advertising:
description: That's the song that should have been sung yesterday at McCannErickson as the word came in from Barton Brands, Inc., Chicago, that the agency was getting more than $3million in billings for Canadian Mist, House of Stuart Scotch, Very Old Barton, Kentucky Gentleman Bourbon and a new (happy) product.

title: Quake Hits Fairbanks
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, April 14 (AP)  A mild earthquake struck Fairbanks today. State troopers said they had no reports of damage or injuries.

title: Move Called Good News
description: The easing of the ban on direct American trade with China was termed good news long overdue yesterday by business leaders.

title: Blast Damages Soviet Office
description: AMSTERDAM, Thursday, April 15 (AP)A big explosion badly damaged the Soviet trade delegation building in Amsterdam early today. The police said they believe a bomb had been set off. Four of the 20 occupants of the building and a woman passerby were injured.

title: Market Place: ??
description: When Scudder, Stevens & Clark set up the Scudder Development Fund, there was considerable anxiety at the Park Avenue headquarters that the widows and orphans would flock to this riskladen fund vehicle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As Admiral Outlaw said in his April 8 OpEd article: One too often remains silent on issues which gnaw the vitals of his being.

title: A U.S. COURT FREES STOPFRISK CONVICT
