description: The United States Court ofl Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday overruled, 6 to 1, its own threejudge anel and the Connecticut Supreme Court and ordered the release of a convict after four years of imprisonment.

title: Industrial Production Up;
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 Industrial production rose very slightly in March after its February decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: ADDICT CONTROLS IN SCHOOLS SCORED
description: The State Commission of Investigation yesterday criticized the efforts of the city's Board of Education to combat heroin addiction among its more than one million students.

title: Sweig's Perjury Conviction Upheld by U.S. Court Were
description: The perjury conviction of Martin Sweig, onetime aide to John W. McCormack, former Speaker of the House of Representatives, was affirmed here yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in unanimous decision.

title: MRS. SAMUEL SHAPIRO
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 14 Mrs. Sonya White Shapiro, founder of Camp Sequoia in Rock Hill, N.Y., died today after a short illness at her home, 708 Bach Court. She was 82 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Before long BristolMyers, the country's sixth largest advertiser, will be going into test market with a soluble aspirin. Its name is Dissolve simple and to the point.

title: Bank Rate Cut in Denmark From 8% to 7% Today
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 14 (Reuters)  The National Bank today announced a cut in Denmark's bank rate from 8 per cent to 7 per cent. The bank rate is the interest charged on loans to member banks from the central bank.

title: How Men Fare Sewing a Dress
description: Remember those intrepid businessmen who were to make a dress for their wives? In our last episode they were puzzling over all those funny looking pieces of tissue paper with the strange little markings: the pattern.

title: WILLIAM WALSH
description: William Walsh of 1452 Beach Avenue, the Bronx, a paper handler at The New York Times since 1969, was killed Tuesday in an automobile accident on the West Side Highway in Manhattan. His age was 32.

title: NIXON EASES CHINA TRADE EMBARGO TO ALLOW NONSTRATEGIC EXPORTS;
description: WASHINGTON, April 14President Nixon announced today a relaxation of the 20yearold embargo on trade with Communist China and four other moves designed to improve relations.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL LIFTS NYLON PRICE
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising prices on all fine denier filament nylon yarns by an average of 8 per cent, effective immediately.

title: T. J. FOLKS JR., HEAD OF LUMBER COMPANY
description: T. John Folks Jr., a Long Island lumber executive, died Monday in Buenaventura, Colombia. With Mrs. Folks, the former Bernice O'Keefe, he had been on a vacation cruise when he was taken ill.

title: Unending Municipal Pay Spiral
description: The overwhelming rejection by New York City firemen of the costly contract recommended by an impartial factfinding panel reflects the irrationality that marks the expectations of most rankandfile unionists today, and nowhere more so than in the municipal civil service.

title: Peace Cavalry From the Sky
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Sky cavalry, which has been very much in the news since the invasion of Laos, is much more than a passing fad. It is a military innovation of great significance. It would seem to be the ideal combination of air power and land power, and when properly organized, it is the optimum combination of mobility and fire power. It should prove to be an extremely effective peacekeeping organization under the control of, for example, the United Nations.

title: Los Angeles Bridges a Theatrical Gap
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 Where can you see James Earl Jones playing Othello, Henry Fonda playing Abraham Lincoln, and Maggie Smith as the rambunctious Gilda in No6I Coward's Design for Living"? Not in New York.

title: Exchange Seat Up $55,0001
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday seat sale of $250,000, up $55,000 from the previous sale. The current bid is $220,000, with $275,000 asked.

title: Labor Officials Approved
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of George C. Guenther of Reading, Pa., to be an Assistant Secretary of Labor. Also confirmed was Horace E. Menesco of Cushing, Okla., to be administrator of the Wage and Hours Division in the Labor Department.

title: Glen Cove Says It Can't Provide Extra Guards for Soviet Mission
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., April 14 President Nixon has been advised by Mayor Andrew J. DiPaola that because of its financial position, Glen Cove will no longer be able to provide extraordinary police protection to the Soviet Mission here.

title: Chou, 73, and Team Hippie Hit It Off
description: PEKING, April 14Premier Chou Enlai surprised the United States table tennis team today with his sharp wit, relaxed air and interest in the hippie movement.

title: Will Leads A.B.C. Singles By 19 Pins on Series of 736
description: DETROIT, April 14 (UPI)Jerry Hill of Lawton, Okla., took first place today in the American Bowling Congress's regular singles at Cobo Hall Lanes.

title: Helms Defends the C.I.A. As Vital to a Free Society
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Director of Central Intelligence, Richard Helms, vigorously defended his agency today as necessary to the survival of a democratic society and asked the nation to take it on faith that we too are honorable men devoted to her service.

title: Casualty of Apartheid
description: High on any list of those meriting the thanks of people of goodwill everywhere are the small company of white South Africans who defy heavy odds to resist the evils spawned by apartheid. For years one of these has been Joel Carlson, a young Johannesburg lawyer who scored notable victories for justice for black Africans even when confronted by such legal monstrosities as the Terrorism Act.

title: City Bank Lists Its Stock Investments
DR. HUBERT F. SEARCY
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 14Dr. Hubert F. Searcy, retired president of Huntingdon College in Montgomery, died today. He was 63 years old.

title: N.Y.U. Considering Dropping Basketball And Its Track Team
A Backward Step on Abortion
description: The vehement emotion that marked last year's battle in the State Legislature over abortion reform will be rekindled by the call of New York's Roman Catholic bishops for reversal of the decision made then to remove most of the archaic obstacles to legalized abortion.

title: Soviet Discouraging Trips to Cholera Area
description: MOSCOW, April 14 Soviet authorities attempted today to prevent crowding, of southern beach resorts summer and any new outbreak of cholera or other epidemics by telling citizens that the south is not really good for them if they are used to the north.

title: Ralston Bows, 76, 61
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 14 (AP)Dennis Ralston and Bob Lutz were ousted today in the second round of a $25,000 open tennis tournament.

title: Most U.S. Priests Found To Oppose Birth Curb Ban
description: Two studies sponsored by the American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church have found that a majority of the country's priests reject the church's teaching against artificial birth control and believe that priests should be free to marry.

title: Cat Stevens Puts Observations In Songs, Obscure or Dramatic
description: The mystique surrounding British pop performers is still so strong that an artist of only moderate ability can do well here if he has that accent.

title: Celanese Reports 16.6% Lag in Profit in Quarter
description: The Celanese Corporation's firstquarter net income fell 16.6 per cent to $13.1million, or 90 cents a share, from $15.7million, or $1.10 a share, in the yearearlier period. Sales were $268.5million, up 3 per cent from $259.5million a year ago.

title: EMANUEL A. MEYER
description: ARDSLEYONHUDSON, N.Y., April 14Emanuel A. Meyer, retired food distribution company executive and consultant, died today in White Plains Hospital after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Hudson House here.

title: Hogan to Play at Houston
description: HOUSTON, April 14 (AP)Ben Hogan, one of golf's former greats, will play in the $125,000 Houston Champions tournament May 13, officials said today. It will be Hogan's first tournament since he withdrew from the Westchester Classic in New York last summer because of knee trouble.

title: Vatican Word on Music May Rule Out Here Comes the Bride
description: Here Comes the Bride and other popular musical compositions traditionally heard at wedding services may soon be on the way out in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: WAR HEARING SET BY SENATE PANEL
Reconsider the Wolf, a Sweet Singer of the Wilds
description: Wolves do not howl to frighten men, but to communicate with other wolves and, possibly, because they get lonely.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 14, 1971

title: Mohawk, Back in Service, Is Merging With Allegheny
description: The financially troubled Mohawk Airlines, which resumed service yesterday after one of the longest and most bitter strikes in airline history, said last night that it and Allegheny Airlines had agreed in principle to merge.

title: Merit Scholarships Awarded to 1,300; 23 Are From City
description: The names of the winners in the first of three categories of the National Merit Scholarship competition were announced yesterday. Among the 1,300 high school seniors were 23 from New York City.

title: Britons Favor Referendum
description: LONDON, April 14 (Reuters) Four out of five Britons would like a national referendum before this country joins the European Economic Community. according to an opinlion poll published today.

title: A.B. C. COUNTERS FILM TRUST SUIT
description: The American Broadcasting, Companies, Inc., is seeking over $100million in damages from several major filmproduction companies, and demanding the dissolution of the Motion Picture Association of America.

title: DRUGLYRIC LAWSUIT DISMISSED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit attempting to strike down Federal Communications Commission guidelines on the broadcast of songs with drugoriented lyrics. United States District Court Judge William B. Jones ruled yesterday he lacked jurisdiction. The agency in announcing the guidelines March 5, said the failure of radio and television lexecutives to oversee music broadcasts would raise serious questions as to whether continued operation of the station Iis in the public interest.

title: Kennedy Holds Hearing on Health Here
description: One witness said that I suppose I'll have to die, that's all, because the city and state might not have enough funds to keep him provided with the services of a kidneycleansing machine.

description: WASHINGTON. April 14Following are excerpts front an address by Richard Helms, Director of Central Intelligence, before the American Society of Newspaper Editors:

description: Beverly Sills, has had a monopoly on the title role of Lucia di Lammermoor at the New York City Opera, with good reason, but for the company's final performance of the Donizetti opera this season, on Tuesday night, the part was turned over to another leading singer, Patricia Brooks.

title: Insiders'
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on stockholdings of large shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The report includes the following:

title: Soviet Avoids Comment, But Uneasiness Is Seen
description: MOSCOW, April 14The Soviet Union, long concerned over the possibility of a. major improvement in Cemmunist China's relations with the United States, has so far avoided direct comment on the current diplomacy between Washington and Peking but has shown some uneasiness in its initial press coverage of the developments.

title: Text of the Announcement by President Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's statement today on trade with and travel to Communist China.

title: Bullets Victors, 10180; Tie Series With Knicks
DEFENSE FUND GUT IS BACKED IN POLL
description: WASHINGTON, April 14Half of those individuals questioned in a recent poll believe that the United States should reduce spending for national defense and military purposes, the Gallup organization said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gunnar A. Johansson's recent letter raises a question that is crucial to continued sociological progress in this country.

title: Impactof Air Fare Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The stock market has confirmed the judgment, of the airline presidents that the, Civil Aeronautics Board's new fare policy, providing incfeases of up to 9 per cent, is a big opportunity for the industry. But there are serious concerns here, on the C.A.B. and off, not only, that such record price increases are bad news for travelers but that they could also start the airlines down the rail roads cycle of decline. Higher prices, starting with a 6 per cent increase on May 7, come at a time of stagnating demand: traffic growth, that averaged nearly 15 per cent per year through the midnineteen sixties has dropped to zero in the current recession. And while the C.A.B. has told the airlines that their prosperity depends on filling. up their now halfempty planes, the board also calculates that the fare increases will turn away more than 6 per cent of the already depressed airline traffic.

title: Franz X. Amrein, 71, Dies; Edited Swiss Weekly Here
description: Franz X. Amrein, editor of Die Amerikanische Schweizer Zeitung, Swiss weekly newspaper in this city, died yesterday of a heart attack in Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 596 Riverside Drive.

title: THE CEYLON CRISIS: TOLL IN THOUSANDS
description: HONG KONG, April 14  An insurrection by radical youths, apparently Communistled, has plunged Ceylon into a bloody civil war that has had a shattering effect on the beautiful tropical island.

title: A SEALE WITNESS SHIFTS TESTIMONY
description: NEW HAVEN, April 14A key prosecution witness against Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther leader, and Ericka Huggins, under crossexamination by defense counsel today, gave a substantially different version of the killing of Alex Rackley than he gave last summer at an earlier trial involving that death.

title: Latins Plead for Greater U.S. Aid as. Q.A.S. Opens General Assembly in Costa Rica
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 14  Latin American leaders pleaded today for a greater United States commitment to development assistance through trade and aid for this region of 220 million people.

title: SAVINGS BANK BILL IN CONNECTICUT GAIN
description: The Connecticut Legislature, in a move that has national significance, has moved a step closer to giving mutual savings banks in that state a limited authorization to offer checking accounts to their depositors. Similar measures are pending in several other New England states, and on a national level the Presidential Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation is considering whether all thrift institutions should have this authority.

title: U.S. INTELSAT ROLE MAY BE REDUCED
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) United States voting power over International Communications Satellite policies would be cut to 40 per cent under an agreement that may be concluded here among member nations in the next few weeks.

title: Kidde Chief in Proxy Fight
description: Fred R. Sullivan, chairman of Walter Kidde & Co., Inc., notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday he would participate in the pending proxy fight for Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation. According to Mr. Sullivan's statement, he is not a member of the dissident stockholders committee but has indicated his willingness to be one of its candidates for the board of directors at the annual meeting on May 18.

title: Roundup: Jackson of A's Is Back in Homer Groove
description: When last in the public eye, in July of 1969, Reggie Jackson of the Oakland Athletics had Babe Ruth's record and Roger Maris's asterisk on the run, not to mention fans in rightfield seats throughout the American League.

title: Court Rejects Manson Plea
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI) Motions by Charles M. Manson and Susan Atkins to dismiss another murder charge against them were rejected today in Superior Court. Manson and Miss Atkins appeared in the courtroom of Judge Raymond Choate on the charge they had killed Gary Hinman, a musician.

title: Head of Prison Guards'
description: The head of a prison guard association called yesterday for art inquiry into a charge by the chairman of the city's Board of Correction that it was difficult to get a conviction of prison personnel out of the office of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

title: Nixon Attends as Casey Takes S.E.C. Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)William J. Casey was sworn in today as a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission  an agency President Nixon said has a greater impact on this nation than most Federal units.

title: Screen: 'Margo's' Love:Israel Import Opens at Carnegie Hall Cinema
description: Ten years into marriage with a pleasure-seeking, beauty-parlor haunting, until-dawn-orgying wife; youngish Dr. Talmorhe of the crinkly eyes and crooked grinreturns to his Jerusalem home one rainy night to find a girl collapsed at his front gate. She is Margo, heroine of a new Israeli film called "Margo," and she is something of a handful, being a good 50 pounds overweight.Margo has just escaped an assault on her virginity attemped, as nearly as I can tell, solely because it is there) and she is therefore a little apprehensive about Talmor's kind invitation to come in and warm up. But Margo isn't fat for nothing, and the Talmor household offers her marvels yet unknown: "What a wonderful kitchen! Your wife must be very happy.""My wife seldom visits the kitchen" (in a tone usually reserved for "my wife can never have children," or the like)."Who cooks for you? . . ."And that is the real interest, the meat and potatoes and cream soda with the main course, so to speak, of "Margo," a film that in most respects is no different from any other disillusioned-maturity-meets-innocent-youth-and-discovers-love movie  except that it is much worse.There are all the paraphernalia of the crystalization of love, the usual lovers' poses in romantic places (in this case, shrines of the three major faiths), even a nude love-making scene  which confines itself to very selective details on account of Margo's special plumpness problem.But the thrust of "Margo" is really somewhat antiromantic, and try as it will to feel, it really wants to moralizeto show what is wrong with his wife, Shoshana (Beracha Ne'eman, and the worst of the film's many ludicrous performances) that Dr. Talmor should want to leave her and give up his university post that her father. Professor Levinhartz, pulled so many strings to get for him.What is wrong, of course, is that she doesn't cookwhile Margo cooks up a storm. Not gourmet things, mind you, but the wholesome well-seasoned foods that are the way to a man's heart. "Margo" may be the first love-story movie in which the tenderest close-ups are reserved not for the heroine's face or figure (understandably), but for her handsslicing the raw onions that will go into her lover's salad.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Household Finance Corporation has announced the appointment of Arthur E. Rasmussen, 48 years old, to the additional post of chief executive officer. Mr. Rasmussen, who is president, succeeds H. E. MacDonald, chairman, who relinquished his title and duties as chief executive officer, a position he has held for The last 18 years. Mr. Rasmussen joined the company as president in 1967 from the Avco Corporation, where he was financial vice president. Mr. MacDonald, who will continue as chairman of the board and executive committee joined the company, which traces its origin to an office established in 1878, as executive, vice president and was elected president in 1951, He became chairman in 1966.

title: Agnew Says Americans Are United on Pollution
description: DETROIT, April 14 (AP)Vice President Agnew said today that the monetary costs of controlling pollution would be nothing compared to the tremendous cost of not controlling it.

title: A Basic Book on Wine That the Novice Can Actually Understand
description: Someone was saying recently that the people in charge of the road signs on, off and about the Long Island Expressway cater purely and simply to that segment of the public that already knows Where it's going. It is also true that the authors of most basic wine books seem to have written them for the people already conversant with the finer distinctions between a LafiteRothschild and a MoutonRothschild, a Sauternes and a Barsac. And, lo, the poor innocent who buys such books for selftutelage.

title: U.S. War Pullout Urged
description: DETROIT, Apr. 14 (AP)The Southern Christian Leadership Conference called today for the total withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam. The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, head of the organization, said it wanted all American troops withdrawn by the end of August.

title: Conservatives Appoint
description: The Conservative party announced yesterday that Serphin R. Maltese, a Queens lawyer, had been appointed executive director of the party. He replaces James D. Griffin, who served for three and a half years.

title: STOCK LIST GAINS IN AMEX TRADING
U.S. JungleClearing Bombs Now Turned on Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam April 14Military officers here say the United States command used sevenandonehalftonbombs in the Central Highlands this week primarily to clear the thick jungle canopy from North Vietnamese storage areas near the Laotian border, but also to kill enemy soldiers who might be nearby.

title: Seigel Is Named President By Society of Silurians Were
description: Kalman Seigel, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, was elected president of the Society of the Silurians last night.

title: Bridge: ?? ?? ?? Notice in National Event
description: In the national championships, such as the tournament recently concluded in Atlanta, attention focuses on the winners of major titles. But of the several thousand participants many have no chance of winning an important event and they know it. They are realistically content to play in onesession side games that offer some chance of success but little prestige in the event of victory.

title: Abuse of Child Mental Patients Is Charged Here
description: Two former employes of a state mental institution for children on Wards Island charged yesterday that the patients were subjected to severe physical and emotional abuse and gross psychiatric neglect.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: VIENNA, Md.If all goes well, the progeny of striped bass caught in Maryland's Nanticoke River will make new waters farther north their home.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Mike Snell does not watch the evening news. All they want to talk about is pollution, ecology, the war over in Nam, and I'm just not interested. Now if they want ask me to handle it I'll help em out, sure. But nobody's asking me, and I'm not interested watching them talk about how they're going to handle it, not when there's a good John Wayne movie on. He sipped from a glass of Jim Beam, and dragged on his cigarette. Couple years ago tried to enlist, but they didn't want me cause I had two kids, didn't want to pay. Now they come around, they hear a rumor me and the old lady separated. But I'm not going. Opportunity knocks but once I tell em.

title: Son of Menuhin May Lose American Citizenship
description: LONDON, April 13  Gerard Menuhin, second son of Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, was born in Edinburgh because his parents were there for the music festival. That happenstance may soon cost him his American citizenship.

title: Yale Repertory Stages Woyzeck and Play
Stuart Burrows Meets The Test in Met Debut
description: By the time Stuart Burrows came to that classical test of the lyric tenor, Don Ottavio's Il mio tesoro intanto, in the second act of Tuesday night's Don Giovanni at the Metropolitan Opera, the handsome Welshman had already established himself as an artist any opera house would be happy to have on hand. Previously, in this, his Metropolitan debut, Mr. Burrows had shown a sense of Mozart style and taste in a sweet, unforced Dalla sua pace. And he had contributed his light but supple voice to the ensemble numbers with restraint that does not seem to come easily to tenors.

title: CHOU SAYS NEW PAGE HAS OPENED
description: PEKING, April 14Premier Chou Enlai received the visiting American table tennis players today and told them that their trip to Communist China had opened a new page in the relations of the Chinese and American people.

title: Cliff Keuter Troupe Dances a Premiere, Poem in October
description: Cliff Keuter, whose dance company is appearing weeknights through Sunday matinee at Riverside Church, 120th Street and Claremont Avenue, presented another premiere Tuesday night in the second program of the series.

title: FAIRNESS IS PLEDGED IN G.M.ISUZU DEAL
description: TOKYO, April 14 (UPI)James M. Roche, board chairman of the General Motors Corporation, was told today by Japan's International Trade and Industry Minister, Mach! Miyazawa that application of the proposed capital tieup between G.M. and Isuzu Motors, Ltd., will be given fair consideration.

title: Insurgents Ask Aid
description: NEW DELHI, April 14The prime minister of the secessionistproclaimed government of East Pakistan appealed in a, radio broadcast today for recognition of his new government and aid.

title: Bold Favorite Syndicated
description: CHESAPEAKE CITY, Md., April 14 (AP)Bold Favorite, a son of Bold Ruler, has been syndicated and will begin stallion duty in Maryland starting next year. Bold Favorite, now training in Florida, has earned $215,000.

title: DOCTOR PRODUCES ANTIWASP VENOM
description: CHICAGO, April 14By injecting a group of patients with a native wasp venom and then letting wasps sting them, a Connecticut physician has developed a treatment that apparently has protected such sensitive people from the sometimes serious allergic effects of wasp stings.

title: REV. CHARLES PECK, VICAR EMERITUS, 82
description: BOSTON, April 14The Rev. Charles Russell Peck, vicar emeritus of the historic Old North Church (Episcopal), died today at the age of 82. He had homes here and in Princeton, Mass.

title: Auto Bumper Rule Issued; Insurance Benefit Likely
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 The Department of Transportation issued a modified safety standard today for protective bumpers on passenger cars.

title: Kent to Dedicate Memorial
description: KENT, Ohio, April 14 (AP)The Center for Peaceful Change at Kent State University, a living memorial to the tragedy of last May 4, will be dedicated on the first anniversary of the killing of four students in a confrontation between antiwar demonstrators and Ohio National Guard troops on campus.

title: Soviet Reported Ready For New Space Feat
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (UPI) Scientific sources said today that the Soviet Unionwould send up at least two manned spacecraft within the next few days in a series of launchings to Inaugurate the second decade of Soviet space exploration:

title: Friendly Relations With China Go Back To Earliest Days of U.S. Independence
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 United States relations with China began in 1784, one year after the original 13 colonies were formally recognized as independent.

title: Michel Briere, Hockey Star Injured in Crash, 21, Dies
description: MONTREAL, April 14 (UPI)Michel Briere, who led the Pittsburgh Penguins to the 1970 Stanley Cup semifinals and was critically injured in an auto accident two weeks later, died yesterday. He was 21 years old.

title: E.C.A.C. Likely to Ease Transfer Rule
description: When Buffalo dropped intercollegiate football last January the players hopes and aspirations vanished, according to Bob Deming, who lost his head coaching job at the same time. But there was a chance for those athletes to play their sport if they transferred to another college. That's what many have done.

title: Marines Deactivated
description: Saigon, April 14 (Reuters), The Third Marine Amphibious Force was deactivated today at a ceremony in Danang, where the marines first landed in March, 1965. The force, the largest ever deployed by the Marine Corps overseas, once numbered 80,000 men fighting the Vietcong in the five northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

title: Charles Greenwald, Served Investigation Department
description: Charles Greenwald, former first deputy commissioner of the Department of Investigation of New York City, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived at 8409 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is worthwhile, I think, to recognize the turning point in United States history that the defeat of the funding for the SST constituted. I do not mean only the willingness to accept and to act on the environmental arguments that were brought against the plane; certainly that was a landmark. In the larger perspective I think the votes in the House and the Senate were unprecedented in the history of technology in the United States, and probably in the world.

title: Marshal George Mills, Led British Bomber Command
description: LONDON, April 14 (AP)Air Chief Marshal Sir George Holroyd Mills, former chief of Britain's bomber command, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: F.T.C. CHALLENGES RECENT ACQUISITIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today challenged recent acquisitions by GeorgiaPacific Corporation of Portland, Ore., and the Budd Company of Philadelphia, as contrary to antitrust laws.

title: FIRE UNION SPURNS PROPOSED ACCORD; LINDSAY ADAMANT
description: Members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association overwhelmingly rejected yesterday a new contract recommended by their leaders, once again setting back the hectic and drawnout negotiations between the city and its uniformed services.

title: Meany Calls Nixon Steel Action a Bid for LowWage Economy
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, bitterly attacked President Nixon's inflation alert to the steel industry today, saying the Administration was seeking to establish a lowwage economy.

title: Joffrey Ballet to Make Debut Visit to London
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet will make its first visit to London, it was announced yesterday. The company will begin a threeweek engagement at the Coliseum May 19 under the management of Richard Graham.

title: Undetected Syphilis Is Said To Affect 500,000 in U.S.
description: ST. LOUIS, April 14 (UPI)s More than a half million persons in the United States are suffering from undetected syphilis and are in urgent need of skilled medical attention, the American Social Health Assodation Said today.

title: Reporting Called Lazy
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) Mr. Noyes, in his State of the Press address, told the convention that American newspapers were guilty of lazy and superficial reporting.

title: STEINGUT PROPOSES EXTRA JOBLESS AID
description: ALBANY, April 14 (AP)Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut said today that he would seek legislation to extend unemployment benefits to jobless workers for another 13 weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your first report on the demise of the SST on March 26 included an outline of a bill introduced by Senator Muskie that would make $100 million available for research and development in aviation safety and urban mass transit and would give contractors who have had Federal programs canceled in the last year and cities with severe unemployment prior claims on the funds.

title: Meeting at a Taxi Stand
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 14 (UPI)The United States table tennis team's invitation to go to Red China grew out a meeting between two men at a taxi stand April 6 in Nagoya, Japan, according to a letter from team official.

title: 8ManJuries Scheduled
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aprt1,14 (AP) Beginning May 1 civil cases can be tried before eightman juries in the Federal 'District Court for the EaStent. District of Pennsylvania under a rule adopted by the judges yesterday. The traditieinal 12man panel will be used if either party objects to the Smaller jury.

title: DEFENSE FINISHES IN CRIMMINS CASE
description: The defense in the Alice Crimmins murder and manslaughter trial rested its case at 3:15 P.M. yesterday after producing two witnesses who contradicted the chief thrust of the prosecution case against the 32yearold defendant.

title: Economic Crisis Casts Doubt On Future of WNYC Stations
description: The future of New York City's radio stations, WNYC and WNYCFM, and the municipal television outlet, WNYCTV, are in doubt because of the city's economic crisis.

title: Cut of 11,250 in Teaching Jobs Feared in City
description: A substantial cut in teaching positions and school programs and services for next fall has been projected by city authorities on the basis of their preliminary budget estimates for the fiscal year 197172.

title: A Times Reporter Enters China After Seeking Visa for 20 Years
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, April, 15Tillman Durdin, a New York Times correspondent, crossed into Chinese territory from Hong Kong this morning, the first representative of an American newspaper to enter Communist China in the wake of Peking's new friendliness toward Americans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your editorial Trouble for the Dollar of April 1 you urge that the continuous deficit in our balance of foreign payments which reached nearly $10 billion last year may lead to disastrous consequences. I agree with your warning but find two of the points you make in support of it debatable.

title: Screen: Rural Diabolism:' Satan's Claw' Opens in Horror Double Bill
description: Shortly after a farmer unearths the remains of a rather poorly buried devil (a furry claw and some other parts that look as if they might have come from an ancient Model-T), an insolent ungodliness seizes the rural community in 17th-century England. Angel Blake, a girl who'd probably be no better than she should be under any circumstances, throws caution to the winds and attempts to seduce the Rev. Fallowfield by revealing her breasts. He remains faithful to God, but most of the children, one by one, capitulate to the dark powers, some to be served up as sacrifices, some simply to serve as aides de camp.I've resisted the temptation to call this high camp because "The Blood on Satan's Claw," of which the foregoing is only a most general prcis, is cinematic diabolism of some style and intelligence, nothing, perhaps, to confuse with "Les Vampyres," but still a horror movie of more than routine interest. It opened yesterday at the Harris Theater on 42d Street in the company of another British film, "The Beast in the Cellar," which is of routine interest.Although "The Blood on Satan's Claw" is based on an original screenplay by Robert Wynne-Simmons, it has a good deal of the quality of an H.P. Lovecraft work, in the vulnerability of even its heroic characters, as well as in its pastoral landscape that contains the threat of "eeveel" within every sun-dappled glade. Most particularly, it contains Lovecraft's perfectly straightfaced acceptance of a universe whose natural order may, at any time, be overturned by supernatural disorder.The film is the second to be directed by Piers Haggard but, as far as I can learn, it's his first to be released in this country. Mr. Haggard, a former member of Britain's National Theater and assistant to Lindsay Anderson on the stage production of "Luther," is apparently a director of some authority, having avoided the intimations of humor contained in a number of the character names, and having resisted the orgiastic fruitiness to which the horror films of Freddie Francis are so often heir.Of the performers, I especially liked Linda Hayden, as Angel Blake, the sort of girl who, fully clothed, could have easily unhinged Salem, and Patrick Wymark, as the stern, rather Old Testament judge who finally gets to the root (and claw) of the problem."The Beast in the Cellar," written and directed by James Kelly, looks and sounds very much as if it might have first been planned as a bad play for the ladies who rattle teacups during London matinees. It's about two elderly sisters, Flora Robson and Beryl Reid, who hide something in the basement that keeps getting loose and carving up the soldiers on a nearby army base. The ladies spend most of their time in the parlor, drinking tea and talking the plot over and out.Anyone interested in seeing "The Blood on Satan's Claw" would do well to catch it at one of the neighborhood houses where the double bill opens today. At the Harris yesterday, the projection was faulty, the audience restless, and the auditorium so brightly lit that the night scenes became light blue blurs.

title: First Escape in 40Year History of Attica Prison Apparently Confirmed
description: The superintendent of the Attica Correctional Facility said yesterday that Joseph J. Sullivan, an inmate of the prison for four years, apparently had engineered the first successful escape from the maximumsecurity prison in its 40year history.

title: Staggered Hours Called a Success After 1Year Trial
description: A yearold experiment to stagger the hours of more than 60,000 people who work for 70 lower Manhattan concerns to reduce rushhour subway and train congestion has been called a success. As a result, plans are being made to double the number of employes on the schedule.

title: U.S. Urged to Decide On Population Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)  The rapid increase in population means that the United States Government will eventually have to decide whether to coerce its citizens into having fewer children Donald Rumsfeld White House counselor, said today.

title: B.O.A.C. 747 Jet Starts LondonNew York Service
description: LONDON, April 14 (Reuters)  Britain's largest airline sent its first jumbo jet flight to New York today  almost a year behind schedule.

title: AN AMUSING PIECE AT CONCERT'S END
description: In its nearly three decades of existence, the Koussevitzky Muic Foundation has encouraged a rather steady output of new compositions by commissioning composers from many countries to write new works.

title: NATO Rules Eased
description: PARIS,.April 14Over the last two decades the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has progressively eased the embargo rules it applies on sales to China and other Com munist countries.

title: HAROLD M'DOWELL, N.Y.U. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Harold W. MacDowell, professor of marketing and director of the doctoral program of the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, died an Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N. J., on Tuesday after a long Illness. He was 68 years old, and had been stricken in Europe last July. His home was at 17 Holmehill Lane, Roseland, N. J.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination,, 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A DANCE PROGRAM BREAKS TRADITION
description: Traditionat moderndance pieties were thrown Casually overboard Tuesday evening when Ze'eva Cohen decided to give a solo program using other choreographers works for the bulk of her performance at the Cubiculo. Though custom and usage has heretofore dictated that the dancerchoreographer appear exclusively in her own pieces, Miss Cohen chose to perform the works of four other choreographers in addition to her own.

title: A New Course: Adorning Jeans
description: Jann Johnson may soon be walking around with her autobiography decorating her from the waist down. Recently she began to paint, appliqu, embroider and stud a pair of jeans with symbols of the story of my life so far. She had already decorated some denim shorts with colored or metallic nailheads, each one implanted by hand.

title: State Says Waldorf Padded Bills by 2%
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz sued the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for more than $452,000 yesterday, accusing it of putting hidden charges on the bills of its customers.

title: Bullets or Bread?
description: Washington's pretense of nonintervention in Pakistan's tragic internal conflict has been shattered this week by State Department acknowledgment that the United States has been selling ammunition and other nonlethal military equipment to the repressive Pakistani Government and by the Administration's persistent refusal to impose a ban on such sales. As long as these sales continue, the United States places itself alongside China on the side of the military regime in Islamabad and, in effect, makes itself a party to the continuing slaughter of Pakistan's Bengali majority and to the suppression of the recently elected majority party in Pakistan's still unconvened National Assembly.

title: Nixon to Attend Dedication
description: TULSA, Okla., April 14 (AP) Officials announced yesterday that President Nixon had confirmed that he would attend ceremonies June 5 intrking completion of the McClellanKerr Arkansas River Navigation System. Dedication ceremonies will be at the Tulsa: Port of Catoosa.

title: BLUE CHIPS PACE SURGE IN STOCKS
Yugoslav Envoy to Sweden Dies of Wounds by Croats
description: STOCKHOLM, April 15 (Reuters)The Yugoslav Ambassador to Sweden, Vladimir Rolovic, died tonight of wounds suffered when he was shot last) week by Croatian extremists, according to a spokesman at the Karolinska Hospital.

title: Mets Idled by Snow; Play at Army Today
description: The Mets game with the Montreal Expos in Montreal yesterday was postponed because of snow.

title: RAIL PANEL FAVORS SIGNALMEN'S RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  A Presidential emergency board recommended today a wage increase package totaling more than 25 per cent for 10,000 railroad signalmen who have threatened to strike the nation's railroads.

title: TV: A British Poet's Protest Against World War I
description: While the Public Broadcasting Service is not without its financial problems, it is also not without a good deal of inventive imagination in operating within those problems. The latest example of what can be accomplished on a relatively small budget will begin tonight at 8:30 as NET Playhouse starts a 15part weekly series carrying the catchall label Biography!

title: Use of Public TV Envisioned For HighSchool Equivalency
description: John W. Macy Jr., president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, envisioned yes terday the use of noncommercial TV for a nationwide system of highschool equivalency preparation to enable viewers to advance their careers and broaden their job opportunities.

title: Both Sides Rest in Trial of Black Panthers Here
description: Both sides rested yesterday in the case of 13 Black Panthers on trial here for an alleged bomb conspiracy case.

title: Music: Soulful Glissando Swoops
description: If God created great whales, whose voices were put on phonograph records last year, He also created the gentle wolf, that sweet singer of beasts, that muchmaligned carnivore whose only attitude is live and let live so long as it eats.

title: Theater: Young Candide
description: If what this town needs is a fairtogood dirty children's show for fairtogood dirty children, it may have found one in Candide, which last night opened at the South Hall of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater on Lafayette Street.

title: New Bloomingdale's Store
description: Bloomingdale's, the New York based department store chain, announced yesterday that it would open a 100,000squarefoot homefurnishings store in Jenkintown, Pa., early in 1972. The unit will be part of Bloomingdale's proposed homefurnishings chain, with the first store to open in September in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Pakistan Asserts Troops Wiped Out All Miscreants in Key Town
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 14The Pakistani Government reported today that its troops, pushing west from Dacca, had reached the key town of Rajshalli and had wiped out all miscreants and Indian infiltrators in this area.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 14There will be no ribaldry or callous jest today. Taxation is too solemn a subject for the mouthings of fools. Rather, with deference and respect, we give over this space to those great minds which have expressed themselves on taxation down through history in terms worthy to be chiseled in marble or hung in embroidery over horsehair sofas. Thus:

title: Soviet Radioactivity Noted
description: STOCKHOLM, April 14 (UPI) Radioactivity caused by an underground nuclear explosion in the Ural Mountains of the Soviet Union was detected in Sweden last week, the National Defense Research Institute said today. The institute said it had determined that the radioactivity had originated from an underground nuclear bomb that was detonated March 23.

title: IRELAND'S ECONOMY REPORTED LAGGING
description: PARIS, April 14The Republic of Ireland is in serious economic difficulties, a study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 14When man bites a clog, that's news; but when a frontrunning Presidential candidate bites J. Edgar Hoover, that's big news. So the most important thing about Senator Edmund Muskie's charges against the F.B.I. may be that the fabled. Director at last has lost the special immunity from criticism that for so long characterized him, mother and the flag.

title: Cosmos 406 Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 14 (AP)The Soviet Union launched today Cosmos 406, an unmanned earth satellite designed for some unspecified type of space research. It was the fifth Scviet launching announced this month.

title: Senate Has Little to Do
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Senate returned today from an Easter recess but had little to do. During the fourhour session, routine resolutions and nominations were approved in a few minutes. The rest of the time was taken up with speeches on sundry topics.

title: Variety of Foods Can Often Result In Pet Malnutrition
description: The nutritional needs of dogs, because of similarities in physiology and metabolism, are very much like those of man, said Dr. Ben E. Sheffy yesterday at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon at the Hotel McAlpin. Sheffy is professor of nutrition and assistant director of the Veterinary Virus Institute at Cornell. Since man rarely has sufficient knowledge to feed himself correctly, the dog cannot be expected to fare better, he said.

title: John Boys Marries Miss Howard
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 14In St. Andrew's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Desolie Alma Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harold Howard of Temora, New South Wales, Australia, was married to. John Holden Stone Boys, an assistant vice president at the Chemical Bank in New York. He is the son of Mrs. Milburn Gladstone Boys of Jacksonville and the late Commander Boys, U. S. N. It The Rev. David Damon performed the ceremony.

title: POMPIDOU'S AIDE BACK IN ALGIERS
description: PARIS, April 14President Pompidou, who interrupted his vacation to confer most of the day with top French officials, sent Nerve Alphand, Secretary General of the Foreign Ministry, to Algiers tonight with the French answer to Algeria's latest moves in the longstanding conflict over oil and other relations.

title: Dr. William B. Lipphard Dies; Cleric, Editor and Author, 84
description: Dr. William B. Lipphard, a prominent Baptist clergyman, editor and author, died yesterday at the Baptist Home for the Aged, 3260 Henry Hudson Parkway, the Bronx. He was 84 years old.

title: Revolutionary War Cannon Disappears in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 14The Westchester County Parkway Police have asked antique dealers in the area to be on the lookout for a Revolutionary War cannon that disappeared from its base here last month.

title: An Opening Door
description: A historic change for the better is taking place relations between the United States and the Chinese People's Republic. What an incredulous world saw yesterday was, in effect, the announcement by Chou Enlal and Richard M. Nixon of a major step toward normalization of ChineseAmerican relations, as both countries open their doors to each other's citizens while laying the groundwork for resumption of trade and, probably, for subsequent economic and technical cooperation.

title: Philadelphia Transit Union Defies Court's Strike Ban
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) A Common Pleas Court judge issued a preliminary injunction today calling for an end to a threeclay transit strike, but officials of the enjoined union voted to defy the injunction.

title: Blair &
description: Blair & Co., a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been adjudicated bankrupt by a Federal court referee.

title: Personal Finance
description: The tax collector likes to splash tax fraud cases all over the newspapers just before April 15 to discourage lastminute sleight of hand. The Internal Revenue Service would never use Mrs. Margaret L. Nicoll's story.

title: GROWTH CONTINUES FOR LATIN AMERICA
description: WASHINGTON, April. 14Economic growth in Latin America apparently continued at a relatively rapid. pace last year, the. InterAmerican Bank reported today.

title: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. FOR VIEW ON SUEZ
description: JERUSALEM, April 14Israel is asking the United States to suggest specific procedures for international policing of the Suez Canal zone if an Israeli troop withdrawal enables the United Arab Republic to reopen the waterway, official sources said today.

title: Coast Priest, Married 7 Years,. Dismissed and Excommunicated
description: PACIFICA, Calif., April 14The pastor of a large Roman Catholic Church here, was excommunicated today after it, was discovered that he had been secretly married ,for nearly seven years.

title: Negotiated Fees Stirring Rift as Vote Approaches
description: Wall Street girded itself yesterday for a crucial test of the concept of negotiated sates commissions on stock transactions, amid indications that a major rift over the issue had developed in the investment community. As of today, the membership of the New York Stock Exchange must accept or reject amendments proposed to the exchange's constitution, providing for the abolition of fixed rates on the portion of all transactions above $500,000 in value.

title: Hungarian Aide to Visit Pope
description: ROME, April 14The Vatican announced today that the Hungarian Foreign Minister, Janos Peter, who arrived here as guest of the Italian Government today, would call on Pope Paul VI Friday. The audience will mark the first visit to the Pontiff by a Hungarian Commun?st official.

title: Hearing Ordered on Ending Of Labor Bureau Briefings
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)A House subcommittee on freedom of information ordered today that public hearings be held next week on the Labor Department's discontinuance of press briefings on monthly cost of living and unemployment figures.

title: Philippine Air Force Crash Kills 39 North of Manila
description: MANILA, April 15 (Reuters)  Thirtynine persons, including highranking officers of the Philippine Air Force, were killed today when a military plane crashed near the air base north of Manila.

title: Executive Changes
description: Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, a division of the Celanese Corporation has appointed Allan It. Dragone as president. He succeeds Louis F. Laun who has resigned as president of the division and as a corporate vice president. Mr. Dragone joined Celanese in February, 1966, as president and general manager of film and sheets in the Celanese Plastics Company:division, and in 1967 became president of the Celanese Coatings Company. Last August he became executive vice president of Celanese Fibers Marketing. Mr. Laun who joined Celanese in 1957 was named the first president of Celanese Fibers Marketing when the division was formed in December, 1964. Previously he was executive vice president of Celanese Fibers. He took over marketing of fibers in 1960 and during his tenure fiber sales of the company rose from $175million to $535million. Mr. Laun said that he has been considering reducing his business responsibilities for some time and wanted to explore other fields of endeavor to enter at some future time.

title: Odyssey House Chief Wins Acquittal on Overcrowding
description: Dr. Judianne DensenGerber, executive director of Odyssey House, was found not guilty yesterday of charges that she had violated the City Building Code last year by overcrowding a South Bronx adolescent addict rehabilitation center.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Down
description: OTTAWA, April 15 (Canadian Press)  New 91Day Canadian Treasury bills were auctioned today with $165million at an average price and yield of 99.232 and 3.10 per cent. Last week, the same amount was auctioned of 92day bills at a price and yield of 99.242 and 13.03 per cent. Also sold were $45million of 182day bills at 98.373 and 3.32 per cent. Last week $45million of 183day bills were sold at 98.413 and 3.22 per cent.

title: Black Genocide Seen
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  A black family planning consultant told the population commission today that many Negroes regarded talk of zero population growth as genocide aimed at them.

title: Sports of The Times
description: No flag of distress yet flies in alarming fashion from the mainmast of the good ship Knickerbocker. Although no seams appear to have sprung leaks, one distressing fact becomes increasingly apparent. People aboard are starting to get their feet wet.

title: Texas Board Pares May Oil Production
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 15slide in demand for Texas crude oil led the Texas Railroad Commission today to reduce production during May by about 49,,000 barrels a day.

title: Long Delay Upsets Conviction of Two In Yonkers Assault
description: ALBANY, April 15The State Court of Appeals today dismissed the convictions of two Yonkers men for assault and maiming on the ground that a fouryear delay in bringing them to trial had effectively deprived them of their constitutional and statutory right to a prompt trial.

title: Market Place:  Pollution Costs And Steel Mills
description: FAIRLESS HILLS, Pa., April 15Down the load a piece from this town there as a 3,900acre peninsula surrounded by a reverse sea of water from the Delaware River. It contains United States Steel's Fairless works, one of the most efficient and cleanest steel milts. In the world.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 15According to wellinformed PingPong circles, the United States and China are now turning a new page or beginning a new era's or something like that, but the China experts here are suspicious of all sweeping cliches.

title: New British Envoy to Soviet
description: LONDON, April 15 (AP)The Foreign Office announced today that John E. Killick. Assistant Under Secretary, would be Britain's next Ambassador to the Soviet Union. He will take up the post in September, replacing Sir Duncan WiIson, who is retiring.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS A NONPROFIT SETUP FOR HEALTH CARE
description: Governor Rockefeller called yesterday for a major restructuring of medical practice in New York State, including the creation of nonprofit medical corporations.

title: Mets Trounce Army, 80, As Three Hurlers Excel
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 15Before a record crowd of 8,000 mostly youngstersthe New York Mets trounced Army, 80, today in their traditional seveninning exhibition game at Doubleday Field.

title: Hassan Defers U.S. Visit
description: RABAT, Morocco, April 15 (AP)King Hassan II has postponed a trip to the United States scheduled for next week, official sources said tonight. The postponement was believed to be the result of the conference of Arab leaders in Algiers proposed by King Hassan.

title: Hirohito in Hiroshima to Honor Dead
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, April 15 Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako arrived here today to pay tribute to the victims of the atomic bomb.

title: Advertising:
description: The top of the news seems to belong to J. Walter Thompson today. It has reported that last year it billed $773milliona high. And it announced that it has a corporate creative executive vice presidenta brand new title.

title: TIGERS TOP YANKS ON RUN IN 9TH, 32; USE 6 RELIEVERS
2 Guest Artists to Dance With American Ballet
description: Anna Larkesen, prima ballerina of the Royal Danish Ballet, and Edward Verso of the City Center Joffrey Ballet will appear with the American Ballet Company in its coming season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The company, directed by Eliot Feld, will open Tuesday for a threeweek run through May 9.

title: Antiwar Activist Joins Army
description: An antiwar activist reported for Army service here yesterday, but outside the induction center he announced that he would do all he could to organize GI's to fight for a prompt end to the war in Southeast Asia. Twenty sympathizers demonstrated for a halfhour outside the induction station at 39 Whitehall Street, where 23yearold Steve Wattenmaker, a campus coordinator for the Student Mobilization Committee, reported just before 7 A.M.

title: STANDARDS URGED FOR FOOD STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  The Federal Government proposed today that national income eligibility standards be established for operating food stamp programs uniformly in all states.

title: French Orbit 7th Satellite
description: PARIS, April 15 (AP) A French Diamant B rocket fired from French Guiana put a 211pound satellite in orbit today to study solar radiation. It was the seventh scientific satellite sent aloft by France.

title: DOLLARS COUNTED TWICE IN EUROPE
description: PARIS, April 15  The world's central banks have suddenly discovered that through mirror tricks In the Eurodollar market they are counting the same billions of dollars of reserves twice.

title: Saigon's Troops Open a Drive on Enemy Regiment in Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 15 (AP)South Vietnamese troops supported by United States aircraft opened a drive in the Central Highlands today against North Vietnamese forces that have been on the attack there for 15 days, South Vietnamese headquarters said.

title: 2 of 10 Academic Chairs Eliminated by Legislature
description: ALBANY, April 15Two of the state's ten $100,000 academic chairs established to lure leading scholars to New, York campuseswill be eliminated this year and the legislator who cut their funds said he hoped to abolish them all.

title: Arms Cache Found in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 15 (AP)British paratroops found a cache of arms and explosives at an athletic field in the heart of the Roman Catholic Ballymurphy quarter here today. An army spokesman said that the cache was one of the biggest found this year.

title: LILIAN HERLEIN
description: Lilian Herlein, who had appeared on the musical and variety stage, died in French Hospital on Tuesday evening after a brief illness. She was believed to be in her seventies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: BLOOD, says the doublesized sticker in shouting capitals. What? Tired Blood? Bloody Mary? Blood n Guts? No. On second glance, you read the smaller letters, giving BLOOD saves lives, and still smaller, United States Postage. The thing is a sixcent stamp, put out to celebrate Blood Donor Month.

title: George Scott and Patton Win Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, April 15Patton, the titanic study of a man at war, swept the 43d Academy Award presentations tonight by winning seven Oscars, including best picture of the year.

title: Wedding of Miss Nixon May Be Televised Live
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The White House said today that Tricia Nixon and Edward Finch Cox will be married in the Rose Garden on June 12 in a ceremony that may be televised live to the nation.

title: France Halts Talks With Algeria; Hints at End to Special Relations
description: PARIS, April 15France cut off further negotiations with Algeria today over their oil relations and indicated that the special ties between the two countries would now be put strictly on a business basis.

title: 4 Cyclists Injured in Fight
description: UPPER DARBY, Pa., April 15 (UPI)  Two motorcycle clubsthe Warlocks and the Pagansbattled on a downtown street in this southeastern Pennsylvania town with ??uns and knives early today, leaving four members wounded, the police reported. About 20 members of the two clubs went to a bar where the fighting broke out, according to the police. The fight spilled into the street and about 15 shots were exchanged before the police arrived.

title: Books of The Times
description: Poetry is almost as popular as pot with the young these days. In the spring of 1969, at the Poetry Festival sponsored by Lehigh's School of Education, more than 1,000 people participated. Out of this Woodstock of poetry came the greater part of this book11 essays by 10 poets and/or teachers who conducted workshops at inner city elementary or high schools.

title: PANTHER KILLING IS LAID TO PURGE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 15Defense counsel for Bobby G. Scale, the Black Panther leader, and Erika Huggins ended two and a half days of crossexamination of Warren Kimbro today without getting him to change the account he gave in Superior Court here of the torture, kidnapping and slaying of Alex Rackley.

title: Blackout on City Payroll Costs
description: New Yorkers are staggering through the windup phases of another municipal labor crisis in the familiar position of knowing almost nothing authoritative about the key factsand least of all about how much the various elements in the projected contract would cost the taxpayers.

title: Florida U. Students Mob Home Of President After Police Battle
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 15 A raucous crowd of 800 angry students flocked to the home of the president of the University of Florida tonight, demanding his resignation and screaming their criticism of the school's racial policy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Earl Ubell's recent probing article, Are We Spending Money for the Wrong Care? [The Week in Review], cuts unerringly to the heart of America's health issue. At a time when public attenion has been directed to one or another national health program, Mr. Ubell makes a vital contribution by suggesting that more doctors and more hospital beds may not be the sole answer to the growing need for health services.

title: Amex Prices Register a Drop in Heavy Trading
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A recent column by Tom Wicker and the March 26 letter from Leslie P. Hemry (Health Insurance Association) on the question of a national health insurance program, raise several very fundamental questions that will soon have to be resolved by the American people through Congress.

title: Taiwan Appears Resigned to a U.S.Red China Thaw
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 15The Chinese Nationalists gave the impression today of paying scant attention to the developments in relations between Communist China and the United States.

title: Japanese Payments Record
description: TOKYO, April 15 (Reuters)Japan had a record surplus of $530million in its balance of international payments for March because of active expansion of exports and a slowdown in imports, according to preliminary figures released by the Finance Ministry today.

title: Cosmetics That One Can Cook at Home
description: If you follow a recipe, you can stretch the family dollar a little furtherby making some cosmetics and toiletries right in the kitchen.

title: F.B.I. SAID TO BUG A HOUSE MEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent an informer into Representative John Dowdy's office on Capitol Hill in 1970 with a hidden tape recorder strapped to his back, according to reliable sources.

title: MARCH FAILS SHOW A SLIGHT DECLINE
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that failsthe inability of brokers to make timely delivery of securitiesdropped slightly in March despite record trading volume that month.

title: Death as Precept
description: TOKYO  In the Christian world, suicide is considered a grave sin. But for Japanese people, it carries a significance unknown to Christendom. In certain cases, suicide can be an extremely beautiful act, worthy of the highest praise.

title: COOPS WEIGH SUIT ON NIXON TAXMAN
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The National Rural Electric Cooperatives Association announced today that it may seek a court action to block the $3billion tax cut for business that the Nixon Administration plans to put into effect.

title: TV Network Sales Rose But Revenues Declined
description: Although TV network unit sales were up again (by 1.1 per cent) in March compared to March of 1970, revenues were off 11 per cent to $142,791,500.

title: Saxbe Supports Hoover
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, predicted today that if the Democrats won the next Presidential election J. Edgar Hoover would be ousted as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He said that Mr. Hoover deserves better than that.

title: Terrorists Kill Brazilian
description: Rio DE JANEIRO, April 15Terrorists machinegunned and killed Alberto Boilesen, a 55yearold Brazilian businessman of Danish origin, on a street in sao Paulo today. The terrorists were reported to have left leaflets declaring that Mr. Boilesen, president of a bottledgas distributing company, was shot in retaliation for the recent killing of a terrorist leader, Devani de Carvalho, by the Sao Paulo police.

title: Newport Council Votes Film Festival License
description: NEWPORT, R.I., April 15 (AP)  A license for a threeday folk festival was approved by a 5to2 vote of the Newport city Council Wednesday, despite one opponent's claims that it is not a good idea to encourage very large crowds to concontrate in one area.

title: Chase Manhattan Reports A 36.4% Rise in Earnings
Canadiens Trounce Bruins, 83, and Tie Series at 3 Victories Each
Art: A Ten Downtown
description: In 1968, under the collective banner of Ten Downtown, 10 artists opened up their respective lofts in or near the downtown Soho area and exhibited their work for three weekends in April. Since then, it has become an annual event. It was organized in such a way that the original 10 artists chose 10 other artists to replace them the following year and the second 10 chose a third 10 and so on. This year's Ten Downtown opened up their lofts last weekend and they will be open two more weekends, Saturday and Sunday, from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Crisis in Newark
description: NEWARKIn NewArk there are over three and onethird billion dollars a year made retail, across the counter. The 65 per cent blacks and 10 per cent Puerto Ricans who comprise the city's majority get hold of less than 1 per cent of this economic. power. The rest of it is carried out to the suburbs by whites who feel no responsibility or commitment to life in NewArk at all, but who simply come to work or do business here, then go home to their version of paradise.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 15, 1971

title: Top Art Auctions Boom, though Economy Sags
description: Haven't they heard of the recession? asked a nonbidding viewer at ParkeBernet last month, after a snappy auction in which 53 buyers paid $2.5million for 66 impressionist and modern paintings.

title: Five New Productions Due at the Met
description: For the 197172 season, his last as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, Rudolf Bing has scheduled five new productions, several debuts and the revival of 12 operas that have not been presented by the company for a year or more. The season will open on Sept. 20 with the Margaret Webster production of Verdi's Don Carlo, which was the opening work at the beginning of Mr. Bing's administration in 1950.

title: Reeves, Rams Owner, Dies
description: Dan Reeves, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, died of cancer in his apartment here yesterday. He was 58 years old. An obituary appears on Page 40.

title: BUILDING INSPECTORS REJECT PROPOSALS
description: The city Building Inspectors Union voted overwhelmingly last night to reject an impasse panel's recommendations to end. a 19monthold contract dispute with the city.

title: Summer Air Wins by 5 Lengths Over Shuvee in Aqueduct Dash
description: Summer Air of the Darby Dan Farm had little trouble taking the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, beating the runnerup, Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee, by five lengths.

title: Griffin Praises F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Senator Robert P. Griffin of Michigan said today that the F.B.I. was at an Earth Day rally here last year not because Senator Muskie was a speaker but because such individuals as Rennis Davis were on the same platform. The Republican leader said the F.B.I has a duty to keep track of those in our society who have an avowed purpose to destroy it, and added that he was glad to know the agency was doing its job.

title: OffDuty Patrolman Kills A Second in Brooklyn Club
description: An offduty city patrolman was shot and killed yesterday by an offduty Transit Authority patrolman in a dispute in a private Brooklyn club in which neither, apparently, was aware that the other was an officer and had a right to carry a gun.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am dismayed by the article by the Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre Jr. On the one hand he tells us that we are all to blame for the crimes of Lieutenant Calley and the criminal policy which put him in Vietnam. On the other hand he takes a swipe at righteous and naive citizens, the marching kind.

title: Man Held in HitRun Case
description: AMITY HARBOR, L. I., April 15 (UPI)A 51yearold postal employe was arrested by the Suffolk County police tonight and charged with leaving the scene of an accident April 3 in which two teenage boys were killed. The man, Joseph F. Casey of 20 DeSoto Road, Amity Harbor, L. I., was arraigned in Amityville Village Court and released on $250 bail by Judge J. J. Donahue.

title: Britons Say Chinese Accept
description: LONDON, April 15 (UPI)Communist China has accepted an invitation to send a table tennis team to Britain, British players reported from Peking today.

title: Good Italian Food Is Easy on Purse
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Baghdad Is Seeking To Disprove Charge It Oppresses Jews
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15Iraq has opened a counteroffensive against charges that members of her Jewish community are being persecuted.

title: Liechtenstein: A Tiny Corner of Europe That Is Doing Big Things
description: VADUZ, Liechtenstein, April 9Six weeks after this tiny principality rejected women's suffrage by a narrow margin, its leaders are feeling uncomfortable about all the publicity the event received.

title: VILLAGE UNIT URGES CLOSING OF A HOTEL
description: Community Planning Board 2 demanded last night that the city close the Greenwich Hotel, at Bleecker and Thompson Streets, as expeditiously as possible on the ground that it is a haven for narcotic dealers and addicts.

title: Big Board Amends Rules To Allow Flexible Rates
description: The membership of the New York Stock Exchange has avoided a confrontation with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department by passing new rules to implement negotiated sales charges on certain large stock transactions.

title: House With the Spirit (and Possibly Spirits?) of an Earlier Age
description: EYE, N. Y.There are fearful ghosts (The Canterbury), friendly ghosts (Casper), ghosts that stalk the ramparts (Hamlet's father) and even ghostly ghost writers as in The Ghost and Mrs. Muir. And here, in a 100 year old, 16 room Victorian house, there are ghosts who use the telephonewhich may explain those extra message units that inexplicably pile up on the phone bill.

title: ComicBook Industry to Allow Stories on Narcotics
description: For the first time since they banded together 17 years ago to adopt a code to govern their industry, the country's major comic book publishers agreed yesterday to give themselves written permission to deal with the subject of narcotics.

title: MRS. COURT GAINS S. AFRICAN FINAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 15 (UPI)  Mrs. Margaret Court and Evonne Goolagong disposed of British opponents today to complete an allAustralian lineup in both singles finals at the South African open tennis championships.

title: Survey Finds Population Growth Is Viewed as a Potential Problem
description: The Gallup Poll has found that an overwhelming majority of Americans think population growth in the United Staes is a potential problem but not necessarily for the immediate future.

title: PUBLISHERS FIGHT POSTAL RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)  A suit to halt temporary increases in postage rates, expected by May 16, was filed today in United States District Court here by magazine and newspaper publishers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dr. B. W. Gajwani's letter (April 5) requires some analysis. It is perhaps easy to mislead the American people by telling them that the arms supplied by them are misusedin Pakistan's case, against India and not China.

title: Talks on Contracts With Sanitationmen And P.B.A., Go On
description: The city continued its bargaining talks yesterday with patrolmen and sanitationmen, but a spokesman said the city had no new offer to make to the firemen, who rejected a tentative agreement last Wednesday.

title: CRIMMINS JURORS STUDY 2 WOMEN
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins and Mrs. Marvin Weinstein stood side by side for almost a minute yesterday in front of the jury in the State Supreme Court Building in Queens both 5 feet 2 inches tall, both, with high cheekbones and long noses and both obviously little nervous.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Would it not be wise for the City of New York to contract with a selfliquidating agency to tow cars that have received tickets for illegal parking? This agency could be in intercom contact with meter maids, who would report license number, car and location for pickup. The agency could get $25 of the $50 towing charge.

title: Cooke Has First Audience With Pope in Nearly a Year
description: ROME, April 15Cardinal Cooke, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, had a halfhour audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican today.

title: China Held Closer to U.N. Seat
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15  The apparent thaw in relations between Washington and Peking has convinced many diplomats here that the Communist Government now has a real chance of being seated in the United Nations this fall as China's sole legitimate representative.

title: 11 WAR PROTESTERS SEIZED AT I.R.S. HERE
description: Eleven persons were arrested yesterday afternoon when demonstration against taxes to support the war in Vietnam ended in a sitin outside the offices of the Internal Revenue Service at 120 Church Street.

title: Film Focuses on Trial of Chicago 7
description: Remember the good old days? Remember the time Abbie Hoffman, who was wearing an American flag, shared the guest bench on the Merv Griffin Show with Virginia Graham, who was wearing a lot of things that sparkled, rippled or were cinched in? The network blacked out Mr. Hoffman because his clothing was objectionable. Remember when Jerry Rubin appeared on a Channel 13 talk show and smoked pot and insulted liberals?Remember an underground movie called "Brand X," in which Abbie, as naked as a jaybird, lay back in a bathtub full of money, which he set fire to, but then he had to climb out at the last minute, as if he had just remembered that self-imolation was not in his contract? Remember? It was only a year or so ago, when revolution for the hell of it was still something of a groove.Morley Markson's feature-length documentary, "Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family," contains none of these memorable moments, being, instead, a montage of events, personalities and reactions relating to last year's Chicago conspiracy trial. However, its principal actors are those spry, venerable old stars of revolution-as-burlesque, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin, and in revolution-as-burlesque, as in most other forms of theater, over-exposure (as well as complete exposure) can be fatal. It removes the mystery.Time has taken its terrible toll and although Mr. Hoffman and Mr. Rubin were two of the eight defendants at the trial, they were the two least interesting, as well as the two most garrulous. From this vantage point, they simply are no longer as important as the issues raised by the trial and the manner in which the trial was conducted.This is the curious effect of Mr. Markson's very uneven film, which, when Mr. Rubin and Mr. Hoffman are on the screen, approaches a purity of boredom, that is, in the revolutionary context, downright counterrevolutionary. If Mr. Robin, at one point, can stand and accuse America of boredom, so shall he be accused. That's show biz, gentlemen, which there is no other business like, except possibly revolution.The problem with "Breathing Together" as a movie is that it doesn't seem to realize any particular concept on the part of its producer-director, as much as it makes do with the material that could be obtained. Some of this is first-rate: R. Buckminster Fuller, seated in a lawn chair, looking like a tidily tailored prophet, talking about the changes taking place in this country, about the evils of property, about our confrontation with "invisible information" (radio signals) and exhorting us to "let go of the physicalapprehend the metaphysical."It's just bits and pieces, but bits and pieces of Buckminster Fuller are better than entire chunks of the two stars. I also liked a couple of pastoral sequences featuring Allen Ginsberg, the poet and player, and was moved, with the help of hindsight, by a sequence showing a Chicago rally being addressed by Fred Hampton, the Black Panther leader shortly to be shot dead by Chicago police. That was not burlesque.However, "Breathing Together" never succeeds in fusing its various parts into a more meaningful whole. I. for one, know no more about the Chicago trial now than I did before I saw the film, which, though fancily edited, is ordinary journalism. It opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum for one week.In yesterday's review of "The Blood on Satan's Claw," I inadvertently compared the film to "Les Vampires," by Louis Feuillade. The comparison should have been to "Vampyr," by Carl Drever. The difference is, roughly, the difference between gangsters (Feuillade) and ghouls (Dreyer).
