title: TIME INC. PROFITS UP 6% IN QUARTER
description: Time Inc., the nation's leading magazine publisher, reported yesterday that firstquarter earnings rose 6 per cent from a year earlier, despite a 4 per cent slide in revenues.

title: Methodists Elect Texan
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 15 (AP)Bishop O. Eugene Slater of San Antonio today was named presidentelect of the Council of Bishops of the United Methodist Church. He will assume office in April, 1972.

title: Poindexter Asks Davis Bail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (UPI)David Poindexter, acquitted Monday in New York on Federal charges of having harbored Angela Davis as fugitive, turned up in San Francisco today to speak at a news conference for her release on reasonable bail. He said he would travel around the country in cooperation with the National United Committee to Free Angela Davis. He was acquitted on charges that he traveled with Miss Davis for weeks while she was sought on a murder charge.

title: SALARIES OF U.M.W. ROSE 25% IN YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Salaries of officers and employes of the United Mine Workers increased 25 per cent last year to $2.35million, according to union records newly filed with the Labor Department.

title: Citizen Suits on Pollution Opposed by White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Nixon Administration opposed today a bill designed to assure citizens an almos, unlimited right to file suits in Federal courts for the protection of the environment.

title: CEYLON BIDS EMBASSY OF PYONGYANG CLOSE
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 15 North Korea has been larked to close its embassy in Colombo immediately for complicity in the insurrection to overthrow the Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, informed sources said today.

title: Dr. Herman P. Martell Is Dead; Led Jewish Civil Service Group
description: Dr. Herman P. Mantell, president of the Council of Jewish Organizations in Civil Service and for many years a school principal here, died of cancer yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 246 West End Avenue.

title: ROGERS ASSURES LATINS ON TRADE
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 15  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the Nixon Administration would work with Congress to develop an open market in the United States for both traditional and new exports from Latin America.

title: Father of L. I. Paralytic Tells of High Cost of Care
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 15 The Senate Subcommittee on Health heard testimony today that a family with an annual income of $50,000 had to pay between $75,000 and $100,000 a year for the care of a paralyzed son.

title: Arms Halted, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The United States has not delivered arms or ammunition to Pakistan since fighting erupted there March 25, officials said today. They added that there was no military equipment for Pakistan in the pipeline and that further deliveries were under review.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: VIENNA, Md.When the spring spawning run of striped bass reaches its peak in the Nanticoke, long reaches of the river are slick with the oil globules from the mil, ions of eggs released by the fish, and even if a strong wind is blowing, the surface of the water, calmed by the oil, is as smooth as a millpond.

title: INSURANCE CONCERN TO MOVE OUT OF CITY
description: The General Reinsurance Corporation announced yesterday that it would move its 250man national headquarters from Park Avenue to Greenwich, Conn., by late 1973.

title: City Seeking Laws To Broaden Betting
description: ALBANY, April 15New York City hopes the initial success of offtrack betting will serve as a springboard for legislative changes that would open all sports to legal wagering and let 18yearolds use betting parlors.

title: Apollo 14 Astronaut Is Sued for Divorce
description: HOUSTON, April 15 (AP) Capt. Edgar D. Mitchell, the Apollo 14 astronaut, who landed on the moon, was sued for divorce today.

title: Death Row Cells for Women
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 15 (UP)California is building a death row for women to house the three young women under sentence of death for their part in the TateLaBianca slayings. An isolated, sixcell unit is being added to the onestory reception center at the California Institution for Women near Frontera for Susan Atkins. Leslie Van Houten and Patricia Krenwinkel.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose, 0.1 From theWeekAgo Level
Wrath of Palestinians on Cairo Radio Is Aimed Mainly at Jordanian Leaders
description: CAIRO, April 15The wrath and scorn of the Voice of Assifa, the Palestinian: program back on the Cairo radio after a sevenmonth involuntary intennission, seems to be direct ed these days mainly at the authorities in Jordan.

title: NATION'S OUTPUT RESUMED GROWTH IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The nation's total output resumed fairly vigorous growth in the first quarter of this year, though a good part of the reason was recovery from the General Motors strike, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: N.Y.U., Needing the Money For Institutional Quality, Drops Basketball, Track
description: New York University will not compete in basketball or track and field next season and will stop recruiting athletes for those sports at once, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James M. Hester, the university's president.

title: Berrigan Case Subpoenas Served on 10 by the F.B.I.
description: BOSTON, April 15Teams of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, operating in four cities, served subpoenas today on at least 10 persons, ordering them to appear before the Harrisburg, Pa., grand jury that indicted the Rev. Philip J. Berrigan and five other persons on charges of conspiring to destroy Government property and kidnap a Federal official.

title: Maritime Chiefs Hail Prospects For Resumption of China Trade
description: Spokesmen for American shipowners and seamen yesterday hailed the prospect of remining the trade with mainland China that stopped with the Communist takeover in 1949.

title: PHILADELPHIA UNION ORDERS STRIKE END
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP)Leaders of a striking transit union submitted to court pressure tonight and ordered their 5,200 members to end a fourday walkout that had tied up public transportation for more than a million riders daily.

title: Armand Denis, Author, Is Dead; Produced TV Films on Animals
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 15Armand Denis, the television film director and author, died today at his country home 12 miles from here after a Iong illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Parishioners Rally Behind Priest Who Married
description: PACIFICA, Calif., April 15They were not shocked. Many of them were not even surprised. And if there was any anger, they hid it well.

title: Jersey Senate Approves Bill on Sewage Pollution
description: TRENTON, April 15  A measure that would give New Jersey the power to prohibit large housing developments and apartment construction without adequate sewagetreatment facilities was approved unanimosuly today by the State Senate.

title: Agnew Grants Request for Mass Antiwar Demonstration on Capital Lawn
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Vice President Agnew said today that he had decided to grant a request by an antiwar group to hold a mass rally on the West Lawn of the Capitol later this month.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE DOWN FROM 70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended April 10 was below the volume in the corresponding 1970 week. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an unusually large increase because of labor problems in the trucking industry during the comparable week of 1970.

title: British Show Gain In Overseas Trade
description: LONDON, April 15 (Reuters)  Britain's overseas trade in March ended with a surplus of $2.7million, the Government announced today.

title: PLUMBING CONCERNS SETTLE U.S. CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The Justice Department today filed a proposed settlement of pricefixing charges against eight major plumbing fixture manufacturers that had been sued for millions of dollars in overcharges by states, cities and towns.

title: REED SET TO PLAY AGAINST BULLETS
STALIN CRITICIZED IN A SOVIET NOVEL
description: MOSCOW, April 15A novel that suggests that many Russians worshiped Stalin in his lifetime out of a naive faith in his infallibility has just been published here and is attracting considerable attention in intellectual circles.

title: Overloose Campaign Controls
description: The Nixon Administration and Senate Democrats are reportedly nearing agreement on a compromise plan to control political campaign spending. As was painfully demonstrated by Mr. Nixon's veto of an earlier version last year, the enactment into law of any bill in this mineladen field would be a triumph. To be reasonably effective, however, a bill must contain certain minimum provisions.

title: Federal Tax Deadline Gone for Another Year
description: ANDOVER, Mass., April 15 (AP)Today was the deadline for filing 1970 Federal income tax returns.

title: A Samurai's Strategic Rise to Power
description: Despite the Western-style music (I mean cowboy-Western), the familiar presence of Toshiro Mifune in the lead, the by now accustomed ordering of spaces and deployment of forcesit is just possible that Hiroshi Inagaki's "Samurai Banners," which opened yesterday at the Bijou, belongs to an altogether stranger order of being than at first we might imagine. I think this because in all its extraordinary length (almost three hours) and for all its self-evident effort to be popular, it never seems, at least in ways that I can recognize, to rise above or even to equal the interest of its particular events."Samurai Banners" deals with an unattached samurai, Kansuk Yamamoto (Toshiro Mifune), a cripple and a brilliant military strategist, who insinuates himself into the service of a great feudal warlord of the Takeda clan whom he counsels in the early stages of the lord's ambitious career. The movie begins in the 1540's, with Takeda's first victories, follows his rise as one of the most powerful leaders in Japan, notes his admission to the priesthood (when he takes the name "Shingen"), and leaves him in 1561 after a massive battle with another priestly warlord, Kenshin Uesugi, which proves indecisive but which results in the bloody death of the strategist Kansuk.I mention all this because "Samurai Banners" makes a considerable thing of historyincluding dates and war conferences and plans and even animated battlefield maps painted on the screen at the same time that it means to be something more than history, or at the very least to annex to its history a vision of personal tragedy destiny. Thus Kansuk falls in love with a princess (Yoshiko Sakuma) whom Takeda takes as his second wife and who bears him a son and a little later dies without even seeking more from Kansuk than a kind of gruff fatherly protection.But when he diesas a Mifune hero ought to die, an enemy arrow in one eye and maybe half a dozen more scattered about his bodyit is in his lord's service but for himself, so that he may join his lady. And this story might have made a movie of great traditional beautyinstead of the sometimes colorful but usually perfunctory pageant that "Samurai Banners" seems most charitably to be.Inagaki handles his camera with an expertisein massive tracks, elegant crane shots and demanding anglesthat wars with the basic crudity of his sense of the dramatic moment and makes for a nagging unpleasantness that always results when there is more technique than feeling, and when visual display exceeds any sustained sense of controlling idea.

title: A Cold Dish for a Warm Day
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Newark Teachers Reject Pact; Gibson Expected to Offer Plan
description: NEWARK, April 15  The Newark Teachers Union today rejected the Board of Education's latest proposal to settle the 11weekold teachers strike here.

title: Appraising Mideast Intelligence
description: LONDONFor reasons comprehensible only to those who have worked in a diplomatic service, no government can afford to keep its public fully informed on what it does in the field of international, relations. Sometimes it must conceal the reasons for its actions, and sometimes the actions themselves. In some rare instances, it must pretend to be taking one set of actions while actually taking another, and to present the public with a largely fictional picture of what is doing and why.

title: ORLANDO BOY CHOIR IN TULLY PROGRAM
description: When too much wasn't asked of it musically, the Singing Boys of Orlando proved to be an attractive ensemble in its concert in Tully Hall on Wednesday night. The fouryearold integrated, nonsectarian choir included 33 youngsters from Florida under the direction of Byron ?? He had disciplined them well in phrasing, enunciation and deportment, and he wisely did not make them force their youthful voices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I. W. Abel of the United Steelworkers is caught in a vise. Surely Its knows that wage increases for his rank and file that outstrip productivity will only lead to further increases in imports, with a corresponding drop in domestic production. This, ironically, would reduce employment for steelworkers in this country.

title: Fourth of Texas Eligible For U.S. Aid in Drought
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (Reuters)About a quarter of Texas was declared eligible for special disaster relief today because of a drought believed to be the worst since the midnineteenfifties.

title: Auto Pollution Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency will hold a public hearing next month to determine if the automotive industry is making a good faith effort toward meeting motor vehicle emission standards that are to go into effect in 1975. William D. Ruckeishaus, the agency's administrator, said the hearings will be held here May 67.

title: Shanghai Feast Challenges Americans
description: SHANGHAI, April 15 (UPI) A banquet offered today to the visiting table tennis team supported. goodnatured complaints by. seine of the Americans that the Chinese are giving them too much to eat.

title: PAKISTANI TROOPS ACCUSED BY INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, April 15The Indian Government charging that Pakistani troops had fired machine guns into Indian territory, warned Pakistan today to stop such actions or face any consequences that may ensue.

title: Theater: Latest Essay in Geriatrics;70, Girls, 70, Arrives at the Broadhurst
description: Life, as Mae West omitted to say, begins at 70.

title: Beyond PingPong Diplomacy
description: As the Chinese People's Republic moves now to reestablish longsevered external contacts, there is much in its conduct reminiscent of the similar Soviet process in the mid1950's, the years just after Stalin's death.

title: U.S. Team Is Welcomed in Shanghai; Sees the Sights, Plays Another Match
description: SHANGHAI, April 15A Chinese sports official told 15 members of the United States table tennis delegation today that he was very glad you have come to Shanghai, and that their presence was a sign of friendship which we hope extends to all the American people.

title: Times Reporter in China Gets Visa for One Month
description: CANTON, China, April 15 There was a slight hitch at the start of the venture into China.

title: Moscow Reports Moves
description: MOSCOW. April 15 (Reuters) Toss reported today on President Nixon's fivepoint plan for improving relations with China under the headline Mutual Gestures of Peking and Washington.

title: Cuban Exiles, Too, Are Troubled by Generation Gap
description: MIAMI, April 15Puffs of clouds sail across the Miami evening sky and a buttermilk moon casts a soft halflight on the roofs of the sprawling Cuban district. Under one roof, Ada Merritt Junior High School, America's newest immigrants sing a chorus of their first English words: ... four, five, six... Rolando Amador,a handsometeacher with dark curly halr, stands beneath a giant banyan tree in the courtyard and listens to the singsong count of his countrymen echoing from an upstairs classroom window.

title: Bridge Saved, Pakistan Says By ERIC PACE
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 15 The Pakistani radio said tonight that Pakistani troops had prevented Indian infiltrators and antistate elements from dynamiting the strategic Bhairab railroad bridge in East Pakistan.

title: Suspect Is Seized in Paraguay As Smuggler of Heroin to U.S.
description: A Federal indictment was announced here yesterday against a Frenchman identified as the head of an operation that smuggled millions of dollars of heroin into the United States from Paraguay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I for one violently oppose the April 5 OpEd article by the Very Rev. Francis Sayre Jr. I do not feel our nation is on trial and I do not derive pleasure from selfincrimination. I certainly do not feel, as does the Very Reverend Sayre, that almost all we have been wont to count as precious in this world is being slaughtered.

title: Bishops Study Challenges Ban on Married Priests
description: An official report commissioned by the American Roman Catholic bishops says that there is no solid theological foundation for church policies banning women from the priesthood or restricting priests from marrying.

title: Mary Donlon, Judge, Is Wed
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 15The marriage of Judge Mary H. Donlon, senior judge of the United States Customs Court in New York, to Martin Joseph Alger, a retired vice president of the New York Central Railroad Company, took place this morning.

title: Three More Join in Effort To Unseat Fox Management
description: Three more men joined the dissident group of stockholders seeking to unseat the management of Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation yesterday by filing the necessary documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Tito Threatens Purge in Unity Crisis
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15President Tito has brought a smoldering crisis into the open and vowed to salvage the unity of Yugoslavia even if he has to purge his own Communist party.

title: Minotaur Theme Of Cretan Film Devoted top Sex
Tennis Tournament Will Invite Chinese To Compete Here
description: The United States Open tennis tournament announced yesterday that it would invite Communist China to compete in the tournament, which will be held at Forest Hills, Queens, from Sept. 1 to 12.

title: Fanny May Earnings Rose $2.6Million in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association today reported its firstquarter earnings reached $5.5million, up from $2.9million in the previous threemonth period.

title: Merck's Earnings Higher
description: Three major drug companies] announced firstquarter earnings yesterday that were only slightly changed from their 1970 levels.

title: The Top Cop and Snooping Issue
description: WASHINGTON, April 15When a Republican President is less than zealous in the defense of J. Edgar Hoover against his leading Democratic challenger, it can be fairly deduced that the nation's legendary top cop is in trouble. For the moment, it is easier to understand the causes of the trouble than to know how deep it runs or where it will lead. Responding to Senator Edmund S. Muskie's charges of unwar ranted snooping on peaceful assemblies on last year's Earth Day, the White House says that it is against such surveillance and doubts that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has done anything contrary to policy.

title: Reiner Victor in Tennis Special to The New York Times
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., April 15Gar Reiner of New Hyde Park, L.I., defeated Joe Garber, Brooklyn, 63, 61; Jim Landis, Roslyn, L,I., beat Chuck Ackerman, Staten Island, 63, 61, and Gene Mayer Woodmere, LI., beat Steve Geller, Brooklyn, 61, 60, today in the first round of the Concord junior tennis tournament.

title: 7 of 9 Cigarette Companies to Carry Warning in Ads
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Seven of the country's nine cigarette manufacturers have agreed to include a health warning in advertisements of their products.

title: U.S. Stops Money Due Newark Till Housing Unit Reorganizes
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it would freeze payment of $400,000 due the debtridden Newark Authority, because the authority had not agreed to reorganize itself along lines urged last January.

title: OTB Retreats a Elton Derby: Exacta to Replace Triple
description: While offtrack betting continued at an orderly pace in Grand Central Terminal yesterday, OTB did some rethinking about the Kentucky Derby.

title: Reconciliation in Uganda
description: General Idi Amin, military ruler of Uganda, has kept his promise to bring home the body of Sir Edward Frederick Mutesa, the late Kabaka (king) of Buganda, for traditional burial. But he wisely prefaced this move, designed to ease old tribal divisions, by declaring that there can be no return of feudal kings or kingdoms, because Uganda is going forward, not backward.

title: British Team Visits Old Tombs
description: PEKING, April 15 (Reuters)  British table tennis players visited two of China's most famous historic monuments today, the Great Wall and the Ming Tombs, accompanied by interpreters and officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A major issue in the Newark teachers strike which began on Feb. 1 has been binding arbitration, which the school board claimed that neither nor the community could live with.

title: 1,000Man Civil Force Urged To Spot and Commit Addicts
description: A special 1,000man force to scoop up heroin addicts from the streets of New York before they commit crimes was pro, posed yesterday by City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath.

title: Kaneko Leads on a 67
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 15 (AP)  Mitsuo Kaneko of Japan, shot a fiveunderpar 67 today for a onestroke first round lead in the $15,000 Korean open golf championship.

title: Hijacking Pact Action Urged
description: WASHINGTON, April 15, (Reuters)  President Nixon asked Congress today to ratify promptly an international convention signed by 60 countries that calls for extradition or severe punishment of airplane hijackers. Mr. Nixon said he believed that the convention drawn up in The Hague in December would be an effective deterrent to hijackings.

title: Tocks IslandAnother Look
description: The decision of the Council of Environmental Quality to request another study of the Tocks Island Dam gratifying if the move is not merely a delaying tactic. It is nine years now since, Congress authorized the vast project, and reports on it would almost suffice to line the bottom of the proposed 37mile lake it would create in the midst of the magnificent Delaware River Valley. In those years scores of people have been forced to sell their homes, and others, anticipating an ultimate claim on their property, would like to sell but no longer even expect to. It is unfair, in human terms, to leave people in limbo for such a length of time, unable either to plan or to move out.

title: U.S. TIRE CONCERNS STYMIED BY DUTCH
description: The battle between the B. F. Goodrich Company and the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company for control of the Netherlands tire producer, N.V. Rubberfabrielc Vredestein, continued stalemated yesterday after a Dutch court ruled that neither of the American companies could vote their shares in Rubberfabriek. The Dutch court ruling prevents both American companies from registering and voting their Vredestein shares and leaves the Dutch company in the hands of its management for the present.

title: Those Giant Toys Are the Furniture
description: Any resemblance between the educational toys in Bloomingdale's toy department and the store's new children's furnishings section (fifth floor) is strictly on purpose. Or so it seems in the international assemblage of chairs, beds and chests that look like outsize playthings. Take the collection by Anthony Graham Designs, a British producer, that uses the same big wooden screws to bolt frames to chests, chair seats, table and desk tops. The collection comes in combinations of two or three colors (white, yellow, red and blue) at prices ranging from $35 for a combination chair and table to $195 for a large wardrobe.

title: Alcoa Reports a Sharp Decline in Earnings
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15John D. Harper, chairman and chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America, told the concern's annual meeting. here today that earnings in the first quarter dropped 42 per cent, compared to income for the 1970 period.

title: Hundley on Disabled List
description: CHICAGO, April 15 (UPI)Randy Hundley, Chicago Cub catcher, was placed on the 15day disabled list today to undergo, treatment for his injured right knee. Ernie Banks, who has been on the disabled list, will fill Hundley's place.

title: C. Russell Hurd And Mrs. Sif ton Marry at Resort
description: Mrs. Carolyn Sifton of Toronto, granddaughter of the late Sir Clifford Sifton, founder of a Canadian newspaper empire, was married in Acapulco, Mexico, last night to C. Russell Hurd of Acapulco. The civil ceremony took place at the house the bide rented for the winter from Mrs. Emi Fors.

title: Statement by Mitchell
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPHAttorney General John N. Mitchell defended today the F.B.I.'s presence at an Earth Day rally in Washington on the basis of advance information indicating that persons with records of violence were planning to attend.

title: Editors Protest Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The American Society of Newspaper Editors sent to the House of Representatives today a telegram denouncing the action of a House Commerce subcommittee in subpoenaing all background material amassed by the Columbia Broadcasting System for its controversial documentary program The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: Protest in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)  The Soviet Embassy protested harassment of three of its diplomats yesterday and asked the United States to provide appropriate protection for embassy personnel. State Department officials said today. The Jewish Defense League claimed responsibility for the incident.

title: Stage: Baal's Inventive Experiment
description: Take a large industrial spool (the sort that power companies leave in city streets), three long metal cylinders, two bent stovepipes, a metal ring large enough to circle someone's neck, a rope and a white ball. Turn two actors loose, like children at play in an attic, and watch them make dramatic use of found objects.

title: ExAgents Back Hoover
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 15 (AP)The president of the National Society of Former Special Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today denounced recent criticism of Mr. Hoover as unwarranted an? unjust.

title: SOVIET ASSURED BY U.S. ON CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The White House said today that the United States efforts to improve relations with Communist China were in no way meant to embarrass or exert pressure on the Soviet Union.

title: MOUNTAIN TURNS UP ROCKMUSIC VOLUME
description: Mountain is New York's contribution to that ominus music Called heavy rockall power, thunder, noise, etc. The group finished a fourday engagement at the Fillmore East last night.

title: PLAN CHALLENGED ON JOBLESS GOAL
description: A top economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis challenged yesterday the recent proposal by the Joint Economic Committee that the President and the Congress should adopt as a longterm objective the longterm goals of an unemployment rate no higher than 3 per cent and an annual increase in (prices) of no more than per cent.

title: WHEAT FUTURES REGAIN GROUND
description: Rain in the Southwestern areas where Winter wheat is I grown caused heavy liquidation of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesIterday.

title: Success Reported in Relocating Welfare Families Out of Hotels
description: In the first month of the program to move 100 welfare families a month from hotels to better housing, 64 families had moved by yesterday, 291 more were in the process ofl moving and 55 more have signed leases and will move soon, the City's Housing Authority reported.

title: Shanker Warns of Havoc From a Big Teacher Cut
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, warned yesterday that a cut of 11,250 teaching positions next fall because of the city's tight financial situation would create such havoc that the Mayor might as well shut down the schools altogether:

title: CHARLES F. PABST, HEALTH CRUSADER
description: Dr. Charles F. Pabst, retired chief dermatologist of Greenpoint Hospital, Brooklyn, who worked earnestly to prevent serious sunburn and other skin troubles, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 83 years old and lived at l.5 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

title: NO REST FOR TIRED IN TONIGHT'S PAGE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 15Whoever gave the name of Tired to the son of Bret Hanover and Schatzie was responsible for a misnomer. The sophomore colt, rated a strong, contender in tomorrow night's $20,000 final of the Sagamore Hill Pacing Series at Roosevelt Raceway, has not lived up to his name.

title: MISS NORELL MAKES HARPSICHORD DEBUT
description: Judith Norell, a harpsichordist who is completing her studies with Albert Fuller at the Juilliard School, made her New York recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night playing music by Francois Couperin, Domenico Scarlatti, Bach and Haydn.

title: Speno Estate Is $1Million
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 15 (AP) The late Senator Edward J. Speno, Republican of East Meadow, who died of a heart attack in Albany Feb. 17, left an estate of almost $1.1million, according to his will, which was filed today in the Nassau County Surrogate's Court. His assets included $362,300 in real property and personal property valued at $729,310. The entire amount was left to his widow, Audrey.

title: ABEL DEFIES NIXON ON STEEL WAGE BID
description: PITTSBURGH, April 15 (UPI) I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said today that his union members resent deeply the intrusion by the Nixon Administration into the forthcoming steel contract negotiations.

title: Books of The Times
description: Despite Sylvia Plath's tragic fate (she committed suicide in 1963 at the age of 31); despite the legend that has grown up around her writing (she published more than 170 poems, a novel, a verse play and five short stories in less than a decade); and despite her novel's long and controversial history (it was published in England under a nom de plume in 1963 and has circulated widely here in Its English edition, but has not hitherto been published in America because of pressure from the author's family), one attempts to read The Bell Jar for its own esthetic sake. And insofar as that is possible, one takes pleasure in doing so, for the book is not nearly so crude and formless as its reputation has had it. Indeed, stripped clean of its extraesthetic detritus and viewed from the vantage point of the 1970's, The Bell Jar seems, not just the moving story of Esther Greenwood's psychic suffering, but a metaphor of an entire era suffocating under a bell jar.

title: Bridge: ?? To Contract in NoTrump
description: A player in notrump who has a weak suit that the opponents can attack effectively may have to play with considerable subtlety to discourage them from doing so. It may be possible to persuade them to continue on a road that leads them nowhere.

title: Turbine Generator Plant Is Being Built in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., April 15The Brown Boveri Corporation broke ground here today for the $10million nucleus of what may develop into the nation's third major turbine generator manufacturer.

title: Dutch Blast Damages Russian and U.S. Offices
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 15 (AP)  An explosion rocked the Soviet trade delegation's building here early today and damaged the United States Consulate next door.

title: Paraguay Raises Pay Level
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 15 (AP)The Government of President Alfredo Stroessner today decreed a 10 per cent increase in the minimum wages of Paraguayan workers, the first such increase since 1964. It was designed to match the increase in the cost of living, which the Government said had risen 10.5 per cent since 1964.

title: This Year's Budget Crisis Real
description: The voices of fiscal doom emanating from City Hall have a familiar ring.

title: STUTTGART GROUP SINGS BACH MASS
description: At any one moment during Bach's B Minor Mass, given Wednesday night by the Stuttgart Bach Chorus and Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, the makings of a superlative performance were present.

title: AID PLAN IN PERIL, PHYSICIANS WARN
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Medical educators warned today of an impending financial crisis that could disrupt medical student recruitment and jeopardize efforts to get more minority group members into the health professions.

title: JANE FONDA SIGNS FOR FRENCH FILM
description: Jane Fonda and Yves Montend have been signed to star in Tout Va Bien (Everything Is Fine), a feature film to be directed in English and French versions by JeanLuc Godard, the controversial moviemaker who was a pioneering member of France's New Wave.

title: Van Arsdale, in Court Accord, Faces New Taxi Union Election
description: Harry Van Arsdale, the city's most powerful labor leader, must face a rerun of his November, 1969, reelection as president of the taxi drivers union because of alleged irregularities in the original voting.

title: LINDSAY ATTACKS RELIEF MINIMUM;Says $2,400aYear Plan in Congress Insults the Poor
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday attacked as outrageously inadequate proposals in Congress for a welfare minimum of $2,400 a year for a family of four.

title: Brave New World for PingPong
description: Now that a PingPong ball has cracked the Bamboo Curtain and the game of table tennis has suddenly bounced into the center of international diplomacy, there are New Yorkers who are saying they knew. all along that the game had a lot more punch than the public knew.

title: Strike in Rome Gives Tourists Day to RememberOr Forget
description: ROME, April 15This city never seemed lovelier than it did today under a cloudless spring, sky, with the pine trees whispering in a soft breeze, the traffic unusually light, and the sounds so subdued that one could heat) the fountains splash in the squares. One could also hear the groans of hungry and thirsty tourists.

title: They, Back at Talks, Offers Nothing New
description: PARIS, April 15Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese delegation at the peace talks here, returned to the conference table today after a sevenweek absence but he brought no change in his country's position with him.

title: Woman Sues Columbia Over Interview on Sex Life
description: A woman sued Teachers College of Columbia University, and one of its psychologists, for $4million yesterday, contending that she bald been seen and heard by students during what she had thought was confidential interview about her sex life.

title: Store Sales Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended April 10 was an estimated $776,000,000, an increase of 15 per cent above the $676,000,000 sales for tha corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the week were an estimated $7,740,000,000, an increase of 14 per cent above the $6,782,000,000 sales for the same period last year.

title: Rush Quits Redskin Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) Clive Rush, former head coach of the Boston Patriots, who two months ago was named offensive coordinator for the Washington Redskins, resigned today for health reasons.

title: Roundup: Powell and Orioles Roll On
description: After a whiter of fishing off the Florida coast, hitting fungoes to a junior college baseball team and speaking at dinners that featured curdled gravy, John Wesley (Boog) Powell is tilting seismographs again in the American League.

title: 6 Newsmen to Interview Nixon Over 2 Radio Networks Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 An hourlong interview with President Nixon by four newspaper executives and two reporters will be broadcast live on radio tomorrow night.

title: Monroe Portrait on View
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)A Gilbert Stuart portrait of President James Monroe, on loan from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been placed in the White House on a wall outside the state dining room. The painting, done from life, shows Monroe sitting at a writing table.

title: DR. BERNARD LINDEN, SPACE PHYSICIST, 45
description: Dr. Bernard Robert Linden, a physicist who first specialized in electronic tubes and later turned to the food industry, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 45 years old and lived at 4 Hemlock Drive, North Caldwell, N.J.

title: MANSFIELD BACKS HOOVER AND F.B.I RIDICULES CRITICS
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader, came to the defense of J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investigation today and charged that recent criticism of the agency and its director contained more noise than substance.

title: DAN REEVES DIES; OWNER OF RAMS
description: Daniel F. Reeves, the principal owner of the Los Angeles Rams, who brought the franchise west from Cleveland in 1946, died in his New York apartment of cancer yesterday he was 58 years old.

title: Stravinshy Is Interred in Venice B Near Grave of Friend Diaghilev
description: VENICE, Italy, April 15In golden sunshine, Igor Stravinsky was buried today in the cemetery on the island of San Michele, close to his friend and early patron, Sergei Diaghilev.

title: Red China to Aid Mauritania
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania,) April 15 (Agence FrancePresse) Communist China is to finance the building of a deepwater port here, Foreign Minister Harndi ould Moul nass is Mauritania announced ??

title: Nader Named Winner 0f $10,000 Berg Prize
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, was named today the 1971 winner of the $10,000 Max Berg Award for a major achievement in prolonging or improving the quality of human life.

title: 3 Republican Senators Ask Withdrawal Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Complaints came from the Republican side of the aisle in the Senate today that President Nixon had not gone far enough with his plans of disengagement from the Vietnam war.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South AfricaAny South American tour forces certain conclusions that are best reported immediately, even from another continent. The first conclusion is that there has been a major change in relations with North America. The Monroe Doctrine's inherent philosophy that developed into an effort to exclude foreign powers from a market where the U.S.A. sought outlets for its capital surplus is now wholly outdated. One wry joke heard in Latin lands is: The Alliance for Progress must be succeeding; we are getting a better class of dictator.

title: For the Public Weal Joseph Chamberlain Wilson
description: Last year one of the division managers at the Xerox Corporation decided that he should be devoting his life to something more worthwhile than helping one of America's giant corporations make more money.

title: Mass for Daniel Reeves
description: A Mass of the Resurrection for Daniel F. Reeves, the principal owner of the Los Angeles Rams who died on Thursday at the age of 58, will be offered at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street, at 10 A.M. on Monday. Interment will be private at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. There will be a memorial service at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in West Los Angeles at 8 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Soviet 1970 Census Shows Unexpected 5% Decline in Those Listing Themselves as Jews
description: MOSCOW, April 16The Soviet Union made public today its 1970 census results for ethnic groups, showing an unexpected decline in the number of people declaring themselves to be Jewish.

title: Macbeth Seeks Theater
description: The cast of Macbeth had to abandon Thursday night's performance after the stage of the MercerO'Casey Theater, which was damaged by fire, proved too weak to hold more than a few members of the cast. Jack Dell, a spokesman for the revival, said that another theater would he sought to house the attraction.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: State Department Critical
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (Reuters)  The State Department said today that it was disturbed by the publication in a Polish newspaper of details of a Soviet plan submitted at Big Four negotiations on ways to improve access to West Berlin.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 16 (AP)  Fourthseeded Arthur Ashe of Richmond defeated fifthseeded Marty Riessen of Tucson, Ariz., 64, 67, 63, today and gained the semifinals of Charlotte's $25,000 open tennis tournament.

title: Killing of 2 Brink's Guards Is Charged to 2 Chicagoans
description: CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) Two Chicago men were charged with murder today in the shooting deaths of two Brink's, Inc., armored guards on the city's South Side.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At precisely 2:07 P.M. of the day his income tax was due, The Sport stepped behind an orange wooden barrier on the floor of Grand Central Terminal to make his very first legal offtrack bet. The lunchhour crowd had thinned, and several hundred persons, mostly men in clean, worn, unstylish clothing, shifted their feet on the stone floor waiting to be waved out of the holding area and onto one of the lines leading to a selling window. The Sport got a green daily double ticket and marked in the letters CC, representing Stormin Walter in the first race and Old McDonald in the second that night at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Bridge Is Partially Closed
description: The main roadway on the Manhattan Bridge was closed to vehicular traffic in both directions yesterday afternoon and is expected to be reopened Monday at 3 P.M., Highway Commissioner Vincent J. Gibney reported. The closing was ordered to allow a contractor tq., make repairs. During the shutdown vehicles will be detoured to the bridge's upper roadway, which is open to all traffic, Mr. Gibney said.

title: NIXON BARS HALT IN RAIDS TILL FOE FREES ALL P.O.W'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 16President Nixon said tonight that United States air power would continue to be used against North Vietnam and its forces as long as a single American prisoner was held by Hanoi.

description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin and George Lincoln, director of the Office of Emergency Planning, have been directed by President Nixon to go to Texas to assess drought conditions, the White House said today.

description: LONDON, April 14The fate of personal privacy in the age of the computer is worrying lawyers officials and civil libertarians across Western Europe.

title: China Identifies Interim Aide
description: TOKYO, April 16 (AP)Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, today identified Deputy Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei as its acting foreign minister. Chen Yi, the Foreign Minister, disappeared from public view last year, after the Cultural Revolution.

description: They sat quietly, inconspicuous in the drab, uncrowded hearing room, listening to testimony on the effects of Medicaid cuts made by the Legislature.

title: Poll Finds Majority Think Calley Was a Scapegoat,
description: The American people believe that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was made the scapegoat. for the massacre of civilians in the South Vietnamese village of Mylai, according to a poll conducted for the American Broadcasting Company.

title: Black Hessians in a White Man's Army;
description: WASHINGTONI volunteered to serve Uncle Sam. In 1947 I quit a predominantly white high school because I couldn't compete academically. I was soon faced with the black dropout's classic choicehustle on the streets or join the Army.

title: New Everglades Fire
description: MIAMI, April 16 (UPI)Weary firefighters no sooner contained a huge blaze threatening the northeastern part of droughtstricken Everglades National Park today when another big fire erupted in the cypress timberland at the park's northwestern border.

title: AMEX LIST MIXED IN QUIET TRADING
FRED S. RADNITZ, 75, OF CASCADE LINEN
description: Fred S. Radnitz, a senior officer and director of the Cascade Linen Supply and Laundry Company of this city, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old and lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: 7MAN JURY CHOSEN TO TRY CAPT. KOTOUC

title: Russian Delegate Returns To Arms Limitation Talks
description: VIENNA, April 16Vladimir S. Semyonov was back here today to head the Soviet delegation at the strategicarms limitation talks after having missed the last three meetings.

title: ROCHE IS HOPEFUL ON DEAL IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, April 16 (UPI)James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, wound up a four day visit to Japan today, saying he was hopeful that the Japanese Government will approve a G.M. bid to assume a minority interest in Japan's sixth largest automobile maker, the Isuzu Motor Company.

title: Blindfold Baseball
description: The baseball Yankees and the football Giants contribute to the city's morale as well as to its economy. What would New York be like without the Yankees? The question may not have quite the urggncy of some others being asked in this time of budgetary stresswhat would New York be like without a Police Department, Fire Department, schools, for Instancebut it is a subject that is proper concern to city officialdom.

title: Reform Democrats Now Spurn the Mayor
Hooker Performs With a Pop Group He Helped Inspire
description: There's much talk of how thisorthat old bluesman influenced thisorthat young band, but Thursday night was one of the few times a blues master actually gave a concert with a group he helped inspire.

title: Art: 3 Shows of Pol Bury's Sculpture
description: Pol Bury, the Belgian kinetic sculptor who had his first oneman show in New York to 19M, is now the subject of a retrospective that opened to the public yesterday at the Guggenheim Museum and two gallery shows that open today at Lefebre, 47 East 77th Street, and Weintraub, 992 Madison Avenue at 77th.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although the Controller's report referred to in your March 11 editorial (Who Knows About Drugs?) found only seventeen rehabilitated addicts were graduates of the Phoenix program, The Times knows better. In October 1970 The Times requested and received the names of over 150 rehabilitated individuals who had completed the Phoenix program (61 of whom are now involved as staff leaders in human resource programs throughout the country).

title: REDS IN ITALY HAIL U.S.CHINA CONTACTS
description: ROME, April 16The Italian Communist party welcomed today the new contacts between mainland China and the United States and expressed Its hope that a reconciliation also might be possible between Peking and Moscow.

description: CHAMPOIGN, III., April 16 State undercover narcotics agents seized nearly seven pounds of LSD valued at more than $1million in a raid here yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended a Denver brokerage house, B. J. Leonard & Co., from certain overthecounter trading activities for selling unregistered stock of Mastercraft Electronics Corporation in 1968. Leonard drew a 10day suspension and its president, James Owsley, was suspended for 20 days, starting Monday.

description: HIROSHIMA, April 16What a splendid job the people of Hiroshima have done, Emperor Hirohito declared today after peering at the rebuilt city through a field glass from a hill overlooking the central area.

description: Joseph Love, board chairman of the corporation of his name at 1333 Broadway, one of the largest manufacturers of children's wear, who was a leader in veterans'.activities, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel.

title: Collection of Chinese Art on Display

title: Upstate Congressman Favors Phone Tapping
description: ALBANY, April 16 (AP)Representative Carlton J. King, Republican of Saratoga Springs, told an Albany Chamber of Commerce audience today that he would have no objection to having his telephone tapped and he criticized Hale Boggs of Louisiana, who is Democratic House leader, for speaking out against the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Lyric Freedom Marks Mary Frank's Drawings
description: Mary Frank is best known on the New York art scene as a sculptor, but she is also a draftsman of uncommon talent. Her drawings, ranging from tiny sketchbook notations to elaborate fullscale compositions, are indeed an important aspect of her work. The poetic transformations of the figure that we find in her sculpture are explored and perfected in the drawings with a marvelous lyric freedom, offering us a range of expressive possibilities that are more slowly and more selectively realized in the more obdurate threedimensional medium.

title: Science Unit Names Head
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP)Dr. William W. Marvel of Princeton, N. S., was named president of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia today. He is a consultant for the International Council for Educational Development in New York.

description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 16 (AP)Roberto de Vicenzo shared the thirdround lead today in the Spanish open golf tournament with 17yearold Dale Hayes of South Africa and Tomas Lopez of Spain at 206. De Vicenzo carded a 71 today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recently revealed new United StatesVietnam pacification program outlines plans to use children of both sexes over the age of seven in supporting units, for an expanded civilian antiguerrilla combat organization in rural areas.

title: Rumpled Academic Administrator
description: His shoelaces always seem to be untied. He drives around town in a battered old black Checker that saw service as a cab. He is a big, shambling man and can be found at home in a clutter of books ranging from spy, thrillers to statistical tomes. He could easily be taken for a rumpled, retiring thinker. But to those who have known him over the last eight years as chancellor of the City University of New York, Dr. Albert H. Bowker is a dynamic administrator, a brilliant scholar and a masterful politician committed to expanding educational opportunities and improving the quality of education.

title: Jewels the Way Nature Made Them
description: From mine to hand with hardly a pause for a setting: uncut stones, sometimes embellished with polished gems, sometimes not, are being sold on rings, necklaces, bracelets and pins. These days even jewelers on Fifth Avenue and environs are showing uncut diamonds or unpolished emeralds in pieces. Nathan Holz, for instance. One doesn't simply walk in off the street and ask to see some jewelry in his salon on the 11th floor of 5 East 57th Street. Mr. Holz's customers come recommended by other clients such as Mrs. Bernard Gimbel or Mrs. J. C. Penney. But then one can buyfor $10,000a diamond spray pin like the one the Elmer Bobsts bought and gave to Julie Eisenhower. Or a gold bracelet ($550) that looks like stacked sheafs of wheat, or a very modern brushed gold ring for $100.

description: PARIS, April 16  Financial men clashed today over proposals aimed at improving the functioning of the international bond market.

description: TROY, Ala., April 14Max Rafferty, whose brand of educational fundamentalism was rejected by California voters last November, is ensconced here now on a campus that is run by a college roommate of Gov. George C. Wallace.

These Red leaders support revolutions, expecting to seize control of them or to take advantage of the anarchy they cause in order to grab power. Russian training and support enabled the Chinese Reds to seize power. Russian and Chinese factories supplied the firepowerand China a good portion of the manpower for the attempt to seize all of Korea by force.

title: GAF ProxyVote Results Are Put Off Until May 10
description: SHELBY, Ohio, April 16The outcome of the bitter proxy fight for control of the GAF Corporation will not be known until May 10.

title: SWEEP BY SAIGON REPORTED OPENED
description: SAIGON South Vietnam April 16  A large force of South Vietnamese infantrymen who came out of Laos last month has reportedly begun moving west again into the Ashau Valley, a major enemy base area near the Laotian border southwest of Hue.

title: 11 MORE ARE CITED IN BERRIGAN CASE
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16 The Federal Bureau of Investigation served subpoenas today on 11 more persons ordering, them to appear before the Harrisburg, Pa., grand jury involved in the Berrigan case.

title: U.S. Team, Nearing Tour's End, Sees a Ballet Staged by Mao's Wife
description: CANTON China April 16The United States table tennis team, on the last leg of its visit to Communist China attended a ballet staged by the wife of Mao Tsetung today.

title: The Screen:The Traverses Adopt Elephant Family
description: Here it is again, a school-less Saturday, and parents may be wistfully wondering if there is a halfway decent new feature available for the children. There is indeed. Take them straight to "An Elephant Called Slowly." It's ideal for the 4- to 11-year age bracket. The Walter Reade Organization has had the gumption to book it for three weekends at neighborhood houses, Saturday and Sunday matinees, starting today.The "Born Free" team, Bill Travers and Virginia McKenna, are back in Africa again, this time adopting a trio of elephants (Slowly is the name of the baby) who nose into their Kenya backyard, where the couple are housekeeping for some absent friends.Co-written by Mr. Travers and James Hill, producer-director, the picture is a tame, dramatically uneventful affair, nowhere near as finished or forceful as "Born Free." Frail and even rambling in structure, the picture edges purposefully into the wilds for some magnificently authentic animal footage.As Mr. and Mrs. Travers explore the veldt, the animals seems even more plentiful and varied than in "Born Free" (which has a sequel, "Swing Free," still unrealesed here). The camera holds hard and close to the wildlife in fascinating detail, everything from humming birds to rhinos. The only jolt, handled discreetly, is the sight of some jungle wild dogs finishing off a gazelle.In one brief, charming sequence, the couple visit the animal farm of their old friend, George Adamson, whom Travers portrayed in "Born Free." The Traverses themselves are as personable and winning as ever. But it does take the picture a good half hour to get going, as they twitter around the premises rather coyly. As for the restvery nice indeed. Treat the youngsters.

title: Sutton Is in Group Negotiating to Buy Amsterdam News
description: Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton said yesterday that he was a member of group of investors that is negotiating to buy The New York Amsterdam News.

title: Policy on Treatment of Vietcong Suspects Assailed
description: SAIGON South Vietnam April 16  Two Congressmen Who are opponents of the war in Vietnam today criticized the program designed to weed out and punish Vietcong political leaders and agents in the civilian population.

title: Inspector Drowns in Mine
description: NEMACOLIN, Pa., April 16 (UPI)  A state mine inspector drowned today in the Buckeye Coal Company's Nemacolin Mine, where two miners died in a fire last March 26. The inspector, William C. Groves, 55 years old, of Carmichael, Pa., was with a crew supervising efforts to quench the underground blaze, which has been burning for 22 days.

title: BIGGEST BUILDING IN BROOKLYN SET
description: A rundown corner of downtown Brooklyn was designated yesterday as the site for the largest private office building in Brooklyn an 18to 20 story tower.

title: 9 Go Today in 47th Wood; Eastern Fleet Heads Field
description: The Wood Memorial, one of the most popular stakes races of the New York Racing Association's calendar, will have its 47th running today at Aqueduct.

title: Executive Changes
description: First Union, Inc., has announced the election of Edwin S. Jones as president and chief operating officer of the multibank holding company at the company's annual meeting in St. Louis. He was previously a vice president.

title: Censorship in Queens
description: The language of the slums is as harsh as the life reflects. Its obscenities are descriptive of the human condition. To outlaw the words instead of understanding the frustrations and anger out of which they spring to order perfume to be sprayed over the stench social sores.

title: DE ROSA'S GROUP IN JAZZ PROGRAM
description: A 16piece jazz band, the College AllStars, conducted by Clem De Rosa, proved to be much more than its name suggested when it played yesterday afternoon at La Martinique, the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street.

title: Antiwar Sleepin at Washington Monument Is Barred
description: WASHINGTON April 16Attorneys for the Federal Government obtained an injunction today that would prevent a group of antiwar veterans from sleeping overnight on the Washington Monument grounds next week.

title: 65% Stock Margin Is Set On Fanny May Purchases

Mr. Henderson, who has conducted the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra of London, will lead his first concert in Tulsa in October.

title: 8 HELD IN GUNFIRE IN TEAMSTER RIFT
description: NASHVILLE, April 16Two top officials, four employes and two members of Local; 327 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were arrested today after an exchange, of gunfire last night at the home of the local's president, Don Vestal. No one was injured.

Also on the program will be a short play, The Cowboy Mouth, by Mr. Shepard and Patti Smith. The double bill will he given in St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street, through June 5.

title: 5 Are Arrested in Protest Against Welfare Cutbacks

title: ROBERT H. SNYDER, LAWYER HERE, 64
description: Robert H. Snyder, a New York lawyer and a leader in the work of Goodwill Industries, died of cancer Thursday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 200 East 71st Street.

title: Books of The Times
description: There's a true story behind The White Dawn. In the spring of 1896 a small whaleboat was towed far away from the mother ship by a harpooned whale and wrecked on the shore of West Baffin Island in the Canadian Arctic, north of Hudson Baywhere no white men had ever landed before. Three of the crew survived and were sheltered by hospitable Eskimos, who nursed them to health and welcomed them into their community. Yet when the whaling ship returned the following spring seeking its lost crew members, no sign of them remained. What happened? James Houston is a Canadian artist who spent 12 years among the Eskimos, nine of them as the first Civil Administra tor of West Baffin Island, and he's made a novel out of the accounts handed down by the Sikusalingmuit people that clarifies the mystery of their first, fatal encounter with the white man 75 years ago.

title: Some Girls Feel Called to Nursing Even Before Grade School
description: How old is a girl when she makes up her mind to be a nurse?

title: STEELPRICE RISE IS SET BY ARMCO
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to increase prices on all stainless steel except tubing, effective with April 26 shipments. The company's advancedmaterials division said that increases of 5.5 per cent on chromiumnickel and 7 per cent on straight chromium grades would be added to the price bases of stainless steel sheets, strip, bar, wire, wire rods and billets.

title: OTB WAGERERS GO FOR LONGER ODDS

title: Market Place: Rights Defended Of Small Holder
description: You're a oneshare owner in People's Capitalism. You've heard what Alfred R. Rose thinks about people in your life raft who make proposals at annual meetings.

title: A Coal Town That Never Looks Back
description: SCRANTON, Pa.In every geography course I had in elementary school, the textbook listed Scranton, Pa., as the center of the world's richest deposits of anthracite coal. It always was with a bit of pride that I read. Scranton's name in a book that dealt with so many faroff places. I even remember one book that called it the World Anthracite Capital.

Ronald Millar's Abelard and Heloise, costarring Diana Rigg and Keith Michel, will close at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on April 24 after 53 performances. Siobhan McKenna's one woman show Here Are Ladies will conclude its engagement at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater on May 9 after 67 showings.

title: BUCKS VANQUISH LAKERS, 117 T0 94

The Bucks moved within one victory of the National Basketball Association playoff final.

title: CHRYSLER NOTES GET HIGH RATING
