title: RULES FOR CREDIT TO BROKERS EASED
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The Federal Reserve Board took its second action in two weeks today aimed at making it easier to raise capital to shore up nearbankrupt brokerage firms. Both actions liberalized margin requirements.

title: WILLIAM D. ECKERT, EXBASEBALL HEAD
description: (AP)William Dole Eckert, a former Air Force lieutenant general and commissioner of major league baseball, died of a heart attack suffered while playing tennis today at Freeport in the Bahamas. He was 62 years old.

title: Lunokhod on Moon 5 Months
description: MOSCOW, April 16 (UPI)The Soviet Union's moon rover, the Lunokhod completed five months on the lunar surface today and technicians began preparing to close it down for its sixth lunar night, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Starts of Housing In March Climbed To 1,918,000 Rate
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Housing starts rose strongly in March to an annual rate of 1,918,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS SUE OVER DELAYS
description: The city was accused yesterday by a legalaid organization and a welfarerights group of having ignored state rulings to restore benefit cuts to welfare clients.

title: Saigon Flies in Fresh Troops to Bolster Fire Base
description: FIRE BASE 6 South VietApril 16The South Vietnamese Army flew 400 fresh troops to the top of this narrow battleshattered hilltop base today. For 15 days North Vietnamese force has besieged this strategic position near the Cambodian and Laotian borders in the South Vietnamese highlands.

title: CEYLON'S SCHOOLS TO STAY CLOSED
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 16, (Reuters)  The Government announced today that the island's schools, which were to reopen for the new term next week, would remain closed be cause of fighting between the armed forces and leftwing insurgents.

title: ANTHONY CRAIG
description: Anthony Craig, a retired building service man, died yesterday at the home of his soninlaw, Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, in the Throgs Neck area of the Bronx. His age was 76.

title: Van Arsdale Defends Taxi Union Vote
description: Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of the taxi drivers union, denied yesterday that there were any serious irregularities in the union's last election of officers.

title: Translating Some Latin Into a Feast
description: A Roman feast took place on a recent afternoon in the kitchen of one of those large, elderly, nondescript houses in the Bronx. The participants were an older woman, three young women and four young men.

title: Former Colombian Aide Is Given 10Year Term on Drug Charge
description: A former Colombian vice consul, Jose Alvaro Cordoba Bojassen, was sentenced in absentia here yesterday to 10 years In prison for smuggling cocaine.

title: 3 Western Powers Cool to. Soviet Plan On Berlin Problems
description: BERLIN, April 16  The ambassadors of Britain France the United States and the Soviet Union met today for the 18th session of their talks to ease the problems of this divided city.

title: U.S. Experts on China Say The Big Problems Remain
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The words and gestures goodwill that have passed between the United States and Communist China over the last 10 days have improved the atmosphere between them but have not gone to the heart of the problems that separate them.

title: Team Back in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG Saturday April 17The American team crossed over the railway bridge from Shumchun, China, to Hong Kong this morning.

title: 3 Authors Are Named Winners Of Columbia's Bancroft Prizes
description: The three winners of the 1971 Bancroft Prizes for books of exceptional merit and distinction in the fields of history (including biography), diplomacy and international relations have been announced here by Columbia University.

title: NET AT HONEYWELL DECLINES SHARPLY
description: Profits of Honeywell, Inc., were cut in half during the first quarter of 1971, the company reported yesterday.

title: Widow of Man Who Received A Mechanical Heart Sues
description: HOUSTON, April 16 (AP)The widow of the first man to live with a mechanical heart has filed a Federal court suit asking for $4.5million in darnages in connection with the death of her husband two years ago.

title: M.T.A. Again Warns of Rise In Subway and Rail Fares
description: A director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday repeated a warning that fares on the city's transit system and the commuter railroads would have to be increased sharply unless subsidies were obtained.

title: Wall Streeters Pay Nixon a Bullish Visit
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP)A delegation of three of President Nixon's Wall Street friends went to the White House today to tell him they are finding the economy very much better.

title: Device Protects Little Leaguers
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A chest and throat protector that was patented this week is mandatory equipment for all catchers among the 2 million Little Leaguers in 31 countries. Dr. Creighton J. Hale, a research physiologist, was granted Patent 3,574,861, as signing it to Little League Baseball, Inc., Williamsport, Pa., of which he is vice president and research director. A feature of the protector is a special collar with a padded section to cover the wearer's throat. A strap across the back of the neck keeps the device from sliding down and exposing the throat to injury from a fast ball or a foul tip.

title: Ralph Hale Mottram, 87, Author Of Antiwar BestSeller, Is Dead
description: LONDON, April 16  Ralph Hale Mottram, author of The Spanish Farm, a bestseller about World War I, died last night at King's Lynn, Norfolk. He was 87 years old.

title: Johns Hopkins Adds Woman
description: BALTIMORE, April 16 (UPI) Dr. Marjorie G. Lcwisohn, a New York City physician, was named yesterday to the board of trustees of Johns Hopkins University the first woman ever appointed.

title: DELIVERY ALLOWED OF BLAIR ACCOUNTS
description: The liquidator of Blair & Co., an insolvent brokerage firm, was authorized yesterday by a Federal court here to continue delivering out customer accounts, despite an involuntarybankruptcy ruling issued earlier in the week. The United States District Court temporarily stayed the administration of Blair in bankruptcy proceedings, pending a hearing May 12.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Gen. M. B. Ridgway has represented for me the very finest that our military establishment has produced. Through the years his voice brought sanity and balance to a profession whose occupational hazard is the polar opposite. In his essay (OpEd April 2) he laments, as must all Americans, the deterioration of morals in the Army where, because of the nature of its mission, maintenance of a high code is an understandable imperative.

title: PRICES TUMBLE IN CORN FUTURES
description: Unconfirmed reports that an effectiVe fungicide to check corn blight had been developed caused considerable selling in the corn futures pit at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday and sent prices tumbling. The blight last year caused heavy damage to the corn crop.

title: Losert of Austria Beats Granieri in Fencing Foil Final
description: Lanky Roland Losert of Austria, who was runnerup last year, staged a mighty comeback in the final match last night to capture the Martini & Rossi foil crown at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor When President Nixon removed restrictions on visits to China by U.S. citizens, he was simply recognizing China's inevitable admission to the United Nations. His decision reflected the realities of changing world opinion. It was a lowfisk way of demonstrating American openness and of winning some diplomatic points.

title: Schubert Quartets By Amadeus Group Heard at Museum
description: An audience that overflowed onto the stage gathered in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night to hear the Amadeus Quartet play the first of three concerts of Schubert's chamber music it is giving there this month.

title: TOP JERSEY COURT ASKS 6MAN JURIES
description: TRENTON, April 16  The New Jersey Supreme Court urged Gov. William T. Cahill and the state Legislature today to propose a constitutional amendment that would reduce the required number of jurors from 12 to six in criminal court cases.

title: Rain Drenches Parts of Texas; Effect on Drought Called Slight
description: HOUSTON, April 16  A Pacific storm rumbled across dustdry Texas today, occasionally dumping rain and hail in torrents. The first reports were that the storm would have only a temporary effect on the droughtstricken state.

title: BONN MAKES WAY FOR BOSTON POPS
description: BONN, April 16Looking down froth Olymp tonight, the Germans were flabbergasted by their first sight of the Boston Pops, its wealthy Bostonian supporters and the Edward M. Kennedys trying to savor combinations of music, wine, and the limelight at the same time.

title: Birgit Finnila in Lieder
description: Birgit Finnila, the Swedish contralto, is one of those artists who create advance excitment through word of mouth. She has a long list of credentials: Gerald Moore accompanied her in England in the spring of 1966; it was her debut and his final London appearance. She has sung with an impressive list of conductors and on five continents.

title: Rose of Okla. State Takes Mile at Kansas in 3:59.5
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 16, (UPI)Larry Rose, of Oklahoma State startled 2,500 Kansas relays fans today by winning the Universitycollege onemile run in 3 minutes 59.5 seconds.

title: Psychopoetry: A New Way of Reaching the Disturbed
description: Practitioners of psychopoetrythe use of poetry in treating mental illnessmet in a crowded conference room at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn yesterday to explore the frontiers of their burgeoning art.

title: TWO SENATORS URGE CURB ON PRESIDENCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, told the nation's newspaper editors today that on the issue of making war, an impotent Congress has lost its capacity to challenge the actions of a strongwilled President.

title: Leaving Pest at City UniversityMove Stuns Colleagues
description: Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancelor of the City University since 1963, was named chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley yesterday

title: 2 ExU.S. Aides Disagree Over Reorganization Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 16Former members of two of the Government's major regulatory commissions disagreed today over the proposal of an Administration study group that these agencies be reorganized with a single individual at their head. The various commissions now have anywhere from five to 11 members, each with a vote.

title: Air Attack Reported
description: DARSANA Pakistan April 16  Chuadanga supposedly the headquarters of the recently proclaimed government of an independent East Bengal was attacked by Saber jets of the Pakistan Air Force this morning, according to informants here.

title: Phantom Pensions in Industry
description: Private pension plans now cover the majority of American workers, but the security which these plans seem to offer is often a delusion. If a worker quits or Is fired before he is 65, he usually forfeits his rights to a company pension. Similarly, if he dies, his widow collects nothing.

title: DR. GE.',RR1T JUDD 4TH, HOFSTRA PROFESSOR
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 16Dr. Gerrit P. Judd 4th, Distinguished professor of history at Hofstra University, died today in Nassau Hospital, Mineola of a liver ailment. He would have been 56 years old on May 15 and lived at 168 Tullamore Road, Garden City.

title: Jane Fonda Wins Delay
description: CLEVELAND, April 16 (UPI) Jane Fonda, the actress, has obtained a threemonth continuance of assault and battery charges brought against her last November by a policeman at Cleveland's Hopkins Airport. Judge Edward F. Feighan granted the delay yesterday.

title: COLLEGE HEADS GET FREE HOUSING
description: Free housing will be provided for presidents of community colleges, the Board of Higher Education has decided despite Controller Abraham D. Beatne's complaint that this was improper while the city was pressed for money.

title: U.S.Instruments Shown
description: MOSCOW, April 16In the small exhibition hall of scientific instruments on Moscow's far south side, a small group of American businessmen set up a display this week in an attempt to do their part to promote the modest trade between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Pakistan Says Sabotage Raids on Power Plants Fail
description: KARACHI, April 16  The Government radio said tonight that Pakistani troops had prevented saboteurs from blowing up two power stations in East Pakistan.

title: RAPED TEACHER SUES CITY FOR $2MILLION
description: A New York City teacher who was raped at Public School 63 in the Bronx on March 19 has begun legal proceedings for a $2million damage suit against the city and the Board of Education.

title: SAUER TO RETIRE; ASSAILS FOOTBALL
description: George Sauer, the New York Jets wide receiver, announced his retirement from pro football yesterday at the age of 27. Sauer told Weeb Ewbank, the coach, he was quitting because he was generally dissatisfied with the game as it is being played now.

title: Karachi a Night Town, Even for War News
description: KARACHI Pakistan, April 16Everything important happens at night, the newsmen of Karachi say.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 16The Daily Express, last unreconstructed voice of the Empire and British xenophobia, had a headline in Chinese at the top of page one this morning. Next to it, in English, there was reassurance: Don't worryit's just another way of saying The Express is inside China. An Express reporter was there with the PingPong players.

title: STANLEY RYPINS, PROFESSOR HERE
description: Dr. Stanley Rypins of 8 West 13th Street, author and emeritus professor of English literature at Brooklyn College, died Thursday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 80.

title: L.S.Pensak Weds Miss Olmstead
description: MILLBURN, N. J., April 16  Miss Marjorie Helen Olmstead, a guidance counselor at the Wayland (Mass.) Junior High School, was married here this afternoon to Larry S. Pensak. Judge Milton Freiman of the Millburn Municipal Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Hours of Terror for a Trapped Bengali Officer
description: AGARTALA India April 13 On the night of March 25 Dabir recalls, he and the two other East Pakistani officers in the 53d Field Artillery Regiment were standing outside when they heard their commander tell the West Pakistani officers he had summoned to his office:

title: Tensions in Yugoslavia
description: Two dramatic events this month have underlined the fierce nationalistic currents raging among the peoples of Yugoslavia and threatening that country's continued existence as a united state. First there was the shameful murder of the Yugoslav Ambassador in Stockholm by emigre Croat extremists. Now President Tito has delivered a remarkable speech warning that nationalistic differences among Communist leaders in his country are so great that he may have to purge his party to preserve national unity.

title: Stokes Rules Out 3d Term as Mayor; Hints Wider Role
description: CLEVELAND April 16Mayor Carl B. Stokes, in a surprise move, announced tonight that he would not seek reelection this fall.

title: Chinese Ballet a Story of Revolution
description: Red Detachment of Women, the ballet seen in Canton yesterday by the touring United States table tennis team has been assessed by Mao Tsetung in these words.

title: 3 Million Tons in 1970
description: MOSCOW, April 16The Soviet Union, lifting its veil of statistical secrecy on the production of chromite, has disclosed that output last year reached three million tons of this ore, the principal Soviet item of export to the United States.

title: India Charges Genocide
description: NEW DELHI, April 16  The Indian Government today described the Pakistani Army's actions in East Pakistan as savage and medieval butchery and preplanned carnage and systematic genocide.

title: Lawsuits May Terminate Annual Log Drive Down the Kennebec
description: SKOWHEGAN, Me., April 16For most of the 151 years that Maine has been a state, the Kennebec Log Driving Company has pretty much owned the Kennebec River, at least from iceout until icein.

title: PICTURES SHOWN TO SEALE JURORS
description: NEW HAVEN, April 16The jurors who will decide whether Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins bear any of the blame in the slaying of Alex Rackley two years ago watched today as the prosecution presented the rope, bullet shells, adhesive tape and wire coat hanger that were found with the dead man's body.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Does Rosalie D. Atkinson [letter April 1] want to pay 15 cents for first class letter? Think of the millions of unhappy people when this day happens. It will happen soon if the postal services continue their overpricing policy on the ever declining volume per household of third class mail, the most profitable class of mail the postal services have.

title: Gulf of Albany
description: Austerity is the watchword in Albany. Budgets for Medicaid, education and welfare are in jeopardy. But the muddy bottom of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's pet project, the South Mall, continues to soak up millions. The progress of this 100acre flight of fiscal fancy has been so consistently paved with taxpayers gold that the latest $52million adjustment paid to a concern with an original $97million contract seems like businessasusual.

title: Pope Sees Budapest Aide; Meeting Is First of Its Kind.
description: ROME April 16The Hungarian Foreign Minister Janos Peter had a 45minute audience with Pope Paul VI in the Vatican today. The meeting was the first between a Pontiff and a member of Communist Hungarian Government.

title: H.E.W. Installs Publicity Aide
description: WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) Robert O. Beatty was installed today as the first assistant secretary for public affairs in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Mr. Beatty, who is 46 years old, is a former director of communications for the Boise Cascade Corporation in Boise, Idaho. He has also held other public relations posts in the West and was editor for seven years of the magazine Outdoor America.

title: GIBSON GIVES PLAN IN NEWARK STRIKE
description: NEWARK, April 16Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson proposed tonight a compromise settlement of the bitter 11weekold teachers strike and asked for the support of every Newarker in getting his proposal accepted.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, April 17Mr. Durdin's wife, Peggy, a widely published journalist, was granted a visa to enter China today.

title: DynamiteLaden Freighter Aground Near U.S. Station
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 16  A freighter carrying 280 1tons of dynamite has run aground near an island in the Bahamas where the Air Force maintains space tracking facilities.

title: MalaysiaSingapore Defense Accord Set
description: LONDON, April 16  Britain and four other Commonwealth nations reached formal agreement today on joint defense arrangements for Singapore and Malaysia.

title: MinorityAid Model Is Failure on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A California investment company, once regarded by the Nixon Administration as a successful model of its minority capitalism program, has failed.

title: Rangers Begin Semifinals Tomorrow Night in Chicago
description: The first two games of the New York RangersChicago Black Hawks Stanley Cup semifinal playoff will be played tomorrow and Tuesday in Chicago, both at 8:30 P.M.

title: F.D.R. Drive to Be Closed
description: The main roadways of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be closed between 3 A.M. and noon tomorrow from 20th Street to 40th Street in both directions. The Traffic Department announced yesterday that northbound traffic will be diverted from 20th Street and southbound traffic from 40th Street, The closing, according to the Traffic Department, will enable the removal of an overhead Con Edison coal conveyer.

title: Surprise to Illinois Man Is Triplets at Age 74
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ili., April 16 (UPI)Henry Bagley, 74 years old, became a father of triplets today.

title: Vermont Is 19th to Ratify Amendment on Voting Age
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 16 (AP)The Vermont Senate completed legislative ratification today of the proposed amendment to the United States Constitution lowering the voting age in all Federal state and local elections to 18.

title: Oscar Surprises Scott; He's Still Not Interested
description: George C. Scott still doesn't want an Oscar, even though he won one for Patton Thursday night.

title: Amfac Agreement Is Set To Acquire LambWeston
description: Amfac, Inc., announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to acquire LambWeston, Inc., a major processor of frozen potatoes and other vegetables. Subject to negotiations of a definitive agreement, and approval by shareholders of LambWeston, Amfac will exchange sixtenths of a share of its common stock for each of the approximately 1,389,000 outstanding shares of LambWeston.

title: 3 ISSUES OF STOCKS ARE OFFERED IN WEEK
description: New stock issues registered continuing gains this week, the seventh week in a row, in somewhat quieter trading than in recent months.

title: Shorts for the Winter? Paris Says Oui
description: PARIS, April 16 (UPI)The house of Christian Dior, opening the Paris readytowear fall winter fashion shows, today continued its inglorious retreat from last winter's long look.

title: 2 PLANS OFFERED FOR COBBLE HILL
description: Puerto Rican residents of Cobble Hill are divided on the Port of New York Authority's proposed $9million pier ex pansion in that Brooklyn neigh borhood, with one group of res idents favoring abandonment of the project in favor of revital izing housing in the community and the other seeking a com promise that would include both modernization of the piers and new housing.

title: LOOPHOLE IS SEEN IN POLLUTION LAW
description: NEW HAVEN, April 17  A possible loophole that could allow industries to avoid the penalties of a key waterpollu tion control law stirred concern at an enforcement conference here this week.

title: Year of Desegregation A Trying One in South
description: SUMTER, S. C., April 17A high school teacher here de cided one day recently to en tertain his desegregated class of 12thgraders with a film of one of last fall's football games between Sumter and a rival town.

title: the traveler's world
description: Purely by chance, the author of this column recently checked into a hotel that was immediately besieged by demonstrators opposing a speech by Vice President Agnew. The following is a report on a hectic day in the life of a fullup, besieged hotel.

title: Order Bidding Draft Boards Share Offices Is Rescinded
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)  Selective Service has halted its plan to have many local boards across the country share office quarters and cleri cal personnel to try to save money.

title: Reader's Report
description: While William A. Block, M.D., might have been attending to his general praotice, he was concocting this dossier of an overworked general practitioner who is dedicated to his call ing, is emotionally involved with the fate of his patients, and makes house calls. In spite of its documentary flavor, this is clearly a work of fiction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ELIZABETH ELEVEN FACES TEST TODAY
description: Elizabeth and the German Hungarians, who hold the one two spots in the South Group of they GermanAmerican Soc cer League, will clash today at Farcher's Grove in Union, N. J., while New York Hota, which leads the North Group, will travel to Fall River, Mass., to meet Taunton in an East ern semifinal for the United States Challenge Cup.

title: Portuguese Premier Settling Down to Rightist Course
description: LISBON, April 17  Premier Marcello Caetano, who has steered a zigzag political course between stability and change, stems to be straightening out considerably to the right of center.

title: NORTH EASTERN WINS AT BOSTON COLLEGE
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 17 (AP)  Northeastern captured four events and piled up 61 points today in easily winning the Boston College Relays for the second consecutive year.

title: Bonn Reports Membership In Far Right Under 30,000
description: BONN, April 17The total membership of West Germany's extreme rightwing National Democratic party and 65 other far rightwing splinter groups has dropped below 30,000 for the first time in four years, the Government has disclosed.

title: EARTH WEEK, '71 IS MUTED AFFAIR
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 17Plans for the observance of Earth Week on Long Island beginning tomorrow are gen erally on a smaller scale and at a lower key than they were last year for Earth Day, ac cording to leaders of Long Is land environmental group.

title: Mrs. Andrews Married
description: TEANECK, N. J., April 17 Mrs. Anita E. Andrews and Deane McGowen, of Teaneck, were married here this morning in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Joseph James; the rector. The bride, widow of Andrew Andrews, is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scherer of Palisades Park. Mr. McGowen, a member of the sports staff of The New York Times, is a son of the late Roscoe McGowen, who was a sportswriter for The Times, and the late Mrs. McGowen of North Wood stock, Conn. The bride groom's first wife the former Irene Byrnes, died.

title: Buckley, on First Republican MoneyRaising Tour, Calls Receptions Pleasing
description: HOUSTON, April 17Sen ator James L. Buckley of New York, making his first money raising tour for the Republican party, said today that he was pleased at his reception around the country.

title: Navy Officer to Marry Miss Wagner
description: EAST NORWICH, L. I., April 17  Miss Nancy Van Home Wagner and Lieut. (jg.) Henry Fay Mixter Jr., U.S.N.R., are planning a June wedding in St. John's Epis copal Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

title: News of Dogs
description: For centuries, Afghan hounds have chased gazelles in their native Afghanistan. Today, they will chase a fox tail on Staten Island.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Boulder Brook Show, unofficial opening of the sea son in the metropolitan Area, is scheduled for next Friday and Saturday at the club in Scarsdale.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward Albee Fights Back
description: ALL OVER is what Edward Albee calls his new play, now struggling valiantly for life at the Martin Beck Theater. And all over is what wisecracking woewishers are saying about the career of the 43yearold playwright who, just nine years ago, shattered conventions, nerves and possibly a few marriages with his scalding portrait of a carnivorous couple named Martha and George in Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

title: Ottawa Is Impressed by China's Choice of Ambassador
description: OTTAWA, April 17  The Chinese Government's selection of Huang Hua as Ambassador to Canada augurs much for serious, expanding Chinese re lations not only for Canada but also for North America and perhaps the hemisphere, Ottawa diplomats believe.

title: The Citadel Thrives in an Alien Times
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., April 6The Citadel, South Caro lina's 129yearold military col lege, is thriving on a program of hard work and Spartan patriotism alien to the pervas ive yotith culture elsewhere.

title: Dr. Mary G. Beale Is Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Dr. Mary Garven Beale, a pediatric interne at Children's Hospital in Boston was mar ried here this afternoon to Dr. George Joseph Berakha, a surgery interne at Johns Hop kins Hospital in Baltimore. The Rev. C. Leslie Glenn, per formed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel at the Washington Cathedral where he is a canon.

title: Award to Patrolman Shot By City Policeman Reduced
description: The appellate division of State Supreme Court yesterday reduced to $600,000 a jury award of $950,000 to a Suffolk County patrolman paralyzed in his lower limbs by gunshots fired by an offduty New York City policeman more than five years ago.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Barium Cloud to Be Launched In a Study of Magnetic Fields
description: On Tuesday night a new and very bright star is scheduled to appear in the sky over the Western Hemisphere. It will be a manmade barium cloud that should help scientists under stand the magnetic and elec trical fields of space.

title: Art
description: COMPOSER Morton Feld man, in a recent mem oir of New York in the 1950's, slyly attributes the artistic fecundity and panache of that period to one brief momentmaybe, say, six weeks  [during which] nobody understood art A sweet tribute to the adventuring spirit of Ab stract Expressionist days, this tantalizing proposition is also a welldirected swipe at the kind of art works and attitudes (aside from those of sassy, alleluding Pop Art) that succeeded the fifties formalist works and analyti cal attitudes that made un derstanding art a compul sory, quasiscientific exercise. Thus were the dumb, for tuitous achievements of the forties and fifties either ra tionalized or rejected in the production of the smart esthetic engines of the six tiesimplacable stripe and colorfield paintings and Min imal sculptures redolent less of the studio than of the art journals in which their ex egesis was ponderously per formed.

title: News of the Rialto
description: HAROLD PINTER, demigod to some and enigmatic playwright to others, is bound for the lists with his first fulllength drama since 1965. It is called Old Times and if the votaries will be patient while the Royal Shakespeare Company gives it its initial airing in June in London, it can be vouchsafed that New York will get it next winter.

title: Miss Noonan Has Nuptials
description: St. Anselm's Roman Cath olic Church in Brooklyn was the setting yesterday after noon for the marriage of Miss Kathleen Marie Noonan and Donald David Scalley. A reception was given at the Pierre Roof.

title: British Banker Plans to Wed Sarah Andrews
description: WILTON, Conn., April 17  Mr. and Mrs. Albert O'Beirne Andrews, formerly of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, MisS Sarah Hall Andrews of New York, to Peter Denis HillWood of London, son of Mr. and. Mrs. Denis HillWood.

title: Whites, Driven by Fear and Prejudice, Flee Newark to Suburban Communities
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., April 17 Everybody that can get out, gets out. Nobody in their right mind stays. It's a dying city, and you don't want to die with it.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: In 1971, women have ac cess to men's bars, but the barrier of the Men's Club of Advertising Planning has not fallen. Women's involvement must be welcomed if adver tising is to be believed and respected.

title: Things Go Better With Wine When It's Made From Grapes
description: ITALIANS tell the story of the old wine maker whose sons have been summoned to his deathbed for what ever final words of wisdom he can impart to them. With his last breath he manages to gasp, Si fa anche con  I'uva. (You can also make it with  grapes.)

title: Stars Take 21 Edge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 17 (AP)Ron Boone scored 27 points and Mery Jackson and Willie Wise added 24 apiece tonight to lead Utah to a 121108 victory over Indiana Pacers and give the Stars a 21 edge in the Western Division playoffs.

title: Army Investigator In War Crime Case Dies of Gun Wound
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) An Army investigator exam ining charges that a major gen eral and another officer cov ered up alleged American atrocities in Vietnam has died from what the Pentagon called an apparently selfinflicted gun shot.

title: Tennis Umpires Seeking Slice of Prize Money
description: MIAMI, April 17Large prizes and the increased pres sure of tournament competi tion are creating an an tagonistic feeling between professional tennis players and linesmen, a top tennis umpire said today.

title: RYUN DOES 3:55.8 FOR KANSAS MILE
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 17 Jim Ryun posted the fastest time in the world for the year in the onemile run today. He was clocked in 3 minutes 55.8 seconds in the Glenn Cunning ham mile at the Kansas Relays.

title: Today I Feel Like I Am Somebody!
description: actress recently on tour with Lorraine Hansberry's To Be Young, Gifted and Black

title: M'CALL'S FARMS OUT WORK, LACKING PACT
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 17 Inability to obtain a no strike, nolockout guarantee from its Bookbinders Union has prompted the McCall Printing Company, which publishes about 75 magazines here, to furlough 1,931 of its 4,400 em ployees, effective Monday.

title: BUSHWICK FIGHTS STEPCHILD ROLE
description: Bushwick is the stepchild of Brooklyn, says Joseph Coletti, an architect who has lived there all his life.

title: Pop
description: IN the last few months two surprising, special records have come over the hill, titled with the names of the artists, Ry Cooder (Reprise) and Fraser & DeBolt (Columbia). Cooder, from California, and Fraser & DeBolt, from the Canadian MidWest have in common a musicianship that leaves most rock in the dust, an in spired craziness of personal expression, and a vision of people as feeling individ uals, not a ticketbuying fes tival mass. In its original fineness, the music of the new culture was character ized by an intimate, personal honesty and a vivid portrayal of daily reality. Standardized and industrialized rock has become a polluted flow of overamplified trivia, in con trast to which these two beautiful albums are pure spring water.

title: China Trade: Wary Hope
description: Aircraft, wheat, tractors, fertilizers: These are among items prominent in a new vi sion of China trade that opened last week for Ameri can business.

title: Et Al.
description: A collection of routine pieces on trout fishing by Heming way, Robert Travers, Jesse Hill Ford, Richard Brautigan and several lesserknowns. A Sports Illustrated nonbook.

title: Wennersson Wins Star Sail
description: BRENZONE, Italy, April 17 (UPI)  Stig Wennersson of Sweden, the defending cham pion, won the Star Class Euro pean spring sailing champion ships today.

title: LOGGING IN A PARK ARGUED IN ONTARIO
description: TORONTO, April 17An On tario advisory committee con cluded hearings this week on proposals to stop all logging in a wilderness of trees and streams on the province's bor der with Minnesota. The park, one of the largest in North America, is visited in summer by tens of thousands of tour ists, campers and canoeists from the United States.

title: Nixon Hails Libraries
description: President Nixon marked the opening of the 1971 National Library Week observance yes terday with a statement com mending the unique and grow ing role of our libraries in the realization of our national goals. The National Library Week Program, which begins its 14th annual weeklong ob servance today, is aimed at erasing illiteracy at all age lev els, according to a statement released by the National Book Committee and the American Library Association, sponsors of the program.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONOn the Senate floor this week, John Stennis of Mississippi powerfully detailed the fact that the nation is and has been following dual standard on the question of school integrationforcing it in the South and ignoring it elsewhere.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Recordings
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S recording of the nine completed symphonies of Mahler, the most im pressive feat of sustained musicmaking in the conduc tor's career so far, con tinues to stand as the only complete set in the cata logue. But at least four conductors are burning up the track behind him, well on their way toward pro viding their own integral versions. Georg Solti is near ly there, with seven sympho nies; Rafael Kubelik and Maurice Abravanel have re corded six each, and Bernard Haitink, the youngest of the contenders, also has now reached the sixth stage.

title: P.S.C. Proposes a Dispatcher To Rule in Power Emergencies
description: The State Public Service Commission has proposed that a single statewide dispatcher be given binding authority to or der electricity savings, including the actual blacking out of some areas, in major emergencies.

title: Drama Mailbag.
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Milton Barlow Marries Miss Diana Hallowell
description: ANDOVER, Mass., April 17 Miss Diana Hallowell was married here this afternoon to Milton McClintock Barlow in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Crocker, who was assisted by the Rev. J. Edison Pike.

title: Scotch Plains and Boys Hih Set Schoolboy Records in QueensIona Relays
description: The weather was favorable for running yesterday at Down ing Stadium on Randalls Island, and the high school athletes responded accordingly at the QueensIona Relays. Meet rec ords were set in the three events for schoolboys, in con trast to the poor times in Fri day's cold weather.

title: FLORIDA U. HEAD DISAVOWS RACISM
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., April 17 Stephen C. O'Connell grew up in this state believing the sep aration of Negroes and whites to be just a commonplace thing, a way of life.

title: Wanted: A Dr. Spock for black mothers
description: THE middleclass white mother consults her pediatrician, a Bank Streettrained nursery school teacher, or a child psy chologist when her child throws tantrums. She consults Speck when he wets his bed. And she rushes to a psychiatrist when she finds traces of marijuana in his desk drawer.

title: LA CORTE JUMPS 69 FOR JERSEY RECORD
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., April 17  Two state records fell as New Jersey scholastic track stars tuned up for the Penn Re lays at the eighth annual High land Park meet today at the high school field.

title: Pakistan's MadeinU.S.A. Arms
description: ESSEX, Conn.The appalling strug gle now going on in East Pakistan is a further testimony to the folly of doling out arms to friendly govern ments with little regard for whom they are to be used against or for what reasons.

title: Flushing Recalls Its Start As a CivilRights Haven
description: Hardly distracted by the noise of traffic and the bustle of shoppers on Flushing's Northern Boulevard, a small band of Queens residents stepped back through history the other day to the time when Flushing was a center for religious freedom and a major market for rare and beautiful nursery plants.

title: For Young Readers
description: A book about what? A fleet of U.S. battleships on a world cruise back in 1907? Sounds dull. And, actually, it isn't the most riveting chronicle ever written. Yet, there's a certain enchantment about the entire affair: America flexing its mili tary muscles to the rest of the world while Roosevelt  Teddy not Franklin D.whose brainchild the voyage was, stands by like a proud father passing out cigars to, oh, Chi na, Japan, Italy, ignoring the possibility that they might ex plode. It was a brave and fool ish and naive excursion, a gal lant display of bravado, demon strating that America had emerged as a world power aft er the sterile vears which fol lowed the Civil War.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Back to Basics

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  It boggles the mind, the State Depart ment official said, shaking his head in disbelief. I can't come to grips with it.

title: New Talks Held on Berlin
description: BERLIN, April 17 (Reuters) Representatives from East and West Berlin met again today to discuss mutual relations and the possibility of allowing West Berliners to visit East Berlin. They apparently failed to reach an accord.

title: 2d Graders in Queens Create a Museum
description: The children of a second grade class in Public School 220 in Forest Hills, Queens, discovered recently that ?? play show and tell, too. The main difference, they found, was that the adults called their displays a museum.

title: Marist Crews Triumph
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 17Marist College oarsmen swept three races on the Hud son River this morning, with Marist playing host to Wil liams, Amherst and New York State Maritime College.

title: Rockaway Man Is Charged With Criminal Attack on Nun
description: A 23yearold Rockaway, Queens, man is being held by Queens police on charges of criminally attacking a teaching nun early yesterday after breaking into the Stella Maris Convent at 11114 Beach 112th Street in Rockaway.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Mary Brown Bride Of Charles Connell
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany here yesterday afternoon Miss Mary Ellen Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Brown of New York, was married to Charles Patrick Connell, son of Mrs. Charles P. Connell of New York and the late Mr. Connell. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Raymond P. Rigney, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents in 1943.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgetown Beats Syracuse By 2 Feet on Onondaga Lake
description: SYRACUSE, April 17 (AP) The Georgetown University var sity heavyweight crew defeated Syracuse by two feet in a 2,000meter race on Onondaga Lake today. The University of Massachusetts finished third.

title: Franciszek Waniolka, 58, Dies;
description: WARSAW, April 17 (Reuters) Franciszek Waniolka, a for mer deputy premier and mem ber of the Communist party's ruling Politburo, died in this city Thursday, the official news agency PAP reported. He was 58 years old.

title: TENANTS PROTEST ON THE EAST SIDE
description: The Mount Sinai Medical Center acknowledged yesterday that some apartment buildings it owns were poorly main tained, as some 500 commu nity residents marched to pro test the institution's role as a landlord on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: Body of Fisherman Found
description: EAST ISLIP, L. I., April 17 The Coast Guard recovered the body of Michael Ick, 19 years old, of Brentwood, from Great South Bay this afternoon but continued to search for his three companions missing since late yesterday afternoon when their 14foot boat failed to re turn from a fishing trip. The missing youths are Pat Erick sen, Fred Spadaro and Clayton Gray, all 18 years old and all of Brentwood.

title: Overhaul for Old Ironsides
description: BOSTON, April 17 (AP)The Navy has requested some $5 million to give Old Ironsides its. first major overhaul in 40 years. The ship, formally known as the U.S.S. Constitu tion, is permanently berthed at the Charlestown Naval Ship yard.

title: National Notes
description: Check it with Harry, has become a familiar refrain among New York's labor and political leaders in recent years. For Harry Van Arsdale ranks near the top of any list (including that of New York Magazine) of those men who make the city go or stop. His pyramid of power has its base in his role as chief of the 36,000member taxi drivers' union. He is also head of the Central Labor Council, the umbrella organization of all un ions in the city affiliated with the A.F.L.C.I.O. And his nod for a political candidate usually car ries with it labor's endorsement.

title: MAYOR SEES AIDES ON BUDGET CRISIS
description: At 9:18 yesterday morning, Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aure lio listed himself on the signin book at the front door of City Hall, which was closed for, the weekend to all routine, business.

title: Miss King Diving Victor
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 17 (UPI)Air Force Capt. Micki King of Pontiac, Mich., won the women's threemeter springboard competition today at the Hall of Fame interna tional diving championships. The men's title went to Mike Finneran of Fort Lauderdale, student at Ohio State.

title: Fran E. Phillips Engaged to Marry
description: NEW ORLEANS, Apirl 17 Mr. and Mrs. John Gurley Phillips have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fran Evelyn Phillips, to Roger Alan Grayson, a son of Lieut. Col. Cyrus Grayson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Grayson of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Northeastern Sets Record
description: BOSTON, April 17 North eastern University swept the varsity, jayvee and freshman races in a heavyweight triangu lar regatta with M.I.T. and Bos ton University today over the Charles River's 2,000  meter course.

title: Judge to Be Given Medal For Good Citizenship
description: James B. M. McNally, as sociate justice of the Appel late Division of the State Supreme Court, will be awarded the Good Citizen ship Medal by the New York chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution at a Patriots Day commemoration at the Women's National Re publican Club tomorrow night.

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Maple Syrup Crop Down
description: MONTEPLIER, Vt., April 17 (AP)Primarily because of the weather, it appears that Ver mon't maple syrup crop will be a poor one this year, according to Edward R. Eurich, State Agriculture Commissioner. Warm days and cool nights are needed to produce a lot of maple sap, which is boiled down to make the syrup. This year, daytime high tempera tures have been 4 to 10 de grees cooler than the norm.

title: Headliners
description: Eugene J. McCarthy, the former Senator and 1968 Presi dential candidate, once said, I would rather be considered Washington's most political poet than its most poetic poli tician. It's the difference in standards. Since he decided against running for reelection last year, ending a Congres sional career of 22 years, Mr. McCarthy has devoted him self to reading, writing, lecturingand presenting his po etry, often on college campuses. Last week it was announced that he would teach poetry next fall at the University Maryland. The assignment, friends said, would not alter the Minnesota Democrat's plans to participate in national politics. I'm an existential runner, indifferent to space. I'm running here in place.McCarthy, the poet, referring to McCarthy, the politician.

title: World War I Fliers Recall Days of Glory
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The foes of the Red Baron gathered here today not to curse him but to recall their exploits against German squadrons.

title: G. C. Van Dyke Weds Miss Payne
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., April 17  Miss Susan Wal ley Payne and Garret Calvin Van Dyke, both of Basking Ridge, were married here this afternoon in the Pres byterian Church. The Rev. Reinhardt Van Dyke, the bridegroom's father and director of the Migrant Min istry for the New Jersey Council of Churches, per formed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. William H. Felmeth, pastor of the church.

title: Art Notes
description: STAID old Geneva (Switz erland), not exactly known as a city of pre mieres, will nevertheless be first in Europe to stage a show of art by black Ameri cans. Titled Eight Afro American Artists, and di rected by Henri Ghent, dap per, strapping director of the Brooklyn Museum's Commu nity Gallery, the exhibi tion will inhabit Geneva's Rath Museum from June 11 through Sept. 5.

title: Rejoicing in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 17 (Reuters)  Crowds of youths ran through the streets of Trip oli chanting the Arab nation is one in demonstrations of suport tonight for the new federation of Libya, Egypt and Syria.

title: Michael C. King Marries Miss Susan E. Robinson
description: HILLSDALE, N. J., April 17 Miss Susan Ellen Robinson was married here this morn ing to Michael christopher King. The Rev. Edward Myers performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. John the Baptist Ro man Catholic Church.

title: The Brokers' View
description: If listed stocks are moving up, can unlisted issues lag far behind?

title: Sloop Becomes a Classroom in New Rochelle
description: The Hudson River sloop Clearwater, which has spent most of her oneyear exist ence in the campaign against pollution on New York's waterways, has been em barked on a new project that of a floating classroom for public school students.

title: At best new anguish, at worst old mush
description: A powerful river of poetry has come out of South America in this century. Pablo Neruda and Cesar Vallejo are in my opinion the great est poets born on the American con tinent since Whitman. Octavio Paz, born in Mexico in 1914, who has had a previous volume of selected poems in English, has become the most highly praised poet of the generation immediately after Vallejo and Neru da. The present book, containing wrrk since 1957, makes clear certain drawbacks that the Spanish American literary tradition has as well. At its best, as in Vallejo and Neruda, and Vicente Huidobro, the Latin Ameri can drives forward into what has never been named, into states of an guish the Europeans never managed to describe; at its worst, it leans into soft oceans of romantic mush, where all women are fiery and all roses are sacred and all kisses are eternal.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Ali's Appeal of Draft Conviction Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) Muhammad Ali gets a final round before the Supreme Court Monday in his legal fight to avoid going to jail for refusing induction into the Army.

title: DR. LAM CHIFUNG
description: HONG KONG, April 17 (UPI) Dr. Lam ChiFung, president and founder of the Hong Kong Baptist College, died today after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Letter to the Editor 12  No Title
Recruiters Offer a Vietnam Alternative
description: WASHINGTON. April 17 Army recruiting sergeants are offering this year's high school graduates a likely way to avoid both the draft and a trip to Vietnam. It is called the European option.

title: For Young Readers
description: I learned early, from my peergroup grapevine, not books (and not, fortunately, from experience) that one didn't contract venereal disease from drinking fountains or toilet seats. It was my first look, I think, into the pit of Original Sin. The young readers of V.D.: Facts You Should Know will be spared such a shock, for they will read that syphilis and gonorrhea are transmitted largely by sexual contact i.e., intimate bodytobody, or mucous membrane  to  mucous membrane, contact. This is a curiously abstract way of de fining what poets like to call the act of love, which (at least, in its most conventional form) involves the insertion of the penis into the vagina. A book on the wages of sin, I suppose, need not dwell on job description.

title: Steps Listed to Prevent Multiple Collisions in Fog
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) Steps aimed at preventing mul tiple vehicle collisions in fog, such as the 29vehicle crash that killed six persons on the New Jersey Turnpike on Nov. 29, 1969, have been recom mended by the National Trans portation Safety Board.

title: Margaret J. Moore Wed in Providence
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 17 Miss Margaret Jane Moore and William Henry Blair were married here this afternoon at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Paul C. Kintzing Jr.

title: Art
description: THERE are many artists nowadays whose principal appeal is to be found in the way their work brings us a kind of communiqu from the historical front. We don't ex pect to take much pleasure in such work, and the work itself is decidedly not designed to give us any. It func tions, for better or worse, as a signal  more often than not, as a danger signal. If nothing else, it alerts us to new strains in the pathology of our own culture.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Concludes the Pittsburgh National Bank in a recent de tailed assessment of the com position of unemployment:

title: SoftLens Clamor
description: Leonardo da Vinci may have beat Dorothy Parker to the conclusion that men seldom make passes at girls who wear glasses, for centuries ago the versatile Italian thought of replacing framed spectacles with hid den lenses resting on the eye itself.

title: U.A.W. Refuses to Back Antiwar Protest
description: ST. LOUIS, April 17Leon ard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, made a passionate plea here today for an end to the war in Vietnam but said that the union Aid not officially support the protest in Washington planned for next Saturday.

title: Chess
description: WILLIAM EWART NAPIER was the British chess champion in 1904. His felicitous script in collaboration with his brother covered a series of pamphlets under the title of Amenities and Background of Chess Play, reformed, reedited and now rebound in paperback, under the title of Paul Morphy and the Golden Age of Chess.

title: Senators Win, 53
description: CLEVELAND, April 17 (UPI) Frank Howard beat out a bunt to trigger a fourrun seventh inning that gave the Washing ton Senators an uphill 53 vic tory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: ANTS ARE FOUND TO USE CHEMICALS
description: For many years it has been known that some species of ants make war and practice slavery, but it has now been found that they use a form of chemical propaganda in sub duing their enemies.

title: Nuptials Held For Ellen Breen, David Lomasney
description: WESTBROOK, Conn., April 17Miss Ellen Sinnott Breen, daughter of Thomas Francis Breen of Old Saybrook and the late Mrs. Eleanor Sinnott Breen, was married here to day to David Pales Lomas ney, son of Mrs. Anderson F. Hewitt of Oyster Bay, L. I., and the late David Arms Lomasney of New York. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church, by Msgr. Terence P. Finnegan.

title: Holzers Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born on April 5 to Mr. and Mrs. Hans Holzer at the LyingIn Hos pital. Mrs. Holzer is the for mer Countess Catherine Bux hoeveden,

title: Penn Oarsmen Capture Childs Cup for 6th Straight Year
description: Pennsylvania, which has been, with Harvard, the reigning crew power in the East the last few seasons, introduced its new eight in the Childs Cup regatta here yesterday.

title: The New, Young capitalists: Getting Rich on their Own Terms
description: The young businessmen of the seven ties, stalking, their first, million dollars, may wear blue jeans to meet with a banker. But the secrets of their success are straight out of Horatio Alger: Hard work will bring just rewards.

title: Carmen Lombardo Dead at 67; Helped Lead Royal Canadians
description: Carmen Lombardo, the mu sician, songwriter, and singer, died of cancer at his winter home in North Miami yester day. Mr. Lombardo was the mu sic director of his brother's band, which is known as Guy Lombardo and His Royal Ca nadians. He was 67 years old and lived at 184 Woodmere Boulevard, Woodmere, L.I.

title: '72 Autos to Warn on Use of Belts
description: DETROIT, April 17  The styling and engineering will not change much, but the 1972 cars will have one of the most noticeable new features in the history of the automobile in dustry.

title: BIRDS SAID TO FLY BY MAGNETIC CUES
description: An ornithologist at Cornell University has reported what may be the first conclusive evi dence of a centuriesold idea that birdssomewhat in the manner of marinersuse mag netic cues in their navigation system.

title: Garelik Suggests Demolishing Yankee Stadium and Moving the Garment Center to the Ball Park's Site
description: Moving the garment industry from crowded midManhattan to the Bronx, supplanting Yan kee Stadium and the deteriorat ing neighborhood around the stadium, was suggested yester day by City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

title: Dig A Proper Hole
description: DEPTH of planting can determine the success or failure of many garden

title: TWO PARKS ON L.I. PLANNED FOR 1973
description: BABYLON, L. I., April 17 Two private hunting and fishing clubs dating to the mideighteen hundreds will be opened to the public in July, 1973, by the Long Island State Park Com Mission.

title: C.C.N.Y. to Hear Mrs. King
description: Mrs. Coretta Scott King will be the speaker at City College's commencement exercises June 1. Eight years ago her late hus band, the Rev. Dr. Martin Lu ther King, spoke to a C.C.N.Y. graduating class. She will also receive the college's Martin Lu ther King Medal for lifelong dedication to humanitarian ideals.

title: 5 Months for Moon Robot
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (UPI) The Lunokhod I robot marked, the completion of its fifth month on the moon today, hav ing struggled free of a crater in which it bogged down and nearly tipped over, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said. The eightwheeled moon rover land ed with the unmanned Luna 17 spacecraft on Nov. 17.

title: Brooklyn to Open Summer Festival At Borough Hall
description: Downtown Brooklyn will take on the air of a carnival to morrow when Happenings 71, a summerlong series of noontime entertainment pro grams, begins on the steps of Borough Hall.

title: The World
description: CAIROEight needlenosed supersonic jet interceptors swept low over the Nile Delta last week, their swift flight underlining a new dimension in the dangerous potential for a new and more savage war in the Middle East.

title: National Notes
description: The clock strikes 5, and down they runthe millions of New Yorkers who descend upon the city's subway lines at the end of each working day. Thus, the rushhour crunch. But for a year now, more than 60,000 men and women in 70 lower Manhattan finns have been finessing the crunch by working staggered hours, generally from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., rather than the usual 9 to 5.

title: RCA's Biggest Shareholder
description: Fifteen years ago in Dal ton, Ga., Martin B. Seretean and two others invested their lifesavings in one carpet tufting machine and a lease on a dilapidated metaland wood shack that was later condemned.

title: The Strange Tale of American Attempts to Leap the Wall of China
description: DURING one week last January, 11,000 prominent American busi nessmen and experts on China found an intriguing offer in their mail. For $6,000 apiece (and onethird off for wives) they were invited to join the first organized group of American businessmen and scholars ever to visit Communist China.

title: Expos Defeat Reds, 32, on Fairey's TwoRun Double, His First Hit of 1971
description: MONTREAL, April 17 (UPI) Jim Fairey made his first hit of the season a big one today as he drove in two runs with a double in the sixth inning to lead the Montreal Expos to a 32 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Coney Island Unit Elects
description: Silvio J. Pinto, operator of the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island, has been elected president of the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce. Instal lation ceremonies will be held next Thursday at the 48th an nual dinner of the chamber at the Deauville Cabana and Yacht Club. 3939 Shore Parkway. Brooklyn.

title: Shows, Tours, Lectures
description: AN Indoor Gardening Show will be held this week at Gimbel's, New York, Sixth Avenue at 33d Street. The show is sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc. and seven local amateur horticultural groups. A large selection of house plants will be available for sale to the public.

title: Leematt and Raja Baba Victors in Split Handicap as Garden State Opens
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J. April 17 (AP)  C. Oliver Goldsmith's Leematt and Michael T. Phipp's Raja Baba won a divisions of the Delaware Valley Handicap on the opening day at Garden State Park today.

title: 2 WRITERS ARRESTED BY POLICE ON TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 17  The political police in the last two weeks have arrested two writers who are close friends of two Taiwanese dissidents under detention since midFebruary.

title: Economic Woes Keep Tempers Short as Argentina Awaits the Return of Democracy
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 17 After a lapse of nearly five years Argentina's allpowerful military establishment is taking steps toward an eventual return to elected leadership. But politi cians and others remain pro foundly skeptical about the ultimate chances of real de mocracy and, meanwhile, many Argentines are in an angry mood.

title: Edith S. Schur Is Betrothed
description: Miss Edith Samuel Schur, a copy editor with Harper's magazine, will be married this June to Peter Michael Leavitt, an assistant district attorney for Kings County.

title: Road Back to Merion
description: ARDMORE, Pa., April 17 With its tradition, relatively short yardage and 124 bunk ers, the Merion Golf Club is awaiting the 71st United States Open championship. But there is more reverence here for Bobby Jones and Ben Hogan than for Charlie. Coody, the Masters champion.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: OffDuty Patrolman Mugged
description: An offduty patrolman in mufti was mugged by three men early yesterday in a wait ing room in a Long Island Rail road station in Brooklyn, the police reported. The victim, Kenneth Williams, 50 years old, assigned to the Gates Avenue Station in Brooklyn was in the waiting room at Atlantic and Nostrand Avenues shortly after Friday midnight when the three men assaulted him from the rear striking him on the head. His revolver, $7 and a police identification card were taken. The patrolman was treat at St. John's Hospital and released.

title: Running the College as a Business
description: Many colleges and univer sities, buffeted by soaring expenses and declining rev enues, are turning increasing ly to sophisticated business management techniques to help insure their future.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: A Ball That Had Something for Everybody From Washington's Different Worlds
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 It's become some kind of a 16yearold rite of spring when annually the movers and shakers of Washington's several worlds of society, art, politics and diplomacy gather at the Corcoran Gallery of Art to have a ball.

title: His Answer to the Slump
description: DETROIT  What can a business do when the change in national mood wipes out its business? Is there money to be made in the new prop erties?

title: CHARLES W. LIPSCOMB
description: GLEN ROCK, N.J., April 17 Charles W. Lipscomb, a copy editor on The New York Herald Tribune from 1928 to 1945 and the American Weekly Magazine from 1945 to 1963, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital, pater son. He was 70 years old and lived at 156 Delmar Avenue. Mr. Lipscomb, who was born in Baltimore, began as a re porter on The Baltimore Ameri can. Before going to The Herald Tribune, he had worked as a publicity man for Loew's Enter prises.

title: SMITH, ASHE REACH FINAL AT CHARLOTTE
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 17 (UPI)Stan Smith and Arthur Ashe scored upsets over Tony Roche and Cliff Richey today to advance to tomorrow's final of the North Carolina National Bank invitation tennis tourna ment.

title: SusanD.Howard Bride Of Harvard Professor
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Ap irl 17Miss Susan Dunlap Howard was married here this afternoon to James H. Case 3d. The Rev. William A. Spurrier, uncle of the bride and professor of religion at Wesleyan University, per formed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: F.D.A. in Switch Now Calls Plastic Balls Flammable
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration, whose initial tests had shown that a plastic toy called the Nerf Ball did not appear to be flammable, has now declared the ball flammable.

title: C. W Post Festival Will Feature 1906 And Play by Moody
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 17 The fourth annual American Theater Festival at C. W. Post College, scheduled for next Thursday through May 1 at the Greenvale campus, will feature the year 1906.

title: Penn Captures Relays
description: Although slowed almost to a standstill by a bad baton pass, Marty Liquori ran a half mile in 1 minute, 50.4 seconds yes terday as the anchorman in Villanova's victory in the sprint medley in the QueensIona Relays at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: MOVING OF TREES IS BEGUN IN PARK
description: Parks Department workmen have begun moving 17 trees in back of the Metropolitan Museum of Art off the site where the Lehman Pavilion will be built this summer. The trees will be transplanted to the east and west sides of Central Park's East Drive.

title: Gulf Sheikdom Seeks Pilots for Air Force
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP) The ruler of the sheikdom of Qatar on the Persian Gulf is about to build up his air force and needs pilots to fly his planes.

title: Royals Beat Brewers, 53
description: MILWAUKEE, April 17 (UPI) Ed Kirkpatrick and Amos Otis hit homers in a 13hit Kansas City attack today, as the Royals defeated the Mil waukee Brewers, 53, with ninthinning relief help from Ted Abernathy.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Though reduced aerospace activity currently afflicts a number of communities in central Connecticut, contrib uting to a statewide un employment rate of 8.5 per cent, the current 21 per cent unemployment rate, or some 5,200 workers, that prevails in Bristol is not directly re lated to aerospace cutbacks.

title: The World
description: BELFASTNow, 18 months after the first wave of rioting, looting and burning in Belfast's heavily populated Falls area, most people have forgotten the few short days in which over 300 people were seriously in jured, 500 houses were burned to the ground, and 4,000 men, women and children were sud denly rendered homeless.

title: MAO'S WORK USED IN LITERACY DRIVE
description: HONG KONG, April 17The regional authorities in Commu nist China's Yunnan Province have introduced a crash course in reading for illiterate work ers and peasants so that they will be able to study and un derstand the writings of Chair man Mao Tsetung.

title: Coins
description: THE theme for National Coin Week, which starts today, is Nu mismaticsthe Hobby of All Ages and this year's program promises to be the most interesting one since the American Numismatic Association introduced the event in 1924.

title: U.S. Team Is Returning Horne With Mixed Impressions of China
description: TOKYO, April 17The ex cursion of 15 American table tennis players to China ended today where it began eight days agohere in Tokyo.

title: The World
description: AGARTALA, East PakistanWar is hell, everyone says, but it is usually hell for both sides.

title: A mitzvah you will earn if you read this wonderful book
description: TIME: The spring of 1916. But it could be 1915 or maybe the fall. Who knows? Calendars and aneroid barometers are still unknown to me. Anyway, the temperature is what is known in British novels of the 19th century as clement. Not hot. Not cold. Not good, either. But then, what in life is? Nose sniffling weath er, let's say. But not unbearably so.

title: Independence Ceremony
description: BAIDYANATH TALA, Paki stan, April 17 (AP)The in dependence of Bangla Desh was formally proclaimed today in this East Pakistani town a half mile from the Indian border.

title: The CleanUp
description: This is cleanup season in the woodland and out across the countryside. Nature makes good use of the litter that accumulates, turning it into leaf mold, renew ing the soil, healing the scars. But winter takes a toll that calls for the scavengers. Some of them are busy all winter, but snow and ice hide many a carcass from them. Now they are revealed and, in the scheme of things, must be disposed of. So the scavengers, the carrion eaters, are doubly busy.

title: Harvard Eight Beats Brown to capture Stein Trophy Seventh Year in Row
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 Harvard's heavyweight crew continued its perfect record in Stein Trophy competition today by outrowmg Brown on the Charles River.

title: Maybelle Taylor Becomes Bride
description: BALTIMORE, April 17 Miss Maybelle Anne Taylor and Robert Alvin Bennett were married here this after noon by the Rev. Leslie Branch, a cousin of the bride, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter Clever.

title: Mock Warfare Is Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)The Pentagon has an nounced tha the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines will team up early next month for two weeks of mock warfare along the North Carolina coast.

title: Stamps
description: INTERPHIL '76, the inter national stamp show in Philadelphia that will celebrate the American bicentennial, is booked for May 28 to June 6, 1976, at the Philadelphia Civic Center. A good portion of the Civic Centeran area encompass ing 140,000 square feet (ap proximately three umturfed football fields) will be utilized for the show; and more space, if necessary, is available.

title: Jeannette Marie Rynne Plans Wedding to Michael M.deRham
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y. April 17The engagement of Miss Jeannette Marie Rynne to Michael Meredith deRham has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Rynne, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Frederic Foster deRham of Casey Key, Fla., and Mrs. Frances M. Blagden deRham of Tuxedo Park.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe desolate, windswept island of Amchitka in the Aleutians was the site of an underground hydrogen  bomb test in 1969 that raised a storm of controversy. Since then, the quiet has been broken only by occa sional sea otter visitors, whom ?? Energy Commission per sonnel have taken great pains to relocate. But there were signs last week that Amchitka is in for more pyrotechnics, as the A.E.C. reaffirmed its intention to test another and more potent thermo nuclear weapon there next fall.

title: Scholarship Fund Is Penalty
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI)Pub lishers of the Police Recorder have agreed to establish a $1,000 scholarship fund for po licemen's children. In agreeing to the offer a Superior Court judge also exacted a civil pen alty of $2,500 and ordered the publishers to stop receiving the public into believing the publi cation was an official organ of California law enforcement agencies.

title: UNESCO TO ADAPT SESAME STREET
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17  A United Nations commission has reported that Sesame Street, the popular American television program of preschool education, is being adapted as a possible aid to early education in developing countries.

title: Mickey Harris, 54, Pitcher With Red Sox Pennant Team
description: FARMINGTON, Mich., April 17 (UPI)Maurice (Mickey) C. Harris, who helped pitch the Boston Red Sox to the 1946 pennant, died Thursday after a short illness. He was 54 years old.

title: Dominic Gori Weds Elisabeth McNamara
description: HARWICH PORT, Mass., April 17Miss Elisabeth Ann McNamara and Dominic Rob ert Gori were married here this morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Trinity by the Rev. James Hipp.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Ashe to Conduct Clinic For Pratt's Net Squad
description: Arthur Ashe will visit Pratt Institute on Wednesday to help conduct a tennis clinic.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Reiner, Mayer Reach Final In Concord's Junior Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 17  Gary Reiner and Gene Mayer gained the final of the fifth annual Corcord junior in vitation tennis tournament to day.

title: PIRATES BEAT METS, 20;
description: The New York Mets, who have been averaging one run a game for the last week, fell be low even that minimumsupport level yesterday and were de feated by the Pittsburgh Pirates, 20.

title: Et Al.
description: The professional autobiogra phy of the codiscoverer of cor tisone and winner of the 1950 Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology. Kendall describes, in routine prose, his early work in thyroid research and subse quent concern with the adrenal cortex. There are interesting in sights into scientific methodol ogy and a researcher's spirit of dedication to his longrange goal. While not technically writ ten, the boost will interest mainly students of science.

title: Foundation Refuses to Give Iraq Aid to Rebuild Babylon
description: LISBON, April 17Iraq's ap peal for financial aid to rebuild Babylon has been turned down by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, it was announced here today.

title: Millions in Soviet Donate A Day's Work to Country
description: MOSCOW, April 17All out for the Subbotnik was the slogan of the day as millions throughout the Soviet Union used part of their weekend to work without pay for the state.

title: PRINCETON PARLEY ON WEATHER IS SET
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 17 More than 60 scientists from 16 nations will meet at Princeton University next week to discuss means of obtaining the most scientific information from a global atmospheric observing system that is scheduled for completion in 1976.

title: OBSERVER
description: About midnight several days ago, a man appeared on the television screen in the cellar of our house to tell about a killing he had committed. Everybody else in the house had gone to bed. I mention this because the odd aspect of this whole business, looking back on it, was one watcher's personal re action to this midnight of television and, in order to convey any sense at all of the peculiarity of the thing, I have to give you a glimpse of my personal situation.

title: Grow It in a Basket
description: REMEMBERING the graceful ferns and ivies on the front porch of my child home, always yearned for an outdoor hanging bas ket. I thought this must be an unfulfilled dream, since I now lack a porch or low house roof from which to suspend one.

title: Richard Gerstle Mack to Wed Miss Bokara Hennen Legendre
description: MOUNT HOLLY, S. C., April 17Mrs. Sidney Legendre of Medway Plantation has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bokara Hennen Legendre, to Richard Gerstle Mack of Monterey, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Mack of Cannel, Calif.

title: Braves Top Phils, 62
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (UPI)Earl Williams hit the first two home runs of his major league career and Or lando Cepeda and Hal King contributed solo drives today to Carry the Atlanta Braves to a 62 victory over the Philadel phia Phillies.

title: Brezhnev Goes to Bulgaria
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (AP) The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, left by train today for Sofia to at tend the Bulgarian Communist party's 10th congress. The con gress opens Tuesday and is expected to last about a week.

title: RONALD NORTHEY, 50, WAS MAJOR LEAGUER
description: PITTSBURGH, April 17, (UPI)  Ronald J. (Ron) Northey, former major league baseball player, coach and scout, died last night after he was stricken in his home.

title: Headliners
description: Adam Clayton Powell began his rise to power when he replaced his father as pastor of Harlem's large Abyssinian Baptist Church in 1937. He had a talent for reaching people, and in 1945 he was elected the first Negro from the East to serve in Congress. A symbol of success to blacks, the flamboyant and highliving preacher represented Harlem in the House for 12 terms. Think big! he often told his followers. But Mr. Powell's power began to erode in the early 1960's when he became involved in a highly publi cized lawsuit, and last year he lost the Democratic pri mary. The cycle was completed last week back where it all began. Mr. Powell, now 62, announced from the pulpit his resignation as pastor of the Abyssinian Church to go live in the Bahamas. The time has come for a change, he said.

title: Williamsburg Of the West' Rises in Illinois
description: NAUVOO, Ill.This tiny village, drowsing on a hilltop overlook ing a sweeping bend of the Mississippi River here, is on its way to becoming what leaders of the Utah Mormon Church hopefully call the Williamsburg of the West.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  There is a sense of mystery in this town over what President Nixon and his Council of Economic Advisers were try ing to accomplish last week with their comments on the forthcoming steelwage nego tiations.

title: Navy Sweeps River
description: DERBY, Conn., April 17 Navy scored a threerace sweep from Yale and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia on the Housatonic today.

title: Science
description: One of the most astonish ing discoveries of this century has been the observation, beginning in the 1960's, of objects that look like faint stars but are apparently mil lions or billions of times brighter. The distancemeas uring methods of astronomy seem to indicate that these objects are so distant that their light must have taken billions of years to reach us.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONOn Nov. 4, 1965, his first full day on the job, former Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien promised steady improvement of mail serv ice, including eventual overnight delivery almost anywhere in the country.

title: Foreign Notes
description: International reconciliation was in the Asian air last week. Not only were Communist China and the United States progress ing from table tennis to mat ters of trade and journalistic visits, but North Korea, long regarded as the most hard nosed Communist regime of them all, was making verbal overtures to South Korea. Speak ing at the Supreme People's As sembly in Pyongyang, North Korean Foreign Minister Ho Tan noted that South Korea had re cently suggested exchanges of journalists and sportsmen be tween the two Koreas, and said: We express support for such policy statements, consid ering that they are of affirma tive significance for easing the prevailing tension and accom plishing  NorthSouth unifi cation, the longcherished de sire of the whole nation. He suggested meetings in the truce village of Panmunjom or else where to talk it over.

title: Hawaii Sees Economic Gain
description: Statehood for Hawaii has advanced to the point where it too makes use of such latterday measurements as econometric models to an alyze economic prospects. In Hawaii's case its model has served as a promising outlook for growth in the state for the next three years.

title: Peter Serkin Performs Music of Mid20th Century
description: A bracing program of mid 20thcentury piano music was played at the Metropolitan Mu seum Friday night by Peter Sorkin. The oldest pieces were two of Olivier Messiaen's Vingt Regards sur l'Enf ant Jsus, which date from 1944, and the newest was Michael Riesman's Phases for Elec tronically Modulated Piano, which was composed last year.

title: Office Memo: AB in the Exacta
description: Offtrack betting has added a new di mension to the takealetter routine of the New York secretary.

title: Common Market:
description: PARIS  Britain is again trying to get into the Common Market, but this time the chances look better for the door to open. Blocked by Charles de Gaulle in two earlier attempts to join, Britain opened the third, and probably the decisive, round of talks last June 30 in Luxembourg. Nearly 10 months later the two sides are dead locked over the terms of entry, but intense diplomatic activity is underway to try to find com promises.

title: Off To a Good Start on the penthouse
description: THOUGH tis early to plant everything, those who garden on ter races and penthouse can set out woody ornamen tals  evergreens, trees and shrubs. Annuals, hanging bas kets and foliage plants can not go outdoors until mid to late May.

title: The girls can leave when they want but want to stay
