description: At the Livingston School for Girls (P.S. 8), which Mrs. Esther Rothman has headed for 11 of its 12 years, everyone learns: principal, teachers, students and even parents. It didn't have to turn out that way. When the Board of Education created the day school for beaters of teachers and firesetters and cursers and otherwise thoroughly ineffable and incorrigible girls, Mrs. Rothman recalls, it exiled the institution to an 83yearold build ing in Greenwich Village that was slated for demolition. Naturally. Most of the students were black or Puerto Rican, and they were used to slums, weren't they?

title: Johncock Gets Indy Car
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 17 (AP) Gordon Johncock and Larry Dickson were named as drivers for two of the five new entries received for the Indianapolis 500mile auto race, bringing the total to 68. Johncock will drive one of the two Fordpowered cars entered by Rolla Vollstedt Enterprises Inc., of Portland, Ore. Dickson will drive an Of fenhauser for Grant King Rac ers of Indianapolis.

title: EGYPT AND SYRIA WERE ONCE JOINED
description: Although a federation of Arab countries was long a dream of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the Egyptian leader who died last September, the one union he succeeded in forming lasted less than four years.

title: The Baker's Flowers
description: THERE is a most fascinating story associated with the beautiful deciduous azaleas which are now becoming available in this country. It is complicated and intimately connected with the dedicated work of one or two people.

title: HIGHER FEE PLANNED FOR FEDERAL CAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Interior Department has a plan that would cost the camping faintly much more for a season of tenting on Federal campgrounds. Although the de partment's proposal has its ori gins with some members of Congress, the legislation still faces tough opposition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Linesman Hit by Stone During Soccer Dispute
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP) A linesman was felled by a stone and the police ar rested 23 struggling fans in Leeds today during the English League soccer match won by West Bromwich, 21.

title: Kennedy Declines Again
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP) Senator Kennedy said again today that he would not run for President in 1972 under any circumstances.

title: Miners Averaged $5.70
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Labor Department says that the nation's coal miners averaged $5.70 an hour in total pay and fringe benefits in 1969, and that union men earned rearly twice as much as non union miners.

title: Television
description: How does the black artist meet the chal lenges of his career and our society? These matters were discussed recently on NET's Black Journal by Sammy Davis Jr. and Black Journal's Tony Brown. Excerpts from their conversation follow. Brown began by asking Davis:

title: HORTON'S 5TH HIT WINS FOR TIGERS
description: DETROIT, April 17 (UPI) Willie Horton, who hit two homers earlier, slashed a bases loaded twoout single in the 10th inning today for his fifth straight hit and sixth run batted in as the Detroit Tigers edged the Boston Red Sox, 109.

title: Explosion in West Orange Damages Jewish Center
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sun day, April 18  An explosion early this morning damaged the Jewish Center on Pleasant Val ley Way here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Feminists Hold RapeDefense Workshop
description: With an arsenal of leg kicks, arm chops and blood curdling shouts, two bare foot petite women demon strated yesterday their belief that any woman could defend herself against sexual assault with a few simple karate tactics.

title: Movies
description: A GIRL can make a mis take, but a smart girl doesn't make the same mistake twice. That's why Mario Thomas is going to star in producer William Castle's new film, She'll Never Get Off the Ground.

title: CAR RACE QUALIFIERS PACED BY GLOTZBACH
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N. C., April 17 (UPI)  Charlie Glotz bach drove a 1971 Chevrolet at 104.525 miles an hour today, leading the final qualifying ses sion for tomorrow's 11th an nual Gwyn Staley 400 Grand National stock car race.

title: Astros Top Dodgers, 53
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 (UPI) Doug Rader's twoout triple in the eighth drove in Bob Wat son with the winning run to night as the Houston Astros posted a 53 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Whatever Became of the Travel Sticker?
description: IN this age of nostalgia, when they're bringing back the fads of the Twen ties and Thirties, I say bring back the travel sticker! I am moved to write this entreaty because of the death of an old friendmy trusty Number One suitcase. It died of a sidesplitting quite beyond any leathercrafter's skill to mend, but it went out in a blaze of glory, plastered with colorful travel stickers.

title: Pop
description: IN LESS than two years, Isaac Hayes, the shaven headed singer his cronies have dubbed the Black Moses, has surfaced at the top of the rhythm n blues and jazz charts. Record buy ers long accustomed to vocal hysterics served up with their soul music have discovered Hayes's cooler style.

title: Stokes Hopes to Help Organize Minorities' National Coalitions
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 17 Mayor Carl B. Stokes of Cleve land said today that he had de cided not to seek a third term in order to work nationally in organizing political coalitions that involve minorities and the poor.

title: GEIBERGER SHARES ONESTROKE LEAD
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 17 Lean Al Geiberger shot a four under par 67 today to tie at 208 with Mason Rudolph for the head after the third round of the $150,000 Monsanto open golf tournament.

title: Royals' Baseball Students To Tour Central America
description: SARATOGA, Fla., April 17 (AP)Members of the Kansas City Royals Baseball Academy will begin a twoweek goodwill tour of four Central American countries May 7.

title: U. OF NEW MEXICO OPENS LAW BUILDING
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 17The Navajo blessing way Ceremony opened the dedica Vim program for the Univer lity of New Mixico's new 1.7 feillion law school building itere this morning.

title: Red China Hints Softening Of Position on Tie to U.S.
description: CANTON, China, April 17 Chinese Communist officials, have hinted at a softening of conditions that might lead to establishment of diplomatic re lations between Peking and Washington.

title: Knicks Seek WrapUp Today;
description: BALTIMORE, April 17Phys ical condition, the vagaries of officiating, the luck of the bounce and mental states will be more important than master strategies or past performances when the New York Knicks and Baltimore Bullets square off tomorrow in the sixth game of their National Basketball Asso ciation series.

title: How Ready the Coast Guard?
description: During the Korean war when large quantities of munitions were passing through American ports, Con gress passed the Magnuson Act giving the Coast Guard broad powers to regulate activities in American harbors as a protection against sabotage or accident. That emergency measure, still in effect, has been invoked by environmental groups in a plea for new Coast Guard traffic controls to reduce the risk of oil spills.

title: Mrs. Court Defeats Miss Goolaon
description: JOANNESBURG, April 17 (UPI)Mrs. Margaret Court beat her doubles partner, Evonne Goolagong, 63, 61, in the all  Australian women's singles final at the $$51,000 South African open tennis championships today.

title: 10,000 See Chiefs Win
description: ATLANTA, April 7 (UPI) Kaizer BoyBoy Motaung broke a scoreless tie midway in the first half tonight to lead the Atlanta Chiefs to a 20 victory over the Montreal Olympics in their North American Soccer League opener before 10,000.

title: Is McCloskey The McCarthy of '72?
description: ON Feb. 10, Congressman Paul N. (Pete) McCloskey Jr., a 43 yearold Californian previously known chiefly for his victory over Mrs. Shirley Temple Black in a spe cial election in 1967, made a speech at Stanford University. It was an un usually biting speech for any mem ber of Congress to have made; com ing as it did from a Republican who had been in Washington for only three years, it verged on heresy. Mc Closkey suggested a national dia logue to discuss the impeachment of President Nixon as a means of changing the President's war policy, argued that Mr. Nixon and Presi dent Johnson had breached the Con stitution through the arrogant use of power, and asserted that what we are doing in Laos is as great a crime as those we executed Japa nese and German officials for in World War II.

title: Try Something New This Year
description: THIS is shopping time. Catalogues carry big ger than life, full color photos of all the newest plants. Seed racks and garden centers display scores of tempting attractive items. Considerable strength of character is needed to keep from buying one of everything.

title: FULL REPORT SOUGHT ON CITY LABOR TALKS
description: The full report of the impasse panel in the city's labor nego tiations with policemen, firemen and sanitationmen should be, made public. Mayor Lindsay urged yesterday in a statement.

title: VOTING CAMPAIGN OPENS IN TRINIDAD
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 15In this tropical na tion where blackpower dem onstrations almost toppled the Government a year ago, tradi tional politics holds center stage these days.

title: 48 Great Neck Students Pick Their Curriculums
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April 17An experimental public high school program with no classes, no grades and no formal structure is rounding out an apparently successful first year here for 48 jun iors and seniors.

title: Leaving Stalled Car Costly
description: BOSTON, April 17A $65, 000 personal damage Judgment against a man who left his stalled car in the center of a highway was upheld this week by the State Supreme Court. The man left his car after it Iran out of gas. According to testimony, another car swung to avoid the vehicle and ran into a tree.

title: Elizabethan Heterodox
description: Thomas Hariot is known chiefly to Americans for his famous Brief and True Report of the New Found Land of Virginia (i.e. North Amer ica), which he wrote in Armada year, 1588. It is a classic of scientific and anthropological observation by the most original and wideranging of Elizabethan scientific intellects. Some idea of its importance may be gathered from the fact that 17 edi tions of it appeared in Europe in the quarter of a century after its publica tion: no other English book arrested so much attention on the Continent certainly not Shakespeare. It had been translated into Latin, and pub lished by De Bry with illustrations in those days it was not necessary for anyone abroad to know English.

title: Photography
description: CONTAINING more than 300 pages and nearly 200 illustrations, a com pletely revised and en larged edition of Small Mi noxBig Pictures has just been released in the United States (English language edi tion). Priced at $6.95, and available from Minox dealers, or direct from the Minox Com pany, P.O. Box 1060, Wood side, N.Y. 11377, the book is a compendium of Minox pho tography techniques and equipment. Written by Rolf Kasemeier, worldwide sales manager of the company, and translated by E.F. Linssen, Fellow of the Royal Photo graphic Society (Great Bri tain), the 4 by 6 inch volume traces the use of the Minox from its first model, introduced in the 1930's, to its latest computerized Model C. Subjects covered include how to get most effective re sults with the camera, choice of film, lighting, flash, copy ing, processing and enlarg ing techniques

title: Mellon's Mill Ref Captures Newbury's Greeham Stakes
description: NEWBURY, England, April 17 (Reuters)Mill Ref, owned by Paul Mellon of the United States, recorded a fourlength victory today in the Greeham Stakes.

title: GEN. HENRI ZELLER, VETERAN OF 2 WARS
description: PARIS, April 17General of the Army Henri Zeller, a vet eran of both World Wars, died at Val de Grace Military Hos pital here last night. He was 75 years old. He was the broth er of Gen. Andr Zeller, two years his junior, who was sen tenced to 15 years' imprison ment for his part in the April, 1961 coup d'tat in Algiers, and amnestied in 1968.

title: Foreign Notes
description: India and Pakistan, their un easy relationship under added strain owing to the East Paki stani revolt, agreed on one thing last week: to send aid to their tiny island neighbor, Ceylon, which was being ravaged by civil war. To support the leftist government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike against the ultra leftist guerrillas calling them selves Che Guevarists, India sent six helicopters and four frigates, and Pakistan sent two helicop ters. In addition, Britain, which ruled the ancient and pleasant island for 133 years before grant ing it independence in 1948, supplied small arms and ammu nition, andacting as a kind of middlemansix helicopters bought especially from the United States, which did not wish to be come involved openly.

title: A PentagonShaped Cemetery, Dry Elephant Tails and Other Wonders of the Mysterious East
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanThe registration form at the Grand Hotel in Taipei calls upon guests to put down, for the edification of the local police, the number of their firearm license. The police are efficientand ubiquitous. I have an encounter, unarmed, with a foreign resident of the city whose Tai wanese maid has been carted off in handcuffs by some cops. The charge is stealing from a former employer. It develops that the alleged victim gave his maid a money order in anticipation of her becoming his concubine. The girl has had second thoughts, but has kept the money order, though she hasn't cashed it.

title: When You Get There, You've Arrived
description: GREENWICH, Conn.Pan American World Airways named three new members to its board of directors last month and it just so happens that they all live here.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MANTA, TIPPING TIME WIN ON COAST GRASS
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 17 (AP)Manta raced to her sixth career grasscourse victory without a loss in the second division today after Tipping Time won the first in the split $50,000 Long Beach Handicap for fillies and mares at Holly wood Park.

title: At the Met, Creeping Socialism?; Strictly For Trill Seekers
description: SATURDAY evening saw the end of the Metro politan Opera's 1970.71 season, and a most signif icant season it turned out to be, though a good deal of the interest concerned matters outside of the daytoday business of putting on seven operas a week from Sept. 14 to April 17.

title: OFFICER OPPOSES CITIZEN PATROLS
description: Deputy Chief Inspector Ar thur B. Hill, commander of the Police Department's 13th Divi Sion in Brooklyn, is encourag ing the formation of auxiliary police unitsas an alterna tive to citizen patrolsto deal with a crime rate that has alarmed many residents of the area.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW type of carpet cushion material re cently put on the mar ket is made of a high density polyether foam that gives it unusual wear charac teristics, as well as providing it with qualities that prolong the life of any carpet under which it is installed. Avail able in various thicknesses up to  inch, this new foam type cushioning makes any carpet feel more luxurious by adding a feeling of resiliency and thickness to the carpet, regardless of its quality or type.

title: HLS of the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON.

title: Wilhelm Reich The Psychoanalyst as Revolutionary
description: DURING the student revolts that shook many European univer sities in the spring of 1968, the influence of the errant psycho analyst, Wilhelm Reich, was much in evidence. In Paris, Reichian sym bols* depicting the human conflicts produced by societal repression of sexuality were crudely painted on the walls of the Sorbonne. In Berlin, student members of freelivingand loving communes pelted police with softbound copies of Reich's The Mass Psychology of Fascism. Reich, who died in an American prison in 1957 and who had been expelled from the psychoanalytic movement for his political involvements, was being resurrected everywhere in Europe as a hero/saint to students demanding social reform.

title: Modest Trillion
description: After the long stagnation in the economy, the 6.5 per cent rate of growth in the first quarter is welcome. But confidence that it marks a durable turn would be greater if the bulk of the expansion were not attributable to recovery from one strike and preparations for another.

title: Education
description: For some time, fiscal pres sures have been building on the country's universities and colleges. Administrators have warned of cutbacks to ac commodate tighter budgets. Last week several develop ments indicated retrenchment was well in progress:

title: Two City U. Colleges Aid MinorityGroup Businesses
description: A program to assist minority groups in the management of small business was started last week in Jamaica, Queens, by two senior colleges of the City University.

title: Chiefs Acquire Homan
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 17 (AP)The Kansas City Chiefs acquired Dennis Homan from the Dallas Cowboys for Gloster Richardson. Both are wide re ceivers.

title: Nimeiry Voices Support
description: CAIRO, April 17 (Reuters) General Nimeiry tonight ex pressed the Sudan's full sup port for the federation of Egypt, Syria and Libya.

title: Kentucky to Get Grant
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Interior Department will grant $106,240 to buy more land for the John James Audubon State Park in Henderson Coun ty, Ky. Under the grant, the Kentucky Department Of Parks will acquire 164 acres to be used as a buffer between the park and private developments.

title: Science
description: Improved varieties of hybrid corn introduced since 1950 have more than doubled the yield per acre and have provided the vast amounts of feed grain needed to feed the nation's enormous hunger for steaks, chops, hamburgers and other meats.

title: NEW TAMPA AIRPORT OPENS FOR TRAFFIC
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 17The new $80million Tampa Interna tional Airport, called one of the most functional in the country by John Shaffer, administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, was officially opened on Thursday.

title: Declining Memberships Forcing Changes in East Side Protestant Churches
description: The wealthy, influential and prestigious East Side churches that were for decades the show cases of Protestantism in the city are changing, in varying degrees, to cope with declining attendance and rejection of traditional forms of worship.

title: SOVIET ECOLOGISTS REOPEN LAKE ISSUE
description: MOSCOW, April 17A So viet conservationist has dis closed that the Government is going ahead with a second woodplup mill near Lake Bai kal, which has been described by other ecologists as one of the best known examples of the misuse of water resources in the Soviet Union.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Philip Harwick Power Fiance Of Sarah Hutchins Goddard
description: GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich., April 17Mr. and Mrs. Wendell Converse Goddard have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Sarah Hutchins Goddard, to Philip Harwick Power, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bar num Power of Ann Arbor.

title: Et Al.
description: Subtitle: The Letters of Fred erick Jackson Turner and Alice Forbes Perkins Hooper 1910 1932. Mrs. Hooper was the heiress of a Midwestern rail road fortune and patroness of the Huntington Library, which the historian F. J. Turner helped set up. Their correspondence, which the library now hand somely publishes as a memen to, is courtly on his side and rather giddy on hers, not re vealing of either.

title: STATE EXPANDING ITS U.S. LOBBYING
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Governor Rockefeller has de cided to wage a more active lobbying effort on behalf of New York State with Congress and the Nixon Administration.

title: Foreign Notes
description: When President de Gaulle granted Algeria independence in 1962 after a long and bitter war, he did so within the frame work of a special relationship that amounted to an experiment in enlightened decolonization. Algeria received more cultural and economic help than Tu nisia and Morocco, which had gained their freedom in the 1950's. In return, French com panies were given control over twothirds of Algeria's oil pro duction, an important factor in General de Gaulle's plan to make France independent of American and other oil inter ests.

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (AP)  Alexander Matveyev, a Soviet weight lifter, set a world rec ord yesterday in the middle weight division when he pressed 377 pounds, Tass, the Soviet prec agoncy reported today.

title: 2 Senators Apparently Thwart Navy on Third Nuclear Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  The Navy has apparently been thwarted by two Senators, Clif ford P. Case of New Jersey and Walter F. Mondale of Minne sota, in a plan to start building a third nuclearpowered carrier without the specific approval of Congress.

title: President Will Ask Congress for Authorization to Name EconomicAssistance Coordinator in A.I.D. Reform
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  President Nixon plans to ask Congress next week for auth ority to name a new coordinator of economic foreign aid who would serve as chairman of the three agencies the President wants to substitute for the Agency for International Devel opment.

title: A BLACK PANTHER FOUND SLAIN HERE
description: The bulletriddled body of a man whom the police identified as a Black Panther was found yesterday afternoon in the burned ruins or the party's Corona, Queens, office.

title: Moonsplash First by Neck As Arlington Park Opens
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)  Moonsplash beat Honest Effort, a stablemate, by a neck in the $10,000 Balmoral Handicap to day at Arlington Park.

title: Why the Israelis Are Being Difficult
description: TEL AVIV.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JOHANNESBURG, Souk Africa The local story goes that when planes are about to land here the pilot an nounces over the intercom: You are now approaching Jan Smuts Airport. Please extinguish your cigarettes, ad just your seats and fasten your seat belts. For local time, set your watches back twenty years.

title: Hahn Leads Korean Open
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 17 (AP)Hahn ChangSang of Korea, the defending champion, took a threestroke lead today by carding a oneunderpar 71 for a threeround total of 210 in the Korean open golf cham pionship. Lu LiangHuan of Tai wan shot a 69 for a total of 214 and tied Walter Godfrey of New Zealand.

title: HAZEWINKLE TAKES GRECOROMAN TITLE
description: EUGENE, Ore., April 17 (AP) One title was decided early today at the United States Wrestling Federation's Greco Roman championships.

title: Background of the Drug
description: Dr. Vincent Dole and Dr. Marie Nyswander of Rocke feller University first introduced methadone as a mainte nance drug for heroin addicts in the midnineteensixties. Since then, many physicians who have used and refined their techniques have reported promising results.

title: Sports of the times
description: Less than half a minute of the game remained when Willis Reed, walking down court alongside Dave DeBusschere, smiled for the first time all night. At the same moment Bill Bradley and Walt Frazier ex changed attaboy slaps on the rump. Like everyone else In Madison Square Garden on Friday they knew that the victory of the imperiled Knicks over the. Baltimore Bullets was secure.

title: U.S. Archeologists Solve Mystery of Stone Slab Near Acropolis
description: ATHENS, April 17The mys tery of a large limestone slab discovered near the Acropolis has just been solved by Ameri can archeologists, who identify it as the stone on which the nine archons, the elected lead ers of ancient ??, stood when they took the oath of office.

title: Bill to Allow Wide Buses Stirs a Dispute in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 17A bill that would allow the width of buses operating on the Fed eral interstate highway system to be increased six inches has stirred a dispute in the House.

title: Computerized Transit on Coast Facing a New Delay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 BART, the longdelayed Bay Area Rapid Transit system, which is scheduled to begin limited passenger service here next January, is running into new difficulties.

title: L.I. Aviation Buff Soars Into the Sky Out of Basement Hangar
description: DEER PARK, L. I., April 17 Some men build barbecue pits in their backyards.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: College Opened in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 17 (Agence FrancePresse) Emperor Haile Selassie has opened a municipal technical college here that was built with French aid. It will offer courses in Frenchin public works, topography, house building, hy draulic engineering and town planning.

title: Pulse of Business Sustains the Gait Of Roaring Market
description: AROUND the start of spring a month ago, it has now become apparent, the pulse of business developed a faster beat that has helped sustain the quickened gait of the roaring stock market. The better economy, improving corporate profits and easier monetary conditions have combined to push stock prices steadily higher to their best levels in almost two years.

title: Karen Blickwede Becomes Bride
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 17  Miss Karen Blickwede, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Blickwede, was married here this morning to Computer Technician/2 Kim ball James Knowlton, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Q. Knowlton of Bloomington, Ind.

title: Bid for an Extension On Bias Suit Expected
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 17  The Oyster Bay Town Board is expected to ask for an extension of time in which to reply to a law suit by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that con tends the town's zoning laws are discriminatory. The deadline for a reply is Mon day.

title: Stalking Lions in Canada? Yesbut Stay in the Car
description: ROCKTON, OntarioIt was a nippy spring day, with even a touch of winter still lingering in the air, and it seemed hardly the time or place to stalk lions. Yet this was what we were doingand with considerable success.

title: Religion
description: Four years ago, the Ameri can bishops of the Roman Catholic Church voted to put $500,000 into a major study, of the American priesthood, The motives for the project were mixed. Some church leaders argued that intelli gent decisionmaking in the postVatican II period re quired solid data on the atti tudes of priests toward im portant issues like church government. Others saw it as a convenient way of reducing the immediate controversy over the celibacy issue, which was just emerging as a major problem for the church.

title: Son Is Born to Swains
description: WYNNEWOOD, Pa., April 17A son was born on April 4 in Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia to Mr. and Mrs. William Merrick Swain Jr. The child has been named for his father. Mrs. Swain, the former Miss Gertrude McFarland Goheen, is a daughter of Robert F. Goheen, president of Prince ton University, and Mrs. Go heen. The child is the grand son also. of Mr. and Mrs. Will liam M. Swain of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia. The child's father is a vice president of I. N. A. Properties in Phila delphia.

title: WILLIAM D .ECGKERT, EXBASEBALL HEAD
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., April 16 (AP)William Dole Eckert, a former Air Force lieutenant gen eral and commissioner of major league baseball, died of a heart attack suffered while playing tennis Friday at Freeport in the Bahamas. He was 62 years old.

title: Bridge Catching an expert by surprise takes naiveteor genius
description: EVERY routine situation in play and defense is well  known to the bridge expert, although, of course, he may not be conversant with the esoteric squeezes that abound in doubledummy problems. In bidding he often does meet fresh problems, perhaps most often because the opponents are using some new device. But once the auction is over, he very seldom receives surprises, and if he fails, it is likely to be through poor judgment, bad luck or lack of concentration.

title: Favored Unconscious Wins by Lenths and Sets Record in California Derby
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 17 (AP)  Unconscious strength ened his claim as the best West Coast candidate for the Ken tucky Derby with a three length victory and a record time in the $125,400 California Derby at Golden Gate Fields today.

title: Cigarettes and TV
description: The ban on cigarette ad vertising on television and radio that went into effect on Jan. 2 has had no ad verse effect so fax on sales of the major cigarette manu facturers.

title: White Sox Snap Losing Streak at 7
description: CHICAGO, April 17 (UPI) Tom Bradley struck out 10 men and allowed only four hits today as he pitched the Chica go White Sox to a 40 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 17 (UPI)Harry Knudsen, 48 years old, who received a new heart in a transplant operation Feb. 22, died Wednesday night, Stanford Medical Center an nounced yesterday.

title: Et Al.
description: This is Harvard Historical Monograph No. 62, subtitled Marseille, Lyon, Paris and the Reaction to a Centralized State. 18681871 and while it is of more general interest than Harvard Historical Mono graph No. 61 (The Rumanian National Movement in Transyl vania, 17801849) it still is not destined for wide readership. Quite well written.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Most mystery fiction being as solidified in its formulas as a cowboy novel, it is unusual for a writer to come up with a new twist. But two, within recent months, have: James Anderson in his ASSASSIN (Simon& Schus ter, $4.95) and Campbell Black in THE PUNCTUAL RAPE (Lip pincott, $4.95). Both books carry with them a feeling of doom. And both have ingenious endings. The conclusion of Assassin, indeed, will have the reader's eyes popping. Some may call it unbelievable, though Anderson has spent a good deal of time building up his hero's character, so that it points di rectly to the way he eventually does act.

title: Hawks Alter Lines for Rangers
description: CHICAGO, April 17  In a surprise move that indicates how much respect the Black Hawks have for the Rangers, the Chicagoans will reorganize two lines for their Stanley Cup playoff semifinal series, which begins here tomorrow night.

title: The Sheriffs of England Meet to Form a Union
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP) The Sheriff of Nottingham, whose ancient predecessor pursued Robin Hood through Sherwood Forest, has formed a trade union with his fellow sheriffs.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: State Enforces Law on Waste Discharge From Yachts
description: Boat owners who have been hoping that the state law pro hibiting any kind of discharge of waste into the water would be delayed, changed or dropped because of the impending Fed er al law can now expect the worst: The state is going ahead with its plan to enforce the un popular law.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SUEZ TALKS SEEN AT CRUCIAL STAGE
description: JERUSALEM, April 17Is raeli officials today indicated their belief that diplomatic dis cussions aimed at an agreement to reopen the Suez Canal had reached a crucial stage.

title: Judith Ann Winter Has Nuptials
description: Miss Judith Ann Winter was married here last eve ning to Martin E. Andrucki in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Elizabeth C. McGrath Married
description: The marriage of Miss Eliz abeth C. McGrath to Stephen Babcock Brown took place here last evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick McGrath, parents of the bride. Only members of the imme diate families attended the ceremony.

title: BROOKLYN TO WAIT FOR BIG PROJECTS
description: Like, those Ebbets Field fans of yore, top Brooklyn officials find that some of their fondest projects keep winding up in the wait till neat year category.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  Pacification will be fully realized not when we will have occupied each inch of earth but when we will have conquered all the hearts and won all the minds.

title: Negro Colleges Suffering Under U.S. Aid Policy
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Public Negro colleges in several Southern states are finding it virtually impossible to expand or to integrate as Federal funds are poured into competing predominantly white institutions.

title: Jeanine S. Miller And Lawyer Set Wedding in June
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 17Mr. and Mrs. Charles Duncan Miller have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanine Stewart Miller, to Richard Terry Abrahams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Abrahams of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Nixon Speaks Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI) President Nixon will deliver two speeches Monday, the White House announced. He will address a Republican Gov ernors Conference at Williams burg, Va., at 11:30 A.M. At 9 P.M., he will speak to the 80th Continental Congress of the Daughters of American Revolu tion in Washington.

title: Dartmouth Board Votes to Consider A Women's School
description: HANOVER, N. H., April 17 The board of trustees of Dart mouth College voted today to consider at its October meeting the establishment of an asso ciated school for women.

title: More Summer Conceptions
description: PARIS, April 17 (Reuters) Europeans conceive more babies in summer than at other sea sons. According to a French study published here. The Na tional Demographic Institute, which conducted a survey throughout Europe, said the most conceptions were in June, July and August, while Novem ber had the fewest.

title: A Daughter Is Born To James Roosevelts
description: GENEVA, April 17A daughter was born on Sun day to Mr. and Mrs. James Roosevelt in, the Geneva Can tonal Hospital. Mrs. Roose velt the former Mary Win skill of Chester, England, and Mr. Roosevelt, eldest son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, were married in October, 1969. The child has been named Rebecca Mary.

title: The plaint of the Virgin Islands: We Have Been Encroached On, Invaded, Engulfed
description: CHRISTIANSTED.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  Lumumba Uni versity, which the Soviet Union established to educate students from nonCommunist develop ing countries, celebrates its 11th anniversary this year. The school, on Moscow's south side, has figured in the news recent ly in conjunction with reported revolutionary movements in Mexico and Ceylon.

title: Books: an Executive's Many Hats
description: THE TWELVE HATS OF A COMPANY PRESIDENT. By Willard F. Rockwell Jr. Pren ticeHall, Inc. 244 pages.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Architecture
description: THE new architecture show at the Museum of Modern Art is prob ably not for city plan ners. Will Insley: Ceremonial Space, consists of a one room exhibition of a large architectural modelif that is the way you describe the threedimensional vision of a mystic and esthetic experi ence, it will be in the mu seum's architecture and de sign galleries, with drawings and photomontages, through May 3. Concerned with some thing called Onecity and Ex tended Space, it is best de scribed by the artistarchi tect:

title: Manhattan Defeats Iona and NewYork Maritime
description: The Manhattan College var sity eightoared crew, rowing in a borrow shell, defeated Iona and New York State Maritime College in the collegeclub New York Rowing Association re gatta yesterday on the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx. It was Manhattan's first varsity victory of the season against three defeats.

title: In Forest Hills, They're Off and Runningto the Betting Parlor
description: Jack McNamara used to sell 10 racing tip sheets a day to Forest Hills bettors stopping at his newsstand on the corner of Queens Boule vard and 71st Avenue. But that was before the city opened its offtrack betting shop a block away on April 8.

title: E. MICHIGAN WINS FOUR OHIO RELAYS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17 (UPI)  Athletes from the state of Michigan dominated the 34th Ohio Relays in Ohio Stadium today, taking 11 of 21 events and setting three of four meet records.

title: Bucknell Coed Manages a Letter
description: Harvard may still be debat ing the possible award of a varsity letter to the coed manager of its ski team, but Bucknell University has al ready given a varsity B to a browneyed girl who man ages its crosscountry team and assists the manager of the track team.

title: PERUVIAN REGIME WOOS THE MASSES
description: LIMA, Peru, April 16The Peruvian military Government is planning new legislation to organize popular support for its populist revolution by de decree, now two and a half years old.

title: National Notes
description: For neither love nor money could Common Cause get the time of day  or night  last week.

title: Et Al.
description: African songs, mainly of the Zulu and Xhosa peoples, cho sen from the repertoire of Miri am Makeba. Solomon Mbabi Katana's introduction contains illuminating comments on black folk music, but is all too short. Dean Alexander's illustrations are superb. The musical nota tion and transliterated lyrics are large and clear. A book for singing.

title: 4 Men Invade Court At Night and Dump 1,000Traffic Tickets
description: Four young men with an ap parent hate for traffic sum monses invaded a traffic court in lower Manhattan early yes terday morning and heaved four bundles of unpaid traffic tick ets out the window to the street below.

title: Et Al.
description: Articles, many excellent in themselves, that consider the problems, complaints, preju dices, aspirations of the lower middle and worldngclass white American. The effect is confu sion by diversity of thought. Peter Binzen's Wlaitetown, U.S.A. provides a ?? clearer picture of the Silent Majority.

title: Muskie Ends Fruitful 2Day Political Visit to New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., April 17 I've never regarded the people of New Hampshire as an automatic constituency, said Senator Edmund S. Muskie of the neighboring state of Maine.

title: Dance
description: ONCE upon a time, when the world was inno cent and even the least innocent among us were much younger, it used to be urged upon dance and music critics that they ought to get out a little more. My God! unkind people would say, how can you admire that terrifyingly in ept production of Aida or Swan Lake'? Do you not realize that the 20th century has hit the theater? How can you be so effortlessly, cubic ally square? How indeed? At one time it was a rather good question.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: M. P. in Vietnam: A Thin Line Between Discipline and Harassment
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17He is a tall, courtly man who saysunlike most American soldiersthat being here has made him more hu man.

title: FRANCIS G.MAYER, A PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Francis G. Mayer, a profes sional photographer of art mas terpieces, died Friday at his home, 251 East 51st Street, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 79 years old.

title: Art
description: TWO big new exhibitions, the Whitney Museum's Contemporary Black Artists in America, which turns out to be one big vanilla pudding, and the Met ropolitan's The Cubist Epoch, which sounds histori cal but adds nothing to our historical appreciation of that epoch, may very well be straws in the wind. I hope they are, or I find their curi ous disconnection with their putative subjects most en couraging.

title: 130 Hurt as Stands Fall
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., April 17 (AP)The center section of a 20tier bleacher collapsed dur ing an automobile race at a track near here tonight. At least 130 persons were reported in jured. Six ambulance companies and rescue squads carried the injured to two Wilmington hos pitals. William Morrison, direc tor of the New Hanover Memo rial Hospital, said there was no indication that any were criti cally injured.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: VIENNA, Md.For many years, wih typical male con ceit, striped bass anglers have referred to fish of over 30 pounds as bull bass.

title: 5% in U. S. Cite Spanish Origins
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17 The Census Bureau has report ed that 9.2 million Americans, 5 per cent of the population, idenitfy themselves as having an origin in a Spanishspeak ing country.

title: Movies
description: MILOS FORMAN, the Czech director, came to New York, lived in the East Village, hung around Fillmore East and clearly spent a lot of time at the Bethesda Foun tain. This is hot stuff for a European and as glamorous to a Czech as a Welsh sea port is to someone in the Sa hara. What we take for grant ed is the fact that New York, with its rock culture, is the most radical spot for anyone on earth with the exception of those who have never opened their ears and eyes and nose and throat to youth at all.

title: Engineers Propose Traffic Ban In Midtown During Work Days
description: The banning of private cars, taxis and city buses in midtown Manhattan for 11 hours every working day was suggested yesterday by the New York City Chapters of the New York State Society of Professional En gineers.

title: Granieri Loses 2d Final in Row As Fenveysi Takes Epee Title
description: Nickola Granieri, the bouncy Italian from Turin, encountered frustration for the second straight time last night when he was beaten in the pe final of the International Martini & Rossi fencing tournament.

title: Robert E. Boerum Weds Denise DeGroot
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., April 17Miss Denise De Groot and Robert E. Boerum were married here this morn ing in the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King. The Rev. John F. Corr per formed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Plain song for an apocalypse
description: In the beginning was Scream, begins a poem revising the Book of Genesis. Ted Hughes's substitution, on this early page in Crow, of Scream for Word suggests the violent, primi tive energy and the furious assault upon despair which striate the nearly 80 poems in this book. Reading Crow is a profoundly disturbing experience. This is no mere book of verses, but a wild yet cunning wail of anguish and resilience, at once contemporary, immediate, and as atavistic as the archaic myths it resembles.

title: Accord on Union Reached By Egypt, Libya and Syria
description: CAIRO, April 17President Anwar elSadat tonight an nounced plans for a union of Egypt, Libya and Syria with a common stand of no compro mise with Israel. The union, Mr. Sadat said, will have one President, one flag, one an them and one federal capital.

title: Discus, Toolight, Costs Swede a World Record
description: MALMO, Sweden, April 17 (Reuters). Ricky Bruch of Sweden achieved what he thought was a world discus record of 70.15 meters (230 feet 1 inches)only to find that the discus weighed a few grams too little for the throw to be approved.

title: Queens Community Ballet Stepping to a Lively Tune
description: It was not the typical ballet public. Most in the audience were 4 feet tall and wore beanies. But they applauded en thusiastically and, after the performance, besieged the dancers on the street for auto graphs.

title: Benjamin H. Russell Marries Miss Sally Putze in Darien
description: DARIEN, Conn., April 17 Miss Sally Putze and Ben jamin Harvey Russell were married here this afternoon in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Church by the rec tor, the Rev. Dr. Robert Nel son Back.

title: Brazil Captures 20 Lead Over Ecuador in Davis Cup
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, April 17 (AP) Tom Koch and Jos Edison Mandarino sent Brazil to a 20 lead over Ecua dor in the South American Davis Cup tennis competition today by winning the first two singles.

title: Mrs. Weiner Has a Son
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., April 17Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Weiner of Sands Point be came the parents of a son on March 27. The child, named James Rieur, was born in the North Shore Hospital in Man hasset. His father is a partner in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts.

title: The World
description: SAIGONIt was a very hard decision, said a South Viet namese army captain in Pleiku last week. The North Viet namese got into the Montagnard villages, and were firing at heli copters. We used a psywar mis sion [an airplane with a loud speaker] to call the Monta gnards and try to get them out of the enemy locations but the North Vietnamese did not let the villagers out. We set a time for them to leave, and then we would bomb. After noon on the final day we bombed, many villages. After, we found many bodies. Some of the Monta gnards had stayed in their vil lages and there were too many enemy.

title: GREECE CURBS ROLE OF MILITARY COURTS
description: ATHENS, April 17 (Reuters) The Greek Government today eased martiallaw regulations, in force here since the army seized power four years ago, by restricting the jurisdiction of military tribunals to try certain civilian offenders.

title: U.S. Aides Express Interest
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 United States officials ex pressed interest in reports from China that the Peking Govern ment might be willing to dis cuss the establishment of diplo matic relations with the United States.

title: National Notes
description: Winds up to 60 miles an hour howled across West Texas and part of Oklahoma last week, fill ing the air with dust. Residents of Lubbock, Tex., couldn't see across the street; there was a 20car crash on an interstate highway near Amarillo. But it was the farmers who felt the brunt of what the United States Weather Service called one of the worst droughts in the na tion's history. In parts of Texas, less than an inch of rain has fallen in the past seven months.

title: Former Criminals Are Teachers In Criminology Course in Jersey
description: MONTCLAIR, N. law courses are given by lawyers and chemistry is taught by chemists why should not crim inology be taught by criminals, or rather, by former criminals?

title: Pastor Pays Off Easter Bet
description: CINCINNATI, April 17 (UPI) The Rev. Ted Moore, pastor of the Church of Christ in Big Prairie, Ohio, has paid off a bet he made with his congrega tion. He had said he would bicycle the 200 miles from his church to Cincinnati if more than 500 persons attended Easter Sunday services. A total of 540 attended. Mr. Moore started his journey Sunday and completed it Wednesday.

title: Gadfly's Sting Is $1Million
description: Rodney B. Shields was 16 years old when he attended his first annual meetinga session of the Flintkote Com pany in 1958.

title: Music
description: THE Metropolitan Opera leaves town on its an nual spring tour tomor row. For my sons, Adam, 11, and Lawrence, 8, this is a bit of a blowper haps more financial than es theticthat only the resump tion of Little League practice may assuage. But for myself arid my wife, who have been dutifully making the trek between our home and the Met for the past eight months, the Met's closing is good news indeedalmost like being told of the repeal of income tax.

title: Outdoor Laboratories Tell It Like It Is
description: APRIL 22, 1971. What will the youth of America contribute for Earth Day this year? According to the U.S. Soil Conservation Service (SCS), the answer is strictly academic because the 1970 event has already jolted Americans into action.

title: CONGRESS TO SPUR BILL ON DURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Democrats in both the House and Senate are organizing drives for early passage of leg islation to reform the automo bile insurance system despite the Nixon Administration's op position to a Federal law at this time.

title: Handsome Shrubs That Are Carefree
description: SOME of the finest plants for low upkeep landscapes can be found among the viburnums. One might almost say that there is a viburnum for every situation.

title: THOUSANDS USE UP JOBLESS BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Thousands of Americans have exhausted their unemployment insurance benefits and the num ber is rapidly increasing as the unemployment situation con tinues to stagnate.

title: AUSTRALIAN ISLE VIRTUAL FIEFDOM
description: LORD HOWE ISLAND, Aus tralia, April 6Towering motels and other urban encroachments on natural beauty are unlikely to intrude on the tranquil green landscapes and unpolluted beaches of Lord Howe Island so long as this South Pacific out post of Australia remains a virtual fiefdom, protected by Australian law, of a few long established local families.

title: CEYLON REPORTS GAIN IN DRIVE ON REBELS
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 17 (AP)  Security forces cleared a former rebel stronghold and reopened five abandoned police stations today despite continu ing insurgent activity, the gov ernment announced.

title: French Name Satellite
description: PARIS, April 17 (Reuters) France's space center today named its new research satel lite Tournesol (sunflower) and said signals showed it was functioning correctly. The satel lite, also called the D2A, was launched Thursday from French Guiana to study the distribu tion of hydrogen in the solar field.

title: Et Al.
description: Mr. Speirs finds the differ ence between the two writers greater than the similarities. Tolstoy sought answers to life's problems, Chekhov revealed them. The language and ap proach are reminiscent of one's favorite college prof. A book to keep beside the works of these masters.

title: Reader's Report
description: The bestkept secret of Lester Goran's latest is what, ex actly, it is all about. There is geographic continuity, it is true: Shirnen Groff, a forgotten novel ist (as well as a prodigious wencher, drunkard, and per sona so non grata he's forbid den to enter the State of Con necticut), experiences a paper back revival and goes in search of an unpublished opus that had been abandoned (in parts) at the homes of several ex wives. If Shimen can ever put this 2,200page major effort to gether again, he and his pub lisher anticipate a milliondol lar blockbuster with the Nobel Prize as a fringe benefit. So? So there ensues a picaresque crosscountry odyssey, with lay overs at Miami, Los Angeles, Taos and Cape Hatteras. In each of these destinations. Shi men exhibits a relish for mis adventure that keeps him in Chaplinesque ferment.

title: Mrs. King Advances
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 17 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King and Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of England coasted to victories today in the semifinals of the $30,000 Caesars Palace tennis tournament.

title: Stamps
description: TWO Canadian pioneers, one in the political field, the other an ex plorer and adventurer, will be honored postally by Canada on May 7. A 6cent stamp will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the death of Louis Joseph Papi neau, a French Canadian po litical reformer; another 6c is for the 200th anniversary of the overland expedition of Samuel Hearne to the Cop permine River and Canada's Arctic coast. The designs of the stamps were created by Jacques Guillon Designers, Inc., Montreal, and the British American Bank Note Company, Ottawa, will print 12 million of each.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: LEVITT TO HIRE 200 TO AUDIT 3 CITIES
description: ALBANY, April 17  At a time when state agencies are under orders to cut staffs and spending, Controler Arthur Levitt will hire as many as 200 more auditors to implement legislation permitting him to audit the finances of New York City, Rochester and Buffalo.

title: U.S. Olympic Team Medals Are Available to the Public for First Time
description: Official team commemora tive medals, issued to honor United States Olympic ath letes, have been made avail able to the public for the first time, the United States Olym pic Committee has announced.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH LEADS BY A STROKE
description: RALEIGH, N.C., April 17 (AP)Kathy Whitworth carded a par 72 to maintain a one stroke lead today after two rounds of the $20,000 Raleigh Golf Classic.

title: Et Al.
description: Shortlined poems that toss together mordant witticisms on the Terrible State of Our Soci ety; also some rather good Viet nam columns Eastlake wrote for The Nation. Eastlake has been and should be better.

title: Study Concludes Yale Trustees Perpetuate Their Own Stratum
description: The Yale University Study Commission on Governance has criticized the trustees of the Yale Corporation as a selfper petuating group based on class and drawn from a narrow stratum of society.

title: Et Al.
description: An unsuccessful but worthy candidate for the recent N.B.A. translation award. Feydeau's farces  two were transported here lately  are a staple of the Comedie Francaise. They are concerned with the absurd ities of everyday, middleclass life, somewhat in the Iris Mur doch manner but offhand and even slapstick. Getting Fey deau's puns and idiomatic humor across is no light task, but these translations are as light as air.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: GULFSTREAM 2MILE IS WON BY SABMUS
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 17 (AP)  The Horatio Luro trained entry of Sabinus and Northern Monarch finished one two today at Gulfstream in the $25,000 Green Valley Handicap at two miles on the grass longest race of the Florida season.

title: No Resistance Met
description: SAIGON, April 17 (AP)  South Vietnamese troops probed deeper into the Ashau Valley today without meeting any resistance.

title: Giants Win, 5 to 3, As Mays Doubles, Hits 633d Homer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 Willie. Mays, reacting to a nearsellout Bat Day crowd of 32,896, drove in three runs with his fifth homer and a double, scored a run and stole third base today as the San Francisco Giants extended their winning streak to six with 53 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Child for Buttenwiesers
description: BELMONT, Mass., April 17 A daughter was born last Tuesday to Dr. and Mrs. Paul A. Buttenwieser in the Boston Hospital for Women. Mrs. Buttenwieser is the for mer Miss Catherine Frum of Cleveland. Her husband, a child psychiatrist, is the son of Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, investment banker, and Mrs. Buttenwieser of New York. The child, the couple's third, has been named Janet Adele. She is the granddaughter also of Mrs. Philip L. Wright and the late Paul W. Frum.

title: Nixon Bowls 7 Games, Raises Average to 165
description: WASHINGTON, April 17. (UPI)President Nixon has increased his average bowling score to 165 and has set a new record for himself229.

title: GEORGE S. BECKWITH
description: KEESEVILLE, N.Y., April 17 (AP)George S. Beckwith, pres ident of the Ausable Valley Telephone Company, died today in a hospital at Burlington, Vt., at the age of 76.

title: John Nicholas Collin Is Fiance Of Patricia Alexandre Herrick
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., April 17The engagement of Miss Patricia Alexandre Herrick to John Nicholas Collin, son of Mrs. Michael MilesSharp of Woodbridge, England, and Hugh G. Collin of Dorset, England, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. J. Alexandre Tompkins of Cedarhurst and Walter R. Herrick of West Hartford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N. Y. An August wed ing is planned.

title: Ponti Acquires Play Rights
description: Film rights to the Off Broad way play House of Blue Leaves, by John Guare, have been acquired by the Italian producer Carlo Ponti. Accord ing to the play's representa tives, present plans call for the playwright to adapt it to the screen with the director Mel Shapiro.

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Fordham's Hall of Fame to Add Four Members
description: Hank Borowy, Zev Gra ham, Wellington Mara and the late Ed Kelleher have been named to the Fordham Ath letic Hall of Fame for 1971. They will be feted at the 37th annual Block F dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel on May 15.

title: Women's Job Study Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) The Labor Department has announced a $75,000 grant for a study on how to place more women in job apprenticeship programs. The grant to the ?? Department of ?? ?? ?? and ?? ?? ?? Monday

title: Arsenal Gains Tie for Lead in Soccer
description: LONDON, April 17 (Reuters) Arsenal appeared today on the verge of winning the Eng ish League First Division cham pionship after Leeds. lost, 21, at home to West Bromwich. Ar senal, which last won the cham pionship in 1953, defeated New castle United, 10, to move into a tie for first place.

title: The European Discovery Of America The Northern Voyages A.D. 5001600. By Samuel Eliot Morison. Illustrated. 712 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.
description: Crammed into cockleshells, scanty crews of splendid seamen changed the world

title: Photography
description: IN 1845 the English art crit is John Ruskin discovered for himself the peculiar power of the camera. He was in Venice sketching old palaces for a projected study of Italian architecture and in his drawings he was having difficulty distinguishing be tween the shadows and the stains on the ancient stones. Then he discovered daguer reotypes of the palaces and wrote about them enthusi astically to his father:  every chip of stone and stain is there, and of course there is no mistake about the pro portions Daguerreo types taken by this vivid sun light are glorious things  anyone who had blundered and stammered as I have done  and then sees the things he has been trying to do  done perfectly and faultlessly in half a minute, won't abuse it afterwards.

title: Alcindor, at 24, Is a Growing Menace
description: Lew Alcindor celebrated his 24th birthday Friday night and the party was on the Los An geles Lakers.

title: PAY DISPUTE IS SEEN AS THREAT TO CAMPS
description: A spokesman for 21 Jewish community centers and Y.M.H.A.'s, and Y.W.H.A.'s warned last week that they would not be able to go ahead with their summer, camp pro grams unless an agreement was reached today with employes that would eliminate the possi bility of labor problems.

title: Foreign Notes
description: It was a big day in Haiti last Wednesday, President Francois Duvalier's 64th birth day. But when it came time for the birthday parade past the Presidential palace, Papa Doc, who has ruled the Caribbean nation with an iron hand since 1957, was not in his accustomed place on the reviewing stand. Instead, flanked by a general and a colonel, there stood the dictator's rotund, 20year  old son and proclaimed heir, Jean Claude. The absence of the elder Duvalier added fuel to re cent reports that he had suf fered a stroke in midMarch and was seriously ill.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Locking In on Vietnam
description: Seventeen years ago, Vice President Richard M. Nixon, speaking before the American Society of Newspaper Editors, sent up his famous trial balloon proposing that if necessary American ground troops be employed in Indochina to prevent a Communist takeover there. Seventeen years to the day and 44,000 American deaths, later, President Richard M. Nixon, speaking before the American Society of Newspaper Editors, made it clear that American troops will not be totally withdrawn from Indochina until one part of that countrynamely, South Vietnamhas developed the capacity to defend [itself] against a Communist takeover. Plus ca change.

title: Service to L.I. by Major Airline, To Start April 26, Stirs Dispute
description: BOHEMIA, L.I., April 17  After more than a decade of fighting for it, the town owned Long Island Mac Arthur Airport here is get ting service from a major airline.

title: TAIWAN FIGHTING ITS BRAIN DRAIN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 17  The Chinese Nationalist Gov ernment, responding to objec tions from academicians, has dropped a program designed to help counter the brain drain to the United States. But it is looking for other ways to in duce more Chinese scholars and scientists to return.

title: Hanoi Assails Nixon Refusal To Set Date for Withdrawal
description: PARIS, April 17 (AP)North Vietnam accused President Nixon today of having ad vanced absurd pretexts for not yielding to the Communist demand that a date be set for total United States withdrawal from South Vietnam.

title: The Time Is Ripe for China to Shift Outward Again
description: Historians will conclude that our new contact with Peking is less surprising than the fact that it has been so long delayed. Since 1950 Washington has officially sent more men to the moon than it has to China, even though China is closer, more populous, and the trip less costly and dangerous. So deep has been the rut of nonrecognition that President Nixon recently made headlines by uttering the two words People's Re public. After these magic words, how ever, a boy from Santa Monica with shoulderlength hair and purple bell bottom trousers suddenly finds himself in Peking asking the fabulous Chou En lai, What do you think of hippies?

title: Soviet Plans Airbus Within Next 5 Years
description: MOSCOW, April 17 (AP) The Soviet Union will de velop a 300passenger airbus within the next five years, Tass, the Soviet press agen cy, reported today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Oyster Bay Still Retains the Patina of the Days of T.R.
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 17Across the Long Island Railroad tracks and hard by a cluster of huge cylindrical fuel storage tanks here lies an official memorial to Theodore Roosevelt. It is a watch pocketsize park, containing one wooden picnic table and a couple of benches with slats missing.

title: Expos, Red Sox to Play
description: MONTREAL, April 17 (Ca nadian Press)The Montreal Expos will play the Boston Red Sox in an exhibition game in Boston, May 13. Proceeds will go to the Jimmy Fund for chil dren's cancer research.

title: EVERGLADES FIRES POSE HEALTH PERIL
description: MIAMI, April 17 (AP)Ex hausted fire fighters contained a 50,000acre blaze in the Ever glades west of Miami today, but smoke that had blanketed the heavily populated southeast coastal cities for days became a hazard to health.

title: COSMOS WIN, 21, IN LEAGUE DEBUT
description: ST. LOUIS, April 17The New York Cosmos opened their first season in the North Ameri can Soccer League in most suc cessful fashion tonight, defeat ing the St. Louis Stars, 21 before 3,701 fans at Busch Me morial Stadium.

title: About Motor Sports
description: A couple of years ago Paul Newman starred in a featurelength movie, Win ning. It was a good picture. Now Newman appears as the hostnarrator in a onehour television special entitled Once Upon a Wheel. He should have quit when he was winning. Once Upona Wheel, to be shown from 9 to 10 o'clock tonight over the ABC Television Net work (in New York, Channel 7), is a pre tentious jumble, a travesty on auto racing and a carica ture of filmmaking. The show is all the more dis appointing because it follows by only two weeks The Hard thargers, a perceptive and sensitive depiction of the Southern stock car circuit.

title: Would you believe croquettes?
description: CHICKEN CROQUETTES

title: Water Company Seeks Rate Rise In Queens, Nassau
description: The state's Public Service Commission, in testimony last week on a 10.9 per cent rate increase sought by the Ja maica Water Supply Company, heard the concern's president say the increase was needed because there is a constant attrition in our return and it is impossible to carry on busi ness that way for long.

title: For Young Readers
description: Someone tried to kill me, Cathy gasps into the telephone, but the moment she utters the words she knows she should not have taken her friends' dare to just dial a number and speak that line. Two peo ple die in an auto crash as a result of that prankthinking the voice is their daughter's. These are the parents of Mary Ann Connolly, a girl of whom Cathy is only dimly aware. Only Cathy and her friends know the truth about the hoax telephone call, and they band together in a vow of silence. In the weeks that follow, wher ever Cathy goes, Mary Ann is therea haunting, forlorn pres ence. Driven by her own guilt, Cathy becomes friendly with Mary Ann, knowing the risk of discovery but seemingly powerless to resist. With each meeting between the two girls, and despite the warnings of the conspirators in silence, Cathy's confession comes ever closer.

title: Newark:
description: NEWARK  If this strike comes out badly, Jesse Jacob, president of the Board of Edu cation, told newsmen last week, whites are going to say that Mayor Gibson is just a stupid nigger and not see him as a po litically naive man.

title: Abby Jean Pirnie Will Be Married
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., April 17Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Pirnie have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Abby Jean Pirnie, to Abbot Bennett Lipsky Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Lipsky of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

title: Felling Sycamores to Make Way for Sewer Fought in Forest Hills
description: In the middleclass Queens bastion of Forest Hills, a group of homeowners are fighting to keep the trees on their streets from being cut down.

title: Television
description: author of Hollywood in the Forties

title: BATYA ZAMIR DANCES OFFERED AT CROSBY
description: Among the physical people, those to whom motor energy is all and grace a fortuitous hap pening, choreographer Batya Zamir has emerged as a talent ed designer of movement prob lems. Her work is less choreog raphy than highly charged gamesmanship in which success and at times it seems survival rests on the ability to work within rules a little more adroitly than another. She and her group presented a program of seven works Friday evening at the Crosby Street Project, 61 Crosby Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Murderer of Industrialist Reported Killed in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17  Army authorities announced to day the killing of one of the five terrorists who machinegunned a DanishBrazilian business lead er to death on a So Paulo street two days ago.

title: Columnar Trees Stand Straight and Tall
description: With smaller plant ing spaces available in gardens and along city streets, there is an increasing need for nar row trees. They become ex tremely important for tall screens to shield out some undesired view. Fortunately, there are many narrow trees available, and more nursery men are beginning to grow them. At least 60 different kinds are growing in the Arnold Arboretum in Boston.

title: Restoration of Old Boathouse In Prospect Park Has Begun
description: A 66yearold boathouse that was once a center for boating, din ing and strolling and that had been vandalized in recent years is coming to life again in Brooklyn's 526acre Prospect Park.

title: About Pro Football
description: The pro football team with the most difficult schedule in the coming season is one that can ill afford the chal lenge, the Philadelphia Eagles. Furthermore the schedule dis tinctly favors seven of the eight teams that qualified for the National Football League playoffs last season, the exception being Baltimore. The Colts have inherited the same set of op ponents the Jets had last season, the foes out side the Eastern Division of the American Conference be ing Cleveland, the Giants, Minnesota, Pittsburgh, Los Angeles and Oakland.

title: Tufts Medical Post Filled
description: MEDFORD, Mass., April 17 (AP)Dr. William B. Schwartz was named Endicott Professor and chairman of the depart ment of medicine at Tufts Uni versity School of Medicine to day. Dr. Schwartz, a leading authority on kidney diseases, was also named physician in chief at the New England Medi cal Center Hospitals. He suc ceeds Dr. Samuel H. Proger, who is retiring from both posi tions.

title: Orthodox Church Celebrating Easter Under Julian Calendar
description: Orthodox churchgoers are celebrating Easter today, one week after their fellow Chris tians in the Protestant and Ro man Catholic communions ob served the festival of the Resurrection.

title: $3.6Million Grants For Crime Drive Awarded to City
description: ALBANY, April 17  Federal grants for crime control pro grams totaling $6.8million were awarded today to 20 cities and counties throughout the state, with more than half going to New York City.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 17  In the capital these days, nothing fundamen tal has changed, but everybody senses that change is coming. The problems, the headlines, the arguments and the cast of characters are all the same, but the deeper tendencies or trends of events are a little different.

title: Rum Customer Triumphs in Bye Bye Byrd Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 17 The notsosilent majority among the 31,305 harness rac ing buffs at Roosevelt Raceway tonight backed the Laverne HanoverRum Customer entry in the $25,000 Bye Bye Byrd Pace.

title: CASH BIND IS FELT BY LOS ANGELES
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17  Los Angeles, which has avoided the fiscal problems plaguing most big American municipali ties, is experiencing a severe cash bind.

title: Jane Flues, Graduate Student, Engaged to Matthew Sirnchak
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Mr. and Mrs. A. Gilmore Flues have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jane Sidney Flues, to Matthew Stephen Simchak. He is the son of Mrs. Mac Leod Simchak and Matthew Szymczak.

title: BOWIE STAKE WON BY COLD COMFORT
description: BOWIE, Md., April 17 (AP) Cold Comfort won the $59,100 Barbara Fritchie Handicap, the closingday feature at Bowie to day. Office Queen, last year's champion 3yearold filly, fin ished sixth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: MISS BARKER SINGS AMELIA IN BALLO
description: If Joyce Barker's performance as Amelia in Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera began poorly Fri day night, it got progressively better and ended well.

title: Music
description: DON'T talk to Gina Bachauer about de clining audiences and enthusiasm for con cert music in the United States. She will tell you there is no such thing. The Greek born pianist, who will give a recital at Philharmonic Hall on April 28, is celebrating 20 years of annual tours of this country, and she had her say recently about what she has observed here.

title: Rightists and Leftists Clash In Milan and 23 Are Injured
description: MILAN, Italy, April 17 (UPI) Rightists and leftists battled each other and the police today in Milan, and at least 23 per sons were reported injured.

title: 2 IN OMAHA GUILTY IN POLICE SLAYING
description: OMAHA, April 17  Two members of the National Com mittee to Combat Fascism were found guilty today of the bobbytrap killing of a police man in Omaha last Aug. 17.

title: Searching for culprits to blame a bad war on
description: Two of the men who brought us the war on television think they know why the United States got stuck in Vietnam. Marvin Kalb of C.B.S. and Elie Abel, who used to work for N.B.C., say that four and a half of our last six Presidents (F.D.R. is the full, Nixon the hedging half exception) often appeared to be out of touch with the real world when they made East Asia policy. They were unwitting dupes, of too many Calvinist forebears, Pearl Buck nov els and Charlie Chan films. For Kalb and Abel would have us be lieve the inexorable progression from Yankee Clipper to Yangtse gun boat to helicopter gunship was not an aberration, but rather the con tinuous expression of a simple minded missionary zeal to make Asia safe for Americans.

title: A NEW INCURSION IN LAOS POSSIBLE, ABRAMS INDICATES
description: HUE, South Vietnam, April 17Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States military com mander in Vietnam, said here today that a new South Viet namese incursion into Laos from the Ashau Valley, 25 miles west of Hue, could not be ruled out.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: From 75 that lay on the bench
description: Poems, so we have been taught, are never finishedonly abandoned; the publication of a poem signifies not that no more ought to have been done to it, merely that no more could be done. For a poet to permit the publication of a volume of his work in his own lifetime is excusable only in terms of the last infirmity of noble mind: he should really, for getting arrogant Milton, be content with the circulation of drafts, and only on his deathbed give a wry blessing to the launching of an im perfect oeuvre. He should be like Cavafy:

title: Et Al.
description: The popular author of Mus ic for the Millions, The Life and Death of Tin Pan Alley and 50 other books stumbles into tomorrow's music, some of which was written 40 to 70 years ago. Unlucky title for a superficial book. Not much about music, just biographical facts from the clipping file.

title: Television
description: IN the fracas over The Selling of the Pentagon, there is one curious fact that tends to get lost in the giant shuffle. As television journalism, the Co lumbia Broadcasting System news documentary was undoubtedly strong television. But, in the overall context of the mass media, it was relatively tame journalism.

title: Et Al.
description: An academic hardhat on the generation gap. K. Ross Toole, professor of history at Montana State, published a letter decry ing student revolutionaries. It was reprinted in U.S. News & World Report and The Reader's Digest, and brought 20,000 re plies from readers. This volume is an expansion of his original statement  an attempt to set bounds on academic free dom, dissent and such mat ters, while lambasting the no tion of relevance. The tone Is calm and commonsensical., tailored for Middle America. The problems have already been forked over by Mr. Toole's betters.

title: Yugoslavs, Although Classless, Show Taste for Good Manners
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17A new column on social and business etiquette written by a distinguished Yugoslav diplomat is becoming a circu lation builder for a Belgrade newspaper and a reminder that manners matter even in a the oretically classless society.

title: Bowker Calls His Move Irresistible as Search for Successor Begins
description: The search for a successor to Dr. Albert H. Bowker as chancellor of the City Univer sity began yesterday while Dr. Bowker called his move to the University of California at Berkeley irresistible.

title: Cards Beat Padres, 40
description: SAN DIEGO, April 17 (AP) Steve Carlton pitched a four hitter tonight and Joe Hague hit a tworun homer as the St. Louis Cardinals handed the San Diego Padres their fourth straight setback, 40.

title: Paris Trek
description: PARISA horde of Amer ican buyers, disenchanted with Seventh Avenue's inabil ity to divine what will be ac cepted in fashion, has de scended on the French capi tal this weekend. They are here for the fallwinter show ings of the French readyto wear industry, France's own version of Seventh Avenue.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The unadjusted February jobless rate in Minnesota was 6.1 per cent, or 98,800 out of a work force of 1,633,000. This compares with an un adjusted 6.5 per cent rate, or 85,200 out of a work forceof 1,306,000 in February, 1960.

title: Progress in Nuclear Control
description: A long step toward a worldwide surveillance system to deter proliferation of nuclear weapons has now been taken by the adoption of international guidelines for this purpose.

title: Platt Cup Regatta Is Won
description: ITHACA, N.Y., April 17The undefeated Princeton light weight crew maintained a steady 34 stroke on the Ithaca Flood Control Channel today, to edge shells from Cornell and Rutgers and capture the Platt Cup for the second straight year.

title: 100SHIP U.N.FLEET IN HUNT FOR FOOD
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17In the search for more food sources for developing countries the Food and Agri culture Organization of the United Nations has under taken fishing operations all over the world. It now employs nearly 100 vessels of different sizes, up to the 145foot ship Chindalle, operating from Pu san, South Korea.

title: The Czars Made Leningrad the No. 1 Soviet City
description: LENINGRADIt is very hard to keep up with the Czars when sightsee ing. Sergei, a husky young man with black hair and blue eyes, made the announcement gravely as we stood in the brown, timeworn lobby of the Europa Hotel, off Nevsky Prospekt, Leningrad's main avenue. He was my guide, just this minute assigned by In tourist to show me the city; we were discussing where to begin.

title: T.V.A. Gets New Controller
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 17 (AP)Kenneth D. Hatcher, as sistant controller of the Tennes see Valley Authority since 1961, has been promoted to control ler. He succeeds Gifford C. Cruze, who is retiring after 37 years of service.

title: APOWER CRITICS OPPOSE L.I. PLANT
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L. I., April 17Two of the country's most severe critics of nuclear power testified here this week against the construc tion of Long Island's first nu clear power plant at Shoreham on the North Shore.

title: Spirit of Cooperation Found Among Ecology Units
description: To Nancy Mathews there is a family feeling of co operation among the many environmental groups that have sprung up with the growing interest in ecology.

title: A FRENCH PROGRAM IS SUNG BY ALLARD
description: The program that Maurice Allard presented in Tully Hall on Thursday night was one to anticipatea choice set of works by Lully, Debussy, Pou lenc and Ravel and French folk songs arranged by Canteloube. The baritone, who teaches at the University of California in Irvine, was obviously dedicated to the French song literature, and it showed in his attractive, knowledgeable performances.

title: GREAT MYSTERY WINS STAKE AT KEENELAND
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 17 (AP)B. A. Dario's Great Mys tery defeated favored True North today in the $22,400 Ben Ali Handicap.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe nation's economy is looking better. But it remains a major problem with the consumer, for many job seek ersand for the White House.

title: The barn mystique; Barn mystique
description: To many naturestarved urbanites, the idea of converting a barn has a particular mystique. For a full year, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Klein combed nearby rural areas until they found their 150yearold dairy barn. It was part of a complex of farm buildings set on gently rolling land hedged. by stone fencesand it was about an hour's drive from the city. One floor had been converted for living about 70 years ago. Renovating was a thrilling experience, says Mrs. Klein. We lived in the barn and learned to love it. We knew exactly what to change and where to respect the old lines. The lofty living room was virtually unaltered, the kitchen was expcmded and the loft became the master bedroom. A second old barn was bought to provide suitably old and weathered materials for the renovation. We used every inch, reports Ellie Klein. The siding provided fronts for the kitchen cabinets (below), and the old floor boards were used to make the dropleaf dining table (at bottom). An antique hunt turned up the four Victorian farmhouse chairs in the dining room. In the kitchen, unfinished ladderbacks were antiqued a warm yellow.

title: Miss Barbara Ann Smith Is Affianced
