description: LADUE, Mo., April 17The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Smith to James Lowell Shannon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shannon of Riegles ville, Pa., has been announced by the future bride's. parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. L. Smith of Ladue.

title: Tense economies and strong silences
description: In the four years since the publi cation of Battle Report, Harvey Sha piro's poetry has undergone a change. The strengths of the earlier book have been combined to create a more unified and, ultimately, a more mov ing voice. The lapses into iambic reg ularity, the echo of Yeatsian rhetoric are gone. Their place has been taken by simply spoken rhythms, expressing a precise appetite for situations and emotions. The swiftness of the lan guage in This World recalls, at times, William Carlos Williams, to whom one of the finest poems in the book is dedicated; but it is a recall which does not in the least subtract from the personal fierceness and the originality of the poems.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Congratulations!

title: Suzanne Merrill Rae Is Married
description: WEST NEWTON, Mass., April 17Miss Suzanne Mer rill Rae, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Garfield Rae Jr. of Boston and Nantucket, was married here this after noon to Charles Volichardt Moore. He is the son of Mrs. Robert A. Powers of Green wich, Conn., and the late James L. Moore of Lookout Mountain, Tenn.

title: Optimism on Strike Is Voiced in Newark
description: The chief mediator in the 11 weekold Newark teachers' strike said yesterday that he was definitely optimistic about a settlement today on the basis of new compromise terms proposed by Mayor Ken neth A. Gibson.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The word coordinate has a long history in mathematics, where it refers mainly to sets of numbers in geome try. But on Seventh Avenue coordinates are known as the components of ensembles of garments that harmonize suf ficiently to be worn together.

title: Et Al.
description: An autobiography, with ob servations on JapaneseAmeri canness, by a young, second generation JapaneseAmerican. Okimoto was born in 1942 in an internment camp. In grade school he suffered the taunts of schoolmates at Princeton and Harvard subtler forms of condescension. His reaction has been an increased militancy and a desire to understand his Ja panese roots. In many ways Okimoto is typical of his sub culture: dutiful son, hardwork ing, successoriented, middle class, yet critical of his heritage and the America that forced it upon him. The voice is sound and authentic.

title: A Troubled Commissioner
description: He was neither a baseball man nor a prominent figure in Washington. He had not, in fact, played baseball since Madison High School in Indiana, but in November, 1965, officials of the national pastime picked him for its highest postcommissioner of baseball.

title: GOOD BEHAVING CAPTURES $112,200 WOOD MEMORIAL;
description: Good Behaving won the $112,200 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, and man aged to cloud the 3yearold sit uation.

title: Arverne Mirrors Renewal Woe
description: Along more than 50 blocks of bleak beachfront in the Arverne section of Queens, the decaying remains of a oncebustling resort com munity stands as a silent testimony to the delays and frustrations of urban re newal.

title: City Names First Woman Golf Pro
description: A 53yearold Brooklyn grandmother, Mrs. Helen Gilligan Finn, has scored a golfing first. After more than 80 years of municipal golf in New York City, she is the first women to become an in structor at a public course.

title: MINORITIES SEEK OAKLAND POWER
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 17 A coalition similar to the one that swept the Berkeley city elections two weeks ago is con tending for power here in mu nicipal elections Tuesday.

title: Siffert Sets Track Record In Le Mans Spring Trials
description: LE MANS, France, April 17 (UPI)Jo Siffert of Switzer land broke the Le Mans track record in posting the fastest time during the first day of annual spring trials for the Le Mans 24hour sports car race.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Unemployment figures are now about 6 per cent na tionally. Analysis of the over all picture has focused at tention on the plight of aerospace, electronics and, to some extent, executivelevel workers who have experi enced layoffs in the current economic slump.

title: SQUIRES TRIUMPH, TIE SERIES AT 11
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 17 (AP) The Virginia Squires trounced the Kentucky Colonels, 142122, tonight to square their Ameri can Basketball Association Eastern Division final series at a victory each.

title: DATE CODE BACKED BY MEAT PACKERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)Most processed meats, produced by major packers will soon carry a simplified new date code. It will tell con sumers when the meats were packaged or when they should be taken off sale, a meat indus stry spokesman reported.

title: Mrs. Burden was very grateful for the news
description: It never occurred to any of us, growing up Jewish in Passaic, NJ., in the forties, that there could be such a thing as a Jewish aristocracy. There were plenty of Jews with money in our town and a number in positions of power. But let one of them put on airs (like switching from the schul to the Temple) and someone like my Aunt Katie was lamely to remind him that his grand father was a horse thief in Shnip itzik.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Wyoming, where state em ployment offices do on oc casion list cowboys under helpwanted advisories, had an unemployment rate for February of 6.2 per cent. This compared with a 6.6 per cent rate for the same month in 1957.

title: Child to Mrs. McKnight
description: A daughter was born on March 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rhinelander McKnight of New York in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. McKnight is the former Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Lord. The child has been named Sarah Lord.

title: LAWMAKER URGES RENT RISE LIMIT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 17 Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer proposed this week that all apartment house owners who are members of the Long Island Builders Institute volunteer to limit rent increases on their fa cilities.

title: KEATING REPORT STIRS PAKISTANIS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 17 The Pakistan radio said to night that Pakistani troops yes terday evening secured Chua danga, the town that Indian propagandists had been claim ing as the seat of the so called Bangla Desh Government.

title: CUBAN REFUGEES MARK'61 INVASION
description: MIAMI, April 17Several hundred Cuban exiles gathered here today to dedicate a modest monument on the 10th anni versary of the illfated Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba.

title: Ethics of Methadone Use Questioned
description: On the afternoons of March 31 and April 7, a man posing as a heroin addict showed up at the West Side Medical Cen ter and, with a minimum of questioning, walked away with a total of 560 milligrams of methadone.

description: KOHALA, Hawaii, April 16 Neither the bright sun nor the sweet scent of crushed cane can dispel the air of gloom that settled on this place March 1.

title: Pennsylvania Destroys Guns

description: LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., April 17For 10 years now, the public has had only limited access to almost 1,500 acres of woodlands, upland mea dows, salt marshes, ponds, baronial halls and more than a mile of undeveloped shore along Long Island Sound.

description: The English, department at City College will begin a mas ter's program in creative writ ing this fall with the addition of three visiting authors to its faculty.

title: Robin Stein Engaged
description: Miss Robin Ellen Stein's engagement to Steven Gene Miller has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Stein of New York. The future bride attends Har cum Junior College in Bryn Mawr, Pa. Her father is a vice president of the Shapiro Brothers Factors division of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Her fianc, son of Mrs. Edith Miller of Elmont, L. I., is a senior at Temple University.

title: Lagos Sets Stiff Arms Curb
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 17 (Agency FrancePresse)Own ers of arms and amunition in Nigeria's three warravaged eastern states face $1,400 fines and two years' imprisonment under an order issued here to day. The order was reportedly aimed at suppressing the mounting wave of armed rob beries in areas affected by the civil war that ended one year ago.

title: Georgetown's Crew Wins
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 17 (AP)Georgetown University's varsity heavyweight crew de feated Syracuse by less than two feet today in a 2,000meter race on Onondaga Lake. The University of Massachusetts finished third. Georgetown's winning time was 6 minutes 21.9 seconds. Syracuse was timed in 6:22.3 and UMass in 6:27.2.

title: 3 Who Studied Magnetism Win Vetlesen Prize for Geophysics
description: Three scientists whose study of remnant magnetism in rocks helped resolve a variety of fun damental problems relating to the earth and past movements of its continents received the Vetlesen Prize last night.

title: Gas: Best of Both Worlds? Bill Could Please Industry, Consumer
description: Who would expect a Stat en Island Congressman to come up with a bill that seems to satisfy most seg ments of the natural gas industry and yet improves the supply of natural gas for consumers?

title: Many Colleges Find Admission Requests Down for the Year
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)  State universities and land grant colleges are getting a record number of freshman application for next fall, but inflation and student, unrest have produced a sharp increase in the number of those colleges reporting a drop in admissions requests.

title: Advances in Transmitting News To Be Shown at Press Meetings
description: Major new techniques for dramatically speeding news will be displayed by The Associated Press and United Press Inter national during press meetings starting here tomorrow.

title: Mansfield Now Backs Inquiry Into F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 Sentiment for an inquiry into the activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was building tonight among Demo cratic members of a subcom mittee that has been investi gating Government surveillance of private citizens.

title: Crum, U.C.L.A. Aide, Named Louisville Basketball Coach
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17 (UPI)Denny Crum, who helped John Wooden mold National championship basketball teams at University of California, Los Angeles, was named today as head basketball coach at the University of Louisville.

title: Paul Moore Marries Anne Emelia Gray
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., April 17  In Grace Episcopal Church here today Miss Anne Emelia Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nomer Gray, was married to Paul Winfield Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben T. Moore of New York and Cream Ridge. The Rev. Thomas Foster performed the ceremony.

title: A Man in Pursuit of Laughter
description: MOST movies are about lives that achieve at least one moment of splendor, when some body succeeds, perhaps only briefly, in breaking free of a preset pattern to act with an exalted purpose that he prob ably doesn't even understand. The act can be anything from the making of the su preme sacrifice to the de livery of a Bronx cheer, but whatever it is, you can bet that it's the principal reason the movie was made. Even the dim, dumb heroine of Barbara Loden's Wanda achieves something akin to splendor when she stops vomiting long enough to as sist in one of the saddest, smallest, most perfectly doomed bank robberies ever planned.

title: Goodies For the Gourmet To Grow
description: THERE are ample reasons why more people are turning to vegetable gardening every year. Astronomi cal prices is one compelling rea son; the great concentration of danger ous insecticides used on commercial crops is another; and the inferior, un healthy quality of much commercially grown produce is perhaps the most im portant.

title: Reader's Report
description: For some reason which I have not been able to discover, two sets of reminiscences run paral lel here. One recollects the hey day of mad King Ludwig of Bavaria. The other memories are those of Hannah, a woman of 50 living in presentday Lon don, whose Nazi lover aban doned her and their child to the SS.

title: TULANE TAKES LEAD IN KENNEDY REGATTA
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17 (AP)Tulane University, skip pered by the defending cham pion, John Dane, took the lead after three races in the Ken nedy Regatta today in Chesa peake Bay.

title: Persian Gulf Unity Efforts Impaired
description: MANAMA, Bahrain, April 4  A squabble over an island known as the Young Camel has hampered lastditch efforts to form a union of the tiny Arab states here along the Persian Gulf.

title: Reader's Report
description: Yes, you are like the sea, Angele  with your turbulence and your calms, your infinite bounty. How do you say in English, gaspillage?

title: Fans of Traditional Jazz on L.I. Forming Society
description: WEST BABYLON, L.I., April 17The driving passion of the Montfort Fathers to build a church, a school and a convent in Borneo has indirectly led to the founding of the Long Island Traditional Jazz Society.

title: Gloucester: Fading Hulls and Hauls
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.Down for the summa? shouts a Glouces terman above the roaring March snowstorm. A grin is the only reply, but the exchange reminds both men of a Gloucester verity: Wounds from a 350year struggle with the sea have not yet proved fatal to America's first fishing port because warm months here are a remarkable ointment.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: BabySitting Course Set
description: The sixth in a series of courses in baby sitting for high yahool boys and girls will be conducted May 7 and 14 in the meeting room of St. John's Queens Hospital, at 9002 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst. Students wishing to take the course should write for an ap plication to the director of community relations at the hos pital. Registration will close May 1.

title: The World
description: The continental shelf of Asia, running from waters off Burma to the seas between China and Japan, has become the focus of an in tense search for oil. More than 50 companies are drilling, doing geological studies or hold ing concessions. This activity has drawn the attention of some antiwar groups that have charged that the United States is fight ing in South Vietnam to protect oil industry interests. Thus far, most Congressmen appear to consider the charges unsubstantiated. The Saigon Government, however, is interested in attracting the oil industry to the area. On industry's side, preliminary seismic studies of offshore Vietnam have labeled it as geo logically a good risk. Only two countries in the entire area are producing oil in substan tial commercial quantitiesAustralia and In donesia. Indonesia, the center of most of the activity, is now producing about 900,000 bar rels a day, almost entirely from onshore wells, but output is expected to climb to more than a million barrels a day this year, with the bulk of the addition coming from offshore wells. In the waters off Burma, Malaysia, Thailand and Cambodia, the activity is confined to surveys or preliminary drilling. Every Asian nation would like to find oil at home or at least nearby, and this quest has brought Japan, South Korea and Taiwan into con flict over jurisdiction and rights to grant con cessions in certain sections of the East China Sea. Communist China also is interested in oil in the area. United States awareness of this was demonstrated last week when it warned the Gulf Oil Corporation, which has an exploration contract with the Chinese Na tionalists, that it could not protect survey or drilling ships in the disputed areas around the Senkaku Islands.

title: Reader's Report
description: The trains no longer stop at McBee's Station, the old home stead of the McBees of Ashton, Ga. When 64yearold Letitia Graham McBee requires trans portation into town, she goes out on the highway and flags down a bus. Mrs. McBee has come so far down in the world during her 20 years of widow hood, she is almost eyeball to eyeball with encroaching Crack ers, whose housing develop ments abut her propertybut Letitia is as indomitable as some of Faulkner's great ladies, and as disastrously impervious to change.

title: Report of Hot Pants at Papal Audience Stirs Furor
description: ROME, April 17The re ported presence of young women in shorts in an audi ence with Pope Paul VI caused a controversy between the Vati can and a conservative Roman newspaper today.

title: Hatcher Faces a Tough 3Way Fight in Gary's Mayoral Primary
description: GARY, Ind., April 15Rich ard G. Hatcher, the first black man to be elected Mayor of a Northern city, is in a fight for his political life against an other prominent black official and a MexicanAmerican as well as the regular Democratic organization of Lake County.

The junior turned out for spring football practice last week with high hopes that might be realized if he and his teammates live up to the potential on this rather strong Orange team.

title: Tender for Summer
description: SOME of summer's bright est blossoms come from the socalled tender bulbs and corms. They are not winter hardy and are planted as soon as the soil is warm and workable.

title: Angels Top Twins, 43, for 6th in Row;
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 17 (AP)Gerry Moses walloped two home runs and Tony Conig liaro hit one today to lead the California Angels to a 43 vic tory over the Minnesota Twins. It was the Angels' sixth straight triumph.

description: For more than 20 years, Duke Ellington has been opening his programs with the signature tune, Take the A Train. At his concert on Friday night in the Great Performers at Phil harmonic Hall series, however, he began with a signature he used briefly in the 1940s, Things Ain't What They Used to Be.

title: Movies
description: WHAT kind of woman would go on as the very last guest on the David Frost show, where she barely gets to utter a peep, and not let it bother her; would, at the age of 33, take movie roles that make people think she is in her 40's and not let it bother her; would let herself get typecast as a hysterical suburban housewife and not let it bother her; and would play a partially nude scene even though she has one inverted nip pleand not let it bother her? (Well, not much, anyway.)

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 (AP)Dr. Warren E. C. Wack er, an internist on Harvard's faculty of medicine at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Bos ton, will become director of university services and Henry K. Oliver Professor of Hygiene July 1.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 17 Nineteen women and four men, all college graduates and two of them with doctor of Philos ophy degrees, have returned to school to be trained as volun teer counselors in the Family Court of Nassau County.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Apri1 17 The state official who recently saved a forest, a waterfall and a pristine creek from the de struction of strip miners may soon be leaving his job.

title: Nabokov's Russian Games
description: After the Soviet cosmonaut Gher man Titov returned to earth from out er space not so many years ago, he vividly described his overwhelming experience of seeing the enlarged moon pass alarmingly close to his spacecraft. The sight reminded him of Gogol, Titov said. His impressions were frontpage news and his re mark was picked up by newspapers everywhere. One of the San Francisco papers that reported it felt obliged to explain to its readers that Nikolai Gogol was a Russian writer, gave his dates and, apparently exhausting its stock of information, ventured that Gogol was noted for his descrip tions of the rising of the moon.

title: Rangers Win Opener in Overtime, 21
description: CHICAGO, April 18 Again delivering in the clutch, a new habit, the Rangers began their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight the way they had ended the series against the Toronto Maple Leafswith an overtime victory.

title: NATHAN GOODMAN
description: Nathan Goodman, a lawyer Specializing in tax work, died Saturday at his home. He was 73 years old and lived at 229 East 79th Street and also at Bolton Landing on Lake George N. Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his Week in Review article of April 11, Earl Ubell Suggests that we forgo programs to treat alcoholics and rely instead on changing people's at titudes about drinking in order to re duce the incidence of the disease. Even if attitude changes were as easy as Mr. Ubell implies, the fact remains that there are hundreds of thousands of people who require treatment for al coholism now. The healthcare system must respond to this need.

title: The Screen: Coming of Age in the 'Summer of '42':Good Humor Mark of Fine Arts Arrival Its Youthful Principals Grow Up During War
description: Robert Mulligan's "Summer of '42" is a memory movie, written, directed and acted with such uncommon good humor that I don't think you'll be put off by its sweet soft-focus, at least until you start analyzing it afterwards. It is, perhaps, just a little too perfect, a little too symmetrical; not the way things really were, but the way they should have been (and the way they always are in recollections of tea and sympathy):The movie is the memory of what it was like to be 15-year-old Hermie, almost 30 years ago, spending the summer with his family on an island off the New England coast, longing to be a man among women but having to make do with Oscy, who was bigger and thus could beat him up whenever he wanted to, and Benjie, who was younger and dumber, but who had access to an illustrated marriage manual.It was a time of Unguentine, "Mary Noble, Backstage Wife," Bette Davis movies, double-dip ice cream cones (for 12 cents), paddle ball, a distant war and immense frustration. There was the night, for example, when Hermie sat in the back row of the movie house, ecstatically caressing Aggie's upper arm under the wildly mistaken impression that he had somehow managed to grab hold of her breast.Racked with guilts and exploding with mad desires, Hermie conducts himself like Jack the Ripper, a mysterious lodger in his own house and a figure of some eccentricity abroad, especially to Dorothy, a war bride and the "older person" of 22 whom he loves from afar. "You should be careful," he says when she goes shopping without a grocery cart. "You could get a hernia.""Summer of '42," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, is the story of Hermie's coming of sexual age under circumstances that are, I suspect, a good deal more common in novels and screenplays (and in the Hermie-like fantasies of middle-aged writers) than in real life.However, one of the good things about the film, which is based on an original screenplay by Herman Raucher (who later turned it into a novel, in the manner of Erich Segal), is the reticent quality of its romanticism, which is recorded by the camera matter-of-factly, not subjectively indulged or interpreted in the cinematic equivalents to purple prose.Not so strangely, what works in the screenplay fails utterly in the novel, in which Mr. Raucher gives every impression of trying to write up to the form (sand dunes are described as "sulking in the grass," and mist is "fickle," giving way to wind "in spiteful little gushes"). As a novelist, Mr. Raucher has great need of the kind of direction and performances provided by the film.Nostalgia can be rather easily and cheaply obtained in moviesa little fuzzy camerawork, a sad old song on the soundtrack and a tear manufactures itself in the eye. Mr. Mulligan ("To Kill a Mockingbird," "Inside Daisy Clover") knows all the tricks but, with the exception of Michel Legrand's background score, he employs them with discretion in "Summer of '42."He is particularly successful with his young performersGary Grimes as Hermie and Jerry Houser as Oscy, neither of whom betrays the mystery of his youthful status with the perfunctory mannerisms of child actors. They are exuberant and intense and very, very funny. Also fine are Jennifer O'Neill, as the "elderly" Dorothy, a girl of almost magical loveliness and vulnerability, and, in smaller roles, Katherine Allentuck (Maureen Stapleton's daughter) as the besieged little Aggie, and Oliver Conant, as the chicken-hearted Benjie, a guy who grows faint and flees at the prospect of a blind date.Mr. Mulligan shot the film in northern California, in and around Mendocino, where Norman Jewison shot "The Russians Are Coming The Russians Are Coming." Then, as now, I was a little put off by the comparatively mountainous coast, which looks like Cape Cod might have looked before the Ice Age. That's not terribly important, however, in a romantic film whose foreground is mostly accurate, in which sexual panic and fist fights and nose bleeds are treated with the great comic respect they deserve.

title: Citizens Budget Panel Opposes City AdTax Plan
description: The Citizens Budget Com mission yesterday attacked Mayor Lindsay's plan to im pose a 6 per cent tax on ad vertising in media, based on the city audience of the media. The city promptly issued statement defending the tax, which would be paid by the advertiser.

title: HOTA SCORES, 41, IN 2D OVERTIME
description: New York Hota reached the Eastern final of the United States Challenge Cup for the first time by defeating Taunton, (Mass.), 41, in the second over time period yesterday. Five of Hota's players had played for the New York Cosmos Satur day night in St. Louis.

title: STUDENTS CONFER WITH UNION GROUP
description: ST. LOUIS, April 18  The headquarters of the Teamsters Union Joint Council 13 Is right next to the campus of St. Louis University, but yesterday was the first time that students and workers had come together to find out what they had in com mon.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 18The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here.

title: ASHE DOWNS SMITH IN FINAL BY 63, 63
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 18 (UPI)Arthur Ashe had little trouble defeating Stan Smith, 63, 63, in the men's singles final of an open tennis tourna ment today.

title: Tico Taco Huntington Victor
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., April IS  Joan Kieselstein's Tico Taco, ridden by Ken West, cap tured both classes over fences and finished second in the undersaddle test to score 11 points and win the green work ing hunter championship today at the combined Huntington horse show and junior Olym pics.

title: U. S. Banks React To Venezuela Law
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 18The Chase Manhattan and First National City Banks are once again showing their sharp division in thinking about banking in Latin Amer ica. This time it is their sep arate approaches to the prob lem of rising nationalism in Venezuela.

title: AUDREY MAPLE DIES; ACTRESS OF 20'S, 72
description: Audrey Maple, a musical comedy star of the nineteen twenties arid nineteenthirties, died yesterday at her home, 15 West 72d Street, after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived also at Maple Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Israelis Feel Arabs' Plan for Union Could Block Efforts for an Accord
description: JERUSALEM, April 18Is rael's policymakers speculated today about the possibility that Egypt's proposed union with Syria and Libya could block the pending moves toward a nego tiated peace.

title: ORIOLES TRIUMPH OVER YANKS, 116, ROUTING BUNSEN
description: BALTIMORE, April 18The Yankees received rough treat ment here today as the Balti more Orioles shelled four New York pitchers for 15 hits and an 116 victory.

title: Brazil Wins Doubles, Ousts Ecuador in Davis Cup Play
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, April 18 (AP)Brazil won the dou bles from Ecuador today for 30 lead and advanced to the next round in the Davis Cup tennis championship.

title: COMPANIES HEAD FOR BOND MARKET
description: American corporations con tinue to head doggedly to the bond market to borrow, and the expected cutback in fi nancing activity so far shows no signs of developing.

title: Mine Sighted in Channel
description: DOVER, England, April 18 (AP)Ships were warned to day to beware of a World War II mine floating in a shipping lane in the English Channel. The mine was first sighted and reported by a Soviet ship a mile from Les Casquets near the Channel Islands.

title: Vietnamese Discuss Fall Voting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18As South Vietnam approaches its presidential election campaign, the voters whose ballot is compulsory voice a wide range of emo tions, often tinged by deep weariness with war.

title: GILBERT PERKINS OF CHEMICAL BANK
description: Gilbert H. Perkins, who be gan as an office boy and be came vice chairman of the Chemical Bank, died Friday on Mountainside Hospital, Mont clair, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 147 Upper Moun tain Avenue, Montclair.

title: BOMB CLUES SOUGHT IN A JERSEY BLAST
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 18A bomb squad from Fort Monmouth, agents of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation and the local police sought clues today in the rubble left by an earlymorning explosion at the Jewish Center here.

title: China Blames the Soviet For Loss of Fishermen
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 19 (AP)  Communist China charged today that a Soviet ship collided with a Chinese fishing boat in the Gulf of Tonkin on March 31 and that 11 fishermen were lost.

title: Swede Clips Lift Record
description: FALUN, Sweden April 18 (AP)Hans Bettembourg, a Swedish middleheavy weight lifter, set a world record today by pressing 424.6 pounds. Bo Johansson of Sweden held the previous mark of 419.1 pounds.

title: Steel Users Bracing for Price Changes
description: PITTSBURGH, April 18Last week's inflation alert produced no big reaction in the steel markets. Steel users were alert ed to the probability of future price increases sometime ago. By last week, users were well along with programs aimed at hedging against both steel in flation and a possible steel strike Aug. 1.

title: Ontario Hostages Freed
description: KINGSTON, Ontario, April 18 (UPI)Convicts in control of Kingston Penitentiary for the last five days released all five of their hostages today, with out receiving concessions, and ended their rebellion, Solicitor General JeanPierre Goyer said.

title: Called Saulte
description: MOSCOW, Monday April 19 (Reuters)The Soviet Union orbited a scientific space sta tion named Salyut, (Salute) to day, but there were apparently no men aboard.

title: Engineer Weds Laura Brown
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 18Miss Laura Jane Brown and Leo Girard C. Hajenius were married here this after noon in the Reformed Church by the Rev. James Stackpole.

title: For the Families of Policemen, These Are Bewildering Times
description: As little girls, they were taught to respect policemen. Now they are grown up and have a more personal stake in the admonitions of their childhood. They are married to policemen.

title: Billion Each in China and India Forecast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16An Asian population growth that will crowd China and India with more than 1 billion people each in less than 30 years is forecast by latest United Nations calculations. More than half the world's population is expected to be in South and East Asia.

title: McCloskey Asks Halt In Bombing of Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters)  Representative Pauu N. McCloskey of Cali fornia today called on Presi dent Nixon to end what he said appeared to be the deli berate destruction of Laotian villages by calling an immedi ate halt to bombing through out Indochina.

title: Amman Renews Arms Hunt
description: AMMAN, Jordan, April 18 (Reuters)Jordanian troops to day resumed a search for arms in Amman that they began a week ago. Inhabitants were asked to stay indoors until the operation ended.

title: Mari Glynn Married To James M. Nugent
description: Miss Mari Glynn of Elm hurst, Queens, and James M. Nugent of Brooklyn and Long Beach, L. I., were married here yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Connelly.

title: EAST PAKISTANIS CLAIM CONSULATE
description: NEW DELHI, April 18The predominantly East Pakistani staff of Pakistan's diplomatic mission in Calcutta took over the establishment today and transformed it into a mission of the newly proclaimed pro visional government of Bangla Deshthe Bengal Nation.

title: FOSTER OF RUTGERS NAMED UTAH COACH
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 18 (AP)Bob Foster, Rutgers basketball coach, an nounced tonight that he had ac cepted a similar post at Utah.

title: NEW ALLIED DRIVE NOT STARTED YET, U.S. AIDES ASSERT
description: LAVANG, South Vietnam, April 18The joint American and South Vietnamese invasion of the enemyheld Ashau Valley will not get under way until Wednesday at the soonest, ac cording to ranking American military sources here at the operation's forward command post just south of Quangtri.

title: Bridge: American Association Play Sets Mark With 1,200 Tables
description: The spring national cham pionships of the American Bridge Association that ended in Cleveland yesterday were the biggest in the history of the Association, which pro vides primarily for black players. In four days, the number of tables in play was more than 1,200.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: LE MANS, France, April 18 (UPI)Jackie Oliver of Britain broke all the track speed rec ords while driving a 5  liter Porsche 917 today in trials for the 24Hours of Le Mans apto race scheduled next June.

title: China Visit Shows Change of 25 Years
description: CANTON, China, April 18 It would be presumptuous to make any sweeping generali ties about China on the basis of a week's stay. I can only report on what I have seen in Peking, Shanghai, Canton and the areas around them. And I can make an appraisal of the moral, political and intellectual climate.

title: Vasquez and Spencer Meet In 12Round Bout Tonight
description: David Vasquez and Chuck Spencer will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum in a 12round bout billed as being for the North Ameri can bantamweight champion ship.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  The dis tinguished whitehaired gentleman, a Fellow of Trinity College, led the way into the library designed for Trinity by Christopher Wren. Then he apolo gized for having to rush off.

title: Dr. Sussman Weds Patricia Benedikt
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 18 Miss Patricia Lyn Benedikt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Stephen Benedikt of Larchmont, was married here today to Dr. Howard Michael Sussman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Sussman of New York. The ceremony was per formed in the White Plains Hotel by Rabbi Morris Gold berg of East Rockaway, L. I.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The most sexually hip of American sports, harness racing, went through its great orgy of selfanalysis in the nineteensixties and came up with one truly sensational hypothesis: The appeal of a night out at the trotters was the illusion that a man and a woman were interacting in a sexually charged atmosphere filled with erotic symbols while actually they were able to go separate ways and avoid confrontation. With this kind of information harness racing should have been able to take over the American recreational conscious, but, unfortunately, the sport itself is too simple and narrow to support such hot and heavy action, and sex was left for baseball, which is so square still merchandises Ladies Days, and basketball and foot ball, which use sex almost accidentally.

title: Jersey Forest Fire Rages Over 10,000 Acres of Pine
description: PARKERTOWN, N. J., April 18A windwhipped forest fire burned out of control over 10,000 acres of sandy pine forest near here today, forcing authorities to close sections of the Garden State Parkway.

title: Banks Forming Unit to Aid F. I. du Pont in Refinancing
description: A syndicate of major banks, led by the Chase Manhattan, is being formed to assist in the re financing of F. I. du Pont, Glore Forgan & Co., a major broker age firm that is emerging from financial difficulties.

title: Newark School Strike Ends As Gibson Plan Is Backed
description: NEWARK, April 18The bit ter 11weekold Newark teach ers' strike ended today when the Board of Education and the Newark Teachers Union voted to accept a contract proposed by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson.

title: Chess: 2 Talented Brothers Meet With Interesting Outcome
description: In the forefront of chess activities among the top ech elon players, the Byrne broth ers, Robert and Donald of New York and Pennsylvania, respectively, have accumu lated many accolades. Robert, a 43yearold grandmaster, re cently led a sixman round robin in the fourth Gold waterMarshall international of 1971. His score was 3 1.

title: St. Thomas Church in Dispute With Hierarchy
description: The rector, wardens and ves try of St. Thomas Church, one of the most influential Episco pal parishes in the nation said yesterday that they had lost confidence in the top manage ment of their denomination and feared an everwidening credi bility gap between national headquarters and the church membership at large.

title: Canadiens Down Bruins,42,0usting Defending Champions from Cup Playoffs
description: BOSTON, April 18This city went into mourning today: the Montreal Canadiens eliminated the beloved Bruins from the Stanley Cup playoffs of the Na tional Hockey League.

title: A Vast Nation for Southwest Pacific
description: KIETA, New GuineaOne of the world's last frontiers, the vast Australian  administered tropical area known as the ter ritory of Papua and New Guinea, is moving swiftly to ward independence despite extraordinary physical and cul tural impediments to nationhood in this wild, hot, malarious, violent and beautiful country.

title: Boston Marathon Skirts the, Female Issue Again
description: BOSTON, April 18  Mrs. Sara Mae Berman is not among the official 1,067 en tries in the 75th annual Bos ton Marathon tomorrow.

title: Auto Kills Commack Youth
description: COMMACK, L. I., April 18 A 13yearold boy was killed by a car here last night as he walked across Jericho Turn pike. The victim was William Curcuruto, of 24 Sarina Drive, Commack. No charges were filed against the driver, iden tified by the police as Law rence Zambryski, 18, of 297 Fifth Street, East Northport.

title: Pennsy Operators Face Proxy Test by New Haven
description: Richard Joyce Smith, the trustee of the New Haven Rail road Companylargely a cor porate shellis considering a proxy fight against manage ment of the Penn Central Com pany, the holding company that owned the Penn Central Trans portation Company before it filed for trusteeship last June.

title: Fires in Florida Are Called A Growing Health Hazard
description: MIAMI, April 18 (AP) Of ficials warned today of increas ing health hazards from ash and smoke pollution caused by smoldering muck and sawgrass fires in droughtparched south ern Florida.

title: A Record Deficit for Payments Is Listed After Lag in Quarter
description: The United States balance of payments showed further de terioration during the first quarter to a record deficit on the officialsettlements basis, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported over the weekend.

title: Advertising:
description: Interpublic, which is very big overseas, will soon be bigger. It has worked out a deal to buy a group of Eng lish ad agencies, an Italian ad agency and a British pub lic relations company.

title: Hawaii Campus Church Bridges the Generation Gap
description: HONOLULU, April 17The music, first heard in the mind of Johann Sebastian Bach, was coaxed front a piano by a young man, bare to the waist, whose long, sunbleached hair almost touched the keys as he leaned down in concentration.

title: Volpe Wins Praise From Mrs. Johnson For Billboard Stand
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)Secretary of Transpor tation John A. Volpe's newest assault in the battle of the billboards still has not toppled a sign, but it has won praise from Mrs. Lyndon B. John son.

title: Soviet Sends Another Space Vehicle Into Orbit
description: MOSCOW, Monday; April 19 UPI)  The Soviet Union aunched an orbital scientific space station today. The an nouncement by the Tass press agency did not say whether the station was manned.

title: GROUP FIGHTS BILL ON ADOPTION CURB
description: The Citizens Committee for Children of New York an nounced its opposition yester day to an adoptionreform bill pending in the Legislature that Would establish a 30day time limit in which a mother could revoke her permission to give up her child for adoption.

title: SAMUEL YAFFE
description: Samuel Yaffe, a manufac turer of foundation garments, died here yesterday at the age of 82. He lived at 27 East 65th Street.

title: Gucci Shops Spread Amid a Family Image
description: Spurning what would ap pear to be a normally high noonhour traffic, the two Gucci leather goods and fashion stores at 689 and 699 Fifth Avenue close their doors every day between 12:30 and 1:30 P.M. Custom ers may knock but they can't get in.

title: CEYLON NAMES PANEL TO RESTORE ORDER
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 18 The Ceylon Government to day named a sevenmember committee to reestablish civil authority in areas affected by two weeks of insurgent activity.

title: BRASS GROUP SHOWS FINE MUSICIANSHIP
description: The American Brass Quintet was presented in a benefit con cert at Town Hall Saturday night by the Greater New York Committee to Aid African Stu dents.

title: Miss Laganella in Sweep
description: RIVER VALE. N. J., April 18  Lisa Laganella of Wyckoff swept the equitation division of the Holiday Farm's horse show today. She won the Maclay Trophy, the Medal Class, the United States Equestrian Team equitation event and the horse manship championship.

title: Mississippi Loyalist Democrats Nominate Evers for Governor
description: JACKSON, Miss., April 18 James Charles Evers became the first Negro candidate for Governor in the 154year his tory of this state today.

title: Crime on the Campus Spreading Fear
description: There is a new kind of crime on the city's college campuses  crime that fre quently goes unreported by its youthful victims but is nonetheless spreading fear through the university com munity.

title: The Electoral Option in Vietnam: I
description: WASHINGTONFor more than two decades American officials have pro vided a vast range of rationales for our involvement in South Vietnam. But only one consistent theme emerges: to permit the South Viet namese freely to choose their govern ment. President Nixon has reiterated this American objective. As recently as April 7 he reminded us that Ameri cans are fighting in Vietnam so that the people there can choose the kind of government they want. If the South Vietnamese are able to ex ercise a free choice, we will have achieved an honorable, albeit costly, victory.

title: Social Work Returns to Local Focus
description: To Thomas M. McKenna, the young, new supervisor for the city's 35 settlement houses, social work in the neighborhoods is just now returning to patterns estab lished a generation ago.

title: AMEX TO AUTOMATE BOND SERVICE IN MAY
description: The American Stock Ex change announced over the weekend the implementation, starting early May, of an auto mated comparison and clear ance service for the more than $3billion in bonds listed on the exchange.

title: KY SEES LONG ROAD TO SELFDEFENSE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 18 (AP)  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that it would take 15 or 20 years before South Vietnam was cap able of defending itself, but he added that the current pace of American troop withdrawals was reasonable.

title: Major Changes Mapped for Fox Operations
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, who earlier this month was ap pointed chief executive offi cer of Twentieth Century Fox in all but name, intends to push a major restructur ing of the giant motion pic ture producer and distributor.

title: Alfonso Narvaez And Miss Harfst Wed in Virginia
description: BRACEY, Va., April 18 Miss Dabney Herndon Harfst was married here today at noon to Alfonso A. Narvaez of New York.

title: Mental Ills Linked to Marijuana
description: Two psychiatrists have found that normal youngsters can suffer serious psychological disturbances following regular smoking of marijuana, without the use of other drugs.

title: Across the Country: Millions May Join in LowKey Environmental Drives
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Improvement of the environ ment, which formally pre empted national attention for only a single day last year, is the focus of a week of ac tivities across the country starting today.

title: Miss Callas Will Teach Two Juilliard Courses
description: Maria Callas will join the Institute of Special Studies at the Juilliard School for two sixweek sessions next year, starting on Oct. 11 and on Feb. 7. According to Peter Mennin, president of Juil liard, the 47yearold soprano, who has not sung in opera or on other stages for more than five years, will direct, advise and counsel qualified performers in the lyric tra dition.

title: 8 Seized on Gun Charges Here After Black Panther Is Slain
description: Eight persons were arrested on gun charges yesterday fol lowing the murder of a West Coast Black Panther official whose bound and bulletriddled body was found in the burned ruins of the party's office in Corona, Queens.

title: Brinkmanship With Japan
description: A major crisis with Japan that could damage American security interests severely is looming as a result of President Nixon's decision to hand back Okinawa by treaty, rather than executive agreement. A treaty would require a twothirds Senate vote; the alternative course would require at most a majority vote of both houses of Congress.

title: 3,500YearOld Wall Painting Shown in Athens
description: ATHENS, April 14Two prehistoric wall paintings, spectacularly restored after lying buried for 3,500 years under volcanic ash on the Aegean island of Thera, have been put on display for the first time at the Athens Archeological Museum.

title: TULANE KEEPS TITLE IN KENNEDY REGATTA
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 18 (AP)Tulane University rallied for a fourthplace finish in the last heat to retain its John Kennedy Regatta championship today.

title: Tokyo Express Nears End
description: BOSTON, April 18 (AP)The aircraft carrier ShangriLa, nicknamed the Tokio Express during World War  when she launched numerous air raids over Japan, will close her career at Boston tomorrow. The aging carrier was to arrive at the South Boston Annex of the Boston Naval Shipyard to be decommissioned.

title: Nader and Law Students Urge Inquiry on Auto Style Changes
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Ralph Nader, a persistent critic of the automobile industry, and 39 members of The Yale Law Journal urged the Federal Trade Commission today to investi gate the industry's practice of changing the styles of cars every year.

title: Dr. Primack Marries Elaine Stein
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 18 Miss Elaine Judy Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shelley Stein of Scarsdale, was married here this after noon to Dr. William A. Prim ack, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Primack of Haver hill, Mass. Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center.

title: From Canton to Peking, a Trip From Provincial to Grandiose
description: PEKING, April 17The tran sition in China from Canton to Peking is from provincial to metropolitan, from ordinary to grandiose.

title: Miss Susan Lebow Wed to Dr. Wexler
description: SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., April 18Miss Susan Lebow, a re search analyst with the New York Life Insurance Com pany, and Dr. David Edward Wexler, a secondyear resi dent in dermatology at Mount Sinai Hospital, were married here this afternoon.

title: Taylor Sets Back Barthes In Final of Sicilian Tennis
description: PALERMO, Sicily, April 18 (UPI)Roger Taylor of Britain fought off a strong rally by Pierre Barthes of France to win the third set today and went on to take the men's singles at the Palermo open tennis tour nament, 63, 46, 76, 62.

title: MISS WHITWORTH TRIUMPHS IN GOLF
description: RALEIGH, N. C., April 18 (UPI)Kathy Whitworth posted a threeunderpar 69 in the final round today to win the Raleigh golf tournament for her first victory of the season.

title: Brazil Reports the Killing Of Leader of Leftist Ring
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 Brazilian security forces an nounced today that they had killed the leader, of five leftist terrorists who had slain Hen ning A. Boilesen, Danish born Brazilian business leader.

title: STEWART TAKES SPAIN GRAND PRIX
description: BARCELONA, Spain, April 18 (UPI)Jackie Stewart of Scot land defended an early lead against a strong challenge from Jackie Ickx of Belgium today and went on to win the Spanish Grand Prix. It was his third straight victory in the event and it gave him the lead in world driver standing.

title: 57 Reporters Are Honored
description: The American Political Sci ence Association announced yesterday it had cited 57 re ?? ?? ?? reporting of public affairs. In this area the ?? reporters, who will ?? plaques, are ?? ?? of Newsday, ?? ?? of The Long ?? ?? ?? Ryan of ?? ?? and David K. Ship ler of The New York Times.

title: Connally Reported Favoring Guarantee By Government of Loans to Lockheed
description: Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. has put forward a plan to ask Congress to authorize guarantees of $250million to $300million in loans to the financially shaky Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, top industry sources said last night.

title: Postal Unions Say Blount Stalls as Deadline Nears
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)With less than 36 hours before the deadline for volun tarily reaching its first con tract agreement with the new United States Postal Service, seven postal unions accused Postmaster General Winton M. Blount today of a public be damned attitude in reaching a settlement.

title: News Analysis
description: Television is not governed primarily by the First Amend ment, Congress, the Federal Communications Commission or the White House; it is ruled first by the power of the dollar. That reality is currently being raised in a period of political tensions and economic uncer tainties in broad casting. Talk in highly responsible corporate quarters pointed over the weekend to the possibility that major sponsors are judging advertising pur chases not only on the basis of ratings and potential sales but also on the political positioning of the networks, something new in the media's everchang ing evolution. The issue, if it materializes, is that discreet support of straight entertain ment shows ultimately can af fect budgets for forthright news and documentaries. Money from the former pay for the latter.

title: TV: After Oscar Debacle, 2 Worthwhile Studies
description: It was the kind of thing from which there is no quick recovery. The Academy Awards special, splattered last Thursday evening over the National Broadcasting Company's network and hap less homes throughout the world, can be dismissed most charitably as an unnatural disaster.

title: Advertising:
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, which is a privately held company and doesn't have to report on its performance, has gone ahead and done it anyway. Do you think their 43 per cent increase in net profits last year had any thing to do with it? And may be they don't want to stay quite so private.

title: Shanghai Revisited: Now a Workaday City
Parish Fund Campaign Halted by Ousted Priest
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 UPI)  An excommunicated Roman Catholic priest called a halt today to a fundraising drive by parishioners in tended to ease his way into a new career.

title: Ethiopian Official Dies
description: JERUSALEM, April 18 (Reut ers)Zewge Mariam, Ethio pia's Deputy Foreign Minister, died in Hadassah Hospital here today after nearly two months of special treatment for an ill ness.

title: REV. C. ALBAN TOWNSEND
description: The Rev. C. Alban Town send, rector of St. Peter's Epi scopal Church in Port Chester, N.Y., from 1961 to 1966, and Protestant chaplain of the Port Chester Police and Fire Depart ments, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 395 Westchester Avenue, Port Chester.

title: 500,000 Hear Park's Rival Charge Korean Corruption
description: SEOUL, South Korean, April 18A crowd estimated at half a million people today heard Kim Dae Jung, the chief opposi tion candidate for president, bitterly attack what he called Government corruption.

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLE EVOKES CONTRASTS
description: One of the most valuable functions of Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society has been to present in tandem a a group of musicians who might not, under ordinary cir cumstances, join talents for an evening of musicmaking. Such was the case in Tully Hall Friday night when Charles Treger (violin), Pierre Fournier (cello) and John Browning (piano) got together for a con cert of contrasting chamber works.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your recent editorial emphasizing that governments everywhere must adopt a strong position toward kid nappers so that political kidnapping might be curbed is a timely call for international action against this rap idly spreading threat to organized social life.

title: Revival of Arab Militancy Seen in Federation Plans
description: CAIRO, April 18A revival of Arab militancy against is rael, after an eightmonth lull during a quest for a political accommodation, seems to be foreshadowed by the an nouncement last night that Egypt would join the hard line countries of Libya and Syria in a union to bear the name the Federation of Arab Republics.

title: I. J. Markin to Be Acquired
description: An agreement in principle has been reached for the acqui sition of I.J. Markin & Co., a Chicago mortgage banking firm, by the First Chicago Corpora tion.

title: F.B.I. Back to Normal, Catching Suspects and Keeping Mum
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  It's business as usual, no prob lems at all. We're just going about normal tasks.

title: Mets Win, 52, Then Lose, 21
description: The New York Mets and Pitts burgh Pirates divided a wind swept doubleheader before 51, 905 persons in Shea Stadium yesterday and broke off their first encounter of the year on even terms after four games.

title: BOMB PLOT BALKED, ISRAELI POLICE SAY
description: TEL AVIV, April 18The po lice said today that they had thwarted an Arab guerrilla plot to explode incendiary bombs throughout Israel during Pass over, when there were many tourists in the country.

title: City's Taxing Power Leads Legislature's Agenda
description: New York City's request for nearly $880million in new tax ing authority leads a long list of unfinished business for the State Legislature, which will resume its session tomorrow after a 12day recess.

title: Personal Finance: TravelCheck Aid
description: You're in London, Paris, Moscow, or maybe, Shelby, Ohio, and you lose your trav elers checks.

title: 10,000 Gather at Rhode Island's Capitol for Start of Dump Nixon Campaign
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 18 More than 10,000 advocates of peace in Indochina gathered today on the steps and lawns of Rhode Island's Capitol for the kickoff of a national Dump Nixon campaign.

title: Triangular Politics and China
description: Presidential press secretary Ronald L. Ziegler told reporters the other day that current Washington efforts to improve ties with Peking are in no way related to our relations with the Soviet Union, but it is doubtful anybody, including Mr. Ziegler, took the statement seriously.

title: Design Engineering Show Opens Today at Coliseum
description: The Design Engineering Show will begin a fourday run today at the New York Coliseum, which is expected to be attend ed by 20,000 design engineers from this country and abroad by the time it closes late Thurs day afternoon.

title: Pierre Luboshutz of DuoPiano Team Dies at 76
description: ROCKPORT, Me., April 18 Pierre Luboshutz, the concert pianist died last night in his home here at the age of 76. He and his wife, Genia Nemenoff, were highly ac claimed as duo pianists.

title: Disorder in Brescia
description: BRESCIA, Italy, April 18 (UPI)  Riot policemen used tear gas and baton charges to break up an unauthorized march by hundreds of young monarchists here today.

title: Jackson Says the Economy, Not War, Is Prime Issue
description: DETROIT, April 18 (UPI) The nation's economynot Vietnamshould be the major issue of Democrats in the 1972 political campaigns, according to Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, who is a possible candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation.

title: Federation Plan Is Lauded by Soviet
description: MOSCOW April 18  The Soviet Union today hailed the proposed new federation of Egypt, Libya and Syria as a major gain toward ultimate victory over the forces of ag gression, Zionism and neo colonialism in the Middle East.

title: School Accord in Newark
description: The end of the elevenweek Newark school strike is victory for reason in a situation that threatened the survival of that troubled city. Primary credit for the settlement belongs to Mayor Gibson, whose refusal surrender to coercion by black militants resulted in compromise formula reasonable enough to win ratifi cation by twothirds of the Board of Education.

title: Wedding to Be Missed
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)Ens. David Eisenhower will not be able to attend the wedding of Tricia Nixon, his sisterinlaw, on June 12. He says he will be on his ship in the Mediterranean.

title: Nuptials in Jersey For Lynn Sosnow
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., April 18Miss Lynn Carol Sos now and Robert Stephen Singer, both of New York, were married here this after noon in Temple Emanuel by Rabbi Andre Ungar.

title: Young Honored at Parley
description: ST. LOUIS, April 18 (UPI) The delegate assembly of the National Association of Social Workers opened four days of hearings and legislative ses sions today with a tribute to the late Whitney M. Young, Jr. Mr. Young had been president of the group since 1969 and was executive director of the National Urban League.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Like My Family There at Union House
description: For Mrs. Julio Sabater the twicedaily walk between her home at 251 East 105th Street and the Union Settle ment House at 237 East 104th around the block is a walk to friends, help, companionship and, in one sense, her free dom.

title: 13 Table Tennis Players ha U.S. After China Visit
description: After a visit to Communist China, most members of the United States table tennis team returned to the United States yesterday.

title: Tel Aviv's New Museum to Be Dedicated Today
description: TEL AVIV, April 18They were scrubbing the marble floors and carefully dusting the gnarled bronze statues by Jacques Lipchitz. A scaf fold obstructed the glass en trance and light fixtures were sprawled along the large plaza leading to the modern new building of the Tel Aviv Museum.

title: WEEK OF PROTESTS ON WAR TO START
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The first contingents of an ex pected total of 1,500 Vietnam war veterans began arriving here this afternoon in prepara tion for a weeklong series of antiwar protests named Oper ation Dewey Canyon Three.

title: Lindsay Joins Marchers in Central Park and Bikers on the Grand Concourse
description: Enthusiasts in the city began Earth Week obser vances yesterday with a mod est scattering of local en vironmental fairs and dis plays, a demonstration in the Bronx in behalf of bikes, and a 16mile walk from the Battery to 110th Street and back for health research.

title: CUTS WILD AFFECT CITY'S POOR AREAS
description: The city's poor and disadvan taged appeared likely to feel sharply the economies ordered by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to meet the crisis caused here by cutbacks in state revenueshar ing.

title: Report on Extremist Armies Stirs Italy
description: ROME, April 18The Gov ernment is investigating the leak of a secret report by its chief representative in Milan on illegal private armies organized by leftist and neoFascist ex tremists.

title: The Biennial Quest for the Gold Thimble
description: A man has walked off with one of the two highest awardsa gold thimblein the latest competition of Amateur Needlework of To day, Inc., the largest and oldest (37 years) amateur needlework society in the United States. Its 17th bien nial exhibit opens Tuesday at The Lighthouse.

title: Bucks Beat Lakers,11698, to Gain N.B.A. Final
description: MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP)  Pulling away in the second half, the explosive Milwaukee Bucks crushed the Los Angeles Lakers, 11698, today and won the National Basketball Asso ciation's Western Division final playoffs, 4 games to 1.

title: Hoover's Removal Urged
description: BALTIMORE, April 18 (UPI)  Representative Parren J. Mitcshell, Democrat of Mary land, called today for the re moval of J. Edgar Hoover as director of the F.B.I., the aboli tion of the House Internal Security Committee and sup port for a domestic intelligence review hoard. He spoke at a meeting of Americans for Dem ocratic Action.

title: Bullets Even Knicks' Series, 33
description: BALTIMORE, April 18  What seemed so amazing only one week ago seemed perfectly natural today as the Baltimore Bullets ripped apart the New York Knicks, 11396, and evened their National Basket bal Association playoff series at three victories each.

title: Detroit Archdiocese to Shut 56 Schools
description: DETROIT, April 18  Fifty six of the 269 Roman Catholic schools of the Detroit archdio cese will be closed at the end of the present term, John Car dinal Dearden, the Archbishop here, announced last night.

title: CITY SHIFTS POLICY ON RENEWAL GOAL
description: The city has adopted a new policy that emphasizes renew Ling whole city blocks in run down areas under its loan pro gram for rehabilitating housing. In the past, the program's low Interest loans went for projects involving only one building on a block.

title: MAYOR ABOLISHES 2,800 JOBS IN MOVE TO SAVE MILLIONS
SIR JOHN WEIR, 91, QUEEN'S PHYSICIAN
description: LONDON, April 18 (Reuters)  Queen Elizabeth's physician, Sir John Weis, who attended the birth of her four children, died during the weekend. He was 91 years old. There are no survivors.

title: Blasts Strike San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., April 18, (AP)Two explosions caused extensive damage but no in juries today at stores owned by United States concerns in San Juan's El Comandante shop ping center, the police reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Anyone who regularly reads the editorial page of The Times must be quite convinced by now that the alli gator status here and elsewhere is our top national priority. How else can one otherwise explain several editorials dedicated to this subject during the past two years? These editorials re flected complete misinformation and, therefore, appear to be an attempt to create confusion in the public mind in the hope of arousing sufficient in dignation to influence legislators.

title: Turn of Screw Finds Star, 13, Spencer Mason
description: When Robert Puleo's boy soprano changed not long ago in midseason, the New York City Opera had an un usual casting problem. One opera singer's indisposition, however, means another's big break, and Spencer Mason took over the important role of Miles in Britten's The Turn of the Screw, which he first sang on April 10 and again yesterday afternoon.

title: Woman in the News
description: Carole Anderson Graves was 32 years old last Tues day. There was no birthday party. Mrs. Graves, who speaks with a gentle voice and is misleadingly undynam ic in appearance, spent the day in the Essex County Cor rectional Center in Caldwell, N. J., where she had been a prisoner since March 4, serving a jail sentence for contempt of court.

title: Oil at Sea
description: While American environmentalists press for tighter regulation of shipping in coastal waters to prevent oil spills arising from collisions and groundings, the British have been agitated by a similar problem arising from tanker accidents in the Dover Strait outside their terri torial seas.

title: Lazar Urges Private Car Ban On Major Crosstown Streets
description: The chairman of the city's new Taxi and Limousine Com mission suggested yesterday that some crosstown streets in midManhattan be reserved for taxis, buses and commercial ve hicles.

title: Ramsey Clark Again Denies Knowledge of Surveillance Planning
description: Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, reiterated yesterday his denial of having any knowledge of government al surveillance of political dis sidents while he served in the Johnson Administration.

title: Books of The Times
description: HISTORY OF THE SECOND WORLD WAR. By B. H. Liddell Hart. 768 pages. Putnam. $12.50.

title: Recipes That Go With Earth Week
description: To celebrate the second annual Earth Week, which begins today, recipes using natural ingredients might be appropriate on the family menu. Such earth foods will be prepared by Bow Ross, a cooking consultant, in the Gourmet Kitchen at Abraham & Straus throughout the week.

title: Hahn Victor in Korean Golf
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 18Hahn ChangSan of South Korea shot a oneunderpar 71 today and won the $15,000 Ko rean open golf championship for a second consecutive year. Hahn finished with a fourday total of 281, four strokes ahead of his closest rivals.

title: S. E. C. WILL MEET WITH STOCK AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Key staff members of all the major securities industry organ izations will meet with the Securities and Exchange Com mission tomorrow in an attempt to decide how close the indus try may be to a recurrence of operational and financial prob lems and what should be done about them.

title: BANKERS MOVING ON EURODOLLARS
description: BASEL, April 18  Central bankers of the major industrial countries looked at ways to in crease their influence over the volatile dollars that were be hind recent disorders on the currency exchanges.

title: Governor Appeals to People
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 18 The Governor of East Paki stan, in a radio address tonight, called on absent East Pakistani troops, policemen and civil. servants to return to duty and warned the populace not to harbor what he called mis creants and fascists in their homes.

title: South Korean Division To Quit South Vietnam
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Mon day, April 19 (AP)  South Korea plans to withdraw an infantry division from South Vietnam before the end of this year, Foreign Minister Choi KyuHah said today. The withdrawal would in volve 13,000 to 15,000 of the 50,000 South Korean troops now in South Vietnam.

title: PETTY IS VICTOR IN 250MILE RACE
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C., April 18 (AP)Richard Petty sped past a faltering Bobby Isaac shortly after the halfway point and breezed to an easy victory today in the Gwyn Staley Memorial 250mile stockcar race.

title: Hail Boston, We Who Run Salute You!
description: Today is a religious holiday in Bos ton. More people will attend its rites than went to church on Easter Sun day. Though the Massachusetts cal endar reads Patriot's Day, the anni versary of Paul Revere's ride is merely a pretext. The real occasion is the seventyfifth running of the Boston Marathon.

title: Russian Jews' Rights Urged at Rallies
description: Jewish leaders yesterday called on the Soviet Union to restore the cultural and re ligious rights of Jews and per mit them to emigrate, particu larly to Israel. Their appeals were emphasized by demon strations at Hunter College and on Long Island.

title: AARON SMITH
description: Aaron Smith, former presi dent of Joseph Smith & Sons, New York manufacturers of men's clothing, died Friday in Sarasota, Fla. He lived at 64 Griffen Avenue, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Bena's Second Chance Pays Off in Saber
description: The greatest surprise since the annual international Mar tini & Rossi fencing competi tion made its debut at the New York Athletic Club 11 years ago was turned in last night by a quiet  mannered, 19  year  old premedical student from France.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: APRIL 19, 1971 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Cranko Reflects on Changes in the Stuttgart Ballet
description: Riddle for balletomanes: What is the same but differ ent and new but older? Answer: Germany's Stuttgart Ballet, which opens tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for a sixweek season.

title: Met's 86th Season Ends With Hoffmann
description: The Metropolitan Opera ended its 86th regular sea son of performance in New York Saturday night with the presentation of Offenbach's Les Contes d'Hoffmann, in which Rgine Crespin, Nicolai Gedda and Gabriel Bacquier had leading roles.

title: Theater: The Struggles of 2 Educated Black Men
description: One day the New York Shakespeare Festival is going to have to give its Public Theater on Lafayette Street some such name as Drama Citythe world's first the atrical supermarket. It has so many theaters honey combed into the old Astor Library building that I often wonder whether any people find themselves in the wrong theater by mistake and uaex pectedly end up watching, say, Siobhan McKenna in stead of Subject to Fits.

title: Bernardi Leads City Opera's Abduction
description: Mario Bernardi, conductor of the National Arts Center Or chestra of Canada in Ottawa, made his New York City Opera debut at the New York State Theater Saturday afternoon leading Mozart's The Abduc tion From the Seraglio.

title: Earth WeekNo Vogue
description: A year ago Americans were observing their first Earth Day. Environment was certainly the word of the mo ment, but veteran conservationists had reason to ask themselves whether the country was merely enjoying another vogue or whether it had finally awakened to the physical perils confronting a longabused planet.

title: Reiner, Seeded First, Wins In Concord Junior Tennis
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 18Gary Reiner of New Hyde Park, L.I., the East's top ranked 16yearold player and seeded No. 1, won the fifth an nual Concord junior invitation tennis tournament today by de feating Gene Mayer of Wood mere, L.I., 63, 67, 64.

title: PEACE CORPS AIDE QUITS IN PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, April 18  The Peace Corps' director of minority affairs has resigned his post and filed a formal complaint with the Civil Serv ice Commission, accusing the Peace Corps of discrimination against women and minorities.

title: ALARM IS SOUNDED ON EURODOLLARS
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, April 18 Prof. Fritz Machlup of Prince ton University today warned conference of some of the world's leading monetary au thorities, meeting here at the Bologna Center of the Johns Hopkins University, that the rapid and uncontrolled growth of the Eurodollar market could lead to very severe trouble.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDON  Ken Russell is the British Orson Welles. As the director of Women in Love and The Music Lov ers, his international reputa tion is that of the filmmaker who goes always just too far, who outstrips his backers, his critics, even his fans, in the race toward the wilder shores of contro versy. Last week, he was in monkish retreat at Pine wood Studios, an hour's leafy drive from London, paring down for the censor his version of The Devils, which he has directed, written and co produced for Warner Broth ers, based on the John Whit ing play, itself derived from Aldous Huxley's classic study, about the possessed nuns of Loudun in the 17th century. After a 10day break, he be gins work, this time for MetroGoldwynMayer, on a screen adaptation of Sandy Wilson's The Boy Friend, star??ing the endearingly ex iguous model, Twiggy.

title: Pay Dispute Halts Debut Of B.O.A.C.'s Jumbo Jets
description: LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) A pay dispute today ground ed at the last minute the first commercial jumbo jet flight by the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

title: INDISCRETION WINS AT BENNETT SHOW
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., April 18 Terri Cunningham piloted In discretion to the regular work ing hunter championship at the Bennett College spring horse show today after a hackoff with Mrs. Karen Bacon's Acad emy Award.

title: Roundup: Angels Johnson Does His Walloping Best
description: Alex Johnson, a polished hitter, and a questionable fielder, and Frank Healy, a rookie catcher off to a fine start, figured prominently yesterday in baseball's ver sion of the California gold rush.

title: Littler Takes Monsanto Golf by 3 Shots
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., April 25 (AP)  Gene Littler, a bland, unemotional professional with 18 years on the tour, shot a closing fourunderpar 67 and won the $30,000 first prize by three strokes in the Monsanto open golf tournament today.

title: Gen. Jose Clark. Flores Of Mexico, Olympic Official
description: MEXICO CITY, April 18 (AP) Gen. Jos de Jesus Clark Flo res, a vice president of the In ternational Olympic Committee, died early today at his home, a family spokesman announced. He was 62 years old.

title: The Bowker Resignation
description: The resignation of Dr. Albert Bowker is a severe blow to the City University. Eight years ago his appointment as chancellor of the newly centralized institution was viewed with anxiety, if not outright hostility, by the system's several college presidents who saw in Dr. Bowker a threat to their independence. It is a measure of his success, as an academic leader and as a political tactician, that his decision to accept the chancellorship of the University of California at Berkeley has evoked consternation among his colleagues here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I take issue with James Reston's suggestion [April 2 column] that the President's Foreign Intelligence Ad visory Board provides a model for assisting the President effectively to control domestic spying by Govern ment secret agents.

title: KETO TAKES SECOND IN A.B.C. WITH 724
description: DETROIT, April 18 (AP)  Bob Keto of Minneapolis, Minn., put together eight straight strikes in his final game today for 268 and a 724 total to grab second place in the American Bowling Congress tournament regular singles standings.

title: Veniamin G. Bogorov, 66, Soviet Marine Biologist
description: MOSCOW, April 18Venia min G. Bogorov, Soviet ocean ographer and marine biologist, died Friday while attending a conference in Kishinev, capital of the Moldavian Republic. He was 66 years old.

title: EDWARD C. ROTHROCK
description: Edward G. Rothrock, who re tired recently as assistant cor poration secretary and manager of the Washington office of Pan American World Airways, died Saturday of cancer in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 60 years old and lived in Bluemont, Va.

title: RATE FLEXIBILITY URGED AT PARLEY
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 18 Wider latitude for the trans portation industry in setting passenger and freight rates was recommended here today by a group of over 60 influential conferees, many from outside the transport field.

title: 1,000 YOUTHS OPEN COLORADO PARLEY
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 18  The White House Confer ence on Youth began tonight in this isolated mountain re sort with an observer remark ing, The biggest authority sym bol the kids can march on here is the Rockies, towering ma jestically just to the west.

title: Ervin Rules Out Inquiry Into F.B.I. Now
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. said today that he would not make the Federal Bureau of Investi gation a target of his inquiry into Government surveillance unless he saw some evidence of illegality first. He said he had not found such evidence in nearly three years of search.

title: G.I.'s Ambushed Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 19 (UPI)A hun dred enemy soldiers ambushed an American patrol 31 miles northwest of Saigon Saturday afternoon in the closest large scale fighting to the capital so far this year, United States military spokesmen said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 27 Hurt in Bus Plunge
description: TOKUSHIMA, Japan, April 18 (Reuters)  Twentyseven per sons were injured today when a bus skidded off a road and fell 15 feet into an orchard ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

title: Weather Satellite Up
description: MOSCOW, April 18 (AP) The Soviet Union announced today the launching of a weather satellite in the Meteor series aimed at aiding weather forecasting and studying the amount of heat being reflected from the earth. The craft, launched yesterday, is in a nearcircular orbit about 390 miles above the earth.

title: Real Phil Ochs Back, But There's a Penalty
description: When Phil Ochs appeared at Carnegie Hall a year ago he was wearing a gold suit and leading a rock band. Many of those who bought tickets to hear the protest singer sing his familiar quiet songs were outraged.

title: Greek Easter in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 18 (Reu ters)Hundreds of Greek Cyp riote pilgrims took part in the traditional Easter Sunday pro cession of the Greek Orthodox Church here today.

title: College Students and Air Cadets Find Each Other Just Like Everybody Else
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 18Hey, you guys aren't the fascists I thought you were, a beard ed Princeton senior said in great amazement to a trim, blueuniformed cadet at the Air Force Academy here.

title: Dailies Report Gains in'70 As Publishers Meet Here
description: Daily newspapers across the country gained circulation, rev enues and jobs last year, and should show modest but steady growth again this year, the American Newspaper Pub lishers Association reported yesterday.

title: Arab World Expects Increased Strength From the New Union
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 The Arab world reacted favor ably today to the federation an nounced yesterday by Egypt, Syria and Libya, and saw in it strength for the Arabs against Israel.

title: 3 Professors to Be Cited By N.Y.U. on Thursday
description: Three veteran professorsa historian, a social studies edu cator and a mathematician have been named to receive New York University's Great Teacher awards for 1971.

title: Poseidon Missile Launched
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 19 (UPI) The nuclear subma rine, the U.S.S. John C. Cal houn, launched a new Poseidon missile at sunset today on test and training flight to an Atlantic Ocean target area. It was the first launching of the multiple warhead rocket since the first Poseidon submarine went to sea March 31 with 16 combatready missiles.

title: Rail Corporation Adopting Image Geared to Future
description: The quasigovernmental cor poration that will take over the nation's intercity passenger, trains May 1 adopted yester day a new name, a patriotic color scheme, and a Madison Avenueinspired image that it hopes will help bury the public's conception of trains as slow, shoddy and archaic.

title: McGovern Says Hoover Tried to Get Pilot Dismissed
description: Senator George S. McGov ern yesterday accused J. Ed gar Hoover, director of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation, of having attempted to destroy the career of a Trans World Air lines pilot who was critical of the F.B.I.'s handling of a hi jacking in 1969.

title: First Peking Envoy in Italy
