description: ROME, April 19, (Reuters) China's first ambassador to Italy since the Communists came to power 22 years ago ar rived here today from Paris. He is Shen Ping, former head of the Foreign Ministry depart ment that deals with Western Europe, the United States and the Pacific Ocean.

title: Inconsistency Issue Is Raised as Mackell Testifies on Narcotics
description: The State Commission of In vestigation questioned Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell yesterday about why his office had permitted a de tective, indicted for conspiring to sell heroin, to plead guilty to the misdemeanor charge of official misconduct.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Negro Illegitimacy Rate Drops as Whites' Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Black women, on the average, had significantly fewer illegiti mate babies in the late 1960's than at the beginning of the decade, while white women had more, according to a Census Bureau study issued today.

title: Richard Bond Is Picked For Philadelphia Award
description: Richard C. Bond, president of the board of trustees of John Wanamaker, Inc., and a trustee of the Penn Central Company, has been named the recipient of the 1971 Ed ward Powell Award, it was announced yesterday in Phil adelphia by Mayor James H. J. Tate.

title: Polish Institute to Meet
description: The Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America is scheduled to convene its second congress of scholars and scien tists Friday to Sunday at Columbia University. The con gress, cosponsored by Colum bia's School of International Af fairs and Institute on East Cen tral Europe, will have as its theme: Poland in World Civi lization 19181970.

title: LOAN DATA GIVEN BY DUPONT FIRM
description: A spokesman for F. I. du Pont, Glore Forgan & Co. gave additional details yesterday of the pending financing arrange ment with a group headed by H. Ross Perot, chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Cor poration.

title: Offtrack Derby Betting Starts April 28
description: Kentucky Derby fever began rising here yesterday, both on the track and off the track.

title: LEVER BROTHERS BID DENIED IN U.S. COURT.
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 19 A petition by Lever Brothers to stop Federal Trade Commis sion proceedings on a proposal requiring detergent makers to list ingredients on packages and display pollution warnings in advertisements was dismissed today in United States District Court.

title: I.R.S. Warns Against Low Withholding
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service recommended today that mil lions of Americans increase the sums withheld from their pay checks for income taxes this year. If they do not, the agency said, they may have to pay large additional amounts to meet their tax bills next April.

title: DR. JOSEPH K. HILL, PROFESSOR, DIES
description: ExPresident of Downstate Medical Center Was 52

title: Former Economy Minister Is Assassinated in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 19 (Reuters)Assassins shot and killed Alberto Larrea Humerez, Economics Minister in the for mer Barrientos Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Du Pont Shifts Officers;
description: Charles B. McCoy was elected yesterday as chairman of the board of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., succeed ing Lammot du Pont Copeland Sr., who did not stand for reelection.

title: Ky Says Aim Should Be Political Victory
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that his country should work to achieve a political resolution of the war, not press for a military victory over the Communists.

title: Chinese Permitting Close Look at Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, April 19 A small group of foreign news men, including this correspond ent, two Japanese, one Swiss, three Britons and four Cana dians, today started a fourday program that proinised to give them the most extensive look at affairs in Shanghai, China's largest city, that any journal istic group has had in recent years.

title: OBSERVER
description: Very little scholarly attention is be ing paid to the decline of memorable utterance. We can easily find out how many Americans prefer canned spa ghetti to frozen peas, thanks to the miracle of market research. Thanks to Drs. Gallup and Harris, we can tell in an instant whether bluecollar workers in Fargo, N. D., think Edmund Muskie is a better man than Ronald Reagan for getting the detergent out of the creek, but there is no laboratory any where that can tell us how sharply the volume of memorable utterance has fallen off since the days of, say, Harry Truman.

title: Ouster of Trooper Because of Weight Is Upheld by Court
description: A state trooper who was dismissed last April primari ly because he was over weight and detracted from the sharp image the state police desired lost his appeal for re instatement yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Hartke and Thurmond Join On Veterans' Pension Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, and Sen ator Strom Thurmond, Republi can of South Carolina, an nounced today that they will write a bill that would main tain a veteran's pension rights if Social Security or other Gov ernment pensions increase.

title: Securities Officials Agree That Operations Go Well
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Major securities industry or ganizations and the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today that there are no widespread operational prob lems in the industry that would require general restrictions on stock trading.

title: Friends Gather to Toast Art of Maria Janis
description: The Southampton crowd, which tends to be very en thusiastic about paintings, stood around the Bodley Gallery last night, saying nice things about Maria Cooper Janis. And well they should. The elegant Mrs. Janis is one of their own. She's also an artist.

title: Orbiting Soviet Workshop Is Expected to Be Manned
description: MOSCOW, April 19An un manned research workshop launched by the Soviet Union this morning into orbit around the earth is expected to become a manned mission.

title: Columbia Dips Oar for Wisconsin
description: The oarsmen at Columbia yesterday sent $50 they had collected to the University of Wisconsin, whose athletic director, Elroy Hirsch, has threatened to drop crew in a budget cut.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBT PLAN IS FILED FOR ROBINSON & CO.
description: Donald M. Collins, the receiv er for Robinson & Co., a former member firm of the New York Stock Exchange now in liquida tion, has filed a plan for paying off the firm's debts. The plan involves an advance of about $1.4million from the ex change's Special Trust Fund.

title: Plant Is Fined $149,000 By Illinois Pollution Board
description: CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) The Illinois Pollution Control Board levied a $149,000 fine to day against an asphalt roofing plant in Joliet, which it said discharged as much untreated waste into the Des Plaines Riv er as a city with a population of 90,000 without a sewage treatment plant.

title: Prices of Bonds Tumble Across a Broad Front
description: Bond prices tumbled across a ?? yesterday, apparently because of a growing belief that the longawaited economic upturn is finally at hand.

title: GIANTS WIN, 42, FOR 9TH STRAIGHT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (UPI)Ron Bryant, taking over in the first inning after Frank Reberger hit a batter and walked one and then left the game with a sore shoulder, pitched the San Francisco Gi ants to a 42 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today for their ninth straight triumph.

title: Unions Score City's Cuts; Rally and March Planned
description: Reacting sharply to an nounced cutbacks in city jobs and the threat of mass layoffs, the largest union of city em ployes isued an angry call yes terday for a mass rally at City Hall and a march on Albany next Tuesday.

title: Bay of Pigs Plus Ten
description: Superficially, little has changed in Cuba since the Bay of Pigs debacle a decade ago. Cuba itself remains tightly under Fidel Castro's control, economically viable only because of heavy Soviet subsidy. Both Castro's hopes and Washington's fears that the tactics which brought him to power in Cuba might enable other radicals to take over in the rest of Latin America proved illusory.

title: J. Eliot McCormack, 66, Dead; Con Edison Production Chief
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., April 19J. Eliot McCormack, who retired in 1969 as vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company for production and distribution operations, died today in Long Island Jew ish Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 66 years old and lived at 62 Longview Road.

title: Squires Get 21 East Lead, Beating Colonels, 150137
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 19 (AP)Ray and Charlie Scott tossed in 30 points each as the Virginia Squires defeated the Kentucky Colonels, 150137, to night to take a 21 lead in their fourofseven American Basket ball Association East Division playoff finals.

title: Cambodians Under Attack
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 19 (AP)The high command reported today that Cambodian troops trying to clear Pnom penh's highway to the sea had reached a point three miles from the position where other Cambodians were surrounded and under enemy attack.

title: POPULATION GROUP OFFERS CARE PLAN
description: The Population Council out lined a plan yesterday for pro viding maternity care and birth control services to people of underdeveloped countries throughout the world at a pro jected annual cost of 60 cents a person.

title: ALLIES REPORTED PROBING IN ASHAU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 20Government reconnaissance troops were re ported pushing through the Ashau. Valley yesterday in preparation for an allied drive against that longtime enemy stronghold near the Laotian border.

title: COURT DENIES PLEA BY AIR CONTROLLERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to a group of New York air traffic control lers who were disciplined by the Federal Aviation Adminis tration after a nationwide walk out on March 25, 1970.

title: Allon Arrives in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Yigal Allon is expected to give details tomorrow of Israel's po sition on an agreement to re open the Suez Canal when he meets with Secretary Rogers.

title: No Official Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20A State Department spokesman said this morning that the United States had no official confirmation of reports of Pre mier Lon Nol's resignation.

title: U.S. Filmmakers DeEmphasizing Sex
description: Major segments of the American motion picture in dustry are turning away from the detailed exploration of sex that has marked some re cent feature films.

title: Murtagh to Drop 12 of 30 Counts In Panther Case
description: Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh denied defense mo tions to dismiss all charges against 13 Black Panthers yes terday, but announced that he would submit to the jury only 18 of the 30 counts alleged in the indictment.

title: State Curb Urged On Electrical Use
description: The city's Environmental Pro tection Administration warned yesterday that unrestricted growth in the use of electricity was threatening irreparable damage to the health and liv ing conditions of New Yorkers.

title: Spring Snowstorm Isolates 1,500 Youth Conference Delegates at Remote Mountain Retreat in Colorado
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 19  As if the White House Con ference on Youth were not iso lated enough in this mountain retreat 1,500 miles from Wash ington, heavy snow fell this morning, marooning the confer ence and its delegates.

title: SOUTHERNER SCORES U.S. ON INTEGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Senator James B. Allen, Democrat of Alabama, opened the Senate's first civil rights (debate of the year today with a charge that the Federal estab lishment makes school integra tion demands on the South that it does not enforce in the North.

title: Fire Destroys Jersey Store
description: FORT LEE, N. J., April 19 (UPI)A fire that shot flames 60 feet into the air and forced Route 9W to be closed de stroyed a 10,000squarefoot supermarket here early today. The loss was estimated at about $1million. An adjacent bakery, bowling alley and Chi nese restaurant were severely damaged by smoke and water.

title: Indecision and Resentment Mark Newark School's Reopening After Strike
description: NEWARK, April 19Barrin ger High School in this city's North Ward opened its doors on schedule this morning for the first school day after the 11week teachers' strike. For the principal, teachers and stu dents, it was a day of inde cision, resentment and drift.

title: Merger News
description: Agreement in principle was announced yesterday to merge the Granite City Steel Com pany, the nation's 14th largest steel producer, into the Na tional Steel Corporation, which is ranked fourth. The com panies outlined an exchange of stock that would be worth about $88million.

title: APPALACHIA POOR HIT HEALTH CARE
description: KINGWOOD, W. Va., April 19 The poor of Appalachia told a Senate subcommittee today that the medical care they re ceived was as deficient as the eroded hollows and strip mined ridges in which they lived.

title: Jersey Woodlands Closed
description: TRENTON, April 19 (AP) Acting Gov. Raymond H. Bate man, the Senate President, or dered today that state forests and woodlands be closed in South Jersey because of the threat of forest fires. Gov. Wil liam T. Cahill is attending a conference in Virginia.

title: Xerox Profit Advances 8% To Set a Quarterly Record
description: The Xerox Corporation had the highest earnings for any quarter in its history in the initial three months this year, but the 8 per cent gain over the 1970 period was the small est yet, according to the re sults reported yesterday. Operating revenues for the first quarter were up 12 per cent to a record high for the period.

title: L. GORDON MILLER
description: SPARTA, N. J., April 19 L. Gordon Miller, a stockbroker, died Saturday in Newton Me morial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: 2 WITNESSES HELD IN CORONA DEATH
description: Two Black Panthers were held yesterday as material wit nesses in the murder of a West Coast Panther here Saturday. One of them, the police said, was tied up in the building at the time of the crime.

title: Rockefeller Urges Labor to Back Nixon RevenueSharing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  Governor Rockefeller urged or ganized labor today to reverse its position and support the Nixon Administration's plans for sharing Federal revenues with state and local govern ments.

title: Back to Khartoum?
description: The proposed new Arab federation of Egypt, Syria and Libya signals a dangerous turn from negotiation toward confrontation in the Middle East.

title: Scantlin Shows System For Data Transmission
description: Scantlin Electronics, Inc., an nounced yesterday the introduc tion of what it called a new, multipurpose dataretrieval and communications system that permits a user to program his own terminals to receive finan cial data.

title: Pakistan Accuses India of Attack in East
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 19  The Government charged today that armed Indian na tionals supported by artillery fire from Indian territory at tacked a border post in East = Pakistan Friday.

title: Charge by G.O.P. War Foe On Bombing of Laos Denied
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters)  The State Depart ment today denied charges by Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey, California Republican, that the United States was embarked on a policy of sys tematically wiping out. Laotian villages by bombing.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: SOMOZA EXPECTS POLITICAL CHANGE
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 19 (UPI)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua Says he expects to see a Stronger twoparty system and elections routinely witnessed by Observers from the Organiza tion of American States follow ing constitutional reform here.

title: ALI IS NO PACIFIST, U.S TELLS COURT
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Government argued before the Supreme Court today that Muhammad Ali, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, was not eligible for draft exemption as a pacifist because he was opposed only to white men's wars.

title: Draft Conviction Reversed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir cuit reversed today the draft convitcion of Christian Wins low Hayden, 23yearold son of Sterling Hayden, the actor. Young Hayden had been con victed of failure to report for induction and failure to report for preinduction physical ex amintion. The court upheld the youth's claim of conscientous objector status.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Bill Yields Plummet, Declining Below the 4% Level
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Treasury bill yields retreated below the 4 per cent level at today's auction, declining sharply from last week's lev els, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Agnew Voices Misgivings On the U.S.China Thaw
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 19Vice President Agnew ex pressed misgivings today about the visit to China of the United States table tennis team and the apparent thaw in relations between the two countries.

title: HERMAN ZUCH, OWNED KEEN'S CHOP HOUSE
description: Herman Zuch, who retired last year as president of Keen's English Chop House, 72 West 36th Street, died Saturday in Miami Beach, where he had his winter home. He was in his seventies and lived at 24 Old Mamaroneck Road, White Plains.

title: MARKET ROLLS ON IN NEW ADVANCES
description: The most dynamic stockmar ket recovery in more than three decades kept rolling forward yesterday and, in the process, is passed a milestone.

title: Beverly Sills Tailors Recital To Dazzle Philharmonic Hall
description: Beverly Sills is a soprano who thrives on audience re action. She senses it, seizes on it and takes off in the most pleasing possible way for the particular people in front of her. She is anything but aloof on stage, with her ready smile and her feeling of taking the audience into her confidence.

title: Japan Says 3 Fighters Buzzed a Soviet Ship
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 20 (Reuters)  Three F  86F jet fighters of the Japanese Air SelfDefense Force mistaken ly buzzed a Soviet destroyer during maneuvers last month off Iki Island, southern Japan, the Defense Agency said to day.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 19, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

title: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Close to 284,000 Target
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19 (Reuters)The num ber of United States forces in Vietnam fell last week to within 4,000 of President Nixon's May 1 target of 284, 000 troops.

title: Carol Semple Wins Medal
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 19 (AP)Carol Semple recovered from a first hole double bogey 6 to shoot a threeunderpar 71 and win the qualifying medal today in the 69th NorthSouth amateur championship.

title: RYUN AND LIQUORI TO MEET IN MILE
description: Jim Ryun has, agreed to com pete against Marty Liguori and possibly Kipchoge Keino in the mile run at the International Freedom Games in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on May 16 at Franklin Field, Philadelphia.

title: INQUIRY ACCEPTED BY ROLLS HOLDERS
description: LONDON, April 19 (UPI) Shareholders of RollsRoyce, Lt., have agreed to a govern ment investigation of the com pany's affairs, it was announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE REOPENS DEBATE OVER ABM
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The antiballistic missile debate began again in the Senate to day with many of the same arguments but little of the en thusiasm or organized opposi tion of past years.

title: Oil Countries Shun Blame For Increases in Prices
description: The Venezuelan Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons, Dr. Hugo Prez La Salvia, came to New York yesterday to tell American consumers that the oilproducing countries should not be held responsible for re cent and future petroleum prod uct price increases.

title: Man in the News
description: A visitor to the Jerusalem office of Yigal Allon, the Israeli Deputy Premier, who is in the United States for talks today, wanders a maze of dingy corridors in an old Arab house until, suddenly, he is startled by a brilliant orange wall, vivid abstract paintings and modern furniture  Mr. Al lon's suite of of fices. The 52 yearold leader is also the Minister of Education, the latest in his string of Cabi net posts. He is also one of Israel's earliest war heroes, a retired major general, as well as the originator of the Allon plan for the set tlement of Israel's border with Jordan and the author of several books dealing with military matters.

title: Slow Learners
description: Although the Department of Agriculture has many experienced officials and its Agricultural Research Serv ice includes many scientifically learned men, they are remarkably slow learners about environment. For more than fifteen years, they have been spraying various chemicals on the land and water of several Southern states in a futile effort to kill the fire ant, a not very important agricultural pest.

title: G.M. President's Vocal Wife Inspires Controversyand Charity
description: DETROITThe strongest muscle in my body is my mouth, said Dollie Cole, and there may not be many of the Motor City's auto rich who disagree.

title: Dr. Harold DeWindt Dies at 60; Led Church Here for 11 Years
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., April 19The Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt, pastor of the Kirk intheHills here since 1953 and pastor of the West Park Pres byterian Church, New York, from 1942 to 1953, died Satur day in Ford Hospital, Detroit, after a short illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Amex Closes Mixed After Early Gains
description: Prices were mixed on the American Stock Exchange yes terday after some late selling pressure reduced the sizes of the earlier gains.

title: Mejia Marathon Winner; M'Mahon 5 Seconds Back
description: BOSTON, April 19Sprinting the last 200 yards on blistered feet, a 30yearold Colombia Olympian, Alvaro Mejia, won the 75th annual Boston Mara thon today by the slimmest margin in history  five sec onds.

title: CONILL SHOWING INCOME GROWTH
description: The Conill Corporation, the parent company of the Conti nental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Chicago's largest bank, reported a sharp increase yesterday in its income before securities transactions.

title: The Talk of the Bluegrass Country
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 There are moments of great peace and beauty in the Blue grass Country when one can stroll near shaded pastures, close enough to reach out and touch a possible Ken tucky Derby Winner. It would be vastly impolite and even dangerous to actually touch a fiery and valuable stallion. But such is the proximity of mass mankind to the treasures of the horse farms. Civilization is looming down hard, as close as the whining jets on final approach to Blue Grass Field, or the highway that sliced through Calumet Farm a decade ago.

title: RUSS HODGES DIES; VOICE OF GIANTS, 61
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (UPI)  Russ Hodges, who broadcast New York and San Francisco Giants baseball games for 22 years, died tonight at the age of 61.

title: Army Transfers Officer Critical of Laos Push
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 20 (AP)The United States Army has re lieved the commander of a helicopter battalion because he criticized the allied opera tion in Laos and allowed a television crew to film heli copters using napalm on enemy positions, it was learned today.

title: Avco Plans LayOffs
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 19 (UPI)The Avco Corporation's aerostructures division today announced plans to lay off 750 workers because of requested slowdowns in production of wings for the Lockheed L1011 airbus. Avco said the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation asked the division, which has been pro ducing two complete wings a month, to cut back to about one a month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR WEIGHS FILIBUSTER ON AID
description: Governor Rockefeller sug gested yesterday that New York members of Congress might organize a filibuster to drama tize a need for fairer sharing of Federal aid to help industrial states from going bankrupt.

title: HELEN M. HOTCHKISS OF HUNTER COLLEGE
description: Helen M. Hotchkiss, who taught English literature at Hunter College day and eve ning sessions from 1928 until her retirement in 1963, died yesterday after a short illness in Lake Worth, Fla., where she had been living. She was about 75 years old.

title: 3 Jerseyans Cleared In Bus Crash Fatal To 7 L.I. Children
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 19  Involuntary manslaughter charges against three New Jer sey men, arising from the bus accident last July 15 in which seven Long Island schoolchil dren died, were dismissed to day by Judge Henry V. Schei rer in Lehigh County Criminal Court here.

title: PENTAGON IS LINKED TO DEFECTIVE C5A'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)Senator William Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin, accused the Defense Depart ment today of accepting C5A cargo planes from the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation that it knew to be defective.

title: PROGRESS IS SEEN IN AIRBUS TALKS
description: Builders, banks and customers trying to save the Lockheed L1011 airbus tried with only limited success yesterday to conclude an agreement that would open the way for a key White House move in the mara thon rescue effort.

title: Inquiry by Berrigan Grand Jury Stalled
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 The renewal of a Federal in vestigation by a grand jury that indicted the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and others was de layed here today because the Federal Government appeared unprepared to deal with legal issues involved in the attempt to question new witnesses.

title: Screen: Vapid Erotica
description: My Secret Life is the autobiography of the anony mous Victorian gentleman who devoted a large part of his energies to sex and sur vived until old age to write about it in precise detail, some of which is quite cheer ful, some unbelievable, and some as unwittingly gloomy as one of Dickens's wittingly gloomy social tracts. Printed in Amsterdam at the author's expense sometime toward the end of the 19th century, it remained a little known clas sic of pornography and social history until Grove Press brought it out in this country in 1966, its original 11 vol umes reprinted as two, plus a onevolume abridgment for the paperback trade.

title: The Greening of Thumbs: Tips on Growing Things Even Without a Garden
description: A flower show for people without gardens opened yes terday at Gimbels.

title: Holders Back Detroit Edison Management
description: Stockholders of the Detroit Edison Company backed their management at the annual meeting here yesterday at 30 East 42d Street and voted down a move to force offi cers to retire at 65 years of age and directors at 70.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FEMALE EUNUCH. By Germaine Greer. 349 pages. McGrawHill. $6.95.

title: MAYOR THREATENS TO CUT 90,000 JOBS UNLESS STATE AIDS
description: Mayor Lindsay warned yes terday that he would eliminate 90,000 city jobs, as the most drastic of four alternatives open to the city, unless the State Legislature restored its cuts of city funds and increased the city's taxing powers.

title: Injury Clouds Giacomin's Role Tonight
description: CHICAGO, April 19Ed Gia comin, the Rangers' goalie, had a throbbing pain today that had kept him up all night. But un like in previous playoffs it wasn't a headacheit was a badly cut left hand.

title: CRIMMINS WITNESS DESCRIBES DEAL
description: The convict who the prose cution asserts helped Mrs. Alice Crimmins kill one of her two children testified yesterday that a former assistant district at torney told him he could go home free if he would give in Criminating evidence against Mrs. Crimmins.

title: 2 JAZZ BANDS SET FOR COLLEGE FINAL
description: HAMDEN, Conn., April 19 A 23piece jazz band and an experimental quintet carried off top honors last weekend at the Quinnipiac College intercollegi ate jazz festival.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION WAS OFF LAST WEEK
description: Steel production fell by 0.9 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: Sierra Leone Now Republic; First President Is Sworn
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, April 19 (Reuters)Prime Min ister Siaka P. Stevens, who last month survived two efforts to assassinate him and an at tempted coup d'tat today de clared this West African nation a republic.

title: Brazil and Argentina Balk Plan for Cut in Latin Arms Spending
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 19A proposal to reduce mili tary expenditures in Latin America, presented by Colom bia and Costa Rica to the gen eral assembly of the Organiza tion of American States, was criticized strongly by Brazil and Argentina today.

title: Voting Amendment Ratification Stalled in the Jersey Assembly
description: TRENTON, April 19A final move to complete New Jersey's ratification of an amendment to the United States Constitu tion that would lower the vot ing age to 18 in all elections stalled unexpectedly tonight in the Assembly.

title: Talk of Golf
description: Considerable interest has been created by remarks of Clifford Roberts, tournament chairman of the Masters golf tournament held annually at Augusta, Ga., concerning the absence of black competitors in this prestigious event. A letter addressed to Roberts dated April 8 was sent to the press building there by Mrs. Lee Elder of Wash ington, wife of the black profes sional. The enve lope was marked for the at tention of five individuals including this writer. The club subsequently forwarded the letter, which had been re ceived the day after the Masters concluded.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brezhnev in Bulgaria for Party Parley
description: VIENNA, April 19 (Reuters) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the So viet Communist party leader, arrived in Sofia today at the head of a large Soviet delega tion to attend the 10th con gress of the Bulgarian Com munist party opening there to morrow.

title: IN THE NATION
description: LULA, Ga., April 19In the window of the Red Top Restaurant here, in red, white and blue letters, a public appeal has been prominently posted. It reads:

title: FRANK A. SHAILER
description: Frank A. Shailer, a retired ex Equitable Life Assurance So ecutive vice president of the ciety of the United States, died yesterday in New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 83 years old and lived at 19 Everett Street, East chester, N. Y.

title: Pfizer Earnings Hit Peak
description: John J. Powers, Jr., chairman and president of Pfizer, Inc., re ported at the annual meeting yesterday that the company registered the highest earnings and sales for any first quarter.

title: Bridge: Old Austrian Bidding System Is Modernized by Australians
description: Those philosophers who claim that history always re peats itself could find con siderable supporting evidence for their thesis by studying bridge history.

title: High Court to Hear Trust Suit On Marketing of Private Brand
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to consider a Govern ment attempt to outlaw as anti competitive an exclusive sys tem of privatebrand merchan dising by an association of small supermarkets.

title: Friends and Foes of Stokes Acquiesce in Decision
description: CLEVELAND, April 19The political friends and enemies of Mayor Carl B. Stokes have at least one common feeling today: They do not quarrel with his decision to give up office this fall.

title: Young Russian Actors Study Yiddish
description: MOSCOWYoung Russian actors have been studying Yiddish to be able to perform with the Moscowbased Jew ish Dramatic Ensemble, the Soviet Union's only profes sional Yiddish theater group.

title: Wheat Futures Show a Sharp Decline
description: Improved weather conditions in the winterwheat areas of the country, coupled with reports of a decline in Canadian stocks, sent prices of wheat futures plunging yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: M'CRACKEN OPPOSES LURCHING CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  President Nixon's chief eco nomic adviser said today that the aim of Government eco nomic policy from now on must be to minimize the stopgo pattern that has characterized the economy and economic pol icy since the mid1960's.

title: Maple Syrup Time, Late This Year, Sends Upstate Farmers Into Woods
description: WEST HARPERSFIELD, N. Y., April 17A late spring that has kept upstate farm ers shivering in their winter workclothes while people in New York City enjoyed light topcoat weather has delayed the harvesting of the maple syrup crop this year.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass Every outdoors writer should live in the country, close to the source of his in spiration, but there are times when one yearns for the classic simplicity of a New York apartment.

title: NEWARK PARENTS BAR 100 TEACHERS
description: NEWARK, April 19About 100 teachers who took part in the 11week Newark teachers' strike were prevented from re turning to their classrooms in six separate schools here today by the president of the Board of Education and groups of par ents who said they did not want the teachers back.

title: Bullets Eliminate Knicks, 9391
description: The dynasty of the New York Knickerbockers, estab lished amid such excitement last May, ended on its 346th day last night as the Baltimore Bullets completed an uprising against great odds and elim inated the defending champions from the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Nixon, in Speech to D.A.R., Urges Federal Renewal
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 President Nixon restated his plea for reform and renewal of the Federal system in a speech here tonight to the 80th Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: Clerks' Union Strikes at REA, Protesting New Highway Runs
description: Members of the Railway and Airline Clerks' Brotherhood went on strike yesterday against REA Express in a dis pute over the company's estab lishment of 17 new highway runs in the Northeast.

title: State Is Dismissing 8,250, With Wide Cutsin Seivices
description: ALBANY, April 19The lay off of 8,250 state employes was announced today by budget of ficials, who detailed widespread reductions in such public serv ices as health, higher education and recreation.

title: Nixon Seeks Welfare Role That Will Promote Dignity
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 19  In a tough speech ex tolling the dignity and the value of hard work, President Nixon said today that the suc cess of his welfare reform pro grams would be measured by the dignity it promotes and not by the dole it provides.

title: Push Begins in Mozambique
description: MOZAMBIQUE, Beira, April 19 (Agence FrancePresse) The Portuguese armed forces in Mozambique have begun new sweep operations against the Mozambique Liberation Front on three fronts now that the rainy season is over, the Nampula headquarters an nounced today.

title: CASTRO REJECTS NEW TIES TO U.S.
description: MIAMI, April 19  Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba said to night that his Government was in no way way interested in establishing normal relations with the United States.

title: WEEDEN REPORTS JUMP IN EARNINGS
description: Weeden & Co., one of Wall Street's few major publicly owned brokerage houses, said yesterday that it had experi enced a sharp increase in reve nues and earnings in the March quarter, largely reflecting the strong improvement in the stock market.

title: Prepaid Plan On Law Fees Passing Test
description: SHREVEPORT, La., April 18Seven hundred construc tion laborers and their fami lies here, who are enrolled in the nation's first test of pre paid legal insurance, are demonstrating that bluecol lar families are not inclined to become legal hypochondri acs when their legal costs are covered by insurance.

title: OFFICERS ELECTED BY PAPER COMPANY
description: The election of three execu tive vice presidents of the In ternational Paper Company was announced yesterday by Paul A. Gorman, chairman and presi dent.

title: ARMY FIVE HIRES A VILLANOVA AIDE
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., April 19 Dan Dougherty, an assistant basketball coach at Villanova for five seasons, was appointed head coach at Army today. He succeeds Bobby Knight, who left the Academy last month for the head job at Indiana Univer sity.

title: Man Killed and 2 Policemen Are Wounded in Harlem Gunfight
description: Two policemen were wounded  one critically  as one of them shot and killed an alleged gunman and wounded two other suspects in a gunfight late yesterday after noon in a Harlem tenement.

title: 1,000 Veterans Begin Week's Protest Against War With Capital March
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 About 1,000 veterans, protest ing against United States in volvement in the Indochina war, began a weeklong dem onstration in the capital to day with a march from Arlington Memorial Cemetery past the south gate of the White House to the Capitol steps.

title: France Threatens to Halt Sale of Jets If Libya Sends Them to Other Nations
description: PARIS, April 19 (Reuters)A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that France would block the delivery of Mirage jets to Libya if she discovered that they were going to other countries.

title: NIXON IS PICTURED AS WARY OF PRESS
description: President Nixon was described yesterday as being much more cooperative to newsmen than his predecessor, Lyndon B. Johnson, but at having set up an elaborate apparatus of ad vertising and public relations experts for monitoring and in fluencing what is written about him.

title: I.O.S. TIES SEVERED BY WYNDHAM WHITE
description: GENEVA, April 19  Sir Eric Wyndham White, the for mer international officer who took over the troubled Invest ors Overseas Services last year, has now completed his with drawal from the mutualfund complex.

title: STONY BROOK DEAN SPURNS H.E.W. POST
description: OLD FIELD, L. I., April 19 Dr. Edmund D. Pellegrino, dean of the State University Medical School at Stony Brook, said to day that he had discontinued discussions with the Nixon Ad ministration about becoming the Government's top medical officer.

title: White House Aide Criticizes Heavy Social Cost of Environmentalists' Goals
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 One of the Government's top economists criticized and even ridiculed some environmental ists today, saying they would impose too heavy a social cost in trying to achieve their goals.

title: Advertising:
description: Because they work well in advance, publishers of the big monthly national maga zines are in a position to re port on the first half of this year. Some did very well with a little extra help from the cigarette companies and Detroit. And even those that didn't see better days com ing.

title: VASQUEZ REGISTERS 7THROUND VICTORY
description: A crowd of 2,500 showed up early at the Felt Forum last night, bought all 301 of the spe cial lunchandpunch chicken dinners on sale, then stayed late to see a local bantam weight favorite, Davey Vas quez, score a seventhround technical knockout over Chuck Spencer of Cleveland.

title: Dance: Eugene Onegin
description: Germany's leading ballet company, the Stuttgart Ballet, arrived back in town last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with its sump tuous and dramatic version of EugeneOnegin.

title: Accounts of Devonshire Being Transferred Out
description: Customer accounts of the First Devonshire Corporation, an insolvent former member of the New York Stock Ex change, are being transferred out of the firm to other broker age houses under a stipulation reached with the exchange, the firm's receiver and its creditors.

title: Xerox Profit Advances 8% To Set a Quarterly Record
description: The Chrysler Corporation re ported yesterday a profit of $10.8million, or 22 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1971.

title: MRS. CHARLES M. CLARK
description: Mrs. Valerie Graham Clark, a partner in the interior deco rating firm of Trask & Clark and the wife of Charles Martin Clark, chairman of the Stock Exchange concern of Estabrook & Co., died yesterday in the Harness Pavilion of the Colum biaPresbyterian Medical Cen ter. She was 59 years old and had homes at 139 East 79th Street and in Oyster Bay, LI., and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: 8,000 in Seoul Protest
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 19  More than 8,000 students from seven universities resumed antiGovernment demonstra tions today for the third week, clashing violently with riot policemen. Today's demonstra tions were staged in observance of the 11th anniversary of the 1960 student revolt that toppled the Government of the late President Syngman Rhee. The youths are demanding an end to compulsory military train ing in the colleges and denouncf ing restrictions on the press and on academic freedom.

title: Budget Cuts Will Hit Hard at City U.
description: The most stringent budget option announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay would make it impossible for the City Uni versity to admit a freshman class next fall.

title: ALBANY CAUTIOUS ON LINDSAY PLEAS
description: ALBANY, April 19Mayor Lindsay's pleas for restoration of cuts in state aid and for $880million in new taxing powers are expected to receive the same sharp scrutiny from budget  conscious Republican legislative leaders that was ex hibited earlier this month when $760million was trimmed from Governor Rockefeller's pro posed $8.45billion state budget.

title: See More of America
description: Back in 1965 Congress passed the Highway Beautifica tion Act, a law to remove all billboards from rural sections of the interstate and primary highway systems. Only now, six years after enactment, is there real promise that the law is to be obeyed. Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe is making sounds indicating that at long last action is to be taken to remove these illegal eyesores.

title: Retired Diamond Cutter Strikes It Lucky Here
description: A retired diamond cutter and a shipping clerk were among the first prize winners yesterday in New York State's $100,000 lottery draw ing, held at the Port Author ity's Midtown bus terminal.

title: I.C.C. REPORT HITS PENNSY'S FAILINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 19  The Interstate Commerce Com mission issued a 1,500page re port today on the Penn Central Transportation Company sum marizing the financial indis cretions of that enterprise and its predecessor companies  the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroadsfrom 1963 until bankruptcy last June. The two railroads merged on Feb. 1, 1968.

title: Madison Ave. Without Cars Draws Pedestrians' Raves
description: Midtown Madison Avenue, usually a maelstrom of honk ing, fumeemitting autos and scurrying secretaries, was closed to all vehicles but buses for two hours yester day, and everyone except the cab drivers appeared to en joy the Earth Week respite.

title: Treasury Seeks Extension For Buying of Public Debt
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (Reuters)  The Treasury De partment has asked Congress to extend the authority under which Federal Reserve banks can purchase publicdebt obli gations from the Treasury for two more years up to June 30, 1973.

title: Transit Patrolman Indicted In ChangeBooth Holdups
description: A Transit Authority patrol man, accused of devoting his offduty hours to holdups of subway change booths, was in dicted yesterday on charges of robbery and attempted robbery.

title: Diamonds No Longer Loretta Young's Best Friend
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., April 19 (AP)  Loretta Young, the actress, says she's prepared to sell her jewels and her home to insure success of her campaign to aid underprivileged youth in the Phoenix area.

title: BROKER SUSPENDED ON S.E.C. CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended Arthur S. Miller, a former offi cial of Ling & Co., Inc., Dallas. from associating with any broker or dealer for 90 days, on the ground that he allegedly violated antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Indians Top Red Sox, 54
description: BOSTON, April 19 (UPI) Roy Foster's tworun homer in the 13th inning gave the Cleve land Indians a 54 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.

title: Belco Plans Bin Outlay For Peruvian Oil Search
description: LIMA, Peru, April 19 (UPI) The United Statesowned Belco Petroleum Company of Peru an nounced plans today to invest more than $25million in oil ex ploration in Peru in the next two years.

title: Boston U. Damaged by Fire
description: BOSTON, April 19 (AP)Firel did damage estimated at $250, 000 to Boston University's School of Fine and Applied Art early today. The cause of the fire was under investigation by the Boston arson squad.

title: Twins Defeat Royals, 98
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 19 (AP)Harmon Killebrew drove in six runs today as the Minnesota Twins built a 90 lead and then survived Bob Oliver's grand slam homer to shade the Kansas City Royals, 98. The victory ended a six game Minnesota losing streak.

title: About Pro Football
description: With the retirement of George Sauer Jr. and the questionable status of Don Maynard, the New York Jets need a wide receiver of stature if they are to fulfill their Super Bowl ambition during the next National Football League campaign.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the early days of intercollegiate athletics the most important man in any sport was the captain of the team. The natural assumption was that the other undergraduates had elected him because he had the best leadership qualities, was the most skillful performer and had the superior knowledge to transmit to less advanced teammates. He ran the show just as did the team captains at Oxford, Cam bridge and the other British molders of America's sports traditions.

title: RULES TIGHTENED FOR METHADONE
description: The West Side Medical Cen ter is adopting new rules to minimize the chances that meth adone might be dispensed ac cidentally to nonaddicts.

title: 2 Suspects Held in Ft. Hamilton Holdup
description: The Federal Bureau of In vestigation announced last night the arrest of two sus pects in last week's robbery of a bank on the Fort Hamil ton military base in Brooklyn.

title: Advertising:
description: Kinney RentACar will an nounce today a multipronged expansion effort that its chief, Harold L. Oshry, hopes will put it in the top five by 1975. By that time the com pany expects to have its own operation in 52 cities and franchises in 225.

title: Thant Sees Heightened Urgency For Mideast Peace Effort Now
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19Secretary General Thant declared today that the announcement of plans for a union between Egypt, Syria and Libya had confirmed him in his conviction that now is the last chance for peace in the Middle East.

title: Dodger Rally Beats Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, April 19 (AP) Billy Grabarkewitz doubled home two runs in the eighth inning tonight with his first hit of the season as the Los An geles Dodgers defeated the San Diego Padres, 32. It was San Diego's sixth straight loss.

title: Market Place: How the Funds Look at A.T.&T.
description: Years ago American Tele phone and Telegraph was a favorite of the mutual funds. Then the funds became disil lusioned.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT HITS 814,000 IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) The Government announced today Britain's worst April un employment figures in 31 years, strengthening fears that one million people could be jobless by Christmas.

title: U.S. SELLING ISRAEL 12 MORE F4 JETS; WEIGHS NEW BID
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The United States is delivering 12 more Phantom fighterbomb ers to Israel and is considering a request for more, according to Administration officials.

title: Stage: Yerma Now Playing in English
description: It should surprise no one familiar with the Greenwich Mews Spanish Theater that the city's only yearround bi lingual acting company has done right by Yerma in an Englishlanguage version. Even to come close to the passion, poetry and economic structural drive of the great Garcia Lorca's text is no mean feat. See what this excellent unit has done at its attractive, downtown lair, 141 West 13th Street.

title: Sudanese Pledge Reported
description: CAIRO, April 19President Gaafar elNimeiry was reported today to have pledged that the Sudan would ultimately join the Federation of Arab Repub lics. A dispatch from Khartoum by Egypt's Middle East News Agency quoted General Nimeiry as having said that the Sudan must prepare a new constitu tion and build a strong political organization before joining the federation.

title: Shift in Friendship Seen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 19 The Mirage issue, which led to the revival of French influ ence in the Arab world under Charles de Gaulle in the wake of the 1967 ArabIsraeli war, may now cause the opposite effect, observers here felt.

title: Liberals in Mills Committee Prepare to Push for a Higher Federal Investment in Welfare Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 Liberals in the House, backed by a broad range of national organizations, will move within the next week to increase the Federal investment in the wel fare reform bill now scheduled for floor action next month.

title: California Ratifies
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 19 (AP)California today be came the 20th state to ratify an amendment to the United States Constitution extending to persons aged 18 through 20 the vote in state and local elec tions as well as on Federal ballots.

title: Industry Capacity Use Up Slightly in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The nation's manufacturing industries operated on the average at a slightly higher percentage of capacity in the first quarter than in the final quarter of 1970, the Federal Reserve Board reported to day.

title: Gabriel Rubino, a Lawyer Here Since '13, Dies at 81
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., April 19Gabriel Rubino, a Manhat tan lawyer since 1913, died to day at his home, 50 Nanna hagan Road, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Pollution Isn't THAT Serious
description: BALTIMOREToday, air pollution endangers our health. Tomorrow it may endanger our survivalor so we are often told during Earth Week. A few of the sternest ecological prophets are measuring the life expectancy of the human race in decades. Air pollu tion, they caution, may make this gen eration of Americans the last.

title: Arabs Fidgeting Less With Their Worry Beads
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Worry beads, the small strings of beads that Arabs have long loved to fidget with, are showing signs of going out of style.

title: STUDENTS PRODUCE A SPIRITED RAVEL
description: L'Enfant et les Sortilges, said Maurice Ravel. was writ ten in the spirit of an American operetta. It received just that type of carefree, zestful per formance during the weekend by the 150 children (8 to 18 years old) of the Manhattan School of Music's Preparatory Division, with the assistance of some of the older student col leagues at the college itself.

title: $14Million Project Planned By Japan on Electric Cars
description: TOKYO, April 19 (UPI) The Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today a $14million project to develop five types of electric cars to help reduce air pollu tion in large Japanese cities.

title: JOSEPH L. SMITH, 79, 28 YEARS ON BENCH
description: RUMSON, N.J., April 19 Joseph L. Smith, who retired as a Superior Court Judge in 1961 after 28 years on the bench, died yesterday at his home, 65 West River Road. He was 79 years old.

title: AN ELECTRIC TRUCK DISPLAYED AT SHOW
description: A prototype of an electrically operated pickup truck is one of the principal exhibits on dis play at the Design Engineering Show that opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum.

title: Phone Call Record Of Boggs Reported Under Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 The Justice Department sub poenaed the longdistance tele phone records of Representa tive Hale Boggs of Louisiana the House Democratic floor leader, reliable sources said to night.

title: Fighting in East Reported
description: NEW DELHI, April 19 (Reu ters)Heavy fighting was re ported today in several areas of East Pakistan where the Pakistani Army was said to be pressing an allout offensive to seal off the province's borders.

title: Taft Institute Honors Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) President Nixon received to day the first Citizenship Edu cational Medal of the Robert A. Taft Institute of Government in recognition of his influence and contributions to American poli tics. The institute, set up nine years ago as a tribute to the late Republican Senator from Ohio, is a bipartisan foundation that promotes seminars on gov ernment to help prepare young people for participation in politics.

title: Ottawa Closes Prison
description: OTTAWA, April 19 (UPI) The Government announced to day that it had ordered riot wrecked Kingston Penitentiary closed and a formal inquiry begun into a fourday rebellion there in which a prisoner was killed.

title: Standard Poodle Triumphs
description: CRANSTON, R. I., April 19 A white standard poodle, Alekai Alie of Stonebridge, owned by Janet Abrahams of Meriden, Conn., was named best of 1,436 dogs yesterday at the 66th show of the Rhode Island Kennel Club.

title: Eckert Rites on Friday
description: A funeral service for Gen. William Eckert, former base ball commissioner, will be held Friday at Fort Myers Chapel in Virginia. Burial will be in Arling ton Cemetery, a spokesman in the commissioner's office said yesterday.

title: G.I.'s in Ashau Valley: A Long, Bitter History
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 19There are times when, as a young officer put it, the war in South Vietnam resembles an old film running backward.

title: HANS POPPER
description: Hans Popper, an art collector, philanthropist and businessman, died in San Francisco April 12 at the age of 66. He was found er and president of the Western Steel and Metal Corporation.

title: LON NOL RESIGNS, BLAMING HEALTH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tues day, April 20Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol resigned today as Premier of Cambodia. The general, who is 57 years old, cited health rea sons in a letter to the Head of State, Cheng Heng.

title: The Wolf Cry Is Real
description: Rising costs and declining revenues in a paradoxical period of inflation and recession have had a clearly adverse impact on New York City's budget. The pressures of skyrocketing payroll and welfare costs, coupled with cutbacks in expected state and Federal assistance, create an acute fiscal crisis for the city. It confronts a budg etary deficit of perhaps $300 million in this fiscal year and a deficit of perhaps three times this size in the year beginning July 1.

title: The Electoral Option in Vietnam: II
description: WASHINGTONIt is difficult for an American to secondguess an elec tion in the United States, All the more so when he tries to predict one abroad. But, based on what one can glean from the mood of the South Vietnamese in the 1967 election and what one can divine of their present mood, a conse quential, nonCommunist, propeace opponent to President Thieu might have at least an even chance.

title: BOHACK STORES HERE CLOSED BY A STRIKE
description: Most of the 175 Bohack supermarkets in New York City and in Westchester County were closed yesterday by a strike of members of Local 1500 of the Retail Food Clerks Union.

title: City Job and Budget Cuts
description: The following chart indicates the number of jobs eliminated, and the size of the agency budget, for the coming fiscal year, under four options presented by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Tudor Reward Wins as Pimlico Opens
description: BALTIMORE, April 19Tudor Reward swung to the outside when blocked on the last turn and got up in the final strides for a nose victory today in the $29,250 Riggs Handicap as Pimlico opened its 30day spring meeting.

title: Jersey College Blacked Out
description: UNION, N. J., April 19 A power failure at Newark State College here today closed classes and caused postpone ment of an Earth Week pro gram until the week of May 16. Classes will resume tomorrow night. The college, which was built in 1958 for 1,100 students, has 4,000 day and 8,000 night students. A college spokesman said the blackout apparently resulted from an overloading of wiring and transformers.

title: ISRAEL GIVES U.S. PROPOSAL ON SUEZ
description: JERUSALEM, April 19Is rael gave the United States her longawaited ideas and propos als today for achieving an in terim arrangement with Egypt to permit the reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Tornadoes Rip Texas Panhandle
description: HEREFORD, Tex., April 19 (UPI)A tornado cut a seven  mile trail through Hereford early today, injur ing 40 persons and causing $2million in damage. No deaths were reported.

title: Old Shell Kills 9 in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW, April 19 (UP1) Nine children were killed and four injured Thursday near Kharkov by the explosion of a World War  artillery shell that they found during a school recess, according to an official report that reached Moscow today from the Ukraine.

title: CARNEGIE KILT BAND GIVES PROGRAM HERE
description: The CarnegieMellon Univer sity Kiltie Band was on hand in Carnegie Hall Sunday night for its fifth annual New York concert. This is a remarkable virtuoso assembly of 100 stu dent musicians, and if their program was designed more to show off the band's capabilities than to present an evening of musical sustenance, few would have complained in the face of such impressive playing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Jones Win Net Final
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 19 (AP)Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of Britain earned $9,000 yester day by defeating Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., 75, 64, in the final of the $30,000 Caesar's Palace World Tennis championships. Mrs. King, who got $4,800, had won the previous six tournaments on the tour.

title: Executive Changes
description: Swift & Co. announced yesterday in Chicago the creation of a director of public responsibility to rec ommend policy and over see activity in consumer, nutrition and environ mental affairs. Named to the new post was Law rence E. Klinger, 41 years old, who has been senior administrative assistant to the executive vice presi dent, chemicals and indus trial products group. Mr. Klinger joined the diversi fied corporation with ma jor interests in food, chem icals, insurance and petro leum, in 1952 as a research chemist, and has held va rious managerial positions over the years. Robert W. Reneker, president, said that, in the new post, the director's responsibility will encompass our entire range of business. We be lieve that the coordination of these activities at the corporate level will increase the overall effectiveness of what is being accomplished throughout Swift.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SWISS SAYS HE SOLD JET PLANS TO ISRAEL
description: GENEVA, April 19A Swiss engineer admitted today that Israel had paid him nearly $200,000 for blueprints of an engine used in the French Mi rage jet fighter.

title: Legislators Seek to Cut Speno Funds
description: ALBANY, April 19Sponsors of a bill that would have nearly tripled the late State Senator Edward J. Speno's death bene fits prepared today to amend it to reduce the death payment by $135,285 to about $80,000.

title: Jane Russell to Star As Joanne in Company
description: Jane Russell, the film star, will make her Broadway de but in the role of Joanne in the Harold Prince musical, Company, on May 10, suc ceeding Elaine Stritch.

title: Mayor's Budget Options
description: The following are highlights of Mayor Lindsay's de scription of the impact on the city of four budgetary options:

title: Albee Play May Close
description: Edward Albee's latest play, All Over, will end its run at the Martin Beck Theater on May 1 after its 42d perform ance unless business im proves, it was announced yesterday.

title: Local Production Company Set Up as BlackOriented
description: The formation of a black, locallybased film, television and play production organiza tion, the Toussaint Group, Inc., was announced yesterday by Gordon Watkins, president, and Perry Watkins and Kenny Fun dus, vice presidents.

title: Fire Hits Cherokee Forest
description: NASHVILLE, April 19 (AP) A portion of Cherokee National Forest in southeast Tennessee was closed to the public early today after more than 38 fires were reported in one 72hour period.

title: LAURA B. BLACKBURN
description: Laura Browning Blackburn, an administrative assistant in ad vertising operations at News week magazine, died of cancer Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 37 years old and lived at 896 First Avenue.

title: Pope Exhorts Hairdressers
description: ROME, April 19 (AP)Pope Paul  exhorted 600 hair dressers today to work with so briety because their art affected morals. He called on the hair dressers, who are attending a convention here, to serve healthy beauty with authentic and sober art, facilitating self respect and respect of one's neighbor.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 20, 1971

title: Ottinger Asks Phone Customers To Hold Back Part of Payment
description: Former Representative Rich ard L. Ottinger opened a cam paign yesterday that would in volve New Yorkers in with holding a portion of their pay ments to the New York Tele phone Company until service is upgraded.

title: Reds Defeat Mets by 32 On Bench's Homer in 8th
description: CINCINNATI, April 21  It was just another typical eve ning in the young life of John ny Bench, Most Valuable Play er: Two excellent throws from his catcher position and a gamewinning homer in the eighth inning.

title: Magnavox Signs Order That Bars PriceFixing
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) The Magnavox Company has signed an order barring it from fixing prices and terminating dealers that sold Magnavox products at cut rates, the Fed eral Trade Commission an nounced today.

title: SovietJapanese Issue: Do Crabs Swim?
description: TOKYO, April 20Premier Eisaku Sato sent a represent ative to Moscow today in an effort to break the deadlock in negotiations over fishing rights between the Soviet Union and Japan.

title: China Envoy in Rome
description: ROME, April 20 (Reuters) Sheng Ping, China's first Ambassador to Italy since the Communists came to power in Peking in 1949, presented his credentials to President Giuseppe Saragat today. Italy and China established diplo matic relations Nov. 6.

title: Up With People Tonight
description: Up With People, a musical show performed by young peo ple who pursue academic stud ies while touring, will be given three times at Philharmonic Hall beginning tonight with a benefit performance. The other performances will be tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and Friday at 8:30 P.M. Sponsors for the perform ances include Senator Jacob K. Javits, Sargent Shriver and Su perintendent of Schools Harvey B. Scribner.

title: CRIME FIGURE HELD FOR CONTEMPT HERE
description: Morris Barra, a reputed mem ber of the organized crime fam ily once run by the late Vito Genovese, pleaded guilty yes terday in State Supreme Court, the Bronx, to a charge of crim inal contempt.

title: Dance: Feld's Romance
description: Spring is hereor at least it was here, just like Kilroy and Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company is back at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where last night it opened a threeweek season. Mr. Feld's company, young, ardent and forceful, is a joy to watch. They are dancers who always endearingly per form to the very tip of their expectation, and as a result they are both exciting and fun to watch earlier ballet Intermezzo. Here he has varied the duet structure with the occasional ensemble, as in the earlier ballet, but also with trios and quartets.

title: Roundup: Aaron's 598th Home Run Helps Braves Top Pirates, 20
description: When Hank Aaron reached his 36th birthday last Febru ary baseball's prognostica tors differed on his chances of surpassing Ham Ruth's record of 714 home runs.

title: WASHINGTON
description: Vice President Agnew is in trouble againthis time for differing with President Nixon on Chinaand people keep asking how he manages to do it. The explanation is really fairly simple: he's an amiable man who says about what he thinks.

title: For Urban Dwellers, the Pakistani Tent
description: Shop Talk

title: KAHANE IS ARRESTED IN PROTEST ON IRAQ
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane and nine of his young supporters in tbe militant Jewish Defense League were arrested last night in demonstration outside the Iraqi mission to the United Nations on 79th Street near Fifth Av enue.

title: MERVIN HUTTON, 41, JERSEY CONDUCTOR
description: VIENNA, April 20 (AP) Mervin Hutton died of heart failure Monday night just after conducting for the ballet Deadly Sins Theater an der Wien. He was 41 years old, and lived in Burlington, N. J.

title: Appeal by Western Union
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday asked the Federal Communications Com mission to reconsider its recent ruling prohibiting common car riers from purchasing data services from affiliated data processing companies

title: CANADIENS ROUT NORTH STARS, 72
description: MONTREAL, April 20 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire scored three goals and Marc Tardif two for the Montreal Canadiens tonight as the Canadiens took the first game of the National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinal series from the Minnesota North Stars, 72.

title: Yiddish Group Benefit Set
description: The Yiddish Theatrical Alli ance will give it s annual per formance for its relief fund on May 16, at 2 P.M., at Carnegie Hall. Performers from the Y?? dish and Broadway stage, tele vision and opera will parlici pate.

title: Bank of New York Agrees to L.I. Link
description: Merger News

title: Psychiatrist Finds Sams Can Testify at Seale Panther Trial
description: NEW HAVEN, April 20  George Sams Jr., the prosecu tion's star witness against Bobby G. Seale, was described by a courtappointed psychia trist today as competent to tes tify in the SealeHuggins trial.

title: Union Pacific Tender Plan
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) The Union Pacific Corporation and the Union Pacific Railroad said today they were working on a plan by which the holding company would require the shares of the railroad remaining in the bands of the public through a tender offer to be made through smith Barney & Co.

title: Madison Avenue a Magic Promenade as Night Falls
description: Mayor Lindsay officiated last night at the opening of this spring's first weekly Madi son Avenue Magic Promenade. He arrived 25 minutes late at 61st Street and Madison Ave nue for the ceremony.

title: Manuscript Could Change Views on Mayans' Religion
description: An 11page fragment of calendar book that is expect ed to throw new light on the religion and astrological phi losophy of the ancient Mayan culture of Mexico and Cen tral America will be publicly disclosed here today for the first time.

title: Harter Quits Penn To Become Coach Of Oregon Quintet
description: Dick Harter, who coached Pennsylvania's basketball team to Ivy League titles and Na tional Collegiate tournament berths this year and in 1970 resigned yesterday to become coach at Oregon, where the going might be more difficult.

title: Susan Fischer Wed To Dennis A. Allred
description: Miss Susan Fischer and Dennis Alan Allred were married Monday in Rio de Janeiro. District Judge Re nato Tonini performed the civil ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Al bertal, friends of the couple.

title: Wallace Not Surprised
description: The Supreme Court's rulings were denounced as tragic and discriminatory yesterday by some Southerners.

title: Charred Remains of a Man Thought to Be Panther Found
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., April 20 (UPI)The charred, scattered remains of a man believed to be a Black Panther party captain, Fred Bennett, was found at a remote revolutionary bomb fac tory near this coastal commu nity, officiials disclosed today.

title: Holders of Merrill Lynch Approve Plan to Go Public
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., announced yes terday that its shareholders had overwhelmingly approved proposal for the concern to be come a public corporation through a public stock offering.

title: Key Features of Banking Reform Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The heads of two Federal regulatory agencies took excep tion today to major provisions of a mammoth bank reform bill as the House Banking Commit tee opened hearings.

title: Theater: On the Other Hand, Why Buss the Critic
description: Maxine Klein has written a show about a word. The word is kiss, the show is Kiss Now, and it opened last night at the Martinique Theater.

title: Mine Kills Three Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, April 20 (Reuters) Three Israeli Army officers were killed and four soldiers were wounded when a mine blew up their vehicle on a dirt track near Beit Govrin today, a military spokesman said.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MASERU, LesothoThis little Afri can country, formerly Britain's pro tectorate of Basutoland, has been independent for five years. It bears the same relationship to the South African Republic as San Marino does to Italy, being entirely surrounded and thus vulnerable to isolation from the outer world at the whim of another government.

title: A.P. ELECTS MILLER AS CHIEF 10TH TIME
description: Paul Miller, chairman and chief executive officer of the Gannett Company, was elected yesterday to his 10th consecu tive oneyear term as president of The Associated Press.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Separate Those Powers
description: The average American still tends to assume that when Congress appropriates a sum of money for a particular program or project and the President fails to veto it, precisely that sum of money will be spent in the allotted time. Few assumptions are less warranted; as a result, a political confrontation between the executive and legisla tive branches of government is not far in the offing.

title: Executive Changes
description: The BASF Wyandotte Corporation, the Amer ican member of the multinational BASF Group of Germany, announced yesterday the election of Robert B. Semple as chairman and Dieter H. Ambros as president Mr. Semple had served as president and Mr Ambros as executive vice president of the chemical company which has sales in the area $225million.

title: RUSSIANS ARE SILENT ON NEW SPACE SHOT
description: MOSCOW, April 20The So viet Union maintained a puz zling daylong silence today on progress of its latest space ef fort, the unmanned research station Salyut, which is orbit ing the earth.

title: Missing U.P.I. Correspondent Is Reported Dead in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 20 (UPI)A body believed o be that of Catherine M. Webb, the United Press International bu reau manager in Pnompenh has been found in southwestern Cambodia, where she disap appeared April 7.

title: AGRICULTURE SALUTE IS PLANNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 President Nixon announced to day that he would confer with farm leaders on domestic and foreign issues on May 7 as a Salute to Agriculture Day.

title: 400 Delegates to Youth Conference Give Top Priority to People's Peace Treaty to End Vietnam War
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 20  The biggest unofficial meeting so far at the White House Conference on Youth has listed the people's peace treaty to end the war in Viet nam as its highest priority.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 20, 1971

title: Soviet Is Hailed as Bulgarian Reds Meet
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 20 With praise for the Soviet Union, rather moderate attacks on both the United States and Communist China and promises of a better life for this coun try's 8.5 million citizens, the Bulgarian Communist leader opened his party's 10th congress here today.

title: How Not to Economize
description: Having amply demonstrated how not to make a budget by ramming wrongheaded budget bills through in the middle of the night, Republicans in control of the state's governmental machinery at Albany are now demonstrat ing how not to achieve economies. They are making cuts across the board, without regard for priorities.

title: Creek Chiefs, on Date of Coup, Tell of Objectives for Fifth Year
description: ATHENS, April 21Greek leaders, celebrating their fourth year in power, out lined tonight what they called their chief goals.

title: RCA TO MAKE GLASS FOR PICTURE TUBES
description: CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio, April 20 The RCA Corporation Made its formal entry into the glass business here today. Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and presi dent, told a gathering of about 200 persons that this made his company the first and only domestic television picturetube manufacturer in the glass busi ness.

title: Rangers Lose; Series Tied, 11
description: CHICAGO, April 20The Rangers, those demon playoff performers, are only human. After four straight victories in Stanley Cup play, they bowed tonight to the Black Hawks, 30.

title: Big A Percentage Players Have Pointless Day
description: Any jockey who can win, with 28 per cent of his mounts is worth a bet, so the per centage players went for Brau lio Baeza yesterday at Aque duct.

title: McGee Offers Timber Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Legislation to ban clear cut ting of forest trees on Federal land for two years was intro duced today by Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyo ming. His bill also called for establishing a commission to investigate the practice of clear cutting, under which virtually the entire stock of timber is removed from a designatedi area for commercial purposes.

title: Bronx Man Seized As HitRun Driver In a Police Death
description: A 24yearold Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with criminally negli gent homicide in the hitand run killing of an offduty patrolman last Feb. 27.

title: MERGER APPROVED BY STEEL UNION
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The United Steelworkers of America agreed at its Pitts burgh headquarters today to absorb by a merger District 50, Allied and Technical Trades the independent, 200,000mem ber conglomerate union that has been a center of controversy in recent years.

title: Goodell Says He Will Run Against Nixon in Primary
description: NEW HAVEN, April 20 (AP) Former Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York said here tonight he would challenge President Nixon for the Repub lican Presidential nomination in 1972 if Mr. Nixon's policies on Vietnam did not change.

title: Hearings on El Paso Gas Case End Without a Decision on Bill
description: SEATTLE, April 20  Sena tor Warren Magnuson ended today two days of hearings into the El Paso Natural Gas Company antitrust divestiture matter without coming closer to a resolution of the political and legislative problem that encircles him.

title: A Version of Hippocratic Oath Adopted for Soviet Physicians
description: MOSCOW, April 20The So viet Union has adopted its own version of the Hippocratic oath for physicians, to take effect with next June's graduating class of the medical schools.

title: John Galloway Jr. Dies in Crash; State Supreme Court Justice, 64
description: State Supreme Court Justice John H. Galloway Jr. was killed Monday night in a singlecar accident on the Bruckner Ex pressway in the Bronx. A pas senger in his car, John V. Hig gins of 168 Ellison Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y., was treated at the Bronx Municipal Hospi tal Center, where his condition was reported as satisfactory yesterday.

title: Pakistan Demands India Oust Diplomats
description: NEW DELHI, April 20 (UPI) Pakistan demanded today that India oust dissident East Pakis tani diplomats who seized the Pakistani deputy high commis sion, or consulate, in Calcutta on Sunday.

title: MRS. ISRAEL KAPLAN
description: Mrs. Jennie Kaplan, widow and former partner of Israel Kaplan, owner of Kaplan's Cloaks and Suits in the Bronx, died yesterday at Einstein Hos pital. She was 88 years old and lived at 3400 Fenton Ave nue, the Bronx.

title: PANEL'S PAY PLAN DISCLOSED BY CITY
description: The City Office of Collective Bargaining made public yester day the recommendations of a special impasse panel in the fire, police and sanitation con tract disputes.

title: Senate Holds Session in Kingston, Its 1777 Birthplace
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., April 20 Amidst turmoil with the British, the state's first Con stitution was approved in this gracious Hudson Valley city 194 years ago today, and New York's government was born.

title: A Masked Toughness
description: To her friends, Kate Webb she detested being called Cath erinewas softvoiced, friendly and gentle, qualities that masked her reporter's tough ness. To those who did not know her, she appeared as a waif, plodding the Saigon streets in a striped dress and sandals, her feet almost as dirty as the sidewalks.

title: Joseph M. Wohl, 61, Aide For Cinerama Sales Abroad
description: Joseph M. Wohl, vice presi dent of foreign sales for Cin erama, Inc., died yesterday at his home, 200 Central Park South. He was 61 years old.

title: Shareholders Get News
description: Stuart K. Hensley, chairman of the board of WarnerLam bert, opened the annual stock holders meeting yesterday with the news of the Federal Trade Commission's antitrust investi gation, which he had received two hours before.

title: Vermont Legislature Votes Aid for Parochial Schools
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., April 20 (AP)The Vermont legislature passed today a precedentset ting bill for aid to parochial schools. Shortly afterward the lawmakers adjourned the 1971 session.

title: SHARES ON AMEX LOWER AT CLOSE
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in its worst per formance in almost two months yesterday as the list declined on moderate trading.

title: Estes Again Seeks Parole From 15Year Prison Term
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Billie Sol Estes, the onetime outstanding young American whose fictional fertilizer tanks earned him paper millions and a 15year prison term, is mak ing his second bid for parole.

title: Phone Protesters Warned They Face A Service Cutoff
description: The New York Telephone Company warned yesterday that it would be required un der law to terminate the serv ices of subscribers who might follow the advice of former Representative Richard L. Ot tinger to withhold partial pay ment of bills to get better service.

title: Newark School Board's Chief Orders 100 Teachers Shifted
description: NEWARK, April 20  The president of the Newark Board of Education, Jesse L. Jacob, ordered 100 teachers who had been on strike transferred to day after parents groups, for the second day protested their return to classes.

title: Books of The Times
description: BEING THERE. By Jerzy Kosinski. 142 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich $4.95.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ALBANY, April 20A bill that would give a natural moth. er 30 days to decide whether to go through with adoption was approved today by the State Assembly. The measure, sponsored by Joseph It Pisani, Westchester Republican, was sent to the Senate.

title: Tardy Kennedys Upset Germans
