description: BONN, April 20  Your Teddy Kennedy is a rube, a senior protocol officer of the Bonn Government said recently to an American ac quaintance. The word he used means turnip in Ger man, but it is also the slang equivalent of rapscallion. He did not mean it kindly.

title: Bridge: Even Experts Need Someone To Listen to HardLuck Tales
description: There is considerable evi dence to support the conten tion that most husbands would be well advised to avoid playing bridge with their wives. But it does not follow that an expert is bet ter off with a nonplaying wife: He needs a sympathetic and understanding ear into which to relate the injustices he has suffered at the hands of his opponents, his part ners and the fates.

title: Bomb Threat Halts Jet
description: LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) An anonymous telephone bomb threat forced a United Airlines Super DC8 jet with 66 passengers and a crew of seven aboard to return to Los Angeles International Airport early to day shortly after it took off for Chicago. The police said the plane and all luggage it was carrying had been searched but no bomb hart been found. The plane took off again a short time later, the police said.

title: Senators Open Hearing on Ending War
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Before an applauding audience of veterans of the Vietnam war, the Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee opened hear ings today on how to end the war.

title: AP Reporter Expelled
description: COLOMBO, April 20 (Reuters) The Ministry of Information and Broadcasting said today that Mort Rosenblum, a cor respondent of The Associated Press, had been asked to leave Ceylon for sending false re ports about the situation in the country. [The foregoing Asso ciated Press dispatch from Co lombo was filed by Mr. Rosen blum.]

title: Eurodollar Refinancing Set By the ExportImport Bank
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The ExportImport Bank an nounced today that it would re finance the $1billion short term Eurodollar borrowing it undertook in January. The new issue will be for three months at 6 per cent interest. Subscrip tions will be open until Thurs day, with payment due next Monday.

title: Police Shift Tactics To Curb Heroin Sale
description: Major changes in police methods to prevent the use and sale of heroin here were an nounced yesterday by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: House Subpoena Is Rejected by C. B. S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Columbia Broadcasting System refused today to com ply with a House subcommittee subpoena demanding that the network furnish the subcom mittee with all materials gath ered for its controversial pro gram The Selling of the Penta gon.

title: CHANGE FORESEEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The unanimous decision on school desegregation handed down today by the Supreme Court means that most South ern cities will have to increase classroom integration greatly in the opinion of lawyers who have sought disestablishment of the dual system.

title: U.S. AND CANADA SIGN A SATELLITE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  The United States and Canada signed today an agree ment for the first cooperative international communications technology satellite, forerunner of a spacecraft that may some day provide vastly improved communications for Alaska and isolated northern areas of Cana da.

title: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY ISRAELI MOVE ON OPENING CANAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The State Department said to day that Israel's new proposals on reopening the Suez Canal had cleared the way for further negotiations on an interim peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Firm on Guarantees
description: LONDON, April 20Prime Minister Edward Heath reaf firmed today his government's insistence on guarantees con cerning the future of the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation's Tri star airbus before proceeding with the Rolls engine to power the plane.

title: PHONE RATE RISE IS CUT $16MILLION
description: ALBANY, April 20The Ap pellate Division today reversed a lower court order that had given the New York Telephone Company an annual rate in crease of nearly $16million more than the amount approved by the Public Service Commis sion, and ordered the company to refund the money to its cus tomers.

title: Yarbrough Joins Dan Gurney Team In Trentonian 200
description: About Motor Sports

title: NIXON DEFERRING AN INFLATION REIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 A high Administration eco nomic official indicated today that President Nixon, is as far away as ever from establishing a wageprice review board or guidelines to try to speed progress against inflation.

title: Additional Times Shares Voted by Stockholders
description: Shareholders of The New York Times yesterday voted at the annual meeting at Town Hall, to reserve an additional 500,000 shares of the company's Class A common stock for em ploye purchase, and an added 150,000 shares for stockoption issuance.

title: BURGER PROHIBITS CAMPING ON MALL
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger late today reinstated a district court ban against overnight camping on the Mall by Viet nam veterans demonstrating for an end to the war.

title: Appeal Raises Chance a Missing Attica Inmate May Have Been Slain in Prison
description: ALBANY, April 20An at torney for Joseph J. Sullivan, who has disappeared from the Attica Correctional Facility, raised the possibility here to day that he might have been murdered in the maximumse curity prison.

title: MRS. FRANK A. BLAIR
description: WEEHAWKEN, N. J., April 20Mrs. Lucy Knies Blair, the widow of Frank A. Blair, an employe of The New York Times, died here Sunday at the age of 75. She was the mother of Kenneth Blair, assistant com posing room foreman at The Times on the night shift.

title: GUARDS CLEARED IN TOMBS STUDY
description: A Federal Investigation into an inmate's death in the Tombs last year has concluded that there is no factual basis to support a finding of miscon duct against prison guards.

title: LIQUIDATION VOTED FOR MILL FACTORS
description: The stockholders of the Mill Factors Corporation voted yes terday to sell the remaining as sets of the insolvent finance company to James Talcott, Inc., a leading commercial finance concern, and then liquidate their company.

title: BIG BOARD IS SUED BY DALLAS BROKER
description: DALLAS, April 20A Dallas broker has sued the New York Stock Exchange, management of the exchange and a group of member firms charging that they broke the antitrust laws by restraining the trade of listed shares off the exchange floor.

title: Publishers to Mount Campaign On Understanding of Free Press
description: The nation's newspaper pub lishers announced plans yester day for a campaign to streng then public understanding of a free press and to develop thinking and informed read ers.

title: Jersey Rail Certificates
description: Robert D. Timpany, the trus tee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, yesterday signed with the Marine Midland Bank here for $6million of Govern mentguaranteed trustee certifi cates for the bankrupt railroad.

title: ASSEMBLY SAYS NO TO L.I. SOUND SPAN
description: ALBANY, April 20A bill denying the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority the power to build a bridge across Long Island Sound between Oyster Bay and Rye was approved to day by the State Assembly.

title: Defending Big Business
description: Individuals and agencies have competedsometimes blindlyto be on the crest of the wave of consumer protection. In the 1960's, consumer legislation came into political vogue. Much of this was necessary, and serves our society well. Yet the shortterm political advantage offered by spectacular but unsound consumer legislation can do lasting damage to the very consumers it purports to help.

title: Whyte's, on Fulton St., Closes Its Doors
description: Whyte's restaurant, a fi nancialdistrict landmark for 66 years has shut its doors.

title: An Internal Matter?
description: Washington is following a dangerously shortsighted policy in continuing to insist that the Pakistani military government's slaughter of democratically elected leaders and repression of the majority of its population in East Pakistan is strictly an internal matter. Although the army appears to have the Bengali uprising under control for the moment, the bloodbath in Bangla Desh has immediate and longrun implications that the world community cannot afford to ignore.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, April 20 (Reuters) Soviet scientists gave the remotecontrolled Lunokhod moon rover a final check today before night set in on the moon.

title: Penn Central Drops Plan
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 Trustees of the Penn Central Company said in Federal Dis trict Court today, that they had dropped a plan to issue $15 million worth of trustees' cer tificates to help finance the line's entry into the new Na tional Railroad Passenger Cor poration.

title: Dollars vs. Gold
description: Economic Analysis

title: SENATORS SUBDUE YANKEES BY 72; HOWARD CONNECTS
description: Frank Howard and Tim Cul len hit home runs as the Wash ington Senators whipped the Yankees, 72, yesterday, but only Cullen received a post game telephone call from Washington.

title: State Motto Case Continued
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 20 (UPI)The case against a rabbi charged with placing black tape over part of the state motto, Live Free or Die on his New Hampshire license plates was continued indefinitely in district court here yesterday. Rabbi Ra fael Sonnenfield, 35 years old, of Concord, was accused of tap ing over the words or Die on the plates. No reason was given for the continuance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRISON RIOT INQUIRY ORDERED BY OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, April 20 (UPI) The Government has ordered a formal inquiry into the fourday riot at Kingston Penitentiary that left one inmate dead and 11 wounded before it ended abruptly Sunday.

title: ROBERT E. PEACH, AIRLINE OFFICIAL
description: UTICA, N. Y., April 20 (AP) Robert E. Peach, one of the first pilots for Mohawk Air lines, who rose in nine years to become its president in 1954, was found dead of selfinflicted gunshot wounds of the head today. Oneida County Coroner Preston R. Clark issued a ver dict of suicide.

title: STATE TRIES PLAN ON DRUNK DRIVERS
description: A new program that will give a person convicted of drunken driving the option of attending a rehabilitation class instead of losing his license will be tried in, Westchester County and in Buffalo and Syracuse, starting next Sep tember.

title: Broadcast Group Names Cronkite Man of the Year
description: Walter Cronkite has been named broadcaster of the year by the International Radio and Television Society.

title: Gains Registered By Copper Futures; Soybean Advance
description: Copper futures prices rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here in moderately heavy trading on no particular ly bullish news.

title: Wife of Suspect in Holdup At Fort Hamilton Is Seized
description: The wife of a suspect in last week's $405,000 robbery of a bank on the Army base at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, was held in $100,000 bail yesterday, charged with being an acces sory after the fact.

title: Advertising:
description: The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, not about to sit silently by while TV claims to be the nation's No. 1 source of news, com missioned a study of its own. Needless to say things came out pretty well, or you prob ably wouldn't be hearing about it.

title: AGNEWNIXON RIFT ON CHINA IS DENIED
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The White House moved quick ly today to mute public discus sion of an apparent private dis agreement between President Nixon and Vice President Ag new over the Administration's liberalized policy on China.

title: Epstein Conducts M.I.T. Symphony
description: Shades of Leonardo! There is a new Renaissance in the making. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology Sym phony Orchestra played at Carnegie Hall Monday night, and it was hard to tell the engineers, physicists, chem ists or whatever, from the musicians, everyone having played so well. It was a con cert that would have been a credit to a professional or chestra.

title: JUDGE STAYS ORDER TO RETURN BABY GIRL
description: A Brooklyn couple temporar ily retained custody of their adopted baby girl, Lenore, un der a ruling yesterday by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Fed eral Court here.

title: White Mayor Winner in Racially Divided Cairo, Ill.
description: CAIRO, III., April 20 (UPI) The White Mayor of this ra cially divided city won another term today by a majority of nearly four to one.

title: Modern Museum Sets Brakhage Film Show
description: A retrospective showing of all of the films made by Stan Brakhage will begin tomor row and continue through May 5 at the Museum of Modern Art. Mr. Brakhage, one of the leading experi mental moviemakers, will be represented by 35 films he has created since 1952.

title: Borges Accepts Book Prize, Gives Advice in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, April 20Jorge Luis Borges, the grand old man of Argentine letters, accepted the Jerusalem Book Prize last night with some gentle advice to writers  avoid politicizing literature lest you muffle the divine whispering of the muse.

title: Javits Accused by Ribicoff Of Hypocrisy on Schools
description: WASNINGTON, April 20Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff charged Senator Jacob K. Javits today with hypocrisy for being unwilling to accept desegregation for his state, though he is willing to shove it down the throats of the Senators from Mississippi.

title: PHONE ISSUE TOPS ACTIVITY IN BONDS
description: Investors responded enthusi astically to a huge Bell Tele phone offering yesterday and braked the skidding corporate, bond market.

title: The Army Decides Its Married Women Can Have Children
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Army is going to allow its female officers and enlisted women to have children.

title: P.S.C. WARNS CITY ON CURBING CON ED
description: ALBANY, April 20The Pub lic Service Commission today warned the state and local gov ernments, including New York City, that antipollution meas ures directed at utilities could result in utility rate increases or a reduction of electrical gen erating capacities.

title: Largest Tanker Launched
description: KURE, Japan, April 20 (Reu ters)The world's largest tank er, the 372,400ton Nisseki Maru, was launched here today. The owners, the Tokyo Tanker Com pany, said the $26.4million tanker would make 10 trips a year on the JapanPersian Gulf route after completion in Sep tember.

title: Hopes Thin for the Millions Adrift Across Indochina
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20Uprooted, some times by those who are called friends and sometimes by those called enemies, millions of living victims of the war are adrift in Indochina.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N.Today
description: April 21, 1971

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court Ruling Upholding Busing to End Segregation
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's unani mous opinion, written by Chief Justice Warren E. Burg er, and issued today, on de segregation of the Charlotte Mecklenburg County, N. C., school system:

title: Kennecott Net Off 40.1%;
description: The Kennecott Copper Cor poration, the leading producer of American primary copper, announced yesterday that earn ings in the first quarter plunged 40.1 per cent compared with those of the 1970 period.

title: Heiberg Impressive in Piano Debut
description: Although the names of Beethoven, Debussy and Schumann appeared in Har old Heiberg's debut piano re cital in Tully Hall on Mon day night, the program was unusual. Neither Beethoven's Sonata in G (Op. 31, No. 1) nor Schumann's Davids bndlertnze is played much.

title: S.EC. ASKS SPEED ON BROKER DATA
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it did not get information fast enough when brokerage firms were encountering financial and operational problems and it pro posed a new rule that would re quire virtually instantaneous notification and explanation when brokers started having such problems.

title: Kilroy Named Patriots' Aide
description: BOSTON, April 20 (UPI) The New England Patriots hired today Frank (Bucko) Kilroy, a onetime lineman for the Phil adelphia Eagles and recently a scout for the Dallas Cowboys, as their new director of player personnel.

title: New Head at Sweet Briar
description: Dr, Harold Bartlett White man Jr., vice chancellor for stu dent affairs at New York Uni versity, has been appointed president of Sweet Briar (Va.) College. On July 1, he will suc ceed Dr. Anne Gary Pannell, who will retire after 21 years as the college's fifth president.

title: PECHINEYUGINE TIE FORMS FRENCH GIANT
description: PARIS, April 20  France's largest company has just been born as Pchiney and Ugine Kuhlmann decided on terms of a merger creating a new metal and chemical giant with annual sales of $3billion.

title: 12 Mayors Will Start 1Day Visit Here Today
description: Continuing their tour of major cities to focus national attention on urban problems, 12 mayors, members of the Legislative Action committee of the United Stafes Confer ence of Mayors, will begin a dayandahalfvisit her to day.

title: Con Ed Says It Will Confine Ads To Urging Power Conservation
description: The chairman of the Con solidated Edison Company, Charles F. Luce, said yester day that the utility had dis banded its sales promotion de partment and would use adver tising only to urge customers to conserve electricity. Mr. Luce said he believed it was the first such action by any utility in the nation.

title: An F.B.I. Inquiry
description: Recent disclosures concerning the Federal Bureau Investigation make clear that a Congressional review the agency's numerous and farranging activities necessary. Appropriations subcommittees perform some of this Congressional function. With regard to the F.B.I., however, these subcommittees have long since reduced themselves to the role of claques dutifully applauding for J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Advertising:
description: Today on the occasion of her birthday, Queen Eliza beth II, will bestow on Beefeater gin the Queen's Award to Industry for Export Achievement. No other gin has been so honored, but it's Beefeater's third time.

title: Market Place: Of Shareholders And Proposals
description: Perhaps the Securities and Exchange Commission ought to consider having sharehold ers post bond before they of fer proposals at annual meet ings.

title: 116 Are Arrested in Protest Over Alleged College Cuts
description: Sixteen young persons, most of them students, were arrested yesterday following a sitin at the president's office of the Borough of Manhattan Com munity College, 134 West 51st Street.

title: VOTING DISTRICTS TO BE CUT IN CITY
description: A plan for the Board of Elec tions to save $zmillion a year by reducing election districts by about 20 per cent and cut ting the number of inspectors needed for registration was ap proved yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: 3 BANK COMPANIES SEE GAINS IN PROFIT
description: Three major regional one bank holding companies pro jected higher earnings for 1971 at their annual meetings yester day.

title: U.S. Seeking a New Indictment Replacing One in Berrigan Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 20 United States Attorney Wil liam S. Lynch confirmed today the Government had renewed deliberations of the grand jury that indicted the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and five others on conspiracy charges to examine the possibility of returning a superseding indictment to replace the one originally hand ed down in January.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Harold Addelston Is Dead; Teacher of Dentistry at N.Y. U.
description: Dr. Harold Kane Addelston, chairman of the department of dentistry for children at New York University, died Monday apparently of a heart attack on the way to his office at 424 Madison Avenue. He was 62 years old and lived at 215 West 90th Street.

title: Fashions to Applaudand to Laugh At
description: PARIS, April 20For ap plauseand for laughter, too Omits Clark, the British de signer, is leading the way at the French readytowear winter collections here.

title: Chrysler Unit Bank Loans Soar
description: DETROIT, April 20  The bank borrowings of the Chrys ler Financial Corporation have soared $400million, to $831 million, since Dun & Bradstreet downrated the company's notes a month ago.

title: A British Boat Is Seized And Sunk Off Irish Coast
description: DUBLIN, April 20 (Reu ters)A visiting British Navy survey launch, the Stork, was seized during the night from its mooring in the harbor of Baltimore, near Cork, towed to sea and de stroyed with explosives, police sources said today. No one was aboard at the time. Part of the boat washed ashore later.

title: JULIUS ISRAEL
description: Julius Israel, cofounder of the Regal Knitwear Company, manufacturers of children's wear, died at his office Mon day, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South.

title: PANTHER DEFENSE BEGINS TO SUM UP
description: The first of six lawyers for 13 Black Panthers on trial in State Supreme Court here for an alleged bomb conspiracy began summing up the defense case to the jury yesterday.

title: Council Holds Up Vote for City Employes' Pensions
description: Councilmen berated the Lind say administration yesterday for the pension benefits It had negotiated with some city em ployes, then postponed ap proval of the deal, which has prompted the Legislature to delay action on pension bills.

title: TV: See Any Good Sitcoms Lately?
description: Mary Tyler Moore is sitcom.

title: Berkeley Recount Set
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 The Berkeley City Council voted today to begin a recount on Thursday of votes cast for Mayor in the hotly contested April 6 city elections.

title: V.D. Experts Warn of Fund Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 While cases of venereal disease are increasing nationally to a degree that alarms experts, the resources available to deal with this serious health problem have been decreasing, specialists said here today.

title: ORDERLY RETREAT STAGED BY STOCKS
description: The DowJones industrial average, after marching uphill for 10 trading days in a row, retreated a few steps yester day. It was a most orderly retreat.

title: SOONHEE LEE GIVES SONG RECITAL HERE
description: Some sopranos work all through their careers in hopes of developing the clear, power ful top notes that perked up ears at SoonHee Lee's song re cital on Monday night at Car negie Recital Hall. The young Koreanborn singer, a Juilliard School graduate, has one of those odd voices that do not sound free or interesting until they reach the top third or so of their compass.

title: Wilkins Sees Guidance
description: Roy Wilkins said in New York yesterday that the Su preme Court ruling gave badly needed guidance to states and cities, according to Reuters.

title: A.E.C. Lets Princeton Build Hydrogen Research Device
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 20 The United States Atomic Energy Commission hasgrant ed permission to the Plasma Physics Laboratory of Prince ton University to build a $1 million research device that will be used for studying the fusion of hydrogen isotopes.

title: Chinese Runners Invited
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., April 20 (AP)The New England Ama teur Athletic Union has invited Communist China to send ath letes to compete in the Hol yoke Marathon June 6. The or ganization's commissioner, Wal ter Childs, said here that he had mailed the invitation to Premier Chou Enlai today.

title: MENDOZA CONVICTED IN ATTACK ON POPE
description: MANILA, Wednesday, April 21 (Reuters)Benjamin Men doza y Amor, was convicted to day of attempting to kill Pope Paul VI last year at Manila International Airport.

title: Nixon Ancestor Served As a Spy in Revolution
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) The Daughters of the American Revolution have traced President Nixon's ge nealogy and discovered he had an ancestor who served in a company of spies in the Revolution.

title: CHARLIE CHIN OFFERS VARIETY OF BALLADS
description: With considerable help from his friends, Charlie Chin, gui tarist, banjoist, autoharpist and singer, presented a varied pro gram of ballads and blues Mon day evening at the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.

title: EDUCATION BOARD HEARS THE PUBLIC
description: There were firm demands, indignant complaints and angry denunciations. There were his torical references, quotes from ancient literature and shouts of Right on! There were charges of phony promises and crimi nal shakedowns in schools. And once last night someone even thanked the Board of Educa tion.

title: School District Bans a Book on East Harlem
description: A book that vividly depicts life and language in Spanish Harlem has been banned from student libraries in a predomin antly white, middleclass local school district in Queens.

title: PATROLS IN ASHAU ENTER 2D WEEK No Major Allied Clash With Foe in Valley Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 21 (AP)  Allied reconnaissance in the Ashau Valley of South Vietnam entered its second week yes terday with still no report of any significant contact with enemy troops in what has long been one of their strongholds.

title: EGYPTIANS EXPECT NEW SOVIET MOVE
description: CAIRO, April 20A new initiative by the Soviet Union to break the ArabIsraeli dead lock was forecast here today as the Egyptian Foreign Minis ter, Mahmoud Riad, ended four days of consultations in Mos cow.

title: STARS WIN BY 12699 FOR 3.1 SERIES LEAD
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 20 (AP)Leading by as much as 36 points in the second half, the Stars crushed the Indiana Pacers, 12699, tonight, giving Utah a 31 advantage in the American Basketball Associa tion's Western Division play offs.

title: Purchasing Man Named
description: Jerry Korman, purchasing manager of The New York Times, has been elected presi dent of the Newspaper Purchas ing Management Association. This organization consists of a group of 100 purchasing agents from the leading newspapers in the United States. He succeeds Paul Dean, purchasing manager of The Chicago Tribune.

title: Karachi Reports Gains
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 20 The Pakistani Government announced tonight that its armed forces had destroyed most of the remnants of the in filtrators and antisocial ele ments around seven East Paki stani towns that it said it had taken control of in recent days.

title: OPINION BY BURGER
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Supreme Court unanimous ly upheld today the constitu tionality of busing as a means to dismantle the dual school systems of the South.

title: China's Changing Society Seems to Cut Birth Rate
description: SHANGHAI, April 20Mrs. Hu Fangtsu was emphatic about it. Children are a lot of trouble, she said. Nobody wants very many of them any more. The leader of a pro duction team in the Machiao commune in the countryside 18 miles west of Shanghai, the 35yearold Mrs. Hu has one child, and she and her husband have no plans to add another.

title: Dissident Crews Threaten, Philadelphia Transit Accord
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP)  Transit union leaders said tonight that most of the union's members were ready to return to work, but holdout pickets at three of the city's 12 car barns threatened to ex tend Philadelphia's transit strike into its 10th day.

title: Major Integration Rulings
description: Following are major school desegregation cases decided by the Supreme Court before its decision yes terday on busing:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Course Burger Has Charted
description: News Analysis

title: Patton Campaign: It Took 19 Years
description: On Oct., 21, 1951, Frank McCarthy, a staff producer at 20th CenturyFox sent a cable to Darryl F. Zanuck, then the studio, head, sug gsting a movie about Gen. George S. Patton Jr. From Europe, Mr. Zanuck cabled, Get going on it.

title: MACEO THOMAS, 73, INTERRACIAL LEADER
description: Macro A. Thomas, a retired fuel sales manager and real es tate broker who was a founder of the Catholic Interracial Council, died yesterday at his home, 4018 Wilder Avenue, the Bronx, following a short illness. He was 73 years old.

title: 76ers Sign Wohl of Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basetball As sociation signed Dave Wohl their No. 3 draft choice today.

title: Ohio Pledges a Subsidy to Retain Rail Link
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 State subsidies appeared today to offer a substantial chance of closing the 525mile gap be tween Buffalo and Chicago in the National Railroad Passen ger Corporation's planned service when it starts opera tion May 1.

title: Senate Study Finds Drug Abuse by G.I.'s A Rarity in Combat
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)  A Senate subcommittee staff report said today drug abuse is on the upswing in the armed forces but rarely occurs in com bat.

title: VOUCHER SCHOOLS BACKED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 A former Superintendent of New York City schools urged Congress today not to block establishment of an experimen tal program, under which par ents would, buy education for their children in either pub lic or private schools.

title: CHARLES D. MERCER
description: BOSTON, April 20 Charles Douglas Mercer, retired presi dent of the Wilcox & Gibbs Sewing Machine Company, died today after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 32 Cliton Road, Brooklyn.

title: Policeman Pleads Guilty To Charge of Payoff Were
description: A suspended New York City patrolman pleaded guilty yes terday to a charge of coercion arising from his solicitation of a $300 payoff from a narcotics addict whom he had threatened with felony charges.

title: Volpe Backs a No Fault Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Secretary of Transporta tion expressed willingness to day to compromise on whether no  fault automobile insur ance should be mandated by Federal law.

title: Aiken Urges Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, pro posed today that the Constitu tion be amended to allow 18 yearolds to become members of Congress. The Constitution now requires that a person be at least 25 to serve in the House and at least 30 to serve in the Senate. The 78yearold Senator said young people are now better prepared to take their place in the social, eco nomic, and political world than those of us who came before them.

title: SERGIUS M. GOTTLIEB
description: Sergius M. Gottlieb, a civil engineer and former assistant of the Division of Proj ?? Coordination of the city Department of City Planning, died Monday, after a brief ill ness, at the ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived at 106 Pinehurst Avenue.

title: PENTAGON REVEALS RISE IN FRAGGINGS
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Fragging incidents among United States troops in Viet nam doubled in 1970 over the previous year, the Pentagon dis closed today.

title: Head of Drake Named President of Oklahoma
description: NORMAN, Okla., April 20 (UPI)The long search for a new president of the Univer sity of Oklahoma officially ended today with the naming of Paul Sharp, president of Drake University, to the po sition.

title: Botany Manager Tie Ends
description: Botany Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday that an agreement had been signed ter minating the management of its Rothschild stores in Chicago by Irwin Jaeger. Also ended was the management  consulting services of all the Botany stores by Mr. Jaeger and Henry C. Schwartz.

title: President Optimistic
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (Reuters)President Nixon to day voiced a high degree of optimism over the economy in a meeting with Congressional leaders at the White House.

title: G.O.P. Governors End Meeting in Mood of Harmony
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 20The spring meetting of the Republican Governors Confer ence ended today in a mood of harmony that matched the soft sunshine and the blossom ing rebuds and dogwoods out doors.

title: Built Up 3Plane Line
description: Mr. Peach, who had also been chairman and chief executive officer of Mohawk, played a leading role in building it from a threeplane operation in the nineteenforties into a major re gional carrler.

title: Mills Proposes $2 Minimum Wage by February to Ease Welfare Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 20  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, pro posed today that the minimum wage be raised to $2 In hour next February, a year earlier than under pending legislation.

title: FIRE BOMBS FOUND AT A QUEENS BASE
description: Molotov cocktails were found yesterday in seven trucks and two jeeps at an Army Reserve center in Jamaica, Queens, that had been the target of two previous bombings in the last year.

title: Judge in Charlotte Dispute James Bryan McMillan
description: Man in the News

title: Plan for Lockheed Loan Is Opposed by Mansfield
description: Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield said yesterday that he opposed proposals that Lockheed authorize a Gov ernment guarantee of loans to salvage the program to pro duce Lockheed air buses powered by RollsRoyce jet engines. The Montana Demo crat told newsmen in Wash ington there had been too much bad management at Lockheed.

title: ChabanDelmas Asks Patience For Social Reforms in France
description: PARIS,, April 20Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas pleaded today for time and patience in constructing a new society.

title: Religion Professor Sentenced
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 (AP)  Dr. Robert McAfee Brown, professor of religion, has been sentenced to five days in jail for taking part in a Good Friday protest of the Viet nam war at the Berkeley draft board. Together with 16 others, the Stanford University profes sor was convicted of obstruct ing a public thoroughfare. Giv en a choice yesterday of paying a $50 fine or going to Santa Rita prison farm, all chose jail.

title: Flee by the Thousands
description: NEW DELHI, April 20 (Reu ters)With fighting reportedly continuing in East Pakistan to day, refugees by the thousands were said to be fleeing from the eastern province to India.

title: LAYOFF PROTEST IS PLANNED HERE
description: The city's public employe unions decided yesterday to join forces next Tuesday in a rally at City Hall followed by a bus trip to Albany to protest the budget cuts and threatened mass layoffs of municipal workers.

title: Pnompenh Aides to Ask Lon Nol To Reconsider His Resignation
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, April 21 (Reuters) Two high Cambodian officials said today they hoped to per suade Premier Lon Nol to with draw his resignation.

title: No PingPong for Castro
description: Fidel Castro accused President Nixon of being a peace monger the other day, but then the Cuban dictator emphasized that he is made of sterner stuff. The Yankee imperialists have no right and no basis for dreaming of any kind of normalization of relations with Cuba or con ciliation with Cuba, Castro asserted. Mr. Nixon's offense, at least in the eyes of Havana's leader, was to suggest that if Castro dropped his antagonistic, anti American line, the United States would consider chang ing its position toward Cuba. To Castro this proved that Nixon has surpassed all the limits of demagoguery.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When a team rides into a championship on the wings youth, balance, and strength and depth, some of the more imaginative observers begin envisioning repeat perform ances of such constancy that the period of such dominance is given the instant label of dynasty. The New York Knicker bockers presumably embarked on such a longterm pre eminence a year ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutual Funds Told Social Issues Should Guide Their Investments
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Project on Corporate Re sponsibility asked the nation's 12 largest mutual funds today to adopt a whole new standard for their investment decisions, under which the funds would consider corporate policies in two areas of social policy be fore investing.

title: Greek Resistance Lives
description: PARISWe once had an unwelcome guest in our house. It was during the wartime occupation of Greece by the Germans. Nazi officers were billeted in people's homes. We drew Gunther. Gunther had a constant need to prove that he was of the master race. He did so by brandishing an enormous revolver and commanding us to watch him urinate on the living room floor. Then he would wave to us with the revolver and say:

title: Chinese Table Tennis Team to Visit U.S.
description: DETROIT, April 20A Chi nese table tennis team will visit the United States in the near future, Graham B. Steenhoven, president of the United States Table Tennis Association, said today.

title: Banker and 4 Brokers Indicted in Eatontown Case
description: NEWARK, April 20The for mer president of the Eaton town, N.J., National Bank, which was declared insolvent and closed last August, was indicted today with four stockbrokers in connection with a scheme to misuse bank funds to pur chase more than $200million worth of stock.

title: CA TV Franchise Shakedowns Charged in Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 20The president of a New Jersey community television company told a legislative inquiry today that officials from two Mon mouth County communities had attempted to extort $8,5001 under the table in return for, awarding local cable television franchises.

title: EARNINGS HIGHER AT DOW CHEMICAL
description: Slight gains in sales and earnings for the first quarter were reported yesterday by the Dow Chemical Company.

title: Stanford Law Dean To Head a Council On Foreign Affairs
description: The election of Bayless A. Manning, dean of the Stanford University Law School, as full time president of the Council on Foreign Relations was an nounced here yesterday by David Rockefeller, chairman of the council's board.

title: Third OTB Shop Opens In East Bronx Today
description: The Off track Betting Cor poration will open its third shop today at 375 East 149th Street in the Bronx at 11 A.M.

title: Knicks: The Difference a Year Makes
description: It all ended so abruptly for the New York Knickerbockers Monday night, when the Balti more Bullets eliminated them from the National Basketball Association playoffs, that it was easy to lose sight of two contrasting truths: That signs of Knick deterioration were long visible and often noted and, that when all else is said, a couple of bounces of the ball could have made them, instead of the Bullets, the survivors.

title: F.T.C. PLANS SUIT ON DRUG MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was planning to file suit to undo the acquisition of Parke, Davis & Co. by the WarnerLam bert Company. This is the same merger that the Justice Depart ment declined to move against last fall, even though its Anti trust Division had recommend ed filing suit.

title: SUITS IN SPECK CASE ENDED OUT OF COURT
description: CHICAGO, April 20 (UPI) An outofcourt settlement has been reached in part of a civil damage suit filed on behalf of the families of eight student nurses slain by Richard Speck in July, 1966, and one nurse who survived the mass mur der.

title: Bank of America Bombed
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 (AP)A pipe bomb exploded at a branch of the Bank of Amer ica today, shattering windows, doors and hurling fragments as much as 60 feet. It was the sec ond blast there in less than two months, the latest of many ex plosions at Bank of America branches throughout the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Parley on School Finances
description: Murry Bergtraum, president of the Board of Education, said last night the board had invited the 31 community school boards and more than 70 other civic groups to a special meeting to morrow at 2 P.M. to discuss the city's severe financial crisis and its effects on the public school system.

title: William A. Roche, Official Of Catholic Charities, 54
description: CHATHAM, N. J., April 20 William A. Roche, executive sec retary of the Cardinal's Com mittee of the Laity of the Cath olic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, died today in Morristown Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 25 Hick ory Place.

title: New Fund Formed to Help Colleges Invest Endowment Money
description: A nonprofit corporation has been formed with the aid of the Ford Foundation to ar range for mutual, professional investment management of col lege and school endowment funds.

title: On South Africa
description: WASHINGTONThe South African Government's proposal to the. World Court in the latest phase of the South West Africa controversy ought to have aroused a good deal more interest than it has.

title: Black Woman Who Alleged Bias Is Dismissed by Post Office Here
description: A black woman postal em ploye who has battled with New York Post Office authorities for 14 months because she felt dis criminated against because of her sex and her color has been dismissed.

title: Liberty Revives; 5Cent Price Stays Dead
description: Reading time: 2 min., 57 sec.

title: Reciprocal Treatment Seen
description: WASHINGTON, April 20Of ficial United States sources, when asked today whether the Chinese visitors would be granted interviews with high Administration officials, re called the cordial reception accorded the American team during its visit to China, espe cially by Premier Chou Enlai in Peking. They said they as sumed that the Chinese would be granted reciprocal treat ment.

title: White House Welcomes News
description: WASHINGTON, April 20 (Reuters)  The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Zieg ler, said today that the United States Government would wel come the visit by a Chinese table tennis team.

title: Theater Planned in Hotel
description: Plans for the construction of a new 500seat legitimate thea ter in the Empire Hotel, Broad way and 63d Street, were an nounced yesterday by H. B. Cantor, president of the Carter Hotel chain, which recently took over the operation of the Em pire. The theater will be located on the second floor of the hotel. It will feature a marquee fac ing the New York State Theater and will be managed by Walter Carlin and David A. Cantor, son of the owner.

Buckley un derscored one of his rare dif ferences with the Nixon Admin istration today by advocating a revenueshifting proposal to replace President Nixon' plan to turn $5billion in Fed eral tax revenues over to the states and localities without strings.

title: Train Dispatchers Reach Agreement With Railroads

title: Uniroyal in 10% Gain

Vila, chairman and presi dent, reported to stockholders yesterday. It was the first quar terly increase made by the company in two years. Sales rose 8 per cent to a record of $413million from the previous year's $381million.

title: Anglican Panel Favors Allowing The Divorced to Wed in Church
description: LONDON, April 21A corn mission of the Church of England proposed today that divorced persons be allowed to remarry in church.

title: Wife of Suspect in Robbery UR, Hamilton Bank Freed

description: DENVER, April 21 (AP) Walter Mode of Natick, Mass., assumed the presidency of the American Society for Public Administration at its national convention here today. He is the New England Regional Commissioner of the Social Security Administration. The 10,000member society is national educational and pro fessional organization.

title: BUSINESS TAX CUT BACKED BY JAVITS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Senator Jacob K. Javits today criticized the critics of the Ad ministration's recent move toward cutting business taxes.

title: Market Place: Bag of Paeans For Manhattan
description: Okay, so you're tired of that rotten commute to Man hattan and you dream of an executive suite in the Elysian fields of Connecticut or New Jersey.

title: CAMBODIAN CHIEF IS ASKED TO STAY
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 21Gen. Lon Nol received a new mandate today to form a government following his res ignation yesterday for reasons of ill health. The action came amid strong indications that a powerful group of colonels, headed by the general's brother, would have opposed any other solution.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Assails Court's Nine Old Men
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UPI)Mrs. John N. Mitchell said today that the Supreme Court should be abolished for its ruling upholding the practice of busing to inte grate public schools.

title: JOSEPH J. STERN, 64, WAS LAWYER HERE
description: Joseph J. Stern, a partner in the law firm of Scribner & Mil ler, died yesterday in Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 500 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Roundup: Stargell Hits 3 Home Runs for the 4th Time
description: Wilver Dornel Stargell, baseball's third best known Willie, hit three home runs against the Atlanta Braves last night for the second time this season. This time his team, the Pirates, won the game, 102, at Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh.

title: College Sports Notes
description: New York University's de cision to drop intercollegiate basketball and track does not appear to be symptomatic of a trend. However, other pri vate institutions in large metropolitan areas are tak ing a serious look at their varsity budgets as well as the budgets of all depart ments of educa tion.

title: Screen: Horror Tales:House That Dripped Blood' Bows Here
description: The horror movie is inherently the most imperfect of genres, combining as it does an aspiration toward the sublime with the mechanics of the high school play. The combination may be naturalat least the way anything unavoidable is naturalbut it rarely engenders great art, and even we who love them must admit that most horror movies fail on every level. Such failure, however, may be more or less interesting. And it is in terms of the esthetics of failure that I am of several minds about Peter Duffell's "The House That Dripped Blood," which moves in many directions, but never too far from the mechanics of the high school play.I mean that it is the kind of movie in which you never see the dark at the top of the stairs but that you may be sure a face will appear to fill it. Always on cue, doors creak, clocks strike 12 and lights flicker and burn low. Doors, clocks, lights and the dark at the top of the stairsall belong to a house that serves as the connecting link among the four brief vignettes that makes up "The House That Dripped Blood," a film in which (as any connoisseur of titles will have guessed) neither the house nor anything else drips blood.The first vignette concerns a murder-story author who moves to the house with his beautiful young wife and who shortly thereafter begins to see the maniacal strangler he is writing about. The second deals with a retired business man, the house's next tenant, who, in the local wax museum (a wonderful convenience), discovers on exhibit a beautiful Salome with uncanny resemblance to a girl long dead. Whoever cannot immediately figure out the central twists to these anecdotes needs more than a movie review to help him. Both stories are as dull in development as they are in idea.But the latter two stories, though necessarily too short and too schematic, generate some interest, and humor, and even a bit of characterization. One of these has to do with a shy little girl whose father won't let her go to school with other little girls and especially won't let her play with dolls. And the other, a piece of quite charming silliness, tells of a horror-film actor who in his search for verisimilitude visits the local curio shop to purchase a cloak"Exactly what a Transylvanian vampire might have worn." He gets his cloak, and though he feels a slight chill when putting it on, he finds that he kisses his leading lady with renewed intensity. . . .As a director, Peter Duffell, though at no time a stickler for needless subtleties does better, the better his material. In fairness I should say that when he doesn't have to creak a door, he doesn't; and when he can play with a characterization he does.In horror movies, I usually find myself liking actors, and for "The House That Dripped Blood" I also have a list. Ingrid Pitt, as the vampire lover's lady, for her face and figure, and Jon Pertwee, her flamboyant lover, perhaps mostly for his face. Chloe Franks, in the third story, is the most nearly bearable (and most beautiful) child actress I have seen. As her governness, Nyree Dawn Porter begins her performance in what looks like confusion, but ends by suggesting a complexity that helped make worthwhile an afternoon at the movies."The House That Dripped Blood" opened yesterday at the Penthouse Theater and the 59th Street East Twin Cinemas.

title: Feud Ruled Out in Slaying
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., April 21 (UPI)The slaying of a 25 yearold Black Panther leader, Fred Bennett of Berkeley, was not connected with the party's leadership feud between Huey Newton and Eldridge Cleaver, the police said today. Frag ments of Mr. Bennett's body were found yesterday near revolutionary bomb factory in the Santa Cruz Mountains, but a police spokesman said Mr. Bennett was slain on or about [last] Jan. 6, nearly two months before the intraparty fighting began.

title: ARON FINELT
description: EDGEWATER, N.J., April 21 Aron Finelt, president and founder of the Finelt Jewelry Casting Corporation in New York, died at his home here yesterday, apparently of a heart ailment. He was 63 years old.

title: Saigon Marines Are Airlifted to Positions Near Ashau
description: LAVANG, South Vietnam, April 21American helicopters today flew about 1,500 South Vietnamese marines to landing zones north of the Ashau Val ley, where reconnaissance in preparation for allied attacks has been under way for more than a week.

title: Bucks Beat Bullets, 9888, In Opener of Title Series
description: MILWAUKEE, April 21The Oscar RobertsonLeW Alcindor combination proved a bit too much for the aggressive Balti more Bullets tonight as the Mil waukee Bucks won the first game of the fourofseven game finalround series for the Na tional Basketball Association championship, 9888.

title: Personal Finance: Age and Maturity
description: When I was one and twenty I heard a wise man say . . . These beginning words of a poem by A. E. Housman stressed the im portance 50 or more years ago of being 21. That is the traditional age associated with a young man's or wo man's reaching majority, a kind of pompous word that signifies both freedom and responsibility.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Everything's coming to a head. We need a second air port$2 billion; that didn't happen overnight. The Federal Government comes down and says we have to have new waterpollution controls; the Chattahoochie River didn't get that way yesterday. We had to increase the police force by 33 per cent, and crime didn't become a crisis today. Now the fire inspec tors tell me City Hall should be condemned, because it doesn't meet safety stand ards. If I don't get some help, I'm going to disappear.

title: Head of City University Foresees Closing of System Under 2 of Lindsay's Budget Options
description: The City University would be forced to close next Sep tember under either of the two most stringent budget options announced by Mayor Lindsay on Monday, Dr. Albert H. Bow ker, the university's chancellor, said last night.

title: Inflation Rate of 0.2% in March Continued U.S. Trend for Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The rise in consumer prices continued in March at the slow er rate of recent months, the Labor Department reported to day.

description: We can't seem to get any help. We're dealing with alien legislatures, suburban and ru ral legislatures. . . . There's going to be a city that goes bankrupt because it can't sell its bondsand that's going to happen soon.

title: FUKS SHOWS VIGOR IN VIOLIN RECITAL
description: Mauricio Fuks, violinist, played everything robustly, with gusto at his Carnegie Recital Hall appearance Tues day night. He has an even technique, gets around the rotes ably and has an open, direct performing manner.

title: SENATE UNIT MAPS CAMPAIGNING CURB
description: WASHINGTON April 21 A campaign spending bill that would set relatively high lim its for all House candidates and for Senate candidates from sparsely populated states is be ing drafted for final consider ation by tI?? ??nate Commerce Committee tomorrow.

title: Minichiello to Be Released
description: ROME, April 21 (UPI)  A court of appeals today reduced the jail sentence of Raffaele Minichiello, the United States marine who hijacked an airliner from the West Coast to Rome in 1969, and ordered him re leased from prison May 1. The court cut Minichiello's jail term from 7 to 3 years and gave him a pardon for an additional two years, leaving him only 10 more days to serve.

title: Success Is Savored by Black Lawyer in Charlotte Busing Case
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 21Julius Chambers sat in his office today with the same deadpan expression that he usually presented to the white school board lawyers who have opposed him in court across the state of North Carolina.

description: Anniversaries

title: Bridge: Televised Match on Sunday Features World Champions
description: Bridge returns to the tele vision screen Sunday after a gap of about eight years.

title: Taiwan Glass Is Reported Sold Under Fair Value
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Treasury Department said today that clear sheet glass from Taiwan was being sold in the United States at less than fair value.

description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) Senator Walter F. Mondale said today he had letters from an American troop commander indicating United States Forces planned a ground attack deep into North Vietnam early this year.

title: Witnesses at P.S.C. Hearing Assail Con Ed's Service

title: Shut Eye Captures Toboggan for Third in Row and Returns $43.60
description: Larry Adams rode Shut Eye to a $43.60 upset in the $33, 100 Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. But the jockey had to do some heavy sweating before, during and after the race to get the vic tory.

description: Some 1,200 shareholders gathered here yesterday under tight security measures for the annual meeting of the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Mrs. Florence W. Meyer, A Founder of Nurses Unit
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., April! 21  Mrs. Florence Ward Meyer, a lifelong resident active in community affairs, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, after a short illness. Mrs. Meyer, who was 81 years old, was the widow of J. Edward Meyer, president of the Cord Meyer Development Company in New York.

title: Suspect Slain After Chase Following a Bank Robbery
description: Daniel Grant, 22 years old, of 149 East 39th Street, died yes terday afternoon, the police said, after having been shot earlier while fleeing a Dank rob bery on the upper East Side.

description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Following is the White House summary of President Nixon's message to Congress today on the reform of the foreign aid program:

title: C.B.S. Sees Recovery

Frank Stanton, president of the network, dispensed with his customary report on opera tions to reassert the company's stand against a Congressional subpoena that it feels violates freedom of the press.

title: Movie Producer Is Fined On Conviction of Perjury
description: Samuel Bronston, the motion picture producer, was fined $2,000 in Federal Court here yesterday on his conviction for perjury in a 1966 bank ruptcy case involving a film company that he owned.

title: Agencies to Report Environment Data On Projects Early
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The President's Council on Environmental Quality made, it official today that, starting July 1, Federal agencies must reveal expected environmental impact at least 90 days in ad vance of proposed actions.

title: Blue Grass Today Attracts 14, With Dynastic Rated 52 Choice
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 The Blue Grass Stakes, race that in recent years has had a strong bearing on the outcome of the Kentucky Derby, will have its 47th run ning tomorrow on the Keene land Race Track. Because of the lack of a dominant horse in the 3yearold division this year, the 1mile event has attracted 14 contestants, the most since 1954, when the same number competed.

title: Yanks Bow
description: The Yankees and the Wash ington Senators were in late season form yesterday  the form teams often show late in the season when they aren't going anywhere but home.

title: ROGERS MAY VISIT EGYPT AND ISRAEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Secretary of State William P. Rogers is expected to visit Egypt, Israel and and several other Middle Eastern countries early next month, informed sources said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: DON'T SAY YES UNTIL I FINISH TALKING. A Biography of Darryl F. Zanuck. By Mel Gussow 318 pages. Doubleday. $7.95.

title: Immigration Official Named

Mr. Marks, a ca reer employe who has served as deputy district director since 1956, succeeds P. A. Esperdy, who retired after 43 years.

title: WALL ST. EXECUTIVE ARRESTED IN THEFT

title: Justice Burger's Warning
description: Although the Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that busing of pupils to achieve school desegregation is constitutional, the issue at the heart of Chief Justice Burger's opinion is not busing at all. It is rather the Court's belief that the school authorities of Charlotte, N. C., and other Southern districts, have openly defied the 1954 Supreme Court ruling that outlawed the mainte nance of dual school systems.

title: Writers Honor Glasser
description: Robert A. Glasser, chairman of the New York State Har ness Racing Commission, was voted an honorary life mem bership in the New York chap ter of the United States Har ness Writers' Association yes terday. Glasser will be honored at the writers' annual dinner dance at the Four Seasons Country Club, Woodbury, L. I., May 16.

title: Nixon and Steenhoven Discuss a Chinese Visit
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)President Nixon dis cussed Communist China and table tennis today with the head of the United States team that visited mainland China last week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: How bad is it? We have higher tax load than New York City and the most segregated suburbs in the country. . . The cities are financing education, police and healththe social over head of poverty  with the property tax, a tax that was designed only to finance fire, sewer and garbage costs. The Federal income tax should be financing social overhead costs.

title: Liberals Turned Back
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 21 Five Oakland City Council men yesterday turned back a challenge by a liberal slate of candidates calling itself the Oakland Coalition.

description: BUFFALO, April 21 (AP) The head of Marine Midland Banks, Inc., told stockholders today the Company's assets rose by $1billion in 1970 and its gross revenue went up $70 million.

title: SOYBEANS SHOW DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Reports that the preparation of fields for the planting of corn and soybeans was proceed ing rapidly sent prices of those futures down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Later, corn futures recovered but beans continued along in a weak vein.

description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., April 21The school dis trict here is wealthier than it thought by $45,000, as a re sult of discovering an old oil painting that had been hanging in the office of the superintendent of schools for many years.

description: MOORESTOWN, N.J., April 21 A funeral service will be held Saturday al the Lewis Funeral Home here for Clyde Robinson, a creative designer of Moores town and Paris, who died in Strasbourg, France, on April 9. He was 58 years old.

description: A Brooklyn manufacturing company has decided against moving out of the city and will instead build a big addition to its plant, the city announced yesterday.

description: WORCESTER, Mass., April 21 (AP)The United States Steel Corporation has an nounced plans to close its 140yearold wire works oper ation here July 31. About 200 persons will lose their jobs at the Worcester Wire Works, which employed 4,000 persons during its peak years in World War II.

title: TV: Lessons of Men at Law and Changing Scene
description: In his new novel, Being There, Jerzy Kosinski's pro tagonist is a gardener whose only knowledge of the out side world is what he has seen on television. His name, appropriately enough, is Chance. Consider, if you will, the possibilities.

title: PRICES ON BONDS CONTINUE SLIDE
description: Bond prices continued to re treat again yesterday as large new offerings received only mixed reception and many in vestors and dealers stepped to the sidelines to await still higher yields.

title: CECIL PARKER, 73, A BRITISH ACTOR
description: LONDON, April 21 Cecil Parker, the stage and movie actor who specialized in por trayals of the typical English gentleman, died yesterday at his home in Brighton. He was, 73 years old.

title: 2 Win $ 1Million Each in the Jersey State Lottery
description: TRENTON, April 21 (AP) A former bricklayer who now sells insurance and a civilian employe of the Army in Phila delphia each won $1million to day in the New Jersey State Lottery.

title: OBSERVER

description: JERSEY CITY, April 21A 5yearold child and a passer by who ran into a, burning apartment building here to at tempt to rescue its occupants were both killed tonight.

title: IN THE NATION
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., April 21 They, used to tell a rather deferential joke here that Charleston had three riversthe Ashley, the Cooper and the Mendel. The special election to fill the Congressional seat of L. Mendel Rivers, who died in December, is cer tainly being conducted in that spirit.

description: The Consumer Price Index in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose by six tenths of 1 per cent last month, marking the 47th successive monthly price advance in the area, the Bureau of Labor Sta tistics reported yesterday.

description: Your editorial Making Justice More Equal (April 2) contained a plea for public contributions to the Legal Aid Society with which we concur. Cer tainly, the quality of the legal repre sentation presently provided indigents in this city needs great improvement.

Warner, the company's president, told 200 stock holders at the annual meeting here today. He reported a 241 per cent gain in net income on a 15 per cent rise in com bined revenues and sales.

title: 2 BLASTS IN ATHENS MARK DATE OF COUP

The Gov ernment, headed by Premier George Papadopoulos, marked its fourth anniversary in power today.

description: Paul A. Porter who, as for mer chairman of the Federal Communications Commission under President Roosevelt, was known as a tough regulator of broadcasting, urged yesterday the permanent award of licens es to radio and television sta tions.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The population of Balti more is 905,000. Of that fig ure, 305,000 pay the state in come tax. Of those, 187,000 pay on an income below $3,000 a year. So that leaves 118,000 substantial taxpayers as my base. The more I hit them with increased real es tate taxes, the more of them move outand the more Bal timore becomes a repository for the poor.

title: 150 Ingres Drawings of Rome Shown
description: Rome is two cities, a tem porary one that begins at street level and goes up about 10 feet, all people and auto mobiles and shop fronts and hubbub, and the eternal one just above it, a quiet city that doesn't change much. This is still the city our fa thers and grandfathers and greatgrandfathers visited on the Grand Tour, the great tawny  walled baroque city studded with earlier monu ments that still somehow ac commodates the de hands of the 20th century. It is the Rome that Jean  Auguste Dominique Ingres fell in love with early in the 19th cen tury and recorded in drawing after drawing.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On School Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate defeated today an amend ment by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, to require that Negro children from inner cities be inte grated into suburban schools in all sections of the nation.

title: American Ballet Dances New A Poem Forgotten

Ribicoff's proposal designed to require large cities and their suburbs in all parts of the country to integrate their schools within 12 years.

title: MIG'S BEING SENT, CEYLON CONFIRMS
