title: Vote Is Nearly 3 to 1
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., April 21 (AP)Tabulation of the votes earlier today showed that the delegates had approved by nearly 3 to 1 the resolution recommending to President Nixon an immediate halt to United States military action in Southeast Asia and with drawal of all American forces and logistical support by Dec. 31.

title: Newsmen Held Threatened
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)  Representative Mc Closkey said today that news men covering the Indochina war were afraid they would be beaten or killed if they wrote articles, critical of the Laotian Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your April 5 editorial (Honduras Back on Course), commenting on our recent general elections, although per haps intended to be basically compli mentary to my country, unfortunately contains at least four falsehoods which I am obliged to point out for the bene fit of the millions of readers of The Times who might otherwise remain misinformed as to the political maturity of our citizenry:

title: The AllAmerican Look of the 40's Is Back
description: The cover girl of the nine teenforties is making a come back. Remember her in a Shetland sweater, with wind swept hair, In the front seat of a convertible, looking as if she'd just been swimming or riding or golfing? Her healthy, athletic kind of good looks hasn't exactly been in the fashion forefront these days of frizzy hair and funky clothes.

title: U.S. CLOSING DOWN A LATIN COMMAND
description: BALBOA, C. Z., April 21  The Southern Command, a symbol of United States mili tary presence in Latin America, is awaiting a decision from Washington on when to close its doors.

title: TEXAS ALLOWS SALES OF LIQUOR BY DRINK
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 21 (Reu ters)Texas legalized the sale of hard liquor in saloons today for the first time in more than 50 years.

title: Armco Steel Rescinding Price Cuts in Stainless
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was rescinding previously an nounced price increases for stainless steel that were to have gone into effect April 26.

title: The First Black Master at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21 Two years ago, Yale Uni versity became one of the first major schools in the na tion to establish a broad based black studies program. Last June, a black Federal judge was elected to the board of trustees, which governs the university. Today, Yale's presi dent, Kingman Brewster Jr., an nounced the ap pointment of Richard Allen Goldsby, a 36yearold associ ate professor of biology, as the first black master in the university's 12college resi dential system.

title: BREZHNEV, IN SOFIA LAUDS ORBITING LAB
description: MOSCOW, April 21Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist party leader, said today that Salyut, the unmanned orbital workshop, represented an important stage in the Soviet Union's space program.

title: Inwood Studying Varied Housing Plan
description: What can you say about an area whose main features are a sevenblocklong sprawl of subway repair yards, worn out industrial buildings and a junklined waterfront?

title: France to Drop Napoleon and Moliere From Bank Notes
description: PARIS, April 21Two of France's greatest heroes, Na poleon Bonaparte and Jean Baptiste Poquelin  alias Molierehave been demoted by the Bank of France.

title: Miss Stacy Gains Semifinal Round In Pinehurst Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 21 (AP)Hollis Stacy, the defend ing champion, and Barbara Mc Intire, a fivetime winner, won a pair of matches each today to move to the semifinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament along with Lancy Smith and Bethy Barry.

title: Magnavox Price Policies Will Continue in 36 States
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 UPI)The Magnavox Company said today that it was continu ing Fair Trade price policies in 36 states not covered by a consent order negotiated with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Graebner, Richey Advance; Solomon Posts Tennis Upset
description: HOUSTON, April 21 (AP) Topseeded Clark Graebner of New York and secondseeded Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., won secondround matches in the $25,000 River Oaks invi tation tennis tournament today.

title: Modern Museum Plans Free Garden Admission
description: For the first time in its 18 year history, the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture gar den will be free to the public every Friday, Saturday and Sunday evening from May 14 through Oct. 10 as a result of a $25,000 grant from the Mobil Foundation, Inc.

title: Both Sides Give Summations in the Crimmins Trial
description: The defense and prosecution summed up their cases yester day in the trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who is accused of having killed her two children in 1965.

title: JOHN S. ZINSSER, 76, CHEMICAL EXECUTIVE
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., April 21 (AP)  John Sharman Zinsser, a retired pharmaceutical manu facturer, died yesterday in his home at Sweet Briar, near here, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Expert on Oil Spillages Disputes Hopeful Study on Santa Barbara
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  The validity of scientific studies that reported negligible ecologi cal damage from the oil well blowout off Santa Barbara, Calif., has been sharply chal lenged by a leading scientist in the field.

title: Police Occupy High Schools After Caracas Students Riot
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 21 (AP)The police took con trol of the main high schools in Venezuela's capital today after hundreds of students staged violent demonstrations.

title: Winfrey, Dr. Fager in Hall of Fame
description: Bill Winfrey, the trainer, and Dr. Fager, the horse, were voted into racing's Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: Bainbridge Isle Known for Berries And Jalna Kennel
description: Bainbridge Island is a 30 minute ferryboat ride in Puget Sound from Seattle. Named for William Bainbridge a naval officer of Old Ironsides fame, it is known for its strawberries. Among dog show fanciers on the Coast it is also known as the home of the Jalna Kennel a top pro ducer of Peking ese for several decades. At the recent Pekingese Club of America specialty in New York, many Eastern fanciers also heard about Jalna, which is now owned by Anne and Melvin Samek.

title: Advertising:
description: He was dark and not bad looking. She, an attractive blonde. He called her Sandy. She called him Alan. As a team they were the first act yesterday morning in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Hotel.

title: U.S. Jet Fires in North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday (Reuters)  A United States Navy A7 fighter bomber fired a rocket at an antiaircraft missile sight in North Vietnam's Mugia Pass Tuesday, the Ameri can command reported today. The pilot was said to have fired the rocket when his equipment detected that the North Viet namese were preparing to fire a missile.

title: Insurgents Described
description: COLOMBO, April 21 (AP) The army commander described the insurgents today as very highly disciplined and welled ucated young people from mid dleclass homes and said that 75 per cent of them were be tween 18 and 20 years of age.

title: NEW ORDERS OFF IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 New orders for durable goods declined by $700million in March from a February level that was revised upward for the second time, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Unemployment is at the doorsteps of the Mayors. In the inner city we have 25 per cent unemployment, and among young people it's 48 per cent.... I have a disaster plan budget cutting city em ployes if we don't get more money. I'm going into every city service. I'll close 15 to 31 recreation centers and six firehouses . . . and if you see services cut back, you'll see blowups of some kind.

title: Saigon Airport a Smugglers' Paradise
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21 Smuggling at Tan sonnhut Airport here has grown to such overwhelming dimen sions that the sole function of customs at the airport seems to be to assist the smugglers to bring in their contraband without hindrance, according to an official United States re port.

title: The Perils of Trade With China
description: WASHINGTONEver since the rev olution against the Manchus establish ing the first Chinese Republic in 1911 three generations of my family have been deeply involved in the attempt to transform China politically, educa tionally and economically into the kind of modern nation in which one of the truly great peoples of history could have the Four Freedoms that friends of China wish for all the peoples of the worldfreedom of speech and ex pression, freedom of worship, freedom from want and freedom from fear.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: I don't go to the State Legislature to attack; I go in selfdefense. I say: Will you please stop giving new pen sion rights to every small group of city employes. I have to pay them, and they're killing me. They don't cost you a dime. . . . If we get revenue sharing, I'll use it to stop tax increases, to keep people from jumping into the suburbs.

title: CAMPUSES QUIET ON WAR PROTEST
description: Enthusiasm on college cam puses for the antiwar demon stration in Washington this weekend has been generally running low.

title: MGM Forms World Unit
description: MetroGoldwynMayer, Inc., announced yesterday that it had formed EMIMGM Film Productions, Ltd. The new com pany will produce a number of motion pictures for the inter national market. Nat Cohen, chairman of AngloEMI, will be managing director and Rob ert Littman, MGM's director of European production, be comes deputy managing direc tor. James T. Aubrey Jr., presi dent of MGM, will be board chairman and Bernard Delfont, chairman and chief executive of the EMI Film and Theatre Corporation, will serve as dep uty chairman.

title: She Still Cooks Fijian Food, but Ah, Those Hamburgers . . .
description: Part of my husband's job, Mrs. Se loti Sikivou, wife of the Fiji Ambassador to the United Nations, said this week, is to tell people more about Fijilittle Fiji, composed of its 320 islands about 1,000 miles north of New Zealand.

title: Last Novel by Remarque To Be Published in Munich
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 21 (Reuters)The manu script of the last novel by Erich Maria Remarque, author, of the World War I classic All Quiet on the Western Front, was handed to his publishers here yesterday by his widow, Paul ette Goddard, the American ac tress.

title: Witness Links Seale to House Where Murder Victim Was Held
description: NEW HAVEN, April 21  A nervous, and unhappylooking 17yearold girl testified in the SealeHuggins trial here today that she was at Black Panther party headquarters when Bobby G. Seale was alleged to have gone there and ordered Alex Rackley killed.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Surrounded by the marvels of modern science, engineer ing and communication, there are some of us who listen to a different drummer, who watch for signs that are not neon.

title: Humane Society Sues U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) The Humane Society has gone to court to make the Depart ment of the Interior stop or alter its program of killing predatory animals, primarily in Southwestern and Western states. The suit, which was filed in United States District Court here, contends poisoned bait has killed a large number of rac coons, bobcats, badgers, foxes and skunks. Water also has been polluted by lethal toxi cants, according to the suit.

title: George Fielding Eliot, 76, Dies; Military Writer of World War II
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., April 21 (AP)Maj. George Fielding Eliot, a military analyst and author, died today at a hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Litch field.

title: Dr. Isadore Margaretten, 80, Of Neurological Institute
description: Dr. Isadore Margaretten, processor or neurology at the Neurological Institute of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, died of a heart attack yesterday at the institute. He was 80 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

title: Stage: Rousing Long Day's Journey
description: What is probably the greatest of American plays and a landmark in 20th century drama opened at the Promenade Theater last night in a staging that is authentic, heartfelt and thrilling. The play is Eu gene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night, and this new production by Arvin Brown starring Robert Ryan, Stacy Keach, Geraldine Fitz gerald and James Naughton becomes one of the glorious highlights of many a season.

title: AUGUSTE NOGUES, FRENCH GENERAL
description: PARIS, April 21 (Reuters) Gen. Auguste Charles Nogus who resisted the Allied land ings in North Africa during World War II, died here yester day. General Nogues, who was sentenced in absentia to 20 years at hard labor after the war, was 95 years old.

title: U.S. Employment Service Called Insensitive to Poor
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The National Urban Coalition and the Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law charged today that the United States Training and Employ Anent Service was an incom petent bureaucracy largely responsible for what they called the failure of Federal man power programs.

title: Up in Central ParkUgh!
description: What is a park for? The beauty of untampered nature? The peace of si lence? The games of young and old? A sanctuary from an overpowering city for those who crave it?

title: Short Interest Dropped in April Period
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a closely watched technical indicator of stockmarket conditions, fell sharply in the month ended April 15.

title: RISE OF 6C A PACK IN CIGARETTE TAX SOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 21Seven Republican legislators from the New York City area today in troduced a bill to increase, the state cigarette tax by 6 cents a pack to raise enough funds to restore $75million in revenue sharing state aid to localities, including $48million to New York City.

title: Mobil Oil Increases Net 12.5%
description: Net Income of the Mobil Oil Corporation rose 12.5 per cent to $132.5million, or $1.31 a share, in the first quar ter of 1971.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: We're as close to the bot tom as any American city everything has been racial in Newark since 1967. Remem ber, we're 60 per cent black, 10 per cent Puerto Rican and 30 per cent a minority group. If things are not done for the Newarks of the country, they will hit bottom, and then the country will hit bottom.

title: Policing the Suez
description: Israel's response to Egyptian proposals for reopening the Suez Canal encourages some hope of progress toward disengagement and peace in the Middle East.

title: Inco Earnings Decline
description: TORONTO, April 21  A leading United States indus trialist suggested today that Washington's guarantees of American investments in Latin America might be selfdefeat ing.

title: Clarion Group, Led by Jenkins, Offers Scarlatti
description: As fact, symbol or both, the murder of Abel by his brother Cainthe first homi cidehas provided a potent subject for the creative artist over the centuries.

title: Louis Harris Tells Publishers Of New Coalition for Change
description: A leading opinion researcher told the nation's newspaper publishers yesterday that a new coalition shaping up for change in the country in cluded the new affluents, the poor and those under 30.

title: White House Youth Conference Proves to Be AntiEstablishment
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.. April 21The unmistakable tone of the White House Conference on Youth emerged today as anti Administration, anti Estab lishment and dovish, despite the diversity of the 1.000 young persons who came here from every state in the union.

title: MICHIGAN SENDS MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: It is good that a number of universities around the country have expanded the programs of their music schools to provide for the exploration of current trends in musical composition, and the prospect of hearing the University of Michigan's Con temporary Directions Ensemble at Town Hall on Tuesday night was pleasing. It was presented by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation.

title: High Court Upholds D.C. Abortion Law
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 In its first decision on the con stitutionality of antiabortion laws, the Supreme Court up held the District of Colum bia's abortion statute today by a 5to2 vote.

title: Lawyer for Joan Bird Says She Was Worked Over by Police
description: A lawyer for Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers on trial for an alleged bomb conspiracy, declared in State Supreme Court yesterday that she was worked over by the police to get her to implicate others.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors and offi cers of listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Air Taxi Hits Two Cottages In Virgin Islands, Killing 8
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., April 21  A twinengine air taxi bound for San Juan, P. R., crashed into the Island Beach comber Cottage Hotel in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, today, killing all eight persons aboard. No fatalities were re ported in the hotel.

title: RANK WILL SELL XEROX INTEREST
description: The Rank Organization, Ltd., of Great Britain and the Xerox Corporation of the United States, which since 1956 had been partners in selling office copiers and xerographic equip ment outside North America under the egis of Rank Xerox, Ltd., are parting ways.

title: Now His Designs Go on the Floor
description: You can take a pattern, put it on dress fabric and it will look one way, but put that same motif on floor covering and it will look en tirely different. That's one of the lessons Julian Tomchin, who won a Coty Award for his fabrics designs, learned when he did his first collec tion of carpeting for the Har mony Carpet Corporation.

title: Albany's Welfare Warfare
description: Across the whole desolate legislative battlefield Albany, stark and shocking as it is, no other program has suffered quite so much damage as the welfare pro gram. Welfare has been a favorite target in this bitter year of budgetary retrenchment. The most reactionary elements within the State Legislature have hoisted the banner of welfare reform and enacted a legion distinctly nonreform measures.

title: Love Story Criticized
description: ROME, April 21 (UPI)The Vatican Weekly, L'Osservatore della Domenica, which disliked the book Love Story, took an equally dim view today of the movie. The magazine last week called the novel by Erich Segal a romance pill for lazy minds, Today it said: From an artistic point of view, the film is noth ing, even more than the book is nothing from a literary point of view.

title: ORMANDY LEADS BACH'S PASSION
description: Eugene Ormandy led the Philadelphia Orchestra through Bach's St. Matthew Passion at Philadelphia Hall on Tuesday night, and managed to make that stupendous musicdrama seem bloated and drab. The experience proved to be a dis orienting one, like stepping into a time machine and finding one self back in Queen Victoria's time, hearing Bach done in the overstuffed style our forebears had to accept because they knew no other.

title: PORNOGRAPHY RING BROKEN UP IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 21 Nassau County District Attor ney William Cahn said today that his office had broken nationwide, $250,000  a  year pornography business, which al legedly used little girls, includ ing the photographer's own three and one  half  year  old daughter, as models for lewd photographs.

title: Chicago Prices Are Up, Too, but Rise Is Steeper Here
description: CHICAGO, April 21  New Yorkers who believe they are steadily becoming economically worse off than other Americans are right, at least when com pared with Chicagoans.

title: NEW DATA SUGGEST A HEPATITIS VIRUS
description: New York researchers have found what they believe is fur ther evidence of the existence of a virus that causes serum hepatitis.

title: Rockets Keep Albeck
description: DENVER, April 21 (AP) Stan Albeck, recently deposed as head coach of the Denver Rockets, was named director of player personnel and assistant coach of the American Basket ball Association team today.

title: S. Smith Griswold Dead at 62; Early Fighter Against Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) S. Smith Griswold, a pioneer in the fight against air pollu tion, died of cancer yesterday at the Naval Hospital in nearby Bethesda, Md. He was 62 years old.

title: Texas Districts Dissolved
description: TYLER, Tex., April 21 (AP) A Federal judge today or dered three allblack school districts in East Texas dissolved and told the State of Texas not to allow district boundary changes that would create or maintain dual school systems based on race.

title: Times Man Honored
description: Glenn Fowler, real estate ed itor of The New York Times, received a plaque yesterday from the National Association of Real Estate Editors naming him real estate editor of the year. The presentation was made to Mr. Fowler by Rexford E. Tompkins, chairman of the association's board, in a cere mony at the Yale Club.

title: Fairchild Hiller Allowed To Sue McDonnell Aircraft
description: ALBANY, April 21 (UPI) The Court of Appeals today returned to lower courts a $15 million claim against the Mc Donnell Aircraft Corporation, after denying McDonnell three of its defenses in the case.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: In some ways we're better off than a place like New York.... But every city has to face something. We have 100,000 trained and educated people out of workengi neers and technicians in aero space and other things. It's a whole new class, and no one knows how to deal with it.... I love to see the other Mayors; misery loves com pany.

title: Drug Merger Talks Planned
description: The WarnerLambert Com pany said yesterday that it in tended to notify the Federal Trade Commission that it would enter negotiations with the Government agency on the announcement Tuesday that the F.T.C. was planning to file suit to undo the drug maker's acqui sition of Parke Davis & Co.

title: An Independent Is Upset Victor In Election for Mayor of Dallas
description: DALLAS, April 21  Wes Wise, an independent oneterm City Councilman who was a television sportscaster, was elected Mayor of Dallas yester day in an upset victory over his multimillionaire opponent, Avery Mays.

title: A Picasso Brings $124,800
description: LONDON, April 21 (UPI) Les Adieux du Pecheur, painted in Barcelona in 1902 by Pablo Picasso during the artist's blue period, was sold at auction today for $124,800.

title: Executive Changes
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday that, following its annual meeting on May 10, Lawrason Riggs 3d, now president and chief executive officer, would become chairman and chief executive officer and John C. Duncan would succeed him as president. D. Broward Craig will become executive vice president.

title: Calley Letters Easing Off And Shifting, Check Finds
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP1) The flood of angry letters pro testing the murder conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. has subsided on Capitol Hill, and Congress is now hearing from a small minority in sup port of the trial and verdict.

title: Bengalis Seeking to Regroup Their Forces for Guerrilla Action
description: BEDAI, India, April 21The disorganized western units of the Bengali independence forces are regrouping in the districts bordering India's West Bengal state, trying to marshal them selves to carry out guerrilla counterattacks.

title: Sports of The Times
description: I never took Digel till I got this bleeping job, said Ted Williams, in great good humor. And I swear in my room, some choice bleeping words, let me tell you.

title: MISS DAVIS LOSES BID TO BAR JUDGE
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 21Angela Davis lost today in her effort to have the judge assigned to her pretrial hear ings removed from the case.

title: 34,000 Jobs Lost Here In'70, U.S. Survey Finds
description: The city suffered a net loss of 34,000 jobs during 1970, the first decline since 1963, the Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported yesterday.

title: Knapp Panel Upheld On Subpoena Power By State High Court
description: ALBANY, April 21The State Court of Appeals today upheld the power of the Knapp Com mission, to subpoena New York City policemen in a corruption investigation and to demand their financial records.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: It's the same every place  that's what we're trying to tell Congress. Let me start by saying that we will lock up 26 playgrounds this sum mer because we don't have the funds for people to run them. . . . We're in trouble, and we need help.

title: Chess: TaimanovFisher Match Set for May 13 in Canada
description: The elimination and qual ification match between Mark Taimanov and Bobby Fischer on the road to a chal lenge for the world chess championship, has been set for Vancouver, British Co lumbia, for May 13, at the Uni versity of British Columbia. Play will be paced at the rate of 40 moves in two and a half hours and the game will be adjourned, if necessary, after five hours.

title: 70 VASSAR STUDENTS SEIZE DEAN'S OFFICE
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Thurs day, April 22About 70 stu dent demonstrators took over the Dean of Faculty's office at Vassar College here early this morning in a protest over the college's decision not to rehire six teachers.

title: Syrian Chief of Staff Visits LebaneseIsraeli Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 The Syrian Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Mustafa Tlas, today visited the Lebanese border with Israel at the invitation pf the Lebanese Army com mander.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Boston is a tinderbox. . . The fact is, it's an armed camp. It means something that Louise Day Hicks got 49 per cent of the vote against me. Everyone, black and white, knew what she stood forone black district voted against her 650 to 2. One out of every five people in Boston is on welfare. Look, we raise 70 per cent of our money with the property tax, but half our property is un taxable and 20 per cent of our people are bankrupt. Could you run a business that way?

title: PLEDGE ON TEXTILES BY MILLS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)Three Southern Gover nors said today that Repre sentative Wilbur D. Mills had promised he would support leg islation restricting textile im ports if a voluntary restraining plan offered by the Japanese textile industry did not prove effective.

title: Mets Halt Reds, 52;
description: CINCINNATI, April 21Tom Seaver set a Met record for con secutive scoreless innings, add ed nine strikeouts to his leagueleading total and even got a victory in tonight's 52 decision over the Reds.

title: Soviet Denounces Chinese Reds For Shift on Relations With U.S.
description: MOSCOW, April 21The So viet Union, in its first comment on the apparent warming of relations between the United States and Communist China, denounced the Chinese today for quickly coming to terms with those whom it had just called enemies.

title: Ne Win Leaves the Hospital
description: LONDON, April 21 (UPI) Gen. Ne Win, president of Burma, left London's King Edward VII Hospital today after two weeks of treatment for an undisclosed alment.

title: Concern in London
description: LONDON, April 21Diplo matic sources here expressed deep concern today over the in troduction of Soviet aircraft and personnel into the conflict in Ceylon.

title: Amtrak Critic Threatens To Delay Start of Service
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  Representative Harley Co. Stag gers, Democrat of West Vir ginia, said today that he would not have sponsored the Na tional Railroad Passenger Cor poration bill last year if he had known it would cut existing service in half and cancel the historic trains through his own district.

title: Dissident Group At Fox Attacked By Management
description: The management of Twenti eth CenturyFox Film Corpora tion opened its counterattack yesterday against the dissident group seeking control of the company before the attack for mally got under way.

title: BOGGS TO ASSERT A TAP WAS FOUND
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 Representative Hale Boggs of Louisiana, the House majority leader, will tell his colleagues tomorrow that a telephone company investigator found tap on the Boggs home tele phone last summer.

title: Direct Bus To Wall St. Catches On
description: In the week and a half since its inception, the ex press bus run between the Yorkville section of the Up per East Side and the Wall Street area has more than doubled its passenger volume.

title: The AntiEnvironmentalists
description: Besides the expected and appropriate speeches on pro tecting the environment, Earth Week has produced a number of pronouncements urging limits to such protec tion. Conservation is all very well, their authors suggest, but other matters should have prioritysuch as poverty, crime and even the need to attract industry to depressed areasand, anyway, the threat of pollution is overdone. Such arguments seem to us painfully illogical when they are not downright disingenuous.

title: No Title
description: Our population is 593,000, but we provide the transpor tation facilities, every major park, the zoo, cultural facili ties and the airport for a metropolitan area of 1.1 mil lion. And we get nothing back from the suburbs; they contribute nothing. We don't even get the sales tax, be cause of shopping centers in the suburbs. All we get is the poor and an eroding tax base. . . . The trend is fright ening. . . . We tax anything that moves. I might go to suburbia myself.

title: PRESIDENT SEES OVERHAUL OF AID; ASKS $3.2BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, April 21  President Nixon proposed a major revision of economic and military foreign aid today and asked Congress to provide $3.2 billion for the programs in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: 5 TIMES NEWSMEN HONORED BY GUILD
description: Page One Awards in three categories and honorable men tions in two other categories were won by members of The New York Times, it was an nounced yesterday by the News paper Guild of New York.

title: Court of Appeals, 43, Upholds Whitmore's Assault Conviction
description: ALBANY, April 21The Court of Appeals today upheld by a 4to3 vote the assault conviction of George Whitmore Jr., whose confessions in two murder cases were later re pudiated in a storm of legal controversy.

title: JOHN J. FINLAY
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 21John J. Finlay, who retired in 1956 as president of the Chicago advertising agency of Aubrey, Finlay, Marley & Hodgson, Inc., died Sunday in Hartford Hospital. He was 77 years old and had moved here frim New York in 1968.

title: Poll Finds NoFault Insurance Backed When It Is Understood
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 The Gallup Poll reported today that most Americans who pres ently understand the nofault automobile insurance concept are in favor of it.

title: GATT SEEKS TO AID POORER COUNTRIES
description: GENEVA, April 21The fair trade rules under which most of the world's commerce is conducted are to be suspended in favor of the poorer countries in order to help them raise their foreign earnings from ex ports.

title: Even Songs at a Nursery Figure in China's Policy
description: SHANGHAI, April 20  The thought of Mao Tsetung and Chinese national policy are in tegral elements of study and play, even for small children, at the Pengpu workers housing complex on the outskirts of Shanghai, foreign newsmen found on a visit to the com plex this morning.

title: Andes Evidence Indicts Cholesterol
description: BOSTON, April 21A group of medical researchers from Harvard University and the University of Quito, Ecuador, have discovered what they believe is evidence of a link between low cho lesterol and the absence of heart disease among the el derly of a remote Andean village.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In light of the importance of public education, President Nixon should push for the creation of a separate Department of Education. The present combination of Health, Education and Welfare is too cumbersome and fails to education due.

title: Currency Chief Opposes Sweeping Bank Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)Controller of the Cur rency William B. Camp told Congress today he is against the enactment of a sweeping bankreform bill now pending.

title: Piper Jaffray Plans Issue
description: Piper Jaffray & Hopwood, Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, plans public offering of stock late this spring or early summer, H. C. Piper Jr., chairman, told the an nual meeting in Minneapolis.

title: White House Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)Richard A. Moore, a for mer Los Angeles television ex ecutive who has been working for Attorney General John N. Mitchell, joined the White House staff yesterday as a spe cial counsel to President Nixon. Mr. Moore, 57 years old, will be undertaking special projects for the President, the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Zieg ler, announced, but he did not specify a particular area.

title: STATE TO REDUCE HELP TO ADDICTS
description: ALBANY, April 22The State Narcotic Addiction Con trol Commission announced to day that the admission of ad dicts into its treatment centers would be suspended indefinitely next Friday because of state budget cutbacks.

title: JAMES SACHS, 63, LEGISLATOR, DIES
description: James H. Sachs, a West chester County legislator and an entrepreneur who had pub lished books, magazines and a newspaper, died here Wednes day of a cardiac arrest. He was 63 years old and lived in Pound Ridge, N. Y.

title: T.W.A. Pares Deficit for First Quarter
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., April 22Trans World Airlines, Inc., reported today that pre liminary unaudited results for the first quarter, including earnings of the whollyowned Hilton International Hotels, showed a net loss of $38.2 million.

title: Union Camp Will Increase Variety of Paper Prices
description: The Union Camp Corporation said yesterday that it would increase prices by $10 to $20 ton on a wide variety of print ing papers, converting papers and paperboard. Included in the Increases are envelope, tablet, offset and continuousforms paper, as well as coated Bris tols and related papers and paperboards. Similar increases were announced recently by the International Paper Company.

title: RESERVE MEASURE GAINING IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 A subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee approved by a 54 vote today the grant ing of authority to the Federal Reserve Board to set differing Reserve requirements against various types of bank loans and investments.

title: TV: Stimulating Topical Debates on Advocates
description: Called The Advocates, it's a weekly onehour pro gram coproduced by Public Television stations WGBH in Boston and KCET in Los Angeles. It also offers a re freshing alternative to the predictably dull news inter view usually tucked away in the gray recesses of a Sunday afternoon.

title: Sams Testifies Seale Ordered Panthers to Murder Rackley
description: NEW HAVEN, April 22The state's star witness against Bobby G. Seale testified today that Mr. Seale walked into the room where Alex Rackley was tied to a bed, asked Rackley whether he was a police in formant and then, despite the man's insistence that he was not, ordered him killed.

title: U.S. Ends Freeze On Housing Funds To Assist Newark
description: NEWARK, April 22  The Federal Government announced yesterday that it had ended freeze on $400,000 for the debt ridden Newark Housing Au thority that it imposed last week. The money was released because the authority had com plied with a request for organ izational changes.

title: 92 Asian Treasures Sparkle at Museum
description: Occasionally, In the hug cormugger of things, a good little show, a handsome vest pocket of an exhibition, turns up and it is not herald ed with the usual superlative fanfare. Often exhibitions of this type are not spectacular in the conventional sense, not immediately appealing in their subject matter or theme, and frequently they are discredited as after thoughts or spacefillers.

title: Wheat Prices Rise, Spurred by Fears Of Drought Damage
description: Wheat futures advanced sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but late profittaking halved the rise before the close of trading.

title: CONSULTANT BILL HEED UP IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 22The Sen ate today unexpectedly can celed its approval of a bill limiting consultant contracts so it could take up a measure that would place greater con sultant strictures on Mayor Lindsay.

title: Contacts With Zambian Are Reported by Vorster
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 22Prime Minister John Vorster said last night that the President of Zambia had engaged in private diplo matic contacts with South Africa while publicly denounc ing her policies of racial sepa ration.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Aycock Brown, whose de lightful presence has graced to Outer Banks of Carolina's Dare County for many years, is now busily informing writ eranglers all over the nation that his area offers some of the Atlantic Coast's best fishing.

title: Cahill Closes Forests In Northern Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 22 (UPI) Gov. William T. Cahill closed all forests, woodlands and oven spaces in northern New Jersey today because of drought conditions and fire hazards.

title: Papa Doc, a Ruthless Dictator, Kept the Haitians in Illiteracy and Dire Poverty
description: Although patently a dictator who would not hesitate to kill his enemies in order to main tain his power over the black Republic of Haiti, Francois Duvalier would have had the world believe he was really just a simple little country doctor, so loved by his people that it became his abiding duty to remain President for Life.

title: DELIBERATIONS BEGIN AT CRIMMlNS TRIAL
description: An allmale jury began de liberating yesterday in the trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins, who is accused of murder and man slaughter in the 1965 deaths of her two children.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corpora tion announced yesterday in Mountain View, Calif., that Walter Burke, a director of the company for 14 years, has been elected chairman of the board Mr. Burke replaces the late inventor and industrial ist, Sherman M. Fairchild.

title: City School Board Calls for  Increase
description: The president of the Board of Education called yesterday for a massive public campaign to obtain more school funds, but he said this would succeed only if city residents let it be known that they were willing to pay higher taxes.

title: Criminal Court Judge Is Censured for Conduct
description: A Criminal Court judge was censured by the Appellate Di vision of State Supreme Court yesterday for improper behav ior with a woman whose son had appeared before him on a marijuana charge.

title: Hoffa May Not Seek Reelection as Teamster Chief
description: DETROIT, April 21  James R. Hoffa, the president of the Teamsters, has told top leaders in the union that he will not seek another term as president of the 2.1 millionmember union if court attempts fail to ob tain his release from jail soon.

title: SHULTZ CAUTIONS ON ECONOMIC PUSH
description: WASHINGTON, April 22A close adviser to President Nixon warned today against the temptation to go overboard on excessive stimulation of the economy.

title: A Trattoria Near a Museum
description: The restaurants on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, hosed on the relationship of food and serv ice to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PNOMPENH, Friday, April 23 (Reuters)Sources close to the Government said today that General Lon Nol had named a new cabinet, retaining the premiership himself and ap pointing three deputy premiers. But there was no official con firmation of the report.

title: 50 Bicyclists Ride for TrafficFree Lanes Here
description: Fifty bicycle riders who seek establishment of a traf ficfree lane on major streets and more racks for their vehicles at office buildings glided down Fifth Avenue yesterday in a biketowork rally for Earth Week.

title: CARLOADINGS BY RAIL DECLINED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended April 17 was below that of the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage during the same period regis tered a sizable increase be cause of the labor situation in the trucking industry last year.

title: Rise in G.N.P. Slowed
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The nation's real total output, averaged over the fourth quarter of 1970 and the first quarter of 1971, rose a little less rapidly than in the third quarter of last year before the automobile strike, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: U. S. Official Meets Sadat Amid Moves to Open Suez
description: CAIRO, April 22President Anwar elSadat conferred for more than an hour and a half today with a visiting State De partment official at a crucial moment in United States efforts to promote an agreement on an Israeli pullback in the Sinai Peninsula and subsequent re opening of the Suez Canal.

title: Denial by Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 22 Near the end of an allday Cabinet meeting, the Foreign Ministry today issued a state ment denying that there had ever been any question of a meeting between President Kaunda and Mr. Vorster.

title: Impetuosity Takes Blue Grass
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 Impetuosity won the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland to day, to the surprise of most ob servers in the crowd of 14,956 persons and to most horsemen generally.

title: Bridge: Charity Games to Be Played At Many Area Clubs Tonight
description: Duplicate games that form part of a wider tournament have become increasingly popular in recent years, whether organized on a na tionwide basis or limited to one area. They allow play ers who do not wish to ven ture far from their own doorsteps to participate in a major event.

title: Seasonal Rhubarb Dessert
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Market Place: Dousing Hopes On Egypt's Oil
description: While the Egyptian Gov ernment has been touting the quality and quantity of the flow from its new El Alamein oil field in the Western desert, the Standard Oil Com pany (Indiana), the operator, has been softpedaling then development.

title: Net Off 51% at St. Regis
description: Profit of the St. Regis Paper Company in the March quarter fell 51 per cent from the period a year ago on a sales decline of 5 per cent, William R. Adams, president and chief executive officer, reported at the annual meeting in the Commodore Ho tel yesterday.

title: Environmental Review
description: Buried in the unfinished business of the last session of Congress was a bill of such compelling good sense that it is hard to see why its enactment should be delayed another week. A proposal for a Joint Congres sional Committee on the Environment, it was passed by the Senate a month ago, with Senator Muskie Maine taking the lead.

title: Robert PuleoOpera Star in Eclipse at 15
description: Robert Puleo, an opera star in eclipse, sat in a re hearsal room backstage at the State Theater and looked back at his extraordinary career, which collapsed around his head the other day. The boy soprano was singing a leading role in the New York City Opera's The Turn of the Screw when his voice changed.

title: Haitians Here Joyful, but Fear a Bloody Struggle
description: Haitians in this city were joyful at news of the death of Dr. Francois Duvalier, Presi dent of Haiti, but expressed fear that a bloody struggle for pow er might follow.

title: ABUSES CHARGED IN AUBURN PRISON
description: Relatives of several prisoners in the state prison at Auburn, N. Y., charged yesterday that one of the inmates had been beaten and severely teargassed while the relatives visited the installation last Sunday.

title: Ballet: Birgit Keil Stars in Juliet Lead
description: The Stuttgart Ballet's ver sion of Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet, choreographed by John Cranko, had its first per formance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House and swept a lovely young German dancer named Birgit Keil into the international ranks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Eugene Cormolly's April 14 letter not only contains serious misrepre sentations but, more important, char acterizes my bill (A. 4237) in such a way as to give the public the impres sion that as deputy minority leader I am attempting to use my political position for my own personal gain, and for that of my colleagues.

title: Senate Panel Votes For Draft Extension And Cut in Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to con tinue the military draft for two more years and to reduce by more than half the increases in pay and benefits approved by the House last month.

title: WIECHERS' 64 LEADS TALLAHASSEE GOLF
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 22 (UPI)  Jim Wiechers shot an eightunderpar 64 today to lead the Tallahassee open golf tournament before rain delayed play twice and eventually halted it.

title: TWO OPTIONS MADE STANDARD BY G.M.
description: DETROIT, April 22The Gen eral Motors Corporation will make automatic transmissions and power steering standard equipment on most of its big cars, raising the base car price $350.

title: Edmund Lowe, Screen Star, Dead at 79
description: HOLLYWOOD, April 22  Edmund Lowe, a pioneer film tough man who created the role of Sergeant Quirt in What Price Glory, died yesterday on the Motion Picture County Hospital. He was 79 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

title: Roundup: Stargell Continues Bombing
description: The Atlanta Braves' pitch ing staff got another home run dose from Willie Star gell last night.

title: REDS AT PARIS TALKS HAIL WAR FOES IN U.S.
description: PARIS, April 22 (AP)The Hanoi and Vietcong delegates at the Vietnam peace talks ex pressed warm feelings today for the antiwar demonstrators in the United States.

title: New Presidential Candidate
description: KEY WEST, Fla., April 22 (AP)John Quinn, a 47year old Florida attorney, said to day he would enter the New Hampshire Presidential pri mary next year with a youth backed campaign.

title: Consolidated Foods Lifts Profit by 2.5%
description: The Consolidated Foods Cor poration posted new records in sales and earnings for the 39 weeks ended March 27, with an indicated gain in results for the third fiscal quarter.

title: Duvalier, 64, Diesin Haiti; Son, 19, Is New President
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 22  President Francois Duvalier, dictator of Haiti for 13 and a half years, died last night. His death was announced this morning by the Govern ment radio several hours after his son, JeanClaude, was sworn in as the new President for Life of the world's oldest black republic.

title: Canadian Company Will Buy Home Oil
description: Merger News

title: Screen: American Dream:' Derby' Mixes Fantasy and Fact Skillfully
description: Any movie that contains an argument about who hid the raisins intended for the spaghetti must be  at least in that partas authentically and eccentrically American as the chewing of gum while eating corn flakes, even if it's cinma verit of occasionally stage-managed truth.Such a film is "Derby," which, like the Roller Derby it casually uses as a metaphor for one American dream, so mixes fact with fantasy that even its participants may not be aware when one leaves off and the other begins. The movie, which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous, Murray Hill and Juliet 2 Theaters, is funny without being exploitative, important without being unduly earnest.All of the people in "Derby"  the Roller Derby skating stars like Charlie O'Connell and Eddie Krebs, the would-be skating star, Mike Snell, his family and friendssomehow seem cheerfully disposed towards putting on an authentic show. The result is that "Derby" has both the authority of fiction and the ambiguity of truth, qualities that, when they were reversed, made Allan King's "A Married Couple" such a calculated, perhaps even self-deceiving, put-on.In his film, if you remember, Mr. King and his camera crew lived with a Canadian advertising man and his family through months of marital crisis, the details of which were presented as solemn truth, accidentally discovered. Much of "Derby" is equally intimate, as Robert Kaylor, the director, and his camera crew move in with the family of Mike Snell, a $147-a-week employe of the Dayton Tire & Rubber Co., to record something of the life of a young man who has no doubts about the identity of his dream.The difference between "A Married Couple" and "Derby" is hardly one of detail. Mr. Kaylor has gotten some remarkably personal footage of Snell family life, as when Mike, talking to his best friend, compares the sexual talents of various recent girl friends to those of his wife.There is a curious confrontation between Mike's wife, accompanied by one of her girl friends, with a lady down the block who has apparently been sleeping with just about any guy who'd drop around, including Mike. The women face each other across a patchy yard, talk in circles, call each other "man," and then part by exchanging desultory threats. Barbara Loden's Wanda might well be living next door.This scene and a number of others were obviously set up for the camera, but the truth lies not in the spontaneity of the confrontation but in the rather sad and funny style with which it is played.The ultimate difference between something like "A Married Couple" and "Derby" is that the making of the movie is obviously a major factor in the lives being recorded, a kind of preview of the success Mike seeks as a Roller Derby star. There is nothing unseemly about this spectacle, as there was in the self-conscious intimacies of "A Married Couple."If Mike Snell's story gives "Derby" its shape, scenes of the Roller Derby itself, an acknowledged amalgam of sport and pre-arranged spectacle, plus interviews with its various stars, give the filmand Mike's lifea fascinating context. Charlie O'Connell reminisces about the good things the derby has given him (a San Francisco hilltop house with a swimming pool); a bunch of the derby's female stars tell adolescent dirty jokes; on two occasions, which are unrelated, young men show off for the camera the guns they carryjust, as they say, to be on the safe side. One of these is Mike's best friend in Dayton, who explains, in a matter-of-fact way, that he's tired of being hassled and beat-on by drunk hillbillies whenever he goes into a Dayton bar."Derby" was commissioned by Jerry Seltzer, the son of the man who founded the Roller Derby in 1935, and who has nursed the derby through good times (in the 1950's, when it was a major television attraction) and bad (in the 1960's, when the public seems to have lost interest).I'm especially amazed that a film which was designed to be self-serving should be such an accurate report on a time and place, and should also have such an unsentimental regard for its people. For men like Mike Snell, there will always be the challenge of a new frontier, which, in this case, happens to be the Roller Derby.

title: North Carolina Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)  The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court to day to reverse a lower court decision allowing a North Caro lina school district to split into two separate systems, one of which would serve most of the white students in the rural area.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 22, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

title: Phillies Trade Briggs, 27, To Brewers for 2 Rookies
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies traded John Briggs, an outfield er, to the Milwaukee Brewers today for a pair of rookies.

title: Gilson Gray, Adman, Dead; Drafted Broadcast Code
description: PROVIDENCE, April 22 (AP) Gilson Gray of Bristol, an advertising man who helped formulate the code of practice for the broadcast industry, died Tuesday in Jane Brown Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Applications to Ivy Colleges Off 7%
description: Final application figures for the Ivy League colleges next fall show a decline of almost 7 per cent after steady growth for the previous three years.

title: WEAPONS SEIZED IN ILLINOIS RAIDS
description: CARBONDALE, TH., April 22 (AP)Drugs and large caches of explosives and weapons were seized in raids in a threecoun ty area of southern Illinois to day. An investigator said the authorities had information that some of the arms had been headed for the racially troubled town of Cairo, Ill.

title: Why Veterans March Against the War
description: WASHINGTONAll this week Amer ican veterans who served in Vietnam are protesting against the continua tion of the war and for immediate withdrawal. Tomorrow they will join the ranks of other Americans in a mass demonstration against the Nixon Ad ministration's continued false promises and in support of Congressional bills to stop the bloodshed on both sides and end the war now.

title: Amex Prices Are Up As Turnover Gains; Index Is Ahead 0.04
description: The volume of trading on the American Stock Exchange in creased slightly yesterday and prices rose at about the same rate.

title: RUSSIA LAUNCHES 3 MEN INTO ORBIT
description: MOSCOW, April 23  The Soviet Union placed a three man spacecraft into orbit around the earth today to car ry out joint experiments with the orbiting research workshop Salyut launched four days ago.

title: Price of Admission To the Bronx Zoo To Rise Next Week
description: The Bronx Zoo will increase its adult admission fee, now 75 cents on Fridays, Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, to $1 next Friday.

title: Books of The Times.
description: ROOTS OF INVOLVEMENT. By Marvin Kalb and Elie Abel. 336 pages. Norton. $8.95. AMERICA'S ASIA. Edited by Edward Friedman and Mark Selden. 458 pages. Pantheon. $10.

title: Stennis School Plan Is Backed by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Senate voted today, 44 to 34, to declare that it was, the policy of the United States to enforce school de segregation laws in areas where the segregation resulted from residential patterns as well as in communities where the seg regation had been sanctioned by law.

title: U.S. Ships Are Keeping Close Eye on Haiti Area
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The United States increased its military surveillance of Haiti today following the death of President Francois Duvalier.

title: 5 TOP DEMOCRATS AS NIXON TO SET DATE FR ULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Five Democratic Senators, all potential Presidential nominees, urged President Nixon tonight to establish a terminal date for the withdrawal of all Amer ican forces from Vietnam.

title: The Mayors' Message
description: The mayors of eleven of the nation's largest and most important cities joined Mayor Lindsay in touring New York City this week. Members of the legislative action committee of the United States Conference of Mayors, they have been visiting urban areas across the country, frankly conceding that their road show is designed to dramatize their common plight.

title: Baeza Rides First 3 Winners and Leads With 40 Victories
Haiti After Papa Doc
description: When Francois Duvalier became President of luckless Haiti in 1957, he vowed to erase its image as a land of misery and to direct a Government of national unity that would reconcile the nation with itself. Instead, his corrupt regime mired Haiti's five millions ever deeper in helpless poverty, his divideandrule policy unraveled what little social fabric existed, and he built a record for barbarity and bestiality unmatched even by Haitian predecessors or by his late neighbor, Generalissimo Tru jillo of the Dominican Republic.

title: SOVIET BELIEVED INSTALLING MIRY'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Intelligence reports indicate that the Soviet Union may have begun to put multiple warheads on some of its missiles and that it is rapidly expanding the con struction of new, larger silos to house the missiles, according to high Administration sources.

title: Advertising:
description: Before emplaning for Miami where they would once again seek to instill fire into their sales people, the marketing advertising top kicks of East ern Air Lines, were kind enough to preview the adver tising they'll be firing at the vacation market.

title: EDWIN CALVERLEY, ARABIC SPECIALIST
description: HARTFORD, April 22Prof. Edwin E. Calverley, a specialist in the Arabic language and Is lamic culture, died at a nurs ing home here today after long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Leesona Settles Lawsuit With J. P. Stevens & Co.
description: In settling a lawsuit with Leesona Corporation, J. P. Ste vens & Co., Inc., has agreed to resume royalty payments to Lee sona for use of stretchyarn machines and processes, it was announced yesterday. Pay ments, however, dating back to the summer of 1969, will be at 50 per cent of the previous rate.

title: Music: Amsterdam Visit
description: The Dutch are supposed to be a solid people, but then one thinks of Willem Men gelberg, one of the wild men of the podium. And his Am sterdam Concertgebouw nev er was a solid orchestra, nor is it so under its current di rector, Bernard Haitink. The Concertgebouw is still one of the great orchestras, precise and powerful, capable of huge but disciplined bursts of sound as well as of ethere al tenderness.

title: The Voice of Youth
description: The planners of the White House Conference on Youth were aware of President Nixon's dislike for dissident demonstrations. They therefore wanted young Americans to be heardbut not too loudly, That is why they took the 1,500 delegates to the mountains of Estes Park, Coloradoout of sight and earshot of sensitive Washing ton. What started as a policy of caution was turned into a virtual parody of maximum security through isolation, when nature dumped masses of snow on the meeting.

title: CHICANOS SETTLE A REZONING FIGHT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 A Chicano group announced yesterday a settlement of Its legal fight to force a suburban city to rezone land for low in come housing.

title: Shell Income Drops 18%;
description: Net income of the Shell Oil Company fell 18 per cent to $45,097,000, or 67 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1971, Denis B. KemballCook, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

title: 9SYearOld Newsmen Look to Future
description: Edward King Gaylord and John Netherland Heiskell both have a 33yearold argument against retirement at age 65, and they're both still winning it every day.

title: WILTS RING PRICE PROVES TOO TALL
description: HOUSTON, April 22 (AP) Negotiations for a July 26 heavyweight boxing bout at the Astrodome between Mu hammad All and Wilt Chamber lain, the pro basketball star, broke off today when Chamber lain demanded a taxfree guar antee of $500,000.

title: Princess Anne Takes Lead In English Horse Trials
description: LONDON, April 22 (Reuters) Princess Anne took the lead today in the Badminton horse trials, Britain's top test of horsemanship.

title: Resignations Reported Of ITT Levitt Officers
description: The two top operating of ficers of ITT Levitt, Inc., the country's largest homebuild ing concern, have resigned, it was learned yesterday. The officials are Richard M. Wasserman, president and chief executive officer, and Richard P. Bernhard, execu tive vice president for oper ations.

title: More Troops Flown In
description: LAVANG, South Vietnam, Friday, April 23More Govern ment troops were airlifted yes supply concentrations con terday into a mountainous area near the Laotian border where a search for enemy troop and tinued.

title: Congressmen Back Fight to Get Gulf Oil to End Work in Angola
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Two Congressmen from the New York area endorsed today a proxy fight aimed at forcing the Gulf Oil Corporation to cease its operations in Portu guese Angola.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PEKING TEAM QUITS LAWN TENNIS GROUP
description: LONDON, April 22The In ternational Lawn Tennis Fed eration disclosed today that China had withdrawn from membership.

title: A Turning Point Is Seen for Bond Market
description: The bond markets, badly shaken this week by plunging prices and rising rates, ap peared late yesterday to reach a turning point.

title: Rangers' Line Rewrites Club Records
description: Vic Hadfield, Jean Ratelle and Rod Gilbert stirred the ghosts last night in the Eighth Avenue parking lot where the old Madison Square Garden once was.

title: A.T.E T. May Offer Preferred Stock
description: DALLAS, April 22  The American Telephone & Tele graph Company expects to make a fairly prompt offering of rights for convertible stock to its 3.1 million share owners, H. I. Romnes, chairman and president, told 1,740 persons at the annual meeting here to day.

title: Edna Dierking, Assistant To N.Y.U. Vice President
description: Edna A. Dierking, former assistant to the vice president for business affairs of New York University, where she had worked four years before her retirement in 1963, died of can cer Wednesday at University Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 2 Washington Square Village.

title: S.C.I. REITERATES ATTACK ON POLICE
description: The State Commission of Investigation, repeating its charge that police corruption has corroded the enforcement of narcotics laws, said yester day that the effort of the New York Police Department to curb heroin was ineffective and a failure.

title: U.S. Fighters Strike Missile Bases in North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 23 (AP)  United States fighterbombers struck three times yesterday at missile and antiaircraft sites in North Vietnam and just across the border in Laos, the American command announced.

title: Excerpts From Democrats' Remarks on Vietnam
description: Following are excerpts from a Democratic response, broad cast and televised last night on the American Broadcasting Company network, to Presi dent Nixon's April 7 speech on troop withdrawals. The speakers were Senators Hu bert H. Humphrey of Minne sota, George S. McGovern of South Dakota, Birch Bayh of Indiana, Henry M. Jackson of Washington, Harold E. Hughes of Iowa and Edmund S. Mushie oft Maine.

title: Publishers Urge Making F.T.C. Consumers' Protection Agency
description: The Federal Trade Commis sion should become the nation al consumer protection agency, the American Newspaper Pub lishers Association said yester day, instead of having a new agency set up, as Congress has proposed.

title: AVERAGE WAGE IS UP BY $1.37 FOR MONTH
description: WASHIINGTON, April 22 (AP)  The average weekly wage of some 48 million rank andfile workers increased $1.37 in March, to $123.98, and outstripped the month's rise in consumer prices, the Government said today.

title: Ceylon Opens Drive Against Rebel Sanctuaries
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 22 The Government announced today the start of a drive to recapture those areas of Ceylon controlled by young ultraleftist insurgents.

title: Credit Expands Rapidly
description: Federal Reserve credit con tinued to expand at a rapid rate during the twoweek pe riod ended Wednesday, bank ing data published yesterday indicated.

title: S.E.C. Is Unsatisfied by Capital Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Securities and Exchange Commission has told the New York Stock Exchange that it is not satisfied with the ex change's latest proposals for in suring the relative permanence of capital invested in brokerage firms.

description: To the Editor:

title: Farber Wins Top Columbia ScholarAthlete Award
description: Martin S. Farber, a senior from New Hyde Park, L. I., was named Columbia's lead ing scholarathlete and pre sented with the Eisenhower Watch at the 50th annual awards dinner of the Colum bia University Varsity C Club last night on the Colum bia campus.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Lynch Chairman's New Position May Differ From That of Big Board
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., has called for the elimination of the $15 com mission surcharge on stock transactions that has been in effect in Wall Street for more than a year.

title: 600 Laid Off at Pindyck
description: Charles Pindyck, Inc., an in fant's wear manufacturer here, with plants in the South, has laid off its 600 employes and temporarily curtailed opera tions pending talks with cred itors and lenders in order to re solve its current financial prob lems. Most of the concern's workers are employed in the South.

title: DOBERMAN IS JUDGED BEST OF 1,326 ENTRY
description: WINCHESTER, Va., April 22 Ch. Dolph Von Tannenwald, a 4yearold Doberman pin scher owned by Sheila and George West of Long Island, was judged best in show today at the Shawnee Kennel Club's 20th annual event.

title: Hadfield Excels As Rangers Win
description: That almostmystical feeling that the Rangers are in the midst of something speciala trip to the Stanley Cup final continued last night as they overcame their poor perform ance of two nights earlier to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 41.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeze on States' Costs Planned for Welfare Bill Albert Says Mills Agrees to Provision for More Federal Aid, Keeping Local Outlays Steady or Cutting Them
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Speaker Carl Albert reported today that the welfare bill taking final form in the House Ways and Means Committee would be amended to provide increased Federal assistance and freeze the costs to state and local governments for wel fare programs at their present levels or less.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Hurrying through Grand Central Terminal not long ago, I noticed the tall and distinguishedlooking man just as we were rushing past each other. Each of us was swept along by the swiftmoving multitudes and he never saw me. But I spotted him too late for even a hello and the thought suddenly struck that he was weaving his way through the throngs without anyone else recognizing him.

title: STOCK PRICES END WITH SLIM DROP
description: Airline stocks moved aloft yesterday, while such special ties as Control Data and Bausch & Lomb posted sharp gains.

title: Pamela Poole Bride in Quebec
description: Miss Pamela Poole and Clifford Dean Ross were mar ried on April 12 in Old Fort Pond, Quebec, where they teach.

description: ANTIWar coveragelive all day from Wash ington. Sat. 10 a.m. WBAL 99.5 FM.Advt.

title: City Hospitals Struggle With Nursing Shortage
description: Several children in the South Bronx were hospital ized recently with possible brain damage because they ate lead paint from the walls of their slum apartments. But because there was only one nurse foe their 40bed ward, the children, unattended, ate the same kind of paint from the walls of Lincoln Hospital.

title: G.I. Housing Priority Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Pentagon and the Hous ing and Urban Development Department announced today that lower income military fam ilies would be given priority in selected housing projects.

title: College Admission Data
description: Following is a table comparing applications and admis sions at Ivy League colleges and the Seven Sisters women's colleges. Each school accepts more students than it can place to allow for those accepted by more than one college.

title: Cholera and Smallpox Reported
description: CALCUTTA, April 22 (AP) The West Bengal state govern ment reported tonight that cholera and smallpox had broken out among nearly half a million refugees who had fled to India from East Pakistan.

title: Honduras and El Salvador Agree at O.A.S. Meeting to Resume Negotiations
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 22 An agreement between Honduras and El Salvador to resume talks toward a full peace settlement emerged to day as the most promising result of the First General As sembly of the Organization of American States, which closes formally Saturday.

title: SUSPECT SLAIN HERE TIED TO SKYJACKING
description: A fingerprint check yesterday revealed that a young man shut to death by a policeman on Wednesday after an at tempted bank holdup on the Upper East Side was wanted by the Federal Bureau of In vestigation as a plane hijacker.

title: G.I. Deaths Pat at 56, A Rise of 14 for Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 22 (Reuters)Fiftysix Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, the United States com mand announced today.

title: $2.4Millionin Bonds Missing
description: A brokerage concern here said yesterday that about $2.4 million of municipal and corporate bonds were missing from its office. The company, Pershing & Co., said the loss was covered by insurance. Regular auditing procedures disclosed the loss Monday, the Pershing concern said. Munici pal bonds, mostly in denomina tions of $1,000 and $5,000, ac counted for about $1.3million of the loss, and corporate bonds totaling about $1.1million made up the remainder, ac cording to F. William Pershing, senior partner.

title: Bomb Explodes in Midtown Soviet Trading Office
description: A bomb In an attach case exploded yesterday at the offices of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, the Soviet trade agency, on Lexington Avenue. No one was injured.

title: Israeli Industry Easing Dependence on Foreign Arms
description: JERUSALEM, April 22  The vast armaments industries of Israel are, to all appear ances, rapidly reducing the country's longstanding depend ence on the United States and other arms suppliers abroad.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Early in 1968, not long after his graduation from the Navy's officer candidate school, Lieut. j.g. John Forbes Kerry visited Vietnam for the first time when his ship stopped over in Danang after a brief tour in the Gulf of Tonkin. I went ashore and saw the barbed wire, the ma chine guns and a woodpile of dead Vietcong bodies, Mr. Kerry recalls, and it hit me all at once. This was my first contact with the land war, and at first it looked like something out of the movies. Then I re alizedI said my God, what is going on herethis is really a war.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAPETOWN  Most South African whitesand they are this country's only firstclass citizensfeel a deep sense of isolation from the rest of the world and tend to blame foreign coun tries and organizations for what they consider unfair bias. Arms boycotts, exclusion from international sports and moral protests are received here with bitterness and a feeling that other nations, dwelling within their own glass houses, shouldn't throw stones.

title: Desegregation Course Charted By Legal Unit After Bus Ruling
description: There was a trace of triumph in the room. A feeling that the war was not yet over, but that an important corner had been turneda major battle won.

title: C. O. 's Find a Rise in Acceptance
description: Across the nation, con scientious objectors assigned to civilian work in lieu of mili tary service are moving into an increasing variety of jobs, living comfortably if modestly and encountering little or no harassment.

title: Hawaii Air Pact Ended
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)  Hawaiian Airlines notified the Civil Aeronautics Board by telegram today that the agree ment for a merger with Aloha Airlines had been ended.

title: G.I. HOUSING BIAS IN GERMANY CITED
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People told the Defense Depart ment yesterday that discrimina tion in housing had become the most pervasive problem confronting black American servicemen in West Germany.

title: Ford Says Safer, Cleaner Cars Will Cost U.S. Consumer More
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., April 22Henry Ford 2d, the chair man of the Ford Motor Com pany, said today that Ameri cans would have to pay more for their cars, accept fewer models and forget about the annual model changes if the automobile industry is to meet Federal air and safety standards and still remain competitive.

title: Two Patrolmen Are Indicted On Charges Filed in Bronx
description: A Transit Authority patrol man charged with sexually abusing a young woman, and a New York City policeman ac cused of shooting a tavern owner and one of his employes were indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury.

title: SST Is Alive and Well in Europe
description: Congress has, for the time being at least, grounded the American SST. It had concrete concerns about the SST, both ecologicalthat it might threaten the environment; and economicthat it might tax instead of benefit the people.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PARIS April 22The Com munist delegates at the peace conference said today that Pres ident Nixon had pledged to keep American troops in Vietnam indefinitely.

title: Bullets, Bucks Look to Strike a Verve
description: In the cold, factfilled world of schedules and results, the final round of the National Bas ketball Association champion ship playoffs began Wednesday night in Milwaukee, with the Bucks beating the Baltimore Bullets, 9888, for a 10 lead in the fourofseven series.

title: Vladimir Nabokov, 72 Today, Writing a New Novel
description: Vladimir Nabokov, the cele brated Russianborn Ameri can author of Lolita and Ada who lives in Switzer land, is 72 years old today a date that he impishly notes coincides with the reputed birth date of Shakespeare. In the best of health, he is busy composing a new novel, ten tatively titled Transparent Things.

title: U. S. Aide Denies Laos Bombing Is a Major Cause of Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  The State Department said to day that American bombing was not a major cause of civilian refugees in Laos.

title: Rein on Volpe Charged
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, accused the White House today of forbid ding Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe to endorse a Federal nofault automobile in surance plan. In testimony last month, Mr. Moss told a conference of communications workers, he endorsed nofault insurance. But the White House would not permit him to en dorse a Federal nofault pro gram. Instead, he expressed support for a hodgepodge of state nofault laws.

title: Campus Leaders Support Bowker on City U.'s Possible Closing
description: Faculty and student leaders yesterday joined officials of the City University in saying the university would be forced to close next September under either of the two most stringent budget options announced by Mayor Lindsay on Monday.

title: Rebel Offer Reported
description: COLOMBO, April 22 (UPI) The leaders of the uprising, which began April 5, were re ported today to have offered to talk terms with the Govern ment. This offer was contained in a letter circulated to officials in the leftwing Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike and to Colombo newspapers.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that the follow ing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Boggs Tells House of Tap on Phone
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Representative Hale Boggs, de fending his charge that the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion has been tapping the tele phones of members of Con gress, told the House today that the telephone line of his private home was tapped in 1970.

title: Screen: Ann Arbor Ten
description: The short film, like the short story or the short poem, fulfills expectations and follows laws of its own laws and expectations that are and ought to be a little more meticulously demanding than those applicable to any thing so ambitiously various as just the runofthemill long film. Proponents of the small hard gemlike flame to the contrary, it is probably easier to be brilliant for two minutes than for two hours.

title: 75 Inmates From Homicide Wing Battle Guards on Rikers Island
description: Seventyfive inmates clashed with guards yesterday morning at the Adolescent Remand Shel ter on Rikers Island after a fist fight between a guard and a young prisoner.

title: Allegheny Airlines In Deal With Mohawk
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Allegheny Airlines and Mo hawk Airlines outlined today proposal made to Mohawk's subordinated lenders as part of a reorganization of Mohawk's debt and capital structure.

title: Liquori to Run in Penn Relays Today
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 Marty Liguori will make the first of several spring visits to Franklin Field tomorrow and Saturday, but neither Jim Ryun nor Kipchoge Keino will be challenging him on this track and field weekend.

title: TWINS HERE TONIGHT ; METS TO VISIT CUBS
description: The Yankees and the Mets will return to action today aft er a day off yesterday. The Yanks will meet the Minnesota Twins tonight at the Yankee Stadium and the Mets play the Cubs this afternoon in Chicago.

title: CONTROL DATA SEEKS AN END TO I.B.M. SUIT
description: The Control Data Corpora tion reported yesterday sharply higher firstquarter earnings and asked the Federal court for dismissal of an antitrust suit filed against it by the In ternational Business Machines Corporation in St. Paul on Wednesday.

title: GOVERNOR WANTS RELIEF OVERSEER
description: ALBANY, April 22Gover nor Rockefeller asked the Leg islature today to authorize the appointment of a welfare in spector general with broad powers to investigate state and local welfare operations to in sure proper expenditure of wel fare funds.

title: CHINA MAY BE EASING REBEL AID, THAI SAYS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22The Government of Thailand has begun to detect signs that Communist China may be moving toward greater restraint in its support of rebel movements in Thailand and other Southeast Asian coun tries, the Thai Foreign Minister, Thanat Khoman, said today.

title: Britain and France Authorize Building of 4 More Concordes
description: LONDON, April 22  Brit ain and France agreed tonight on a further move toward com mercial production of their su personic aircraft, the Concorde.

title: Onegin Is Danced By Jan Stripling For Stuttgart Ballet
description: Cool toward innocent love and drawn toward destruction by his flawed conception of honor, Eugene Onegin is and was a subject for epic poetry.

title: Settlement of Drug Overcharge By Five Companies Is Approved
description: A $32.5million settlement was approved yesterday for private hospitals and health plans that complained they were illegally overcharged for antibiotic drugs.

title: A ChildWelfare Report Stresses Integrity of Family
description: A report calling for the complete reorganization of the city's child welfare sys tem that would stress keep ing a family together instead of placing children in foster homes is being released today by the Citizens' Committee for Children.

title: Books of The Times
description: BLUE MERIDIAN. The Search for the Great White Shark. By Peter Matthiessen. 204 Pages. Illustrated. Random House. $8.95.

title: FLOYD WILLIAMSON, A FORMER NEWSMAN
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., April 22Floyd Williamson, a former newspaperman and fundraiser in New York, died yesterday in Biddeford. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: On Reverse Sides of Generation Gap?
