description: They are rich, renowned, beautiful and black. They are also mother and daugh ter. In the nineteenseventies such a situation might in sure an automatic generation gap.

title: AD RESTRICTIONS ON FUNDS SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., said at a meeting of the mutualfund industry today that mutual funds had been public whipping boys for too ong. Congress and the Securi ties and Exchange Commission should turn their regulatory jattention to other, larger, in stitutional investors, he added.

title: Wanamaker, Jenner 1, 2 In the Decathlon at Drake
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 22 (AP)Rick Wanamaker, former Drake University stand out, won two events today and captured the decathlon at the 62d Drake Relays with 7.693 points.

title: 5 IN JERSEY CITED IN KICKBACK CASE
description: NEWARK, April 22  Five men who until recently consti tuted the entire Union City school board were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of extorting kickbacks from companies doing business with the board.

title: Pacers Defeat Stars, 127 to 109, To Stay Alive in ABA Playoffs
description: ANDERSON, Ind., April 22 (AP)The Indiana Pacers stayed alive in the American Basketball Association Western Division playoffs with a 127 109 victory over the Utah Stars tonight.

title: City Policeman Suspended In L. I. Pornography Case
description: A 28yearold policeman who was allegedly involved in a Long Island pornographic ring that used young children as models was suspended from the force yesterday.

title: Board Backs 34th St. Heliport
description: Community opposition failed yesterday to block a new East Side heliport proj ect, but it detoured a city ran for a trailer park to house families displaced by urban renewal.

title: Administration Debating Response to Busing Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Administration's prelimi nary assessment of the Su preme Court's decision on school busing in the South has confronted President Nixon with a host of delicate political and legal issues. And it has brought the first glimmerings of yet another internal debate over racial policy.

title: MISS STACY GAINS GOLF FINAL AGAIN
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP)  An eagle 3 on the 14th hole sparked the late rally of Hollis Stacy, the defending champion, as she and a five time winner, Barbara McIntire, scored semifinal victories to day in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: Doctors in China Explain LimbSaving Technique
description: SHANGHAI, April 22Doc tors at the No. 6 People's Hospi tal here say that they lead the world in reconnecting severed hands, arms and fingers.

title: Chase Raises Prime Rate To 5% From 5%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, reacting to higher shortterm in terest rates in the open market, announced yesterday an in crease in its prime, or minimum rate on business loans to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, ef fective this morning.

title: Store Sales Up for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended April 17 were an estimated $729million, an increase of 4 per cent over the $698million for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail sales for the latest week were an esti mated $7,358,000,000, an in crease of 6 per cent from the $6,876,000,000 of the corre sponding week of last year.

title: Burglary Suspect Is Slain By Patrolman on East Side
description: An unidentified man de scribed by the police as a sus pected burglar was shot and killed last night by a patrolman during a chase down a fire escape and across backyards on the Upper East Side.

title: Inflation's Smaller Bite
description: The slowdown of inflation reflected in the consumer price index for the first quarter is the most encouraging development thus far in the fight to steady the purchas ing power of the dollar. If sustained for the rest of the year, it would mean an inflation rate of less than 3 per cent, only about half the dangerous rate of 196970.

title: ALOYSIUS H. ZUGGER
description: BUFFALO, April 22 (AP) Aloysius H. Zugger, who man aged Hilton hotels across the country during his 47year hotel career, died today in Mil lard Fillmore Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LON NOL CONFERS ON NEW MANDATE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 22  Gen. Lon Nol met with his advisers today for consul tations on whether he should accept the renewed mandate to form a government given to him by Chief of State Cheng Heng yesterday.

title: City Asks P.S.C. to Reject Increase in Phone Rates
description: The Lindsay administration, arguing that telephone service in New York City was poor and that it had beep excep tionally bad in part of Man hattan and Brooklyn, urged yesterday the rejection of a $391million rate increase for the New York Telephone Com pany.

title: Nicklaus, Barber Lead Golf on 69's
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 22 Jack Nicklaus and Miller Barber shared the lead at 69 today after the first round of the Tournament of Champions, but the course, with its high rough, proved too exacting for most players. The field consisted of 35 professionals who had won at least one tourney on the circuit dur ing the last 12 months.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $5.5BILLION PLAN TO PROVIDE JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Brushing aside threats of a Presidential veto, the House ap proved today a $5.5billion eco nomic development bill embrac ing a crash program to create jobs for the unemployed.

title: Pakistan Reports Indians Do Not Recognize Bengalis
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 22  India has given assur ances that she does not recognize the socalled Bangla Desh regime proclaimed by separatists in East Pakistan, the Pakistani radio said tonight.

title: Judge Lets Veterans Sleep on the Mall; Rebukes U.S. Aides
description: WASHINGTON, April 22An angry Federal judge sharply criticized the Justice Depart ment tonight as he dissolved an injunction against camping on the Mall by Vietnam veter ans demonstrating against the war.

title: JANOWSKI IS HEARD IN A VIOLIN RECITAL
description: At the age of 20, Piotr Janow ski, the violinist from Poland who was heard Wednesday night at Tully Hall, plays with the finished technique and mature musicianship of some cone twice his age.

title: HARVARD WEIGHS 3YEAR PROGRAM
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22  At least two major uni versities, Harvard and Prince ton, are considering cutting their undergraduate programs from four years to three.

title: NEW YORK
description: When the mayors of America's ma jor cities visited New York this week, three things were fairly obvious: First, they felt the crisis of the cities was the major threat to the security of the nationmore serious than Vietnam or anything else. Second, they felt that the bankruptcy and anarchy of the cities were underestimated by the peo ple and by the state and Federal Governments; and third, they feltin fact they knew  that their campaign for President Nixon's revenueshar ing and taxreform programs was failing.

title: BUCKLEY DEFENDS PRESIDENT ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Senator James L. Buckley of New York and three other Re publican Senators took the Senate floor today to defend President Nixon's withdrawal policy in Vietnam.

title: Papp Chooses Next Play
description: Joseph Papp's next produc tion at the New York Shake speare Festival Public Theater will be The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel, a new play by David Rabe, opening May 16. Jeff Bleckner will direct. Ron O'Neal, William Atherton and Joseph Fields will play leading roles.

title: 489532 Wins in Jersey
description: MENLO PARK, N.. J., April 22 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey State lottery is 489532. The holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000; with the last five digits, $4,000; the last four $400 and the last three, $40. Hold ers of tickets with the last two digits qualify for the mil lionaire's drawing to he held later this year. The drawing today was at the Menlo Park Shopping Center.

title: Corporation Profits Up 4% From First Quarter of '70
description: Profits of major American corporations chalked up their first yeartoyear gain in the first quarter since 1969, the First National City Bank report ed yesterday on the basis of a preliminary tabulation of state ments from 685 companies.

title: Manson Enters San Quentin, But He'll Leave It Soon
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 22 (UPI)Charles M. Manson, sentenced to die for the mur der of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons, was moved into San Quention state prison today to become the 94th occupant of California's Death Row.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 23, 1971

title: COLOMBO SR. IS HELD ON GAMBLING COUNTS
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday indicted Joseph A. Colombo Sr., on charges of controlling a $10 millionayear gambling syndi cate in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Nassau County.

title: Movers Reach Tentative Pact; Industry Plans a Rate Increase
description: The moving industry here announced yesterday that it would have to increase rates for local and longdistance mov ing as a result of higher labor costs under a tentative agree ment reached with two team sters unions.

title: Swedish Bank Rate Cut By Half a Point to 6%
description: STOCKHOLM, April 22 (Reu ters)Sweden lowered her bank rate to 6 per cent from 6.5 per cent today. The new rate be comes effective tomorrow.

title: Hardin Asks Fast Aid to Drought Area
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin called on Con gress today to act speedily on new farm credit legislation to help combat the searing drought in the Southwest.

title: Pakistani Diplomat Rebuffed
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 22 Mahdi Masud, the Pakistani diplomat who armed here last night as the new Deputy High Commissioner, tried unsuccess fully today to take control of the Calcutta mission.

title: Yves Saint Laurent: He's Still Flirting With the Midi Length
description: PARIS, April 22The midi length is not dead. Not to Yves Saint Laurent, at any rate.

title: Coal Operators Attack Mine Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  Spokesman for two Important segments of the coal industry opened strong public attacks today on the Bureau of Mines, accusing it of unreasonable enforcement of Federal safety standards. They said that the bureau was forcing the closure of safe mines.

title: Nun Teacher Shortage Forcing College to Shut
description: EMMETTSBURG, Md., April 22 (UPI)St. Joseph College, one of the oldest Roman Catholic women's schools in the nation, will close in June, 1973, because of a shortage of teaching nuns, college offi cials announced today.

title: GRAEBNER, BELKIN REACH SEMIFINALS
description: HOUSTON, April 22 (AP) Firstseeded Clark Graebner of New York and Mike Belkin of Canada advanced to the semi finals today in the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament.

title: FIRE ANT SPRAYING RESUMED IN SOUTH
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) A Government spraying pro gram against fire ants was re sumed on April 12 and is ex pected to cover more than seven million acres in the Southeast this year, the Agri culture Department announced today.

title: RULE ON EQUAL TIME OPPOSED BY BURCH
description: TUCSON, Ariz., April 22  The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Dean Burch, said here yesterday that he favored doing away with the requirement that broadcast ers grant equal time to all can didates for an office if they give time to one.

title: Claremont School Fills Post
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., April 22 (AP)Dr. Barnaby C. Kee ney, who has been serving as spokesman for a consortium of five major universities in Washington, is leaving the na tion's capital to become the first president of the Clare mont Graduate School, effec tive June 1. The appointment of Dr. Keeney, former president of Brown University, was an nounced yesterday.

title: Nixon Sends Condolences
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (Reuters)President Nixon to day sent a brief message ex pressing his condolences to the family of Haiti's President, Francois Duvalier, who died last night.

title: Advertising:
description: The oil industry, which has been catching its share of the broadsides from environment alists, will counter with an advertising barrage backed by $4million.

title: CONSERVATION ACT PASSES ASSEMBLY
description: ALBANY, April 22The As sembly approved a bill today that permits individuals and groups to bring suit in State, Supreme Court against corpo rate polluters as part of their constitutional right to a clean and healthful environment.

title: Violin Finals Tomorrow
description: The finals of the Cosmopoli tan Violin Competition will be held tomorrow morning at 9 at the Ethical Culture Society Auditorium, Central Park West at 64th Street, and will be open to the public. Contestants from Canada, Portugal, Israel, Japan, Korea and the United States will compete for a prize of $1,000 and solo perform ances with the Cosmopolitan Young People's Symphony at Philharmonic Hall on May 15 and 18.

title: The Stage: Adaptations of Metamorphoses and Story Theater
description: Son of Story Theater arrived at the Ambassador Theater last night to run in alternation with Paul Sills's charmingly horrific adapta tions of Grimm fairy tales. These new tales have been adapted from Ovid's Meta morphoses, but those hop ing for a possible Dirty Story Theater are in for slight disappointment. Arnold Weinstein's adaptations of Ovidean love and frolics is tactful almost to the point of chastity. But like its prede cessor it has charm, origi nality and imagination.

title: Philharmonic Plays Oiseaux Exotique
description: The audience was part of the story at the Thursday night New York Philharmonic concert. After Pierre Boulez, with Paul Jacobs at the piano, had conducted Olivier Mes siaen's Oiseaux exotiques, there was a mixture of cheers and boos. When the partici pants came out for deserved bowsMr. Jacobs had played brilliantlythe cheers drowned out the boos. But there was no exodus, as there had been last week. Everybody seemed interested, and there was an excitement in the hall that Philharmonic concerts normally do not arouse.

title: Reginald Cleveland Dies at 84; Times' First Automobile Editor
description: RANDOLPH, Vt., April 23  Reginald M. Cleveland, the first automobile editor of The New York Times and later the news paper's aviation editor, died here today at the Tranquility Nursing Home, He was 84 years old.

title: Macmillan Says Eisenhower Yielded All Power to Dulles
description: LONDON, April 23Former Prime Minister Harold Macmil lan said tonight that President Eisenhower, at the end of his first term, had really surren dered all power to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles.

title: White House Sets a Quiet Tone For Today's Antiwar Protest
description: WASHINGTON. April 23 The White House set a tone of official forbearance today to ward the antiwar demonstra tors who will gather tomorrow to conduct their fourth mass protest here since President Nixon took office.

title: MAYOR SEES CUTS IN DRUG PROGRAM
description: The city's antinarcotics pro grams would be cut to rib bons by state budget reduc tions, Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday in a news conference at City Hall.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Several weeks ago we learned that Brazil's leading theater director Augusto Boal, had disappeared in So Paulo on his way home from a re hearsal at his theater, The Arena Theater of So Paulo. It was only on March 9 that further word reached us outlining some of the details of his disappearance.

title: Northeast Airlines Agrees To a TakeOver by Delta
description: Merger News

title: New Sports Policy Stirs South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 23A heavily quali fied step toward racial integra tion in sports, announced last night by Prime Minister John Vorster, was both applauded and condemned in South Africa today.

title: James F. Clyne Jr., 44, Lone Star Cement Counsel
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 23  James F. Clyne Jr., general counsel and secretary of Lone Star Cement Corpora tion, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 44 years old and lived here.

title: 63 Illegally Parked Cars Display P.B. A. Cards
description: A total of 63 illegally parked private cars displaying Patrol men's Benevolent Association membership cards were in the streets around the 17th Pre cinct Police station at 3 P.M. yesterday.

title: SWISS IS SENTENCED FOR PASSING SECRETS
description: GENEVA, April 23Alfred Frauenknecht, a 44yearold Swiss jetengine expert, was sentenced to four and a half years' imprisonment today for selling to Israel the blueprints and other documents needed to build engines used in the French Mirage3 fighter.

title: Prices of Peppers and How They Grew
description: WASHINGTONHow can it be, in this farmrich coun try, that vegetable staples such as green peppers or cucumbers or leeks are priced so high? Is a greedy little syndicate somewhere making undue profit on green peppers selling for 35 cents apiece?

title: Wolff's 9UnderPar 135 Leads in Tallahassee Golf
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 23 (UPI)  Randy Wolff of Beau mont, Tex., shot a 69 today to take a onestroke lead after two rounds in the Tallahassee open golf tournament. Wolff had a nineunderpar 135 at the midway point.

title: DeVoe to Coach Va. Tech
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 23 (AP)Don DeVoe, an assistant at Ohio State, agreed today to a threeyear contract as the new head basketball coach at Virginia Tech. DeVoe succeeds Howie Shannon, who resigned March 30.

title: MANSFIELD SEEKS TAX PLAN REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, asked the Democrats on the Senate Finance Commit tee today to examine the Nixon Administration's plan to cut business taxes by $3billion an nually and to decide whether such action infringed on Con gressional prerogatives.

title: Pearl Buck: Dawn in the East
description: PERKASIE, Pa.A new day is just over the horizon. I know it from an everincreasing light. The day never dawns suddenly. At first there is only darknessthe darkness of the moon less night. If the sky is clouded there are no stars, But for watchers for the dawn, of whom I am one, the very darkness has its changes. It grows less dense, blackness becomes not light, but a different shade of the dark. Slowly, and then with increasing speed, the sky is grey, the clouds dis perse, there is a glow in the East.

title: Mining Company Is Ordered to Stop Polluting Lake
description: DULUTH, Minn., April 23 The Reserve Mining Company, which each day dumps 67,000 tons of taconite tailings into Lake Superior, was told today that it would have to stop pol luting the lake in this manner or face Federal court action.

title: Orchestra Auditions Set
description: The National Orchestral As sociation will hold auditions from May 4 to 8 for young in strumentalists working and living in the New York area who would like to play with the training orchestra next sea son. Grantsinaid are available to qualifying players

title: Spartan Test Called Success
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that the Safeguard missile system passed its 12th flight test successfully on Wednesday despite the failure of a Polaris missile nose cone that was to have been its target over the Pacific. The Pentagon spokes man, Jerry W. Friedheim, said the Spartan missile success fully intercepted the space point and the Spartan mission was termed a success.

title: PRODUCTIVITY UP IN FIRST QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Productivity, or output per manhour, rose strongly in the first quarter of this year, as expected, the Labor Depart ment reported today.

title: Births
description: JACOBSONMr, and Mrs. Martin announce the birth of their daughter Jan Michele, April 23, 1971.

title: Body of 2d Lost Bronx Boy Is Found in Harlem River
description: The body of 7yearold Frank Ramos, who had been missing fro mhis home in the Bronx for the last month, was found floating in the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: N. Y. High School Elevens Allowed to Play 9 Games
description: ALBANY, April 23 (AP) The State Board of Regents voted today to permit high school football teams to play nine games a season, instead of the usual eight, at the op tion of local school officials.

title: Japan Leads Aussies, 20
description: TOKYO, April 23 (AP)Ja pan took a 20 lead over Aus tralia in the Eastern Zone Sec tion A Davis Cup finals today by capturing two marathon singles matches with sharp, ac curate tennis.

title: Sports of The Times
description: I think that everyone should get into some sport activity, but I think that people should do it in order to seek the rewards you're supposed to get out of it, said George Sauer last week in what may have been his valedictory to professional football. I don't think they should go into any authoritarian system of sport that implicitly and explicitly tries to keep them in a prolonged stale of adolescence.

title: Bengalis Ask Recognition
description: NEW DELHI, April 23 (UPI) The Bengali independence movement appealed to the United States and China today to recognize it as the rightful government of East Pakistan.

title: WILLIAM S. MULLEN
description: William S. Mullen, chief clerk of the New York County Sur rogate's Court since 1966, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home, 181 Bergen Avenue, Ridgefield Park, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: Art: John Chamberlain's Sculptures
description: If you have never felt en thusiastic about John Cham berlain's sculptures made from crumpled automobile body parts (I, for one, have always been able to contain myself in their presence), you might find his new exhibi tion at Leo Castelli, 4 East 77th Street, an agreeable surprise. On the other hand, if you have been one of Mr. Chamberlain'f, admirers, you may feel that he has sacri ficed force for elegance.

title: ChinaA Policy
description: The first need for America in its dealings with China is a policy. At the outset, however, let us say what policy is not.

title: Cambodia Without a Premier For 4th Day as Lon Nol Confers
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 23  Cambodia remained with out a government for a fourth day today as Gen. Lon Nol consulted with his medical and political advisers on whether to accept a renewed mandate to serve as Premier.

title: Barrios's 212 Leads by Shot
description: MADRID, April 23 (UPI) Valentin Barrios of Spain posted a oneunderpar 71 today for a 212 total and a onestroke lead in the Madrid open golf tourna ment. Tomas Lopez, who also had a 71, was second at 213.

title: HUNDREDS FIGHT BRUSH FIRES HERE
description: Hundreds of firefighters were pitted yesterday against brush fires, spread by winds of more than 40 miles an hour, in parched sections of the New York metropolitan area.

title: SAMS DENOUNCES SEALE AND GARRY
description: NEW HAVEN, April 23In a 10minute tirade today that left many in the courtroom stunned, the state's star wit ness against Bobby G. Seale accused both him and his law yer, Charles R. Garry, of playing upon people, using the blacks and the whites, telling lies and incriminat ing people in an effort to pro tect the image of the Black Panther party.

title: Museum Theme: Stop, Look, Listen and Sense
description: If you see some people in the next three weeks running up Avenue of the Americas to feel the wind on their faces, don't worry. They're part of the new show at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts and so, probably, are you.

title: ChainStore Volume Rises
description: March chainstore sales felt the effects of a later Easter and showed the smallest gain in many years, according to a compilation of volume of the country's leading chain and catalogue organizations.

title: Barber and Nicklaus Still Share Golf Lead
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 23Despite a triple bogey 7 at the opening hole, as a re sult of a bad drive, Miller Bar ber remained tied with Jack Nicklaus for the lead in the Tournament of Champions to day. Each had a total of 140.

title: Bomb Goes Off at Stanford
description: STANFORD, Calif., April 23 (AP)A bomb exploded early today in the darkened building where the Stanford University president, Richard W. Lyman, ha:: his office. Damage was es timated at more than $25,000. No injuries were reported.

title: Sore Leg May Keep Choice Out of Rich Pace Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 23 Eddie Cobb was a disconsolate figure as he sat at his office desk in Barn O at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. He had interrupted a telephone con versation with one of his own ers to disclose that Maida Mil lion, the early favorite to cap ture tomorrow night's $25,000 freeforall pace here, may not even go postward in the one mile feature.

title: Cosmos Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched new satellite in the Cosmos se ries today, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

title: Great Southwest Puts Off Meeting For 3 Months
description: The financially ailing Great Southwest Corporation, a land developer and amusementpark operator, disclosed yesterday that it would be unable to com plete its annual report to stock holders on schedule and, as a result, had postponed its an nual meeting for three and a, half months.

title: Miss Austin Shares Lead
description: MIAMI, April 23 (UPI) Debby Austin and Sandra Spuzich fired twounderpar 72's today to tie for the lead in the first round of the Bur dine's women's invitation golf tournament.

title: Veteran Posed as Pilot To Build Antiwar Role
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)The Air Force said to day that Alfred H. Hubbard, identified Sunday in a nation wide telecast as a Vietnam veteran and a former Air Force captain and pilot, ac tually had been a sergeant with no record of service in Vietnam.

title: ANTHONY J. MARANGA
description: Anthony J. Maranga, associ ate director of St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases in the Bronx, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 47 years old and lived on the grounds of St. Barnabas at Third Avenue and 183rd Street.

title: 6th Army Head Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Pentagon announced to day that Lieut. Gen. Alexander D. Surles Jr. would become commanding general of the 6th Army, with headquarters in San Francisco. He will replace Lieut. Gen. Stanley R. Larsen, who is being reassigned as dep uty commander and chief of the Army in the Pacific area.

title: Temple Replaces Rabbi It Ousted
description: Temple Shaaray Teflia, a prominent Upper East Side Reform synagogue, has elect ed Rabbi Harvey M. Tattel baum, a former Navy chap lain with the Marine Corps, as its new spiritual leader.

title: Throngs in Haiti Pay Homage to Duvalier
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 24  Papa Doc! Papa Doc! the women of Haiti wailed today as they filed past the body of Dr. Fravgois Du valier lying in state in the presidential palace.

title: Councilwoman Sees GiveAway Of City's Stations to Channel 13
description: Councilwoman Ruth Lerner of Brooklyn charged yesterday that the city was trying to give away the municipal broadcasting stations to Chan nel 13, whose chairman is one of Mayor Lindsay's former law associates.

title: McCarthy Says Telephone Was Tapped in Campaign
description: SCRANTON, April 23 (AP) Former United States Senator Eugene J. McCarthy says his telephone was tapped during the 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: Most Arms 'Seized In Illinois Obtained Over Long Period
description: CARBONDALE, III., April 23 (AP)A widely publicized ser ies of raids through three southern Illinois counties lost considerable stature today as officials reviewed the oper ations.

title: Woman in High Court Case Guilty on Heroin Charge
description: Mrs. Dollree Mapp, the de fendant in a criminal case that resulted in a landmark decision by the United States Supreme Court barring the admission of evidence seized without a war rant, was convicted yesterday of the illegal possession of 18 ounces of heroin.

title: Cane Wins Poetry Society Gold Medal
description: Melville Cane's 12th book of poetry, Eloquent April, was published on April 15, the au thor's 92d birthday. And, Thurs day night, still in the midst of an active dual career of poet and copyright lawyer, Mr. Cane captured the Gold Medal of the Poetry Society of, America.

title: STANS, IN ATHENS, HAILS THE REGIME
description: ATHENS, April 23Maurice H. Stans, the United States Secretary of Commerce, praised today the sense of security that he said the Greek Govern ment gave American companies operating in this country.

title: Mayor Signs Bill Requiring Dating of Perishable Foods
description: Mayor Lindsay signed a lo cal law yesterday requiring that most perishable foods sold in the city be dated to insure freshness.

title: JERSEY STANDARD RAISES EARNINGS
description: The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) achieved the highest revenues and earnings in its history in the first quar ter this year, with respective increases of 14.5 per cent and 17.2 per cent, the best in at least five years, according to the results reported yesterday.

title: HARRYING OF ENVOYS DENOUNCED BY BUSH
description: George Bush, the United States permanent representa tive to the United Nations, made a vigorous denunciation last night of recent harrass ment of foreign diplomatic missions here.

title: No Exit for Appalachia ...
description: According to the generous definition written into Fed eral law, Appalachia is a region which stretches across thirteen states from the southern tier of New York through West Virginia and Kentucky to the northeast corner of Mississippi. Since the beginning of the Kennedy Administration a decade ago, this region has been the beneficiary of approximately $2 billion in special Federal assistance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have hoped that press analysts would offer more than morningafter commentary on President Nixon's April 7 Vietnam speech. They have not done so.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Countdown for the Derby Begins Today
description: LOUISVILLE, April 23 The Churchill Downs spring meeting will start tomorrow and about 22,000 fans are expected to he on hand. That turnout, however, will be minimal compared with the throng that will cram into the old track a week from tomorrow. On that clay the 97th running of the Kentucky Derby, the country's most famous horse race, will be held. The attendance will be about 100,000. That fig ure is a Madison Avenue status  type approximation, for in actuality no statistics regarding attendance are re leased by the Churchill Downs management. The only de positories for the real figure as regards paid attendance are the Internal Revenue

title: PRICES MOVE UP IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened lower yester day but rallied and closed up slightly on increased volume.

title: Mets Top Cubs in 12th, 76;
description: CHICAGO, April 23It took 4 hours and 12 innings and re quired the services of 38 play ers on both sides, but the New York Mets finally outlasted the Chicago Cubs, 76, today in their first encounter of the season.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK LISTS RISE IN PRICES
description: The Diamond Shamrock Cor poration said yesterday that it would raise prices on six grades of precipitated calcium car bonates, used by the paint, plas tics and rubber industries, by $3 to $5 a ton, effective May 1 for spot customers and June I for contract customers.

title: Lord Portal of Hungerford, 77, Royal Air Force Marshal, Dies
description: LONDON, April 23Marshal of the Royal Air Force Viscount Portal of Hungerford, who as Chief of the Air Staff played a, major role in the shaping of Air Force policy during World War II, died yesterday at his home in Chichester, Sussex. He was 77 years old.

title: In Bustling Shanghai, Growth Is Outward
description: The Talk of Shanghai

title: Disaster Fund May Grow
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a bill to day to make $265million avail able for the Small Business Administration's disaster loan fund. Loans are made from the fund on favorable terms to vic tims of natural disasters.

title: Ashau Sweep Continues
description: SAIGON, April 24 (AP)The allied search for enemy troop and supply concentrations in and around the Ashau Valley went into its 11th day with no significant contact reported.

title: ChinaJapan's Role
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.As we emerge from the sweet delight of watching Chinese and Americans smile at each other and begin to think seriously of how to get along with China, the position of other nations in the East Asian equation comes into focus. Aside from Russia, whose effect on China intrigues us much and puzzles us more, the important countries are Japan and Taiwan.

title: Ceylon to ReEducate Rebels Not Involved in Violence
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 23 The Ceylonese Government, asserting that the ultraleftist uprising was subsiding after two and a half weeks, an nounced plans today to reedu cate those insurgents who had not been directly involved in violence.

title: Haitians Here Ask U.S. Not to Support New Regime
description: Members of the Haitian Re sistance, a coalition of about a dozen organizations that rep resent most of the Haitians here, called on the United States yesterday to withdraw its support of the new regime of JeanClaude Duvalier and to cease all interference in Hai tian affairs.

title: Hess Celebrates in Prison
description: BERLIN, April 23 (AP)Ru dolf Hess, former deputy to Adolf Hitler, held a reunion in West Berlin's Spandau prison today to celebrate the 71st birthday of his wife, Else. Mrs. Hess went to the prison ac companied by their 32yearold son, Wolf Ruediger, a Hamburg engineer. Hess, the last of seven top Nazis sent to Spandau, will be 77 on Monday.

title: Car Sales Decline 6.7%;
description: DETROIT, April 23Sales of new cars from April 10 to April 20 went down 6.7 per cent from the yearearlier period.

title: Mitchell Backs U.S. Right To Wiretap for Security
description: WASHINGTON, April 23In a vigorous defense of the Nixon Administration's use of wire tapping, Attorney General John N. Mitchell insisted today that the Government's right to de fend itself against violent at tack must prevail over some in dividuals; right of privacy.

title: Yale Prom Is Revived This Time at Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 23 The 127yearold Yale Prom, whose demise was of ficially announced last fall, danced back onto the social calendar tonight. But it was a long way from New Haven. The 1971 Yale Prom was staged by Princeton.

title: Fireflies Help Cancer Detection
description: Patents of the Week

title: Veterans Discard Medals In War Protest at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  In twos and threes, the medals flew over a wire fence that had been hastily erected in front of the Capitol and landed at the feet of the statue of Chief Jus tice John Marshall, at the build ing's west entrance. The men, who had won the medals in Vietnam were throwing them away.

title: Merrill Lynch Lists an Offering Of $140Million With S.E.C.
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the largest investment house, registered an initial public offering of million of its own common shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission yester day. The huge concern, which had announced plans some time ago to go public, pro posed a maximum offering: price of $35 a share, which means the offering would he worth a maximum of $140 million. Half the offering is being sold by Merrill Lynch land half by its present stock holders.

title: State Union Sues to Save Jobs By Having the Budget Nullified
description: ALBANY, April 23The Civil Service Employes Association asked the State Supreme Court here today to declare unconsti tutional the recently enacted budget for 197172 that is causing the layoff of thousands of its members.

title: FiveYear Term Imposed On a Jewish Militant Here
description: A Jewigh Defense League member who had pleaded guilty to making false statements in his application for a passport was sentenced in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to five years in prison.

title: Roundup: McLain Loses Out Twice
description: The change in uniform ap parently hasn't done much to improve Denny McLain's temperament.

title: Admiral and RCA Request Antitrust Division Ruling
description: The Admiral Corporation and RCA said yesterday that they had jointly requested that the Antitrust Division of the De partment of Justice inform them if it plans to take any action on the proposed acquisi tion of Admiral's color TV pic ture tube manufacturing equip ment by RCA

title: U.S. Gold Stock Dropped in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 United States international monetary reserve assets de clined by $192million to $14,342,000,000 in March, the Treasury reported today.

title: 4 Seized on Bond Charges
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., April 23 (UPI)Four persons were held by the Federal authorities yes terday on charges of attempting to sell stolen United States saving bonds. They were identi fied as Joseph Henry of North Bergen, N. J.; Ralph Mercuro of Roselle Park, N. J.; Billie Brum mitt of New York City, and Carmen Michel of Baytown, Tex.

title: Yanks Beat Twins, 73
description: Bert Blyleven must have thought he was witnessing, the reincarnation of Babe Ruth.

title: WAR FOE INDICTED IN KISSINGER CASE
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 23 (AP)A Federal grand jury in vestigating the alleged plot to kidnap President Nixon's na tional security adviser indicted an antiwar activist today for unlawfully, willfully and knowingly refusing to testify about the case.

title: WAR RALLY TODAY EXPECTS NEW AID
description: Organizers of the New York contingent in today's mass anti war rally in Washington are counting upon legions of first time protesters  from the suburbs, the trade unions, and from new political groupsto offset what they agree is a noticeable drop in student in volvement in war protests.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday the elec tion of C. William Verity Jr. as board chairman succeeding Logan T. Johnson, who retired earlier this month, Mr. Verity will continue as president and chief executive officer.

title: 4 RECORDS FALL IN DRAKE RELAYS
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 23 (AP)Meet records were bro ken in four events today at the 62d Drake Relays, but the world recordholding Texas A. and M. 880yard relay team was defeated.

title: Cougars File a Suit to Get Cunningham Out of N.B.A.
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 23 (AP)The Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball As sociation filed suit today to prevent Billy Cunningham from playing with the Philadelphia 76ers of the rival National Bas ketball Association next sea son.

title: $5,000 Recycled in Error
description: ROCHESTER, April 23 (AP) Gloria J. Anderson, 27 years old, told officials of an Earth Week paperrecycling drive to day that when she bundled some newspapers to be picked up she accidentally wrapped in a plastic bag that contained $5,000 in cash. The paper was picked up Tuesday, a day before she discovered the money was missing, and is beyond recall. I guess I was kind of stupid not to put the money in bank, Miss Anderson said.

title: Legislature Keeps Its Own Budget Intact
description: ALBANY, April 23  State agencies have started laying off employes and education, welfare and local government officials are still trying to as sess the full impact of the Legislature's budget cuts, but one major unit of state gov ernment has been spared such problems.

title: '71 GROWTH LAG SEEN IN COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, April 23There is likely to be an appreciable slowdown in economic growth in the European Common Mar ket in 1971, in spite of a revival in the United States and Cana da, the Common Market Com mission said today.

title: Versatile Crewmen of Soyuz 10
description: Men in the News

title: Abbott Laboratories
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (UPI) President Edward J. Ledder of Abbott Laboratories told the annual meeting today the Jus tice Department is investigat ing Abbott's agreement with Cutter Laboratories for joint development of a stopper sys tem for intravenous fluid bot tles.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS SPENDING LIMITS FOR '72 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 Legislation that would limit the 1972 Presidential candidates to spending $13.9million each on radio, television, newspapers, magazines and billboards was approved unanimously today by the Senate Commerce Com mittee.

title: Ray's Brother Sentenced
description: ST. LOUIS, April 23 (UPI) John Larry Ray, brother of James Earl Ray, who pleaded guilty to the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was sentenced to 18 years in prison today for his part in a bank robbery. Federal District Court Judge William H. Webster sen tenced Ray, 37 years old, and Ronald S. Goldenstein, 31, to 13 years in prison in the $53, 000 holdup of a bank in St. Peters, Mo., on Oct. 26. Ray had been charged with driving the getaway car.

title: Rockets Strike Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, April 24 (AP)Three 122mm. rockets crashed into the outskirts of Pnompenh ear ly today, destroying three buildings and wounding five civilians, the high command re ported.

title: COLONELS DEFEAT SQUIRES, 115107
description: HAMPTON, Va., April 23 (AP)  The Kentucky Colonels, with Dan Issel putting in key baskets at the end, held off a Virginia comeback tonight for a 115107 victory and a 32 lead over the Squires in their fourofseven game American Basketball As sociation Eastern Division play off final.

title: HAITINK CONDUCTS CARNEGIE CONCERT
description: Joy without superflash, magic without supertricks: these were some of the special qualities of the concert by the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, led by Bernard Haitink, Thursday night at Car negie Hall.

title: MINORITY HIRING UPHELD BY COURT
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 The Nixon Administration's Philadelphia Plan cleared an other hurdle yesterday, when the United States Court of Ap peals for the Third Circuit up held its legality.

title: To the Bengalis in Karachi, Home Seems Far Away
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 23 Sometimes I feel homesick, said Jalal Ahmed, looking down shyly at his hands, but then I take a trip to Chittagong and I am all right for a couple of more years.

title: Furlie Is Full of Soul After Year on Boards
description: Purlie revisited is still Purlie victorious. After a number of vicissitudes, this black musical has ended up at the ANTA Theater, and though it has changed its theater a few times since its opening a year or so ago, it still has the same old soul. In fact, I think it now has more soul.

title: Books of The Times
description: FREAKSHOW: The Rochsoulbluesjazzsichjew blachhumoraexpoppsych Gig and Other Scenes from the CounterCulture. By Albert Goldman. 387 pages. Atheneum. $10.

title: Joseph Stern, Cartoonist In Boston for 46 Years
description: BOSTON, April 23  Joseph Stern, a cartoonist with The Boston Herald Traveler for 46 years, died today at his home in Brookline. He was 79 years old.

title: NORTHSOUTH WON BY MISS MINTIRE
description: PINEHURST, N.C., April 23 (AP)Barbara McIntire stunned 17yearold Hollis Stacy, the defending champion, with fivehole sweep starting at the second hole and went on to score a 6and5 victory today for her sixth North and South amateur golf championship.

title: WILLIAM D. TUCKER, LONGTIME LAWYER
description: William D. Tucker, who prac ticed law here for more than 50 years, specializing in estates, trusts and real estate, died yes terday in Atlantic City Hos pital. He was 83 years old and lived in Margate, N. J. His of fice was at 420 Lexington Avenue.

title: Drumbeat in Washington
description: Thousands of demonstrators will assemble in Wash ington today to protest continuation of the Vietnam war. How much effect their march will have on Admin istration military policy is impossible to predict, but vanguard group made up of Vietnam Veterans Against the War already has accomplished one welcome reversal of Administration policy in an area important to the right of peaceful protest.

title: MARKET REBOUNDS IN SURGE OF BUYING
description: Buying strength surged into the stock market yesterday, sending the glamour issues fly ing and moving blue chips higher.

title: New Ways of Teaching on Trial
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. Now, what does this one say? asks Mrs. Martha Golden, an animated, graying teacher, holding up a flashcard to the six second graders.

title: Plot Foiled, 4 Hostages Are Freed
description: A plot to rob a check cashing service  apparently modeled on the successful robbery last week of a Brook lyn bank  went awry yes terday when the four holdup men were spotted in the act of kidnapping their victims.

title: SOVIET BLOC Pun BIG SEABED STUDY
description: MOSCOW, April 23  In the absence of an international authority on exploitation of seabed resources, the Soviet Union and its allies have quiet ly agreed on an ambitious pro gram of surveys and extrac tion of valuable minerals found on the ocean floor..

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: San Diego Shifts on War, With Many Now Opposed
description: SAN DIEGO, April 22Harry Kripton was a hawk. I really wanted us to go into Vietnam, he remembered the other day. I was more like John Wayne than John Wayne himself.

title: Market Place:
description: You might think that a rise in the banks' prime lending rate such as occurred Thurs day would cool investor en thusiasm for moneysensitive realestate investment trusts.

title: COSSITT TEAM WINS IN FIGURE SKATING
description: A selfemployed New York architect and a 16yearold junior high school pupil won the mixedpairs title as the 49th annual Middle Atlantic figure skating championships opened yesterday at the Sky Rink here.

title: Francis Reverses Trend in Paintings
description: What the painter Sam Francis has done with the field spaces or area against which he played his coin, has been the index to the development of his art. Ever since 1956, when he had his first New York exhibition, it became apparent that the field as an esthetic device was of no small importance to him. As time wore on, Mr. Francis gave increasing ly more prominence to the field and by 1967 the field had almost completely dis placed the color. Color was relegated to the edges of the canvas in the form of thin strips and the rest of the can white field.

title: New Issue Market Registers Gains 8th Week in Row
description: The new issue market climbed for the eighth straight week in quiet trading, but the margin by which advances exceeded declines was slim.

title: Egypt's Press and TV Berated For Too Much Attention to U.S.
description: CAIRO, April 23  Com plaining that Egyptians were being subjected to brainwash ing by American influences, a Cairo newspaper has berated the Egyptian press, radio and television for devoting too much space and time to im portant or trivial, serious or ridiculous events taking place in America.

title: U.S. Raid in North Vietnam May Have Damaged 2 MIG's
description: SAIGON, Saturday, April 24 An attack by United States Navy jets on enemy antiaircraft defenses at the Quanlang air field in North Vietnam Thurs day afternoon may have dam aged one or two MIG21 aircraft located on the ground near the site, the United States com mand announced this morning.

title: India Asks Relief Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22India has requested United Nations assistance for halfmillion refugees from East Pakistan.

title: PAKISTAN CLOSING AN OFFICE IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, April (Reuters) The Pakistan radio said to night that Pakistan had decided to close down the Deputy High Commission office in Calcutta and had asked India to close her Deputy High Commission office in Dacca.

title: Ecology and Economy
description: News Analysis

title: Mrs Crimmins Guilty in 2 Deaths
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins was convicted yesterday of murder in the first degree in the death of her 5yearold son, Edmund Jr., and of manslaughter in the first degree in the death of her daughter, Alice Marie, 4. They died on or about July 14, 1965.

title: A Clarification
description: The management of the Union Pacific Corporation and the Union Pacific Railroad Company announced earlier this week that they had under con sideration a proposal under which the Union Pacific Corpo ration would acquire the re mainin,Y publicly held stock of the railroad. Directors will make no decision as to whether the proposal will be adopted until they have received the ad vice of investment banking con cerns, expected within the next three weeks.

title: MacLaury, 39, Will Head Minneapolis Reserve Bank
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 23 (AP) Bruce K. MacLaury, Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, was, named today the new president, of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. He has resigned his present post but will remain with the Treasury until June.

title: Levitt Returns to I.T.T. Unit in Crisis
description: A corporate crisis precipitat ed by the sudden resignation of the two top executive offi cars of ITT Levitt, Inc., has brought out of retirement Wil liam J. Levitt, who retired three years ago as head of one of the world's most successful homebuilding concerns.

title: CEYLON'S DELEGATE TO SEEK THANT POST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 23  Ceylon today an nounced the candidacy of her permanent representative, H.S. Amerasinghe, to succeed U Thant of Burma as Secretary General of the United Nations.!

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 23The flurry over the Supreme Court's unanimous new decisions on school segregation will not long obscure a growing unease, on other matters, among the Court's real friends and critics. They know the Court cannot always be wise or even consistent. The one thing they do ask of judges given such great power is intellectual honesty. Something must be said when that has gone wrong. It has.

title: Leonhardt, in Tully Hall Recital, Offers Variety at Harpsichord
description: Even before Gustav Leon hardt, the Dutch harpsichordist, walked onstage at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night the audience broke into applause. A stagehand had merely raised Ithe top of the 1642 Johannes Ruckers harpsichord, displaying two opulent Flemish paintings, that decorated the underside of the lid, so that the gilded, instrument stood revealed in all its effulgent glory. That Mr. Leonhardt went on to play a similarly attractive recital only made the cup run over for the assembled throng of harpsichord connoisseurs.

title: Paris Report: Last Winter's Wardrobe Need Not Go to Thrift ShopYet
description: PARIS, April 23  There the girls were, dancing out on the runway, laughing, tee tering a little uncertainly in their anklestrapped, plat formsoled shoes, showing off their hairdos, which had been frizzed into great floating blond and red clouds.

title: Carl Smith, Pediatrician, Dies; A Specialist on Blood Diseases
description: Dr. Carl H. Smith, an inter nationally known authority on children's blood diseases, died yesterday in New York Hospi tal. He was 75 years old and lived at 103 East 84th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The welfare situation in New York and the nation has obviously reached crisis proportions. There are, however, two separate but curiously interrelated measures which can be taken to effect marked improvement in this tragic aspect of our culture:

title: F.B.I. Offices Here Picketed
description: One hundred members of the Italian American Civil.Rights League demonstrated in front of the Federal Bureau of In vestigation offices last night to protest alleged F.B.I. harass ment of ItalianAmericans. The demonstrators carried signs de nouncing the F.B.I. and its di rector, J. Edgar Hoover.

title: HOFFA TO TESTIFY AT INQUIRY HERE
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned president of the international Brotherhood of Teamsters, will be moved this weekend from his cell in Lewisburg, Pa., to New York to testify before a Federal grand jury investigat ing alleged improprieties in volving the teamster pension fund.

title: U.S. Furniture Designers Find a New Market for Their Talents
description: Wendell Castle, one of America's most inventive furniture craftsmen, has tired of just making things for rich people. So he's switching from handcrafted oneof akind designs to those that can be turned out on an assembly line. Mass production, he said, seems the only answer.

title: Jersey Schoolboys Take 4 Events to Dominate First Day of Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 New Jersey schoolboys had one of their best days in the 77 year history of the Penn Relays today. Garden State athletes won the distance medley relay, two of the three field events, the invitation twomile run, and qualified the fastest four some in the 440yard relay.

title: Paris School Reopens
description: PARIS, April 23 (Reuters) The Ecole Normale Superieure, a traditional training ground for France's intellectual elite, reopened today after a three week closure caused by leftist disorders.

title: Daylight Time Begins At 2 A.M. Tomorrow
description: Daylight saving timea confusion for many that sheds light for alltakes ef fect here at 2 A.M. tomorrow.

title: HOUSE JAMESON, 68, RADIO AND TV ACTOR
description: NEWTOWN, Conn., April 23 House Jameson, an actor who for many years played the role of the father in The Aldrich Family on both radio and television, died today in Danbury Hospital. He lived at 40 Mount Pleasant Road. His age was 68.

title: CITY CHURCH UNIT THREATENS SPLIT
description: The Metropolitan Association of the United Church of Christ has voted to terminate its mem bership in the Council of Churches of the City of New York if the council's execu tive leadership is not replaced within a year.

title: Nixon Envoy in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 23 (Reuters) David M. Kennedy, President Nixon's roving ambassador, ar rived here today for a one week visit during which he will meet Government leaders. In formed sources said he would urge the Japanese Government to expedite the liberalization of imports and capital investment from abroad.

title: RICHEY ADVANCES TO NET SEMIFINALS
description: HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Bob Carmichael of France advanced to the semi finals of the 37th annual River Oaks tennis tournament today.

title: Cultural Affairs Workers Hold Death Watch' to Protest Cuts
description: Members of the city's De partment of Cultural Affairs staged a lunchhour death watch yesterday to protest the proposed budget cuts threaten ing most of the city's arts pro grams.

title: THEODORE SWITZ, AN EDUCATOR, 69
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., April 23Dr. Theodore M. Switz, business executive, educational administrator and prominent Episcopal layman, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 69.

title: EDUCATION BOARD PLANS FUND DRIVE
description: The Board of Education an nounced, plans yesterday for a campaign to mobilize public support to obtain more funds for schools and city services in the face of the threatened cutback in staffs and programs.

title: Blacks Act at Ohio College
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, April 23 (UPI)About 25 black stu dents locked themselves inside the Wilmington College adminis tration building for 19 hours today to publicize their de mands, including increased fi nancial aid. They left after conferring with the college president for two and a half hours.

title: Rogers Asks New Chapter in China Ties
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today the United States hoped that the new con tacts with China would become a new chapter in relations between the two countries and not just a new page, as Pre mier Chou Enlai suggested last week.

title: Rome Oll Company
description: CALGARY, April 23 (Cana dian Press)No questions came from Me floor today at the annual meeting' of the Home Oil Co., Limited, even though a major switch in control was virtually complete.

title: Clearing House Admits Franklin
description: The New York Clearing House Association, which has been called the nation's most exclusive banking club, will shortly admit its first new member in 28 years.

title: Auto Output to Rise
description: DETROIT, April 23 (AP) Domestic auto production was scheduled to climb 28 per cent this week over last, as five Ford plants returned to work and full production schedules were resumed at G.M. and Chrysler.

title: Liquori Runs 4:04.1 Mile In Villanova Relay Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 23 Marty Liguori doesn't know how fast he can run the mile.

title: SOYBEANS LOWER IN HEAVY SELLING
description: Commodities futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade dropped sharply yesterday aft er advancing early in the ses sion under heavy selling.

title: Study of Concorde Is Ordered by Heath
description: LONDON, April 23Prime Minister Heath has ordered his toplevel policy analyst, Lord Rothschild, to make a special study of the Concorde super sonic aircraft project.

title: $25,000 PRIZES GIVEN
description: The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday the recipients of its annual awards in art and ar chitecture.

title: INSURANCE CLAIMS IN NOFAULT DROP
description: BOSTON, April 23 (UPI) Auto insurance companies in Massachusetts have realized great savings during the first three months of the nofault system but have not passed the benefits on to the public, Gov. Francis W. Sargent said today.

title: ..but Hope for Jobless
description: The Appalachia bill would be on its way to President Nixon's desk were it not that the House added an unrelated amendment authorizing $2 billion for a nation wide program of public works, principally water and sewage projects. The amendment authorizes up to 100 per cent in Federal grants in areas which have sub stantial unemploymentusually 6 per cent or more among the entire work force or among Vietnam veterans.

title: RED CROSS IN HANOI ASKED TO LIST NEEDS
description: GENEVA, April 23  The League of Red Cross Societies has asked the North Vietnam Red Cross Society to specify what kind of supplies it would like to obtain from a $200 thousand donation by the Unit ed Nations Children's Fund, it wap disclosed today.

title: STAFF AT QANTAS WARNED OF CRISIS
description: SYDNEY, April 23 (AP) Qantas, the Australian interna tional airline, has told its staff it is facing a financial crisis and is struggling to stay out of the red.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: March on Washingtonlive, allday cover age.Today, 10 A.M., WBAI, 90:5 FMAdvt.

title: Jazz Concert in New Orleans Provides a Contrast in Ages
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 23  Thomas Sancton, a novelist and newspaperman who has written extensively about New Orleans, last night contributed in vicari ous fashion to what should at least be a footnote in this city's cultural history. His son, Thomas Jr., who was taken as child to hear the jazz musicians at Preservation Hall by his jazzloying father and who later studied clarinet with George Lewis, one of New Or leans's latterday jazz stars, came home from Harvard Uni versity with a jazz band that provided one of the high points of the opening concert of the fourday New Orleans jazz and heritage festival.

title: Ayub to Be Treated in U.S.
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 23 (AP)Former President Mo hammad Ayub Khan will leave Pakistan Monday for medical treatment in the United States, family sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevin's Old Detractors Turn Lyrical Over His Play
description: When the Rangers resume their Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Chicago Black Hawks tomorrow afternoon, banner of apology presuma bly will hang from the top deck of Madison Square Gar den, as it did during Thurs day night's game. In careful, homemade style, it read:

title: Screen: Ideas for Cliches
description: I think that Melvin Van Peebles has the talent, the intelligence and even the in stincts of a good filmmaker despite a growing body of evidence to the contrary. The latest exhibit, Sweet Sweet back's Baadasssss Song, Van Peebles's third and worst feature, opened yester day at the Art and Cinerama theaters, and at the Loew's Victoria.

title: Soyuz Orbit Shifted; Link to Lab Awaited
description: MOSCOW, April 23The threeman spacecraft Soyuz 10, which was launched last night, corrected its orbit today in ap parent preparation for a ren dezvous with the unmanned scientific workshop Salyut.

title: President of Diners Club Is Elected Its Chairman
description: R. Newell Lusby, president and chief executive officer of the Diner; Club, Inc. was elected to the additional office of chairman succeeding J. Victor Herd who became chair man of the executive commit tee. The officers were elected at the organizational meeting on Tuesday, but the company made the announcement of the change yesterday.

title: Alexey Brodovitch, 76, Is Dead; Leader in Fashion Photography
description: PARIS, April 23  Alexey Brodovitch, former art director of Harper's Bazaar and teacher of many prominent photograph ers and illustrators, died April 15 in Le Thor, near Avignon, France, after a long illness. He was 76 years old and had been residing in Vaulouse with his brother, Georges, for sev eral years.

title: Senate Unit Acts on Student Deferment
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today the Nixon Administration's request that the President be given authority to eliminate student deferments under the draft.

title: McDonnell Douglas Net Down for First Quarter
description: ST. LOUIS, April 23James S. McDonnell, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's 72year old president and chairman, bluntly told his sharehold ers here today our earnings are still declining. . . They will continue to decline a little until we get into heavy deliv eries of our latest aircraft, the wonderful threeengine DC10.

title: Antiques: Differences in Plated Silver
description: Sheffield plated silver is a field to be explored by col lectors who admire English silver but do not feel up to paying the prices that fine 18thcentury examples are bringing these days.

title: ExMarine Recounts 1969 U. S. Incursion in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, April 23A former Marine lieutenant told a group of Congressmen today that his unit penetrated nearly five miles inside Laotian terri tory in February, 1969, as part of a twoweek interdiction and ambush mission.

title: MORTON H. FRY DEAD; A BANKER HERE, 83
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 23 Morton H. Fry, senior partner in Riter, Pyne, Kendall & Hol lister, investment bankers at 100 Wall Street, New York, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 199 Upper Moun tain Avenue.

title: Bridge: In Swiss Team Championship Large Field Expected Today
description: Nearly all tournaments con sist of a number of independ ent events, but in recent years the Greater New York Bridge Association has found it desirable to devote a com plete weekend to a single team contest.

title: MOST BIG BANKS JOIN IN RATE RISE
description: All but a lvmdful of the na tion's largest banks joined yes terday in raising their prime lending rates to 5 per cent from 5 per cent.

title: ChinaThe U. N. Issue
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Twice since 1949 the People's Republic of China has actively sought acceptance by the world community. Peking's initial ef forts to enter the U.N. and to estab lish diplomatic relations came to an end in the fall of 1950 with the U.S. drive in Korea to the Chinese border.

title: Mississippi State U. Gets Turner Catledge's Papers
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., April 23 (AP)Turner Catledge, former executive editor of The New York Times, donated his per sonal papers today to the li brary at Mississippi State Uni versity.

title: HUMPHREY BACKS LOAN TO LOCKHEED
description: Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey, Democrat of Minnesota, gave qualified support yester day to the idea of a Govern ment guarantee of loans to salvage the program to build a Lockheed airbus powered by RollsRoyce jet engines.

title: Heifetz Makes Rare TV Appearance
description: Through the years, a few of music's glamour boys Toscanini, Horowitz, Rubin stein, to mention three have been the subject of fulllength television shows. Now comes Jascha Heifetz the greatest of all violin stars. The American Tele phone and Telegraph Com pany sponsored the show, which was given last night on the National Broadcasting Company network. It was not the first time Heifetz has appeared on television. Some years back he did a series of masterclass shows with his pupils. But here he was in effect giving a recital on his own.

title: Church Blamed for Bias Against Women
description: A Roman Catholic woman theologian charged yesterday that the Christian church over the centuries had perpetuated discrimination against women by maintain ing that the practice had di vine sanction.

title: Nassau to Aid Bus Concern By Buying Its Rolling Stock
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 23 Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today that an agreement had been reached between the county and the Hempstead Bus Corporation that would permit the bus line to continue normal service for its 12,000 daily riders.

title: Nigeria Reaches Oil Accord
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 23 (Reuters)Nigeria announced tonight agreement with the AngloDutch ShellBP group on a new posted price of $3.21 barrel for crudeoil exports. This is an 85cent increase in the basic posted price fixed in September. The Government also announced that the French concern Safrap would resume operations with Nigerian Gov ernment participation.

title: ...Ordeal by Bus
description: The Metropolitan Transit Authority deserves credit for a good idea well executed in the new express bus service between the upper East Side and Wall Street. But it de serves blame at the same time for a general service that has gone downhill as fast as the fare has gone up.

title: ExJersey Mayor Linked to Zicarelli Gets Bribery Term
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., April 23 (AP)  A county judge to day gave former Mayor John R. Armellino of West New York a tongue lashing and then sen tenced him to 48 to 56 monthly in state prison for conspiracy to protect underworld gambling in his town.

title: Knudsen Being Sought To Head'White Motor
description: CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) The White Motor Corpora tion in Cleveland confirmed today that officials were ne gotiating with Semon E. Knudsen, Motor president of the Ford Motor Company, to become White Motor's chair man and chief executive officer.

title: Station in Space ...
description: The latest Soviet space spectacular follows a long series of indications by Kremlin leaders that their present priority in manned space flight is establishment of a long lasting station in space. This latest experiment seems an important  as well as expensive  step on the road toward that objective.

title: COAST RIDER GETS CALL FOR GREY LAG
description: Where is the rest of New York? asked Jerry Lambert with an eartoear grin. This is the second time I've been to the big city and all I've seen so far are a couple of motel rooms and Aqueduct.

title: Ange Lorenzo, Composer, Author of Seepy Time Gal
description: SAGINAW, Mich., April 23 (AP)Ange Lorenzo, a musi cian and restaurateur who wrote the song Sleepy Time Gal, died yesterday in Saginaw Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Goldwater Denounces Proposals to Curb President's War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, April 23  Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that proposals to impose legis lative restrictions on the Presi dent's warmaking powers were improper, unwise and perhaps illegal.

title: S.E.C. CENSURES JESUP & LAMONT
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the American Stock Exchange announced dis ciplinary actions yesterday against Jesup & Lamont, the brokerage firm, for the alleged misuse of inside information about the Parvin  Dohrmann Company.

title: A Footnote: Kaiser's Plan to Invade U.S.
description: STONY BROOK, L.I. April 23  A candidate for a Ph.D. in history says he has un covered evidence for the first time that Germany had formal plan to attack and in vade the United States at least 14 years before the United States entered World War I, in 1917.

title: Green's Grand Slam Helps A's Defeat Tigers, 54, for 7th Victory in Row
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 24 (AP)Dick Green smashed basesloaded homer during fiverun sixthinning rally to day as the Oakland Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 54, for their seventh consecutive vic tory.

title: Artists Going to the People in Queens
description: Twenty years ago a Queens artist, Michael Mundel, since 1934 an exhibitor at the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition tin Greenwich Village, gathered 20 friends and formed the Greater Now York Outdoor Art Association.

title: Angels Win on Grand Slam
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., April 24 (UPI)Roger Repoz smashed a grandslam homer with one out in the ninth tonight to give California a 74 victory over the Baltimore Orioles and snap a fourgame Angels' losing streak.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Girl, 18, Raped in Queens Home; The Police Arrest Suspect, 29
description: An 18yearold Queens Col lege student was raped in her bedroom in the affluent Jamaica Estates section of Queens at about 3:30 A.M. yesterday.

title: Miss Flanzer Plans Bridal
description: SCARSDALE, N, Y., April 24Miss Jan Cynthia Flanzer and Barry Alan Lerner plan to be married in September.

title: Virginia Hart Plans Bridal
description: NEW HAVEN, April 24 Mr. and Mrs. James K Hart have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Virginia Kaull Hart, to Dr. George I. Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Thomas of Seattle.

title: Photography
description: THE latest issue of aper ture (no. 15:3) is an illustrated and annotat ed catalogue of Being Without Clothes, a major exhibit organized by Minor White which was presented at M.I.T. in November of last year.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Dream Ending

title: Commissioning Turns Out New Breed
description: Going Into Commission brings out a new breed. A man on his boat is not the same man off it. He may look the same (despite the clothes), but he isn't. The legend of the sea backs this up.

title: SEARCHERS AWAIT LOCH NESS STAR
description: Loch Ness, the Scottish lake that is the La Scala of mon ster seekers, opens a new sea son next month with an old plot, improved props; a familiar cast and high hopes that its reticent star will end a millen ium and a half of shyness and take a lingering bow.

title: Judge Motley to Hear Suit Against City's Use of Welfare Hotels
description: A trial has been set In Fed eral Court here on the question of housing welfare recipients in hotels.

title: Sharp Rise in U.S. Indians Tied to Census Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Census Bureau counted 791,839 American Indians in the nation last year, an increase of more than 50 per cent over the 1960 count or 523,591. But there are not really that many more Indians, the bureau said.

title: Facts on the Kentucky Derby
description: Fastest and youngestNorthern Dancer, in 1964, ran the 1 miles in 2 minutes for the Derby record. He was the youngest winner in Derby history. Foaled in Canada May 27, 1961, he was not yet 3 years old when he won on May 2, 1964.

title: City to Have Old Paper Recycled and Use Some
description: The city is going to use some recycled paper in its offices and, in turn, the manu facturer of the paper has agreed to buy the city's waste paper for recycling, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: Emerson, Whitman and James as prefigures of creeping apocalypse
description: Is the anarchic temper of modern art and literature a menace to so ciety? The question has been with us for a long while, but in recent years the radical youth movement has given it a new meaning. Some critics  I think especially of Lionel and Diana Trillinghave been sug gesting that classical modern cul ture may be a prime source of the bitter hostility which so many of the young now direct against our social institutions. They remind us that most of the great imaginative works pro duced in the West since the roman tics exalt the idea of escaping wholly from societal bonds. In fact many of them were designed with the express purpose of subverting confidence in the binding values and authorities of middle class life.

title: Rent Curbs Appear Dim For Nassau
description: ALBANY, April 24High legislative sources report that there is little chance that bills to permit Nassau County municipalities to control rents will pass during the current session.

title: Anne Horgan Wed To Robert E. Moses
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N, Y., April 24Miss Anne Joyce Horgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Horgan Jr. of Pelham Manor, was married here this afternoon to Robert Everett Moses, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Everett Moses of Ridgewood, N. J.

title: LATIN BISHOPS WARN OF GROWING VIOLENCE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 24A conference of Latin American Bishops on social action has warned that violence was spreading alarmingly in the continent.

title: Letter to the Editor 11  No Title
Class Dates Listed By Offshore School
description: The fiveyearold Offshore Sailing School, with more than 900 men and women graduatets, will launch its 1971 learntosail New York City classes May 3 and its Edgartown, Martha's Vine yard, Mass., weeklong vaca tion courses June 13, accord ing to Steve Colgate, di rector.

title: Atomic Power Plant to Give Data to Environmentalists
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., April 24 (AP)Officials of the $160mil lion Vermont Yankee atomic power plant, nearing comple tion in nearby Vernon, have agreed to provide environmen talists with all pertinent data on the plant.

title: Miss Noll Shines in Title Role Of Naughty Marietta Revival
description: She's back! No, not Mae West but Naughty Marietta. And the Village Light Opera Group has her. Good show!

title: Cities Show Interest in Traffic Baits As Love Affair With the Auto Wanes
description: America's love affair with the automobile, a torrid ro mance for decades, appears to be cooling off in a number of cities. While divorce isn't im minent, some trial separations are already under way.

title: Prisoner in 2Story Fall
description: A 15year old youth arrested for loitering for the purpose of using narcotics jumped or fell from the thirdfloor window of the 41st Precinct station on Simpson Street in the Bronx in an apparent escape attempt early this morning the police said. He landed on the roof of a firstfloor wing and broke a leg. The youth's name was not released because of his age.

title: Booby Trap Kills 7 G.I.'s
description: SAIGON, April 24 (AP) Seven United States soldiers were killed and 12 wounded yesterday in the explosion of an American artillery shell that enemy troops had rigged as booby trap, the command re ported today.

title: ProHero
description: To the Editor: May I respond in kind to Ju dith Viorst's recent lament in verse  titled AntiHeroine?

title: YANKEES BOW;
description: At the end it looked like the climax of a Fellini movie: Rain falling heavily, lightning flash ing, papers swirling around haphazardly, people standing around feeling frustrated and empty.

title: Coed Water Skiing: Vote of Confidence
description: I like being a woman. like having a man carry my skis and help me into boats, not because I am so fragile as to be incapable of per forming these small necessi ties for myself, but because it makes me feel like woman.

title: RABBIS DISCUSS ENROLLING YOUTHS
description: Despite theological differ ences, spiritual leaders of Re form and Conservative Judaism in the New YorkNew Jersey Connecticut area will cooperate in developing joint programs aimed at attracting young people back to the synagogue and Jewish life.

title: 2 RUSSIAN CRAFT LINK UP IN ORBIT AND SOYUZ LANDS
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, April 25 The Soviet Union's threeman spacecraft Soyuz 10 made an unexpectedly early return to earth during the night after having docked and flown joint ly with the unmanned orbital laboratory Salyut for a period of five and a half hours yester day.

title: COOPER UNION SITE IN JERSEY BACKED
description: Students, faculty members and alumni of Cooper Union have organized a committee to try to save the school's campus at Ringwood, N. J., which is scheduled to be closed this fall for financial reasons.

title: MIG'S MAY SHIFT MIDEAST BALANCE
description: Authoritative United States sources believe that the Soviet Union has shifted the strategic balance in the eastern Mediter ranean in its favor by sending two new types of fighter planes to Egypt.

title: Robin K. Feuer Is Bride Here
description: Miss Robin Kathryn Feuer and Christopher Miller, both of whose parents are educa tors, were married here last evening at the Cornell Club by a rabbi.

title: Et Al.
description: Reprint from 1929. Moder ately thorough in its research and probably effective at its initial publication, even shock ing in its affirmative evalua tion of black life in America. Still its purpose seems dated: to show the Negro's friends among the white people that their faith in him has not been unjustified or unfruitful. A historical artifact.

title: Fordham Alumni to Give Danowski Sports Award
description: Ed Danowski of East Mea dow, L.I,, a celebrated quar terback for Fordham in the early nineteenthirties and later with the New York football Giants for seven years, has been named the 17th winner of the Fordham College Alumni Achieve ment Award in Sports.

title: Super Wave Captures O'Brien Hanover Open Handicap Pace at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 24 All of the early speedsters faded, leaving the $25,000 O'Brien Hanover open handi cap pace to the late closers at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The onemile feature, clocked in 2 minutes 1 2/5 seconds, was won by Super Wave, noted for his rallying strength, by threequarters of a length from Leroy N.

title: Newport Sailboat Show To Feature New Design
description: The first Newport (R.I.) in ternational sailboat show will open to the public Oct. 1, beginning a fourday, inthe water exposition of sailboats from the United States, Can ada, Britain and France.

title: Leeds Wins, Trails Arsenal by Point
description: LONDON, April 24, Reuters  The English League First Division soccer leadership race moved toward an exciting fin ish today as Leeds United downed Southampton, 30, to move within I point of first place Arsenal, which tied, 22, with West Bromwich.

title: Television
description: FRIDAY evening the National Broadcasting Company presented Heifetz over its tele vision network, offering what the master violinist called his first fullfledged con cert program for TV.
