To night at 8, WPIXChannel 11 will present an hourlong concert program featuring the Empire Sinfonietta. In the notorious shotgun rela tionship between music and television, the local showing of a relatively unknown group is likely to be the more significant occasion.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I am afraid that Donald Stewart's article on Icelandic Airlines did less than justice to that carrier. I have traveled on it; my daughter has trav eled on it. There were no de lays of any significance; your article made it sound as though delays were common. Icelandic has been known to overbook. Last spring, my (laughter and some friends were booked on Icelandic and when they arrived at Ken nedy Airport to begin their journey to Amsterdam, they were told that the plane was full. Without payment of any additional fare, they were transferred by Icelandic to Finnair, which took them by jet (leaving at about the same time as the Icelandic plane was scheduled to leave)

title: Kerr on Underground
description: BLACKS who have been to Cornell and to Yale are given the onceover in two otherwise un related plays now appearing at the Public under the joint title of Underground. The report is at best ambiguous, at worst decidedly depress ing.

title: Fleet Wing Is Easy Winner In Stake at Arlington Park
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) Fleet Wing, owned by Gerson I. Fox of Hollywood, Calif., led all the way today to win the $15,000 Crete Handicap by 3 lengths before a crowd of 21,073 at Arlington Park. Royal Sur render edged Cassie Red for second.

title: Gardens
description: FOR those who like to have all their garden information neatly packaged here is some good news. Two superb encyclopedias are making their debut this spring. One is for outdoors; one is for indoors.

title: Charters Gain at St. Thomas After 2Year Slack Period
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, Virgin IslandsIn 1969, when the gross tourist income of the Virgin Islands was $105million, boating and other water sports accounted for $22million.

title: PEARCE WINS MEDAL IN NORTHSOUTH GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (UPI)Eddie Pearce, a Wake Forest student from Temple Terrance, Fla., shot a one underpar 70 today to pace the qualifiers for the men's North South amateur golf champion ship.

title: scuffles Mar Coast Rally After Parade Led by G. I.'s
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 Active duty servicemen led peaceful march of thousands through the streets of San Francisco today in a giant dem onstration against the war in Southeast Asia.

title: ALEXANDER DRYAKHLOV
description: LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) Alexander Dryakhlov, 31 years old, London correspondent for the Soviet News Agency, was killed and three other Soviet citizens were injured last night in a cartruck crash in central England. Soviet and British au thorities declined to give de tails of the accident, but re liable sources said the Russians were on their way to a Young Communist League meeting in Scarborough.

title: Pollution Is Hitting Caribbean, Too
description: FAJARDO, P.R.  Reports of pollution in Long, Island Sound, Lake Michigan or San Diego Bay have become com monplace and raised few ecological eyebrows. But, somehow, word of pollution in the beautiful, once virgin Caribbean, comes as a shocker.

title: Surfers in Puerto Rico Find the Waves Friendlier Than the People
description: PUNTA RINCON, P, R., April 12With hair down to their shoulders and surfboards un der their arms, they came to Punta Rincon looking for the endless summer. All that some of them found was the winter of their discontent.

title: Photography
description: PHOTO EXPO 71, which opened at McCormick Place here on Satur day, April 17, and which finishes it 9day run at 10 P.M. today, is un doubtedly the largest exhibit of photographic equipment ever put together in the coun try. The show, which is open to the public, as well as to members of the trade, is serv ing as a display case for a num ber of new products, some of which are being shown to the public for the first time, and some of which will not even be delivered to dealer's shelves for some months to come.

title: PEKING DUCK
description: 12 to 16 steamed pancakes (recipe at right]

title: New Satellite Launched
description: FORMOSA BAY, Kenya, April 24 (Agence FrancePressc)  A joint ItalianAmerican team of technicians successfully orbited today a 360pound satellite in tended to collect information from the upper atmosphere.

title: A GARBAGE DUMP BECOMES A PARK
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 24  They keep building ce ment buildings and junk like that, said a freckledfaced little boy. There isn't much land left like this. Cement that's all there is.

title: Dear Diarythe Fantasy Life of Tom Eyen
NAVY CREW VICTOR IN GOES REGATTA
description: ITHACA, N. Y., April 24The Navy heavyweight oarsmen de feated crews from Cornell and Syracuse to capture the 17th annual Goes Trophy Regatta on the Ithaca flood control channel today.

title: Miss Casals Gains Final
description: SAN DIEGO, April 24 (AP) Rosemary Casals of San Fran cisco, trailing, 06, 45, rallied to beat Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego today and enter the final of the last tournament on the women's tennis tour.

title: The Burden and the Curse
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened hear ings last week on proposals to end the war In Vietnam in the face of President Nixon's evident intention to con tinue American military involvement in Indochina until the South Vietnamese attain the capacity to defend themselves against a Communist takeoverthat is, indefinitely.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A.H.S.A. Official Predicts End Of Drug Use on Show Horses
description: KATONAH, N. Y., April 24 Dr. Jordan Woodcock pre dicted today that eventually show horses will be com pletely free of drugs including phenylbutazone (Bute), which now is allowed to be administered by the American Horse Show Asso ciation. Dr. Woodcock, who

title: For Young Readers
description: Jennie Jameson is, by her own ad mission, a nice girl from the white middle class. tier decision to spend her first year out of college teaching black kids in a ghetto school nat urally brings a wide range of reac tions from friends, family, fellow teachers and black parents:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mr. Callender's proposals are so simple and clear that I am amazed that he did not implement these very proj ects when he was the First Deputy Administrator of the Housing and Development Administration only a very short time ago.

title: New of the, Rialto
description: ANTHONY SHAFFER, who recently collected a Tony for his smash hit, Sleuth, has another thriller in store for us. It's called Play With a Gypsy and present charts call for a course similar to that follow ed by Sleuth. It will be of fered first in London (how soon remains to be deter mined) with Michael White as the sponsor. Then, be cause no one at the moment seems to have any doubt about its success, it will emi grate to New York under the banner of Helen Bonfils, Mor ton Gottlieb and White, the local pilots of Sleuth.

title: Thoughts of Eric Hoffer, Including:
description: VERYWHERE we look at present we see something new trying to be born. A pregnant, swollen world writhing in labor, and everywhere untrained quacks are officiating as obstetri cians. These quacks say that the only way the new can be born is by a Caesarean opera tion. They lust to rip the belly of the world open.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Jockey Dies in Attempt To Sweat Off 6 Pounds
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, April 24 (Reuters)An Australian jockey, Noel Mifflin, col lapsed and died at a sauna bath today as he tried to sweat off six pounds for an afternoon race meeting.

title: Elizabeth F. Kelley Is Affianced
description: LAKE FOREST, III., April 24Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Kelley 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fenley Kelley, to Collister Johnson Jr. He is the son of Mrs. and Mrs. Johnson of Far Hills, N. J., and West Tisbury, Mass. A wedding in August is planned.

title: Vacation Pay for Farmers
description: OSLO, Norway, April 24 (Reuters)  Norway will soon become the first country in the world to finance vacations for farmers. Under proposals to be submitted to Parliament, farm ers and their wives will re ceive four weeks' vacation each year and about $280 in cash. The plan is scheduled to start May 1 for a fouryear trial period.

title: Princeton Victor in Lacrosse
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 24 Bill Pettit scored three goals today for Princeton Univer sity's lacrosse team as it de feated Dartmouth, 75, for its first victory in seven contests.

title: Can a University's Computer Be a Socrates, Too?
description: NEW HAVENAt American law schools the Socratic method is king, and many professors spend careers rejecting the notion of declarative statements as a kind of lsemajest.

title: Home of Frank Fontaine Seized in Tax Dispute
description: BOSTON, April 24 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service has seized the suburban Win chester home of the entertainer Frank Fontaine for an alleged failure to pay $450,900 in back taxes.

title: For Young Readers
description: In a faroff time that has not yet come, there is a little girl named Alala who can change her color, size or shape at will. She lives with her parents, one black, one white, in an inflatable plastic bubble of a house which floats all over the world. Bored, Alala takes to disappearing into the TV set where she moves in on and alters the plots of a host of teleplays from Cinderella to Uncle Tom's Cabin. At last her father takes drastic action by rapidly switching channels so that Alala finds herself tossed about midst far less palatable fare and is so alarmed she ends her teletrips forever. That's the plot, no more fantastic than dozens of others.

title: The World
description: PNOMPENHA morbid bat tie over a man who, although gravely ill and largely incapaci tated, appears to represent the best hope for governmental sta bility in this beleaguered coun try, diverted Cambodia's atten tion from the war last week.

title: COPPER KAHN WINS IN JUMPING EVENT
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 24 Ralph J. Caristo's Copper Kahn went through two clean rounds to win the first prelim inary juniper class as the Boul der Brook Horse show got under way today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Refreshing, but, I feel, un aware are Eugene Callender's proposals to stimulate private financing in the lowincome housing market [Toward Housing for Poor, April 11].

title: YOUTH IS STRESSED BY EVANGELICALS
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 The Negro youth with close cropped hair, dark rimmed glasses, conservative gray suit and white shirt easily won the attention of the nearly 1,200, mostly graying, members of the National Association of Evangelicals.

title: Late Virginia Surge Beats Navy in Lacrosse, 11 to 7
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 24The University of Virginia's topranked lacrosse team broke open a close game with four goals in the fourth period tc:t post an 117 victory over Navy before a crowd of more than 5,000 today.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
Movies
description: EVERYBODY'S doing it Dennis Hopper, Peter Fonda, Paul New man, Sidney Poitier, Maximilian Schell, Jack Nicholson, Elaine May, Barbara Loden, Clint Eastwood, Alan Arkin, Ossie Davis, Jack Lerornon. Doing what? Becoming directors. And if these distinguished actors can move to the other side of the camera, why shouldn't Stacy Keach? Well, that's just what he is doing. Recently, a short which Keach directed, wrote and starred in was shown on TV's The American Dream Machine. It was called The Repeater and it dealt with the plight of prisoners, Now he is ready to make his directorial debut on a feature length film  an adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's novel, Outer Dark. Keach has already written the screenplay, in

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Thank you for Andreas Freund's coverage from Paris of the Max Ernst show which is indeed a splendor at l'Orangerie des Tuileries, and the first time that the museum has exhibited the work of a living artist.

title: Woman Wins Job Suit
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., April 24 (AP)Mrs. William B. Weeks of Swainsboro has been award ed nearly $31,000 in back pay by a Federal judge in her suit against the Southern Bell Tele phone Company, charging job discrimination. The company had refused to give Mrs. Weeks a job as a switchman because of a Georgia Labor Commission regulation that says a woman may not be required to lift more than 30 pounds on her job. The job involves the main tenance and testing of switch ing equipment.

title: American Museum Asking Admission, But Visitor Sets It
description: The American Museum of Natural History has started charging an admission fee, but it is letting visitors decide the amount. The museum suggested 50 cents for adults and 25 cents for children, but all vis itors were required to pay something.

title: Mark Loder Fiance of Elissa Margolis
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 24  Mrs. and Mrs. David Margolis have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elissa Margolis, to Mark Loder. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Laurence E. Loder of Madi son, Wis. A June wedding in Madison is planned.

title: The New York Times and United Press International
description: CATANIA, Siclly, April 22 Europe's largest active vol cano, Mount Etna, is spew ing masses of molten rock and, every now and then, a few incandescent holders. in its present eruption, the 11th in this century, and is at tracting thousands of sight seers.

title: Miss Marcia Riklis
description: Miss Marcia Riklis and Ben jamin Kletter, who are stu dents at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, plan to be married here Sept. 12.

title: STATE HOSPITALS REDUCING STAFFS
description: Dismissal notices were sent last week to 2,839 employes of state mental hospitals and schools for the mentally re tarded.

title: Karen Dunn Bride Of Dr. Neil Kavey
description: Miss Karen Ellen Dunn, who is on the staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, was married here yesterday to Dr. Neil Barton Kavey, a resident psychiatrist at the New York State Psy chiatric Institute.

title: The Odyssey of the Stella Maris II
description: In an age and at an age when most men are prisoners of conformity, 44yearold Tom Bailey of Portland, Ore gon, is an exception. Suc cumbing to the call of adven ture, he realized a dream latent in all of us but ful filled by only a few,

title: District 50 Leaders Favor Merger With Steelworkers
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The board of directors of Dis trict 50 of the Allied Techni cal Workers voted unanimously today to approve merger with the 1.5  million member Steel workers Union.

title: Janet R. Terry, David Kollock Plan to Marry
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Dr. Luther L. Terry, former Surgeon General of the United States, and Mrs. Terry have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Janet Reynolds Terry, to David Peter Kollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hall Kollock 3d of Chestnut Hill.

title: Mary Amann Is Wed To Neil W. Maguire
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 24Miss Mary Therese Amann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Francis Amann, was married here this morning to Neil William Maguire, son of Mrs. Neil Xavier Maguire of Roslyn Heights, and the late Mr. Maguire, who was assistant city editor of The New York JournalAmerican.

title: Lewis College Names Head
description: LOCKPORT, Ill., April 24 (AP) Lester Carr, 36 years old, vice president for academic af fairs at Salve Regina College in Newport, R. I., has been named president of Lewis College.

title: Samuel Johnson and The Life of Writing
description: Paul Fussell, professor of English at Rutgers, can use contemporary references bril liantly. He not only makes a good case for black humor in the macabre moralism of Samuel Johnson's Lives of the Poets, but convincingly traces this strain in him to a famil iarity with Suetonius. One is reminded of the glee with which Evelyn Waugh collected gossipy proofs of man's de pravity, all the while chortling Horrible! Horrible! Fussell Also shows how the oriental tale, Rasselas, flirts with an 18th  century equivalent of campsteering deftly around the snare in which his oriental play, Irene, had been caught.

title: Out of Place in America
description: Sociologists with liberal sym pathies are showing a tendency to turn their subject into storefront religion, complete with fire and brimstone. It is as if the facts have become so hard to arrive at that they are increasingly falling back on faith as the only way to knowl edge.

title: STRIP MINING FOES GAINING CONVERTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Supporters of a bill that would outlaw the $200millionayear strip mining industry have sought and won some converts here.

title: SENATORS DOWN BREWERS, 5 TO 4
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Frank Howard stroked a two out single in the ninth inning tonight that scored Tim Cullen and gave the Washington Sena tors a 54 victory over the Mil waukee Brewers.

title: the traveler's world
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. In these days of popular deni gration of space exploration, the tourist is likely to approach this vast spaceage outdoor science museum in a defensively skeptical frame of mind. Three or more hours later he is likely to leave the center convinced that it was a valuable and exciting experience, going away imbued with the credo that is the guiding light of the National Aero nautics and Space Administration peo ple who work here:

title: The Trudeau Years in Canada: He and Nation Much the Same
description: OTTAWA, April 24  Pierre Elliott Trudeau began his fourth year as Prime Minister of Can ada this week still the nation's political pacesetter.

title: Fires and Explosions Among Worst Dangers
description: With the exception of col lisions, boatmen face no greater personal danger than fires and explosions.

title: JOHNSON CAPTURES P.S.A.L. MAT FINAL
description: John Johnson reversed Gary Clark 30 seconds into the last period to score the only points and win the title by 20 in the 119pound class at the second annual Public Schools Athletic League wrestling champion ships yesterday.

title: Pan Am Trials Open Friday
description: QUANTICO, Va., April 24 (AP)The first of a series of eliminations to select the Unit ed States women's track team for the Pan American Games July 30 through Aug. 13 will share the spotlight here Friday and Saturday with the 14th an nual Quantico Relays.

title: Harvard Captures Compton Cup for Ninth Straight Year on Lake Carnegie
description: PRINCETON, N. J., April 24 Coach Harry Parker, who shifted seven of his eight Har vard varsity oarsmen during the week, found another win ning alignment today as the Crimson captured the Compton Cup for the ninth straight year, beating Princeton and Massa chusetts Institute of Tech nology.

title: Unconscious Will Carry The Hopes of California
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 An owner, a trainer and jockey all making their first try in the Kentucky Derby form the team behind Uncon scious, California's hope at Churchill Downs next Satur day.

title: Time and Motion
description: To the Editor: Any writer of a recently pub lished book is about as eager to tangle with you as a repent ant sinner with St. Peter . . but the Gilbreth tribe (and, brother, we are legion) is up set by psychiatrist Joel Kovel's unqualified assertion, in his re view of Frederick Taylor: A Study in Personality and Inno vation, that Taylor is known today as the inventor of the timeandmotion study.

title: For the young in shape
description: Jungle flowers bloom on a halter top and midcalf skirt of green, white and red silk. $110. By Norma Druz for D. D. Dominick, 246 East 51st Street. Bandanna print in purple, white and red has saronglike skirt. Oscar de la Renta Boutique. $95. Sutton Place, Bloomingdale's. Hats, James Holton.

title: Et Al.
description: Of the mad scramble to fly farther and faster than the fel low before. Mr. Montague con siders the wellknown flights of Lindbergh, Alcock and Brown, and others; but he is also inter ested in the illconceived ven tures of hopeful airmen in un prepared planes. Montague doubts that Admiral Byrd flew over the North Pole and to that point exhumes contemporary evidence, some of which was later suppressed by a publish er fearing the wrath of the powerful Byrd family. Monta gue, a newsman of the twen ties, nicely catches this whacky era of flying, when greed was the copilot.

title: Revenue Sharing Is a Counterrevolution
description: POOR Publius, operating under the name of Alexander Hamil ton, had only $4.2million of the public burden to distribute in his first three years as Secretary of the Treasury. Most of it came from cus toms collections, and after he paid interest on the public debt and the costs of the Army and its veterans there wasn't very much left for guarding the least wealthy part of the community from anything. But Publius was richly endowed with an idea, a Federal idea whose meaning and power seem to have escaped the notice of his successors as they plot New American Revolution.

title: The World
description: The role that PingPong has been playing in the current thaw between Peking and Washington is not the first time that table tennis has symbolized a turn to friend Her contact between China and the West. This cartoon, first published in Punch on April 24, 1901, shows the Chinese Foreign Minister in a game with Britannia and refers to negotiations that followed the Boxer Rebel lion. The original caption was: Ping Pong, or A Game that he does understand.

title: Plant in a Pillow
description: PEOPLE have been plant ing in pots for cen turies, so why not break out with some thing newa plastic pillow! Commercial growers on the West Coast have been using them for some time, but home gardeners can adapt them to their own needs, especially for propagating plants for bedding, window boxes and hanging baskets.

title: Deep in the Heart of Texas, Real World M.B.A.'s
description: AUSTIN, TexasIn a con ference room at the Alumni Center of the University of Texas the other evening, Jack Wrather, an oil heir turned entertainment con glomerateur was distributing wisdom to graduate students.

title: Corporate View in Lens of Youth
description: One of the pictures. Stewart Jackson submitted to the 1970 National High School Pho tography Exhibition showed a manhole cover.

title: Youth Center in Suffolk Seeks $23,000
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I April 24  A youth center here is asking voters to ap prove on May 5 the allocation of $23,000 that could give it a permanent base after two years of wandering.

title: 6 Killed in Fire in Oslo
description: OSLO, Norway, April 24 (Reuters)Six persons includ ing a 22yearold woman and a baby, died in a fire in an old fivestory building in the cen ter of Oslo early today, the po lice said. Two men have been arrested in connection with the fire, they said.

title: UConn Club to Honor Ruck, N.H.L. Officer
description: Don V. Ruck, vice presi dent of the National Hockey League, has been selected to receive the outstanding con tribution award at the 18th annual sports awards din ner of the UConn Club at the Ambassador restaurant in Hamden, Conn., May 7.

title: N.Y.A.C. Coxswain's Story: He Knew What Would Be Coming After Winning the Race
description: The New York Athletic Club's eightman crew trimmed more than 2 minutes from the course record yesterday in winning the 14th annual Hughes Cup race from Sands Point, L. I., to the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

title: The World
description: TORONTOThe customary target of Canadian national ists has been the pervasive American presence in Can ada's economy  more than half the country's manufac turing, for example, is con trolled by American compa nies. More recently, concern about United States influ ence and Canadian inde pendence has expressed it self in a new sphere, edu cation and communications. The most recent instance of such concern came a few days ago, when the govern ment of Ontario offered to lend nearly $1million to one of Canada's leading book publishers, McClelland and

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: As one who traveled to India last year specifically to study with the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, I must take issue with the article in which he was mentioned. The author would have one believe that the ash ram is indeed a very strange place and that the practices which are taught there are equally bizarre if not irra tional. As he himself admits, nothing can be gained with the lack of persistence and commitment that he brought to the subject. Regardless of this, his description of his experiences at the ashram is Incongruent with what I saw during my four months there with the Maharishi's con tinued attendance.

title: $25,000 Offer Is Made In Bid for Squaw Valley
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 24California's effort to sell its holdings at Squaw Valley, the scene of the 1960 Winter Olympic Games in the Sierra Nevada, drew one bidder yes terday. The offer, $25,000 for the more than 1,000 acres, two skilifts, a hotel and other buildings, was consid erably less than what the state had hoped for.

title: Buffalo Raceway to Open
description: BUFFALO, April 24 (AP)  Buffalo Raceway begins its 30th harness racing season Monday night with a 10race program, a new electric mobile starting gate and a $100,000 overhaul. It will operate 84 nights.

title: Red Sox Win, 42
description: BOSTON, April 24 (AP) George Scott homered in the eighth inning to break a tie and Billy Conigliaro also con nected to give the Boston Red Sox a 42 victory over the Chicago White Sox today, their fourth in a row.

title: World of Sport Diving Weightless and Eerie
description: Weightless, sinuous as dolphin, you move through halls of light. Branching weed waves you on. Glinting coral and seabed rock give back the sun's brilliance in the eerily beautiful hues of inner space.

title: Brooklyn Renewal: Urban Cinderella?
description: To the planners and de velopers of downtown Brook lyn, the transformation of an already bustling commercial district into a major regional center is just now entering a new phase.

title: The Urban Dilemma
description: Can the old cities be saved; do Americans want save them?

title: City Cuts Complaint Hours
description: The central complaint bureau of the city's Rent and Housing Maintenance Department will receive complaints between A.M. and 5 P.M. on weekdays only, abandoning its schedule of 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Benjamin Altman, the de partment's Commissioner, said the schedule change was forced by city budget cuts, The bureau, whose number is WO 43000, handled nearly 600,000 tele phone calls last year, he said.

title: Iowa State Names Aide
description: AMES, Iowa, April 24 (AP)  Jim Overturf was named acting athletic director at Iowa State today. He took over from Clay Stapleton, who left to become athletic director at Florida State,

title: STUDY TO BE URGED ON HEREDITY'S ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)A committee of the Na tional Academy of Science will urge next week that a study be made to determine the role of heredity in human behavior and performance.

title: Jamie Rosenthal, Editor, to Marry
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 24  Mr. and Mrs. Richard Laurence Rosenthal of Stam ford and New York have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jamie Gould Rosenthal of Washing ton, to David Martin Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wolf of Van Nuys, Calif. The wedding is planned for June 25.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: A.B.A. Playoffs

title: CUBS TOP METS DESPITE AGEE SLAM;
description: CHICAGO, April 24  The Chicago Cubs, who had lost six of their seven previous games, survived a grand slam by Tom mie Agee today and defeated the New York Mets, 75.

title: No Comment in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 The State Department had no immediate comment today on the Soviet protest. Officials said there had been no time to study the text.

title: Dodgers Top Reds, 54
description: CINCINNATI, April 24 (AP) Manny Mota's runscoring single in the ninth inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 54 victory over Cincinnati. The triumph was the fifth straight for the Dodgers.

title: Space
description: The Soviet Union may have yet to land men on the moon or take closeup photographs of Mars, but it has a way of set ting important trends in space exploration.

title: NEW CREDITLAW GOES INTO EFFECT
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Consumers will be able to chal lenge the accuracy of adverse reports on their credit ratings and to seek correction of er rors under a Federal law that went into effect today.

title: Muscovy
description: Subtitled Russia Through Foreign Eyes, 15531900, this is a traveler's timecapsule jour ney through bygone Russia. The guides are a varied group, ranging from the 16thcentury Englishman Richard Chancel lor searching for the fabled Cathay to Mme. de Stall to George Kennan. Miss Wilson has diligently combed the liter ature and presents brief ex cerpts stitched together by long strands of narrative, most of which paraphrase the eyewit ness accounts. The result is an interesting picture of Russian life, customs, pastimes and amusements  a historically grounded insight into the na character.

title: BetelLeaf Chewers in Karachi Joyfully Await Taste of Peace
description: KARACHI, Pakistan April 24There was joy in Ka rachi this week at the news that shipments of betel leaf, the Pakistani equivalent of chewing gum, would be re sumed soon from East Pak istan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Richard Helms's defense of the C.I.A. [news story April 15] is thoughtful and intelligent but bypasses an essential point. He rightly recognizes the con flicts of values and procedures inher ent in an open society's operating an organization that deals in secret infor mation.

title: PENSION PLEDGES CHECKED BY CITY
description: The trustees of city pension funds are being asked to pass again on the soundness of $150Million in mortgage com mitments made two years ago but then held up when some employes in the Controller's office were indicted.

title: Et Al.
description: Subtitled Images of UnAm erican Subversion From the Revolution to the Present, this is an anthology of writings that describe and locate a wide va riety of conspiracies in Amer ica. Professor Davis, who won a Pulitzer Prize for The Prob lem of Slavery in Western Cul ture, covers such deviations as pro and antislavery fac tions, antiCatholic groups up to the Liberty League, Com munist and McCarthyite organ izations, antiWarren Commis sion writings of today. Davis provides an introductory essay to each section and generally elucidates the importance of conspiratorial thinking in American history. One hopes he will further expand his tenta tive theories

title: Penn's Varsity Crew Triumphs in Blackwell Cup for Sixth Straight Year
description: DERBY, Conn., April 24 Penn's varsity crew won the Blackwell Cup for the sixth straight year today, defeating Vesper Boat Club of Philadel phia, an invited guest, and Yale, in the rain on the Housatonic River. It was a close race and Penn's marginone length over Vesper and a length and a quarter over Yale  was achieved with a sprint in the last 200 meters.

title: Lighting an underground mix
description: THE MIX IN ACTION White Formica platforms with cushions and bolsters covered in contrasting pat terns serve as sofas and guest beds. The Art Deco print on the slab cush ions has a certain similarity to the geometric Shapiro painting. An Afri can mask by the window and the preColumbian statue on the glow ing oval table add ethnic accents. MULTIPURPOSEBy careful plan ning, the designers were able to pack a wall of books and a grand piano into the living room. An upholstered screen beside the entry door creates a hallway as well as a piano al cove. Antique kilim and Kazak rugs repeat the red wall color. OFFICE REFLECTIONSThe mir rored wall in the tiny office reflects the storage system. Cabinet fronts and counters are wrapped in charcoal vinyl; illuminated panels run across the top. On one wall a mask from New Guinea provides an ethnic coun terpoint to the Ernest Posse painting. Two popular themes in interior design these days are ethnic art and Art Deco. But together? The de signing firm of SchuleMcCarville dared the mix this belowstreetlevel apartment, and their gamble paid off. The threeroom space was a shambles, they recall, when they started. White floors, plat. formed couches covered in Art Deco fabrics and imaginative lighting were major factors in the trans formation. Lighting, of course, was particularly im portant in the belowground rooms. The designers recessed lights in counters, installed glowing tables and covered whole walls with large mirrors, which not only reflect light but create an illusion of rooms beyond. Ethnic art, in the form of kilims and oriental rugs on the floors and African artifacts, adds cm unexpected, yet completely compatible accent.

title: Miss Carmichael Is Betrothed To Peter Foley, Law Student
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 24  Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Cromwell Carmichael Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ernes tine Morris Carmichael, to Peter Michael Foley. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Foley of New York and Birmingham, Mich.

title: imaginative, $29, Takes 25th Golden Gate Handicap
description: ALBANY, Calif., April 24 (AP)Imaginative held off closing charge by Most Host to win the 25th running of t?? $40,000added Golden Gate Handicap by a neck today.

title: PumpOut Is Easy at Captree
description: BABYLON, L. I.People used our best pumpout stations last summer with almost as little fuss as they might in buying chew ing gum, said Al Kappauf, the bait station manager at Captree State Park. They put the coins in the slot of our Johnny Trap machine, and in a few minutes the job was done and they were on their way.

title: STANS REMARKS HAILED BY ATHENS
description: ATHENS, April 24United StatesGreek relations boomed this weekend after a twoday official visit to Athens by Sec retary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, broadly interpreted here as a gesture of support by the Nixon Administration for the militarybacked regime of Greece.

title: OBSERVER
description: The telephone was ringing. Sam sat up in bed, struggling upward out of deep sleep, fumbled in the dark and when he had found the light switch, looked at his watch.

title: COAST GROWERS THREATEN TO MOVE
description: IMPERIAL BEACH, Calif., April 24Several leading pro duce growers of San Diego County said this week that they might move their farming oper ations into Mexico, or go out of business entirely, if Cesar Chavez succeeded in organiz ing their field workers.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Instead of being viewed as a rival, [foreign invest ment] ought to be considered as a most valuable auxiliary, conducing to put in motion a greater quantity of produc tive labor, and a greater por tion of useful enterprise, than could exist without it.

title: ROCKEIELLER TELLS MAYOR NEW TAXES CAN DESTROY CITY
description: ALBANY, April 24Gover nor Rockefeller warned Mayor Lindsay today that the new city taxes the Mayor had pro posed, coming on top of the new state taxes recently ap proved by the Legislature, could well destroy the econ omy of the city of New York and go a long way toward pull ing down the state as a whole.

title: Neanderthal Man, Lacking Pharynx, Called Baby Talker
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Reconstruction of the vocal apparatus of Neanderthal man of some 40,000 to 70,000 years ago indicates his language must have sounded like unintelligible human baby talk, phonetically inefficient and shortsuited on vowels.

title: F.B.I. AGENTS VITAL TO A HOUSE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 24At a time when unusual criticism of J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has come from ranking mem bers of Congress, a study re veals that a powerful House committee depends heavily on the bureau.

title: Hussein Reported to Ask Mufti To Return to Jordan From Exile
description: RAMALLAH, Israel  occupied Jordan, April 20Arab travel ers from Amman report that King Hussein has invited the aged former Mufti of Jerusalem a stormy leader of Palestinian Arabs in the years before Israel became a stateto return from exile and join his entourage.

title: Inmate, 16, at Bikers Island Stabbed by Another Youth
description: A 16yearold inmate at the Rikers Island Adolescent Re mand Shelter was stabbed in the chest with a sharpened bed spring yesterday by another prisoner, the police said.

title: Frances Schaefer To Be July Bride
description: OSTERVILLE, Mass., April 24The engagement of Miss Frances Baldwin Schaefer to J. Griffin Doyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Doyle of Larchmont, N. Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Schaefer of Oster ville.

title: GREEN'S 202 PACES FLORIDA GOLF BY 3
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 24 (AP)Hubert Green broke away from Lee Trevino today and took a commanding three stroke lead with a 14underpar 202 after three rounds of the $60,009 Tallahassee Open golf tournament.

title: HOFFMAN, AT 80, THRIVING AT U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 (AP)Paul G. Hoff man, who gave up executive rank in the automobile industry to run the Marshall Plan, will be 80 years old Mondayand he is still working as an inter national civil servant.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24Secretary General Thant left today on a fiveday trip to Europe, during which he will confer with his special rep resentative for the Middle East, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, and pre side at several United Nations meetings.

title: Roel and Brenninkmeyer to Wed Ann Marie Stuecheli on June 5
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., April 24Dr. and Mrs. Milton B. Stuecheli have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Ann Marie Stue cheli, to Roeland BrennInk meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Brenninkmeyer of Bloemendaal, the Nether lands, formerly of Larch mont, N.Y.Ohrbach's, Inc., the New Yorkbased specialtystore chain that has been acquired by the Brenninkmeyer in terests of the Netherlands. His father, who is retired, was an executive with C & A, the family's international re tail complex.

title: Dr. Lloyd Gross Weds Carol Lankford
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., April 24Miss Carol Ann Lank ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Garrison Lankford of Wallingford, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Lloyd William Gross of Mill Valley, Calif., son of Mrs. Edward Francis Keenan of Lake Success, L. I., and the late William Lawrence Gross.

title: Ecologists Join Politicians in an Effort to Save Great South Bay
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., April 24 Local politicians, conserva tionists and fishermen along the Great South Bay are con sidering a regional approach to the problem of salvaging and securing their estuarine environment here.

title: Stay as Sincere As You Are, Oscar
description: A man is eating a mush room (or, perhaps, a piece of orange, or an apple  it doesn't matter). He does nothing else, and why should he? He just eats. There are thoughts and reveries appear ing on his face, and disap pearing again, as he contin ues eating. . . . He likes what he is eating, and that could last a million years. His unpretentiousness amazes us. Why doesn't he think of something else to do; why doesn't he Want anything else? . . . Yes, lie disappoints us, because he just eats his apple. . . . What pompous asses are!

title: Running for Mayor On a Garbage Truck
description: WHEN Mayor Lindsay named Assemblyman Jerome Kretch mer to be the new Environ mental Protection Administrator in January, 1970, one dismayed en vironmentalist summed up Kretch mer's nonqualifications by saying, Jerry knows about air pollution be cause he breathes, he knows about solid waste disposal because he takes out the garbage, but he doesn't know about the pollution of water because he probably doesn't drink much of the stuff.

title: The Long Struggle For Black Power By Edward Peeks. 448 pp. Scribner's. $7.95.
description: Descriptions of black self help endeavors (here construed as black power), beginning with Richard Allen's and Ab salom Jones's establishment of the Free African Society of Philadelphia, and closing with the Panthers. Peeks maintains that the only valid black power is the struggle to achieve eco nomic and social equality to the end of joining in the great Am erican Way. A view that ig nores contemporary contradict ing evidence and the present thrust of black militants. The research is secondhand.

title: Mailman, 63, Finds Route Not at All Routine
description: Striding briskly along a tree studded bluff overlooking the Hudson River on a crisp, cool morning recently, Mike Katz hunched forward slightly under the weight of the 28 pounds of mail on his back, waved his arm at the scene and said: This is the kind of stuff that keeps me in here.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Burke
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Bryan E. Burke of Teaneck, N.J., on April 14 in the Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck. Mrs. Burke is the former Miss Gratia Schastey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Lincoln Schastey of Haworth, N.J. The child, whose father is a police sergeant in Tea neck, is named Theresa Ellen. She is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip E. Burke. also of Teaneck.

title: JUDGABbE, $12.80, FIRST IN GREY LAG
description: Allowed to make his own pace during the early running of the 28th edition of the Grey Lag Handicap, Saul Nadler's Judgable turned in a frontrun ning effort at Aqueduct yes terday to win the $85,700 stakes by 1 lengths.

title: Army Hires G.I.'s Wives For KP of Four Bases
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)The Army, abolishing KP to encourage enlistments, is hiring some soldiers' wives to work in the mess halls.

title: Patricia E. Bobermin Plans May Bridal
description: EAST GREENBUSH, N.Y., April 24Miss Patricia Eliza beth Bobermin and Alexander Charles Sutherland 2d plan to be married in May.

title: Small Submarine Ready for Underwater Exploration
description: A new dimension has been added for those interested in underwater exploration. The broadened undersea horizons are opened by the development of a line of one man and twoman submarines that are available through All Ocean Industries, Inc., of Houston.

title: Sewanhaka, Boys High. Take Championship Races in Penn Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 New York schoolboys, pushed into the background yesterday, came to the fore today with two victories in the three cham pionship running events. They also won the triple jump, the only field event today.

title: Architecture
description: YES, that's a broken column on this page, and this is going to sound like a broken record. The needle seems to get stuck on preservation, even though the commitment here is as much to the future as to the past.tional, social and planning support, at the community level and as far as you can go. Names count as much as expertise. Assemble the kind of leader  organization that will make politicians and bankers think twice. If there is no official local preserva tion group, form one, legally. This probably won't be your last battle.

title: F.B.I. File on War Foe Runs 5 Pages
description: BOSTON, April 24Docu ments stolen from an office of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation and just made available, contain a lifetime profile of an individual whose only recorded crime was breach of the peace in 1954, for which he was fined $5.

title: Soviet Industrial Gain Is Said to Exceed Goal
description: MOSCOW, April 24The Soviet Union announced to day that its industrial econ omy had performed better than planned during the first quarter of the year.

title: $3.44Billion Spent in 1970
description: An estimated 44,070,000 persons participated in rec reational boating during 1970, and an estimated $3.44bil lion was spent for new and used motors, boats, acces sories, safety equipment, fuel, insurance, docking, mainte nance, launching, storage, re pairs and boating club memberships, according to Boating Industry Association.

title: National Notes
description: Agnew Again

title: SYDNEY AIR DIRTY, AUSTRALIANS FIND
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 24 Newcomers to Sydney are often told that this airy green city, the most populous in Aus tralia with nearly, three million people, has one of the most appealing urban environments in the world.

title: Theater in Washington. D.C.
description: EUGENE IONESCO, whose play WipeOut Games has just been given its American premiere at the Arena Stage in Washington, first came to public notice as the author of a group of bizarre one acters in which intimations of anguish and despair were at least partly obscured by bursts of highspirited an archic whimsy. (At one point in The Bald Soprano, for instance, The clock strikes as much as it likessurely the most beguiling stage direction since Exit, pursued by a bear.)

title: Chemicals Present Array of Hazards
description: The yachtsman frequently handles an array of chemi cals or chemical preparations in the form of paints, paint removers, cleansers, corro sion inhibitors, bleaching agents and fuels. He may not always be aware of in juries that may result from improper storage, handling or use of these materials.

title: Nigerians Execute 3
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 21 (UPI)Fifty thousand people watched a firing squad shoot three men today in Lagos' first public execution since the Ni gerian civil war ended in Jan uary, 1970. The men had been condemned for robbery with

title: Panama's Cabinet Given a Leftist Slant
description: PANAMA, April 21A Cabi net shakeup dictated by Gen. Omar Torrijos, the strongman behind the Panamanian regime, has given a more leftist com plexion to the Government.

title: THOMAS BROGAN, A POLITICIAN, DIES
description: YONKERS, April 24Thomas A. Brogan, who as a political leader in this city headed a Democratic machine that ran Yonkers for decades and who built a successful construction company, died last night In his winter home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old.

title: Eastover is and isn't a murderer
description: Frankly, An Education in Blood offers few easy pleasures. It does, however, present a set of profound and distressing speculations on man's condition.

title: HOKKAIDO ROPING IT WILL CATCHUP
description: SAPPORO, JapanHere in Hokkaido we have all the space one needs, Naohiro Dogakinai said with an expansive sweep of his hands. The potential for development is unlimited.

title: Courtesy Is Urged in BoatTrailering
description: Everyone agrees that cour tesy afloat helps toward the safety and enjoyment of boating. Since most out boards spend almost as much time trailered along high ways as they do in the water, courtesy and consideration on the highway is also neces sary.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: To the Financial Editor: Mr. Handler calls settle ments obtained in certain of these class actions a type of blackmail. I object to this characterization. Mr. Handler fails to state that every class action settlement is made by defendant represented by counsel of its choice and that all such settlements require approval by a United States district court judge.

title: Annapolis Honors Educator
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 24 (AP)'the president of Rens selaer Polytechnic Institute, Dr. Richard G. Folsom, has been awarded the Distinguished Pub lic Service Award at ceremon ies at the United States Naval Academy. Dr. Folsom was hon ored specifically for his efforts from 1959 to 1971 that led to a complete modernization of the curriculum at the Naval Academy.

title: Nassau Medical Office Expects a Rise in Work
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., April 24A fourstory building near the County Medical Center here houses the offices and labora tories of Nassau's medical de tectivesthe 44 specialists of the Medical Examiner's office whose job it is to investigate death in violent or unusual forms.

title: QUEENS HEARINGS ON CITY PLAN SET
description: The City Planning Commis sion will hold a public hearing in each of the 14 community planning districts in Queens during May and early June to enable residents to participate in the review of the Queens volume of the Plan for New York City.

title: Sarah Small, Student, Engaged To Dixon Stroud, Penn Alumnus
description: MONKTON, Md., April 24 Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Reid Small have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Small, to William Boulton Dixon Stroud Jr. Mr. Stroud, who is known as Dixon, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stroud of West Grove, Pa.

title: A Peripatetic Exhibition
description: Chess

title: Wellington's New Look
description: Six years ago the Welling ton Management Company faced the grim prospect of seeing its fortunes decline, perhaps into oblivion, unless it made a drastic change in a business formula that had made it a leader in the mu tual fund industry for a gen eration.

title: Movies
description: FEMINISTS are fond of insisting that if only women were given a chance to make films, a distinctly different view of womenand menmight emerge. The truth of this assertion is, of course, a mat ter of speculation because the number of female filmmakers has been so few. Aside from Leni Riefenstahl, Shirley Clarke, Agnes Varda and a few others, none has achieved much prominence.

title: Dibley and Mrs. Court Head Australian Tennis Rankings
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, April 24 (Reuters)A Davis Cup player, Colin Dibley, is Austra lia's No. 1 tennis player among men and Mrs. Margaret Court is No. 1 among women.

title: Royals Blank Indians
description: KANSAS CITY, April 24 (UPI) Jerry May drove in three runs with a double and single and Mike Hedlund pitched a three hit shutout today to give the Kansas City Royals a 60 vic tory over the Cleveland Indians. May drove in the first run

title: South Korean Candidates Winding Up Presidential Campaign
description: CHONJU, South Korea, April 23The campaign speech was over. The President, Chung Hee Park, had departed, his back ramrodstiff, his face set in a grim smile. He waved occasion ally with a lack of spontaneity. As the stands of the huge sta dium emptied, the band played a Korean version of The Battle Hymn of the Republic.

title: FULLMER TO FIGHT CASSIDY IN FORUM Frazier Music Group Will Entertain Tomorrow
description: Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, rugged middleweight, who has fought seven world champions in his ring career, will fight in the main bout of the final Monday program for the month of April tomorrow night at the Felt Forum, facing Long Island's leading 160pound contender, Bobby Cassidy of Levittown, LI., in a 10rounder.

title: Giants Triumph Over Pirates, 2 to 0, as Bryant Allows Only Three Hits
description: DOUBLES ACCOUNT FOR BOTH TALLIESClemente Reaches 2,721 Hits and Ties Gehrig for 26th on Career ListPITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP) Ron Bryant, a 23yearold lefthander, limited the Pitts burgh Pirates to three hits to day in pitching the San Fran cisco Giants to a 2.0 victory.

title: Miss Barbara Van Ess Is Bride Of Lieut. Thomas K. McInerney
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 24  The marriage of Miss Barbara Van Ess, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Van Ess, to Lieut. Thomas Kelly McInerney, U.S.M.C., took place in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here this morning. The Rev. Robert Redmond performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The bridegroom, who is stationed at Camp Lejeune, N. C., is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Mc Inerney of Larchmont and Osterville, Mass.

title: Wooden Boardwalk at Rockaway May Be Replaced by Plastic
description: The Rockaway Boardwalk, the second longest in North America and perhaps the world, may not be made of boards forever.

title: BoatCamping Requires Proper Craft and Motor
description: These are the days when the cliff dwellers suffer from a strange malady.

title: REAL SAILING: The Golden Eagle, a 71foot schooner of Seven Seas sailing club based on City Island, the Bronx
description: As the sun sets a little longer on the horizon each day, and the northwest breezes become just a little warmer, there's a certain kind of excitement beginning to build among the members of sailing clubs.rounded group of people, Charles said. but the em phasis is definitely on people who like to sail. They can do as much or as little of the actual work as they like or are qualified to do, and enjoyment is one of our best accomplishments.

title: Art
description: IMAGINE, if you can, novel on which Henry James has collaborated with James Purdy, and you might begin to have the vaguest glimmer of the drama that was traced in the extraordinary life of Romaine Brooks, the painter whose work is currently the subject of a small exhibition at the Whitney Museum of Ameri can Art. And it is important, in this case at least, to know something of the artist's life in approaching her work. Romaine Brooks was an American expatriate who was better known to the Eu ropean haute monde than to the American art public. In deed, she is now virtually unknown as an artist in this country. Although she died only a few months agoon Dec. 7, 1970, at the age of 9641er career belongs to another era, and her paint ings, of which a large num ber are portraits, are, in ad dition to being powerful pic torial statements in their own right, important visual docu ments in the cultural his tory of that era.

title: EARLY SAILING PACE IS SET BY ONDINE II
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 24 (AP)Ondine II, a 73foot ketch owned by Sumner Long of Larchmont, N. Y., broke clear shortly after the start today and at sundown was leading the 500mile interna tional yacht race from St. Pet ersburg to Isla Mujeres, Mexico.

title: The Dow and 1,000
description: Wall Street is echoing these days with confident cries of Dow 1,000.

title: Laird Says He Plans to Quit. As Defense Chief in 1973
description: MADISON, Wis., April 24 (UPI)Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird told the University of Wisconsin Daily Cardinal in a copyrighted interview that he would leave his cabinet post in 1973.

title: L.I. Park Is Turned Into Nature School for Children
description: KINGS PARK, L.I., April 3  Mr. Brody. is this worm a boy or a girl?

title: COLONELS CAPTURE EAST PLAYOFFS, 4.2
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels, losers to Virginia during the regular season, beat the Squires, 129117, tonight and captured the American Basketball Asso ciation's East Division playoff final, four games to two.

title: Course for Youngsters Paying Off
description: There are 22,000 addition al young boatmen in New York State now who will probably be safer, more skilled pilots than their par ents. This is the number of youngsters between 10 and 14 years of age who spent four hours studying how, and how not, to be better boatmen. The course, Make Sure, Make Shore, is spon sored by the Division of Ma rine and Recreational Ve hicles in Parks and Recrea tion.

title: BOLD AND ABLE TAKES DERBY TEST BY THREE LENGTHS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 Bold and Able of the Calumet Farm registered the victory in the Stepping Stone Purse at Churchill Downs today. Racing as an entry with Eastern Fleet, Bold and Able came through with a threelength success in the sevenfurlong sprint.

title: Residents Split on Site for Gowanus High School
description: Proponents of different sites for the new Gowanus High School in South Brooklyn con fronted one another last week at a public hearing marked by heckling and noisy demonstra tions.

title: IN THE NATION
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.The Stars and Bars of the Confederacy still fly above the South Carolina state capitol. But beyond the heroic statue of Pitchfork Ben Tillman and within the walls of the beautiful old building permanently scarred by shells from General Sher man's guns, Governor John C. West has set out upon a new political course.

title: Jersey Sports Car Club Lists DialaRally Telephone Service
description: About Motor Sports

title: Series on Immunology
description: An eightweek series of seminars on advances in im munology began at the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens last week. The series, sponsored by the center's de partment of surgery and the Academy of Medicine of Queens, will examine the cur rent state of immunologic knowledge from allergy to cancer. The center is at 8825 153d Street in Jamaica, Queens.

title: M.I.T.'S OARSMEN REGISTER SWEEP
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 The Massachusetts Institute of Technology lightweight var sity crew rowed to an easy twolength victory over Colum bia and Cornell today for sweep in the Geiger Cup re gatta. The Engineers also won the freshman and junior var sity races over the 2,000meter course.

title: BETSY ROSS GOES TO FORWARD GAL
POINT OF VIEW
description: To the Financial Editor: The class action has proved to be a valuable legal tool. It has made it possible for the small in vestor or consumer to obtain legal representation that is adequate to meet the expen sive and talented litigation facilities of the corporate de fendants. It affords a method for obtaining redress, regard less of amount, while barring to the offending defendant the fruits of his fraud. ?? has been a valuable supple ment to Government law enforcement activities and, has proved an effective, man, ageable tool for justice.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Garden to See
description: THE gardens at Cara moor, the estate of the late Walter T. Rosen, will be open to the public, beginning Saturday until June 12, Tuesday through Saturday. There are over 40 landscaped acres with many walks, including an Italian Garden, sculpture dis plays and wooded glades.

title: Foes of War Are Evicted From a Railroad Station
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April 24 Antiwar marchers assembling at the Penn Central railroad station here to travel to Wash ington early today were evicted by the railroad police on the ground that they were travel ing by bus and not by train.

title: Cleaners and Powders Are Being Cleaned Up
description: The recent realization that laundry and household deter gents have been fouling our waters for decades with phos phates and other persistent chemicals has influenced some cleaningproducts manu facturers to clean up their cleaners and market powders and liquids advertised as biodegradable.

title: Little patience with and much advice for her own victimized class
description: I must admit I approached The Female Eunuch with suspicion. I first heard about it last fall from a male magazine editor who had read the British edition and said it was the most brilliant piece of femin ist writing be had ever read, and it has since been recommended to me by four different men, not to men tion Norman Mailer, who plugged it in the course of his antifeminist ti rade in the February Harper's.

title: THOMAS CARROLL, AIDED THE BLIND
description: BOSTON, April 24The Rev. Thomas J. Carroll, a pioneer in rehabilitation work for the blind and executive director of the Catholic Guild for the Blind, died here today. Father Carroll was 61 years of age.

title: Suburban Schools Using Guard Dogs
description: Faced with steadily in creasing vandalism and bur glary of buildings and equip ment, a number of school systems on Long Island and in Westchester County have started to rent guard dogs.

title: Miss Leva Plans Marriage in Fall
description: BETHESDA, Md., April 24 Miss Lloyd Rose Leva, a re search assistant to Sidney R. Yates of Illinois, and Daniel Jeffrey Plaine, a lawyer with the Washington law firm of Steptoe and Johnson, plan to be married in the fall at the home of the prospective bride's parents.

title: D. A. Hewitt Fiance Of Phyllis Myers
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 24Miss Phyllis Myers and Duncan Adams Hewitt will be married June 30 in Lloyd Neck.

title: Demonstrations in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, April 24 (UPI) Participants in the leadership convention of Canada's New Democratic party staged small demonstration today to show their solidarity with antiwar demonstrations in the United States. About 400 dem onstrators gathered outside the Civic Arena, where the con vention is being held.

title: Evansville Pair Gets Lead In Women's Title Bowling
description: ATLANTA, April 24 (UPI) The Evansville, Ind., tandem of Janis Schlimmer and Donna Stuercenberger took over first place today in the Division One doubles competition of the Women's International Bowling Congress championship tourna ment with a total of 1,134 pins.

title: Books:
description: Three years ago American business was rocking in the largest wave of corporate raids, takeovers and mergers in its history.

title: TOBIN INSTRUCTED TO STRESS TRANSIT
description: The Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority 12 men long viewed as passive approvers of professional staff decisionsconvened a meeting recently with the authority's executive director, Austin J. Tobin, and, according to some who were there, took their sub ordinate to task.

title: On the West Coast, It Might Be a Baritone Asking, Your Call, Please ?...
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Con gress may have had women's rights in mind, but there are about 300 men working as switchboard operators be cause the 1964 Civil Rights Act forbids job discrimina tion for reasons of sex.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Students of environmental law, members of conservation groups and others who would like to gain greater under standing of the complex struggle now under way to preserve our natural environ ment should not be without Joseph L. Sax's sharply writ ten Defending the Environ mentA Strategy for Citizen Action (Alfred A. Knopf, 252 pages, $6.95).

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: About Pro Football
description: Following the recent death of Daniel R. Reeves, the Los Angeles Rams' first and only president, conjecture arises as to the future of the fran chise. It seems probable that Reeves' majority Interest will be sold. But to whom and for how much?

title: China's Most Popular Ballet Has a Communist Message and a Plot Reminiscent of Uncle Tom's Cabin
description: TIENTSIN, April 24 Take the story of Uncle Tom's Cabin and make it into a ballet with Chinese setting and Chinese a characters and you have rough ly the equivalent of the most popular theater piece now pay ing in the People's Republic of China.

title: CLAIR L. PECK SR., 89, WEST COAST BUILDER
description: LOS ANGELES, April 24 (UPI)  Clair L. Peck Sr., who built about 1,000 office buildings, hospitals, department stores, churches and industrial plants, in Los Angeles Cotinty in the last 56 years, died yesterday at the age of 89.

title: Local OTB Network Becoming a National Hook Up
description: The New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation is now attracting bets from around the country as horseplaying bus inessmen and college students have set up an economical communications sys tem to simplify their desire for betting action and to improve the financial wellbeing of trusted friends here.

title: Marmureanu Wins Net Final
description: TEL AVIV, April 24 (Reu ters)Petro Marmureanu of Rumania won the $1,000 first prize in the Israeli spring ten nis championships today, scor ing a 63, 63 victory over Greg Perkins of Australia in the final.

title: Coins
description: MARY THOMAS BROOKS, Director of the Mint, will head the panel of speakers at the Educational Forum to he conducted at the Metropoli tan New York Numismatic Convention in the Park Sher aton Hotel on May 69, it was announced by Ernest Bain, the show's general chairman.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor: I read with interest your ar ticle on Fordham's Hall of Fame Addition of Four New Members in Sunday's sport section.

title: Annapolis School Gets Bermuda Sailing Base
description: The Annapolis Sailing School will open its first for eign branch this month. With a location in Florida and the home base on the Chesapeake Bay, the school will have its new location in Bermuda at the Princess Hotel.

title: Five Are Chosen to Get Albert Einstein Awards
description: Five men who have distin guished themselves in the sci ences, public affairs, arts and human rights have been chosen to receive the Albert Einstein Commemorative Awards for 1971 from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Music
description: THE ending of the New York City Opera's season this evening, with a performance of Mozart's Ab duction from the Seraglio. carries with it the usual statistics. But statistics do not always make for dull reading, and comparative statistics can be illuminating. Some who take the City Opera more or less for granted are apt to forget how busy a company it really is. The Metropolitan Opera, which ended its season on April 17, had 217 performances in its 31 weeks. But the City Opera had almost as busy a year. Even with the break between its fall and spring seasons, it ended up with 156 performances in 20 weeks.

title: New York
description: A Harlem community group was meeting recently on the sub ject of pervasive narcotics ad diction. Speakers described how addicts came into apartment house hallways to get their fix es, how children coming home from school stumbled over ad dicts who had passed out on the doorstep. Some sobbed as they described such scenes.

title: Black experience as a galaxy
description: In the song Express Your self the 103d Street Watt's Band advises whatever you do, do it good. Benjamin Mays is of this tradition, for whatever he did he did it good. His life exemplifies a tradition of ex cellence, illustrated elsewhere by Ralph Ellison's Long Okla homa Eye, Satchel Paige's Hesitation Pitch, the legen dary black man who built a whole town with 5 million handmade bricks, and Marcus Garvey's tenacity.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Any privateeye story with reasonable amount of sophisti cation and with a thoughtful protagonist is automatically bracketed with Raymond Chan dler and Ross Macdonald. Few deserve the accolade; most of them tiptoe in the shadow of the Masters. One author who works in the Macdonald style without clich is Mark Sadler. His latest Paul Shaw novel HERE TO DIE (Random $4.95), is a fine, sensitive book that has action without recklessness; a social point of view that presents no easy answers; and a wellplotted mystery that at times is credible.

title: Surviving The 70's
description: Retrospective novelists of the future may have to use the Professor as the representative type of our age, as the Rogue, the Provincial Gentlewoman, the Businessman, and the Urban Proletarian now represent va rious moments in the past. Aca demic intellectuals have since the 1940's publicly figured as red menaces, TV sages, govern ment insiders, heroes of tech nology, freeloading leeches, and most recently corrupters of democratic youth or epito mes of universal establishmen tarian hypocrisy. And as a cul ture founded on the professorial talents  exact knowledge, mo ral casuistry and intellectual hocus  pocus  drifts closer to utter, devastating absurdity, the professional thinker becomes a convenient and by no means in nocent scapegoat. I do not like thee, Dr. Fell  and for Fell read Strangelove, Pangloss, Frankenstein, No, or what you

title: Clocks Set Ahead For Daylight Time
description: Daylight saving time took effect today at 2 A.M.

title: Customers Come First For Dealer
description: Marine dealers, like other retailers, can often be heard bemoaning their association with suppliers. Often they blame the boat manufacturer for a lost sale because they (the builder) don't know what the customer wants. If they were on the firing line like the dealer they'd build boats to meet the boatman's needs, not just to satisfy their high priced designers and their production capabilities.

title: YOUNG JEWS SEEK A RELIGIOUS STYLE
description: Shaped as much by social un rest in the United States during the last decade as by the classi cal events of Jewish history, some young Jews have begun to search for a new religious style that is traditional in be lief but independent of major Jewish institutions.

title: Miss Lord Betrothed to Benjamin Winthrop White, Medical Student
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., April 24 Miss Madeleine d'Ivry Lord and Benjamin Winthrop White, a greatgrandson of the late Stanford White, the archi tect, and grandson of the late Lawrence Grant White, who served as president of the National Academy of Design, plan to be married here in September in St. James' Ro man Catholic Church.

title: Court Ruling Puts Results Of Berkeley Race in Doubt
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 24 A ruling by a state judge cast new doubt yesterday on the re sults of Berkeley's disputed municipal election. The judge directed that 100 late absentee ballots be included in the to tals.

title: Taiwan Authorities Raid Secret Rituals in an Attempt to Curb an Outlawed Religious Group
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanIn the last few months the authorities have made two mass arrests involv ing more than 30 people, most ly teenaged girl factory work ers, found performing rituals of an outlawed secret religious group.

title: SOVIET PILOTS ROLE NOTED BY MRS. MEIR
description: JERUSALEM, April 24 (AP) Premier Golda Meir conceded today that Israeli and Soviet pilots might battle if hostilities erupted in the Middle East.

title: Hobby Boat Paves Way For Cement
description: When John Samson was using steel and cement to build a boat in 1965, a skep tical friend suggested that on launching day he should shackle himself to the ves sel's chain plates just to demonstrate his confidence.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAPETOWNSouth Africa's Prime Minister, John Vorster, a blocky, thin lipped, quietvoiced man, resembles other world leaders in suspecting the press of being unfairly biased against his policy. He claims this country's papers keep telling untruths and pre dicting disasters.

title: Y.W.C.A. in City Elects New Board of Officers
description: The election of Mrs. Albert H. Gordon as president of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City for a threeyear term was announced yesterday

title: Et Al.
description: An admiring biographical sketch of Lenin by his closest collaborator. Modestly Leon Trotsky offers his essay as fragment for a future bio graphy. Here are all the seeds of Stalin's totalitarianism. As Trotskyologist Bertram Wolfe remarks in his introduction: How terrible does Trotsky's arrogant and boastful exalta tion of terror become as we contemplate the long reach of Stalin to Trotsky's safe refuge in his fortress home in Mexico, as an Alpine pick crashes into his skull, and the blood from his brain spills over a sheet of his. manuscript of the Life of Stalin.Interesting Com munist curiosa.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: For Young Readers
description: This is a wonderful novel, a rare bridging of the distance between books for children and adults. It is about Julia Redfern on her way to becoming a writer, a process illumi nated with many truths and insights. Julia is somewhere around 11 or 12  exactly how old doesn't matter. She is a thinking, feeling, growing person, that's what counts. The year is 1924, the place is Berkeley, Calif.

title: Instruments Aid Sailor's Safety In Varied Ways
description: A visit to a wellstocked marine store gives you the opportunity to see many types of marine instruments. In fact, there may be so many instruments that you tend to take them for grant ed and not pay much atten tion.

title: Forests set Visitors Record
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)  The United States Forest Service says Americans spent 172.5 million visitor days, a record, last year on public land operated by the agency. That was a gain of 10 million from 1969, the agency said. A visitor day is equivalent to one per son's spending 12 hours using the nation's 154 national for ests.

title: JAZZ FETE ENDS IN NEW ORLEANS

description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 24 Northeastern University's varsity heavyweight crew de feated Brown University by length today over a 2,000meter course on the Seekonk River.

title: The Nixon Plan

title: Lennie Hayton, Composer, Dies; Was Husband of Lena Horne
description: Leonard George (Lennie) Hayton, composer, conductor and arranger, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Desert Hos pital, Palm Springs, Calif. He was 63 years old.

title: Miss Erin Farrell Bride of Hunt Smith

I., April 24Miss Erin Hill Farrell, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Babcock Farrell of New York and Joseph An thony Farrell, was married here this noon to Thurston Huntting Smith Jr., who is known as Hunt Smith, a com mercial photographer in New York. description: BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) Deborah June Lang, whose family connections with rac ing dates back to a great grandfather, has been named Miss Preakness at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Television

About 40 of us  actors, their relatives and friends, director, technical crew, Tac tical Patrol Force police, photographers, reporters and assorted hangersonare jammed into a small bodega (grocery) on 11th Street and Avenue B where WNBCTV is videotaping They Can't Even Read Spanish, a halfhour play abbut Puerto Rican life in New York, which will be seen on Channel 4 at 7 P.M. Saturday, May 8.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Simulated fur fabric  of ten referred to as fake fur  has come of age. Women's coat manufacturers who spe cialize in synthetic fiber gar ments are projecting sales increases ranging upward of 20 per cent from 1970.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
