description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Power Boat Group Hails Miami Woman
description: A 28yearold Miami house wife and mother of two, Mrs. Sharon Chambers, was lion ored recently by Sports Illus trated magazine as one of the first two women ever to re ceive an American Power Boat Association national high point championship in outboard pleasure craft rac ing.

title: Banks Test Antitrust
description: The Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco and the Anti trust division of the Depart ment of Justice appear to be on a collision course. The outcome of this confronta tion could well have a sig nificant bearing on whether any mergers between signifi cant banking institutions are possible under present anti trust law.

title: Stars Gain 11 Soccer Tie With Tornado on Late Goal
description: DALLAS, April 24 (AP) Casey Frankiewicz slammed home a rebound off the goal keeper to give the St. Louis Stars a 11 draw with the Dal las Tornado tonight in a North American Soccer League game.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: OPTIMISM over prospects for the economy and for the financial markets continues to be the watchword in Government, business and invest ment circlesa sentiment that is rather solidly based in recent economic statistics and trends.

title: U.S. Pavilion's Use Is Issue in Queens
description: At least a halfdozen com munity groups in Queens are continuing to press the city administration to preserve the now Silent United States Pa vilion of the 196465 World's Fair for use as a major muse um for the borough.

title: ARCHITECTS URGE POLLUTION FIGHT
description: The New York chapter of the American Institute of Ar chitects said last week that architects, as professionals, re sponsible for shaping the en vironment must utilize their skills to reduce pollution through conservation of energy and through design planning.

title: A Stage Irish Drunk who died of drink
description: A few jokes . . . London, 1956.

title: Ousted West Pointer Joins Naval Academy
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)A young Tennessean who was thrown out of the Military Academy at West Point last fall, for saying he had shined his shoes when he had not, is getting another chance at a service career, this time in the Navy.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONOn those rare occasions when it can be measured at all, progress in the tortured Middle East negotiations usually comes in small steps. One such step was taken last week when Israel, after months of Amer ican pressure, finally came forward with a set of ideas and proposals for the re opening of the Suez Canal.

title: CONSUMER GIVEN TIPS BY BUTCHERS
description: There was no aroma, no scent, no pungent odor in the room. Yet the atmosphere was highly appetizing.

title: A Cycle Circle in Yellowstone
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK  We had come to vsit this old  favorite natural wonder in a new way, exploring the byways, stopping whenever the mood struck us, not worrying about a place to park the car. We were on bicycles. It was as though we had never been here before. All our senses leaped to life and we got to know Yellowstone by touch, sound, smell and even taste.

title: Et Al.
description: A grimsometimes monoto nously solook at one wo man's wallow in drugs, prosti tution, hipster life, and all the rest of the forties and fifties underground scene. Florrie Fisher was a notsonice Jew ish girl of a conventional, wealthy family. She was turned on to pot by a musician (re member when only musicians smoked?) and went on to hero in, cocaine, and anything else around. Her addiction lasted 20 years. She tells of her life as a prostitute (hubby was her pimp) quite vividly. At last she was cured by Synanon, has re married and begun a new ca reer helping addicts. Moral: Don't take that first toke, kids.

title: Edward Teller: Reopen the Skie
description: LIVERMORE, Calif.  Seventeen years ago President Eisenhower pro posed the Open Skies policy: Let us permit inspection of both Russia and the United States from the air, in an open manner. In fact, let us enforce an open skies policy similar to our old firm position on the free dom of the seas.

title: Let Me Show You The Caves of Crete, My Dear
description: PSYCHRO, Crete  I'm going to show you a real caveman, I told my friend. He'll jump in front of the car as soon as we reach Psychro. My friend, Julie, a young American tourist of especially pleasing countenance, was impressed. As well she should be. After all, I was the old Cretan hand, having lived here as prac ticing ne'erdowell on and off on sev eral occasions over the past six years. She was the suitably wideeyed coed come to see the glories of Greece. What better opportunity for us both. Or so I thought.

title: Bar Unit to Honor Burger
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger of the United States Su preme Court will be the prin cipal speaker at a Law Day din ner of the Federal Bar Coun cil on May 3 at the Pierre Hotel. The council's Learned Hand Medal for excellence in Federal jurisprudence will be presented to Chief Justice Bur ger by Chief Judge J. Edward Lumbard of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sec ond Circuit.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: A recent evening flight be tween Tampa and New York indicates to Me that some domestic airlines  for the large profits to be derived from liquor sales in flight may be operating their planes as flying bars to the incon venience of most of their passengers. I enjoy a drink when flying, but service of drinks to some ought not be permitted to inconvenience all. It is understandable be cause, at $1.50 a drink, the profit is large and the temp tation strong to sell as many drinks as possible within the twodrink per passenger lim it. During the trip in ques tion the first hour of the two hour flight was devoted sole ly to selling and serving

title: Lawyer Weds Mrs. Griggs In Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Mrs. Joan Kerman Griggs, daughter of George F. Ken nan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union and Yugo slavia, and Mrs. Kennan of Princeton, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Walter Pozen, a member of the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan and manag ing partner of its Washington office. The ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, La fayette Square, was per formed by the Rev. Herbert L. SteinSchneider.

title: Marilyn Stasio, Cue Critic, Is Bride
description: REVERE, Mass., April 24 Miss Marilyn Louise Stasio, drama critic of Cue, the New York weekly entertainment magazine, was married at Immaculate Conception Ro man Catholic Church here today to Richard Joseph Hummler, a theatrical press representative. The Rev. Wil liam J. Cummings performed the ceremony, which included marriage vows written by the couple and selections from Scripture and Shakespeare.

title: Billboard to Be Removed
description: FREEPORT, Me., April 24 (AP)The first billboard in the nation to be taken down under the Federal highway beautifi cation program will be re moved from Interstate 95 here Tuesday afternoon.

title: DR. HERMANN KOHL; FOUNDED NORDA OIL
description: Dr. Hermann Joseph Kohl, founder and board chairman of Norda Essential Oil and Chemi cal Company, Inc., manufac turers of flavors and per fumery, died yesterday at his home, 186 Riverside Drive. His age was 81.

title: Music
description: IF Leonard Rose were a businessman, he would probably be a successful one. As a person, he fits the conventional picture. At 52, he is in fine physical shape, trim and energetic. He is goodlooking, well groomed, conservatively dressed. He is articulate. His opinions are sound; he has a decent concern for his fel low man and a respectable interest in international af fairs. He has met at least one President of the United States. He is conscientious. He has a house in Hastings onHudson, and he commutes to New York when his work takes him there. He has two grown children, a son who is an economist in Washing ton, a daughter who just got married. He has expensive hobbies. He used to be a good golfer, but his game has fallen off because his business travels take up so

title: R.efugees From Haiti Struggle To Open Up a New Life Here
description: Each morning as the first light touches the clustered tenements of central Brook lyn, a caravan of French speaking Haitians prepares to depart for factories, situated one hour away on the south shore of Suffolk County.

title: New Chairman at Brandeis
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 24 (AP)Jacob Hiatt, a Worcester business executive, was named today to become chairman of the Brandeis University Board of Trustees effective July 1. He succeeds Lawrence A. Wien of New York, whose retirement after five years as chairman be comes effective June 30.

title: Bay Staters Are Indicted On U.S. Pollution Charges
description: BOSTON April 24 (AP)A federal grand jury has indicted two Massachusetts corpora tions and their presidents on charges of water pollution,

title: A timeless, walled Yaddo for a gifted misfit
description: Twenty years ago, when he was 30, a talented white collegeeducated jazz pianist named James Blake found himself serving a twoyear sentence in the Duval County jail in Jackson ville, Fla., charged with petit larceny and breaking and entering. It was his first experience at doing time, and although Blake was absurdly out of character as a criminal type and, by this own admission, the world's most inept burglar, he discovered that confinement offered such sover eign satisfactions and fulfillments that he caused himself to be incar cerated at the Jacksonville jail or, even more happily, at The Joint, the Florida State Penitentiary at Rai ford, for 13 of the next 20 years.

title: Futuristic Weapons Tested at Reservation on Coast
description: HUNTER LIGGETT MILI TARY RESERVATION, Calif.

title: The World
description: The Western Hemisphere's second republic lost its long time ruler with the death last Wednesday of President Francois Duvalier, and Haiti watchers are preparing for a considerable spell of sec ondguessing. The mystery of the Duvalier regime out lives the death of its archi tect, and Haiti's future re mains as unpredictable as its past is murky.

title: Davidsons Have Child
description: A daughter was born on April 7 to Mr. and Mrs. Peter Davidson in University Hos pital. The child has been named Karen Julia.

title: INDIA REPORTS FIRING ON PAKISTAN BORDER
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 24 An Indian spokesman said today that Pakistani troops in company strength had fired across the border of East Pakis tan at the Indian village of Petrapole.

title: Chess
description: In the following position, after gruelling contest between Tchigorin and Caro, of CaroKann fame, Tchigorin, White, let go a sockdolager, which put the game on ice. What is White's move which writes finis to hostilities?

title: On the Planet Polluto
description: Can a nation that spends far more money destroying the ecology of Vietnam than im proving its own ever forestall its environmental degradation?

title: Letter to the Editor 9  No Title
Kashmir's Tourist Trade Hurt by Pakistani Conflict
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, April 24Tensions caused by the conflict in Pakistan have hurt the tourist business in Kashmir, which has a border with West Pakistan.

title: Karate Is A Thing of The Spirit By Harry Crews. 218 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $5.95.
description: Gaye Nell Odell is a brown belt

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: It was stated in the article First Lady of the Passport Office by Robert Sherrill (Travel section, March 14) that the only places where one could have a passport application processed in Con necticut were 12 post offices in eight state cities. For your information, 100 of the 125 probate courts in Connecticut have been processing pass port applications for the last eight and onehalf months. The applicant usually gets the passport five to seven days after applying. This court handles applications from several probate districts that did not choose to handle applications. In fact, we have had applicants from other states who happened to be in the area when they decided that wanted

title: Super Wave Captures O'Brien Hanover Open Handicap Pace at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 24 All of the early speedsters faded, leaving the $25,000 O'Brien Hanover open handi cap pace to the late closers at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The onemile feature, clocked in 2 minutes 1 2/5 seconds, was won by Super Wave, noted for his rallying strength, by threequarters of a length from Leroy N.

title: The Vodka Special to Estonia
description: HELSINKI, FinlandSo you're taking the Vodka Special? re marked our taxi driver as he drove us past the colorful out door fruit and vegetable market of Hel sinki's South Harbor. Ahead loomed the large white ship whose threefoot black letters just barely proclaimed it to be the Tallinn, for Russian letters seem to have important parts missing. This was an Estonian ship, a superferry with cruise vessel aspirations that daily plies the Baltic between East and West, link ing Finland's capital with Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, now one of the 15 republics that make up the Soviet Union.

title: A Guide With a Case of the FiveHa Laughs And Other Curiosities of the Inscrutable ast
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Before his deposal in 1965, the late President Sukarno never got this capital city finished according to his hearty tastes. Today, it still has a halfcom pleted look. Conspicuous among some new buildings that are now cropping up not far from some of the strong man's old aborted ones are the regional headquarters of three international pow ersWest Germany, Japan and the Seventh Day Adventists. Some of the monuments that were designed in Ja karta in Sukarno's time did get finished and remain in placea statue memo rializing revolution, for instance, a gift from the Soviet Union. Its sculptured figures wear Indonesian clothes but have Slavic features. Sukarno himself put up a towering column surmounted by an undeviatingly Indonesian figure with hands upstretched and fingers outthrust. This memorial was supposed to sym bolize independence, but since Sukarno's passing some cynical Indonesians, be cause of the statue's empty, groping hands, have taken to calling it the symbol of indigence.

title: Harlem's Zion Church Marks 150th Year
description: With marching bands, flow erdecked floats and the glit ter of twirling batons, thou sands of Protestant blacks paraded through Harlem yes terday afternoon to mark 150 years of religious and com munity service by the Afri can Methodist Episcopal Zion Church in New York.

title: Olivia Langdon Schieffelin Married
description: St. George's Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Olivia Lang don Schieffelin to E. Wayne Nordberg. The Rev. John Jay Schieffelin Jr., cousin of the bride, performed the cere mony, assisted by the Rev. Edward O. Miller, rector of the church. A reception fol lowed at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: For Young Readers
description: In The Vicksburg Veteran, F. N. Monjo views the battle of Vicks burg through the eyes of 12yearold Fred Grant. Fred, the son of Ulysses S. Grant, accompanied the general in 1863 as he ran the gantlet under the Vicksburg bluff, slogged through swampy bayous, lived off the land deep in enemy territory and sent the victory telegram to Lincoln so the President could say: the Father of Waters again goes unvexed to the sea.

title: A $ 20 Million Club Promotes Sunfish
description: CARACAS, Venezuela Organizing a world Sunfish regatta is a simple thing if you have a $20million club behind you.

title: Cooke Urges Drive by Catholics For State Abortion Law Repeal
description: A plea from Cardinal Cooke requesting Roman Catholics in the New York Archdiocese to make their views against abor tion known to the state's elect ed officials will be read today at all masses in the 407 par ishes of the archdiocese.

title: ESTHER BINDURSKY
description: MEMPHIS, April 24 (AP) Esther Bindursky, editor of The Lepanto (Ark.) New Record for many years, died last night in Baptist Hospital. She was 66 years old.

title: MISS HAYNIE TAKES SHOT LEAD WITH 145
description: MIAMI, April 24 (UPI)San dra Haynie, who lost in a sud dendeath playoff here last year, took over the lead after two rounds today in the Bur dine's Women's invitation golf tournament with a scrambling threeunderpar 71.

title: 53 CAIRO ISSUES STILL ECHO TODAY
description: CAIRO, April 24  When Secretary of State William P. Rogers comes to Cairo early in May to seek to promote peace between Egypt and Israel, per sistent echoed of the Middle Eastern problems and griev ances of 18 years ago will be heard in the conference rooms.

title: VILLANOVA WINS 3 RELAY CROWNS So, Carolina Beats Wildcats 2 Titles for Adelphi
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 24 Marty Liquori of Villanova wound up an undefeated Penn Relays career today, but that was about the only measure of form to survive a string of sur prises at the 77th annual track and field carnival.

title: The Nation
description: FACT: In September, 1969, two parents, their teenage daughter and eightyearold son could fly roundtrip between New York and San Francisco for $786. Starting May 7, if the same family boards a jet, the fare will be $979.

title: WR CHLLENGES DISMISSED HERE
description: Two decisions by Federal judges here dismissing separate cases of two soldiers who had challenged orders sending them to Vietnam on the ground that the war was unconstitutional have been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Questor: It's in a Name
description: LOS ANGELES,  If we had kept the Dunhill name, we would have been forever explaining that we weren't in the retail tobacco business, P. M. Sandy Grieve found himself explaining here re cently.

title: Boating Advanced by Amateurs
description: The Amateur Yacht Re search Society, whose mem bership includes such indi viduals as Prince Philip and impecunious and otherwise unknown citizens, is not strictly amateur.

title: Son Born to the Golding
description: A son was born to State Senator Harrison J. Goldin of the Bronx in Mount Sinai Hospital on April 5. The child has been named Daniel Gideon Alexis. Senator Goldin represents the 30th Sena torial District.

title: Hog Cholera Cases Down
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Only 55 hog cholera cases were reported in the country in the first quarter of 1971, a drop of nearly 70 per cent from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said to day. Each case represents an infected herd, officials ex plained. Any infection discov ered results in slaughter of the herd, with stateFederal indem nities for the owner.

title: Bayh Cultivates the Politicians in Quest for Support in 1972
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 24 Edwin P. Fifielski is the alder man for Chicago's 45th Ward. He is middleaged, wears his hair in a crewcut and stands with conservatives on many so cial issues.

title: The World
description: CALCUTTA  The independ ence struggle in East Pakistan is drawing the United States, the Soviet Union, Communist China and India into a sort of diplo matic minuet and maneuver with considerable potential conse quences. What these countries eventually decide to do could determine not only the outcome of the war but also the future course of South Asia.

title: EXECUTIVE, SISTER KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: DENVER, April 24 (AP) George H. B. Gould, president of the Gates Lear Jet Corpora tion, and his hister, Mrs. Bar bara G. Davis, were killed last night when their station wagon was struck by a car fleeing the police.

title: A Future for Fly Ash?
description: The power companies have been spew ing profits as well as pollutants into the atmosphere, researchers  who are backing up their opinion with invest ment capitalbelieve.

title: Niagara Bus Plan Set
description: BUFFALO, April 24 () The Niagara Frontier Transpor tation Authority plans to pur chase and operate three bus companies now serving Buffalo, Niagara Falls and the Tonawan das, it s chairman says. There is no one in our authority who can run a bus so we hope to buy the management also, William E. Miller told the Fron tier Press Club Thursday night.

title: NIXON IS PLANNING A FARMER SALUTE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  President Nixon plans to stage a miniature county fair at the White House May 7, with cat tle, hogs, sheep and a host of farm exhibits, as a salute to American agriculture.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reluctant April
description: A late spring means a busy May. No matter how reluctant the change from dormancy to leaf and blossom, the season always catches up with itself before June and summer. Now, in this last week of April, we can say that March is definitely behind, though April will leave a good deal of unfinished business for May to tend to.

title: Germ Warfare on Insect Pests
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered disease organisms that can wage warfare against pests on crops as effective ly as conventional insecticides. Al though the bacteria and viruses are fatal to insects, laboratory experiments have proved them safe for man and other life.

title: Being There By Jerzy Kosinshi. 142 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $4.95.
description: Chance learns how from television

title: CANADIENS FORGE 21 PLAYOFF LEAD
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 24The Montreal Canadiens, with Frank Mahovlich and Jac ques Laperriere showing the way, defeated, the Minnesota North Stars, 63, tonight and took a 21 edge in their Na tional Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series.

title: MISS CARLSON'S DUO WINS SKATING TITLE
description: Skating to a medley of Irish tunes, with shamrocks decorat ing their green costumes, Mary Beth Braun and Nancy Carlson captured the women's pairs title last night in the Middle Atlantic figure skating champi onships at the Abe Stark Skat ing Rink in Coney Island, Brooklyn.

title: GERMAN LEFTISTS SAY THEY HOLD TEACHERS
description: BONN, April 24  The West German police were searching today for Prof. Berthold Rubin and his Cologne University as sistant, who have been missing since Wednesday and are be lieved to have been kidnapped by leftists.

title: Law
description: Only two and a half months had passed since the drive be gan, yet last Tuesdayin an un precedented burst of speed and unanimitythe New York State Assembly passed a new adop tion bill. Its key provision: A natural mother who gives up her baby for adoption would have only 30 days to change her mind; from then on, if the baby has been placed with a family for ad option, she would be unable to get it back.

title: A YearRound Festival Of Lanterns in Spain
description: IN the Orient, feasts of lanterns are usually held once 1. year, but in Spain the tourist can enjoy a feast of lanterns the year round. My enchantment with Spanish street lamps began in Jerez, where I glimpsed the centerpiece pictured here. The glass was missing, and a vagrant, windblown seed had turned the lamp into a planter, symbolizing for me the verdancy of southern Spain. At the right, stately senti nels guard a bridge on the site of Seville's 1929 exposition, one of the city's most impressive showcases today. But even the most utilitarian of street lights manage to take on special poetry in Spain. The extravaganza at lower left Barcelona, for example, doubles as a bench for pedestrians.

title: Anita Finston to Wed
description: Miss Anita Louise Finston and Warren Belmar will be married on May 23 at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Finston have announced the engagement of their daugh ter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Belmar, also of New York.

title: James G. Rogers Dead at 88; ExAssistant Secretary of State
description: DENVER, April 24  James Grafton Rogers, an Assistant Secretary of State under Presi dent Herbert Hoover who had also been an educator, a poet, a lawyer and a leading citizen of Colorado, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 88 years old.

title: Nigeria Expects Loan
description: KANO, Nigeria, April 24 (Agence FrancePresse) The World Bank will lend Nigeria more than $50million to help the postwar economic recovery, the Finance Commissioner, Chief Obafemi Awolowo, an nounced here last night.

title: U.S. LISTS VIEWS ON ENVIRONMENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  Gingerly and tactfully, the United States is initiating over tures to the world community to bring some order out of environmental chaos.

title: Graebner, Richey Gain Final
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (UPI) Topseeded Clark Graebner and secondseeded Cliff Richey ad vanced today to the final of the River Oaks tennis tourna ment by winning grueling threehour matches that were finished under the lights.

title: 7 Records Bettered in Drake Relays
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, April 24 (AP)Seven major meet rec ords, including that for the pole vault in which two com petitors cleared 17 feet, tum bled today in the wrapup of the 62d Drake Relays.

title: A. C. Paddock Weds Wendy Brewer
description: MILTON, Mass., April 24 Miss Wendy Ellen Brewer was married here this after noon to Anthony Conaway Paddock of New York. The Rev. Prescott Wintersteen performed the ceremony in the First Parish Church (Uni tarian).

title: Promises to Keep
description: Truth, not unconvincing humility, is the grandest virtue and accord ingly I may observe that I am better qualified than any man alive to re view a book on the public life of Chester Bowles. He succeeded me in de facto responsibility for price con trol in World War H. (I was in charge of prices until just before he became head of O.P.A. as a whole.) He preceded and followed me as Am bassador in India. We worked to gether in the Presidential campaigns of 1956 and (in lesser measure) of 1960 and in the early months of the Kennedy Administration in 1961. He is a friend, which is a disadvantage only if the book in question 4s bad. Only then do you have to consider whether the author should get the truth from you or someone else. This, fortunately, is an extremely good book.

title: U.S. Says Job Total Dropped by 44,000 During a Year Here
description: Employment in the New York northeastern New Jersey area for the year ended last Febru ary declined by 44,000 to a total of 6,579,000 workers, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional director here of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Elegant Eggplant
description: E GGPLANT can grow as well  though more briefly, of coursein New York or Massa chusetts as in Israel or the south of France. Here in northeastern United States, the harvest starts about Au gust 1530 and lasts until the first frost.

title: Book Reviews Cardinal Rules Of Boat Safety
description: Some 46 million Americans will go down to the water this year in fishing boats, outboards, ketches, yawls, catamarans, canoes, rowboats and rafts. Last year, Ameri cans spent nearly $4billion for new and used boats, motors, safety equipment, docking, insurance, fuel, maintenance, launching, stor age, repairs and club mem bership.

title: MICHIGAN YOUTHS FELL BILLBOARDS
description: DETROIT, April 24  Six young men from Ann Arbor, home of the University of Mich igan and site of the nation's very first environmental teach in, have attained Robin Hood reputations as bold, elusive billboard bandits.

title: Compliments in Athens
description: Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans has managed to outdo even the American Ambassador, Henry J. Tasca, in unnecessary praise of the ruling colonels during the very week in which they were celebrating the fourth an niversary of their destruction of constitutional govern ment in Greece.

title: Water Is Last Frontier For Flight From Cares
description: The United States, ideal for the pleasure boatman, has thousands of miles of navi gable shoreline, and many more miles of inland rivers and lakes, All are potential cruising and recreation grounds for the boatman, whether he be novice or ex pert, a bluewater sailor, ca noeist or weekend fisherman, waterskier or picnicker.

title: New Postmaster In Brooklyn Got Job the Hard Way
description: Brooklyn has Its first post master appointed under the Post Office Department's new merit selection procedure. Martin Shapiro, who began working as a substitute mail clerk in 1921, is the first merit appointment to this job in 170 years.

title: Dr. Mead Says the Nonsense of Many in Women's Lib Gets Us Nowhere
description: Dr. Margaret Mead declared yesterday that she had been working for women's equality all her life, but that she could have no sympathy, as a schol ar, with the amount of utter nonsense that she said had been spoken by some members of the women's liberation movement.

title: TERRIER IS BEST IN RESTON SHOW
description: RESTON, Va., April 24Ch. Twinpond Plaid Cymru, a 2 yearold Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Robert V. Clark Jr., of nearby Middleburg, Va., was named best in show at the Old Dominion Kennel Club's 56th event. The classy Welsh, ably handled by his breeder, Peter J. Green, survived gale winds in the area and the competition of 3,084 other entries.

title: Education
description: ESTES PARK, ColoAmer ica spends much time and en ergy analyzing its youth, but during the White House Con terence on Youth here last. week youth was more inter ested in analyzing America.

title: MRS. FAIRFIELD, 87, EXMISSIONARY, DIES
description: Mrs. Daisie Gehman Fairfield, a former Congregational Chris tian Church missionary in China, died Friday in Claremont, Calif., at the age of 87.

title: Judith Severinsen Is Engaged to Wed
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., April 24Carl (Doc) Severinsen, musical director of the Johnny Carson Tonight show, and Mrs. Severinsen have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Judith Dayle Severinsen, to Emory Castimore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Castimore of of Augusta.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gardens
description: IMPATIENS is an old fashioned annual with renewed popularity. The Fl hybrids have more profuse blooming, larger flowers and thicklybranch ing dwarf forms. Also, new colors, bicolors, and double flowers have been developed.

title: New Head of Junior College
description: BOSTON, April 24 (AF) Grahm Junior College has an nounced the election of Dr. Arthur M. Griffin, headmaster of the Cheshire Academy, Cheshire, Conn., as president of the twoyear college. Dr. Griffin, 53 years old, a one time Eastern Airlines pilot, will take over June 30 for Milton L. Grahm, the college's presi dent and founder.

title: Art
description: THE past couple of weeks have brought to New York two exhibi tions by a couple of artists, at once curiously related and totally divorced from one another, whose work, each in its own way, demands superla tives. George Segal, with new sculp tures at the Sidney Janis Gallery, is surely one of the best sculptors at work anywhere today, while Mel Ramos, at French & Co., has cranked out the tack iest, the cheapest, the tawdriest, and at once the most pretentious set of paint ings that I can remember having seen in a respectable gallery  or perhaps we must now say formerly respectable gallery  in a long time.

title: Crimmins Confession in'68 Reported
description: An alleged confession by Mrs. Alice Crimmins that she had killed her two young childrenmade while under the influence of a nerve soothing drugwas ruled in admissible as evidence by the judge in her recent trial, it was disclosed yesterday by sources close to the case.

title: 1862 Railroad Scrip Found
description: ATLANTA, April 24 (UPI) Four big boxes of scrip, issued by the Western and Atlantic Railroad in 1862 to give change to customers without the exact fare, have been discovered in vaults of the Georgia State Treasury. The scrip will be turned over to the state archives.

title: Glass Table Proves Fatal
description: CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI) Edward Seals, 25 years old, fainted, fell onto a glasstopped table in his home, and bled to death from throat cuts, police reported today.

title: U.S. PLANES BOMB 2 SITES IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24American fighter planes bombed two missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command an nounced today. It also reported that in other action its planes had chased an enemy MIG21 out of Laos and had been fired on four times by antiaircraft rockets.

title: Mills Backed for President  Two House Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) Two of Representative Wilbur D. Mills's colleagues have urged his candidacy for President, which the Arkansas Democrat disclaims.

title: Hanging Together
description: Like sitting in a liberal echo chamber. What do blacks ac tually want? Was there a dif ference, after all, between white immigrants and slaves? Taylor argues that the liberal ap proach to black problems will finally work; but in the face of recent history it seems like a daydream to believe that people (not the daydreamers, of course) will voluntarily give up their luxuries so that others can have the necessities.

title: Sofia Puts Its Best Foot Forward for Week of Communist Party Congress
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 22 The day before Bulgarian Communists opened their tenth party congress here, the con cierge of the highrise apart ment building where many diplomats live came to call on his tenants. His message was simple.

title: Should We Have War Crime Trials?
description: To the Editor: Neil Sheehan's essayreview on our Southeastern Asia situ ation (based on a 33book bibli ography collected by Mark Sacharoff) is a painstaking survey of our criminal record in that area  and a milestone in the coverage of the long drawn Indochina War . . . It is also one of those editorial acts that may soon translate itself into a political act, even a po litical force.

title: BONN PARTIES END TRUCE ON BERLIN
description: BONN, April 24A twodec adeold tradition by which West German Government and Oppo sition parties made common cause on the Berlin issue col lapsed this week under partisan political controversy.

title: Metamorphosis of a Hawk: Why an exNavy Hero From Tennessee Attacked J. Edgar Hoover
description: THE first news last December was something of a surprise. Con gressman William R. Anderson, Democrat from Tennessee, former commander of the Nautilus, the nu clear submarine that made man's first voyage under the North Pole, had at tacked J. Edgar Hoover on the floor of the House of Representatives. A bit of news in itself, since Hoover is not often attacked, at least in public, by men whose jobs depend on elec tions. Even more rarely is he criticized by exNavy heroes from rural Tennes see. And not only was Hoover being attacked, but two Catholic priests, Daniel and Philip Berrigan, convicted of destroying draftboard records and imprisoned in a Federal penitentiary, were being defended by Anderson. The fact that Anderson's district is a swath of the Bible Belt, where funda mentalists tend to prejudge Catholics with very grave suspicion, spiced the surprise.

title: Colombia Diversifies Exports
description: Diversify and increase exports. Such is the simple, sound prescription for de veloping countries suffering from onecropeconomy weak ness.

title: Documents at Queens College Offer Glimpse of Old New York
description: In a firstfloor room of the Paul Klepper Library at Queens College, 300 years flash by with the turn of a page.

title: Pact Said to LetAtomArms Stay Temporarily in Japan
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 United States officials and foreign diplomatic sources have disclosed that for years secret agreement with the Japanese Government has per mitted the United States to move nuclear weapons tem porarily into Japan.

title: Some in South Believe Court's Ruling Upholding Busing Will Have Little Effect on Segregated Schools
description: ATLANTA, April 24The re action across the South to the Supreme Court's unanimous ruling this week upholding the constitutionality of busing as a means to dismantle the dual school systems contained a curious blend of astonishment, anger and optimism among some white parents and educa tors that it will have little or no effect.

title: One Way to Figure the Derby
description: When legal off track betting on the Kentucky Derby makes its debut here next Wednesday, New Yorkers will start employing the usual variety of selection methods.

title: MITCHELL EXPECTS VIOLENCE TO COME
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)Relieved that today's antiwar protest had occurred peacefully, Attorney General John N. Mitchell nonetheless persisted with his warning that there was substantial likeli hood of violence in the next two weeks of demonstrations here.

title: 348YearOld Book Given
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 24 (AP)  A 348yearold volume of the plays of Shakespeare has been presented to Brown Uni versity on the anniversary of his birth and death. The collec tion of 36 plays was given this week by Mr. and Mrs. William V. A. Hansen of Barrington, Ill., in memory of her father, Alfred MacArthur, brother of the late playwright Charles Mac Arthur.

title: John Valenstein Plans to Marry Karen Wishnew
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., April 24Miss Karen Ann Wish new and John Martin Valen stein plan to be married here on June 6.

title: RUTGERS CREW WINS ON CHARLES
description: BOSTON, April 24Rutgers University's varsity heavy weight crew authored the row ing surprise of the season as it Outstroked Boston University and Dartmouth over the 2,000 meter course on the Charles River today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If, as many maintain, it was indeed his military training that divested Lieu tenant Calley of his humanity and taught him to hate and to kill innocent and defenseless civilians, he is to be pitied and forgiven more than pun ished. If he is indeed more victim than criminal, his corrupters must be found and dealt with, and their perversion of soldiers' consciences stopped.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For decade after decade some facts of baseball life were accepted by all true believers as being selfevident and incon trovertible. The homerhitting records of Babe Ruth and the basestealing records of Ty Cobb would be safe forever. Not only were they unbreakable but they also were unapproachable. Oh, yeah?

title: DEVICES TO DEFUSE BOMBS ARE STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) The Justice Department, in cooperation with the Army and the Navy, has sanctioned two research programs aimed at neutralizing homemade bombs and developing new bomb dis posal techniques.

title: Dance: Lubovitch Series
description: It was in October, 1968 that Lar Lubovitch first pre sented his dance company in New York and since that time his company has given spasmodic but regular New York performances. How ever, its fourperformance series at the New York Fes tival Public Theater, which opened at midnight Friday and continues tonight and tomorrow night, represents the group's most successful engagement to date.

title: Lindsay Lays Fiscal Cuts to Politics
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day tat cuts in the state budget, and the city fiscal crisis they heighten, were the result of political rather than economic decisions.

title: Hartford Symphony Excels in Mahler
description: There is a mystique about certain works of music that require enormous performing forces, Their size and the fact that they rarely get done mag nifies their value, sometimes beyond their worth. One case in point is Schoenberg's GurreLieder. Another is Mahler's Eighth Symphony, nicknamed the Symphony of a Thousand because it calls for an enlarged symphony or chestra, several choruses and eight soloists.

title: Movies
description: (After reading too much wex . . . or vexing too much weed or weeding too much rex . . or . aw, the hell with it.) WELL, come on IN! She stood in the doorway of her 17thcentury farm house, a nursing mother of a cat curled at her feet, which were curled around the cat. Barefoot she padded across the lush carpeting to the brick hewn fireplace where logs were burn ing, sending their licking flames sky ward and aft., an orangey glow light ing her hair with a feathery touch.

title: Expos Defeat Astros
description: HOUSTON, April 24 (AP) Ron Brand drove in the decid ing run with a basesloaded single in the ninth inning to night as the Montreal Expos downed the Houston Astros, 32.

title: Pedestrians Have Replaced Traffic In Jams on the Via Frattina in Rome
description: ROME, April 17  There are people jams every after noon in the Via Frattina, the latest addition to a grow ing archipelago of what Ital ians call pedestrian islands in this increasingly congest ed capital.

title: The Criminal Court In Brooklyn to Get Site for New Home
description: In an exchange of courthouse sites, the City Planning Com mission has approved capital budget funds for the planning of a new Criminal and Surro gates Court building in down town Brooklyn.

title: Flipping Over Follies
description: NEITHER Clive Barnes nor Walter Kerr liked Follies and they are this newspaper's drama critics. I am not about to say that they were wrong, and right and wrong, rave and pan are the least of theater criticism anyway. I do believe, though, that every artwork is either good or it isn't, and I am convinced that Follies is monumental theater. Not because I say so but because it is there for anybody to see. Moreover, its im portance as a kind of theater transcends its interest as an example of a musical. I mean to notice this in The New York Times because if this truly great work is not recognized in these pages, then a part of reality will have gone unre corded there.

title: The Nation
description: ATLANTAFor many white Southerners last week, the news of the Supreme Court's ruling in a North Carolina school case evoked a Yossarianlike reaction, heavy with disbelief that the nine Justices in Washington had once again raised the ante in the school desegregation battle.

title: Bridge Lead My Suit!  Sometimes
description: IN bygone years a player defending notrump who failed to lead the highest card of his partner's bid suit would be suspected of crass in competence or mental decay. Both branches of this maxim have with ered with the passage of time. If the highest card is an unsupported honor and the suit has more than two cards the honor should not be led  you would lead low from Q x x whether your partner has bid the suit or not. And there are many situations in which partner's suit should not be led at all.

title: RUTGERS TO OFFER STUDENT SPEEDUP
description: NEWARK, April 24Rutgers University's Newark College of Arts and Sciences will intro duce and advanced placement program this fall, enabling ac ademically gifted high school students to enroll as fulltime or parttime students In accredited college courses after complet ing their junior year.

title: The Nation
description: Pollution Protest: For the Real Story, Look Beyond Earth Week

title: Barrios Wins Madrid Open By 2 Strokes on 73 for 285
description: MADRID, April 24 (UPI) Valentin Barrios of Spain won the Madrid open golf tourna ment today with a oneoverpar 73 over the 6,900yard Puerta de Hierro course for a 72hole total of 285.

title: Son to the Sultans
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., April 24A son was born to. Dr. and Mrs. Burton S. Sul tan last Saturday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. Mrs. Sul tan is the former Miss Mari lyn T. Ringel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ringel of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The child, whose father is an ophthalmologist, is named Peter Glenn.

title: City Wary on Summer Power Outlook
description: The city probably will have enough electrical power to get through the summerif Con solidated Edison's Big Allis generator worksMayor Lind say's utilities committee re ported yesterday.

title: Distaff Skipper of 71 Is Still Making Waves
description: MIAMIIn a flashback to the days when a much younger Gar Wood used to zoom up and down Miami Beach's Indian Creek in his hot raceboats, challenging wouldbe opponents in his top hat, coat and tails, beautiful Biscayne Bay has become the habitat of a fly ing yellow boat with another amazing skipper.

title: Lord Hussar, Bold Statement Win Stakes Divisions at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, April 24Lord Hussar qualified for a shot at the $150,000 Preakness on May 15 and Bold Statement, bene fitting from a great ride by Bill Hartack, shared honors today at Pimlico race course as each won a division of the Wood lawn Stakes for 3year olds.

title: Muskie Declares Mitchell Distorted Wiretap Remarks
description: 0HAHA, April 24 (UPI) Senator Edmund 5. Muskie criticized Attorney General John N. Mitchell today for distort ing remarks the Senator made in the controversy over alleged wiretapping by the Federal Bu reau of Investigation.

title: Long Bus. strike Upsets Mill Basin Life
description: The 15,000 reiden a will Basin in Brooklyn Will enter their ninth week with out bus service tomorrow as state mediators try to settle the labor dispute.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: To the Financial Editor: Back in the nineteenthir ties, when the Senate Sub committee on Banking and Currency disinterred quite a few smelly skeletons from the corporate closet, the era of the stockholders' deriva tive action commenced.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SmallBoat Rentals Mushroom in Florida Keys
description: SmallBoat Rentals Mushroom in Florida Keys.

title: Meat Inspection Programs In 2 More States Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Apri1,24 (AP) Meat inspection programs in Texas and West Virginia have been certified as at least equal to Federal standards, raising the approved list now to 44 states, the Agriculture Depart ment has announced.

title: ...Here, Men Leave Operator Job to the Women
description: There may be men working as telephone operators the West Coast, but in New York, the girls at the switch board still form an exclusively female sorority with immediate prospects for coeducation in sight.

title: Younger Marriages Are Urged In Russia to Raise Birth Rate
description: MOSCOW, April 24  While the Chinese are postponing marriage to control the popula tion level, the Russians were bluntly told this week to marry at an earlier age to produce more children. Bachelors were denounced for not doing their part.

title: The Economics of Altiminuni
description: John D. Harper, chairman and chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America, remarked in Pitts burgh the other day, I sym pathize completely with man who's been affected by a plant closing, but there's really nothing you can say to him that helps. The econom ics are the economics.

title: State Budget Cuts to Close 89YearOld Fish Hatchery
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., April 24The state fish hatchery in this bucolic North Shore villagea major tour ist attraction, breeding ground and research center for 89 years is scheduled to be closed because of budget cuts by the State Legislature.

title: Tourists Give the Admiral The Fits
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica Rear Admiral David F. Welch, the gruff and blunt command er of the United States naval station here at the bottom of the world, doesn't like touristsat least, not those who have the gall (or spirit of adven ture, depending on how you see it) to want to visit this aweinspiring conti nent the size of Mexico and the United States combined. It got to the point last summerthe Antarctic summer has just ended and winter darkness has descend ed until Augustthat the admiral was quoted in a New Zealand newspaper headline as having said: Tourists give me fits.

title: Janet La Gattuta Plans L. I. Marriage June 6
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., April 24Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam La Gattuta have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Nancy La Gattuta, to Wil liam Daniel Himes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Himes Jr. of Hanover, Pa. The wedding is planned for June 6 at the. Community Church of East Williston.

title: Wig Sale Aids Red Cross
description: HARRISBURG, ILL., April 24 (UPI)The 1971 Saline County Red Cross fund drive has gone over the top by a hair. The drive, with a goal of $8,000, reached a total of $8,320, of which $3,970 came from sale of 1,000 wigs by the Bank of Harrisburg.

title: Little Progress in Cleaning Up the Air
description: WASHINGTONThe elec tric power industry, under attack for years because of its rates, is now being hit on another flank, this time over air pollution.

title: Daniel Adams to Marry Miss Anderson
description: MORRISVILLE, Pa., April 24  Mrs. Harry Cooper Anderson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kathyrn Arlene Ander son, to Daniel Drysdale Adams. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Allan K. Adams of Rose Lake, Minn., and Lake Placid, Fla, A wedding in June is planned.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  This is the first demonstration I've ever been to, but I told myself I'd been swearing at the TV set long enough.

title: Mrs. Deyo Married To G.H. McNeely Jr.
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Lyle Deyo of Montclair, N, J., and George Hummel McNeely Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa., and Lake Placid, N. Y., were married here yesterday afternoon by the Rev. William H. Hudnut, acting pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Helm. A reception was given at the Colony Club.

title: SILVESTER IS VICTOR IN DISCUS ON COAST
description: WALNUT, Calif., April 24 (AP) Jay Silvester used a stiff wind to his advantage in the discus while Arne Kvalheim of Norway won the 5,000meter race in the top performances today at the Mount San An tonio Relays.

title: Fun Vehicles Are Cousins to Boats
description: Sail and power boats have a new cousinthe offthe road fun vehicle. Boat manufacturers are building them, boat dealers are sell ing them and people are buying them.

title: Exhibition of Crafts
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 24An exhibition of fine crafts by the Long Island Craftsmen's Guild will open here tomorrow At 3 P.M. and run through May 9 at the Nassau Community College Firehouse Gallery. The hours are 1 to 5 P.M. daily, ex cept from 7 to 9 P.M. on Thurs days. Admission is free.

title: Eleanor Wear and Edward Rose Wed
description: Miss Eleanor Rodda Wear, a teacher of the third grade at the Buckley School, was married yesterday to Edward Douglas Rose, head of Buck ley's history department. The Rev. Dr. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyte rian Church.

title: The World
description: TIENTSINLittle old Mrs. Wu Fungming tells how miserable life was in pre Communist times and how satisfying it is today. . . . Directors of a factory that has been nationally public ized as a model describe how workers, technicians and cadres form a threeinone combination to make im proved new machinery . . .

title: Delivery of a Times Edition Delayed by Union Dispute
description: A work stoppage by members of the Newspaper and Mail De liverers Union yesterday inter rupted normal delivery of the early editions of the Sunday New York Times to Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Padres End Losing Streak
description: ATLANTA, April 24 (AP)  Clarence Gaston tripled in the eighth inning and scored on Ollie Brown's infield single as the San Diego Padres snapped an eightgame losing streak with a 32 victory over the At lanta Braves tonight.

title: Ten sons and daughters who expressed what their parents repressed
description: One consequence of postwar tech nology has been the acceleration of change in our society, so that we seem to produce a new generation about every five years. J. Anthony Lukas's book about the generation that came to first maturity in the middle and late sixties is both freshly new and already historic. Of the 10 biographies which are the body of the book, Jerry Rubin is the oldest subject, I believe, and probably the least typical.

title: Floating Snack Bar to Be Commissioned Soon
description: Going into commission in its home port on Travers Is land Creek off Long Island Sound is the craft Snack Bar, length 50 feet, beam 20, draft 25 inches.

title: FAST FELLOW SNAPS COAST STAKES MARK
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 24 (UPI)Fast Fellow set a stakes record and raced to a victory of 5, lengths today in the $50,000 second division of the Will Rogers Stakes for 3year olds on the turf at Hollywood Park.

title: Canadian Native Named Chief Chaplain of Army
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)  Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird has an nounced the appointment of Brig. Gen. Gerhardt W. Hyatt as Chief Chaplain of the Army.

title: Ceylon's Police and Army Fight Rebels With Terror
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 24 Ceylon's outnumbered and unprepared police force and army have resorted to mass ar rests, torture, executions and other terror tactics in attempt ing to put down young, well organized armed insurgents who attacked more than 100 police posts three weeks ago and continue to hold dozens of villages and sizable portions of the countryside.

title: SUMMER SESSIONS ABROAD July/Aug 8293. Sec ad Travel Section 10, page 28. Edue'l Travel Assn, 533 5th Ave, NYadvl,
BUSINESS LETTER
description: It's annual meeting time again, but they don't seem to make them the way they used to. It's enough to make one wonder if anyone really cares.

title: Brooklyn Botanic Garden Benefit Set
description: The Brooklyn Botanic Gar den's annual benefit plant sale, which opens a twoday run May 5, will be bigger and more varied than ever before, with everything from marigolds and potted plants for children costing 25 cents to delicate Japanese Bonsai arrangements with a price tag of $250.

title: REUSS OF CARDS BEATS MILS, 50
description: ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP) Gerry McNertney's first Na tional League home run and Jerry Reuss's sixhit pitching paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 50 victory over the Phila delphia Phillies tonight.

title: Italian Racer Injured
description: MONZA, Italy, April 24 (AP) Alfa Romeo, trying to halt the Porsche dominance in car racing, lost its top driver today for the Monza 1,000kilometer race tomorrow. Nanni Galli of Italy, who had the fourth best time in Friday's trials, suffered a separated shoulder when his car went out of control during trials on a rainsoaked course today.

title: Law
description: We live in a nation that prides itself on championing the principle that a man is innocent, and free to pursue his normal life, until his guilt is proven. As Justice Robert Jackson once put it: Imprisonment to protect society from predicted but un consummated offenses is ...un precedented in this country and . . . fraught with danger of ex cess and injustice...,.

title: A Funny Man for This Season
description: DAVID STEINBERG! Hey, you're lookin terrific, David. We're gonna move up your career two notches while you're standing there.

title: SOVIET PROTESTS HARASSMENT HERE
description: MOSCOW, April 24The So viet Union delivered a protest to the United States today over continuing attacks against So viet offices in New York.

title: BEST LAID PLANS . .
description: TWOANDAHALFYEAROLD Laura handed my 6monthold John her well  cuddled teddy bear. Ws wonderful that she shares her toys so nicely, I said to her mother, Jill.

title: PENSION RISE SEEN FOR THE AFFLUENT
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 Social Security retirement ben efits for the nation's middle income and upper  income groups would be sharply im proved under the new Social Security bill, which is nearing final approval in the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Letters:
description: That the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is a kookamong other undesirable things  seemed to be the attitude taken by Ezra Millstein in his Search for the Perfect Guru in India (Travel section, April 4). The article showed no under standing of the subject. have read all the Maharishi's books and was initiated into transcendental meditation at his Spiritual Regeneration Movement center In New York about four years ago. I spent three weeks last January at his ashram, or meditation compound, in Rishikesh, listening to tapes of all his lectures and courses and taking part daily in the meditation.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
2 English Setters Capture Long Island Field Trials
description: SOUTH HAVEN, L.I., April 24 The first field trial in the United States was held a cen tury ago at Memphis, Tenn., when some sportsmen, arguing, over the merits of their dogs, decided to hold a contest. The winner was Knight, an English setter.

title: A Swedish canal That Goes Climbing Over Mountains
description: MOUNTAIN GOAT BOATSThe Wilhelm Tham, one of a fleet of three Gota Canal boats, sails right through the middle of Sweden between Goteborg and Stockholm dur ing the summer months. Some of the canal's 65 locks, built a century ago, are barely large enough for the boats and many of the wooden gates are still manually operated.

title: Brooklyn Truckway Proposal Draws Wide Opposition
description: Governor Rockefeller's pro posal to expand the Belt Park way into a 10lane highway with a stretch of four lanes to be used by trucks is being opposed by Borough President Sebastian Leone, 23 of Brook lyn's state legislators and a number of civic groups. They contend that the expansion would create a wasteland of bordering neighborhoods and endanger wildlife in the Ja maica Bay Refuge.

title: Dachshunds Can Earn Points In Yankee Trial Next Sunday
description: News of Dogs

title: Staten Island Club Wins
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., April 24 The Staten Island Cricket Club beat Haverford College by 102 runs today. The scores were 159 for four wickets declared for the victors to Haverfordi College's 57.

title: U.N. GETS APPEAL FOR COMPUTER AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24A United Nations panel of experts has asked for special aid to emerging countries to give them the full benefit of modern computer techniques in developing their economies.

title: REFUGEES WORRY INDIAN OFFICIALS
description: CALCUTTA, India, April 24  Several hundred thousand refugees fleeing the Pakistan Army have poured into India from East Pakistan, and Indian officials are expressing increas ing concern that they may soon become a serious disrup tive influence.

title: East Germany Soccer Victor
description: GERA, East Germany, April 24 (Reuters)East Germany scored a 2.1 victory over Lux embourg in their group seven European soccer championship game today. The Germans led, 10, at halftime. In a group two game at Budapest, Hungary and France tied, 11.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Foster Beats Anderson, Keeps LightHeavyweight Title
description: TAMPA, Fla., UPI)Bob Fos ter, extended to the full 15 rounds for the first time in his career, retained his world light weight boxing title with a un unanimous decision over Ray Anderson tonight.

title: Rangers, Ahead in Series, 21, Meet Hawks Today at Garden
description: The message Walt Tkaczuk will chalk on the Ranger lock erroom blackboard today will be simple: It's a 2of4 series.

title: Area Delegates to Go To Arizona Meeting
description: The United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, District 3, will be well represented at the organization's national spring conference in Scotts dale, Ariz., next Wednesday through Saturday.

title: Albany Asked to Liberalize Law on Prescription Drugs
description: Health Services Administra tor Gordon Chase has urged passage of three bills that he said yesterday would allow con sumers to save money by com parison shopping for prescrip tion drugs. The three bills are now before the State Legisla ture.

title: Art
description: THERE is a certain vir tue, I believe, in an art ist's pushing his style or technique to its log ical conclusion: everyone wants to know what lies at the end of a road. The dan ger, of course, is that he may eventually find himself at a dead end. The sculptures of Larry Bell, the 32yearold California artist, which are now on display at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, seem to be approaching that ultimate stage.

title: Announcements
description: Engagements

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: John Westergaard, the se riousminded young man who is president of Equity Re search Associates, was mus ing last week about the suc cess of Levi Strauss & Co., the bluejeans maker whose stock has been one of the hotter new issues in the mar ket this year. It came out at $47 a share on March 3, quickly bounded, up to $60 and has been hovering near that level in recent weeks.

title: The Terrifying Homosexual World of the Jail System
description: It's definitely a homosexual world, said a man whose years as a prison inmate qualify him to speak with authority.

title: The Spencer family falls apart
description: Art, Picasso tells us, is a lie that leads to the truth. This paradox is especially true in painting, where a purely represented reality would not have enough interest to draw the viewer's eye to the discovery of a hidden or difficult truth. In litera ture, the elegant or outrageous lie might not seem so necessary; but, without it, the reader skims rapidly over familiar landscapes, ignoring or never confronting the truth of the ordinary. We are occasionally out raped by certain of our contempo rariesMailer, Dickey, Roth come to mindwho take great risks, impro vise worlds of their own and argue us into accepting them, but we are always stimulated by and involved with these writers. The fiction of lesser, safer, more reasonable and per haps more civilized writers may pass by unnoticed because it does not with

title: PEACE CORPS ROLE ENDING IN PANAMA
description: PANAMA, April 24 (UPI) Panama is the first Latin American nation to terminate its agreement with the United States Peace Corps.

title: Many Rank City With Worst Slumlords
description: The City of New York is gaining a reputation in slum communities and among some of its own housing officials as a careless, indifferent landlord worse than profiteering slum lords.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Ronnie Haigler was saying, Playing basketball is not reality. People do things for the player they wouldn't do for others. He is not prepared to come down to earth. When he leaves some jive college he never should have gone to in the first place, no degree, no more dream playing pro ball, what's he got? Drugs, maybe. It's all part of this fanatical emphasis on winning. Ridiculous.

title: Anthony Davis, Suzanne Gould Wed in Suburbs
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 25In Temple Israel here this afternoon, Miss Suzanne Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence R. Gould, was married to An thony Edward Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Davis of Wallington, England. Rabbi Jacob K. Shankrnan per formed the ceremony.

title: Walter Marvin, Broker, Is Dead; ExPartner in Hemphill, Noyes
description: Walter Sands Marvin, a stock broker and former newspaper man who had been active in developing commercial aviation and in promoting the arts, died Saturday at ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street and in Quogue, L. I.

title: City TV and Radio Stations Cutting Staffs and Time
description: The city's radio and tele vision facilities have been or dered to cut their operating hours to the minimum time al lowable under their licenses from the Federal Communica tions Commission. The reduc tion will take effect Saturday after the dismissal of 55 em ployes Friday night in the municipal budget crisis.

title: Wilson of Britain to Speak At Labor Symposium Here
description: Harold Wilson, former Prime Minister of Britain, is scheduled to be the featured speaker at an international symposium on publicemployment labor rela tions in the New York Hilton May 3 to 5.

title: Teamsters Approve Terms With Movers; Rates to Be Raised
description: Union teamsters ratified new threeyear contracts yesterday with 350 moving and storage companies, thus ending a 25 day strike that had drastically cut moving in the downstate area. Normal service is expected to resume today.

title: NEW CRITERIA SET ON RETREAD TIRES
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 After more than three years of deliberation, the Federal Gov ernment has issued a safety standard requiring retreaded tires for passenger cars to meet the same performance criteria as new tires.

title: ZINK AND MISS PAIGE WIN SKATING TITLES
description: A pair of rallying victories marked the Middle Atlantic figure skating championships that ended yesterday at the Abe Stark Rink in Coney Island, Brooklyn.

title: Matches Are Blamed
description: CLEVELAND. Apri10.25 (AP) Three children died early today in a fire in East Cleveland. Firemen said it had been started by two other children playing with matches.

title: Stage: Musical Resuscitation of Frank Merriwell
description: George Jean Nathan  no mean critic, or at least no meaner than most  in The American Mercury for Sep tember, 1925, at least I think it was September, offered his opinion that Burt L. Standish, the pseudonymous author of Frank Merriwell, was one of America's most peculiarly eminent practitioners of the art of fiction. His curious song deserves to by sung.

title: Tkaczuk and Rangers' Pride Are Bruised
description: Walt Tkaczuk, the New York Rangers' leading scorer the last two seasons, was ordered into Lenox Hill Hospital last night with what the 23yearold cen ter described as just a bruise, that's all in the calf of his right leg.

title: Businessmen Are Held Less Prone to Mental Illness
description: LONDON  Senior business executives, in spite of the well publicized stress and strain of their lives, are less likely to become mentally ill than those lowe, down the social scale, ac cording to a consultant psychiatrist.

title: Du Pont Co. to Hire 200
description: The Du Pont Company an nounced last night that because of continued improvement in the demand for nylon, Dacron polyester and Qiana nylon, it would hire 200 production workers at its Chattanooga, Tenn., plant between now and June 7.

title: RICKEY CAPTURES RIVER OAKS FINAL
description: HOUSTON, April 25 (UPI) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., played one of his best matches today as he crushed Clark Graebner of New York, 62, 61, 62, in the final ofl the $25,000 River Oaks tennis tournament before a capacity crowd of 2,200.

title: Rosewall Beats Drysdale
description: DENVER, April 25 (AP) Australia's Ken Rosewall used pinpoint placements to defeat Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 62, 62, in the final of the Unit ed Bank invitation professional tennis tournament today.

title: GERMAN KIDNAPPING OF TEACHER A HOAX
description: BONN, April 25 (UPI)A professor of history admitted, today that he pretended to have been kidnapped by leftwing activists in hopes of preventing a Social Democratic victory in a West German state election this weekend.

title: STUTTGART DANCES ROMEO AND JULIET
description: Brawling and lovemaking are the twin activities of Romeo and Juliet's Verona, and the Stuttgart Ballet's as well. Romeo encompasses both in his course, but Juliet's brother Tyb alt seems singlemindedly dedi cated to fighting. Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, Heinz Claus danced the part of Romeo and Jiri Kylian assumed the role of Tybalt, both for the first time this season.

title: PAKISTAN ALTERS IMPORTING POLICY
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 25The Pakistani Government, in a communique released late yesterday, banned the import ing of 46 kinds of goods ranging from razor blades to refriger ators.

title: Bucks Top Bullets, 10283, To Gain 20 Lead in Series
description: BALTIMORE, April 25  A, 3016 third quarter gave the Milwaukee Bucks control of the game and the series today as they whipped the Baltimore Bullets, 10283, for a 2.0 lead in the fourofsevengame play off for the championship of the National Basketball Associa tion.

title: Johnny Pot Drops Star
description: A spokesman for the man agement of The Ballad of Johnny Pot, the musical that opens tonight at Theater Four, reported yesterday that David Carradine, who was to star in the title role, has had to be let go by the management be cause of artistic differences over the interpretation of the role, John Bennett Perry, Mr. Carradine's understudy, will take over.

title: Fire Razes Jersey Beach Club
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 25Fire destroyed the Mont( Carlo Pool and Beach Club!. here today, hastening the de mise of the blocksquare recrea tional complex, which was a. focal point for countless thous ands of summer visitors. The club, which faced the board; walk, was scheduled for demo lition to make way for a 23. story luxury apartment building.

title: Antimerger Bill Planned
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House Judi ciary Committee, said today he planned to introduce legislation to prohibit the nation's 500 largest industrial corporations from merging with each other or with any smaller company with assets of $100,000 or more. This would go far be yond the Nixon Administration policy of scrutinizing mergers between the tap 200 largest concerns as listed in the For tune magazine index annually.

title: How to Live NonJim Crow
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C.When a col league of mine at South Carolina State College told me that she and her hus band had attended the inaugural ball of the new Governor of South Carolina on Jan. 19, 1971, she commented with a trace of bitterness on the fact that ten or fifteen years ago blacks not only would not have been invited, but alsoif invitedwould not have been admitted had they gone.

title: Colombia Quells Uprising by Students
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 25 The Colombian Government has put down a series of stu dent uprisings that crackled across the country like a string of firecrackers by closing five universities in the last week and occupying some campuses with soldiers and police.

title: Five Killed in C47 Crash At Airport in Wyoming
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 25 (AP)Five Air Force men were killed tonight when their C47 twinengine transport crashed and burned behind a row of homes at Cheyenne Municipal Airport. The plane was at tempting to land in a light driz zle.

title: President Jonas of Austria Is Reelected
description: VIENNA, April 25Austria's federal President, Franz Jonas, was reelected today in a na tional vote for another sixyear term.forming a government and to accept or refuse the resignation of a cabinet.

title: Let WNYC Live
description: It is hard to imagine New York City without WNYC. The municipal radio station has been broadcasting since 1924; it is one of the least of the city's frills. With an operating cost annually of $500,000, WNYCAM and FM brings news of the city and hearings of its agencies, sessions of the United Nations and reviews of the world press, Shakespeare's plays and Gilbert and Sullivan operettas and, most important, a daily aural feast classical music.

title: SURCHARGE GETS BE BOARD BACKING
description: The New York Stock Ex change has gone to bat to defend the $15 commission surcharge on stock transactions that has been in effect for more than a year to provide rate relief for member firms.

title: Meeting Explores History From Psychologist's View
description: If I don't open my mouth they may take it for the wis dom of age, mused Erik H. Erikson, the grand old man of psychobiography.

title: New Head of School Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Paul B. Salmon, 51 years old, was named today to head the American. Association of School Administrators. Mr. Salmon is Superintendent of Schools in Sacramento, Calif. He will suc ceed Forrest E. Conner, who will retire July 1.

title: Massive Computerized Study of the Arts Is Begun
description: The most comprehensive survey and analysis ever at tempted of America's non profit performing arts is be ing undertaken by the Ford Foundation.

title: T.V. Soong Is Dead at 77 ; Aide of Nationalist China
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Apriri24 (AP)T.V. Soong, long an of ficial of the Chinese National ist government, died here to night. He was 77 years old.

title: MRS. LEO YARROW, 50, LED NATURE WALKS
description: Mrs. Eleanor Wolman Yar row, a musician who became botanist, died yesterday in Doc tors Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived at 2750 Olinville Avenue, the Bronx.

title: A Woman Who's Learning To Drive Her Own Truck.
description: When Emmie Peek becomes a queen of the road next month, she will have to deal with loneliness, boredom and the fear of jackknifing her tractortrailer rig. But what she worries about most are women drivers.

title: 3Way Fight to Succeed Rep. Rivers to Be Decided Tomorrow
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., April 25The voters of South Caro lina's First Congressional Dis trict will choose a successor Tuesday to the late L. Mendel Rivers, after a campaign that has served to reinforce the leg ends concerning Mr. Rivers's political power.

title: Helen Hayes in Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Helen Hayes is in a hos pital for treatment of a respir atory infection. A spokesman for Providence Hospital said she was admitted yesterday.

title: St. Patrick's Rings to the Drums and Voice of AfricanLatin Mass
description: The beat of African drums sounded in St. Patrick's Ca thedral yesterday afternoon in an orchestral and choral per formance of a new African setting for the Latin mass.

title: Two Subway Holdup Suspects Are Shot by Hidden Policemen
description: Two Transit Authority police men staked out in a porter's room of a Brooklyn subway station yesterday afternoon, shot two holdup suspectsone criticallyafter hearing a de mand for money over a speaker hooked up to the change booth.

title: Zhivkov Renamed as Head Of Communists in Bulgaria
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 25 (AP)  The Bulgarian Commu nist party leader, Todor Zhiv kov, who has been in office for 17 years, was reelected as first secretary at a Central Com mittee meeting today that con cluded the 10th party congress.

title: Doberman Pinscher Rated Best At Baltimore Kennel Club Show
description: TIMONIUM, Md., April 25 Mr. and. Mrs. George West's 4 yearl.old doberman pin scher, Ch. Dolph von Tannen wald, increased his claim as top working dog of 1971 by placing best in show at the Baltimore County Kennel Club today.

title: Super Value Acquisition
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 (AP) Super Value Stores, Inc., of suburban Minneapolis has com pleted the acquisition of ShopKo Stores, Inc., Green Bay, Wis., with the issuance of 305,465 shares of Super Value common stock valued at nearly $10.5 million.

title: Newark Airport Head Will Retire Saturday
description: Vincent A Carson, the only man ever to, manage all three of New York's major airports, will retire next Saturday as general manager of Newark Airport, where his colorful ca reer began 35 years ago.

title: KID ORY SITS IN FOR AN OLD PAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 25 What had been planned as the climactic program of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Fes tival, a tribute to Louis Arm strong, lost some of its sparkle last night when Mr. Armstrong was not able to make the trip back to his hometown. The famous jazz trumpeter is in Beth Israel Hospital in New York recuperating from a heart ailment.

title: JOURNALISM AWARDS WON BY 5 MAGAZINES
description: The 1971 National Magazinel Awards, sponsored by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, have been won by The Nation, Rolling Stone, Vogue, Esquire and The At lantic Monthly.

title: Six Vietnam Veterans, on TV Charge That U.S. Betrayed Them
description: Six veterans of the Vietnam war, in a frank, freewheeling television discussion last night, accused the United States Gov ernment of having betrayed them and agreed that the Southeast Asia conflict was a racial war.

title: Barges Promise City More Electric Power
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. More power for New York City this summer 624,000 kilowatts in all is being readied in the famed ship building yards here.

title: Calley Clemency Opposed
description: BOSTON, April 25 (AP) The Advocates, a public af fairs program of the Public Broadcasting System, reported today that viewers responding to a program on First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., had voted overwhelmingly against grant ing him clemency. 85 per cent of the letters responding to a telecast April 13 had opposed clemency to Lieutenant Calley, convicted of murdering civil ians at My Lai in South Viet nam.

title: Carolyn Knapp Bride of Thomas Cullins
description: NORTH FERRISBURG, Vt., April 25  Miss Carolyn Glines Knapp, a social work er, was married here this noon to Thomas Van Schaick Cullins, an architect with Burlington Associates. The Rev. William Hollister of Christ Church Presbyterian of South Burlington per formed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam H. Schubart, friends of the couple.

title: The Theater: A Flavorful She Stoops to Conquer
Maine Sugar Industries Settles Rife With Growers
description: The Finger Lakes Sugar Beet Growers Association has dropped all bankruptcy pro ceedings against Maine Sugar Industries, it was announced over the weekend by James Garlick, president of the asso ciation and Fred H. Vahlsing Jr., president of Maine Sugar of Montezuma, Inc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am home on leave from Vietnam and I have read Burke Marshall's Op Ed article, We Must End the War (April 10.) As a responsible officer of the United States Army in Vietnam, should like to comment on this article from firsthand knowledge.

title: Threat to Economic Integration
description: PARISConfidence is suspicion asleep, said Benjamin Disraeli. After a remarkably quiet year in the inter national money markets, suspicion about the dollar has been reawakened by huge deficits in the American bal ance of payments. The United States ran a deficit of $10.7 billion to foreign central banks last year. During 1971's first quarter the deficitas estimated by the Morgan Guaranty Bank totaled $5 billion, a $20billion annual rate.

title: Haute Cuisine That's Organic
description: The Leopard, an East Side restaurant specializing in haute cuisine, will offer dishes made from organic ingredients starting this week.

title: 58 Left Homeless in Bronx By Fire in Two Tenements
description: A threealarm fire in two Bronx tenements, at 3911 and 3909 Third Avenue, left one occupant and two firemen in jured, and 58 persons homeless yesterday.

title: Rogers Due in Cairo May 4
description: CAIRO, April 25It was an nounced here today that Secretary Rogers would arrive in Cairo on May 4 for two days of talks during his tour of Middle Eastern capitals.

title: U.C.L.A. Volleyball Victor
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP) The University of California, Los Angeles, successfully de fended its national collegiate volleyball championship last night by taking three straight games from the University of California, Santa Barbara, 156, 1715, 1715.
