description: To the Editor:

title: Many Copter Pilots Eager for Combat
description: FORT. RUCKER, Ala.Capt, William Villaire, an Army heli copter pilot with a. tour in Viet nam behind him, takes a hard. bitten attitude toward military realities.

title: MRS. WALTER FLORY, ARTIST AND WRITER
description: CLEVELAND, April 25Mrs. Julia McCune Flory, painter, il lustrator and author and founder of the Cleveland Play house, died yesterday at her home in Shaker Heights. She was 89 years old, the widow of Walter L. Flory, a lawyer.

title: FOUR MET ERRORS LET CUBS CAPTURE 2D STRAIGHT, 93
description: CHICAGO, April 25  The New York Mets, who are hav ing a long April, committed four errors today and lost their second game in a row to, the Chicago Cubs, 93.

title: Chess:
description: A powerhouse of a tourna ment was the recent 16man Tallinn International, in Es tonia, in which Paul Xeres, one of the greats, shared first prize with a former world champion, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union. Each posted an 113 score.

title: BENNETT ELLEFSON, RESEARCH SCIENTIST
description: Dr. Bennett S. Ellefson, since 1960 vice president of General Telephone and Electronics Lab oratories, Inc., died Saturday night at his home, 21404 33d Road, Bayside, Queens. He was 60 years old.

title: Israeli Investment Flow Grows
description: Israel continues to attract foreign capital at a record pace despite the political situation in the Near East, Yeshapahu Stop per, director of Israel's Invest ment Authority, said here last week.

title: Mild Tremor in Los Angeles
description: SAN FERNANDO, Calif., April 25 (UPI)A Mild tremor, an aftershock of the big earth quake of Feb. 9, rolled through the Los Angeles basin this morning, awakening some people but causing no reported damage. The temblor, felt at 7:50 A.M., measured 3.8 on the Richter scale. The February quake measured 6.6 and caused 64 deaths.

title: Ronan View on Fares Awaited by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay said last night he expected a statement on the subway fare to be is sued later this week by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority.

title: Music: 2 Cultures Blend
description: The folk mass that had its world premiere yesterday St. Patrick's Cathedral could claim more authenticity than most of its genre. The Royal Mass of Mogho, composed the Rev. Rene Guirma, though it used the ancient Roman Catholic Latin text, was rooted in the songs and culture the West African people of Upper Volta, who trace their musical tradition back more than 3,000 years.

title: Vote of the Week In the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 Following are the votes of dele gates from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: All Sides Applaud Peaceful Protest in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, April 25  The organizers of yesterday's antiwar demonstration and city officials said today, that they were pleased that the massive march and rally had not been accompanied by violence.

description: To the Editor:

title: Conservatives Win in West Germany
description: KIEL, West Germany, April 25The conservative Christian Democrats won a majority to day in the SchleswigHolstein state elections, a victory that weakened, at least indirectly, the position of Chancellor Willy Brandt's SocialLiberal coalition in Bonn.

title: Film: Eric Rohmer's 'Collectionneuse'
description: Eric Rohmer's "La Collectionneuse," which opened yesterday at the 72d Street Playhouse, is, in terms of actual chronology, the third film that Rohmer made in his projected cycle of Six Moral Tales, all variations on the theme of the man who, in love with one woman, is momentarily attracted to another."La Collectionneuse" was made in 1967, before "My Night at Maud's" (which was supposed to be produced before "La Collectionneuse" but was delayed because Jean-Louis Trintignant was not available), and before "Claire's Knee." Although it is an early work, it has the appearance of a late work, almost of a last work, as if the manners, attitudes and interests of "My Night at Maud's" and "Claire's Knee" had been worn out, leaving the exhausted shell of parody.The film, of course, is neither a last work nor a parody, but a kind of overture to the two superb movies that were to follow it. However, because most of the criticism that was wrongly directed at "Maud" and "Claire" can be somewhat more rightly applied to "La Collectionneuse," I can recommend it only to those moviegoers who are already convinced (as I am) that Rohmer is one of the most original and independent directors at work today. For the uninitiated, it will be a lovely, arid bore.The time is (once again) summer, and the setting is the south of France, a vacation villa near Saint-Tropez inhabited by Adrien (Patrick Bauchau), the film's narrator, a handsome esthete who works occasionally as an antiques dealer but who says, more accurately, that his life is his work; Daniel (Daniel Pommereulle), a painter who doesn't paint, and Hayde Hayde Politoff), a magnificently constructed young woman who sleeps around the neighborhood with an instructive, careless ease that's most disturbing to the elevated sensibilities of the two men.Adrien and Daniel tease and ridicule Hayde and nickname her "the collector." Adrien, whose mistress is spending the summer in London, is at first simply annoyed by Hayde's sexual presence, since she makes it difficult for him to concentrate on his vacation schedule of doing nothing well. Hayde, however, is not easily ignored, and when Daniel begins a lethargic affair with her, Adrien's defenses are such that he interprets it as part of her scheme to seduce him.Adrien is very much the early prototype for Jean-Louis of "My Night at Maud's" and Jerome of "Claire's Knee," an intellectual with an almost obsessive distrust of idle passion, as if idle passion equals disorder, chaos and the collapse of civilization, and is, therefore, the ultimate immorality. Like Jean-Louis, Adrien is drawn, against his will, toward this other woman. This time, however, it's a very minor skirmish. His triumph  through a fortuitous accident that allows him to exercise his free choiceis of almost indecently limited application.Much of the comedy in "La Collectionneuse," as in Rohmer's later films, is provided by the otherwise aware hero's elegant self-deceptions about his own motives, followed by his dimly seen perceptions of what could be another truth. In this context, it is a momentous event (and, comparatively speaking, momentously funny) when Adrien begins to have doubts about the affair of Hayde and Daniel. "I couldn't be sure," he tells himself with complete seriousness, "that their complicity was entirely for my benefit."Almost everything in "La Collectionneuse" is of a slightly more gross and less interesting order than in "My Night at Maud's" and "Claire's Knee." Everything, that is, except Nestor Almendros's camerawork, which is as susual, beautiful. It's as if the film were a kind of living notebook for what Rohmer was to do later, with greater ease and refinement. It's no mere coincidence that in his last film Rohmer was able to say about all he had to say with Claire's right knee, but when he introduces Hayde, in a bikini, his camera has to make a complete inventory of herthigh, small of the back, arm, nape of the neck, and both knees.There is a certain chilliness and lack of spontaneity to all of the performances, especially Bauchau's, which, I suspect, has as much to do with the tiny scope of the film as to the actor's talents. "My Night at Maud's" and "Claire's Knee" suggest living worlds outside the films' rarefied milieus, whereas "La Collectionneuse" exists in splendid, arrogant isolation. Adrien is tiresome. Daniel is enigmatic, and Hayde is sweet, and great to look at, but, after a while, sadly commonplace.A note of interest to local film buffs: the Seymour Hertzberg who is listed in the credits (he plays Sam, the American art collector whom Adrien solicits), is the nom d'cran of Eugene Archer, a former New York Times film reviewer who, I'm told, has absolutely no intention of acting again. He is an excellent reviewer.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are going to be traveling this summer by auto, bus, train, plane or ship, you should be giving some thought to the insur ance you haveand maybe don't even know you have and to the coverage you'll need to protect yourself and your family.

title: Rural Blaze in Ohio
description: GALLIPOLIS, Ohio, April 25 (AP)  Five persons died and two were critically injured in a fire that swept a frame home in rural Gallia County today.

title: Record Amount for Armaments Is Budgeted by South Africans
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 25 (AP)  South Africa has budgeted a record amount this year to maintain and mod ernize her armed forces, strong est on the African continent.

title: Heath Frogram Faces Harsh Economic Test
description: LONDON, April 25  When Edward Heath moved into 10 Downing Street last June, to the surprise of nearly everyone but himself, he came with program quite unlike any in re cent British political history.

title: 1,000 War Protesters Block Jersey Turnpike 4 Hours
description: SWEDESBORO, N.J., April 25 All traffic was halted for nearly four hours tonight on a 25mile stretch of the New Jer sey Turnpike by about 1,000 antiwar demonstrators return ing from Washington.

title: State's Attorney in Chicago Appears Before Jury on Panther Raid Today
description: CHICAGO, April 25State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan is to appear tomorrow before special grand jury investigating the 1969 deaths of two Black Panthers in a predawn police raid amid wiedespread reports that the jury has already voted an indictment against him.

title: PREMIERES PLAYED BY YOUTH SYMPHONY
description: The Youth Symphony Or chestra of New. York mixed its media Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall and came up with two world premieres: Eclipse, a suite for rock band and or chestra devised by the four members of bwap, and Opus 31, Miniatures for Synthesizers, Computers and Diverse Instru ments by Paul Conly and Allen Razdow.

title: Increased Protest Expected By Companies at Meetings
description: A number of American com panies expect their annual meetings to become forums for increasingly sophisticated so cial protest, according to a study by the Conference Board, a private economic research or ganization.

title: Five Horses Expected to Clarify Derby Roles in Trial Tomorrow
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 The final stakes event at Churchill Downs before the 97th running of the Kentucky Derby next Saturday will be the Derby Trial. And the expecta tion is that it will help in measure to whittle the large field for the classic.

title: Long's Ondine Keeps Lead In 500Mile Yacht Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 25 (AP)Ondine II, S. A. (Huey) Long's 73foot ketch from Larchmont, N. Y., kept the lead as 17 boats headed for Mexico today in the 500mile St. Petersburg to Isla Mujeres yacht race.

title: Australia Ties Japan, 22, in Davis Cup On Dibley's 5Set Victory
description: TOKYO, April 25 (AP) Colin Dibley kept alive Aus tralia's Davis Cup tennis hopes today with a 63, 64, 57, 3.6, 86 victory over Keishiro Yanagi of Japan, tying their Eastern Zone series at 22.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COPPER KAHN GAINS HORSE SHOW HONORS
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 25 Copper Kahn, a model of con sistency, scored 14 points to win the preliminary jumper championship tonight at the final session of the Boulder Brook horse show.

title: Faculty and Students: Few Squares
description: Who were the students, faculty members and administrative leaders at Old West burywhat were they like?

title: Colon, Kaczorek Victors
description: Tony Colon, an unattached runner from New York, won the 5,000meter event and Charles Kaczorek of the Millrose Athletic Association took the 10,000meter run yesterday in a development meet spon sored by the Road Runners Club of New York at Van Cort landt Park, the Bronx

title: The View From Sofia
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev's decision to visit Bulgaria for the congress of the Bulgarian Communist party is a reminder of the importance the Kremlin attaches to Eastern Europe even at times when the area is relatively calm and away from the world spotlight.

title: At 19, President for Life JeanClaude Duvalier
description: Man in the News

title: MISS HAYNIE'S 219 WINS MIAMI GOLF
description: MIAMI, April 25 (AP)  Sandra Haynie, who lost last year in a suddendeath playoff with Carol Mann, fired a par 74 today for a 54hole total of 219 and a one stroke victory in the Burdines Women's invita tional golf tournament.

title: VERDICT IN LISBON ON CUBAN EXPECTED
description: LISBON, April 25The trial of a Cuban Army captain here this week is regarded as an attempt by Lisbon to prove conclusively its claims of for eign intervention in the guer rilla movement in Portuguese Guinea.

title: Housing Decay Called National Blight
description: A survey of housing aban donment in seven cities con cludes that the phenomenon is national in scope and more severe in St. Louis, Cleveland and Chicago than in New York, where it has received the most publicity.

title: Palermo Warns on Garbage
description: PALERMO, Sicily, April 25 (UPI)City officials asked the Government yesterday to order the army into Palermo to re move 2,500 tons of uncollected garbage. Authorities said they feared the garbage would cause an epidemic. They described the situation as grave and warned that the sixday strike by most of the 3,000man sanitation force could not continue.

title: Bridge : South Africa Player Wins Spero Memorial Trophy Here
description: Many players who have learned their bridge skills in other countries have settled in New York City since World War II, but none has made as much impact on the metro politan scene as a young South African has done re cently. The South African, Stan Turecki, who arrived 20 months ago, not only became the 1970 New York Player of the Year, a title awarded to the most successful tour, nament player, but also be came the first winner of the Richard Spero Memorial Trophy for the best perform ance in a year in team events scored by international match points.

title: Americans Win World Cup
description: NEWTON, Mass., April 25 (AP)Dennis Ralston beat Roy Emerson, 61, 67, 76, and clinched a victory by United States players over Australians in the second annual $30,000 World Cup professional tennis series today. Ralston recovered from 35 in the last set.

title: Nationalist Party Leacler In Indonesia Dies at 59
description: Nationalist Party Leader In Indonesia Dies at 59

title: Stars Down Canadiens, 52, Even Playoffs at 2 Apiece
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 25 (AP)Murray Oliver rammed, in two goals and J. P. Parise scored the tiebreaker to pace the Minnesota North Stars to a 52 triumph over the Montreal Canadiens tonight and tie their, Stanley Cup semifinal playoffs at two games apiece.

title: Rosalie Siegel Is Bride Here
description: The marriage of Miss Ro salie Siegel to Dr. Evan R. Wolarsky took place yester day at the home of Dr. and Mrs. William Wolarsky, par ents of the bridegroom, in Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Edward Schoenfeld performed the ceremony.

title: Child Labor on Farm Has Few Restrictions
description: PONCHATOULA, La., April 25Lenaldo Salinas got up at 5 A.M. the other day to be in Allen Perrin's long, unshaded strawberry fields by dawn.

title: HUNGARIANS VOTE FOR PARLIAMENT
description: BUDAPEST, April 25  The Hungarian Communist regime pursued its program of con trolled reforms today as seven million voters went to the polls in the first general elections in which officially backed can didates stood a chance of los ing.

title: Carol Neblett, in Local Debut, Excels in Marx and Wolf Songs
description: Carol Neblett is known here as one of the brighter stars of the New York City Opera, but opera is not the only thing she knows. She has studied artsong interpre tation with Lotte Lehmann and Pierre Bernac, who really know what it is all about, and it is apparent that she has learned a lot from them.

title: East Side Doorman Slain By Another in Argument
description: A doorman in an apartment house between Park and Lex ington Avenues shot and killed a fellow doorman in the lobby of the building at 133 East 80th Street last night after an argu ment, the police said.

title: Celler Says Wiretapping Policy May Be Leading to Police State
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 UPI)Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that the Attorney General's wiretapping policies might be leading the nation toward a police state.

title: Storm Kills 12 Filipinos
description: MANILA, April 25 (AP)Re ports from islands in the cen tral Philippines said that more than 12 persons were killed and dozens were missing after tropical storm today. Damage to crops and buildings was re ported high, but no overall assessment was available.

title: REA EXPRESS MEN END 7DAY STRIKE
description: Bowing to a court restrain ing order, members of the Rail way and Airline Clerks' Brother hood yesterday ended a nation al strike against REA Express.

title: Hawks Rout Rangers, 71
description: A deadly perfect rebound per formance by the Black Hawks caught the Rangers flatfooted yesterday, and the Chicagoans skated to a 71 rout to even their Stanley Cup semifinal series at two victories apiece.

title: FOREIGN AID SETUP CALLED SHAMBLES BY SENATE GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the present foreign aid program was a shambles and that no amount of mobile maneuvering can save it.

title: BROADENED ROLE URGED FOR N.A.S.D.
description: M. A. Schapiro & Co., a lead ing bank stock dealer, proposed over the weekend that the Na tional Association of Securities Dealers register as a national securities exchange.

title: US. ENVOY FAVORS MORE AID TO HAITI
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, April 25The United States Ambas sador, Clinton E. Knox, today advocated an early increase in American aid to the new Gov ernment of President Jean Claude Duvalier.

title: Joffrey II Dancers Excel in Marcello In Children's Series
description: The City Center Joffrey Bal let's apprentice company, con veniently known as Joffrey II, gave a brief but revealing Sat urday matinee at Town Hall as part of the current New York Children's Theater Center se ries.

title: Nixon Conversation on Calley Reported
description: Washington Notes

title: Nuptials for Miss Susan Miller
description: Miss Susan Linder Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Miller of New York, was married here yes terday afternoon to Michael Barocas, son of Mrs. Albert Barocas of Massapequa, L. I., and the late Mr. Barocas. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg per formed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Sholom.

title: U.S. Funds Revive Vocational Training On Rikers Island
description: A Federal manpowertraining program is being reinstituted at Rikers Island Reformatory after an interruption of more than year for a lack of funds.

title: YORTY CONSIDERS PRESIDENTIAL BID
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25  Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles, who has a long record of unpredictable and often un successful political behavior, will arrive in New Hampshire tomorrow to test the water and see it it is warm enough for him to enter the state's Demo cratic Presidential primary net year.

title: Japan Bans DDT Sales
description: TOYKO, April 25 (AP)The Agriculture and Forestry Min istry has banned all sales of DDT in Japan. The ministry banned the manufacture of the pesticide in 1969. The ministry said it was also banning retail sales of four other pesticides, Endrin, Dieldrin, Aldrin and BHCto unauthorized persons.

title: Demonstration in Washington
description: In what must rank as one of the more poignant and eloquent protests against this nation's continued involve ment in the war in Indochina, wounded and decorated veterans last week hurled their battle ribbons and medals at symbols of government in Washington representing the authority which sent them into battle. The massive numbers of antiwar demonstrators who gathered both San Francisco and the nation's capital over the weekend underscored the rising tide of disenchantment that sweeps now coast to coast, across much of American society.

title: OUTLOOK CLOUDED FOR U.S. OFFERINGS
description: The Treasury, which sought so long to issue Government bonds carrying interest rates higher than 4 per cent, now appears unlikely next month to use its newly gained power to sell them.

title: Secrecy on Ashau Drive
description: SAIGON, April 25The joint United States and South Viet namese operation in the Ashau Valley area is 12 days old and still surrounded by official secrecy, leading some observers to wonder if something has gone wrong, or if the operation is just a training exercise for fresh Government troops.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your short editorial of April 5 rela tive to the President's imposition of limitations on military medical per sonnel in the performance of abortions sets forth in a most striking manner the great confusion in thinking in which you so readily indulge concern ing human life.

title: Study on Foster Children Shows Most Get Homes
description: A new study indicates that well over half the children who go into foster care in the city go back to families or are otherwise discharged from fos ter care within a year. But chances for others leaving dur ing their remaining years of childhood fade rapidly.

title: Consumers Union to Give Corvairs a Monoxide Test
description: The nonprofit Consumer Un ion intends to test several hundred Chevrolet Corvairs in an effort to determine Whether the automobile's heating system delivers carbon monoxide gas into the passenger compartment.

title: Dutch Try to Reform Political System Where Parties Proliferate
description: THE HAGUE, April 25  Tu lips and politicians are the most prominent features of the Dutch landscapes this spring. Both are present in extraordinary num bers and variety, but the Dutch do not seem to appreciate them in equal measure.

title: Steel Hedging Seen As Holding Threat Of a Summer Lag
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25 Steel producers are starting to look beyond Aug. I. Mill offi cials said last week there was little doubt about volume in the period prior to that date. June is filling up fast, said one official. I see no respite through the end of July.

title: QUARTER'S PROFIT OF KODAK OFF 18%
description: Worldwide net earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in the first quarter fell 18 per cent to $67,912,000, or 42 cents a share from $82,603,000, or 51 cents a share, in the pe riod a year earlier, according to the report released today. It was the largest quarterly de cline in about 20 years.

title: New Regulations on Coast Shrink Wilderness Areas
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 The shrinking of the Western wilderness was marked here last week by two regulatory actions.

title: Stratton for Shelving War Issue, But Women. Indicate Otherwise
description: ALBANY, April 25Women members of the Democratic State Committee gave a cool reception, including some boos and hisses, tonight to Repre sentative Samuel S. Stratton's assertion that there is very little difference between Demo cratic and Republic positions on the Vietnam War.

title: Dr. Laurence Kyle, Headed Georgetown U. Department
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Dr. Laurence H. Kyle, chair man of the department of medi cine at Georgetown University, died yesterday in Panama, the university announced today. He was 55 years old and lived in suburban Oakton, Va.

title: Damon Stetson Is Honored By Fire Fighters Group
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The International Association of Fire Fighters announced to day the winners of its 1970 nationwide contest for the best newspaper stories and pictures on the hazards of firefighting.

title: Agnew Disagrees but Cites Protesters for Orderliness
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (UPI)  Vice President Agnew said today that he strongly disagreed with the aim of yes terday's antiwar rally in Wash ington and found it grotesque that some of the demonstrators had carried Vietcong flags.

title: Chile, Brazil Tied, 11
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 25 (UPI)Jaime Fillol.pulled Chile into a 11 tie with Brazil in the South American Davis Cup final today when he defeated Jose Edison Mandarino, 61, 86, 46, 108.

title: W. Germany Triumphs
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 25 (Reuters)West Germany beat Turkey, 30, in a European soc cer championship Group Eight game today.

title: Kaat and Oliva Help Twins Crush Inept Yankees, 80
description: The Yankees put it all to gether yesterdaypoor hitting, poor fielding and poor pitching and suffered their seventh defeat in nine games as the Minnesota Twins recorded an 80 victory.

title: ROCK BEAT ALTERED BY WINTER CONSORT
description: Two of the most prominent schools of rock might be called Pure Excitement and Texture.

title: Players Back from China Join TableTennis World on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., April 25 Citizens of the ferocious little world of tournament table ten nis gathered here today for the annual Long Island cham pionships and to welcome three of their number who, as part of the American team, went to Communist China earlier this month.

title: Nixons Back in Capital; Dog Stays in Maryland
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)President Nixon, after a working weekend at his Camp David, Md., retreat, flew back here this evening, temporarily leaving behind a runaway dog.

title: Concordia Choir Shows High Spirit
description: The Concordia Choir, from Bronxville, N. Y., is one of the most regular college choral visitors to New York each spring. For its 1971 concert, held at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, the 60voice choir, led by Ralph C. Schultz, showed again that it is a pleasant, no nonsense group that sings with spirit and understanding.

title: A Penn Central Derailment Blocks Route for 12 Hours
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (UPI)Sixteen Penn Central Railroad passengers coaches, four freight cars and a loco motive derailed early today.

title: NICKLAUS, ON 279, WINS BY 8 SHOTS
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 25The golf season is young but Jack Nicklaus, by winning the Tournament of Champions today, already has earned $102,903.

title: 300 PolishAmerican Scholars End a 3Day Symposium Here
description: The centurieslong ties of Po lish nationalism that have sur vived partition, occupation and immigration were in abund ant evidence at Columbia Uni versity yesterday as a three day congress of PolishAmeri can scholars and scientists ended.

title: Dollar Problem Is Causing European Monetary Alarm
description: VIENNAA call for a funda mental reexamination of the mometary system in view of the problems of the dollar was made last week at a business men's conference here as warn ings of the consequences of monetary instability grow shril ler all over Europe.

title: WARING WILLIS, 69, AN OBSTETRICIAN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 25Dr. Waring Willis, an ob stetrician and gynecologist here for 40 years, died today at his home, 2 Wellington Circle. He was 69 years old.A leader in his profession, Dr. Willis was president in 1965 of the Medical Society of the State of New York and earlier had been president of the Westchester County Medi cal Society. He was a Fellow of the American Medical So ciety and a member of its House of Delegates and of its com mittee on community health services.Born in Portadown, Ireland, Dr. Willis went to school in Birkenhead, England, and the Collegiate Institute of North Bay, Ontario, where he pre pared for Queens University in Kingston, Ontario. He received both his B.A. and M.D. there; the honorary Doctor of Laws degree that Queens is to bestow this June will be posthumous.

title: Resor Arrives in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 (A11) The Secretary of the Army, Stanley R. Resort arrived today to study the progress of Vietnamization and to look into the problem of drug addiction in the Army.

title: Rep. Robert Corbett Dies at 65; Dean of Pennsylvania Delegation
description: PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP) Representative Robert J. Cor bett, a Republican who was dean of Pennsylvania's Congressional delegation, died today at Su burban General Hospital here. He was 65 years old. He had been hospitalized Thursday with a cerebral thrombosis. He is survived, by his widow, the former Ruthe McClintock, and a daughter, Eleanor Louise. A funeral service will be held here Tuesday.

title: Their Apartment Is a 5Room Jungle
description: Dorr and Jennie Watkins live like Tarzan and Jane in a jungle of palms, baskets of orchids and the heady scent of flowering jasmine. They aren't exactly swinging on vines, since their forest is in an apartment building on the West Side. But give them time.

title: Leftist Party in Canada Picks Moderate as Chief
description: OTTAWA, April 25Moder ate forces of the socialistmind ed New Democrats, who form Canada's third largest political party, prevailed over a radical Canadian nationalist faction at a party convention that ended here last night.

title: Lon Nol Acceptance Of Post Is Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 25Informed political sources said tonight that Gen. Lon Nol had decided to serve once more as head of the Government. The gen eral resigned from the post last Tuesday because of ill health.

title: Chou Attacks U.S. but on a Mild Note
description: PEKING, April 25Premier Chou Enlai struck a relatively mild note in a speech at a ban quet held here tonight to mark the first anniversary of the summit conference of Viet namese, Cambodian and Lao tian regimes at war with the United States and its allies in Indochina.

title: SERBS' PRIDE AIDS RAILWAY PROJECT
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 25An outpouring of na tionalistic pride and private cash is helping to complete longdeferred railroad from Bel grade to the Adriatic Sea port of Bar.

title: ... and a WageWelfare Interlock
description: Chairman Mills of the House Ways and Means Com mittee has injected a new dimension into the long Congressional wrangle over welfare reform by his plan to tie together passage of a $2anhour Federal floor under industrial wages and President Nixon's proposal for a Federal floor under family income.

title: 5 Children Killed
description: ST. PAUL, April 25 (AP)  A fire of undetermined cause early today killed five children sleeping in a twostory home at the north end of the city. Officials said no adults were at home when the fire broke out.

title: The Catholic Resistance:
description: There is an important theological discussion going on in the Catholic Church, paralleling the philosophical and political debates which have been born of the social ferment occurring throughout the world. The theme of this discussion is referred to as the Theology of Peace (usually in the United States and Europe) or the Theology of Revolution and the Theology of Liberation (in Latin America and the Third World). The debate goes on not only in Catholic universities, rectories and convents, but more significantly, in the streets where morality must be lived even before it is formulated.

title: SCAGLIONE OFFERS RECITAL ON GUITAR
description: Classic guitarplaying is an intimate art, and Ronald Scag lione emphasized the fact with a vengeance in his Saturday night program at Carnegie Reci tal Hall. Even those sturdy dis play pieces, Tarrega's Recuter dos de la Alhambra and Al bniz's Leyenda, emerged as mere wisps of sounds, so deli cately did Mr. Scaglione brush the strings.

title: MRS. RALPH PETERS JR.
description: GLEN HEAD, L. I., April 25 Mrs. Helen Frew Peters, widow of Ralph Peters Jr., former president of the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Com pany, later merged into the Chemical Bank, died yesterday in Community Hospital, Glen Cove. She was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Hot Dog Sellers Told: Get a Lean Little Doggie
description: Bess Myerson says the Department of Consumer Af fairs will become the sole watchdog of the city's hot dogs because of reluctance by the Federal Government to inspect cooked sausage on the supermarket level.

title: Romney to Speak Today
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 25 (AP)George W. Romney, Sec retary of Housing and Urban Development, will be the key note speaker tomorrow as the twoday New England Town Meeting on Intergovernmental Reform convenes at the Univer sity of Massachusetts. The con ference, sponsored by the Inter state Relations Committee of the New England Council, Is de signed to bring governmental officials in New England to gether to examine means of reforming Federal and state government.

title: Fay Gralower Wed To Dr. Eisenberg
description: Miss Fay Grajower was married here yesterday after noon to Dr. David Ellis Eisen berg. Rabbi Leo Jung per formed the ceremony at the Jewish Center.

title: Books of The Times
description: CLAUSEWITZ. A Biography. By Roger Parkin son. Foreword by Michael Howard. 352 pages. Illustrated. Stein and Day. $10.

title: Women's Arrests Increase
description: LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP)The number of women arrested in Los Angeles County rose 23 per cent in 1970, and Sheriff Peter J. Pitchess said the liberation of modern wo men might have had something to do with it. Noting that the number of men arrested had increased only 10 per cent, he said: Numerous sociological studies of the female criminal ity have predicted that the fe male crime rate would approach male criminal rates as the wo men achieve greater freedom and equality with males.

title: Cheryl Beth Kornberg Married
description: Miss Cheryl Beth Kornberg and Dr. Albert M. Lefkovits were married here yesterday afternoon in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza by Rabbi Emanuel Rackman.

title: Israeli Cabinet Authorizes Further Talks on Formula to Reopen Suez Canal
description: JERUSALEM, April 25The Israeli Cabinet reviewed the latest diplomatic exchanges with the United States today, and authorized further discus sions aimed at finding a for mula to reopen the Suez Canal and separate the Israeli and Egyptian front lines.

title: Petty Takes NASCAR Race
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 25 (AP)Richard Petty gained the lead after Donnie Allison's engine failed today and outran David Pearson for a narrow vic tory in the Virginia 500. The 262.5mile race is part of the Grand National Division pro gram of the National Associa tion for Stock Car Auto Racing. He drove a 1971 Plymouth across the finish line one sec ond ahead of Pearson's 1970 Ford.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Advertising:
description: The way the gang at Gard ner has it figured, about $150million is spent in this country each year to select, buy and evaluate media for advertising. They want a big ger slice of that pie and they're going to work hard to get it.

title: Advertising:
description: Having built up a good backlog of experience since getting out of Harvard three years ago, Richard G. White has established the Progres sive Rock Network. It is an affiliation of 34 FM progres sive rock radio stations in the top 50 markets which he is seeking to sell to national advertisers as a package.

title: New Arms Are Shown
description: TEL AVIV, April 25  Israel unveiled tonight her recent ac quisition of some advanced arms, and the military com mand termed the weapons buildup during the last year unprecedented.

title: MAYOR DISAGREES WITH ROCKEFELLER ON TAX WARNING
description: Mayor Lindsay said last night he profoundly disagreed with Governor Rockefeller's warning against new taxes as destruc tive and asserted there were no data to back it up.

title: Federal Reserve Staff Scores Economy Model
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 The staff of the Federal Reserve Board has strongly criticized new mathematical model of the economy that has attracted some attention within the Nix on Administration and tended to support the Administration's optimistic forecast for the econ omy this year.

title: Reforming Welfare ...
description: The twoyear effort to reform the nation's disastrous welfare system will accomplish little if it fails to ease the crushing financial burden welfare has put on the major states and cities.

title: Life and Death of a FarOut College
description: The State University Col lege at Old Westbury, L. I.. opened three years ago as a muchheralded experiment  an amalgam of libertarianism, actionoriented urban studies and Socratic dialogue about man's great ideas.

title: Parade Here Salutes Israel's 23d Year
description: To the repeated, joyous chant of Am Yisroel Chai (the people, of Israel live). thousands of men, women and children paraded up Fifth Ave nue yesterday in celebration of Israel's 23d anniversary as a nation.

title: MachineTool Orders Hit 11Year Low in 1st Quarter
description: New orders for American ma chine tools, a closely watched indicator of future business trends, dropped in the first quarter to their lowest level in almost 11 years. At a total of $176.4million, they were at the most disappointing level since the third quarter of 1960.

title: Scholarship Ball Draws Detroit's Blacks
description: DETROIT, April 25It was the Sterling Ball, the Motown partyand it was what a Motown party was supposed to be: screaming loud, jammed and mainly black.

title: It's Not Always Costly to Be in Fashion
description: Shop Talk

title: RodriguezOliver in Porsche Triumph in Monza's 1,000
description: MONZA, Italy, April 25 (UPI) Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico and Jackie Oliver of Britain drove a fiveliter GulfPorsche 917K to a record smashing vic tory today in the sixth Monza 1,000kilometer auto race.

title: Roundup: Expos Triumph, 21
description: One year ago, the Montreal Expos started their second sea son in the National League by losing 10 of their first 11 games. It was an embarrassment to Manager Gene Mauch, who had predicted, The Expos will win 70 in 70.

title: Dissidents Attack Big Losses at Fox
description: The 20th CenturyFox Stock holders Protective Committee yesterday opened its battle to change the management of the movie company with an attack on the company's present board as well as Darryl F. Zanuck, its chairman. Mr. Zanuck recently stepped down as chief execu tive officer.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1971

title: SLUGGISH SERAGLIO AT THE CITY OPERA
description: The City Opera production of Mozart's The Abduction From the Seraglio has drifted into rather sluggish ways, and even Mario Bernhard's spirited con ducting could not keep Friday night's edition from sounding tired.

title: Bomb Thrown at Theater
description: CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP) A bomb thrown at the Hanna Theater in downtown Cleveland early today bounced off the marque and exploded at the curb, blowing out more than 40 windows in the Hanna Building, and causing minor damage to storefronts, the police reported. The rock musical Hair has been playing at the theater.

title: Guided Missile Techniques Applied to Artificial Vision by Coast Scientists
description: PASADENA, Calif., April 25 The techniques used to guide military missiles to their targets may one day help the blind to see again, a team of California medical and aerospace scien tists says.

title: CEYLONESE TROOPS SAID TO TAKE TOWN
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 25 Government troops yesterday moved into Deniyaya, 100 miles southeast of Colombo, after encountering slight resistance, a Government statement said today. The town, set among tea plantations, was the last large urban center controlled by the leftist insurgents.

title: Trevino Cards 68 for Total of 273 and Captures $60,000 Tallahassee Open
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 25 (AP)Lee Trevino charged home with a fourunderpar 68 today and won the $60,000 Tal lahassee open with a 72hole score of 273.

title: Seattle Fire Kills 12; Careless Smoking Reported as Cause
description: SEATTLE, April 25 (AP)A fire apparently caused by a smoker's carelessness swept through a threestory apart ment building today, killing 12 persons.

title: Adelphi Campus Life Attracting Local Track Stars
description: Top high school athletes in the metropolitan area, par ticularly in track and field, would attend local colleges if they could derive the same liveawayfromhome feeling offered by schools in the South, Midwest and West, Ron Bazil said yesterday.

title: PARK VOWS LIMIT ON TIME IN OFFICE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Apri 25President Chung Hee Park pledged publicly today that he was seeking only one more term as President while his chief lieutenants, Rim Jong Pil, told a press conference that knowledgeable people here an ticipate that United States troops in Korea will be with drawn by 1975 except for a token force.

title: Screen: 'Saturday Morning,' a Fugitive From TV
description: The idea behind "Saturday Morning" is a sound one in this day and age. As the color camera peers at them closely, 20 American students, white and Negro, ranging in age from 15 to 19, lounge comfortably in a sylvan glade and exchange views primarily on self and sex. The film arrived Saturday morning at the Baronet.The youths are bright, personable and well-spoken. Much of what they say, mildly prodded by a group leader and one adult on the sidelines, is interesting and certainly revealing. There are genuinely affecting moments, as when one girl tearfully admits her inability to distinguish between emotion and thought.But with all due respect to Kent Mackenzie, the director-producer, and to Gary Goldsmith, chief of Dimension Films, the picture seems best slotted for a television featurette running 40 minutes or so. It stretches out for 90. When the film hits 65, the sound of a droning fly becomes symbolic.Television slotting would certainly call for toning down some of the language. Square as it may sound, the kids are too expressive for all that casually "with it" filth, which is more monotonous than offensive. Even more annoying are those repetitious ya-knows. Samples: "Would you want your spouse, ya-know, to be a virgin, ya-know? At least theoretically, ya-know?" A girl reminds us that, "I'm, ya-know, a woman." Yeah, yeah.Two blondes are absolutely endearing in their candor and thinking, especially one doll named Robin. One of the ladssee for yourselfcould use a psychiatrist. We especially liked the pert-spoken black girl named Jean, who speaks her piece succinctly and won't be intimidated. But we still think that "Saturday Morning" calls for compression and prime time on Saturday night TV.

title: 2 CHURCHES HERE NEARING MERGER
description: About 200 members of his toric Grace Episcopal Church visited the equally historic Epis copal Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street yesterday in a cautious second step toward merger.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One may agree with Paul T. K. Lin's evaluation of the roles of the U.S. and Japan in Taiwan ('Two Chinas= Chinas, OpEd April 14) and indeed go much further with respect to Chiang's U.S.supported occupation of Taiwan.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKING FUND FOR JETPORT
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he would ask the Legislature today to appropri ate $30million from a previous ly approved bond issue to ex pand Stewart Airport into New York's longsought fourth ma jor jetport.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, April 25  In observance of Law Day, a group of New York law yers plan to march this Friday to Foley Square in lower Manhattan, there to speak about ending the war in Indo china. In several other cities commit tees of lawyers are working for an end to the war.

title: Docking Described By Crew of Soyuz
description: MOSCOW, April 25A crew member of the Soyuz 10 space. craft, which returned to the earth early this morning, today described the docking of hi! ship with the unmanned orbita laboratory Salyut as a little like a train entering a railroad terminal.

title: Mosley Captures Trentonian 200 For His First USAC Triumph
description: TRENTON, April 25Mike Mosley, a 26yearold driver from Brownsburg, Ind., won the Trentonian 200 today for the first victory of his career in the championship division of the United States Auto Club.

title: Arts Abroad
description: VIENNAThe specter of Prague's proscribed literary spring is haunting Vienna's cultural scene.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Central Park transversespar ticularly the 66th Street transverse are becoming filthier with each pass ing day. There is now a monumental accumulation of trash, paper and as sorted rubbish which, in the case of the 66th Street transverse, covers the walks as well as the sides of the in clines above the transverse.

title: MRS. KING TAKES SAN DIEGO FINAL
description: SAN DIEGO, April 26 (UPI) Mrs. Billie Jean King bor rowed a racquet from her op ponent, Rosemary Casals, after having lost the first set and fallen behind, 0.4, in the sec ond and recovered io win the $2,500 first prize in the San Diego women's open tennis tournament yesterday.

title: CITY COUNCIL ASKS PENSIONS OF 75%
description: The City Council is asking the State Legislature to let the Council's members and em ployes retire with a 75 per cent pension after 20 years service.

title: Pakistani Aide Here Renounces Ties With Regime
description: The 28yearold vice consul of Pakistan here renounced his ties with the Pakistani Govern ment yesterday, saying he would not serve a government killing our own people.

title: LISBON ARMY COURT FINDS CUBAN GUILTY
description: LISBON, April 26 Lisbon's military court convicted Capt. Pedro Rodriguez Peralta of the Cuban Army today on charges of having served as a training instructor and adviser to the African party for the Indepen dence of of Guinea and Cape Verde.

title: Dorothea H. Denslow Dies at 70; Sculptor Founded Center Here
description: Dorothea Henrietta Denslow, sculptor, who founded and directed the Sculpture Center here until her retirement last year, died yesterday in East Stroudsburg (Pa.) Hospital. She was 70 years old and had moved to Mountain Home, Pa.

title: U. S. AIDES ASK DELAY ON PHOSPHATE MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  The Nixon Administration and the nation's largest deter gent maker asked the Federal Trade Commission today to de lay action on a proposal to re quire manufacturers to warn consumers that phosphate detergents pollute water.

title: CALIFORNIA AIDE DISPUTES PANEL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26  The investigation of Califor nia Rural Legal Assistance, an antipoverty agency, began here today before a special commis sion that refused to allow Lewis K. Uhler to speak unless he would follow commission rules.

description: The prime business loan rate of the major bankswhich was increased last week to 5 per cent from 5 per cent at most institutionsis likely to go still higher this year, a leading bank economist said yesterday.

description: MOSCOW, April 26Thel Russians have a name for it Makhina (pronounced Ma heeenah) meaning a thing of huge size.

description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Clark MacGregor, Counsel to the President for Congres sional Relations, and Mrs. MacGregor entertained last night and tonight at the first of a series of informal little dinners designed to better ac quaint the White House, Cap itol Hill and the Cabinet. There will be another set of parties next Sunday and Monday.

description: Acute lymphocytic leukemia, which kills more young children In this country than any other disease, is yielding in everin creasing numbers to intensive, combination therapy with po tent drugs and radiation.

description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI) Following are ex cerpts from the text of Presi dent Nixon's speech today to the United States Chamber of Commerce:

description: PARIS, April 26  The Viet cong today called on American soldiers in Vietnam to stop fighting or desert and added that some American soldiers were fighting in the Vietcong ranks.

title: Vegas Vic Choice in Derby Trial Today
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 The Derby Trial has at tracted a field of eight for its running tomorrow, and four of these are considered likely starters in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. Even if four should be rated good enough for the big race, it will be too many, for the great problem now is to cut down the topheavy Derby field. The number of potential participants still hovers be tween 20 and 25.

description: LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) Secretary Rogers arrived here tonight to attend the South east Asia Treaty Organization ministerial meeting, which he said would be concerned with economic cooperation and the future development of Indo china.

description: WASHINGTON, April 26 North Vietnamese MIG fighters have darted into southern Laos in the last few weeks on sev eral occasions to threaten U.S. aircraft, a Pentagon spokes man said today.

description: WESTBURY, L. I. April 26 Ferric Hanover had to be scratched from a $15,000 over night event Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway because of a minor throat inflammation, but Ben Webster his trainer driver, is hopeful the 4yearold won't miss the $105,969 Reali zation Pace this Saturday night.

title: Phoenix Gets Bowl Game
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 26 (AP)Phoenix, Ariz., was granted a football bowl game today, the 12th major postseason clash to receive National Collegiate approval.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS JERSEY STADIUM
description: TRENTON, April 26  The creation of a state authority designed to attract the New York Football Giants to North Jersey was overwhelmingly ap proved, 53 to 6, tonight in the State Assembly. Before pas sage of the bill, opponents charged that the authority in volved a conflict of interest.

description: Macramethe art of crea tive knottyinghas in the last few years sprung from the obscurity of old sailors' homes and Victorian parlors into a highly popular craft.

description: The Cinema 5Rugoff The ater management will admit everyone free today to their 14 movie houses in Manhat tan, Brooklyn and on Long Island.

description: The Rockefeller achninistra tion is reportedly considering the proposal of legislation that would loosen rent control in the state.

title: East Pakistani Worker Absenteeism Said to Aggravate Economic Strains
description: A month after the military crackdown in East Pakistan, absenteeism by Bengali work ers is still crippling the econ onmy, according to wellin formed travelers who were in East and West Pakistan this week.

title: Books of The Times
description: KURT SCHWITTERS. By Werner Schmalenbach. 402 pages. Harry N. Abrams, Inc. $35. Contemporary painters and sculptors often talk about closing the gap between art and life, but Kurt Schwitters did, al most 50 years ago. He literally inhabited his art. Gutting his house in Hanover, he turned it into a Merzbaua multistoried constructivist sculpture. From the inside. the Merzbau resembled a rain forest of abstreet forms, a warehouse of sur plus imagination. It was like an im mensely complicat ed lock into which Schwitters himself fitted as the key. Every night, he climbed up this gar gantuan creation and slept on top of it, as though rest ing on his achieve ment. Merz was the root name of all Schwitters's art, derived from a scrap of the word commerz in one of his collages. The Merzbau began as a sort of stalactite, com bining several Dadalike constructions with titles like Cult Pump and Gallows of Desire into a Cathedral of Erotic Misery. Composed of pieces of junk that Schwitters incessantly collected and then plastered over, it eventually became the visual poem of a man who recycled the waste products of his environment and made them into art.

title: AIDE SAYS LON NOL MUST BE PREMIER
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 26Lon Nol was described by one of his official counselors today as a man too ill either to make important decisions or to be informed of bad news. Nonetheless, the counselor said, he situation in Cambodia is such that the general must again head the Government.

title: George K. Garvin Dies at 73; Founder of Exchange Firm
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., April 26 George K. Garvin, a co founder of the New York Stock Exchange concern of Faber, Garvin & Co., now the Garvin Bantel Corporation, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: Mao Said to Welcome a Nixon Visit
description: Chairman Mao Tse  tung would welcome a visit from President Nixon and would be happy to talk with him, ac cording to Edgar Snow, the American writer who has had frequent access over the years to Chinese Communist officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Governor Rockefeller certainly re ceived, bad advice in deciding to scuttle the communitydevelopment , bond issue and put in its place a trans portation bond issue.

title: Agnew Calls Hoover's Critics Politically Motivated
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 26 Vice President Agnew strongly defended J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investi gation here today in an 11 page, 28minute speech devoted entirely to the director, the agency and their critics.

title: Lower Drinking Age Backed
description: BOSTON, April 26 (AP)The Massachusetts House of Repre sentatives gave final approval today to a bill that would lower tthe legal drinking age to 19. The bill now goes to the Senate.

title: School Trackman Dies
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 26 (AP)Bill Brown, a 16 yearold sophomore at Robert E. Lee High School, died yesterday afer collapsing last Wednesday during a track meet.

title: Prices of Bonds Retreat; Treasury Sale Is Awaited
description: The credit markets, muddling along as they await the terms of the Treasury's $8.44billion refinancing tomorrow, declined quite sharply in quiet trading yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: New Interior Post Backed
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill creating a sixth post of Assistant Secre tary of Interior. It would deal with budgeting and manage ment operations.

title: AMEX LIST MIXED; TRADING OFF A BIT
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended on the fence yesterday as the list finished mixed on moderate trading.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Lowest Since July, 66
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)United States troop strength in South Viet nam dropped to 281,400 men last week, the United States command announced today. The total was 2,600 below the ceiling set by President Nixon for May 1 and represented the lowest level in nearly five years.

title: Rockefeller Expected to Veto Bill Barring Bridge Over L.I. Sound
description: ALBANY, April 26Gover nor Rockefeller will veto a bill that would have barred con struction of a bridge across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay, L. I., to Rye, administra tion sources said today.

title: Turkey Imposes Martial Law in 11 Areas
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 26 (AP)The Government declared martial law tonight in 11 of Turkey's 67 provinces.

title: PROSECUTOR FINED BY CHICAGO JUDGE
description: CHICAGO, April 26  The special prosecutor heading a grand jury investigation into the deaths of two Black Pan thers in a predawn police raid in 1969 was held in contempt of court today and fined $50 an hour on a roundtheclock basis.

title: German Vote in Focus
description: The state election in SchleswigHolstein was doubtless a setback for Chancellor Brandt's coalition government in West Germany but this aspect should not be exag gerated. Nor should one salutary result be overlooked:. the vote for the neoNazi National Democratic party (N.P.D.) dropped to 1.2 per cent, costing it all four its seats in the state legislature and reinforcing the impression that it is collapsing throughout the country.

title: She Was Perfect Grandmother for the Rock Musical Part
description: The star of Broadway's newest rock musical is a 75 yearold diabetic grandmother from Louisiana who has sur vived two heart attacks and nine major operations.

title: Trimming the Bulge
description: Political campaign spending gets more bloated every year. What with television specials, spot commercials, continuous polling of the electorate, direct mailings to voters on computerized listsnot to mention the tra ditional balloons, billboards and bumper stickersthe list of things on which campaign managers spend money keeps growing. Now the Presidential campaigns are getting under way more than a year before the first primary is held. If democracy is not to die of this excessively rich fare, a financial diet is clearly in order.

title: P.S.C. Bars Picturephone Test; Cites Faults in Regular Service
description: ALBANY, April 26The state Public Service Com mission today rejected a pro posal by the New York Tele phone Company to establish intercommunications picture phone service on an experi mental basis in lower Man hattan.

title: Cairo Hints Wariness on Motive Behind Rogers Trip to Mideast
description: CAIRO, April 26The Egyp tian leadership, although it has officially welcomed Secretary of State William P. Rogers's an nouncement that he would visit Cairo, indicated today that it was wary of the motives behind the trip and skeptical that any benefit for Egypt would emerge.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) Mrs. Ann Jones was appoint ed today captain of Britain's Wightman Cup tennis team, which will meet the United States in Cleveland Aug. 20 to 22.

title: PANTHERS ON TRIAL ARE CALLED VICTIMS
description: The 13 defendants are ac cused of conspiring to bomb public places and to murder policemen, and of possessing illegal weapons and dangerous explosives. Their trial, in State Supreme Court at 100 Centre Street, began last September.

title: Commuter Copters Begin NassauManhattan Runs
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 26Twelve Long Island com muters proved something today that they had long suspected it Is more expensive to travel to New York City by helicop ter than it is by Long Island Railroad or by automobile, but it is also much faster.ing air at the terminal at the Roosevelt Field Industrial Park, the commuters boarded the 12 seat, red and white amphibious Sikorsky S62A and took off promptly at 7:45 o'clock for the heliports at Wall Street and East 60th Street.

title: 72 OTB WINDOWS OPEN THIS WEEK FOR DERBY BETS
description: A total of 72 windows for win or exacta betting on the Kentucky Deity will be avail able this week to New York racing fans, officials of the city's Offtrack Betting Corpora tion announced yesterday.

title: Protesters Block a Bridge
description: Five cars blocked the Brook lynbound entrance to the Ver razanoNarrows Bridge for one minute yesterday afternoon to protest welfare cuts in city, state and Federal budgets. The protest was staged before the start of the peak traffic period and caused only a minor tieup on the Staten Island side of the bridge. The demonstration was sponsored by a branch of the island's North Shore Commu nity Rights Council and Coali tion for the People's Budget, two antipoverty groups.

title: DOW SLIPS BY 3.19 AS TRADING EASES
description: While blue chips rested yes terday on Wall Street, glamour stocks staged a calisthenics show starring the contactlens issues.

title: TRIAL TOED KOTOUC MAIMED PRISONER
description: ATLANTA, April 26A former soldier testified today in the courtmartial of Army Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc that the stocky intelligence officer cut off the first joint of a finger of a Vietcong suspect he was questioning a few hours after the mass killings at the hamlet of Mylai three years ago.

title: ManHour Output Figure Clarified by Labor Agency
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Productivity, or output per manhour, rose only about half as much in the manufacturing sector of the economy in the first quarter as reported last week, the Labor Department disclosed today.

title: Benton & Bowles Shifts Executives
description: Advertising:

title: Japan Denies Report of Pact With U.S. on Nuclear Arms
description: TOKYO, April 26 (UPI)A Government spokesman denied today as groundless a report that Japan and the United States had a secret agreement permitting nuclear weapons to be introduced temporarily into Japan.

title: New Jet Service Operating
description: BOHEMIA, L. I., April 26 Jet air service by a major air line began at Long Island Mac Arthur Airport this morning when an American Airlines Boeing 727 left here with a full complement of 93 passengers bound for Chicago.

title: Principal Restored By a Divided Vote At Jamaica School
description: After five months of contro versy, the community school board that removed Mrs. Des iree Greenidge as acting princi pal of Shimer Junior High School in Jamaica, Quens, re solved this morning to reinstate her.

title: FORMER HEAD OF UNIT TARGET OF I.O.S. SUIT
description: GENEVA, April 26  In vestors Overseas Services has brought a criminal action in the courts here against Arthur F. Adelson, former head of In vestment Properties Interna tional, Ltd., a subsidiary, spokesman for the investment group said today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The anti war demonstration here last week and those still to come suggested again how widespread is the opposition to continuing the war. But there is not yet a shred of evidence to suggest that this demonstrable opposition is causing the Nixon Administration to change its basic course.

title: Experimental Open Theater Carrying On
description: The Open Theater, that leading experimental theater company, has not dis bandedcontrary to rumors and published reports.

title: OBSERVER
description: Reading about Kaiser Wilhelm's secret plan to invade the United States back before World War I could make your hair stand on end if you started thinking about what this coun try would be like today if the Kaiser's plan had succeeded,

title: British Leyland's Family Car, MakeorBreak Model, Shown
description: LONDON, April 26The Brit ish Leyland Motor Corporation, the last major Britishowned company in the worldwide au tomobile business, introduced today its new family car, the Morris Marina.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 26, 1971 THE PRESIDENT

title: Young Duvalier, Meeting Press, Hints at a Friendlier Outlook
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 26JeanClaude Duvalier, the 19yearold President for Life of this black republic, in dicated today that his new re gime would seek friendlier relations with the outside world.

title: Chairman Sidesteps Retirement Questions Mrs. Soss Ejected From Meeting
description: TORONTO, April 26Thom as J. Watson Jr., chairman of International Business Machines Corporation, promised today to bend every effort to appoint a woman to the board of di rectors this year.

title: LUNAR HOT SPOT LINKED TO QUAKES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  The moonquakes detected by Project Apollo instruments with clocklike regularity as the moon makes its closest approach to the earth each month appear to originate in a single hot spot deep within the moon.

title: Western Electric Makes Wage Offer In Contract Talks
description: The Western Electric Com pany, one of 21 Bell System companies now engaged in con tract negotiations, made its ini tial wage anti benefit offer yes terday to representatives of the Conmiunications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the name of economy (sic), a fi nancially and socially disastrous step was taken by our New York State legislators in their recent action dur ing the budget crisis. The newly en acted Social Service Law signed by Governor Rockefeller on April 12 eliminates payment for Home Health Services for nonwelfare Medicaid pa tients.

title: Population Center of U.S. Edges Westward in Illinois
description: MASCOUTAH, Ill., April 25 Like most Americans, Law rence Friederich has picked up and moved two or three times.

title: STATE BANKING CHIEF APPROVES MERGERS
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday his approval of the proposed merger of the Franklin Savings Bank and the Kings Highway Savings Bank to form a com bined institution with $1billion in assets, and nine offices. The merger must also be approved by the Federal Deposit Insur ance Corporation.

title: ... and an Epilogue in Albany
description: The least debatable element in the budget plight of New York City and the rest of this state's urban areas is that it was made vastly worse by the inordinate cuts in state aid voted by the Republican majority in the Legislature. One member of that majorityState Sena tor Roy Goodman of Manhattanhas now appointed himself leader of a drive in Albany to restore the cuts.

title: AUSTRALIA UPSET IN DAVIS CUP PLAY
description: TOKYO, April 26 (AP)The tennis fortunes of Australia took another dip today when Japan eliminated her in the Eastern Zone Section A final of the Davis Cup.

title: HEAD OF A COLLEGE IN BRONX RESIGNS
description: Dr. Nasry Michelen resigned yesterday as president of Hos tos Community College in the South Bronx, saying that the college needed new leadership after a series of crises that placed its operation In jeop ardly.

title: $50Million Bank Loan Is Obtained by Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration announced yesterday that it had obtained $50million in new bank loans to tide it over while it seeks to conclude negotiations for huge longterm financing needed to salvage its L1011 airbus program.

title: HIGHER EARNINGS REPORTED BY FORD
description: DETROIT, April 26  The Ford Motor Company reported today firstquarter profits of $169.2million, or $1.57 a share, up 36 per cent from $124.4mil lion, or $1.15 a share, a year ago.

title: A.T. & T. Financing Asked
description: New York City's municipal utilities planner contended yes terday that the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company not the individual consumer  should be called upon to pay for improving the deterior ated telephone service here.

title: Alabama Files Suit To Block Pollution By 13 Big Concerns
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 26 (AP)Alabama's attorney gen eral used a centuriesold legal concept today to charge 13 large companies in Birmingham with endangering the lives of citizens by polluting the air.

title: Mets Trounce Cards, 122
description: ST. LOUIS, April 26The New York Mets knocked Bob Gibson out of the box within four innings tonight and routed the St. Louis Cardinals, 122, for Torn Seaver's fourth straight victory of the year.

title: Pierre Boulez Conducts New and Newer Music
description: The newest music con ducted by Pierre Boulez in the New and Newer Music program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night dated from 17 years ago, his own Le Marteau sans Maitre. It fol lowed old and older works by Schoenberg (the 1926 Suite, Op. 29, sometimes known as the Septet) and Stravinsky (Berceuses du chat and Pribaoutki, dated 1916 and 1914, respectively).

title: CRIMMINS JUDGE BARRED WITNESS
description: An examination of the tran script of the murder trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins confirmed yesterday that the prosecution had tried unsuccessfully to get the judge to permit testimony by a doctor purporting to show that she had admitted killing her two children.

title: Cruguet and Vasquez Ride Three Winners Each on Aqueduct Card
description: C'est trois, Jean Cruguet, the quietmannered French jockey who learned to ride horses near his boyhood home in Nice, said yesterday. My Mounts, they have been better this year. And, I have been very lucky.

title: T.V. Soong Is Dead at 77; Aide of Nationalist China
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)The death of T. V. Soong, longtime banking genius of the Chinese Nationalist regime, at a private dinner party last might was ascribed today to food lodged in the windpipe.

title: MISS MAKAS BOWS AS COSTANZA HERE
description: Mozart's The Abduction From the Seraglio has only six characters, all of them major, although only five of them sing (the Pasha is speaking part).

title: BUDGES BACKS MORE URBAN AID
description: ALBANY, April 26  Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges said today that he favored the restoration of about $75million in state aid to cities because recent budget cuts voted by the Republican  controlled Legisla ture kind of pulled the rug out from under the local govern ments.

title: Love Story (19thCentury Style)
description: A year or so ago I was making film in Dublin. It was, naturally, about James Joyce, and a good deal of the filming was done in the ruins of 7 Eccles Streetthe final demolition of which was suspended while the cameras drank up what had been, in Joyce's imagination if not in fact, the bedroom where Bloom slept with his feet on the pillow and Molly Bloom yessed her way into eternity. I got back to England to learn that in Shot tery, near StratforduponAvon, a youth had quarreled with his girl and set fire to Anne Hathaway's cottage as thehellwithit gesture.

title: U.S. Experts Puzzled
description: The SoyuzSalyut mission has American space experts puz zled. From the sketchy informa tion that has been made public, they are unable to determine if it was a success or a failure, a major step toward a manned orbiting laboratory or a small, hesitant step.

title: Harlem Crime Toll Is Put at $2Billion
description: A sharp increase in crimes in central Harlem doing 1970 attributed primarily to a rise in narcotics addictionraised the cost of crime to more than $2billion for residents and property owners there, a study by the Small Business Chamber of Commerce dis closed yesterday.

title: PRESIDENT URGES BUSINESS TO SHUN SENSE OF DESPAIR
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 President Nixon told an ap preciative audience of business men today that despite a sense of despair in some elements of the population, there was no reason to lose confidence in the nation's economy, the aims of its foreign policy, or its sense of concern for the poor.

title: Former Nun Is Cited in Berrigan Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 26 The Federal Government has asked that a second witness called before the grand jury here be found in contempt for refusing to answer the grand jury's questions.

title: French Seek Embargo on Algerian Oil
description: PARIS, April 26The French oil industry, with Government support, sought today to im pose a worldwide embargo on Algerian petroleum and natur al gas.

title: 6 Air Force Men Cleared Of U.S. Charges Overseas
description: MANILA, April 26 (AP) The United States Government dropped bribery and other charges today against six sen ior Air Force noncommissioned officers accused in connection with the operation of enlisted men's clubs at bases in Thai land.

title: Texan Dies in Fuel Accident
description: DALLAS, April 26 (UPI) V. E. Brock, 47 years old, of Benbrook, Tex., died yesterday of burns he received at a Fort Worth service station Saturday. Two cars collided in front of the station. One crashed into gasoline pump, and gasoline spewed over Mr. Brock. The gasoline ignited and burned him over 90 per cent of his body.

title: Marinduque Gets Loan
description: MANILA, April 26 (UPI) The Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corporation reported today it had signed a $27mil lion lineofcredit agreement with the ExportImport Bank. Proceeds will be used to fi nance up to 45 per cent of the cost of purchases in the United States of equipment, material and services for development of I nickel facilities in the Philip pines.

title: ISRAELIS TO DESIGN KENNEDY CENTER BOX
description: TEL AVIV, April 26Israeli artists will decorate the lounge off the President's box in the Symphony Hall of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington, it was announced here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: During the first week in May most of the school and library districts in New York State will be asking the voters to approve their budgets so that the education of the children and the continuation of library service might not be impaired.

title: Policy on Sterling Detailed by French
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, April 26  French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Es taing said today the problem of sterling balances, one of the issues in Common Market nego tiations with Britain, would come up in any BritishFrench summit conference and spelled out France's position in the greatest detail yet.

title: Health Hazard Seen in Narrow Emphasis on Garbage Recycling
description: An official of the American Public Health Association warned yesterday that narrow emphasis on recycling as a means of solving the nation's waste problem could create a public health problem by delay ing the disposal of garbage.

title: Flyers Shift Farm Club
description: RICHMOND, April 26 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League an nounced today the transfer here of their Quebec City American Hockey League fran chise for the 197172 season. The team will he operated by Richmond Sports International, a business group with the Fly ers furnishing the players, coach and trainer.

title: FUND CUTS IN STUDY OF FUSION DEPLORED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 A leading specialist in environ mental hazards said today that current budgetary restraints on the development of pollution free fusion energy were in utter disgrace.

title: Executive Changes
description: Smith, Kline & French Laboratories announced yesterday following its annual meeting in Phila delphia, that Thomas M. Rausch, president and chief executive officer, has been elected to the additional position of chairman. Mr. Rausch, 49 years old, succeeds Walter A. Munns who retired as chair man at the annual meeting. Richard L. Matthews was elected a group vice president.

title: TV: Wide World of Sports Turns 10
description: In the beginning there was the soaring sound of Richard Strauss's Thus Spake Zara thustra. Then the announcer came on with a quote from Bernard Berenson, something about standing on a street corner with a tin cup to col lect minutes from passersby.

title: Durer's Graphics Are Still Amazing
description: WASHINGTON  The cli mactic celebration of the 500th birthday of Albrecht Dilrer, who was born on May 21, 1471, will begin on May 21, when a yearlong exhibi tion of the German master's work opens in his natal city, Nuremberg. In the meanwhile, the National Gallery in Wash ington is doing pretty well with an exhibition of Dilrer prints and drawings from American collections that opened Sunday and will re main on view through June 6.

title: PRICES DECLINE FOR PORK BELLIES
description: The futures prices of pork belliesthe basic material for baconfell again yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Ex change.

title: ExFootball Star Cleared
description: LOS ANGELES, April 26 (Reuters)Misdemeanor charg es of battery and disturbing the peace against Jim Brown, 35 yearold actor and former foot ball star with the Cleveland Browns, were dismissed today by Judge Irwin J. Nebron in Municipal Court here because of the prosecution's failure to produce witnesses. Mr. Brown was accused of beating two young women and throwing them down a stairway In his home in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles last Feb. 12.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: YOU can unveil arrrels of your cuturel Get a copy of how To Consult the I Ching. N'tI.t at bookstores now. Putnam./oi...l.

title: Senate Votes $1.4Billion To Aid School Integration
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate approved today $1.4billion Administrationsupported bill to help commu nities integrate their schools. The vote was 74 to 8. Seven Southern Democrats and one Republican, Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, opposed the measure.

title: MAYOR ADVOCATES BROAD HOME RULE
description: Mayor Lindsay called yester day for sweeping reform of state laws to give local govern ments more independence from the state and more power to rule themselves.

title: The Budgetary Drama ...
description: There is no clash between right and wrong this time. The annual scenario in which the Governor of New York State and the Mayor of New York City play leading roles, each taking credit for the good, each eschewing blame for the bad, has taken on this year the more somber tones of Greek tragedy. There is less a clash between right and wrong than between right and right. To a considerable extent, Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay are both correct in their apparently contradictory assertions.

title: CHARLES R. WEBER
description: Charles R. Weber, who had headed the tanker brokerage concern of that name since 1941, died Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a lcmg illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 630 Park Avenue.

title: Dr. Karl Blessing Is Dead at 71; Led West German Central Bank
description: BONN, April 26Dr. Karl Blessing, former president of West Germany's Central Bank, died last night while on holi day in southern France, the bank announced today. He was 71 years old. He died minutes after suffering a heart attack during a stroll at Orange, a city an the Rhone Valley, the bath said.

title: No Plans on New Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The State Department said today that there were no plans by the United States to provide new economic aid to Haiti as sug gested by the American Ambas sador in PortauPrince, Clinton E. Knox.

title: REACTIONS MIXED ON JETPORT PLAN
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., April 26 Reaction ran hot and cold here today on Governor Rocke feller's proposal to converti nearby Stewart Airport into the metropolitan area's fourth ma jor jetport. The Governor seeking $30million from a $2.5 billion state transportation bond issue to purchase 10,000 acres, here for jetport development.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A community shower room separates the dressing rooms of the New York Rangers and the New York Knicker bockers just beyond the arena proper in Madison Square Garden. When last visited, each was an exceedingly gloomy place.

title: Sugarman Calls for Law Giving Job Priority to Residents of City
description: Human Rescurces Admin istrator Jule M. Sugarman pro posed yesterday that legisla tion he enacted to force public and private employers in the city to hire a qualified city resident before a nonresident.

title: Slumping Yanks Oppose White Sox Here Tonight
description: The Yankees will attempt tonight to pull out of a slump that has seen them lose seven of their last nine games when they meet the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadi um. The teams will end the twogame series tomorrow night.

title: Brooklynite Pleads Guilty In Fire Death of 4 in '69
description: A handyman pleaded guilty yesterday to the murder of four persons who died in a fire he set the night of Oct. 2, 1969, in a threestory tenement in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Boeing's Profits Rise
description: SEATTLE, April 26 (UPI) The. Boeing Company at its annual meeting here reported an increase in firstquarter profits to $7,185,000, or 33 cents a share, from $6,181,000, or 29 cents a share, in the ini tial 1970 period. Sales rose to $857,969,000 in the quarter from $809,457,000.

title: COWAN, DEFENDER, GAINS AT PINEHURST
