description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 26 (AP)Gary Cowan of Canada, the defending champion, and seven of the eight United Slates Walker Cup players sur vived today's opening round of the NorthandSouth amateur golf tournament.

title: Physicians Say Proposed Cuts Threaten Health Unit
description: About 80 scientists and med ical educators urged the Lind say administration yesterday to restore proposed budget cutbacks of $2.5million that the doctors said threatened the survival of the city's Health Research Council.

title: Maravich Trial Set
description: SARASOTA, Fla., April 26 (UPI)  Pete Maravich of the Atlanta Hawks pleaded inno cent today to a charge of driv ing while intoxicated. A trial was set for June 2.

title: People's Lobby Begs for End of War
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Anti war protesters clad in bur lap sacks and smeared with makebelieve blood pleaded on Capitol Hill today for an end to the conflict in Vietnam.

title: Rangers and Hawks Resume Tonight
description: Ranger fans were asking yes terday, How can a team play so superbly on a Thursday and so poorly on a Sunday?

title: GUGGENHEIM AIDE OUSTED IN DISPUTE
description: Edward Fry, associate cura tor of the Guggenheim Museum, was dismissed by the museum's director yesterday in a contro versy over the cancellation of a show by Hans Haacke, the artist, that was to have includ ed photographs of Manhattan slums labeled with the names of the buildings' owners.

title: Conglomerate Reports a FirstPeriod Profit
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., the hardpressed conglomerate re ported yesterday firstquarter earnings of $1,889,000 before extraordinary items, which was equal to 18 cents a share. This compares with a loss of $9, 313,000 before an extraordinary charge and $15,345,000 after the charge in the yearearlier period.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Title Captured By Griffin Group on Last Deal
description: A welljudged opening lead on the final deal result ed in a victory Sunday night for Toni Griffin's team in Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship.

title: Zamir Chorale Marks Israel Independence Day
description: A Buxtehude cantata and a contemporary jazz piece by. J. Labes, each performed with an appropriate instru mental ensemble, were juxta posed in the eclectic program put on by the Zamir Chorale in Carnegie Hall Sunday night. It was the group's 11th annual concert in honor of Israel Independence Day, and the varied music was sung in Hebrew except for two pieces in English.

title: Knicks' Reed to Undergo Knee Surgery Tomorrow
description: Willis Reed of the Knicks will enter Roosevelt Hospital today to undergo surgery on the sore left knee that has hampered his play for the last two seasons.

title: Bank of Greece Governor Praises Vigor of Economy
description: ATHENS, April 26  Deme trios Galanis, governor of Greece's central hank, praised today the vigor of the national economy but called for a care ful watch on high liquidity the amount of cash readily ac cessible to the public.

title: Hugh Downs Leaving Today
description: Hugh Downs, host of the Na tional Broadcasting Company's television network show To day, will take leave of the program in October. He will be replaced by Frank McGee, it was announced yesterday by Reuven Frank, president of N.B.C. news.

title: STEPHEN JEWETT, A PSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Stephen P. Jewett, a lead ing psychiatrist here before his retirement 10 years ago to West Falls, N. Y., died there yes terday at the age of 87.

title: City Hall Dominance of S.I. Plan Is Fought
description: As Richard T. Connor, the Richmond Borough President, puts it, the Lindsay admin istration has been handling the vast Staten Island devel opment plan like a fellow trying to design the 747 on the back of a matchbox.

title: Estes Granted Parole in Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)Billie Sol Estes, the one time West Texas promoter who has been in Federal prison since 1965, won parole today effective July 12.

title: London's 3d Airport to Be Built on Coast
description: LONDON, April 26  The Government today ruled out any inland site for a new Lon don airport. The decision was a victory for environment over economicsprobably the most significant in Britain so far.

title: Treasury Rill Yields Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly com petitive sale of these short term securities today:

title: POINTER IS NAMED BEST AT BEL AIR
description: BEL AIR, Md., April 26 Wright Tisdale's orange and white pointer, Ch. Shandown's Tough O'Kings, was chosen best in show at the Harford County Kennel Club's 20th an nual event today. Virgil D. Johnson of Savannah Beach, Ga. made the decision in the final class of six dogs from the entry of 1,500.

title: HIGH COURT ROLES VOTERS MAY BLOCK HOUSING FOR POOR
description: Voting 5 to 3, the Court ap proved a 1950 California law that has been used by voters to prevent the construction of almost half the lowrent hous ing proposed for the state in the last 20 years.

title: STARS REIMBURSED IN M'DANIELS LOSS
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 26 (AP)The Utah Stars and Carolina Cougars of the Amer ican Basketball Association have settled their dispute over Jim McDaniels, Vince Boryla, the Stars'general manager, said today.

title: Allied Chemical Net Soars by 49%
description: The Allied Chemical Corpo ration has developed an air cushion restraint system for automobiles and will build multimilliondollar interim pro duction facility to make the safety device, John T. Connor, chairman, told some 600 share holders at yesterday's twohour annual meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: ANNE J. MILLER, 73, EXSOCIAL WORKER
description: Mrs. Anne Jablonower Miller, a former social worker and the wife of Louis Miller, retired chairman of the executive com mittee of Random House, died Sunday in Montefiore Hospital after a long illness. She was 73 years old and lived in Palm Beach and at 111 East 80th Street here.

title: Nixon Names 4 as Judges On Local Federal Benches
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 President Nixon today nomi nated four Federal judges to fill longstanding vacancies on the United States courts in the New York City area.

title: Former Jersey Legislator Begins 16Month Sentence
description: NEWARK, April 26 () Former Assemblyman Peter W. Moraites surrendered to Fed eral authorities this morning to begin serving a 16month pris on sentence for accepting mon ey from a company that had sought loans from a bank of which he was a director.

title: AirIndustry Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  The Senate Commerce subcommittee on aviation plans hearings from May 18 to May 20 on the economic status of the airtransport industry.

title: Cooley Denies Wrongdoing In Use of Artificial Heart
description: HOUSTON, April 26 (AP) Dr. Denton A. Cooley, the heart surgeon, filed today an answer to a $4.5million suit in stituted by the widow of the world's first artificial heart re cipient, Haskel Karp.

title: HEALTH COST RISE OF 50% EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The leading proponents of na tional health insurance ap peared before Congress today to criticize each other's plans and agree on only one thing the country's health care bills will rise almost 50 per cent in the next three years.

title: Madison Traffic Ban Opposed by Merchants
description: Madison Avenue merchants polled by the Fifth Avenue Association overwhelmingly oppose the traffic ban from noon to 2 P.M. currently in effect on weekdays along the avenue from 42d to 57th Street, the 1,000member as sociation reported yesterday.

title: Columbia ExAide Guilty of Larceny
description: A former assistant to the bur sar of Columbia University was indicted yesterday on charges of having diverted $185,000 in tuition checks and other funds for his personal use.

title: Furniture Men Turn to Showmanship
description: HIGH POINT, N. C.Wom en's fashions come and go with the seasons, but the sturdy sofa, to the dismay of the people who make and sell furniture, can sit in the living room for 11.7 years. What's more, the American family is in the market for home furnishings only four times in a lifetime.

title: The Theater: The Ballad of Johnny Pot Arrives
description: John Perry Replaces Carradine in Lead

title: Indiana Standard, Union and Continental Oil Up
description: Indications that the first quarter of 1971 was good to the petroleum industry received additional support yesterday as the Standard Oil Company (In diana), the Continental Oil Com pany and the Union Oil Com pany reported solid earnings performances for the period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial concerning Mayor Lindsay's plan to collect more taxes as a means of providing essential services prompted me to reflect on some of the reasons services are not provided in an area familiar to me.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The threat to New York's municipal broadcast facilities, even if the mone tary savings accompanying their dis continuance were sizable, can only be viewed with dismay. So identified has WNYC become with this community that the mind rejects the thought of its loss. [Editorial April 26.]

title: PANEL URGES U. S. SEEK EARLY ENTRY OF PEKING TO U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A special Presidential commis sion recommended today that the United States seek as early as practicable admission of Communist China to the United Nations but without the expulsion of Nationalist China.

title: Seven Killed in Utah Crash
description: LAYTON, Utah, April 26 (AP) A twocar broadside collision. in this northern Utah com munity killed seven persons yesterday. The dead were iden tified as Lester R. Del Rio, 28 years old; his three sons, Eu gene, 10, Eddie, 7, and Lennie, and three l6yearolds in the other car, William Allen Bach, the driver; Debra Maynes, and William David Bath.

title: Roundup: Perry of Twins Revives Cy Young Form
description: For the first time this sea son Jim Perry pitched last night in the manner expect ed of last year's Cy Young Award winner as the Amer ican League's outstanding pitcher.

title: Threat to Campus Freedom
description: The national mood of economic frustration and anti intellectual reaction has begun to feed a growing move ment against academic tenure. The arguments marshaled for abolishing professorial job security are cloaked in highminded rhetoric of academic reform. This is a trans parent disguise of the economic and political anger which provides the true motivation.

title: Nazi's Son Hurt in Bavaria
description: AMBFRG, West Germany, April 26 (AP)The Rev. Martin Bormann Jr., a Roman Catholic priest and the son of the man who was Hitler's deputy, was reported in critical condition today. He was in a traffic ac cident yesterday involving a United States military vehicle near this Bavarian town, the police said. His father dis appeared near the end World War II.

title: Miss Armin Violin Winner
description: Adele Armin, 24yearold Ca nadian violinist, won the first Cosmopolitan Violin Competi, Lion conducted by the Cosmo politan Young Peoples Sym phony Orchestra. The finals were held Saturday. The vio linist was awarded $1,000 and performances as soloist with the orchestra at Philharmonic I Hall on May 15 and 18.

title: Bomb Threat in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) An anonymous tip that a bomb was to go off in the Cap itol today set off an intensive search that the police said pro duced negative results.

title: Samuels Urges Caution By FRANCIS X. CLINES
description: ALBANY, April 26The head of the Offtrack Betting Corpo ration expressed concern today that growing upstate interest in entering the offtrack field presented a great danger of killing race tracks in that area.

title: School Board Told Allocations Are Futile in Light of Fund Cuts
description: A city Board of Education hearing on methods of allocat ing school funds was told yes terday that without proper funding of education, what we are talking about is how to spread the watereddown mar Igarine on unenriched bread so that we can all starve equi tably.

title: Burns Endorses Restrictions on Banks
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Arthur F. Burns, the Chair man of the Federal Reserve Board, endorsed today a limited extension of statutory restric tions on interlocking personnel of financial institutions.

title: Munition Dump Destroyed As Foe Steps Up Attacks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 27A huge am munition dump in the side of a coastal mountain was exploded by enemy shelling early yester day, the third day of  wave of attacks through much of South Vietnam.

title: MAYOR SWEARS IN SANITATION CHIEF
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in the ninth man to head the city's Sanitation Depart ment since he took over at City Hall in 1966.

title: Rural Folk Fear Common Market Perils Way of Life
description: TULLAGHANOGE, Ireland, April 13To Brendan Lynch, who farms 53 acres of County Meath land here, the Euro pean Common Market means a house every two miles with a Mercedes car, and bureaucrat who thinks he knows better than we carrying a blueprint that says either you fit in or you die.

title: House Gets Bill to Renew Loans to Medical Students
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 A bill introduced in the House of Representatives today seeks to avert what educators have called an impending crisis in support for medical education.

title: British Census Is On, With Few Incidents
description: LONDON, April 26  More than 100,000 census enumera tors set out today in heavy rain and unseasonable snow to collect 18 million forms dis tributed for Britain's 1971 census.

title: Veterans Aide Cites Gains In Treating Drug Addicts
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)  Donald E. Johnson, Admin istrator of Veterans Affairs, testified today that good prog ress was being made in treat ing drug addicts among Viet nam war veterans who seek rehabilitation.

title: Carrier Lists a Slight Rise for Quarter
description: The Southern Pacific Com pany, one of the most diver sified of the nation's railroads, reported yesterday a net in come for the first quarter of $18,461,226, or 69 cents a share, up slightly from the $18,389,745, or 68 cents a share, reported for the com parable period a year ago.

title: Bendix Lifts Profit 36%;
description: The Bendix Corporation re ported yesterday a 36 per cent increase in earnings for the second fiscal quarter.

title: Notes on People
description: The Beatles, with a little help from their friends, their lawyers, have agreed at last not to disagree about efforts of one of them, Paul McCart ney, to get out of their part nership.

title: Net Rises 17% at Tenneco
description: Tenneco Inc., reported yes terday a high in firstquarter operating revenues, while net income ran higher than the yearago period.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As to Governor Rockefeller's ridicu lous comment to the effect that elimi nation of 90,000 municipal jobs would leave Mayor Lindsay where he was in 1966, the Governor should note that there is now incalculably more crime, more poverty, more illness and more filth in the city than there was in 1966, and that the deteriorating quality of New Yorkers' lives is attributable in large measure to the Governor's lack of leadership or concern for the city and his constant concurrence in the fiscal starvation of the city.

title: JOBLESS BACKED ON DISPUTED PAY
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 The Supreme Court ruled unan imously today that states can not suspend unemployment compensation payments to job less persons while their former employers challenge their eligi bility.

title: Gunman Robs Jersey Bank Of $80,000 and Gets Away
description: PENNSAUKEN, N. J., April 26 (AP)Wearing a ski mask and carrying a sawedoff shot gun, a man robbed the Fidelity Bank of New Jersey here of $80,000 today, the police said.

title: DOROTHY OCHTMAN, STILLLIFE PAINTER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., April 26 Dorothy Ochtman, an artist, who was known for her still fifes, especially flower paint ings, and her portraits of chil dren and adults in home set tings, died today in Greenwich Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived on Stanwich Lane.

title: Dance: Feld's Theater in Premiere
description: Eliot Feld's latest ballet, Theater, seen over the weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is an in teresting and impressive work. It is a gloss on the com media dell' arte, and it is a gloss on one or two earlier ballets to do with clowns, clowning, tragedy and unful filled aspirations:

title: Market Place: Portofit Eyxamined At Chryssler Unit
description: Throughout the long debate over the creditworthiness of the Chrysler Corporation, the company's financing arm, the Chrysler Financial Corpora tion, has stood as a bulwark in the storm. Or has it?

title: MRS. SPATT URGES NEW PLANNING UNIT
description: A former member of the City Planning Commission, Beverly Moss Spatt, has recommended that the commission be abol ished and its duties assumed by a powerful new agency under the direct control of the Mayor.

title: Private Antitrust Suit Filed Against Penn Central Units
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 26 (UPI)A New York City law yer filed a private antitrust suit against the Penn Central Com pany and its railroad subsidiary today, charging mismanage ment of the railroad's finances. The suit, filed in the United States District Court here by I. Alton Bader, seeks $1.2 billion in triple damages from the Penn Central Company, the Penn Central Transportation Company, its four court appointed trustees and several former railroad officials and several brokerage houses.

title: Frazier Knocks Out 8 Songs
description: With his legs twitching in side his redstriped blue jwnpsuit, Joe Frazier enter tained the early arrivals at last night's Felt Forum box ing show as a rock singer, not as the world heavyweight champion. And the difference was obvious.

title: Hoffa Here for Grand Jury Hearing on Pension Fund
description: James R. Hoffa, the impris oned president of the Interna tional Brotherhood of Team sters, arrived at the Federal House of Detention here yes terday to await his scheduled appearance before a Federal grand jury today.

title: The Catholic Resistance: II
description: In Protestant North America, Cath olics have often felt the need to re assert their fundamental loyalty as Americans. Yet now, at a time when our society faces profound polariza tion, public attention has been drawn to the socalled Catholic Resistance. The emergence of this phenomenon illustrates the way that religion de termines an individual's relationship to his government.

title: Zealous Sanitation Commissioner Herbert Elish
description: One of the ways that the city's new Sanitation Com missioner sometimes like to think of himself is as a for mer twosewer man from Brooklyn.

title: SECURITY RESTORED, HUSSEIN DECLARES
description: BEIRUT, April 26King Hus sein said today that security and stability had been reestab lished in Jordan and that the time had come for national re construction and development.

title: Josephine Schaefer, 77, Is Dead; Vice President of Elliman & Co.
description: Josephine Grattan Schaefer, a vice president and director of Douglas O. Elliman & Co., died Sunday at her home, 125 East 63d Street, after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

title: LAWSUIT WEIGHED BY F.I.DUPONT SON
description: MAY BRING SUITS: Ed mond duPont, son of the founder of F.I. duPont, Glore Forgan, may file law suits concerning takeover.

title: U.S. Combat Deaths In Vietnam at 45,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)  The number of American deaths in com bat in Vietnam has reached 45,000.

title: Interior Official Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) The Interior Department an nounced today the appointment of Robert A. Kelly, 39 years old, public relations director for the PepsiCola Company, as direc tor of communicationspublic information officerfor the In terior Department. Mr. Kelly, resident of Old Greenwich, Conn., will take office May 3. He will replace Edward P. Es sertier, who is accepting a ca reer assignment in Interior's office of information.

title: Watson's Team Wins
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., April 26The team of Bob Watson of Wykagyl, Joe Bove of Sterl ing Farm, Bob Fox of Rock Hill and Pete Duffy of South ward Ho scored 31, 3364 to day to win the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association propro tournament at the Tam O'Shanter Golf Club. Par for the 6,658yard course is 36, 3672.

title: 2 New Lawsuits Challenge Start of Amtrak Service
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Two new lawsuits, another round of Congressional hear ings this week and criticism from Ralph Nader today are challenging the plans of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation to start operations on a shrunken national net work next Saturday.

title: India Restricts Travel by Pakistani Aides
description: NEW DELHI, April 26The Indian Government imposed re strictions today on the travel of Pakistani diplomats and their families and servants, making it impossible for them to leave India without New Delhi's per mission.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: William Hegmann Jr., a Sandoval, Ill., metallurgical engineer, believes he has per fected an economical tech nique for producing softiron pellets for shotgun shells.

title: Uganda's Ties With Neighbors Worsen as East African Leaders. Continue to Rebuff Arvin
description: JINJA, Uganda, April 25 Relations between the Govern ment of Gen. Idi Amin and sev eral neighboring countries have beendeteriorating rapidly.

title: 2 ExJohnson Aides Back WarmakingPower Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 Two men who advised Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson on the Vietnam war today endorsed proposals to impose legislative restrictions on the President's power to commit the nation to War.

title: NEW H.R.A. STATUS FOUGHT BY BEANIE
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie urged the City Council yester day not to establish the Human Resources Administration as superagency dealing with wel fare and poverty.

title: Brazil Beats Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 26 (AP)Brazil defeated Chile, 32, in the South American Zone of the, Davis Cup today.

title: Draft of UnitPricing Rules Is Scored
description: Retailers asserted yesterday that the city's proposed regu lations on unit pricing were discriminatory, and they contended that the rules would not be widely applicable to slumarea stores, where unit pricing was needed most.

title: James McInerney, Taught Engineering at Manhattan
description: James S. McInerney, an as sistant professor of civil engi neering at Manhattan College and a consulting engineer, died yesterday in Yonkers Profes sional Hospital after a short illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 13060 Glenwood Ave nue in Yonkers.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION UP BY 0.7% IN WEEK
description: Steel production rose by 0.7 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: Tennis Turnabout Down Under
description: No matter which philosoph ical side of the racquet you prefer, rough or smooth, the JapanAustralia Davis Cup series finally has put tennis in its proper perspective.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 27, 1971

title: N.Y.U. Board Elects Banked
description: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman and chief executive officer of the Irving Trust Company, has been elected to the New York University board of trustees, John M. Schiff, chairman, an nounced yesterday.

title: Angela Davis Again Fails To Have Judge Disqualified
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)The California District Court of Appeal rejected today a second attempt by the black militant Angela Davis to dis qualify Superior Court Judge Alan A. Lindsay from hearing her murder trial.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The man in the middle of Washington's smoky room gossip these days is Big Ed Muskie of Maine. Much of the smoke is coming from the Senator himself, but suddenly all the pros in both parties are muttering against him, which is the treatment usually re served for the frontrunner.

title: Credit Markets: Treasury Set to Refinance Notes
description: The credit markets got jit tery yesterday as they awaited the Treasury's announcement scheduled todayof plans to refinance $8.44billion of matur ing notes. Bond prices declined, interest rates climbed and two major corporate bond sales ex petcted today were put off a week.

title: Delay by Transcontinental
description: The Transcontinental Invest ing Corporation said yesterday that its report on 1970 results would be further delayed pend ing a study of an unreconciled loss in its Transcontinental Music subsidiary. If the loss in the subsidiary cannot be recon ciled, the parent will have a maximum loss after Federal in come tax credits of about $5.5 million. The company said it could not determine whether the loss resulted from poor bookkeeping or other causes.

title: Nixon's Health Care Proposal Is Altered and Offered in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 President Nixon's longawaited health care plan to cover 200 million Americans was intro duced in the House today but not in the form that he had originally wished.

title: Connally Seeks $67.2Million To Audit More Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said today that he wanted the Internal Revenue Service to increase the number of Federal income tax returns it audits.

title: Armor Post to Patton's Son
description: FORT KNOX, Ky. April 27 (UPI)Brig. Gen. George S. Paton, son of the World War II general, became assistant commander of the Army Armor School today.

title: Ceylon's Student Revolt: Years in the Planning Stage
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 24 Ultraleftist revolutionary stu dents plunged Ceylon into guerrilla war this month after years of careful organization and planning. While they were planning their attempt to seize power, Government leaders ap pear to have viewed the stu dents as harmless idealists at best and as juvenile delinquents at worst.

title: Soong Rites Here Saturday
description: A funeral service for T. V. Soong, banking expert and longtime confidant of General issimo Chiang Kaishek, is planned for 3 P.M. Saturday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The 77year old Mr. Soong collapsed and died Sunday night in San Fran cisco after dining with friends. Death was attributed to food lodging in the windpipe.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CAPETOWN  Britain's equivalent of Vietnam was fought here in South Africa Seventy years ago. The cruel Boer War ruined the British reputa tion for international morality, lost the respect of foleign friends for considerable period, and stirred up hornet's nest of political opposition at home.

title: MISSISSIPPI VOTE HELD UP BY COURT
description: BILOXI, Miss., April 27A threejudge Federal panel ruled today that Mississippi could not implement a new open primary law opposed by Mayor Charles Evers of Fayette and other Negro leaders in the state.

title: Brancusi sculpture, The Kiss, adorns cover of sex booklet given to all students at Yale.
description: NEW HAVENWhen Lor na Feinstein and Philip Sarrel were teenagers growing up next door to each other in Belle Harbor, Queen, N. Y. they would often spend their summer afternoons reading the Kinsey reports to each other.

title: HAWKS TURN BACK RANGERS, 3 T02, IN OVERTIME GAME
description: CHICAGO, April 27  Hockey's powder keg, Bobby Hull, finally exploded in the Rangers' faces tonight.

title: COWAN DEFEATS JENARD ON LINKS
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 27 (AP)  The defending cham pion, Gary Cowan of Canada, led a parade of winning favor ites through the second round of the North and South ama teur golf tournament today on the 7,000yard, par72 No. course at the Pinehurst Coun try Club.

title: Leary Is Leaving A.&S. To Head Holmes Subsidiary
description: Howard R. Leary, former Police Commissioner of New York City, announced yester day that he was leaving his job as vice president of security at Abraham & Straus to be come president of the Holmes Security Corporation, a newly formed subsidiary of Holmes Protection, Inc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: Marcia Haydee a Spitfire of a Carmen
description: The thing that is most right about John Cranko's Carmen, given its Ameri can premiere by the Stuttgart Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is Marcia Hayde's spitfire per formance of Carmen. It is not enough.

title: Dio Given TwoYear Term For Mortgage Kickback
description: Frank Dioguardi, also known as Frankie Dio, of North Miami Beach, Fla., pleaded guilty yes terday to a mortgagekickback scheme for a $950,000 loan to build a hospital in Mid land, Tex.

title: Ralston, Drysdale, Stolle Advance in $50,000 Tennis
description: DALLAS, April 27 (UPI)  Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, Fred Stolle of Australia and Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., scored straightset vic tories in the first round of the $50,000 Rawlings tennis tourna ment today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 28, 1971

title: Korean Vote Count Gives Park Big Lead In Bid for 3d Term
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednes day, April 28President Chung Hee Park appeared today to be sweeping toward a convincing victory in his bid for a third term.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yes terday for the second consecu tive session in steppedup volume.

title: Reagan Asks Resignation of Unit Investigating Poverty Lawyers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 Gov, Ronald Reagan today called on a threemember com mission to resign if it did not intend to follow his prescrip tion for investigating Califor nia Rural Legal Assistance, a legal aid program for the poor.

title: Yanks Top White Sox in 12th
description: When the Yankees loaded the bases and failed to score in last night's 11th inning, it looked like last Saturday all over again.

title: Hearing on Army Ordered
description: WASHINGTON April 27 (UPI)  In a 2to1 decision, the United States Court of An peals ordered a lower court to day to hold fullscale hearings into whether the Army had overstepped its mission when it engaged in surveillance of domestic protest groups.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALI & NINO. By Kurban Said. Translated from the German by Jenia Graman. 237 pages. Random House. $5.95.

title: Pentagon Delaying A Nuclear Carrier in Budget Squeeze
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Pentagon postponed in definitely today its proposal to build a giant nuclearpowered aircraft carrier that was esti mated to be the highestpriced warship in history.

title: Stockholders Receive Diverse Reports as Corporations Hold Their Annual Meetings
description: The Continental Can Compa ny does not expect any real upturn in the packaging busi ness until the second half of this year, providing the econ omy shows a definite pickup, Ellison L. Hazard, chairman and president, told sharehold ers at yesterday's annual meet ing in the Biltmore Hotel here.

title: Coast Social Set Prepares for Boomtown
description: LOS ANGELESThe party that caps the social season for many here is in rehearsal. Rehearsal really is the proper word, for the annual Boom town Party, given by a philanthrophic group called SHARE, is a hybrid event half party, half show.

title: Bishops Assail Study Urging Marriage for Priests
description: DETROIT, April 27The American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church opened their annual spring meeting here to day with a flurry of criticism of an officially commissioned theological study calling for the ordination of women and free dom for priests to marry.

title: From a Puerto Rican Prison
description: SAN JUANI am writing from jail in Puerto Rico, the last classical colony in Latin America. The slave master relation, Ti whatever form, negates that which separates human being from animals: freedom.

title: Suit Asks Delay in Takeover Of U.S. Trains by Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)A suit was filed today in Federal District Court to de lay for at least 30 days the scheduled takeover Saturday of most of the nation's passenger trains by a Governmentbacked corporation.

title: G.M. Profit Climbs 75%;
description: DETROIT, April 27The Gen eral Motors Corporation an nounced today that both unit and dollar sales for the first quarter of 1971 were the highest for any quarter in thel corporation's history, while profits were the third highest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ARABS WARN PARIS ON AN OIL EMBARGO
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 A call by two French petroleum companies for a worldwide em bargo against Algerian oil has evoked Arab warnings of coun termeasures.

title: Mets Subdue Cards, 21, As Koosman Gets Victory
description: ST.. LOUIS. April 27  The New York Mets, who disposed of Bob Gibson inside of four innings last night, took a little longer with Steve Carlton to night. But they still survived a hairraising ninth inning to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 21, and send Carlton to his first loss of the season.

title: HOUSE UNIT WARNS ON AID OVERHAUL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The House Foreign Affairs Committee warned today that there was virtually no chance that the President's $3.2billion foreign aid reorganization plan would be passed in this ses sion.

title: JAPAN TO DOUBLE SPENDING ON ARMS
description: TOKYO, April 27  Japan's Defense Agency announced plans today for more than doubling the nation's expendi ture on its armed forces in the five years beginning next April 1.

title: At ParkeBernet, It's Called Erotica, Not Pornography
description: Pornography for the mass es is for sale on 42d Street, but erotica for the moneyed classes went on auction yes terday at ParkeBernet Gal leries, 980 Madison Avenue.

title: Arraignment at Arrest Site
description: A 23yearold man was ar raigned in Criminal Court yes terday on misdemeanor charges of possessing noxious materials after a guard allegedly discov ered him trying to hide aerial magnesium flares inside a fire hose in the Criminal Court Building, 100 Centre Street. Lee R. Colon of 10 Manhattan Ave nue, was released on parole after arraignment inside the same building where he had been arrested about 11 A.M.

title: Dr. Land Introduces 2 Camera Models
description: NORWOOD, Mass., April 27Dr. Edwin H. Land, the man who invented the Pola roid Land camera, held a news conference today. That may not sound like a big news story, but for the shy 61yearold scientistbusi nessman, it was something of an innovation.

title: Law Agency Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Dean Pohlenz, administrative assistant to Senator Roman L. Hruska, Republican of Nebraska, was named today as assistant administrator of the Law En forcement Assistance Adminis tration.

title: Enemy Shells Bases 4th Consecutive Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 28 (AP) Enemy gunners, taking advan tage of a period of moonless nights, staged small shelling at tacks against allied installa tions early yesterday for the fourth consecutive day.

title: 3 Realist Artists' Work Shown by 2 Museums
description: If, by a wild stretch of the imagination, the Brooklyn Museum and the Studio Mu seum in Harlem were reck oned as the pulsebeat and showcase of the contempo rary art trend, realism would now be in high ascendancy. This week the Studio Museum on Fifth Avenue at 125th Street opened an exhibition of Benny Andrews, and the Brooklyn Museum inaugu rated a joint exhibition of David Levine and Aaron Shikler All three artists are committed exponents of real ist art.

title: Gulf Angola View Wins
description: ATLANTA, April 27  Gulf Oil Corporation stockholders overwhelmingly rejected today four proxy proposals submit ted by a dissident group who accused Gulf of perpetuating Portuguese colonialism in Af rica.

title: Ballet: City Troupe Opens Its Season
description: To the 17thcentury Eng lish divine, Thomas Fuller, we owe the following intel ligence connected with the opening last night at the State Theater of the New York City Ballet.

title: Tito Due to Meet Leaders Today in Crisis
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27Preparations for a meeting of Yugoslavia's top Communists are taking place in an atmos phere mingling secrecy and alarm.

title: E.E.C. Ministers Meet
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, April 27  Finance Minister Valerie Giscard d'Estaing, of France suggested at a 5hour meeting of Common Market ministers that the dollar should be devalued through an in crease in the official $35an ounce price of gold, sources at the meeting disclosed.

title: Eastman Shows LowLight Color Film; Instant Pictures Promised in Future
description: FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 27The Eastman Kodak Company demonstrated new lowlightlevel, color mo tionpicture film here today, but promised an instant camera only for some future time.

title: Relief Expansion Slows
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)Latest welfare statistics released today show the first significant slowing since mid 1969 in the booming expansion of relief rolls.

title: Challengers Reach Impasse on Format Of Yachting Trials
description: LONDON, April 27 .(AP) Yachtsmen from Britain, France and Canada failed to day to agree on a formula for elimination races to decide who will challenge the United States for the America's Cup.

title: 200 Riot in Newark Jail Over Conditions
description: NEWARK, April 27Prison ers rioted today in the Essex County Jail, assaulting guards, destroying furniture and set ting a series of small fires.

title: Jerusalem Aide Stirs Uproar Over 68 View on City's Status
description: JERUSALEM, April 27Some members of the Jerusalem City Council demanded tonight the removal of Mayor Teddy Kol lek's acting deputy for develop ment and planning when'it was reported that he shad advocated returning part of. Jerusalem to Arab sovereignty.

title: Alarm Concern Making Refunds
description: The city's Consumer Af fairs Department said yester day that it had gotten a con sent agreement requiring a burglaralarm company that had been selling doortodoor in slum areas here to refund more than $125,000 to its customers.

title: Connally Says Politics Inspires Critics of Tax Cut for Business
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. charged today that political considerations had motivated the recent at tacks by Democrats and some lawyers and economists on the Nixon Administration's plan to reduce business taxes by some $3billion a year.

title: McGovern Would Let Reds in Southeast Asia
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 27 (AP) George S. Mc Govern told a university cam pus audience here tonight that if he was elected Presi dent, he would never again commit American troops to Southeast Asia, even in the face of a Communist take over.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater: Two by Austria's Handke
description: Peter Handke, the young avantgarde Austrian writer, has said that the basic idea behind his plays is making people aware of the world of the theaternot of the out side world. In his theater objects are deprived of their normal function in reality. They have an artificial func tion in the game I force them to play. To the untutored eye, Handke is playing mini mal theater. But for him it is close to total theater, since everything  the word, the sentence, as well as the object  is, in his word, dramaturgy.

title: Trail Blazer in Navy Samuel Lee Gravely Jr.
description: Man in the News

title: BETTING ON DERBY OPENS HERE TODAY
description: Offtrack betting's Mint Julep Special will prance onto the track here today to the bugling of fullpage advertisements headed: Psssssst. Wanna Bet on the Kentucky Derby?

title: GEORGE HAGGARTY, GOLF TITLIST AT 63
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 27 George Haggarty, an investor and in recent years a leader in senior golfing, died last night of leukemia in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 68 years old and had homes at Delray Beach and at Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich.

title: DirtTrack Auto Racing Buried With Paving of Columbia Track
description: About Motor Sports

title: Law Center Criticizes Proposal To Reorganize Regulatory Units
description: WASHINGTON, April 27. The Center for Law and Social Policy, a public interest law firm, criticized today the pro posals of a presidentially ap pointed council for the reor ganization of the Government's regulatory agencies.

title: Aborigines Lose Land Claim Suit in Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, April 27Australia's 160,000 abori gines have no legal title to their ancient tribal lands, ac cording to judgment handed down in the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory in Alice Springs today.

title: Nixon News Conference Set for Tomorrow Night
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)President Nixon will hold a White House news conference Thursday at 9 P.M. that will be open to live radio and television coverage.

title: ROCKEFELLER URGES EASED RENT CURBS
description: ALBANY, April 27Gover nor Rockefeller called today for a substantial relaxation of the rent control laws covering New York City and the rest of the state.

title: Hawaiian Leper Colony Afflicted by Fear of Change
description: The Talk of Kalaupapa

title: Mediator Is Appointed Maritime Coordinator
description: Robert E. Kennedy, a com missioner in the New York office of the Federal Media tion and Conciliation Service, has been appointed national maritime coordinator by J. Curtis Counts, director of the service.

title: Earnings Up at U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yes terday that firstquarter earn ings rose 14.7 per cent from the yearearlier level on slight ly lower sales.

title: Nevada Hit by Quakes
description: RENO, April 27 (AP)A series of short, sharp earth quakes shook the Sierra Ne vada around Lake Tahoe last night. There were no reports of damage.

title: CONGRESS STUDIES 2 CONSUMER BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Congress got to work today on two major consumer protection bills with the Nixon adminis tration renewing its opposition to, both of them.

title: COUNCIL IS UPSET BY PENSION BILL
description: Embarrassed by the introduc tion at Albany of a pension in crease for City Councilmen during a period of municipal financial crisis, Council leaders denounced the plan yesterday.

title: DR. E. H. KILLIIEFFER, EXPERT ON TARIFFS,
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 27 Dr. Elvin H. Killheffer, an authority on tariffs and inter national trade, died yesterday at his home near Stuart, Fla., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: APPEAL PLANNED ON WIRETAP CURB
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Justice Department said today that it would appeal to the Supreme Court the ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the. Sixth Circuit that the Government may not wire tap domestic groups sus pected of subversion without advance approval by a court.

title: MORE PRIESTS URGED FOR ROME'S SLUMS
description: ROME, April 27Pope Paul VI's vicar for Rome called to day for a missionary effort in the city to win its deChris tianized masses back for the church.

title: New Barium Cloud Test Set
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The next attempt to launch a Germandesigned barium cloud experiment from Wallops Is land, Va., will be made in the May 2024 period, the National Aeronautics and Space Ad ministration said today. Cloud conditions last night forced a fifth postponement of the ex periment.

title: Raymond Blattenberger Is Dead; Was Public Printer During 50's
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., April 27 Raymond Blattenberger, who was Public Printer in the Eisen hower Administration, died yes terday in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Camden after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 445 Pelham Road.

title: Tennessee Primary in 72 Approved by Legislature
description: NASHVILLE, April 27  A Presidential preference primary in Tennessee next May 4 to select and instruct delegates to the national nominating con ventions was approved today by the state legislature.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly com petitive sale of ninemonth and oneyear securities today.

title: 10,000 City Workers Go To Albany to Protest Cuts
description: ALBANY, April 27Ten thou sand New York City employes came to the Capitol here today seeking restoration of budget cuts that have threatened many with the loss of their jobs.

title: DEMOCRATS CLEAR PUBLIC JOBS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Democrats dealt President Nixon's revenuesharing plan another blow today as they pushed through the House Edu cation and Labor Committee their own program of public service jobs for the unem ployed.

title: HATFIELD ASKS LIMIT ON CONGRESS TERMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Unlike most members of Con gress who work to perpetuate their Washington service, Sen ator Mark O. Hatfield proposed today that no Senator or Rep resentative be allowed more than 12 consecutive years in office.

title: Tientsin Doctor of Acupuncture Says His Needles Cure Many Ills
description: TIENTSIN, China, April 24 The husky young woman, a weaver at the No. 1 Tientsin Carpet Factory, lay watching placidly as Dr. Nyi Fujung pulled 12 acupuncture needles from her stomach, left, leg and knee joint.

title: New Delhi Charges Pakistanis Raid Village in India and Kill
description: NEW DELHI, April 27 (AP) Some Pakistani soldiers who have been fighting separatists in East Pakistan reportedly crossed into India today and exchanged fire with Indian se curity forces.

title: Virginia Forests Closed
description: RICHMOND, April 27 (UPI) All Virginia parks and forest lands were closed today by Gov. Linwood Holton because of an 'extraordinary fire haz ard in the state. Several thou sand acres of timber have burned in Virginia during the last three dry weeks. The Weather Bureau forecast rain for tomorrow.

title: 4th Volume of Soviet Encyclopedia Shows OpenMindedness on the Arts
description: MOSCOW, Apil 27  The fourth volume of the new 30 volume Soviet Encyclopedia is out, and the game of second guessing its editors on politi cally sensitive subjects contin ues.

title: 3 in Senate Offer Bill To Permit Girl Pages
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)Three Senators seek ing to break the tradition of allmale pages introduced legislation today that would prohibit sex discrimination in hiring the young aides for members.

title: Mrs. Clara Spector Noble, Knitting Firm CoFounder
description: Mrs. Clara Spector Noble, co founder with her husband, the late Israel Noble, of the Noble Knit Manufacturing Company in 1943, died Monday evening in the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, LI., after a brief illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 11050 71st Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Phelps Considered by Rutgers And Penn for Basketball Coach
description: Rutgers has joined Pennysl vania in considering Dick Phelps of Fordham as a can didate for basketball coach.

title: Jets Sign Snell to a OneYear Contract
description: Matt Snell signed a contract yesterday to play fullback for the Jets for what he said might be his last season. The club also announced the signing of Al Atkinson, the defensive cap tain, and Coach Weeb Ewbank said Joe Namath had promised he would report to training camp on time.

title: PRIORITY IS GIVEN PAYMENTS POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Secretary of the Treasury and a member of the Federal, Reserve Board both firmly re jected today a policy of benign neglect for the nation's bal ance of international payments.

title: LESTER DONIGER, EXPUBLISHER 61
description: Lester L. Doniger of 26 Wild wood Drive, Great Neck, L. I., editor, publisher and business executive, died yesterday in University Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

title: ADOPTIVE PARENTS LOSE LENORE SUIT
description: A Federal judge yesterday turned down a new effort by a Brooklyn couple to keep cus tody of die baby girl named Lenore they adopted 10 months ago.

title: Southwest Forest Plans Bid for Intermountain Co.
description: J. B. Edens, chairman of Southwest Forest Industries, Inc., of Phoenix, announced yes terday an agreement in princi ple under which his company intends to make an offer for the Intermountain Company, Missoula, Mont., maker and marketer of lumber products.

title: Flood Leaves Baseball; Cites Personal Problems
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)Curt, Flood, the Wash ington Senators' center fielder, quit baseball today with the explanation to the team's own er, Bob Short, that he had very serious personal prob lems mounting every day.

title: Educator Takes New Post
description: Dr. Ralph Lee, the director of the Queens College SEEK (Search for Education, Eleva tion and Knowledge) program has been named president of Forest Park Community Col lege in St. Louis, effective Aug. 1, 1971. Forest Park Community College is eight years old and has an enrollment of 6,000 students.

title: Goodell Heads Drive To Raise $1Million For Urban League
description: Former Senator Charles E. Goodell will head a drive to raise $1million to help meet the yearly operating costs of the New York Urban League. The drive will start today.

title: Music: Art of the Lied
description: There is a type of singer, often firstclass and often English, who seems happiest when presenting a prograni that rises to its blithest in such numbers as Purcell's In the black, dismal dungeon of despair.

title: First Billboard Razed Under 1965 Road Law
description: FREEPORT, Me., April 27 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe and Gov. Ken neth M. Curtis participated in a ceremony here today mark ing the first removal of a bill board under the Federal High way Beautification Act of 1965.

title: LEX LINDSAY, STAGE AND SCREEN ACTOR,69
description: HOLICONG, Pa., April 27  Lex Lindsay, a retired actor of stage and screen, died Saturday in Doylestown Hospital after a short illness at the age of 69.

title: Executive Changes
description: J. J. Newberry Company announced yesterday the election of Robert W. Conley as president of J. J. Newberry Canadian Ltd. Leslie A. Raphael was made vice president of the Sweet Sixteen Division; William C. Wright, to vice president the Gault Brothers, Ltd. division; Lee Schwenk, named vice president of the United Stores of Canada division; and Sidney Harrison, will be vice president of the Harrison Famous Fabrics division. All four vice presidents will report to Mr. Conley.

title: Concerns in Many Cities Leaving for the Suburbs
description: When the General Dynam ics Corporation announced two months ago that it was moving its national headquarters out of the city, New York's loss appeared to be St. Louis's gain as the company announced:

title: Nixon Plans to Name First Black Admiral
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Appointment of the first black admiral in the history of the United States Navy will take place soon, Secretary of De fense Melvin R. Laird said today.

title: Mrs. John McCormack Is Dead; Widow of Famed Tenor Was 84
description: DUBLIN, April 27Mrs. Lily Foley McCormack, widow of John McCormack, the great Irish tenor, died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 84 years old and had been ill since last May.

title: Retaliation by India
description: NEW DELHI, April 27In dia, charging that Pakistan had virtually interned Indian diplo mats in Dacca in theirhouses, ordered strict police vigilance today on the movements of Pakistani diplomats in Calcutta.

title: MSGR. CLEMENT RIEGER
description: Msgr. Clement J. Rieger, pastor emeritus of St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., died Monday in Frances Schervier Home and Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Science Unit Widens Membership Scope
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The National Academy of Sci ences, regarded as the nation's foremost scientific group, de cided today to increase sharply its membership from the ranks of leaders in medical, social and behavioral research.

title: ADM. W. N. THOMAS, EXCHAPLAIN CHIEF
description: LAKE JUNALUSKA, N. C., April 27 (AP)Rear Adm. Wil liam N. Thomas, retired chief of Navy chaplains, died today in a rest home. He was 79 years old.

title: SHERIFF CRITICIZED ON HOBART DISORDER
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., April 27 (AP)A special grand jury, in a report made public today, sharply criticized the Ontario County Sheriff for his handling of an undercover agent and disorder at Hobart College.

title: Eiichi Nishimura, Leader Of Japan's AntiRed Party
description: TOKYO, April 27  Eiichi Nishimura, chairman of the Democratic Socialist party, died of a cerebral hemorrhage today. He was 67 years old and had been ill five months.

title: Kotouc Cleared on One Charge But Maiming Accusation Stands
description: ATLANTA, April 27  The military judge in the Army courtmartial of Capt: Eugene M. Kotouc directed a verdict of acquittal today in one of two charges that the Government has brought against the stocky career officer.

title: Earnings Reports Issued by Major Corporations Reflect an Irregular Pattern
description: Profits reported yesterday by major corporations showed an irregular pattern.

title: AILEY'S DANCERS CRACKLING AGAIN
description: Sheer performing electricity flashing and crackling around stage is the notsosecret weap on of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, which opened its brief twoweek season last night at New York City Center.

title: Chiang Doubts Big Change In U.S.Peking Relations
description: Generalissimo Chiang Kai shek said in a television inter view yesterday that he thought there would be no substantial change in relations between the Chinese Communists and the United States, and he again predicted that he would return to govern the mainland.

title: Soviet Calls on Developing Countries To Form United Fronts Like Chile's
description: MOSCOW, April 27The So viet Union today called on de veloping countries to follow Chile's example and create unit ed fronts of Communists and others favoring noncapitalist systems.

title: Campaign Cost Reform
description: News Analysis

title: Rise in Men's Wear Sales Seen for Summer and Fall
description: A significant increase in men's wear buying at the wholesale level will be reflect ed in greatly improved sales this summer and fall, James T. O'Neal, president of the Na tional Association of Men's and Boys' Apparel Clubs, Inc., said yesterday at a news con ference. Retailers have be come accustomed to the new styles, he added, and have ad justed their buying schedules to meet demand.

title: Bethlehem Steel Raises Earnings 17% in Quarter
description: WILMINGTON, Del., April 27Earnings of the Bethle hem Steel Corporation rose 17 per cent in the first quarter, compared to income in the 1970 period, the concern's annualmeeting was told here today. Stewart S. Cort, chairman and chief executive officer of Bethlehem, the nation's sec ond largest steel producer, said profit in the latest quar ter was $33.1million, or 75 cents a share, up from a re stated $28.3million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: U.S. Sues to Void Merger Of Hannifin and Schultz
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)The Government filed suit today to void a purchase that joined the nation's two leading manufacturers of fuel system components for in flight refueling of military air craft.

title: Hotel Rents for Welfare Clients And Length of Stay Cut by State
description: The state ordered a limit yes terday for the first time on both rent and length of stay for welfare recipients in hotels$5 a person a day as top rent, and six months as the allowable stay.

title: Con Edison Net Up; N.Y. Telephone Off
description: Firstquarter earnings were up for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., but down for the New York Telephone Company as the two giant utilities released their re sults for the period yesterday.

title: Some Companies'Earnings Reflect Economic Upturn
description: A group of the nation's larg est business enterprises an nounced their financial results yesterday for the first quarter of 1971, indicating for the most part that prosperity has re turned to the corporate world after a year's absence.

title: Advertising:
description: Herbert Maneloveg, one of the bestknown media men in the advertising business, is joining McCannErickson in the newly created position of director of media services.

title: Surrender Day Decided
description: COLOMBO, April 27 (Reu ters)  The Government to day fixed Saturday as the day for insurgents to surrender and accept the Prime Minister's pledge of reasonable treat ment.

title: Miss Edith H. Harkness Wed To Kenneth Mckinnon, Lawyer
description: SNEDEN'S LANDING, N.Y., April 27Miss Edith Hale Harkness and Kenneth Perry McKinnon, a Washington lawyer, were married last Saturday afternoon at the home here of Mrs. Rebekah Harkness, mother of the bride and patron of the arts. Mr. and Mrs. Lester S. Scott, brotherinlaw and sister of the bridegroom, witnessed the ceremony, performed by State Supreme Court Justice Morris Spector.

title: Copper Volume Hits 70 High; Prices of Futures show a Drop
description: Sales of copper futures reached a new high for the year of 2,322 lots of 25,000 pounds each yesterday on the Commodity Exchange (Comex) here. The previous high point was reached on April 13, when 2,139 lots were sold.

title: New Men in Executive Suites
description: It was a busy day yesterday for the men who paint the names on executivesuite doors as the White Motor Corpora tion, Texaco, Inc., the Ameri can Smelting and Refining Com pany and the Foster Wheeler Corporation announced major leadership changes.

title: A Private Air Force Helps Jersey Fight Fires
description: LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., April 27Fire Corn, this is Greystone Tower. Smoke at 115 degrees about three and a half miles out.

title: Deficit Is $2.71Million
description: In the first quarter of 1971 it was better to haul freight than to move people.

title: Karachi Claims Victory
description: KARACHI, Pakstani, April 27The Pakistan radio said tonight that Pakistani armed forces had destroyed all anti state elements in the entire coastal region of East Pakistan.

title: Dictatorship in Freetown
description: Siaka Stevens has tried to bolster his obviously shaky position by making Sierra Leone a republic and promot ing himself from Prime Minister to Supreme Chief of State with sweeping powers. He has thus gone back on numerous promises and departed from the last ves tiges of constitutionality, even though an obedient Parlia mentdominated by his partyendorsed the action.

title: Israeli ExOfficial Indicted
description: TEL AVIV, April 27 (UPI) Ezer Weizman, a retired major general and former Minister of Transport in the Israeli Govern ment, was indicted today on charges of manslaughter in the death of a pedestrian, Mr. Weizman was at the wheel of a car that struck and killed an 81yearold doctor near Tel Aviv on March 21, the police said. He is free on bail.

title: In Linens, Too, Style Isn't Static
description: Shop Talk

title: Saigon Orders Ouster of Writer Who Reported on  Tiger Cages
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27The South Vietnamese Government has ordered Don Luce, a 36yearold American writer, to leave the country before May 16.

title: 17 Japanese Killed in Fire
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, April 27 (Reuters)  Seventeen firemen were burned to death today while fighting a forest fire near Kure, 12 miles southeast of here. The firemen were re ported to have been trapped in the blaze, which raged for more than 15, hours.

title: International Computers Introduces a New Series
description: International Computers, Ltd., the largest nonAmerican data processingequipment manufac turer in the world, yesterday announced a new series of computers including four new central processors.

title: Mill Factors Tie Completed
description: James Talcott, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had formally completed its previ ously announced acquistion of the insolvent Mill Factors Cor poration for a :663million package of cash, notes and preferred stock.

title: Goodman Denounced by Democrats, Defended by G.O.P. on Budget Vote
description: ALBANY, April 27Demo cratic legislators made today what was described as an inn precedented personal attack against State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Repub lican.

title: Walcott in Sheriff's Race
description: CAMDEN, N. J., April 27 (AP) Jersey Joe Walcott, former heavyweight boxing champion has been named the Democratic nominee for Camden County Sheriff by the County Demo cratic Committee. Mr. Walcott, whose real name is Arnold Cream, was selected by the committee last night. He is presently Camden's Director of Community Relations. In 1968, he ran independently for the Sheriff's office in the Demo cratic primary, but was de feated.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS CEILING ON DRAFT FOR NEXT 2 YEARS 150,000 Annual Limit Urged Laird Predicts Calls of 10,000 a Month in 1971
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate Armed Services Committee took a step today toward restricting the unlimited Presidential power to draft troops by approving a ceiling on the number of men that can be conscripted in the next two fiscal years.

title: HOUGHTON RECEIVES SKOWHEGAN AWARD
description: Arthur A. Houghton Jr., president of Steuben Glass and chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was the recip ient last night of the Skow hegan Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney Award.

title: Cambodians Return
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 27 (Reuters)  Cambodian troops who reportedly have been fighting on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos returned to Pnompenh today.

title: Maddock* Rides a Winner
description: An apprentice made his Aqueduct debut a winning one yesterday when Donald Mad dock booted home Three Stable's I'm Your Boy in the fourth race.

title: STUDENTS HELPED TO PICK COLLEGE
description: More than a million high school students who annually take the college board scholas tic aptitude and achievement tests will be able to have per sonal data sent to colleges along with their test scores starting next fall, the College Entrance Examination Board announced yesterday.

title: The Quest for Justice
description: In any society, the quest for justice is an endless and often frustrating journey. In the middle of a war being waged against a cruel, elusive enemy in an alien country, this quest takes on nightmarish qualities. Yet in Vietnam, as in other wars in the past, the American armed forces have to measure their conduct against this country's laws and ideals. No other standard would be either practical or morally tolerable.

title: Dollars and Eurodollars
description: Economic Analysis

title: Altman Director Named
description: Ira Neimark. vice president and general merchandise man ager of B. Altman & Co. has been elected to the Allman board: A resident of Harrison, N. Y., he joined Altman's in 1069.

title: TV Finally Approved by South Africa
description: JOHANNESKIRG, South Af rica, April 27  The South African Government today ap proved the introduction of al television service.

title: Godson of Rivers Wins Race for His Seat
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., April 27 Mendel J. Davis, the godson and namesake of the late Rep resentative L. Mendel Rivers, Democrat of South Carolina, won a special election for his seat here today.

title: Joseph B. Schwartz, Judge And Prosecutor in Jersey
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., April 27Joseph B. Schwartz, a New Jersey workmen's compensa tion judge and former Assist ant United States Attorney, died late yesterday after sur gery in Houston. He was 66 years old and lived at 103 Lewis Street.

title: GATT Begins Trade Talks
description: GENEVA, April 27Govern ment officials of the major trading nations began here to night the private talks that will be a feature of the informal session to be held by the inter national agency that sets the guilelines for most of the world's trade.

title: Abortion Law's Foes Plan For New Debate on Issue
description: ALBANY, April 27Legisla tive proponents of repealing the state's liberalized abortion law made plans today for rehearing of the controversial issue, but they were unsure whether an opportunity for full. scale debate would arise.

title: East German to Hold Opera Seminars on L.I.
description: Walter Felsenstein, direc tor of the Komische Opera of East Berlin, will conduct seminars and opera demon strations and introduce show ings of two of his opera films on May 11 and 12 at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I. His ap pearance there will be spon sored by the Center for Con temporary Arts and Letters in conjunction with Stony Brook's music and theater arts departments and the Eastern College Opera Con sortium.

title: Pie Traynor in Hospital
description: PITTSBURGH, April 27 (UPI) Pie Traynor, a Hall of Fame third baseman and former man ager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, entered Allegheny General Hos pital for a checkup last night after complaining of feeling ill. The 71yearold Traynor com piled a career batting average of .320 in 1,941 games with Pittsburgh. He managed the Pirates from 1935 through 1939. Last weekend, Traynor was in his home town of Fram ingham, Mass., for a speaking engagement.

title: News Executive Out As Paper in Newark Reshapes Its Course
description: NEWARK, April 27George Kentera, executive editor of The Evening News here, re signed today. He will be suc ceeded by James Idema, who resigned recently as editorial page editor of The Denver Post.

title: They Lived Today's Ideas Yesterday
description: They are antiestablish ment, pacifists, vegetarians and have elected to wrest their living from the land through organic farming rather than compete in the frenetic pace of the urban rat race.

title: Reward in Capital Bombing Fails to Draw a Response
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)  A $100,000 reward posted nearly two months ago for information on the bomb ing of the United States Capitol has failed to draw a single response, the Senate Demo cratic leader, Mike Mansfield, said today.

title: State's Urban Development Chief Urges Power to Neighborhoods
description: The president of the State Urban Development Corpora tion yesterday proposed a massive decentralization of gov ernmental power back to the people in all their varied neigh borhoods.

title: HUNGARIAN VOTERS UNSEAT 8 DEPUTIES
description: BUDAPEST, April 27 (AP) Eight incumbents in the Hun garian Parliament were unseat ed by newcomers in the general election Sunday, according to the official results, announced today. Two incumbent deputies were forced into runoffs.

title: PROSECUTOR IS FIRM ON CRIMMINS REPORT
description: Despite a reported disclaimer by the physician, the Queens District Attorney's office in sisted yesterday that Dr. Lester Samuels, a prison doctor, had told them that he had heard Mrs. Alice Crimmins say three years ago: Why, why, why did I do it? They were my chil dren.

title: More Complaints Of Ethnic Slights Are Reaching F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)The Federal Communi cations Commission is getting a rising number or complaints that films and broadcast pro, grams degrade or demean eth nic or racial groups, Commis sioner Robert E. Lee said today.

title: CITY PURCHASING PUBLIC THEATER
description: The final scene of the some times stormy drama involving city purchase of Joseph Papp's Public Festival Theater was played yesterday at City Hall the City Council voted to buy the theater's building at 425 Lafayette Street for $2.6mil lion.

title: Court Rejects U. S. Move to Jail Man Out on Bail in Picket Case
description: Federal Judge Joseph C. Za vatt rejected yesterday the Gov ernment's move to jail Anthony Augello and to revoke his $60, 000 bail pending his appeal on 12year sentences for extortion and possession of stolen goods.

title: LAIRD SAYS SOVIET RENEWS ABM WORK
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that construc tion had resumed at one or more of four antimissile sites on the outskirts of Moscow aft er a break of about three years.be deploying multiple warheads on some large SS9 missiles was true.

title: Oil Concerns List Gains
description: The petroleum industry con tinued to show improved earn ings for the first quarter of 1971 as Texaco, Inc., the Phillips Petroleum Company, the Marathon Oil Company and the Getty Oil Company reported decidedly higher profits for the period.

title: REV. W. H. STEPHENS
description: CHATHAM, N.J., April 27 The Rev. William H. Stephens, a retired Methodist minister, died yesterday in a nursing home home here. He was 90 years old and lived at 16 Mercer Ave nue.

title: First National City to Offer LowCost Life Insurance
description: The First National City Bank, the largest in New York, an nounced yesterday plans to offer lowcost term life insur ance to its 500,000 savings ac count depositors. First National City is the first major commer citl hank to offer such a plan, but mutual savings banks for many years have operated life insurance departments.

title: Funds Asked for Study
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Senate Banking Commit tee voted today to ask $333,240 in Senate funds for the investi gation of the nation's stock markets planned by its securi ties subcommittee.

title: Capital Cities Announces Sale of Two TV Stations
description: The Capital Cities Broad casting Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold WSAZTV, HuntingtonCharles ton, W. Va., to Lee Enterprises, Inc., for $18million and WTEN TV, Albany, N. Y., to the Poole Broadcasting Corporation for $19million.

title: Grand Jury Here Calls Hoffa, But Testimony Remains Secret
description: James R. Hoffa testified be fore a special grand jury for more than two and a half hours yesterday in the closely guard ed United States Court House at Foley Square.

title: Canadiens Beat North Stars, 61, for 32 Lead in Series
description: MONTREAL, April 27 (UPI) Pete Mahovlich scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens took a 32 lead in the fourofseven game National Hockey League Stanley Cup semifinals with a 61 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Executive Arrogance
description: Attorney General Mitchell appears obsessed with the belief that only his right to tap wires without court war rant can protect this nation from subversion. As the country's chief legal officer he has placed himself a curious position visvis the law. The powers on which he insists have been held in violation of the Constitu tion, and a lower court's ruling to that effect has been upheld by the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati. Mr. Mitchell is now taking his case the Supreme Court.

title: Alas for Fish, Heron Back in London
description: LONDON, April 27The heron, that stately bird of remote waters, has become a resident of London.

title: Bohack Strike Settled
description: Striking retail clerks and managers approved a contract agreement last night with the management of Bohack super markets by a vote of 1,286 to 256, the union announced. The union membership ratified a tentative agreement reached Monday night at the offices of Local 1500, Retail Clerks Inter national Association, at 22101 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Vil lage.

title: THE KINGSTON TRIO RETURNS TO TOWN
description: The Kingston Trio, one of the foundation stones of the pop folk boom of the late 1950's, is back in business after a slight hiatus with the same old high spirits and fraternity house humor but with a partially new set of faces.

title: Unconvincing Civic Ambassadors
description: The city is desperately in need of more state aid, but we doubt that the thousands of municipal employes who massed outside the State Capitol in Albany yesterday did much to persuade, legislators of that need.

title: U.S RAISES ISSUE ON BIG BOARD RULE
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The Justice Department's anti trust division believes that some serious antitrust problems could arise from the planned change in the rules of the New York Stock Exchange that would, in the future, permit an individual or corporation to in vest in more than one member firm of the exchange.

title: Reed Enters Hospital
description: Willis Reed, the New York Knicks' center, entered Roose velt Hospital yesterday in prep aration for surgery today to repair his injured left knee. Dr. Andrew H. Patterson, the Knickss team physician, will perform the operation.

title: Proceeding Backward
description: There is a certain AliceinWonderland logic in ?? legislative history of the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay to Rye. First, Governor Rockefeller asks authority to build the span. The Legis lature, in order to push through an omnibus transporta tion bill, agrees. Next the legislators, hearing for the first time from their constituents, try to rescind the authorization and continue to try, unsuccessfully, for four years. Then the Governor orders a study, at a cost of $162,500, to determine whether the bridge is feasible and on the whole a good idea, following which the Legislature finally succeeds in passing, overwhelmingly, a bill to call off the whole project.

title: Bridge : Holton Remembered for Aid To Game Here in the Thirties
description: Tournament veterans recall with limited nostalgia the days in the thirties when it cost 25 cents to play in a local duplicate game. They were greatly indebted at that time to Jim Holton, who died last month at the age of 72. He contributed greatly to the development of tournament bridge in the New York area, especially in Brooklyn.

title: Defendant in a Plot to Kill Itkin Is Found Guilty in Stock Fraud
description: A Long Island lawyer who is awaiting trial on charges of plotting the murder of Her bert Itkin, a Government in iformer, was convicted of stock fraud conspiracy yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: ECUADOR MOVING TOWARD ELECTIONS
description: QUITO, Ecuador, April 27 President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra today began setting up a framework to let the voters ex change his civilian dictatorship for representative democracy by next year.

title: LOCKHEED'S NEED OF LOANS IS CITED
description: Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said yes terday that if the Lockheed Air craft Corporation was to sur vive its financial troubles, there would have to be a Govern ment guarantee of about $250 million in loans to he company.

title: MARKET RESUMES ITS TREK UPWARD
description: The stock market surged yesterday with alternating waves of speculation and profit taking but its main undertone was a yeasty strength not readily visible in the popular averages.

title: COURT ORDERS DELAY IN HOSPITAL CLOSING
description: A group of parents obtained a court order yesterday that temporarily blocks the state from closing a Lower East Side institution that houses their mentally retarded children.

title: Rival Banquet Protests Law Day Speech by U.S. Security Official
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 Robert C. Mardian, the Justice Departments chief internal security official, delivered to day the bar association's of ficial Law Day speech to 100 lawyers in a banquet room while three times as many law yers participated in a rival meeting in the adjoining room.

title: Favored Vegas Vic Takes Derby Trial
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 The favored Vegas Vic, run ning in the silks of Betty Sech rest and Charles Fritz, won the $21,400 Derby Trial today, and the accomplishment may have helped to reduce the topheavy field for the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

title: Sams Says He Was Calm While Torturing Rackley
description: NEW HAVEN, April 27 George Sams Jr., the prosecu tion's chief witness in the mur der trial of Bobby C. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins here, testified today that he had not lost his temper, nor been ex cited,, nor even perspired while he beat Alex Rackley with a stick and then scalded him with boiling water.

title: Market Place: Making the Best Of Waste Paper
description: While the rest of the paper industry is cutting up virgin timber to make pulpand experiencing a profits squeeze into the balancethe Fort Howard Paper Company has taken the wastepaper route to rising earnings.

title: Angela Davis Hearings Off; Appeal on Judge Pressed
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 27 (UPI)Judge Alan A. Lind say postponed the Angela Davis hearings again today after a stormy session in which he had to outshout her co defendant and in which her attorneys accused him of hold ing black defendants in a slave position.

title: Advertising:
description: Hill & Knowlton, which is one of the world's largest publicrelations agencies and which recently lost its chair man and chief executive officer, has named Richard W. Darrow, the president, as chief executive. John W. Hill, the 80yearold founder, has returned to the chairmanship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Railroads Go to High Court To Bar Selective Strikes
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)The nation's railroads appealed today to the Supreme Court a ruling that allows se lective strikes against a few carriers to bring bargaining pressure on the entire industry.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The International Federation announced its list qualifying standards for next year's Olympic Games Munich, and then Jesse Owens was encountered at a base ball game in Yankee Stadium. Or maybe it was the other way round, not that the order of events mattered even a bit. Yet an association of ideas was generated and it made for a jarring juxtaposition.

title: War Foes Lobby, With Permission, at Capital Draft Headquarters
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)Antiwar protesteri'but tonholed employes of the na tion's draft headquarters today with the blessing of the dirge tor. A few other demonstrators were arrested after spending the night in the office of Seno for Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the minority leader.

title: ROGERS BIDS CHINA BE CONSTRUCTIVE IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: LONDON, April 27Secre tary of State William P. Rogers called on China today to begin to play a constructive rather than disruptive role in South east Asia.

title: AlcindorRobertson Tour
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson of the Milwaukee Bucks will make a sixnation tour of Africa in June, the State Department said today. Accompanied by Coach Larry Costello, they will conduct clinics and give exhibi tions.

title: A Rein on Hot Pants
description: LONDON, April 27 (AP)The Royal Ascot, the annual horse race for high society, approved hot pants for women at this year's running. But then the Duke Norfolk, the Queen's representative at Ascot, heard about it and today said absolutely not.

title: Mayor Is Renominated
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 27 Charles S. Stenvig, the police detective who was elected May or of this city two years ago as a political independent, won re nomination by a landslide to day over two partisan oppon ents.

title: Playoff Marks in Reach of Bucks
