description: All sorts of recordbook op portunities beckon the Mil waukee Bucks as they take on the Baltimore Bullets tonight in Milwaukee in the third game of the final fourofseven series for the National Basketball Association championship. The game will be televised here at 9 P.M. on Channel 7.

title: 2 Children in Hospital 5 Months Awaiting Repair of Paint Peril
description: Two children have waited at, Lincoln Hospital for more than five months for the city to cover the leadbased paint on the walls of their tenement althotigh the children could have gone home two weeks after they arrived.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater Owner Mobbed on Free Day
description: Donald S. Rugoff, the the ater owner, spent all day yes terday giving away free movie admissions to celebrate the 50 years his family has been in the business. He was struck in the face several times by angry young people for his efforts.

title: PRINCESS ARMGARD
description: AMSTERDAM, April 27 (AP) Princess Armgard zur Lippe Biesterfeld, mother of Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, has died at her home at Diepen heim. She was 87 years old.

title: March Trade Surplus Up
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 The nation's surplus of exports over imports improved in March for the second consecu tive month but did not return to the high levels of mid1970, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Roundup: Aaron Joins Ruth, Mays at 600 Homers
description: Baseball's exclusive 600 homerun club admitted its third member last night Henry Louis Aaron, who came into the major leagues in 1954 when the Atlanta Braves were the Milwaukee Braves.

title: China and America: Beginnings
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The dramatic reversal in SinoAmerican relations, is far more profound than mere Ping Pong diplomacy. Current contacts are actually increasingly semiofficial in nature.

title: SNIPER WOUNDS 5 IN BROOKLYN SLUM
description: A sniper wounded five per sonsnone seriouslyas they lounged on a tenement stoop on a rundown street in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

title: Lindsay Announces 8 Nominees For the City's Taxi Commission
description: The names of eight proposed members of the new commis sion that will regulate the city's taxicab business were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Black Business: A Study in Failure
description: By all normal standards, black busi ness, once considered the hope of the ghetto, remains a national failure.

title: Newscaster Admits Error On Source of Hanrahan Data
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (UPI) State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan appeared again to day before a special grand jury that is reportedly considering indicting him on charges of ob structing justice in connection with the police slaying of two Black Panther leaders.

title: GRIM TASK FACES RANGERS TONIGHT
description: Deadly serious, a few Rangers worked out yesterday for what could be their final game of the season.

title: Hudson Legislator Asks Swivel for ytrebiL ssiM
description: TRENTON, April 28 (AP) A Hudson County legislator believes his constituents are getting the wrong impression of the Statue of Liberty and he wants the President of France to turn things around.

title: PAKISTAN REVIEW SET BY AID GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 A consortium of 11 nations, including the United States, plans to meet in Paris Friday to weigh the mounting fiscal and food crisis in Pakistan.

title: Mayor Invests $4 on OTB Derby Choice
description: With the towers of Manhat tan replacing the twin spires of Churchill Downs as a back drop, legalized offtrack betting on the Kentucky Derby began here yesterday.

title: METALS FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISES
description: Futures prices of metals rose yesterday in fairly active trad ing.

title: Canadian Oil Output Up
description: OTTAWA, April 28 (Canadian Press)  Canadian refineries produced 37,733,400 barrels of petroleum products in February, a 4.6 per cent rise from the 1970 month, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

title: STATE MAY BLOCK CHASE MOVE TO L.I.
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, has moved to block the plan of the Chase Man hattan Corporation to start a new banking subsidiary in Garden City, L. I., in suburban Nassau County.

title: RESERVE EXPANDING BOOK ENTRY SETUP
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday it was expanding its socalled book entry system for handling Government securi ties, previously confined to certain New York City banks, to those held by all member banks of the Reserve for the accounts of their customers.

title: RADICALS ASSAIL FULBRIGHT PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Representatives of a radical antiwar group accused the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee today of a lack of initia tive in ending the Vietnam war and called Congress the puppet of the madmen who are in power.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Berrigan Jury Charges Witness, Former Nun With Contempt
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 28 A Federal court handed down one contempt charge today and set further hearing contempt charges against five other wit nesses as a grand jury investi gation here moved through its second week of attempts to in terrogate reluctant witnesses.

title: IVAN LANGSTROTH
description: Ivan Langstroth, a pianist, composer and teacher, died Sun day in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 306 East 96th Street.

title: Pan Am Registers a Loss;
description: Pan American World Air ways, Inc., reported yesterday in a preliminary and unaudited statement for the first quarter, that it had incurred a net loss, of $23,876,000. This compared with a $19,558,000 net loss re ported in the same quarter a year ago.

title: Science Group Balks a Study of Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  The National Academy of Sciences accepted today a com mittee report calling the study of human racial differences a proper and socially relevant scientific subject, but it re jected a recommendation for taking direct action on such studies.

title: Israel Rogosin Is Dead at 85; Textile Man and Philanthropist
description: Israel Rogosin, a textile in dustrialist and philanthropist, who said he liked nothing bet ter than to teach others the knowledge he had acquired in his specialty, died last night at New. York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Allen hurst, N. J.

title: MAYOR DEDICATES BROOKLYN PLANT
description: Mayor Lindsay toured an assembly line in a huge, shell like structure in Brooklyn yes terday and exchanged greetings with some of the 1,000 em ployes at the dedication of the building, which will house an electronics factory.

title: Court Tells Police to Cut $50 Tow Charge to $25
description: A State Supreme Court Jus tice yesterday ordered the Po lice Department to cut in half the $50 fee for towing away cars illegally parked in mid town Manhattan.

title: Laird Says Neutral Ships Would Evacuate P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reu ters)Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird said today he had been assured that ships of neu tral nations were available to evacuate prisoners of both sides in the Vietnam war if Hanoi would agree to transfer prisoners to third countries.

title: Trevino Puts Masters Back on His Tourney List
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 28  Lee Trevino, who sur prised the golf world by de clining to play in the Masters tournament at Augusta, Ga., the last two years, has changed his mind.

title: Ottinger Backs McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Although the Presidential pri mary season is nearly a year away, former Representative Richard L. Ottinger of New York announced today his en dorsement of Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: CAMBODIAN DRIVE NEARING KEY PASS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, April 29 (Reuters)  Cambodian troops under heavy attack reportedly fought their way yesterday to within two miles of a Government garrison besieged at a jungled mountain pass on Pnompenh's road link to the sea.

title: Police Threaten Suit
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 28 The New York City Police De partment's Traffic Squad Benev olent Association said today that it would seek injunctions in both Federal and state courts one hour after Mayor Lindsay lays off a member of the asso ciation.

title: BAYH, IN TALK HERE, SCORES NIXON AGAIN
description: Senator Birch Bayh of Indi ana, one of several seeking con sideration for the Democratic nomination for President, at tacked President Nixon last night for criticizing new isola tionists in the United States without specifying whom he meant.

title: Books of The Times
description: Like people who hate drinking alone, readers of mystery or suspense novels tend to urge them on you. They seem to feel a need, also, to defend the taste. Sus pense novels are often better written than serious ones, they tell you, which is like saying crossword puzzles are good for your vocabulary, or you follow Playboy for its fiction. Some years ago, Edmund Wilson expressed his irritation at this kind of proselytizing. In a crotchety article on the subject, he asked Who cares who killed Roger Ackroyd? To him, the effort of reading mysteries was like unpacking a crate of straw only to discover a bent and rusty nail at the bottom.

title: Bomb Explodes at Bank
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 28 (AP)A pipe bomb exploded outside the Bank of America branch at Kaiser Center in Oakland today, shattering a dozen windows. There were no injuries. Bank of America branches have been the target of 15 bombings and 17 burn ings since February, 1970. Asked why the bank has been a repeated target, a spokes man said today, We're as per plexed as anyone else except the people who are doing it.

title: Governor Names 2 To Court of Claims; One Is a Democrat
description: ALBANY, April 28  Gov ernor Rockefeller today designated two Queens men who were active in his re election campaign for State Court of Claims judgeships.

title: Screen:
description: That Hungarian blonde bonbon, Anna Gael, and Mac Ahlberg the Swedish direc torwriter, who previously teamed on intimate inspec tions of such liberated types as Fanny Hill and I, A Woman, now are overex posing Nana in a manner to which Emile Zola's clas sic, 19thcentury, lower depths hustler never was ac customed.

title: FRANK BUDGEN 89, JOYCEAN SCHOLAR
description: Frank Budgen, a close friend of James Joyce in his, most cre ative years, and whose own writings about the Irish author have provided others with many insights; died Monday in Lon don. He Was 89 years old.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, April 28One of the most difficult jobs in Government these days is held by Jim Dandy, Assistant Secretary of State for Balder dash and Guff, which are not, as the casual newspaper reader may suppose, obscure islands in the Arabian Sea, but highly spiced ingredients essential to a wellcooked foreign policy.

title: RAYMOND HOPPER, RESTAURATEUR, 63
description: Raymond F. Hopper, a prom inent restaurateur, died yester day in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y., after a long ill ness. He was 63 years old and lived at 54 Edgewood Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: METS BEAT CARDS 3D STRAIGHT TIME; GENTRY 91 VICTOR
description: ST. LOUIS, April 28The New York Mets, who regained their health this week on the banks of the Mississippi, made it three straight tonight when they overpowered the St. Louis Cardinals, 91.

title: Storm Scene Described
description: COLUMBIA, Ky., April 28 Douglas Frodge used to have a nice view from his farmhouse On a hill overloking Butler's Creek, the white frame Mount Pleasant Christian Church and two neighboring farms across Route 551.

title: Millions on Coast Ignore Peril of a Cataclysmic Quake
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., April 28  Only two and a half months ago a sudden thrusting movement within the broad network of the San Andreas fault cost 64 lives near Los Angeles, but today you would hardly know it. All along the 600mile fracture in the earth's crust, which has been generat ing severe earthquakes for eons, Californians are living as if there would never be another.

title: News of Dogs
description: Mention the names of Alan and Peggy Westphal to most dog fanciers and they will immediately associate the Bedford, N. Y., couple with dachshunds. And with good reason, for wire, longhaired and smooth badger dogs bred by their kennel have won 100 championships over 15 years. But now a silver buff cocker span iel is making her bark heard. Since last December, when she was named best in show at Wor cester, Mass., Ch. Sagamore Toccoa has become a top Westphal winner. On Feb. 28, when Peter Knoop gave Toccoa her second major all breed award, in a field of 1,268 at New Haven, he said: She is one of the greatest specimens of the breed I've ever seen.

title: Negotiators Meet Again
description: VIENNA, April 28  Soviet and American negotiators met today for twoand a half hours in the longest session yet in their talks here on limitation of strategic arms.

title: City Will Cut Off Hotel Rent Aid for 550
description: The city, decided yesterday to halt the payment of rent for some 550 single men on welfare who have been living in the controversial Greenwich Hotel.

title: Music: From Academe
description: When modern music, bleed ing from a hundred wounds, beat a retreat into the walled camps of our universities more than a decade ago, groups of skillful musicians who felt no antipathy toward experimental art began at taching themselves to these friendly institutions. One such ensemble, the Contemporary Group, founded in 1966 at the University of Washington, played at Town Hall on Tues day night and persuaded one that little a composer could compose would be beyond its Corporate expertise:

title: 2TO1 STOCK SPLIT IS VOTED FOR G.E.
description: MIAMI, April 28Stockhold ers of the General Electric Company approved overwhelm ingly today as expected a two forone split in the stock.

title: CANISIUS IS UPHELD IN BID FOR STATE AID
description: ALBANY, April 28 (AP) An appellate court ruled today that Canisius College in Buffalo should not be denied state fi nancial aid because of its ties with the Roman Catholic Church.

title: U.S. Urges Peaceful Solution for Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The State Department suggest ed today that one possible so lution to the dispute over the status of Taiwan would be a negotiated agreement between the Chinese Nationalist and Chi nese Communist Governments.

title: Step Is Taken to Avoid Upward Pressure on Longer Offerings
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Treasury steered clear to day of any longterm issues in a large May refunding offer, in a conscious effort to avoid put ting more upward pressure on longterm interest rates.

title: Goodyear Plant to Expand
description: AKRON, April 28 (UPI)  Goodyear Tire & Rubber Com pany announced today plans to expand and modernize its tire and rubber plant in Colmar Berg, Luxembourg, at a cost of $25million.

title: VORSTER BID GETS SUPPORT IN AFRICA
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 28President Felix Houphouet Boigny said today that the black nations of Africa should ac cept recent overtures from South Africa and join her in a dialogue free from reserva tions as a step toward chang ing that country's separatist ra cial policies.

title: The Park Lane, Midtown's Latest Luxury Hotel, to Open Saturday
description: There are paint cans in the lobby, ladders in the hallways, rubbish on the stairs, hundreds of unmade beds and thousands of yellow sheets still in stacks in the basement.

title: Korea Votes for Continuity
description: President Chung Hee Park's expected thirdterm victory in the Korean elections extends for four more years the firm rule of a colorless but effective military leader who first came to power in a coup ten years ago.

title: FoodStamp Plan Has Brought $43Million in U.S. Funds Here
description: The Federalstatecity food stamp program was reported yesterday to have pumped $43 million in Federal bonus funds into New York City in its first six months, while helping 850, 000 poor people to stretch food dollars by 40 per cent.

title: Unified University Asked
description: SALEM, Mass., April 28 (UPI)Gov. Francis W. Sar gent said today that Massa chusetts should consider es tablishing a single, unified state university system. We must reexamine the role of the state colleges as a group within the public higher edu cation system as a whole, Mr. Sargent said in a speech at Salem State College.

title: STARS TOP PACERS, WIN WEST PLAYOFFS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 28 (AP)The Utah Stars defeated the Indiana Pacers, 108101, to night in the seventh and decid ing game of the American Basketball Association's West ern Division playoffs.

title: 35 Newark Union Teachers Allowed to Return to Work
description: NEWARK, April 28 (UPI)A compromise settlement between community residents and New arkboard of Education officials resulted today in allowing back 35 teachers who had been barred from their school since the 11week strike ended.

title: COWAN IS UPSET ON LINKS 2 AND 1
description: PINEHURST, N. C., April 28 (AP)Peter Zaccagnino, a 49 yearold lawyer from Hartford, defeated the defending cham pion, Gary Cowan of Canada, 2 and 1, and Downing Gray won by the same score from Walker Cup player, Allen Mil ler, to share upset honors to day in the third round of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: The Piomotion List
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)  In addition to Captains Shepard and Gravely, these are the Navy captains whose selec tion for promotion to admiral was announced today:

title: Guzman, Mulligan Gain In River Plate Tennis
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 28 (AP) Francisco Guzman of Ecua dor turned back Martin Mulli gan of Australia, 75, 61, 6.4, tonight to move into the final of the River Plate Tennis Tour nament.

title: HusbandWife Duo Of Pianists Gives First Recital Here
description: A good wife is a steadying influence. That seemed to be the moral of the excellent two piano recital given by Ena Bron stein and Philip Lorenz in Tully Hall on Tuesday night. Both had appeared here in solo re citals some years ago. Miss Bronstein showed exceptional promise then; Mr. Lorenz was chastised for letting his rhythms get out of control. In their first joint program here, the hus bandandwife team played with a fine unanimity of tone, style and rhythm.

title: Kansas Students Reject Bid to Help University
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., April 28 (AP)Students at the Univer sity of Kansas have rejected a proposal that $130,000 of their activities funds be turned over to the university to help offset a budget cut made by the Kansas Legisla ture.

title: Lockheed Chief Optimistic
description: LONDON, April 28 (UPI)  The Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion's chairman, Daniel J. Haughton, met British officials today and said afterward he thought the RollsRoyce jet en gine for Lockheed's Tristar air bus would be saved.

title: Screen:
description: Slide over, Myra Brecken ridge. The British are now demanding equal time and room. They've made a dull, dirty, laboriously infantile sex comedy christened Percy, about a male genitalia trans plant. The film opened yes terday on the circuits, and it smells to high heaven.

title: The Nightmare of a Firefighter
description: Every fourth year or thereabouts the city's Department of Personnel gives notice that the filing period for the fireman's examination is open. I read such a notice recently, and a plethora of remembrances danced through my mind. I have been a fire fighter for eight years, but I remem ber the day I filed for the exam as clearly as a king remembers his coro nation, or a cardinal his elevation.

title: U.S. Won't Quarantine Future Moon Walkers
description: HOUSTON, April 28 (AP) The space agency said to day that future astronauts re turning from the moon would not be required to be held in quarantine for 21 days.

title: Office Queen Beats Favored Shuvee by 2 Lengths in Aqueduct Bed o'Roses
description: A gloomy, rainy afternoon at Aqueduct was nearly all gloom for Ron Turcotte yesterday. The talented, Canadianborn jockey, who was aboard Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee in the $32,800 Bed o'Roses Handicap, was beaten in the feature after being disqualified in the pre ceding race.

title: Nixon Wants More Wilderness Areas
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  President Nixon asked Congress today to add 14 areas to the country's wilderness system as a precious and irreplacable resource of human society.

title: FEDERATION PLAN IS BACKED IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, April 28In a re buke to critics of Egypt's plan to join a federation with Syria and, Libya, a leading Cairo edi tor emphasized today that the move was urgently required by military strategy against Israel.

title: SOVIET ANALYZES ALLIES' LAOS PUSH
description: MOSCOW, April 28 The Soviet Defense Ministry news paper, in an analysis of the recent Laotian operation, said today that the South Vietnam ese suffered heavy losses be cause American advisers un derestimated the opposing forces in the area and were caught by surprise by the in troduction of tanks and heavy artillery.

title: Boy, 2, Stabbed by Woman Let Into Apartment on a Ruse
description: A woman who was admitted to a Lower East Side apartment after she knocked on the door and asked for a glass of water yesterday stabbed a 2yearold boy five times in the head and fled, according to the police.

title: Prep School to Be Coed
description: NEW CANAAN, CONN., April 28St. Luke's School, a 43 yearold boys' preparatory school here, will become co educational this fall from grades 7 through 12. Mrs. James Smith of Wilton, who has headed the lower grades, has been named dean of girls it was announced today. Eric More, formerly of Shipley School, Bryn Mawr, Pa., was recently named headmaster of the nondenominational school.

title: Morgan Yacht Wins Race From Florida to Mexico
description: ISLA MUJERES, Mexico April 28 (AP)Encore Cherie won the St. PetersburgtoMex ico yacht race today despite finishing well behind the scratch boat, Ondine, in the 17yacht event.

title: Congressman Sees Deception in Ratio Of Noncombat Dead
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)Representati William D. Ford has said that the mili tary's explanation of a recent rise of noncombat deaths in South Vietnam has not allayed his suspicions that the Penta gon is engaging in a grisly numbers game to hide hor rors of the war.

title: When She Orders Food, She Calls Chicago or San Francisco
description: LOUISVILLE, KyWe had heard of Lydia Ling through her son, Robert, a young New York advertising executive.

title: CANARSIE SCHOOL HIT BY RACIAL DISORDERS
description: For the second day, racial disorders broke out at South Shore High School in the Canar sie section of Brooklyn yesterday after 125 black students staged a sitdown at noon in the cafeteria.

title: Personal Finance: Paring Food Bills
description: Inflation eats holes in any one's budget, like a mouse nibbling at cheese. Recently the pace has slowed a little, but the consumer price index was 119.8 last month, up from 114.5 in March, 1970, a rate of increase that works out to 4.8 per cent, seasonally adjusted.

title: Screen: The Ceiling
description: The Ceiling, a 40min ute semidocumentary by the Czechoslovak director Vera Chytilova, opened yesterday at the New York Cultural Center on a program with the Pavel Juracek and Jan Schmidt Josef Killian.

title: City Comes Up With Money for New Limousines
description: Financial crisis or not, the city administration has found more than $60,000 for new limousines for some of its highranking officials starting with Mayor Lindsay.

title: 9 Bombs Explode in Rosario
description: ROSARIO, Argentina, April 28 (AP)Nine bombs exploded in Rosario today, five at United Statesowned businesses. A po liceman was critically wounded.

title: POLICE ORDER END TO CRIME NOTICES
description: The Police Department has told its men to stop issuing lia bility notices to the owners of buildings in which there has been a gambling, narcotics or prostitution arrest until fur ther notice.

title: U.S. Files a Suit to Block Colorado Bank Acquisition
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today to block the acqui sition of the Exchange National Bank of Colorado Springs by First National Bancorporation, Inc., of Denver, the state's sec ondlargest banking chain.

title: Notes on People
description: Thousands of fans of Mont serrat Caball will not get to hear her glorious soprano at the Metropolitan Opera House next autumn. From London comes word that she is ex pecting a baby.

title: SATELLITE GAUGES XRAY STARS' SPIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 On April 12 the Uhuru, a com pact little satellite in orbit over the equator, recorded what sci entists believe were the effects of a cataclysmic event far out in the Milky Way.

title: Japan Rate Rise Forecast
description: TOKYO, April 28 (Reuters)  A Japanese news agency pre dicted today that the Bank of Japan would lower its discount rate by 0.25 per cent, to 5.5 per cent on Friday.

title: Man in the News
description: To the quiet, erudite stock broker who will take over next month as the publisher, board chairman and chief ex ecutive officer of The New York Amsterdam News, the step will be far more than a move from the General Mo tors Building on Fifth Avenue to a rickety, fourstory walk up in Harlem. The broker, Clarence Benjamin Jones, sees the acquisi tion of the news paper by the group of black businessmen he heads as a vital move in the black man's historical progression.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS CASE AGAINST SEALE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 28 The prosecution rested its case, against Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins at noon today, having called 11 wit nesses over the last six weeks in an effort to prove that the defendants helped kidnap and kill Alex Rackley in May, 1969.

title: State Will Start Reduction In Relief Checks Saturday
description: ALBANY, April 28Three fourths of the state's welfare recipientsmost of them bro ken families in New York City will have their relief pay ments cut as of Saturday, ac cording to figures released to day by the state Department of Social Services.

title: Rickover Says 17 Defense Contractors Have Violated Law by Refusal to Provide Information on Costs
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover charged today that several steel and computer companies had defied the truthinnegotia tions act by refusing to supply the Government with cost and pricing information on their defense contracts.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: YOU can unvell secrets of your future! Get a copy of How To Consult the I Ching. $6.95 at bookstores now. Putnam.Advt.

title: Chicago Ensemble
description: The climax of the New York orchestral season came on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall, courtesy of Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. Wagner's Das Rheingold, every note of it, was presented, in a concert version of course (otherwise it would have been the climax of the opera season).

title: Wage Level a Problem in China
description: PEKING, April 28Wage levels appear to be an unsettled and controversial question in some sectors of the economy of the People's Republic of China.

title: French Rescue a Chinese
description: PARIS, April 28A Chinese Communist technician, appar ently in a drugged coma, was seized by Orly Airport police men today from a group trying to take him aboard a plane bound for Shanghai.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Premiere of Choral Dances by Ailey
Market Place: Bit of Caution On Oil Outlook
description: Major oil, companies have sprinkled the financial pages with black gold over the last several days. Their earnings have been good by and large and longteem holders have probably sat hack reassured.

title: Georgia Pacific Plans To Call Preferred Stock
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 28 (UPI) Directors of the Georgia Pa cific Corporation decided today to call the remainder of a con vertible preferred stock issue worth nearly $90million at cur rent market prices.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Su preme Court has left a lot of people puzzled as to the net effect of its two recent major decisions, one on school busing and the other on housing. Taken together, what do they portend for the profound problem of racial divi sion in America?

title: DYNAMICS PROFIT SLIPS IN QUARTER
description: The General Dynamics Cor portation reported yesterday that its firstquarter net profit dropped to $4,553,000, equal to 43 cents a share, from $11,506, 000, or $1.09 a share, in the initial three months last year. Sales in the period were $456 million against $569,215,000 year earlier.

title: Heublein to Reduce Amount Of Shares in Merger Deal
description: Heublein, Inc., announced that it had proposed a reduc tion in the number of its shares offered in the planned merger with Kentucky Fried Chicken, The move was made to provide a reserve for nonrecurring losses that may be incurred by Kentucky Fried.

title: Hole in the Roof Over Rents
description: Governor Rockefeller's proposal for wholesale relaxa tion of rent controls in this city is as incomprehensible as it is disruptive.

title: AMEX LIST UP .03 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Trading was heavy on the American Stock Exchange yes terday with 8,202,840 shares changing hands, the busiest day since early February. However, at day's end the index was up only a little to close at 26.68, only .03 ahead for the day.

title: ProChina Reds in Italy Start Newspaper, Plan New Movement
description: ROME, April 28A pro Peking group that split from the Italian Communist party more than a year ago started publishing a daily newspaper today and announced plans for organizing a new political movement.

title: FEDERAL JOB PLAN GOES INTO EFFECT
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A tough Federal job health and safety program covering 57 million workers in more than four million places of employ ment went into effect today.

title: Flood's Goodby: I'll Go Crazy If I Don't Get Out
description: MADRID, April 28 (UFO Curt Flood, who quit baseball and the Washington Senators last night, arrived here from Lisbon tonight, registered in a hotel and refused to elaborate on his decision to leave the sport a second time.

title: California Standard Gains
description: Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California rose 16 per cent to $119,875,000, cr $1.41 a share, in the first qua ter of 1971, the company re ported yesterday.

title: Amsterdam News Is Sold to Black Group
description: The 62yearold New York Amsterdam Newsone of the oldest black weeklies in the United Stateshas been sold for $2million to an allblack group headed by Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sut ton and Clarence B. Jones, a lawyer and stockbroker.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Left Off French Team; Protests May Undo Action
description: PARIS, April 28A flurry of protests greeted the exclusion of a black Rugby player from an allstar French team that is about to tour South Africa. As a result, it now seems probable that the decision will be re versed.

title: Yankees and White Sox Rained Out at Stadium
description: The Chicago White Sox New York Yankees game was called because of rain early last night, setting up a dou bleheader on Saturday, July 17, beginning at 1 P.M.

title: 23 HERE AWARDED MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS
description: Of more than 1,000 winners of $1,000 National Merit Scho larships announced yesterday, 23 were New York City high school seniors.

title: EASIER PENALTIES IN MARIJUANA USE KILLED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 28  A bill proposed by Governor Rocke feller to soften substantially the penalties for marijuana of fenses was killed in the As sembly Codes Committee to day.

title: I.C.C. SEEKS TO BLOCK INQUIRY IN I.0.S. DEAL
description: Robert L. Vesco, board chair man of the International Con trols Corporation, has filed suit to block an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the company's financial dealings with I.O.S Ltd., it was disclosed yester day.

title: Political Inertia Compounding Cambodia's Government Crisis
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 28The Cambodian Govern ment crisis, now in its ninth day, goes deeper than the sur face calm of Pnompenh indi cates and it is causing profound concern to diplomats interest ed in a stable Cambodia.

title: Politics and Priorities
description: Secretary of the Treasury Connally, the Texas Demo crat who has a wellearned reputation for knowing a political consideration when he sees one, says the critics of the Administration proposal to cut business taxes by $3 billion a year are politically motivated. He directs this charge not only at Democratic politicians but also at lawyers and economists who have disputed both the legality and the economic wisdom of giving up $36 bil lion in tax revenues over the course of the next decade by liberalizing depreciation allowances.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES A 5YEAR TREATY FOR CURB ON AM'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Soviet Union has proposed to the United States a detailed fiveyear treaty limiting their missile defenses to 100 inter ceptor missiles protecting each nation's capital, Administration officials revealed today.

title: TV and Radio to Carry News Conference at 9
description: The following New York television stations will carry President Nixon's news con ference live tonight at 9 o'clock: WCBSTV (Channel 2), WNBCTV (Channel 4), WNEWTV (Channel 5), WABCTV (Channel 7).

title: Sports of The Times
description: As Julie Fink once told Sam (The Genius) Lewin, The public makes the favorites and the public is usually wrong. Buoyed by his recent offtrack betting success, The Sport agrees with Julie and The Genius. Betting on favorites like putting your savings in a bank without Federal deposit insurance. Or buying stocks. The Sport, as you remember, recently plunged, betting $2 at Grand Central Terminal on the CC combination for a daily double at Roosevelt Raceway. CC did not win that night, which damaged The Sport's investment projections, but it did win the following night, which convinced The Sport that once his timing improved his portfolio would prosper.

title: Rogers Says U.S. Favors Exchanges Of Newsmen and Students With China
description: He also said a visit to main land China by President Nixon might well be possible . . . down the road a piece if re lations between Washington and Peking continued to im prove and China began to com ply with the rules of interna tional law.

title: Mansfield Joins Drive to Delay Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, joined today the Congressional drive to postpone the start of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation at least six months and expand its schedule.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ThreeNation East African Community Imperiled
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, April 28 The East African Commun ity's common telephone service works so well that, from his exile in Tanzania, Milton Ohote, Uganda's former President, could easily dial a call to political conspirator in Kampala.

title: Suddenly, an Awareness
description: The New York City councilmanic pension bill which surfaced, suddenly, in Albany has been quickly aban doned by the councilmanic leadership. Majority Leader Thomas Cuite, who is usually aware of everything going on at City Hall, says he was unaware that such a bill had been introduced. Now that he is aware that a bill somehow traveled from City Hall to Albany con taining new benefits for members of the Council at a time of municipal austerity, he opposes it.

title: Investment Held Key to State Rent Plan
description: Governor Rockefeller's pro posals to relax rent control here are designed, state housing officials said yesterday, not to stave off abandonment of build ings in the slums, but rather to encourage private investment in buildings occupied by middle income tenants.

title: Earnings Decline Of 19% Reported By National Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, April 28 I George A. Stinson, president and chief executive officer of the National Steel Corporation, told the concern's annual meet ing here today that earnings in the first quarter fell by 19 per cent, compared to those of the 1970 period.

title: OneDay Sale of Nostalgia
description: Does anybody want a tall Spanish comb or a Heinz pickle pin or a dozen circle pins? A whole trove of these nostalgic treasures is going on sale Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the City and Country School, 165 West 12th Street.

title: Mudson Stars in Vadim's Pretty Maids
description: At least in the popular imagination, the French di rector Roger Vadim has gen erally been envied for his marriages more than he has been admired for his movies. But if you recall the achieve ments (in movies, not mar riages), with No Sun in Venice, Dangerous Ac quaintances, Blood and Roses, Circle of Love, Barbarella, etc., you will discover more good than bad. And even when bad, Vadim's sense of plot, place and character makes for work that is never uninteresting and, perhaps more important, insubstantial.

title: SMITH HARPSICHORD SHORT ON AUTHORITY
description: If good intentions guaranteed successful recitals, the one given by Robert Smith at Car negie Recital Hall on Tuesday night would surely have been laudable.

title: Two Arrested Here In Fraudulent Use Of City Dump Sites
description: The heads of two demolition companies were arrested yes terday on charges of selling and using $25,000 worth of counterfeit tickets allowing dumping at city sites.

title: ExG.I. Alleges 30 Slayings Near Mylai
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 A former Army sergeant said today that he took part in the killing of about 30 Vietnamese men, women, and children in a village called Truong Khanh, near Mylai, in April 1969.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1971

title: KOTOUC DESCRIBES MAIMING INCIDENT
description: ATLANTA, April 28Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc took the witness stand today at his courtmartial and used the outstretched hand of his pros ecutor to demonstrate how he had chopped off the end of a prisoner's finger.

title: MARSHALL S. FOSTER
description: MADISON, N. J. April 28 Marshall S. Foster, an associate In the brokerage concern of Spencer Trask & Co., died yes terday at his home, 32 Pine Avenue. He was 72 years old.

title: India, Alleging Pakistani Attacks Warns of Serious Consequences
description: NEW DELHI, April 28 Warning of potentially  ous consequences, India filed a strong protest with Pakistan todayover what New Delhi de scribed as several instances of unprovoked firing on Indian territory.

title: Wood, Field and Stream High Number of Snowmobile Accidents in Maine Is Cause for Concern
description: Snow is still on the ground In many parts of northern New England and warm spring rains are probably Ail that will bring an end to snowmobile accidents, says Maine's Fish and Game Safety Coordinator, John F. Marsh.

title: Students Clash in Venezuela
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, April 28 (Reuters)Demon strating students hurled home made teargas grenades at po licemen today, official sources reported. More than a dozen students were detained.

title: PRESIDENT NAMED UTILITY CHAIRMAN
description: Donald C. Cook, president and chief executive officer of the American Electric Power Company, the nation's largest investorowned electric utility, was given a new corporate cap to wear  that of chairman.

title: U. S. Judge Drops First of Indictments In U.M.W. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 A Federal judge dismissed to day the first indictment ob tained by the Justice Depart ment in a fivemonth grand jury investigation of the United Mine Workers of America. Government lawyers conceded that the indictment had been inappropriate.

title: Westminster Fund Tie Voted
description: Shareholders of the West minster Fund, a $55million exchange fund managed by the Anchor Corporation, approved yesterday the acquisition of all the assets of the fund by the Anchor Growth Fund.

title: TAX LAWYER SEEN AS NEW I.R.S. HEAD
description: Washington, April 28John nie M. Walters, Assistant At torney General in charge of the Justice Department's Tax Divi sion, is almost certain to be appointed Commissioner of In ternal Revenue.

title: Neighborhoods: Downtown More Than Just Wall Street
description: Every weekday, from early morning until midafternoon, a minibus leaves Beekman Downtown Hospital to fetch the elderly and infirm for treatment from Chinatown, Little Italy and the Spanish and Jewish areas of the Low er East Side.

title: Quebec Said to Plan Huge Hydroelectric Project
description: TORONTO, April 28  The Province of Quebec will build one of the world's largest hy droelectric projects along sev eral rivers that flow into James Bay, 500 miles north of Montreal, Quebec, sources said today.

title: Anaconda Reaches an Accord With Chile
description: The Anaconda Company, a major producer and fabricator of copper, said yesterday it has reached an agreement with Chile to buy 3,000 tons a month of blister copper for processing at its Perth Amboy, N.J., smel ter.

title: Yugoslaus Open Talks to End Disputes of Rival Nationalities
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 28President Tito and other Yugoslav Communist leaders opened talks today on how to reconcile differences between the country's rival nationalities and establish a new federal structure.

title: FRENCH MOVE STIRS RISE IN GOLD PRICES
description: PARIS, April 28  Renewed French advocacy of a higher official gold price stirred a fresh round of speculative buy ing of the metal today in Eu ropean centers.

title: Advertising:
description: Although the Department of Consumer Affairs hasn't decided yet whether it should require advertisers to supply substantiation of claims, it is sort of giving the idea a try.

description: To the Editor:

description: April 28, 1971

title: AMOCO IS ACCUSED OF FALSE GAS ADS
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., April 28 (UPI)The American Oil Com pany and 22 service  station operators in Suffolk County were charged today with sell ing leaded gas that had been advertised as leadfree.

title: WESTBURY TRIPLE RETURNS $4,704
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 28 The biggest triple payoff at Roosevelt Raceway came to night in the eighth race, with the 8.56 combination return ing $4,704.20 for $2. Don Rin aldo, from the No. 8 post, crossed the line in front to pay $12 in the win slot, Fargo Rich ard finished second for a $9.60 place payoff and Royal Avenue took third with a $10.80 price for show.

title: FEED'S NEW BALLET FEATURES NEVINS
description: THE GODS AMUSED (world premiere), choreography, Eliot Feld; music, Claude Debussy; costumes, Frank Thomason; lighting, Jennifer Tinton; conductor, Christopher Keene, Present ed by the American Ballet Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. With Daniel Levins, Elizabeth Lee and Christine Sarry.

title: GATT Nations Open Talks On World Trade Problems
description: GENEVA, April 28Member nations of the General Agree ment on Tariffs and Trade be gan today informal discussions on world trade problems in preparation for their next full dress assembly in November.

title: 400 City College Students Protest State Budget Cuts
description: Classes were suspended at City College for one hour yes terday as 400 students attend ed a rally prcrtesting the Legis lature's budget cuts.

title: Record in Commitments Reported by Fanny May
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) Interest rates rose yesterday as the Federal National Mort gage Association issued a rec ord $313.9million in mortgage purchase commitments.

title: GAIN IS REPORTED IN BUSINESS INDEX
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The Government an nounced another sign of ex panding economy today, re porting that its leading business indicators advanced for the fifth straight month.

title: MAUD UPSETS ROCHE AT DALLAS, 63, 63
description: DALLAS, April 28 (UPI Thirdseeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa moved into the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Rawlings tennis tournament to day with a 63, 76 victory over Owen Davidson of Australia. This is the fifth tournament on the World Championship Tennis tour.

title: COAST AID HEARINGS IN PRISONS PLANNED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 A commission investigating Gov. Ronald Reagan's criticism of a federally financed legal aid agency said today that it would hold hearings in two Cali fornia prisons.

title: HAROLD KELLY, HEAD OF RED BANK PAPER
description: RED BANK, N.J., April 28 M. Harold Kelly, publisher of The Red Bank Daily Register, died this afternoon, apparently of a heart attack, as he worked on the lawn of his home in nearby Lincroft. He was 60 years old.

title: TV: Filmed Biography of Beethoven
description: Opening shot: A closeup of a doctor peering into someone's ear. What is your profession? asks the doctor. Musician, answers the pa tient. You may need to change it, warns the doctor.

title: Tax Bill Aids Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) A bill designed to give a $750 tax advantage to homeowners who fix up their property was introduced in the House today with 106 cosponsors.

title: House Gets Bill to Expand Lending by Savings Units
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reuters)  A bill to expand the lending authority of sav ings and loan institutions was introduced today by the chair man of the House Banking Committee, Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas.

title: Surgery Is Performed On Reed's Ailing Leg
description: Willis Reed of the New York Knickerbockers under went surgery yesterday to correct the tendonitis above his left knee.

title: Mine Union Found Liable In Civil Suit Over Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A Federal district judge today held the United Mine Workers of America, its multimilliondol lar welfare and retirement fund and the unionowned National Bank of Washington jointly li able for millions of dollars in damages.

title: Stocks Advance Modestly;
description: The stock market made a modest advance yesterday in the third heaviest trading ses sion in history.

title: Japan's Proposal On Textiles Scored
description: The Japanese plan for con trolling textile shipments to the United States, scheduled to be gin July 1, was denounced yes terday as illegal under this country's antitrust laws.

title: Ashau Sweep Continues
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 29 (AP)  An Americqnbacked South Viet namese ground operation in the Ashau Valley area in the north ern quarter of the country en tered its third week yesterday. So far, however, no major con tact with the enemy has been reported.

title: Ivy Bands Play Here May 7
description: The concert bands of Harvard University and Princeton Uni versity will give a joint concert at Philharmonic Hall on May 7. Each band will play a group of selections alone, after which the two will perform together. The Harvard conductor is Frank Battisti. David Uber conducts the Princeton band.

title: Advertising:
description: The blackowned and op erated company that pub lishes Essence, a magazine for black women, has an nounced some top manage ment changes.

title: Helping Cancer Patients and Families
description: Cancer Care, of necessity, works with a fair amount of dispatch. Rarely does its relationship with clients con tinue more than a year, for they have reached the stage where there is little more that medical science can do. Last year more than 5,000 patients were aided.

title: Woody Allen Leads a 'Bananas' Revolution
description: If you twist its arm (and anybody canthe movie is small), Woody Allen's new film, "Bananas," proclaims that all of life is raw material for a television game show. It opens with Howard Cosell and the staff of A.B.C.'s Wide World of Sports enthusiastically covering the Assassination of the Week, that of the President of the Latin-American republic of San Marcos, whose expiration, on cue, highlights the week of festivities begun with the sacking of the United States Embassy.Some hallucinations later, the movie ends with Mr. Cosell hosting the on-camera consummation of a marriage, in the gold and white bridal suite of the Royal Manhattan Hotel, complete with instant replays and quarrelsome, post-encounter statements by the two principals.Woody Allen is incurably, hopelessly sane, and "Bananas," which began yesterday at the Coronet Theater, is, without doubt the best Woody Allen comedy I've seen since his last film, "Take the Money and Run." It's also an indecently funny movie, on its own, and in spotsa qualification I add with some hesitation because I'm not sure that its unfunny spots are terribly important.Thirty years ago, some very perceptive critics, including James Agee and Otis Ferguson, used to grow all sad and misty in print because W. C. Fields seldom made a movie that was as funny in its entirety as it was in its individual parts. Today, it doesn't make any difference. That was the sort of movie Fields made, and now we accept the rhythm of his comic genius, since it was an indispensable part of that genius.The same may well be true of Woody Allen who, when he is good, is inspired. However, when he's bad, he's not rotten; rather, he's just not so hot."Bananas," which was directed and written by Allen (with Mickey Rose), had to do with Fielding Mellish (Allen) a frail, sly New York products tester, who accidentally becomes the dictator of San Marcos, and with Nancy (Louise Lasser), the sort of new school girl who breaks engagements to participate in dock strikes and yearns for relevance in her relationships.Although it is cast in the comparatively classic, dumb-slob-who-succeeds narrative form, nothing in the story is so important that it can't be interrupted or forgotten for a visual or verbal gag, a variation on an old joke, some satire that takes reality to its outer reaches, or just a nice, crazy reference to a film classic ("Potemkin") that has almost been loved to death.Allen's view of the world is fraught with everything except pathos, and it's a view I happen to find very funny. Here is no little man surviving with a wan smile and a shrug, but a runty, wise-mouthed guy whose initial impulses toward cowardice seem really heroic in the crazy order of the way things are. "New York Rifle Council Declares Death a Good Thing," reports a headline. The comic world of Allen's Fielding Mellish, however, is more fanciful than bleak or black. When Fielding, in a reverie, hears harp music, there is a logical explanation: there's a man playing a harp in Fielding's closet.Allen is his own best actor, diffident and defensive, but I also like Miss Lasser (the former Mrs. Allen), who reminds me of a young Elaine May, and Carlos Montalban, as a Castro-like freedom fighter who, at his victory celebration, goes a little nuts and declares Swedish to be the official language.Any movie that attempts to mix together love, Cuban revolution, the C.I.A., Jewish mothers, J. Edgar Hoover and a few other odds and ends (including a sequence in which someone orders 1,000 grilled cheese sandwiches) is bound to be a little weirdand most welcome.

title: Governor, Citing Tax Loss, Sets A ContrabandCigarette Inquiry
description: ALBANY, April 28  Gover nor Rockefeller directed the State Commission of Investiga tion today to make a thorough examination of criminal involve ment in the cigarette industry, with particular emphasis on conditions in New York City.

title: 21 IN THE RUNNING FOR DERBY ROLES
description: LOUISVILLE, April 28The number of possible participants in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday remained at 21 today. The definitive rundown will be made tomorrow morning, when $1,000 will have to be put up by each interest contemplating the competition.

title: Roundup: A MiniMonster Keeps Saving the Red Sox
description: Ken Tatum, Carl Yastrzem ski and Sonny Siebert are turning the clock back to 1967, the year the Boston Red Sox won the American League pennant.

title: Bridge: Television Gets A for Effort On Aces' Match With AllStars
description: The televised bridge match Sunday on the Columbia Broadcasting System between the World Champion Dallas Aces and the Goren All Stars was a creditable at tempt to bring the tensions of highlevel tournament bridge to the viewing audi ence.

title: Executive Changes
description: Merck & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday the election of Dr. Antonie T. Knoppers as president of the healthproducts firm. He succeeds Henry W. Gadsden, who was elected chairman of the board, succeeding the late Charles S. Garland. Mr. Gadsden, who had been president since 1965, will continue to be chief executive officer. Dr. Knoppers was formerly a senior vice president. The company also elected Adolph G. Rosengarten Jr., to the newly created position of vice chair man. Mr. Rosengarten is the senior of the board, having first been elected a director in 1934 Dr. Knoppers' responsibilities as president will include the direction of Merck's activities in scien tific research and development, corporate planning, and corporate development. He joined Merck in 1952, and served as president of Merck Sharp & Dohme International from 1957 to 1967, when he was elected a senior vice president.

title: FOR BILLY DANIELS, THE MAGIC REMAINS
description: Billy Daniels is still putting out That Old Black Magic although his hair has turned to smoky gray. But nothing else seems to have aged about the singer who is appearing at Dangerfield's, 1118 First Ave nue.

title: News Analysis
description: NEW DELHI, April 28The Indians, with strong sympathies for the monthold Bengali inde pendence struggle in East Pak istan, are trying to keep theirl balance on a diplomatic tight rope, buffeted by a heavy wind.

title: Rail Retirement Improved
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a 10 per cent increase in monthly pensions and benefits for 1.6 million re tired workers retroactive to Jan. 1, 1971.

title: Her Love Of Fabrics Turns Into A Business
description: Inger McCabe is a house wife, mother and professional photographer. She doesn't particularly consider herself a woman of fashion, even though she might pull a big, dashing bright red hat over her curly hair when she goes to see an editor about a pho tographic assignment.

title: Superfecta Starts . . . by the Numbers
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 28  Superfecta, a word not to be found in any dictionary, will be added officially to the lexicon of harness race betting with the opening of Monticello Raceway's season tomorrow night.

title: 16 Die in Brazil Plane Fire
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 28 Sixteen of 81 passengers and crew of a Brazilian Air Force transport were killed this morn ing by an explosion in an eng ine. The DC6 had returned to Manaus, an Amazon river port, after engine trouble in flight. All aboard jumped onto the runway, but one woman re turned for a suitcase. She died with 15 of those who were showered by flaming fuel as the engine exploded.

title: Rockefeller Says the State Pays $36Million in Consultant Fees
description: ALBANY, April 28  Gov ernor Rockefeller released an inchthick list of state consul tants today and disclosed that the state was paying about $36 million in consultant fees.

title: SCHOOLS GET EDICT IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 (AP)A Federal judge ordered today that the San Francisco Board of Education produce a plan for full integration of the school district's 48,000 elemen tary school pupils in the next school year.

title: U.N. ENLISTS DUBOS FORPOLLUTION STUDY
description: The United Nations has asked Dr. Rene J. Dubos, the Pulitzer Prize winning biologist, to bring together the material that will be the basis of the first United Nations conference on saving the global environment.

title: Soviet Orbits Cosmos 409
description: MOSCOW, April 28 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched to day the 409th in its Cosmos series of unmanned spaceships, the press agency Tass re ported.

title: Girl, 19, Seized as Witness In Bombing of U.S. Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested a 19 yearold girl here last night as a material witness for a grand jury in Seattle that is looking into the bombing of the United States Capitol on March 1. They arrested her on a roof near a commune in which she lived.

title: Grateful Dead Draws FarOut Fans
description: At the Woodstock Festival, the Great White Hope of the 1960's, the audience was the whole show. This has not been the case since. Audiences have been generally morose. But the Grateful Dead has a way of bringing out the fancy in a rock audience and is doing so, magnificently, this week at the Fillmore East.

title: SHERMAN SON SAYS MIDAS FIGHT IS LOST
description: CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) Gordon Sherman conceded to day he had lost his proxy fight to wrest control of the Midas International Corporation from his 72yearold father, Nate Sherman, who founded the automobileparts company.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in holdings by major shareholders, directors and offi cers of their listed companies. The lists include the folowing:

title: News Analysis
description: Why is the fate of the radio and television facilities of WNYC important in light of the many other agonizing reduc tions that confront the city in the current budget crisis? Can one give a higher priority to municipal broadcasting than the maintenance of an institution for retarded children, the size of the police force or other essential services affecting individual resi dents? The torture of the decision is one of the heartbreaks of a city in depression: Everything has some claim to civic worthi ness, and making a choice is a fearful task. When it comes to the airwaves, however, one is not talking of a resource that, given better times or a closer legislative entente of New York, Albany and Washington, can be retrieved on command. The abandonment of channels on the air is akin to the sur render of portions of Central Park to building developers. Once done, the deed cannot be undone.

title: TRUST SUIT PLANNED ON HUBBELLPYLE TIE
description: A complaint by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice will be served on Harvey Hubbell, Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., the company revealed yester day. The complaint protests the merger of the PyleNational Company into Harvey Hubbell in a transaction valued at about $13million in stock.

title: The AllAmerican Robin
description: Is there anyone in this country who has never heard a robin's song? Probably not, even if it wasn't recognized, for of all our songbirds the robin is the most widespread. All summer the robins are busy in dooryard, pasture and uniodland of the northern and middle states from coast to coast. All winter they are seen throughout the South. Many of them winter in the thickets and marshes of the North, but the arrival of the migrant flocks from the South is an annual signal that spring is at hand.

title: Nassau to Fight State Order
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 28 The new limit that the state will pay toward rent for wel fare recipients living in hotels will mean that Nassau County taxpayers will pay almost $3 million more a year, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today.

title: Action by U.S. Relieves Credit Markets Corporates Gain
description: The credit markets breathed a sigh of relief yesterday after noon after they found that the Treasury had decided against offering any longterm bonds when it refinances $8.44billion of notes that mature in mid May.

title: Colgate Net Sets Record; President Is Named Chief
description: The ColgatePalmolive Com pany posted record firstquar ter results for the 11th successive year and expects 1971 will become the 11th consecutive year of increased sales and earnings, George H. Lesch, chairman, reported to more than 600 shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting at the Statler Hilton Hotel here.

title: More Seek Peace Corps
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)Applications to join the the Peace Corps, which had dropped steadily in the last four years, are now increasing, according to the agency. As of the week ending April 24, 19,180 persons had applied this year to become Peace Corps volunteers against a total of 19,022 for all of last year.

title: Wabash Cannon Ball, Rail Legend, to Rumble No More
description: ST. LOUIS, April 27 Nothing went right from the start.

title: U.S. Ties With Taiwan Lose Warmth
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 28 A formal correctness has crept into relations between the Chi nese Nationlist Government and representatives of the United States in place of the warmth that once existed.

title: Sharp Quarterly Advance Is Reported for G.M.A.C.
description: The General Motors Accept ante Corporation, the financial arm of General Motors Corpora tion, yesterday reported sharp ly increased net income from fi nancing of $23,342,000 in the first quarter, up from $13,012, 000 in the same first three months of 1970.

title: U.S. Jets Attack in North
description: SAIGON, Thursday, April 29 (Reuters)Two United States Navy F8 Crusader jets attacked North Vietnamese radardi rected antiaircraft sites 110 miles northwest of the demili tarized zone yesterdays the United States command an nounced today.

title: Aeolian Chamber Group Plays 1971 Music That Looks to Past
description: At best, music that quotes other music has a special strength. Sensitively used, it can be a way of heightening emo tions. The composer shares his own free associations with the listener in a way that doesn't distort the original music, but shapes it.

title: Rivers's Godson Wins House Seat, Fulfilling a Dream
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., April 28  Some of his childhood chums imagined themselves as John Wayne or Audie Murphy, but the dream that captured Mendel Jackson Davis was dif ferent.

title: Bucks Win 3d in Row, 10799
description: MILWAUKEE, April 28  With their unemotional pre cision, the Milwaukee Bucks dominated the Baltimore Bul lets, 107999, tonight in taking a 30 lead in the National Basketball Association cham pionship series.

title: Shepard and a Negro Named Admirals
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)  The Navy announced to day the selection of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., America's first man in space, as the first astro naut to become an admiral. At the same time, it said that Capt. Samuel L. Gravely Jr., commander of a guided missile frigate, would become its first black admiral.

title: Dutch Coalition Government Loses Majority in Parliament
description: THE HAGUE, Thursday, April 29 (UPI)Premier Piet J. S. De Jong's coalition Government lost its majority in parliamen tary elections yesterday.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Improve World Payments Balance
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Two leading international monetary officials made an urgent plea today for improve ment in the United States balance of international payments to save the stability of the world monetary system.

title: Welcomed in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, April 28  South Afri cans today welcomed a report that President HouphouetBoig ny would he prepared to open a dialogue with South Africa.

title: M.T.A. AND CITY ASK EAST RIVER TOLLS
description: The city and the Metropoli tan Transportation Authority are expected to announce today a program to charge tolls on four East River bridges, in crease Triborough tolls and seek $110million in state aid to maintain subway and commut ertrain rights of way.

title: LINDSAY PROPOSES 9.2BILLION BUDGET IN FISCAL RETREAT
description: A $9.2billion city budget for next year was proposed yes terday by Mayor Lindsay, who also sought permission to fur lough city workers for the first time since the Depression.

title: G.M. PAYS $20,000 FOR CRITICAL MAIL
description: DETROIT, April 28The De partment of Transportation said today that it would examine 100,000 microfilmed letters of complaint from Chevrolet cus tomers that the General Motors Corporation paid $20,000 to re cover from two suburban De troit salvage dealers last week.

title: Michigan Governor Rejects Extradition Of Arkansas Negro
description: LANSING, Mich., April 28 Gov. William G. Milliken re fused today to extradite to Ar kansas a 21yearold Negro fugitive who said he feared for his safety if returned.

title: Theater: Strindberg's Dance of Death Given Uneven Revival
description: Strindberg's characters are on the edge of madness, the edge of feeling, their pas sions circumscribed by their selfregard and selfhatred. They are more animal than human, but fascinating. They are never entirely realistic, and yet they have the valid ity of their own conven tion. Last night at the Ritz Theater, Strindberg's Dance of Death showed all the corrosive power of a play wright who dares to manip ulate melodrama to the ends of art.

title: Chess : Petrosian Is Heavy Favorite Over Hubner in Seville Match
description: Whoever emerges from the forthcoming elimination matches as the challenger for the world chess title held by Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, it is unlikely to afford a bigger surprise than the qualification of 22yearold Robert Hubner of West Ger many for a place in the trials. Hubner's success at the inter zonal tournament, held last winter at Palma, Majorca, was astonishing.

title: Tornadoes Lash 3 States; 10 Are Killed in Kentucky
description: COLUMBIA, Ky., April 28 (UPI)Tornadoes struck Ken tucky, Illinois and Tennessee last night and early today, kill ing at least 11 persons and leaving more than 100 others injured.

title: Dubcek Said to Manage A Garage in Hometown
description: BONN, April 29Alexander Dubcek, the deposed Commu nist party leader of Czecho slovakia, is working in his hometown of Bratislava as a garage manager for the city's parks department, according to Quick, the illustrated West German weekly.

title: Sports of The Times
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29When the sun began to mount in the sky at an indecently early hour this morning, its rays danced off the dew at Churchill Downs, where the 97th Kentucky Derby will be run on Saturday. There wasn't enough warmth in that sun, however, to draw off the dew. Hence, what was to develop into a nice day started off on the chilly side.

title: Selected Shorts at Whitney
description: The current program in the Whitney Museum's New American Film Makers Series offers another group of short movies from the Ninth Ann Arbor Film Festival. With few exceptions, it is a dis appointing selection.

title: Dayan Even Money Choice In Westbury Trot Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 29 Dayan, last season's 4year old trotter of the year, will be making his debut tomorrow as the evenmoney choice in the one mile, $25,000 Su Mac Lad Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: ROCHESTER, April 29 (AP) According to an article pub lished in today's Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, Leichner said the players' main complaint concerned rules for socalled development clubs. Under N.H.L. rules, he said, 10 of the 16 players on develon ment clubs must be under 26, with goaltenders exempted.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 16, Stabbed In Hallway of High School
description: A 16yearold Erasmus Hall High School student was stabbed above the heart, yes terday afternoon in a hallway of the Brooklyn school during an attempt to rob him, the police of the Snyder Avenue station reported.

title: Patrolman Kills Robber In Bar Near City Hall
description: A holdup man was killed in a gun battle with a transit pa trolman in a bar near City Hall early this morning, the police reported. The patrolman and two patrons were wounded.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WEEKEND MAN. By Richard B. Wright. 247 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95.

title: EXPERT'S APPRAISAL: NOT ONE SOLID HORSE
description: Tommy Trotter, racing sec retary and handicapper for The, Jockey Club and the New York Racing Association, says he wouldn't even want to try to pick a favorite for, the Ken tucky Derby.

title: Pennzoil United
description: Firstquarter net income of Pennzoil United, Inc., declined to $15.6million, or 48 cents share, from $22.5million, or 69 cents a share, in the similar three months a year ago, it was reported yesterday. Revenues were $189million against $202.2million.

title: Consumer Interest in Homes Increases;
description: WASHINGTON, April 29A strong increase in consumer plans to purchase homes and related items but otherwise no major change in consumer sen timent was reported today by the Commerce Department.

title: ANEMIA IS FOUND COMMON IN POOR
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Federal Government re leased results today of a nutri tional survey, the largest ever made in the United States, that found anemia and serious vita min deficiencies in large num bers of the poor.

title: SCHOOL REZONING IN QUEENS SCORED
description: Murry Bergtraum, the presi dent of the Board of Education, has recommended the scrap ping of a controversial plan that would rezone nearly all the areas., from which high schools in Queens draw their students.

title: Derby Action Swamps OTB
description: Without encouragement from a single mint julep or banjo tune, offtrack betting on the Kentucky Derby broke into a gallop here yesterday.

title: Court Bars Release of Girl Held as Bombing Witness
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The United States Court of Ap peals here denied a request to day that the 19yearold girl being held as a witness in the Capitol bombing case be re leased front custody.

title: HOUSE TO SHELVE AID REFORM PLAN FOR THIS SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The House Foreign Affairs Com mittee has decided to put President Nixon's $3.3billion foreignaid reorganization plan in cold storage for this session of Congress.

title: Allison Wins the Pole
description: DARLINGTON, S. C., April 29 (UPI)Donnie Allison captured the pole position today for Sun day's Rebel 400 with a speed of 151.471 miles an hour.

title: Biologist, Scoring Secrecy, Quits Academy of Sciences
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (AP)A University of Chicago biologist announced today that he had resigned from the National Academy of Sciences in protest against its sponsorship of secret research.

title: Advertising:
description: The forces that are out to gain control of Twentieth CenturyFox today unleashed the first of a planned adver tising blitz that will end with the embattled company's an nual meeting on May 18.

title: Reserve Revises Index Of Industrial Production
description: The Federal Reserve Board has largely completed a basic overhaul of its widely followed index of industrial production. According to Harold C. Pas ser, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Af fairs, the revised indexwhich is now scheduled to be pub lished in Junecould give a very different picture of the first quarter than the present measure.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: April 29, 1971

title: SEALE WINS A FIGHT TO KEEP HIS GOATEE
description: NEW HAVEN, April 29A Federal judge today ordered Connecticut jail officials to stop insisting that Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther party chair man, shave his goatee and to release him from punitive seg regation.

title: Decay of a Union
description: A dismaying series of scandals, climaxed by the murder sixteen months ago of insurgent Joseph A. Yablonski, has long made it plain that the once proud United Mine Workers is in an advanced state of moral debility. But even the multiplicity of such evidences of decay could not take the shock out of the abuses a Federal judge has found in management of the union's huge pension and welfare fund.

title: METS BEAT CARDS ON 3HITTER, 70, FOR 4TH IN ROW
description: ST. LOWS, Apr, 29The New York Mets completed a four game sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals today and in the bar gain ended Joe Torre's hitting streak at 22 games.

title: Black Africa's Cities Teem With Youths Seeking Jobs but Finding Poverty
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 26 Ignatius Chukwuka has left his rural village and come to Lagos to look for a job, but his pros pects are dim and growing, dimmer.

title: Norton Simon's Art On View Before Sale
description: Nineteenth and twentieth century paintings and other works of art from the pri vate collection of Norton Si mon, the West Coast indus trialist, are on exhibition at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, where they will be auctioned next Wednesday.

title: Housing's Struggle in Suburbia
description: News Analysis

title: S.L.A. Marshall: On the Nature of War
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich.My attention has been drawn to an essay opposite your editorial page wherein Burke Marshall, acting as judge, jury and prosecutor, convicts all Americans of the crime at Mylai toward mitigating what was triggered by the direct ac tion of one lieutenant.

title: NATHAN A. ROBINS
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., April 29Nathan A. Robins, founder and retired president of the May Knitting Company of New York, children's sweaters and swim wear, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital, Suffern. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 Cole Avenue.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon took a step yesterday to make good on a promise to open top Federal jobs, in the $25,000 to $40,000 a year category, to women. He appointed four women to such jobs.

title: Spy Plane Hunts the Polluters
description: A twin  engine prop  jet carrying electronic and pho tographic detection gear de veloped for war began flying over New York waterways this week to see if the equip ment could perform a peace time job of detecting water polluters from the air.

title: SUPERFECTA GETS BIG PLAY IN DEBUT
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 29 Lone Shark ($25.60), driven by Don Gillis, won a $1,600 handicap mile for trotters as Monticello Raceway, opened its 14th season of harness racing tonight, but the result of the feature seemed to be of sec ondary interest to most of the 9,136 firstnighters.

title: Dow Cuts Polyether Price
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it was tem porarily reducing the price of flexible urethane polyethers used in making slab urethane foam by 1 cent a pound, be cause of widespread discount ing practices. The new price will be 13 cents a pound and applies only to tankcar ship ments of 20,000 gallons or more.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Fights Shift in Food Stamp Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Proposed Federal regulations designed to establish national eligibility Standards for food stamps would seriously impair the relatively new foodstamp program in New York City, the Senate Select Committee on Nu trition and Human Needs was told today.

title: Alcan Aluminium
description: Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., the leading Canadian primary alu minum producer, reported yes terday firstquarter consoli dated net income of $14.5mil lion, equal to 42 cents a share. This compares with earnings of $18.8million, or 55 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year ago. Revenues in the period from sales and all other sources rose to $332mil lion against $328million a year ago.

title: POLICEMAN FOILS ATTEMPT ON LIFE
description: A 27yearold policeman who has been cited for heroism in entinarcotics work foiled an ambush attempt and set off manhunt early yesterday.

title: Gina Bachauer Offers Piano Majesty
description: Gina Bachauer attacks the piano with such queenly conviction that even her er rors, like Victoria's, exude a certain majesty.

title: Physicist Believes He Intercepted a Solar Neutrino
description: After years of trying to in tercept ghost particles that speed to earth from the core of the sun, Dr. Raymond Davis Jr., of the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L.I., be lieves he has finally done so.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: There are times when the sheer volume of fly fishing literature threatens to de press me. There is so much of it the mind boggles.

title: J. & L. Chief Explains Dividend
description: PITTSBURGH, April 29 William J. Stephens, chair man and chief executive offi cer of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, emphati cally denied the allegation of a stockholder here today that the steel concern was or dered to declare a dividend in the first quarter by Ling TemcoVought, Inc., which owns 81 per cent of J. & L.

title: New Coalition Sought in Netherlands After Election
description: THE HAGUE, April 29The Netherlands was in search of a new ruling majority today fol lowing substantial electoral losses for the centerright Gov ernment coalition.

title: Fillmores East and West Are Closing
description: Bill Graham, the dynamic, longhaired impresario of rock, announced yesterday that he would permanently close the doors on his twin citadels of rock culturethe Fillmores East and West.

title: Jim French Looms As the One to Beat: It's in Orange Cards
description: The following analysis of tomorrow's Kentucky Derby was provided by Saran Schroeder, a public selector known to racing fans through out the East as Clocker Law ton. His orange cards are the biggest selling of the tip sheets available at tracks in New York, Florida, Mary land, Delaware and New England. Here's what the Clocker thinks will happen in the Derby:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Adm. Arthur A. Ageton Dies; Wrote Naval Officers' Manual
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Rear Adm. Arthur A. Ageton, an author and diplomat, died at the Naval Hospital in Bethes da, Md., last Friday. He was 70 years old and lived here at 3900 Connecticut Avenue, N.W.

title: Otto Lehmann, Opera Coach; Conducted at City Center
description: Otto Lehmann, musicologist, conductor and opera coach, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital of a stroke. He was 65 years old and lived at the Winslow Hotel, Madison Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Rich Germans Shunning Marks;
description: PARIS, April 29Rich West Germans are fleeing from marks, even as the rest of the world can't seem to buy enough of them.

title: 2 Buildings Here Housing Pakistan Offices Vandalized
description: Two buildings here housing Pakistan agencies were struck last night by vandals.

title: HAMLETS WIPED OUT, EXMARINE TESTIFIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters)A former marine corporal, Kenneth James Camp bell, said today that two North Vietnamese hamlets were wiped out in August, 1968, and their 30 civilian inhabitants killed by American artillery on the chance they may have been supplying rice to Communist troops.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Budgetary Default
description: At a time of dire fiscal crisis, when Mayor Lindsay has warned of the grim prospect of being forced to lay off up to 90,000 city workers and of closing City University to a freshman class, he is nonetheless submitting a non austerity budget to the City Council today. This is a proposed $9.2billion budget which, unrealistically, as sumes the full restoration of state aid to the city as well as the city's winning authority to impose close to $1 bil lion in additional taxes of its own.

title: Dick & Merle Will Get Roosevelt Name Back
