description: Roosevelt & Son, the oldest name in investment banking in the United States, will be brought back to life next Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TURINA SONGS LIFT MISS SCOTT'S DEBUT
description: A group of Twine songs were free of what seemed like in hibiting nervousness and a slight vocal indisposition in Miriam Scott's singing during her debut recital at the New York Cultural Center on a Wednesday night. They had a vitality and personal involve ment absent from most of the program and they suggested that the New York sopranocould be an attractive per former under different circum stances.

title: SOYBEAN MEAL UP IN ACTIVE BUYING
description: Better prices for soybean oil and meal at the cash level resulted in considerable buying of futures of those commodities yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Cambodians and Enemy Clash Again in HandtoHand Battles
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 29 (AP)Cambodian troops fought handtohand battles with enemy soldiers today for the second consecutive day on Route 4, Pnompenh's supply route from the sea, the high command said.

title: A Rockefeller Divorce
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. (AP) Former Gov, Winthrop Rocke feller and Mrs. Jeanette Edris Rockefeller, his wife of 14 years, were divorced today. The suit, which Mrs. Rockefeller March 26, was uncontested. Grounds for the divorce were general indignities, the standard basis for asking for a divorce in Arkansas. The decree did not specify a settlement.

title: To Mrs. Levine, A Peacock Ball Without Jewels
description: The chairman of interna tional affairs won't be wear ing diamonds at the Lila Motley Cancer Foundation's annual Peacock Ball at the Plaza tomorrow nightif in deed Mrs. Joseph E. Levine, wife of the movie magnate, still owns any diamonds.

title: LIQUORPRICE BILL PASSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 29The Sen ate gave final passage today to a bill requiring that liquor be sold by retailers at a mark up of at least 12 per cent over its wholesale cost.

title: Good Behaving's Brother Pointed for 1974 Derby
description: OCALA, Fla., April 29 (UPI)  A full brother to Good Be having was foaled at the Meadowbrook Farm last night and Neil Hellman, his owner, said today he would make no mistake about declaring him for the 1974 Kentucky Derby.

title: Mills Seeks Welfare Bill Votes; He May Add Rise in Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, lapparently fearful that his wel fare reform bill is headed for trouble on the House floor, is moving on several fronts to win more votes.

title: Bridge: A Risky System Minimizes The MotherinLaw's Role
description: A bidding style quite pop ular all over the world is the M.W.D. System, but it should be pointed out that Make Wife Dummy is less popular, with the wives than the hus bands.

title: Bucks Need One More Victory to Wind Up a Happy Trip
description: The 737th gameand per haps, the last (God willing) of the National Basketball Association season will take place tonight in Baltimore, where the Milwaukee Bucks will try to end the champion ship playoffs by completing a fourgame sweep of the Baltimore Bullets.

title: Gen. Argyropoulos, 72, ExGreek Official of NATO
description: ATHENS, April 29 (AP) Retired Lieut. Gen. Archimedes Argyropoulos, once accused of plotting a takeover of Greece, died of a hteart attack here last week, it was learned today. He was 72 years old.

title: MRS. G. HARLAN MILLER
description: Mrs. Harriette Gowen Miller, a former sculptor and painter, who more recently conducted the Whimsey antique shop in Arlington, Vt., died yesterday in Paris at the age of 79.

title: Castle & Cooke
description: The consolidated net income of Castle & Cooke, Inc., for the fiscal year ended March 31 fell to $10,072,000, or 91 cents a share, from $17,625,000, or $1.69 a share, in the preceding year, the largest company based in Hawaii reported yesterday.

title: U.S. EASES LIMITS ON CITY HOUSING
description: The Federal Government will allow the city to use money lalloted for the Model Cities Administration to lower the cost of public housing, it was announced yesterday.

title: Dr. Connie M. Guion Dies at 88; Leading Physician and Educator
description: Dr. Connie M. Guion, who had been associated for more than half a century with the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, died last night at the New York Hospital. She was 88 years old and had been in failing health for the last year.

title: RESCUED CHINESE GUARDED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, April 29  The Chi nese traveler who was seized by Orly Airport policemen yes terday from a group trying to take him aboard a Shanghai bound plane remained under heavy guard today.

title: Altesse Royale Captures 1,000 Guineas in England
description: NEWMARKET, England, April 29 (AP)  Altesse Royale, a 251 shot ridden by the French jockey, Yves Saint Martin, led all the way today In winning the onemile 1,000 Guineas Classic for 3yearold fillies by 1 lengths.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY SOUGHT IN HOCKEY
description: PORTLAND, Ore., April 29 (UPI)The Justice Department has been given 27 pages of alleged abuses of hockey play ers and is looking into possible antitrust violations, Curtis Leichner, a lawyer representing the Professional Hockey Players Association, said today. The association has members in the Western League and American League.

title: PENTAGON DENIES A NUMBERS GAME
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Defense Department said today that while combat casual ties in Vietnam declined 70 per cent between 1968 and 1970, noncombat casualties had re mained almost constant.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Service. Write: The New York Times. Library Serv ices, Box FP480. 229 West 43d Street. New York, N.Y. 10036. ADVT

title: General Host Lists Profit, Says It Weighs LinkUps
description: After looking over 200 com panies since the beginning of 1970, the General Host Corpo ration now has a few in which it is interested, Harris J. Ash ton, chairman and chief execu tive officer, told the annual meeting yesterday in the Hilton Hotel.

title: NEW MUSIC CARD BEGINS CALMLY
description: Things were calm and often quiet at the Evenings for New Music concert presented at Car negie Recital Hall on Wednes day night by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts of the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: April 30, 1971

title: White & Co. Suspended
description: CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) The Midwest Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sus pension from membership of White & Co. Inc., of St. Louis for failure to meet the ex change's requirements of capi tal condition.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PARIS, April 29A spokes man for the Communistled pro visional Revolutionary Govern ment said today that the kill ings described by Mr. Notley in Washington had been broad er in scope than the witness realized.

title: Rusk Favors China Seat in U.N. Along With Taiwan Membership
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said here today that he favored the admission of Com munist China to the United Nations and the continuing membership of Nationalist China.

title: Ford Assails Muskie and Fulbright Stands on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 Before a gathering of Jewish leaders, Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie and Senator J. W. Fulbright of undermining American support of Israel.

title: OffDuty Officer Wounds KnifeWielder on Subway
description: An offduty police captain shot and seriously wounded a man wielding a butcher knife aboard a subway train at Colum bus Circle last night after the man allegedly menaced a num ber of passengers and the captain himself.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILED BY 12 REPUBLICANS
description: ALBANY, April 29  The 12 Republican Assemblymen from New York City accused Mayor Lindsay in a statement today of intentionally underestimat ing by nearly $150million the amount of money existing taxes would produce for the city dur ing its 197172 fiscal year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 4% Climb in Capital Spending Expected
description: American companies plan to increase their expenditures for plant and equipment by 4 per cent this year, it was reported yesterday by the McGrawHill Publications Company in its annual survey of capital spend ing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadiens Gain Final
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 29There was a wild Stanley Cup finish here tonight, too.

title: Truck Hijacking Increases; Cargoes Sold as Bargains
description: In the early morning hours a tractortrailer truck stops at a red light at a deserted street corner here. The driver pays no attention to the car that pulls alongside until four men jump out, one of them waving a pistol.

title: Price of Gold Climbs in London
description: PARIS, April 29The dollar improved slightly against some of the continental currencies today, but the price of gold continued to climb, hitting an 18month high of $39.45 an ounce in London.

title: CAIRO RATIFIES FEDERATION PLAN
description: CAIRO, April 29Egypt to night completed the formalities of ratifying a plan for federa tion with Syria and Libya after several days of intensive dis oussions that led to the amend ment of some statutes of the agreement.

title: Derby Field Drops to 20; Impetuosity Gets Last Post
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 The Kentucky Derby field held at 21 when the draw was made for post position today.

title: Roundup: New Scenery Helping Sims, Swoboda
description: Duke Sims and Ron Swo bode, power hitters who out lived their usefulness with their former teams and were traded between seasons, helped win games yesterday.

title: 23 Arraigned Here For Invading Office Of Board of Rabbis
description: Twentythree members of the militant Jewish Defense League were arraigned in Cri minal Court yesterday on charges stemming from the league's invasion of the offices of the New York Board of Rabbis on Wednesday.

title: I.T.T. NET UP 12% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation re ported yesterday that it real ized an increase of 12 per cent, in earnings as well as sales and revenues in the first quar ter this year.

title: S.E.C. Urges Rule Affecting Rebates On Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Apr. 29  The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today the proposed rules under which the sellers of frontend load mutual fund plans are to notify their customers when they are en titled to refunds if they decide not to go through with their investment.

title: Democrats Seeking Higher City Taxes On OutofStaters
description: ALBANY, April 29 Demo cratic leaders in the Assembly proposed today a sevenfold in crease in the commuter tax paid to New York City by out ofstate residents.

title: Queens Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)1 The Defense Department an nounced today that Specialist 4 Edward W. Corcoran of Long! Island City, Queens, of the Army, had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON PROFIT TAKING
description: The highflying airline stocks took a nosedive yesterday amid heavy profit taking as the gen eral market advance began to stall.

title: Stalemate in Berlin
description: Moscow's failure to move toward a Berlin agreement threatens to undermine the substantial progress that has been made toward an EastWest dtente in Europe.

title: Duryea Rewrites Albany Script
description: News Analysis

title: Midas Management Slate Triumphs by Almost 2 to
description: The final results of the vot ing in the proxy contest for control of the MidasInterna tional Corporation, which were released yesterday, showed that 1,644,136 proxies favored the management slate of directors while 906,060 chose the oppo sition slate.

title: Racial Outbreak at South Shore High School in Brooklyn Is Traced to Earlier Tensions
description: The police patrolled the ground floor and outside of South Shore High School in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday after two days of conflict between black and white students.

title: NIXON INDICATES INDEFINITE STAY FOR VIETNAM G.I.'S
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 President Nixon said tonight that a residual force of United States troops would remain in South Vietnam indefinitely no matter how long it takes if Hanoi refused to release American prisoners of war.

title: PEACE TOUR SET BY CONGRESSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  More than 20 members of Con gress have agreed to travel around the country in a new antiwar program designed to bring constituent pressure on Senators and Congressmen re luctant to push for an early withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam.

title: Israel Said to Press for Suez Assurances
description: JERUSALEM, April 29  Israel is pressing for more spe cific and precise assurances than the United States has yet offered as her price for pulling troops back from the Suez Canal and allowing the water way to be reopened, reliable Israeli sources said today.

title: New YorkBucharest Flight
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 29 (AP)A Pan American World Airways turbojet landed at Otopeni Airport today, in augurating regular service be tween New York and Bucharest.

title: Richard Kiley in Play About Beerbohm Due in Fall
description: Sir Max Beerbohm, the English critic, writer, cari caturist and social commenta tor, will be represented on the Broadway stage next fall in a new play by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee called The Incomparable Max!

title: Teacher Praises the Cultural Revolution
description: PEKING, April 29  Prof. Chien Weichang, a researcher and lecturer at the California Institute of Technology from 1940 to 1946, says that he is a contented product of protrac ted and painful thoughtre molding by students, workers and soldiers at Peking's Tsing hua University during the Cul tural Revolution.

title: Kotouc Is Acquitted of Maiming A Vietnamese Prisoner at Mylai
description: ATLANTA, April 29An Army courtmartial jury cleared Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc of guilt today in the maiming of a Vietnamese prisoner three years ago at Mylai 4, an act the officer said he had com mitted by accident.

title: Radical, Yes, but Violent? Reports Differ
description: Leslie Bacon, the 19year old girl being held as a material witness in the bombing at the United States Capitol on March 1, has led the life of a radical in the last year. But what that means depends on who is saying it.

title: Francis Salutes Clutch Effort As His Club's Finest Hour
description: Emile Francis, the coach and general manager of the New York Rangers, said of his team's 32 overtime vic tory over Chicago last night:

title: For Whom the Tolls
description: Subway and bus riders in New York City and everyone who tries to live or work or breathe in automobile clogged Manhattan should applaud the tolls for four East River bridges just proposed by Mayor Lindsay and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Certainly that applause should come most strongly from the Board of Estimate, the City Council and other official bodies in a position to know the gravity of the city's overall prob lems. Putting tolls on these bridges and raising tolls on those that already have them would be for the general benefit of the city.

title: Shutdown in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 29 (UPI)Montclair High School was shut down for the third straight day toddy after a dem onstration by black students over school officials' criticism, of a black guidance counselor.

title: Mohawk Airlines
description: UTICA, N. Y., April 29 (AP) Mohawk Airlines, having suf fered through the worst year of the airline industry's history, is developing its strength to contribute toward a merger with Allegheny Airlines, stock holders were told today.

title: Store Sales Up for Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended April 24 was an estimated $760million, an increase of 6 per cent above the $716million sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the week was an estimated $7,469,000,000, an increase of 7 per cent above the $6,971,000,000 sales for the same period last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Glass Imports Upheld
description: WASHINGTON, April 9 (A) The Treasury Department ruled today that cast or rolled glass from Japan was not being sold in the United States at less than its fair value. The decision means that additional duties will not be imposed against the glass imports.

title: REV. JOHN DALEY OF GEORGETOWN U.
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The Rev. John M. Daley, dean of the graduate school at Georgetown University from 1954 to 1959 and Provincial of the Maryland Province of the Society of Jesus from 1959 to 1965, died Tues day in Georgetown University Hospital, after a stroke. He was 55 years old.

title: WADKINS, CAMPBELL GAIN AT PINEHURST
description: PINEHURST, N.C., April 29 (AP)Lanny Wadkins, Bill Campbell, Vinny Giles and Eddie Pearce won two matches each today to advance to the semifinals of the North and South amateur golf tourna ment.

title: Foster Parents Retain Custody of Baby Lenore
description: The little girl who has come to be known as Baby Lenore remained with her foster par ents under a Federal court order yesterday while lawyers sought to take the adoption dispute to the United States Supreme Court.

title: BLAIKIE LOSES SUIT TO DISMISS RANKIN
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice yesterday dismissed a suit by a New York City taxpayer requiring Mayor Lindsay to dis miss H. Lee Rankin, the city's Corporation Counsel, on the ground of conflict of interest.

title: SIR FRANK LEE, 67, OF TREASURY DIES
description: LONDON, April 29 (AP)  Sir Frank Lee, master of Cor pus Christi College at Cam bridge University and a former top civil servant well known in the United States and through out the commonwealth, died yesterday at the age of 67.

title: Sales Again Boom for 5th Avenue Stores
description: Fifth Avenue's big, posh stores, which took the brunt of the consumer buying lag last year, are currently enjoying one of their best months in more than a year.

title: ANTITERROR LAW LAPSING IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, April 29  The Canadian Government decided today to let its special anti terrorist legislation expire on schedule at midnight tomorrow night.

title: FLOOD CHECKS OUT OF HOTEL IN MADRID
description: MADRID, April 29 (UPI) Curt Flood, who quit baseball Tuesday for the second time while his suit against the sport was still on appeal, checked out of his hotel here today and headed for the airport.

title: Bar TV Crews From Raids
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 29 (AP)Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie ordered the Illinois Bureau of Investigation today not to take television crews with bureau agents on raids such as those in southern Illinois last week. Several persons were arrested on weapons and narcotics charges in the raids.

title: Hanoi Asks U.S. to Open Talks Now on Pullout Date
description: PARIS, April 29North Viet nam invited the United States today to open negotiations this very day, or tomorrow, or another day on setting a date for the withdrawal of all Amer ican troops from South Viet nam.

title: GRAHAM AND CUPIT SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 29 Billy Casper, suffering from bursitis, withdrew from the $125,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tourney today as Lou Graham and Jacky Cupit shared the firstround lead with 65's.

title: Save the Shore Parkway
description: It would be bitterly ironic if Jamaica Bay, recently saved from the fatal incursion of additional runways Kennedy Airport, should now be ruined by a fourlane truckway within fifty feet of its waters. Yet that is dangerous possibility if the Legislature approves, as part of Governor Rockefeller's highway improvement bill, proposal to add four truck lanes to Brooklyn's scenic Shore Parkway.

title: Catholic Bishops Resist Changes Within Church
description: DETROIT, April 29  The American Bishops of the Ro man Catholic Church ended their annual spring meeting here today with an apparent determination to seek a restora tion of order and the tradition al line of authority after a pe riod of turmoil in the church.

title: DUVALIER IS TOUGH ON EMIGRE POLICY
description: PORT  AU  PRINCE, Haiti, April 29JeanClaude Duvalier, the new 19yearold President of Haiti, said today that Com munists and troublemakers among Haitian migrs in the United States would not be al lowed to return home.

title: Screen: Godard's Social Mix, 'Vladimir and Rosa':Chicago Conspiracy Trial Is One Item
description: "Vladimir and Rosa," wherein Jean-Luc Godard offers his thoughts and precepts relating to last year's Chicago conspiracy trial, women's liberation and black power, among other things, is the committed (some would say committable) French director's latest revolutionary film. Yet, more than anything he has done since "Weekend," it recalls the work of the pre-Mao Godardmovies like "Two or Three Things I Know About Her," "La Chinoise," and even "Band of Outsiders," although that film was made at the height of what might be called Godard's Kuomintang period (1964)."Vladimir and Rosa" is no less an essay film than "Wind from the East" and "Sympathy for the Devil" (and, I assume, "Pravda" and "See You at Mao," which I did not see), but the essay has a straightforward structure and it is played mostly in the burlesque form of a political cartoon. It is anything but obscure in its methods.The film opens with a couple of Weathermen being beaten by comic strip cops with clubs that are intended to have the heft of balsa wood. Prop blood, wiped away, reveals smooth, undamaged flesh. In the course of the trial, the Judge sits at his bench, looking like a snappish griffin, overruling the most reasonable objections of the defense, sustaining the wildest objections of the prosecution, and drawing labels ("hippies," "yippies") on the thighs and breasts of a Playboy-like centerfold.When someone representing Bobby Seale is led from the courtroom, the screen goes playfully black. (Coincidentally, the prosecution's trial procedures also are lampooned, with equal vehemence, in Woody Allen's new film, "Bananas," which indicates we may be in for a season of similar rip-offs)."Vladimir and Rosa" frequently cuts away from the trial for lettle lectures on the meaning of conspiracy, for dialogues between a pretty feminist and her lover, who, radical though he is, can't help but being a bit of a male chauvinist, and between Godard and his filmmaking partner, Jean-Pierre Gorin, on the problems of translating revolutionary theory into revolutionary film.One of these takes place on a tennis court, with the dead-panned Godard and Gorin pacing along the net as a hot game of doubles goes smashing back and forth over their heads. In spite or himself, apparently, Godard cannot resist a comic image, even one at the expense of his own politically grave image.Such moments evoke the earlier Godard films, even though distantly. The manner in which the Chicago trial is parodied is bitter, but the playing is exuberant and energetic, as childlike as the fantasies once enacted for Godard by Belmondo, Brialy, Karina and their friends.The movie, unfortunately, is a good deal more than memories. It is not only stern and didactic in ways that are either enigmatic or tirsome (and sometimes both), but it is also, quite literally, pale and fuzzy.As Godard has embraced revolution and discarded the possessions of the bourgeoisie, he has also discarded what he seems to regard as the luxury of film style. In its technical aspects, "Vladimir and Rosa" looks weak and undernourished, like someone who has given all his salary to The Cause and must subsist on Kool-Aid and french fries.The movie was produced by the Dziga-Vertov cooperative, which doesn't assign individual credits. I've no idea who wrote, photographed or edited the film, although Godard's hand can be detected from time to time. In addition to Godard and Gorin, I also recognized in the cast Anne Wiazemsky, as a women's liberator, and Juliette Bertho as a Weatherwoman type.In case you're wondering, the title is in reference to Vladimir Ilich Ulyanov (Lenin) (1870-1924) and Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919), a leading German Marxist, to whom Godard and Gorin liken themselves, as theoreticians suddenly confronted with the opportunity to practice what they preach. Like all Godard titles, it has the proper touch of poetry.

title: UAL LOSS WIDENS TO $332MILLION
description: UAL, Inc., the holding com patty that controls United Air Lines, the world's biggest air line, announced yesterday that incurred a $332million loss in the first quarter of 1971.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Win in 3d Overtime, 32;
description: While a crowd too stunned to cheer suddenly gasped, the Rangers scored a memorable 32 playoff victory in the third overtime last night and forced a seventh and deciding game against the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Madison Square Garden
description: The report of the Madison Square Garden Corporation dis closed yesterday a net income of $408,000, equal to 2 cents a share, for the nine months ended Feb. 28. This compared with a net loss of $1,593,000 in the prior year's period. Consoli dated revenues improved in the ninemonth period to $82,018, 000 from $75,318,000 a year earlier.

title: Chimp at Bridgeport Zoo Gave 3 Persons Hepatitis
description: The City Health Officer of Bridgeport, Conn., said yes terday that a zoo director, his daughter and a zoo em ploye had been hospitalized with infectious hepatitis in January after coining in con tact with a baby chimpanzee.

title: India's Allegations Of Border Forays Denied by Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 29 The Pakistan radio said to night that Indian allegations that Pakistani forces had en tered Indian territory and had fired on Indian nationals were absolutely untrue and base less and charged that India was sending more infiltrators into Pakistan.

title: Albert Urges U.S. Parley On Jobless and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (UPI)House Speaker Carl Al bert accused President Nixon and top Administration officials today of being out of touch with reality and proposed a national conference on unem ployment and inflation.

title: Yanks Recall Jones, 25. From Syracuse Affiliate
description: The New York Yankees an nounced yesterday that they were recalling Gary Jones, a 25yearold lefthanded pitcher from their Syracuse farm club.

title: Theater: Shyre's Winning O'Casey
description: With the sudden cancella tion of a regularly scheduled play. Pictures in the Hall way, Paul Shyre's adapta tion of volume two of Sean O'Casey's autobiog raphy; slipped into Lincoln Center's Forum Theater last night. The booking may be abrupt but the play is a treas ure.

title: Unbeaten Bold Reasoning Wins Aqueduct Dash
description: Bold Reasoning, a fleet 3 yearold son of Boldnesian, brightened an otherwise damp and overcast day at Aqueduct yesterday by ripping off his fourth straight impressive vic tory and thereby forcing him self into consideration for some of the upcoming stakes races for horses of his age.

title: Rail Men Face Job Disruptions When Amtrak's Service Starts
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 For railroad labor, the National Railroad Passenger Corpora tion's start of Amtrak service this weekend is the start of another painful series of job losses and disruptions.

title: Lon Nol to Head Military In Cambodia Compromise
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 29Gen. Lon Nol tonight was named chief of the Cam bodian armed forces and Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak was asked by Chief of State Cheng Heng to form a new Govern ment. General Sirik Matak has requested time to consider the proposal.

title: Cannes Entry Rejected, Soviet Quits Festival
description: MOSCOW, April 29 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has with drawn from this year's Cannes Film Festival after rejection of the Soviet entry. Film indus try sources said the Russians had failed to understand what they called the organizers negative attitude.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The present budgetary crisis in New York City has been partially brought about by the outrageous demands of the municipal unions for higher and higher salaries and pensions.

title: Girl Arrives in Seattle for Bombing Inquiry
description: SEATTLE, April 29Leslie Bacon arrived here tonight, under subpoena, to testify be fore a Federal grand jury looking into the bombing of the United States Capitol in Washington announced here that the grand jury would meet tomorrow, day it had intended to be in recess.

title: School in Suffolk Closed
description: WEST BABYLON, L. I., April 29West Babylon Senior High School was closed today while school officials worked to pre vent a recurrence of a racial disturbance that resulted yes terday in the arrest of two persons and injuries to 12 persons.

title: BEAME WOULD CUT CITY'S BUDGET GAP BY $276.9 MILLION
description: A way to reduce the gap in next year's city budget by $276.9million was described yesterday by the City Con troller and promptly challenged as unrealistic by the City Budget Director.

title: Rogers Arrives in Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 29 (AP)Secretary Rogers arrived here today under security pre cautions tightened by Turkey's imposition of martial law in the capital and in 10 other areas of the country.

title: DETECTIVE DRAWS JAIL FOR BRIBERY
description: Michael Martin, a former city detective accused of selling confidential information to banks and airlines, was sen tenced yesterday to 90 days and a fine of $5,000.

title: Women's PanAm Trials Begin Today
description: QUANTICO, Va., April 29 It has been suggested that women's track and field in the United States began with Willye B. White.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: RIVALRY STRAINING COALITION IN ITALY
description: ROME, April 29The nine monthold Government of Pre mier Emilio Colombo appeared strained today by power strug gles within the centerleft coali tion on which it rests.

title: Jersey Zinc to Shut Units
description: The New Jersey Zinc Compa ny, a subsidiary of Gulf & West ern Industries, Inc., announced plans yesterday to shut down facilities in Illinois, Wisconsin and Colorado, a move that may affect 825 workers.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WOLFMAN. By the WolfMan. With the Case of the WolfMan, by Sigmund Freud and a Supplement by Ruth Mack Bruns wick. Foreword by Anna Freud. Edited, With Notes, an Introduction and Chapters by Muriel Gardner. 370 pages. Basic. $10.

title: The Old Devil in a New Age
description: CONWAY, Mass.Stephen Vincent Benet's The Devil and Daniel Web ster is one more proof that myths are made of time as well as tales. It first appeared in The Saturday Evening Post in 1936, a short story of unusual delight but a short story notwithstand ing. Today it is a fable from which men quarry plays.

title: Ivory Coast's Leader
description: Man in the News

title: State Puts 6Month Limit On CriminalTrial Delays
description: The chief judge of New York announced yesterday that beginning a year from tomorrow the state courts, in all but homicide cases, would dismiss criminal charges against anydefendant who through no fault of his own had not been brought to trial within six months of his arrest.

title: PENSION INCREASE SOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, April 29  A bill has been introduced in the As sembly to expand pension bene fits for state legislators, the Lieutenant Governor, the Con troller, the Attorney General, judges and many court em ployes.

title: Reorganization Plan Filed For the Roberts Company
description: A plan for reorganization of the Roberts Company, textile machinery manufacturer in Sanford, N.C., has been sub mitted to referee in bankruptcy in Greensboro, N.C., it was an nounced yesterday.

title: Staff of Modern Museum Joins Union
description: The Professional and Staff Association of the Museum of Modern Art, a group of em ployes that has been negotiat ing with the museum over salaries, working conditions and a voice in policymaking has voted to affiliate with the Distributive Workers of America, an independent, lib erally oriented union affiliat ed with the Alliance for La bor Action.

title: West Germans Registered A Trade Surplus in March
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, April 29 (Reuters)  West Ger many's trade surplus rose to 1,885,000,000 marks in March from 94,000,000 marks in February and from 1,505,000, 000 marks in March last year, the Federal Statistics Office said today. West Germany's mark is quoted at 27.32 cents.

title: Vatican Rules Against Priests Who Disagreed on an Encyclical
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The Vatican has ruled that Roman Catholic priests disci plined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle here in 1968 over a dispute in interpreting an en cyclical on birth control must comply with the teaching norms set down by the arch bishop and by the church.

title: FORUM EXPLAINS BILL FOR FINANCING WPIX
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)A Federal inquiry heard testimony yesterday on the fi nancial qualifications of a group seeking to wrest control of television station WPIX.

title: Lionel Hampton's Wife Dies in His Offices Here
description: Mrs. Lionel Hampton, wife of the bandleader, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart at tack, yesterday in the offices of Lionel Hampton Enterprises, 165 West 46th Street. She was 57 years old and maintained homes in this city and in Los Angeles.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yes terday the apointment of Robert E. Mulcahy as president of the Fibers Division. Alan Belzer was named to succeed Mr. Mulcahy, who previously was president of the company's Fabricated Prod ucts Division. Mr. Belzer previously was general manager of that division's film department. The corporation also announced the appointment of Richard G. Sanders as president of Nodaway Valley Foods, Inc., a subsidiary. Group vice president John H. Bernard was elected to the board of Allied Chemical earlier this weer.

title: CHANNEL 13 PICKS TOP PROGRAM AIDE
description: A shakeup in Channel 13 was effected yesterday with the appointment of Jack Willis, co executive producer of The Great American Dream Ma chine, to replace Christopher W. Lukas as program coordi nator of noncommercial WNET.

title: HUBERT J. MATTHEWS OF ENGLISH CHURCH
description: The Venerable Hubert John Matthews, archdeacon emeritus of Hampstead, London, died in his sleep Tuesday in Mijas, Ma laga, Spain. He was 82 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New British Assurances on Sterling as Reserve Currency Stirring Optimism on Market Application
description: LONDON, April 29A fresh feeling of optimism is in the air about Britain's application to join the European Economic Community.

title: Martin Building Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)  Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, demanded today that plans to name a new Federal Reserve building annex after the retired reserve board chairman, Wil liam; McChesney Martin, be rescinded, by Congressional ac tion if necessary.

title: At 60, Prof. Ginzberg Relaxes With a Little Work
description: Today is Prof. Eli Ginzberg's 60th birthday, so the Columbia scholar is taking his wife to Atlantic City for what he regards as a weekend of relaxa tion. While there he expects to write four papers and put the finishing touches on his 43d hook.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  There is a remarkably close if little known partnership between Israel and South Africa. This relationship be tween the nation controlling Africa's southern tip and the nation still hold ing the gate to its northern tip affects political, economic and military affairs.

title: Hanoi Reports a Prisoner Denies Capture of Tchepone
description: HONG KONG, April 29 (Reu ters)A captured South Viet namese officer was quoted today by the North Vietnam news agency as saying that Saigon troops never reached the strategic town of Tchepone during last month's strike against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in southern Laos.

title: MEMBER SCORES SECURITY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 The House Internal Security Committee was pictured today by one of its members as an unauthorized secret snooper that maintains files on hunt dreds of thousands of Ameri cans.

title: Screen:
description: A new batch of movie shorts arrived last night at the Film Forum, 256 West 88th Street, that compact, en terprising new showcase for American experimental screen craftsmen. The pictures are running Thursday through Sunday night for two week ends.

title: Market Place:
description: The forthcoming demise of the Wabash Cannon Ball and scores of other famous trains has sparked renewed Con grestional debate.

title: Rep. Dowdy Gets 6th Delay In BriberyConspiracy Trial
description: BALTIMORE, April 29Fed eral Judge Roszel C. Thomsen, for the sixth time, has post poned the bribery conspiracy trial of Representative John Dowdy because of the Texas Democrat's reported ill health.

title: AMEX LIST DROPS; VOLUME ALSO OFF
description: Increased profit taking weak ened most issues on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday as the list finished lower on moderate trading.

title: Refurbishing of 11 Stations On PATH Line Is Planned
description: A program to rehabilitate 11 of the 13 PATH commuter rail road stations in New York and New Jersey is to begin soon with a design study financed in part by a $78,500 grant from the Federal Department of Transportation.

title: Dining Out: A Choice of Chocolate Chicken or Braised Fin
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Another Way the U.S. Has Left Its Mark on Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29  Although she is only 4 years old, Nina Deng remembers the day her fa ther, a United States Navy chief petty officer, went back to the states and his American wife. Her mother, Dang Thi Hoa, carried her to the door and tearfully waved goodby. Her father cried, too. He kissed them and prom ised to write every week.

title: EAST RIVER TOLLS DEFEATED IN POLL
description: Officials holding a majority of votes on the Board of Esti mate came out yesterday against a proposal to charge 25 cent tolls on the four East River bridges that are now tollfree.

title: Advertising:
description: What started two years ago as an effort at internal self improvement has become a fullfledged subsidiary of the J. Walter Thompson Company. The venture is called Communispond, Inc., which tells you next to nothing. But the people in volved in it will tell you almost more than you want to know, which they did yes terdaycharmingly, warmly, forcefully, smilingly and with proper gesticulations.

title: Dance: Donizetti Variations Revival
description: If familiarity bred nothing but contempt we would have little to worry about. Con tempt we can handle. Unfor tunately, familiarity also breeds familiarity. Because New York City Ballet is our resident company in New York, perhaps twice in a while we take it for granted and forget that it is one of the very greatest dance com panies the world has ever known, and that it is right here and now dancing better than it has ever danced be fore.

title: Not for TeetotalersVeal in Wine, Rum Flan
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: POLITICS REVIVING IN WEST PAKISTAN
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, April 29 For two weeks or more, polit ical figures have been holding small meetings and news con ferences around West Pakistan, asking that the military Gov ernment turn over at least some power to the people and their elected representatives.

title: 45 Killed in Week; American War Toll Now Over 45,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Ap ril 29 (UPI)  The United States command announced to day that 45 Americans died in combat last week in Indochina, raising the total in the war since the beginning of 1961 past the 45,000 mark.

title: Hazeltine to Pay Zenith $22Million In Suit Settlement
description: The Hazeltine Corporation and Hazeltine Research, Inc., agreed yesterday to pay the Zenith Radio Corporation $22.5million in cash and cred its in settlement of a 13year old antitrust suit that was car, ried as high as the Supreme. Court.

title: TEAMSTERS PENALTY STANDS IN U.S. COURT
description: A Federal Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday let stand a $50,000 fine imposed on Tues day for contempt of court against four officers of a team ters local for a sixday strike against the Emery Air Freight Corporation.

title: Jersey Assembly Votes a Halt To New Cable TV Franchises
description: TRENTON, April 29  Re acting to charges of illegal shakedowns and other wide spread irregularities in the rapidly expanding cable tele vision industry, the New Jer sey Assembly tonight unani mously approved a oneyear moratorium on local cable tele vision franchise awards.

title: DR. LEON WULMAN, JEWISH AGENCY AIDE
description: Dr. Leon (Leib) Wulman, director of the American Com mittee of Oeuvre de Secours des Enfants, an international Jew ish health organization, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 20 West 72d Street.

title: Hatfield to Be Speaker
description: NORFOLK, Va., April 29 (AP) U. S. Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, will be guest speaker here Saturday al the commissioning of the Mount Hood, an ammunition ship.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP)United States B52 bombers struck at targets in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam today in another intensive effort to force North Vietnamese troops from jungle bases, the United States com mand said.

title: TREASURY BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: The impact from the Treas ury's decision not to offer a new longterm bond issue did not last long.

title: POLICE SEIZE 200 IN CAPITAL MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 More than 200 demonstrators were arrested late today as they attempted an unauthorized march from a building of the Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare near the Capitol to the White House, about a mile away.

title: RAIL FREIGHT DOWN, BUT TRUCKING GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended April 24 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck ton nage in the same period was considerably, higher because of work stoppages in the truck ing industry last year.

title: Volkswagen
description: WOLFSBURG, West Ger many, April 29 (AP)  Volks wagen, West Germany's and Europe's largest automobile maker, announced today that its profits declined 42 per cent last year to $52million.

title: Beirut Prepares for Rogers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20 President Suleiman Franjieh consulted through the day to day with the 99 members of the Lebanese Parliament on what should be discussed with Secretary of State William P. Rogers during his visit here Monday.

title: Kleiman Announces Candidacy For Manhattan Surrogate Post
description: Criminal Court Judge Alfred H. Kleiman announced yester day that he was a candidate for election to the surrogate's post in Manhattan held for four years by Samuel J. Silverman between tours of service on the State Supreme Court.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 29In a few days now, Hubert Horatio Humphrey will be 60 years old. You couldn't tell it from his spirit, which is blithe and sassy, or from his hair, which by some hidden fountain of youth or miracle of alchemy, grows darker with the passing years, but here he is at the opening of another decade, knock ing hopefully at the White House door.

title: JUDGE ORDERS HALT TO STATE LAYOFFS
description: ALBANY, April 29 (AP)A State Supreme Court justice to day ordered a halt to all dis missals of state employes until he has ruled on the constitu tionality of the methods in which the state budget was passed.

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC CONTINUING TALKS
description: The Communications Work ers of America made it clear yesterday that the union ex pected to continue negotiations with the Western Electric Com pany beyond tonight's midnight expiration of the contract cov ering 29,000 installers.

title: Holophane Seeking A New Merger Bid By JohnsManville
description: Merger News
